title: 15th International Conference on Human Retroviruses: HTLV and Related Viruses
abstract: The proceedings consist of 253 contributions. Topics discussed will include: altered CD4+/CD8+ T-cell ratio in human T-cell leukemia virus type I splenocytes in transgenic mice with inflammatory arthropathy; viral expression directs B cell fate in BLV-infected sheep; tet-Inducible Lymphoma in a New Fiscally Transgenic Mouse Model; Bovine immunodeficiency virus as a potentiating cofactor for experimental bovine leukemia virus infection in sheep; Bovine MHC Class II DR Molecule Plays a Key Role in Bovine Leukemia Virus (BLV)-Induced Lymphoma; Comparative proteomic analysis of cancer stem cells in a Tax-transgenic (Tax-Tg) mouse model of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma; a life-attenuated BLV deleterious vaccine candidate to inhibit virus transmission in cattle herds; and high-throughput sequencing unveils novel microRNAs in the bovine leukemia virus (blv)-induced ovine leukemia model.

title: 102nd Annual Meeting of the American Association of Immunologists, IMMUNOLOGY 2015
abstract: The Proceedings include 1758 essays. Topics discussed will include: de novo recognition and HLA association of public T cell responses to cytomegalovirus using high-throughput immune repertoire sequencing; abrogation of CD59 function restores the activities of neutralizing and non-neutralizing antibodies in inducing antibody-dependent complement-mediated lysis of HIV-1 virions and provirus-activated latently infected cells; Evaluation of Bone Marrow in Cowpox Virus Infection in Cynomolgus Macaques; Glycosylphosphatidylinositol deficiency attenuates production of infectious HIV-1 and renders virions vulnerable to complement attack; and Restoration of immune system, activation, and virus reservoirs in gut-associated lymphoid tissues in SIV-infected, long-term non-progressive Chinese rhesus monkeys on antiretroviral therapy.

title: Recommendations for a standardized avian coronavirus (AvCoV) nomenclature: Outcome of discussions within the European Union COST Action FA1207: "Towards Control of Avian Coronaviruses: Strategies for Vaccination, Diagnosis and Surveillance"
abstract: Viruses within the Coronaviridae family show variations within their genomic sequences, particularly within the main structural protein, the spike (S) glycoprotein gene. Therefore, many different antigenic forms, serotypes or variant strains of avian coronaviruses (AvCoV) exist worldwide. Only a few of them, the so-called protector types, protect against different serotypes. New serotypes arise through recombination or spontaneous mutations. Antigenic virus variants that differ significantly from known serotypes arise from time to time. The result of this variability is inconsistent nomenclature and classification of viral strains. In addition, no uniform classification methods are currently defined. As part of COST Action FA1207 "Towards control of avian coronaviruses: Strategies for Diagnostic, Surveillance, and Vaccination" (working groups "Molecular Virology" and "Epidemiology"), we have set ourselves the goal of defining and developing a uniform and internationally standardized nomenclature develop classification of AvCoVs. We recommend using "CoV Genus/AvCov/Host/Country/Sample ID/Year" to refer to AvCoV strains.

title: First genome sequence of Newcastle disease virus genotype VIII from Jordan
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) was detected by reverse transcriptase-PCR (RT-PCR) from total RNA isolated from a backyard chicken spleen in Jordan. The complete genomic coding sequence of NDV/chicken/Jordan/J11-spleen/2018 was obtained using MiSeq (Illumina) sequencing. Phylogenetic analysis of the concatenated coding sequences classified the virus as a class II subgenotype VIIi.
authors: Ababneh, M.;Ferreira, H. L.;Khalifeh, M.;Suarez, D. L.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Genotyping of bovine leukemia virus isolates circulating in the Stavropol region
abstract: The bovine leukemia virus (BLV) circulating on the territory of the Stavropol Territory of Russia is characterized according to the modern classification of subspecies. BLV proviral deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) was separated from the peripheral blood of animals naturally infected with this virus. Subsequent amplification, sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of a fragment of the env gene with a length of 444 nucleotide pairs (pn) made it possible to assign the investigated isolates to genotypes 4 and 6. In addition, we dissected the localized BLV isolate apart from clusters of isolates of all eight known genotypes, allowing for classification as atypical. In the course of sequencing a section of the env gene of BLV provirus isolates separated in this region, the presence of 31 point mutations in the studied locus was detected, 11 of which are significant: 2 transversions and 9 transitions.
authors: Abakin, S. S.;Krasovskaya, T. L.;Surgikova, E. S.;Gendzhieva, O. B.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of sheeppox during an outbreak of sheep in Sharkia Governorate, Egypt
abstract: Sheeppox virus (SPPV) is one of the listed and reportable diseases affecting sheep production with a significant impact on trade in new breeds of sheep. This study was conducted to identify sheeppox using cell culture, electron microscope (EM) and open reading frame (ORF) 103 gene during an outbreak of the local sheep breed that occurred in April 2017 in Sharia Governorate, Egypt. Affected adult sheep showed typical skin pox lesions on the face, inner lips, inner thigh and under the tail. The incidence rate of infection was 23.5% and the mortality rate in young lambs aged 3 to 6 months was 8.2%. Forty-three scab and tissue samples from clinically diseased adult sheep and dead lambs were collected and cultured on Vero cells. The cytopathic effect (CPE) was observed within 3 to 7 days in 40 specimens. A typical poxvirus had a brick-like shape with rounded ends when EM stained negatively and an ovoid structure with a dumbbell-shaped DNA core with concave body sides when EM positively stained. Bands of about 570 bp relative to SPPV were obtained by conventional PCR using the ORF103 gene. The sequence amplicon was analyzed by NCBI-BLAST and registered in GeneBank under accession number MG873537, and a phylogenetic tree was constructed showing that the isolated SPPV strain differed from other SPPV strains isolated in Egypt, India, China and the USA. resembled tribes. Finally, both EM and PCR are considered to be sensitive, rapid and powerful methods for identifying SPPV from tissue and scab samples without the need for further culture, in addition to the useful and easy use of the ORF103 gene to distinguish SPPV from other capripoxviruses.
authors: Abd-Elfatah, E. B.;El-Mekkawi, M. F.;Bastawecy, I. M.;Fawzi, E. M.

title: Isolation and molecular characterization of novel infectious bronchitis virus variants from vaccinated broiler flocks in Egypt
abstract: The present study aimed to determine the molecular characteristics of circulating strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) in vaccinated broiler flocks in Giza and Fayoum governorates. Thirty-four isolates were collected and egg multiplication demonstrated its ability to induce typical IBV lesions after three to five consecutive passages. Three selected isolates were identified as IBV using a real-time reverse transcriptase PCR assay targeting the nucleocapsid (N) gene and further characterized by partial spike (S) gene sequence analysis. The phylogenetic analysis revealed their grouping into two variant groups. Group I consisted of a variant (VSVRI_F3) that shared 99.1% nucleotide sequence identity with the Q1 reference strain. Group II consisted of variants VSVRI_G4 and VSVRI_G9, which shared 92.8% to 94.3% nucleotide identity with Egyptian variants Eg/12120S/2012, Eg/12197B/2012, and Eg/1265B/2012. With regard to the deduced amino acid sequence, the three variants had a similarity of 77.1% to 85.2% with the vaccine strains currently used in Egypt. These results underline the importance of monitoring the prevalence of IBV variants in vaccinated broiler flocks and adopting an appropriate vaccination strategy.
authors: Abdel-Sabour, M. A.;Al-Ebshahy, E. M.;Khaliel, S. A.;Abdel-Wanis, N. A.;Yanai, T.

title: Retrotransposable elements on the W chromosome of the silkworm Bombyx mori
abstract: The sex chromosomes of the silkworm Bombyxmori are designated ZW(XY) for females and ZZ(XX) for males. The B. mori W chromosome does not recombine with the Z chromosome and autosomes, and genes for morphological traits on the W chromosome have not yet been mapped. In addition, femininity is determined by the presence of a single W chromosome, regardless of the number of autosomes or Z chromosomes. In order to understand these interesting features of the W chromosome, it is necessary to analyze the W chromosome at the molecular biological level. To first isolate W chromosome-specific DNA sequences as random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) markers, we compared the genomic DNAs between males and females by PCR with 10-mer random primers. To date we have identified 12 W-specific RAPD markers, and with the exception of one RAPD marker, all deduced amino acid sequences of these W-specific RAPD markers show similarity to previously reported amino acid sequences of retrotransposable elements from different organisms. After constructing a B. mori DNA lambda phage genomic library, we obtained two lambda phage clones, one with the W kabuki RAPD sequence and one with the W samurai RAPD sequence, and found that this DNA -Sequences included nested structures of many retrotransposable elements. To further analyze the W chromosome, we obtained 14 W-specific bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clones from three BAC libraries and subjected these clones to shotgun sequencing. The resulting assembly of sequences did not produce a single contiguous sequence due to the presence of many retrotransposable elements. Therefore, we coupled the PCR with shotgun sequencing. Through these analyses, we found that many long terminal repeat (LTR) and non-LTR retrotransposons, retroposons, DNA transposons and their derivatives have stratified on the W chromosome. These results strongly suggest that retrotransposable elements are the major structural component of the W chromosome.
authors: Abe, H.;Mita, K.;Yasukochi, Y.;Oshiki, T.;Shimada, T.

title: A novel sapelovirus-like virus isolation from wild boar
abstract: novel sapelovirus-like virus was isolated from a wild boar (Sus scrofa). In this study, partial viral genomic nucleotide sequences were determined using the rapid determination system for viral nucleic acid sequences (RDV) Ver. 3.1, which we recently developed for novel virus discovery. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 and 3A proteins and their nucleotide coding sequences from enteroviruses and sapeloviruses showed that the isolated virus was closely related to porcine sapelovirus. RT-PCR detected viral sequences in six of 48 wild boar fecal samples. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Abe, M.;Ito, N.;Sakai, K.;Kaku, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishimura, M.;Kurane, I.;Saijo, M.;Morikawa, S.;Sugiyama, M.;Mizutani, T.

title: Genomic and single nucleotide polymorphism analysis of infectious bronchitis coronavirus
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is a gamma-ray coronavirus that causes a highly contagious respiratory disease in chickens. A QX-like strain was analyzed by high-throughput Illumina sequencing, and genetic variation across the entire viral genome was examined at the sub-consensus level by single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) analysis. Thirteen open reading frames (ORFs) in the order 5'-UTR-1a-1ab-S-3a-3b-EM-4b-4c-5a-5b-N-6b-3'UTR were predicted. The relative frequencies of missense:silent SNPs were calculated to provide a comparative measure of variability in specific genes. The most variable ORFs in descending order were E, 3b, 5'UTR, N, 1a, S, 1ab, M, 4c, 5a, 6b. The E and 3b protein products play a key role in coronavirus virulence, and RNA folding showed that the mutations in the 5'UTR did not alter the predicted secondary structure. The frequency of SNPs in the ORF of the spike (S) protein was 0.67%, below the genomic average of 0.76%. Only three SNPS were identified in the S1 subunit, none of which were localized to the hypervariable region (HVR)1 or HVR2. The S2 subunit was significantly more variable, containing 87% of the polymorphisms detected across the entire S protein. The S2 subunit also contained a previously unreported multi-A insertion site and a stretch of four contiguous mutant amino acids mapped to the stalk region of the spike protein. Template-based protein structure modeling led to the first theoretical model of the IBV spike monomer. Given the lack of diversity observed at the subconsensus level, the tenet that the HVRs in the S1 subunit are highly tolerant to amino acid changes induced by genetic drift is challenged.
authors: Abolnik, C.

title: Development of the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5: sequence data indicate stepwise changes of the cleavage site
abstract: The genetic composition of an H5-subtype hemagglutinin gene quasispecies recovered from ostrich tissues infected with the H5-subtype influenza virus was analyzed using a next-generation sequencing approach. The first evidence for repeated copying of a stretch of poly(U) in the connecting peptide region in the hemagglutinin cleavage site (HACS) by viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) is provided. Several mismatched RNA species were detected in the infected host, corresponding to probable intermediate sequences between the putative low pathogenic precursor nucleotide sequence of the H5 influenza strain and the highly pathogenic gene sequence of the avian influenza virus. In silico analyzes of the identified RNA sequences predicted that the intermediate H5 sequence PQREKRGLF plays an important role in subsequent mutational events that relocate the HACS coding region from stable base pair RNA regions to a single-stranded bulge and thereby the connecting Prepare peptide coding region for RdRP hatching.
authors: Abolnik, C.

title: Outbreaks of H6N2 avian influenza viruses in chickens resulted from a reassortment of ostrich viruses H6N8 and H9N2
abstract: The first recorded outbreak of avian influenza (AI) in South African chickens (H6N2 with low pathogenicity) occurred in June 2002 in Camperdown, KwaZulu/Province of Natal (KZN). To determine the source of the outbreak, we defined the phylogenetic relationships between different H6N2 isolates and the previously unpublished gene sequences of an H6N8 virus isolated from ostriches in the Leeu Gamka region in 1998 (A/Ostrich/South Africa/KK98/98 ). We have shown that two distinct H6N2 genetic lineages (sublineages I and II) circulated in the Camperdown area, which later spread to other regions. Sublineages I and II shared a recent H6N2 common ancestor, resulting from a resorting event between two South African ostrich isolates A/Ostrich/South Africa/9508103/95 and (H9N2) A/Ostrich/South Africa/KK98/98 (H6N8). In addition, H6N2 sublineage I viruses displayed several molecular genetic markers, including a 22 amino acid stalk deletion in the neuraminidase (NA) protein gene, predicted increased N-glycosylation, and a D144 mutation of the HA protein gene associated with the Adaptation of AI viruses to chickens. The H6N2 NS1 and PB1 genes recently shared common ancestors with those of contemporary Asian HPAI H5N1 viruses. Our results suggest that ostriches are potential mixing vessels for strains of avian influenza virus (AIV) outbreaks and support other reports that H6 viruses are able to establish stable lineages in chickens. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Bisschop, S.;Gerdes, T.;Olivier, A.;Horner, R.

title: Phylogenetic analyzes of low pathogenicity H6N2 avian influenza viruses from chicken outbreaks (2001-2005) indicate that they are reassortants of the historic low pathogenicity avian influenza viruses H9N2 and H6N8 from ostriches
abstract: Low pathogenicity (LPAI) and high pathogenicity (HPAI) avian influenza viruses are regularly isolated from South African ostriches, but in 2002 the first documented outbreak of LPAI (H6N2) in South African chickens on commercial farms in the Camperdown area of KwaZulu /Natal occurred ( KZN) province. A sequence analysis of all eight genes was performed and a phylogenetic analysis was performed based on the hemagglutinin and neuraminidasc sequences. Results of phylogenetic analysis indicated that the chicken H6N2 viruses most likely arose from a reassortment between two South African LPAI ostrich isolates: an H9N2 virus isolated in 1995 and an H6N8 virus isolated in 1998 of recent common ancestor. One of these sub-lines was limited to the province of KZN. The neuraminidase gene contained a 22 amino acid deletion in the NA stalk region implicated in adaptation to growth in chickens, while the other group, although lacking the NA stalk deletion, referred to commercial Farms spread to other provinces. The persistence of certain H6N2 types in some regions for at least 2 years supports reports from Asia and southern California suggesting that H6N2 viruses can form stable lineages in chickens. It is likely that the ostrich H6N8 and H9N2 precursors to the chicken H6N2 viruses were introduced into ostriches from wild birds. Ostriches, in which AI infections are often subclinical, can serve as mixing vessels for LPAI strains that occasionally spread to other poultry.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Bisschop, S. P. R.;Gerdes, G. H.;Olivier, A. J.;Horner, R. F.

title: Complete genomic sequence of an African avian Paramyxovirus type 4 strain isolated from a wild duck
abstract: random amplification/deep sequencing approach was used to determine the complete genome sequence of an avian paramyxovirus type 4 (APMV-4) strain isolated in 2010 from a wild duck in South Africa. This sequence represents the fourth complete genome of APMV-4 in public sequence databases and the first for the African continent. A total of 87,402,081 paired-end reads were received from Illumina, of which 47,338,867 (54.16%) mapped to reference genome EU877976. The entire genomic sequence of 15,054 nt, including the intact termini, was recovered with high redundancy (coverage per base: average = 198,861.06, minimum = 52, and maximum = 1,790,889). Pairwise comparison of complete genomic nucleotide sequences showed that APMV-4/Egyptian goose/South Africa/N1468/10 had 97.3% sequence identity with APMV-4/KR/YJ/06 and 96.4% sequence identity with APMV-4/Mallard duck/Belgium shared /15129/07 and 90.8% nucleotide sequence identity with APMV-4/duck/HK/D3/75. Genomic features were consistent with previously sequenced viruses, including predicted open reading frames for the NP, P, F, and L genes, but variations in the coding regions for the M and HN genes were identified. The sequencing approach chosen in this study was able to successfully indicate quasi-species in the viral inventory.
authors: Abolnik, C.;de Castro, M.;Rees, J.

title: Characterization of Pigeon Paramyxoviruses (Newcastle Disease Virus) isolated from 2001 to 2006 in South Africa
abstract: Pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1), a variant of the Newcastle disease virus that mainly affects pigeons and pigeons, has been isolated in South Africa since the mid-1980s. Phylogenetic evidence suggests that pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 viruses have been introduced into South Africa multiple times based on the presence of two separate lineages, 4bi and 4bii, which have been circulating in Europe and the Far East since the early 1990s. In 2006, a PPMV-1 virus was isolated from an African ground hornbill (Bucorvus leadbeateri) that became acutely infected with PPMV-1 and died, probably after ingesting infected pigeon carcasses on a closely related PPMV-1 strain in the region was also isolated from pigeons collected nearby. The hornbill isolate had ICPI and MDT values characteristic of PPMV-1 strains. The threat of PPMV-1 to poultry production and biodiversity in southern Africa underscores the importance of monitoring the spread of this strain.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Gerdes, G. H.;Kitching, J.;Swanepoel, S.;Romito, M.;Bisschop, S. P. R.

title: Characterization of a highly pathogenic H5N2 subtype influenza A virus isolated from ostriches in South Africa in 2004
abstract: Objectives: The strain HPAI H5N2 that caused an outbreak in ostriches in Eastern Cape Province, South Africa in 2004 was characterized. Design: Hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and agar gel immunodiffusion (AGID) were performed on sera from ostrich farms in the outbreak region, and intravenous pathogenicity testing (IVPI), reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), nucleic acid on the isolated during the outbreak HPAI-H5N2 virus sequencing and phylogenetic comparisons were performed. Results: The deduced amino acid sequence at the HA0 cleavage site determined by RT-PCR and nucleotide sequencing was PQREKRRKKRGLF and thus the virus fell under the definition of a highly pathogenic virus but was isolated in a chicken IVPI test for the virus isolated from the index case and a value of 0.63 was measured, which is below the criterion for highly pathogenic viruses in this in vivo test. After another passage in fertilized eggs, a second IVPI was performed and an increased value of 1.19 was obtained. Cloacal swabs were taken from the initial IVPI birds, inoculated into incubated chicken eggs, and a third IVPI was then performed on the resulting hemagglutinating infectious allantoic fluid. An index of 2.73 was recorded. Conclusions: HI test appears to be the more sensitive test compared to AGID when testing sera for antibodies to avian influenza. An ostrich-derived virus with a virulent HA0 site was initially non-virulent in chickens, but virulence increased after passage in the latter. Phylogenetic analyzes showed the link between AI viruses transmitted by wild ducks and those infecting ostriches. © 2009 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Londt, B. Z.;Manvell, R. J.;Shell, W.;Banks, J.;Gerdes, G. H.;Akol, G.;Brown, I. H.

title: Complete genome sequence of a velogenic Newcastle disease virus isolated in Mexico
abstract: Cases of the highly virulent Newcastle disease virus are increasing in Mexico. In 2005, an outbreak of Newcastle disease occurred on a laying hen farm in Puebla state, despite vaccination with the LaSota strain. Farmers experienced a significant drop in egg production as a result of a field challenge virus. In this study, we characterize the virus responsible for the outbreak, APMV1/Chicken/Mexico/P05/2005. The virus is categorized as a velogenetic virus with an intracranial pathogenicity index of 1.99 and a mean time of death of chick embryos of 36 hours. The full genome length of the virus was sequenced at 15,192 bp. In addition, phylogenetic analysis classified the virus as a member of class II, genotype V. The highly pathogenic nature of the virus has been linked to the amino acid sequence at the fusion protein cleavage site, which contains several basic amino acids (RRQKR; F). © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: AbsalÃ³n, A. E.;Mariano-MatÃ­as, A.;VÃ¡squez-MÃ¡rquez, A.;Morales-GarzÃ³n, A.;CortÃ©s-Espinosa, D. V.;Ortega-GarcÃ­a, R.;Lucio-Decanini, E.

title: Avian Influenza: Global Assessment of a Potential 21st Century Pandemic
abstract: The emergence of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) of Asian descent and subsequent spread to other parts of the world, as well as the continued spread of the Eurasian-African H5N1 epidemic to domestic, wild and human birds, has attracted unprecedented attention and threat in recent times from a potential pandemic about the bird-human connection. Historically, from 1878 to 1955, avian plaque was described in many countries in Europe, Asia, North and South America, and Africa as an avian disease with high mortality, and the etiology was proven to be a filterable virus. In the 1930s to 1950s, avian plaque disappeared as an endemic disease in most parts of the world. In 1949 the first report of a low virulence disease in chickens caused by the LPAI virus was reported. In 1955, the etiology of fowl plaque was determined to be influenza A virus, which was subsequently identified as the H7 subtype. In 1959, an "avian plaque-like" outbreak was described in chickens, the first report of avian plaque caused by a non-H7 AI virus, ie the first avian plaque outbreak caused by the H5 subtype of AI virus. In 1961, the first wild bird infections and fatalities in South Africa's common terns were reported. In 1966 and 1971, the first H5 and H7 LPAI viruses were identified; Prior to this period, only HPAI viruses had subtypes H5 and H7. In 1970, the serological AGID test was introduced, which allowed easy and rapid identification of AI virus-infected poultry flocks. In 1972 there was the first isolation of LPAI viruses from asymptomatic wild birds: ducks in the United States and shorebirds in Australia. In 1981, the term "highly pathogenic avian influenza" was accepted as the standard nomenclature for avian plaque and related synonyms. In 1983, LPAI virus was observed to mutate to HPAI virus during the LPAI field outbreak, and specific genomic changes were identified in the proteolytic cleavage site of hemagglutinin responsible for the virulence change. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, molecular criteria were added to the definition for classifying an AI virus as HPAI. 2002 saw the first reported infections and deaths in a variety of wild bird species by AI virus H5N1 HPAI virus. The main objective of this review is to highlight the global situation of HPAI and provide baseline information to show the potential pandemic nature of the virus so that control and prevention strategies can be improved.
authors: Abubakar, M. B.;Aini, I.;Omar, A. R.;Hair Bejo, M.

title: Phylogenetic and molecular characterization of the coronavirus affecting bovine and avian species in Cuba
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) and bovine coronavirus (BCoV) are pathogens of veterinary importance affecting birds and cattle in Cuba; however, the molecular properties and genetic diversity of these viruses are unknown. This study aimed to determine the molecular properties and genetic diversity of both agents based on the spike S gene. Molecular analysis was performed on field strains of BCoV collected between 2009 and 2011, and phylogenetic studies were performed using partial or full S gene sequences as phylogenetic markers. Studies on phylogenetic inference in the S1 region of recent isolates of IBV were also performed. All Cuban bovine coronavirus sequences were in a single cluster, supported by 100% bootstrap and 1.00 posterior probability values. The Cuban BCoV sequences were also clustered with the USA BCoV strains corresponding to GenBank accession numbers EF424621 and EF424623, suggesting a common origin for these viruses. This phylogenetic cluster was also the only group of sequences in which no recombination events were detected. Of the 45 amino acid changes found in the Cuban strains, four were unique. On the other hand, two putative genotypes were found in the herds examined that were genetically distinct from the H120 strain of the Massachusetts genotype used in the Cuban vaccination program. In addition, a potentially nephropathogenic IBV isolate was found for the first time in Cuba. This research received the 2012 prize from the Cuban National Academy of Sciences. © Biotecnologia Aplicada 2013.
authors: Acevedo, A. M.;MartÃ­nez, N.;BrandÃ£o, P.;Perera, C. L.;FrÃ­as, M. T.;Barrera, M.;PÃ©rez, L. J.

title: Viromic analysis of wastewater input into a river basin reveals a diverse accumulation of RNA viruses
abstract: The detection of viruses in the environment depends heavily on PCR-based approaches that require reference sequences for primer design. While this strategy can accurately detect known viruses, it does not find new genotypes or emerging and invasive virus species. In this study we investigated the use of viromics, ie high-throughput sequencing of the viral fraction of the biosphere, for the detection of human/animal pathogenic RNA viruses in the Conwy river basin in Wales, UK. Using a combination of filtration and nuclease treatment, we extracted the viral fraction from wastewater and estuary water and sediment, followed by high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) analysis on the Illumina HiSeq platform to discover RNA viral genomes. We found a higher abundance of RNA viruses in wastewater samples than in river water and sediments, and we assembled a complete genome of norovirus genotype GI.2 from wastewater wastewater not simultaneously detected by conventional reverse transcription-quantitative PCR (qRT-PCR). became. . The co-presence of different rotavirus signatures in the effluent indicated the potential for zoonotic infections in the region and suggested effluents from pig farms as a possible origin of these viruses. Our results demonstrate that viromics can be an important tool in detecting pathogenic viruses in the environment and can be used to inform and optimize reference-based detection methods, provided that appropriate and rigorous controls are included. IMPORTANT Enteric viruses cause gastrointestinal diseases and are often transmitted fecal-orally. When wastewater is discharged into river systems, these viruses can contaminate the environment. Our results show that we can use viromics to find the range of potentially pathogenic viruses present in the environment and identify predominant genotypes. The ultimate goal is to trace the fate of these pathogenic viruses from origin to the point where they pose a threat to human health and inform reference-based detection methods and water quality management.
authors: Adriaenssens, E. M.;Farkas, K.;Harrison, C.;Jones, D. L.;Allison, H. E.;McCarthy, A. J.

title: Prevalence of porcine parvoviruses in some South African pig herds with a background of porcine circovirus type 2 infection
abstract: Classical porcine parvovirus is an important causative agent of reproductive disorders in swine with a confirmed history of global distribution. However, detection of many novel porcine parvoviruses has increased in recent years, but there is a lack of information on the occurrence and prevalence of these viruses in South Africa. Molecular detection of some known parvoviruses, namely porcine parvoviruses (PPVs)-1, 2, 3 and 4, porcine bocavirus-like virus (PBo-likeV) and porcine bocaviruses (PBoV1/2), was archived on 110 randomly selected individuals Pigs conducted samples collected in 2015 and 2016. Samples were drawn from previously screened and confirmed porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) infected farms, with farm-level incidence ranging from 5.6 to 60%. The results showed that all parvoviruses screened were present as follows: PPV1 (29.1%), PPV2 (21.8%), PPV3 (5.5%), PPV4 (43.6%), PBo-likeV (21 .8%) and PBoV1/2 (44.6%). The frequency of double infections of the viruses was even 18.2% for PPV2/PPV4 and PPV4/PBoVs; while 17.3% and 7.3% of the samples screened showed multiple infections with the three and four viruses, respectively. Further phylogenetic analysis of partial PPV1, 2 and PBoV1/2 sequences revealed two major clades for each of the viruses. This study reports the first epidemiological investigation and molecular characterization of classical and emerging porcine parvoviruses in South African swine herds. It also provides insight into the diversity and distribution of these viral pathogens within the herds of the study area and confirms their potential for co-infection with PCV2.
authors: Afolabi, K. O.;Iweriebor, B. C.;Obi, L. C.;Okoh, A. I.

title: Biological characterization and next-generation genome sequencing of the unclassified Cotia virus SPAn232 (Poxviridae)
abstract: The Cotia virus (COTV) SPAn232 was isolated in 1961 from sentinel mice at the Cotia field station in São Paulo, Brazil. Attempts to classify COTV within a recognized genus of Poxviridae have yielded conflicting results. Studies by various investigators suggested some similarity to myxomavirus and swinepox virus, while another study characterized COTV SPAn232 as a vaccinia virus strain. Due to the lack of consensus, we performed an independent biological and molecular characterization of COTV. Virus growth curves reached maximum yields at approximately 24-48 h and were accompanied by viral DNA replication and a characteristic early/late pattern of viral protein synthesis. Interestingly, COTV did not induce detectable cytopathic effects in BSC-40 cells up to 4 days post-infection and only generated viral plaques after 8 days. We determined the complete genomic sequence of COTV using a combination of next-generation 454 and Illumina DNA sequencing technologies. A unique contiguous sequence of 185,139 bp containing 185 genes, including the 90 genes conserved in all chordopoxviruses, was obtained. COTV has an interesting panel of open reading frames (ORFs) associated with host defense evasion, including two novel genes encoding CC chemokine-like proteins, each present in double copy. Phylogenetic analysis revealed the highest values for amino acid identity with cervidpoxvirus, capripoxvirus, suipoxvirus, leporipoxvirus, and yatapoxvirus. However, COTV was grouped within this clade as a distinct branch, which clearly precluded its classification as an orthopoxvirus. Therefore, our data suggest that COTV may represent a new genus of smallpoxviruses. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Afonso, P. P.;Silva, P. M.;Schnellrath, L. C.;Jesus, D. M.;Hu, J.;Yang, Y.;Renne, R.;Attias, M.;Condit, R. C.;MoussatchÃ©, N.;Damaso, C. R.

title: Lumpy skin disease outbreaks in Greece in 2015-16, implementation of emergency vaccination and genetic differentiation between field isolates and vaccine virus strains
abstract: The aim of this study is to present epizootiological data from the lumpy skin disease (LSD) outbreaks in Greece in 2015–16, following the introduction of emergency vaccination and total eradication, together with laboratory data on genetic differentiation between field isolates and live attenuated vaccine virus strains. A descriptive geographic chronology analysis was performed to show the progressive westward shift of outbreaks and concomitant absence of further outbreaks in previously affected regional units where high vaccination coverage was achieved. The isolation and molecular characterization of LSDV from the first recorded case in Greece (Evros/GR/15 isolate) was performed. The two live attenuated LSD vaccine viruses currently used for emergency immunization in Greece have been sequenced and linked to the Evros/GR/15 isolate in 3 genomic regions (GPCR gene, RPO30 gene and partial LSDV126/LSDV127 genes). compared. Sequence comparisons showed clear differences between the Evros/GR/15 isolate and the vaccine strains. Phylogenetic analysis resulted in the placement of the Evros/GR/15 isolate in the same clade with all field LSDV isolates, while grouping vaccine strains into a distinct cluster within the LSDV clade. Additional samples from animals with skin nodules (N=13) were characterized by sequencing in the 3 genomic regions mentioned above. Among them, the attenuated vaccine virus was identified in 5 vaccinated animals. A PCR-RFLP method targeting the LSDV127 gene was developed and proved to be able to discriminate between the characterized field and vaccine strains. The results of the present study support the importance of timely and intensive vaccination for the control of LSDV diseases and the genetic differences between the Evros/GR/15 isolate and the vaccine strains. This forms the basis for the development of PCR-based DIVA assays, which would be of great importance for effective disease surveillance and control during LSD vaccination campaigns.
authors: Agianniotaki, E. I.;Tasioudi, K. E.;Chaintoutis, S. C.;Iliadou, P.;Mangana-Vougiouka, O.;Kirtzalidou, A.;Alexandropoulos, T.;Sachpatzidis, A.;Plevraki, E.;Dovas, C. I.;Chondrokouki, E.

title: Spread of emerging infectious laryngotracheitis viruses in Australia
abstract: Infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT) is a major viral disease in chickens in many countries around the world. In this report, the status of ILT in Australia was used as a model to assess the evolution of ILT viruses (ILTVs). Because of its geographic isolation, Australia harbored its own lineage of ILT viruses (ILTV) until 2007. However, investigation of the ILT viruses (ILTV) involved in outbreaks between 2007 and 2009 has found that many of the outbreaks were caused by two new virus genotypes, class 8 and class 9. These two were found to be recombinant Viruses arose as a result of recombination between pre-existing live vaccine strains (SA2 and A20) and another live vaccine strain (Serva) introduced into the country in 2007. The new recombinant ILTVs also showed significantly higher virulence and replication capability compared to a previously prevalent Class 2 ILTV. In the current study, examining a large number of ILTVs isolated in outbreaks between 2009 and 2015 revealed the emergence of another recombinant virus (class 10) which appears to have become a predominant genotype in New South Wales. However, in Victoria, recombinant class 9 gradually became the dominant virus, replacing class 2. As such, there was an unusual pattern in the geographic spread of the emerging viruses across different states in the country. These results suggest that ILTV is rapidly evolving towards greater portability and hence greater capacity to propagate in ILTV-free areas.
authors: Agnew-Crumpton, R.;Vaz, P. K.;Devlin, J. M.;O'Rourke, D.;Blacker-Smith, H. P.;Konsak-Ilievski, B.;Hartley, C. A.;Noormohammadi, A. H.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of the Orf virus in the Kashmir Himalayas
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV) is a zoonotic pathogen that mainly affects sheep and goats and is responsible for considerable economic damage. ORFV is endemic to all major sheep and goat farming areas of the world including the Indian subcontinent. However, the nature of ORFV circulating among sheep and goats in the Kashmir Himalayas has not yet been characterized. In the present study, we describe natural ORFV outbreaks in sheep and goats in the Kashmir Himalayas. We demonstrated the presence of ORFV in the eschar lesion by PCR amplification of the major envelope protein (B2L) gene. We sequenced the virus interferon resistance gene (VIR) and determined its phylogenetic relationship to that of the published reference sequences. Phylogenetic analysis based on the VIR gene revealed that the ORFV isolates from the Kashmir Himalayas were separated into two major clusters. The sheep isolates showed genetic homology with the sheep strains reported from Greece and Italy, whereas the goat-specific strain showed homology with the goat strains reported from China. This study demonstrates the presence of ORFV infection in sheep and goats and reports the first phylogenetic analysis of ORFV strains prevalent in the Kashmir Himalayas.
authors: Ahanger, S. A.;Parveen, R.;Nazki, S.;Dar, Z.;Dar, T.;Dar, K. H.;Dar, A.;Rai, N.;Dar, P.

title: Host-parasite relationships of bacteria and phages can be revealed by oligostickiness, a measure of relaxed sequence similarity
abstract: Motivation: Recent metagenome analysis has revealed a large number of host-unassigned viruses. Although assigning viruses to their hosts is fundamentally important not only for virology but also for disease prevention, it has been a tedious and difficult task so far. The only effective method for this purpose was to find them in the same microscopic view. Now, we tried a computational approach based on bacterial and phage genome sequences and introduced a physicochemical parameter, SOSS (Set of Oligostickiness Similarity Score), derived from oligostickiness, a measure of the binding affinity of oligonucleotides to template DNA. Results: We could confirm host-parasite relationships of bacteria and their phages by SOSS analysis: all tested phages (25 species) had a remarkably higher SOSS score with their host than with unrelated bacteria. Interestingly, according to SOSS values, lysogenic phages such as lambda phage (host: Escherichia coli) or SPP1 (host: Bacillus subtilis) have a significantly higher similarity to its host than its non-lysogenic (shedding or virulent) ones such as fd and T4 (host : E. coli) or phage gamma and PZA (host: B. subtilis). This finding is very promising for associating host-unknown viruses with their host. We also examined the relationship between codon usage frequency or G+C content of genomes to interpret the phenomenon revealed by SOSS analysis and obtained evidence supporting the hypothesis that higher SOSS levels result from cohabitation in same environment, which can cause the common biased mutation. Therefore, lysogenic phages that remain inside longer resemble the host. Â© The Author 2009. Published by Oxford University Press. All rights reserved.
authors: Ahmed, S.;Saito, A.;Suzuki, M.;Nemoto, N.;Nishigaki, K.

title: Genetic diversity and comparison of diagnostic tests to characterize foot-and-mouth disease viral strains from Pakistan 2008–2012
abstract: We report the laboratory analysis of 125 clinical specimens from suspected cases of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in cattle and Asian buffalo collected in Pakistan between 2008 and 2012. 89 of these samples were found to contain viral RNA by rRT-PCR, 88 of which were also found by virus isolation (VI) to contain infectious foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV), with strong correlation between these tests (κ = 0 ,96). Samples that were VI positive were serotyped by antigen detection ELISA (Ag-ELISA) and VP1 sequence acquisition and analysis. The sequence data identified FMDV serotypes A (n=13), O (n=36), and Asia-1 (n=41), including three samples in which both Asia-1 and O serotypes were detected. Serotype A viruses have been classified into three distinct Iran-05 sublineages: HER-10, FAR-11 and ESF-10. All Asia-1 serotypes were in group VII (Sindh-08 lineage) in a genetic group distinct from viruses isolated before 2010. All serotypes O have been classified as PanAsia-2 within two distinct sublineages: ANT-10 and BAL-09. Using VP1 sequencing as the gold standard for serotyping, the overall sensitivity of the Ag-ELISA to correctly determine the serotype was 74% and the serotype-specific sensitivity was 8% for serotype A, 88% for Asia-1 and 89% for O. The serotype-specific specificity was 100% for serotype A, 93% for Asia-1 and 94% for O. Interestingly, 12 out of 13 serotype A viruses were not detected by Ag-ELISA. This study confirms previous reports on the regional genetic diversity of FMD in Pakistan and underscores the importance of continued validation of diagnostic tests for rapidly evolving pathogens such as FMD.
authors: Ahmed, Z.;Pauszek, S. J.;Ludi, A.;LaRocco, M.;Khan, E. U. H.;Afzal, M.;Arshed, M. J.;Farooq, U.;Arzt, J.;Bertram, M.;Brito, B.;Naeem, K.;Abubakar, M.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Human endophthalmitis caused by pseudorabies virus infection, China, 2017
abstract: We report a human endophthalmitis caused by pseudorabies virus infection after exposure to sewage at a pig farm in China. High-throughput sequencing and real-time PCR of the vitreous revealed pseudorabies virus sequences. This case showed that the pseudorabies virus could infect humans after direct contact with contaminants.
authors: Ai, J. W.;Weng, S. S.;Cheng, Q.;Cui, P.;Li, Y. J.;Wu, H. L.;Zhu, Y. M.;Xu, B.;Zhang, W. H.

title: Whole genome analysis of porcine kobuviruses from pig faeces in Japan
abstract: Porcine kobuviruses (PoKoVs) are ubiquitous in swine populations worldwide and are considered enteric viruses in swine. Although PoKoVs have been detected in pigs in Japan, complete genomic data for Japanese PoKoVs are not available. In the present study, 24 near-complete or complete sequences of the PoKoV genome obtained from 10 diarrheal faeces and 14 non-diarrheal faeces of Japanese pigs were analyzed using a metagenomic approach. Japanese PoKoVs shared 85.2-100% identity with the full nucleotide coding sequences (nt) and the closest relatedness of 85.1-98.3% with PoKoVs from other countries. Twenty of 24 Japanese PoKoVs carried a 90 nt deletion in the 2B coding region. Phylogenetic tree analysis revealed that PoKoVs were not grouped according to their geographic region of origin and the phylogenetic trees of genetic regions L, P1, P2, and P3 had distinct topologies from each other. Analysis of the similarity plots using strains from a single farm revealed partially different similarity patterns between strains from identical farm origins, suggesting that recombination events have occurred. These results indicate that different PoKoV strains are widespread and geographically unrestricted on pig farms worldwide, and the coexistence of multiple strains leads to recombination events of PoKoVs and contributes to the genetic diversity and evolution of PoKoVs.
authors: Akagami, M.;Ito, M.;Niira, K.;Kuroda, M.;Masuda, T.;Haga, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Kishimoto, M.;Sano, K.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Oka, T.;Ichimaru, T.;Yamasato, H.;Ouchi, Y.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Two new "legumoviruses" (genus Begomovirus) naturally infecting soybeans in Nigeria
abstract: Two new "legumoviruses" (genus Begomovirus; family Geminiviridae) that naturally infect soybeans (Glycine max L. Merr.) in Nigeria have been molecularly characterized. Based on characteristic symptoms in soybeans, the two viruses are tentatively named Soybean Mild Mottle Virus (SbMMV) and Soybean Chlorotic Blotch Virus (SbCBV). SbCBV has a bipartite genome while SbMMV has only one DNA A component. The DNA A component of SbMMV is 2,768 nucleotides (nt) in length and the DNA A and DNA B components of SbCBV are 2,708 and 2,647 nt in length, respectively. In pairwise comparisons, the DNA A component of SbMMV and SbCBV showed 62% nt sequence identity, suggesting that these two viruses are different. While DNA A of SbMMV contains two virion and four complementary sense open reading frames, that of SbCBV lacks the viral sense AV2, a characteristic gene present in “old world” begomoviruses. A pairwise comparison with the corresponding nucleotide sequence of other begomoviruses in the databases showed that SbCBV had a maximum of 74% identity with Cowpea Golden Mosaic Virus and SbMMV had a maximum of 65% identity with Mungbean Yellow Mosaic India Virus and Kudzu Mosaic Virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the DNA A component of SbCBV and SbMMV, along with those of other begomoviruses available in the databases, indicated an accumulation of the two viruses within the "Legumovirus" clade of the begomovirus phylogenetic tree. In addition, the DNA A and B components of SbCBV from Centrosema pubescens Benth were found to be identical to those from soybean, suggesting that wild legume species are a potential alternative host for the virus. As soybean is an introduced crop, the identification of two distinct begomoviruses naturally infecting soybeans in Nigeria suggests the emergence of "legumoviruses" in plant species native to Africa and underscores their potential threat to sustainable cultivation of soybeans on the African continent. © Springer Verlag 2010.
authors: Alabi, O. J.;Kumar, P. L.;Mgbechi-Ezeri, J. U.;Naidu, R. A.

title: Serological and antigenic properties of Malaysian orf virus isolates - an in vitro comparative study
abstract: Three Malaysian goat orfvirus isolates (GV1, GV2 and GV3) were compared in their serological properties and protein profiles with three sheep orfviruses (LBV Malaysian isolate, ORFII and NZ2 reference strains). Serological tests such as cross-agar gel precipitation test (AGPT), serum neutralization test (SNT), ELISA, indirect immunofluorescence test (IIF) and indirect immunoperoxidase test (IIP) showed that the viruses were closely related. However, serotyping of these isolates by homologous and heterologous titration of their hyperimmune sera (HIS) in SNT and ELISA showed contradictory results and did not allow classification of these viruses as of goat and sheep origin. Protein analysis of these isolates was performed using SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE), Western blotting, and physical staining and immunodetection of blotted protein profiles. The results showed that these isolates differed mainly in the 41.5, 39.5 and 37.5 kD polypeptide bands. These analysis techniques allowed the classification of these isolates into four groups, GV1 and GV2 in the first, GV3 in the second, LBV and ORFII in the third, and NZ2 in the fourth.
authors: Alajeeli, K. S. A.;Iskander, F.;Ibrahim, A. L.;Zamrisaad, M.

title: Insights into Reston virus spillover and adaptation of virus genome sequences
abstract: Reston virus (filoviridae family) is unique among viruses of the Ebolavirus genus in that it is considered non-pathogenic to humans, unlike the other members, which are highly virulent. However, the virus has been linked to multiple outbreaks of highly fatal hemorrhagic fever in non-human primates (NHPs), particularly cynomolgus monkeys (Macaca fascicularis) native to the Philippines. In addition, Reston virus was isolated from domestic pigs in the Philippines. To better understand virus spillover events and potential adaptation to new hosts, the entire genome sequences of representative reston virus isolates were obtained using a next-generation sequencing (NGS) approach, and comparative genome analysis and virus fitness analysis were performed . Nine viral genome sequences were completed for new and previously described isolates obtained from a variety of hosts including a human case, non-human primates and pigs.
authors: Albarino, C. G.;Wiggleton Guerrero, L.;Jenks, H. M.;Chakrabarti, A. K.;Ksiazek, T. G.;Rollin, P. E.;Nichol, S. T.

title: A molecular epidemiological study of avian paramyxovirus type 1 (Newcastle disease virus) isolates by phylogenetic analysis of a partial nucleotide sequence of the fusion protein gene
abstract: For 174 Newcastle disease virus (avian paramyxovirus type 1) isolates, a sequence of 375 nucleotides in length encompassing the region coding for the cleavage activation site and the signal peptide of the fusion protein gene was determined. These were compared to the sequences of 164 isolates published on GenBank and the resulting alignment analyzed phylogenetically using maximum likelihood. The results are presented as unrooted family trees. Briefly, the isolates were divided into six broadly distinct groups (lines 1 through 6). Lines 3 and 4 were further subdivided into four sub-lines (a through d) and line 5 into five lines (a through e). Considerable genetic heterogeneity has been identified in avian paramyxovirus type 1, which appears to be influenced by host, time and geographic origin. It is concluded that by using this data set it will be possible to rapidly type future virus isolates based on their nucleotide sequence and draw conclusions about their origin.
authors: Aldous, E. W.;Mynn, J. K.;Banks, J.;Alexander, D. J.

title: Genome characterization of a pathogenic porcine rotavirus B strain identified in 2015 in the Republic of Buryatia, Russia
abstract: An outbreak of intestinal disease of unknown etiology with 60% morbidity and 8% mortality in weaned piglets occurred in November 2015 on a farm in the Republic of Buryatia, Russia. Metagenomic sequencing revealed the presence of rotavirus B in the faeces of diseased piglets, while no other pathogens were identified. The clinical disease was reproduced in experimentally infected piglets, expressing the 11 RVB gene segments for strain Buryat15 with an RVB genotype constellation of G12-P[4]-I13-R4-C4-M4-A8-N10-T4-E4-H7 revealed. This genotype constellation has also been identified in the United States. While the Buryat15 VP7 protein lacked unique amino acid differences in the predicted neutralizing epitopes compared to the previously published porcine RVB G12 strains, this report on RVB in Russian pigs advances our epidemiological knowledge of the global prevalence and genetic diversity of RVB.
authors: Alekseev, K. P.;Penin, A. A.;Mukhin, A. N.;Khametova, K. M.;Grebennikova, T. V.;Yuzhakov, A. G.;Moskvina, A. S.;Musienko, M. I.;Raev, S. A.;Mishin, A. M.;Kotelnikov, A. P.;Verkhovsky, O. A.;Aliper, T. I.;Nepoklonov, E. A.;Herrera-Ibata, D. M.;Shepherd, F. K.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: The long view: a selective review of 40 years of Newcastle disease research
abstract: This review was written for the series celebrating 40 years since the first issue of Avian Pathology. The authors' aim was to present developments in Newcastle disease (ND) research over the past 40 years that they considered significant. During these 40 years there have been several panzootia of this serious disease in poultry and in the last 30 years there has been persistent panzootia in domestic pigeons which has spread to wild birds and poultry. The 40-year period began with global outbreaks of severe ND, which served as an important impetus for ND research. Although early work focused on controlling the disease, particularly through the improvement and development of new vaccines and vaccination schedules, ND virus was considered a useful laboratory virus for replication and virulence studies even before the 1970s. This review covers historical developments in the following areas: understanding the molecular basis of virulence; Epidemiology and relationship of different ND strains, both antigenic and genetic; the emergence of virulent strains and their relationship to low virulence viruses; sequencing and understanding of the viral genome and genes; the development of molecular-based rapid diagnostic tests; and the phylogeny and molecular taxonomy of ND virus. The authors suggest areas where future research could or should be pursued. © 2012 Copyright Crown Copyright.
authors: Alexander, D. J.;Aldous, E. W.;Fuller, C. M.

title: Development of a methodology based on commercialized SERS-active substrates for rapid differentiation of Poxviridae virions
abstract: Surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) can be made an attractive approach for identifying Raman-active compounds and biological materials (ie, toxins, viruses, or intact bacterial cells/spores) through the development of reproducible, spatially uniform SERS-active substrates. Recently, reproducible (from substrate to substrate), spatially homogeneous (over large areas), SERS-active substrates have been commercialized and are now commercially available. We used these patterned surfaces to acquire SERS spectral signatures from intact bovine papular stomatitis, pseudo-cowpox, and yaba monkey tumor viruses. Striking spectral signature features make it possible to distinguish between these genetically distinct Poxviridae-Chordopoxvirinae virions. In addition, partial least squares, a multivariate calibration method, was used to develop PC-based algorithms useful for the classification of unknown parapoxvirus samples (e.g., bovine papular stomatitis virus and pseudo-cowpoxvirus) unique to SERS spectral signatures are based. To our knowledge, this is the first report detailing the application of these commercially available (COTS) SERS-active substrates to identify intact poxviruses.
authors: Alexander, T. A.

title: Etiology and pathology of epidemic outbreaks of avian influenza H5N1 infection in Egyptian chicken farms
abstract: Epidemic outbreaks of the avian influenza (AI) virus H5N1 have been reported frequently in Egypt over the past nine years. Here we examine the involvement of AI H5N1 in acute respiratory disease outbreaks that occurred in several commercial chicken farms in Egypt in 2011 and we describe the pathology caused by the virus during the course of the outbreak. Twenty-one chicken farms with a history of acute respiratory symptoms and high mortality were screened for AI H5N1. Virus identification was based on a hemagglutination inhibition test and PCR detection and sequencing of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes. Virus distribution was determined by immunohistochemical staining for AI antigens in organs from infected birds. Standard H&E staining was performed for histological examination of the affected organs. 81% of the birds examined, representing 100% of the farms examined, were positive for the AI H5N1 virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of the isolated virus indicates its membership in clade 2.2.1. Viral antigens were localized to the endothelial cells of the heart, liver, lung and skin where pathologic lesions including congestion, hemorrhage, multifocal inflammation and necrosis were observed simultaneously. According to the pattern of viral antigen and lesion distribution in the visceral organs, we propose cardiovascular and circulatory failure as the probable cause of death during these outbreaks. In conclusion, the present study further confirms the epidemic status of the AI H5N1 virus in Egypt and demonstrates the highly pathogenic nature of the local isolates.
authors: Ali, A.;Elmowalid, G.;Abdel-Glil, M.;Sharafeldin, T.;Abdallah, F.;Mansour, S.;Nagy, A.;Ahmed, B.;Abdelmoneim, M.

title: Molecular characterization of the complete genomes of two novel field isolates of cowpea chlorotic blotch virus and their phylogenetic analysis
abstract: Cowpea chlorotic mottle virus (CCMV, family Bromoviridae) is found worldwide and has long been used as a model virus, but data on the genetic diversity of field isolates are lacking. Recently, two new field isolates (Car1 and Car2) of CCMV derived from cowpeas showed marked phenotypic symptoms when inoculated into cowpeas. CCMV-Car1 induced severe mosaic and intervenal chlorosis, while CCMV-Car2 caused mild mottle and leaf curl. Both isolates resulted in an asymptomatic infection of Nicotiana benthamiana. The complete genome of both isolates was amplified, cloned and sequenced by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction using specific primers against the CCMV sequences available in the GenBank database. Both nucleotide and amino acid sequences were compared between the newly sequenced CCMV isolates and the three previously characterized CCMV strains (T, M1 and R). Phylogenetic analysis of the RNA-1 sequence showed that CCMV-Car1 was in a separate branch from the remaining CCMV isolates, while CCMV-Car2 was grouped together with CCMV-R. Two main groups were obtained based on the RNA-2 and RNA-3 sequences. One group included CCMV Car1 and CCMV Car2 isolates, while the other contained CCMV T, CCMV M1 and CCMV R strains. Recombination programs detected a potential recombination event in the RNA-1 sequence of the CCMV Car2 isolate but not in the RNA-2 and RNA-3 sequences. The results showed that both mutations and recombination played important roles in the genetic diversity of these two new CCMV isolates. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Ali, A.;Shafiekhani, M.;Olsen, J.

title: Hendra and Nipah Infection: Emerging Paramyxoviruses
abstract: Since first appearing in the mid-1990s, henipaviruses have reappeared almost every year in Australia and Southeast Asia. In total, more than 12 Nipah and 48 Hendra virus outbreaks have been reported in Southeast Asia and Australia respectively. These outbreaks are associated with significant economic and health damage, leaving most high-risk countries (particularly in Southeast Asia) unable to bear the burden of such economic threats. Until recently, there were no real therapeutics to treat or prevent these deadly infections. However, international collaborative research has led to the identification of a potential Hendra vaccine for horses that may provide antibody protection against Hendra virus infection. So are we there with the current knowledge and after almost 2 decades since their first discovery? This review article summarizes the history of henipavirus emergence and briefly evaluates potential anti-henipavirus vaccines and antivirals. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Aljofan, M.

title: Genetic characterization of the Wad Medani virus (WMV) (Reoviridae, Orbivirus) isolated from the tick Hyalomma asiaticum Schulze et Schlottke, 1930 (Ixodidae: Hyalomminae) in Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan and Armenia and from the tick H. anatolicum Koch, 1844 in Tajikistan]
authors: Al'khovskiÄ­, S. V.;L'Vov D, K.;Shchelkanov, M. Iu;Shchetinin, A. M.;Deriabin, P. G.;Gitel'man, A. K.;Aristova, V. A.;Botikov, A. G.

title: A virus detection method involving DNase treatment and its application to identify two bovine parvovirus species
abstract: The identification of previously unrecognized viral agents in serum or plasma samples is of great medical interest but remains a major challenge, mainly because of the abundance of host DNA. The current methods, library screening or representation difference analysis (RDA), are very laborious and require selected sample sets. We have developed a simple and reproducible method for detecting viruses in single serum samples, based on DNase treatment of the serum, followed by restriction enzyme digestion and sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA) of the fragments, and evaluated its performance against known methods viruses. Both DNA viruses and RNA viruses at a concentration of ≥106 genome equivalents per ml were reproducibly identified in 50 µl of serum. During the evaluation of the method, two previously unknown parvoviruses were discovered in the bovine sera used as a diluent. The nearly complete genome sequence of each virus has been determined; their classification as two species (tentatively named bovine parvoviruses 2 and 3) was confirmed by phylogenetic analysis. Both viruses have been found to be common contaminants of commercial bovine serum. DNase treatment of serum samples can prove to be a very useful tool for virus detection. The DNase SISPA method is useful for screening large numbers of samples and also allows for rapid sequencing of high titer viruses.
authors: Allander, T.;Emerson, S. U.;Engle, R. E.;Purcell, R. H.;Bukh, J.

title: Cloning of a human parvovirus by molecular screening of respiratory specimens
abstract: Identifying new virus species is a key issue for investigating infectious diseases, but it is technically very difficult. We have developed a system for large-scale molecular virus screening of clinical samples based on host DNA depletion, random PCR amplification, large-scale sequencing and bioinformatics. The technology was applied to pooled human airway samples. The first experiments detected seven human virus types without the use of a specific reagent. Viruses detected included a coronavirus and a parvovirus, both of which were uncharacterized at the time. The parvovirus, tentatively named human bocavirus, was identified in a retrospective clinical study in 17 additional patients and associated with lower respiratory tract infections in children. The molecular virus screening method offers a general, culture-independent solution to the problem of detecting unknown virus species in individual or pooled samples. We propose that systematic research into the viruses that infect humans, the "human virome," can be initiated.
authors: Allander, T.;Tammi, M. T.;Eriksson, M.;Bjerkner, A.;Tiveljung-Lindell, A.;Andersson, B.

title: Estimation of viral richness from shotgun metagenomes using an abundance counting approach
abstract: BACKGROUND: Viruses are important drivers of ecosystem functions, yet little is known about the vast majority of viruses. Viral shotgun metagenomics enables the investigation of broad ecological questions in phage communities. An ecological feature is the richness of species, i.e. the number of different species in a community. Viruses do not have a phylogenetic marker analogous to the bacterial 16S rRNA gene to estimate richness, and thus contig spectra are used to measure the number of viral taxa in a given community. A contig spectrum is generated from a viral shotgun metagenome by assembling the random sequence reads into groups of sequences that overlap (contigs) and counting the number of sequences that group within each contig. Currently available tools for analyzing contig spectra to estimate phage richness are limited by relying on rank abundance data. RESULTS: We present statistical estimates of virus richness from contig spectra. The program CatchAll (http://www.northeastern.edu/catchall/) was used to analyze contig spectra in terms of frequency count data rather than rank frequency, allowing for formal statistical analysis. In addition, the impact of potentially false low-frequency counts on richness estimates was minimized by two methods, empirical and statistical. The results show higher estimates of virus richness than previous calculations in almost all environments analyzed, including pig feces and treated freshwater. CONCLUSIONS: CatchAll provided consistent estimates of richness across viral metagenomes from the same or similar environments. Furthermore, analysis of pooled viral metagenomes from different environments via mixed contig spectra resulted in larger estimates of richness than that of the component metagenomes. Using CatchAll to analyze contig spectra will improve estimates of the richness of viral shotgun metagenomes, particularly of large datasets, by providing statistical measures of richness.
authors: Allen, H. K.;Bunge, J.;Foster, J. A.;Bayles, D. O.;Stanton, T. B.

title: Antibiotics in the feed induce prophages in the microbiome of pig faeces
abstract: Antibiotics are an inexpensive tool to improve feed efficiency and prevent disease in farm animals, but the full extent of their side effects is not yet known. Antibiotics have been shown to mediate gene transfer by inducing prophages in certain bacterial strains; Therefore, a side effect could be prophage induction throughout the gut microbiome. Here we used metagenomics to assess the effect of two dietary antibiotics (Carbadox and ASP250 [chlortetracycline, sul-famethazine, and penicillin]) on porcine intestinal phage metagenomes (viromas). We also monitored the bacterial communities using 16S rRNA gene sequencing. ASP250, but not carbadox, caused significant population shifts in both the phage and bacterial communities. Antibiotic resistance genes such as B. Multidrug-resistance efflux pumps were identified in the viromas, but antibiotics in the diet did not cause significant changes in their frequency. The frequency of genes encoding phage integrase was significantly increased in the viromas of drug-treated pigs versus the viromas of non-medicated pigs, demonstrating the induction of prophages by antibiotic treatment. Population dynamics of phages and bacteria were also studied. We observed a decrease in the relative abundance of Streptococcus bacteria (prey) when Streptococcus phage (predators) were abundant, supporting the kill-the-winner ecological model of population dynamics in the pig fecal microbiome. The data show that the dynamics of the gut ecosystem are influenced by phages and that prophage induction is a side effect of antibiotics in the feed. © 2011 Allen et al.
authors: Allen, H. K.;Looft, T.;Bayles, D. O.;Humphrey, S.;Levine, U. Y.;Alt, D.;Stanton, T. B.

title: The Ostseeviroma: Diversity and transcriptional activity of DNA and RNA viruses
authors: Allen, L. Z.;McCrow, J. P.;Ininbergs, K.;Dupont, C. L.

title: ICTV virus taxonomy profile: Asfarviridae
abstract: The Asfarviridae family includes African swine fever virus as a single species whose isolates have linear dsDNA genomes of 170-194 kbp. Virions have an inner core, an inner lipid membrane, an icosahedral capsid, and an outer lipid envelope. Infection of domestic and wild pigs results in an acute haemorrhagic fever transmitted by contact or ingestion, or by ticks of the Ornithodoros genus. Native pigs act as reservoirs in Africa, where the infection is endemic and from where periodic introductions to Europe occur. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the taxonomy of the Asfarviridae, available at www.ictv.global/report/asfarviridae.
authors: Alonso, C.;Borca, M.;Dixon, L.;Revilla, Y.;Rodriguez, F.;Escribano, J. M.;Lefkowitz, E. J.;Davison, A. J.;Siddell, S. G.;Simmonds, P.;Sabanadzovic, S.;Smith, D. B.;Orton, R. J.;Harrach, B.

title: Epidemiological study on air filtration systems to prevent PRRSV infection in large herds of sows
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is the most economically important pathogen in the US swine industry. Transmission of aerosols between herds is a major concern in regions with high swine density, and filtration of the incoming air, combined with standard biosecurity procedures, has been shown to prevent transmission of PRRSV to susceptible herds. To quantify the effects of air filtration in reducing the risk of PRRSV outbreaks, we compared the incidence rate of new PRRSV introductions in 20 filtered and 17 unfiltered control sow herds in a swine-rich region of North America during a 7-year study period. Events of introduction of new viruses were detected by phylogenetic analysis of PRRSV ORF5 gene sequences. Putative new viruses were defined as exogenous (introduced) based on differences in ORF5 nucleotide sequence compared to previous farm isolates. The impact of cutoff values for sequence differences ranging from 2 to 10% on case definition and relative risk was assessed. Unfiltered farms suffered about 0.5 outbreaks per year, with a seasonal increase in risk during cooler periods. The baseline risk before filtration was about 0.75 per year in treatment farms, about 50% higher than in control farms. Air filtration significantly reduced the risk of PRRSV introduction events to 0.06–0.22 outbreaks per year, depending on the cut-off values used to classify a virus isolate as new to the herd. Overall, air filtration resulted in an approximately 80% reduction in the risk of introducing novel PRRSV, suggesting that in large sow farms with good biosecurity in pig-rich regions, approximately four-fifths of PRRSV outbreaks could be due to aerosol transmission. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Alonso, C.;Murtaugh, M. P.;Dee, S. A.;Davies, P. R.

title: Characterization of H5N1 influenza, a virus that caused the first highly pathogenic avian influenza outbreak in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Introduction: An outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 in domestic birds occurred in Saudi Arabia (SA) in 2007. METHODS: Forty-three hemagglutinin (HA) and 41 neuraminidase (NA) genes from HPAI H5N1 viruses were sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically. Fully sequenced genes were performed to compare them with other viral HA and NA gene sequences reported in the public databases are available. Results: Molecular characterization of the H5N1 viruses revealed two genetically distinct clades, 2.2.2 and 2.3.1, of H5N1 viruses circulating in the area. Amino acid sequence analysis of the HA gene showed that the virus from 2.2.2 contained the sequence SPQGERRRK-R/G at the cleavage site, while the virus from 2.3.1 contained the sequence SPQRERRK-R/G. In addition, a few mutations involving amino acid substitutions such as M226I at the N-link glycosylation site were identified in two of these isolates. The amino acid sequence of the NA gene revealed a 20 amino acid deletion in the NA stalk region, which is required for increased virulence of influenza viruses and their adaptation from wild birds to domestic chickens. Since close contact between humans and birds is inevitable, a thorough understanding of virus epidemiology, factors affecting virus spread, and molecular characterization such as phylogeny and substitution rates of H5N1 viruses circulating in the region is required. Conclusion: Two genetically distinct clades were found to be circulating in the country, which could likely lead to recombination and the emergence of more virulent virus strains. These results could be helpful to authorities developing control measures against these viruses.
authors: Al-Qahtani, A. A.;Mubin, M.;Almajhdi, F. N.;Alarifi, S.;Cruz, D. M. D.;ul Rehman, M. S. N.;Ismail, M. M.;Ahmed, N.;Al-Blowi, M. H.;Khalak, H.;Al-Ahdal, M. N.

title: DISTRIBUTION OF CHICKEN ANEMIA VIRUS IN TISSUES, CASES AND ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES UP TO 56TH DAY AFTER ARTIFICIAL...
authors: Alsharari, M.;Islam, Afmf;Renz, K. G.;Burgess, S. K.

title: Molecular characterization of the first strains of bovine herpesvirus 4 (BoHV-4) isolated from in vitro production of bovine embryos in Argentina
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus 4 (BoHV-4) is increasingly believed to be responsible for various reproductive tract problems. The virus mainly infects blood mononuclear cells and shows a specific tropism for vascular endothelia, reproductive and fetal tissues. Epidemiological studies suggest that it affects reproductive performance, and its presence at various sites in the reproductive tract underscores its potential transmission in transfer-stage embryos. This work describes the biological and genetic characterization of BoHV-4 strains isolated from an in vitro bovine embryo production system. BoHV-4 strains were isolated in 2011 and 2013 from granulosa cells and bovine oocytes from ovarian batches collected at a local slaughterhouse and used as “starting material” for in vitro bovine embryo production. Compatible BoHV-4 CPE was observed in the co-culture of granulosa cells and oocytes with MDBK cells. The identity of the isolates was confirmed by PCR assays targeting three ORFs of the viral genome. The phylogenetic analyzes of the tribes suggest that they were not evolutionarily related. Therefore, it is possible that BoHV-4 ovarian infections, at least in Argentina, have periodically emerged during the development of the virus, which may have implications for in vitro embryo production systems. Therefore, although BoHV-4 does not appear to be a common risk factor for in vitro embryo production, data are still limited. This study demonstrates the potential of transferring BoHV-4 by embryo transfer. Furthermore, the high variability among the BoHV-4 strains isolated from aborted cows in Argentina underscores the importance of further research on the role of this virus as a pathogen with the potential to cause reproductive diseases in cattle. The genetic characterization of the isolated strains provides data for a better understanding of the pathogenesis of BoHV-4 infections. In addition, it will lead to fundamental insights into the molecular aspects of the virus and the way these strains circulate in the herds.

authors: Aluthge, N. D.;Tom, W.;Burkey, T. E.

title: broad spectrum, one-step reverse transcription PCR amplification of the neuraminidase gene from multiple subtypes of influenza A virus
abstract: BACKGROUND: The emergence of highly pathogenic influenza A virus strains in a variety of human and animal hosts with wide geographic distribution has highlighted the importance of rapid virus identification and subtyping for outbreak management and treatment. Type A viruses can be divided into subtypes according to the viral envelope glycoproteins, hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. Here we review the existing specificity and amplification of published primers for subtypes of neuraminidase genes and describe a new broad spectrum primer pair that can recognize all 9 neuraminidase subtypes. RESULTS: Bioinformatic analysis of 3,337 full-length influenza A neuraminidase segments in the NCBI database revealed semi-conserved regions not previously targeted by primers. Two M13-tagged degenerate primers, NA8F-M13 and NA10R-M13, were designed from these regions and used to generate a 253 bp cDNA product. One-step RT-PCR testing was successful in 31/32 (97%) cases using a touchdown protocol with RNA from over 32 different cultured influenza A virus strains representing the 9 neuraminidase subtypes. Frozen blinded clinical nasopharyngeal aspirates were also tested and were mostly of the N2 subtype. The amplified region was directly sequenced and then used in database searches to confirm the identity of the template RNA. The generated RT-PCR fragment contains one of the mutation sites associated with oseltamivir resistance, H274Y. CONCLUSION: Our one-step RT-PCR assay followed by sequencing is a rapid, accurate, and specific method for the detection and subtyping of different neuraminidase subtypes from a range of host species and from different geographic locations.
authors: Alvarez, A. C.;Brunck, M. E.;Boyd, V.;Lai, R.;Virtue, E.;Chen, W.;Bletchly, C.;Heine, H. G.;Barnard, R.

title: High-throughput double-stranded RNA sequencing reveals a novel cytorhabdovirus in a transgenic common bean line resistant to bean golden mosaic virus
abstract: Using high-throughput double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) sequencing, we identified five RNA viruses in a golden mosaic bean virus (BGMV)-resistant transgenic line of common bean with symptoms of viral infection. Four of the identified viruses have previously been described as infecting common beans (Cowpea Mild Mottle Virus, Bean Rugose Mosaic Virus, Phaseolus vulgaris Alphaendornavirus 1 and Phaseolus vulgaris Alphaendornavirus 2) and one is a putative novel plant rhabdovirus (genus Cytorhabdovirus) tentatively named beans -associated cytorhabdovirus (BaCV). The BaCV genome presented all five open reading frames (ORFs) found in most rhabdoviruses: nucleoprotein (N) (ORF1) (451 amino acids, aa), phosphoprotein (P) (ORF2) (445 aa), matrix ( M) (ORF4) (287 aa), glycoprotein (G) (ORF5) (520 aa), and an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L) (ORF6) (114 aa), as well as a putative locomotor protein (P3) (ORF3) ( 189 aa) and the hypothetical small protein P4. The predicted BaCV proteins were compared to homologous proteins of the nearest cytorhabdoviruses and a low level of sequence identity (15-39%) was observed. Phylogenetic analysis shows that BaCV is clustered with yerba mate chlorosis-associated virus (YmCaV) and rice streak mosaic virus (RSMV). Taken together, our results provide strong evidence that BaCV is indeed a new virus species in the genus Cytorhabdovirus (family Rhabdoviridae), the first rhabdovirus identified to infect kidney bean.
authors: Alves-Freitas, D. M. T.;Pinheiro-Lima, B.;Faria, J. C.;Lacorte, C.;Ribeiro, S. G.;Melo, F. L.

title: Serpins, viruses and the virome: new directions in therapy
authors: Ambadapadi, S.;Chen, H.;Zheng, D.;Liu, L.;Dai, E.

title: Bovine-like coronaviruses in domestic and wild ruminants
abstract: Coronaviruses (CoVs) produce a wide range of disease syndromes in different mammalian and avian host species. These viruses are known for their ability to alter tissue tropism, cross species barriers, and adapt to ecological variations. The inherent genetic diversity of CoVs, caused by the accumulation of point mutations and the high frequency of homologous recombination, is predicted to be the main determinant of these competencies. Several CoVs (eg, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome - CoV, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome - CoV) have been found to cross the interspecies barrier and cause various disease states in different animal hosts. Bovine CoV (BCoV) is a major cause of gastroenteritis and respiratory disease in bovine calves, dysentery in lactating cows, and transport fever pneumonia in beef cattle. Although it has long been recognized as a restrictive bovine pathogen, CoVs closely related to BCoV have been recognized in dogs, humans, and other ruminant species.
