Biological, antigenic and genetic analyzes of the so-called "bovine-like CoVs" suggested classifying these viruses as variants of the host spectrum and not as independent virus species. In this review, the various bovine-like CoVs identified in domestic ruminants (water buffalo, sheep, goat, dromedary, llama, and alpaca) and wild ruminants (deer, wild cattle, antelope, giraffe, and wild goat) are discussed in terms of epidemiology, transmission, and virus properties. The data presented demonstrate the importance of these viruses for the persistence of BCoV in nature, its spread into new geographic zones and the continued emergence of disease epidemics in cattle ranches.
authors: Amer, H. M.

title: A metagenomic analysis shows the diversity of faecal vioma in asymptomatic pigs in East Africa
abstract: Pigs harbor a variety of viruses that are closely related to human viruses and are suspected of having zoonotic potential. Little is known about the presence of viruses on smallholder farms where pigs are in close contact with humans and wildlife. This study provides insight into viral communities and the prevalence and characteristics of enteric viral co-infections in smallholder pigs in East Africa. Sequence-independent amplification and high-throughput sequencing were applied to metagenomic analysis of viruses in feces of asymptomatic pigs. A total of 47,213 de novo assembled contigs were constructed and compared to sequences from the GenBank database. The Blastx search results showed that 1039 contigs (>200 nt) were related to viral sequences in the GenBank database. Of the 1039 contigs, 612 were not assigned to viral taxa because they shared little similarity to known viral genomic or protein sequences, while 427 contigs shared a high degree of sequence similarity to known viruses and were assigned to viral taxa. The most common contigs refer to mammalian viruses resembling members of the Astrovirus, Rotavirus, Bocavirus, Circovirus, and Kobuvirus genera. Other less common contigs were related to members of the Sapelovirus, Pasivirus, Posavirus, Teschovirus, and Picobirnavirus genera. This is the first report on the diversity of faecal vioma in pig populations in East Africa. The results of the present study help to elucidate the etiology of porcine diarrheal diseases and to identify potential zoonotic and emerging viruses in the region. Further research is needed to compare the occurrence of these viruses in healthy and diseased pigs to better elucidate their pathogenic role.
authors: Amimo, J. O.;El Zowalaty, M. E.;Githae, D.;Wamalwa, M.;Djikeng, A.;Nasrallah, G. K.

title: Association of an increased conviction rate of broiler carcasses due to liver abnormalities with immunosuppressive disorders in the Saskatchewan broiler industry
abstract: The aim of this study was to identify the causative agents of hepatitis observed in broilers at processing. Livers from chickens from 16 Saskatchewan broiler farms with gross hepatitis lesions were collected at processing. In addition to routine bacterial isolation and histopathological examination, serological examinations for infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) and chicken anemia virus (CAV), calculation of the ratio of bursal weight of Fabricius (BF) to body weight (BBW), and histopathological examination of the BF were carried out. Of the 264 livers with gross lesions, 83% had multifocal to coalescent necrotizing hepatitis, 16% had perihepatitis, and 1% had bleeding. No definitive causative microorganisms were isolated from the liver lesions; however, no significant bacterial isolations were performed. Bursal atrophy, low BBW ratio, and high antibody titer to IBDV each correlated with the rate of overall convictions (P=0.0188, P=0.0001, and P=0.0073, respectively). Nucleotide sequencing of IBDV isolated from the BF identified variant strains Delaware-E and 586. Liver lesion conviction was correlated with antibody titer to IBDV and BBW (P=0.016 and P=0.027, respectively). The results of this study indicate that hepatic lesions in Saskatchewan chickens are currently not caused by a primary bacterial pathogen but are associated with evidence of immunosuppression that is likely due to an IBDV variant.
authors: Amini, K.;Zachar, T.;Popowich, S.;Knezacek, T.;Goodhope, B.;Willson, P.;Gomis, S.

title: Kiyoshi Tajima1 and Rustam Aminov2* National Organization for Agriculture and Food Research, National Institute of Livestock
authors: Aminov, R.

title: Pet rodents and fatal lymphocytic choriomeningitis in transplant recipients
abstract: In April 2005, 4 transplant recipients became ill after receiving organs infected with lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV); 3 later died. All organs were from a donor exposed to an LCMV infected hamster. The hamster was traced through a pet store in Rhode Island to a distribution center in Ohio and additional LCMV-infected hamsters were discovered in both. Rodents from the Ohio facility and their parent Arkansas facility were tested for the same LCMV strain as the 1 implicated in transplant-related deaths. Phylogenetic analysis of virus sequences linked the rodents from the Ohio facility to the Rhode Island pet store, index hamster and transplant recipients. This report describes animal tracing and supporting laboratory testing.
authors: Amman, B. R.;Pavlin, B. I.;Albarino, C. G.;Comer, J. A.;Erickson, B. R.;Oliver, J. B.;Sealy, T. K.;Vincent, M. J.;Nichol, S. T.;Paddock, C. D.;Tumpey, A. J.;Wagoner, K. D.;Glauer, R. D.;Smith, K. A.;Winpisinger, K. A.;Parsely, M. S.;Wyrick, P.;Hannafin, C. H.;Bandy, U.;Zaki, S.;Rollin, P. E.;Ksiazek, T. G.

title: Genetic characterization of 2008 reassortant influenza A virus (H5N1), Thailand
abstract: In January and November 2008, outbreaks of bird flu were reported in 4 provinces of Thailand. Eight influenza A H5N1 viruses were recovered from these 2008 AI outbreaks and extensively characterized and analyzed for nucleotide identity, genetic relatedness, virulence determinants, and possible reassortment sites. The results show that the 2008 H5N1 viruses exhibited genetic drift characteristics (less than 3% genetic differences) commonly found in influenza A viruses. Based on a phylogenetic analysis, clade 1 viruses in Thailand have been divided into 3 distinct branches (subclades 1, 1.1 and 1.2). Six out of eight H5N1 isolates were identified as reassorted H5N1 viruses, while other isolates belong to an original H5N1 clade. These viruses have been reassorted between subclades 1.1 and 1.2 between lineages and thus represent new reassorted 2008 H5N1 viruses. The reassorted viruses acquired H5N1 subclass 1.1 (PA, HA, NP and M) and subclass 1.2 (PB2, PB1, NA and NS) gene segments in Thailand. Bootsscan analysis of concatenated full genome sequences of the 2008 H5N1 viruses supported the reassortment sites between subclass 1.1 and 1.2 viruses. Based on the estimate of the time of the most recent common ancestor of the 2008 H5N1 viruses, the potential date of a genetic rearrangement of the viruses could be traced back to 2006. Genetic analysis of the 2008 H5N1 viruses showed that most virulence determinants in all 8 genes of the viruses remained unchanged. In summary, two predominant H5N1 lineages were circulating in 2008. The original CUK2-like lineage circulated mainly in central Thailand and the re-sorted lineage (subclades 1.1 and 1.2) circulated mainly in lower northern Thailand. To prevent re-sorting, priority should be given to preventing the spread of H5N1 viruses in high-risk areas. In addition, surveillance and whole genome sequencing of H5N1 viruses should be routinely performed to monitor genetic drift of the virus and new reassorted strains, particularly given possible reassortment between avian and mammalian H5N1 viruses.
authors: Amonsin, A.;Lapkuntod, J.;Suwannakarn, K.;Kitikoon, P.;Suradhat, S.;Tantilertcharoen, R.;Boonyapisitsopa, S.;Bunpapong, N.;Wongphatcharachai, M.;Wisedchanwet, T.;Theamboonlers, A.;Poovorawan, Y.;Sasipreeyajan, J.;Thanawongnuwech, R.

title: Perennial evolutionary dynamics of West Nile virus in suburban Chicago, USA, 2005-2007
abstract: West Nile virus has evolved in line with its spread across North America, but little is known about the evolutionary dynamics of the virus at the local level. We analyzed viral nucleotide sequences from mosquitoes collected in 2005, 2006, and 2007 from a known transmission "hot spot" in suburban Chicago, USA. Within this approximately 11 × 14 km area, the viral envelope gene has increased in genetic diversity at the nucleotide level by approximately 0.1% per year. Each year, viral diversity was higher in densely built-up "residential areas" than in more open "urban green spaces" such as cemeteries and parks. Phylodynamic analyzes showed an increase in incidence around 2005, consistent with a higher-than-average peak in mosquito and human infection rates that year. Analyzes of times to the most recent common ancestor suggest that WNV may have arisen predominantly in 2005 and 2006 from viruses present in 2004 and 2005, respectively, but that WNV had an older common ancestor in 2007, possibly indicating a predominantly mixed or exogenous origin. These results demonstrate that the population of WNV in a suburb of Chicago is an admixture of viruses both locally derived and introduced from elsewhere, containing evolutionary information aggregated across a breadth of spatial and temporal scales. © 2010 The Royal Society.
authors: Amore, G.;Bertolotti, L.;Hamer, G. L.;Kitron, U. D.;Walker, E. D.;Ruiz, M. O.;Brawn, J. D.;Goldberg, T. L.

title: Genetic analysis of bovine Akabane virus isolates in Korea
abstract: Bayesian Inference (BI) and Neighbor Joining (NJ) analyzes of the phylogenetic relationships between the nucleotide sequences of the Akabane virus N gene revealed an unclear topology between genogroups I-III, likely caused by genetic rearrangement or recombination between these genogroups . In contrast, phylogenetic nucleotide and amino acid tree analyzes of the M-RNA segment were consistent with the topologies obtained using the BI and NJ methods. Therefore, unambiguous genogrouping of Akabane virus isolates should be performed using the M-RNA segment. Four Korea isolates were classified into genogroup II along with Akabane virus strains isolated from all areas of Japan including the island of Okinawa. However, more nationwide isolates and more clinical data from Korean cattle ranches are needed in the future to confirm the precise relationships between genotypes and pathogenicity. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: An, D. J.;Yoon, S. H.;Jeong, W.;Kim, H. J.;Park, B. K.

title: The gene sequences UL31 to UL35 of the duck enteritis virus correspond to their homologues in the herpes simplex virus
abstract: Five ORFs in the duck enteritis virus (DEV) genome that correspond to the UL31, UL32, UL33, UL34, and UL35 genes of herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) were identified by modified targeted gene walking PCR amplified, cloned and sequenced. The genes UL33, UL34 and UL35 were oriented from left to right of the genome, while UL31 and UL32 had an opposite orientation. A comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences of the DEV ORFs with their alphaherpesvirus homologues revealed well conserved regions with the exception of the UL34 and UL35 genes. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that DEV is closer to the genus Mardivirus than to any other genus of the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae. Based on this evidence, we proposed assigning DEV to the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae.
authors: An, R.;Li, H.;Han, Z.;Shao, Y.;Liu, S.;Kong, X.

title: Analysis of the entire genome of the epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus identified constrained genome constellations and preferential rearrangement
abstract: Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease Virus (EHDV) is a Culicoides-borne orbivirus that causes hemorrhagic disease in wild and domestic ruminants. A collection of 44 EHDV isolated between 2008 and 2012 was fully sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. Serotype 2 viruses were the dominant serotype in all years except 2012 when serotype 6 viruses accounted for 63% of isolates. A high genetic similarity (>94% identity) between the VP1, VP3, VP4, VP6, NS1, NS2 and NS3 segments of virus serotypes 1 and 2 prevented the identification of reassortment events for these segments . In addition, there was low genetic diversity (>96% identity) within the serotypes for VP2, VP5 and VP7. Preferential reassortment within the homologous serotype was observed for VP2, VP5 and VP7 segments for type 1 and type 2 viruses. In contrast, type 6 viruses were all reassortants containing VP2 and VP5 derived from an exotic type 6, with the remaining segments most similar to type 2 viruses. These results suggest that reassortment between type 1 and type 2 viruses requires the preservation of the VP2, VP5 and VP7 segment constellation, while type 6 viruses require only VP2 and VP5 and onto the type 2 -Line VP7 are restricted. Since type 6 VP2 and VP5 segments were identified exclusively in type 2-derived VP7 viruses, these results indicate functional complementation between the type 2 and type 6 VP7 proteins. © 2014 SGM.
authors: Anbalagan, S.;Cooper, E.;Klumper, P.;Simonson, R. R.;Hause, B. M.

title: Dietary energy drives the dynamic response of the bovine rumen viral communities
abstract: BACKGROUND: Rumen microbes play a larger role in host energy uptake than gut microbes in monogastric animals. Although genome-based advances provide access to the vast diversity of uncultured microbes, our understanding of the variables that shape rumen microbial communities is still in its infancy. Viruses have been shown to affect microbial populations through a variety of processes, including cell lysis and reprogramming of host metabolism. However, little is known about the processes that influence the distribution of rumen viruses or how viruses can modulate microbially driven processes in the rumen. To this end, we investigated how the structure and function of the rumen bacterial and viral community responded in five steers fed four randomized diet regimens in a crossover design. RESULTS: Total digestible nutrients (TDN), a measure of dietary energy, best explained the variation in bacterial and viral communities. Other ecological drivers of viral communities were dietary zinc levels and microbial functional diversity. Using partial least squares regression, we show significant associations between the abundance of 267 virus populations and variables driving variation in rumen viral communities. Although rumen viruses were dynamic, 14 near-ubiquitous virus populations were identified, suggesting the presence of a central rumen virus composed largely of novel viruses. In addition, analysis of virally encoded metabolic auxiliary genes (AMGs) indicates that rumen viruses possess glycosidic hydrolases that may enhance the breakdown of complex carbohydrates to increase energy production. Other identified AMGs play a role in redirecting carbon to the pentose phosphate pathway and one pools carbon through folate to increase viral replication. CONCLUSIONS: We show that rumen bacteria and viruses have distinct responses and environmental drivers to nutritional disorders. Our results indicate that rumen viruses have implications for understanding the structure of the previously identified nuclear rumen microbiota and affect microbial metabolism through a variety of AMGs. Rumen AMGs appear to have implications for microbial metabolism that are broadly consistent with the current paradigm in marine systems. This study provides a basis for future hypotheses on the dynamics of virally mediated processes in the rumen.
authors: Anderson, C. L.;Sullivan, M. B.;Fernando, S. C.

title: Characterization of co-circulating swine influenza A viruses in North America and identification of a novel H1 genetic clade with antigenic importance
abstract: Several genetically and antigenically distinct hemagglutinin genes of the H1 and H3 influenza A virus (IAV) subtypes co-circulate in North American swine. This diversity has evolved through repeated transmission of IAVs from humans to pigs and subsequent antigenic drift in pigs. To understand the evolutionary dynamics of these different HA lineages in North American swine, we performed a phylogenetic analysis of 1576 H1 and 607 H3 HA gene segments, as well as 834 N1 and 1293 N2 NA gene segments, and 2126 M gene segments. These data showed annual co-circulation of H1N1, H1N2, and H3N2 viruses, with three HA clades representing the majority of HA sequences: of H1 viruses, 42% became H1Δ1 and 40.6% became H1Δ and H1Δ classified the H3 viruses 53% were classified as Cluster IV-A H3N2. We have discovered a genetically distinct subgroup consisting of 37 H1 viruses isolated between 2003 and 2013 which we have classified as H1γ-2. We estimated that this clade had been circulating in pigs since about 1995, but was only detected in pigs in 2003. This group of viruses is antigenically distinct and when measured by antigenic mapping was up to 7 antigenic units from other H1γ viruses. Therefore, vaccines against modern H1γ viruses are unlikely to provide cross-protection against γ-2 viruses. The long-term circulation of these γ-2 viruses suggests that smaller populations of viruses may be under-reported given the long branch lengths and detection gaps in the national dataset. The identification of these γ-2 viruses demonstrates the need for robust surveillance to capture the full diversity IAVs in swine in the US and the importance of antigenic drift in the diversification and emergence of new antigenic variants in swine, complicating vaccine design .
authors: Anderson, T. K.;Campbell, B. A.;Nelson, M. I.;Lewis, N. S.;Janas-Martindale, A.;Killian, M. L.;Vincent, A. L.

title: A phylogeny-based global nomenclature system and automated annotation tool for swine influenza A virus H1-hemagglutinin genes
abstract: The H1 subtype of influenza A viruses (IAVs) have been circulating in pigs since the 1918 human influenza pandemic. Over time, and aided by further introductions from non-pig hosts, porcine H1 viruses have diversified into three genetic lineages. Due to limited global data, these H1 lineages were named based on colloquial context, leading to the proliferation of inconsistent regional naming conventions. In this study, we propose rigorous phylogenetic criteria to establish a globally consistent nomenclature of porcine H1 virus hemagglutinin (HA) evolution. These criteria, applied to a dataset of 7,070 H1-HA sequences, resulted in 28 distinct clades as the basis for the nomenclature. We have developed and implemented a web-accessible annotation tool that can assign these biologically informative categories to new sequence data. The annotation tool assigned the combined dataset of 7,070 H1 sequences to the correct clade more than 99% of the time. Our analyzes showed that 87% of porcine H1viruses from 2010 to date had HAs belonging to 7 contemporary cocirculating clades. Our nomenclature and web-accessible classification tool provide researchers, diagnosticians, and public health officials with an accurate method to assign clade designations to HA sequences. The tool can be easily updated to follow evolving nomenclature as new clades emerge, ensuring continued relevance. A common global nomenclature facilitates comparisons within and between regions of IAVs infecting humans and swine, and can provide insight into the diversity of swine H1 influenza virus and its impact on the selection of vaccine strains, diagnostic reagents and test performance, and thereby the Communication simplify data. IMPORTANCE A fundamental goal in the life sciences is the definition of groups of organisms based on evolutionary history and the naming of these groups. For swine influenza A viruses (IAVs), understanding the genetic lineage of the hemagglutinin (HA) of a circulating strain aids in the selection of vaccine antigen and allows inferences to be made about vaccine efficacy. Previous reports of H1 virus HA in swine have relied on colloquial names, often with burdensome and stigmatizing geographic toponyms, making comparisons between studies difficult. To overcome this, we developed an adaptive nomenclature using measurable criteria for historical and contemporary evolutionary patterns of global H1 porcine IAVs. We have also developed a web-accessible tool that classifies viruses according to this nomenclature. This classification system will support agricultural production and pandemic preparedness by identifying key changes in porcine IAVs and providing terminology that enables discussion of porcine IAVs in a shared context between animal and human health initiatives.
authors: Anderson, T. K.;Macken, C. A.;Lewis, N. S.;Scheuermann, R. H.;Van Reeth, K.;Brown, I. H.;Swenson, S. L.;Simon, G.;Saito, T.;Berhane, Y.;Ciacci-Zanella, J.;Pereda, A.;Davis, C. T.;Donis, R. O.;Webby, R. J.;Vincent, A. L.

title: Genetic classification of "Norwalk-like viruses"
abstract: Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction has been used worldwide to diagnose Norwalk-like virus (NLV) infection, however no generally accepted genetic classification scheme has been established. Amino acid sequences from four regions of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) were used to analyze 101 NLV strains, including 2 bovine strains. Based on this analysis, a genetic classification scheme is proposed that distinguishes 99 human strains into 2 main genetic groups consisting of 5 and 10 genetic clusters, respectively. The 2 bovine strains form a newly defined third major genetic group consisting of 2 putative clusters represented by each strain. This classification scheme is well supported by the analysis of the entire ORF2 sequences from 38 strains chosen to represent the genetic diversity of the human strains used above. This scheme should provide a solid scientific basis for the unified classification of NLV strains detected worldwide.
authors: Ando, T.;Noel, J. S.;Fankhauser, R. L.

title: Nipah virus infection
abstract: Nipah virus, a paramyxovirus related to Hendra virus, first appeared in Malaysia in 1998. Clinical presentation ranges from asymptomatic infection to fatal encephalitis. Malaysia has had no cases since 1999, but outbreaks continue to occur in Bangladesh and India. In the outbreak between Malaysia and Singapore, transmission was mainly through contact with pigs, while in Bangladesh and India it has been linked to ingestion of contaminated date palm sap and human-to-human transmission. Bats are the main reservoir of this virus, which can cause disease in humans and animals. There are currently no effective therapeutics, and supportive care and prevention are the main pillars of treatment.
authors: Ang, B. S. P.;Lim, T. C. C.;Wang, L.

title: Molecular Epidemiology and Phylogeny of Nipah Virus Infection: A Mini Review
abstract: Nipah virus (NiV) is a member of the genus Henipavirus of the family Paramyxoviridae, characterized by high pathogenicity and is endemic to South Asia. It is classified as Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) medium. The mortality rate varies between 40% and 70% depending on the severity of the disease and the availability of adequate healthcare facilities. No antiviral drugs are currently available for NiV disease and treatment is supportive only. Phylogenetic and evolutionary analyzes can help to understand the epidemiology and temporal origin of this virus. This review gives an overview of evolutionary studies performed on Nipah viruses circulating in different countries. Thirty phylogenetic studies were published from 2000 to 2015, searching Pub-Med for the keywords “Nipah virus AND phylogeny”, and twenty-eight molecular epidemiological studies were conducted from 2006 to 2015, searching the keywords â “Nipah virus AND molecular epidemiology”. The overall data from the published study, verified as phylogenetic and evolutionary analysis, represent promising tools to detect NiV epidemics, study their origin and evolution, and finally act with effective preventive measures.
authors: Angeletti, S.;Lo Presti, A.;Cella, E.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: Emerging coxsackievirus A6 causing hand, foot and mouth disease, Vietnam
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a major public health problem in Asia and has global pandemic potential. Coxsackievirus A6 (CV-A6) was detected in 514/2,230 (23%) of HFMD patients admitted to three major hospitals in South Vietnam between 2011 and 2015. Of these patients, 93 (18%) had severe HFMD. Phylogenetic analysis of 98 genome sequences revealed that they belonged to Cluster A and circulated in Vietnam for two years before appearing. CV-A6 movements between locations within Vietnam were common, while viral movements across international borders seemed rare. Skyline plots identified fluctuations in the relative genetic diversity of CV-A6 that correspond to major CV-A6-associated HFMD outbreaks worldwide. These data demonstrate that CV-A6 is an emerging pathogen and emphasize the need for active surveillance and understanding of the mechanisms shaping pathogen evolution and emergence, which is essential for the development and implementation of intervention strategies.
authors: Anh, N. T.;Nhu, L. N. T.;Van, H. M. T.;Hong, N. T. T.;Thanh, T. T.;Hang, V. T. T.;Ny, N. T. H.;Nguyet, L. A.;Phuong, T. T. L.;Nhan, L. N. T.;Hung, N. T.;Khanh, T. H.;Tuan, H. M.;Viet, H. L.;Nam, N. T.;Viet, D. C.;Qui, P. T.;Wills, B.;Sabanathan, S.;Chau, N. V. V.;Thwaites, L.;Rogier van Doorn, H.;Thwaites, G.;Rabaa, M. A.;Van Tan, L.

title: Origin of the 1918 H1N1 pandemic influenza A virus studied by codon usage patterns and phylogenetic analysis
abstract: The 1918 pandemic was caused by an H1N1 influenza A virus, which is a negative-strand RNA virus; however, little is known about the nature of its direct ancestral tribes. Here we performed a broad genetic and phylogenetic analysis of a wide range of influenza virus genes, particularly the PB1 gene, to obtain information on the phylogenetic relationship of the 1918 H1N1 virus. We compared the RNA genome of the 1918 strain to many other influenza strains of different origins in a variety of ways, including relative synonymous codon usage (RSCU), effective number of codons (ENC), and phylogenetic relatedness. We found that the 1918 pandemic virus PB1 gene had similar ENC values to classical H1N1 swine and human viruses, but different ENC values from avian and H2N2 and H3N2 human viruses. Also, according to the RSCU of the PB1 gene, the 1918 virus is grouped with all human isolates and “classic” H1N1 swine viruses a H1N1 swine virus that itself could have descended from an H1N1 avian progenitor that long ago completely separated from the mass of other avian viruses The high stability of the RSCU pattern of the PB1 gene indicated that the integrity of the RNA structure is more important for the evolution of the influenza virus than previously thought.Copyright © 2011 RNA Society.
authors: Anhlan, D.;Grundmann, N.;Makalowski, W. H.;Ludwig, S.;Scholtissek, C.

title: Characterization of the highly pathogenic H5N8 avian influenza virus from Egyptian domestic waterfowl in 2017
abstract: In 2016, the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) H5N8 was detected in wild birds in Egypt for the first time. In the present study, we identified HPAI virus H5N8 clade 2.3.4.4 from resident waterfowl in Egypt, suggesting that it is transmitted from migratory birds to domestic fowl. Based on the partial hemagglutinin gene sequence, this virus has a close genetic relationship to the H5N8 subtype viruses circulating in Asia and Europe. Pathologically, H5N8 virus induced nervous symptoms accompanied by encephalomalacia, hemorrhage, nonsuppurative encephalitis and nonsuppurative vasculitis in hybrid ducks. The granular layer of the cerebellum showed multifocal areas of hydropic degeneration and the neurons of Purkinje cells were necrotized or lost. In addition, lungs, kidneys and spleen were congested and necrotizing pancreatitis was also observed. The co-circulation of HPAI H5N1 and H5N8 subtypes with the weakly pathogenic H9N2 avian influenza subtype complicates the control of avian influenza in Egypt with the possibility of the emergence of new reassortant viruses. Therefore, continuous monitoring with the implementation of strict control measures is required. Research highlights: HPAI H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 was detected in domestic ducks and geese in Egypt in 2017. Phylogenetically, the virus was closely related to HPAI H5N8 viruses identified in Asia and Europe. Nonsuppurative encephalitis has been observed commonly in ducks infected with HPAI H5N8 virus. Degeneration of the cerebellar nuclear layer was found in most brain tissues examined.
authors: Anis, A.;AboElkhair, M.;Ibrahim, M.

title: Two novel bocaparvovirus species identified in wild Himalayan marmots
abstract: Bocaparvovirus (BOV) is a genetically diverse group of DNA viruses and a possible cause of respiratory, enteric, and neurological diseases in humans and animals. Here, two highly divergent BOVs (tentatively named Himalayan marmot BOV, HMBOV1 and HMBOV2) were identified in the liver and faeces of wild Himalayan marmots in China by viral metagenomic analysis. Five out of 300 liver samples from Himalayan marmots were positive for HMBOV1 and five out of 99 fecal samples from these animals for HMBOV2. Their almost complete genome sequences are 4,672 and 4,887 nucleotides long, respectively, show a standard genomic organization and contain protein-coding motifs typical of BOVs. Based on their NS1, NP1 and VP1, HMBOV1 and HMBOV2 are most closely related to porcine BOV SX/1-2 (approximately 77.0%/50.0%, 50.0%/53.0% and 79.0, respectively %/54.0% amino acid identity). Phylogenetic analysis of these three proteins showed that HMBOV1 and HMBOV2 formed two distinctly independent branches in BOVs. According to these results, HMBOV1 and HMBOV2 are two different new species in the Bocaparvovirus genus. Their identification advances our knowledge of the genetic diversity and evolution of BOVs. Further studies are needed to investigate their potential pathogenicity and effects on Himalayan marmots and humans.
authors: Ao, Y.;Li, X.;Li, L.;Xie, X.;Jin, D.;Yu, J.;Lu, S.;Duan, Z.

title: Various new astroviruses identified in wild Himalayan marmots
abstract: With advances in virus surveillance and next-generation sequencing, vastly different novel astroviruses (AstVs) and different animal hosts have been discovered in recent years. However, the existence of AstVs in marmots has yet to be shown. Here we identified two strongly distinct AstV strains (tentatively named Qinghai Himalayanmarmot AstVs, HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2) by viral metagenomic analysis in liver tissues isolated from wild Himalayan Marmota in China. Overall, 12 of 99 (12.1%) M. himalayana fecal samples were positive for the presence of genetically distinct AstVs, while only HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 were identified in 300 liver samples. The complete genomic sequences of HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 were 6681 and 6610 nt in length, respectively, with the typical AstV genomic organization. Analysis of the complete ORF 2 sequence showed that these new AstVs are most closely related to the rabbit AstV, mamastrovirus 23 (sharing 31.0 and 48.0% amino acid identity, respectively). Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid sequences of ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2 revealed that HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 form two distinct clusters among mamastroviruses and possibly share a common ancestor with rabbit-specific mamastrovirus 23. These results suggest that HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 are two new virus species of the genus Mamastrovirus in the Astroviridae. The remarkable diversity of these novel AstVs will contribute to a better understanding of AstV evolution and ecology, although additional studies are needed to understand the clinical significance of these novel AstVs in marmots as well as in humans.
authors: Ao, Y. Y.;Yu, J. M.;Li, L. L.;Cao, J. Y.;Deng, H. Y.;Xin, Y. Y.;Liu, M. M.;Lin, L.;Lu, S.;Xu, J. G.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Wild-Type Leukemia Virus: Classification of Soluble Antigens (GSA)
authors: Aoki, T.;Herberman, R. B.;Johnson, P. A.;Liu, M.

title: Aerogenic infection by intestinal bacteria in poultry
authors: Applegate, T.

title: Phylodynamics of the avian influenza clade 2.2.1 H5N1 viruses in Egypt
abstract: Background: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) of the H5N1 subtype is widespread in poultry populations in Egypt and has caused several human infections. Linking the epidemiological and sequence data is important to understand the transmission, persistence and evolution of the virus. This work describes the phylogenetic dynamics of H5N1 based on the molecular characterization of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene from isolates collected from February 2006 to May 2014. Methods: Full-length HA sequences from 368 H5N1 viruses were generated and genetically analyzed to examine their genetic evolution. They were collected from different poultry species, production sectors and geographic locations in Egypt. The Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (BCMMC) method was applied to estimate evolution rates between different virus clusters; In addition, an analysis of the selection pressure in the HA gene was performed using the Single Likelihood Ancestor Counting (SLAC) method. Results: The phylogenetic analysis of the H5 gene from 2006-14 revealed the presence of a virus introduction of the classic clade (2.2.1), from which two main subgroups emerged, the variant subgroup, which was further subdivided into 2 subdivisions (2.2.1.1 and 2.2 .1.1a) and the endemic subgroup (2.2.1.2). The 2.2.1.2 clade showed a high rate of evolution over a 6-year period (6.9 × 10-3 sub/site/year) compared to the 2.2.1.1a variant cluster (7.2 × 10-3 over a period of 4 years). These two clusters are under positive selection since they have 5 different positively selected sites in the HA gene. The mutations at antigenic HA sites 120, 154, and 162, as well as the other two mutations (129γ, I151T) that occurred from 2009 to 2014 were found to be stable in the 2.2.1.2 clade. In addition, 13 groups of H5N1-HPAI viruses were identified based on their amino acid sequences at the cleavage site, and “EKRRKKR” became the predominant pattern as of 2013 in production systems in almost all regions of the country. The prevalence of the 2.2.1.2 clade with triple mutations (120, 129γ”, I151T) associated with increased binding affinity to human receptors is an alarming finding of public health importance.
authors: Arafa, A.;El-Masry, I.;Kholosy, S.;Hassan, M. K.;Dauphin, G.;Lubroth, J.;Makonnen, Y. J.

title: Whole genome characterization of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 from a commercial quail flock in Egypt
abstract: The suspected occurrence of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 in poultry in Egypt is of great concern as this subtype is widespread in various Middle Eastern countries, here we describe the full genetic characterization of an avian influenza virus A (Qa/Egypt/11 ; H9N2) des Subtype H9N2 previously isolated in May 2011 from a clinically normal quail flock in Giza, Egypt. Nucleotide sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin gene of the isolated Egyptian virus showed the highest similarity to a group of recent Israeli strains (97%) circulating in 2006-2010. Sequence homology and phylogenetic analysis indicated that the Qa/Egypt/11 isolate belonged to the A/Quail/Hong Kong/G1/1997-like lineage, identifying novel mutations in all viral proteins. Phylogenetic analysis of the eight genes suggested placement of the Egyptian virus within the same lineage of H9N2 viruses that have been circulating in the region since 2006, particularly with a group of newer Israeli strains. However, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes such as PB2, NP, and PA genes identified possible rearrangement events for these genes with individual Israeli strains. This study points to the progressive evolution of this subtype in the Middle East region and a possible mechanism of viral adaptation in landfowl such as quail. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Arafa, A. S.;Hagag, N.;Erfan, A.;Mady, W.;El-Husseiny, M.;Adel, A.;Nasef, S.

title: Characterization of rabies virus isolates from Sri Lanka using nucleotide sequence analysis of the nucleoprotein gene
abstract: 34 presumptive rabies brain samples from 2 humans, 24 dogs, 4 cats, 2 mongooses, 1 jackal and 1 water buffalo were collected in Sri Lanka in 1995-1996. Total RNA was extracted directly from brain suspensions and analyzed for the rabies virus nucleoprotein (N) gene using a one-step reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Twenty-eight samples were found positive for the virus N gene by RT-PCR and also for the virus antigens by fluorescent antibody (FA) testing. Rabies virus isolates obtained from different animal species in different regions of Sri Lanka were genetically homogeneous. Sequences of 203 nucleotide (nt) long RT-PCR products obtained from 16 out of 27 samples were found to be identical. Sequences of 1350 nt of N genes from 14 RT-PCR products were determined. The examined isolates from Sri Lanka formed a specific cluster, which also included a previous isolate from India, but not the known isolates from China, Thailand, Malaysia, Israel, Iran, Oman, Saudi Arabia, Russia, Nepal, Philippines, Japan and from several other countries. These results suggest that a type of rabies virus is circulating among humans, dogs, cats, mongooses, jackals and water buffalo living near Colombo City and other five remote regions of Sri Lanka.
authors: Arai, Y. T.;Takahashi, H.;Kameoka, Y.;Shiino, T.;Wimalaratne, O.;Lodmell, D. L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of classical swine fever virus isolates from Peru
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF) is considered endemic in Peru, with outbreaks only being reported to the World Organization for Animal Health in 2008 and 2009. However, little is known about the CSF virus genetic subgroup(s) circulating in Peru or their relationship to recent CSF viruses isolated from neighboring South American countries or other parts of the world. In this study, we characterize CSF viruses isolated from domestic pigs from different regions of Peru in mid-2007 to early 2008, molecularly identified from other South American countries. Although the Peruvian isolates are most closely related to viruses from Colombia and Brazil, they form a monophyletic clade, suggesting that they have a distinct evolutionary history. Â©2010 Canadian Food Inspection Agency.
authors: AraÃ­nga, M.;Hisanaga, T.;Hills, K.;Handel, K.;Rivera, H.;Pasick, J.

title: Migratory birds in southern Brazil are a source of several subtypes of avian influenza virus
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is insufficient knowledge of the relationship of the avian influenza virus (AIV) to migratory birds in South America. Accordingly, we examined samples collected over a 4-year period (2009-2012) from wild birds at a large wintering site in southern Brazil. METHODS: We obtained 1212 oropharyngeal/cloaca samples from wild birds in Lagoa do Peixe National Park and analyzed them for influenza A virus by RT-PCR amplification of the matrix gene. Virus isolates were subjected to genomic sequencing and antigenic characterization. RESULTS: Forty-eight samples from 1212 (3.96%) contained detectable influenza virus RNA. Partial virus sequences were obtained from 12 of these samples, showing the presence of viruses H2N2 (1), H6Nx (1), H6N1 (8), H9N2 (1) and H12N5 (1). Since H6 viruses predominated, we generated complete genomes from all 9 H6 viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that they most closely resembled viruses of South American origin. The H6N1 viruses caused no signs of disease in infected ferrets and, despite genetic differences, were antigenically similar to North American isolates. CONCLUSIONS: Lagoa do Peixe National Park is a source of several AIV subtypes, with influenza virus concentrations highest in birds at the end of their wintering season in this region. H6N1 viruses were the predominant subtype identified. These viruses were more similar to viruses of South American lineage than to those of North American lineage.
authors: Araujo, J.;Petry, M. V.;Fabrizio, T.;Walker, D.;Ometto, T.;Thomazelli, L. M.;Scherer, A. L.;Serafini, P. P.;Neto, I. S.;Krauss, S.;Webster, R. G.;Webby, R. J.;Durigon, E. L.

title: Isolation and Rapid Identification of a Kerala Isolate of Duck Enteritis Virus Using the Polymerase Chain Reaction
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is a herpesvirus that causes an acute, contagious, and fatal illness. In this article, we present a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay for DEV DNA. The method used primer sets targeting the viral DNA polymerase gene (UL30), type I membrane protein that binds to heparin sulfate (glycoprotein C) and glycoprotein E of DEV, and was able to generate DNA fragments of the expected size amplify from infected samples. The method provides a valuable tool for rapid laboratory diagnosis of DEV infection. Due to its high-throughput format, the method can be used for large epidemiological surveys and elucidation of pathogenesis, e.g. B. the latency of the virus, be useful.
authors: Aravind, S.;Kamble, N. M.;Gaikad, S. S.;Shukla, S. K.;Khulpae, S. A.;Dey, S.;Mohan, C. M.

title: Molecular features of influenza A (H1N1) pdm09 that was prevalent in Mexico during the 2012-2014 winter season
abstract: Since the emergence of the pandemic H1N1pdm09 virus in Mexico and California, cases have been increasing in Mexico every two years. As observed in previous seasons, the pandemic A/H1N1 09 virus was detected in severe cases during the 2011-2012 winter season and eventually became the most prevalent influenza virus during the 2013-2014 winter season. Molecular and phylogenetic analyzes of the whole viral genome are necessary to determine the antigenic and pathogenic properties of influenza viruses that cause serious consequences of the disease. In this article we analyzed the evolution, antigenic and genetic drift of Mexican isolates from 2009, at the onset of the pandemic, to 2014. We found a clear variation of the virus in Mexico from the 2011-2014 season due to different markers and in agreement with previous reports. In this study we identified 13 new substitutions with important biological effects including virulence, T cell epitope presented by MHC and host specificity shift and some other substitutions might have more than one biological function. Systematic monitoring of mutations throughout the genome of the influenza A virus pH1N1 (2009) circulating at the INER in Mexico City could provide valuable information to predict the emergence of new pathogenic influenza viruses
authors: Arellano-Llamas, R.;Alfaro-Ruiz, L.;Canon, C. A.;Rosshandler, II;Cruz-Lagunas, A.;Zuniga, J.;Vega, R. R.;Wong, C. W.;Maurer-Stroh, S.;Cordoba, S. R.;Liu, E. T.;Hidalgo-Miranda, A.;Vazquez-Perez, J. A.

title: Infectious Disease Eradication Strategies: African Swine Fever and Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS)
abstract: This publication provides a brief overview of two economically important diseases affecting the swine species. Although they are caused by taxonomically distant viruses that produce distinct symptoms and diseases, successful strategies have been employed to control and eradicate them. African swine fever (ASF) is listed on OIE List A and its importance in Europe stems from the increase in outbreaks in sub-Saharan Africa in recent years, and Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS), a disease that is not currently on the OIE list but is perhaps one of the biggest problems in international animal health today. In this article, the authors discuss diseases as well as current strategies to eradicate ASFV and remove PRRS virus from endemic stocks.
authors: Arias, M.;Romero, L.;Aguero, M.;Canals, A.;Zamora, M. J.;Sanchez-Vizcaino, J. M.

title: Co-circulation dynamics and persistence of newly introduced clades of the clades associated with the 2012 West Nile Virus outbreak in Texas, 2012–2015
abstract: The second largest outbreak of West Nile encephalitis and West Nile fever on record occurred in the United States (US) in the summer of 2012. ) into several states where they have not been found before. Whether the 2012 invading strains were able to circulate and overwinter in states with their own endemic WNV population is unknown, and the effect of viral genetics on adaptation and persistence in a new ecological niche is unclear. In this study, we sequenced 70 mosquito isolates from multiple counties across Texas between 2012 and 2015. We identified isolates representative of previously described 2012 WNV groups (groups 8–10) and discovered a new group which we named group 11) were related to the invading 2012 strains and of these was group 10 ( 45/68) predominant. We also observed differences between the 2012 WNV groups that correlate with their genotype. Group 10 WNV in Texas, carrying two putative positive selected variants, had limited introductions in Texas, widespread distribution, and strong evidence of continued persistence possibly indicative of overwintering. In contrast, groups 8 and 11 with no positively selected variants had multiple introductions in Texas, limited distribution, and limited persistence. Finally, we identified a potential transmission source for incoming Group 8 WNV to Texas in New York. Overall, our study suggests that mutations in the WNV genome can affect the range and dynamics of WNV circulation, as well as the ability of different strains to survive in new ecological niches.
authors: Aroh, C.;Liang, C.;Raj, P.;Wakeland, B.;Yan, N.;Wakeland, E.

title: Letter to the Editor: Drift in the nucleoprotein gene of swine influenza virus (H1N1), which causes respiratory disease in swine
abstract: The nucleoprotein (NP) gene of swine influenza H1N1 variant, A/Sw/Quebec/5393/91 (SwQc91), has been sequenced. When compared to other H1N1 strains, 12 amino acid (aa) replacements were observed in the 101-484 aa region of the NP protein, including two aas, 345 and 430, representing the unique lineage of swine viruses. The phylogenetic analysis showed a drift in the NP gene.
authors: Arora, D. J. S.

title: Porcine astrovirus type 3 in the central nervous system of swine with polioencephalomyelitis
abstract: Using next-generation sequencing, we identified and genetically characterized a porcine astrovirus type 3 strain found in central nervous system tissues from 1 piglet and 3 sows with neurological symptoms and nonsuppurative polioencephalomyelitis. Further studies are needed to understand the potential for cross-species transmission and the clinical implications.
authors: Arruda, B.;Arruda, P.;Hensch, M.;Chen, Q.;Zheng, Y.;Yang, C.;Gatto, I. R. H.;Ferreyra, F. M.;Gauger, P.;Schwartz, K.;Bradner, L.;Harmon, K.;Hause, B.;Li, G.

title: Identification of a porcine pestivirus of different lineages in lactating piglets with congenital tremor and reproduction of the disease after experimental inoculation
abstract: Congenital tremor is a sporadic disease in newborn pigs characterized by action-related repetitive myoclonus. Much of the outbreaks of congenital tremors have been attributed to an unidentified virus. The objectives of this project were 1) to detect potential pathogens in samples from piglets with congenital tremors and 2) to develop an infection model to reproduce the disease. A pestivirus of different strains was detected in piglets with congenital tremors using next-generation sequencing. The virus was originally most closely related to a bat pestivirus but is now more closely related to a recently published novel porcine pestivirus tentatively named atypical porcine pestivirus. Real-time quantitative PCR detected the virus in samples from newborn piglets with congenital tremors from two separate farms, but not in samples from unaffected piglets from the same farm. To achieve the second objective, pregnant sows were inoculated with either serum containing the pestivirus or PBS (control) by the intravenous and intranasal routes simultaneously with direct inoculation of fetal amniotic sacs by ultrasound-guided surgical technique. The vaccinations were carried out either on the 45th or on the 62nd day of pregnancy. All sows vaccinated with the novel pestivirus presented piglets with congenital tremors, while control piglets vaccinated with PBS were unaffected. The severity of shivering was assessed for each piglet using videos recorded at 0, 1 and 2 days after farrowing. Tremor severity remained relatively constant in most piglets 0 to 2 days after farrowing. The prevalence of congenital tremors in pestivirus-inoculated litters ranged from 57% (4 out of 7 affected piglets) to 100% (10 out of 10 affected piglets). The virus was consistently detected by PCR in tissues from piglets with congenital tremors but not in control piglets. PCR-positive samples in more than 90% of the piglets included brainstem (37 out of 41), mesenteric lymph nodes (37 out of 41), tracheobronchial lymph nodes (37 out of 41), and whole blood (19 out of 20). Although congenital tremor was first described in 1922, this is the first reported reproduction of congenital tremor following experimental inoculation with a swine pestivirus of different strains. Studies examining disease mechanism, epidemiology, and diagnostic assay development are needed to better understand the pathophysiology of congenital tremors due to this pestivirus.
authors: Arruda, B. L.;Arruda, P. H.;Magstadt, D. R.;Schwartz, K. J.;Dohlman, T.;Schleining, J. A.;Patterson, A. R.;Visek, C. A.;Victoria, J. G.

title: Genetic ancestor of external antigens of pandemic influenza A/H1N1 virus
abstract: The aim of the present study was to uncover the genetic relationships of the external antigens hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) of the 2009 pandemic novel influenza virus A/H1N1 (NIV) with other influenza viruses through phylogenetic, comparative and statistical analyses. Pedigrees of these two antigens show that the sequences of the NIV viruses are relatively homogeneous and that they originate from several viruses circulating in pigs. The phylogenetic tree of HA shows that NIV had the closest relationship to North American swine lines, while NA had to European swine lines. In both segments, NIVs had the closest genetic relationship to swine influenza virus lines. It strongly suggests that pigs are the most likely animal reservoir. Comparative analysis shows that NIVs among clade A showed very low genetic divergence as well as high similarity and also underwent strong purification selection, while the neighboring clade B shows moderate values compared to those of clades CF. This indicates that the classical swine influenza viruses present in clade B may be an ancestor of NIV external antigens. The process of reassortment took place in classical swine influenza viruses. The mutation sites fixed exclusively in pig and human NIV together with the vaccine strain provide an important clue for disease diagnosis and vaccine research.
authors: Arunachalam, R.;Paulkumar, K.;Annadurai, G.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the pandemic influenza A/H1N1 virus
abstract: The principle of the present study was to determine the evolution of the 2009 pandemic novel influenza virus A/H1N1 (NIV) through phylogenetic, comparative and statistical analyses. The phylogenetic trees of eight genomic segments illustrate that the sequences of the NIVs (outbreak group A) are so far relatively homogeneous and were derived from Eurasian and North American porcine, avian and human viruses (group B) through the event of multiple genetic rearrangement. . This implied that some of the influenza viruses in group B had a higher evolutionary potential and acquired the ability for human-to-human transmission after animal-to-human cross-species transmission. The second analysis shows that NIV had attempted a small evolutionary change among humans and had a long evolutionary history before being introduced to humans. Statistical analysis shows that viruses of both the outbreak and the next group have homologous genes in their genomes that may reflect the phylogenetic relatedness of the strains, and also the presence of unique mutations between groups AB may be associated with increased virulence of NIVs. Both phylogenetic and cluster analyzes confirm that gene exchange occurs between viruses originating from different species and that NIV could be generated with unpredictable pandemic potential. Therefore, we conclude that an extensive study should be performed to identify which rearrangement groups are closely related to NIVs and to determine the sites in the genes of NIV under the greatest or least selection pressure, which ultimately matters for effective design will be vaccine and drugs against the "swine flu".
authors: Arunachalam, R.;Paulkumar, K.;Annadurai, G.

title: Subgrouping of group A rotavirus recovered from piglets in Nigeria
abstract: Subgroup analysis using a subgroup specific monoclonal ELISA showed a predominance of subgroup 2 specific antigens of group A swine rotavirus over subgroup 1. Of 113 polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis positive test specimens obtained from 4 states of Nigeria, 31 (27.4%) and 45 (39.8%) had specificities for subgroup 1 and 2, respectively. However, 37 (32.7%) test specimens could not be assigned to any of the known group A rotavirus subgroups. These "unclassifiable" samples likely had neither subgroup 1 nor 2 specificities in the ELISA or could belong to a third subgroup that was unknown or not examined in this study. In all age groups examined, specific antigens of subgroups 1 and 2 were predominant. This was also observed after the annual analysis of subgroup specificity; However, in 1990 and 1991 a higher prevalence of subgroup 2 specificity was observed. Subgroup 1 rotavirus was found in all 4 states studied (Plateau, Benue, Oyo, and Cross River), while subgroup 2 rotavirus was only found in Plateau state. All rotaviruses recovered in this study, regardless of subgroup, exhibited long genomic electrophoretic migration patterns. Thus, the genomic diversity of group A rotaviruses does not necessarily reflect antigenic diversity since there is no compelling correlation between genomic electropherotype pattern and subgroup specificity.
authors: Atii, D. J. I.;Ojeh, C. K.

title: Metagenomic virome analysis of Culex mosquitoes from Kenya and China
authors: Atoni, E.;Wang, Y.;Karungu, S.;Waruhiu, C.;Zohaib, A.

title: Integrated use of three machine learning techniques to classify influenza viruses
authors: Attaluri, P. K.;Chen, Z.;Lu, G.

title: Effects of orally administered Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus on welfare and Salmonella colonization of young chicks
abstract: Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus is a bacterium that preys on and kills gram-negative bacteria, including the zoonotic pathogens Escherichia coli and Salmonella. Bdellovibrio has potential as a biocontrol agent, but no reports have been published of it being tested on live animals, and there is no data on whether Bdellovibrio could spread between animals. In this study, we attempted to fill this knowledge gap by using B. bacteriovorus HD100 doses in poultry with normal gut microbiota or pre-dosed with a colonizing Salmonella strain. In both cases, bdellovibrio was administered orally along with antacids. After administering Bdellovibrio to non-Salmonella infected birds, we measured the health and welfare of the birds and any changes in their gut pathology and cultivable microbiota and found that although one dose of Bdellovibrio at 2 days of age altered the overall diversity of the birds natural gut microbiota in 28-day-old birds, there were no adverse effects on their growth and well-being. Drinking water and faeces from the pens in which the birds were housed as groups showed no contamination by bdellovibrio after administration. Orally administered predatory bdellovibrio to birds predosed with a gut-colonizing Salmonella enterica serovar enteritidis phage type 4 strain (an important zoonotic pathogen) reduced, in comparison, Salmonella counts in avian gut contents and abnormal morphology of the cecum, indicating reduced inflammation of the cecum points to the cecum of the untreated controls or a non-predatory Î”pilA strain, suggesting that these effects are due to predation. This work is a first step towards the therapeutic application of Bdellovibrio in other animal and possibly human infections. © 2011, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Atterbury, R. J.;Hobley, L.;Till, R.;Lambert, C.;Capeness, M. J.;Lerner, T. R.;Fenton, A. K.;Barrow, P.;Sockett, R. E.

title: Genetic characterization of foot-and-mouth disease viruses, Ethiopia, 1981-2007
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is endemic to sub-Saharan Africa. To better understand the complex epidemiology involving multiple virus serotypes and host species, we characterized the viruses recovered from FMD outbreaks in Ethiopia between 1981 and 2007. We have detected 5 of the 7 FMDV serotypes (O, A, C, South African Territories [SAT] 1 and SAT 2). Serotype O dominated, followed by serotype A; Type C was not recognized after 1983. Phylogenetic analysis of viral protein 1 sequences revealed the emergence of a new topotype within serotype O, East Africa 4. In 2007, serotype SAT 1 was discovered in Ethiopia, forming a new distinct topotype (IX) and serotype SAT 2 emerged after an apparent gap from 16 years up again. The diversity of viruses underscores the role of this region as a reservoir for FMD virus, and their continued presence in Ethiopia will greatly influence the spread and subsequent control strategy of the disease on that continent.
authors: Ayelet, G.;Mahapatra, M.;Gelaye, E.;Egziabher, B. G.;Rufeal, T.;Sahle, M.;Ferris, N. P.;Wadsworth, J.;Hutchings, G. H.;Knowles, N. J.

title: Differentiation of proteins and viruses using pyrolysis gas chromatography, differential mobility spectrometry (PY/GC/DMS) and pattern recognition
abstract: It is extremely important to develop novel analytical sensors for the detection of pathogens. Applications of such sensors range from ensuring environmental monitoring to providing human health diagnostic measures to early warning systems for bioterrorism. Certain viruses and bacterial pathogens are of particular concern because they can spread rapidly through the human population during a pandemic, and emerging variants of these pathogens are difficult to detect. This paper provides a reliable detection strategy to classify viruses from harmless proteins. Our novel instrumentation is based on pyrolysis gas chromatography differential mobility spectrometry (PY/GC/DMS) and couples a genetic algorithm-based machine learning method for pattern recognition with a microfabricated solid-state biosensor. Together, this hardware and software combination enabled extremely high classification accuracy (94%) between the T4 bacteriophage from bovine serum albumin (BSA), an unrelated protein. This study suggests that this wearable sensor together with the sophisticated data mining method can be used as a fast, reliable and accurate virus detection tool.
authors: Ayer, S.;Zhao, W. X.;Davis, C. E.

title: Assessment of oxidative stress via total antioxidant status, sialic acid, malondialdehyde and RT-PCR findings in bluetongue affected sheep
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Bluetongue (BT) is a non-contagious infectious disease of ruminants. The pathogen bluetongue virus (BTV) is classified in the Reoviridae family Orbivirus. OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to determine serum malondialdehyde (MDA), total antioxidant load (TAS), total sialic acid (TSA), ceruloplasmin, triglyceride, alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), gamma Glutamyltransferase (GGT), cholesterol, creatinine, albumin and total protein levels in sheep with and without bluetongue disease (BT). MATERIALS AND METHODS: The study included 13 Sakiz crossbreed sheep aged 1-4 years and usually in late pregnancy as the BT group and a control group consisting of 10 healthy sheep. All sheep were clinically examined prior to drawing blood samples. Serum ALT, AST, cholesterol, triglycerides, albumin, GGT, total protein, creatinine, and TAS levels were measured using commercially available kits according to the manufacturer's recommendations using a Biochemistry Auto Analyzer (Sinnowa D280, China). Serum lipid peroxidation was estimated by a previously described method in which MDA reacts with thiobarbituric acid (TBA) to form a colored complex with a maximum absorbance of 535 nm. The TSA value was measured at 549 nm according to the method described by Warren (1959): sialic acid was oxidized to formylpyruvic acid, which reacts with TBA to give a pink product. The ceruloplasmin concentration was measured according to Sunderman and Nomoto (1970): ceruloplasmin and p-phenylenediamine formed a colored oxidation product which was proportional to the serum ceruloplasmin concentration. Real-time RT-PCR and conventional RT-PCR were performed as described by Shaw et al (2007). RESULTS: The biochemical analysis of the serum showed that in the BT group TSA, MDA, triglycerides and ALT and AST were higher and that ceruloplasmin and TAS were lower than in the control group. Serum albumin, cholesterol, creatinine, total protein and GGT did not differ significantly between the two groups. CONCLUSIONS: Serum triglyceride, ceruloplasmin, TSA, MDA, and TAS concentrations may prove beneficial in the diagnosis, prognosis, and biochemical analysis of BT.
authors: Aytekin, I.;Aksit, H.;Sait, A.;Kaya, F.;Aksit, D.;Gokmen, M.;Baca, A. U.

title: Shift in enterovirus species in children in Cameroon - identification of a new enterovirus, EV-A119
abstract: BACKGROUND: Infections caused by human enteroviruses (EVs) are often asymptomatic or mild, although they can cause more serious conditions such as meningitis and acute flaccid paralysis. Electric vehicles pose a threat to children worldwide and outbreaks of aseptic meningitis and hand, foot and mouth disease are frequently reported. AIM: To identify EV strains circulating two years apart among healthy children in a small community in Limbe, Cameroon. STUDY DESIGN: Species and EV types were obtained by partial 5'UTR-VP4 and VP1 sequencing of RNA from stool samples collected in October 2009 and September 2011 from 150 children in Cameroon. RESULTS: A total of 74 children (49%) were infected with 28 different types of electric vehicles. In 2009 there were 29 (54%) infected children and in 2011 45 (47%). There was a significant difference between the types of EV detected, with 15 (47%) children infected with EV-A in 2009 and 22 (71%) with EV-B in 2011 (p=0.0001). In 2009, a child was infected with a divergent EV most similar to EV-A90. Based on the full VP1 sequence, it was shown to be a new EV, designated EV-A119. CONCLUSION: The current study shows a high heterogeneity of circulating EV types in children in Limbe, Cameroon, and a previously undescribed shift in the predominant EV types.
authors: Ayukekbong, J.;Kabayiza, J. C.;Lindh, M.;Nkuo-Akenji, T.;Tah, F.;Bergstrom, T.;Norder, H.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the serotype Asia1 foot-and-mouth disease virus from Sulaimani/Iraq using the VP1 protein: heterogeneity with vaccine strain As1/Shamir/89
abstract: Foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) serotypes O, A and Asia1 are responsible for a significant number of disease outbreaks in Iraq. The current study can be seen as the first molecular characterization of the Asia1 serotype in Iraq. The present study reports detection of the FMDV Asia1 serotype in outbreaks in 2012 and 2014 in local farms in the Sulaimani districts. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete VP1 gene showed that FMDV Asia1 field isolates were among the genetic novel variant Sindh-08 (Group VII), including PAK/iso/11 and TUR/13 strains. The VP1 protein sequence of the circulating FMDV Asia1 genotype showed heterogeneity of nine amino acid substitutions within the GH loop with vaccine strain As1/Shamir/89 (JF739177) currently used in the immunization program in Iraq. Our result showed that differences in the VP1 protein at the GH loop of the locally circulating Asia1 strain of the FMDV serotype could be a reason for the current vaccination failure.
authors: Baba Sheikh, M. O.;Rashid, P. M. A.;Marouf, A. S.;Raheem, Z. H.;Janga, S. C.

title: Origin of the 2009 Mexican influenza virus: a comparative phylogenetic analysis of the major external antigens and the matrix protein
abstract: Triple reassortant swine influenza A (H1) viruses containing genes from avian, human, and swine influenza viruses have emerged and become an outbreak among humans worldwide. Over 1,000 cases were identified within the first month, mostly in Mexico and the United States. Here the phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutin (HA), neuraminidase (NA) and matrix protein (MP) was performed. Analysis showed that the H1 of this reassortant was from American pigs, while the NA and MP were more likely to be from European pigs. All 2009 isolates appear homogeneous and cluster together, although they are distinct from classical human A (H1N1) viruses.
authors: Babakir-Mina, M.;Dimonte, S.;Perno, C. F.;Ciotti, M.

title: Analysis of the leporid herpesvirus 4 genome
abstract: The genome of a herpesvirus highly pathogenic to rabbits, Leporid herpesvirus 4 (LHV-4), was analyzed using high-throughput DNA sequencing technology and primer walking. The assembled DNA sequences were further verified by restriction endonuclease digestion and Southern blot analysis. The total length of the LHV-4 genome has been determined to be approximately 124 kb. Genes encoded in the LHV-4 genome are most closely related to herpesviruses of the genus Simplexvirus, including human herpesviruses (HHV-1 and HHV-2), simian herpesviruses, including cercopithicin (CeHV-2 and CeHV-16) , macacine (McHV-1), bovine herpesvirus 2 (BHV-2), and a lineage of wallaby (macropodid) herpesviruses (MaHV-1 and -2). Similar to other simplex virus genomes, LHV-4 has a high total G+C content of 65-70% in the unique regions and 75-77% in the inverted repeat regions. Orthologues of ICP34.5 and US5 have not been identified in the LHV-4 genome. This study shows that LHV-4 has the smallest simplexvirus genome characterized to date. © 2012 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Babra, B.;Watson, G.;Xu, W.;Jeffrey, B. M.;Xu, J. R.;Rockey, D. D.;Rohrmann, G. F.;Jin, L.

title: Genome sequence of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype O isolated from Morocco in 2015
abstract: The genome of a virus isolated from a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreak in Morocco in 2015 is described here. This virus is classified as lineage Ind-2001d within serotype O, topotype ME-SA (Middle East-South Asia). This lineage is endemic to the Indian subcontinent but has caused outbreaks in the Middle East and North Africa since 2013.
authors: Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Wadsworth, J.;Gray, A.;Abouchoaib, N.;King, D. P.;Knowles, N. J.

title: Identification of a novel hepacivirus in domestic cattle from Germany
abstract: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) remains one of the greatest threats to human health. In recent years, HCV-related sequences have been found in bats, rodents, horses and dogs, suggesting a widespread distribution of hepaciviruses among animals. Using unbiased high-throughput sequencing, a novel virus of the genus Hepacivirus was discovered in a bovine serum sample. De novo assembly resulted in a nearly complete genome encoding a polyprotein of 2,779 amino acids. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed that the virus represents a new species within the Hepacivirus genus. Viral RNA screening showed that 1.6% (n = 5) of 320 individual animals and 3.2% (n = 5) of 158 cattle herds examined in Germany were positive for bovine hepacivirus. Repeated reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) analyzes of animals from a dairy herd demonstrated that a significant percentage of the cows were infected, some of them being viremic for over 6 months. Clinical and autopsy showed no signs of disease, including liver damage. Interestingly, quantitative RT-PCR from various organs and tissues together with the presence of a miR-122 binding site in the viral genome strongly suggest liver tropism for bovine hepacivirus, making this novel virus a promising animal model for human HCV infection.
authors: Baechlein, C.;Fischer, N.;Grundhoff, A.;Alawi, M.;Indenbirken, D.;Postel, A.;Baron, A. L.;Offinger, J.;Becker, K.;Beineke, A.;Rehage, J.;Becher, P.

title: Pegivirus infection in domestic pigs, Germany
authors: Baechlein, C.;Grundhoff, A.;Fischer, N.;Alawi, M.;Hoeltig, D.;Waldmann, K. H.;Becher, P.

title: Monitoring and characterization of low pathogenic H5 avian influenza viruses isolated from wild migratory birds in Korea
abstract: Migratory waterfowl are the natural reservoir of influenza A viruses. However, transmission between species had occasionally resulted in outbreaks in various hosts, including humans. Phylogenetic analyzes were performed to characterize the genetic origins of H5 avian influenza viruses isolated from migratory birds in South Korea. A total of 53 H5 viruses were isolated between October 2005 and November 2008. Full genetic characterization showed that most of these viruses belong to the Eurasian bird lineage. However, some segments of isolates AB/Korea/W235/07 and AB/Korea/W236/07 were clustered with viruses of North American lineage rather than those of Eurasian lineage, suggesting the occurrence of rearrangement between these two avian virus lineages. The phylogenetic analysis further showed that the H5N2 and H5N3 virus isolates were of the H5 phenotype with low pathogenicity. The H5 viruses appear to be antigenically similar to each other, but could be distinguished from a newer HPAI H5N1 virus (EM/Korea/W149/06) by hemagglutinin inhibition (HI) tests. Experimental inoculation of representative viruses showed that certain isolates, notably AB/Korea/W163/07 (H5N2), could be detected in chicken trachea and lungs, but none could be transmitted by direct contact. Furthermore, all viruses could be detected in the mouse lung without prior adaptation, indicating their pathogenic potential in a mammalian host. Taken together, our results underscore the important role that migratory birds play in the replication, transport, and redistribution of avian influenza viruses and emphasize the need for continuous monitoring of influenza virus activity in these bird populations. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Baek, Y. H.;Pascua, P. N. Q.;Song, M. S.;Park, K. J.;Kwon, H. I.;Lee, J. H.;Kim, S. Y.;Moon, H. J.;Kim, C. J.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Novel Rath peptide for intracellular delivery of proteins and nucleic acids
abstract: In the present study, a novel cell-penetrating peptide (CPP) named Rath was identified from avian infectious bursal disease virus. It has the potential to enter and translocate charge molecules into cells regardless of temperature. In addition, it can deliver oligonucleotides intracellularly to primary cells of chicken embryonic fibroblasts in 30 minutes and antibodies within one hour. An ideal delivery vehicle, it has the ability to protect the cargo molecules in the presence of serum and nucleases and exhibits minimal or no cytotoxicity at even higher peptide concentrations tested. The biophysical characterizations showed that Rath has a dominant β-structure with a small β-helix and has remarkable binding ability with protein and DNA. Thus, the characterization of the unique Rath peptide to deliver protein or nucleic acid into cells with non-covalent interaction could be used as an efficient delivery method for various cell-based assays. © 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Bais, M. V.;Kumar, S.;Tiwari, A. K.;Kataria, R. S.;Nagaleekar, V. K.;Shrivastava, S.;Chindera, K.

title: Smallpox virus in bats... so what?
abstract: Smallpox viruses are important pathogens in humans and numerous domestic and wild animal species. Cross-species (including zoonotic) poxvirus infections can have drastic consequences for the recipient host. Bats are a diverse order of mammals known to transmit deadly viral zoonoses such as rabies, hendra, nipah and SARS. Consistent targeted research shows that bats are infected with a rich variety of novel viruses. Smallpoxviruses were recently identified in bats, and the environments in which they were found were dramatically different. Here we review the natural history of smallpoxviruses in bats and highlight the virus' relationship to one another and their context in the Poxviridae family. In addition to considering the zoonotic potential of these viruses, we consider the broader implications of these findings. In particular, the potential to explore and use this newly discovered relationship to study coevolution and cross-species transmission along with fundamental aspects of smallpoxvirus host tropism and bat virology and immunology. © 2014 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Baker, K. S.;Murcia, P. R.

title: Novel, potentially zoonotic paramyxoviruses from the African straw fruit bat Eidolon helvum
abstract: Bats carry a variety of paramyxoviruses that affect the health of humans and domestic animals when spillover occurs. Recent studies have shown high diversity of paramyxoviruses in an urban population of straw-colored fruit bats in Ghana. Here we investigate this further by virus isolation and describe two new rubulaviruses: Achimota virus 1 (AchPV1) and Achimota virus 2 (AchPV2). The viruses form a phylogenetic cluster with each other and with other bat-derived rubulaviruses such as Tuhoko viruses, Menangle virus and Tioman virus. We developed AchPV1- and AchPV2-specific serological assays and found evidence of infection with both viruses in Eidolon helvum in sub-Saharan Africa and on islands in the Gulf of Guinea. Longitudinal samples of E. helvum indicate virus persistence within fruit bat populations and suggest spread of AchPVs through horizontal transmission. We also discovered possible serological evidence for human infection with AchPV2 in Ghana and Tanzania. It is likely that clinically significant zoonotic spillover of Chiroptera paramyxoviruses could be missed in much of Africa where health surveillance and diagnostics are poor and comorbidities such as HIV or Plasmodium sp. are common. © 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Baker, K. S.;Todd, S.;Marsh, G. A.;Crameri, G.;Barr, J.;Kamins, A. O.;Peel, A. J.;Yu, M.;Hayman, D. T. S.;Nadjm, B.;Mtove, G.;Amos, B.;Reyburn, H.;Nyarko, E.;Suu-Ire, R.;Murcia, P. R.;Cunningham, A. A.;Wood, J. L. N.;Wang, L. F.

title: The peste des petits ruminants virus identified in tissues from an Asiatic lion (Panthera leo persico) belongs to Asiatic lineage IV
abstract: In this study, Petits ruminant virus plague (PPRV) was detected in frozen pooled tissue samples from a dead Asiatic lion (Panthera leo persica). Specimens were negative for canine distemper virus and positive for PPRV nucleic acids when tested by one-step RT-PCR using the appropriate virus-specific primers. Subsequent amplification, cloning and sequencing of the partial nucleocapsid, matrix and fusion genes confirmed the presence of PPRV nucleic acid. Comparative sequence and phylogenetic analyzes of the structural genes of the isolated virus confirmed that the virus belonged to Asian lineage IV and was closely related to PPRV circulating in India. Â© 2012 The Korean Society of Veterinary Medicine.
authors: Balamurugan, V.;Sen, A.;Venkatesan, G.;Bhanot, V.;Yadav, V.;Bhanuprakash, V.;Singh, R. K.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analyzes of the structural genes of virulent isolates and vaccine strains of Petits ruminant plague virus from India
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an acute, highly contagious, notifiable and economically important transboundary viral disease of sheep and goats. In this study, sequence and phylogenetic analyzes of structural protein genes, namely nucleocapsid (N), matrix (M), fusion (F), and hemagglutinin (H) coding sequences of virulent and vaccine strains of PPR virus (PPRV) were performed. , were performed to determine the genetic variations between field isolates and vaccine strains. The open reading frame (ORF) of these isolates/strains genes was amplified by RT-PCR, cloned and sequenced. The ORF of the N, M, F and H genes were 1578, 1008, 1641 and 1830 nucleotides (nt) in length and encode polypeptides of 525, 335, 546 and 609 amino acids (aa), respectively, as previously reported. Comparative sequence analyzes of these four genes from isolates/strains were performed using published sequences. It showed 97.7-100% and 97.7-99.8% identity with Asian lineage IV and 89.6-98.7% and 89.8-98.9% with other PPRV lineages on nt - or aa levels. The phylogenetic analyzes of these isolates based on the aa sequences showed that all viruses belonged to lineage IV along with other Asian isolates. This is consistent with previous observations that only PPRV lineage IV has been circulating in India since the disease was first reported. Furthermore, the sequence analysis of the thermostable/thermoadapted vaccine strains showed no significant changes in the functional or structural surface protein-coding gene sequences. It is important to monitor the circulation of the PPRV in susceptible animals through H-gene-based sequence comparisons in addition to the F-gene and N-gene-based approaches to identify the distribution and spread of the virus in the regular outbreaks that occur in endemic countries like India. ©2010 Blackwell Verlag GmbH.
authors: Balamurugan, V.;Sen, A.;Venkatesan, G.;Yadav, V.;Bhanot, V.;Riyesh, T.;Bhanuprakash, V.;Singh, R. K.

title: Infectious bronchitis virus in different physiological systems of birds - A field study in Brazilian poultry flocks
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis is a highly contagious viral disease with economic implications for the poultry farming industry. The disease presents multisystem clinical symptoms (respiratory, renal, enteric and reproductive) and is caused by a coronavirus (infectious bronchitis virus, IBV). The infectious bronchitis virus is divided into different serotypes and genotypes (vaccine strains and field variants). This study aimed to assess the occurrence of IBV in commercial poultry flocks from 3 major producing regions in Brazil and to determine the tropism of the major circulating genotypes for 3 different avian physiological systems (respiratory, digestive, urinary/reproductive). Clinical specimens indicative of IBV infection were collected from 432 different commercial poultry flocks (198 from broilers and 234 from breeders). The total number of biological samples consisted of organ pools from the 3 physiological systems mentioned above obtained from farms from 3 major producing regions: Midwest, Northeast and South. Infectious bronchitis virus was detected by reverse transcription, real-time PCR of the 5 inch untranslated region. Results showed 179 IBV positive flocks (41.4% of flocks), 107 (24.8%) from broilers and 72 (16.8%) from breeders. There were similar frequencies of IBV positive flocks in farms from different regions of the country, most commonly in broilers (mean 54%) compared to breeders (mean 30.8%). Reverse transcription was more frequently detected in the digestive system of breeders (40%) and in the digestive (43.5%) and respiratory systems (37.7%) of broilers. Infectious bronchitis virus genotyping was performed by reverse transcription nested PCR and sequencing of the S1 gene from a panel of 79 IBV positive flocks (45 broilers and 34 breeders).
