The majority of herds were infected with the Brazilian variant genotype than the Massachusetts vaccine genotype. These results demonstrate the dominance of the Brazilian variant (mainly in the intestinal tract) in commercial poultry flocks from 3 major producing regions in Brazil. © 2014 Poultry Science Association Inc.
authors: Balestrin, E.;Fraga, A. P.;Ikuta, N.;Canal, C. W.;Fonseca, A. S. K.;Lunge, V. R.

title: Complete genome sequence analysis of a Hungarian porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus isolated from a pig with severe respiratory disease
abstract: Here we report the isolation of a type 1 porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) from a clinical onset of severe respiratory problems and high fever. The complete genome sequence of the isolate (9625/2012) was determined using next-generation sequencing. The virus belongs to a new branch within subtype 1, clade D, and shows the closest resemblance to PRRSV Olot/1991 and the Amervac vaccine strain. Mutation analysis of 9625/2012 revealed no evidence of recombination but revealed a high proportion of amino acid substitutions in the putative neutralizing epitopes, suggesting an important role of selective immune pressure in the evolution of PRRSV 9625/2012.
authors: BÃ¡lint, Ã;Balka, G.;HorvÃ¡th, P.;KecskemÃ©ti, S.;DÃ¡n, Ã;Farsang, A.;Szeredi, L.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Bartha, D.;Olasz, F.;BelÃ¡k, S.;ZÃ¡dori, Z.

title: Complete genome sequence analysis of a wild type 2 Hungarian PRRSV variant unrelated to MLV isolated in Europe
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is a widespread pathogen of swine causing significant economic losses to the swine industry. The increasing diversity of PRRSV strains is making the disease increasingly difficult to diagnose, control and eradicate. In the present study, the authors report the full genome sequencing of a type 2 PRRSV strain isolated from piglet carcasses in Hungary. Next generation sequencing was used to determine the full genomic sequence of the isolate (PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012). Recombination analyzes performed with the available full-length genomic sequences showed no evidence of such an event with other known PRRSV. When compared to the highly virulent prototype strains VR2332 and JXA-1, clear deletions and one insertion were found in the nsp2 region of PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012. The majority of the amino acid changes in GP4 and GP5 of the virus were in the known antigenic regions, suggesting an important role of immunological pressure in the development of PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that it belongs to lineage 1 or 2 of type 2 PRRSV. Given the absence of related PRRSV in Europe, apart from a partial sequence from Slovakia, the ancestor of PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012 was most likely transported from North America. It is the first documented type 2 PRRSV isolated in Europe that is unrelated to Ingelvac MLV.
authors: Balka, G.;Wang, X.;Olasz, F.;Balint, A.;Kiss, I.;Banyai, K.;Rusvai, M.;Stadejek, T.;Marthaler, D.;Murtaugh, M. P.;Zadori, Z.

title: Two amino acid changes at the N-terminus of the transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus spike protein result in loss of enteric tropism
abstract: To study the molecular basis of TGEV tropism, a collection of recombinants was created between the PUR46-MAD strain of transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus (TGEV), which infects the intestinal and respiratory tract, and the PTV strain, which only infects the respiratory tract infected, generated. The frequency of recombinant isolation was approximately 10 -9 recombinants per nucleotide and was 3.7-fold higher at the 5' end of the S gene than in other regions of the genome. Thirty recombinants were plaque purified and phenotypically and genetically characterized. All recombinant viruses had a single crossover and had inherited the 5' and 3' halves of their genome from the enteric and respiratory parents, respectively. Recombinant viruses were divided into three groups named 1 to 3 depending on the site of crossover. Group 1 recombinants had the crossover in the S gene, while in groups 2 and 3 the crossovers were located in ORF1b and ORF1a, respectively. The tropism of the recombinants was examined. Group 1 recombinants had enteric and respiratory tropism, while group 2 recombinants infected the respiratory but not the enteric tract. Viruses of both groups differed by two nucleotide changes at positions 214 and 655. Both changes may in principle be responsible for the loss of enteric tropism, but only the change of nucleotide 655 was specifically found in the respiratory isolates and most likely this single nucleotide change what leading to a substitution at amino acid 219 of the S protein was responsible for the loss of enteric tropism in the closely related PUR46 isolates. The available data indicate that two distinct domains of S protein are involved in infection of intestinal tract cells with TGEV, mapping between amino acids 522 and 744 and around amino acid 219, respectively. The first domain binds to porcine aminopeptidase N, the cellular receptor for TGEV. A second factor of undefined nature is depicted in the other domain, but may be the binding site for a co-receptor essential for enteric tropism of TGEV.
authors: Ballesteros, M. L.;SÃ¡nchez, C. M.;Enjuanes, L.

title: Investigating outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in Mbala and Kazungula districts of Zambia
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is an acute, highly contagious viral infection of domestic and wild cloven-hoofed animals. It is known to be endemic to Zambia, with periodic outbreaks occurring in different geographic areas of the country. This study was conducted to investigate the presence of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) in reported cases of suspected foot-and-mouth disease in cattle from Kazungula and Mbala districts of Zambia. Sixty epithelial tissue or oesophageal-pharyngeal (OP) swabs (probang specimens) were collected from Mbala (n = 51) and Kazungula (n = 9) and examined for FMD. FMDV viral RNA and serotypes were analyzed by real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) and antigen-enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), respectively. Twenty-two samples (36.7%) were positive for the FMDV genome by qRT-PCR with cycle threshold (Ct) values ranging from 13 to 31. The FMDV-positive samples from epithelial tissue showed relatively higher Ct values compared to those that scrapings were obtained from OPs, regardless of geographic location. Forty percent (40%; n=4) of Mbala epithelial tissues were serotyped into the SAT 2 serotype by antigen ELISA. Kazungula samples were serotyped in SAT 1. These results indicated that there were outbreaks of FMD in Mbala and Kazungula districts in 2012 that were attributed to at least field strains SAT 2 and SAT 1 of FMD serotypes. Furthermore, the regular interaction between buffaloes from Mosi-o Tunya Park and domestic animals from the surrounding areas could contribute to the occurrence of regular FMD outbreaks in Kazungula, while the uncontrolled animal movements across the Mbala-Nsumbawanga borders could be responsible for disease outbreaks in Mbala . In-depth molecular biology studies, including viral sequencing and phylogeny, should be carried out to elucidate the complex epidemiology of FMD in Zambia and thereby provide valuable information needed for the rational control strategy for FMD in Zambia and neighboring countries.
authors: Banda, F.;Kasanga, C. J.;Sallu, R.;Sinkala, Y.;Sinkombe, T. W.;Mulumba, M.;Rweyemamu, M. M.;Wambura, P. N.

title: Isolation and metagenomic identification of avian leukosis virus associated with mortality in broilers
abstract: Avian leukosis virus (ALV) belongs to the Retroviridae family and causes significant economic losses in the poultry industry. Kidney tissues from affected chickens were submitted for virus isolation and identification in embryonated chicken eggs and MDCK cells following an outbreak with high mortality in a broiler flock in northern Malaysia. Evidence of viral growth was indicated by haemorrhage and embryo mortality in the egg culture. While viral growth in cell culture has been evidenced by the development of cytopathic effects. The isolated virus was purified by a sucrose gradient and identified using transmission electron microscopy with negative staining. Further confirmation was achieved by next-generation sequencing and nucleotide sequence homology searches. Analysis of the viral sequences using the NCBI BLAST tool revealed 99-100% sequence homology with the exogenous ALV viral envelope protein. Phylogenetic analysis based on partial envelope sequences showed that the Malaysian isolate was clustered with Taiwanese and Japanese ALV strains that were closer to ALV subgroups J, ALV subgroups E, and recombinant A/E isolates. Based on these results, it was concluded that ALV is related to the present outbreak. It was recommended to conduct further studies on the molecular epidemiology and pathogenicity of the identified virus isolate.
authors: Bande, F.;Arshad, S. S.;Omar, A. R.

title: Unique genomic organization of a novel birdpox virus discovered in turkeys (Meleagris gallopavo)
abstract: Avipoxviruses are emerging pathogens affecting over 200 species of birds worldwide. Genetic characterization of avipoxviruses is performed by analysis of genomic regions encoding 4b and DNA polymerase. Whole genome sequence data are limited to a few avipoxvirus isolates. Based on phylogenetic analysis, three main genetic groups are distinguished. In this study, we report a novel avipoxvirus strain causing skin lesions in domestic turkeys. The virus was identified in Hungary in 2011 in a flock of turkeys vaccinated against avipoxvirus infection. The genome of the isolated strain TKPV-HU1124/2011 was uniquely short (~188.5 kbp) and was predicted to encode a reduced number of proteins. Phylogenetic analysis of the genes encoding 4b and DNA polymerase separated TKPV-HU1124/2011 from other avipoxviruses from Turkey and classified it into a new genetic clade. This study provides new insights into the genetic and genomic heterogeneity of avipoxviruses and demonstrates the importance of strain diversity for vaccine efficacy.
authors: BÃ¡nyai, K.;Palya, V.;DÃ©nes, B.;GlÃ¡vits, R.;Ivanics, Ã‰;HorvÃ¡th, B.;Farkas, S. L.;Marton, S.;BÃ¡lint, Ã;Gyuranecz, M.;ErdÃ©lyi, K.;DÃ¡n, Ã

title: Evolutionary dynamics of the recent epidemic of Peste des Petits Ruminants virus in China in 2013–2014
abstract: Peste des Petits Ruminants virus (PPRV) causes a highly contagious disease, Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR), in sheep and goats that is considered a serious threat to local economies in Africa and Asia. However, the profound evolutionary dynamics of PPRV during an epidemic are not well understood. We performed a phylogenetic analysis of the genome sequences of 25 PPRV strains from China 2013-2014. All of these phyla grouped into a new clade in lineage 4. An evolution rate of 2.61 × 10″6 nucleotide substitutions per site per day was estimated, dating the most recent common ancestor of the PPRV China 2013–2014 phyla to early August 2013 . Analysis of the transmission network revealed that all virus sequences could be classified into five infection clusters, suggesting that long-distance animal transmission plays an important role in the spread of PPRV in China. These results advanced our knowledge of PPRV evolution to achieve effective control measures.
authors: Bao, J.;Wang, Q.;Li, L.;Liu, C.;Zhang, Z.;Li, J.;Wang, S.;Wu, X.;Wang, Z.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of small ruminant plague virus in free-living bharals (Pseudois nayaur) in Tibet, China
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an important viral disease in sheep and goats. The wildlife hosts of PPR, which may play an important role in the epidemiology of this disease, are not well characterized. The research was conducted to investigate PPR virus (PPRV) infection in wild bharals (Pseudois nayaur) in Tibet, China. In 2007, PPRV infection was confirmed in two bharals in Rutog County, Tibet based on clinical signs and detection of PPRV RNA in tissue samples. In 2008, PPRV infection was detected in a bharal in Ge'gyai district of Tibet by competitive ELISA, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and sequence analysis of PPRV fusion protein (F) and nucleoprotein (N) gene segments. The PPRV variant identified in infected Bharal was closely related to other circulating PPRV variants recently identified in sheep and goats from Tibet. This is the first report of PPRV infection in wild bharals. © 2010.
authors: Bao, J.;Wang, Z.;Li, L.;Wu, X.;Sang, P.;Wu, G.;Ding, G.;Suo, L.;Liu, C.;Wang, J.;Zhao, W.;Li, J.;Qi, L.

title: Isolation and complete genome sequence of two reticuloendothelosis virus strains from mixed Marek's disease virus infections in China
abstract: Classified as a gamma retrovirus, reticuloendothelosis virus (REV) has a wide variety of hosts, including chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, and wild birds. REV causes a number of pathological syndromes, most notably host immunosuppression, which can lead to increased susceptibility to other pathogens, severely harming the poultry industry. Mixed REV and Marek's disease virus (MDV) infections have been reported from many countries including China. Previous reports indicated that MDV vaccines were not effective and even less virulent MDV strains would cause some losses due to mixed infections with REV. In addition, impurities in the MDV vaccine could be the main source of REV. In this study, two clinical samples were collected from two flocks of chickens diagnosed with MDV. Two REV isolates were then obtained from the clinical specimens. The isolates, named CY1111 and SY1209, were further confirmed by indirect immunofluorescence assay and electron microscopy. Complete genome sequences of the two REV strains were determined to test the relatedness between them and other REV strains. Pedigrees showed that the two REV strains were closely related to most REV strains isolated from a variety of hosts. Therefore, under natural conditions, REVs can spread freely between these hosts. Also, most of the REV tribes in China belonged to the same group. The present work provides some information on REV in China.
authors: Bao, K. Y.;Zhang, Y. P.;Zheng, H. W.;Lv, H. C.;Gao, Y. L.;Wang, J. F.;Gao, H. L.;Qi, X. L.;Cui, H. Y.;Wang, Y. Q.;Ren, X. G.;Wang, X. M.;Liu, C. J.

title: Blood feeding, susceptibility to Schmallenberg virus infection and phylogenetics of Culicoides (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) from the UK
abstract: Background: Culicoides mosquitoes (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) are responsible for the biological transmission of internationally important arboviruses in livestock. In 2011, a novel orthobunyavirus was discovered in northern Europe that causes congenital malformations and abortions in ruminants. In field studies, Culicoides have been associated with the transmission of this virus, later named Schmallenberg virus (SBV), but no assessment of the susceptibility to infection of field populations under standardized laboratory conditions has been performed to date. We evaluated the influence of membrane type (chicken skin, collagen, Parafilm M®) when offered in conjunction with an artificial blood supply system (Hemotek, UK) on blood supply rates of Culicoides from field collections. Susceptibility to infection with SBV following blood feeding was then compared to an SBV blood suspension provided via either (i) the Hemotek system or via (ii) a saturated cotton swab. Schmallenberg virus susceptibility was defined by RT-qPCR of RNA extractions from head homogenates and compared with Culicoides species and haplotype identifications based on the DNA barcode region of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase 1 (COX1) gene in connected. Results: Culicoides blood eating rates were low for all membrane types tested (7.5% chicken skin, 0.0% for collagen, 4.4% Parafilm M®, with a total of 6029 female Culicoides being offered a blood meal). Susceptibility to infection with SBV by membrane blood supply (8 of 109 individuals tested) and pledglet blood supply (1 of 94 individuals tested) has been demonstrated for the Obsoletus complex with both C. obsoletus (Meigen) and C. scoticus Downes &. Kettles susceptible to infection with SBV through oral feeding. Potential evidence of cryptic species in UK populations was found for the Obsoletus complex in phylogenetic analyzes of cox1 DNA barcodes from 74 individuals assessed at a single field site. Conclusions: The methods described in this study offer the possibility to blood-feed Palearctic Culicoides for vector competence studies and colonization experiments. Susceptibility to SBV infection was 7.3% for membrane-fed members of the subgenus Avaritia and 1.1% for pledglet-fed. Both C. obsoletus and C. scoticus have been confirmed to be susceptible to infection by SBV, with possible evidence of cryptic species within specimens of the British Obsoletus complex, however the impact of cryptic diversity in the Obsoletus complex on arbovirus transmission remains unknown.
authors: Barber, J.;Harrup, L. E.;Silk, R.;Veronesi, E.;Gubbins, S.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Carpenter, S.

title: Mechanisms of persistence in tick-borne diseases
abstract: Through the use of new, highly sensitive diagnostic methods, it has been found that stubborn infections are a common feature of various tick-borne diseases such as babesiosis, anaplasmosis and heart water. Antigenic variation can contribute to disease persistence through the continuous elaboration of new surface structures, and we know in several cases how this is achieved. Known or suspected mechanisms of persistence in Babesia parasites include cytoadhesion and rapid variation of the adhesive ligand in Babesia bovis and genetic diversity in several proteins at the merozoite stage of different Babesia spp. In Anaplasma, extensive variation in the pfam01617 gene family accompanies the cycle of organism levels in chronic infection. A result of the groundbreaking research at Onderstepoort is the definition of a related polymorphic gene family likely to be involved in immunity to heart disease. We are beginning to understand the size of the antigenic repertoire and full definition is imminent, with the possibility of applying high-throughput simultaneous sequencing to the order of 1000 small genomes. We can also, for the first time, consider modifying these genomes and studying the impact on persistence and virulence. However, important biological questions remain unanswered; for example why we are seeing emerging Anaplasma infection in humans and why infection of endothelial cells by Anaplasma is important for persistence in vivo.
authors: Barbet, A. F.

title: DNA sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the ovine adenovirus 3 protease gene suggest that ovine adenoviruses belong to two distinct genera
abstract: To date, the only published ovine adenovirus DNA sequence has been the complete genome of ovine adenovirus isolate 287 (OAV287), which has a strikingly unique genomic organization compared to other mammalian adenoviruses and is properly placed in a new adenovirus genus should be. The protease gene sequence of ovine adenovirus type 3 (OAdV-3) was determined and analyzed. The results of the phylogenetic analysis of the 205 residue protein showed that OAdV-3 belongs to the genus Mastadenovirus and is surprisingly closely related to bovine adenovirus type 2. Despite the common host origin, the evolutionary distance between OAdV-3 and OAV287 turned out to be great, suggesting that sheep, like cattle and poultry, might be infected by distantly related adenoviruses belonging to different genera. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Barbezange, C.;BenkÃ¶, M.;DÃ¡n, A.;Harrach, B.

title: Look for antigenic proteins of porcine circovirus type 2 using the technique of immunohistochemistry
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) is a virus belonging to the family Circoviridae and is associated with post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS). Diagnosis should be based on three main points: the presence of compatible clinical signs, histopathologic lesions, and evidence of nucleic acid and/or viral antigen within the lesions. The method of immunohistochemistry (IHC) enables the detection of viral antigens through the use of specific antibodies and probes. In this study, two sample groups were analyzed by IHC. Group I consists of 32 autopsied pigs with clinical signs indicative of PMWS from commercial farms in the state of Minas Gerais. Group II consists of 109 tissues obtained from the histopathology laboratory with lesions indicative of PMWS. The first and second sampling yielded 7.60% and 60.55% positivity for the presence of the PCV2 antigen, respectively. In both groups, the viral antigens were more frequently detected in lymph nodes and lungs, as evidenced by the intense immunoreactivity of histiocytes. The use of IHC allowed comparison between histopathological changes and the distribution of viral antigen in tissues.
authors: Barbosa, C. N.;Freitas, T. R. P.

title: Research into antigens and antibodies against porcine circovirus type 2 in pigs with and without post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome from commercial farms in the state of Minas Gerais
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV-2) is a non-enveloped, circular, single-stranded DNA virus belonging to the family Circoviridae and is associated with post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS) in piglets. Immunohistochemical (IHC) techniques are applied to detected PCV-2 antigen in the animal tissue lesions. However, asymptomatic or subclinically infected pigs with PCV-2 could spread the virus in the herd. A serological test on apparently healthy pigs could indicate a risk of virus penetration. In this work, antigens and antibodies against PCVS-2 were investigated in pigs from commercial farms in seven and eight mesor regions of the state of Minas Gerais (MG). Thirty-two pigs aged five to eleven weeks showing clinical signs of SMDS were autopsied. PCV-2 antigens were assayed by IHC from either sacrificed pigs (Group I) and diagnostic demand samples (Group II). 7.60% and more than 60% of the first and second groups, respectively, were positive for viral antigen. In both, intense labeling of macrophages and histiocytes, particularly in the lymph nodes and lungs, revealed antigens against CVS-2. In parallel, the Immunoperoxidase Monolayer Assay (IPMA) was applied to antibodies against PCV-2 screened in 955 pigs from 35 full cycle commercial farms from the same mesor regions. All pig herds (100%) presented positive animals (90% to 100% confidence level) and the frequency of responding pigs varied by 96.6% (94.7% to 98.6% confidence level). PCV-2 antibody titers ranged from 1:320 (medium) to 1:10,240 (high). The results indicate that 2.66% and 9% of pigs from the Triangulo Mineiro and Zona da Mata regions, respectively, would be able to develop clinical SMDS and that this percentage reaches 3.35% in total serum.
authors: Barbosa, C. N.;Martins, N. R.;Esteves, E. G.;Freitas, T. R. P.

title: Cloning and sequence analysis of the matrix (M) protein gene of rinderpest virus and detection of another bovine morbillivirus
abstract: We have cloned and sequenced the entire M gene of the vaccine strain of rinderpest virus and the virulent Kabete 'O' strain from which it was derived. The sequences of these two genes are essentially identical (99% at the nucleotide level), but were very different from a previously published Kabete OM gene sequence (M. Limo and T. Yilma, 1990, Virology 175, 323-327). Examination of the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of known Morbillivirus M genes showed that the earlier sequence was clearly from a Morbillivirus, but neither from a rinderpest virus nor from a small ruminant plague virus.
authors: Baron, M. D.;Goatley, L.;Barrett, T.

title: Isolation of several novel paramyxoviruses from pterosaur urine
abstract: Bats have been identified as harboring a number of emerging viruses with zoonotic potential, and there is considerable interest in identifying new bat pathogens to assess risk to human and animal health. Many groups have identified new viruses in bats by detecting viral nucleic acid; However, virus isolation is still a challenge and there are few reports of virus isolates from bats. In recent years, our group has developed optimized methods for virus isolation from bat urine, including the use of primary bat cells. In previous reports we have described the isolation of Hendra virus, Menangle virus and Cedar virus in Queensland, Australia. Here we report the isolation of four additional novel bat paramyxoviruses from urine collected between 2009 and 2011 from fruit bat (Pteropid tat) colonies in Queensland and New South Wales.
authors: Barr, J.;Smith, C.;Smith, I.;de Jong, C.;Todd, S.;Melville, D.;Broos, A.;Crameri, S.;Haining, J.;Marsh, G.;Crameri, G.;Field, H.;Wang, L. F.

title: Current perspectives on the phylogeny of the Filoviridae
abstract: Sporadic fatal outbreaks of disease in humans and non-human primates caused by Ebola or Marburg viruses have spurred research to characterize these viruses in hopes of identifying host tropisms and potential reservoirs. Such an understanding of the relationship of newly discovered filoviruses can help predict risk factors for hemorrhagic disease outbreaks in humans and/or non-human primates. Recent discoveries such as three different Reston Ebola virus genotypes unexpectedly discovered in domestic pigs in the Philippines; and a new species, Bundibugyo Ebolavirus; the recent discovery of Lloviu virus as a potential new genus Cuevavirus within the Filoviridae; and germline integrations of filovirus-like sequences in some animal species provide new insights into filovirus relatedness, its prevalence, and potential for transmission to humans. These new findings show that filoviruses are more diverse and may have had a greater impact on animal evolution than previously thought. Here we review these results in terms of implications for understanding host range, prevalence, and transmission of Filoviridae. © 2011.
authors: Barrette, R. W.;Xu, L.;Rowland, J. M.;McIntosh, M. T.

title: Update on the new 2nd generation rotavirus vaccines authorized in Spain: prospects, challenges and opportunities
abstract: general review and update of the importance of rotavirus and its impact as a source of gastroenteritis in children is provided. Comments are made on viral structure, classification, pathogenesis, symptoms, and treatment. The host's immunological response to protection from wild virus disease is reviewed and shows how after initial infection, reinfection is progressively less severe as severe diarrheal disease is prevented. Briefly, it discusses the epidemiology and burden of disease that shows how rotavirus is the cause of more than 600,000 deaths annually in underdeveloped countries, increased hospital admissions, outpatient visits, and nosocomial infections, and the consequent increased morbidity and mortality for the it stands healthcare. It is striking that the only possible intervention is preventive, since the improvements achieved in health care hygiene conditions, water potability, access to oral rehydration, etc. do not result in a significant decrease in disease incidence in both developed and developing countries have led A's. The most widespread rotavirus serotypes and genotypes known in the world and in our country are described. The focus is on the current emergent serotypes. A comprehensive overview is given of the most important studies that have recently appeared in the scientific literature on the new second-generation vaccines against rotavirus that have been approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMEA) and also in the United States. Although the two vaccines approved in Spain derive from different active ingredients, they have a common goal, which is to prevent severe diarrhea due to rotavirus in children. Extensive safety studies involving more than 70,000 children were required in view of the events related to Rotashield® (first human-bovine reassortant rotavirus vaccine used in the United States and currently being withdrawn from the market) and its association with intestinal intussusception. There is ample evidence that vaccination with either vaccine, Rotarix® and RotaTeq™, is not associated with an increased risk of intestinal intussusception. Studies on efficacy, immunogenicity, adverse events, etc. were also reviewed. They are statistically significant relative to the placebos and are well tested within the acceptable ranges. A list of recent ACID (Advisory Committee Immunization Practices) recommendations for RotaTeq™ is provided. It briefly comments on some of the pharmacoeconomic studies found in the literature, some of which are inexpensive, although more advanced studies will be required once the vaccines are working and public health vaccine pricing is established. Finally, the chances, challenges and perspectives of the current 2nd generation vaccines are discussed. Some of the future ones state the difficulties they must face. It concludes on the importance of persuading pediatricians to use these new vaccines, making parents aware of them, and providing both regulators and them with health education to incorporate them into the general routine practice of vaccination. This requires pharmacoeconomic studies with current and real costs of the disease.
authors: Barrio Corrales, F.;Cuenca Burgos, M. J.;GarcÃ­a FernÃ¡ndez, M. A.;Trillo BelizÃ³n, C.

title: Molecular epidemiology of bluetongue virus in Portugal during the 2004-2006 outbreak
abstract: After 44 years of epidemiological silence, bluetongue virus (BTV) was reintroduced in Portugal in autumn 2004. The first clinical cases of bluetongue (BT) were reported in sheep farms in southern Portugal, near the Spanish border. A total of six BTV, five of serotype 4 and one of serotype 2 were isolated in sheep and cattle during the 2004-2006 animal epidemics. The nucleotide sequence of gene segments L2, S7 and S10 of BTV-4 prototype strain (BTV4/22045/PT04) obtained from the original outbreak and BTV-2 (BTV2/26629/PT05) has been completely determined and compared to those of others parts of the world. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that BTV4/22045/PT04 is related to other BTV-4 strains circulating in the Mediterranean basin since 1998 and sharing the highest identity (99%) with 2003 BTV-4 isolates from Sardinia and Corsica, while BTV2/26629/PT05 is almost indistinguishable from the live attenuated vaccine strain Onderstepoort BTV-2 and its related field strain isolated in Italy. Since BTV-2 live attenuated vaccine has never been used in Portugal, the isolation of this strain may represent a natural circulation of the vaccine virus used in other Euro-Mediterranean countries. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Barros, S. C.;Ramos, F.;LuÃ­s, T. M.;Vaz, A.;Duarte, M.;Henriques, M.;Cruz, B.;Fevereiro, M.

title: Infection of macrophages by a lymphotropic herpesvirus: a new tropism for Marek's disease virus
abstract: Marek's disease virus (MDV) is classified as an oncogenic lymphotropic herpesvirus of chickens. MDV productively and cytolytically infects B, αβT and αγT lymphocytes and latently infects helper T lymphocytes. The aim of this study was to determine whether MDV infects macrophages in vivo and, if so, whether quantitative differences in macrophage infection are associated with the virulence of the MDV strain. Chickens were infected with either virulent MDV (HPRS-16) or "hypervirulent" MDV (C12/130). Flow cytometry with monoclonal antibodies recognizing MDV pp38 antigen and leukocyte antigens was used to identify cells lytically infected with MDV. Macrophages from HPRS-16 and C12/130 infected chickens were pp38+. Macrophages are shown to be pp38+ because they are infected and not because they have phagocytosed MDV antigens, as determined by confocal microscopy using antibodies that recognize MDV antigens of the three kinetic classes of herpesviruses: infected cell protein 4 (ICP4, immediate early), pp38 (early), and glycoprotein B (gB, late). Spleen macrophages from MDV-infected chickens were ICP4+, pp38+ and gB+, and ICP4 had a nuclear localization indicative of infection. Finally, MDV pp38+ macrophages had high inherent death rates, confirming cytolytic MDV infection, although production of virus particles has not yet been demonstrated. These findings have two fundamental implications for understanding MDV pathogenesis: (i) MDV has evolved to disrupt innate immunity in addition to acquired immunity, and (ii) macrophages are excellent candidates for transporting MDV to primary lymphoid organs during the earliest stages of pathogenesis.
authors: Barrow, A. D.;Burgess, S. C.;Baigent, S. J.;Howes, K.;Nair, V. K.

title: Viruses transmitted by ticks
abstract: Tick-borne viruses (TBVs) belong to the largest biological group known as arboviruses, with a unique transmission route through blood-sucking arthropods (ticks, mosquitoes, sandflies, midges, etc.) to a susceptible vertebrate host. Taxonomically, it is a heterogeneous group of vertebrate viruses that occur in several virus families. With just one exception, African swine fever virus, all TBVs have an RNA genome. To date, at least 160 tick-borne viruses are known, some of which pose a significant threat to human and animal health worldwide. Recently, a number of established TBVs have reemerged and spread to new geographic locations due to the impact of anthropogenic activity and the few available vaccines. In addition, new tick-borne diseases are being reported all the time. Significant advances in molecular biotechnology have led to the discovery of new TBVs and further genetic characterization of unclassified viruses, leading to changes in the TBVs classification prepared by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. Although TBVs spend over 95% of their life cycle in tick vectors and the role of ticks as vectors has been known for over 100 years, our knowledge of TBVs and molecular processes involved in virus-tick interactions is poor.
authors: BartÃ­kovÃ¡, P.;HolÃ­kovÃ¡, V.;KazimÃ­rovÃ¡, M.;Å tibrÃ¡niovÃ¡, I.

title: Comparative features of the biological properties of small ruminant lentiviruses
abstract: Infections caused by small ruminant lentiviruses include diseases such as maedi visna (MV) and caprine arthritis encephalitis (CAE). Small ruminant lentiviruses were classified into groups A, B, C, D, and E based on phylogenetic findings and their common origin. The cultivation of the lentiviruses showed the cytopathic effect of the CAE virus strain 75 G-63 in the primary culture of goat synovial membrane cells, which was shown by monolayer destruction and multinucleated cell formation; this was uncharacteristic of M-88, K-796 and Tverskoy strains. High homology was found for the Tverskoy strain with group B small ruminant lentiviruses and the M-88 and K-796 strains with their group A.
authors: Baryshnikova, E. I.;Malogolovkin, A. S.;Kolbasova, O. L.;Tsybanov, S. Zh

title: Novel full genome sequences of West Nile virus lineage 1a from human cases of infection in north-eastern Italy, 2011
abstract: In 2008-2009, several human cases of WNV disease caused by an endemic lineage 1a strain were reported in areas around the Po River in north-eastern Italy. Since 2010, cases have been recorded in nearby northern areas, where both lineages 1a and 2 were discovered in 2011. We describe here two new full-length WNV genome sequences from human cases of WNV infection that emerged in the Veneto region in 2011. Phylogenetic analysis showed that both genomic sequences belonged to lineage 1a and were related to western Mediterranean subtype WNV strains. The new WNV genomes showed a large nucleotide and amino acid sequence divergence from each other and from the WNV strain circulating in Italy in 2008-2009. The presence of different WNV strains in a relatively small geographic area is a new finding with unpredictable implications for human disease that warrants further investigation. © 2012 The Authors. Clinical Microbiology and Infection © 2012 European Society for Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.
authors: Barzon, L.;Pacenti, M.;Franchin, E.;Squarzon, L.;Lavezzo, E.;Toppo, S.;Martello, T.;Cattai, M.;Cusinato, R.;PalÃ¹, G.

title: Swine Flu Viruses in North Vietnam 2013-2014 article
abstract: Pigs are an important intermediate host for the development of pandemic influenza. Vietnam is the largest pig producer in Southeast Asia. Systematic virological and serological surveillance for swine influenza virus was conducted in North Vietnam from May 2013 to June 2014 with monthly sampling of pigs at local and large collective slaughterhouses and at a live pig market. Influenza A seroprevalence in the local slaughterhouses and in the large community slaughterhouses was 48.7% and 29.1%, respectively. 77 influenza A viruses were isolated, all from the large community slaughterhouse. Genetic analysis identified six viral genotypes, including H1N1 2009 pandemic (H1N1pdm09) viruses, H1N2 with H1 of human origin, H3N2 and H1N1pdm09 reassortants, and triple reassorted H3N2 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of porcine and human H1N1pdm09 viruses indicated evidence of repeated human-to-porcine transmission rather than the establishment of H1N1pdm09 as a long-term distinct lineage in pigs. Surveillance at the large community slaughterhouse has proven to be the most efficient, cost-effective and sustainable method of swine influenza virus surveillance in Vietnam.
authors: Baudon, E.;Chu, D. K. W.;Tung, D. D.;Thi Nga, P.;Vu Mai Phuong, H.;Le Khanh Hang, N.;Thanh, L. T.;Thuy, N. T.;Khanh, N. C.;Mai, L. Q.;Khong, N. V.;Cowling, B. J.;Peyre, M.;Peiris, M.

title: A new type of bovine papillomavirus in the genus Dyokappapapillomavirus
abstract: Papillomaviruses are a diverse group of viruses known to infect a wide variety of animal species. Bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) are divided into at least 21 genotypes (BPV1 to BPV21), with most BPV isolates/strains described to date belonging to one of four genera, including delta papillomavirus, xipapillomavirus, epsilonpapillomavirus and dyoxipapillomavirus. Here we describe the identification and genetic characterization of a new type of BPV in the genus Dyokappapapillomavirus. A farm in New York State, USA, reported chronic cases of vulvovaginitis in Holstein cows in 2016. Biopsies and/or swab specimens taken from the vaginal mucosa were subjected to diagnostic evaluation. Conventional diagnostic assays gave negative results and vaginal swab specimens were subjected to viral metagenomic sequencing. Notably, BLAST searches revealed a papillomavirus genome 7480 bp in length (67% nt sequence identity to BPV16). In addition, a phylogenetic analysis of the L1 gene of the papillomavirus identified here (tentatively named BPV22) revealed that it aggregates with members of the genus Dyokappapapillomavirus. Interestingly, the recently identified BPV16, detected in bovine fibropapilloma lesions, also clusters within the dyokappapapillomavirus group. However, each virus forms a separate branch in the family tree. These results indicate that the putative BPV22 represents the second BPV within the Dyokappapapillomavirus genus.
authors: Bauermann, F. V.;Joshi, L. R.;Mohr, K. A.;Kutish, G. F.;Meier, P.;Chase, C.;Christopher-Hennings, J.;Diel, D. G.

title: Analysis of porcine circovirus type 1 detected in Rotarix vaccine
abstract: metagenomic analysis of live human vaccines recently revealed the presence of porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) DNA in the pediatric vaccine Rotarix, which is used to prevent acute gastroenteritis. Using real-time PCR for PCV1, titers of PCV1 DNA were found to be in the range of 6-7log10 copies per dose in multiple lots of Rotarix. Pretreatment of the reconstituted vaccine with the nuclease benzonase, followed by extraction of the nucleic acid and quantification of the PCV1 DNA by real-time PCR revealed that there was no loss in PCV1 DNA titer compared to the untreated controls, suggesting suggesting that the swine viral DNA was present in the vaccine in an encapsulated form. PCV1-permissive PS cells, human HEK293 and Vero cells used for vaccine production were infected with Rotarix and PCV1, respectively, and subjected to immunofluorescence and RT-PCR. Viral genomes were present in both Rotarix-incubated and PCV1-infected cells, while viral transcription was only observed in PCV1-infected cells. Similarly, PCV1-specific protein expression was observed in PCV1-infected cells but not in Rotarix-treated cells. Passage of the supernatant revealed productive infection in PCV1-infected PS cells, but not in HEK293 and Vero cells or in any cell line incubated with Rotarix. The PCV1 DNA present in Rotarix was protected from benzonase digestion; However, PCV1 was not detected by immunoelectron microscopy and was unable to infect PS, HEK293, or Vero cells, suggesting that the large amount of PCV1 DNA present in Rotarix does not represent a corresponding proportion of biologically active virus particles. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Baylis, S. A.;Finsterbusch, T.;Bannert, N.;BlÃ¼mel, J.;Mankertz, A.

title: Complete genome sequences of a cytopathic/non-cytopathic pair of bovine viral diarrhea virus subtype 1a viruses
abstract: The complete genome sequences of both biotypes of a pair of bovine viral diarrheaviruses isolated from a bovine affected by mucosal disease were determined by next-generation sequencing. The cytopathic virus had a 423 base insertion derived from bovine polyubiquitin in the NS2/3 coding region and one nucleotide change. Both biotypes showed an additional glycosylation site in their N-terminus.
authors: Bazzucchi, M.;Bertolotti, L.;Giammarioli, M.;De Mia, G. M.

title: Identification and genetic characterization of bovine enterovirus by combining two next-generation sequencing platforms
abstract: Rapid and accurate diagnosis is assured for infectious diseases in companion animals that can have a significant impact on animal production or clinical practice. In this study, the identification and genetic characterization of a bovine enterovirus (BEV) strain isolated from a calf with diarrhea is described. Two different next-generation sequencing platforms were used. Shotgun metagenomics performed by MinION sequencing (Oxford Nanopore Technologies) enabled the identification of BEV RNA from a cell culture isolate. BEV was then confirmed by a specific real-time RT-PCR assay. To obtain the entire genome of this isolate, the sequence reads obtained from MinION were coupled with those from NextSeq500 (Illumina). Genomic relatedness and phylogeny with existing BEV strains is also reported. Overall, this manuscript underscores the use of the MinION portable sequence technology as a tool for supportive diagnostics in veterinary practice.
authors: Beato, M. S.;Marcacci, M.;Schiavon, E.;Bertocchi, L.;Di Domenico, M.;Peserico, A.;Mion, M.;Zaccaria, G.;Cavicchio, L.;Mangone, I.;Soranzo, E.;Patavino, C.;CammÃ , C.;Lorusso, A.

title: Genetic and antigenic characterization of new pestivirus genotypes: implications for classification
abstract: Currently, the Pestivirus genus includes four approved species, Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus 1 (BVDV-1), BVDV-2, Classical Swine Fever Virus (CSFV), and Border Disease Virus (BDV), as well as a tentative fifth species represented by a single strain is (H138) was isolated from a giraffe in Kenya more than 30 years ago. To further address the problem of pestivirus heterogeneity, we determined the entire Npro and E2 coding sequences for several novel pestivirus isolates. Interestingly, a phylogenetic analysis revealed that a pestivirus isolated in Africa in the 1990s is closely related to strain H138. In addition, several new pestiviruses isolated from a group of sheep are found together with the previously described strain V60 (Reindeer-1) isolated from a reindeer, while one strain of ovine pestivirus (Gifhorn) differs significantly from all previously described pestiviruses, including BDV. We propose to name these mainly ovine pestiviruses BDV-2 (V60-like isolates) and BDV-3 (Gifhorn); consequently, the "classical" BDV isolates should be referred to as BDV-1. As an additional criterion for the segregation of pestiviruses, the antigenic relationship of pestivirus isolates covering all major genotypes observed was examined by cross-neutralization assays. Analysis of antigenic similarities revealed the presence of seven main antigenic groups corresponding to BVDV-1, BVDV-2, CSFV, BDV-1, BDV-2, BDV-3 and "giraffe". Taking into account the host origin, the lack of differences in disease progression, and the results of our genetic and antigenic analyses, we propose that BDV-1, BDV-2, and BDV-3 should be considered as major genotypes within the species BDV. © 2003 Elsevier Science (USA). All rights reserved.
authors: Becher, P.;Ramirez, R. A.;Orlich, M.;Rosales, S. C.;KÃ¶nig, M.;Schweizer, M.;Stalder, H.;Schirrmeier, H.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Genetic typing of Croatian bovine viral diarrheal virus isolates
abstract: Between 2007 and 2011, a total of 1937 sera samples and five spleen samples from nine Croatian dairy herds were tested for Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) using virus isolation and immunoperoxidase testing. BVDV was detected in 13 persistently infected (PI) cattle with a non-cytopathogenic biotype, while isolates from spleen samples were of the cytopathogenic biotype from five animals with fatal mucosal disease. To reveal the genetic typing of Croatian BVDV isolates, viral RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures and amplified by RT-PCR using primers targeted to the 5'-UTR and the Npro gene, followed by direct sequencing of the purified PCR products. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the 5'-UTR genomic region revealed that all Croatian isolates belonged to BVDV genotype 1; 11 isolates were grouped with BVDV-lb and 7 with BVDV-If viruses. The phylogenetic tree derived by the Bayesian approach using combined 5'-UTR/Npro supported the clustering of Croatian isolates into two subgroups. The deduced amino acid sequence of the Npro region revealed 5 sites unique to four native BVDV-If isolates.
authors: Bedekovic, T.;Lojkic, I.;Lemo, N.;Cac, Z.;Cvetnic, Z.;Lojkic, M.;Madic, J.

title: "Schmallenberg virus" - A novel orthobunyavirus emerging in Europe
abstract: SUMMARY In 2011, a novel orthobunyavirus of the Simbu serogroup, Schmallenberg virus (SBV), was discovered using a metagenomic approach. SBV caused a major epidemic in ruminants in Europe. As with related viruses such as Akabane virus, it appears to be transmitted by mosquitoes. Transplacental infection often results in the birth of malformed calves, lambs, and goat kids. Acute infections in adult ruminants or malformed SBV-positive offspring were found in more than 5000 farms in Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Great Britain, Italy, Spain, Luxembourg, Denmark and Switzerland, and high seroprevalences in adult ruminants were observed Core regions in the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium. The discovery of SBV, the spread of the epidemic, the role of vectors, the impact on livestock, public health issues, SBV diagnosis and actions taken are described in this overview. Lessons learned from the Schmallenberg virus epidemic and implications for future outbreaks will be discussed. Copyright © Cambridge University Press 2012.
authors: Beer, M.;Conraths, F. J.;Van Der Poel, W. H. M.

title: Multiple reassorted viruses as the cause of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus epidemic, The Netherlands, 2016
abstract: In 2016, an epidemic of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus subtype H5N8 in the Netherlands caused a mass death of wild birds and several commercial poultry farms and poultry farms were affected. We performed full genome sequencing to examine the relationship between wild bird and avian viruses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the viruses are related to class H5 2.3.4.4 viruses discovered in Russia in May 2016, but have novel polymerase base 2 and nucleoprotein gene segments and two different variants of the polymerase acid segment contained. Molecular dating suggests that the rearrangement events most likely occurred in wild birds in Russia or Mongolia. In addition, 2 genetically distinct H5N5 reassortant viruses have been detected in wild birds in the Netherlands. Our study provides evidence for rapid and continuous reassortment of H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses that could result in rapid changes in viral properties such as pathogenicity, infectivity, transmission, and zoonotic potential.
authors: Beerens, N.;Heutink, R.;Bergervoet, S. A.;Harders, F.;Bossers, A.;Koch, G.

title: Molecular analysis of swine hepatitis E virus from North India
abstract: Background and Objectives: Hepatitis E is the leading cause of enterally transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis in developing countries. In developed countries like the US, Japan and Taiwan, the viruses that infect humans and pigs share the same genotype with a high degree of sequence similarity. Genotype 1 circulates in humans, while genotype 4 is found in swine in India. The present study was designed to investigate the presence of anti-HEV antibodies and HEV RNA in swine populations from North India, to examine the predominant genotype therein and to compare it with other swine and human HEV strains from India. Methods: A total of 67 serum samples were collected from pigs 1 to 6 months of age at the Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI), Izatnagar, Bareily, and subjected to anti-HEV IgG and HEV RNA detection. A phylogenetic tree was constructed using the neighbor joining method and assessed using the inner branch test method with MEGA 4 software. Results: Anti-HEV IgG and HEV RNA were found in 38.8 and 4.5 percent of the pig samples tested, respectively. It was observed that the above samples were of genotype 4e. The three new sequences had nucleotide similarity to other porcine sequences in genotype 4 ranging from 80-98 percent. Interpretation and Conclusions: The three sequences observed in the present study showed nucleotide similarity to other porcine sequences from South and West Indies. The present study suggests that genotype 4 'e' is widespread in northern India.
authors: Begum, N.;Polipalli, S. K.;Husain, S. A.;Kar, P.

title: Relationships and history of live vaccine strains of Newcastle disease
abstract: Previously, Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV) strains were classified solely on the basis of their virulence, but recently grouping based on genetic relationships between the strains has become the method of choice. Live vaccine strains belong to the mild (lentogenic) or moderately virulent (mesogenic) categories, in contrast to the highly pathogenic epidemic viruses of the velogenic group. Using their genetic characteristics and lineage, the placement of vaccine strains in the “NDV world” can be viewed as described below (Figure 1). 1. Lentogenic vaccine strains are present in two of the dozen or so genotypes of NDV found in chickens. One is American group 11 (consisting of vaccine strains B-1, LaSota and F), the other is genotype I (comprising strains Ulster 2C, V4/Queensland and NDV-6/10) also found in wild waterfowl occurs. 2. Mesogenic strains are also present in only two genotypes: Group 11 (strains Roakin and Komarov) and Asiatic genogroup III (strains H and Mukteswar). 3. While the vaccine strains of Groups I and 11 aro are of natural origin, strains H, Mukteswar and Komarov were artificially attenuated, as reported in reports from the 1940s. However, discrepancies between the actual genetic identity and the postulated origin of mesogenic vaccine strains have been identified (Figure 2). a) Since the mesogenic strain H is unrelated to the virulent Herts'33, its putative parent, the reduced virulence of H cannot be attributed to the egg passage procedures performed in England, and even the presence of this strain is puzzling. b) Strains H and Mukteswar with a nucleotide distance of less than 0.3% must originate from the same isolate and therefore cannot be the result of independent developments in England and India. c) The reduced virulence (mesogenic) of the strain H/Mukteswar cannot be associated with an attenuation either; most likely it is a naturally occurring Indian field isolate. d) The mesogenic strain Komarov, intended to be attenuated in ducklings by intracerebral passage of a local velogenic virus in Palestine, is identical to the American (genotype 11) vaccine strain Roakin, for which no scientific explanation can be given.
authors: Bela, L.

title: New viruses in veterinary medicine detected by metagenomic approaches
abstract: In our world today, confronted with extraordinary environmental changes and dramatically intensifying globalization, we face challenges due to many new factors, including the emergence or re-emergence of novel, previously "unknown" infectious diseases. Although we have a wide arsenal of diagnostic methods at our disposal, the majority of conventional diagnostic tests are highly virus-specific or entirely aimed at a limited group of infectious agents. This specificity makes it difficult or even hinders the detection of new or unexpected pathogens, such as. B. new, emerging or re-emerging viruses or novel virus variants. Recently developed viral metagenomics approaches offer a powerful new way to screen samples and detect viruses without prior knowledge of the infectious agent, enabling better diagnosis and disease control in line with One World, One Health principles (www.oneworldonehealth.org ). Using metagenomic approaches, we have recently identified a variety of new viruses, including novel bocaviruses, torque tenoviruses, astroviruses, rotaviruses, and kobuviruses in swine disease syndromes, novel virus variants in honey bee populations, and a range of other infectious agents in additional host species. These results indicate that metagenomic detection of viral pathogens is now becoming a powerful, culture-independent, and useful new diagnostic tool in veterinary diagnostic virology. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: BelÃ¡k, S.;Karlsson, O. E.;BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Berg, M.;Granberg, F.

title: Advances in viral disease diagnostics and molecular epidemiological technologies
abstract: The early and rapid detection and characterization of specific nucleic acids of medical-veterinary pathogens has proven invaluable for diagnostic purposes. The integration of amplification and signal detection systems, including on-line real-time devices, has increased speed and sensitivity, and greatly facilitated the quantification of target nucleic acids. They have also allowed sequence characterization using melting or hybridization curves. Newer generation molecular diagnostic technologies offer unprecedented detection and discrimination methods that are critical for the positive detection and identification of pathogens and the impact of pathogens on the production of antibodies. The development phase of novel technologies requires a thorough understanding of how to accurately diagnose and differentiate current and emerging diseases. The development of novel technologies can only be successful if they are transferred and used in practice with a sustainable quality-assured application to enable optimal detection and effective control of diseases. The aim of these new tools is to detect the presence of a pathogen before the onset of the disease. This manuscript mainly focuses on the experiences of two collaborating centers of the World Organization for Animal Health related to molecular diagnosis and molecular epidemiology of transboundary and endemic animal diseases of viral origin, food safety and zoonoses. © 2009 Expert Reviews Ltd.
authors: BelÃ¡k, S.;ThorÃ©n, P.;LeBlanc, N.;Viljoen, G.

title: African swine fever virus and AIDS
authors: Beldekas, J.;Teas, J.;Hebert, J. R.

title: Propidium monoazide (PMA) and ethidium bromide monoazide (EMA) improve DNA array and high-throughput sequencing for the identification of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses
abstract: Panviral DNA array (PVDA) and high-throughput sequencing (HTS) are useful tools to identify novel viruses of emerging diseases. However, both techniques have difficulties in identifying viruses in clinical specimens due to host genomic nucleic acid content (hg/cont). Both propidium monoazide (PMA) and ethidium bromide monoazide (EMA) have the ability to bind free DNA/RNA but are impermeable to cell membranes. Therefore, both are unable to bind protected nucleic acids such as viral genomes within intact virions. However, EMA/PMA modified genetic material cannot be amplified by enzymes. To evaluate the potential of EMA/PMA to reduce the presence of amplifiable hg/cont in specimens and improve virus detection, serum and lung tissue homogenates were spiked with porcine reproductive and respiratory virus (PRRSV) and processed with EMA/PMA. In addition, PRRSV RT-qPCR positive clinical samples were also tested. EMA/PMA treatments significantly reduced the amplifiable hg/cont and significantly increased the number of PVDA-positive probes and their signal intensity compared to untreated spiked lung samples. EMA/PMA treatments also increased the sensitivity of HTS by increasing the number of specific PRRSV measurements and PRRSV coverage. Interestingly, EMA/PMA treatments significantly increased the sensitivity of PVDA and HTS in two out of three clinical tissue samples. Therefore, EMA/PMA treatments offer a new approach to lower the amplifiable hg/cont in clinical samples and increase the success of PVDA and HTS for virus identification.
authors: Bellehumeur, C.;Boyle, B.;Charette, S. J.;Harel, J.;L'Homme, Y.;Masson, L.;Gagnon, C. A.

title: High-throughput sequencing revealed the presence of an unanticipated parvovirus species in Canadian pigs: porcine partetravirus
authors: Bellehumeur, C.;Boyle, B.;Mandeville, I.;Gagnon, C. A.

title: Atypical rotavirus in chickens in Argentina
abstract: In Argentina, the presence of rotavirus was investigated in a flock of chickens that had intermittent episodes of diarrhea during the winter of 1986. All analyzed samples were negative in the ELISA test (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay). However, when the samples were examined by electron microscopy, particles indistinguishable from standard rotaviruses were detected in some samples. Ten of the 36 samples were positive by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) analysis, all showing the same electropherotype. Based on these results, these viruses were classified as rotavirus-like or atypical rotaviruses.
authors: Bellinzoni, R.;Mattion, N.;Vallejos, L.;La Torre, J. L.;Scodeller, E. A.

title: Serological characterization of bovine rotavirus isolated from dairy and cattle herds in Argentina
abstract: Bovine rotaviruses isolated from cattle and dairy herds in Argentina were serotyped by the immunoperoxidase focus reduction assay as previously described (G. Gerna, M. Battaglia, G. Milenesi, N. Passarani, E. Percivalle, and E. Cattaneo, Infect Immun 43:722-729, 1984). Three strains from cattle herds were related to the UK and NCDV bovine rotavirus strains defined as serotype 6 (Y. Hoshino, TG Wyatt, HB Greenberg, J. Flores and AZ Kapikian, J. Infect. Dis. 149:694-702 , 1984). Two other strains from dairy herds have been classified as bovine viruses related to the bovine strain B223 reported by Woode et al -264, 1983) in the United States. A serotyping antibody capture enzyme-linked immunoassay for the detection of serotype 6 rotavirus using a serotype 6-specific monoclonal antibody was developed and evaluated for strain characterization. Characterization of 72 rotavirus-positive group A faecal samples from bovine herds and 43 faecal samples from dairy herds showed a dominance of serotype 6 rotavirus in bovine herds, but both serotype 6 and non-serotype 6 rotaviruses in dairy herds. Analysis of genomic double-stranded RNA by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis showed that in outbreaks caused by one serotype, only a single electropherotype was present in all samples.
authors: Bellinzoni, R. C.;Blackhall, J. O.;Mattion, N. M.;Estes, M. K.;Snodgrass, D. R.;LaTorre, J. L.;Scodeller, E. A.

title: Newcastle disease virus genotype diversity in Nigeria: challenges in disease control and future prospects
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the most important bird diseases threatening the productivity of poultry around the world. The disease is associated with severe respiratory, gastrointestinal, and neurological lesions in chickens, leading to high mortality and several other production-related losses. The etiology of the disease is an avian paramyxovirus type 1 or Newcastle disease virus (NDV), whose isolates are grouped serologically into a single serotype, but are genetically grouped into a total of 19 genotypes due to the continuous emergence and evolution of the virus. In Nigeria, the molecular characterization of NDV is generally very sparse and mainly focuses on the amplification of the partial F gene for genotype assignment. However, with the introduction of the most objective NDV genotyping criteria using complete fusion protein coding sequences in the phylogenetic taxonomy, the enormous genetic diversity of the virus in Nigeria became very striking. In this review, we examine the current ecological distribution of different NDV genotypes in Nigeria based on the available full fusion protein nucleotide sequences (1662 bp) in the NCBI database. We then discuss the challenges of ND control due to the large genetic distance between the currently circulating NDV isolates and the most commonly used vaccines to combat the disease in the country. Finally, we suggest future directions in the war against the economically devastating ND in Nigeria.
authors: Bello, M. B.;Yusoff, K. M.;Ideris, A.;Hair-Bejo, M.;Peeters, B. P. H.;Jibril, A. H.;Tambuwal, F. M.;Omar, A. R.

title: Novel polyphenol oxidase from a bovine rumen metagenome expression library: biochemical properties, structural analysis, and phylogenetic relationships
abstract: RL5, a gene encoding a novel polyphenol oxidase, was identified by activity screening of a metagenome expression library from bovine rumen microflora. Characterization of the recombinant protein produced in Escherichia coli revealed a multipotent capacity to oxidize a variety of substrates (syringaldazine > 2,6-dimethoxyphenol > veratryl alcohol > guaiacol > tetramethylbenzidine > 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol > 2,2-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzthiazoline- 6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS) â‰« henol red) over an unusually broad pH range from 3.5 to 9.0. Apparent Km and k cat values for ABTS, syringaldazine and 2,6-dimetoxyphenol obtained from steady-state kinetic measurements at 40 °C, pH 4.5 gave values of 26, 0.43 and 0, respectively .45 μM and 18, 660 and 1175 s-1, respectively. The Km values for syringaldazine and 2,6-dimetoxyphenol are up to 5-fold lower and the kcat values up to 40-fold higher than previously for this class of enzymes reported values. RL5 is a 4-copper oxidase with oxidation potential values of 745, 400, and 500 mV versus a normal hydrogen electrode for copper sites T1, T2, and T3. A three-dimensional model of RL5 and site-directed mutants was constructed to identify the copper ligands. Bioinformatic analyzes of the gene sequence and the sequences and contexts of neighboring genes suggested a tentative phylogenetic assignment to the genus Bacteroides. Kinetic, electrochemical, and EPR analyzes provide unequivocal evidence that the hypothetical Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron and E. coli proteins closely related to the derived protein encoded by the RL5 gene are also multicopper proteins with polyphenol oxidase activity. The present study shows that these three newly characterized enzymes form a novel family of functional multicopper oxidases with laccase activity, related to conserved hypothetical proteins harboring the domain of unknown function DUF152, and suggests that some other of these proteins are also laccases could. Â© 2006 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
authors: Beloqui, A.;Pita, M.;Polaina, J.;MartÃ­nez-Arias, A.;Golyshina, O. V.;ZumÃ¡rraga, M.;Yakimov, M. M.;GarcÃ­a-Arellano, H.;Alcalde, M.;FernÃ¡ndez, V. M.;Elborough, K.;Andreu, J. M.;Ballesteros, A.;Plou, F. J.;Timmis, K. N.;Ferrer, M.;Golyshin, P. N.

title: Molecular characterization of the epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus associated with a 2006 Tunisian outbreak in cattle
abstract: In 2006, outbreaks of epizootic haemorrhagic disease (EHD) in cattle were recorded in the Maghreb (Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria), with serious consequences for the herds (head oedema, necrotic lesions of the oral mucosa, teat hyperthermia, accompanied). from anorexia and shortness of breath) and economic losses. The present study provides new information on the molecular characterization of the EHD virus (EHDV) circulating in Tunisia. Genomic segments 2, 3, 6, 7 and 10 of EHDV, corresponding to the VP2, VP3, VP5, VP7 and NS3/NS3A proteins, respectively, were amplified from the blood of an animal by RT-PCR and sequenced. Nucleotide sequence comparisons of these five segments with sequences available in GenBank showed that an EHDV serotype 6 (EHDV-6) was present in Tunisia in 2006. The possible origin of this strain is debated.
authors: Ben Dhaou, S.;Sailleau, C.;Babay, B.;Viarouge, C.;Sghaier, S.;Zientara, S.;Hammami, S.;BrÃ©ard, E.

title: Prioritization of zoonotic viral diseases in wild boar, domestic pigs and the human interface
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Understanding the ecology of disease requires understanding pathogens at the interface between wildlife and livestock. Wild boar (Sus scrofa) pose a public health concern as countries work to prevent and control zoonotic diseases because their populations pose environmental and health concerns due to infectious agents transmissible to domestic pigs and other animal species, including humans. AIM: Prioritize zoonotic diseases at the interface between wild boar, domestic animals and humans. MATERIALS AND METHODS: The evidence-based, semi-quantitative prioritization method included 27 criteria justified in recent publications. According to viral etiology, we have divided them into five categories: epidemiology (eight), prevention/control (three), economy/commerce (four), public health (nine), and society (three). Each criterion had a coefficient from 0 to 7 according to its impact based on evidence (maximum sum of 189). Evidence on the criteria for the nine viral diseases analyzed comes from reviewing 81 sources published between 1977 and 2015. RESULTS: The three diseases with the highest scores and zoonotic potential were swine influenza (133), and hantavirus infection (103), for which the highest scores were observed on epidemiological and public health criteria. CONCLUSION: The semi-quantitative methods of prioritization impartially contribute to evidence-based decision-making; However, due to the lack of data from public health surveillance, they are rarely used in developing countries. Controlling common diseases requires the development of strategies to reduce the transmission of pathogens between wild and domestic animals and humans.
authors: Benavides-Arias, D.;Soler-Tovar, D.

title: Characterization of the surface proteins of influenza A (H5N1) viruses isolated from humans in 1997-1998
abstract: Influenza A (H5N1) virus infected people in Hong Kong between May and December 1997. Sixteen viruses were isolated during this outbreak, including 6 fatal cases. Molecular analysis of the surface protein genes encoding hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) of these H5N1 isolates, a subtype not previously known to infect humans, is presented. The 16 human H5-HA sequences contain several basic amino acids adjacent to the cleavage site, a motif associated with highly pathogenic avian influenza A viruses. The phylogenetic relationship between avian and human H5 hemagglutinin indicates that the human isolates are directly related to isolates circulating among chickens at the five Hong Kong poultry markets before and during the human outbreak. HA sequences from the human isolates and a more recent chicken isolate represent a separate clade within which there are two subgroups, antigenic and distinguishable by the presence of a potential glycosylation site. Likewise, the N1 neuraminidases of human H5 isolates represent a clade that is evolutionarily distinct from previously characterized N1 neuraminidases. The newer human H5N1 virus NA genes are avian-like, suggesting a direct introduction from an avian source rather than the evolution of a human N1 NA. All 16 human NA genes encode a truncated stalk due to a 19 amino acid deletion also found in recent Hong Kong avian H5N1 isolates. Two unique amino acids have been identified in the N1-NAs of recent human isolates; however, it is not known whether these residues affect the host range. Neither the HA nor the NA genes of the human H5N1 virus isolates show evidence of adaptive changes during the outbreak. Although analyzes of the surface protein genes of the HSN1 viruses from this outbreak did not provide immediate answers about the molecular basis of virulence, the analyzes did provide clues to potentially important regions of the genes that are worth further investigating.
authors: Bender, C.;Hall, H.;Huang, J.;Klimov, A.;Cox, N.;Hay, A.;Gregory, V.;Cameron, K.;Lim, W.;Subbarao, K.

title: Analysis of the variability in the non-coding regions of influenza A viruses
abstract: The genomes of influenza A viruses (IAVs) comprise eight negative-sense single-stranded RNA segments. In addition to the protein coding region, each segment has 5' and 3' non-coding regions (NCR) important for transcription, replication and packaging. The NCRs contain both conserved and segment-specific sequences, and the implications of variability in the NCRs are not fully understood. Full NCRs have been determined for some viruses, but a detailed analysis of the potential variability in these regions between viruses from different host groups and locations has not been performed. To assess the level of conservation in NCRs among different viruses, we sequenced the NCRs of IAVs isolated from different wild bird host groups (ducks, gulls, and seabirds). We then extended our study to include NCRs available in the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) influenza virus database, which allowed us to analyze a greater diversity of host species and more HA and NA subtypes. We found that the amount of variability within the NCRs varied between segments, with the greatest variation found in the HA and NA segments and the least in the M and NS segments. Overall, the variability of the NCR sequences was correlated with the phylogeny of the coding region, indicating a vertical coevolution of the (coding sequence) CDS and NCR regions.
authors: Benkaroun, J.;Robertson, G. J.;Whitney, H.;Lang, A. S.

title: Molecular techniques: new possibilities in the light of adenovirus research
abstract: The author summarizes the new possibilities that lie in modern molecular techniques that have revolutionized the methods of virus research and diagnostics by presenting their latest achievements in the field of adenovirus research. Among the new methods, the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has the greatest importance. Due to the large and constantly growing number of known virus serotypes, the classic serological identification of new isolates has become extremely cumbersome. In addition, reliable reference strains and serum collections are rarely available in laboratories. PCR combined with sequencing offers a fast and efficient alternative. The new viruses identified and classified by such methods are called types rather than serotypes. In various veterinary laboratories, numerous adenovirus strains that have been isolated in various veterinary laboratories over the past decades have not yet been characterized. Now these viruses can be typed and classified by sequence analysis of certain genes. The other major advantage of the method is that it allows the molecular characterization of non-isolated viruses. This is particularly valuable for studying adenoviruses from wild animals, when isolating the virus is not usually a realistic option. The author's research group was the first in the world to determine the complete genome sequence of an adenovirus solely by PCRs from infected organ samples from diseased and dead birds, without successfully isolating the virus. Organ samples from various vertebrates found dead in zoos, pet shops or in the wild are continuously screened by PCR in the author's laboratory. Fecal samples are also suitable for screening purposes. In addition to birds and reptiles, a high rate of adenoviral infection in native bats has recently been demonstrated.
authors: Benko, M.

title: A Proposal for a New (Third) Genus within the Family Adenoviridae
abstract: This article presents a proposal for the establishment of a new adenovirus genus to accommodate certain bovine, ovine, and avian adenoviruses with distinctive features that distinguish them from members of the existing genera Mastadenovirus and Aviadenovirus. This proposal was developed from previous versions with advice from the Adenovirus Study Group of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV).
authors: BenkÃ¶, M.;Harrach, B.

title: Does a common architecture reveal a viral lineage that spans all three walks of life?
abstract: Our discovery that the major coat protein of bacteriophage PRD1 resembles that of human adenovirus raised the unexpected possibility that viruses that infect bacteria might be evolutionarily related to those that infect animal hosts. We first consider the development of this idea. We then describe how we used structure-based modeling to show that several other viruses with no detectable sequence similarity likely have envelopes constructed from similar proteins - the "double-barrel trimer". Evidence suggests that the clade includes a variety of viruses infecting very different hosts in all three domains of life: eukarya; Bacteria; and Archaea, which diverged billions of years ago. The current classification of viruses obscures such similarities. We propose that the appearance of a double-barreled trimer coat protein in a large-faceted icosahedral dsDNA virus, regardless of its host, is a very strong predictor of its belonging to a viral lineage with a common ancestor.
authors: Benson, S. D.;Bamford, J. K. H.;Bamford, D. H.;Burnett, R. M.

title: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever: history, epidemiology, pathogenesis, clinical syndrome, and genetic diversity
abstract: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the major tick-borne viral disease in humans, causing sporadic cases or outbreaks of serious disease across a vast geographic area, from western China to the Middle East and southeastern Europe and most of Africa. CCHFV is maintained in vertical and horizontal transmission cycles affecting ixodid ticks and a variety of wild and domestic vertebrates that show no signs of disease. The virus circulates in a number of tick genera, but Hyalomma ticks are the primary source of human infection, likely because both immature and adult forms are actively seeking hosts for the blood meals required at each stage of maturation. CCHF is most common in farm workers after being bitten by an infected tick and to a lesser extent in slaughterhouse workers who are exposed to the blood and tissues of infected animals and medical staff through contact with the body fluids of infected patients. CCHFV is the most genetically diverse of the arboviruses, with nucleotide sequence differences between isolates ranging from 20% for the viral S segment to 31% for the M segment. Viruses with different sequences can be found within the same geographic area, while closely related viruses have been isolated in distant regions, suggesting that CCHFV was at times widespread in the past, possibly by ticks carried by migratory birds or from abroad livestock trade. The rearrangement between genome segments during tick or vertebrate co-infection appears to have played an important role in generation of diversity and represents a potential future source of new viruses. In this article, we first review and summarize the current knowledge of CCHFV molecular biology, conservation and transmission, epidemiology and geographic range together. We also include a detailed discussion of the genetic diversity of CCHFV, including maps of the virus' range with overlaid phylogenetic trees. We then review the characteristics of CCHF, including the clinical syndrome, diagnosis, treatment, pathogenesis, vaccine development, and laboratory animal models of CCHF. The paper ends with a discussion of the potential future geographic spread of the virus. For researchers, we enclose a supplemental table listing all published reports of CCHF cases and outbreaks in the English language literature, as well as some main articles in other languages, with total case numbers, case fatality rates and all CCHFV strains on GenBank. © 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Bente, D. A.;Forrester, N. L.;Watts, D. M.;McAuley, A. J.;Whitehouse, C. A.;Bray, M.

title: Genetic characterization and phylogenetic analysis of host genes of camelpox virus isolates from India
abstract: Camelpox virus (CMLV), a close variant of variola virus (VARV), infects camels worldwide. The zoonotic infections reported from India indicate the need to study the host range genes responsible for host tropism. We report sequence and phylogenetic analyzes of five host genes: cytokine response modifier B (crmB), chemokine-binding protein (ckbp), viral sleep-like (v-slfn), myxomavirus T4-like (M-T4-like ) and b5r from CMLVs isolated from outbreaks in India. Comparative analyzes revealed that these genes are conserved in CMLVs and are 94.5–100% identical at both the nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) level. All genes showed identity (59.3-98.4%) with vaccinia virus (CPXV), while three genes - crmB, ckbp and b5r - shared similarity (92-96.5%) with VARVs on both the nt and aa level. Interestingly, three consecutive insertions of serine residues were observed in the CKBP protein of the CMLV Delhi09 isolate, which was similar to CPXV-BR and VACVs, and five point mutations (K53Q, N67I, F84S, A127T, and E182G) were also similar to zoonotic OPXVs. In addition, some inconsistent point mutations have also been observed in other genes in Indian CMLVs. These indicate that different strains of CMLVs are circulating in India and these mutations may play an important role in the adaptation of CMLVs in humans. The phylogeny showed an accumulation of all CMLVs together, except for CMLV-Delhi09, which was grouped separately due to the presence of specific point mutations. However, the topology of the chained phylogeny showed a close evolutionary relationship of CMLV with VARV and TATV, followed by CPXV-RatGer09/1 from Germany. The availability of this genetic information will be useful in unveiling new strategies to control emerging zoonotic poxvirus infections.
authors: Bera, B. C.;Barua, S.;Shanmugasundaram, K.;Anand, T.;Riyesh, T.;Vaid, R. K.;Virmani, N.;Kundu, S.;Yadav, N. K.;Malik, P.;Singh, R. K.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of host range (E3L, K3L and C7L) and structural protein (B5R) genes of Buffalopox virus isolates from buffalo, bovine and humans in India
