abstract: Buffalopox virus (BPXV), a close variant of vaccinia virus (VACV), has emerged as a zoonotic agent. The host tropism of poxviruses is determined by host range genes. Among host range genes: E3L, K3L and C7L are essential for virus replication by preventing interferon resistance while B5R is essential for virus spread and evasion of host immune response as in VACV. We report sequence analyzes of host genes: E3L, K3L, C7L and membrane protein gene (B5R) of buffalo, bovine and human BPXVs from recent outbreaks in India - their phylogenetic relationship with the reference strain (BP4) and other orthopoxviruses. BPXVs showed sequence homology with VACVs, including zoonotic Brazilian VACV-like viruses. The aa sequences of the E3L and K3L genes were 100% similar in buffalo, bovine and human isolates. However, four significant point mutations (I11K; N12K and S36F in the C7L gene and D249G in the B5R gene) specific only to buffalo isolate were observed. This means that different BPXV strains were circulating during the outbreak. The mutations in C7L and B5R could play an important role in the adaptation of BPXV in humans and cattle, which requires further functional studies. The BPXV strain isolated from buffalo must not be transmitted to humans and cattle. Various point mutations were observed in the host range genes of the reference strain (BPXV-BP4), possibly due to multiple viral passages in cell culture. The phylogeny constructed on the basis of concatenated gene sequences showed that BPXVs are not as closely related to the vaccinia strain (Lister and Lister-derived strain - LC16m8) as previously thought, but more closely related to the reference strain (BPXV-BP4) and other vaccinia and vaccinia-like viruses such as Passatempo and Aracatuba viruses. The availability of information on determinants of host tropism would allow us to understand the molecular mechanism of poxvirus species tropism, which would be useful to uncover new strategies to control zoonotic poxvirus infections. © 2012 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bera, B. Ch;Shanmugasundaram, K.;Barua, S.;Anand, T.;Riyesh, T.;Vaid, R. K.;Virmani, N.;Bansal, M.;Shukla, B. N.;Malik, P.;Singh, R. K.

title: Porcine Rubulavirus LPMV Fusion Protein Gene Analysis: Comparative Analysis of Paramyxovirus F Proteins
abstract: Complementary DNA clones representing the porcine rubula virus LPMV fusion (F) protein gene were isolated and sequenced. The F gene was found to be 1845 nucleotides long and contains a long open reading frame capable of encoding a protein of 541 amino acids. The cleavage motif for F0 in F1 and F2 is His-Arg-Lys-Lys-Arg. A sequence comparison and phylogenetic analysis were performed to identify putative functional domains of Paramyxovirus fusion proteins and also to classify the porcine rubulavirus. The LPMV F gene is most closely related to the F genes of human mumps virus and Simian virus type 5 and is therefore classified in the Rubulavirus genus. However, a coding region for a small hydrophobic protein was not found between the F and hemagglutinin neuraminidase (HN) genes, as previously found in both SV5 and mumps.
authors: Berg, M.;Bergvall, A. C.;Svenda, M.;Sundqvist, A.;Moreno-LÃ³pez, J.;LinnÃ©, T.

title: Phage-bacteria relationships and CRISPR elements revealed by a metagenomic study of the rumen microbiome
abstract: Viruses are the most abundant biological entities on the planet and play an important role in balancing microbes within an ecosystem and facilitating horizontal gene transfer. Although bacteriophages are abundant in rumen environments, little is known about the types of viruses present or their interaction with the rumen microbiome. We performed random pyrosequencing of virus-enriched metagenomes (viromas) isolated from bovine rumen fluid and analyzed the resulting data using comparative metagenomics. With up to 28,000 different viral genotypes recovered from each environment, a high level of diversity was observed. The majority (~78%) of the sequences did not match any previously described virus. Prophages outperformed lytic phages approximately 2:1, with the most abundant bacteriophage and prophage types associated with members of the dominant rumen strains (Firmicutes and Proteobacteria). Metabolic profiling based on SEED subsystems revealed an enrichment of sequences with putative functional roles in DNA and protein metabolism, but a surprisingly low proportion of sequences assigned to carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. We extended our analysis to include previously described metagenomic data and 14 reference genomes. Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) have been detected in most microbial genomes, suggesting past interactions between viral and microbial communities. © 2011 Society for Applied Microbiology and Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Berg Miller, M. E.;Yeoman, C. J.;Chia, N.;Tringe, S. G.;Angly, F. E.;Edwards, R. A.;Flint, H. J.;Lamed, R.;Bayer, E. A.;White, B. A.

title: Using non-invasive metagenomics to characterize wild animal viral communities
abstract: Microbial communities play an important role in the health of organisms and ecosystems. While high-throughput metabarcoding has revolutionized the study of bacterial communities, the generation of comparable viral communities has proven elusive, particularly in wildlife samples where the diversity of viruses and the limited amounts of viral nucleic acid pose particular challenges. Metagenomic sequencing is a promising solution for studying viral communities, but the lack of standardized methods currently precludes comparisons between host taxa or localities. Here, we developed an untargeted shotgun metagenomic sequencing protocol to generate comparable viral communities from noninvasively collected fecal and oropharyngeal swabs. Using samples from vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus), a key species for virus transmission to humans and pets, we tested how different storage media, nucleic acid extraction methods, and enrichment steps affect the detection of viral communities. Based on evidence of viral contamination in fetal calf serum, we recommend storing swabs in RNAlater or another non-biological medium. We recommend extracting nucleic acid directly from swabs and not from supernatant or pelleted material that contained undetectable levels of viral RNA. Results from a low-input RNA library preparation protocol suggest that ribosomal RNA depletion and light DNase treatment reduce host and bacterial nucleic acid and improve virus detection. Finally, by applying our approach to twelve pooled samples from seven sites in Peru, we showed that the detected viral communities were saturated at the depth of sequencing achieved, allowing for unbiased comparisons of viral community composition. Future studies using the methods described here will elucidate the determinants of viral communities across host species, environments, and time.
authors: Bergner, L. M.;Orton, R. J.;da Silva Filipe, A.;Shaw, A. E.;Becker, D. J.;Tello, C.;Biek, R.;Streicker, D. G.

title: Antigenic and genetic characterization of rabies viruses isolated from domestic and wild animals of Brazil identifies the gray fox as a rabies reservoir
abstract: Fifty Brazilian rabies viruses collected from many different animal species and multiple regions of the country were characterized by partial sequencing of the central variable region of the P gene, a locus useful for sensitive molecular epidemiological studies. Phylogenetic analysis of the sequences, which included comparison to other rabies strains from across the Americas, identified three major groups of Brazilian viruses, arbitrarily named BRL-1 through BRL-3. BRL-1 has been found in terrestrial carnivores and clusters with other American cosmopolitan lineage strains. BRL-2 consisted of two distinct isolates obtained from two species of non-hematophagous bats that had evolutionary links to insectivorous bat-derived phyla of North America. BRL-3 consisted of isolates from vampire bats and from livestock species likely infected through contact with vampire bats. The terrestrial group was further divided into three subtypes: BRL-1a was associated exclusively with dogs and cats, while BRL-1b and BRL-1c were found exclusively in gray foxes. These observations strongly support the role of the Brazilian gray fox as a rabies reservoir. Screening of representative Brazilian rabies viruses against a collection of anti-rabies monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) identified a small panel of mAbs that could be used to discriminate between all Brazilian subgroups as defined by the genetic classification in this study. © 2005 SGM.
authors: Bernardi, F.;Nadin-Davis, S. A.;Wandeler, A. I.;Armstrong, J.;Gomes, A. A. B.;Lima, F. S.;Nogueira, F. R. B.;Ito, F. H.

title: Human herpesvirus 7 is a T-lymphotropic virus and is related to, but significantly different from, human herpesvirus 6 and human cytomegalovirus
abstract: An independent strain (JI) of human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) was isolated from a patient with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS). No significant association between HHV-7 and CFS could be established by means of seroepidemiology. HHV-7 is a T-lymphotropic virus that infects primary CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes. HHV-7 can also infect SUP-T1, an immature T cell line, with variable success. Southern blot analysis using DNA probes that scan 58.8% of the human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) genome and hybridize to all HHV-6 strains tested to date revealed only 37 homology to HHV-7 .4% of total probe length. HHV-7 contains the GGGTTA repetitive sequence, as does HHV-6 and Marek's disease chicken herpesvirus. DNA sequencing of a 186 base pair fragment of HHV-7(JI) revealed 57.5% and 36% identity with HHV-6 and human cytomegalovirus, respectively. Oligonucleotide primers (HV7/HV8, HV10/HV11) derived from this sequence only amplified HHV-7 DNA and did not amplify DNA from other human herpesviruses, including 12 different HHV-6 strains. Southern blot analysis with the p43L3 probe containing the 186 base pair HHV-7 DNA fragment hybridized only to HHV-7 DNA. The molecular divergence between human cytomegalovirus on the one hand and HHV-6 and HHV-7 on the other hand is larger than between HHV-6 and HHV-7, which in turn is larger than the difference between HHV-6 strains. This study supports the classification of HHV-7 as an additional member of the human β-herpesviruses.
authors: Berneman, Z. N.;Ablashi, D. V.;Li, G.;Eger-Fletcher, M.;Reitz Jr, M. S.;Hung, C. L.;Brus, I.;Komaroff, A. L.;Gallo, R. C.

title: No evidence of viral sequences in five lepidic adenocarcinomas (formerly "BAC") by a high-throughput sequencing approach
abstract: BACKGROUND: The hypothesis of an infectious etiology of what was formerly known as bronchioloalveolar carcinoma (BAC) is controversial. We examined tumor lung tissues from five patients with previous BAC histology using high-throughput sequencing technologies to discover potential viruses present in this type of lung cancer. Around 180 million single readings of 100 bases were generated for each BAC sample. RESULTS: None of the reads showed significant similarity to Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus (JSRV) and no viruses other than endogenous retroviruses were found. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, we demonstrated the absence of JSRV and other known human viruses in five specimens of well-characterized lepidic adenocarcinoma.
authors: Berthet, N.;Frangeul, L.;Olaussen, K. A.;Brambilla, E.;Dorvault, N.;Girard, P.;Validire, P.;Fadel, E.;Bouchier, C.;Gessain, A.;Soria, J. C.

title: Absence of transmission of foot-and-mouth disease virus from persistently infected cattle to naïve cattle under field conditions in Vietnam
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD), caused by FMD virus (FMD virus; aphthovirus, Picornaviridae), is a highly contagious and economically important disease of domestic and wild ungulate species worldwide. Following the clinical phase of FMD, a large proportion of FMD-infected ruminants become persistently infected carriers, defined by the detection of FMD in oropharyngeal fluid (OPF) specimens 28 days or more post-infection. The aim of this prospective study was to characterize FMD carrier status in cattle after natural infection under typical husbandry practices in Vietnam. Ten persistently infected cattle on eight farms in Long An province of southern Vietnam were monitored for 12 months by monthly screening of serum and oropharyngeal fluid samples. To assess transmission of FMD carriers, 16 naïve cattle were intentionally placed in direct contact with the persistently infected animals for 6 months and monitored by clinical and laboratory methods. The restricted mean duration of FMD carrier status was 27.7 months and the rate of decrease in the proportion of carriers was 0.03 per month. There was no evidence of transmission to naïve animals throughout the study period. In addition, no FMD infection or seroconversion was detected in three calves born to carrier animals during the study. The infection rate for carrier-to-contact transmission was 0 per month, with a 95% upper confidence limit of 0.064 per month. Phylogenetic analysis of viral protein 1 (VP1) coding sequences obtained from carriers indicated that all viruses recovered in this study belonged to the O/ME-SA/PanAsia lineage and were phylogenetically grouped with temporally and geographically related viruses . Analysis of the development of FMDV within the host, based on full-length open reading frame sequences obtained from consecutive samples from one animal, showed that most of the non-synonymous changes in L<sub>pro</sub>, VP2 and VP3 protein coding regions appeared. This study suggests that the duration of persistent FMD infection in cattle may be longer than previously thought, but the risk of transmission is low. Additional novel insights into viral evolution within the host under natural conditions in an endemic environment are provided.
authors: Bertram, M. R.;Vu, L. T.;Pauszek, S. J.;Brito, B. P.;Hartwig, E. J.;Smoliga, G. R.;Hoang, B. H.;Phuong, N. T.;Stenfeldt, C.;Fish, I. H.;Hung, V. V.;Delgado, A.;VanderWaal, K.;Rodriguez, L. L.;Long, N. T.;Dung, D. H.;Arzt, J.

title: Allergic vasculitis during ORF
abstract: ORF is an infectious disease that affects sheep and goats and is caused by a parapox virus. It can be transmitted to humans and is considered an occupational hazard for handling sheep. The authors describe a case of ORF associated with allergic vasculitis with a development suggesting a pathogenetic role of the virus. A 69-year-old woman presented with target-like erythematous plaques indicative of ORF. Ten days after the onset of the first lesion, both non-defeasible purulent papules and necrotic purpura became evident on the legs, ankles, and dorsum of the feet. The histological evaluation revealed a leukocytoclastic vasculitis. These latter lesions resolved in ten days without therapy. At the same time, the ORF lesions also regressed spontaneously three weeks after their appearance. After six months of follow-up, neither ORF lesions nor allergic vasculitis had recurred. Viral infections are well known as etiological factors of vasculitis. Many elements led us to believe that this case of allergic vasculitis correlates with ORF viral infection: time of onset, duration, resolution related to the clinical course of ORF, no need for therapy for recovery, and a 6-month follow-up without relapses. This points to the possibility of classifying the ORF virus in the group of viruses responsible for allergic vasculitis.
authors: Bettoli, V.;Trovato, C.;La Malfa, W.;Pazzaglia, M.

title: Dynamics of acute Montipora-White syndrome: bacterial communities of healthy and diseased M. capitata colonies during and after an outbreak
abstract: Coral diseases contribute to the decline of coral reefs worldwide and threaten the health and future of coral reef communities. Acute Montipora-White Syndrome (aMWS) is a tissue-loss disease that has resulted in the death of hundreds of Montipora capitata colonies in Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii in recent years. This study describes the analysis of coral-associated bacterial communities using high-throughput sequencing generated by the PacBio RSII platform. Samples from three health states of M. capitata (healthy, healthy-ill, and ill) were collected during an ongoing aMWS outbreak and period without an outbreak, and the bacterial communities were identified to determine whether a shift in community structure had occurred between the two periods . The bacterial communities associated with outbreak and non-outbreak samples were significantly different, and an important factor was a large number of operational taxonomic units (OTUs) identified as Escherichia spp. have been identified. in the breakout sequences. Tracing of in silico bacterial sources indicated that this OTU was likely due to sewage contamination from livestock rather than human origin. The most abundant coliform OTU was a culturable E. ferguonii isolate, strain OCN300, but it did not induce disease in healthy M. capitata colonies when used in laboratory infection experiments. In addition, screening of the sequencing result revealed that the most abundant OTUs corresponded to the previously described M. capitata pathogens. The synergistic combination of known coral pathogens, wastewater contaminants and other stressors, such as fluctuating seawater temperatures and bacterial pathogens, have the potential to escalate the degradation of coral reef ecosystems.
authors: Beurmann, S.;Ushijima, B.;Videau, P.;Svoboda, C. M.;Chatterjee, A.;Aeby, G. S.;Callahan, S. M.

title: Prospects for Control and Eradication of Capripox from the Indian Subcontinent: A Perspective
abstract: Sheeppox and goatpox, two capripox infections endemic to India, pose a significant economic threat to small ruminant productivity in the subcontinent. Vaccination of all susceptible sheep and goats is the viable and sustainable means of control. The availability of effective live attenuated vaccines that are inherently thermostable and the development of improved diagnostics offer the opportunity to initiate effective control measures for Capripox. All animals older than 4.5 months can be vaccinated with the current homologous vaccines using a single vaccination by the intradermal or subcutaneous route. The success of the control program must be monitored by active surveillance, particularly for the presence of viruses, since seromonitoring does not allow differentiation between infection and vaccination. And the seroconversion after the Capripox vaccination cannot be adequately detected with the available instruments either. Sustained control efforts require socioeconomic and political stability, adequate infrastructure, and logistical support for vaccine storage and transportation to get vaccines to distant end-users. The availability of veterinary services, improved advisory services to raise awareness among farmers contribute significantly to control campaigns. Poor immunization coverage and inadequate infrastructure in large parts of the country are some of the key elements standing in the way of effectively implementing herd immunity building through vaccination. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Bhanuprakash, V.;Hosamani, M.;Singh, R. K.

title: The current status of sheeppox disease
abstract: Sheep are the shepherd's benches and their economic contribution in terms of meat, wool and hide/skin is immense. Various infectious diseases threaten optimal productivity; among which sheeppox are more important, since the disease restricts the export of sheep and their products, among other economic losses. Although the clinical signs are indicative of the disease, laboratory confirmation is required for a definitive diagnosis and study of the epidemiology. The causative agent, sheeppox virus (SPV), is antigenically and genetically closely related to goatpox virus (GPV) and lumpy skin disease virus (LSDV), the other members of the Capripoxvirus genus. In some countries, SPV and GPV are cross-infectious to small ruminants, posing diagnostic and epidemiological problems. However, recent studies have shown that the viruses are phylogenetically distinct and can be distinguished by molecular tools. Prophylaxis with attenuated vaccines is the choice of control measure because immunity is long-lasting. Detailed information on isolation, identification, pathology, epidemiology, diagnosis and prophylaxis would not only help update the knowledge of the scientific community, but would also be useful for policy makers to take appropriate measures to control and eradicate the disease to formulate. This summary is intended to provide an up-to-date overview of the disease and how to combat it in order to provide the reader with an overview of the problem. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Bhanuprakash, V.;Indrani, B. K.;Hosamani, M.;Singh, R. K.

title: Fluorogenic RT-PCR assay (TaqMan) for the detection and classification of bovine viral diarrhea virus
abstract: single-tube, fluorogenic RT-PCR-based TaqMan test was developed for the detection and classification of Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus (BVDV). TaqMan PCR has been optimized for BVD virus quantification using the ABI PRISM 7700 Sequence Detection System and dual-labeled fluorogenic probes. Two different gene-specifically labeled fluorogenic probes for the 5-inch untranslated region (5-inch UTR) were used to differentiate between BVD type I and II. The sensitivity of the single-tube TaqMan Assay was compared to the two-tube TaqMan Assay and standard RT-PCR using 10-fold RNA dilutions. The single-tube TaqMan assay was 10-100-fold more sensitive than the two-tube TaqMan assay and standardized single-tube RT-PCR. The specificity of the assay was evaluated by testing different BVD virus strains and other bovine viruses. A total of 106 BVD positive and negative pooled or individual serum samples, field isolates and reference strains were tested. Quantification of BVD virus type I and II cRNA was accomplished by a standard curve plotting cycle threshold (CT) versus copy number. The single-tube TaqMan PCR assay was sensitive, specific, and rapid for the detection, quantification, and classification of BVD virus. © 2001 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Bhudevi, B.;Weinstock, D.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1c in migratory birds, 2014–2015
abstract: novel clade 2.3.2.1c H5N1 reassortant virus caused multiple outbreaks in wild birds in some regions of China in late 2014-2015. Based on the genetic and phylogenetic analyses, the viruses have a stable gene constellation with a clade 2.3.2.1c HA , a PB2 gene derived from H9N2 and the other six genes of Asian H5N1 origin. The clade 2.3.2.1c H5N1 reassortants showed a high genetic relatedness to a human H5N1 strain (A/Alberta/01/2014). Further analysis showed that similar viruses circulated in wild birds in China, Russia, Dubai (West Asia), Bulgaria and Romania (Europe) and in domestic poultry in some regions of Africa. Affected areas include the Central Asia, East Asia-Australasia, West Asia-East Africa and Black Sea/Mediterranean air routes. These results indicate that the new clade 2.3.2.1c reassortant viruses are circulating worldwide and may have gained a selective advantage in migratory birds, thereby posing a serious threat to wild birds and possibly humans. [Figure not available: see full text.]
authors: Bi, Y.;Chen, J.;Zhang, Z.;Li, M.;Cai, T.;Sharshov, K.;Susloparov, I.;Shestopalov, A.;Wong, G.;He, Y.;Xing, Z.;Sun, J.;Liu, D.;Liu, Y.;Liu, L.;Liu, W.;Lei, F.;Shi, W.;Gao, G. F.

title: Atypical bovine spongiform encephalopathies, France, 2001-2007
abstract: In France, from July 2001 to July 2007, ≥ 17.1 million adult cattle were tested for bovine spongiform encephalopathy by extensive active surveillance; â‰ˆ3.6 million were >8 years old. Our retrospective western blot study of all 645 confirmed cases revealed that 7 were H-type and 6 were L-type.
authors: Biacabe, A. G.;Morignat, E.;Vulin, J.;Calavas, D.;Baron, T. G. M.

title: Genetic analysis of full-length genomes and subgenomic sequences of TT virus-like minivirus human isolates
abstract: The phylogenetic relationship between the complete genomic sequences of ten Japanese and one French TT virus-like minivirus (TLMV) isolate was examined. Analysis of nucleotide sequence variability and detection of signature patterns for overlapping genes suggested that ORFs 1 and 2 are likely functional. However, this was not the case for a putative third ORF, ORF3. Several nucleotide or amino acid motifs have been identified throughout the viral genome that are conserved in circoviruses such as TT virus (TTV) and chicken anemia virus. The phylogenetic analysis distinguished three main groups of TLMV and enabled the identification of putative recombination breakpoints in the untranslated region. TLMV genomes were detected by PCR in the plasma of 38/50 French blood donors tested and were also identified in peripheral blood mononuclear cells, faeces and saliva. A phylogenetic study of 37 TLMV strains from France, Japan and Brazil showed that the groupings are unrelated to geographic origin.
authors: Biagini, P.;Gallian, P.;Attoui, H.;Touinssi, M.;Cantaloube, J. F.;de Micco, P.;de Lamballerie, X.

title: The History and Biology of Marek's Disease Virus
authors: Biggs, P. M.

title: Polymerase errors accumulated during the natural evolution of the glycoprotein gene of isolates of the Indiana serotype of vesicular stomatitis virus
abstract: We report the entire nucleotide sequences of the glycoprotein (G) gene of 26 isolates of Indiana serotype vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV IND) type 1 from North and Central America. These sequences are also compared to partial G gene sequences of VSV IND type 2 (Cocal) and type 3 (Alagoas) viruses and the complete G gene sequences of the more distantly related VSV New Jersey (NJ) and Chandipura viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the G gene sequences by maximal parsimony revealed four major lineages or subtypes within the classic VSV IND (type 1) viruses, each with a distinct geographic distribution. A high level of VSV genetic diversity has been identified in Central America, with multiple viral subtypes of both the VSV IND and NJ serotypes occurring in this primarily enzootic disease region. Nineteen percent sequence variation but no deletions or insertions were evident within the 5' non-coding and the coding regions of the VSV-IND type 1 G genes. In addition to numerous base substitutions, the 3' non-coding regions of these viruses also contained numerous base insertions and deletions. This resulted in striking variations in G gene sizes, with gene lengths ranging from 1,652 to 1,868 nucleotides. As the VSV IND type 1 subtypes have diverged from the common ancestor with the NJ subtypes, their G mRNAs have accumulated more 3' noncoding sequence inserts, up to 303 nucleotides long. These consist primarily of an inaccurate repeat of the sequence UUUUUAA, which appears to have been generated by a unique polymerase stuttering error. Analysis of the deduced amino acid sequence differences between VSV IND type 1 viruses revealed numerous substitutions within defined antigenic epitopes, suggesting that immune selection may play a role in the evolution of these viruses.
authors: Bilsel, P. A.;Nichol, S. T.

title: Physiological properties and classification of strains of Treponema sp. isolated from pigs in Poland
authors: Binek, M.;Szynkiewicz, Z. M.

title: Different genotypes of nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis viruses co-circulating in the chicken population in China
abstract: Nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis (IB) in chickens has been prevalent in most chicken farms in recent years, although the IB vaccination program has been widely implemented in China. To characterize the S1 protein of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) from China, five representative nephropathogenic IB viruses isolated from chickens in different provinces were genetically and phylogenetically analyzed. The results showed that the length of the S1 genes of the isolates was quite different (1617, 1620, 1623, 1629 and 1632 nucleotides, respectively). The nucleotide and amino acid homology between the five isolates was 76.7% ± 92.1% and 73.9% ± 89.5%, respectively, indicating a large variation in the S1 genes of the isolates. The variation of the S1 genes could affect the antigenicity and pathogenicity of the viruses. Genetically, point mutations, insertions and deletions can be observed at many positions in the S1 protein, particularly at the first 150 amino acids in the N-terminus of the S1 protein. Two motif cleavage sites (RRXRR/S, HRRRR/S) were observed in the five sequenced strains. Phylogenetic analyzes suggested that they belonged to different lineages. These results indicated that different genotypes of nephropathogenic IB viruses co-circulated in the chicken population in China. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bing, G. X.;Liu, X.;Pu, J.;Liu, Q. F.;Wu, Q. M.;Liu, J. H.

title: Enterovirus serotypes in patients with central nervous system and respiratory infections in Vietnam 1997-2010
abstract: BACKGROUND: Enteroviruses are the most common causative agents of human disease. Enteroviruses have recently been implicated in regional and global epidemics, including major diseases (Enterovirus A71 and D68), and are of interest as emerging viruses. Here we typed enterovirus AD (EV) from the central nervous system (CNS) and respiratory infections in Vietnam. METHODS: Data and samples from prospective observational clinical studies conducted between 1997 and 2010 were used. Species and serotypes were determined using type-specific RT-PCR and viral protein 1 or 4 (VP1, VP4) sequencing. RESULTS: Samples from patients with CNS infection (51 children - 10 CSF and 41 respiratory/rectal swabs) and 28 adults (28 CSF) and respiratory infections (124 children - 124 respiratory swabs) were analyzed. Twenty-six different serotypes from the four enterovirus (AD) species have been identified, including EV-A71 and EV-D68. Enterovirus B has been associated with viral meningitis in children and adults. Enteroviruses A (EV-A71 and coxsackievirus [CV] A10) associated with hand, foot and mouth disease have been identified in children with encephalitis. Various serotypes of all four enterovirus species were found in respiratory samples, including 2 polio vaccine viruses, but also 8 CV-A24 and 8 EV-D68. With the exception of EV-D68, the relevance of these viruses in respiratory infections remains unknown. CONCLUSION: We describe the diverse spectrum of enteroviruses from patients with CNS and respiratory infections in Vietnam between 1997 and 2010. These data confirm the worldwide distribution of enterovirus genera and their associations and are important for clinical diagnosis, patient management and response Outbreaks.
authors: B'Krong, N.;Minh, N. N. Q.;Qui, P. T.;Chau, T. T. H.;Nghia, H. D. T.;Do, L. A. H.;Nhung, N. N.;Van Vinh Chau, N.;Thwaites, G.;Van Tan, L.;van Doorn, H. R.;Thanh, T. T.

title: Adenovirus-Infektion der Atemwege bei Putenküken
abstract: virus from turkey poults with respiratory symptoms was isolated in specific pathogen-free embryonated hen eggs and subsequently adapted to chick embryo fibroblasts and turkey kidney cell cultures, where round cell formation was observed. The cloned virus was ether resistant and contained tritiated thymidine. Intranuclear icosahedral virus particles of 80 nm were detected. These physicochemical properties place this isolate in the adenovirus group of viruses. The disease was experimentally reproduced by intratracheal inoculation of day-old turkey poults. Snicking occurred in 100% of the birds and mortality reached 50%. CELO (Phelps strain) antiserum neutralized uncloned and cloned CUA-2 in chick embryos and uncloned virus in chick embryo fibroblast cell cultures. Quail bronchitis virus antiserum neutralized cloned CUA-2 in TK cells. Agar gel precipitation identity lines were generated using CELO antiserum and post-inoculation sera from experimentally infected turkeys. Serologically, this virus is classified as a type 1 adenovirus.
authors: Blalock, H. G.;Simmons, D. G.;Muse, K. E.;Gray, J. G.;Derieux, W. T.

title: Variable and constant regions in African swine fever virus DNA
abstract: Analysis of the SalI restriction pattern of African swine fever virus DNA showed that the SalI recognition sites did not change after more than 100 virus passages in swine macrophages. The virus strain BA71V, obtained from the virus isolate BA71 by adaptation to growth in VERO cells, differed from the unadapted virus by two deletions with a length of 2.5 and 7 kb, which were close to the DNA ends. Restriction analysis of several virus clones obtained from a naturally infected pig revealed length heterogeneity in both variable regions. A comparison of SalI restriction maps of 23 African swine fever virus field isolates (8 African, 11 European and 4 American) has shown that the viral genome consists of a central region of constant length of approximately 125 kb and two variable regions close to the DNA ends with a length of 38-47 kb for the left DNA end and 13-16 kb for the right DNA end. The total length of ASF virus DNA varied between 178 (BA71) and 189 (MOZ64) kb. The 23 African swine fever virus isolates were divided into five groups according to the arrangement of the SalI sites in the central region. Four groups contained only African isolates, while all European and American isolates belonged to the same group. This distribution of isolates suggests that all non-African virus field isolates share a common origin.
authors: Blasco, R.;AgÃ¼ero, M.;Almendral, J. M.;ViÃ±uela, E.

title: Ledantevirus: A proposed new genus in the Rhabdoviridae has a strong ecological association with bats
abstract: The Le Dantec serogroup of rhabdoviruses includes Le Dantec virus from a human with encephalitis and Keuriliba virus from rodents, each isolated in Senegal. The core canyon serogroup includes a loosely related group of rhabdoviruses, many of which have been isolated from bats, including core canyon virus from California, Nkolbisson virus from Cameroon, Central African Republic and Ivory Coast, Kolente virus from Guinea and Mount Elgon bat and Fikirini virus from Kenya and Oita virus from Japan. Fukuoka virus isolated from mosquitoes, gnats, and cattle in Japan, Barur virus from a rodent in India, and Nishimuro virus from pigs in Japan have also been linked genetically or serologically to this group. Here we analyze the genome sequences and phylogenetic relationships of this group of viruses. We show that they form three subgroups within a monophyletic group that we believe should form the new genus Ledantevirus.
authors: Blasdell, K. R.;Guzman, H.;Widen, S. G.;Firth, C.;Wood, T. G.;Holmes, E. C.;Tesh, R. B.;Vasilakis, N.;Walker, P. J.

title: Koolpinyah and Yata Viruses: Two newly identified ephemeroviruses from tropical regions of Australia and Africa
abstract: Koolpinyah virus (KOOLV), isolated from healthy Australian cattle, and Yata virus (YATV), isolated from a pool of Mansonia uniformis mosquitoes in Central African Republic, have been tentatively identified as rhabdoviruses. KOOLV had previously shown to be antigenically related to Kotonkon virus, an ephemerovirus that has caused an ephemeral febrile illness in cattle in Nigeria, but YATV was not antigenic to any other virus tested. Here we report the complete genome sequences of KOOLV (16,133 nt) and YATV (14,479 nt). Each has a complex genomic organization with multiple genes, including a second nonstructural glycoprotein (GNS) gene and a viroporin (α1) gene, between the G and L genes, as is characteristic of ephemeroviruses. Based on an analysis of genome organization, sequence identity, and cross-neutralization, we show that both KOOLV and YATV should be classified as two new species in the genus Ephemerovirus.
authors: Blasdell, K. R.;Widen, S. G.;Diviney, S. M.;Firth, C.;Wood, T. G.;Guzman, H.;Holmes, E. C.;Tesh, R. B.;Vasilakis, N.;Walker, P. J.

title: Fatal ulcerative and hemorrhagic typhlocolitis in a pregnant heifer associated with natural bovine enterovirus type 1 infection
abstract: 2 year old, 7.5 month pregnant Aberdeen Angus from a herd of 100 apparently healthy cows died within 10 hours of hospitalization. Multiple foci of mucosal hemorrhage and ulceration in the spiral colon and cecum were observed at necropsy. Virus isolation from intestinal lesions revealed a cytopathic virus which was found by electron microscopy to be approximately 27 nm non-enveloped virus. Further characterization by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), sequencing of the 5-UTR and partial VP1 coding region, and phylogenetic analysis classified the virus isolate as bovine enterovirus type 1 (BEV-1). No other significant pathogens were detected. This is the first report of isolation of BEV-1 in the United States from an animal with fatal enteric disease in more than 20 years. Further research is needed to determine the prevalence of BEV in North America and to establish the clinical relevance of this understudied virus.
authors: Blas-Machado, U.;Saliki, J. T.;Boileau, M. J.;Goens, S. D.;Caseltine, S. L.;Duffy, J. C.;Welsh, R. D.

title: Bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2-induced meningoencephalitis in a heifer
abstract: The brain of a 15-month-old black Angus female with a 48-hour history of central nervous system disorders was presented to the Oklahoma Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory. Microscopic findings consisted of acute, multifocal meningoencephalitis with neuronal degeneration and necrosis and gliosis. Virus isolation revealed non-cytopathic bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV). Virus genotyping classified the virus as BVDV type 2. Immunohistochemical labeling for BVDV antigens with the BVD MAb 3.12F1 clone was in the cytoplasm of neurons, glial cells, ependymal epithelium, perivascular macrophages and spindle cells, smooth muscle cells and intravascular monocytes of the cerebrum and brainstem. Laboratory results support that tissue changes occurred as a result of BVDV type 2 infection. In the absence of other clinical signs associated with BVDV infection and using the microscopic and laboratory evidence presented, we propose that the BVDV type 2 isolated from this case may represent a neurovirulent strain of the virus. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of brain lesions and neuronal viral antigen localization in BVDV genotype 2 virus infection, either congenital or postnatally acquired.
authors: Blas-Machado, U.;Saliki, J. T.;Duffy, J. C.;Caseltine, S. L.

title: Novel circular DNA viruses in stool samples from wild chimpanzees
abstract: Viral particles in stool samples from wild chimpanzees were analyzed using random PCR amplification and sequencing. Sequences encoding proteins distantly related to the replicase protein of single-stranded circular DNA viruses have been identified. Inverse PCR was used to amplify and sequence several small circular DNA virus genomes. The viral genomes were related in size and genome organization to vertebrate circoviruses and plant geminiviruses, but with a different position for the stem loop structure involved in rolling circle DNA replication. The replicase genes of these viruses were most closely related to those of the much smaller (similar to 1 kb) circular DNA chromosomes of plant nanoviruses. Because the viruses share characteristics of both animal and plant viruses, we have named them Chimpanzee Stool Associated Circular Viruses (ChiSCV). Further metagenomic studies on animal samples will greatly expand our knowledge of viral diversity and evolution.
authors: Blinkova, O.;Victoria, J.;Li, Y. Y.;Keele, B. F.;Sanz, C.;Ndjango, J. B. N.;Peeters, M.;Travis, D.;Lonsdorf, E. V.;Wilson, M. L.;Pusey, A. E.;Hahn, B. H.;Delwart, E. L.

title: Epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for the detection of serum antibodies to West Nile virus in several avian species
abstract: We report the development of epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) for the rapid detection of serum antibodies to West Nile virus (WNV) in taxonomically diverse North American avian species. A panel of flavivirus-specific monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) were tested in blocking assays using serum samples from WNV-infected chickens and crows. Selected MAbs were further tested against serum samples from birds representing 16 species and 10 families. Serum samples were collected from birds infected with WNV or Saint Louis encephalitis virus (SLEV) and from uninfected control birds. Serum samples from SLEV-infected birds were included in these experiments because WNV and SLEV are antigenically closely related, are maintained in similar transmission cycles, and have overlapping geographic distributions. The ELISA using MAb 3.1112G possibly discriminated between WNV and SLEV infections since all serum samples from WNV-infected birds and none from SLEV-infected birds were positive in this assay. Assays with MAbs 2B2 and 6B6C-1 readily detected serum antibodies in all birds infected with WNV and SLEV, respectively, and in most birds infected with the other virus. Two other MAbs partially discriminated between infections with these two viruses. Serum samples from most WNV-infected birds but no SLEV-infected birds were positive for MAb 3.67G, while almost all serum samples from SLEV-infected birds but few from WNV-infected birds were positive for MAb 6B5A-5. The blocking assays described here provide a rapid, reliable, and inexpensive diagnostic and monitoring technique for monitoring WNV activity in multiple bird species.
authors: Blitvich, B. J.;Marlenee, N. L.;Hall, R. A.;Calisher, C. H.;Bowen, R. A.;Roehrig, J. T.;Komar, N.;Langevin, S. A.;Beaty, B. J.

title: New leaves in the growing pestivirus tree
abstract: Pestiviruses are a group of viruses of veterinary importance that infect livestock such as pigs, cattle and sheep, as well as wild animals such as wild boar and various species of deer. While only four classic species (classical swine plague virus, bovine virus diarrhea virus types 1 and 2, border disease virus) and a few so-called atypical pestiviruses (e.g. giraffe virus, pronghorn virus, HoBi virus) were known for decades, in recent years A number of new pestiviruses have been identified over the past few years (Bungowannah Virus, Bat Pestivirus, Norwegian Rat Pestivirus, Atypical Porcine Pestivirus, LINDA Virus). Australian Bungowannah virus could be isolated and further characterized by classical sequencing, but all other recent novel pestiviruses have been identified by metagenomics using next-generation sequencing technologies. Here we describe these new viruses and their discovery and characterization. A distinction is made between the occurrence of classic pestiviruses in new species and novel viruses or virus types.
authors: Blome, S.;Beer, M.;Wernike, K.

title: Detection of a novel porcine Boca-like virus in the background of post-weaning porcine circovirus type 2-induced multisystem wasting syndrome
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV-2) has been identified as the causative agent of postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS). However, PCV-2 is a ubiquitous virus in the pig population and a majority of pigs infected with PCV-2 do not develop the disease. Various factors such as age, maintenance, the genetics of PCV-2, other pathogens, etc. have been suggested to contribute to the development of PMWS. However, no proven link between any of these factors and disease development has been found to date. In this study, we investigated the possible presence of other previously unknown DNA containing infectious agents in lymph nodes of Swedish pigs with confirmed PMWS by random amplification and high-throughput sequencing. Although the vast majority of the amplified genetic sequences belonged to PCV-2, we also found genomic sequences of torque tenovirus (TTV) and a novel parvovirus. Detection of TTV was to be expected since TTV, like PCV-2, has been found to have a high prevalence in pigs around the world. We were able to amplify a longer region of the parvovirus genome, consisting of the entire NP1 and partial VP1/2. Through comparative nucleotide sequence analysis and phylogenetic studies, we propose that this is a novel porcine parvovirus with genetic relatedness to bocaviruses. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Fossum, C.;McKillen, J.;Allan, G.;Wallgren, P.;Berg, M.

title: The viral metagenomic analysis shows the co-infection situation in healthy and PMWS-affected pigs
abstract: The development of high-throughput sequencing technologies has made it possible to study and characterize the entire microbiome of individuals, providing better insight into the complex interactions between different microorganisms. This will help to understand how the microbiome affects susceptibility to secondary metabolites and disease development. We applied viral metagenomics to study the virome of lymph nodes from Swedish pigs suffering from the multifactorial disease Postweaning Multisystemic Wasting Syndrome (PMWS) and healthy pigs. The aim is to increase knowledge about potential viruses other than porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) involved in PMWS development, as well as knowledge about the virome of healthy individuals. A diverse viral flora with several viruses present at the same time has been observed in healthy individuals. The majority of viruses identified were small linear and circular DNA viruses such as various circoviruses, anelloviruses and bocaviruses. As expected, high levels of PCV2 sequences were detected in pigs infected with PMWS, but other viruses were also identified in the background of PCV2. In addition to DNA viruses, RNA viruses have also been identified, including a porcine pestivirus that bears close resemblance to a recently (2015) discovered atypical porcine pestivirus in the United States. The majority of viruses identified in the background of PCV2 in PMWS pigs could also be identified in the healthy pigs. PCV2 sequences have also been identified in healthy pigs, but to a much lower extent than in PMWS-affected pigs. Although the method used here is not quantitative, the very marked difference in the amount of PCV2 sequences in PMWS-affected pigs and healthy pigs most likely reflects the very high replication of PCV2, which is known to be a hallmark of PMWS. Taken together, these findings illustrate that pigs appear to have a substantial viral flora made up largely of small single-stranded and circular DNA viruses. Future research on these virus types will help better understand the role these ubiquitous viruses may play in swine health and disease. We also demonstrate for the first time in Europe the presence of a novel porcine pestivirus.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Fossum, C.;Wallgren, P.;Berg, M.

title: A metagenomic analysis reveals the diverse microbial community of a vermicomposting system in Uganda
abstract: Background: Vermicomposting is a mesophilic process that uses earthworms to efficiently and cost-effectively process large volumes of organic waste. In addition to increasing soil fertility, it has been proposed to increase the biomass of beneficial bacteria while reducing harmful bacteria. The aim of this study was to develop a strategy to investigate and characterize the viral as well as the bacterial composition of a vermicomposting system. Materials and Methods: The vermicomposting unit used in this study was set up at Makerere University Agricultural Research Institute in Kabanyolo on the outskirts of Kampala, Uganda and fed 80% cattle manure and 20% food waste. On day 172, composting was terminated and compost samples were collected from three tiers of the unit: the top, middle, and bottom tiers. A metagenomic approach was then applied to characterize the viral and bacterial composition of the vermicomposting system. Results and Discussion: A high abundance and diversity of bacteria was found. Proteobacteria were the largest phyla in the compost (mainly alpha, gamma, and beta proteobacteria), accounting for nearly 65% of the bacterial reads in the datasets. DNA samples from several possible pathogenic bacteria such as Salmonella spp., Escherichia coli, Enterobacter spp., Enterococcus spp. and Clostridium spp. were detected in the vermicompost, suggesting that harmful bacteria may still be present in the vermicast. Phage formed the main viral group; In addition to phages, insect viruses in particular were identified. The only animal or human virus identified was Kobuvirus. In conclusion, metagenomic analysis has been shown to be an efficient technology to characterize the microbial composition of vermicast. The data from this study contributes to a better understanding of the microbes present in this type of composting system and can help determine actions needed to safely manage manure.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Lalander, C.;Komakech, A. J.;VinnerÃ¥s, B.;Boqvist, S.

title: Genomic sequence of a bovine rhinitis B virus identified in cattle in Sweden
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Oma, V.;Khatri, M.;Hansen, H. H.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis of bush pigs (Potamochoerus larvatus) in Uganda identifies new variants of porcinem parvovirus 4 and torque teno sus virus 1 and 2
abstract: Background: As a result of rapidly growing human populations, intensification of animal production, and increasing exploitation of wildlife habitats for animal husbandry, the interface between wildlife, livestock, and humans is expanding, with potential impacts on domestic animal and human health. Wildlife serves as a reservoir for many viruses that can occasionally lead to novel infections of domestic animals and/or the human population. With this in mind, we used metagenomics to examine the presence of viral pathogens in sera collected from bush pigs (Potamochoerus larvatus), a nocturnal wild suid species known for migrating between national parks and farmland in Uganda. Results: Application of 454 pyrosequencing revealed the presence of torque tenosus virus (TTSuV), porcine parvovirus 4 (PPV4), porcine endogenous retrovirus (PERV), a GB hepatitis C-like virus, and a sclerotinia Hypovirulence-associated virus in sera from bush pigs. PCR assays for each specific virus in combination with Sanger sequencing revealed two TTSuV-1 variants, one TTSuV-2 variant and PPV4 in the serum samples, thereby confirming the 454 sequencing results. Conclusions: Using a viral metagenomic approach, we performed a first analysis of viruses present in bushpig sera and demonstrated for the first time the presence of PPV4 in a wild African suid. In addition, we identified new variants of TTSuV-1 and 2 in bush pigs. © 2012 Blomstrom et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;StÃ¥hl, K.;Masembe, C.;Okoth, E.;Okurut, A. R.;Atmnedi, P.;Kemp, S.;Bishop, R.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Berg, M.

title: Characterization of the tonsil virus of conventional pigs and specific pathogen-free pigs
abstract: Swine respiratory disease is a multifactorial disease that can be influenced by a number of different microorganisms as well as non-infectious factors such as animal husbandry and environment. It is widely accepted that the interaction between different infectious agents plays an important role in relation to respiratory diseases. Therefore, we used high-throughput sequencing in combination with viral metagenomics to characterize the viral community of porcine tonsil samples obtained from a conventional herd with respiratory tract lesions at slaughter. At the same time, samples from specifically pathogen-free pigs were analyzed. This study showed a variable co-infection rate among the different pigs. The differences were not seen at the group level but at individual pigs. Some viruses, such as adenoviruses and certain picornaviruses, have been found in most pigs, while others, such as various parvoviruses and anelloviruses, have only been identified in a few pigs. In addition, the entire coding region of porcine parvovirus 7 was obtained, as were the entire genomes of two testoviruses. The results of this study will help elucidate which viruses are circulating in both healthy pigs and pigs with respiratory disease. This knowledge is needed for future studies on the role of viral-viral interactions in disease development.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Ye, X.;Fossum, C.;Wallgren, P.;Berg, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of partial S1 and N gene sequences of isolates of infectious bronchitis virus from Italy revealed genetic diversity and recombination
abstract: total of ten infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) isolates collected from commercial chickens in Italy in 1999 were characterized by RT-PCR and sequencing of the S1 and N genes. Phylogenetic analyzes based on partial S1 gene sequences showed that five field viruses were grouped together with 793/B-type strains and shared 91.3-98.5% nucleotide identity within the group, and one isolate showed very close sequence relatedness ( 94.6% identity) with 624/ I charge. These two IBV types were previously identified in Italy. The other three variant isolates formed a new genotype recently discovered in many countries in Western Europe. For one of these virus variants, Italy-02, which later became the prototype strain, the entire S1 gene was sequenced to confirm its originality. In contrast, phylogenetic analysis of more conserved partial N gene sequences spanning 1-300 nucleotides revealed differential clustering. Thus, three IBV variants of the new Italy-02 genotype, sharing 96.7-99.2% nucleotide identity of the S1 gene with each other, belonged to three separate subgroups based on the N gene sequences. The 624/I-type isolate Italy-06 along with Italy-03, which was undetectable using S1 gene primers, shared 97.7% and 99.3% identity in the N gene region, respectively, with vaccine strain H120. Only one of the 793/B type isolates, Italy-10, clustered with the 793/B strain, which had 99.3% partial N gene identity, while the other four isolates were genetically distant from them ( only 87.7–89.7% identity) and formed separate homogeneous subgroups. The results indicated that both mutational and recombination events could contribute to the genetic diversity of the Italian isolates. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bochkov, Y. A.;Tosi, G.;Massi, P.;Drygin, V. V.

title: Basic research on the transmission of BSE to humans
abstract: Prion diseases in animals and humans belong to the group of neurological diseases with amyloid deposits of the corresponding proteins. Regarding prion disease, the cellular prion protein in its abnormal isoform(s) is an essential component of prion protein aggregates found in affected tissues. In contrast to all neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease or Huntington's disease, prion diseases are transmissible. Therefore, prion diseases have been termed transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSE). The diseases have been known for decades. Scrapie was first described around 1750, a case of BSE was reported in 1850, most likely a misdiagnosis, and human Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) was described in 1920/1930. Transmission of CJD dh kuru was suspected in the early 1950s and incorrectly classified as a slow viral disease. CJD transmission posed a problem for people when transplants from CJD cases were used for treatment. Fortunately, these iatrogenic transmissions have remained limited. But with the rise of BSE and the emergence of CJD cases in the UK and some places in Europe, scientists suspected that bovine-to-human transmission may have occurred. From animal models we know of successful transmission via multiple pathways. Species barriers do not completely prevent transmission. Rather, barriers to transmission may exist that control individual susceptibility to prions. Pathways of transmission, susceptibility to transmission, identification of receptor molecules and molecular mechanisms of the transmission process are being intensively investigated. The current state of knowledge suggests that inapparent stages of prion infection simulate a (nonexistent) species barrier. This inapparent infection precedes overt disease, and therefore most research has focused on the development of highly sensitive test systems to detect minute amounts of pathological prion protein in suspected cases. The no-show should also warn us not to underestimate cases of BSE or human vCJD; currently 124 in Europe and a probable case in Hong Kong (7 March 2002). Whether BSE has spread to other parts of the world through animal food components or meat can neither be ruled out nor confirmed at this time. New data on the transmission and impact of BSE on the human population are summarized in this review.
authors: Bodemer, W.;Kaup, F. J.

title: Comments on the contemporary distribution and epidemiology of BSE and prion diseases
abstract: Prion diseases in animals and humans are neurological diseases with amyloid deposition of the corresponding proteins. Regarding prion disease, the cellular prion protein in its abnormal isoform(s) is an essential component of prion protein aggregates found in affected tissues. In contrast to all neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease or Huntington's disease, prion diseases are transmissible. Therefore, prion diseases have been termed transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSE). The diseases have been known for decades. Scrapie was first described around 1750, a case of BSE was reported in the 1850s, most likely a misdiagnosis, and human Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) was described in 1920/1930. Transmission of CJD dh kuru was suspected as early as the early 1950s and incorrectly classified as a slow viral disease. CJD transmission posed a problem for people when transplants from CJD cases were used for treatment. Fortunately, these iatrogenic transmissions have remained limited. But with the rise of BSE and the emergence of CJD cases in the UK and some places in Europe, scientists suspected that bovine-to-human transmission may have occurred. From animal models we know of successful transmission via multiple pathways. Species barriers do not completely prevent transmission. Rather, barriers to transmission may exist that control individual susceptibility to prions. Pathways of transmission, susceptibility to transmission, identification of receptor molecules and molecular mechanisms of the transmission process are being intensively investigated. Based on the current state of knowledge, we assume that inapparent stages of prion infection incorrectly indicate a (nonexistent) species barrier. This inapparent infection precedes overt disease, and therefore most research has focused on the development of highly sensitive test systems to detect minute amounts of pathological prion protein in suspected cases. The no-show should also warn us not to underestimate cases of BSE or human vCJD; currently about 145 cases have occurred in Europe and a probable case in Hong Kong (June 2003). Whether BSE has spread to other parts of the world through animal food components or meat can neither be ruled out nor confirmed at this time. New data on the transmission and impact of BSE on the human population are summarized in this review. © Georg Thieme Verlag Stuttgart.
authors: Bodemer, W.;Kaup, F. J.

title: Novel viruses in birds: fly through the ceiling or does it need a cage? Verification
abstract: Emerging viral diseases continue to have a major global impact on humans and animals. In order to be able to take appropriate measures in the event of an outbreak of a newly emerging disease, rapid detection of the pathogen is a crucial first step. In this Review, various aspects of virus discovery are discussed, with a particular focus on recently discovered viruses in birds. Novel viruses with potentially large impacts have been discovered in domestic and wild bird species in recent years using various virus detection methods. Few studies report the detection of novel viruses in endangered bird species, although it is important to gain more knowledge about the viruses circulating in these species. Additional studies that focus on the precise role of a novel virus in disease and on the impact of a novel virus on bird populations are often lacking. Obtaining useful information about the role of these novel viruses requires intensive collaboration between different disciplines.
authors: Bodewes, R.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis of faeces from wild small carnivores
abstract: Background: Recent studies have clearly demonstrated the enormous variety of viruses in wild animals. This highlights the need to expand our knowledge of the diversity of viruses present in wild animals and the possible transmission of these viruses to domestic animals or humans. methods. In the present study, we assessed the viral diversity of fecal samples (n = 42) from 10 different species of wild small carnivores living in the northern part of Spain using random PCR in combination with next-generation sequencing. Samples of American mink (Neovison vison), European mink (Mustela lutreola), European polecat (Mustela putorius), European pine marten (Martes martes), stone marten (Martes foina), Eurasian otter (Lutra lutra) and Eurasian badger (Meles meles ) from the family Mustelidae; common genet (Genetta genetta) of the Viverridae family; Red fox (Vulpes vulpes) of the family Canidae and European wildcat (Felis silvestris) of the family Felidae. Results: A number of sequences of possible new viruses or virus variants were detected, including a theilovirus, phleboviruses, an amdovirus, a kobuvirus and picobirnaviruses. Conclusions: Using random PCR in combination with next-generation sequencing, sequences of different novel viruses or virus variants were detected in faecal samples from Spanish carnivores. Detected novel viruses underscore the viral diversity present in the fecal material of wild carnivores. © 2014 Bodewes et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Bodewes, R.;Ruiz-Gonzalez, A.;Schapendonk, C. M. E.;Van Den Brand, J. M. A.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;Smits, S. L.

title: Identification of several novel viruses, including a parvovirus and a hepevirus, in red fox faeces
abstract: Red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) are the most widespread members of the carnivore order. Since they often live in (peri-)urban areas, they are a potential reservoir for viruses transmitted from wild animals to humans or domestic animals. Here we assessed the faecal viral microbiome of 13 red foxes by random PCR combined with next-generation sequencing. Several new viruses including parvovirus, bocavirus, adeno-associated virus, hepevirus, astrovirus and picobirnavirus have been identified.
authors: Bodewes, R.;van der Giessen, J.;Haagmans, B. L.;Osterhaus, A. D.;Smits, S. L.

title: Spatiotemporal Analysis of the Genetic Diversity of Seal Influenza A(H10N7) Virus, Northwestern Europe
abstract: UNLABELING: Influenza A viruses are important pathogens affecting humans, domestic animals and wildlife, and these viruses occasionally cross the species barrier. In spring 2014, increased mortality in harbor seals (Phoca vitulina) associated with infection with an influenza A(H10N7) virus was reported in Sweden and Denmark. Within a few months, this virus spread to seals in the coastal waters of Germany and the Netherlands, causing the deaths of thousands of animals. Genetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of this seal influenza A(H10N7) virus revealed that it was most closely related to several avian influenza A(H10N7) viruses. The collection of samples from infected seals during the course of the outbreak provided a unique opportunity to follow the adaptation of the avian virus to its new seal host. Sequence data for samples collected between April 2014 and January 2015 from 41 different seals from four different countries were obtained by Sanger sequencing and next-generation sequencing to elucidate the molecular epidemiology of the seal influenza A(H10N7) virus describe. The majority of the sequence variations occurred in the HA gene, and some mutations corresponded to amino acid changes not found in H10 viruses isolated from Eurasian birds. In addition, the sequence variation in the HA gene was greater at the beginning than at the end of the epidemic, when a number of the mutations observed earlier had been resolved. These results imply that when an avian influenza virus crosses the species barrier from birds to seals, amino acid changes in HA can occur rapidly and are important for the virus' adaptation to its new mammalian host. IMPORTANT: Influenza A viruses are important pathogens affecting humans, domestic animals and wildlife. In addition to the continuous circulation of influenza A viruses between different host species, cross-species transmission of influenza A viruses occasionally occurs. Wild waterfowl and shorebirds are the main reservoir for most influenza A virus subtypes, and spillover of influenza A virus from birds to humans or other mammalian species can lead to larger outbreaks. In the present study, different sequencing methods were used to elucidate the genetic changes that occurred following the introduction and subsequent spread of an avian influenza A(H10N7) virus among harbor seals of northwestern Europe using different samples collected during the outbreak. Such detailed knowledge of genetic changes required for introduction and adaptation of avian influenza A viruses to mammalian hosts is important for rapid risk assessment of such viruses shortly after they have crossed the species barrier.
authors: Bodewes, R.;Zohari, S.;Krog, J. S.;Hall, M. D.;Harder, T. C.;Bestebroer, T. M.;van de Bildt, M. W. G.;Spronken, M. I.;Larsen, L. E.;Siebert, U.;Wohlsein, P.;Puff, C.;Seehusen, F.;Baumgartner, W.;Harkonen, T.;Smits, S. L.;Herfst, S.;Osterhaus, A.;Fouchier, R. A. M.;Koopmans, M. P.;Kuiken, T.

title: Outbreaks of Newcastle disease in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in 1998, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2004 and 2005 were caused by viruses of genotypes VIIb and VIId
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) infects domestic and wild birds around the world, and infections with virulent NDV strains continue to cause disease outbreaks in poultry and wild birds. To assess the evolutionary characteristics of 28 NDV strains isolated from chickens in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in 1998, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2004 and 2005, we examined the phylogenetic relationships between these viruses and the previously described viruses. For genotyping, a phylogenetic analysis of the fusion gene (F) (nucleotide number 47-421) was performed using sequences from Kazakh and Kyrgyz isolates compared to sequences from selected NDV strains from GenBank. The phylogenetic analysis showed that the 14 newly characterized strains from 1998 to 2001 belong to NDV genotype VIIb, while the 14 strains isolated between 2003 to 2005 were of genotype VIId. All strains possessed a virulent fusion protein cleavage site (RRQR/KRF) and had intracerebral pathogenicity indices in day-old chicks ranging from 1.05 to 1.87, both characteristics typical of NDV strains assigned to the mesogenic or velogenic pathotype. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bogoyavlenskiy, A.;Berezin, V.;Prilipov, A.;Usachev, E.;Lyapina, O.;Korotetskiy, I.;Zaitceva, I.;Asanova, S.;Kydyrmanov, A.;Daulbaeva, K.;Shakhvorostova, L.;Sayatov, M.;King, D.

title: Molecular characterization of virulent Newcastle disease virus isolates from chickens during the 1998 NDV outbreak in Kazakhstan
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) infects domestic and wild birds around the world and has the potential to cause outbreaks in chicken flocks in the future. To assess the evolutionary characteristics of 10 NDV strains isolated from chickens in Kazakhstan in 1998, we examined the phylogenetic relationships between these viruses and the previously described viruses. For genotyping, a phylogenetic analysis of the fusion gene (F) (nucleotide number 47-421) was performed using sequences from Kazakh isolates compared to sequences from selected NDV strains from GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all of the newly characterized strains belonged to the genetic group designated VIIb. All strains possessed a virulent fusion site (RRQRR/F) belonging to velogenous or mesogenic pathotypes with intracerebral pathogenicity indices (ICPI) from 1.05 to 1.87. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Bogoyavlenskiy, A.;Berezin, V.;Prilipov, A.;Usachev, E.;Lyapina, O.;Levandovskaya, S.;Korotetskiy, I.;Tolmacheva, V.;Makhmudova, N.;Khudyakova, S.;Tustikbaeva, G.;Zaitseva, I.;Omirtaeva, E.;Ermakova, O.;Daulbaeva, K.;Asanova, S.;Kydyrmanov, A.;Sayatov, M.;King, D.

title: Phylogenetic analyzes indicate small differences between reticuloendothelosis viruses that infect avian species, including the critically endangered Attwater prairie chicken
abstract: Reticuloendoteliosis virus infection, which typically causes systemic lymphoma and high mortality in the critically endangered Attwater prairie chickens, has been described as a major obstacle to reintroduction efforts at captive breeding facilities in Texas. Although antigenic relationships between reticuloendothelosis virus (REV) strains have been previously determined, phylogenetic relationships have not been reported. The pol and env of proviral REV DNA from prairie chickens (PC-R92 and PC-2404), poxvirus lesions in domestic chickens, prototype REV-A and chick syncytial virus (CSV) from poultry and duck-derived spleen necrosis virus ( SNV) were PCR amplified and sequenced. The 5032 bp containing the pol and most env genes from PC-R92 and REV-A were 98% identical, and the nucleotide sequence identities of smaller regions within pol and env from the REV strains examined ranged from 95 to 99% and 93 to 99%, respectively. The putative amino acid sequences were 97-99% identical in the polymerase and 90-98% identical in the envelope. Phylogenetic analyzes of nucleotide and amino acid sequences revealed the closest relationship between the newer fowlpox-associated chicken isolates, the prairie chicken isolates and the prototype CSV, while only the SNV appeared to be markedly different. While the origin of naturally occurring viruses is unknown, avipox virus can be a critical component in the transmission of these ubiquitous oncogenic viruses. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Bohls, R. L.;Linares, J. A.;Gross, S. L.;Ferro, P. J.;Silvy, N. J.;Collisson, E. W.

title: Forécariah virus, a new member of the bhanja antigen group, isolated in the Republic of Guinea
abstract: A new arbovirus named "Forécariah" was isolated from Boophylus geigy ticks in the Republic of Guinea (West Africa), Forecariah District. This virus is classified into the bhanja antigen group based on its physicochemical, biological and antigenic properties.
authors: Boiro, I.;Lomonossov, N. N.;Malenko, G. V.;Balde, C.;Bah, A.

title: Shotgun pyrosequencing, metagenomic analyzes of porcine and grain plant dusts
abstract: Inhalation of agricultural dusts causes inflammatory reactions and symptoms such as headache, fever and malaise, which can progress to chronic airway inflammation and associated diseases, e.g. B. asthma, chronic bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Although feed particles are the main component of these dusts in many agricultural settings, the inflammatory responses they produce are likely to be attributed to particle-associated bacteria, archaebacteria, fungi and viruses. In this study, we performed shotgun pyrosequencing metagenome analyzes of DNA from pig cage or grain elevator dust, with comparisons to pet-free household dust. DNA sequence alignment showed that 19% and 62% of shotgun pyrosequencing metagenomic DNA sequence readings from porcine facility and household dust were porcine and human, respectively. In contrast, only 2% of such readings came from mammalian granary dust. These mammalian metagenomic shotgun readings were excluded from our analyzes of agricultural dust microbiota. The ten most prevalent bacterial taxa identified in swine facilities compared to grain silos or household dust consisted of 75%, 16%, and 42% gram-positive organisms, respectively. Four of the five most important dust genera in pig facilities were assignable (Clostridium, Lactobacillus, Ruminococcus and Eubacterium with a relative frequency of 4% to 19%). The relative abundances of these four genera were lower in dust from grain silos or in pet-free homes. These analyzes also highlighted the prevalence of Firmicutes (70%) at the stem level, Clostridia (44%) at the class level, and Clostridiales at the order level (41%) in pig facility dust. In summary, shotgun pyrosequencing metagenome analyzes of agricultural dusts indicate that they differ qualitatively and quantitatively at the level of microbial taxa present, and that the bioinformatic analyzes used for such studies need to be carefully designed to account for the potential contribution of non-microbial DNA, e.g of resident mammals.
authors: Boissy, R. J.;Romberger, D. J.;Roughead, W. A.;Weissenburger-Moser, L.;Poole, J. A.;LeVan, T. D.

title: Genetic characterization of bovine viral diarrhea viruses isolated from persistently infected calves born to dams vaccinated against bovine viral diarrhea virus prior to breeding
abstract: Objective - To collect and partially characterize strains of bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDVs) isolated from persistently infected (PI) calves of vaccinated dams, determine the genetic diversity of the isolated viruses, and identify the regional distribution of genetically similar virus subpopulations. Sample population - 17 non-cytopathic (NCP) BVDVs from PI calves from 11 beef or dairy herds. Methods - Viral RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures and BVDV-specific PCR primers were used to amplify >1,000 bases of the viral genome. Deduced sequences were used for molecular phylogenetic analysis to determine viral genotype and genogroup and to assess genetic similarity between BVDVs. Results - Analysis of the 17 NCP strains of BVDV failed to detect a viral genotype or viral genogroup whose existence has not been previously reported in the United States. One virus was classified as genotype 1, genogroup 1b, and 16 viruses were classified as genotype 2, genogroup 2a. Genotype 2 strains were genetically diverse, and genetic similarities were not apparent between viruses from geographic regions larger than a small locality. CONCLUSIONS AND CLINICAL RELEVANCE - Viruses isolated from flocks given a genotype 1, genogroup 1a BVDV vaccine prior to breeding were mainly genetically distinct genotype 2, genogroup 2a BVDV. Vaccination with multiple BVDV genotypes may be required to improve protection. The field strain extraction and analysis methods used in this study are applicable to the evaluation of the efficacy of current BVDV vaccines. Candidates for future vaccines are viruses that appear to be able to evade the immune response of cattle vaccinated against BVDV with existing vaccines.
authors: Bolin, S. R.;Lim, A.;Grotelueschen, D. M.;McBeth, W. W.;Cortese, V. S.

title: Prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus genotypes and antibodies against these viral genotypes in fetal bovine serum
abstract: One thousand lots of pooled fetal bovine serum (FBS) were tested for bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) contamination and/or for contamination with neutralizing antibodies to BVDV. Non-cytopathic or cytopathic BVDV was isolated from 203 FBS lots. Analysis of the viral isolates identified 115 type 1 and 65 type 2 BVDV isolates. A further 23 virus isolates were mixtures of > or = 2 BVDV isolates and were not assigned to the viral genotype. Further characterization of type 1 viruses identified 51 BVDV isolates of subgenotype 1a and 64 subgenotype 1b. Virus neutralizing antibodies were detected in 113 FBS batches. Differential viral neutralization showed that BVDV type 1 induces the antibody detected in 48 FBS lots and BVDV type 2 induces the antibody detected in 16 FBS lots.
authors: Bolin, S. R.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Unexpected diversity and expression of avian endogenous retroviruses
abstract: Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) were identified and characterized in three avian genomes to gain insight into early retroviral evolution. Using the RetroTector computer program to detect relatively intact ERVs, we identified 500 ERVs in the chicken genome, 150 in the turkey genome, and 1,200 in the zebra finch genome. Previous studies suggested that endogenous alpharetroviruses were present in chicken genomes. In this analysis, a small number of alpharetroviruses were seen in the genomes of chickens and turkeys; However, these were vastly outnumbered by beta-like, gamma-like, and alphabeta proviruses. While the avian ERVs belonged to the same major groups as the mammalian ERVs, they were more heterogeneous. The beta-like viruses in particular showed an evolutionary continuum with the gradual acquisition and loss of beta-retroviral markers and a transition from beta- to alpha- and then to alpha-retroviruses. Therefore, birds appear to resemble a melting pot for early ERV evolution. Many of the ERVs were integrated in clusters on chromosomes, often near centromeres. About 25% of chicken ERVs were located in or near cellular transcription units; that's almost random. The majority of these integrations were in terms of orientation in introns. A higher than random number of integrations were >100 kb from the nearest gene. Deep sequencing studies of chick embryo fibroblasts revealed that approximately 20% of the 500 ERVs were transcribed and translated. A subset of these was also transcribed in vivo in chickens and showed tissue-specific expression patterns. SIGNIFICANCE Studies on avian endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) have given us a glimpse into an earlier retroviral world. Three distinct classes of ERVs have been observed, with many of the characteristics of mammalian retroviruses and some important differences. Many avian ERVs have been transcribed and translated.
authors: Bolisetty, M.;Blomberg, J.;Benachenhou, F.;Sperber, G.;Beemon, K.

title: Avian host range of avipoxviruses
abstract: An overview of the occurrence of smallpoxviruses in different bird species is given. The first publications appeared in Europe around 1850. At that time smallpox was diagnosed as a clear disease entity on the basis of clinical signs, while later the detection of Bollinger inclusion bodies (1877) enabled an etiological diagnosis through microscopically visible virus aggregates. Virus isolation in embryonated chicken eggs and direct electron microscopy gained prominence as diagnostic tools in the 1950s. Also briefly described is avipoxvirus taxonomy, virus characteristics, clinical signs, types of prevention, and diagnostic procedures. Of the approximately 9000 bird species, approximately 232 species in 23 orders have been reported to have acquired natural smallpox virus infection. However, it is likely that many more birds are susceptible to avipoxviruses.
authors: Bolte, A. L.;Meurer, J.;Kaleta, E. F.

title: Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus and discovery of a recombinant porcine enteric coronavirus, Italy
abstract: Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) has been detected sporadically in Italy since the 1990s.
