We report the phylogenetic relatedness of porcine enteric coronaviruses collected in Italy between 2007 and 2014 and identify a drastic change in PEDV strain variability and a new porcine enteric coronavirus arising from recombination of transmissible gastroenteritis virus and PEDV .
authors: Boniotti, M. B.;Papetti, A.;Lavazza, A.;Alborali, G.;Sozzi, E.;Chiapponi, C.;Faccini, S.;Bonilauri, P.;Cordioli, P.;Marthaler, D.

title: Sequence comparison of the L2 and S10 genes of bluetongue viruses from the United States and the People's Republic of China
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) infection of ruminants is endemic in much of the United States and China. The S10 and part of the L2 gene segments of Chinese prototype strains of BTV serotypes 1, 2, 3, 4, 12, 15 and 16 were sequenced and compared to the same genes from prototype and field strains of BTV from the USA. Phylogenetic analysis of the S10 gene separated the Chinese viruses into a monophyletic group distinct from the US viruses, while similar analysis of the L2 gene separated strains of BTV by serotype regardless of geographic origin. Copyright (C) 1999 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Bonneau, K. R.;Zhang, N.;Zhu, J.;Zhang, F.;Li, Z.;Zhang, K.;Xiao, L.;Xiang, W.;MacLachlan, N. J.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of orfviruses isolated from outbreaks in goats in Assam, a northeastern state of India
abstract: Two outbreaks of Orf virus (ORFV) (a parapoxvirus) infection in goats occurring in Golaghat and Kamrup districts in Assam, a north-eastern part of India, were investigated. The disease was diagnosed using standard virological and molecular techniques. The entire protein coding region of the B2L gene from two isolates has been cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis based on B2L amino acid sequences showed that the ORFVs identified in these outbreaks were closely related and both were closer to the ORFV Shahjahanpur 82/04 isolate from North India. The present study found that the precise characterization of the genomic region (B2L gene) could provide clues to the genetic variation and movement of circulating ORFV strains in India. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Bora, D. P.;Barman, N. N.;Das, S. K.;Bhanuprakash, V.;Yogisharadhya, R.;Venkatesan, G.;Kumar, A.;Rajbongshi, G.;Khatoon, E.;Chakraborty, A.;Bujarbaruah, K. M.

title: Isolation and molecular characterization of orf virus from natural outbreaks in Assam goats
abstract: Outbreaks of contagious ecthyma (caused by a parapox virus) in goats were investigated in 6 districts of Assam, a northeastern state of India. Diagnosis of the disease was carried out using both standard virological and molecular methods. Four representative isolates from different localities were selected for phylogenetic analysis. The orf virus major envelope protein (B2L) was selected for molecular analysis. Sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the selected sequences at the nucleotide level revealed that the orf virus isolates were closely related (97.6-100%) and the highest similarity to the orf virus isolate 82/04 (98.4% ) reported from Shahjahanpur, India. The data will provide insight into the transmission of the virus from the north to the north-east of the country.
authors: Bora, M.;Bora, D. P.;Barman, N. N.;Borah, B.;Bora, P. L.;Talukdar, A.;Tamuly, S.

title: Physicochemical and morphological relationships of some arthropod-transmitted viruses to bluetongue virus - a new taxonomic group. Physiocochemical and serological studies
authors: Borden, E. C.;Shope, R. E.;Murphy, F. A.

title: Outbreaks of neuroinvasive astrovirus associated with encephalomyelitis, weakness and paralysis in weaned pigs, Hungary
abstract: large, highly productive pig farm in Hungary had a 2-year history of neurological disease in weanling (25-35 day old) pigs with clinical signs of posterior paraplegia and a high mortality rate. Affected pigs that were dissected had encephalomyelitis and neural necrosis. Porcine astrovirus type 3 was identified by reverse transcription PCR and in situ hybridization in brain and spinal cord samples from 6 animals from this farm. Among the tissues tested by quantitative RTPCR, the highest viral loads were detected in the brainstem and spinal cord. A similar type 3 porcine astrovirus was also identified in archived brain and spinal cord samples from two other geographically distant farms. Viral RNA was predominantly restricted to neurons, particularly in the brainstem, cerebellum (Purkinje cells), and cervical spinal cord. Astrovirus was generally undetectable in feces but was present in respiratory specimens, suggesting possible respiratory infection. Astrovirus could cause a common, neuroinvasive epidemic.
authors: Boros, A.;Albert, M.;Pankovics, P.;Biro, H.;Pesavento, P. A.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Identification and full genome characterization of a novel picornavirus in Turkey (Meleagris gallopavo)
abstract: Members of the Picornaviridae family are important human and animal pathogens, although few (n = 11) picornaviruses have been identified from avian sources compared to the thousands of known bird species (>10 000). This study reports metagenomic detection and full genome characterization of a novel turkey picornavirus from fecal samples collected from eight turkey farms in Hungary. Using RT-PCR, both healthy (two out of three) and diseased (seven out of eight) commercial turkeys with enteric and/or growth retardation syndrome shed virus in seven (88%) of the eight farms. The viral genome sequence (turkey/M176/2011/HUN; GenBank Accession No. JQ691613) shows a high degree of amino acid sequence identity (96%) with the partial P3 genomic region of a picornavirus recently reported in turkey and chickens from the USA and probably belongs to the same species. In regions P1 and P2, turkey/M176/2011/HUN is most closely related to, but distinct from, kobuviruses and turdivirus 1. A full genome analysis revealed the presence of distinctive picornavirus amino acid motifs, a potential type II-like 5â€² UTR internal ribosome entry site (first identified in picornaviruses of avian origin), and a conserved 48 nt "dumbbell-like" structure located at the 3rd -inch UTR of turkey/M176/2011/HUN and members of the picornavirus genera Avihepatovirus and Kobuvirus. The general occurrence of turkey picornavirus - a new species of picornavirus - in fecal samples from healthy and diseased turkeys in Hungary and the US indicates the worldwide occurrence and endemic spread of this virus in turkey farms. Further studies are needed to investigate the etiological role and pathogenic potential of this picornavirus in livestock. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Boros, A.;Nemes, C.;Pankovics, P.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Genetic characterization of a novel turkey picornavirus (Meleagris gallopavo) distinct from turkey galliviruses and megriviruses and distantly related to members of the genus Avihepatovirus
abstract: This study reports the metagenomic detection and full genome characterization of a novel turkey picornavirus from fecal samples from healthy (1/3) and affected (6/8) commercial turkeys with enteric and/or growth disorders in Hungary. The virus was detected in seven of the eight farms examined. The turkey/M176-TuASV/2011/HUN genome (KC465954) was genetically distinct from the currently known picornaviruses of turkey origin (megriviruses and galliviruses), showing distant phylogenetic relatedness and shared genomic features (e.g., uncleaved VP0 and three predicted and unrelated 2A). Polypeptides) against duck hepatitis A virus (DHAV) of the genus Avihepatovirus. Full genome analysis revealed several distinct genomic features such as the presence of two aphthovirus 2A-like sequence repeats in a row with DxExNPG/P ribosome skipping sites (76%, 23/30 amino acids identical), the first being aphthovirus 2A-like sequence, located at the end of the VP1 capsid protein (VP1/2A1 'ribosome-skipping' site). The phylogenetic analyses, the low sequence identity (33, 32 and 36% amino acid identity in the P1, P2 and P3 regions) to DHAV and the type II-like internal ribosome entry site suggest that this turkey picornavirus is related, but differs from it differs from the genus Avihepatovirus, and it may be the founding member of a novel Avihepatovirus sister-clade genus. This is the third taxonomically most distinct picornavirus clade identified in turkeys with distinct symptoms. © 2013 SGM.
authors: Boros, A.;Nemes, C.;Pankovics, P.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: A diarrheal chicken infected simultaneously with multiple picornaviruses: complete genome analysis of avian picornaviruses representing up to six genera
abstract: In this study, all currently known chicken picornaviruses including a new one (chicken phacovirus 1, KT880670) were identified by viral metagenomics and RT-PCR methods from a single sample from a diarrheal chicken suffering from a total of eight picornavirus coinfections in Hungary. The complete genomes of six picornaviruses were determined and their genomic and phylogenetic properties as well as structural UTR-RNA models analyzed in detail. Picornaviruses belonged to the genera Sicinivirus (the first complete genome), Gallivirus, Tremovirus, Avisivirus and "Orivirus" (two potential genotypes). In addition, the unassigned phacoviruses were also detected in several samples from chickens in the United States. Multiple co-infections promote and facilitate picornavirus recombination and evolution and may eventually contribute to the severity of diarrhea in chickens, one of the most important human food sources.
authors: Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Adonyi, Ã;Fenyvesi, H.;Day, J. M.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Genome characterization of a novel chicken picornavirus distantly related to members of the genus Avihepatovirus, with a single 2A protein and a Megrivirus-like 3' UTR
abstract: Members of the genus Avihepatovirus and related picornaviruses ("Aalivius") of duck, turkey and chicken possess an identical 2A peptide composition including three functionally unrelated 2A peptides, which is a characteristic genomic feature of these monophyletic avian picornaviruses. The complete genome of a novel picornavirus provisionally named Orivirus A1 (KM203656) from a cloacal sample of a 4-week-old diarrheic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) distantly related to members of the genus Avihepatovirus has been characterized. The study strain contains a type II-like IRES, a single 2A protein of unknown function unrelated to the avihepatovirus 2A proteins, and a long 3' untranslated region (UTR) with multiple repeated sequence motifs followed by an AUG-rich region. The repeated sequences of the 3' UTR show significant identity with the "unit A" sequences of phylogenetically distant Megriviruses. The presence of a new single 2A and the megrivirus-like "unit A" motif suggests multiple recombination events in the evolution of this new picornavirus.
authors: Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Adonyi, Ã;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Comparative whole genome analysis of chicken and turkey megriviruses (family Picornaviridae): long 3'-untranslated regions with a potential second open reading frame and evidence for possible recombination
abstract: UNLABELING: Members of the family Picornaviridae are small, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA (+ssRNA) viruses that can infect various vertebrate species, including birds. One of the recently identified avian picornaviruses with a remarkably long (>9,040 nucleotides) but still incompletely sequenced genome is turkey hepatitis virus 1 (THV-1; species Melegrivirus A, genus Megrivirus), a virus associated with liver necrosis and Enteritis has been implicated in commercial turkeys (Meleagris gallopavo). This report presents the results of genetic analysis of three complete genomes of megriviruses from fecal samples from chickens (chicken/B21-CHV/2012/HUN, GenBank accession number KF961186, and chicken/CHK-IV-CHV/2013/HUN, GenBank accession number KF961187) (Gallus gallus domesticus) and turkey (Turkey/B407-THV/2011/HUN, GenBank Accession No. KF961188) (Meleagris gallopavo) with the largest picornavirus genome described to date (up to 9,739 nucleotides). The close phylogenetic relationship to THV-1 in the non-structural protein coding region of the genome and the possession of the same type of internal ribosomal entry site (IVB-like) suggest that the study strains belong to the genus Megrivirus. However, the genome comparisons revealed numerous unique variations (e.g. different numbers of potential 2A peptides, unusually long 3' genome parts with different lengths of a potential second open reading frame, and multiple repeating sequence motifs in the 3' untranslated region) and heterogeneity between sequence relationships the structural and non-structural regions of the genome. These differences suggest the classification of chicken Megrivirus-like viruses into a new candidate species in the genus Megrivirus. Based on the different phylogenetic positions of chicken Megrivirus-like viruses in the structural and non-structural regions of the genome, the recombinant nature of these viruses is plausible. IMPORTANCE: Comparative genomic analysis of turkey and novel chicken Megriviruses revealed numerous unique genomic features, e.g. heterogeneous sequence relationships (possibly due to a recombination event) between the structural and non-structural regions of the genome. Our results could help us to better understand the evolution and diversity (in terms of sequence and genome layout) of picornaviruses.
authors: Boros, A.;Pankovics, P.;Knowles, N. J.;Nemes, C.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Genomic analysis of a novel picornavirus from a migratory waterbird, the barnacle goose (Anser albifrons)
abstract: The complete genome of goose picornavirus 1 (GPV-1) strain Goose/NLSZK2/HUN/2013 (MF358731) was identified by RT-PCR and next-generation sequencing from a cloacal sample of a migratory waterbird, the bald headed goose (Anser albifrons) in Hungary. The genome of GPV-1 shows an L-3-3-4 organizational pattern with a 5'-terminal origin of replication (ORI) region, a type IV IRES and a Hbox/NC type 2A protein. This virus showed the highest overall sequence identity to members of the genus Kobuvirus, although the phylogenetic position of GPV-1 differs in the P1, 2C, and 3CD phylogenetic trees analyzed, further increasing the diversity of known avian picornaviruses.
authors: Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Simmonds, P.;Kiss, T.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Multiple divergent picobirnaviruses with functional prokaryotic Shine-Dalgarno ribosome binding sites present in a diarrheal chicken cloacal sample
abstract: Picobirnaviruses (PBVs) of the family Picobirnaviridae have bisegmented (S1 and S2 segments), double-stranded RNA genomes. In this study, a total of N=12 complete chicken PBVs (ChPBV) segments (N=5 from S1 and N=7 from S2, Acc. No.: MH425579-90) were isolated using viral metagenomic and RT-PCR techniques a Single cloacal sample from a chicken suffering from diarrhea. The identified ChPBV segments are unrelated and distant from all currently known PBVs. In silico sequence analyzes revealed the presence of conserved prokaryotic Shine-Dalgarno-like (SD-like) sequences upstream of the three putative open reading frames (ORFs) of the S1 segment and a single putative ORF of the S2 segments. According to the results of expression analyzes in E. coli using 6xHis-tagged ChPBV segment 1 recombinant construct and Western blot, these SD-like sequences are functional in vivo, suggesting that S1 of study PBVs may contain three ORFs and supports the bacteriophage nature of PBVs.
authors: Boros, Ã;PolgÃ¡r, B.;Pankovics, P.;Fenyvesi, H.;Engelmann, P.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Characterization of neutralization sites on circulating variant swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV): A new site is shared by SVDV and the related Coxsackie B5 virus
abstract: Using a panel of novel monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), five neutralizing, conformational sites on the antigenic variant swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) currently circulating were identified. In studies of the antigenic conservation of these sites, the four described antigenic/genetic groups of SVDV showed distinguishable patterns, supporting this classification. By sequencing mAb-resistant mutants, the five sites were accurately mapped and located on a three-dimensional model of the SVDV capsid. All were found to be oriented towards the outer surface of the capsid to varying degrees. Three of the five sites found in VP1, VP2 and VP3 correspond to epitopes previously identified in historical isolates as sites 1, 2a and 3b, respectively. Another site, site IV, which maps to position 258 of VP1, corresponds to a recently reported epitope and is described in this study as specific for isolates of the youngest antigenic group of SVDV. A fifth site is described for the first time and corresponds to the unique neutralizing site common to both SVDV and Coxsackie B5 viruses; it maps to positions 95 and 98 of VP1, but may also contain nearby positions belonging to site 1 on VP1's BC loop, suggesting the classification of site Ia. These results may have useful diagnostic and epidemiological applications, since mAbs at the new conserved site Ia provide universal reagents for SVDV detection systems, while the specificity of mAbs at site IV makes them unique markers for the youngest SVDV strains.
authors: Borrego, B.;Carra, E.;GarcÃ­a-Ranea, J. A.;Brocchi, E.

title: The role of viral population diversity in the adaptation of bovine coronavirus to new host environments
abstract: The high mutation rate of RNA viruses allows a diverse genetic population of viral genotypes to exist in a single infected host. Genetic diversity in the host could make the viral population better able to respond and adapt to a variety of selection pressures such as host switching events. Several new coronaviruses, including SARS, have been identified in human samples in just the past decade, showing the potential of coronaviruses as emerging human pathogens. Deep sequencing has been used to characterize genomic changes in coronavirus quasispecies during a simulated host transition. Three bovine coronavirus-infected bovine nasal specimens were used to infect human and bovine macrophage and lung cell lines. The virus replicated relatively well in macrophages, but the lung cell lines were not infected efficiently enough to allow passage of non-laboratory adapted samples. Approximately 12 kb of the genome was amplified before and after passage and sequenced with average coverages of nearly 950x (454 sequencing) and 38,000x (Illumina). The consensus sequence of many of the passaged samples had a 12 nucleotide insert in the consensus sequence of the spike gene, and several point mutations were associated with the presence of the insert. Deep sequencing revealed that the insert was present in the unpassaged samples but was very rare and could quickly shift to dominate the population if placed in a different environment. The insert encoding three arginine residues occurred in a region associated with fusion entry into host cells and may allow infection of new cell types via heparin sulfate binding. Analysis of the deep sequencing data showed that two distinct genotypes were circulating in each sample at different levels of abundance, and supports the hypothesis that the mutations present in passaged strains were 'selected' from a pre-existing pool and not by de novo Mutation and subsequent population fixation.
authors: Borucki, M. K.;Allen, J. E.;Chen-Harris, H.;Zemla, A.;Vanier, G.;Mabery, S.;Torres, C.;Hullinger, P.;Slezak, T.

title: Capripoxvirus vaccine against livestock diseases in Africa
abstract: Five different livestock viral diseases, lumpy skin disease (LSD), sheeppox (SPP), goatpox (GTP), Rift Valley fever (RVF) and small ruminant plague (PPR), circulate in the same regions of Africa, imposing a great burden for economic activity and public health. Although commercial vaccines against these viruses are available, the cost of implementing regular multi-disease vaccination regimens is prohibitive for most African farmers. A single, affordable, multivalent vaccine that protects against all 5 diseases simultaneously would therefore be of great benefit to the livestock industry in Africa. It could also serve as a platform for developing new vaccines of importance to other developing countries around the world. In this article we provide an overview of the economic importance of livestock farming in Africa, the pathogens responsible for RVF, PPR, SPP, GTP and LSD and the vaccination strategies currently used to combat them. We then review the experience with the development of attenuated capripoxvirus vaccines against LSD, SPP and GTP and recombinant capripoxvirus vector vaccines against RVF and PPR. We conclude the article by presenting the rationale for a single, multivalent capripoxvirus vector vaccine that would protect against all five livestock diseases and describe the approach a consortium of Canadian and South African researchers are taking to develop such a vaccine. Crown Copyright © 2013 Published by Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Boshra, H.;Truong, T.;Nfon, C.;Gerdts, V.;Tikoo, S.;Babiuk, L. A.;Kara, P.;Mather, A.;Wallace, D.;Babiuk, S.

title: Molecular Genetic Analysis of Varicella Zoster Clinical Isolates (VZV)
abstract: The varicella zoster virus (VZV) is classified in the alpha herpesvirus subfamily. The VZV genome is extremely conserved. Molecular genetics brings more information about evolutionary processes of VZV, mechanisms of infection processes of VZV and also about VZV pathogenesis. VZV causes chickenpox (varicella) in childhood and can also reactivate later in life and cause shingles (herpes zoster) in the same person. Both diseases are the same type of virus. In recent years, molecular genetic analysis methods (whole genome sequencing, microarray techniques) are helping to collect more detailed information about the VZV genome, including information about genetic recombination.
authors: BoÅ¡tÃ­kovÃ¡, V.;BoÅ¡tÃ­k, P.

title: Evidence of cross-species transmission of Astrovirus associated with ovine and bovine encephalitis
abstract: We report the identification of a neurotrophic astrovirus associated with encephalitis in a sheep. This virus is genetically almost identical to an astrovirus recently described in neurologically diseased cattle. The similarity indicates that astroviruses of the same genotype can cause encephalitis in different species.
authors: Boujon, C. L.;Koch, M. C.;Wuthrich, D.;Werder, S.;Jakupovic, D.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Genetic characterization and codon usage bias of full-length hepatitis E virus sequences shed new light on genotypic distribution, host restriction and genome evolution
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) occurs in different species and ecological niches. It has been divided into 4 major mammalian genotypes. In this study, 3 new full-length porcine HEV genomes were sequenced and the results revealed no distinct host determinant compared to human isolates belonging to the same genotype. Nucleotide composition and codon usage bias were determined to characterize HEV host restriction and genome evolution. A particular nucleotide bias was observed for A and C nucleotides in all HEV genotypes. Apart from the hypervariable region ORF1 and the overlapping region ORF2/3, no nucleotide bias was observed between the 3 codon positions. It has also been shown that CpG dinucleotides are underrepresented in HEV as in most RNA viruses. The effective number of codons used in the HEV genome was high, indicating a lack of codon bias. A correspondence analysis of the relative usage of synonymous codons was performed and showed that the evolution of HEV is not driven by geographic or host factors but is representative of HEV phylogeny. These results confirm that the evolution of the HEV genome is mainly based on mutational pressure. Natural selection, which involves, for example, fine-tuning of translational kinetics and escape from the host immune system, may also play a role in shaping the HEV genome, particularly in the hypervariable region of ORF1 and the overlapping region of ORF2/3. These regions could be involved in host restriction. Finally, this study demonstrated the need to re-evaluate the possible subtyping classification. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Bouquet, J.;Cherel, P.;Pavio, N.

title: Identical consensus sequence and conserved hepatitis E virus genomic polymorphism during controlled interspecies transmission
abstract: High-throughput sequencing of bile and feces from two pigs experimentally infected with human hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotype 3f revealed the same full-length consensus sequence as in the human sample. Twenty-nine percent of the polymorphic sites found in HEV from the human sample were conserved throughout infection of the heterologous host. Transmission of HEV quasispecies between species is the result of genomic negative selection pressure for random mutations that can be deleterious to the viral population. The intrahost nucleotide diversity of HEV was found to be in the low range of other human RNA viruses but correlated with values found for zoonotic viruses. Human-pig HEV transmission does not appear to be modulated by host-specific mutations, suggesting that adaptation is mainly regulated by environmental drivers. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Bouquet, J.;Cheval, J.;RogÃ©e, S.;Pavio, N.;Eloit, M.

title: Whole genome deep pyrosequence analysis of duck influenza A virus development in pig cells
abstract: We studied the subpopulation level evolution of a duck influenza A virus isolate during passage in porcine tracheal cells. The whole genomes of the A/mallard/Netherlands/10-Nmkt/1999 strain and its porcine cell-passaged progeny were analyzed by 454 pyrosequencing with a coverage depth of several hundred to several thousand reads at each point. This allowed the characterization of defined minority subpopulations of gene segments 2, 3, 4, 5, 7 and 8 present in the original isolate. These minority subpopulations ranged from 9.5% (for segment 2) to 46% (for segment 4) of their respective gene segments in parental stock. They were likely contributed by one or more viruses circulating in the same area, at the same time, and in the same or a sympatric host species. The minority subpopulations of segments 3, 4, and 5 died out upon viral passage in pig cells, while the minority subpopulations of segments 2, 7, and 8 completely replaced their majority counterparts. The virus passaged with porcine cells was therefore a three-segment reassortant and also contained point mutations in segments 3 and 4. The passaged virus was more homogeneous than the parental strain, with only 17 single nucleotide minority polymorphisms present overall at a frequency of over 5% of the genome . Although limited to one sample here, this deep-sequencing approach highlights the evolutionary versatility of influenza viruses, using their genetic diversity, propensity for mixed infections, and rearrangement to adapt to a new niche of the host environment.
authors: Bourret, V.;Croville, G.;Mariette, J.;Klopp, C.;Bouchez, O.;Tiley, L.;Guerin, J. L.

title: Complete genome-based molecular characterization of encephalitis-associated bovine astroviruses
abstract: Novel species of astroviruses have recently been identified in connection with bovine neurological diseases. These viruses include the Bovine Astrovirus CH13 (BoAstV CH13), which was detected in a cow with encephalitis in Switzerland. Molecular testing by a combination of reverse transcription (RT)-PCR and in situ hybridization (ISH) showed that astrovirus infection accounts for about a quarter of cases of bovine viral encephalitis of unknown etiology. However, whether these animals were infected with BoAstV CH13 or other astrovirus species had yet to be investigated. In the present study, we sequenced the entire Astrovirus genome in brain tissue from eight RT-PCR and/or ISH positive cattle. Phylogenetic comparison of the genomic RNA and the encoded non-structural and structural proteins revealed that all of these astrovirus strains were very similar to BoAstV CH13, as well as a bovine encephalitis strain (BoAstV NeuroS1) reported from the US, and differed significantly from other previously reported astroviruses . Conserved 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs) have been predicted to have distinct secondary RNA structures that likely play a role in viral RNA replication and/or protein translation. Based on these data, we propose that BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1 represents a novel genotypic species within the Mammastrovirus genus. The high degree of similarity between the strains and their relative distance to other genotype species suggest that some astroviruses have evolved to acquire factors that specifically contribute to neuroinvasion. (C) 2016 The Authors. Published by Elsevier BV
authors: Bouzalas, I. G.;Wuthrich, D.;Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Drogemuller, C.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Neurotropic astrovirus in cattle with nonsuppurative encephalitis in Europe
abstract: Encephalitis is a commonly diagnosed condition in cattle with neurological disorders. Many affected animals show a non-purulent inflammatory reaction pattern in the brain. While this pattern supports a viral etiology, the causative agent remains unknown in a large proportion of cases. Using viral metagenomics, we identified an astrovirus (bovine astrovirus [BoAstV]-CH13) in the brain of a cow with nonsuppurative encephalitis. In addition, BoAstV RNA was detected by reverse transcription PCR and in situ hybridization in about a quarter (5/22 animals) of cattle with nonsuppurative encephalitis of unknown etiology. Viral RNA was mainly found in neurons and at the site of pathology. These results support the assumption that BoAstV infection is a common cause of encephalitis in cattle. Phylogenetically, BoAstV-CH13 was closely related to rare astrovirus isolates from encephalitis cases in animals and one human patient. Future research must address the pathogenetic mechanisms, epidemiology, and potential cross-species transmission of these neurotrophic astroviruses. Copyright © 2014, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Bouzalas, I. G.;WÃ¼thrich, D.;Walland, J.;DrÃ¶gemÃ¼ller, C.;Zurbriggen, A.;Vandevelde, M.;Oevermann, A.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: A viral metagenomic approach to a non-metagenomic experiment: Mining next-generation sequencing datasets from porcine DNA identified several pigs...
authors: Bovo, S.;Mazzoni, G.;Ribani, A.;Utzeri, V. J.;Bertolini, F.

title: viral metagenomic approach to a non-metagenomic experiment: Mining next-generation sequencing datasets from porcine DNA identified several porcine parvoviruses for a retrospective assessment of viral infections
abstract: Shot-gun next generation sequencing (NGS) on whole DNA extracted from samples collected from mammals often produces reads that are not mapped to the host's reference genome (i.e., unmapped reads) and are usually identified as by-products of the experiments are discarded. In this study, we mined Ion torrent reads obtained by sequencing DNA isolated from archived blood samples from 100 performance-tested Italian large white pigs. Two reduced representation libraries were prepared from two DNA pools each constructed from 50 equimolar DNA samples. Bioinformatic analyzes were performed to identify unmapped reads on the reference pig genome obtained from the two NGS datasets. In silico analyzes included read-mapping and sequence assembly approaches for viral metagenomic analysis using the NCBI Viral Genome Resource. Our approach identified sequences matching several viruses of the Parvoviridae family: porcine parvovirus 2 (PPV2), PPV4, PPV5 and PPV6, and porcine bocavirus 1-H18 isolate (PBoV1-H18). The presence of these viruses was confirmed by PCR and Sanger sequencing of individual DNA samples. PPV2, PPV4, PPV5, PPV6, and PBoV1-H18 were all identified in samples collected in 1998-2007, 1998-2000, 1997-2000, 1998-2004, and 2003, respectively. For most of these viruses (PPV4, PPV5, PPV6 and PBoV1-H18), previous studies reported their first emergence much later (5 to more than 10 years) than our identification period and in different geographical areas. Our study provided a retrospective analysis of apparently asymptomatic parvovirus-infected pigs and provided information that may be important to define the occurrence and prevalence of different parvoviruses in southern Europe. This study demonstrated the potential of mining NGS datasets not originally derived from metagenomics experiments for viral metagenomics analysis in a livestock species.
authors: Bovo, S.;Mazzoni, G.;Ribani, A.;Utzeri, V. J.;Bertolini, F.;Schiavo, G.;Fontanesi, L.

title: Molecular characterization of Menangelvirus, a novel paramyxovirus infecting pigs, fruit bats and humans
abstract: Menangle virus (MenV), isolated in August 1997 after an outbreak of a reproductive disease in a pig pen in New South Wales, is the second previously unclassified member of the Paramyxoviridae family to be identified in Australia since 1994. Similar to Hendra virus (HeV), MenV appears to be a virus of fruit bats (fruit bats) of the genus Pteropus. No serological cross-reactivity was detected between MenV and other known paramyxoviruses, and to facilitate virus classification, a cDNA subtraction method was used to obtain virus-specific cDNA from MenV-infected cells. The cloning and sequencing of the products allowed the determination of the entire sequences of the NP, P/V, M, F and HN genes. Comparison of the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences for each gene with members of the Paramyxoviridae family, determination of the P gene mRNA editing strategy, and phylogenetic analyzes confirmed that MenV is a novel member of the Rubulavirus genus. However, the deduced protein sequence of MenV HN showed only limited sequence homology compared to binding proteins of other paramyxoviruses. Major differences within the amino acid residues considered important determinants of neuraminidase activity suggest that MenV HN is unlikely to possess the same level of neuraminidase activity characteristic of other rubulavirus and respirovirus HN proteins. © 2001 Academic Press.
authors: Bowden, T. R.;Westenberg, M.;Wang, L. F.;Eaton, B. T.;Boyle, D. B.

title: Mechanism of action of A238L: An immune evasion protein from African swine fever virus
authors: Bowick, G.

title: Analysis of the host cell differential nuclear proteome induced by attenuated and virulent hemorrhagic arenavirus infection
abstract: Arenaviruses are important emerging pathogens and include a number of hemorrhagic fever viruses that are classified as NIAID Category A Priority Pathogens and CDC Potential Biothreats. Infection of guinea pigs with New World Arenavirus Pichindé virus (PICV) was used as a level 2 biosafety model for Lassa virus. Despite continued research, little is known about the molecular basis of the pathogenesis, which has hampered the development of novel antiviral therapeutics. Modulating the host response is a potential strategy for treating infectious diseases. We have previously studied the global host response to attenuated and fatal arenavirus infections using high-throughput immunoblotting and kinomics approaches. In this report, we describe the differential nuclear proteomes of a murine cell line induced by mock infection and infection with attenuated and lethal variants of PICV, analyzed by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis. Spot identification using tandem mass spectrometry revealed the involvement of a range of proteins that regulate inflammation via possible modulation of NF-κB activity and several heterogeneous nuclear ribonuclear proteins. Pathway analysis revealed a potential role for the transcription factor XBP-1, a transcription factor involved in major histocompatibility complex II (MHC-II) expression; differential DNA binding activity was revealed by electrophoretic mobility shift assay, and differences in surface MHC II expression were seen after PICV infection. These data are consistent with the results of several previous studies and highlight potential differences between transcriptional and translational regulation. This study provides a number of differentially expressed targets for further research and suggests that key events in pathogenesis can be identified early in infection. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Bowick, G. C.;Spratt, H. M.;Hogg, A. E.;Endsley, J. J.;Wiktorowicz, J. E.;Kurosky, A.;Luxon, B. A.;Gorenstein, D. G.;Herzog, N. K.

title: Genomic sequences of prototype Australian bluetongue virus serotypes reveal global relationships and possible routes of entry into Australia
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) is transmitted by mosquitoes (Culicoides spp.). It causes disease mainly in sheep and occasionally in cattle and other species. BTV has spread to northern Europe, causing disease in sheep and cattle. The introduction of new serotypes, changes in vector species, and climate change have all contributed to these changes. Ten BTV serotypes have been isolated in Australia with no apparent associated disease. Simplified methods for preferential isolation of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) and template preparation enabled high-throughput sequencing of the 10 genome segments of all Australian BTV prototype serotypes. The phylogenetic analysis reinforced the previously characterized western and eastern topotypes, but revealed unique features of several Australian BTVs. Many of the Australian BTV genome segments (Seg-) were closely related and clustered within the eastern topotypes. A new Australian topotype for Seg-5 (NS1) was identified, with taxa spread across multiple serotypes and over time. Seg-1, -2, -3, -4, -6, -7, -9 and -10 of BTV_2_AUS_2008 were most closely related to the related segments of viruses from Taiwan and Asia and not to other Australian viruses, leading the conclusion supports that BTV_2 recently entered Australia. The Australian BTV_15_AUS_1982 prototype proved unusual among Australian BTV isolates, with Seg-3 and -8 being distantly related to other BTV sequences from all serotypes. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Boyle, D. B.;Bulach, D. M.;Amos-Ritchie, R.;Adams, M. M.;Walker, P. J.;Weir, R.

title: The evolution of human influenza A viruses from 1999 to 2006: A full genome study
abstract: Background: Knowledge of the complete genome constellation of seasonal influenza A viruses from different countries is valuable for monitoring and understanding strain evolution and migration. At present, only a few complete genome sequences of influenza A viruses from Europe are publicly available, and there are few longitudinal genome studies of human influenza A viruses. We have studied the evolution of circulating H3N2, H1N1 and H1N2 human influenza A viruses from 1999 to 2006, we have analyzed 234 Danish human influenza A viruses and characterized 24 complete genomes. Results: H3N2 was the predominant strain in Denmark during the study period, but H1N1 dominated the 2000-2001 season. H1N2 viruses were first observed in Denmark in 2002-2003. After years of little genetic change in the H1N1 viruses, the 2005-2006 season revealed H1N1 with greater variability than before. This indicates that H1N1 viruses are evolving and that H1N1 is likely to be the dominant strain again soon. In general, the influenza A hemagglutinin (HA) of H3N2 viruses formed seasonal phylogenetic clusters. Different lineages have also been observed circulating together within the same season. Evolution has been stochastic, influenced by small "jumps" in genetic distance rather than constant drift, particularly with the introduction of the Fujian-like viruses in 2002-2003. Evolutionary periods of stasis have also been observed, which may indicate well-suited viruses. The evolution of H3N2 viruses was also influenced by gene reassortments between lineages from different seasons. None of the influenza genes were affected by strong positive selection pressure. Antigenic site B in H3N2 HA was the preferred site for genetic alterations during the study period, probably because site A was masked by glycosylation. Substitutions at CTL epitopes in the genes encoding neuraminidase (NA), polymerase acidic protein (PA), matrix protein 1 (M1), nonstructural protein 1 (NS1), and particularly the nucleoprotein (NP) have been observed. The N-linked glycosylation pattern varied over the study period and the H3N2 isolates from 2004 to 2006 were highly glycosylated with ten predicted sequences in HA, the highest level of glycosylation observed in this study period. Conclusion: The present study is, to our knowledge, the first to characterize the evolution of complete genomes of influenza A H3N2, H1N1, and H1N2 isolates from Europe over a seven-year period from 1999-2006. More accurate knowledge of the circulating strains could have implications for predicting the following season's strains and thus for better matching of vaccine composition.
authors: Bragstad, K.;Nielsen, L. P.;Fomsgaard, A.

title: Genomic evolution of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) isolates revealed by deep sequencing
abstract: Most studies on the development of PRRSV have been limited to a specific region of the viral genome. A thorough genome-wide understanding of the impact of different mechanisms on shaping PRRSV genetic diversity is still lacking. For this purpose, deep sequencing was used to obtain genomic sequences of a diverse set of 16 isolates from a Hong Kong region with a complex epidemiological record of PRRSV. Genome assemblies and phylogenetic typing revealed the co-circulation of strains of both genotypes (type 1 and type 2) with different Nsp2 deletion patterns and different evolutionary lineages ("high fever"-like and local endemic type). Recombination analyzes revealed genomic breakpoints in both structural and non-structural regions of the genomes of both genotypes, with evidence for many recombination events originating from a common ancestor. In addition, the high coverage per nucleotide allowed the characterization of smaller variants arising from the quasi-species of each strain. Overall, 0.56-2.83% of the sites turned out to be polymorphic with respect to related consensus genomes. The distribution of minor variants across each genome was not uniform, indicating the influence of selective forces. The proportion of variants capable of causing an amino acid change in their respective codons ranged between 25-67%, with many predicted to be non-detrimental. Low-frequency quenching variants have also been discovered, presenting a possible mechanism for their sudden occurrence, as mentioned in previous reports.
authors: Brar, M. S.;Shi, M.;Hui, R. K.;Leung, F. C.

title: Border disease in cattle
abstract: Within the family Flaviviridae, viruses within the genus Pestivirus, such as border disease virus (BDV) of sheep, can cause large economic losses in livestock. Originally, the taxonomic classification of pestiviruses was based on the host species from which they were isolated, but many pestiviruses are now known to exhibit broad species tropism. This review provides an overview of BDV infection in cattle. The clinical, haematological and pathological-anatomical findings in cattle transiently or permanently infected with BDV are broadly similar to those of cattle infected with the closely related pestivirus Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV). Accordingly, diagnosis of BDV infection can be difficult as it must be distinguished from various bovine pestiviruses. The latter is very relevant in countries with control programs to eradicate BVDV in bovids, since in most cases pestivirus infections in sheep, which serve as reservoirs for BDV, are not included in the eradication programme. Transmission of BDV between sheep and cattle occurs regularly, but BDV in cattle appears to be of little general concern. Nonetheless, BDV outbreaks at farm or local level can be very costly.
authors: Braun, U.;Hilbe, M.;Peterhans, E.;Schweizer, M.

title: Characterization and transmission of swine influenza virus (H1N2) in ferrets, Chile
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of the influenza hemagglutinin (HA) gene has suggested that commercial pigs in Chile harbor unique human seasonal H1-like influenza viruses, but further information, including characterization of these viruses, was not available. We isolated influenza virus (H1N2) from a pig in a backyard production farm in central Chile and showed that the HA gene was identical to that in a previous report. Its HA and neuraminidase genes were most similar to human H1 and N2 viruses from the early 1990s, and the inner segments resembled influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. The virus replicated efficiently in vitro and in vivo and was transmitted in ferrets by droplet infection. Antigenic it differed from other swine viruses. Analysis of hemagglutination inhibition suggested that antibody titers against the Chilean swine H1N2 virus were reduced in those born after 1990. Further studies are needed to characterize the potential human risk and ecology of swine influenza in South America.
authors: Bravo-Vasquez, N.;Karlsson, E. A.;Jimenez-Bluhm, P.;Meliopoulos, V.;Kaplan, B.;Marvin, S.;Cortez, V.;Freiden, P.;Beck, M. A.;Hamilton-West, C.;Schultz-Cherry, S.

title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Circoviridae
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes viruses with small, circular, single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genomes, including the smallest known animal viruses. Members of this family are divided into two genera, circovirus and cyclovirus, distinguished by the position of the origin of replication relative to the coding regions and the length of the intergenic regions. Within each genus, the species delimitation threshold is 80% genome-wide nucleotide sequence identity. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the taxonomy of the Circoviridae, available at www.ictv.global/report/circoviridae.
authors: Breitbart, M.;Delwart, E.;Rosario, K.;Segales, J.;Varsani, A.

title: Shotgun metagenomics of biological dyes with ultra-deep DNA sequencing
abstract: Detailed molecular analysis of blood or other biological evidence at a crime scene is often hampered by the low quantity and quality of extractable DNA. In most cases, however, determining the origin and composition of a stain is a prerequisite for the final clarification of criminal proceedings. standard methods, e.g. B. Amplification of DNA followed by microsatellite typing or mitochondrial DNA sequencing, are often not sensitive enough to provide sufficient and conclusive data. We applied ultra-deep DNA sequencing using 454 pyrosequencing technology to a whole genome amplification (WGA) environmental biology stain that was unsuccessfully analyzed using standard post-WGA methods. However, with the combination of WGA and 454 pyrosequencing, we were able to generate 7242 individual sequences with an average length of 195 bp. A total of 1,441,971 bp DNA sequences were generated and compared to public DNA sequence databases. Using RepeatMasker and BLAST (Basic Logical Alignment Search Tool) searches against known microbial and mammalian genomes, it was possible to determine the metagenomic composition of the dye, ie 4.2% bacterial DNA, 0.3% viral DNA, 2,7 % fungal DNA, 10.3% repetitive mammalian DNA, 0.9% porcine DNA, 0.13% human DNA and 81.5% DNA of unknown origin. Our data show that 454 pyrosequencing has the potential to become a powerful tool not only in basic research but also in metagenomic analysis of biological trace materials for forensic genetics. © 2009 Elsevier Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Brenig, B.;Beck, J.;SchÃ¼tz, E.

title: A proposal for a common nomenclature for viral clades constituting the Varicella zoster virus species: Summary of the 2008 VZV Nomenclature Meeting, Barts and the London School of Medicine and Dentistry, 24-25. July 2008
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the causative agent of chickenpox and zoster, was the first human herpesvirus to be fully sequenced and the first for which vaccines were approved and widely used. Three groups have published genotyping schemes based on single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and identified five distinct phylogenetic clades between them, with two additional putative clades. The sequencing of over 23 complete VZV genomes from around the world further refined the phylogenetic distinctions between SNP genotypes. Widespread surveillance in countries where the varicella vaccine is now used and the difficulties arising from three unique genotyping approaches prompted an international meeting where a common nomenclature based on phylogenetic clades was agreed. In this article we review the original genotyping schemes and discuss the basis for a new common nomenclature for VZV strains. We propose a minimum set of SNPs that we recommend for genotyping these viruses. Finally, we propose criteria by which novel clades can be recognized.
authors: Breuer, J.;Grose, C.;Norberg, P.;Tipples, G.;Schmid, D. S.

title: Sequencing of the nucleocapsid protein gene of porcine epidemic diarrhea virus confirms that this virus is a coronavirus related to human coronavirus 229E and porcine transmissible gastroenteritis virus
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of 1.7 kbp cDNA encompassing the region closest to the 3' end of the porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) genome was independently determined for two European isolates of PEDV. Almost identical results were obtained for the two isolates derived from cases of PEDV infection in Belgium and Great Britain in 1977 and 1987, respectively. The sequences contained an open reading frame (ORF) of 1323 nucleotides (nt) that showed moderate identity with the nucleocapsid (N) gene of other coronaviruses. The closest similarity, both at the nucleic acid and protein levels, was to human coronavirus 229E. However, the PEDV-N gene was significantly larger than that of human 229E and swine transmissible gastroenteritis viruses. This reflects the presence of a putative insertion of approximately 135 nt located towards the middle of the N gene. A second 336 nt ORF, possibly encoding a leucine-rich protein similar to but shorter than the bovine coronavirus internal protein, was found in the PEDV-N gene. Several RNA motifs typical of coronaviruses have also been observed. These results confirm the earlier preliminary classification of PEDV as a coronavirus.
authors: Bridgen, A.;Duarte, M.;Tobler, K.;Laude, H.;Ackermann, M.

title: WHO expert consultation on rabies
authors: Briggs, D.;Bourhy, H.;Cleaveland, S.;Cliquet, F.;Ertl, H.;Fayaz, A.;Fooks, A.;Hemachudha, T.;Ichhpujani, R. L.;Kaboyo, W. R.;Koprowski, H.;Madhusudana, S. N.;MÃ¼ller, T.;Nel, L.;Quiambao, B.;Rupprecht, C. E.;Salahuddin, N.;Sudarshan, M. K.;Tordo, N.;Wandeler, A. I.;Wilde, H.;Cliquet, F.;Spinola, F.;Belotto, A.;Bhatia, R.;Endo, H.;Ganter, B.;Gibert, R.;Grachev, V.;Knezevic, I.;Mc Adams, D.;Meslin, F. X.;Miranda, E.;Morgeaux, S.;Roungou, J. B.

title: Prberprüfung der weltweiten Verbreitung des Maul- und Klauenseuche-Virus von 2007 bis 2014
abstract: The foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus affects farm animals worldwide. There are seven different serotypes, each with a variety of topotypes, genetic lines, and strains. Some lineages have distinct characteristics that can contribute to sporadic spread beyond their recognized endemic areas. The aim of this study was to review the main epidemiological events of FMD that occurred worldwide between 2007 and 2014. Serious epidemics caused by O/Asia/Mya-98 lineage foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) in Japan and South Korea in 2010 were previously disease-free. In India, where FMD is endemic, the most important event was the reappearance in 2008 of the O/ME-SA/Ind-2001 lineage. Remarkably, this lineage, usually restricted to India, Bangladesh, Nepal and Bhutan, was also found in Saudi Arabia and Libya in 2013 and caused multiple outbreaks in Tunisia and Algeria in 2014-2015. In January 2011, FMD-positive wild boar were found in Bulgaria, where the disease was last seen in 1996, followed by 12 outbreaks in livestock infected with FMD O/ME-SA/PanAsia2. In 2012, FMDV SAT2 caused outbreaks in Egypt and the Palestinian Territories. Another significant event was the appearance of FMDV Asia1 Sindh-08 in the Middle East. In South America, an outbreak of FMD serotype O, topotype Euro-SA, was reported in Paraguay in 2011, which was then vaccinated to be FMD-free. Lessons learned from past events point to the need for an integrated strategy that includes coordinated global and regional efforts to control and monitor FMD. Specific local characteristics related to the host, environment and virus that condition the occurrence of FMD should be carefully considered and taken into account to adapt appropriate strategies into local plans. In this overview we have compiled relevant epidemiological FMD events to provide a global overview of the current situation. In addition, we discussed current challenges in various MKS areas.
authors: Brito, B. P.;Rodriguez, L. L.;Hammond, J. M.;Pinto, J.;Perez, A. M.

title: The enteric virome in inflammatory bowel disease
authors: Brooks, J.;Watson, A.

title: Nonmaternal transmission is the major transmission route of ovine lentivirus in a flock of sheep: A molecular epidemiological study
abstract: Transmission of ovine progressive pneumonia virus (OPPV), a lentivirus of sheep, occurs through both maternal and non-maternal means. At present, the contribution of each route of transmission to the overall prevalence of OPPV in herds is poorly understood, as previous serological-epidemiological studies have not been able to accurately trace routes of transmission within an infected herd. In this study, the amount of maternal OPP transmission in a naturally infected ewe flock was assessed by applying molecular analyzes to proviral sequences derived from peripheral blood leukocytes of OPP-positive mother-daughter pairs (N=40). Both proviral envelope (env) and long terminal repeat (LTR) sequences were used separately and combined in the following 2 sequence analysis methods: phylogenetic analysis and pairwise distance calculations. True maternal transmission events were defined as agreement in 2 of the 2 sequence analysis methods. Using this criterion, proviral env sequences resulted in a maternal transmission frequency of 14.3% and proviral LTR sequences in a maternal transmission frequency of 10%. Both proportions of maternal transmission differed significantly from equality (P < 0.0001). This indicates that the remaining 85.7-90% of daughters become infected through non-maternal transmission. This is also the first study to calculate the proviral OPP change rate for the env gene and the LTR promoter. Accurately defining OPPV transmission routes provides important epidemiological data that support management aimed at reducing herd transmission and virus dose. © 2010.
authors: Broughton-Neiswanger, L. E.;White, S. N.;Knowles, D. P.;Mousel, M. R.;Lewis, G. S.;Herndon, D. R.;Herrmann-Hoesing, L. M.

title: Antigenic and genetic analysis of H1N1 influenza A virus from European swine
abstract: H1N1 influenza A viruses, which have been isolated from pigs in Europe since 1981, were examined both antigenically and genetically and compared with H1N1 viruses from other sources. Swine and avian H1N1 viruses can be divided into three groups: avian viruses, classical swine viruses and "bird-like" swine viruses. Little or no reactivity of swine "bird-like" viruses in HI assays with monoclonal antibodies against swine classical viruses was associated with amino acid substitutions within antigenic sites of hemagglutinin (HA). The phylogenetic analysis of the HA gene revealed that classical swine viruses from European swine are most similar to each other and closely related to North American swine strains, while the "bird-like" swine viruses cluster with avian viruses. "Bird-like" viruses introduced into pigs in the UK in 1992 appear to have originated directly from strains in pigs in continental Europe at the time. The HA genes of the swine viruses examined had undergone limited variation at antigenic sites and also contained fewer potential glycosylation sites compared to human H1N1 viruses. The HA showed an antigenic drift that was more pronounced in "bird-like" swine viruses than in classical swine strains. Genetic analyzes of two recent "bird-like" swine viruses revealed that all RNA segments are most closely related to those of avian influenza A viruses.
authors: Brown, I. H.;Ludwig, S.;Olsen, C. W.;Hannoun, C.;Scholtissek, C.;Hinshaw, V. S.;Harris, P. A.;McCauley, J. W.;Strong, I.;Alexander, D. J.

title: Molecular comparisons of full-length metapneumovirus (MPV) genomes, including newly identified French AMPV C and D isolates, support a possible subclassification within the MPV genus
abstract: Four avian metapneumovirus (AMPV) subgroups (AD) have been previously described due to genetic and antigenic differences. However, full-length sequences of the only known isolates of European subgroup C and subgroup D viruses (duck and turkey origin, respectively) have not been available to date. These full-length sequences were determined and compared to other previously reported full-length AMPV and human metapneumovirus (HMPV) sequences using phylogenetics, comparing nucleic and amino acid sequences, and examining codon usage bias, and compared. The results confirmed that subgroup C viruses were more closely related to HMPV than to the other AMPV subgroups in the study. This was consistent with previous findings on partial genome sequences. Closer relationships between AMPV-A, B and D were also evident in the majority of the results. Three metapneumovirus "clusters" HMPV, AMPV-C and AMPV-A, B and D were further supported by codon bias and phylogenetics. The data presented here together with those of previous studies describing antigenic relationships also between AMPV-A, B and D and between AMPV-C and HMPV could require a subclassification of metapneumoviruses similar to that used for avian paramyxoviruses and AMPV-A , B grouped, and D as type I metapneumoviruses and AMPV-C and HMPV as type II. © 2014 Brown et al.
authors: Brown, P. A.;Lemaitre, E.;Briand, F. X.;Courtillon, C.;Guionie, O.;AllÃ©e, C.;Toquin, D.;Bayon-Auboyer, M. H.;Jestin, V.;Eterradossi, N.

title: Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus - Strategic Decisions for Diagnosis and Control
abstract: In the 15 years since the last in-practice article on Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV), understanding of the molecular mechanisms of viral replication and mutation, particularly biotypic variation, has exploded. Hand in hand came a better understanding of the importance of BVDV as a primary pathogen in cattle, particularly as a cause of reproductive losses. A BVDV vaccine is now available in the UK which offers a better chance of protection against infection. However, for the veterinarian, the strategic decisions related to diagnosis, control and vaccination continue to present difficult dilemmas and this article focuses on these issues.
authors: Brownlie, J.;Thompson, I.;Curwen, A.

title: Viral meningitis epidemics and a single, recent, recombinant, and anthroponotic origin of swine vesicular disease virus
abstract: Background and Objectives: Swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) is a close relative of the human enterovirus B serotype, coxsackievirus B5. As the etiological agent of an important emerging animal disease, several studies have attempted to explain its origin. However, some key questions remain, including the full biological lineage of the virus and its geographic and temporal origin. Methods: We sequenced near-complete genomes from 27 SVDV and 13 coxsackievirus B5 specimens, all originally isolated between 1966 and 2006, and analyzed them in conjunction with existing sequences and historical information. Results: While analyzes involving 24 additional nearly complete SVDV genomic sequences show clear evidence of intra-SVDV recombination, all 51 SVDV isolates remain monophyletic. This supports the hypothesis of a single anthroponotic transmission origin. Analysis of individual coding and non-coding regions supports that SVDV is of recombinant origin between coxsackievirus B5 and another enterovirus B serotype, most likely coxsackievirus A9. Extensive Bayesian sequence-based analysis of the time of the most recent common ancestor of all analyzed sequences places this within a few years of 1961. Epidemiological evidence points to China as an origin, but there are no available samples to test this conclusively. Conclusions and Implications: The historical investigation and clinical aspects of the enterovirus B serotypes involved put the current results in line with a hypothesis that SVDV transmutes through co-infection, recombination, and a single anthroponotic event during large viral meningitis epidemics 1960/ 1961 including the ancestral serotypes. The exact geographical origin of SVDV cannot remain verifiable due to historical aspects.
authors: Bruhn, C. A. W.;Abel Nielsen, S. C.;Samaniego, J. A.;Wadsworth, J.;Knowles, N. J.;Gilbert, M. T. P.

title: Role of Schmallenberg virus infection in congenital malformations in ruminants in Scotland spring 2017
abstract: Scotland's Rural College (SRUC) together with the Moredun Research Institute are conducting surveillance for Schmallenberg virus (SBV) infection in cattle and sheep. This article reports findings on diagnoses of fetopathy associated with SBV infection and other congenital anomalies in these species made between January 1 and May 5, 2017.
authors: BrÃ¼lisauer, F.;Scholes, S.;Caldow, G. L.;Rocchi, M.;Dagleish, M. P.;Chianini, F.

title: genetic study of the interaction of the Piry virus with Drosophila. II. Classification of viral agD mutants and some preliminary characterizations
abstract: Piryvirus mutants selected for altered growth characteristics in Drosophila melanogaster were previously referred to as agD mutants. This paper presents a classification scheme for grouping some of these mutants and also presents the properties of some members of each group. Analysis of the mean incubation time at 20°C relative to time at 28°C (tÌ„20, tÌ„28) for each agD clone compared to the range of similar data for wild-type viruses allowed us to define 4 classes of agD -Mutants: (1) mutants equally affected at both temperatures, (2) cold-sensitive mutants in Drosophila (csD), (3) heat-sensitive mutants in Drosophila (tsD), and (4) mutants whose mean incubation time could not be reduced to either 20 can still be estimated at 28°C. All agD mutants are listed. The majority of them were also ts in chick embryo cells (CEC) and some were divided into complementation groups. Some correlations have been noted. For example, the agD mutants that were ts+ in CEC were often (7 out of 12) weakly cold-sensitive in Drosophila. Those tsD mutants that were also ts in CEC all belonged to complementation group I (L protein). True csD mutants, whose incubation time divergence increased regularly with wt and which were also ts in CEC, all belonged to group I except one, which belonged to group V (G protein). Three mutants fell into a distinct subclass of csD mutants characterized by a defect in CO2 sensitivity symptom expression below a certain temperature. One of these was further characterized and was in complementation group V. Some fourth class mutants were examined for their ability to invade flies. He was more or less affected. Among these mutants, mutations have been assigned to L, N, and G proteins independently of this phenomenon, suggesting that different physiological defects are involved. A comparison of the phenotypes in Drosophila of some of the agD mutants with other members of the vesiculovirus family was performed. The analogy of sigma rhabdovirus with tsD mutants is also reported.
authors: Brun, G.

title: Rotavirus 993/83, isolated from calf faeces, closely resembles an avian rotavirus
abstract: Polypeptides from purified virions of calf rotavirus (RV) isolate 993/83 and those from pigeon RV isolate PO-13 co-migrated on SDS-polyacrylamide gels. Two polypeptides of 45K and 47K were detected at the position of VP6. Both proteins behaved like authentic VP6 protein with EDTA and heat treatment. RV 993/83 and PO-13 displayed identical one-dimensional peptide maps for VP2 and the 45K and 47K proteins. More than 70% of sera from German cattle older than 1 year showed neutralizing serum antibodies against RV 993/83 and RV PO-13.
authors: Brussow, H.;Nakagomi, O.;Minamoto, N.;Eichhorn, W.

title: Bovine herpesvirus 4 genome: cloning, mapping, and strain variation analysis
abstract: The restriction map of the genome of bovine herpesvirus 4 (BHV-4) (V. test strain) was generated for the restriction enzymes EcoRI, BamHI and HindIII by analysis of clones from a lambda library (Sau3AI partial digest) and from a plasmid library (EcoRI fragments) . A genome unit was defined as the length of the unique central portion flanked at both ends by one of the terminal tandem repeats, termed polyrepetitive DNA (prDNA), estimated at 113 ± 2 kbp. A restriction map of test strain V prDNA revealed internal 200 bp tandem repeats of different sequences. This region in the prDNA was highly polymorphic between BHV-4 strains, even in a viral DNA preparation from a plaque-purified strain. The right-hand junction between the repeated and unique sequences of the genome occurred at an almost constant location, but the left-hand junction contained a modified prDNA and was variable between BHV-4 strains. The unique central part of the genome was very similar among the four strains considered, with some variations due to the presence or absence of a restriction site and four length variations were observed, located at positions 0.006 to 0.034 (left end), 0.211 to 0.225, 0.864 to 0.881 and 0.962 to 0.984 (right end). The total length variation of a genome unit does not exceed 1 kbp.
authors: Bublot, M.;Van Bressem, M. F.;Thiry, E.;Dubuisson, J.;Pastoret, P. P.

title: The ancient evolutionary history of polyomaviruses
abstract: Polyomaviruses are a family of DNA tumor viruses known to infect mammals and birds. To probe the deeper evolutionary history of the family, we used a combination of viral metagenomics, bioinformatics, and structural modeling approaches to identify and characterize fish and arthropod-associated polyomavirus sequences. Analyzes based on the divergent new sequences indicate that polyomaviruses have gradually co-evolved with their animal hosts for at least half a billion years. Phylogenetic analyzes of single polyomavirus genes suggest that some modern polyomavirus species arose after ancient recombination events involving distantly related polyomavirus lineages. The improved evolutionary model provides a useful platform for the development of a more accurate taxonomic classification system for the Polyomaviridae virus family.
authors: Buck, C. B.;Van Doorslaer, K.;Peretti, A.;Geoghegan, E. M.;Tisza, M. J.;An, P.;Katz, J. P.;Pipas, J. M.;McBride, A. A.;Camus, A. C.;McDermott, A. J.;Dill, J. A.;Delwart, E.;Ng, T. F.;Farkas, K.;Austin, C.;Kraberger, S.;Davison, W.;Pastrana, D. V.;Varsani, A.

title: Inflammation of the teats of cows caused by a smallpox virus
abstract: Clinical and laboratory studies on enzootic inflammation in cow teats have been conducted. The isolated virus was classified as a pox group based on its physicochemical and biological properties. It appears to be smallpox virus officinale. Treatment of the teats with a 3.0% alcohol-water solution of pyoctanine plus milking (catheterization) resulted in recovery.
authors: Buczek, J.;Krzyzanowski, J.;Majer, B.;Malinowski, E.

title: Rift Valley fever seroprevalence and abortion rates in livestock in Kisoro District, Southwest Uganda (2016): A prerequisite for zoonotic infection
abstract: Background: Rift Valley fever (RVF) is classified as a viral hemorrhagic fever and is endemic to East and West Africa. RVF is caused by an arthropod-borne virus (RVFV); The disease is zoonotic and affects human and animal health and international trade. In livestock it leads to abortion, while human infection occurs through close contact with infected animals or animal products. Methods: A quantitative observational study with stratified sampling was conducted in the western region of Uganda. Blood samples and abortion events from 1000 farm animals (goats, sheep and cattle) were collected and recorded. The serum was analyzed for RVFV IgG reactive antibodies using a competitive ELISA assay. Results: The overall RVFV seroprevalence was 10.4% (104/1000). Cattle had the highest seroprevalence (7%), followed by sheep (2.2%) and goats (1.2%). The species-specific RVFV seroprevalence was highest in cattle (20.5%), followed by sheep (6.8%) and goats (3.6%). RVFV seroprevalence was significantly higher (p<0.001) in the northern highlands (21.8%) than in the southern lowlands (3.7%). The overall prevalence of miscarriage was (17.4%), sheep had the highest prevalence of miscarriage (7.8%), followed by goats (6.3%) and cattle (3.3%). The species-specific abortion prevalence was highest in sheep (24.1%), followed by goats (18.8%) and 9.7% in cattle. Conclusion: RVFV is endemic in Kisoro District and livestock in the highland areas are more likely to be exposed to RVFV infection than those in the southern lowlands. Livestock outbreaks will most likely lead to zoonotic infection in Kisoro District.
authors: Budasha, N. H.;Gonzalez, J. P.;Sebhatu, T. T.;Arnold, E.

title: Molecular analysis of H7 avian influenza viruses from Australia and New Zealand: genetic diversity and relationships from 1976 to 2007
abstract: The complete genome sequencing of 11 Australian and 1 New Zealand avian influenza A virus isolates (all subtype H7) has allowed comparison of the sequences of each of the genome segments with those of other avian influenza A viruses of the H7 subtype. Inferences about phylogenetic relationships for each segment were used to develop a model of the natural history of these viruses in Australia. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin segment shows that the Australian H7 isolates form a monophyletic clade. This pattern is consistent with long-term independent development, which in this case is associated with geographic regions. Based on analysis of the other H7 hemagglutinin sequences, three additional geographic regions were confirmed for which similar monophyletic clades were observed. These regions are Eurasia plus Africa, North America, and South America. Analysis of the neuraminidase sequences from the H7N1, H7N3, and H7N7 genomes revealed the same region-based relationships. This pattern of independent evolution of Australian isolates is supported by the results of analysis of each of the six remaining genomic segments. These results, coupled with the occurrence of five different neuraminidase subtype combinations (H7N2, H7N3, H7N4, H7N6, H7N7) among the 11 Australian isolates, suggest that the maintenance host(s) is almost exclusively associated with Australia . The single lineage of Australian H7 hemagglutinin sequences, despite the occurrence of multiple neuraminidase types, suggests the existence of a genetic pool giving rise to a variety of reassortants rather than the existence of a small number of stable viral clones. This evolutionary pattern likely occurs in each of the above regions.
authors: Bulach, D.;Halpin, R.;Spiro, D.;Pomeroy, L.;Janies, D.;Boyle, D. B.

title: Influence of hepatitis C virus 3-untranslated region on IRES-dependent and Cap-dependent translation initiation
abstract: Translation of hepatitis C virus (HCV) genomic RNA is directed by an internal ribosome entry site (IRES) in the 5 inch untranslated region (5-UTR), and the HCV-3 UTR enhances IRES activity. Since the HCV 3″-UTR has a unique structure among 3″-UTRs, we examined a possible communication between the 5″ and the 3″-UTR of HCV during translation using chimeric reporter RNAs. We show that translation driven by the HCV IRES and the HCV-like IRES of porcine technovirus (PTV), which belongs to a completely different family of viruses (picornaviruses), or the EMCV IRES, is also mediated by the HCV-3 UTR is enhanced or by a poly(A) tail in different cell types. © 2010 Federation of European Biochemical Societies.
authors: Bung, C.;Bochkaeva, Z.;Terenin, I.;Zinovkin, R.;Shatsky, I. N.;Niepmann, M.

title: Estimating population diversity using unreliable low-frequency counts
abstract: We consider the classic population diversity estimation scenario based on abundance count data (the number of classes or taxa represented once, twice, etc. in the sample), but with the proviso that the lowest abundance counts, particularly the singletons observed, may not be reliable. This is particularly evident with data derived from modern high-throughput DNA sequencing, where errors can result in sequences being incorrectly assigned to new taxa instead of being matched to existing, observed taxa. We consider a spectrum of methods to address this problem, with a particular focus on fitting a parametric mixture model and deleting the component with the highest diversity; We also consider the data to be left-censored, effectively clustering two or more low-frequency counts. We find that these purely statistical “post-processing” corrections are highly dependent on the underlying assumptions, but that such methods can still be useful.
authors: Bunge, J.;BÃ¶hning, D.;Allen, H.;Foster, J. A.

title: Clinical and pathological characterization of an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza H7N8 in commercial turkeys in southern Indiana
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is a systemic fatal poultry disease caused by multiple subtypes of influenza A virus and classified based on serological responses to hemagglutinin and neuraminidase surface glycoproteins. In January 2016, a new subtype of HPAI-H7N8 was diagnosed in a flock of commercial turkeys (Meleagris gallopavo) in southern Indiana. Clinical signs and history included increased mortality, dyspnea, head tremors, recumbency, and sleepy or unaware birds. Postmortem examination of six recently dead birds revealed reddish mucus in the choanae and trachea and marked pulmonary edema. Histologic lesions in the brain included severe, multifocal lymphohistiocytic meningoencephalitis with foci of malacia, neuronal necrosis, and neuronophagia. All anatomical sites of the brain were affected, although histological changes in the cerebellum were considered mild. Other histological lesions included pulmonary congestion and edema, splenic congestion and lymphoid depletion, fibrinoid necrosis of vessels within the spleen, and multifocal acinar necrosis of the pancreas. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) was weakly positive for influenza A in the brain; IHC was negative in other tissues tested. The clinical and pathologic features of this case were consistent with previously published material on HPAI and are additional to cases of known or suspected mutation of a low pathogenic virus to a highly pathogenic virus.
authors: Burcham, G. N.;Ramos-Vara, J. A.;Murphy, D. A.

title: The isolation of a latent adeno-like virus from chicken kidney cell cultures
authors: Burke, C. N.;Luginbuhl, R. E.;Helmboldt, C. F.

title: Etiological Classifiable Viral Infections in Domestic Animals: Situation 1970
authors: BÃ¼rki, F.

title: Herpesvirus Strigis: a new avian herpesvirus. I. Biological Properties
abstract: virus isolated from dead owls with a syndrome called hepato splenitis infectiosa strigum (HSIS) killed chick embryos after inoculation by a variety of routes. Type A miliary necrotic foci and nuclear inclusion bodies were observed on CAM and in embryonic livers and spleens. In chick embryo fibroblast tissue cultures, type A syncytia, giant cells and nuclei appeared. These features, along with biochemical and biophysical properties described in another article, allowed the HSIS virus to be classified as a herpes virus. No serological cross-reaction was observed between HSIS virus on the one hand and infectious laryngotracheitis virus, Marek's virus and 5 non-avian herpesviruses on the other hand. The HSIS virus is therefore considered a new avian herpes virus. Herpesvirus Strigis is suggested as an appropriate name since its natural host is owls of the order Strigiformes.
authors: Burki, F.;Burtscher, H.;Sibalin, M.

title: bovine adenoviruses. III. Division into two subgroups using immunodiffusion tests
abstract: Bovine subgroup II adenoviruses, actually represented by the officially recognized serotypes 4 to 8, possess soluble antigens that do not cross-react with either classical mastadenovirus (human or bovine subgroup I) or aviadenovirus antigens or their respective antibodies in immunodiffusion assays. Previously, small amounts of the antigen reactive with the classic mastadenovirus group were detected in bovine subgroup II adenoviruses by cross-complement fixation. However, no bovine subgroup II specific adenovirus antigen was detected in classical mastadenoviruses. So far, the serodiagnosis of bovine adenoviral infections has been severely hampered by ignoring these facts, which has led to a severe underestimation of the frequency of such infections. We propose a third genus, Paramastadenovirus, within the family Adenoviridae, including currently known and future strains, that mainly contain the novel group-reactive soluble antigen shown here.
authors: Burki, F.;Hinaidy, B.;Bockmann, J.

title: Classification as a separate equine herpesvirus of isolate 53/69 from equine coital rash
abstract: During an outbreak of equine coital rash (ECE), a virus strain designated ECE 53/69 was isolated from a vaginal swab. It induced plaques, polykaryotic giant cells and Cowdry type A nuclear inclusion bodies in horse cell cultures. The replication of ECE 53/69 was completely inhibited by IUDR. It proved sensitive to ether, trypsin, heat and low pH. All of these features, as well as the electron microscopic data described elsewhere, allowed the strain to be classified as a herpesvirus. That it was an equine herpesvirus was demonstrated by natural and experimental infections in horses and by replication occurring exclusively in equine cell cultures. Equine cytomegaloviruses also replicate exclusively in equine cells. However, they do so much more slowly and remain cell-bound. ECE 53/69, in contrast, causes a very rapid cpe and is released into the tc medium at a high titer. Equine rhinopneumonitis virus differs from ECE by replication in a broad spectrum of heterologous cells, lack of cross-neutralization, cross-complement fixation, and different clinical manifestations. ECE 53/69 is thus a separate equine herpes virus species.
authors: Burki, F.;Pichler, L.;Sibalin, M.

title: Virus classification and nomenclature
authors: Burnet, S. M.

title: Inactivation of viruses by aziridines
abstract: Ethyleneimine (EI) and N-acetylethyleneimine (AEI) have been shown to inactivate viruses belonging to most of the families described by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. The mechanism by which they inactivate the viruses is not known. This article describes experiments with foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) and poliovirus that suggest that the inactivating lesion is on the RNA.
