authors: Burrage, T.;Kramer, E.;Brown, F.

title: Hepatitis E virus in farm rabbits, wild rabbits and pet farm rabbits in the Netherlands
abstract: Rabbits have been suggested as a zoonotic source of hepatitis E virus. Phylogenetic analyzes of HEV isolates from farm, wild and pet rabbits in the Netherlands (23, 0 and 60% respectively) showed that they belong to the published rabbit HEV sequences and differ from most human isolates. Dutch rabbits are unlikely to be a zoonotic source.
authors: Burt, S. A.;Veltman, J.;Hakze-van der Honing, R.;Schmitt, H.;van der Poel, W. H. M.

title: Influenza A virus subtypes in wild birds in north-eastern Spain (Catalonia)
abstract: Since the spread of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in 2005, many surveillance programs for poultry and wild birds have been initiated worldwide. This study describes for the first time the detection of different subtypes of avian influenza virus (AIV) in wild birds in the western Mediterranean (Catalonia, northeastern Spain). During a 3-year period (from mid-2006 to mid-2009), 1374 birds from 16 different families were examined and a total of 62 AIV were detected using a real-time reverse transcriptase PCR assay. AIV have been recorded more frequently in the families Anatidae, Phoenicopteridae, Rallidae and Laridae. Of the 62 positive samples, 28 AIV could be isolated in embryonated eggs. All isolates were subtyped by hemagglutinin and neuraminidase inhibition techniques and 10 different hemagglutinins (HA) and 7 neuraminidases (NA) were found in 13 different subtype combinations. The most common combinations were H4N6 (22.2%) and H1N1 (18.5%). The HA and NA gene sequences of different AIV subtypes were compared and aligned with the available AIV strains from genome databases. Our studies of AIV phylogenetic analysis revealed that all AIV genes sequenced from wild birds in northeastern Spain were clustered within Eurasian bird clades, including the sequences of the H8, N4, and N5 genes, which are found in Europe for the first time were analyzed. The results contribute to the understanding of AIV in the Mediterranean and Europe. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Busquets, N.;Alba, A.;Napp, S.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;Serrano, E.;Rivas, R.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.;MajÃ³, N.

title: Studies on the sialidase and the esterase of influenza viruses
abstract: The main contributions of the author and his collaborators to the sialidase (EC 3.2.1.18) of influenza virus types A and B and to the O-acetylesterase (EC 3.1.1.53) of type C are summarized. After a brief introduction to the subject, the author's negative results on inhibitors are commented on. Then the special features of the three methods examined are discussed using the NADH determination as a measure of the silaidase activity. The spectrofluorometric measurement of NADH concentration is a more sensitive and convenient method than spectrophotometry, although less sensitive than that based on bioluminescence. Sialidase activity is generally higher in type A than type B influenza virus; However, some differences were noted between the three subtypes A analyzed. In addition, thermal stability and stability to changes in pH are higher for duck influenza viruses, followed by those of humans and finally by those of pigs. O-acetyl terase of type C influenza virus shows broad specificity; it acts on O-acetyl containing compounds which need not be sialic acids. It seems that this enzyme could help to facilitate the action of influenza virus type A and B sialidase. The peculiarities of influenza virus type C suggest including this type as a new genus in the future classification of viruses.
authors: Cabezas, J. A.

title: Circulation of rabies virus in non-hematophagous bats in the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 2001-2010
abstract: Introduction: Rabies is one of the best-known deadly zoonoses, responsible for 55,000 human deaths annually. Transmission to humans occurs primarily through the bite of domestic or wild animals infected with the virus. This paper shows the circulation of this virus in non-hematophagous bats in the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Methods: A survey was conducted on the number of bats sent for diagnosis by the Seção de Virologia of the Instituto Municipal de Medicina Veterinaria Jorge Vaitsman that were positive for rabies. The positive animals were identified and the isolated viruses sent for antigenic typing using indirect immunofluorescence. The results were compared to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention antigen panel. Results: Between 2001 and 2010, the laboratory received 555 non-hematophagous bats for rabies diagnosis, of which 198 (35.7%) were from Rio de Janeiro City. A total of 11 (5.5%) animals were positive for this disease. Antigenic typing revealed the predominance of variant 3 in 9 (81.8%) of the viruses isolated; 1 virus was classified as variant 4 and 1 variant was identified that segregated with the viruses in insectivorous bats. Conclusions: The data obtained in this study demonstrated the presence of rabies virus in synanthropic populations of non-hematophagous bats in the city of Rio de Janeiro. The circulation of this pathogen in these animals poses a serious risk to human and animal health and requires attention and control measures by the authorities.
authors: Cabral, C. C.;de Morais, A. C. N.;Dias, A. V. A. B.;AraÃºjo, M. G.;Moreira, W. C.;Mattos, G. L. M.

title: Molecular epidemiology of enterovirus and parechovirus infections by patient age over a 4-year period in Spain
abstract: The epidemiology and clinical association of enterovirus (EV) and parechovirus (HPeV) infections, as well as type distribution by age, were determined during a 4-year study period in Spain. A total of 21,832 clinical specimens were examined for EV between 2010 and 2013 and the detection rate was 6.5% (1,430). Of the total EV-negative samples, only 1,873 samples were available for HPeV testing in 2011-2013. HPeV was detected in 42 (2%) of them. Positive samples were genotyped by PCR and sequencing. EV infections occurred in all patient age groups: neonates (17%), children aged 28 days to 2 years (29%), children aged 2 to 14 years (40%) and adults (14%). 34 different EV types were identified. HPeV infections were only detected in infants < 8 m (70% neonates, P < 0.05). All but one HPeV were HPeV-3. Differences in the detection of type frequency were found depending on age and clinical manifestation. Coxsackievirus (CV)-B4 (61%), CV-B5 (83%) and HPeV-3 (64%) were more common in neonates than in elderly patients (p<0.05). Echovirus (E)-3 (60%), E-18 (47%), E-25 (62%), CV-A6 (61%), CV-A16 (72%) and EV-71 (75%) were mainly detected in children aged 28 days to 2 years (P < 0.05), while E-6 (79%), E-20 (88%) and E-30 (85%) in children > 2 years and adults were predominant (P<0.05). Clinically, meningitis was associated with EV (P<0.01), while encephalitis was more common in HPeV-infected patients. CV-B types were associated with myocarditis (90%; P<0.05) and EV-type A with hand, foot and mouth disease/atypical rash (88%; P<0.05). J.Med. virol. 89:435-442, 2017. © 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
authors: Cabrerizo, M.;Diaz-Cerio, M.;Munoz-Almagro, C.;Rabella, N.;Tarrago, D.;Romero, M. P.;Pena, M. J.;Calvo, C.;Rey-Cao, S.;Moreno-Docon, A.;Martinez-Rienda, I.;Otero, A.;Trallero, G.

title: Molecular evolution of H1N1 swine flu in Guangdong, China, 2016–2017
abstract: Pigs are the primary host of H1N1 swine influenza virus (SIV), but H1N1 can also infect humans, occasionally causing severe respiratory disease. To follow the development of SIV in Guangdong, China, we conducted an epidemic investigation in 2016-2017. Nine H1N1 influenza viruses have been isolated from swine nasal swabs. Antigenic analysis revealed that these viruses belonged to two distinct antigenic groups represented by A/Swine/Guangdong/101/2016 and A/Swine/Guangdong/52/2017. In addition, three genotypes known as GD52/17-like, GD493/17-like and GD101/16-like were identified by phylogenetic analysis. Importantly, the genotypes containing at least 4 pdm/09 internal genes have become prevalent in China in recent years. A total of 2966 swine serum samples were used to conduct haemagglutination inhibition (HI) testing and the results showed that the seroprevalence values of SW/GD/101/16 (32.2% in 2016, 32.1% in 2017) were significantly higher were than the seroprevalence values of SW/GD/52/17 (18.0% in 2016, 16.7% in 2017). Our study showed that the three reassortant genotypes of H1N1 SIV currently circulating in China are stable, but H1N1pdm09 poses human health challenges as internal genes are introduced into these reassortant genotypes. Strengthening SIV surveillance is therefore critical to controlling SIV and minimizing their potential public health threat.
authors: Cai, M.;Huang, J.;Bu, D.;Yu, Z.;Fu, X.;Ji, C.;Zhou, P.;Zhang, G.

title: Genetic characterization and evolutionary analysis of 4 Newcastle disease virus isolates, complete genomes of aquatic birds in southern China in 2003-2007
abstract: In this study, complete genomes of four strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from ducks and wild birds in Guangdong Province, China, from 2003 to 2007 were sequenced and analyzed. Pathogenicity tests in chick embryos and chickens show that D3 and R8 are lentogenic and W4 and P4 are mesogenic strains. Phylogenetic analysis using all six genes provides a high resolution profile for genotype designation as genotype I for D3 and R8 strains and genotype VI for W4 and P4 strains. In addition, molecular dating based on various genes suggests that D3 and R8 diverged from their common ancestor around 1998; W4 and P4 diverged from their common ancestor around 1999. Subsequent selective pressure analysis revealed specific features of gene evolution in all 4 phyla since their divergence from the most recent common ancestor. Furthermore, the geographic origins of 4 phyla via two independent introduction events were inferred to be from Europe by phylogeographic analysis. This provides insights into the potential impact of waterbird migration on NDV epidemiology. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Cai, S.;Li, J.;Wong, M. T.;Jiao, P.;Fan, H.;Liu, D.;Liao, M.;Jiang, J.;Shi, M.;Lam, T. T. Y.;Ren, T.;Leung, F. C. C.

title: Identification and analysis of differentially expressed microRNAs in PK-15 cells infected with Japanese encephalitis virus using deep sequencing
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), a mosquito-borne flavivirus, causes acute viral encephalitis with high morbidity and mortality in humans and animals. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-coding RNAs that are important modulators of intricate host-pathogen interaction networks. However, our knowledge of the changes that occur in miRNAs in host cells after JEV infection is still limited. To understand the molecular pathogenesis of JEV at the level of post-transcriptional regulation, we used Illumina deep sequencing to sequence two small RNA libraries prepared from PK-15 cells before and after JEV infection. We identified 522 and 427 miRNAs in infected and uninfected cells, respectively. A total of 132 miRNAs were significantly differently expressed after challenge with JEV: 78 were upregulated and 54 downregulated. The sequencing results for selected miRNAs were confirmed using RT-qPCR. GO analysis of host target genes revealed that these dysregulated miRNAs are involved in complex cellular signaling pathways, including the metabolic pathway, the inflammatory response, and the immune response. To our knowledge, this is the first report on the comparative expression of miRNAs in PK-15 cells after JEV infection. Our results will support further studies on the role of miRNAs in JEV replication and identify potential candidates for antiviral therapies against JEV.
authors: Cai, Y.;Zhu, L.;Zhou, Y.;Liu, X.;Liu, X.;Li, X.;Lang, Q.;Qiao, X.;Xu, Z.

title: Small but mighty: The role of rumen microbes in livestock farming
authors: Cammack, K. M.;Austin, K. J.;Lamberson, W. R.

title: RUMINNAT NUTRITION SYMPOSIUM: Small but mighty: The role of rumen microbes in livestock farming
abstract: The microbes that live in the rumen convert low-grade, fibrous plant matter into usable energy for the host ruminant. Comprised of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, archaea, and viruses, the rumen microbiome forms an elaborate symbiotic network essential for host ruminant maintenance, immune function, and overall production efficiency. Robert Hungate laid the foundation for research into the rumen microbiome. This area of research has expanded tremendously with advances in methodology and technology that have improved not only the ability to describe microbes in taxonomic and density terms, but also to characterize populations of microbes, their functions, and their interactions with each other and with the host. The interplay between the rumen microbiome and the host contributes to the variation in many phenotypic traits that the host animal expresses. A better understanding of how the rumen microbiome affects host health and performance may lead to new strategies and treatments to improve traits. Furthermore, elucidating maternal, genetic, and environmental factors that influence the establishment and development of the rumen microbiome may provide new insights into potential mechanisms for manipulating rumen microbial composition to improve long-term host health and performance. The potential of these tiny but powerful rumen microbes to play a role in improving livestock production is estimated, although relatively unclear.
authors: Cammack, K. M.;Austin, K. J.;Lamberson, W. R.;Conant, G. C.;Cunningham, H. C.

title: Complete genome sequence of porcine parvovirus 2 obtained from swine sera
abstract: A complete genomic sequence of porcine parvovirus 2 (PPV-2) was verified by viral metagenomic analysis of pig sera. A phylogenetic analysis of this genome shows that it is very similar to the previously described North American PPV-2 genomes. The complete PPV-2 sequence is 5,426 nucleotides long.
authors: Campos, F. S.;Kluge, M.;Franco, A. C.;Giongo, A.;Valdez, F. P.;Saddi, T. M.;Brito, W. M.;Roehe, P. M.

title: First detection and molecular characterization of nebovirus in Brazil
abstract: Nebovirus is a new genus of viruses belonging to the family Caliciviridae that has recently been characterized in cattle and is associated with gastrointestinal disorders such as diarrhea, anorexia and intestinal lesions, particularly in calves. The aim of this study was to investigate the prevalence of neboviruses in Brazilian cattle and to phylogenetically analyze the detected virus strains. A prevalence of 4·8% of neboviruses was found in fecal samples from 62 cattle from different Brazilian states. All positive animals were < 20 days old and had diarrhea. Phylogenetic analysis grouped the virus sequences into the Newbury1 clade. There was >96*0% nt (100% aa) sequence identity between the virus sequences in this study and >88*8% nt (>94*4% aa) identity with Newbury1/UK. Our results show for the first time the emergence of neboviruses in Brazil as well as South America and the first Newbury1-like nebovirus found outside the UK.
authors: Candido, M.;Alencar, A. L. F.;Almeida-Queiroz, S. R.;Buzinaro, M. G.;Munin, F. S.;Godoy, S. H. S.;Livonesi, M. C.;Fernandes, A. M.;Sousa, R. L. M.

title: Lambda display phage as a mucosal vaccine delivery vehicle for peptide antigens
abstract: Bacteriophages are structurally stable in the gastrointestinal tract and have favorable properties in terms of safety, stability, ease of manufacture, and immunogenicity. These properties make them potential candidates for oral delivery vehicles for vaccines, but little is known about their ability to induce mucosal immune responses in the small intestine. Whole-body imaging of mice confirmed that lambda bacteriophage (LP) were distributed throughout the gastrointestinal tract 24 hours after oral administration. In newborn calves, targeting of LP to the small intestine confirmed that LP were dose-dependently immunogenic and taken up by Peyer's patches. LP-specific IgA responses were induced within both Peyer's patches and draining mesenteric lymph nodes. A lambda display phage (LDP) was constructed to display three immunogenic disease-specific epitopes (DSE) from cervid prion protein (amino acids 130-140 [YML]; 163-170 [YRR]; and 171-178 [YRR]). fused to phage capsid head protein D (LDP-DSE). Targeting purified LDP-DSE to gut segments induced IgA responses to all three peptide epitopes. In addition, delivery of bacteria expressing soluble D-DSE also induced epitope-specific IgA responses in the targeted Peyer's patches. These are the first studies to report the use of LDP to induce epitope-specific IgA responses in the small intestine and confirm that Peyer's patches act as a site for LP uptake. In addition, IgA responses to peptide epitopes on LDP were observed in the absence of mucosal adjuvant. These observations confirm that LDP has the ability to function as a mucosal transport vehicle with protein D as an efficient carrier for peptide epitopes. (C) 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Cano, P. G.;Gamage, L. N. A.;Marciniuk, K.;Hayes, C.;Napper, S.;Hayes, S.;Griebel, P. J.

title: Two novel parvoviruses in frugivorous New and Old World bats
abstract: Bats, a globally distributed group of mammals with high ecological importance, are increasingly recognized as natural reservoir hosts for viral pathogens important to human and animal health. In the present study, we evaluated pools of blood samples derived from two phylogenetically distant bat families, specifically fruit bats (Pteropodidae), Eidolon helvum in West Africa, and two species of New World leaf-nosed fruit bats (Phyllostomidae). Artibeus jamaicensis and Artibeus lituratus in Central America. A sequence-independent virus discovery technique (VIDISCA) was used in combination with high-throughput sequencing to detect two new parvoviruses: a PARV4-like virus called Eh-BtPV-1 in Eidolon helvum from Ghana and the first member of a putative new genus in Artibeus jamaicensis from Panama (Aj-BtPV-1). These viruses circulated in the respective bat colony at rates of 7-8%. Aj-BtPV-1 was also found in Artibeus lituratus (5.5%). Both viruses were detected in the blood of infected animals at high levels: up to 10E8 and up to 10E10 copies/ml for Aj-BtPV-1 and Eh-BtPV-1, respectively. Eh-BtPV-1 was additionally detected in all organs excised from bats (brain, lungs, liver, spleen, kidneys and intestines) and the spleen and kidneys were identified as the most likely sites for viral replication to occur. Our study shows that bat parvoviruses share common ancestors with known human and livestock parvoviruses. We also provide evidence that a variety of Parvovirinae are capable of causing active infection in bats and that they are widespread in these animals with diverse geographic origins, ecologies, and climates. © 2011 Canuti et al.
authors: Canuti, M.;Eis-Huebinger, A. M.;Deijs, M.;de Vries, M.;Drexler, J. F.;Oppong, S. K.;MÃ¼ller, M. A.;Klose, S. M.;Wellinghausen, N.;Cottontail, V. M.;Kalko, E. K. V.;Drosten, C.;van der Hoek, L.

title: The outbreak of swine flu in Argentina reveals a non-contemporaneous human H3N2 virus that is highly transmissible among swine
abstract: Sporadic outbreaks of H3N2 human influenza A virus (IAV) infection in swine populations have been reported in Asia, Europe and North America since 1970. In South America, serological studies in pigs indicate that IAVs of subtypes H3 and H1 are currently circulating; However, no virus isolation or characterization has been reported. In November 2008, an outbreak of respiratory disease in pigs related to swine influenza virus (SIV) infection was detected in Argentina. The current study describes the clinical epidemiology, pathology, molecular and biological properties of the virus. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the virus isolate shared 96-98% nucleotide identities with H3N2 IAVs circulating in humans from 2000-2003. Antigens, sera from experimentally vaccinated animals were mainly cross-reactive with non-contemporary H3N2 influenza viruses of human origin. In an experimental infection in a commercial breed of pig, the virus was of low virulence, but was transmitted efficiently to contact pigs and caused severe disease if an infected animal acquired a secondary bacterial infection. This is the first report of a fully human H3N2 IAV associated with clinical disease in swine in South America. These studies underscore the importance of the cross-transmission of IAVs and SIVs between pigs and humans and call for increased influenza surveillance in swine populations worldwide. © 2011 SGM.
authors: Cappuccio, J. A.;Pena, L.;DibÃ¡rbora, M.;Rimondi, A.;PiÃ±eyro, P.;Insarralde, L.;Quiroga, M. A.;Machuca, M.;Craig, M. I.;Olivera, V.;Chockalingam, A.;Perfumo, C. J.;Perez, D. R.;Pereda, A.

title: Outbreaks of Newcastle disease in Italy in 2000
abstract: Consequences of the epidemic of highly pathogenic avian influenza that struck Italy between 1999 and 2000 included an epidemic of Newcastle disease in northern and central Italy. It affected factory reared poultry, merchant flocks and backyard flocks, with a total of 254 reported outbreaks up to December 31, 2000. Virological studies identified virulent isolates of Newcastle disease virus producing intracerebral pathogenicity indices from 1-6 to 2-0 and which, due to their monoclonal antibody binding pattern could be classified as belonging to group C1. The clinical, gross, and microscopic findings were typical of Newcastle disease, and different bird species were susceptible to varying degrees. Chickens and guinea fowl appeared to be the most susceptible, followed by pheasants, turkeys and ostriches. The epidemiological investigation highlighted the crucial role of a broiler hatchery in starting the epidemic and of traders in its continuation. The control measures of Directive 92/66/EEC are discussed on the basis of outbreaks in backyard stands.
authors: Capua, I.;Dalla Pozza, M.;Mutinelli, F.;Marangon, S.;Terregino, C.

title: Isolation of an avian paramyxovirus type 9 from migratory waterfowl in Italy [3]
authors: Capua, I.;De Nardi, R.;Beato, M. S.;Terregino, C.;Scremin, M.;Guberti, V.

title: Pseudorabies virus neurovirulence
abstract: Virulence is defined as the relative ability of a microorganism to overcome the host organism's defenses and thereby cause disease. Virus-induced virulence is commonly quantified by measuring the median time to death or onset of symptoms following viral inoculation. In this review we distinguish between general virulence and neurovirulence. We define neurovirulence as the level of pathogenesis in the nervous system, but intend it to be broader than the virus' simple ability to grow in the central nervous system (CNS). This distinction is made possible by recent advances that allow an integrated assessment of the degree of pathology, reactive gliosis, and the inflammatory response to infection in the intact organism with specific antisera and molecular probes.
authors: Card, J. P.;Enquist, L. W.

title: Fatal outbreak in Tonkea macaques caused by possibly novel orthopoxvirus, Italy, January 2015 <sup>1</sup>
abstract: In January 2015, 12 captive Tonkea macaques died in a 3-week period in a protected area in Italy. Orthopoxvirus infection was suspected based on negative staining electron microscopic results. The diagnosis was confirmed by histology, virus isolation and molecular analysis performed on various organs of all animals. An epidemiological investigation could not determine the source of infection in the area. Captured rodents were negative on virologic tests, but specific IgG was detected in 27.27% of small rodents and 14.28% of rats. A live attenuated vaccine was administered to the susceptible monkey population and no side effects were observed; a detectable humoral immune response was induced in most vaccinated animals. We performed molecular characterization of the orthopoxvirus isolate by next-generation sequencing. According to phylogenetic analysis of the 9 conserved genes, the virus could be part of a novel clade intermediate between cowpox and ectromelia viruses.
authors: Cardeti, G.;Gruber, C. E. M.;Eleni, C.;Carletti, F.;Castilletti, C.;Manna, G.;Rosone, F.;Giombini, E.;Selleri, M.;Lapa, D.;Puro, V.;Di Caro, A.;Lorenzetti, R.;Scicluna, M. T.;Grifoni, G.;Rizzoli, A.;Tagliapietra, V.;De Marco, L.;Capobianchi, M. R.;Autorino, G. L.

title: Virological and phylogenetic characterization of attenuated lentivirus isolates from small ruminants that evade efficient serological detection
abstract: Three field isolates of small ruminant lentiviruses (SRLVs) originate from a mixed herd of goats and sheep that have been certified free of capric arthritis encephalitis virus (CAEV) for many years. Phylogenetic analysis of pol sequences allowed these isolates to be classified as an A4 subtype. None of the animals showed clinical signs of SRLV infection, confirming previous observations suggesting that this particular subtype is highly attenuated, at least in goats. A real-time quantitative PCR strategy based on primers and probes derived from a highly variable env region allowed us to classify the animals as uninfected, singly or doubly infected. The performance of various serological instruments based on this classification revealed their profound inadequacy in monitoring animals infected with this particular SRLV subtype. In vitro, the isolates showed differences in their cytopathicity and a tendency to replicate more efficiently in goat cells than in sheep cells, particularly in goat macrophages. In contrast, these viruses reached significantly higher viral loads in vivo in sheep than in goats. Both env subtypes infected goats and sheep with equal efficiency. However, one of them achieved significantly higher viral loads in both species. In summary, we have characterized three isolates of SRLV subtype A4 that circulate efficiently in a mixed herd of goats and sheep despite their apparent attenuation and a strict physical segregation between goats and sheep. The poor performance of the applied serological tools indicates that to support an SRLV eradication campaign, it is imperative to develop new subtype-specific tools. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Cardinaux, L.;Zahno, M. L.;Deubelbeiss, M.;Zanoni, R.;Vogt, H. R.;Bertoni, G.

title: An outbreak of pseudo-cowpox in fattened calves in southern Brazil
abstract: Pseudocowpox virus is a parapoxvirus commonly associated with papulovesicular and scab lesions on the teats and udders of dairy cows and is commonly transmitted to humans. An unusual outbreak of skin diseases in fattened calves in southern Brazil is described. Fourteen of 17 male cattle (82%) aged 6 to 48 months feeding on grass pastures were affected. The animals developed papules, vesicles and scabby proliferative lesions on the snout in a clinical course of about 10-15 days. The scabby lesions often presented with exudation and bleeding. The histological examination of the mucocutaneous tissue with detached crusts revealed acanthosis with thickening of the corneal layer and premature cornification (parakeratotic hyperkeratosis). The dermis showed multifocal lymphoplasmic infiltrates. Electron microscopic examination of scab samples revealed typical parapoxvirus particles: oval shaped (260 nm × 160 nm), encased and covered with a helical layer. The polymerase chain reaction using a set of pan-parapoxvirus primers targeting the B2L gene amplified a 590 bp product from DNA extracted from common scab. Nucleotide sequencing of the amplicons revealed 97% nucleotide homology with pseudocowpox virus and less homology with other parapoxviruses: bovine papular stomatitis virus (84%) and orf virus (94%). A phylogenetic tree based on the B2L sequence was constructed showing that the virus is clustered with Pseudocowpox virus isolates. © 2012 American Association of Veterinary Laboratory Diagnosticians.
authors: Cargnelutti, J. F.;Flores, M. M.;Teixeira, F. R. M.;Weiblen, R.;Flores, E. F.

title: Diagnosis and control of an LPAI H5N8 outbreak in a commercial flock of Japanese quail (Coturnix coturnix japonica) in California's Central Valley
abstract: In April 2014, an outbreak of low pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 of North American genetic lineage was diagnosed at a commercial quail farm in Stanislaus County, California. The sudden increase in mortality prompted the submission of 20 Japanese quail (Coturnix c. japonica) to the California Animal Health and Food Safety Laboratory, Turlock Branch. Oropharyngeal and cloacal swabs tested positive for H5N8 influenza A virus by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. The virus was then isolated. In vivo assays and sequencing of the hemagglutinin protein cleavage site classified the virus as a North American genetic lineage with low pathogenicity for chickens. After the diagnosis, a quick and coordinated response was taken to contain the outbreak. The affected premises were depopulated, cleaned and disinfected. Three areas around the affected site - a 3 kilometer (km) radius (high risk zone), a 3-10 km area (buffer zone) and a 10-20 km area (surveillance zone) - have been established for commercial avian influenza testing and non-commercial poultry farms. Surveillance tests and rapid control measures were successful in controlling and eradicating the outbreak and did not show any spread of the virus from the index herd. This report describes the history, diagnosis, surveillance and control measures used to manage this outbreak.
authors: Carnaccini, S.;Crossley, B.;Breitmeyer, R.;Charlton, B. R.;Bland, M.;Fowler, K.;De La Torre, F.;Torchetti, M. K.;Wong, S. S.;Wilson, D.;Jones, A.;SentÃ­es-CuÃ©, C. G.

title: High-throughput sequencing and comparative genomics of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Despite a basic understanding of many aspects of FMD biology, much information about FMD virulence, host range and virus transmission is still poorly understood. Here we present how the use of high-throughput sequencing for full genome sequences of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) has led to a number of new insights into the conservation and variability of viral genome sequences, genetic diversity in nature, and the phylogenetic classification of isolates , including the first complete sequences of the genomes of South African territories type 1 and 3 (SAT1 and SAT3). Comparative genomic analysis of full-length sequences from FMD isolates allowed: (i) the identification of highly conserved regulatory or coding regions critical to aspects of viral biology, as well as novel viral genomic motifs of likely biological relevance; (ii) characterization of the first complete sequences of the SAT1 and SAT3 genomes; (iii) identification of a new SAT virus lineage genetically distinct from other SAT and Eurasian lineages; (iv) accurate identification of globally circulating strains for epidemiological and forensic mapping; (v) evaluation of mutational and recombination processes as mechanisms equally involved in evolution; (vi) mutation rates, tolerance and limitations of genes and proteins during evolution of FMD viruses during in vivo replication and (vi) support for the hypothesis of a new evolutionary model.
authors: Carrillo, C.;Tulman, E. R.;Delhon, G.;Lu, Z.;Carreno, A.;Vagnozzi, A.;Kutish, G. F.;Rock, D. L.

title: The Global Virome Project
authors: Carroll, D.;Daszak, P.;Wolfe, N. D.;Gao, G. F.

title: Chasing Jenner's Vaccine: Cowpox Virus Classification Revision
abstract: Cowpox virus (CPXV) is described as the source of the first vaccine used to prevent the onset and spread of an infectious disease. It is one of the earliest described members of the Orthopoxvirus genus, which includes the viruses that cause smallpox and monkeypox in humans. Both the historical and current literature describe "cowpox" as a disease with a single etiological agent. The genotypic data presented here indicate that CPXV is not a single species but a composite of multiple (up to 5) species capable of infecting cows, humans and other animals. The practice of naming drugs after the host in which the resulting disease manifests obscures the true taxonomic relationships of "cowpox" isolates. These data support the rise of up to four new species within the traditional "cowpox" group and suggest that both wild and modern vaccine strains of vaccinia virus are most closely associated with CPXV in continental Europe and not in the UK, the homeland of smallpox , related are vaccination.
authors: Carroll, D. S.;Emerson, G. L.;Li, Y.;Sammons, S.;Olson, V.;Frace, M.;Nakazawa, Y.;Czerny, C. P.;Tryland, M.;Kolodziejek, J.;Nowotny, N.;Olsen-Rasmussen, M.;Khristova, M.;Govil, D.;Karem, K.;Damon, I. K.;Meyer, H.

title: Vaccinia and Other Viruses With Available Vaccines Show Extensive Homology With The HIV-1 Envelope Glycoprotein: The Prospect Of Using Existing Vaccines To Curb The AIDS Pandemic
abstract: Cross-reactive immunity occurs when infection with or vaccination against a virus protects against another related family member. A search for homologues of the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein revealed that it consists of thousands of intercalating and overlapping viral matches of longer gapped pentapeptides or consensus, which belong to over 70% of the currently sequenced virome, infecting all kingdoms from bacteria to humans . It was also highly homologous to proteins from Visna/Maedi and other ovine viruses, while other proteins (nef/tat/gag/pol) were homologous to proteins from equine infectious anemia virus and HTLV-2/HTLV-3 viruses. This phenomenon suggests that horizontal gene transfer from co-infecting RNA and DNA viruses to retroviruses is extensive and provides a route for the subsequent insertion of non-retroviral genes into human and other genomes via retroviral integration. This homology includes all viruses for which vaccines already exist. Cross-reactive immunity may be effective in AIDS because vaccinia vaccination decreases viral replication in the cells of HIV-1 infected patients for the CCR5 tropic form. Measles, dengue virus, or GB virus C infections also reduce HIV-1 viral loads. A resumption of vaccinia/smallpox vaccination is expected to have a significant impact on the AIDS pandemic, and careful investigation of the potential uses of other existing viral and bacterial vaccines deserves particular attention. This phenomenon may also be relevant to other recalcitrant viruses, bacteria and parasites for which no vaccine exists, and the arsenal of existing vaccines may play a role in diseases other than those for which they were developed. © 2012 Informa Healthcare USA, Inc.
authors: Carter, C. J. C.

title: Hepatitis E virus: A cross-sectional serological and virological study in pigs and humans at zoonotic risk in a high-density pig breeding area
abstract: In Italy, an increase in autochthonous hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections suspected of being zoonotically transmitted from pigs has been recorded; This study was conducted to determine the seroprevalence and risk factors associated with hepatitis HEV exposure in both pigs and humans working on pig farms located in a densely populated pig farming area in the Piedmont region of the north-west located in Italy. The presence of viral RNA in human and porcine samples was also assessed and phylogenetic analysis was performed on HEV positive samples. Samples were taken from forty-two pig farms; 142 workers were included in the study and divided into two groups: (i) 69 workers with occupational contact with pigs (including veterinarians and farmers) recruited from the 42 sampled farms; (ii) 73 without occupational contact with pigs. Forty-one of 42 (97%) pig farms gave a positive result in the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay test for HEV antibodies (Abs). The overall seroprevalence in pigs was 50% (441/879), with a higher seropositivity rate in sows (333/469, 71%). HEV RNA in stool samples was detected in animals from 13 out of 42 farms tested (31%) and a higher positivity was found in piglets (40/246, 16.3%). The phylogenetic analysis classified all HEV isolates within genotype 3 (subtypes 3f, 3e, 3c). All people were negative for HEV virus genome in blood. Five of 142 sera were positive for IgG anti-HEV with an overall prevalence of 3.52% with no statistically significant differences in prevalence rates between zoonotic risk workers and controls (5.7% vs. 1.3%). In contrast, a significant difference (OR 10.1) was observed within the subgroup comprising short-term exposed subjects (veterinarians) versus long-term exposed subjects (farmers), suggesting a correlation between the time of exposure and the probability of indicates HEV infection. Reporting HEV infection is not mandatory in Italy, but continuous epidemiological surveillance should be ensured to clarify the epidemiology of this disease.
authors: Caruso, C.;Peletto, S.;Rosamilia, A.;Modesto, P.;Chiavacci, L.;Sona, B.;Balsamelli, F.;Ghisetti, V.;Acutis, P. L.;Pezzoni, G.;Brocchi, E.;Vitale, N.;Masoero, L.

title: Bovine Papillomavirus in Brazil: Detection of Coinfection of Unusual Types by a PCR-RFLP Method
abstract: The bovine papillomavirus (BPV) is considered to be the causative agent of benign and malignant tumors in cattle. Thirteen types of BPV are currently being characterized and classified into three distinct genera associated with distinct pathological outcomes. The BPV types described, as well as other putative ones, were detected by molecular biology methods, mainly using degenerate PCR primers. In particular, divergences in the nucleotide sequence of the L1 gene are useful for identifying and classifying new papillomavirus types. In the present work, a method based on the PCR-RFLP technique and DNA sequencing was evaluated as a screening tool allowing the detection of two relatively rare BPV types in lesion specimens of a six-year-old Holstein dairy cow, chronically affected by cutaneous papillomatosis . These findings indicate the distribution of BPV with unclear pathogenic potential, since two relatively rare, newly described BPV types, first characterized in Japan, have also been detected in Brazil. © 2013 RF Carvalho et al.
authors: Carvalho, R. F.;Sakata, S. T.;Giovanni, D. N. S.;Mori, E.;BrandÃ£o, P. E.;Richtzenhain, L. J.;Pozzi, C. R.;Arcaro, J. R. P.;Miranda, M. S.;Mazzuchelli-De-Souza, J.;Melo, T. C.;Comenale, G.;Assaf, S. L. M. R.;BeÃ§ak, W.;Stocco, R. C.

title: Two novel zirconia-like viruses detected in human feces: full genome sequencing and electron microscopic analysis
abstract: Application of viral metagenomic techniques and a series of PCRs in a human stool sample enabled the detection of two novel circular nonsense DNA viral genomes with 92% nucleotide similarity. The viruses have been tentatively named Circa-like Virus-Brazil (CLV-BR) strains hs1 and hs2 and have genome lengths of 2526 and 2533 nucleotides, respectively. Four large open reading frames (ORFs) were identified in each of the genomes, and differences between the two genomes were mainly observed in ORF 2. However, only ORF 3 showed significant amino acid similarities to a putative rolling circle replication initiator protein (Rep). with low identity (36%). Our phylogenetic analysis, based on the Rep protein, showed that the CLV-BRs do not cluster with members of the Circoviridae, Nanoviridae, or Geminiviridae families and are more closely related to Circo-like genomes previously found in purified water and feces a wild rodent and a bat have been identified. The CLV-BRs are members of a putative novel family of circular Rep-encoding ssDNA viruses. Electron microscopy revealed icosahedral (similar to 23 nm) structures, likely reflecting the novel viruses, and rod-shaped virus particles (similar to 65-460 x 21 x 10 nm in length, diameter and axial channel, respectively). Circo-like viruses have been identified in human and other mammalian (bat, rodent, chimpanzee, and bovine) stool specimens, human cerebrospinal fluid and sera, and in specimens from many other sources, e.g. As insects, meat and the environment detected. Further studies are needed to classify all new circular DNA viruses and elucidate their hosts, pathogenicity, and evolutionary history. (C) 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Castrignano, S. B.;Nagasse-Sugahara, T. K.;Kisielius, J. J.;Ueda-Ito, M.;Brandao, P. E.;Curti, S. P.

title: Analysis of torque teno virus (TTV) in serum and whole blood from Brazilian non-human primates and in chicken plasma (Gallus gallus domesticus) by the PCR N22 region
abstract: Torque teno virus (TTV) is a recently discovered DNA virus originally isolated from a Japanese patient (initials TT) with posttransfusion hepatitis of unknown etiology. TTV is a circular DNA virus that has recently been placed in a new genus called anellovirus, along with the related torque teno minivirus. Infection TTV has been identified in a number of non-human primates as well as domestic animals. The purpose of this study was to search for TTV in serum and whole blood from Brazilian monkeys and in plasma from domestic chickens by semi-nested PCR of the coding region (N22) followed by genomic sequence and phylogenetic analysis. No serum sample was amplified. TTV DNA was detected in whole blood from 3 (4%) of 75 brown capuchin monkeys (Cebus apella) and 1 (25%) of 4 golden-headed lion tamarins (Leontopithecus chrysomelas). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that one sample shared similarity to a sequence from the cotton-tipped tamarin (Saguinus oedipus) (So-TTV2) and to one from the doroucoulis (Aotes trivirgatus) (At-TTV3). Two samples showed resemblance to a human torque teno minivirus (TLMV). The other sample was clustered with a sequence from the chimpanzee (Pt-TTV6) and with the human TTV strain TA278. The plasma chicken samples tested were all negative. The amino acid sequences reported in this study are the first to be obtained in Brazil from whole blood of non-human primates naturally infected with TTV.
authors: Catroxo, M. H. B.;Nishiya, A.;Sabino, E.;Teixeira, P. S.;Petrella, S.;Milanelo, L.;Vieira, J. C. F.;Diaz, R. S.

title: Circulation of human hepatitis E virus in Bulgaria: Deep Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to control virus spread in the country
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection is endemic in Bulgaria, as evidenced by the seroprevalence of antibodies to the virus in the general population and the high prevalence of registered clinical cases. In this study, a deep Bayesian phylogenetic analysis was performed to provide information on the genetic diversity and distribution of HEV genotypes in Bulgaria. Three different datasets of the HEV virus were created for genotyping using the maximum likelihood method, estimating the evolution rate using the Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo approach, studying the demographic history, and selective pressure analysis. The evolution rate for genotype 3e was 351 × 10 3 substitution/site/year (95% peak posterior density [95% HPD]: 145 × 10 3-575 × 10 3). The root of time to the most recent common ancestor of the Bayesian maximum clade belief tree of the HEV-3e genotype corresponded to the year 1965 (HPD 95% 1949-1994). The Bulgarian sequences grouped mainly in the main group (Group A). The monophyletic clade included all Bulgarian genotype 3e sequences. The demographic history showed a slight growth from 1995 to 2000, followed by a kind of bottleneck in the 2010s, a peak in 2011 and new growth until 2015. Analysis of selection pressure showed no sites under positive pressure but 64 statistically significant sites under negative selection. Molecular epidemiological surveillance by Bayesian phylogeny of HEV virus can help trace the route of human infection after direct contact with the pig source or heating meat, thus improving public health control.
authors: Cella, E.;Golkocheva-Markova, E.;Sagnelli, C.;Scolamacchia, V.;Bruni, R.;Villano, U.;Ciccaglione, A. R.;Equestre, M.;Sagnelli, E.;Angeletti, S.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: First Report of Cowpea Mild Mottle Virus in Chia (Salvia hispanica)
abstract: Chia (Salvia hispanica), a herbaceous plant in the Lamiaceae family, has gained popularity due to its high concentration of health-boosting omega-3 fatty acids. Plants with different virus-like symptoms have been observed in the main chia-growing regions of Argentina. Some plants showed yellowed, mottled and blistering leaves, others shortened internodes and leaf and stem deformities. The aim of this study was to identify the viruses infecting this crop. Forty symptomatic chia plants were collected from nine production fields in northeastern Argentina. Samples were tested for Alfalfa Mosaic Virus (AMV), Cowpea Mild Mottle Virus (CPMMV), Cucumber Mosaic Virus (CMV), Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV) and Tospovirus Group (I, II and III) Genera Potyvirus by DAS-ELISA PTA-ELISA and for Begomovirus by PCR. CPMMV was detected in three plants with different symptoms. Feather-like inclusions formed by virions were observed in these plants by transmission electron microscopy. ORF2 to ORF6 (2462 nucleotides) from the CPMMV viral genome were amplified by RT-PCR. The nucleotide (nt) sequence of the coat protein gene (CP - ORF5) of the chiavirus isolate was obtained and compared to 31 CPMMV sequences reported in GenBank. Results showed between 75.5% and 99.0% of nt identity, which exceeds the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses criteria for carlavirus species differentiation. Phylogenetic analysis using the CP gene nt sequences revealed that the CPMMV chia isolate clumped with other CPMMV isolates from other plant species from Brazil, Ghana, India, Puerto Rico, Taiwan and the US, but from four others India were separated. This is the world's first report of the presence of CPMVV in Chia. Although the other viruses were not detected in this work, it is possible that the different symptoms observed could be caused by a mixture of viruses, since CPMMV was found in chia plants with different symptoms. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Celli, M. G.;Perotto, M. C.;Merino, M. C.;Nome, C. F. D.;Flores, C. R.;Conci, V. C.

title: Taxon ordering in family trees using evolutionary algorithms
abstract: BACKGROUND: In a typical "left-to-right" phylogenetic tree, the vertical order of taxa is meaningless, since only the branch path between them reflects their degree of similarity. To make unsolved trees more informative, we propose here an innovative Evolutionary Algorithm (EA) method to seek the best graphical representation of unsolved trees to give biological meaning to the vertical order of taxa. METHODS: Starting from a West Nile Virus phylogenetic tree, we developed it in a (1+1)-EA by randomly rotating the inner nodes and choosing the tree with the better fit for each generation. Fitness is a sum of genetic distances between the taxon under consideration and the r (radius) nearest taxa. After adjusting the radius for best performance, we developed the trees with (Lambda + Mu) EAs to study the influence of population on the algorithm. RESULTS: The (1+1)-EA consistently outperformed a random search, and better results were obtained when the radius was set to 8. The (lambda + mu) EAs performed as well as the (1 + 1) except for the larger population (1000 + 1000). CONCLUSIONS: The trees showed improvement in both fitness (based on a genetic distance matrix, then close taxa are indeed genetically close) and biological interpretation after evolution. Samples collected in the same state or year moved close together, making the tree easier to interpret. Biological relationships between samples are also easier to observe.
authors: Cerutti, F.;Bertolotti, L.;Goldberg, T. L.;Giacobini, M.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of classical swine fever viruses isolated in Korea between 1988 and 2003
abstract: Twenty-four classical swine fever (CSF) virus isolates obtained from classical swine fever (CSF) outbreaks in the Republic of Korea in 1988 and 2003 were genetically characterized for the partial E2 gene (190 nucleotides) and compared with classical swine fever (CSF) genes reported from other countries. compared viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes between 1988 and 1999 classified Korean field isolates into subgroup 3.2, forming an independent clade distinct from the CSF viruses identified in other countries. In contrast, the viruses isolated during the 2002-2003 classical swine fever epidemics were classified into a different subgroup (2.1). The 2.1 viruses showed close genetic relatedness (92.1-100% nucleotide similarity) to CSF viruses reported from China and Taiwan in 1998-2001. Since no evidence of classical swine fever virus infection was found in the wild boar (Sus scrofa coreanus) population native to Korea, the results of the molecular characterization strongly suggest that the outbreaks of classical swine fever epidemic in Korean swine populations in 2002-2003 were related to the Introduction of a new virus were traced strain or strains, probably from neighboring countries. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Cha, S. H.;Choi, E. J.;Park, J. H.;Yoon, S. R.;Kwon, J. H.;Yoon, K. J.;Song, J. Y.

title: Molecular characterization of ephemeral bovine fever virus in Thailand between 2013 and 2017
abstract: Bovine ephemeral fever (BEF) is an arthropod-borne disease caused by bovine ephemeral fever virus (BEFV), a negative-sense single-stranded RNA virus. BEFV is endemic to tropical and subtropical regions including Thailand, a country in mainland Southeast Asia. However, there are few studies on BEFV and no available information on the molecular properties of BEFV in Thailand. Therefore, the aim of this study was to genetically characterize Thai BEFVs and uncover their evolution through phylogenetic analysis of G gene ectodomain sequences. From 2013 to 2017, blood samples were collected from cattle matching the BEF case definition from three regions of Thailand. Thai BEFV G genes and a full genome of one isolate, East Asia/TH/LRI0045/2016, were sequenced and characterized. In addition, their phylogenies were constructed. This is the first report on the genetics of BEFV in Southeast Asia. The G-ectodomain coding region of Thai BEFV found between 2013 and 2017 is closely related to the second and third subclades of the East Asian lineage. In addition, we observed a mutation in the putative P' ORF of all Thai BEFVs that generated a premature stop codon. The Thai G gene sequences are closely related to those of isolates from mainland China and Taiwan. The overall genomic sequences of Thai BEFV and East Asia/China/JT02 L/2002 share common features, suggesting a common evolutionary relatedness between East and Southeast Asian strains. Further studies on the relationship between animal translocation, circulation of BEFV in the Greater Mekong subregion, and acquisition of additional G gene sequences could improve the understanding of BEFV epidemiology in mainland Southeast Asia.
authors: Chaisirirat, T.;Sangthong, P.;Arunvipas, P.;Petcharat, N.;Thangthamniyom, N.;Chumsing, W.;Lekcharoensuk, P.

title: Metagenomic analysis of antibiotic resistance genes in faeces of dairy cows after therapeutic administration of third-generation cephalosporins
abstract: Although dairy manure is widely applied on land, it is relatively understudied compared to other livestock as a potential source of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) for the environment and ultimately human pathogens. Ceftiofur, the most widely used antibiotic for dairy cows in the US, is a 3rd generation cephalosporin, a class of antibiotics critical to human health. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of typical ceftiofur antibiotic treatment on the prevalence of ARGs in the faecal microbiome of dairy cows using a metagenomic approach. Fecal β-lactam ARGs were found to be increased in Holstein cows administered ceftiofur (n=3) compared to control cows (n=3). However, the total number of ARGs in all classes was not measurably affected by ceftiofur treatment, likely due to the dominance of unaffected tetracycline ARGs in the metagenomics libraries. Functional analysis using MG-RAST also revealed that ceftiofur treatment resulted in an increase in gene sequences associated with 'phages, prophages, transposable elements and plasmids', suggesting that this treatment also had the ability for horizontal transmission enriched by ARGs. Additional functional shifts were noted with ceftiofur treatment (eg, increases in genes associated with stress, chemotaxis, and resistance to toxic compounds; decreases in genes associated with aromatic compound metabolism and cell division and the cell cycle ), along with measurable taxonomic shifts (increase in Bacterioidia and decrease in Actinobacteria). This study demonstrates that ceftiofur has a broad, measurable and immediate effect on the metagenome of cow feces. Given the importance of 3rd generation cephalospirins to human medicine, their continued use in dairy cattle should be carefully considered and waste treatment strategies investigated to slow the spread of ARG from dairy manure. Copyright ©:
authors: Chambers, L.;Yang, Y.;Littier, H.;Ray, P.;Zhang, T.;Pruden, A.;Strickland, M.;Knowlton, K.

title: Cross-species transmission and emergence of novel viruses in birds
abstract: Birds, the only living members of the Dinosauria group, are flying warm-blooded vertebrates that exhibit high biodiversity, roosting and migratory behaviors, and unique adaptive immune systems. Birds are the natural reservoir for numerous virus species and therefore gene sources for the evolution, origin and spread of novel viruses. Human encroachment on the natural habitats of wild birds, domestication of wild birds as pets or racing birds, and increased human consumption of poultry have allowed avian viruses to cross species barriers and cause zoonosis. Recently, a novel adenovirus was found exclusively in birds, causing an outbreak of Chlamydophila psittaci infections in birds and humans. Instead of being the main cause of an outbreak by jumping directly from birds to humans, a novel avian virus can be an augmenter of another zoonotic agent causing the outbreak. A comprehensive avian virome will improve our understanding of the evolutionary dynamics of birds.
authors: Chan, J. F. W.;To, K. K. W.;Chen, H.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of goat orf virus in Taiwan
abstract: An outbreak of contagious ecthyma in goats in central Taiwan was investigated. The disease was diagnosed by physical and histopathological examinations, and the etiology of the disease was identified as ORF virus by electron microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and sequence of the major envelope protein (B2L) gene. The entire protein coding region of the B2L gene has been cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the B2L amino acid sequences showed that the orf virus identified in this outbreak was closer to the Indian ORFV mukteswar 59/05 isolate. This is the first report of molecular characterization of orf virus in Taiwan. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Chan, K. W.;Lin, J. W.;Lee, S. H.;Liao, C. J.;Tsai, M. C.;Hsu, W. L.;Wong, M. L.;Shih, H. C.

title: Analysis of genomic sequences of 95 papillomavirus types: uniform typing, phylogeny and taxonomy
abstract: Our aim was to investigate the phylogenetic relationships of all known papillomaviruses (PVs) and the possibility of constructing a supratypical taxonomic classification based on this information. Of the many detectably homologous segments present in PV genomes, a 291 bp segment of the L1 gene is notable because it is flanked by the MY09 and MY11 consensus primers and contains highly conserved amino acid residues that encode the Simplify sequence alignment. We determined the MY09-MY11 sequences from human PV type 20 (HPV-20), HPV-21, HPV-22, HPV-23, HPV-24, HPV-36, HPV-37, HPV-38, HPV-48 , HPV-50, HPV-60, HPV-70, HPV-72, HPV-73, ovine (sheep) PV, bovine PV type 3 (BPV-3), BPV-5 and BPV-6 and created a database that now includes HPV-1 through HPV-70, HPV-72, HPV-73, seven as yet untyped HPV genomes, and 15 animal PV types. Three additional animal PVs were analyzed based on other sequence data. We constructed phylogenies based on partial L1 and E6 gene sequences and distinguished five major clades, which we call supergroups. One of them brings together 54 genital PV types, which can be further divided into eleven groups. The second supergroup has 24 types and combines most of the PVs typically found in patients with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, but also includes several types typical of other skin lesions such as HPV-4. The third supergroup combines the six known ungulate fibropapillomaviruses, the fourth includes the cutaneous ungulate PVs BPV-3, BPV-4 and BPV-6, and the fifth includes HPV-1, HPV-41, HPV-63, the oral PV of the dog , and the cottontail rabbit PV. The chaffinch PV and two rodent PVs, Micromys minutus PV and Mastomys natalensis PV, are not grouped due to the relative isolation of their respective lineages. Within most supergroups, groups formed on the basis of cladistic principles unite phenotypically similar PV types. We discuss the basis of our classification, the concept of PV type, speciation, PV host evolution, and estimates of their evolutionary rates.
authors: Chan, S. Y.;Delius, H.;Halpern, A. L.;Bernard, H. U.

title: Whole genome sequencing of goat bluetongue virus 1 isolate MKD20/08/Ind in India
abstract: This release reports the full genome sequencing of bluetongue virus-1 (BTV-1) isolate MKD20/08/Ind from goats in northern India. The total size of the BTV-1 genome was found to be 19,190 bp. A comparative study between the Indian isolate and other global isolates found it to belong to the "eastern" BTV topotype. The full genome sequence of BTV-1 will provide important information about its geographic origin and will also prove useful for comparing the Indian isolate to global isolates from other host species.
authors: Chand, K.;Biswas, S. K.;Sharma, G.;Saxena, A.;Tewari, N.;Mahajan, S.;Pandey, A. B.

title: Comparison of the genome sequence of two live attenuated vaccines from the United States against infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV)
abstract: This study was performed to identify unique nucleotide differences in two US chick embryo (CEO) vaccines [LT Blen (GenBank Accession: JQ083493), designated Vaccine 1; Laryngo-Vac® (GenBank Accession: JQ083494), designated as Vaccine 2] of the infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV) genome compared to a reference ILTV genome sequence of an Australian Serva vaccine [Gallid herpesvirus 1 (GaHV-1) ; GenBank accession number: HQ630064]. The genomes of the two ILTV vaccine strains were sequenced using the Illumina Genome Analyzer 2X in 36 cycles of single-ended reads. The results showed that only a few nucleotide differences (23 in Vaccine 1; 31 in Vaccine 2) were found and indicate that the US CEO strains are virtually identical to the Australian Serva CEO strain that produced a European vaccine is of origin. The sequence differences demonstrated the spectrum of variability between vaccine strains. Only eight amino acid differences were found in ILTV proteins including UL54, UL27, UL28, UL20, UL1, ICP4 and US8 in Vaccine 1. Similarly in Vaccine 2 eight amino acid differences were found in UL54, UL27, UL28, UL36. UL1, ICP4, US10 and US8. Another comparison of US CEO vaccines using multiple ILTV genomic sequences revealed that US CEO vaccines are genetically close to both Serva vaccine and 63140/C/08/BR (GenBank Accession: HM188407) and differ from the differ between the two CEO vaccines of Australian origin. SA2 (GenBank Accession: JN596962) and A20 (GenBank Accession: JN596963), which showed great similarity to each other. These data demonstrate the potential of high-throughput sequencing technology to gain insights into the sequence variation of different ILTV strains. This information can be used to discriminate between vaccine ILTV strains and also to identify emerging mutant strains of field isolates. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Chandra, Y. G.;Lee, J.;Kong, B. W.

title: Virus isolation and molecular epidemiology of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) from an outbreak in free-ranging wild birds, India 2016
abstract: We report the molecular epidemiology of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) implicated in an outbreak that killed wild wild birds in Mysore, Karnataka state, India. The virus was typed as HPAI A(H5N8) by conventional and TaqMan probe-based real-time PCR assays. Six isolates of HPAI virus were obtained in 9 day old embryonated chicken eggs. The hemagglutinin gene-based phylogeny of virus isolates showed >99.9% nucleotide sequence identity with HPAI A(H5N8) isolates from migratory and domestic fowl from China and Korea, suggesting that either these wild birds migrated through Korea and/or eastern China or these have resulted in dead birds must have had direct or indirect contact with wild birds migrating from east China and/or Korean regions. The study highlights the role of migratory wild birds in the global spread of HPAI.
authors: Chandranaik, B. M.;Byregowda, S. M.;Venkatesha, M. D.;Ramesha, K. R.;Nandini, P.;Reddy, P.;Bindu, K. V. T.;Shivashankar, B. P.;Shankar, B. P.;Rani, M. S.

title: Lessons from the largest avian flu virus epidemic in Taiwan, 2015
abstract: The largest avian flu (AI) epidemic in history began attacking poultry and wild birds across Taiwan on January 6, 2015. This study analyzed surveillance results, epidemiological characteristics, and viral sequences using government-released information with the intention of making recommendations to minimize future pandemic influenza. The highly pathogenic H5 2.3.4.4 class AI viruses (HPAIVs) were not detected in Taiwan prior to 2015. Four types of pathogens were identified during this epidemic: the three new subtypes H5N2, H5N8 and H5N3 of class 2.3.4.4 HPAIVs and an endemic chicken H5N2 (Mexican lineage) subtype of weakly pathogenic AI viruses. Mixed subtypes also co-circulated, with H5N2 clade 2.3.4.4 HPAIVs being accompanied by the H5N8 and H5N3 subtypes or ancient H5N2 viruses in the same farm. More than 90% of domestic geese died from this AI epidemic; Geese were hardest hit in the early outbreaks. The epidemic peaked in mid-January for all three new H5 subtypes. Spatial epidemiology revealed that the most affected areas were in southwestern coastal areas. Different geographic distributions of AI virus subtypes were found in terrestrial fowl (mainly chickens), with hot spots of H5N2 clade 2.3.4.4 compared to previously endemic ancient H5N2 viruses in Changhwa (P=0.03) and Yunlin counties (P=0.007). , or from central Taiwan. Phylogenetic and sequence analyzes of all early 10 Taiwan H5 clade 2.3.4.4 isolates covering the three subtypes showed that they differed strongly from the HA of earlier local H5viruses of domestic ducks (75%-80%) and chickens (70% -75%). However, they had the highest percentages of sequence identity (99.53%-100%), with the HA from A/crane/Kagoshima/KU13/2014(H5N8) isolated on December 7, 2014 in Japan being higher than that of the most recent American and Korean H5-HPAIVs [A/Northern pintail/Washington/40964/2014 (H5N2) and A/gyrfalcon/Washington/41088-6/2014 (H5N8): 99.02% - 99.54% and A/Baikal teal /Korea/Donglim3/2014 (H5N8): 98.61%-99.08%], suggesting a likely common ancestor of these H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses. The multiple subtypes of the H5 clade 2.3.4.4 HPAIVs imply high viral reassortment. We recommend the establishment of an integrated surveillance system that includes clinical, virological, and serological surveillance of poultry and wild birds, swine, and other mammals common in traditional multi-animal mixed farms and high-risk human populations as a critically important step towards future pandemic influenza minimize.
authors: Chang, C. F.;King, C. C.;Wan, C. H.;Chang, Y. C.;Chan, T. C.;David Lee, C. C.;Chou, P. H. B.;Li, Z. R. T.;Li, Y. T.;Tseng, T. J.;Lee, P. F.;Chang, C. H.

title: Dual infection of gnotobiotic calves with bovine group A strains and porcine group C rotavirus affects the pathogenesis of group C rotavirus
abstract: There is serological evidence that group C bovine rotavirus exists in the United States, but there are no reports of its isolation. Ninety fecal samples from calves with diarrhea, 81 samples from adult cows with diarrhea (winter dysentery), and 20 fecal samples from healthy adult cows were analyzed using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, immune electron microscopy, and reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR). Three adult cow diarrheal samples were positive by RT-PCR only, and a group C rotavirus was isolated from a positive sample in monkey (WD534tc/C) kidney cells (MA104). Genetically and serologically, the WD534tc/C strain was more closely related to the group C Cowden swine strain than to the bovine Shintoku strain. Since the original cow feces also contained a group A rotavirus (detected after passage in cell culture), we hypothesized that such dual rotavirus infections might play a role in rotavirus pathogenesis and host adaptation. Therefore, we investigated the pathogenesis of WD534tc/C alone or in combination with virulent (IND/A) or attenuated (NCDV/A) group A bovine rotavirus in gnotobiotic calves. WD534tc/C alone induced diarrhea with no (or limited) virus shedding in vaccinated calves (n=3). In contrast, all calves (n=2) co-infected with WD534tc/C and IND/A developed diarrhea and shed both viruses, while calves (n=3) co-infected with WD534tc/C and NCDV/A developed diarrhea but neither excreted viruses. Infection with WD534tc/C or NCDV/A alone caused only mild villus atrophy (jejunum and/or ileum), while dual infection with both viruses induced lesions throughout the small intestine. Although IND/A alone caused villous atrophy, more widespread small bowel lesions occurred in calves co-infected with WD534tc/C and IND/A. In conclusion, co-infection of calves with group A rotavirus enhanced the faecal shedding of a group C bovine rotavirus and the extent of histopathologic lesions in the small intestine. Thus, our results suggest a possible new hypothesis involving dual infections for the adaptation of heterologous rotaviruses to new host species.
authors: Chang, K. O.;Nielsen, P. R.;Ward, L. A.;Saif, L. J.

title: Nipah Virus: Phylogeny and Replication
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of Nipah virus isolates from Malaysia, Bangladesh and Cambodia indicated the presence of at least two distinct clusters of NiV strains. Based on the major glycoprotein (G) gene, the Nipah virus tambun isolate clustered with Nipah virus isolates from Cambodia and Bangladesh, while the remaining isolates from Malaysia were clustered in a separate cluster. Sequence heterogeneity among Malaysian Nipah virus isolates was noted, but the overall genomic sequence divergence value was low, suggesting a possible recent introduction of the virus. Nipah virus replicated well in stable porcine kidney cells and human lung fibroblast cells. On the other hand, human monocytes were infected with Nipah virus, but the cells did not support productive infection. Similarly, infection of human neuronal cells did not result in the release of high yields of infectious virus. The monocytes can serve to spread Nipah virus from the site of infection, including across the blood-brain barrier. And in the brain, the Nipah virus is probably spread through the cell-to-cell spread mechanism.
authors: Chang, L. Y.;AbuBakar, S.

title: Torque teno minivirus infection in chronic cervicitis and cervical tumors in Isfahan, Iran
abstract: Objectives: Torque teno mini virus (TTMV) is classified as a betatorquevirus genus of Anelloviridoe. Little is known about the prevalence of TTMV in humans. Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer in women worldwide. This study aimed to estimate the TTMV infection frequency in cases of cervicitis and cervical tumors including intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and adenocarcinoma and the possible role of this virus in the etiology of them in an Isfahan population. METHODS: 79 cervicitis cases and 42 tumors were collected from the histopathological records of Al-Zahra Hospital in Isfahan, Iran. DNA was extracted and subjected to nested polymerase chain reaction. Results: A total of 62% of the samples tested were positive for TTMV. It was positive in 52.4% of adenocarcinoma, 68.4% of CIN and 100% of SCC cases. For cervicitis, 48% of cases were positive. In the phylogenetic construct, two of the cervical tumor isolates and two of the cervicitis isolates were placed in the same cluster with previously reported isolates from Japan (EF538880 and AB041962). In addition, three of the isolated cervical tumors (JQ734980, JQ734981, and JQ734982) were arranged in a different cluster. Conclusion: The presence of the virus in cervical tissue suggests possible sexual transmission of the virus. Copyright (C) 2013 S. Karger AG, Basel
authors: Changani, L.;Bouzari, M.;Talebi, A.

title: Isolation and characterization of a feline syncytial virus
abstract: syncytium-forming virus was isolated by trypsinization culturing and serial passage of kidney tissue from an apparently normal kitten. Growth of the virus in the Crandell feline kidney cell line and a complete study of its biological properties were performed. The morphogenesis and morphology of this feline syncytial virus was examined by electron microscopy. The properties of the virus as shown in this study warrant further efforts to definitively classify it. It is concluded that feline syncytial virus, bovine syncytial virus and monkey effervescent all belong to the same virus group.
authors: Chappuis, G.;Tektoff, J.

title: Host specificity, pathogen exposure, and superinfections affect the distribution of Anaplasma phagocytophilum genotypes in ticks, deer, and livestock in a fragmented agricultural landscape
abstract: Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterial pathogen that is mainly transmitted by Ixodes ricinus ticks in Europe. It infects wild mammals, livestock, and occasionally humans. Roe deer are considered the main reservoir, but the genotypes they carry differ from those found in livestock and humans. Here we investigated whether roe deer are the main source of the A. phagocytophilum genotypes circulating in searches for I. ricinus nymphs in a fragmented agricultural landscape in France. First, we assessed pathogen prevalence in 1837 I. ricinus nymphs (sampled along georeferenced transects) and 79 roe deer. The prevalence differed dramatically between ticks and deer: 1.9% and 76%, respectively. Second, we characterized the diversity of A. phagocytophilum genotypes found in 22 infected ticks and 60 infected deer using high-throughput amplicon sequencing; The aim was to determine the frequency of co-infections. Only 22.7% of infected ticks carried genotypes associated with roe deer. This finding fits with others suggesting that cattle density is the main factor explaining the density of infected ticks. To study epidemiological scenarios that can explain these patterns, we constructed compartment models that focused on how exposure to A. phagocytophilum and infection dynamics affected pathogen prevalence in roe deer. At the exposure levels predicted by the results of this study and the literature, the high prevalence in roe deer was observed only in the model where superinfections could occur during all stages of infection and when the probability of infection after exposure was greater than 0.43. We then interpreted these results from the perspective of livestock and human health.
authors: Chastagner, A.;Pion, A.;Verheyden, H.;Lourtet, B.;Cargnelutti, B.;Picot, D.;Poux, V.;Bard, E.;Plantard, O.;McCoy, K. D.;Leblond, A.;Vourc'h, G.;Bailly, X.

title: Avian influenza A (H9N2) reassortant viruses in chickens in poultry retail stores, Pakistan, 2009-2010
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of influenza viruses collected from chickens in live poultry retail stores in Lahore, Pakistan between December 2009 and February 2010 showed that influenza A(H9N2) lineage polymerase and nonstructural genes were generated by inter- and intra-subtypical reassortments . Many observed amino acid signatures were characteristic of human isolates; hence their circulation might enhance inter- or intra-subtypical rearrangement.
authors: Chaudhry, M.;Angot, A.;Rashid, H. B.;Cattoli, G.;Hussain, M.;Trovo, G.;Drago, A.;Valastro, V.;Thrusfield, M.;Welburn, S.;Eisler, M. C.;Capua, I.

title: Variations in lentiviral gene expression in monocyte-derived macrophages from naturally infected sheep
abstract: 79 1-year-old lambs from three individual farms and one fattening farm were examined for natural lentivirus infection. We used three different methods to detect infection and identify the stage of the ovine lentivirus life cycle in blood-derived macrophages. Cytopathic infectious virus was obtained from 14/14 Border Leicester animals derived from a naturally infected herd. No virus particles, virus proteins, virus-specific antibodies, or viral DNA were detected in samples from 34 lambs from two South Kansas City farms. However, we identified 11 infected animals among 31 fattening lambs. Specific viral proteins were immunoprecipitated from animal macrophages, but no infectious cytopathic virus was isolated from these cells. Cells from ten of the other feedlot animals contained viral DNA, but neither viral particles nor proteins could be detected by our techniques. Thus, in these naturally infected animals, the virus life cycle either proceeded to completion, dependent on the differentiation of infected progenitor cells in the blood, or remained arrested at the DNA stage despite maturation of monocytes to macrophages. Sequence analysis of the env gene of viral genomes from two of the ten fattening sheep revealed sequences that differed from known ovine and caprine lentiviruses. Surprisingly, these sequences have higher identity (of nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences) with caprine arthritis encephalitis virus than with the ovine prototype, Maedi Visna virus. These data suggest that the ovine and caprine lentiviruses found in North American sheep may share a common ancestral genotype that is closely related to the caprine virus.
authors: Chebloune, Y.;Karr, B.;Sheffer, D.;Leung, K.;Narayan, O.

title: Deriving the clonal structure of virus populations from time-series sequencing
abstract: RNA virus populations undergo processes of mutation and selection that result in a mixed population of viral particles. High-throughput sequencing of a viral population subsequently contains a mixed signal from the underlying clones. We want to identify the underlying evolutionary structures. We use two sources of information to attempt this; within segment linkage information and mutation prevalence. We show that clone haplotypes, their prevalence, and maximal parsimony can be identified from reticulated evolutionary structures, although the solutions may not be unique, even for complete information sets. This is applied to an influenza infection chain, where we infer evolutionary structures, including reassortment, and demonstrate some of the interpretation difficulties that arise from deep sequencing due to artifacts such as template switching during PCR amplification.
authors: Chedom, D. F.;Murcia, P. R.;Greenman, C. D.

title: Transmission of viral communities between human individuals during transplantation of fecal microbiota
abstract: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is a highly effective treatment for refractory Clostridium difficile infections. However, concerns remain about unwanted co-transmission of pathogenic microbes such as viruses. Here we evaluated FMT from a single healthy human donor to three pediatric patients with ulcerative colitis, each receiving a course of 22 to 30 FMT treatments. Viral particles were purified from donor and recipient stool samples and sequenced; The reads were then assembled into contigs corresponding to viral genomes or partial genomes. Transmission of selected viruses was confirmed by quantitative PCR. Viral contigs present in the donor could be easily detected in recipients, with up to 32 different donor viral contigs appearing in one recipient sample. Reassuringly, none of these viruses have been known to replicate on human cells. Instead, viral contigs were either assessed as bacteriophage or could not be assigned taxonomically, suggesting an unstudied phage. The two most commonly transmitted gene types have been implicated in temperate phage replication. In addition, it has been found that members of Siphoviridae, the group of typically temperate phages that includes lambda phage, are transmitted with significantly greater efficiency than other groups. Based on these results, we propose that temperate phage replication style may promote efficient phage transfer between human individuals. In summary, we have documented the transmission of multiple viral lineages between human individuals by FMT, but in this case series none were from viral groups known to infect human cells. IMPORTANCE The transmission of entire viral communities between humans has rarely been studied but is likely to be of medical importance. Here we investigated fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT), a highly successful treatment for recurrent Clostridium difficile infections and possibly other gastrointestinal (GI) disorders. We studied viral community transmission during FMT and documented transmission of multiple viral lineages between humans. None of these were viruses that replicated on animal cells or were known to be pathogenic. We found that temperate bacteriophages that form stable associations with their hosts were significantly more likely to be transmitted during FMT. This supports a model in which the viral moderate replication style may have evolved in part to support efficient viral transmission between environments.
authors: Chehoud, C.;Dryga, A.;Hwang, Y.;Nagy-Szakal, D.;Hollister, E. B.;Luna, R. A.;Versalovic, J.;Kellermayer, R.;Bushman, F. D.

title: Complete genome sequence of the mesogenic vaccine strain R2B of Newcastle disease virus from India
abstract: Mesogenic vaccine strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) are widely used in many countries in Asia and Africa to control Newcastle disease in poultry. In India, the mesogenic strain R2B was introduced in 1945; It protects adult chickens pre-vaccinated with a lentogenic vaccine virus and provides long-lasting immunity. In this article we report the complete genome sequence of the hitherto unsequenced Indian vaccine strain R2B. The viral genome is 15,186 nucleotides long and contains the polybasic amino acid motif in the cleavage site of the fusion protein, indicating that this vaccine strain evolved from a virulent virus. The phylogenetic analysis of this mesogenic vaccine virus classified it with the viruses belonging to genotype III of class cluster II of NDV. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Chellappa, M. M.;Dey, S.;Gaikwad, S.;Kataria, J. M.;Vakharia, V. N.

title: Minimal nuclear genome sequence typing of bacterial pathogens: a unified approach for clinical and public health microbiology
abstract: Bacterial pathogens represent a major health burden worldwide.
