In the new era of high-throughput sequencing and online bioinformatics, real-time genomic typing of infectious agents, and particularly those with potentially serious clinical consequences, promises to guide clinical care to reduce the harmful effects of Limit infections and prevent potential local infections or global outbreaks. Here we sequenced and compared 85 isolates of Streptococcus suis, a zoonotic pathogen in humans and swine, analyzing 32 recognized serotypes and 75 sequence types, representing species diversity and human clinical isolates of high public health importance . We found that 1,077 of the 2,469 genes are common to all isolates. Excluding 201 common but mobile genes, 876 genes were defined as the species' minimal nuclear genome (MCG). Of 190,894 identified single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), 58,501 were located in the MCG genes and were termed MCG SNPs. A population structure analysis of these MCG SNPs classified the 85 isolates into seven MCG groups, of which MCG group 1 includes all isolates from human infections and outbreaks. Our S. suis MCG typing system provided a clear separation of groups containing human-associated isolates from those containing animal-associated isolates. It also separated the group containing outbreak isolates, including those causing the life-threatening streptococcal toxic shock-like syndrome, from sporadic or less severe meningitis or bacteremia-only isolates. The typing system facilitates the application of genomic data in the fields of clinical medicine and epidemiology and surveillance of S. suis. The MCG groups can also be used as S. suis taxonomic units to define bacterial subpopulations with the potential to cause severe clinical infections and large-scale outbreaks.
authors: Chen, C.;Zhang, W.;Zheng, H.;Lan, R.;Wang, H.;Du, P.;Bai, X.;Ji, S.;Meng, Q.;Jin, D.;Liu, K.;Jing, H.;Ye, C.;Gao, G. F.;Wang, L.;Gottschalk, M.;Xu, J.

title: Genetic analysis of virulence and antimicrobial resistant plasmid pOU7519 in Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis
abstract: Background: Zoonotic Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis (S. Choleraesuis), which causes paratyphoid fever in pigs and bacteremia in humans, usually carry a virulence plasmid and sometimes a separate antimicrobial resistant plasmid or fuse together. This study aimed to analyze the probable mechanism how a virulence-resistance chimera plasmid is formed in S. choleraesuis. Methods: The entire plasmid sequence of pOU7519 in S. choleraesuis strain OU7519 was determined using shotgun cloning and sequencing. Sequence annotation and comparison were performed to determine the sequence responsible for the formation of a chimeric virulence resistance pOU7519. Other chimeric plasmids among the pooled strains of S. choleraesuis were also confirmed. Results: The sequence of pOU719, 127,212 bp long, was identified as a chimera of the virulence plasmid pSCV50 and a multidrug resistant plasmid pSC138 found in S. choleraesuis strain SC-B67. The pOU7519 is a conjugative plasmid carrying various mobile DNAs including prophages, insertion sequences, integrins and transposons, in particular a Tn. 6088-like transposon. By dissecting the junction of the pSCV50-pSC138 chimera in pOU7519, defective sequences at the integrase gene scv50 (int) and its attachment site (att) were found and this probably resulted in a stable chimeric plasmid due to failure of excision from pSCV50-pSC138 -Chimera. A similar chimeric structure was also found in other large plasmids. Conclusion: Deletion of both int and att strains could likely block chimera excision and result in an irreversible, stable pSCV50-pSC138 chimera. The emergence of conjugative virulence and antimicrobial resistant plasmids in S. choleraesuis could pose a public health threat.
authors: Chen, C. L.;Su, L. H.;Janapatla, R. P.;Lin, C. Y.;Chiu, C. H.

title: Ordered shotgun sequencing of a 135 kb Xq25 YAC containing ANT2 and four putative genes, three of which were confirmed by EST matches
abstract: Ordered shotgun sequencing (OSS) was successfully performed using an Xq25-YAC substrate. yWXD703 DNA was subcloned into lambda phage and insert-end sequences of the lambda subclones were used to generate a map to select a minimal tiling path of clones to be completely sequenced. The 135,038 nt sequence contains the entire ANT2 cDNA plus four other candidates suggested by computational analysis. One of the putative genes is homologous to a gene involved in Graves' disease and it, ANT2 and two others, are confirmed by EST matches. The results suggest that OSS can be applied to YACs, consistent with previous simulations, and further indicate that the sequence of the YAC accurately reflects the sequence of uncloned human DNA.
authors: Chen, C. N.;Su, Y.;Baybayan, P.;Siruno, A.;Nagaraja, R.;Mazzarella, R.;Schlessinger, D.;Chen, E.

title: Full genome characterization of a rotavirus B (RVB) strain identified in alpine goats with enteritis demonstrates interspecies transmission in RVB bovine strains
abstract: Rotavirus B (RVB) has been associated with enteric disease in many animal species. An RVB strain was identified in pooled gut samples from Alpine goat kids (aged between 2 and 3 days) exhibiting high (>90%) morbidity, and the complete goat RVB genome was characterized. Histology showed villous atrophy, the samples positive for RVB by real-time RT-PCR and next-generation metagenomic sequencing identified only RVB and orf virus. In the VP4 gene segment, the goat RVB strain had a higher percent nucleotide identity with the Indian bovine RVB strains than with the Japanese bovine RVB strains, but the VP7, VP6, VP2, NSP1, NSP2 and American goat RVB NSP5 gene segments genetically related to the Japanese RVB bovine strains. The results indicate a lack of RVB sequences to understand the reassortment or evolutionary relatedness of RVB strains from cattle and goats.
authors: Chen, F.;Knutson, T. P.;Ciarlet, M.;Sturos, M.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Evolutionary relationships between large double-stranded DNA viruses infecting microalgae and other organisms as inferred from DNA polymerase genes
abstract: To examine the genetic relationship between viruses infecting microalgae, fragments of the DNA polymerase gene (DNA pol) were amplified and sequenced from 13 virus clones representing three genera of distantly related microalgae (Chlorella strains NC64A and Pbi, Micromonas pusilla and Chrysochromulina spp.) infect. . Phylogenetic trees d on DNA pol sequences and hybridization of total genomic DNA showed similar branching patterns. The genetic relatedness calculated from the hybridization and sequence data showed good agreement (r=0.90), indicating that DNA pol sequences can be used to determine genetic relatedness and infer phylogenetic relationships between these viruses. The phylogenetic tree derived from the deduced amino acid sequences of DNA pol of 24 dsDNA viruses, including phycodnaviruses, herpesviruses, poxviruses, baculoviruses and African swine fever virus, agreed well with groupings based on the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses. Microalgae viruses are more closely related to each other than to the other dsDNA viruses and form a distinct phyletic group, suggesting that they share a common ancestor and belong to the Phycodnaviridae. In addition, the Phycodnaviridae are more closely related to the Herpesviridae than to other virus families for which DNA pol sequences are available.
authors: Chen, F.;Suttle, C. A.

title: Identification of key genes induced by avian leukemia virus (ALV-J) infection in chicken cells
abstract: Avian leukemia subgroup J (ALV-J) is one of the most detrimental neoplastic diseases in poultry production. However, the differences between somatic cells and immune cells after infection remain poorly understood. The aim of our study was to demonstrate the differential responses of chickens to infection with ALV-J in different cell lines. In this study, we detected changes in transcriptome expression during infection with ALV-J in chick embryo fibroblasts (CEF) and HD11 cell lines. RNA-Seq was used to determine the expression levels of mRNA transcripts from the two cell types after infection with ALV-J at 1, 4, and 7 dpi, and genomic analyzes were used to group differentially expressed genes into signaling pathways. Quantitative real-time PCR confirmed the expression of 336 and 269 differentially expressed genes in CEF and HD11 lines, respectively, involved in innate immunity (OASL, CCL4), adaptive immunity (LYZ, CD72), apoptosis, and autophagy (WISP2 , COMP) are involved. Inflammation (JSC, IL8) and tumorigenesis (PCNA, GPX3). Notable signaling pathways included the PPARs signaling pathway and ECM receptor interactions in CEF, and the Toll-like receptor, NOD-like receptor, and RIG-I-like receptor signaling pathways in HD11. To our knowledge, this is the first study using high-throughput sequencing methods to study viral infections in different cell types. The results of the present study form a basis for the development of potential biological markers for viral infections.
authors: Chen, G.;Li, Z.;Su, S.;Chang, G.;Qiu, L.;Zhu, P.;Zhang, Y.;Xu, Q.

title: Identification and study of a novel avian coronavirus in ducks
abstract: The rapid discovery of novel viruses using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies, including DNA-Seq and RNA-Seq, has greatly enhanced our understanding of viral diversity in recent years. Timely identification of novel viruses using NGS technologies is also important for us to control emerging infectious diseases caused by novel viruses. In this study, we used RNA-Seq. The novel duck-specific CoV was a potential novel species within the genus gammacoronavirus, as indicated by sequences from three regions in the viral 1b gene. We also conducted a study of CoVs in domestic poultry in China using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) targeting the viral nucleocapsid (N) gene. The survey identified a total of 102 CoV positives. Phylogenetic analysis of viral N sequences suggested that CoVs in domestic chickens have diverged into several region- or host-specific clades or subclades around the world, and IBVs can infect ducks, geese and pigeons, although they mainly circulate in chickens. In addition, this study provided new data supporting the notion that some host-specific CoVs other than IBVs circulate in ducks, geese and pigeons, and indicated that the new duck-specific CoV identified by RNA-Seq in this study, Some CoVs are genetically closer to circulating in wild waterfowl. Taken together, this study has provided new insights into the diversity, distribution, evolution and control of avian CoVs. © 2013 Chen et al.
authors: Chen, G. Q.;Zhuang, Q. Y.;Wang, K. C.;Liu, S.;Shao, J. Z.;Jiang, W. M.;Hou, G. Y.;Li, J. P.;Yu, J. M.;Li, Y. P.;Chen, J. M.

title: Evolution of the complete matrix and the Matrix1, Matrix2 gene of H3N8 equine influenza virus
abstract: In our study, the H3N8 equine influenza virus (EIV) M, M1, and M2 genes were analyzed phylogenetically. The aa sequences of the M1 and M2 proteins have also been aligned and mapped. The result showed that the M, M1 and M2 genes of all recent Florida-2 clade EIV strains isolated after 2007 underwent divergent evolution. It evolved into another group called the Aisan group, which was distinct from the Florida-2 group EIV strains isolated before 2007 and more genetically similar to the European group. This was also revealed by aa sequence analysis of M1 and M2 protein. In addition, the phylogenetic tree of the M2 gene showed that it evolved in a different pattern than the full M and M1 genes. The M1 and M2 gene of two equine influenza viruses from A/Swine/Chibi/01/2005 and A/Swine/Anhui/01/2006 have been confirmed here under frozen evolution. Our studies enrich our knowledge of the H3N8 EIV M, M1 and M2 genes and provide the basis for further research on them.
authors: Chen, J.;Guo, X.

title: Genetic variation of Chinese PRRSV strains based on ORF5 sequence
abstract: Thirteen swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) isolates from different provinces of China were examined and compared to several PRRSV isolates from other countries. Phylogenetic analysis shows that all Chinese isolates of PRRSV in this study belong to the American genotype, with the exception of one strain, B13, which was clustered as a European genotype. Sequence analysis revealed that Chinese PRRSV isolates of the American genotype were very similar in ORF5 sequence and could be divided into two subclasses. One contains PRRSV isolates more closely related to the American vaccine strain MLV Resp and its parent strain VR-2332, the other contains those only distantly related to them. Minor genetic variation occurred within the Chinese isolates, and some strains may have originated directly from the vaccine virus. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Chen, J.;Liu, T.;Zhu, C. G.;Jin, Y. F.;Zhang, Y. Z.

title: Molecular epidemiology of porcine epidemic diarrheal virus in China
abstract: Since the beginning of 2006, the porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) has reappeared in immunized pig herds. Open reading frame 3 (ORF3) is the only accessory gene in the PEDV genome. The entire ORF3 genes of 12 PEDV field strains and one vaccine strain were sequenced. The ORF3 genes of Chinese PEDV field strains (except CH/GSJIII/07) contain a single ORF of 672 or 675 nucleotides (nt) encoding a 223 or 224 amino acid peptide. However, the CV777 vaccine strain and CH/GSJIII/07 contain a 276 nt ORF due to a 49 nt deletion at nt 245-293. The Chinese PEDV field strains and PEDV reference strains are divided into three groups based on the phylogenetic relationship of their ORF3 genes. Chinese PEDV field strains (except CH/GSJIII/07) have a close phylogenetic relationship with Korean strains and are genetically distinct from the PEDV vaccine strains. However, CH/GSJIII/07 has a close phylogenetic relationship with two vaccine strains, suggesting that it may have evolved from a live vaccine strain. Chinese PEDV field strains (except CH/GSJIII/07) can be distinguished from PEDV vaccine strains by a nested RT-PCR method. © 2010 Springer Verlag.
authors: Chen, J.;Wang, C.;Shi, H.;Qiu, H.;Liu, S.;Chen, X.;Zhang, Z.;Feng, L.

title: Origin and future spread of the new influenza virus A (H1N1) that emerged in North America in 2009
abstract: The origin of the novel influenza virus A (H1N1) that has recently emerged in North America is a hot topic of controversy of importance to disease control and risk assessment. Some experts claimed it was an unusually mixed mix of human, avian and swine flu viruses, while others concluded it was an entirely simple rearrangement of two lineages of swine flu viruses. Here, the phylogenetic diversity of the viral PB1, PA, and PB2 gene sequences using online web servers and the results suggest that all 8 genetic segments of the new virus may have originated from two swine influenza virus lineages and one of the lineages a mongrelized mix human, avian and swine flu viruses that appeared in the world about 10 years ago. Considering the recent epidemiological trends of the new virus, we believe it will continue to spread globally and persist in human populations for a long time. It could also spread among swine populations. The future widespread distribution of the new virus may coincide with the disappearance of a subtype of the earlier human influenza A virus.
authors: Chen, J. M.;Sun, Y. X.;Liu, S.;Jiang, W. M.;Chen, J.;Hou, G. Y.;Li, J. P.

title: Reassortant clade 2.3.4.4 of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N6), Taiwan, 2017
abstract: A highly pathogenic A(H5N6) group 2.3.4.4 avian influenza virus was detected in a domestic duck found dead in Taiwan in February 2017. The endemic situation and continued development of various reassortant highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses in Taiwan warrants concern for further reassortment and a fifth wave of intercontinental spread.
authors: Chen, L. H.;Lee, D. H.;Liu, Y. P.;Li, W. C.;Swayne, D. E.;Chang, J. C.;Chen, Y. P.;Lee, F.;Tu, W. J.;Lin, Y. J.

title: Isolation, genome sequencing and functional analysis of two T7-like coliphages from avian pathogen Escherichia coli
abstract: Avian pathogen Escherichia coli (APEC) causes colibacillosis, which results in significant economic losses in the poultry industry worldwide. Because of drug residues and increased antibiotic resistance caused by antibiotic use, bacteriophage and other alternative therapeutics are expected to control APEC infection in poultry. We then studied their biological properties and performed high-throughput genome sequencing and homology analysis of these phages. Assembly results from high-throughput sequencing showed that the structures of both the P483 and P694 genomes consist of linear and double-stranded DNA. The results of electron microscopy and homology analysis showed that both P483 and P694 belong to the T7-like virus, which is a member of the Podoviridae family of the order Caudovirales. Comparative genomic analysis showed that most of the predicted proteins of these two phages had the strongest sequence similarity to Enterobacteria phage BA14 and 285P, Erwinia phage FE44 and Kluyvera phage Kvp1; however, some proteins such as gp0.6a, gp1.7 and gp17 showed lower similarity (<0.85%) to the homologues of other phages in the T7 subgroup. We also found some unique properties of P483 and P694, such as the two types of genes of P694 and no lytic activity of P694 against its host bacteria in liquid medium. Our results serve to advance our understanding of phage evolution from T7-like coliphages and provide the potential application of the phages as therapeutics to treat diseases.
authors: Chen, M.;Xu, J.;Yao, H.;Lu, C.;Zhang, W.

title: Detailed sequencing shows the cross-over map of chimeric genes in two infectious clones of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recombination is an important factor in the genetic diversity of most viruses. A reverse genetics system using green fluorescent protein (GFP) and Enhanced GFP (EGFP)-expressing infectious clones was developed to study the requirements for recombination. However, it is still unclear what types of cross-over events occurred to produce the viable offspring. AIM: We used 454 sequencing to infer recombination events in this system. METHOD: Two infectious Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) clones, P129-EGFP-97C and P129-GFPm-d(2-6), were co-transfected into HEK-293T cells. P129-EGFP-97C is a fully functional virus containing a non-fluorescent EGFP. P129-GFPm-d (2-6) is a defective virus but contains a fluorescent GFPm. Successful recombination was evident by the appearance of a fully functional progeny virus expressing fluorescence. Total RNA was extracted from infected cells expressing fluorescence and the entire fluorescent gene was amplified to produce an amplicon library for 454 sequencing. RESULTS: Deep sequencing showed that nucleotide identities increased from ~37% (in the variable region from 21 nt to 165 nt) to 20% (T<sub>289</sub>C) and then to ~38% (456- 651 nt) changed 100% (672-696 nt) compared to EGFP. The results showed that crossover events occurred in three conserved regions (166–288nt, 290–455nt, 652–671nt), which were also supported by sequence alignments. Remarkably, the short conserved region (652–671nt) turned out to be a crossover hotspot. In addition, four crossover patterns (two single and two double crossovers) could be used to produce viable recombinants. CONCLUSION: The reverse genetics system, which involves the use of high-throughput sequencing, creates a genetic platform to study the generation of viable recombinant viruses.
authors: Chen, N.;Chand, R. J.;Rowland, R. R. R.

title: Viral replication of the porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome and quasi-species evolution in pigs without adaptive immunity
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) replication was studied in a line of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) pigs. Real-time RT-PCR showed a unique course of infection for the SCID group. During the course of infection, viremia was initially significantly lower than in normal littermates, but was significantly increased after 21 days. Deep sequencing of viral structural genes at days 11 and 21 identified seven amino acid substitutions in both normal and SCID pigs. The most significant change was a W99R substitution in GP2, which was present in the inoculum at a frequency of 35% but eventually disappeared in all pigs regardless of immune status. Therefore, amino acid substitutions that occur during an acute infection are likely the result of adaptation of the virus to replicate in pigs and not of immune selection.
authors: Chen, N.;Dekkers, J. C.;Ewen, C. L.;Rowland, R. R.

title: A metagenomic analysis of the fecal vioma RNA fraction indicates high diversity in pigs infected with porcine endemic diarrhea virus in the United States
abstract: Background: The emergence and resurgence of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV) in North America, Asia and Europe has inflicted severe economic losses on the global swine industry. However, the virome of PEDV-infected pigs and its effect on the severity of the disease are still unknown. Advances in sequencing technology have made it possible to characterize the entire microbiome of different body sites for each host. Methods: The aim of this study was to characterize the RNA vioma in PEDV-positive pigs using the hypothesis-free metagenomics approach based on next-generation sequencing. Specifically, 217 PEDV-positive swine fecal swab samples collected from diarrhea-affected piglets in 17 US states during 2015-2016 were analyzed. Results: Bioinformatic analysis based on the Kraken algorithm revealed the presence of up to 9 different RNA genera besides PEDV (genus Alphacoronavirus), including Mamastrovirus (52%, 113/217), Enterovirus (39%, 85/217), Sapelovirus (31%, 67/217), Posavirus (30%, 66/217), Kobuvirus (23%, 49/217), Sapovirus (13%, 28/217), Teschovirus (10%, 22/217), Pasivirus (9%, 20/217) and Deltacoronavirus (3%, 6/217). 58 of 217 piglets (27%) had only one PEDV infection, while the remaining 159 (73%) shed 2 to 9 different viruses. Conclusion: These results demonstrated that PEDV-infected pigs with diarrhea had an extensive RNA viral flora composed of four distinct families: Astroviridae, Picornaviridae, Caliciviridae, and Coronaviridae.
authors: Chen, Q.;Wang, L.;Zheng, Y.;Zhang, J.;Guo, B.;Yoon, K. J.;Gauger, P. C.;Harmon, K. M.;Main, R. G.;Li, G.

title: A novel astrovirus species in the gut of yaks with diarrhea in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, 2013
abstract: The yak (Bos grunniens) is an iconic symbol in the high-altitude region of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Diarrhea is a common disease in yaks, leading to large economic losses. To examine the diversity of viral species, we reported the metagenomic-derived virome in a pooled fecal sample from 20 diarrheal yaks. The nine viruses found in the pooled diarrhea samples were, in order of nucleic acid sequence: influenza A virus, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), rotavirus, ungulate tetraparvovirus 1 (bovine hokovirus), astrovirus (AstV), bovine -Enterovirus, hepatitis E virus, kobuvirus and woodchuck hepatitis virus. Compared to healthy yaks, only AstV had a significantly higher prevalence rate in diarrhea samples, suggesting a correlation with the clinical symptoms of diarrhea in yaks. To further investigate the molecular characterization of yak AstV, a nearly complete genome was obtained from a diarrheal sample. It was 6243 bp in length and shared 46.4-66.2% similarity to other related bovine faecal AstVs. Phylogenetic analysis of the genome showed that the yak AstV fell within the bovine AstVs cluster but was located in a unique lineage, suggesting that a new AstV species was identified in yaks. Interestingly, the ORF2 region of yak AstV had greater similarity and genetic relatedness to deer AstV strain CcAstV-2 than that of bovine AstVs. Further analysis showed that a possible interspecies recombination event occurred in ORF2. In conclusion, this study has advanced our understanding of diarrhea yak viral communities and identified a new AstV that has been associated with diarrhea in yaks.
authors: Chen, X.;Zhang, B.;Yue, H.;Wang, Y.;Zhou, F.;Zhang, Q.;Tang, C.

title: Cloning and molecular characterization of the ORF5 gene from a PRRSV-SN strain from southwest China
abstract: To monitor the genetic variation of PRRSV, the ORF5 gene of PRRSV-SN strain found in Suining City, Sichuan Province was cloned and sequenced. The results indicated that the PRRSV-SN strain was a highly pathogenic PRRSV (HP-PRRSV) variant strain with the North American (NA) genotype. Homology analysis showed that the ORF5 gene of the PRRSV SN isolate shared 89.4% (86.5%) nucleotide (amino acid) sequence similarity to the North American strain VR-2332, 98.8% (96%) similarity to JXA1 and 63.8% (57.7%) similarity to the Lelystad virus strain representative of the European type. Phylogenetic analysis showed that PRRSV-SN belongs to the NA genotype and shares the same subtype as other highly pathogenic PRRSV strains. Amino acid sequence analysis showed that PRRSV-SN has different degrees of variation in the signal peptide, transmembrane region (TM), primary neutralizing epitope (PNE), non-neutral epitopes and N-glycosylation sites compared to VR2332 strain. Antigenicity analyzes showed that the ORF5 gene products of PRRSV-SN and JXA1 have similar antigenic properties and the antigenic epitopes are mainly located in the aa30-39, aa50-60, aa128-141, aa146-155 and aa161-183 regions. In contrast, the antigenic properties of PRRSV-SN are quite different from those of the VR2332 strain. The main differences were that the PRRSV SN strain was significantly narrower than the VR2332 strain in the aa30-39 and the aa50-60 regions, but was significantly broader in the aa136-141 region. The results of this study showed that the epidemic strains causing outbreaks of PRRSV in the farm are still mainly JXA1 variants, but due to the more frequent use of live vaccine immunizations, the genes of the PRRSV epidemic strain still show constant variation. Vaccination with live PRRSV should be reduced and surveillance of PRRSV strains improved.
authors: Chen, X. W.;Li, L.;Yin, M.;Wang, Q.;Luo, W. T.;Ma, Y.;Pu, Z. H.;Zhou, J. L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the human/porcine/avian gene reassortant H1N2 influenza A virus isolated from a pig in China
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Our aim in this study was to determine the genetic characterization and probable origin of H1N2 swine influenza virus (A/Swine/Guangxi/13/2006) (Sw/GX/13/06) from lung tissue of a pig in Guangxi Province , China. METHODS: Eight genes from Sw/GX/13/06 were cloned and genetically analyzed. RESULTS: The hemagglutinin (HA), nucleoprotein (NP), matrix (M), and nonstructural (NS) genes of Sw/GX/13/06 were most closely related to genes from the classical swine H1N1 influenza virus lineage related. The neuraminidase (NA) and PB1 genes were most closely related to the corresponding genes from the human influenza H3N2 virus lineage. The remaining two genes, PA and PB2 polymerase genes, were most closely related to the genes from the avian influenza virus lineage. CONCLUSION: Phylogenetic analyzes indicated that Sw/GX/13/06 was a human/porcine/avian H1N2 virus and was closely related to H1N2 viruses isolated from swine in the United States (1999-2001) and Korea (2002) were isolated. To our knowledge, Sw/GX/13/06 was the first triple reassortant H1N2 influenza A virus isolated from a pig in China. Whether the Sw/GX/13/06 poses a potential threat to the breeding farm and human health needs further investigation.
authors: Chen, Y.;Meng, X.;Liu, Q.;Huang, X.;Huang, S.;Liu, C.;Shi, K.;Guo, J.;Chen, F.;Hu, L.

title: Gene expression profile upon activation of RIG-I in 5'ppp dsRNA-challenged DF1
abstract: The retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) can recognize influenza viruses and trigger the innate immune response. RIG-I is absent from the chicken genome but conserved in the duck genome. The absence of RIG-I makes chickens more susceptible to avian influenza infection and the clinical signs are more pronounced than in other poultry. It is not known whether introduction of duck RIG-I into chicken cells can establish immunity as seen in ducks, and the role of RIG-I in established immunity is unknown. In this study, a chicken cell strain with stable expression of duRIG-I was established by lentiviral infection, resulting in DF1/LV5-RIG-I, and a control strain DF1/LV5 was established in parallel. To verify stable, high-level expression of duRIG-I in DF1 cells, duRIG-I mRNA and protein levels were determined by real-time RT-PCR and Western blot, respectively. Furthermore, double-stranded 5'-triphosphate RNA (5'ppp-dsRNA) was used to mimic RNA virus infection and the infected DF1/LV5-RIG-I and DF1/LV5 cells were subjected to high-throughput RNA sequencing , which yielded 193.46 M reads and 39.07 G bases. A total of 278 differentially expressed genes (DEGs), ie duRIG-I-mediated responsive genes, were identified by RNA-seq. Among the 278 genes, 120 DEGs are annotated in the KEGG database, and the most reliable KEGG pathways are probably the RIG-I-like receptor signaling pathways. Functional analysis by gene ontology (GO) reveals that the functions of these DEGs are primarily related to type I interferon (IFN) signaling, IFN-β-mediated cellular responses, and upregulation of the RIG-I signaling pathway. Based on the common genes of different signaling pathways, a network representing the crosstalk between RIG-I and other signaling pathways was constructed using Cytoscape software. The network suggests that RIG-mediated signaling may interact with Jak-STAT signaling, Toll-like receptor signaling, Wnt signaling, ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis, and MAPK signaling during the transmission of antiviral signals . After screening, a panel of important responsive genes in RIG-I-mediated signaling pathways, such as ISG12-2, Mx1, IFIT5, TRIM25, USP18, STAT1, STAT2, IRF1, IRF7, and IRF8, were analyzed for differential expression by real-time RT-PCR. In summary, by combining our results and the current literature, we propose a RIG-I-mediated signaling network in chickens.
authors: Chen, Y.;Xu, Q.;Li, Y.;Liu, R.;Huang, Z.;Wang, B.;Chen, G.

title: Characterization of a newly discovered bacteriophage infecting Bordetella bronchiseptica in pigs
abstract: novel virulent bacteriophage, vB_BbrM_PHB04, infecting Bordetella bronchiseptica was isolated from wastewater collected from a pig farm in China. The phage vB_BbrM_PHB04 showed growth over a wide range of temperature and pH conditions and showed different efficiencies of plating values and lytic spectra within the same strains at 25°C and 37°C. High-throughput sequencing revealed that vB_BbrM_PHB04 has a linear double-stranded DNA genome with 124 putative open reading frames. Overall, the genome of vB_BbrM_PHB04 showed very little similarity (the highest nucleotide identity 82%, 1% coverage) to other phage sequences in the GenBank database. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that vB_BbrM_PHB04 is a new member of the family Myoviridae. Furthermore, detection of phage genes in phage-resistant B. bronchiseptica variants based on the polymerase chain reaction did not indicate any lysogenic activity of the phage vB_BbrM_PHB04.
authors: Chen, Y.;Yang, L.;Sun, E.;Song, J.;Wu, B.

title: Co-circulation of pandemic H1N1-2009, classical swine H1N1, and avian-like swine H1N1 influenza viruses in pigs in China
abstract: The pandemic A/H1N1 influenza viruses emerged in both Mexico and the United States in March 2009 and have been transmitted efficiently in the human population. They have occasionally been transmitted from humans to other mammals such as pigs, dogs, and cats. In this study, we report the isolation and genetic analysis of novel viruses in pigs in China. These viruses were phylogenetically related to the 2009 H1N1 pandemic influenza viruses isolated from humans and swine, suggesting that the pandemic virus is currently circulating in swine populations, and this hypothesis was supported by serological monitoring of swine sera collected during the same period. further supported. In addition, we isolated two other H1N1 viruses belonging to the lineages classical swine H1N1 virus and avian-like swine H1N1 virus, respectively. Multiple genetic lineages of H1N1 viruses are circulating in the swine population, underscoring the importance of intensive swine flu surveillance in China. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Chen, Y.;Zhang, J.;Qiao, C.;Yang, H.;Zhang, Y.;Xin, X.;Chen, H.

title: Replacement of Japanese encephalitis virus genotype, Taiwan, 2009-2010
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus genotype I first emerged in Taiwan in 2008. Phylogenetic analysis of 37 viruses from swine farms in 2009-2010 classified these viruses into 2 unique subclusters of genotype I viruses and suggested multiple introduction and rapid replacement of genotype III virus with genotype I virus in Taiwan.
authors: Chen, Y. Y.;Fan, Y. C.;Tu, W. C.;Chang, R. Y.;Shih, C. C.;Lu, I. H.;Chien, M. S.;Lee, W. C.;Chen, T. H.;Chang, G. J.;Chiou, S. S.

title: Genetic diversity in the envelope genes of current US porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus strains affects viral antigenicity
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most economically important swine diseases caused by porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV). Genomic sequences of 66 PRRSV strains were obtained using metagenomic sequencing of serum samples collected in the US in 2014 to examine contemporary genetic diversity. Phylogenetic analysis of the genes encoding the coat proteins identified four to eight distinct lineages with >87% intraclade identity. To examine the impact of observed genetic diversity on antigenicity, genomic regions encoding either GP2a-GP3-GP4 or GP5-M in strain SD95-21 were mutated by alleles from each of eight different PRRSV strains using reverse replaced genetics. The GP2a-GP3-GP4 region from only four of the eight strains yielded viable recombinant virus. When viable, both GP2a-GP3-GP4 and GP5-M affected antigenicity differently. A strain-dependent significant loss of cross-reactivity was variably observed by indirect immunofluorescence assays using antisera from pigs vaccinated with commercial modified live vaccines after replacement of GP2a-GP3-GP4 or GP5-M. Significantly reduced neutralization titers were similarly measured using antisera from naturally exposed PRRSV pigs. These results illustrate the need to consider genomic regions adjacent to GP5 for PRRSV epidemiology and vaccination.
authors: Chen, Z.;Collin, E.;Peddireddi, L.;Clement, T.;Gauger, P.;Hause, B. M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Indian rabies virus isolates targeting the complete glycoprotein gene
abstract: Rabies, a deadly viral zoonosis, is endemic in India. There is no report of a phylogenetic study of Indian rabies virus isolates based on the complete G gene. In the present study, a total of 25 rabies-positive brain samples collected between 2001 and 2014 from North India (UP, MP, Delhi, Rajasthan), South India (Kerala and Karnataka) and Gujarat states belonging to six different host species were exposed to G gene amplification by RT-PCR as three overlapping fragments of 881 bp, 991 bp and 618 bp. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that all Indian rabies virus isolates are genetically closely related to arctic 1a lineage viruses. However, two distinct clusters have been identified, namely India South and India North. All Indian rabies isolates had 95.5-100% homology in geography but not in host species. Deduced amino acids comparison showed two amino acid changes, aa 356 in ECTO; N.â†'K and aa 458; M. â†' I which have been found to discriminate between the India South and India North isolates.
authors: Cherian, S.;Singh, R.;Singh, K. P.;Manjunatha Reddy, G. B.;Anjaneya;Ravi Kumar, G. V. P. P. S.;Sumithra, T. G.;Singh, R. P.

title: Evolution of Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus in Canada from 1997 to 2013
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a rapidly evolving, single-stranded RNA virus and a production-limiting pathogen of cattle worldwide. 79 virus isolates collected in Canada between 1997 and 2013 were subjected to next-generation sequencing. Bayesian phylogenetics was used to assess the evolution of this virus. A mean substitution rate of 1.4 x 10 x 3 substitutions/site/year was found for both BVDV1 and BVDV2. Evolution rates in the E2 gene were slightly faster than in other regions. We also identified population structures below the subgenotype level that are likely to have phenotypic effects. Two distinct clusters within BVDV2a are present and can be distinguished in part by a tyrosine to isoleucine mutation at position 963 in the E2 protein, a position associated with the antigenicity of BVDV1 isolates. Pronounced accumulation within all subgenotypes, particularly BVDV2a, is evident and could lead to new levels of genotypic classification. Therefore, continuous monitoring of emerging variants is required.
authors: Chernick, A.;van der Meer, F.

title: Identification of several clades of novel single-stranded circular DNA viruses with conserved stem-loop structures in pig faeces
abstract: Metagenomic analysis of fecal samples collected from pigs with diarrhea detected sequences encoding a replication initiator protein (Rep). The genomes of ten novel single-stranded DNA viruses were determined and revealed a similar genome organization. The two putative open reading frames (ORFs) encoding Rep and the capsid protein are bidirectionally transcribed and separated by two intergenic regions. Stem-loop structures typical of genomes governed by the rolling circle DNA replication mechanism have been observed. Phylogenetically, these ten genomes are in a monophyletic clade with the previously described swine stool-associated virus (PoSCV), but are so diverse that they can be further classified into up to six different virus clades.
authors: Cheung, A. K.;Ng, T. F.;Lager, K. M.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E.;Pogranichniy, R. M.

title: Unique circovirus-like genome detected in pig feces
abstract: Using a metagenomic approach and molecular cloning methods, we identified, cloned and sequenced the complete genome of a novel circular DNA virus, pig stool-associated virus (PoSCV4), from pig faeces. Phylogenetic analysis of the deduced replication initiator protein showed that PoSCV4 is most closely related to a fur seal droppings-associated circular DNA virus.
authors: Cheung, A. K.;Ng, T. F.;Lager, K. M.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E. L.;Pogranichniy, R. M.

title: A variant group of circular single-stranded DNA viruses from pig feces
abstract: Using metagenomics and molecular cloning methods, we characterized five novel small, circular virus genomes from porcine faeces that are distantly related to chimpanzee and porcine faecal-associated circular viruses (ChiSCV and PoSCV1). Phylogenetic analysis placed these viruses in a highly divergent group of this rapidly growing new virus family. Tentatively named Porcine Stool-associated Circular Virus 2 and 3 (PoSCV2 and PoSCV3), this new group of viruses encodes a stem-loop structure (putatively the origin of DNA replication) in the small intergenic region and a replication Initiator protein commonly found in other biological systems that replicate their genomes via the rolling circle mechanism. In addition, these viruses also have three additional overlapping open reading frames in the large intergenic region between the capsid and replication initiator protein genes. © 2013 Springer-Verlag Vienna (outside the USA).
authors: Cheung, A. K.;Ng, T. F.;Lager, K. M.;Bayles, D. O.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E. L.;Pogranichniy, R. M.;Kehrli Jr, M. E.

title: Biology of the Influenza Virus
abstract: Outbreaks of avian influenza A virus in poultry and humans over the past decade have posed a pandemic threat to humans. Here we discuss the basic classification and structure of influenza A virus. The viral genome contains eight viral RNA segments and the functions of viral proteins encoded by this genome are described. In addition, the RNA transcription and replication of this virus will be checked. © 2007 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Cheung, T. K. W.;Poon, L. L. M.

title: Genome analysis of orf virus isolates from goats in Fujian province in southern China
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV), a species of the genus Parapoxvirus of the family Poxviridae, causes a non-systemic, highly contagious and outbreak disease in sheep, goats and other wild and domestic ruminants. Our work to date shows that ORF is ubiquitous in Fujian province of China, a region where there is considerable heterogeneity among ORFVs. In this study, we sequenced whole genomes of four Fujian goat ORFV strains (OV-GO, OV-YX, OV-NP and OV-SJ1). The four strains were 132-139 kb in length, each containing 124-132 genes and approximately 64% G+C content. The most notable differences between the four strains were found near the ends of the genome. Compared to other ORFVs, OV-NP lacked seven and OV-SJ1 three genes near the right terminus. We also examined the skin virulence of the four Fujian ORFVs in goats. The ORFVs with gene deletions showed low virulence, while the ORFVs without gene deletions showed high virulence in goats, suggesting that gene deletion may result in attenuation of ORFVs. Gene 134 has been disrupted in the OV-NP genome due to the absence of the original code. The phylogenetic tree based on complete parapoxvirus genomes showed that ovine and caprine ORFV formed distinct branches with 100% bootstrap. Based on the phylogenetic single gene tree of 132 genes of ORFVs, 47 genes can be easily distinguished as ovine or caprine. To further uncover the genetic variation presented in goat ORFVs and sheep ORFVs, we analyzed the deduced amino acid sequences of gene 008, multiple alignment of gene 008 amino acid sequences from the genomes of five goat ORFVs and four sheep ORFVs yielded 33 unique amino acid acids , distinguishing it as having sheep or goats as its host. The availability of genomic sequences of four Fujian goat ORFVs supports our understanding of the diversity of orf virus isolates in this region and may aid in distinguishing between ovine and caprine orf strains.
authors: Chi, X.;Zeng, X.;Li, W.;Hao, W.;Li, M.;Huang, X.;Huang, Y.;Rock, D. L.;Luo, S.;Wang, S.

title: Diagnosis and phylogenetic analysis of multifocal cutaneous orf virus with outbreak of mixed bacterial infection in goats in Fujian Province, China
abstract: Orf virus outbreaks on goat farms are common in China. In this study, we investigated a severe multifocal cutaneous orf virus outbreak with a correlative mixed bacterial infection lasting up to 6 months with high morbidity (93.7%) and mortality (15%) in children in a herd of crossbreeds Goats in Fujian Province in China. The disease was diagnosed as an infection with Orf virus (ORFV XD strain) associated with Streptococcus pluranimalium and Staphylococcus and identified using standard virological and bacteriological techniques. Multiple sequence alignments and phylogenetic analyzes of the entire ORFV genes 011 (B2L), 059 (F1L), 032 and 080 showed that the virus phylogeny, although clustered in branches of conventional ORF virus strains, still showed high variation within this subgroup . Furthermore, the sequences of the ORFV 080 gene allowed us to discriminate between the different strains with a higher resolution and these observations provided us with a comparative view of the ORFV 080 gene. This is the first report describing an outbreak of severe multifocal cutaneous orf virus with associated bacterial infection in China.
authors: Chi, X.;Zeng, X.;Luo, S.

title: Classification and putative origins of Brazilian porcine circovirus 2 derived by phylogenetic and phylogeographic approaches
abstract: Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) is the main causative agent of post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS) and is associated with several syndromes affecting pigs. The PCV2 genome has three major open reading frames (ORFs), of which ORF2 encodes the capsid protein. In this study, the ORF2 nucleotide sequences of 30 Brazilian isolates were analyzed. The sequences were compared to other GenBank sequences using phylogenetic and phylogeographic approaches. Our results show a high sequence variability in Brazil, since in this work the Brazilian isolates were divided into subgroups 1AB, 2D and 2, showing that the virus was introduced into Brazil more than once. On the other hand, most Brazilian isolates appear to have descended from just one introduction. According to the Pig Breeders' Association, the virus was probably introduced several times by importing animals with an asymptomatic form of the virus or by importing contaminated semen. The results indicate the need to implement sow selection programs to avoid importing animals infected with group 1 PCV2. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Chiarelli-Neto, O.;Yotoko, K. S. C.;Vidigal, P. M. P.;Silva, F. M. F.;Castro, L. A.;Fietto, J. L. R.;Silva Jr, A.;Almeida, M. R.

title: Ranaviruses and other members of the Iridoviridae family: their place in the virosphere
abstract: Members of the family Iridoviridae, collectively referred to as iridovirids, are large, double-stranded DNA-containing viruses that infect invertebrates and cold-blooded (ectothermic) vertebrates. Infections in the former often result in massive viral replication, causing the infected animal to become scaly and eventually fatal. Among the latter, infections target a variety of organs and can cause high levels of morbidity and mortality in commercially and ecologically important fish and amphibian species. The viral replication strategy was elucidated primarily by examining frog virus 3 (FV3) with additional input from other iridovirids of ecological or commercial importance. Replication occurs within both the nuclear and cytoplasmic compartments and involves synthesis of genome length and concatemeric DNA, extensive methylation of the viral genome (vertebrate viruses only), coordinated expression of three classes of viral gene products, and formation of icosahedral virions within the cytoplasmic viral assembly sites. Phylogenetic analyzes describe five genera within the family and suggest that members of the families Iridoviridae, Ascoviridae, and Marseilleviridae form a monophyletic lineage in which ascoviruses are most closely related to invertebrate iridoviruses.
authors: Chinchar, V. G.;Waltzek, T. B.;Subramaniam, K.

title: Genetic diversity of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus strains from Iran
abstract: Background: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) is a member of the Bunyaviridae family and the Nairovirus genus. It has a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA genome that is approximately 19.2 kb in size and contains small, medium, and large segments. CCHFVs are relatively diverse in their genomic sequence and are grouped into seven distinct clades based on S-segment sequence analysis and six clades based on M-segment sequences. Our aim was to gain new insights into the molecular epidemiology of CCHFV in Iran. Methods: We analyzed partial and complete nucleotide sequences of the S and M segments from 50 Iranian patients. The extracted RNA was amplified using one-step RT-PCR and then sequenced. The sequences were analyzed using Mega5 software. Results: Phylogenetic analysis of partial S-segment sequences showed that clade IV-(Asia 1), clade IV-(Asia 2) and clade V-(Europe) accounted for 80%, 4% and 14% of the circulating genomic variants of CCHFV However, one of the Iranian tribes (Iran-Kerman/22) was not associated with any other sequence and formed a new clade (VII). Phylogenetic analysis of complete S-segment nucleotide sequences of selected Iranian CCHFV strains, complemented by representative strains from GenBank, revealed a similar topology as subsequences with eight major clusters. A partial M-segment phylogeny positioned the Iranian tribes in association with either Clade III (Asia-Africa) or Clade V (Europe). Conclusion: Phylogenetic analysis revealed subtle links between distant geographic locations, which we suggest could originate either from international livestock trade or from long-distance transmission of CCHFV by infected ticks via bird migration.
authors: Chinikar, S.;Bouzari, S.;Shokrgozar, M. A.;Mostafavi, E.;Jalali, T.;Khakifirouz, S.;Nowotny, N.;Fooks, A. R.;Shah-Hossein, N.

title: Genetic diversity of reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in pigs in Korea
abstract: The high genetic diversity of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) has been an obstacle to the development of an effective porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) vaccine. This study was conducted to evaluate the degree of genetic diversity among PRRSVs from Korean pig farms where wasting and respiratory syndrome were observed from 2005 to 2009. Samples from 786 farms were tested for the presence of PRRSV using the reverse transcription PCR protocol. A total of 117 farms were positive for type 1 PRRSV while 198 farms were positive for type 2. Nucleotide sequences encoding open reading frame (ORF) 5 were analyzed and compared to those of various published PRRSV isolates obtained worldwide. The sequence identity of the ORF 5 in the isolates was 81.6 ± 100% for type 1 viruses and 81.4 ± 100% for type 2 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of ORF 5 sequences showed that Korean type 1 and 2 PRRSVs were mainly classified into three and four clusters, respectively. The analyzed isolates were distributed across the clusters regardless of year of isolation or geographic origin. In conclusion, our results showed that the genetic diversity of PRRSVs from Korean pig farms is high and has been increasing over time. Â© 2013 The Korean Veterinary Science Society.
authors: Choi, E. J.;Lee, C. H.;Song, J. Y.;Song, H. J.;Park, C. K.;Kim, B.;Shin, Y. K.

title: Sequence analysis of old and new strains of porcine circovirus associated with congenital tremors in pigs and their comparison to strains involved in post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome
abstract: The entire genomes of 7 porcine circovirus (PCV) isolates from pigs with congenital tremor (CT), type A2 or postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) were cloned and sequenced. One isolate (CT-PCV-P7) was from a neonatal pig with CT, type A2, in the late 1960's. Two recent PCV isolates (CT-PCV-P5, CT-PCV-P6) were from 2 affected newborn pigs from different farms with independent CT outbreaks; Type A2. Four isolates (PMWS-PCV-P1, PMWS-PCV-P2, PMWS-PCV-P3, PMWS-PCV-P4) were from pigs with PMWS from 4 different herds. A comparative analysis of these PMWS and PCV isolates showed 99% sequence identity to each other and over 96% sequence identity to previously sequenced PCV2 isolates. However, the CT-PCV-P5 and CT-PCV-P6 isolates shared 99% the same identity with each other and, interestingly, with PMWS-PCV isolates as well. There were no consistent genomic differences between PMWS and more recent CT isolates. The CT-PCV-P7 showed 98% identity similarity with PK-15-derived PCV1 and showed only 72% identity similarity with either CT-PCV-P5 or CT-PCV-P6. The phylogenetic analysis confirmed that the old isolate (CT-PCV-P7) and the new isolates (CT-PCV-P5, CT-PCV-P6, PMWS-PCV-PI, PMWS-PCV-P2, PMWS-PCV-P3 , PMWS-PCV-P4) were correctly classified as PCVI and PCV2, respectively.
authors: Choi, J.;Stevenson, G. W.;Kiupel, M.;Harrach, B.;Anothayanontha, L.;Kanitz, C. L.;Mittal, S. K.

title: Molecular epidemiological study of domestic bird lentogenic Newcastle disease virus in live bird markets in Korea
abstract: Newcastle disease surveillance program was conducted at live bird markets in Korea to advance our epidemiological understanding of the disease in Korea. During the surveillance program, 10 lentogenic Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) were isolated and identified from apparently healthy chickens and ducks at live bird markets. The lentogenic viruses had sequence motifs of either 112GKQGRL117 (n=8) or 112GRQGRL117 (n=2) at the F0 cleavage site. Sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of NDV isolates based on the F protein hypervariable region revealed two distinct genotypes: genotypes I (n=8) and II (n=2). Genotype I viruses were most closely related to strain NDV V4 (n=7) or strain NDV Ulster 2C (n=1). In contrast, genotype II viruses are clustered with the NDV vaccine strains (LaSota and VG/GA), which are commonly used as live vaccines in Korea. The epidemiological importance of NDV in live bird markets in Korea is discussed. © 2012 American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Choi, K. S.;Lee, E. K.;Jeon, W. J.;Kwon, J. H.;Lee, J. H.;Sung, H. W.

title: Epidemiological observations of bovine viral diarrheal virus in native Korean calves
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a major disease in livestock farming worldwide. Little research has been done on the BVDV circulating in the Republic of Korea (ROK). The cases outlined in our study were from rectal swabs taken from calves up to 80 days of age. Twenty-two of 99 native Korean calves with diarrhea were identified as BVDV positive and 3 different 50 untranslated region (UTR) sequences were determined. The results showed that BVDV infections in the ROK were mainly found in winter and in calves under 20 days old. Phylogenetic analysis based on the 50-UTR revealed that our Korean native calf cases belonged to BVDV-2a. Therefore, the outcome of this study will be useful to understand the epidemiology and enable producers in the ROK to better protect their livestock. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Choi, K. S.;Song, M. C.

title: Avian influenza viruses in Korean live poultry markets and their pathogenic potential
abstract: We surveyed the live poultry markets in Korea in 2003 and isolated 9 H9N2, 6 H3N2 and 1 H6N1 influenza viruses. Antigenic and phylogenetic analysis showed that all 9 H9N2 isolates from A/Chicken/Korea/25232-96006/96 were of similar lineage (which caused disease in chickens in Korea in 1996) but were distinct from the H9N2 viruses in southeastern China distinguished. They had at least 4 genotypes and replicated in chickens but not in mice. The H3N2 and H6N1 viruses were new to Korea and likely reassortants of Southeast China avian influenza viruses and more recent Korean H9N2 viruses. All 8 segments of H3N2 viruses formed a single phylogenetic cluster with 99.1 to 100% homology. The H3N2 viruses replicated in chickens and mice without prior adaptation, but the H6N1 virus did not. Our results show an increasingly diverse pool of avian influenza viruses in Korea that are potential pandemic influenza pathogens. © 2004 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Choi, Y. K.;Heui Seo, S.;Kim, J. A.;Webby, R. J.;Webster, R. G.

title: Viral metagenomics reveals the presence of highly divergent Quaranjavirus in Rhipicephalus ticks from Mozambique
abstract: Background: Ticks are primary vectors for many known pathogens affecting human and animal populations worldwide, such as: B. tick-borne encephalitis, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever and African swine fever. In this study, viral metagenomics was used to identify which viruses are present in Rhipicephalus spp. available. Ticks collected from the Zambezi Valley in Mozambique. Methods: RNA was amplified using sequence-independent single-primer amplification (SISPA) and high-throughput sequencing was performed on the Ion Torrent platform. The generated sequences were quality checked and classified by BLAST. CodonCode aligners and SeqMan were used to assemble the sequences. Results: The majority of viral sequences showed the closest sequence identity to the family Orthomyxoviridae, although viruses resembling Parvoviridae and Coronaviridae were also identified. Nearly complete sequences of five orthomyxoviral segments (HA, NP, PB1, PB2 and PA) were obtained, which showed 32-52% amino acid identity to known quaranjaviruses. The sequences were most closely related to Wellfleet Bay virus, which was discovered and isolated from eider ducks during a mortality event in the United States. Conclusions: In summary, this study has identified a very divergent virus in the family Orthomyxoviridae associated with Rhipicephalus ticks from Mozambique. Further genetic and biological studies are needed to investigate the possible pathogenesis of the identified orthomyxovirus.
authors: Cholleti, H.;Hayer, J.;Mulandane, F. C.;Falk, K.;Fafetine, J.;Berg, M.;BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.

title: Characterization of fecal virome of captive and feral Tasmanian devils using virus-like particle metagenomics and meta-transcriptomics
authors: Chong, R.;Shi, M.;Grueber, C. E.;Holmes, E. C.;Hogg, C.

title: Effect of seasonal vaccination on variant selection of the influenza A/H3N2 epidemic
abstract: The impact of vaccination on the dynamics of influenza virus variants in humans, unlike in poultry, is largely unknown. In this study, we compared influenza hemagglutinin (HA) gene sequences isolated from vaccinated and unvaccinated populations to annual vaccine strains. A total of 181 influenza A/H3N2 virus samples isolated from 82 vaccinated and 99 non-vaccinated patients (2011-15, four Japanese influenza seasons) were genetically analyzed using a next-generation sequencer. Amino acid (AA) differences from corresponding vaccine strains were found at 74 out of 329 HA1 sites. There were a maximum of four AA differences within epitopes in the first three seasons (2011–14) and fifteen in the final season (2014–15). Deviation to a greater number of AA differences was found to be more significant in isolates from vaccinated compared to unvaccinated patients (P=0.0005 in 2011-14; P=0.0096 in 2014-15). AA difference rates within epitopes were also significantly higher in isolates from vaccinated than non-vaccinated patients (2.64% vs. 2.14% for 2011–14, P=0.033; 7.78% vs. 6, 59% for 2014-15, P=0.058). . The AA differences at seven sites (48I-278K, 128A-142G, 145S, 158K, and 193S) became dominant in subsequent seasons. At all of these sites, dominance was maintained during isolate mismatch with vaccine strains and was lost after vaccine match. Our data suggest that in humans, vaccination-induced immune pressure helps to select for influenza variants that are genetically distant from vaccine strains.
authors: Chong, Y.;Ikematsu, H.

title: The impact of viral and bacterial community diversity on the prevalence of pathogenic E. coli in pre-harvest cattle
authors: Chopyk, J.

title: Pathogenicity, sequence and phylogenetic analysis of Malaysian chicken anemia virus obtained after low and high passages in MSB-1 cells
abstract: Specific pathogen free (SPF) chickens vaccinated with low passage chicken anemia virus (CAV), SMSC-1 and 3-1 isolates produced lesions indicative of CAV infection. Repeated passages of the isolates in cell culture up to passage 60 (P60) and passage 123 produced viruses that showed a significantly reduced level of pathogenicity in SPF chickens compared to the low passage isolates. Sequence comparison showed that nucleotide changes were thought to contribute to virus attenuation only in the coding region of P60 passage isolates. Phylogenetic analysis showed that SMSC-1 and 3-1 diverge widely, but their P60 passage derivatives shared significant homology with a Japanese isolate A2.
authors: Chowdhury, S. M. Z. H.;Omar, A. R.;Aini, I.;Hair-Bejo, M.;Jamaluddin, A. A.;Md-Zain, B. M.;Kono, Y.

title: Characterization of H9N2 Middle East avian influenza viruses reveals heterogeneity at amino acid position 226 in hemagglutinin and potential for transmission to mammals
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are a valuable tool to monitor changes in viral genomes and determine viral genetic heterogeneity. In this study, NGS was applied to poultry clinical specimens from Jordan to detect eleven low pathogenic H9N2 avian influenza viruses (LPAIV). All viruses tested belonged to the Middle Eastern genetic group A of the G1 lineage. Deep sequencing revealed a high degree of heterogeneity of the glutamine and leucine residues at position 226 in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene, increasing specificity for avian or mammalian-type receptors. In addition, additional amino acid changes were identified in PB1, PA, M1, M2 and NS1 in the viruses tested. Compared to single gene amplification, the application of NGS to monitor and characterize H9N2-LPAIV provides a complete genetic profile of emerging isolates and a better understanding of the potential for zoonotic transmission to mammals.
authors: Chrzastek, K.;Lee, D. H.;Gharaibeh, S.;Zsak, A.;Kapczynski, D. R.

title: Using Sequence Independent Single Primer Amplification (SISPA) for the rapid detection, identification and characterization of avian RNA viruses
abstract: Current next-generation sequencing technologies have revolutionized metagenomic analysis of clinical samples. To achieve the non-selective amplification and recovery of low-abundance genetic sequences, a simplified sequence-independent single-primer amplification technique (SISPA) was applied in combination with the MiSeq platform to target negative- and positive-sense single-stranded RNA viral sequences. This method enabled successful sequence assembly of the full or near-full length viral genomes of avian influenza virus (AIV), infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) and Newcastle disease virus (NDV). In addition, SISPA analysis applied to unknown clinical cases of mixed viral infections revealed genome assemblies composed of 98% NDV and 99% IBV genomes. A complete or nearly complete viral genome sequence was obtained with titers at or above 10<sup>4.5</sup> EID<sub>50</sub>/ml (50% infective dose of the embryo) and virus identification could be performed from the Titers are detected at or above 10<sup>3</sup> EID<sub>50</sub>/ml. Taken together, these studies demonstrate a simple template enrichment protocol for the rapid detection and accurate characterization of avian RNA viruses.
authors: Chrzastek, K.;Lee, D. H.;Smith, D.;Sharma, P.;Suarez, D. L.;Pantin-Jackwood, M.;Kapczynski, D. R.

title: Characterization of a novel gyrovirus in human stool and chicken meat
abstract: Background: The sequence-independent amplification of clinical samples can lead to the identification of new pathogens. Aims: To identify novel viruses in human stool samples from patients with diarrhea and to study the ecology and clinical significance of such viruses. Study design: Nucleic acids extracted from stool samples from patients with diarrhea of no known etiology were subjected to random PCR amplification and Roche/454 pyrosequencing. Newly identified viruses were characterized genetically and epidemiologically. Results: Four gyroviruses, chicken anemia virus (CAV), human gyrovirus (HGV)/avian gyrovirus 2 (AGV2), gyrovirus 3 (GyV3), and a novel gyrovirus (tentatively designated gyrovirus 4 (GyV4)) were identified in human stool samples. GyV4 as well as CAV and AGV2/HGV have also been detected in chicken skin and meat for human consumption. Conclusions: A novel gyrovirus (GyV4) was identified in human stool and chicken meat sold for human consumption. This virus was phylogenetically distinct from previously reported chick and human gyroviruses (chicken anemia virus, human gyrovirus, avian gyrovirus 2, and recently reported gyrovirus 3). The epidemiology and pathogenesis of this virus in humans and chickens needs further investigation. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Chu, D. K. W.;Poon, L. L. M.;Chiu, S. S. S.;Chan, K. H.;Ng, E. M.;Bauer, I.;Cheung, T. K.;Ng, I. H. Y.;Guan, Y.;Wang, D.;Peiris, J. S. M.

title: Molecular evidence of a mixed infection of goatpox virus, Orf virus and Mycoplasma capricolum subsp. capripneumoniae in goats
abstract: The current study investigated an outbreak of mixed infection with goatpox virus (GTPV), orf virus (ORFV) and Mycoplasma capricolum subsp. capripneumoniae (MCCP), which occurred on a Chinese goat farm, with a mortality rate of 60.2%. The clinical signs observed were rash and rapid breathing with frequent coughing. Specific fragments of GTPV p32 gene, ORFV B2L gene and MCCP 16S ribosomal RNA gene were synchronously amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) from the tissues of 12 dead goats. The PCR products were cloned, sequenced and compared to related reference sequences in GenBank for further identification of the pathogens. The present study reports on a mixed infection with GTPV, ORFV and MCCP in goats. © 2011 The author(s).
authors: Chu, Y.;Yan, X.;Gao, P.;Zhao, P.;He, Y.;Liu, J.;Lu, Z.

title: Pathotyping and phylogenetic characterization of Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Peru: definition of two new subgenotypes within genotype XII
abstract: Infections of poultry with virulent strains of avian paramyxovirus 1 (APMV-1), also known as Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs), cause Newcastle disease (ND). This highly contagious disease affects poultry and many other bird species worldwide. In countries where the disease is widespread, constant monitoring and characterization of the isolates causing outbreaks is required. In this study, we report the results of pathogenicity testing and phylogenetic analysis of seven NDVs isolated from several regions of Peru between 2004 and 2015. Six viruses had intracerebral pathogenicity indices (ICPIs) between 1.75 and 1.88, consistent with a velogenic pathotype. The remaining virus had an ICPI of 0.00, consistent with a lentogenic pathotype. These results were consistent with the amino acid sequences at the cleavage site of the fusion protein (F). All velogenic isolates had the polybasic amino acid sequence 112RRQKRâ†“F117 at the F cleavage site. Phylogenetic analyzes of complete F gene sequences showed that all isolates are classified in class II of APMV-1. The velogenic viruses are assigned to genotype XII, while the lentogenic virus is assigned to genotype II, which is closely related to the LaSota vaccine strain. In addition, tree topology, bootstrap values, and genetic distances observed within genotype XII led to the identification of new subgenotypes XIIa (in South America) and XIIb (in China), and possibly two clades within genotype XIIa. All velogenous Peruvian viruses belonged to subgenotype XIIa. Overall, our results confirm the presence of genotype XII in Peru and suggest that it is the genotype currently common in our country. The phylogenetic characterization of these isolates helps characterize the evolution of NDV and can aid in the development of vaccines specific to our regional needs.
authors: Chumbe, A.;Izquierdo-Lara, R.;Tataje, L.;Gonzalez, R.;Cribillero, G.;GonzÃ¡lez, A. E.;FernÃ¡ndez-DÃ­az, M.;Icochea, E.

title: Introduction to the Ecology of Arboviruses (Russian)
abstract: Arboviruses represent the largest group of vertebrate viruses. By 1972, around 400 arboviruses had been registered worldwide, of which around 260 viruses were divided into 41 groups based on their antigenic properties; 130 viruses are not yet grouped. In the universal classification system of viruses, arboviruses are classified into 6 genea: alfavirus, flavivirus, rhabdovirus, reovirus, arenavirus, and enterovirus. Members of these genera differ markedly in biology, morphology, and biochemical and antigenic properties, indicating the heterogeneous character of the arbovirus group. The heterogeneity of this group suggests that the arthropod transmission route of the viruses originates independently from different systematically removed virus genera. All known arboviruses are only pathogenic to vertebrates. They also multiply in arthropod tissue (in vivo and in vitro), but have no pathogenic effect there. It is noteworthy that arthropod specific viruses do not replicate in vertebrate tissues. Cycles of arbovirus circulation are largely determined by trophic relationships of hematophagous arthropods to vertebrates. These relations are most numerous in the group of mammals parasitized by ca. 2500 species of midges, midges, sand flies and ixodid, argasid and gamasid ticks. The trophic relationships of arbovirus vectors with birds are significantly inferior to those with mammals. Apparently, no more than 500 species of hematophages of this category are associated with birds. The most numerous relatives of this group of vertebrates are found in mosquitoes and argasid ticks. Close trophic relationship reptilia reptilla is shown by mosquitoes of the genus Deinocerites, some sandflies of the genus Sergentomyia and all ixodid ticks of the genus Aponoma. The total number of species of arbovirus vectors parasitizing on reptiles does not exceed 50. From an ecological point of view, 212 arboviruses can be classified as mammalian, 39 avian and 3 reptilian arboviruses. There is a close positive correlation (coefficient 0.90) between the number of vectors trophically related to one or another group of soil vertebrates and the number of arboviruses specific to that group. The majority of arboviruses are found on one continent, but spread across two to three continents when they have connections to the mainland (North and South America, Africa, and Eurasia). Arboviruses found in the western and eastern hemispheres are ecologically associated with humans (dengue 2 and 3, yellow fever), domestic animals (sheep bluetongue, wad medani), or with migratory birds and their narrowly specific parasites (Tyuleniy virus). (453 references.)
authors: Chunikhin, S. P.

title: Genetic characterization of the rabies virus field isolates detected in the Russian Federation in 2008-2011
abstract: 63 gene N fragments of rabies virus field isolates detected in different regions of the Russian Federation in 2008-2011 were sequenced. Comparison with previously tested isolates and strains has shown that newly isolated isolates can be classified into five previously described phylogenetic groups: Arctic Group, Central Russian Group, Eurasian Group, Northern European Group and Caucasian Group. The Arctic group isolates detected in the Komi Republic were identical to the previously described rabies virus strain from Yakutia. This is the first reliable case of detecting Arctic group rabies virus in the European part of Russia.
authors: Chupin, S. A.;Chernyshova, E. V.;Metlin, A. E.

title: Genetic characterization of swine flu virus H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 in Thailand
abstract: It is known that pigs are a suitable host for the influenza A virus. No phylogenetic analysis of swine influenza virus (SIV) has been attempted in Thailand. The present report presents molecular and phylogenetic analyzes performed on SIV in Thailand. In this study, 12 SIV isolates from the central and eastern part of Thailand were subtyped and the molecular genetics of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase were elucidated. Three subtypes, H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 are described. The phylogenetic analysis of the SIV hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes shows single clusters with swine, human or avian influenza virus at different locations worldwide. Furthermore, amino acid substitutions have been detected at either the receptor binding site or the antigenic sites of the hemagglutinin gene. © 2008 Springer Verlag.
authors: Chutinimitkul, S.;Thippamom, N.;Damrongwatanapokin, S.;Payungporn, S.;Thanawongnuwech, R.;Amonsin, A.;Boonsuk, P.;Sreta, D.;Bunpong, N.;Tantilertcharoen, R.;Chamnanpood, P.;Parchariyanon, S.;Theamboonlers, A.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Ungulate copiparvovirus 1 (bovine parvovirus 2): Characterization of a new genotype and associated viremia in different bovine age groups
abstract: novel bovine parvovirus 2 (BPV2) genotype of 5394 nt was identified by next-generation sequencing from sera of healthy cattle of different ages bred in Rio Grande do Sul State, Brazil. The genome organization of the new BPV2 genotype retains the two ORFs typical of members of the Parvovirinae with 86.4% of the overall nucleotide sequence identities compared to other members of the subfamily. Phylogenetic analysis revealed a similar clustering with two previously described bovine BPV2 within the genus Copiparvovirus. No significant differences (p ≤ 0.05) were found in the distribution of BPV2 infection in cattle in different age groups. This is the third complete or nearly complete BPV2 genome sequence reported to date and may contribute to a better understanding of copiparvovirus biology and its interactions with the host.
authors: Cibulski, S. P.;Teixeira, T. F.;dos Santos, H. F.;de Sales Lima, F. E.;Scheffer, C. M.;Varela, A. P. M.;de Lima, D. A.;Schmidt, C.;Silveira, F.;de Almeida, L. L.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Phylogeny and clinical aspects of the 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) viral infection
abstract: In the spring of 2009, a new swine influenza A (H1N1) virus emerged and spread worldwide, causing an influenza pandemic. Here, 329 nasopharyngeal swabs from patients with flu-like symptoms were analyzed for the presence of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 virus using real-time PCR. 25 specimens from immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients contained pandemic H1N1 virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes revealed no apparent differences in terms of similarity and/or homology between the sequences identified in immunocompetent individuals and those obtained from immunocompromised patients. Pre-existing clinical conditions can influence the outcome of H1N1 disease.
authors: Ciccozzi, M.;Babakir-Mina, M.;Lo Presti, A.;Marcuccilli, F.;Perno, C. F.;Ciotti, M.

title: Metasecretome-selective phage display approach to unlock the functional potential of a ruminal microbial community
abstract: BACKGROUND: In silico, secretome proteins can be predicted from fully sequenced genomes using various available algorithms that identify membrane targeting sequences. For metasecretomes (collection of surface, secreted, and transmembrane proteins from environmental microbial communities), this approach is impractical, considering that the metasecretome open reading frames (ORFs) represent only 10% to 30% of the total metagenome and in the overdue data set poorly represented lead to an overall poor coverage of the metagenomic gene pool, even in large projects. RESULTS: By combining secretome-selective phage display and next-generation sequencing, we focused sequence analysis of the complex rumen microbial community to the metasecretome component of the metagenome. This approach achieved high accumulation (29-fold) of secreted fibrolytic enzymes from the plant-adherent microbial community of bovine rumen. In particular, we have identified hundreds of previously rare modules belonging to cellulosomes, cell-surface complexes specialized for plant fiber recognition and degradation. CONCLUSIONS: As a method, metasecretome phage display combined with next-generation sequencing has the ability to probe the diversity of surface and secreted proteins at low abundance that would otherwise require extraordinarily large metagenomic sequencing projects. As a resource, the metasecretome display library, supported by the data set obtained by next-generation sequencing, is ready for i) affinity selection by standard phage display methodology and ii) easy purification of displayed proteins as part of the virion for the individual functional analysis.
authors: Ciric, M.;Moon, C. D.;Leahy, S. C.;Creevey, C. J.;Altermann, E.;Attwood, G. T.;Rakonjac, J.;Gagic, D.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrheal virus: detection of an increasing number of variants in Italy
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is responsible for severe economic losses on cattle ranches worldwide. BVDV is an RNA virus with high genomic variability that has practical implications for epidemiology, diagnosis, and disease control. Genetic surveillance has been proposed as a first step in combating BVDV. Thirty-seven bovine viral diarrheal viruses were identified and genetically characterized in persistently infected cattle, animals affected by mucosal disease and in bulk milk. The 5-UTR region was amplified and sequenced, and a phylogenetic analysis was performed comparing all Italian sequences of BVDV available in the Genbank database. An unusual number of persistently infected animals were detected on more than one farm. Phylogenetic analysis assigned all our viruses to BVDV type I and distinguished four distinct subgroups within this genotype. Analysis of old and new viruses revealed the circulation of viruses classified in subgroups BVDV Ia and Ij, which have never been reported in Italy.
authors: Ciulli, S.;Galletti, E.;Battilani, M.;Scagliarini, A.;Gentile, A.;Morganti, L.;Prosperi, S.

title: Detection of Tunisian-like pestiviruses in small ruminants in Italy since 2007
abstract: The genus Pestivirus, which belongs to the Flaviviridae family, includes ssRNA+ viruses responsible for infectious diseases in swine, cattle, sheep, goats and other domestic and wild ruminants. Like most RNA viruses, pestivirus has high genome variability with practical implications for epidemiology, diagnosis, and disease control. In addition to the officially recognized species of the genus Pestivirus, such as BVDV-1, BVDV-2, BDV and CSFV, other pestiviruses have been detected. In addition, most ruminant pestiviruses show little or no species specificity, which has been observed in serological tests, and are capable of infecting multiple species. Small ruminants in particular are susceptible hosts for the most heterogeneous group of pestiviruses. The aim of this study was the molecular characterization of pestiviruses isolated from sheep and goats in Sicily, Italy. Phylogenetic analysis of two viral genomic regions (a fragment of the 5'-UTR and the entire Npro regions) revealed the presence of different pestivirus genotypes in the goat and sheep herds analyzed. Two out of five viral isolates were clustered with BVDV-1d viruses, a strain widespread in Italy but never reported in Sicily. The other three isolates formed a distinct cluster with high similarity to Tunisian isolates recently proposed as new pestivirus species. This is the first evidence of the presence of Tunisian-like pestiviruses in small ruminants in Italy. In addition, one of the isolates was collected from a goat, representing the first isolation of a Tunisian pestivirus from this species.
authors: Ciulli, S.;Purpari, G.;Agnello, S.;Di Marco, P.;Di Bella, S.;Volpe, E.;Mira, F.;de Aguiar Saldanha Pinheiro, A. C.;Vullo, S.;Guercio, A.

title: Correlates of protection from human rotavirus disease and the factors affecting protection in low-income settings
abstract: Rotavirus (RV) is the leading cause of gastroenteritis in infants and children worldwide and is associated with high mortality, especially in low-income areas. The virus is classified into G and P serotypes and further into P genotypes based on differences in the surface-exposed proteins VP7 and VP4, respectively. Infection results in a variable level of protection from subsequent reinfection and disease. This protection is predominantly homotypic in some situations, while broader heterotypic protection is reported in other cohorts. Two antigenically distinct oral RV vaccines are licensed and being widely distributed, including in resource-constrained settings, with funding from the GAVI Alliance. The first is a monovalent vaccine derived from a live attenuated human RV strain, while the second is a pentavalent bovine-human reassortment vaccine.
