Both vaccines are highly effective in high-income settings, but greatly reduced levels of protection are reported in low-income countries. Here, the current challenges facing mucosal immunologists and vaccinators aiming to define immunological correlates and to understand the variable levels of protection that these vaccines confer in humans are considered. Such an understanding is critical to maximize the public health impact of current vaccines and also for the development of the next generation of RV vaccines that are needed.
authors: Clarke, E.;Desselberger, U.

title: Structural analysis of electrophoretic variation in the genome profiles of rotavirus field isolates
abstract: Detailed structural studies were performed on five isolates of bovine rotavirus, which showed variability in the migration patterns of their genomic segments when electrophoresed in polyacrylamide gels. The individual genome segments of each isolate were characterized by partial digestion of terminally radioactively labeled RNA with a base-specific nuclease. This analysis showed that while mobility variations were always associated with detectable changes in nucleotide sequence, sequence changes at least as large as those found in segments that showed electrophoretic mobility variation were also detected in segments that did not show mobility variation. Evidence for the occurrence of genomic segment rearrangement between viruses in the field was obtained by analysis of species 11 RNAs from these five isolates. The general conclusion from these results is that great care is needed in interpreting simple genomic profile analyzes of different isolates for epidemiological purposes and that classifying these viruses solely on the basis of genomic electropherotype could be misleading.
authors: Clarke, I. N.;McCrae, M. M. A.

title: Identification and analysis of the first 2009 H1N1 pandemic influenza virus from US feral pigs
authors: Clavijo, A.;Nikooienejad, A.;Esfahani, M. S.

title: Inactivation of type A influenza virus hemagglutinins by physical and chemical means: a classification aid
abstract: The effects of temperature and treatment with sodium dodecyl sulfate, Tween 20, dithiothreitol, trypsin, or guanidine on the hemagglutinating capacity of six strains of type A influenza virus (A(0)/PR8/34, A(1)/CAME/46). , A(2)/J305/57, A(2)/Bethesda/63, A(2)/HK/Aichi/68 and A(2)/HK/80/68), a strain of the swine virus (A/Swine /76/?) and a horse tribe (A/Equi-2/63). The two Hong Kong strains could be easily distinguished from the earlier A(2) strains by the resistance of their hemagglutinins to trypsin treatment and their inability to regain hemagglutination capacity after removal of dithiothreitol from treated virus preparations. In this respect, the horse strain most closely resembled the Hong Kong variants. The pattern of hemagglutination inactivation also distinguishes the porcine, PR8 and CAME strains from each other and from the other five strains. The results suggest that the classification of type A viruses into groups according to the pattern of inactivation of their hemagglutinins can be a valuable adjunct to standard serology for a more accurate classification of these viruses.
authors: Cleeland, R.;Grunberg, E.;Prince, H. N.

title: A complex mosaic of enteroviruses shapes the transmission and evolution of community-acquired hand, foot, and mouth disease within a single hospital
abstract: Human enteroviruses (EV) pose a major public health risk. This is particularly true in the Asia-Pacific region, where there are increasing numbers of cases of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) and large outbreaks of severe neurological disorders associated with EV-A71 have occurred. Despite their importance, key aspects of EV emergence, epidemiology, and evolution remain unclear, and most studies on EV evolution have focused on a limited set of genes. Here we describe the genomic evolution of EV-A viruses collected from pediatric patients with mild disease who attended a single hospital in western Sydney, Australia over an 18 month period. This analysis revealed the presence of eight viral serotypes - Coxsackievirus (CV) A2, A4, A5, A6, A8, A10, A16 and EV-A71 - with up to four different serotypes circulating each month. Although no large-scale outbreaks have occurred, a high degree of geographic and temporal mixing of serotypes has been identified. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that multiple strains of the same serotype were present in the community and that this diversity was characterized by multiple introductions into the Sydney population, with only a single lineage of CV-A6 showing in situ transmission throughout the study period . Genomic analyzes also revealed the presence of new and historical EV recombinants. Notably, our analysis found no association between viral phylogeny, including serotype, and age, sex, or disease severity (in uncomplicated disease). This study highlights the contribution of EV-A viruses other than EV-A71 to mild EV disease, including HFMD in Australia, and underscores the need for increased surveillance of these viruses to improve outbreak preparedness strategies and vaccine design .
authors: Cobbin, J. C. A.;Britton, P. N.;Burrell, R.;Thosar, D.;Selvakumar, K.;Eden, J. S.;Jones, C. A.;Holmes, E. C.

title: Enhanced arbovirus surveillance with deep sequencing: identification of novel rhabdoviruses and bunyaviruses in Australian mosquitoes
abstract: Viral metagenomics characterizes known and identifies unknown viruses based on sequence similarities to previously sequenced viral genomes. A metagenomic approach was used to identify viral sequences in Australian mosquitoes that cause cytopathic effects in inoculated mammalian cell cultures. Sequence comparisons revealed strains of Liao-Ning virus (Reovirus, Seadornavirus), previously only found in China, Stretch Lagoon virus (Reovirus, Orbivirus) infecting livestock, two novel dimarhabdoviruses named Beaumont and North Creek viruses, and two novel orthobunyaviruses named Murrumbidgee and saline ash viruses. The novel viral proteomes differed by ≥50% compared to their closest, previously genetically characterized viral relatives. Deep sequencing also generated genomes of Warrego and Wallal viruses, orbiviruses associated with kangaroo blindness, whose genomes had not yet been fully characterized. This study highlights viral metagenomics along with traditional arbovirus surveillance to characterize known and emerging arboviruses in mosquitoes collected at the site. Follow-up epidemiological studies are needed to determine whether the novel viruses infect humans. © 2013 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Coffey, L. L.;Page, B. L.;Greninger, A. L.;Herring, B. L.;Russell, R. C.;Doggett, S. L.;Haniotis, J.;Wang, C.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E. L.

title: Characterization of ncRNAs in human pathogenic protists using high-throughput sequencing technology
abstract: ncRNAs are key genes in many human diseases, including cancer and viral infections, and have critical functions in pathogenic organisms such as fungi, bacteria, viruses, and protists. Until now, the identification and characterization of ncRNAs associated with disease has been slow or imprecise, requiring many years of testing to understand intricate RNA and protein-gene relationships. High-throughput sequencing now offers the ability to characterize miRNAs, siRNAs, small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNAs), and long ncRNAs at the genomic level, making it faster and easier to elucidate how these ncRNAs contribute to disease state. However, this technology is still relatively new and ncRNA discovery is not a high-priority application for optimized bioinformatics. Here we summarize background concepts and practical approaches to ncRNA analysis using high-throughput sequencing and how it relates to understanding human disease. As a case study, we focus on the parasitic protists Giardia lamblia and Trichomonas vaginalis, for which the large evolutionary distance has led to difficulties in comparing ncRNAs with those of model eukaryotes. A combination of biological, computational, and sequencing approaches has enabled easier classification of ncRNA classes such as snoRNAs, but also aided in the identification of new classes. It is hoped that a better understanding of ncRNA expression and interaction can aid in the development of less harsh treatments for protist-based diseases.
authors: Collins, L. J.

title: The recently identified flavivirus Bamaga virus is transmitted horizontally by Culex mosquitoes and disrupts West Nile virus replication in vitro and transmission in vivo
abstract: Arthropod-borne flaviviruses such as yellow fever (YFV), Zika, and dengue viruses continue to cause significant human disease worldwide. These viruses are transmitted by mosquitoes when a female ingests an infected blood meal from a viraemic vertebrate host and spits the virus out into a subsequent host. Bamagavirus (BgV) is a flavivirus recently discovered in mosquitoes of the Culex sitiens subgroup collected from the Cape York Peninsula in Australia. This virus groups phylogenetically with the YFV group but may be restricted to most vertebrates. However, high levels of replication in a possum cell line (OK) indicate a possible association with marsupials. To determine whether BgV could be horizontally transmitted by mosquitoes, the vector competence of two members of the Cx. Sitiens subgroup, Cx. annulirostris and Cx. sitiens, for the BgV was examined. Eleven to thirteen days after ingestion of an infectious blood meal, the infection rates were 11.3% and 18.8% for Cx. annulirostris and Cx. sitiens or Cx. Annulirostris transmitted the virus at low levels (5.6% had BgV positive saliva overall); Cx. Sitiens did not transmit the virus. When mosquitoes were intrahorassially injected with BgV, the infection and transmission rates for both species were 100% and 82%, respectively. These results provided the first evidence that BgV can be transmitted horizontally from Cx. annulirostris, the main vector of pathogenic zoonotic flaviviruses in Australia. We also investigated whether BgV might disrupt in vitro replication and in vivo infection and transmission of superinfecting pathogenic Culex-associated flaviviruses. BgV significantly reduced the growth of Murray Valley encephalitis virus and West Nile virus (WNV) in vitro. Whereas prior infection with BgV by injection did not inhibit WNV superinfection from Cx. annulirostris were able to transmit WNV significantly less BgV-infected mosquitoes than sham-injected mosquitoes. Taken together, these data contribute to our understanding of flavivirus ecology, transmission pathways by Australian mosquitoes, and mechanisms for superinfection interference.
authors: Colmant, A. M. G.;Hall-Mendelin, S.;Ritchie, S. A.;Bielefeldt-Ohmann, H.;Harrison, J. J.;Newton, N. D.;Oâ€™Brien, C. A.;Cazier, C.;Johansen, C. A.;Hobson-Peters, J.;Hall, R. A.;van den Hurk, A. F.

title: Viromes as a genetic reservoir for the microbial communities in aquatic environments: A focus on antimicrobial resistance genes
abstract: Although studies of viromas isolated from aquatic environments are becoming more common, most of them are limited to characterizing viral taxonomy. Bacterial readouts in viromas abound, but the extent to which this genetic material plays a role in the ecology of aquatic microbiology remains unclear. To this end, we have developed a useful approach to characterize viral and microbial communities of aquatic environments, with a particular focus on identifying microbial genes contained in the viromas. Virus-like particles have been isolated from water samples collected across the Lambro River, from the source to the highly urbanized area of Milan. The derived viromes were analyzed by metagenomic shotgun sequencing looking for the presence and relative abundance of bacterial genes, with a focus on the genes involved in antimicrobial resistance mechanisms. Antibiotic and heavy metal resistance genes were identified in all virome samples, along with a large number of reads that were assigned to cellular processes and signaling pathways. Virome data compared to those identified in the microbiome isolated from the same sample showed differences in terms of functional categories and their relative abundance. To verify the role of the aquatic virus population in bacterial gene transfer, water-based mesocosms were perturbed or unperturbed with a low dose of tetracycline. The results obtained by qPCR assays revealed variations in the abundance of tet genes in the virome and microbiome, highlighting a relevant role of viral populations in microbial gene mobilization.
authors: Colombo, S.;Arioli, S.;Neri, E.;Della Scala, G.;Gargari, G.;Mora, D.

title: Beyond the bacterial microbiota of the gut: the gut virome
authors: Columpsi, P.;Sacchi, P.;Zuccaro, V.

title: Identification of a recombinant enterovirus with torovirus-like gene insertion during an outbreak of diarrhea in fattening pigs
abstract: Outbreaks of diarrhea in pig farms have raised major concerns in Europe and the US because they can result in dramatic pig losses. During a suspected Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV) outbreak in Belgium, we performed viral metagenomics to assess other potential viral pathogens. Although PEDV was detected, its low frequency indicated that other viruses were involved in the outbreak. Interestingly, a porcine bocavirus and several enteroviruses were the most common in the sample. We also observed the presence of a porcine enterovirus genome with a gene insertion resembling a C28 peptidase gene found in toroviruses, which was confirmed by resequencing, bioinformatics, and proteomics approaches. Furthermore, the predicted sites for insertion suggest that this gene was expressed as a single protein rather than a fused protein. Recombination in enteroviruses has been described as a major mechanism for generating genetic diversity, but gene insertions across viral families are rather uncommon. Although such recombinations between families are rare, our results suggest that these events can contribute significantly to viral evolution.
authors: Conceicao-Neto, N.;Theuns, S.;Cui, T.;Zeller, M.;Yinda, C. K.;Christiaens, I.;Heylen, E.;Van Ranst, M.;Carpentier, S.;Nauwynck, H. J.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Fecal virome analysis of three carnivores reveals a novel nodavirus and several gemycircularviruses
authors: ConceiÃ§Ã£o-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.

title: Modular approach to adapt sample preparation procedures for viral metagenomics: a reproducible protocol for virome analysis
authors: ConceiÃ§Ã£o-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;LefrÃ¨re, H.;Bruyn, P. De

title: Hepatitis E virus is widespread in the swine population of Lao People's Democratic Republic and there is evidence of homogeneity with human Chinese genotype 4 isolates
abstract: The aim of this study was to determine the prevalence and genotypic spectrum of hepatitis E virus (HEV) in the swine population of the northern Lao People's Democratic Republic (PDR). We collected 181 fecal samples from domestic pigs aged 6 months and the fecal samples were stored in RNA stabilization buffer due to cold chain and transport limitations. Twenty-one (11.6%) pigs had detectable HEV RNA and 43.5% of the village pig herds were infected. Based on a 240 base pair nucleotide sequence flanking the junction of open reading frames 1, 2 and 3 (ORF1, ORF2 and ORF3), the isolates were classified phylogenetically within genotype 4. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed distinct genetic groupings of the Laotian HEV isolates and two groups of human and porcine HEV isolates from China. This was the first study to detect HEV genotype 4 in the PDR Laos and indicates that pigs are a potential reservoir for human HEV infection. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Conlan, J. V.;Jarman, R. G.;Vongxay, K.;Chinnawirotpisan, P.;Melendrez, M. C.;Fenwick, S.;Thompson, R. C. A.;Blacksell, S. D.

title: Highly divergent hepaciviruses from African cattle
abstract: The hepatitis C virus (HCV; genus Hepacivirus) is a human pathogen of high relevance. Unique hepaciviruses (HV) have recently been discovered in animal hosts. The direct ancestor of HCV has not been found, but the most genetically related animal HVs exist in horses. To investigate whether other peridomestic animals also carry HVs, we analyzed sera from Ghanaian cattle for HVs by reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR). Nine out of 106 samples from different sampling sites contained HV RNA (8.5%) at a mean viral load of 1.6 × 105 copies/mL. The infection did not appear to be related to the age and sex of the cattle. Nearly complete genome sequencing of five representative viruses confirmed the taxonomic classifications. Bovine HVs formed two distinct phylogenetic lineages that differed by up to 17.7% at the nucleotide level in the polyprotein coding region, suggesting cocirculation of different virus subtypes. A conserved microRNA122 binding site in the 5' internal ribosomal entry site indicated liver tropism of bovine HVs. Phylogenetic analyzes indicated the circulation of HVs in cattle for several centuries. Bovine HVs were genetically very different from all other HVs, including HCV. HVs from genetically related equine and bovine hosts were not monophyletic, confirming host shifts during evolution of the Hepacivirus genus. Similar to equine HVs, the genetic diversity of bovine HVs was low compared to that of HCV genotypes. This suggests an impact of human-modified ecology of peridomestic animals on viral diversity. Further studies should investigate the occurrence of bovine HVs in other geographic areas and breeds, viral pathogenicity in cattle, and the potential exposure of human risk groups such as farmers, butchers, and slaughterhouse workers.
authors: Corman, V. M.;Grundhoff, A.;Baechlein, C.;Fischer, N.;Gmyl, A.;Wollny, R.;Dei, D.;Ritz, D.;Binger, T.;Adankwah, E.;Marfo, K. S.;Annison, L.;Annan, A.;Adu-Sarkodie, Y.;Oppong, S.;Becher, P.;Drosten, C.;Drexler, J. F.

title: Next-generation sequencing as a tool to study the macro- and micromolecular epidemiology of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV).
authors: Cortey, M.;Diaz, I.;Martin-Valls, G. E.;Mateu, E.

title: Heterosubtypic neutralizing antibodies are produced by individuals immunized with a seasonal influenza vaccine
abstract: The target of neutralizing antibodies that protect against influenza virus infection is the viral protein HA. The genetic and antigenic variation in HA has been used to classify influenza viruses into subtypes (H1-H16). The neutralizing antibody response to influenza virus is believed to be specific to some antigenically related isolates within a particular subtype. Although heterosubtypic antibodies capable of neutralizing multiple influenza virus subtypes have recently been isolated from phage display libraries, it is not known whether such antibodies are produced in the course of an immune response to influenza virus infection or a vaccine. Here we report that after vaccination with a seasonal influenza vaccine containing influenza virus subtypes H1 and H3, some individuals produce antibodies that cross-react with H5 HA. By immortalizing IgG-expressing B cells from 4 individuals, we isolated 20 heterosubtypic mAbs that bound and neutralized viruses belonging to multiple HA subtypes (H1, H2, H5, H6, and H9), including pandemic A/ Isolate California/07/09 H1N1. The mAbs used different VH genes and carried a high frequency of somatic mutations. With the exception of one mAb that bound to the spherical HA head, all heterosubtypic mAbs bound to acid-sensitive epitopes in the HA stem region. Four mAbs were evaluated in vivo and protected mice from challenge with influenza viruses representative of different subtypes. These results indicate that seasonal influenza vaccination can induce polyclonal heterosubtypic neutralizing antibodies that cross-react with swine pandemic H1N1 influenza virus and with highly pathogenic H5N1 virus.
authors: Corti, D.;Suguitan Jr, A. L.;Pinna, D.;Silacci, C.;Fernandez-Rodriguez, B. M.;Vanzetta, F.;Santos, C.;Luke, C. J.;Torres-Velez, F. J.;Temperton, N. J.;Weiss, R. A.;Sallusto, F.;Subbarao, K.;Lanzavecchia, A.

title: Evaluation of the virulence of some strains of Peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV) in experimentally infected West African pygmy goats
abstract: Various isolates of peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV) from outbreaks in Africa and India were tested for virulence in West African pygmy goats in Ivory Coast. Six groups of five animals each received a virulent suspension of different virus strains at a concentration of 103 TCID50/mL and the goats were observed 15 days after infection. PPRV strains Côte-d'Ivoire 89 (CI89), Guinea Conakry and Bissau Guinea caused peracute disease; the India Calcutta tribe caused an acute illness; the Sudan-Sennar strain caused acute to mild disease, while the wild-type Nigeria 75/1 strain caused mild disease and the animals recovered. The viruses studied contained examples of PPRV from specific lineages based on their nucleoprotein PPRV gene. This experiment demonstrated that virulence traits could be a useful marker to help classify PPRV isolates. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Couacy-Hymann, E.;Bodjo, C.;Danho, T.;Libeau, G.;Diallo, A.

title: Genetic and antigenic variability in isolates of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) from Belgium
abstract: This report describes the genetic and antigenic variability of the bovine viral diarrhea virus strains isolated in Belgium. Part of the 5" untranslated region and the 5" end of the gp53 (E2) coding sequence were amplified by PCR and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis showed that most field isolates segregated into genotypes Ib or II. Only one of 28 field isolates belonged to genotype Ia. Interestingly, some type I strains differed equally from types Ia and Ib and clustered into additional subtypes within genotype I. Immune sera from young calves experimentally vaccinated with field isolates, first identified on the basis of their sequences, were obtained used in two-way neutralization experiments. The results clearly distinguished Type I from Type II strains, although some degree of cross-neutralization was observed. Within type I, the new clusters could not be antigenically distinguished from the more common type Ib strains or from the type Ia strain NADL, suggesting that BVDV genotype I is antigenically homogeneous. The isolation of BVDV type I and II strains from cell lines and from a bovine vaccine suggests that molecular epidemiological surveillance for BVDV is warranted. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Couvreur, B.;Letellier, C.;Collard, A.;Quenon, P.;Dehan, P.;Hamers, C.;Pastoret, P. P.;Kerkhofs, P.

title: Animal genomics in natural reservoirs of infectious diseases
abstract: Natural virus reservoirs such as wild bats, birds, rodents and non-human primates are generally not model organisms, which until recently have offered limited opportunities for in-depth studies. Next-generation sequencing offers a way to partially circumvent this limitation, as the methods required for data acquisition and analysis are largely species-independent. Comparative genomics and other omics offer new opportunities to study the structure and function of diverse biological systems in wild species that are otherwise unattainable. Genomes of natural reservoir hosts can help identify dominant pathways of virus-host interaction and reveal differences between susceptible and resistant organisms, populations and species. This is of great scientific interest and may also provide a resource for the rational design of treatments for viral diseases in humans and livestock. In this way we will “learn from nature” and one day apply this knowledge to breed disease-resistant livestock or to develop novel therapy and prevention strategies. The genomics of the reservoir host will also open up opportunities for the development of novel vaccines for wildlife, aid in the development of new diagnostic platforms, and have far-reaching implications for developmental and evolutionary biology. In this review, the authors focus on natural reservoir hosts of viral pathogens, although most of the discussion points should be equally applicable to natural reservoirs of pathogenic bacteria, fungi, or other parasites.
authors: Cowled, C.;Wang, L. F.

title: Pseudorabies virus infection in Oklahoma hounds
abstract: Pseudorabies are caused by suid herpesvirus 1, a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. Although pigs are the natural host of pseudorabies virus (PRV), the virus has a wide host range and can cause fatal encephalitis in many species. The United States gained PRV-free status in 2004 after eradicating the virus from native swineherds, but the virus is still present in feral pig populations. The current report describes PRV infection in 3 dogs used to hunt wild boar. The dogs developed clinical signs including facial itching with facial abrasions, dyspnea, vomiting, diarrhea, ataxia, muscle stiffness and death. Two were euthanized and 1 died within approximately 48 hours of the onset of clinical symptoms. The prominent histological changes consisted of neutrophilic trigeminal ganglioneuritis with neuronophagia and equivocal intranuclear inclusion bodies. Pseudorabies virus was isolated from fresh tissue from 2 of the dogs and immunohistochemistry detected the virus in the third dog. Virus sequencing and phylogeny, based on available GenBank sequences, indicated that the virus was likely a field strain closely related to a group of PRV strains previously identified in Illinois. Although PRV has been eradicated from domestic pigs in the United States, it is present in feral pig populations and should therefore continue to be considered as a possible cause of disease in dogs and other domestic animals with compatible clinical histories and symptoms. Continuous surveillance is necessary to prevent reintroduction of PRV into domestic pigs. © 2011 American Association of Veterinary Laboratory Diagnosticians.
authors: Cramer, S. D.;Campbell, G. A.;Njaa, B. L.;Morgan, S. E.;Smith, Ii S. K.;McLin, Iv W. R.;Brodersen, B. W.;Wise, A. G.;Scherba, G.;Langohr, I. M.;Maes, R. K.

title: Chronic arthritis in goats caused by a retrovirus
abstract: A virus was isolated from an adult goat with chronic arthritis and its membership in the group of retroviruses was shown by electron microscopy and biochemical methods. Inoculation of the virus into cesarean-derived, specific pathogen-free goat stores produced arthritic lesions similar to those seen in spontaneous disease. The virus was reisolated from the experimentally induced lesions.
authors: Crawford, T. B.;Adams, D. S.;Cheevers, W. P.;Cork, L. C.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza a(h5n1) viruses at the animal-human interface in Vietnam, 2003-2010
abstract: Mutation and reassortment of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses at the animal-human interface remains a major concern for the emergence of viruses with pandemic potential. To understand the relationship between H5N1 viruses circulating in poultry and the viruses isolated from humans, extensive phylogenetic and molecular analyzes of viruses derived from both hosts in Vietnam between 2003 and 2010 were performed. We examined the temporal and spatial distribution of human cases relative to H5N1 outbreaks in poultry and characterized the genetic lineages and amino acid substitutions in each gene segment identified in humans in comparison to closely related avian host viruses. Six emagglutinin clades and 8 genotypes have been identified in humans, all of which were originally identified in poultry. Several amino acid mutations throughout the genome of viruses isolated from humans have been identified, suggesting the potential of avian viruses that infect humans to rapidly acquire molecular markers associated with mammalian adaptation and antiviral resistance
authors: Creanga, A.;Hang, N. L. K.;Cuong, V. D.;Nguyen, H. T.;Phuong, H. V. M.;Thanh, L. T.;Thach, N. C.;Hien, P. T.;Tung, N.;Jang, Y.;Balish, A.;Dang, N. H.;Duong, M. T.;Huong, N. T.;Hoa, D. N.;Tho, N. D.;Klimov, A.;Kapella, B. K.;Gubareva, L.;Kile, J. C.;Hien, N. T.;Mai, L. Q.;Davis, C. T.

title: Emergence of multiple clade 2.3.2.1 influenza A (H5N1) virus subgroups in Vietnam and detection of novel reassortants
abstract: Phylogenetic analyzes of 169 influenza A(H5N1) virus genomes were performed on samples collected between September 2010 and September 2012 through active surveillance and outbreak responses in Vietnam. While Clade 1.1 viruses existed in southern regions, there were three genetically distinct subgroups of Clade 2.3.2.1 found in northern and central Vietnam. The identification of each subgroup corresponded to the detection of novel reassortants, probably due to their overlapping distributions across the country. While the previously identified clade 1.1 and A/Hubei/1/2010-like 2.3.2.1 genotypes remained the predominant viruses detected, four viruses were identified as reassortants between A/Hubei/1/2010-like (HA, NA, PB2, PB1 , PA, NP) and A/Duck/Vietnam/NCVD-885/2010-like (M, NS) viruses, and in one virus, A/Duck/Vietnam/NCVD-885/2010-like HA, NA, PB1 and NP with A/Hubei/1/2010-like PB2 and PA genes. Additionally, clade 2.3.2.1 A/Hong Kong/6841/2010-like viruses, first discovered in mid-2012, have been identified as reassortants composed of A/Hubei/1/2010-like PB2 and PA and A/duck/Vietnam/ NCVD-885/2010-like PB1, NP, NA, M, NS genes. © 2013.
authors: Creanga, A.;Thi Nguyen, D.;Gerloff, N.;Thi Do, H.;Balish, A.;Dang Nguyen, H.;Jang, Y.;Thi Dam, V.;Thor, S.;Jones, J.;Simpson, N.;Shu, B.;Emery, S.;Berman, L.;Nguyen, H. T.;Bryant, J. E.;Lindstrom, S.;Klimov, A.;Donis, R. O.;Davis, C. T.;Nguyen, T.

title: Main molecular aspects of human coronaviruses and homologies with animal coronavirus strains
abstract: Beginning in 1965, following the discovery of several new human respiratory pathogens, a group of viruses that had been known since 1937, though not under the name of coronavirus, emerged. Avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), murine hepatitis virus (MHV) and some newly described human respiratory viruses named OC43 and 229E showed a similar appearance. These viruses displayed a characteristic fringe of large, prominent, petal-shaped peplomers, or spikes, resembling a crown. They were named “coronaviruses” after this characteristic. Shortly after, several new viruses were added to the coronavirus group, causing disease in pigs, rats, turkeys, dogs, cats and cattle. The variety of infected animal species and the large number of organ systems involved have made Coronaviridae one of the most important virus families in veterinary medicine. The two human coronaviruses (HCV) HCV-OC43 and HCV-229E belong to different antigenic groups. HCV-OC43 has an antigenic correlation with neonatal calf diarrhea coronavirus (NCDCV), swine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (HEV), and MHV. HCV-229E is antigenically related to porcine transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) and canine coronavirus (CCV). Coronaviruses as a group contain a single-stranded, positive RNA genome of 27 to 31 kb with an estimated molecular weight of 6 x 106 to 8 x 106 daltons. In infected cells, the viral RNA genome is first transcribed into a full-length negative-strand RNA, which is in turn transcribed into a positive genomic RNA and six to eight subgenomic mRNAs by a mechanism of leader-primed transcription.
authors: Cristallo, A.;Gambaro, F.;Battaglia, M.;Cereda, P. M.

title: Two loci controlling genetic cellular resistance to avian leukosis sarcoma viruses
abstract: Female chickens known to be heterozygous for resistance to avian leukosis sarcoma virus subgroups A and B were mated with males known to be homozygous resistant to both. The progeny were tested for resistance to representative viruses of the A, B and tentatively defined C subgroups on both the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) and in tissue culture. The segregation ratios of resistance to subgroups A and B viruses were consistent with the previously proposed hypothesis that single autosomal recessive genes control resistance to each subgroup. Mixed infection on the CAM and replicated slab infection in tissue culture with subgroup A and B virus showed that resistance to subgroups A and B was inherited independently. Assays of viruses tentatively classified as subgroup C showed that they consisted largely of a mixture of subgroups A and B viruses, or of particles with the host range specificity of both. However, virus stocks in the subgroup C category, as well as some stocks classified as subgroup B, produced small numbers of smallpox or herds in individuals known to be resistant to subgroups A and B viruses. These Rous sarcoma virus stocks are believed to contain between 1 and 10% of true subgroup C virus.
authors: Crittenden, L. B.;Stone, H. A.;Reamer, R. H.;Okazaki, W.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis and Pathogenicity of H3 Subtype Avian Influenza Viruses Isolated from Live Poultry Markets in China
abstract: The H3 subtype influenza A virus is one of the most important subtypes threatening human and animal health. However, the development and pathogenicity of the H3 avian influenza virus (AIV) circulating in domestic birds in China remains largely unclear. In this study, seven H3-AIVs (four H3N2 and three H3N8) were isolated from poultry in the live poultry market (LPM) in China. Phylogenetic analyzes of whole genomes showed that all viruses were grouped in Eurasian ancestry, except that N8 genes from two H3N8 isolates fell in North American ancestry. Interestingly, the N8 gene of an H3N8 and PB2, PB1, NP and NS of two H3N2 isolates are closely related to those of the highly pathogenic H5N8 viruses circulating in Korea and the United States, suggesting that the H3 Similar AIV internal genes could contribute to the highly pathogenic H5N8 viruses. HA gene lineage and antigenic cross-reactivity results showed that two antigenically distinct H3 viruses circulate in LPM in China. Most H3 viruses replicated in the lungs and turbinate of mice without prior adaptation, and the representative H3 viruses infected chickens without causing clinical symptoms. The reassortment of H3 subtype influenza viruses justifies continuous surveillance of LPM in China.
authors: Cui, H.;Shi, Y.;Ruan, T.;Li, X.;Teng, Q.;Chen, H.;Yang, J.;Liu, Q.;Li, Z.

title: Phylogeny, pathogenicity and transmission of H5N1 avian influenza virus in chickens
abstract: We analyzed five H5N1 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) isolated from different birds in China in 2012. We divided the viruses into four genotypes based on whole genome sequences. Viruses DKE26, GSE43 and DKE53 belonged to genotypes 1-3, respectively. The CKE93 and CKE96 viruses have been classified into genotype 4. Genotypes 1-3 correspond to the viruses carrying the clade 2.3.2 HA gene, and genotype 4 is the virus carrying the clade 7.2 HA gene. To better understand the pathogenicity and transmission of the viruses, we infected chickens with 103 EID50 /0.1 ml GSE43 (clade 2.3.2) or CKE93 (clade 7.2) virus. Our results showed that 6 of 7 specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens vaccinated with GSE43 virus were dead before 7 days post-infection, but all SPF chicks vaccinated with CKE93 virus survived the infection survived. Both GSE43 and CKE93 viruses replicated systemically in chickens. The virus titers of the GSE43 virus in the tested organs were apparently higher than those of the CKE93 virus. Our results showed that the pathogenicity and replication of GSE43 in chickens was much higher than that of CKE93. The GSE43 virus could be transmitted between chickens, but the CKE93 could not be transmitted between chickens by naïve contact. Therefore, different clades of H5N1 AIVs possessed different pathogenicities and transmissibility among chickens. Our study contributes to the knowledge of pathogenic variations of common H5N1 viruses.
authors: Cui, J.;Qu, N.;Guo, Y.;Cao, L.;Wu, S.;Mei, K.;Sun, H.;Lu, Y.;Qin, Z.;Jiao, P.;Liao, M.

title: Identification and genetic characterization of a novel circular single-stranded DNA virus in a human upper respiratory tract specimen
abstract: Metagenomic analysis by high-throughput sequencing is a tool for detecting both known and novel viruses. Using this technique, a novel circular single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) viral genome was discovered in respiratory secretions of a feverish traveler. The virus, named Human Respiratory-Associated PSCV-5-like virus (HRAPLV), has a genome spanning 3,018 bases with two putative major ORFs, the capsid (Cap) and replicase (Rep) proteins inverse encode and are separated by two intergenetic regions. A stem-loop structure was predicted in the larger intergenic region (LIR). The predicted amino acid sequences of the Cap and Rep proteins of HRAPLV showed the highest identity with that of porcine stool-associated circular virus 5 isolate CP3 (PoSCV 5) (53.0% and 48.9%, respectively). The host tropism of the virus is unknown and further studies are warranted to determine if this novel virus is associated with human disease.
authors: Cui, L.;Wu, B.;Zhu, X.;Guo, X.;Ge, Y.;Zhao, K.;Qi, X.;Shi, Z.;Zhu, F.;Sun, L.;Zhou, M.

title: Analysis of microRNA expression profiles in DEF cells infected with duck tembusu virus
abstract: Duck tembusu virus (DTMUV), a member of the Flaviviridae family, is a single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus. Since April 2010, the outbreak of DTMUV has caused major economic losses in China's southeastern provinces. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play an important regulatory role in viral infections by binding to host target genes, or viral genomes. Here, to better understand the molecular mechanisms of virus-host interaction, we identified the miRNA expression profiles in DTMUV-infected and uninfected DEF cells by high-throughput sequencing. A total of 287 known and 63 new miRNAs were identified. 48 miRNAs, including 26 known miRNAs and 22 new miRNAs, were differentially expressed in response to DTMUV infection. Among these miRNAs, 37 miRNAs were upregulated and 11 miRNAs were downregulated. 9 miRNAs were randomly selected for validation by qRT-PCR experiment. The results of the qRT-PCR experiment agreed with the sequencing data. GO enrichment showed that the predicted targets of these differentially expressed miRNAs were mainly involved in the regulation of the immune system, cellular processes, and metabolic processes. Analysis of KEGG signaling pathways revealed that predicted target genes were involved in multiple signaling pathways such as Wnt signaling pathway, TGF-beta signaling pathway, mTOR signaling pathway and FoxO signaling pathway. This is the first study examining changes in miRNA expression in DEF cells after DTMUV infection. Our results provide important clues for a better understanding of the DTMUV-host interaction.
authors: Cui, M.;Jia, R.;Huang, J.;Wu, X.;Hu, Z.;Zhang, X.;Wang, M.;Zhu, D.;Chen, S.;Liu, M.;Zhao, X.;Wu, Y.;Yang, Q.;Zhang, S.;Liu, Y.;Zhang, L.;Yin, Z.;Jing, B.;Cheng, A.

title: Precision Surveillance for Viral Respiratory Pathogens: Virome Capture Sequencing for Detection and Genomic Characterization of Severe Acute Respiratory Diseases…
authors: Cummings, M. J.;Tokarz, R.;Bakamutumaho, B.

title: Precision Surveillance for Viral Respiratory Pathogens: Virome Capture Sequencing for Detection and Genomic Characterization of Severe Acute Respiratory Tract Infections in Uganda
abstract: Background: Precise public health is a novel set of methods for targeting disease prevention and reduction in high-risk subpopulations. We applied a precise public health strategy to severe acute respiratory infection (SARI) syndrome surveillance in Uganda by combining spatio-temporal analysis with genome sequencing to detect and characterize respiratory viral agents with epidemic potential. Methods: Using a national surveillance network, we identified patients with unexplained, influenza-negative SARI from 2010-2015. Spatio-temporal analyzes were performed retrospectively to identify clusters of unexplained SARI. Within clusters, respiratory viruses were detected and characterized in naso- and oro-pharyngeal swab specimens using a novel oligonucleotide probe capture (VirCapSeq-VERT) and high-throughput sequencing platform. Linkage to conventional epidemiological strategies further characterized the transmission dynamics of identified pathogens. Results: Among 2,901 unexplained SARI cases, 9 clusters were detected, corresponding to 301 (10.4%) cases. Clusters were more likely to occur in urban areas and during bi-annual rainy seasons. Within the recognized clusters, we identified an unrecognized outbreak of measles-associated SARI; Sequence analysis implied the co-circulation of the endemic B3 genotype and the D4 genotype, probably imported from England. We also discovered a probable nosocomial SARI cluster associated with a novel picobirnavirus most closely related to porcine and dromedary viruses. Conclusions: Using a rigorous public health surveillance approach, we have identified and characterized the genomics of vaccine-preventable and zoonotic respiratory viruses associated with clusters of severe respiratory infections in Uganda. Future studies are needed to assess the feasibility, scalability, and impact of applying similar approaches during real-time public health monitoring in low-income settings.
authors: Cummings, M. J.;Tokarz, R.;Bakamutumaho, B.;Kayiwa, J.;Byaruhanga, T.;Owor, N.;Namagambo, B.;Wolf, A.;Mathema, B.;Lutwama, J. J.;Schluger, N. W.;Lipkin, W. I.;O'Donnell, M. R.

title: One health - one medicine: uniting human and veterinary medicine within an evolutionary paradigm
abstract: health is a concept since early civilization that promoted the view that there was not much distinction between veterinary and human medicine. Although this shared vision survived through the 19th century, it was all but forgotten by the early 20th century. It is now experiencing a renaissance, coinciding with an awakening of the role evolutionary biology plays in human and animal health, including sexually transmitted infections (STIs). A number of STIs in humans have comparable infections in animals; Likewise, both humans and animals have STIs that are unique to each mammalian camp. These similarities and differences offer opportunities for fundamental medical and public health studies, including evolutionary insights, to be gleaned from ongoing interdisciplinary investigations—particularly with the available molecular analysis tools—in a golden age of mutually beneficial discoveries. © 2011 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Currier, R. W.;Steele, J. H.

title: Preliminary characterization of D'Aguilar virus and three Palyam group viruses new to Australia
abstract: Between 1974 and 1980, 424 viruses were isolated at the Long Pocket Laboratories of the Division of Animal Health, CSIRO, either from insects or from the blood of sentinel cattle, and of these 165 cross-reacted with D'Aguilar virus (a Australian Palyam group virus) in a complement fixation assay. Using neutralization tests, these viruses were divided into four serotypes with the isolates D'Aguilar B8112, CSIRO 11, CSIRO 58 and CSIRO 82 as type strains. The last three were new to Australia. Like other orbiviruses, these four serotypes were partially sensitive to either or chloroform treatment. Neutralizing antibodies to D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11, and CSIRO 58 viruses were detected in bovine, buffalo, deer, and sheep sera, but not in human, equine, porcine, or marsupial sera. Antibodies to CSIRO 82 virus were detected in 85% of 26 buffalo and 0.4% of 495 bovine sera tested. Antibody distribution in Australia for D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CSIRO 58 viruses fell within the distribution limits of Culicoides brevitarsis, the insect from which these viruses were most commonly recovered. The antibody distribution for CSIRO 82 virus isolated from a pool containing C. schultzei and C. peregrinus fell within the much more restricted distribution limits of these species. None of these viruses have been linked to disease.
authors: Cybinski, D. H.;St George, T. D.

title: Third category of genome size of avian paramyxovirus serotype 1 (Newcastle disease virus) and evolutionary implications
abstract: The aim of the study was to determine whether there is a connection between molecular patterns and virus evolution. Therefore, the complete genome sequence of two different apathogenic strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) was determined and a third genome size category of 15,198 nucleotides was identified. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that two major divisions occurred in the history of NDV, resulting in three genome size categories. An ancient division in the ancestral reservoir (wild waterfowl species) resulted in two basal sister clades, class I and II, with genome sizes of 15,198 (due to a 12-nucleotide insert in the phosphoprotein gene) and 15,186 nucleotides, respectively. Progenitors of class II viruses colonized chicken populations and were subsequently converted to virulent forms. These occurred more than once and resulted in an early lineage [including genotypes I-IV and H33(W)] with a genome size of 15,186 nucleotides. A second division occurred in the secondary host (chicken) in the 20th century. This led to the branching of a clade (including recent genotypes V-VIII consisting only of pathogenic viruses) with the simultaneous insertion of six nucleotides into the 5-inch non-coding region of the nucleoprotein gene, increasing the genome size to 15,192 nucleotides. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: CzeglÃ©di, A.;UjvÃ¡ri, D.;Somogyi, E.;Wehmann, E.;Werner, O.;Lomniczi, B.

title: Characterization of a cowpox-like orthopoxvirus that caused fatal infection in humans
abstract: In August 1990, an orthopoxvirus (OPV) was isolated from a severe case of a fatal generalized infection in an immunosuppressed 18-year-old man. In this communication we present a detailed characterization of the causative virus strain. Based on different epitope configurations detected by different monoclonal antibodies, the isolate could be distinguished from other OPV species and was classified as vaccinia virus (CP). This classification was confirmed by a species-specific PCR assay and by physical mapping for the restriction enzymes HindIII and XhoI. Evidence that the infection was acquired from a stray cat is provided based on serological data from neutralization tests, blocking ELISAs and Western blot analysis.
authors: Czerny, C. P.;Zeller-Lue, C.;Eis-HÃ¼binger, A. M.;Kaaden, O. R.;Meyer, H.

title: Outbreaks of zoonotic vaccinia viruses in Brazil
abstract: Vaccinia virus (VACV) was used as a live vaccine during the WHO-led campaign to eradicate smallpox in the second half of the 20th century. The program culminated in the eradication of the disease, one of modern medicine's most important achievements. Interestingly, one of the key factors in the successful vaccination campaign - VACV itself - is poorly understood in terms of its natural reservoirs, evolutionary history and origin, since as a naturally occurring virus it is often thought to be extinct. However, orthopoxviruses other than variolavirus have been known to circulate in Brazil since the early 1960s. In particular, VACV has been associated with naturally acquired infections in humans, cattle and possibly other pathogens since 1999, when outbreaks of bovine vaccinia were consistently reported year after year. In this article, we list and discuss the major VACV outbreaks that have occurred in Brazil over the past 20 years. Phylogenetic issues are considered as recent studies indicate a large genetic variance between isolates. Both published and new clinical and epidemiological data are presented. © 2011 Future Medicine Ltd.
authors: Da Fonseca, F. G.;Kroon, E. G.;Nogueira, M. L.;De Souza Trindade, G.

title: Novel bovine papillomavirus type discovered by rolling circle amplification coupled with next-generation sequencing
abstract: At present, fifteen bovine papillomavirus (BPV) types have been identified and classified into four genera: delta papillomavirus, epsilon papillomavirus, dyoxipapillomavirus, and xipapillomavirus. Here the complete genome sequence of a new type of BPV (BPV 04AC14) recovered from a papillomatous lesion is reported. The genome is 7,282 bp in length and exhibits the classic genetic organization and motifs of members of the Papillomaviridae. Phylogenetic maximum likelihood analyzes revealed that BPV 04AC14 clusters with members of the genus Xipapillomavirus. The nucleotide sequence of the L1 capsid protein of the novel BPV is closely related to its counterpart, BPV3, with which it shares 79% similarity. These results indicate that this virus is a new type of BPV in the genus Xipapillomavirus.
authors: Da Silva, F. R. C.;Cibulski, S. P.;Daudt, C.;Weber, M. N.;GuimarÃ£es, L. L. B.;Streck, A. F.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.;Canal, C. W.

title: Zika virus: what do we know about virus structure, transmission mechanisms and neurological consequences?
abstract: The Zika virus epidemic, which began in Brazil in 2014, has spread to >30 countries and territories in Latin America, leading to a rapid increase in the incidence of microcephalic neonates and adults with neurological complications. At the beginning of the outbreak, little was known about Zika virus morphology, genome structure, modes of transmission, and potential to cause neurological malformations and disorders. As basic research progressed, discoveries of the mechanisms of strain variability, viral transmission to the fetus, and neurovirulence were published. These will surely lead to the development of strategies to block vertical virus transmission, neuronal invasion and pathogenesis in the near future. This article provides an overview of the current literature on Zika virus infections with the aim of gaining a holistic insight into their etiology and pathogenesis. We discuss the history and epidemiology of Zika virus in Brazil, virus structure and taxonomy, ancient and newly identified modes of transmission, and neurological consequences of infection.
authors: Da Silva, L. R. C.;De Souza, A. M.

title: A fatal case of Louping-ill in a dog: immune localization and full genome sequencing of the virus
abstract: Louping-ill (LI), caused by Louping-ill virus (LIV), causes an often fatal encephalitis that mainly affects sheep and black grouse (Lagopus lagopus scotica), but also occurs in other species. An adult male border collie dog was diagnosed with definitive lethal LI, and the lesion profile, LIV antigen distribution, and full genome sequence of the responsible LIV were examined to determine if it differed significantly from ovine-derived LIV. There were no gross lesions. The histological lesions were restricted to the central nervous system and included lymphocytic perivascular cuffs, glial foci, neuronal necrosis, and neuronophagia. Immunolocalization of the viral antigen showed that only small amounts were present in neurons. These histological and immunohistochemical findings were similar to those reported in affected sheep. Compared to published complete genome sequences of ovine-derived LIV, there were only very minor differences, and phylogenetically the virus grouped individually between a subclass containing Scottish strains LIV 369/T2 and G and another subclass containing an English isolate LIV A contained. The isolated canine LIV shares a common ancestor with LIV A. These findings suggest that there is no canine-specific strain of LIV, dogs are susceptible to sheep-associated strains of LI, and with the increase in tick prevalence and therefore exposure to LIV a safe, effective vaccine for dogs may be needed.
authors: Dagleish, M. P.;Clark, J. J.;Robson, C.;Tucker, M.;Orton, R. J.;Rocchi, M. S.

title: Evolutionary analysis of Tembusu virus: Evidence for the emergence of a dominant genotype
abstract: We recently identified Tembusu virus (TMUV) as the causative agent of duck contagious disease, which has been spreading in China since 2010. A recent study has pointed to a possible case of human infection by TMUV, underscoring the need for further investigation of TMUV, particularly its evolution. In the absence of information on the evolution of TMUV, we performed extensive phylogenetic analyzes using the largest collection of complete TMUV open reading frame (ORF) sequences. Our results showed that two viral lineages have been associated with the 2010 outbreak in China, and lineage II, specifically sublineage II-c, has emerged as the dominant lineage currently circulating. We concluded that the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of this TMUV arose around 1996. Evidence of natural recombination was also discovered in the TMUV. Molecular fit analyzes showed that strong negative selection shaped the evolution of TMUV, while also identifying a number of codons that were subject to positive pressure. Our study illustrated for the first time the evolutionary history and character of TMUV and will be helpful for the development of vaccines and diagnostics.
authors: Dai, L.;Li, Z.;Tao, P.

title: Next-generation sequencing strategies to characterize the turkey genome
abstract: The turkey genome sequencing project was initiated in 2008 and relies primarily on next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies. Our initial effort used a synergistic combination of 2 NGS platforms (Roche/454 and Illumina GAII), detailed bacterial artificial chromosome maps (BAC) and unique assembly tools to sequence and assemble the genome of the domesticated turkey Meleagris gallopavo. Since it was first published in 2010, efforts to improve genome assembly, gene annotation, and genome analysis have continued. The initial assembly build (2.01) represented approximately 89% of the genome sequence with 17x depth of coverage (931 Mb). Sequence contigs were assigned to 30 of the 40 chromosomes, with approximately 10% of the assembled sequence corresponding to unassigned chromosomes (ChrUn). The sequence was refined by both genome-wide and area-focused sequencing, including shotgun and paired-end sequencing, and targeted sequencing of chromosomal regions with poor or incomplete coverage. This additional effort has improved sequence assembly, resulting in two consecutive higher genome coverage genome builds (25X/Build3.0 and 30X/Build4.0) with a total current sequence of 1,010 MB. Furthermore, BAC with end sequences mapped to Z/W and MG18 (MHC) chromosomes, ChrUn or not in the previous build were isolated, deeply sequenced (Hi-Seq) and incorporated into the latest build (5.0). To support the annotation and to create a gene expression atlas of the most important tissues, a comprehensive set of RNA samples at different developmental stages was collected from female and male turkeys. Transcriptome sequencing data (using Illumina Hi-Seq) will provide information to improve final assembly and ultimately improve sequence annotation. The most current sequence covers more than 95% of the turkey genome and should yield a significantly improved level of gene annotation, making it a valuable resource for studying genetic variation underlying economically important traits in poultry.
authors: Dalloul, R. A.;Zimin, A. V.;Settlage, R. E.;Kim, S.;Reed, K. M.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolates obtained from outbreak cases in commercial chickens and wild pigeons in Ethiopia
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND), caused by the virulent avian paramyxovirus type 1, is one of the major diseases responsible for devastating outbreaks in poultry flocks in Ethiopia. However, information on the genetic properties of Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) circulating in commercial chickens and wild birds is sparse. In this study, we characterized isolates obtained from 2012-2014 ND-suspicious outbreaks from poultry farms (n=8) and feral pigeons (n=4). The NDVs isolated from pathological specimens by inoculation into embryonated chicken eggs were characterized biologically by conventional intracerebral pathogenicity indices (ICPI) and genetically based on phylogenetic analysis of partial F gene sequences (260 bp) encompassing the cleavage site. The ICPI values of isolates from chickens ranged from 0.9 to 1.8; whereas the ICPI of pigeon isolates was 1.4. All isolates contained several basic amino acids at the deduced cleavage site of the fusion protein, which is a typical feature of virulent viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the partial cleavage site of the F gene (260 bp) showed that all virus sequences obtained from pigeons were identical and clustered within genotype VIh, while the virus sequences obtained from chickens were clustered within genotype VIf. The similarity between the viruses obtained from chickens and those obtained from pigeons was between 82.5 and 85.6%. This suggests that different subgenotypes of genotype VI are circulating in the chicken and wild pigeon population in Ethiopia. This warrants further studies to understand the role of wild birds in the epidemiology of NDV in Ethiopia and also highlights the importance of continuous surveillance in both wild and domestic birds.
authors: Damena, D.;Fusaro, A.;Sombo, M.;Belaineh, R.;Heidari, A.;Kebede, A.;Kidane, M.;Chaka, H.

title: Characterization of the Hungarian porcine circovirus 2 genomes associated with PMWS and PDNS cases
abstract: The authors report data from the first survey on the incidence of postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) and porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome (PDNS) in Hungary. A specific PCR method for the detection of porcine circovirus 2 (PCV-2) was developed, which proved to be suitable for diagnostic purposes. PCR screening of organ samples from pigs suspected of having PMWS or PDNS revealed the presence of PCV-2 in 80% of cases. Six PCV-2 genomes from Hungarian isolates have been fully sequenced. The phylogenetic comparison with all available PCV-2 sequences showed that the porcine circoviruses circulating in Hungary are more variable than in several other European countries. Two Hungarian tribes grouped together with the Spanish tribes and formed a group of their own; two others fell into a common group with the French, British and Dutch strains, while two other strains showed the closest relationship to two of the three known German PCV-2 sequences.
authors: DÃ¡n, Ã;MolnÃ¡r, T.;Biksi, I.;GlÃ¡vits, R.;Shaheim, M.;Harrach, B.

title: Application of the SureSelect target enrichment system for next-generation sequencing to obtain the complete bovine leukemia virus genome sequence
abstract: In this study, the SureSelect target enrichment system for Illumina Multiplexed Sequencing was applied to bovine leukemia virus (BLV) proviral DNA sequencing. The complete genomic DNA sequences of four Vietnamese BLV strains were successfully obtained with high read depth values and 100% genome coverage across all sequenced samples in less than a week. This study provides the first complete Vietnamese BLV genome sequences. Their genetic variability and phylogenetic relatedness were also analyzed and compared to those of 28 complete BLV genome sequences from different parts of the world. The results obtained provided new insights into the genetic diversity of the BLV control gene and also allowed us to identify nucleotide mutations in the gene that might not have been detected with the currently available commercial detection kit.
authors: Dao, T. D.;Bui, V. N.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Mizutani, T.;Ogawa, H.;Imai, K.

title: Rift Valley fever and a new paradigm of research and development to combat zoonoses
abstract: Although Rift Valley fever is a disease that, through its broader societal impact, disproportionately affects vulnerable communities with low resilience to economic and environmental challenges, since its discovery in 1931, the Rift Valley fever virus has been widely used by major global donors and neglected in disease control programs. We describe recent outbreaks affecting humans and animals, and discuss the severe socioeconomic impact on affected communities and the slow pace of new vaccine development. We also discuss the mixed global response, fueled largely by the virus's designation as a potential bioterrorism agent and its potential to migrate beyond its traditional East African borders. We advocate a realignment of strategy with increased global collaboration and sense of urgency and investments focused on an equity-based approach, where funding and research are prioritized as needed, inspired by equity and social justice principles.
authors: Dar, O.;McIntyre, S.;Hogarth, S.;Heymann, D.

title: Development and validation of a highly sensitive real-time PCR assay for the rapid detection of parapox viruses
abstract: Parapoxviruses (PaPVs) cause widespread infections in ruminants worldwide. All PaPVs are zoonotic and can infect humans after direct or indirect contact with infected animals. Here we report the development and validation of a highly sensitive real-time PCR assay for the rapid detection of PaPVs. The new assay (referred to as the RVSS assay) was specific only for PaPVs and showed no cross-reactivity with other poxviruses. Using a recombinant plasmid as a positive control, the analytical sensitivity of the assay was determined to 16 genome copies of PaPV per assay. The amplification efficiency estimate (91-99%), the intra- and interassay variability estimate (standard deviation [SD]: 0.28-1.06 and 0.01-0.14, respectively), and the operator variability estimate (SD: 0.78 between laboratories and 0.28 between operators within a laboratory) were within the acceptable range. Diagnostic specificity was evaluated on 100 samples from healthy, normal animals and all but 1 tested negative (99%). Diagnostic sensitivity (DSe) was evaluated on 77 clinical specimens (skin/scab) from infected sheep, goats and cattle and all tested positive (100%). The assay was multiplexed with beta-actin as an internal positive control and the multiplex assay showed the same DSe as the singleplex assay. Further characterization of the PaPV samples by species-specific real-time PCR and nucleotide sequencing of the PCR products after conventional PCR showed the presence of the orf virus not only in sheep and goats, but also in 1 cow. The validated RVSS assay demonstrated high specificity, sensitivity, reproducibility, and robustness, which are critical for laboratory detection of PaPVs.
authors: Das, A.;Ward, G.;Lowe, A.;Xu, L.;Moran, K.;Renshaw, R.;Dubovi, E.;Reising, M.;Jia, W.

title: Characterization of bovine enteric calici-like virus, Newbury agent 1
abstract: The bovine enteric calicivirus, Newbury Agent 1 (NA1), was characterized to determine whether it is a member of the Caliciviridae and to determine its antigenic relationship to the established bovine enteric calicivirus Newbury Agent 2 (NA2). Solid-phase immunoelectron microscopy (SPIEM) allowed quantification of NA1 virions and identification of fecal samples with optimal virus concentrations. NA1 particles had a diameter of 36.6 nm, an indistinct surface structure resembling that of human small round viruses (SRSVs), and an buoyant density of 1.34 g ml-1. A single capsid protein of 49.4 kDa was detected by Western blotting in purified NA1 preparations made from post-infection but not pre-infection fecal samples and post-infection but not pre-infection sera. According to SPIEM, NA1 was antigenically unrelated to the bovine enteric calicivirus NA2. These properties were consistent with the classification of NA1 within the Caliciviridae, but revealed heterogeneity in the capsid composition of bovine enteric caliciviruses. Copyright (C) 2000 Federation of European Microbiological Societies.
authors: Dastjerdi, A. M.;Snodgrass, D. R.;Bridger, J. C.

title: How many papillomavirus species can go undetected in papilloma lesions?
abstract: Co-infection involving at least seven papillomavirus (PV) types was detected by next generation sequencing (NGS) of randomly primed rolling circle amplification (RCA) products of a bovine papilloma lesion (Bos taurus) from the Brazilian Amazon. Six putative new PV types that could not be detected with current PCR protocols were identified. Their overall L1 nucleotide identities were less than 90% compared to the described PV species and types. L1 nucleotide BLAST sequence hits showed that each new type was related to beta, gamma, dyokappa, dyoeta, and xipapillomaviruses, as well as to two likely new, unclassified genera. Our results show that the use of NGS is relevant for the detection and characterization of distantly related PV and is of great importance in co-infection studies. This knowledge will help us to understand the biology and pathogenesis of PV and contribute to disease control. In addition, we can also conclude that there are many unknown circulating PVs.
authors: Daudt, C.;da Silva, F. R.;Streck, A. F.;Weber, M. N.;Mayer, F. Q.;Cibulski, S. P.;Canal, C. W.

title: Borna disease: current knowledge and virus detection in France
abstract: Borna disease (BD) has been described as a sporadic infectious meningoencephalomyelitis in horses and sheep in Central Europe for more than two centuries. For the past decade, BD epidemiology has been debated. First, its geographic distribution appears to be wider than previously thought. Second, the disease can affect a large number of warm-blooded animal species, including humans. The etiological agent is Borna disease virus (BDV), an enveloped, non-segmented, negative-stranded RNA virus that is classified in the new Bornaviridae virus family (Mononegavirales order). It can produce severe clinical signs of encephalitis with noticeable behavioral disturbances and lead to death. The BDV genome was recently detected in France in the blood and brain of several animal species (horses, cattle, foxes).
authors: Dauphin, G.;Legay, V.;Pitel, P. H.;Zientara, S.

title: Diagnostic phylogenetics reveal a new porcine circovirus 2 cluster
abstract: Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) was prevalent in swine in the United States before PCV2-associated disease (PCVAD) emerged in 2006. Limited nucleotide sequencing of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) encoding capsid, the only structural protein, revealed the presence of two genotypes, PCV2a and PCV2b. Later, PCV2c and mutant PCV2b or PCV2d were also described. However, extensive PCV2 ORF2 sequence databases in veterinary diagnostic laboratories have not been systematically analyzed to determine the genetic diversity of field isolates. Here we interrogated >1100 PCV2 ORF2 nucleotide sequences to assess population diversity and genetic variation. We discovered a new PCV2 genotype that differs significantly from all known PCV2 mainly in the ORF2. Notably, ORF2 contains a unique carboxy-terminal amino acid insertion, resulting in an ORF2 of 238 amino acids. All other ORF2 proteins of PCV2 are 233 or 234 amino acids long. Phylogenetic analysis shows that it is older than other PCV2 genotypes. The results demonstrate the value of analyzing routine diagnostic laboratory sequence databases in population genetic analyzes of animal pathogens.
authors: Davies, B.;Wang, X.;Dvorak, C. M. T.;Marthaler, D.;Murtaugh, M. P.

title: The rare event dilemma: porcine epidemic diarrhea virus in North America
abstract: Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) has been recognized as a swine pathogen for 40 years, but was not detected in the western hemisphere until 2013. Originally causing a relatively mild and sporadic disease, PEDV has been more recently associated with severe diarrheal disease outbreaks in Asia and later in North America. PEDV shares some important properties with two major porcine pandemic viruses (porcine reproductive and respiratory virus; porcine circovirus type 2), which have high mutation rates and high host specificity, and were present in the porcine virome for decades before emerging to cause severe clinical disease. A unique feature of the PEDV in North America has been the implication of feed as a vehicle for transmission, with particular concerns related to porcine ingredients. The importance of relatively rare events that contribute to both the emergence and transmission of PEDV is discussed in relation to approaches to manage the associated risks.
authors: Davies, P. R.

title: Shotgun sequencing experience of a 134 kilobase pair DNA molecule
abstract: To date, large DNA sequences have been obtained by cloning fragments of the target molecule into plasmid, cosmid, or bacteriophage lambda vectors. The 134 kbp channel catfish virus DNA sequence was determined relatively easily by shotgun cloning of random fragments of genomic DNA directly into a bacteriophage M13 vector, sequencing by dideoxynucleotide chain termination, and assembly of the data using Stadens database manipulation programs. Experience gained during this endeavor shows that sequences significantly larger than 134 kbp can be obtained using this approach.
authors: Davison, A. J.

title: Frog adenovirus DNA sequence
abstract: The genome of frog adenovirus (FrAdV-1) has been sequenced and found to be the smallest of any known adenovirus genome. The sequence obtained was 26163 bp in size and contained a substantial direct repeat near the right terminus, implying that it was derived by recombination from a parental genome of only 25517 bp. The closest relative of FrAdV-1 turned out to be turkey adenovirus 3, an avian adenovirus for which no close relative was previously known. Sequence comparisons showed that the two viruses have equivalent gene complements, including a gene whose product is related to sialidases. Phylogenetic analyzes supported the establishment of a fourth adenovirus genus containing these two viruses, in addition to the established genera Mastadenovirus and Aviadenovirus and the proposed genus Atadenovirus. Sixteen genes were identified as conserved between these four lineages and were probably inherited from an ancestral adenovirus.
authors: Davison, A. J.;Wright, K. M.;Harrach, B.

title: Metagenomic analysis of the turkey gut RNA virus community
abstract: Viral enteric diseases are a continuing economic burden on poultry farmers worldwide and, despite extensive research, no single virus has emerged as a likely pathogen and target for prevention and control efforts. Electron microscopy has historically been used to identify suspect viruses, with many small, round viruses defying classification based solely on morphology. National and regional surveys using molecular diagnostics have revealed that suspect viruses are constantly circulating in United States poultry, with many viruses occurring simultaneously and in healthy birds. High-throughput nucleic acid pyrosequencing is a powerful diagnostic technology capable of determining the complete genomic repertoire present in a complex environmental sample. We used the Roche/454 Life Sciences GS-FLX platform to assemble an RNA virus metagenome from flocks of turkeys suffering from enteric disease. This approach resulted in numerous sequences homologous to viruses in the BLAST nr protein database, many of which have not yet been described in turkeys. Our analysis of this turkey gut RNA metagenome specifically focuses on the turkey-derived members of the Picornaviruses, the Caliciviridae, and the turkey picobirnaviruses. Â© 2010 Dayet al Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Day, J. M.;Ballard, L. L.;Duke, M. V.;Scheffler, B. E.;Zsak, L.

title: Comparative analysis of intestinal bacterial and RNA viral communities of sentinel birds housed on selected broiler farms
abstract: There is considerable interest in characterizing the complex microbial communities in the poultry gut and understanding the impact of these dynamic communities on poultry performance, disease status, animal welfare and microbes of importance to human health. Research to characterize the avian enteric vioma has identified new avian viruses, but the role these viruses play in disease and performance problems has yet to be fully characterized. The complex bacterial community present in the poultry gut influences gut development, immune status and animal health, each of which can be an indicator of overall performance. The present metagenomic study was performed to provide insight into the colonization of specific pathogen-free chickens by enteric microorganisms under field conditions and to compare the pre-exposure gut microbiome with the altered microbiome after exposure to field-reared poultry. Analysis of the intestinal virome of contact birds ("sentinels") placed on farms revealed colonization by members of the Picornaviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Reoviridae and Astroviridae, which were absent or present in proportionally lower numbers in pre-contact birds. Analysis of the sentinel gut bacterial community revealed an altered community in the birds after exposure, particularly by members of the Lachnospiracea/Clostridium and Lactobacillus families and genera. Members of the avian enteric Reoviridae and Astroviridae have been well characterized and historically associated with intestinal disease in poultry; Members of the Picobirnaviridae and Picornaviridae have only recently been described in poultry and avian guts, and their role in recognized disease syndromes and poultry performance in general has not been determined. This metagenomic analysis has provided insight into colonization of the avian gut by enteric microbes circulating in commercial broiler flocks and has identified enteric viruses and viral communities that require further investigation to understand their role(s) in avian gut health and disease .
authors: Day, J. M.;Oakley, B. B.;Seal, B. S.;Zsak, L.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic analysis of a novel picobirnavirus originating in Turkey
abstract: Previous metagenomic analysis of the turkey gut RNA virus community identified novel gut viruses that may play a role in poultry gut disease or performance problems identified in the field. As part of the molecular characterization of these novel enteric viruses, a diagnostic reverse transcriptase-PCR assay was developed targeting a novel picobirnavirus (PBV) from Turkey, originally identified in a pooled intestinal sample from turkey poults in North Carolina. Little detailed molecular information is available on the Picobirnaviridae family, particularly for the PBVs that have been described in avian species. This diagnostic assay targets the turkey PBV RNA-dependent RNA polymerase gene and produces a 1135 bp amplicon. This assay has been validated with in vitro transcribed RNA and tested with archival enteric specimens collected from turkey flocks in the southeastern United States. Furthermore, phylogenetic analysis indicates that turkey PBV is unique in that it does not cluster closely with the recognized PBV genogroups that circulate in mammalian hosts. © American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Day, J. M.;Zsak, L.

title: Investigation of enteric picornavirus of turkey and its association with enteric diseases in chicks
abstract: Previous research on the viral community in the gastrointestinal tract of poultry has revealed a number of new and partially characterized enteric viruses. It is evident that the avian gut viral community is minimally characterized and incompletely understood. Studies of the avian gut microbiome have provided some insight into the geographic distribution and rapidly evolving taxonomy of avian enteric picornaviruses. The present study was conducted to provide a comparative metagenomic analysis of gut vioma in a healthy flock of turkeys compared to a field flock. This study revealed a number of enteric picornavirus sequences that were present in the commercial birds in the field but were completely absent from the healthy flock. A novel molecular diagnostic assay was used to monitor the shedding of field strains of turkey enteric picornavirus in commercial chicks vaccinated with picornavirus-positive intestinal homogenates prepared from turkeys suffering from moderate enteric disease. Propagation of this novel enteric picornavirus in commercial chicks resulted in a significant reduction in weight gain and suggests that this common inhabitant of the turkey gut may lead to performance problems or enteric disease in the field.
authors: Day, J. M.;Zsak, L.

title: Molecular characterization of enteric picornaviruses in archival turkey and chicken specimens from the United States
abstract: Recent metagenomic analyzes of enteric viromes in turkeys and chickens have revealed complex viral communities composed of multiple virus families. Of particular note are the new avian picobirnaviruses (family Picobirnaviridae), several genera of tailed phages (family Siphoviridae), and undescribed avian enteric picornaviruses (family Picornaviridae). In addition to these largely undescribed - and therefore relatively poorly understood - avian enteric virus families, these metagenomic analyzes have also revealed the presence of known groups of enteric viruses, such as the chicken and turkey astroviruses (family Astroviridae) and the avian rotaviruses and reoviruses ( family Reoviridae). The order Picornavirales is an evolving group of viruses, particularly among the avian picornaviruses, as several new genera have recently been described based on community analysis of enteric viromes of poultry and other avian species worldwide. Our previous study of turkey enteric picornaviruses suggests that avian enteric picornaviruses may contribute to the enteric disease syndromes and performance problems commonly seen in turkeys in the southeastern United States. This report describes our most recent phylogenetic analysis of enteric-coated turkey and chicken specimens archived at the Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory from 2004 to the present, and is a first step in placing these novel avian picornaviruses within the larger family Picornaviridae.
authors: Day, J. M.;Zsak, L.

title: High global diversity of cycloviruses among dragonflies
abstract: Members of the family Circoviridae, particularly the genus Circovirus, have been thought to infect only vertebrates; Recently, however, members of a sister group in the same family, the proposed genus Cyclovirus, have been detected in insects. In an effort to explore cyclovirus diversity and better understand the evolution of these novel ssDNA viruses, we present here five cycloviruses isolated from three dragonfly species (Orthetrum sabina, Xanthocnemis zealandica, and Rhionaeschna multicolor) native to Australia, New Zealand and the USA were collected. and The genomes of these five viruses have a similar genome structure to other cycloviruses, with a circular genome of ~1.7 kb and two large bidirectionally transcribed ORFs. The genomic sequence data collected during this study was combined with all cyclovirus genomes available in public databases to identify conserved motifs and regulatory elements in the intergenic regions as well as to determine diversity and recombinant regions within their genomes. The genomes reported here represent four different cyclovirus species, three of which are new. Our results confirm that cycloviruses are widespread in winged insect populations; in eight different cyclovirus species identified so far in dragonflies, some of which have a wide geographic distribution. Recombination analyzes revealed both intra- and interspecies recombination events between cycloviruses, including genomes obtained from disparate sources (e.g. goat meat and human feces). Similar to other well-characterized circular ssDNA viruses, recombination may play an important role in cyclovirus evolution. © 2013 SGM.
