authors: Dayaram, A.;Potter, K. A.;Moline, A. B.;Rosenstein, D. D.;Marinov, M.;Thomas, J. E.;Breitbart, M.;Rosario, K.;ArgÃ¼ello-Astorga, G. R.;Varsani, A.

title: Detection of hepatitis E virus in liver, mesenteric lymph nodes, serum, bile and faeces of naturally infected pigs affected by various pathological conditions
abstract: The aim of the present study was to detect the hepatitis E virus (HEV) in various samples from naturally infected pigs and to genetically characterize the detected strains. Serum, bile, liver, lymph nodes and faeces from 69 animals aged 1 week to 4 months with different pathological conditions were collected. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for detection of HEV and histopathology of tissues was performed. Positive RT-PCR samples were sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically. HEV was detected in at least one sample in 26 of 69 animals (37.7%). Bile was the most frequently positive sample, followed by mesenteric lymph nodes, liver, faeces and serum. HEV was detected in pigs aged 1 (n=7), 2 (n=8) and 3 (n=11) months. A total of 22 out of 69 (31.9%) pigs had mild to moderate hepatitis and 15 of them were HEV-RT-PCR positive live pigs in at least one of the tested samples such as liver, mesenteric lymph node and bile. Phylogenetic analyzes confirmed that all detected Spanish swine HEV strains belonged to genotype III. Therefore, genotype III strains are present in a relatively high proportion of pigs between the ages of 1 and 3 months. From this study it cannot be ruled out that co-infections can influence the distribution of HEV in infected pigs. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: de Deus, N.;Seminati, C.;Pina, S.;Mateu, E.;MartÃ­n, M.;SegalÃ©s, J.

title: Antigenic and molecular heterogeneity in recent swine influenza A(H1N1) virus isolates with possible implications for vaccination policy
abstract: To investigate the occurrence of antigenic drift in swine influenza A(H1N1) viruses and the concordance between epidemic and vaccine strains, 26 virus isolates from outbreaks of respiratory disease in fattening pigs in the Netherlands in the 1995/1996 season and reference strains from previous outbreaks were associated with investigated using serological and molecular methods. In contrast to porcine H3N2 viruses, no significant antigenic drift was observed in porcine H1N1 viruses isolated from the late 1980s through 1996. However, in the 26 newer porcine H1N1 virus strains, marked antigenic and genetic heterogeneity was found in hemagglutination inhibition assays and nucleotide sequence analysis. Interestingly, the observed antigenic and molecular variants were not randomly distributed across the farms. This result indicates independent introductions of different swine H1N1 virus variants in the different farms of the study and indicates a clear difference between the epidemiologies of human and swine influenza viruses. The observed heterogeneity may complicate swine influenza control by vaccination and suggests that the efficacy of current swine influenza vaccines needs to be re-evaluated and that the antigenic reactivity of swine influenza viruses should be monitored regularly. © 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: De Jong, J. C.;Heinen, P. P.;Loeffen, W. L. A.;Van Nieuwstadt, A. P.;Claas, E. C. J.;Bestebroer, T. M.;Bijlsma, K.;Verweij, C.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;Rimmelzwaan, G. F.;Fouchier, R. A. M.;Kimman, T. G.

title: Evolutionary origin of 2A-like sequences in Totiviridae genomes
abstract: In recent years, the number of new species that may belong to the Totiviridae family has increased significantly. Most of these new viruses have not yet been included in the official classification of the Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV). In this study, a phylogenetic analysis involving novel sequences of Totiviridae candidates revealed a clade including Giardiavirus and a large variety of novel totiviruses infecting arthropods, protozoa, and molluscs. This extended Giardiavirus clade includes two monophyletic groups, one including Giardia lamblia virus (GLV) grouped with viruses that infect arthropods and vertebrates (GLV-like group), and the other the previously proposed artivirus group (IMNV-like group). Screening the members of the GLV-like group looking for genomic elements previously described in the IMNV-like group revealed the existence of sites with a high propensity to become 2A-like oligopeptides, mainly in a specific subgroup of arthropod viruses, suggesting that these viruses retained ancestral traits. The existence of these "pseudo 2-A sites" associated with phylogenetic reconstruction indicates that these sequences appear at a crucial stage in viral evolution. When they are altered into functional 2A-like sequences, an irreversible pathway to increase genome complexity is initiated.
authors: de Lima, J. G. S.;Teixeira, D. G.;Freitas, T. T.;Lima, J. P. M. S.;Lanza, D. C. F.

title: Akabane, Aino and Schmallenberg viruses - where do we stand and what do we know about the role of domestic ruminants and Culicoides vectors in virus transmission and overwintering?
abstract: Akabane, Aino, and Schmallenberg viruses belong to the Simbu serogroup of orthobunyaviruses and depend on Culicoides vectors for their spread between ruminants. Adult infections are mostly asymptomatic or associated with only mild symptoms, while transplacental transmission of these viruses to the developing fetus can have significant teratogenic effects. Research, primarily focused on congenital malformations, has found a correlation between the developmental stage at which a fetus becomes infected and the outcome of Akabane virus infection. Available data suggest that a similar association also applies to Schmallenberg virus infections, but is not yet fully conclusive. Experimental and field data also suggest that Akabane virus is more efficient than Aino and Schmallenberg viruses in inducing congenital malformations, certainly in cattle. The mechanism by which these Simbuviruses cross annual periods of very low vector abundance in temperate climates is not yet defined. Annual windborne reintroductions of infected mosquitoes from tropical endemic regions with year-round vector activity have been proposed, as has overwintering in long-lived adult mosquitoes. However, experimental and field data indicate that a role of vertical virus transmission in the ruminant host cannot currently be ruled out as an overwintering mechanism. Further studies on Culicoides biology and on specific groups of transplacentically infected newborn ruminants without gross malformations are needed to shed light on this matter.
authors: De Regge, N.

title: Proposal for a new subtype of zoonotic genotype 3 hepatitis E virus: HEV-3l
abstract: The nearly complete genomic sequences of two hepatitis E virus (HEV) strains detected in the faeces of infected pigs have been obtained. Phylogenetic analyzes and p-distance comparisons of the complete coding regions showed a close relationship to the French pig strain FR-SHEV3c-like (p-distance value 0.101) identified in 2006, which belongs to HEV-3 but does not belong to any known subtype. The three HEV sequences showed relatively large nucleotide spacings (p-spacing > 0.129) compared to the other defined HEV subtype references and unclassified strains. The HEV classification criteria and high sequence similarity suggest that these strains can be assigned to a putative new subtype of genotype 3, HEV-31.
authors: De Sabato, L.;Lemey, P.;Vrancken, B.;Bonfanti, L.;Ceglie, L.;Vaccari, G.;Di Bartolo, I.

title: Bovine papular stomatitis in dairy cows and milkers in central western Brazil
abstract: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (BPSV) is a parapoxvirus associated with papular and erosive lesions on the snout, lips, and oral mucosa of cattle. Dairy cow teats are occasionally affected and the infection is commonly transmitted to humans. The present report describes an outbreak of BPSV infection in cows in central western Brazil with human involvement. The disease was observed in neighboring small hand milking farms and affected 20 dairy cows. Signs included painful reddish papules, ulcers and scabbing proliferative lesions on the teats with a clinical course of 7-12 days. Affected cows showed severe local pain that prevented milking from being completed. Histologically, acanthosis, spongiosis and parakeratotic hyperkeratosis with adjacent focally extensive ulcers and multifocal inflammatory infiltrate were observed in the epidermis. Eosinophilic inclusion bodies have been identified in the cytoplasm of epithelial cells. Personnel milking the affected cows developed hand lesions, painful papules that progressed to ulcerative and scabbing lesions within 4-7 days. A polymerase chain reaction using a set of pan-parapoxvirus primers targeting the B2L gene, performed on DNA extracted from scab, amplified a 590 bp product which, on sequencing, showed similarities of 99%, 85% and 84 % with BPSV, the Pseudocowpox virus, or Orf virus. A phylogenetic tree based on the B2L sequence was constructed showing that the virus is clustered with BPSV isolates. Although clinical cases consistent with BSPV infection have been frequently reported in Brazil, the present report identifies the pathogen implicated in bovine and human diseases in the country. © 2012 American Association of Veterinary Laboratory Diagnosticians.
authors: de Sant'Ana, F. J. F.;Rabelo, R. E.;Vulcani, V. A. S.;Cargnelutti, J. F.;Flores, E. F.

title: Laboratory decision-making during the 1997-1998 classical swine fever epidemic in the Netherlands
abstract: The National Reference Laboratory for Classical Swine Fever (CSF) virus in the Netherlands tested more than two million samples for CSF virus or serum antibodies during the 1997-1998 CSF outbreak. The sheer volume of specimens and the prevalence of Border Disease (BD) virus and Bovine Virus Diarrhea (BVD) virus infections in Dutch pig herds required that the laboratory's diagnostic efforts be focused on generating CSF-specific test results during the eradication campaign focused. Detection of 82% of the 429 outbreaks was achieved through the combined use of a direct immunofluorescence and peroxidase assay (FAT/IPA) with specimens (tonsils) from clinically suspect pigs. This indicates that in most outbreaks, the pigs showed clinical signs, recognized by farmers and/or veterinarians, that indicated the presence of classical swine fever virus in a pig herd. A positive diagnosis of 74% of all tissue samples (tonsils) collected from infected pig farms was established by FAT. More than 140,000 heparinized blood samples were tested by virus isolation, resulting in the detection of 4.5% of infected flocks. CSF virus was isolated in approximately 29% of all blood samples from pigs on infected or suspect farms. Multiple serological studies, each performed in a different setting, resulted in the detection of 13.5% of the total number of outbreaks. CSF virus antibodies in the serum were detected by semi-automatic blocking ELISA. About 28.5% of the sera that reacted in the ELISA were classified as positive for CSF virus neutralizing antibodies and 26.5% as positive for other pestiviruses by the virus neutralization test (VNT). We concluded that two of the described CSF laboratory diagnostic methods were critical to the eradication campaign: first, the FAT for screening diseased pigs; and second, ELISA and VNT, when millions of mostly healthy pigs had to be screened for the presence of CSF serum antibodies. However, decision-making based on the results obtained with both methods can be seriously hampered when examining samples from swine herds with a high prevalence of non-CSF pestiviruses.
authors: De Smit, A. J.;Eble, P. L.;De Kluijver, E. P.;Bloemraad, M.;Bouma, A.

title: Araçatuba Virus: A vaccinia-like virus associated with infections in humans and cattle
abstract: We describe a vaccinia-like virus, Araçatuba virus, which is associated with a cowpox-like outbreak in a dairy herd and a related case of human infection. Diagnosis was based on virus growth characteristics, electron microscopy and molecular biology techniques. Molecular characterization of the virus was performed by polymerase chain reaction amplification, cloning and DNA sequencing of conserved orthopoxvirus genes such as vaccinia growth factor (VGF), thymidine kinase (TK) and hemagglutinin. We used VGF homologs and TK gene nucleotide sequences to construct a phylogenetic tree for comparison to other poxviruses. Gene sequences showed 99% homology with vaccinia virus genes and were clustered together with the isolated virus in the pedigree. Araçatuba virus is very similar to Cantagalo virus and shares the same signature deletion in the gene. Araçatuba virus could be a novel vaccinia-like virus or represent the spread of Cantagalo virus.
authors: De Souza Trindade, G.;Da Fonseca, F. G.;Marques, J. T.;Nogueira, M. L.;Mendes, L. C. N.;Borges, A. S.;PeirÃ³, J. R.;Pituco, E. M.;Bonjardim, C. A.;Ferreira, P. C. P.;Kroon, E. G.

title: Novel parvoviruses from wild and domestic animals in Brazil provide new insights into parvovirus distribution and diversity
abstract: Parvoviruses (family Parvoviridae) are small, single-stranded DNA viruses. Many parvoviral pathogens of medical, veterinary, and environmental importance have been identified. In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing (HTS) to examine the diversity of parvoviruses infecting wild and domestic animals in Brazil. We identified 21 parvovirus sequences (including 12 near-complete genomes and 9 partial genomes) in samples from rodents, bats, possums, birds and cattle from the states of Pernambuco, São Paulo, Paraná and Rio Grande do Sul. These sequences were examined using phylogenetic and distance-based approaches and thereby classified into eight parvovirus species (six of which have not been previously described), representing six different genera in the subfamily Parvovirinae. Our results extend the known biogeographical range of previously characterized parvovirus species and the known host range of three parvovirus genera (dependovirus, aveparvovirus, and tetraparvovirus). Furthermore, our investigation provides insight into the ecological dynamics of parvovirus infections in vertebrates, showing that many parvovirus genera contain well-defined sublineages that are widespread within specific taxonomic host groups worldwide.
authors: De Souza, W. M.;Dennis, T.;Fumagalli, M. J.;Araujo, J.;Sabino-Santos, G.;Maia, F. G. M.;Acrani, G. O.;Carrasco, A. O. T.;Romeiro, M. F.;Modha, S.;Vieira, L. C.;Ometto, T.;Queiroz, L. H.;Durigon, E. L.;Nunes, M. R. T.;Figueiredo, L. T. M.;Gifford, R. J.

title: Neurological clinical signs in cattle with Astrovirus-associated encephalitis
authors: Deiss, R.;Selimovicâ€Hamza, S.

title: Neurological clinical signs in cattle with Astrovirus-associated encephalitis
abstract: Background: The detection of neurotrophic astroviruses was achieved using novel genetic methods in cattle suffering from viral encephalitis of unknown cause. Aims: To describe the clinical signs observed in cattle with Astrovirus-associated encephalitis. Animals: Eight cattle (4 cows, 3 heifers and 1 bull of 4 different breeds) were admitted to the ruminant clinic for neurological disorders and 1 cow was examined in the field. METHODS: Cases were selected based on the neuropathologic diagnosis of nonsuppurative encephalitis, a positive in situ hybridization result for astrovirus, and the availability of physical and neurologic examination results. Where available, laboratory results were evaluated. RESULTS: The most commonly observed clinical symptoms were decreased awareness of the surroundings (7), cranial nerve dysfunction (5), and recumbency (5). The cow seen in the field was the only animal showing serious behavioral changes. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cell counts were increased in 4 animals and protein concentration was increased in 3 out of 5 samples. In one case, the presence of Astrovirus in a CSF sample could be identified by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction. Other laboratory abnormalities were nonspecific. Conclusions and clinical significance: Astrovirus infection can be an important differential diagnosis in cattle with clinical signs of brain disease and should be considered after other causes have been ruled out. The clinical and epidemiological relevance of encephalitis associated with astrovirus infection should be further investigated.
authors: Deiss, R.;Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Seuberlich, T.;Meylan, M.

title: Swine vesicular disease: characteristics of the virus strain France 1/73
abstract: The France 1/73 strain of swine vesicular disease has the biological and physicochemical properties of an enterovirus. Single cycle growth on IBR'S2 cells can be detected as early as 2 hr 30 min and the maximum is reached in 5 hrs. Replication takes place in the cytoplasm of the cell. Fluorescein immunofluorescence can show a specific green fluorescence in the cytoplasm within four hours after infection. Virions obtained from this cell system were concentrated with PEG and analyzed by ultracentrifugation in a sucrose gradient. In this way, two particle populations were separated. The first has a sedimentation coefficient of 150S, the other - 75S. After isopycnic centrifugation, the heavier particles are assigned a density of 1.34 g/cm3 and the lighter particles 1.30 g/cm3. The electron microscopic examination shows that the particles have a diameter between 30 and 32 nm. The particles with a density of 1.30 g/cm³ are all dye-permeated and correspond to empty capsids. A potent specific antiserum was produced in pigs with these viral antigens. It can be used for all serological reactions. It is therefore used for differential diagnosis by complement fixation tests (classic reaction at 37°C) using vesicle fluid taken from sick pigs. An inactivated oil adjuvant vaccine was also prepared. The protection rate of vaccinated animals is between 75% and 100% with a probability of 95%.
authors: Delagneau, J. F.;Guerche, J.;Adamowicz Ph. andPrunet, P.

title: Properties of a bovine parvovirus (strain 86/Alger). Type of nucleic acid stability and growth in one step
authors: Delagneau, J. F.;Vincent, J.

title: Foam viruses - a world apart
abstract: Foamy viruses (FVs) or spumaviruses were first described in cell cultures from monkey kidneys in the early 1950s. Later, FVs were isolated in several mammalian species such as cats, cattle and horses. Widespread in non-human primates, they do not occur naturally in humans, although several cases of monkey-to-human transmission have been described. Interestingly, the replication strategy of FVs differs in many aspects from that of other retroviruses, sharing features closely related to pararetroviruses, exemplified by the hepatitis B virus (HBV), but also features closely related to yeast retrotransposons are. These properties led to the creation of a separate viral subfamily by the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy in 2002; the Spumaretrovirinae. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Delelis, O.;Lehmann-Che, J.;SaÃ¯b, A.

title: Microbial diversity of a full-scale UASB reactor applied to poultry slaughterhouse wastewater treatment: integration of 16S rRNA gene amplicon and shotgun…
authors: Delforno, T. P.;JÃºnior, G. V. Lacerda;Noronha, M. F.

title: Microbial diversity of a full-fledged UASB reactor applied to poultry slaughterhouse wastewater treatment: integration of the 16S rRNA gene amplicon and shotgun metagenomic sequencing
abstract: The 16S rRNA gene amplicon and whole genome shotgun metagenomics (WGSM) sequencing approaches were used to examine broad spectrum profiles of microbial composition and metabolic diversity from a full-scale UASB reactor designed for poultry slaughterhouse wastewater treatment is used. Data were generated using the Illumina MiSeq 2 × 250 bp and HiSeq 2 × 150 bp sequencing platforms for 16S amplicon and WGSM sequencing, respectively. Each approach revealed a different microbial community profile, with Pseudomonas and Psychrobacter as the predominant genus for the WGSM dataset and Clostridium and Methanosaeta for the 16S rRNA gene amplicon dataset. Viroma characterization revealed the presence of two virus families with bacteria and archaea as hosts, Myoviridae and Siphoviridae. A great functional diversity has been found, with genes involved in the metabolism of acetone, butanol and ethanol synthesis predominating; and one-carbon metabolism (eg, methanogenesis). Genes associated with the acetotrophic methanogenetic pathways were more abundant than methylotrophic and hydrogenotrophic, confirming the taxonomic results showing the prevalence of the acetotrophic genus Methanosaeta. In addition, the dataset pointed to a variety of metabolic genes involved in sulfur, nitrogen, iron, and phosphorus cycles, with many genera capable of functioning in all cycles. BLAST analysis against the Antibiotic Resistance Genes Database (ARDB) revealed that the microbial community contained 43 different types of antibiotic resistance genes, some of which have been implicated in growth promotion in chickens (e.g. bacitracin, tetracycline and polymyxin).
authors: Delforno, T. P.;Lacerda JÃºnior, G. V.;Noronha, M. F.;Sakamoto, I. K.;Varesche, M. B. A.;Oliveira, V. M.

title: The physicochemical characterization of bovine ephemeral fever virus as a member of the Rhabdoviridae family
abstract: This study of the physicochemical properties of bovine ephemeral fever virus was initiated to determine whether or not it should be classified as a rhabdovirus. In contrast to the regular spherical morphology of some rhabdoviruses, the virus particles are often cone-shaped or slight variants of spherical. The virion contains single-stranded RNA sedimenting at 42S and six proteins with mol. Wt. of 164, 101, 64, 53, 43 and 29 x 103. The P101 protein is found on the virus surface and is glycosylated. It is removed by treating the virus particles with trypsin. It was found that protein P64, the nucleoprotein, is a phosphoprotein, like the N protein of rabies virus, while in vesicular stomatitis virus, NS is the phosphorylated protein. Virus harvests contain defect-interfering particles. The particles are short conical shapes about one-third the length of the infectious virion and resemble in morphology the defect-interfering particles of vesicular stomatitis virus. These particles disrupt the replication of bovine ephemeral fever virus but not the Indiana serotype of vesicular stomatitis virus. They contain single-stranded RNA that sediments at 18 to 20 S. The particles appear to have a protein composition identical to that found in the virus particle. The physicochemical properties of bovine ephemeral fever virus justify its inclusion in the Rhabdoviridae family. The protein composition differs in detail from that found for vesicular stomatitis and rabies viruses, but is similar to that found for Obodhiang and Kotonkan, two serogroup rabies viruses isolated from insects in Africa.
authors: Della-Porta, A. J.;Brown, F.

title: ICTV virus taxonomy profile: Birnaviridae
abstract: Birnaviridae is a family of viruses with bisegmented dsRNA genomes totaling approximately 6 kbp that form icosahedral non-enveloped virions. The family includes four genera, members of three of which (aquabirnavirus, avibirnavirus, and blosnavirus) infect vertebrates (excluding mammals), while members of the fourth genus (entomobirnavirus) infect insects. Each genus includes 1-3 species. Salmonid infectious pancreatic necrosis virus and avian infectious bursal disease virus are two economically important birnaviruses. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the taxonomy of Birnaviridae, available at www.ictv.global/report/birnaviridae.
authors: Delmas, B.;Attoui, H.;Ghosh, S.;Malik, Y. S.;Mundt, E.;Vakharia, V. N.;Lefkowitz, E. J.;Davison, A. J.;Siddell, S. G.;Simmonds, P.;Sabanadzovic, S.;Smith, D. B.;Orton, R. J.;Kuhn, J. H.

title: Animal Virus Discovery: Improving Animal Health, Understanding Zoonoses, and Opportunities for Vaccine Development
abstract: The characterization of viral genomes has accelerated due to improvements in DNA sequencing technology. Sources of animal samples and molecular methods for identifying new viral pathogens and steps to determine their pathogenicity are listed. The difficulties in predicting future cross-species transmissions are highlighted by the wide variety of known viral zoonoses. Recent studies of viruses in wild and domestic animals have characterized numerous viruses, including some closely related to those that infect humans. The evidence of multiple genetic lineages within virus families infecting a single host species that are phylogenetically mixed with viruses found in other host species reflects past cross-species transmission. A better understanding of animal viromas opens up numerous possibilities for the generation of novel vaccines. © 2012 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Delwart, E.

title: Monitoring of the immune response to vaccination with an inactivated vaccine in the context of bovine neonatal pancytopenia by deep sequencing transcriptome analysis in cattle
abstract: Bovine neonatal pancytopenia (BNP) is a new fatal alloimmune/alloantibody-mediated disease of newborn calves caused by ingestion of colostrum from cows vaccinated with a specific vaccine against bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV). Pathogenic MHC class I molecules in the vaccine had been hypothesized, but formal evidence for specific causal MHC class I alleles had not yet been provided. However, the unique properties of the vaccine appear to result in extremely high specific antibody titers in the vaccinated animals, but also appear to lead to other BNP-inducing molecules. Therefore, a comprehensive picture of the immune response to the vaccine is essential. Using the novel next-generation RNA sequencing (RNAseq) approach, our study provides a new holistic, comprehensive analysis of the regulation of the blood transcriptome after vaccination with the specific BVDV vaccine. Our RNAseq approach identified a novel cytokine-like gene in the bovine genome that is highly upregulated after vaccination. This gene has never been described before in any other species and may be specific to the immune response of ruminants. In addition, our data demonstrated a highly coordinated immune response to double-stranded (ds) RNA or a dsRNA analogue following vaccination with the inactivated single-stranded (ss) RNA vaccine. This would indicate either significant contamination of the vaccine with dsRNA from host cells after virus culture or a dsRNA analogue applied to the vaccine. The first option would highlight the potential risks associated with virus culture on homologous cells during vaccine manufacture; the latter option would highlight the potential risks associated with immunostimulatory adjuvants used in vaccine manufacture.
authors: Demasius, W.;Weikard, R.;Hadlich, F.;Muller, K. E.;Kuhn, C.

title: Chicken skin virus analyzed by high-throughput sequencing shows a composition that is very different from human skin
abstract: Recent studies indicate that at homeostasis, human skin is a complex ecosystem whose viromes include circular DNA viruses, particularly papillomaviruses and polyomaviruses. To determine the chicken skin virus in comparison to the human skin virus, a chicken swab pool sample from fifteen healthy barn chickens with five genetic backgrounds was examined for the presence of DNA viruses using high-throughput sequencing (HTS). The results indicate a predominance of herpesviruses of the Mardivirus genus, which originate either from vaccination or a presumably asymptomatic infection. Despite the high sensitivity of the HTS method used here to detect small circular DNA viruses, we have not detected any papillomavirus, polyomavirus or circovirus, suggesting that these viruses may not be present in chicken skin. The results suggest that turkey herpesvirus is present in the skin of vaccinated chickens. This study indicates major differences between the skin viromas of chickens and humans. The origin of this difference needs to be further investigated in relation to skin physiology, environment or viral population dynamics.
authors: Denesvre, C.;Dumarest, M.;RÃ©my, S.;Gourichon, D.;Eloit, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of classical swine fever virus isolated from Taiwan
abstract: Analysis of the E2 sequences of classical swine fever virus from field outbreaks in Taiwan between 1993 and 2001 identified three viral populations with different genotypes, including one historical (subgroup 3.4) and two exotic (subgroup 2.1) strains. The first subgroup 2.1 virus was isolated in 1994, and sporadic outbreaks continued after 1996. Phylogenetic analysis using the E2 region has separated the Taiwanese strains of 2.1 virus into two distinct genotypes (designated 2.1a and 2.1b). The 2.1b viruses were only isolated in 2001 and shared approximately 94.8% nucleotide identities with the 2.1a viruses across the entire genomic sequences. The results suggest that the 2.1a and 2.1b viruses can be introduced from different origins. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Deng, M. C.;Huang, C. C.;Huang, T. S.;Chang, C. Y.;Lin, Y. J.;Chien, M. S.;Jong, M. H.

title: Phylogenetic and genetic characterization of a 2017 clinical isolate of H7N9 virus in Guangzhou, China, during the fifth epidemic wave
abstract: Pathogenic H7N9 influenza viruses continue to pose a public health concern. The H7N9 virus has caused five outbreaks of human infection in China since 2013. In the present study, a novel H7N9 strain (A/Guangdong/8H324/2017) was identified during the fifth wave of the 2017 H7N9 epidemic. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the H7N9 viruses collected during the fifth wave belong to two different lineages: the Pearl River Delta lineage and the Yangtze River Delta lineage. The novel isolate is closely related to the Pearl River Delta H7N9 viruses isolated from patients in Guangdong province. The novel H7N9 isolate has an insertion of three basic amino acids into the hemagglutinin (HA) cleavage site, which could increase virulence in poultry. The 2017 isolate also possesses an R292K substitution in the neuraminidase (NA) protein that confers oseltamivir resistance. This study underscores the pandemic potential of the novel H7N9 virus in mammals; therefore, future characterization and monitoring is warranted.
authors: Deng, Y.;Li, C.;Han, J.;Wen, Y.;Wang, J.;Hong, W.;Li, X.;Liu, Z.;Ye, Q.;Li, J.;Zhou, C.;Yu, L.;Qin, C.;Zhang, F.;Jiang, T.

title: High prevalence of Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus 1 in Chinese pig herds
abstract: Nested RT-PCR was used to examine bovine viral diarrhea virus in 511 samples collected from Chinese pigs showing clinical symptoms between 2007 and 2010. Of these, 137 samples were BVDV positive and the BVDV prevalence rate was 23.1% (9/39). 2007, 27.7% (44/159) in 2008, 33.6% (34/101) in 2009 and 23.6% (50/212) in 2010. Twenty out of 137 BVDV positive specimens were tested for further genetic analysis of the 5' used. -UTR. Phylogenetic analysis revealed them to be BVDV-1 and subtyped into BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b, BVDV-1m, BVDV-1o and an unknown subgenotype. This study showed that BVDVs were widespread in Chinese pig herds and appropriate measures should be taken to control BVDV prevalence in pig herds. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Deng, Y.;Sun, C. Q.;Cao, S. J.;Lin, T.;Yuan, S. S.;Zhang, H. B.;Zhai, S. L.;Huang, L.;Shan, T. L.;Zheng, H.;Wen, X. T.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Transmission of pandemic influenza A(H1N1) 2009 virus in Australian pigs
abstract: Background Pigs possess receptors for both human and avian influenza viruses and are a natural host for influenza A viruses. The 2009 pandemic influenza A(H1N1) virus (H1N1pdm), derived from avian, human and swine influenza viruses, has infected pigs in several countries. Objectives To investigate, by phylogenetic analysis, the relationship between the H1N1pdm viruses isolated from outbreaks in pig farms in Australia and human specimens associated with any of the outbreaks and to determine whether it existed during the human-pig interspecies -Transmission came to a reassortment event. Methods Real-time RT-PCR and whole genome sequencing were performed on RNA isolated from nasal swabs and/or virus cultures. The phylogenetic analysis was performed using the Geneious package. Results Outbreaks of H1N1pdm influenza were detected on three pig farms in three different states of Australia. Further analysis of the Queensland outbreak led to the identification of two different virus strains in the pigs. Two employees working in the same pigsty were also infected with the same two strains found in the pigs. A complete genome sequence analysis of the viruses isolated from pigs and humans revealed no resorting of these H1N1pdm viruses with seasonal or avian influenza A viruses. Conclusions This is the first report of influenza-infected pigs in Australia and marks the end of the influenza-free era for the Australian swine industry. Although no reassortment was observed in these cases, the ability of these viruses to interbreed between pigs and humans underscores the importance of surveillance of pigs for novel influenza infections. © 2012 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Deng, Y. M.;Iannello, P.;Smith, I.;Watson, J.;Barr, I. G.;Daniels, P.;Komadina, N.;Harrower, B.;Wong, F. Y. K.

title: The swine virus and xenotransplantation
abstract: The composition of the porcine virome includes viruses that infect porcine cells, ancient virus-derived elements including endogenous retroviruses inserted into the porcine chromosomes, and bacteriophages that infect a wide range of bacteria inhabiting pigs. Viruses that infect pigs, including viruses that also infect human cells, and porcine endogenous retroviruses (PERVs) are of importance in evaluating the viral safety of xenotransplantation. Bacteriophages, which are associated with bacteria mainly in the gut, are not relevant in this context. Xenotransplantation using porcine cells, tissues or organs is under development to alleviate the shortage of human transplants. Here, for the first time published data describing the viromes in different pigs and their relevance for the virus safety of xenotransplantation are analyzed. In summary, the analysis of the swine vioma has led to the description of numerous new viruses, although their impact on xenotransplantation is unclear. Most importantly, viruses with known or suspected zoonotic potential were often not detected by next-generation sequencing, but instead were discovered by more sensitive methods.
authors: Denner, J.

title: Identification of the new Ghanaian G8P 6 human bovine reassortant rotavirus strain by next-generation sequencing
abstract: Group A rotaviruses (RVAs) are the most important causative agents of acute gastroenteritis in children under 5 years of age worldwide. The monovalent rotavirus vaccine Rotarix was included in Ghana's national Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) in May 2012. However, there is a lack of genetic and phylogenetic data on the full genome of human RVAs circulating prior to the introduction of the vaccine. The common bovine rotavirus VP7 of genotype G8 has been detected sporadically in Ghanaian children, mostly in combination with VP4 genotype P[6]. To study the genomic constellations and phylogeny of circulating RVA strains prior to vaccine introduction, the full genomes of two uncommon G8P[6] strains, GH018-08 and GH019-08, discovered during disease burden monitoring were discovered were characterized by Illumina MiSeq sequencing. The Ghanaian isolates, GH018-08 and GH019-08, presented the unusual, previously unreported genotype constellation G8-P[6]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H3. Phylogenetic analyzes confirmed that 10 of the 11 genes of GH018-08 and GH019-08 were identical/nearly identical, with significant variations noted only in their VP1 genes, and clearly the occurrence of multiple independent interspecies transmissions and rearrangement events between co- circulating bovine/ovine/caprine rotavirus and human DS-1-like RVA strains. These results underscore the contribution of rearrangements and interspecies transmission events to the high rotavirus diversity in this region of Africa and justify the need for simultaneous monitoring of animal and human rotavirus strains.
authors: Dennis, F. E.;Fujii, Y.;Haga, K.;Damanka, S.;Lartey, B.;Agbemabiese, C. A.;Ohta, N.;Armah, G. E.;Katayama, K.

title: Insights into the circovirus host range from the genomic fossil record
abstract: variety of DNA sequences derived from circoviruses (family Circoviridae) have been identified in specimens from humans and domestic animals, often associated with pathological conditions. In most cases, however, little is known about the natural biology of the viruses from which these sequences are derived. Endogenous circovirus elements (CVe) are DNA sequences derived from circoviruses found in animal genomes and provide a useful source of information about circovirus-host relationships. In this study, we screened genome arrays from 675 animal species and identified numerous circovirus-related sequences, including the first examples of cycloviral-derived CVe. We confirmed the presence of these CVe in the germline of the elongated branch ant (Pseudomyrmex gracilis), thereby establishing that cycloviruses infect insects. We examined the evolutionary relationships between CVe and contemporary circoviruses and showed that CVe from ants and mites group relatively closely with cycloviruses in phylogenies. Furthermore, the relatively random mixing of CVe from insect genomes with cyclovirus sequences recovered from vertebrate specimens suggested that contamination might be an important consideration in studies reporting these viruses. Our study shows how endogenous virus sequences can influence metagenomics-based virus discovery. In addition, it raises doubts about the role of cycloviruses as pathogens in humans and other vertebrates.
authors: Dennis, T. P. W.;Flynn, P. J.;de Souza, W. M.;Singer, J. B.;Moreau, C. S.;Wilson, S. J.;Gifford, R. J.

title: Deep sequencing of viral genomes provides insight into the evolution and pathogenesis of the varicella-zoster virus and its vaccine in humans
abstract: Vaccination with the vOka vaccine prevents varicella (chickenpox) in children and susceptible adults. The vOka vaccine strain consists of a mixture of genotypes and, despite attenuation, causes rash in a small number of recipients. Like the wild-type virus, the vaccine builds up a latency in neuronal tissue and can later be reactivated to cause herpes zoster (shingles). Using hybridization-based methods, we purified and sequenced vOka directly from skin lesions. We show that alleles present in the vaccine can be recovered from the lesions and demonstrate the existence of a severe bottleneck between inoculation and lesion formation. Genotypes in each lesion appear to derive from one to three vaccine genotypes with a low frequency of new mutations. No single vOka haplotype and no new mutations are consistently present in rashes, indicating that neither new mutations nor recombination with wild-type are critical for the development of vOka rashes. Instead, alleles derived from attenuation (i.e., not derived from free-living viruses) are present at lower frequencies in rash genotypes. We identify 11 loci at which the ancestral allele is selected in vOka rash formation and demonstrate genotypes in rashes reactivated from latency that cannot be distinguished from rashes occurring immediately after inoculation. We conclude that the vOka vaccine, although heterogeneous, did not evolve to form rashes by positive selection in a quasi-species mode, but rather alleles that were essentially neutral during vaccine manufacture were found in the human subjects, allowing us to identify key sites for rash formation.
authors: Depledge, D. P.;Kundu, S.;Jensen, N. J.;Gray, E. R.;Jones, M.;Steinberg, S.;Gershon, A.;Kinchington, P. R.;Schmid, D. S.;Balloux, F.;Nichols, R. A.;Breuer, J.

title: Molecular aspects of varicella zoster virus latency
abstract: Primary varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection causes varicella (chickenpox) and the establishment of a lifelong latent infection in ganglionic neurons. VZV reactivates in about a third of infected individuals and causes herpes zoster, often accompanied by neurological complications. The limited host range of VZV and, until recently, a lack of suitable in vitro models have severely hampered molecular studies of VZV latency. Nonetheless, recent technological advances have enabled a series of exciting studies, leading to the discovery of a VZV latency-associated transcript (VLT) and providing new insights into our understanding of VZV latency and factors that can trigger reactivation. Deducing the function(s) of the VLT and the molecular mechanisms involved should now be considered a priority to improve our understanding of the factors that determine VZV latency and reactivation. In this review, we summarize the implications of recent discoveries in the VZV latency domain from both viral and host perspectives and provide a roadmap for future studies.
authors: Depledge, D. P.;Sadaoka, T.;Ouwendijk, W. J. D.

title: Deep sequencing of different preparations of live attenuated varicella zoster vaccine reveals a conserved core of single nucleotide attenuating polymorphisms
abstract: UNLABELING: The continued success of live-attenuated varicella zoster vaccine in preventing varicella zoster and herpes zoster is well documented, as are many of the mutations that contribute to the attenuation of vOka virus for replication in the skin. At least three different preparations of vOka are marketed. Here, using deep sequencing of seven lots of vOka vaccine (including ZostaVax, VariVax, VarilRix, and the Oka/Biken working seed) from three different manufacturers (VariVax, GSK, and Biken), we demonstrate that 137 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are mutations present in all vaccine batches. This includes six sites where the vaccine allele is fixed or near fixation that we speculate are likely important for attenuation. We also show that despite differences in vaccine populations between preparations, lot-to-lot variations are minimal, as is the number and frequency of mutations unique to individual lots. This indicates that vaccine manufacturing processes do not introduce new mutations and that live VZV vaccines are extremely stable regardless of the mixture of variants present. IMPORTANT: The continued success of vaccines in preventing chickenpox and shingles, combined with the extremely low incidence of side effects, demonstrates the quality of these vaccines. The vaccine itself consists of a heterogeneous live attenuated virus population and therefore requires deep sequencing technologies to study the differences and similarities in virus populations between different preparations and batches of vaccines. Our data demonstrate minimal inter-lot variability, an important safety feature, and provide new insight into the extent of mutations present in this attenuated virus.
authors: Depledge, D. P.;Yamanishi, K.;Gomi, Y.;Gershon, A. A.;Breuer, J.

title: Classification of rotaviruses: Report of the World Health Organization/Food and Agriculture Organization comparative virology programme
abstract: The Reoviridae Working Team was established in 1975 as part of the World Health Organisation/Food and Agriculture Organization comparative virology programme. The generic name rotavirus was adopted for the reovirus-like pathogens associated with diarrhea in humans and animals, and the Nebraska calf diarrhea virus strain of bovine rotavirus was selected as the reference virus candidate. Stocks of this virus and calf gnotobiotic antiserum were prepared. Antigenic differences between rotaviruses isolated from different species were recognized based on virus neutralization tests; a possible association between antigen specificity and variation in the RNA segments and structural proteins of rotaviruses has been established.
authors: Derbyshire, J. B.;Woode, G. N.

title: Isolation of bovine viral diarrhea virus from bison
authors: Deregt, D.;Tessaro, S. V.;Baxi, M. K.;Berezowski, J.;Ellis, J. A.;Wu, J. T. Y.;Gilbert, S. A.

title: [New classification of enteroviruses in swine: serological and molecular genetic aspects]
abstract: Due to changes in the modern classification and nomenclature of the family Picornaviridae made by the International Committee for Taxonomy of Viruses, a genetic and serological reclassification of 36 industrial, typical and laboratory strains of porcine enteroviruses isolated in Ukraine was carried out . The results of molecular genetic studies of 34 strains assigned to the family Picornaviridae, genus Teschovirus, species Porcines Teschovirus, 2 virus strains did not participate in a polymerase chain reaction with species-specific primers. In the neutralization reaction of the virus it was shown that 23 strains belonging to 1 serotype Porcine Techovirus, 4 strains – PTV-3, 1 – to PTV-6, 1 strain – to Porcine Sapelovirus, three strains have between typical antigenic properties, and 4 strains - antigenically different from the reference strains Porcine Techovirus, Enterovirus G and Porcine Sapelovirus.
authors: Derev'ianko, S. V.

title: 5'-UTR-based phylogenetic analysis of classical swine fever virus isolates from India
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF) caused by classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is a swine fever of global importance. Genetic typing of CSFV isolates can help to understand disease epidemiology and trace the source of the outbreak. 5'UTR sequence analysis and subsequent genetic classification of nine CSFV field isolates from India showed that 3 isolates belonged to genotype 2.1 and were closely related to European CSFV strains. The remaining 6 isolates belonged to genotype 1, which contained old and new strains. However, the genotype 2.1 group consisted only of recent field isolates. The study showed the distribution of both genotypes 1 and 2.1 in the north-eastern part of India.
authors: Desai, G. S.;Sharma, A.;Kataria, R. S.;Barman, N. N.;Tiwari, A. K.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolates occurring in India between 1989 and 2013
abstract: The study details the characterization of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates obtained from commercial flocks of poultry (chickens) and wild birds (cranes) in India over the period 1989-2013. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that most NDV isolates belong to class II, genotype XIIIa and one chicken isolate (108/BAREILLY/AD-IVRI/91) was of genotype VI where it showed 3% diversity over the other viruses, belonging to the same genotype. Another chicken isolate (75/RAMPUR/AD-IVRI/89) clustered in genotype III and showed 4% diversity with genotype III viruses. The crane-derived NDV identified as genotype II corresponds to the vaccine virus. This appears to be the first report of the existence of genotype XIIIa, and its ancestral viruses have been circulating in various bird species in India for two decades. In addition, genetically distinct viruses belonging to genotypes II, III, and VI also circulate in India.
authors: Desingu, P. A.;Singh, S. D.;Dhama, K.;Karthik, K.;Vinodh Kumar, O. R.;Malik, Y. S.

title: Kinetics of expression of the transcript and product of the UL28 homologue of bovine herpesvirus 1
abstract: We report that the bovine herpesvirus 1 (BHV1) UL28 ORF, a homologue of the herpes simplex virus (HSV) UL28 gene, is a functional gene encoding a viral specific protein. The BHV1 UL28 ORF, located at positions 53,058 → 55,538 of the viral genome, encodes a 3.4 kb viral specific transcript that was detected 6 h post-infection (pi), after which its levels increased up to accumulated to 12 hr pi and then remained constant up to 24 hr pi. BHV1 UL28 transcription was found to initiate 95 bases upstream from the start codon of the ORF, which corresponds to 33 nucleotides downstream from a putative TATA box. A BHV1-UL28-specific antiserum raised against a T7-tag/UL28 fusion protein expressed in E. coli specifically reacted with a 100 kDa protein in Western blots of BHV1-infected protein cell lysates. The expression kinetics of the protein were delayed by 6 h relative to those of its transcript, suggesting that the gene is regulated at the translational level. In contrast to the HSV and pseudorabies virus UL28 genes, which belong to early class (β) viral genes, BHV1 has been clearly classified as a β2 gene. Further studies are needed to determine whether these kinetic differences have any functional implications. © 2001 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Desloges, N.;Simard, C.

title: A metagenomic comparison of endemic viruses from broilers with Runting-Sunting syndrome and normal birds
abstract: Runting-Stunting Syndrome (RSS) in broilers is an enteric disease that causes significant economic losses to poultry producers worldwide due to increased feed conversion ratios, reduced body weight during growth and excessive culling. Of particular interest are the viral agents associated with RSS, which have so far been difficult to fully characterize. Previous research on the etiology of RSS has implicated a variety of RNA and DNA viruses, but to date no single virus has been identified as the main causative agent of RSS, and the current opinion is that it may be caused by a community of viruses. collectively known as Virom. This paper attempts to characterize the viral pathogens associated with 2-3 week old RSS affected and unaffected broilers using next-generation sequencing and comparative metagenomics. Analysis of the viromes identified a total of 20 DNA and RNA virus families and 2 unidentified categories consisting of 31 distinct virus genera and 7 unclassified genera. The most prevalent virus families identified in this study were the Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Picornaviridae, Parvoviridae, Coronaviridae, Siphoviridae, and Myoviridae. This study identified historically important viruses associated with the disease, such as chicken astrovirus, avian nephritis virus, chicken parvovirus, and chicken calicivirus, along with relatively new viruses such as chicken megrivirus and sicinivirus 1, and will help advance knowledge of enteric disease in broiler chickens, provide insight into the viral components of a healthy avian gut, and identify a variety of enteric viruses and viral communities amenable to further study.
authors: Devaney, R.;Trudgett, J.;Trudgett, A.;Meharg, C.;Smyth, V.

title: Enrichment of viral nucleic acids by solution hybrid selection with genus-specific oligonucleotides
abstract: Despite recent advances, our knowledge of potential and rare human pathogens is far from exhaustive. Current molecular diagnostic tools rely mainly on the specific amplification of marker sequences and may miss infections caused by unknown and rare pathogens. Using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) can solve this problem; Due to the extremely low proportion of pathogen material in clinical samples, however, the use is only economical in special cases and not in routine cases. In this study, we present a method for semispecific enrichment of viral conservative sequences in an HTS library by in-solution hybridization with genus-specific degenerate biotinylated oligonucleotides. Nucleic acids of the test viruses (yellow fever virus and Japanese encephalitis virus) were enriched by solution hybrid selection using pan-flavivirus oligonucleotides. Furthermore, enterovirus (family: Picornaviridae, genus: Enterovirus) sequences were successfully enriched using foot-and-mouth disease virus (family: Picornaviridae, genus: Aphthovirus) oligonucleotide. The enrichment factor relative to background nucleic acid was approximately 1000-fold. Because hybridization has less stringent oligonucleotide matching requirements than PCR, a few oligonucleotides are sufficient to cover potential sequence variation across the genus, and can even enrich for nucleic acids from viruses of other related genera. The efficient enrichment of viral sequences makes its use in diagnostics cost-effective.
authors: Deviatkin, A. A.;Lukashev, A. N.;Markelov, M. M.;Gmyl, L. V.;Shipulin, G. A.

title: Megaphages infect Prevotella and variants are widespread in gut microbiomes
abstract: Bacteriophages (phages) dramatically shape microbial community composition, redistributing nutrients through host lysis, and driving evolution through horizontal gene transfer. Despite their importance, much remains to be learned about phages in the human microbiome. We examined the gut microbiomes of Bangladeshi and Tanzanian humans, two groups of African baboons, and Danish pigs; Many of these microbiomes contain phage belonging to a clade with genomes >540 kilobases in length, the largest reported to date in the human microbiome and close to the maximum size ever reported for phage. We refer to these as Lak phages. CRISPR spacer targeting indicates that Lak phages infect bacteria of the genus Prevotella. We manually curated 15 different Lak phage genomes derived from metagenomes to completion. The genomes exhibit several interesting features, including use of an alternative genetic code, large intergenic regions that are highly expressed, and up to 35 putative transfer RNAs, some of which contain enigmatic introns. Different individuals have different phage genotypes, and shifts in the frequency of variants over consecutive sampling days reflect changes in the relative frequencies of phage subpopulations. Recent homologous recombination has resulted in an extensive genome mix of nine baboon Lak phage populations. We conclude that Lak phages are widespread in gut communities containing the Prevotella species and conclude that megaphages with intriguing and understudied biology may be common but largely overlooked components of human and animal gut microbiomes.
authors: Devoto, A. E.;Santini, J. M.;Olm, M. R.;Anantharaman, K.;Munk, P.;Tung, J.;Archie, E. A.;Turnbaugh, P. J.;Seed, K. D.;Blekhman, R.;Aarestrup, F. M.;Thomas, B. C.;Banfield, J. F.

title: Molecular and antigenic characterization of piscine orthoreovirus (PRV) from rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)
abstract: Piscine orthoreovirus (PRV-1) causes cardiac and skeletal muscle inflammation (HSMI) in farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar). Recently, a novel PRV (formerly PRV-Om, here called PRV-3) was found in rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) with HSMI-like disease. PRV is considered an emerging pathogen in farmed salmonids. In this study, a molecular and antigenic characterization of PRV-3 was performed. Erythrocytes are the main target cells for PRV, and blood samples collected from experimentally challenged fish were used as the virus source. Viral particles were purified by gradient ultracentrifugation and the complete coding sequences of PRV-3 were obtained by Illumina sequencing. Compared to PRV-1, the nucleotide identity of the coding regions was 80.1% and the amino acid identities of the predicted PRV-3 proteins varied from 96.7% (lambda1) to 79.1% (sigma3). The phylogenetic analysis showed that PRV-3 belongs to a separate cluster. The sigma3 coding region was sequenced from PRV-3 isolates collected from rainbow trout in Europe. These sequences clustered but were distant from PRV-3 isolated from rainbow trout in Norway. Bioinformatic analyzes of PRV-3 proteins revealed that predicted secondary structures and functional domains were conserved between PRV-3 and PRV-1. Rabbit antisera raised against purified virus or various recombinant viral proteins of PRV-1 all cross-reacted with PRV-3. Our results show that despite different species preferences of the PRV subtypes, several genetic, antigenic and structural properties are conserved between PRV-1 and -3.
authors: Dhamotharan, K.;Vendramin, N.;Markussen, T.;Wessel, O.;Cuenca, A.;Nyman, I. B.;Olsen, A. B.;Tengs, T.;Krudtaa Dahle, M.;Rimstad, E.

title: Recent epidemiology of peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV)
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an economically important viral disease of goats and sheep that was first described in West Africa in the 1940s. The virus has been circulating in parts of sub-Saharan Africa for several decades and in the Middle East and South Asia since 1993, although the virus was first described in India in 1987. To investigate the genetic relatedness between isolates from different geographic origins, a selected region of the fusion (F) protein gene of the viruses was amplified using RT/PCR and the resulting DNA product was sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. Viruses from 27 outbreaks in Asian and Middle Eastern countries reported between 1993 and 2000 and two recent outbreaks on the African continent were compared to the prototype African strain. Of the four known lineages of PPR virus, lineages 1 and 2 have been found exclusively in West Africa. Virus from an outbreak in Burkina Faso in 1999 fell into the lineage 1 group. Lineage 3 viruses have been found in East Africa, where such an outbreak occurred in Ethiopia in 1996, and in Arabia and southern India. However, since lineage 3 virus was reported from Tamil Nadu in 1992, there have been no further isolations of lineage 3 virus from India. A virus of this lineage was found circulating in Yemen in 2001. In the last 8 years, only the fourth lineage virus has spread across the Middle East and the Asian subcontinent, reaching east to Nepal and Bangladesh. This virus line was also reported from Kuwait in 1999. The geographic source of the new lineage 4 virus is unknown, although it is most closely related to African lineage 1. The possibility that its past presence in northern India was masked by the spread of rinderpest virus, a related bovine virus, is considered unlikely. © 2002 Published by Elsevier Science BV
authors: Dhar, P.;Sreenivasa, B. P.;Barrett, T.;Corteyn, M.;Singh, R. P.;Bandyopadhyay, S. K.

title: Genetic characterization of clade 2.3.2.1 avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Indonesia, 2012
abstract: Influenza A(H5N1) virus was discovered and characterized in September 2012 following reports of unusually high mortality rates in ducks on farms on the island of Java, Indonesia. Sequence analyzes revealed that all genes were clustered with contemporary clade 2.3.2.1 viruses and not enzootic clade 2.1.3 viruses, suggesting the introduction of an exotic H5N1 clade in Indonesia.
authors: Dharmayanti, N. L.;Hartawan, R.;Pudjiatmoko;Wibawa, H.;Hardiman;Balish, A.;Donis, R.;Davis, C. T.;Samaan, G.

title: Temperate coliphages: classification and correlation with habitats
abstract: Temperate zone coliphages were recovered from sewage, mammalian feces, and lysogenic strains of Escherichia coli. A total of 32 phages of independent origin were divided into six groups using criteria of host range, antigenic homology and prophage UV-inducibility. Evidence of genetic interactions in some cases has validated the classification scheme. Nine phages were assigned to the P2 family and 19 to the lambda family. The remaining four isolates may represent some new phylogenetic types. Phage recovered from the lysogenic strains of E. coli were all found to be related to P2, whereas a majority of the phage recovered as cell-free plaque-forming units belonged to the lambda family. It is suggested that the biological properties of the phages belonging to the two main families are reflected in the observed distribution patterns. The virions of the phage HK256 have multiple tail fibers and could thus represent a "new" virion form among the temperate coliphages.
authors: Dhillon, E. K. S.;Dhillon, T. S.;Lam, Y. Y.;Tsang, A. H. C.

title: Evidence of recombination in neboviruses
abstract: Neboviruses are bovine enteric caliciviruses (genus Nebovirus) associated with enteric disease in calves. When calf faeces from Italian herds were screened using primers targeting a conserved region in the calicivirus RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), nebovirus RNA was detected in calves with enteritis (13.1%), but not in apparently healthy animals. Upon sequence analysis of the RdRP fragment, the Italian viruses formed a tightly conserved group and closely resembled the Nebraska/80/US nebovirus prototype. The process of a 2.2. kb ORF1 fragment encompassing the 3' end of the RdRp and the full-length capsid coding region from two nebovirus strains was determined, revealing marked genetic heterogeneity in the capsid protein as the two Italian viruses divided into two distinct Capsid lines have been classified and proposing a recombination event downstream of the highly conserved shell (S) domain. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Di Martino, B.;Di Profio, F.;Martella, V.;Ceci, C.;Marsilio, F.

title: Genome plasticity of triple reassorted H1N1 influenza A virus during infection of vaccinated pigs
abstract: To gain insight into the evolution of influenza A viruses (IAVs) during infection of vaccinated pigs, we experimentally infected a 3-week-old naïve pig with a triple reassortant H1N1 IAV and placed the seed pig in direct contact with an age - matched vaccinated pigs (n510), We indexed the genetic diversity and evolution of the virus at the intra-host level by deep sequencing of the whole genome directly from nasal swabs collected on two separate samples during infection. We obtained 13 IAV metagenomes from 13 specimens containing the virus inoculum and two specimens from each of the six pigs that tested positive for IAV during the study. Infection generated a population of heterogeneous alleles (sequence variants) that was dynamic over time. Overall, among all 794 polymorphisms, samples were identified that gave rise to 327 alleles, 214 of which were unique sequences. A total of 43 different hemagglutinin proteins were translated, two of which were observed in several pigs, with neuraminidase (NA) conserved and only one dominant NA found throughout the study. The genetic diversity of IAVs changed dynamically within and between pigs. However, most of the substitutions observed in the internal gene segments were synonymous. Our results demonstrated remarkable IAV diversity and the complex, rapid, and dynamic evolution of IAV during infection of vaccinated pigs, which can only be appreciated by repeated sampling of individual animals and deep sequence analysis.
authors: Diaz, A.;Enomoto, S.;Romagosa, A.;Sreevatsan, S.;Nelson, M.;Culhane, M.;Torremorell, M.

title: Molecular properties of Nipah virus glycoproteins
abstract: Nipah virus (NiV) is a highly pathogenic paramyxovirus that emerged from fruit bats in Malaysia in 1998 and has caused an outbreak of severe respiratory disease in swine and fatal encephalitis in humans with high mortality rates. Unlike most paramyxoviruses, NiV can infect a wide variety of mammalian species. Because of this broad host range, its zoonotic potential, its high human pathogenicity, and the lack of effective vaccines or therapeutics, NiV has been classified as a Biosafety Level 4 pathogen. This article provides an overview of the molecular properties of NiV, focusing on the structure, functions, and unique biological properties of the two NiV surface glycoproteins, receptor-binding G protein and fusion protein F. Since viral glycoproteins are important determinants for cell tropism and Virus distribution, a detailed knowledge of these proteins can help to understand the molecular basis of viral pathogenicity. © 2007 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Diederich, S.;Maisner, A.

title: Genetic analysis of avian paramyxovirus-1 (Newcastle disease virus) isolates obtained from swine populations in China relative to commonly used commercial vaccine strains
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) was thought to infect only bird species. However, at least eight NDV strains were isolated from pig populations in China between 1999 and 2006, four of which have been genetically and phylogenetically characterized. Genetic analysis revealed that JL106 and SP13 possessed a 112G-RQGR-L117 motif at the F protein cleavage site, while JL01 and MP01 possessed a 112G-KQGR-L117 motif, indicating that they are all virus-typical were of low virulence. Phylogenetic analysis based on the full-length F gene sequences showed that JL106 and SP13 belonged to genotype II, similar to the commonly used commercial La Sota vaccine strain in China. While JL01 and MP01 are grouped within genotype I, they are genetically identical to the V4 vaccine strain. The animal experiments showed that JL106 can effectively infect chickens. The present results indicate that the use of La Sota and V4 live vaccines and close contact between birds and pigs may have led to cross-species infection. Therefore, it is necessary to continue epidemiological surveillance of swine NDV. © 2010 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Ding, Z.;Cong, Y. L.;Chang, S.;Wang, G. M.;Wang, Z.;Zhang, Q. P.;Wu, H.;Sun, Y. Z.

title: Modulation of microRNAs in two genetically distinct chicken lines with different susceptibility to necrotic enteritis
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNA) play a crucial role in post-transcriptional regulation by affecting the 3'-UTR of target genes. Using two inbred White Leghorn chicken lines, line 6.3 and line 7.2, that display Marek's disease-resistant and disease-susceptible phenotypes, respectively, we used high-throughput small RNA sequencing (HTS) to examine whether miRNAs differ in these two chicken lines after induction are expressed necrotic enteritis (NE). The 12 miRNAs selected from the most down-regulated or up-regulated miRNAs after NE induction were confirmed by their expression in real-time PCR. Among these miRNAs, miR-215, miR-217, miR-194, miR-200a, miR-200b, miR-216a, miR-216b, and miR-429 were highly expressed in gut derived from lineage 7.2, while miR-1782 and miR-499 were downregulated. In the spleen, miR-34b and miR-1684 were the most upregulated miRNAs in lineage 6.3. Notably, five out of six target genes, CXCR5, BCL2, GJA1, TCF12 and TAB3, were differentially expressed between lineage 6.3 and lineage 7.2 and showed repression in the MD-sensitive chicken line. Their expression levels were inversely correlated with those of miRNA obtained from both HTS and real-time quantitative PCR. These results suggest that some miRNAs are differentially altered in response to NE and they modulate the expression of their target genes in the two inbred lines. Overall, HTS analysis of intestinal miRNAs from NE-affected inbred chickens displaying distinct disease phenotypes led to the identification of host immunity genes regulated by miRNA. Future investigations into the function of these miRNAs and their target genes in the host will lead to a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control the host-pathogen interaction in NE. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Dinh, H.;Hong, Y. H.;Lillehoj, H. S.

title: Studies on the Myxovirus Yucaipa: Its Classification as a Member of the Paramyxovirus Group
authors: Dinter, Z.;Hermodsson, S.;Hermodsson, L.

title: The characteristics and classification of bovine viral diarrhea virus
abstract: The study of the C24V (Oregon) and MAC A (Ontario) strains of bovine diarrhea viral viruses has shown that they are ribonucleic acid-containing viruses, with essential lipids and compound helix symmetry, the diameter of the helix being close to 180 Å due to these properties suggested considering the virus a member of the myxovirus group. Swine cholera virus is related to bovine viral diarrhea virus by a "soluble" antigen and also possesses an essential lipid. It is therefore proposed that swine cholera virus is yet another veterinary myxovirus.
authors: Ditchfield, J.;Doane, F. W.

title: Metagenomic analysis of RNA viruses in a freshwater lake
abstract: Freshwater lakes and ponds provide an ecological interface between humans and a variety of host organisms. They are a habitat for the larval stage of many insects and can serve as a medium for the transmission of viruses within and between species such as avian influenza A virus. In addition, freshwater bodies are already known repositories for disease-causing viruses such as Norwalk virus, Coxsackie virus, Echovirus, and Adenovirus. While RNA virus populations have been studied in marine environments, there has been very limited analysis of the virus community in freshwater. Here we present a study of RNA viruses in Lake Needwood, a freshwater lake in Maryland, USA. Our results indicate that, as in studies of other aquatic environments, the majority of the recovered nucleic acid sequences did not show significant similarity to known sequences. The remaining sequences are mainly from viral types with significant similarity to approximately 30 viral families. We speculate that these novel viruses can infect a variety of hosts, including plants, insects, fish, pets, and humans. Among these viruses, we have discovered a previously unknown dsRNA virus closely related to Banna virus, which is responsible for a febrile illness and is endemic to Southeast Asia. In addition, we found several viral sequences distantly related to the Israeli acute paralysis virus, which has been linked to honey bee colony collapse. Our data suggest that freshwater ecosystems serve as storehouses for a variety of viruses (both pathogenic and non-pathogenic) due to their direct contact with humans, domestic and wild animals, and could potentially be involved in the spread of emerging and pandemic diseases. © 2009 Djikeng et al.
authors: Djikeng, A.;Kuzmickas, R.;Anderson, N. G.;Spiro, D. J.

title: Genetic Analysis of Human Rotavirus C: The Appearance of the Indo-Bangladesh Strain in Far East Asian Countries
abstract: Rotavirus C (RVCs) circulate worldwide as enteric pathogens in both humans and animals. Most studies of their genetic diversity focus on the VP7 and VP4 genes, but the complete genomes of 18 human RVCs have been described in independent studies. The genetic background of Far East Asian RVCs differs from other human RVCs found in India and Bangladesh. Recently, an RVC discovered in South Korea in 2010 had a similar genetic background to the Indo-Bangladeshi RVC. This study was conducted to determine the entire genome of eight Japanese RVCs discovered between 2005 and 2012 and to compare them to other human and animal RVCs worldwide to better understand the genetic background of contemporary Far East Asian RVCs. By phylogenetic analysis, the human RVCs appeared to be distinct from animal RVCs. Among the human RVCs, three lineage constellations had prolonged circulation. The genetic background of the Far East Asian RVC has been distinguished from the Indo-Bangladeshi RVC, as previously reported. However, we found one Japanese RVC in 2012 that carried the Indo-Bangladeshi RVC genetic background, while the remaining seven Japanese RVC carried the typical Far East Asian RVC genetic background. This is the first report of the Indo-Bangladeshi RVC in Japan. With this observation and the reassortment event of human RVCs in Hungary, our study shows that the RVCs spread from one region to another.
authors: Doan, Y. H.;Haga, K.;Fujimoto, A.;Fujii, Y.;Takai-Todaka, R.;Oka, T.;Kimura, H.;Yoshizumi, S.;Shigemoto, N.;Okamoto-Nakagawa, R.;Shirabe, K.;Shinomiya, H.;Sakon, N.;Katayama, K.

title: Zoonotic hepatitis E virus: classification, animal reservoirs, and routes of transmission
authors: Doceul, V.;Bagdassarian, E.;Demange, A.;Pavio, N.

title: Sequence analysis of a porcine enterovirus serotype 1 isolate: relationships to other picornaviruses
abstract: The majority of the genomic sequence of a porcine enterovirus serotype 1 (PEV-1) isolate has been determined. The genome was found to contain a large open reading frame encoding a leader protein in front of the capsid protein region. This showed no sequence identity with other picornavirus leader regions and the sequence data suggested that it lacked proteolytic activity. The 2A protease was small and showed considerable sequence identity with the aphthoviruses and with equine rhinovirus serotype 2. The 2A/2B junction possessed the typical cleavage site (NPG/P) exhibited by these viruses. The other proteins shared less than 40% sequence identity with equivalent proteins from other picornavirus genera. Phylogenetic analyzes of the P1 and 3D sequences showed that this virus forms a distinct branch of the Picornaviridae family. Based on the results presented in this paper, PEV-1 has been assigned to a new picornavirus genus. The phylogeny of the virus relative to other picornaviruses is debated.
authors: Doherty, M.;Todd, D.;McFerran, N.;Hoey, E. M.

title: Functional characterization of a monoclonal antibody epitope using a lambda phage display deep sequencing platform
abstract: We have recently described a method called PROFILER for identifying antigenic regions that are preferentially targeted by polyclonal antibody responses after vaccination. Here, to test the ability of the technique to provide insight into the functional properties of monoclonal antibody (mAb) epitopes, we used a well-characterized meningococcal factor H-binding protein (fHbp) epitope recognized by mAb 12C1. An fHbp library constructed on a lambda phage vector, which allows surface expression of polypeptides of widely variable length, was subjected to massive parallel sequencing of the phage inserts after affinity selection with the 12C1 mAb. We discovered dozens of unique antibody-selected sequences, of which the most enriched (termed FrC) could largely recapitulate the ability of fHbp to bind mAb 12C1. Computational analysis of the cumulative accumulation of single amino acids in the antibody-selected fragments identified two over-represented residue stretches (H248-K254 and S140-G154), the presence of which was subsequently found to be required for FrC binding to mAb 12C1. Taken together, these results suggest that the PROFILER technology can rapidly and reliably identify discrete "hot spots" associated with complex conformational epitopes with a crucial role in antigen-antibody interactions, providing useful clues for the functional characterization of the epitope.
authors: Domina, M.;Lanza Cariccio, V.;Benfatto, S.;Venza, M.;Venza, I.;Borgogni, E.;Castellino, F.;Midiri, A.;Galbo, R.;Romeo, L.;Biondo, C.;Masignani, V.;Teti, G.;Felici, F.;Beninati, C.

title: The broad host range and genetic diversity of mammalian and avian astroviruses
abstract: Astroviruses are a diverse family of viruses that infect a wide variety of mammals and birds. Here we describe the phylogenetic diversity and current classification methodology of astroviruses based on the ORF1b and ORF2 genes and highlight the propensity of astroviruses to undergo transmission and genetic recombination between species, greatly increasing diversity and attempts at unification and comprehensive classification strategy.
authors: Donato, C.;Vijaykrishna, D.

title: Identification of Peste des Petits Ruminants Virus, Georgia, 2016
abstract: A phylogenetic analysis of samples collected during reported outbreaks of pestilence ruminants virus (PPRV) in Georgia found a closer relationship to viruses from North and East Africa than to viruses from countries closer to Georgia . This finding has critical implications for the control of PPRV in the region.
authors: Donduashvili, M.;Goginashvili, K.;Toklikishvili, N.;Tigilauri, T.;Gelashvili, L.;Avaliani, L.;Khartskhia, N.;Loitsch, A.;Bataille, A.;Libeau, G.;Diallo, A.;Dundon, W. G.

title: Detection of transmission and resorting events for influenza A virus with genotype profiling method
abstract: Evolutionary transmission and reassortment events for influenza A viruses have traditionally been demonstrated by phylogenetic analysis of the eight gene segments of influenza viruses. Because phylogenetic analysis can be complex, we developed a genotype profiling method that packages the phylogenetic algorithms for analyzing combination patterns of gene segments and integrated epidemiological knowledge. With the method, the analysis of reassortment and transmission becomes a simple and reliable process that combines genotypes that are identical for the biological process of the virus. An application called IVEE that implements the technique is available for all academic users to use http://snptransformer.sourceforge.net. In addition, we noted that a previous summary of swine influenza A virus reassortment events may be inaccurate. © 2011 Dong et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Dong, C.;Ying, L.;Yuan, D.

title: Phylogenetic diversity and genotypic complexity of H9N2 influenza A viruses revealed by genomic sequence analysis
abstract: H9N2 influenza A virus has become established in terrestrial and wild birds worldwide and is occasionally transmitted to mammals including humans and pigs. To fully elucidate the genetic and evolutionary characteristics of H9N2 influenza viruses, we performed a large-scale sequence analysis of 571 viral genomes from the NCBI influenza virus resource database, representing the spectrum of H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from 1966 to 2009. Our study provides a panoramic framework to better understand the genesis and development of H9N2 influenza viruses and to describe the history of H9N2 viruses circulating in different hosts. The phylogenetic panorama analysis of the eight viral gene segments revealed the complexity and diversity of the H9N2 influenza viruses. The 571 H9N2 virus genomes were divided into 74 separate lineages that exhibited marked host and geographic differences in phylogeny. The panoramic genotypic analysis also revealed that H9N2 viruses comprise at least 98 genotypes, which were further subdivided into seven series (AG) according to their HA lineages. The phylogenetic analysis of the internal genes showed that the H9N2 viruses are closely related to the influenza viruses of the H3, H4, H5, H7, H10 and H14 subtypes. Our results show that H9N2 viruses have undergone extensive reassortments to generate multiple reassortants and genotypes, suggesting that continued circulation of multiple genotypic H9N2 viruses around the world in different hosts has the potential to contribute to future influenza outbreaks causing poultry and human epidemics. We propose a nomenclature system to identify and unify all lineages and genotypes of H9N2 influenza viruses to facilitate international communication on the evolution, ecology, and epidemiology of H9N2 influenza viruses. © 2011 Dong et al.
authors: Dong, G.;Luo, J.;Zhang, H.;Wang, C.;Duan, M.;Deliberto, T. J.;Nolte, D. L.;Ji, G.;He, H.

title: Reassortant H9N2 influenza viruses containing H5N1-like PB1 genes isolated from black-billed magpies in southern China
abstract: H9N2 influenza A virus has become endemic in various species of terrestrial and wild birds in Asia and is occasionally transmitted to humans and pigs. To assess the role of black-billed magpies (Pica pica) in the development of influenza A virus, we conducted two avian influenza virus epidemic surveys in wild black-billed magpies in Guangxi, China, in 2005 and characterized three isolated black-billed magpies H9N2 viruses (BbM viruses ). Phylogenetic analysis showed that three BbM viruses were nearly identical with 99.7 to 100% nucleotide homology throughout their genome and were reassortants expressing BJ94-like (Ck/BJ/1/94) HA, NA, M and NS genes, SH/F/98-like (Ck/SH/F/98) PB2, PA and NP genes, and H5N1-like (Ck/YN/1252/03, clade 1) PB1 genes.
