Genetic analysis showed that BbM viruses were most likely the result of multiple reassortments between co-circulating H9N2-like and H5N1-like viruses and were genetically distinct from other H9N2 viruses due to the presence of H5N1-like PB1 genes. Genotypic analysis revealed that BbM viruses evolved from different sources and belonged to a new genotype (B46) discovered in our recent study. Molecular analysis indicated that BbM viruses were likely weakly pathogenic reassortants. However, the results of our pathogenicity study showed that BbM viruses replicated efficiently in chickens and a mammalian mouse model, but were not lethal to infected chickens and mice. Antigenic analysis showed that BbM viruses were antigenically heterologous with the H9N2 vaccine strain. Our study is probably the first report to document and characterize H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from black-billed magpies in southern China. Our results suggest that black-billed magpies were susceptible to H9N2 influenza virus, raising concerns about possible transmission of reassortant H9N2 viruses among poultry and wild birds. © 2011 Dong et al.
authors: Dong, G.;Xu, C.;Wang, C.;Wu, B.;Luo, J.;Zhang, H.;Nolte, D. L.;Deliberto, T. J.;Duan, M.;Ji, G.;He, H.

title: Characteristics of H13N8 subtype influenza virus first isolated from Qinghai Lake region, China
abstract: Background: Since the highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza caused thousands of wild bird deaths in the area in 2005, China's Qinghai Lake has become a hotspot for studying the impact of avian influenza on migratory wild birds. However, the ecology and evolution of the low pathogenic avian influenza virus is limited in this region. This project-based surveillance of bird flu in Qinghai Lake Region was initiated in 2012. Method: In 2012, samples of wild bird droppings and lake surface water were collected in Qinghai Lake. Virus isolation was performed on embryonated chicken eggs. The influenza A virus was determined by rRT-PCR. Virus sequences were acquired by deep sequencing. The phylogenetic correlation and the molecular properties of the viruses were analyzed. Virus growth and infection characteristics, receptor binding preference and pathogenicity were examined both in vitro and. Results: Two influenza viruses of subtype H13N8 were isolated. The viruses belong phylogenetically to the Eurasian lineage. Most genes are associated with gull influenza virus, except for the PB1 gene, which is most likely derived from Anseriformes virus. Evidence of rearrangement between species has been presented. The two viruses have limited growth capacity on MDCK and A549 cells while growing well in embryonated eggs. The dual receptor binding characteristics of the two viruses have been demonstrated. The low pathogenic characteristics were determined by a trypsin-dependency plaque formation assay. Conclusions: The two influenza viruses of the H13N8 subtype are strongly associated with gull origin. The interspecies reassortment of the H13 subtype virus among wild birds Anseriformes and Charadriiformes underscores the importance of increased surveillance for avian influenza in this region. This study is helpful in understanding the ecology, evolution, and transmission patterns of the H13 subtype influenza virus worldwide.
authors: Dong, J.;Bo, H.;Zhang, Y.;Dong, L.;Zou, S.;Huang, W.;Liu, J.;Wang, D.;Shu, Y.

title: Polymorphisms affecting the gE and gI proteins contribute in part to the virulence of an emerging highly virulent Chinese pseudorabiesvirus
abstract: An outbreak of a highly virulent strain of pseudorabies virus, ZJ01, occurred in PRV-vaccinated pigs in China in 2011. In this study, ZJ01 caused fatal diseases, while the Chinese prototypical PRV strain LA caused mild respiratory diseases. Full genome sequencing results show that the two viruses can be divided into two subgroups, distinct from traditional European and US strains. To investigate the potential role of the gE and gI proteins in ZJ01 virulence, we generated several recombinant viruses. Two chimeric viruses (rZJ01-LA/gEI and rLA-ZJ01/gEI) had their gE and gI genes swapped using corresponding genes from ZJ01 and LA. rZJ01-LA/gEI and the parental virus rZJ01 maintained high virulence in piglets, although survival time for rZJ01-LA/gEI infected piglets was apparently prolonged. In contrast, rLA-ZJ01/gEI showed higher virulence than its parental virus rLA. We conclude that changes in the gE and gI proteins contribute in part to the increased virulence of the ZJ01 strain.
authors: Dong, J.;Gu, Z.;Jin, L.;Lv, L.;Wang, J.;Sun, T.;Bai, J.;Sun, H.;Wang, X.;Jiang, P.

title: A new recombinant virulent virus strain of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome in China
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most important swine diseases worldwide. In the present study, a new virulent strain of PRRS virus (PRRSV), GDsg, was isolated in Guangdong Province, China and caused high fever, high morbidity and high mortality in sows and piglets. The genome of this new strain was 15,413 nucleotides (nt) long and a comparative analysis showed that GDsg was 82.4% to 94% co-located with PRRSV type 2 strains, but only 61.5% with the PRRSV Lelystad virus strain of type 1 was identical. Phylogenetic analysis showed that type 2 PRRSV isolates comprise five subgenotypes (I, II, III, IV and V) represented by NADC30, VR-2332, GM2, CH-1a and HuN4, respectively. In addition, GDsg belongs to an emerging type 2 PRRSV subgenotype III. Interestingly, the newly isolated GDsg strain has several discontinuous nt deletions, 131 (19+18+94) at position 1404-1540 and a 107 nt insertion in the NSP2 region. Most importantly, the GDsg strain was identified as a virus recombined between the low pathogenic field strain QYYZ and the vaccine strain JXA1-P80. In summary, a new independent subgenotype and recombinant PRRSV strain has emerged in China, which could pose a new threat to the Chinese swine industry.
authors: Dong, J. G.;Yu, L. Y.;Wang, P. P.;Zhang, L. Y.;Liu, Y. L.;Liang, P. S.;Song, C. X.

title: Dynamic co-evolution and interaction of avian leukosis virus genetic variants and host immune responses
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup Ja (ALV-J), a typical retrovirus, is characterized by the presence of a cloud of different variants and considerable genetic diversity. Previous studies describing the evolutionary dynamics of ALV-J genetic variants have mainly focused on the early infection period or a few randomly selected clones. Here we inoculated 30 specific pathogen-free chickens with the same founder ALV-J strain of known genetic background. Six (three antibody positive and three antibody negative) chickens were selected from 15 chickens with viraemia. Viruses were serially isolated over 36 weeks and then sequenced using the high-throughput sequencing platform MiSeq. This resulted in the largest ALV-J data set to date, consisting of more than three million clean reads. Our results indicated that host humoral immunity could significantly enhance the genetic diversity of ALV-J genetic variants. In particular, selection pressure promoted dynamic proportional changes in the frequency of ALV-J genetic variants. The cross-neutralization experiment showed that along with the change in the dominant variant, the antibody titers specific to infectious clones corresponding to the most dominant variants at weeks 12 and 28 also changed significantly in the sera obtained at weeks 16 and 32 A shift in the dominant variant was observed in antibody-negative chickens. In addition, we identified a new hypervariable region in the gp85 gene. Our study demonstrates the interaction between ALV-J and the host, which could facilitate the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs.
authors: Dong, X.;Meng, F.;Hu, T.;Ju, S.;Li, Y.;Sun, P.;Wang, Y.;Chen, W.;Zhang, F.;Su, H.;Li, S.;Cui, H.;Chen, J.;Xu, S.;Fang, L.;Luan, H.;Zhang, Z.;Chang, S.;Li, J.;Wang, L.;Zhao, P.;Shi, W.;Cui, Z.

title: First report of Porcine Techovirus (PTV), Porcine Sapelovirus (PSV) and Enterovirus G (EV-G) in swine herds in Brazil
authors: Donin, D. G.;Leme, R. de Arruda;Alfieri, A. F.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of rotavirus A NSP2 gene sequences and evidence of intragenic recombination
abstract: The rotavirus nonstructural protein NSP2 is one of the earliest and most frequently produced viral proteins during infection. This protein has several essential roles in the replication cycle including RNA binding, viroplasma formation, helicase and can hydrolyze the β-phosphate of RNA and NTPs acting as RTPase and NTPase. When examining sequences from rotavirus strains isolated between 1984 and 2009 in Australia, the NSP2 gene was found to be highly conserved and clustered with the defined NSP2 genotypes N1 and N2 according to the complete genome-based rotavirus classification system. Phylogenetic analysis showed that NSP2 gene sequences isolated from Australian rotavirus strains formed four distinct lineages. Temporal variation was observed in several clusters during the 26-year period, with lineage D being identified throughout the study period and lineage A being detected only since 1999. This sequence from a human strain closely clustered with the NSP2 genes of bovine rotavirus strains. This study also identified a sequence that lay between the lineages and showed evidence of recombination, the first time that intergenetic recombination has been demonstrated in an NSP2 gene sequence. This study improves the understanding of NSP2 evolutionary mechanisms with a view to improved vaccine design. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Donker, N. C.;Boniface, K.;Kirkwood, C. D.

title: Identification of fungi in shotgun metagenomics datasets
abstract: Metagenomics uses nucleic acid sequencing to characterize biodiversity in different niches such as environmental biomes or the human microbiome. Most studies have used 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing to identify bacteria. However, the falling cost of sequencing has led to a gradual shift away from amplicon analysis and toward shotgun metagenomic sequencing. Shotgun metagenome data can be used to identify a wide range of species, but has rarely been used to identify fungi. Here we develop a sequence classification pipeline, FindFungi, and use it to identify fungal sequences in public metagenome datasets. We mainly focus on animal metagenomes, particularly those from porcine and mouse microbiomes. We identified fungi in 39 out of 70 datasets covering 71 fungal species. At least 11 pathogenic species with zoonotic potential have been identified, including Candida tropicalis. We identified Pseudogymnoascus species from 13 Antarctic soil samples originally analyzed for the presence of bacteria capable of degrading diesel oil. We also show that Candida tropicalis and Candida loboi are probably the same species. In addition, we identify several examples where contaminating DNA was mistakenly included in fungal genome assemblies.
authors: Donovan, P. D.;Gonzalez, G.;Higgins, D. G.;Butler, G.;Ito, K.

title: The Art of Culture: Development of Cell Lines
authors: Dove, A.

title: Assessing the diversity of rodent-borne viruses: investigating high-throughput sequencing and classical amplification/sequencing approaches
abstract: Rodents are distributed all over the world and interact with humans in a variety of ways. They provide vital ecosystem services, some species are useful models in biomedical research, and some are kept as pets. However, many rodent species can have adverse effects such as: B. damage to crops and stored products, and they are health concerns due to the transmission of pathogens to humans and livestock. The first rodent viruses were discovered through isolation approaches and led to breakthroughs in immunology, molecular and cell biology, and cancer research. In addition to rodent-specific viruses, rodent-borne viruses cause a variety of zoonoses. The most prominent examples are recurrent outbreaks of human hemorrhagic febrile illnesses caused by arenaviruses and hantaviruses. In addition, rodents are reservoirs for vector-borne pathogens such as B. tick-borne encephalitis virus and Borrelia spp., and may carry human pathogens but are unlikely to be involved in their transmission to humans. Today, next-generation sequencing, or high-throughput sequencing (HTS), is revolutionizing the speed of new virus discovery, but other molecular approaches, such as generic RT-PCR/PCR and rolling circle amplification techniques also contribute significantly to the rapidly advancing process. However, the current state of knowledge is still only the tip of the iceberg when comparing the known human viruses to those known in rodents, the mammalian taxon with the largest species diversity. The diagnostic potential of HTS-based metagenomic approaches is illustrated by their use in the discovery and full genome characterization of novel bornaviruses and adenoviruses as causative pathogens in squirrels. In summary, HTS in combination with conventional RT-PCR/PCR-based approaches led to a drastically increased knowledge of rodent virus diversity. Future improvements in the workflows used, including bioinformatic analysis, will further enhance our knowledge and preparedness in the event of new virus emergence. Classical virological and additional molecular approaches are needed for genome annotation and functional characterization of new viruses discovered by these technologies and assessment of their zoonotic potential.
authors: Drewes, S.;StrakovÃ¡, P.;Drexler, J. F.;Jacob, J.;Ulrich, R. G.

title: Bats harbor the most important mammalian paramyxoviruses
abstract: The large Paramyxoviridae virus family includes some of the most important human and livestock viruses, such as measles, distemper, mumps, parainfluenza, Newcastle disease, respiratory syncytial virus and metapneumoviruses. Here we identify an estimated 66 new paramyxoviruses in a global sample of 119 bat and rodent species (9,278 individuals). Key discoveries include proof of an African origin for Hendra and Nipah viruses, identification of a bat virus similar to human mumps virus, proof of close relatives in bats of respiratory syncytial virus, mouse pneumonia virus and canine distemper virus, and more direct ones Detection of Sendai virus in rodents. The phylogenetic reconstruction of host associations indicates a dominance of host switching from bats to other mammals and birds. Hypothesis testing in a maximum likelihood framework allows the phylogenetic placement of bats as tentative hosts at ancestral nodes of both major Paramyxoviridae subfamilies (Paramyxovirinae and Pneumovirinae). Future attempts to predict the emergence of novel paramyxoviruses in humans and livestock must rely heavily on these data. © 2012 Macmillan Publishers Limited. All rights reserved.
authors: Drexler, J. F.;Corman, V. M.;MÃ¼ller, M. A.;Maganga, G. D.;Vallo, P.;Binger, T.;Gloza-Rausch, F.;Rasche, A.;Yordanov, S.;Seebens, A.;Oppong, S.;Sarkodie, Y. A.;Pongombo, C.;Lukashev, A. N.;Schmidt-Chanasit, J.;StÃ¶cker, A.;Carneiro, A. J. B.;Erbar, S.;Maisner, A.;Fronhoffs, F.;Buettner, R.;Kalko, E. K. V.;Kruppa, T.;Franke, C. R.;Kallies, R.;Yandoko, E. R. N.;Herrler, G.;Reusken, C.;Hassanin, A.;KrÃ¼ger, D. H.;Matthee, S.;Ulrich, R. G.;Leroy, E. M.;Drosten, C.

title: Bats worldwide carry hepatitis E virus-related viruses, forming a putative new genus within the family Hepeviridae
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is one of the most common causes of acute hepatitis in tropical and temperate climates. Tropical genotypes 1 and 2 are associated with food and waterborne transmission. Zoonotic reservoirs (mainly pigs, wild boar, and deer) are considered for genotypes 3 and 4, which are found in temperate climates. Given the association of several zoonotic viruses with bats, we analyzed 3,869 bat samples from 85 different species and from five continents for hepevirus RNA. HEVs have been identified in African, Central American, and European bats and form a new phylogenetic clade in the Hepeviridae family. Bat hepeviruses were highly diverse and comparable to human HEV in sequence variation. No evidence of transmission of bat hepeviruses to humans was found in over 90,000 human blood donations and individual patient sera. Complete genome analysis of a representative virus confirmed the formal classification within the Hepeviridae family. Sequence and distance-based taxonomic evaluations suggested that bat hepeviruses constitute a distinct genus within the family Hepeviridae, and that at least three other genera encompassing human, rodent, and avian hepeviruses can be identified. This may indicate that hepeviruses have not recently entered mammalian hosts and undergone speciation according to their host limitations. Human HEV-related viruses in livestock and peridomestic animals may represent secondary acquisitions of human viruses rather than animal progenitors causally involved in human HEV evolution. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Drexler, J. F.;Seelen, A.;Corman, V. M.;Tateno, A. F.;Cottontail, V.;Zerbinati, R. M.;Gloza-Rausch, F.;Klose, S. M.;Adu-Sarkodie, Y.;Oppong, S. K.;Kalko, E. K. V.;Osterman, A.;Rasche, A.;Adam, A.;MÃ¼ller, M. A.;Ulrich, R. G.;Leroy, E. M.;Lukashev, A. N.;Drosten, C.

title: Next-generation sequencing reveals diversification of the West Nile virus quasispecies after a single passage in a carrion crow (Corvus corone) in vivo infection model.
abstract: West Nile virus (WNV) occurs as a population of genetic variants (quasispecies) that infect a single animal. Previous estimates of low-resolution viral genetic diversity in wild bird and mosquito samples and in multi-passage adaptation studies in vivo or in cell culture suggest that WNV genetic diversification is mainly restricted to the mosquito vector. This study examined the genetic diversification of WNV in avian hosts during a single passage using next-generation sequencing. Wild-caught carrion crows were infected subcutaneously with a clonal Middle Eastern WNV. Blood samples were taken 2 and 4 days after infection. A reverse transcription (RT)-PCR approach was used to directly amplify the WNV genome from serum samples prior to next-generation sequencing, resulting in an average depth of at least 700x in each sample. Appropriate controls were sequenced to distinguish biologically relevant low-frequency variants from experimentally introduced errors. The WNV populations in the wild crows showed significant diversification away from the quasispecies structure of the inoculum virus. In contrast, WNV populations in intracerebrally infected day-old chicks did not differ from those in the inoculum. While previous studies concluded that WNV genetic diversification was only experimentally demonstrated in its permissive insect vector species, we experimentally demonstrated significant diversification of WNV populations in a wild bird reservoir species.
authors: Dridi, M.;Rosseel, T.;Orton, R.;Johnson, P.;Lecollinet, S.;Muylkens, B.;Lambrecht, B.;Van Borm, S.

title: Full nucleotide sequence of a Chinese serotype Asia1 vaccine strain of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequence of the Chinese vaccine strain Asia1/YNBS/58 of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) has been determined. The results showed that the full genome of YNBS/58 is 8,164 nucleotides (nt) in length, including a 1,061 nt 5″ untranslated region (UTR), a 6,990 nt open reading frame (ORF), and a 113 nt 3″ -Region €² UTR. Genomic sequences of Asia1/YNBS/58 and other known FMDV strains were compared. Homology analysis showed that non-structural proteins are more conserved than structural proteins in FMDV and that the 5 inch UTR is more conserved than the 3 inch UTR. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Asia1/YNBS/58 is clustered in the Asia1 serotype and associated with three other isolates, Asia1/IND/63/72, Asia1/3kimron/63 and Asia1/2ISRL/63, suggesting that they have a close connection genetic relationship. The VP1-, VP2- and VP3-based phylogenetic trees were divided into different clusters according to the different serotypes, while other gene-based phylogenetic trees showed some level of crossing between the serotypes. According to the nucleotide similarities between Asia1/YNBS/58 and two recent Chinese Asia1 isolates, Asia1/HKN/05 and Asia1/JS/05, each forms a different genotype. This study is the first description of the full genomic sequence of the Chinese FMDV serotype Asia1. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Du, J.;Chang, H.;Cong, G.;Shao, J.;Lin, T.;Shang, Y.;Liu, Z.;Liu, X.;Cai, X.;Xie, Q.

title: MicroRNA expression profiling of sheep primary testicular cells in response to bluetongue virus infection
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) is a member of the genus Orbivirus within the family Reoviridae and causes a non-contagious, insect-borne disease in domestic and wild ruminants, mainly sheep and occasionally cattle and some deer species. Viral infection can trigger the changes in cellular microRNA (miRNA) expression profile, which play an important post-transcriptional regulatory role in gene expression and can profoundly affect viral replication and pathogenesis. Here we used deep sequencing technology to determine which cellular miRNAs were differentially expressed in BTV-infected primary testis (ST) cells. A total of 25 known miRNAs and 240 novel miRNA candidates differentially expressed in BTV-infected and uninfected ST cells were identified, and 251 and 8428 predicted target genes, respectively, were annotated. Nine differentially expressed miRNAs and their mRNA targets were validated by quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. Target prediction and functional analysis of these regulated miRNAs revealed significant enrichment for multiple signaling pathways including MAPK, PI3K-Akt, endocytosis, Hippo, NF-kB, viral carcinogenesis, FoxO, and JAK-STAT signaling pathways. This study provides a valuable basis for further investigations into the role of miRNAs in BTV replication and pathogenesis.
authors: Du, J.;Gao, S.;Tian, Z.;Xing, S.;Huang, D.;Zhang, G.;Zheng, Y.;Liu, G.;Luo, J.;Chang, H.;Yin, H.

title: Distribution and characteristics of rodent picornaviruses in China
abstract: Rodents are important reservoir hosts of many important zoonotic viruses. The Picornaviridae family contains clinically important pathogens that infect humans and animals, and an increasing number of rodent picornaviruses have recently been implicated in zoonoses. We collected 574 throat and anal swab samples from 287 rodents of 10 different species from October 2013 to July 2015 from eight representative regions of China. Seven representative sequences identified from six rodent species were amplified as complete genomes and divided into four lineages. Three lineage 1 viruses belonged to a new genus of picornaviruses and were more closely related to hepatovirus than to other genera of picornaviruses based on aa homology. Lineage 2, lineage 3, and lineage 4 viruses belonged to the genera Rosavirus, Hunnivirus, and Enterovirus, respectively, and represented new species. According to both phylogenetic and identity analyses, lineage 2 viruses were closely related to rosavirus 2, recovered from the feces of a child in The Gambia, and lineage 3 viruses were closely related to domestic animal hunnivirus. Lineage 4 viruses provide the first evidence of these enteroviruses and their evolution in rodent hosts in China.
authors: Du, J.;Lu, L.;Liu, F.;Su, H. X.;Dong, J.;Sun, L. L.;Zhu, Y. F.;Ren, X. W.;Yang, F.;Guo, F.;Liu, Q. Y.;Wu, Z. Q.;Jin, Q.

title: Molecular evolution and emergence of the H5N6 avian influenza virus in central China
abstract: Avian influenza virus H5N6 (AIV) has posed a potential public health threat since its emergence in China in 2013. To understand the development and emergence of H5N6 AIV in the avian population, we performed molecular surveillance of live poultry markets ( LPMs) in Wugang Prefecture, Hunan Province, in central China, in 2014 and 2015. Wugang Prefecture lies on the East Asia-Australia migratory bird route and on November 21, 2016, a human death due to H5N6 virus was reported in the prefecture . Overall We collected and sequenced the complete genomes of 175 H5N6 AIVs. In particular, our analysis revealed that H5N6 AIVs contain at least six genotypes arising from the segment rearrangement, including a rare variant possessing an HA gene derived from H5N1 clade 2.3.2 and a novel NP gene , which has its origins in H7N3 viruses. In addition, a phylogenetic analysis revealed that genetically similar H5N6 AIVs tend to cluster according to their geographic region of origin. These results help uncover the evolutionary behavior of influenza viruses before they appeared in humans.
authors: Du, Y.;Chen, M.;Yang, J.;Jia, Y.;Han, S.;Holmes, E. C.;Cui, J.

title: Identification, phylogenetic evolution analysis of GDQY orf virus isolated from Qingyuan city, Guangdong province, southern China
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV) infection results in contagious ecthyma, also called contagious pustular dermatitis, which usually affects sheep, goats, and other small ruminants. It has a wide spread across the world and has also been reported to infect humans. Although many tribes from different parts of mainland China have been isolated, rarely has a tribe been reported from the southern provinces of China. We studied a case of orf virus infection that occurred in the city of Qingyuan, Guangdong Province, southern China. An orf virus strain, GDQY, was successfully isolated and identified by cell culture techniques and transmission electron microscopy. Whole genes from ORFV011, ORFV059, ORFV106 and ORFV107 were amplified for sequence analysis based on their nucleotide or amino acid level. To discuss the genetic variation, precise sequences were used to compare with other reference strains isolated from different districts or countries. Phylogenetic trees based on these strains were constructed and evolutionary distances were calculated based on the alignment of their full sequences. The typical structure of the orf virus was observed in cell culture suspensions inoculated with GDQY, and the full length of four genes were amplified and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis showed that GDQY is homologous to FJ-DS and CQ/WZ on ORFV011 nucleotides. Based on the comparison between GDQY and other isolates, ORFV059 may be more variable than ORFV011. Genetic studies of ORFV106 and 107 are reported for the first time in the presented study.
authors: Duan, C.;Liao, M.;Wang, H.;Luo, X.;Shao, J.;Xu, Y.;Li, W.;Hao, W.;Luo, S.

title: Isolation and characterization of the influenza A virus (subtype H5N1) that caused the first highly pathogenic outbreak of avian influenza in chickens in Bhutan
abstract: We characterized the influenza A/H5N1 virus that caused the first outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in chickens in Bhutan in 2010. The virus was highly virulent for chickens, killing them within two days of experimental vaccination with an intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) of 2.88. Complete genome sequencing of 4 virus isolates was performed for genetic and phylogenetic analysis. The isolates displayed multiple basic amino acids at their hemagglutinin (HA) cleavage site, similar to other "Qinghai-like" H5N1 isolates. The receptor binding site of the HA molecule contained avian-like amino acids (222Q and 224G). The isolates also contained the amino acid residue K at position 627 of the PB2 protein and other markers in the NS1 and PB1 proteins, highlighting the mammalian risk. However, the isolates were sensitive to influenza drugs currently on the market. Sequence analysis showed that the Bhutanese viruses shared 99.1-100% nucleotide homology in all eight genes among themselves and in the Bangladesh 2010 chicken isolate (A/chicken/Bangladesh/1151-11/2010), indicating a common progenitor virus . Phylogenetic analysis showed that the Bhutanese isolates belonged to subclass 2.2.3 (EMA 3) and shared a common progenitor virus with the 2010 Bangladesh virus. Based on evidence of phylogeny and molecular markers, it was concluded that the outbreaks in Bhutan and Bangladesh in 2010 were due to independent introductions of the virus, probably by migratory birds. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Dubey, S. C.;Dahal, N.;Nagarajan, S.;Tosh, C.;Murugkar, H. V.;Rinzin, K.;Sharma, B.;Jain, R.;Katare, M.;Patil, S.;Khandia, R.;Syed, Z.;Tripathi, S.;Behera, P.;Kumar, M.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Krishna, L.

title: Identification of a novel coronavirus from guinea fowl using metagenomics
abstract: While classical virological techniques such as virus culture, electron microscopy or classical PCR have not been successful in identifying the pathogen responsible for fulminant guinea fowl disease, we used metagenomics to identify a novel avian gamma-coronavirus associated with the disease. Next-generation sequencing is an unbiased approach that enables the sequencing of virtually all genetic material present in a given sample.
authors: Ducatez, M. F.;Guerin, J. L.

title: Characterization of a new genotype and serotype of infectious bronchitis virus in West Africa
abstract: Between 2002 and 2007, more than 1000 chickens from commercial farms, live bird markets and backyard farms in Nigeria and Niger were tested for the presence of the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) genome. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete sequences of the Spike 1 (S1) gene revealed a new genotype of IBV which we refer to as "IBADAN". The minimum genetic distance to the closest "non-IBADAN" strains (UK/7/93 at the nucleotide level; H120 and M41 at the amino acid level) reached 24 and 32% at the nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. The complete genome of the IBADAN reference strain (NGA/A116E7/2006) had a genetic distance of 9.7-16.4% at the nucleotide level with all available fully sequenced strains. Since IBV S1 plays an important role in antigenicity, the antigenic relatedness of NGA/A116E7/2006 was compared to strains of other serotypes. NGA/A116E7/2006 did not cross-react with antisera against IT02, M41, D274, Connecticut or 793/B strains in virus neutralization assays. NGA/A116E7/2006 cross-reacted with the QX-like strain ITA/90254/2005, but at a low level (33% antigen relatedness), suggesting that IBADAN also represents a novel serotype. A comparison of S1 sequences identified several amino acids that may play a role in IBV antigenicity. Despite the lack of obvious clinical signs in poultry infected with IBADAN strains, it is important to test the cross-protection of current vaccine strains. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Ducatez, M. F.;Martin, A. M.;Owoade, A. A.;Olatoye, I. O.;Alkali, B. R.;Maikano, I.;Snoeck, C. J.;Sausy, A.;Cordioli, P.;Muller, C. P.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of low pathogenicity H5N1 and H7N3 influenza A virus isolates recovered from a 2006 study site of free-flying wild mallard ducks
abstract: From August 2 to October 11, 2006, clusters of North American lineage low pathogenicity (LP) H5N1 and H7N3 avian influenza A viruses (AIV) and other subtypes were recovered from free-flying, resident, feral mallard ducks used as sentinels at a served side? site. The antigenic subtypes, the pathogenicity potential and the Sanger sequencing of the isolates were determined, the H5N1 and H7N3 isolates were obtained only from samples taken on August 2nd, 2006 and September 8th, 2006 respectively. However, later attempts using next-generation sequencing (NGS) and additional Sanger sequencing found partial H7 segments in other HA-NA virus combinations on 08/02/2006, 09/08/2006 and 10/11/2006. It is well known that AIVs form transient genomic constellations over larger geographic areas and years; These sequential sampling data showed that dynamics of AIVs can be active over a short period of time and newer sequencing platforms improve detection of mixed infections. Both results provide further insight into the natural history of AIVs in natural reservoirs. © 2011 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Dugan, V. G.;Dunham, E. J.;Jin, G.;Sheng, Z. M.;Kaser, E.;Nolting, J. M.;Alexander, H. L.;Slemons, R. D.;Taubenberger, J. K.

title: Viral diversity in porcine intestinal mucus used for the production of heparin as analyzed by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Heparin is one of the most important pharmaceutical products made from animal raw material. To characterize the viral load associated with this raw material, we performed high-throughput sequencing (HTS) on mucus samples intended for heparin production collected from European pigs. We identified Circoviridae and Parvoviridae members as the most prevalent contaminating viruses, along with viruses from the families Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Reoviridae, Caliciviridae, Adenoviridae, Birnaviridae, and Anelloviridae. Putative new virus species have also been identified. The load of several known or novel small non-enveloped viruses that are particularly difficult to inactivate or eliminate during heparin processing was quantified by qPCR. The analysis of the combined HTS and specific qPCR results will influence the refinement and validation of inactivation methods and support the risk analysis of viral heparin contamination.
authors: Dumarest, M.;Muth, E.;Cheval, J.;Gratigny, M.;HÃ©bert, C.;Gagnieur, L.;Eloit, M.

title: Effects of poultry house environment on bacterial community composition in poultry litter
abstract: Viral and bacterial pathogens are a significant economic concern for the US broiler industry, and the ecological epicenter for poultry pathogens is the mixture of bedding material, chicken droppings and feathers that make up the bedding of a poultry house. This study used high-throughput sequencing to assess the richness and diversity of bacterial communities in poultry litter and to look for associations between these communities and a poultry house's environmental characteristics, including its history of gangrenous dermatitis (GD). Cluster analysis of 16S rRNA gene sequences revealed differences in the distribution of bacterial phylotypes between wet and dry litter samples and between houses. Wet litter contained greater diversity, with 90% of the total bacterial abundance occurring in the top 214 OTU clusters. In contrast, only 50 clusters accounted for 90% of the bacterial abundance in dry litter. The sixth largest OTU cluster of all samples, classified as Arcobacter sp., an emerging human pathogen found only in the wet litter samples from a barn with a modern evaporative cooling system. Ironically, the primary pathogenic clostridial and staphylococcal species associated with GD have not been found in any homes; However, there were thirteen 16S rRNA gene phylotypes from mainly Gram-positive strains that were found only in GD-affected pens and were found mainly in wet litter samples. Overall, the environment in the poultry house appeared to significantly affect the composition of bacterial communities in the litter and may play a key role in the emergence of foodborne pathogens. © 2011 Dumas et al.
authors: Dumas, M. D.;Polson, S. W.;Ritter, D.;Ravel, J.;Gelb Jr, J.;Morgan, R.;Wommack, K. E.

title: Molecular and microscopic detection of viruses in marine copepods
abstract: As dominant members of marine mesozooplankton communities, copepods play critical roles in oceanic food webs and biogeochemical cycles. Despite the ecological importance of copepods, little is known about the causes of copepod mortality, and up to 35% of total copepod mortality cannot be attributed to predation alone. Viruses have established themselves as ecologically important infectious agents in the oceans; However, viral infections have not been studied in mesozooplankton communities. Here we used molecular and microscopic techniques to document viral infections in natural populations of the calanoid copepods Acartia tonsa (Dana) and Labidocera aestiva (Wheeler) in Tampa Bay, FL. Viral metagenomics revealed previously undocumented viruses in each species, termed Acartia tonsa copepod circo-like virus (AtCopCV) and Labidocera aestiva copepod circo-like virus (LaCopCV). LaCopCV has been found to be extremely widespread and abundant in L. aestiva populations, with a prevalence as high as 100% in some samples and an average viral load of 1.13 x 10(5) copies per individual. LaCopCV transcription was also detected in most L. aestiva individuals, indicating viral activity. AtCopCV was sporadically detected in A. tonsa populations throughout the year, suggesting temporal variability in viral infection dynamics. Finally, virus-like particles of unknown identity were observed by transmission electron microscopy in the connective tissues of A. tonsa and L. aestiva, indicating that viruses are actively replicating in the copepod connective tissues rather than infecting gut contents, parasites, or symbionts. Taken together, these results provide strong independent evidence for active viral infection in dominant copepod species, suggesting that viruses can significantly affect mesozooplankton ecology.
authors: Dunlap, D. S.;Ng, T. F. F.;Rosario, K.;Barbosa, J. G.;Greco, A. M.;Breitbart, M.;Hewson, I.

title: Bovine enteroviruses in calves: an attempt at serological, biological, and pathological classification
abstract: Bovine enteroviruses have been classified into 8 serotypes to provide a basis for pathogenicity studies. Oral and subcutaneous inoculation of the virus in 1 day to 8 week old calves generally resulted in leukopenia and fever. Of 6 calves without colostrum that were vaccinated before receiving their first milk, 3 died; however, a comparable proportion (9/17) of unvaccinated calves without colostrum also died. Fever and leukopenia developed in 4- to 8-week-old calves exposed to the virus, but less than half of the calves developed diarrhea and few died. None of the colostrum-fed, unvaccinated calves died. Fetal infection in utero appeared to be common, as judged by the detection of antibodies to one or more bovine enteroviruses in fetuses aborted at or beyond 4 months of gestation. The antibodies were assumed to be of fetal origin. It has been postulated that in utero infection may contribute to early death or lack of resistance of the newborn calf to bacterial infection.
authors: Dunne, H. W.;Huang, C. M.;Lin, W. J.

title: Characterization of novel bovine leukemia virus (BLV) antisense transcripts by deep sequencing reveals constitutive expression in tumors and transcriptional interaction with viral microRNAs
abstract: Background: Bovine leukemia virus (BLV) is a delta retrovirus closely related to human T-cell leukemia virus-1 (HTLV-1). Cattle are the natural host of BLV, where it integrates into B cells and causes lifelong infection. Most infected animals remain asymptomatic, but after a prolonged latency period, approximately 5% develop aggressive leukemia/lymphoma, reflecting the disease course of HTLV-1. The mechanisms by which these viruses bring about cellular transformation remain obscure. With both viruses, little or no transcription from the 5'LTR is observed in tumors, however, the proviruses are not transcriptionally silent. In the case of BLV, a cluster of RNA polymerase III transcribed microRNAs is highly expressed, while the HTLV-1 antisense transcript HBZ is consistently found in all tumors examined. Results: Here, using RNA-seq, we show that the BLV provirus also constitutively expresses antisense transcripts in all leukemic and asymptomatic samples examined. The first transcript (AS1) can be alternately polyadenylated, generating a ~600 bp transcript (AS1-S) and a less abundant ~2200 bp transcript (AS1-L). Alternative splicing generates a second transcript of ~400 bp (AS2). The coding potential of AS1-S/L is ambiguous with a small open reading frame of 264 bp, however, the transcripts are mainly retained in the nucleus, suggesting an lncRNA-like role. The AS1-L transcript overlaps the BLV microRNAs and using high-throughput sequencing of RNA ligase-mediated (RLM) 5'RACE we show that the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) cleaves AS1-L. Furthermore, experiments with engineered BLV proviruses, in which the microRNAs are either deleted or inverted, indicate additional transcriptional interference between the two viral RNA species. Conclusions: The identification of new viral antisense transcripts shows that the BLV provirus is far from silent in tumors. Furthermore, the consistent expression of these transcripts in both leukemic and non-malignant clones indicates a crucial role in the virus life cycle and its tumorigenic potential. Furthermore, cleavage of the AS1-L transcript by the BLV-encoded microRNAs and transcriptional interference between the two viral RNA species suggest a shared role in the regulation of BLV.
authors: Durkin, K.;Rosewick, N.;Artesi, M.;Hahaut, V.;Griebel, P.;Arsic, N.;Burny, A.;Georges, M.;Van den Broeke, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of beak and feather disease virus across a host ring-species complex
abstract: Pathogens have been hypothesized to play an important role in host diversity and speciation. The susceptibility of hybrid hosts to pathogens is believed to be a common phenomenon that could promote host population divergence and subsequent speciation. However, few studies have tested for pathogen infection across animal hybrid zones while simultaneously testing for pathogen codivergence in the hybridizing host complex. For 8 years we studied natural infection by a rapidly evolving single-stranded DNA virus, beak and feather disease virus (BFDV), infecting parrots by exploiting a host ring species complex (Platycercus elegans) in Australia. We found that the host subspecies and their hybrids differed strikingly in both BFDV prevalence and burden: both hybrid and phenotypically intermediate subspecies had lower prevalence and burden compared to parental subspecies, while host age, sex, lengths - and latitude as well as temporal effects were controlled . We have sequenced viral isolates throughout the range, which, to our knowledge, revealed for the first time in a host-pathogen system patterns of genomic variation analogous to Mayr's ring species hypothesis. Viral phylogeny, geographical location, intraspecific host densities, and parrot community diversity and composition did not explain the differences in BFDV prevalence or burden between subpopulations. Overall, our analyzes suggest that host functional responses to infection, or infective power, differ between subspecies and hybrids. Our results highlight the role of host hybridization and cline in altering host-pathogen interactions, dynamics that can have important implications for speciation models involving gene flow, and provide insights into how pathogens can adapt to different host populations.
authors: Eastwood, J. R.;Berg, M. L.;Ribot, R. F.;Raidal, S. R.;Buchanan, K. L.;Walder, K. R.;Bennett, A. T.

title: Novel Atlantic bottlenose dolphin parainfluenza virus TtPIV-1 clusters with bovine PIV-3 genotype B strains
abstract: Parainfluenza virus 3 (PIV-3) is a common viral infection not only in humans but also in many other species. Serologic evidence suggests that nearly 100% of children in the United States by age 5 were infected with PIV-3. Similarly, in cattle, PIV-3 is commonly associated with bovine respiratory disease complex. A novel dolphin PIV-3 (TtPIV-1) was reported by Nollens et al. in 2008 by a dolphin diagnosed with an unknown respiratory disease. At that time, TtPIV-1 was found to be most similar to, but distinct from, bovine PIV-3 (BPIV-3). In the present study, similar viral growth kinetics and pro-inflammatory cytokine (IL-1β, IL-6 and CXCL8) production were seen between BPIV-3 and TtPIV-1 in BEAS-2B, MDBK and Vero cell lines. The initial nomenclature of TtPIV-1 was based on a partial sequence of the fusion and RNA polymerase genes. Because of the similarities we saw with the in vitro work, it was important to take a closer look at the TtPIV-1 genome. Full genome sequencing and subsequent phylogenetic analysis revealed that all six TtPIV-1 viral genes are clustered in the recently described BPIV-3 genotype B strains, and it is proposed to link TtPIV-1 to BPIV-3 genotype reclassify B strains.
authors: Eberle, K. C.;Neill, J. D.;Venn-Watson, S. K.;McGill, J. L.;Sacco, R. E.

title: Characterization of the structural proteins of Porcine Epizootic Diarrhea Virus strain CV777
abstract: Swine epizootic diarrheal virus cannot be grown in cell culture; to characterize it, intestinal perfusate material from a pig infected with strain CV777 had to be used. A peak of virus-specific ELISA activity was detected at a density of 1.17 g/ml in isopycnic sucrose gradients. Using immunoprecipitation of radioiodinated purified virus material followed by sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, 3 low molecular weight proteins (20,000 to 32,000 daltons [D]) were found; after blotting of nitrocellulose and glycoprotein identification with concanavalin A and horseradish peroxidase, 1 of the proteins (23,000 D) gave a signal. Another protein of 58,000 D was encountered, which was the only protein that binds an RNA probe. Finally, a protein of 85,000 D was visible, associated with smaller bands of around 110,000 and 135,000 D in most experiments. The same bands were visualized using the concanavalin A blotting technique. The detection of a polydisperse cluster of proteins from 20,000 to 32,000 D (at least 1 of which is glycosylated), of glycosylated proteins from 85,000 to 135,000 D and an RNA-binding protein of 58,000 D is taken as structural evidence that pigs should be infested with diarrheal virus be assigned to the Coronaviridae, notwithstanding the apparent lack of an antigenic relationship with other members of this family.
authors: Egberink, H. F.;Ederveen, J.;Callebaut, P.;Horzinek, M. C.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of foot-and-mouth disease viruses from outbreaks in some states of northern Nigeria in 2013-2015
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) control measures in Nigeria have not been implemented due to the lack of locally produced vaccines and risk-based analysis due to insufficient data on circulating FMD virus (FMD) serotypes/strains. In 2013-2015, blood and epithelial samples were collected from reported FMD outbreaks in four states (Kaduna, Kwara, Plateau and Bauchi) in northern Nigeria. The seroprevalence of FMDV nonstructural proteins (NSP) for the outbreaks was estimated at 80% (72 out of 90) and 70% (131 out of 188) after the outbreak. Antibodies against the FMD serotypes O, A, SAT1, SAT2 and SAT3 were detected nationwide using competitive solid-phase ELISA. The FMD genome was detected in 99% (73 out of 74) of samples from FMD affected animals by rRT-PCR and 59% (44 out of 74) of these samples were found to be cytopathic in cell culture. Three FMDV serotypes O, A and SAT2 have been isolated and characterized. Phylogenetic assessments of the virus isolates showed that two topotypes of FMD serotype O, East African-3 (EA-3) and West African (WA) topotypes, and African genotype (G-IV) FMD strains circulated. of serotype A and FMDV SAT2 topotype VII strains. While the Nigerian serotype O (EA-3) strains were most closely related to a 1999 virus strain from Sudan, the WA strain in Nigeria shares a genetic relationship with three 1988 viruses in Niger. The FMDV serotype A strains were closely related to a known virus from Cameroon, and the SAT2 strains were most closely related to virus subtypes in Libya. This study provides evidence for the co-occurrence of FMD serotypes and topotypes in West, Central, East and North Africa and this has implications for control. Findings help fill the knowledge gap on FMD dynamics in Nigeria and the West African subregion to support local and regional development of vaccination-based control plans and international risk assessment.
authors: Ehizibolo, D. O.;Haegeman, A.;De Vleeschauwer, A. R.;Umoh, J. U.;Kazeem, H. M.;Okolocha, E. C.;Van Borm, S.;De Clercq, K.

title: Bovine herpesvirus type 2 is closely related to primate alphaherpesviruses
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus type 2 (BoHV-2), also known as bovine mammillititis virus, is classified along with herpes simplex viruses types 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2) in the family Herpesviridae, subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae and the genus simplexvirus and ranked other primate simplexviruses on the basis of similarities in 4 genes within the 15 kb U(L) 23-29 cluster. This could be explained by either global similarity or a recombination event that brought primate herpesviral sequences into a bovine virus. Our sequences for DNA polymerase (U(L)30), a large gene adjacent to the previously identified conserved cluster, and glycoprotein G (U(S)4), a gene located as far from the cluster as possible on the circularized genome confirm the close relationship between BoHV-2 and the primate simplexviruses and argue for global similarity and probably a close evolutionary relationship. Therefore, one can speculate that BoHV-2 could pose a greater threat to humans than previously thought.
authors: Ehlers, B.;Goltz, M.;Ejercito, M. P.;Dasika, G. K.;Letchworth, G. J.

title: First outbreaks and phylogenetic analyzes of avian influenza H9N2 viruses isolated from poultry flocks in Morocco
abstract: Background: H9N2 avian influenza viruses continue to spread worldwide in poultry and wild birds. Morocco faced its first outbreaks of the H9N2 influenza virus in early 2016, affecting various types of poultry production. After its introduction, the virus spread very quickly across the country. Methods: Samples were collected from 11 chicken flocks with high morbidity and mortality rates. Four viruses were successfully isolated from broilers and one from broilers and fully sequenced. Results: Phylogenetic and molecular marker analyzes showed that the Moroccan viruses belonged to the G1 lineage and probably originated in the Middle East. As is known for H9N2 viruses, the Moroccan isolates possess several genetic markers that increase virulence in poultry and transmission to humans. Conclusion: The present study demonstrated that H9N2 could have devastating effects on egg production and mortality under field conditions and highlighted a lack of surveillance data on the pathogen in the region.
authors: El Houadfi, M.;Fellahi, S.;Nassik, S.;GuÃ©rin, J. L.;Ducatez, M. F.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 clade 2.3.2.1c in Lebanon, 2016
abstract: We report the phylogenetic analysis of the first outbreak of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 detected in poultry in April 2016 in Lebanon, Europe and West Africa.
authors: El Romeh, A.;Zecchin, B.;Fusaro, A.;Ibrahim, E.;El Bazzal, B.;El Hage, J.;Milani, A.;Zamperin, G.;Monne, I.

title: Detection of the first human G6P[14] rotavirus strain in a child with diarrhea in Egypt
abstract: We report the first detection of a G6P[14] rotavirus strain in the stool of a child participating in a 2004 hospital diarrhea surveillance study in Egypt. the P (VP4) and G (VP7) genotypes of the strain were identified by RT-PCR. We sequenced the VP7 gene and the VP8* portion of the VP4 gene and the strain showed the strongest identity to VP7 [>94% nucleotides (nt), >97% amino acids (aa)] and VP4 (>93% nt, >98 % aa) Sequences of PA169, a new G6P[14] strain first isolated from a child in Italy in the winter of 1987. Additional sequencing and analysis of the other remaining structural (VP1-VP3, VP6) and non-structural (NSP1-NSP5) proteins support this animal-to-human reassortment theory. According to the complete genome classification system, strain G6P[14] (EGY3399) has been assigned to genotypes G6-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A11-N2-T6-E2-H3. The NSP4 and NSP5 gene sequences of EGY3399 were most similar to those of sheep and monkeys, respectively. Coupled with other observations, our results suggest that G6P[14] isolates rarely cause severe diarrhea in Egyptian children and support other studies suggesting that animal rotavirus contributes to the genetic diversity of rotavirus that is transmitted to humans by transmission between species and rearrangement of single or multiple segments has been demonstrated. © 2011.
authors: El Sherif, M.;Esona, M. D.;Wang, Y.;Gentsch, J. R.;Jiang, B.;Glass, R. I.;Baker, S. A.;Klena, J. D.

title: Avian flu: virology, diagnosis and surveillance
abstract: Avian influenza virus (AIV) is the causative agent of a zoonosis that affects populations worldwide with often devastating economic and public health consequences. Most AIV subtypes cause little or no disease in waterfowl, but outbreaks in poultry can be associated with high mortality. Although transmission of AIV to humans is rare and strain-dependent, the virus has the ability to mutate or convert into a form that causes a life-threatening infection. The constant emergence of new influenza strains makes it particularly difficult to predict behavior, spread, virulence, or the potential for human-to-human transmission. Since it is difficult to predict which virus strain or which location will trigger the next pandemic, it is difficult to prepare for this event. However, consistent implementation of biosecurity, immunization and education programs can minimize the risk of AIV. Global surveillance programs aid in the collection and identification of emerging and potentially pandemic strains harbored by the reservoir host. © 2013 Future Medicine Ltd.
authors: El Zowalaty, M. E.;Bustin, S. A.;Husseiny, M. I.;Ashour, H. M.

title: The ovine respiratory syncytial virus F gene sequence and its diagnostic application
abstract: Ruminant respiratory syncytial viruses (RSVs) are divided into 2 subgroups, ovine RSV and bovine RSV. Although ovine RSV infects cattle, its contribution to bovine respiratory disease has not been demonstrated, an important issue for cattle vaccine development. Diagnosis by virus isolation or serology has low or variable sensitivity and/or specificity, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has been recommended as a rapid and sensitive technique for RSV detection. A simple method has been developed to detect and identify bovine and ovine RSVs. First, the nucleotide sequence of the ovine RSV fusion gene (F) was determined and compared to representative strains of bovine RSV and human RSV subgroups A and B. The ovine RSV F gene shares 85 and 72-73% nucleotide identity with bovine RSV and human RSV, respectively. The predicted amino acid sequence of the ovine RSV F gene has 94 and 83-84% amino acid identity to that of bovine RSV and human RSV, respectively. Then, PCR primers were designed that targeted a specific F gene fragment from bovine and ovine RSV. The primers represented bases 85-103 and the complementary sequence to bases 510-493 of the ovine RSV F gene. A similar PCR product (426 bp) was obtained by agarose gel electrophoresis of bovine RSV and ovine RSV. However, the products were unique to the parent virus and could be distinguished by EcoRI or MspI restriction endonuclease digestion. EcoRI cleaved the sheep product into 2 bands (285 and 141 bp) but failed to affect the bovine RSV PCR product. However, MspI cleaved the bovine product into 2 bands (229 and 197 bp) but had no effect on the ovine product. Again, this assay did not amplify any human RSV PCR product. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) followed by restriction enzyme digestion is a useful and practical approach for the detection and differentiation of ruminant respiratory syncytial viruses.
authors: Eleraky, N. Z.;Kania, S. A.;Potgieter, L. N.

title: Accurate classification and hemagglutinin amino acid signatures for association and subtyping of influenza A virus host origin
abstract: Host origin classification and influenza A virus signatures were examined using the HA protein to trace the host of origin of the HA. Hidden Markov models (HMMs), decision trees, and associative classifications were generated for each influenza A virus subtype and its major hosts (human, avian, swine). Host- and subtype-specific features of the HA protein signatures were sought. Host-associated signatures that appeared in different subtypes of the virus were identified. An evaluation of the classification models based on ROC curves and support and confidence assessments for the amino acid class association rules was performed. Host classification based on HA subtype achieved accuracies between 91.2% and 100% using decision trees after feature selection. Host-specific class association rules for avian host ancestry yielded better support and confidence scores, followed by human ancestry, and finally porcine ancestry. This finding indicates the lower specificity of the pig host, possibly reflecting its ability to mix different strains.Â© 2013 Elsevier Inc.
authors: ElHefnawi, M.;Sherif, F. F.

title: Tight linkage of genes encoding receptors for avian sarcoma/leukosis virus subgroups A and C on chicken chromosome 28
abstract: Avian sarcoma and leukosis viruses (ASLV) are divided into six major subgroups (A through E and J) according to the properties of the viral envelope proteins and the use of cellular receptors for virus entry. Subgroup A and B receptors are molecularly identified and their genomic positions TVA and TVB are mapped. The subgroup C receptor is unknown, its genomic locus TVC is thought to be genetically linked to TVA located on chicken chromosome 28. In this study, we used two chicken inbred lines carrying different alleles encoding resistance (TVCR) and susceptibility (TFCS) to infection by subgroup C virus. A back ross population of these lines was tested for susceptibility to subgroup C infection and genotyped for chicken chromosome 28 markers. We confirmed the close association between TVA and TVC loci. Furthermore, we have described the position of TVC on chromosome 28 relative to markers from the consensus map of the chicken genome.
authors: Elleder, D.;PlachÃ½, J.;Hejnar, J.;Geryk, J.;Svoboda, J.

title: Identification and genetic characterization of rabies virus from Egyptian water buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) bitten by a fox
abstract: Rabies is caused by negative-strand RNA viruses classified in the genus Lyssavirus, family Rhabdoviridae, order Mononegavirales. The aim of the present study was to identify and analyze the nucleotide sequence of the nucleoprotein (N) gene of rabies virus (RABV) from two cases of water buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) bitten by a fox in Egypt in 2013. The diseased buffalo showed nervous manifestations with fever. Brain samples from the buffalo suspected of having rabies were collected. RABV in pooled specimens was identified using direct fluorescent antibody (dFA) technique, histopathological examination, and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). In addition, the nucleotide sequence of the partially amplified nucleoprotein (N) gene was compared to the other street strains of RABV available on GenBank. The results showed that the RABV antigen in the brains of diseased buffalo was identified by the dFA technique and the characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions (Negri bodies) and the RABV nucleic acid were detected by histopathology and RT-PCR, respectively. The identified virus showed close genetic relatedness to street strains previously identified from dogs in different governorates in Egypt and to strains identified in Israel and Jordan, suggesting transmission of the virus between Egyptian governorates with possible transmission of and /or points to our neighboring countries.
authors: El-Tholoth, M.;El-Beskawy, M.;Hamed, M. F.

title: Phages rarely encode antibiotic resistance genes: a red flag for virome analysis
authors: Enault, F.;Briet, A.;Bouteille, L.;Roux, S.;Sullivan, M. B.

title: The genome of bovine herpesvirus 1 (BHV-1) strains exhibiting neuropathogenic potential compared to known BHV-1 strains by restriction site mapping and cross-hybridization
authors: Engels, M.;Giuliani, C.;Wild, P.

title: Genetic and virulence characterization of classical swine fever viruses isolated in Mongolia from 2007 to 2015
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF), a highly contagious viral disease affecting domestic and wild pigs in many developing countries, is now considered endemic in Mongolia, with 14 recent outbreaks in 2007, 2008, 2011, 2012, 2014 and 2015 For the first time, CSF viruses isolated from these 14 outbreaks were simultaneously analyzed to assess their molecular epidemiology and pathogenicity in swine. Based on the nucleotide sequences of their 5″ untranslated region, isolates were phylogenetically classified as either subgenotype 2.1b or 2.2, and the 2014 and 2015 isolates classified as 2.1b were closely related to isolates from China and Korea. In addition, at least three different class 2.1b viruses have been circulating in Mongolia. Experimental infection of the representative isolate in 2014 showed moderate pathogenicity in 4-week-old pigs with relatively mild clinical signs. Understanding the diversity of circulating CSF viruses provides insight into disease dynamics and evolution and may inform the design of effective CSF control strategies in Mongolia.
authors: Enkhbold, B.;Shatar, M.;Wakamori, S.;Tamura, T.;Hiono, T.;Matsuno, K.;Okamatsu, M.;Umemura, T.;Damdinjav, B.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Virology in the 21st Century
authors: Enquist, L. W.

title: Structural similarities of porcine cholera virus with togaviruses
authors: Enzmann, P. J.;Weiland, F.

title: Viral detection as a tool for pandemic preparedness
abstract: Emerging diseases are often caused by novel or previously unrecognized zoonotic viral agents, typically of and originating from wild animals. When human or animal cases are first detected, molecular or serological diagnostic assays specific to them do not yet exist, resulting in a delay in identifying the causative agent of an outbreak, as well as its source. Preparing for the emergence of the next virus is a major public health challenge, hampered by an inadequate understanding of the diversity of potential candidates in wildlife reservoirs. Characterizing the diversity of viruses in key wildlife species will help reduce the time between detection and response in an outbreak situation and inform public health strategies that reduce the risk of transmission from animal reservoirs. Pathogen discovery techniques such as consensus polymerase chain reaction (cPCR) and next-generation sequencing (NGS) have been used to identify known and new viruses in animals and humans, but have not been widely adopted in surveillance programs. Metagenomic studies have identified new viruses and new strains of known viruses, and characterized host microbiomes. While NGS represents an unbiased approach to detecting viral sequences, it is limited by lower sensitivity than traditional PCR, requires significant bioinformatics skills, and is prohibitively expensive, and thus not widely used in regions of the world most prone to zoonoses occurring . In contrast, consensus PCR uses standard and widely used technologies, is more sensitive than NGS, and has also been used to identify new viruses in wildlife, livestock, and humans, although it is limited to detecting genetic target sequences that are conserved in known virus groups. The use of cPCR, when possible in combination with NGS and serology, can provide a powerful approach to rapidly identify etiologic agents in an outbreak and to characterize the virome of key wildlife animals known to transmit zoonotic viruses. Here the authors discuss pathogen discovery techniques currently used in human and animal surveillance programs and the challenges of using virus discovery to identify new zoonotic pathogens.
authors: Epstein, J. H.;Anthony, S. J.

title: Key Transitions in Human Evolution Revisited: A Tribute to Ancient DNA
abstract: The origin and diversification of modern humans have been shaped by major evolutionary transitions and demographic shifts. Patterns of genetic variation within modern populations can help reconstruct this similar 200,000-year population history. However, by combining this information with genomic data from ancient remains, one can now directly access our evolutionary past and reveal our population history in much greater detail. This Review outlines the major recent achievements in the study of ancient DNA, and illustrates how the field has recently moved from the amplification of short mitochondrial fragments by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to whole-genome sequencing, thus revisiting our own history. Ancient DNA research has revealed the routes our ancestors took to colonize the planet, with whom they interbred, how they domesticated plant and animal species, how they genetically responded to lifestyle changes, and also what pathogens decimated their populations. These approaches promise to soon resolve many pending controversies about our own origins that cannot be deciphered from modern patterns of genetic variation alone, and therefore offer an extremely powerful toolbox for a new generation of molecular anthropologists. (c) 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Ermini, L.;Sarkissian, C. D.;Willerslev, E.;Orlando, L.

title: Viral communities between sympatric vampire bats and bovines
abstract: Vampire bats are the only mammals known to feed exclusively on the blood of other animals, often domestic cattle. We tested the hypothesis that vampire bat adaptation to hematophagy would have resulted in shared viral communities between vampire bats and cattle as a direct consequence of historical spillover events that have occurred due to hematophagy. We analyzed the presence of different viruses in sample populations from sympatric bat and prey populations and looked for common viruses between taxa. A limited number of viral DNA groups have been identified within each species. However, there was no evidence of a common viral community between the vampire bat and bovine populations tested.
authors: Escalera-Zamudio, M.;Taboada, B.;Rojas-Anaya, E.;LÃ¶ber, U.;Loza-Rubio, E.;Arias, C. F.;Greenwood, A. D.

title: Large deletions in the 5' untranslated region of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype C
abstract: Nucleotide sequences of the 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR) at the 3' side of the poly C tract were compared for 21 isolates of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) serotype C from Europe, South America and the Philippines . A deletion of 43 nucleotides is present in the European isolates compared to most American isolates. A larger deletion of 86 nucleotides is present in some viruses from South America and the Philippines. These deletions include the loss of one or two pseudoknot structures predicted in this region of the 5' UTR. In addition, multiple point mutations have allowed the derivation of a phylogenetic tree that defines a grouping of isolates very similar to that derived from the capsid gene sequences of the same viruses. The study provides evidence that deletion (or addition) events must occur very frequently during the evolution of FMD type C, since viruses that are phylogenetically very closely related (they belong to the same tree branch) evolve in the presence or absence of them distinguish deletions. Implications for the development of FMDV are discussed.
authors: Escarmis, C.;Dopazo, J.;Davila, M.;Palma, E. L.;Domingo, E.

title: Effects of antigenic and genetic drift on serological surveillance of H5N2 avian influenza viruses
abstract: Serological surveillance of avian influenza (AI) viruses is performed by the haemagglutination inhibition (HI) test using reference reagents. This method is recommended by animal health organizations as a standard test to detect antigenic differences (subtypes) between circulating influenza viruses, vaccine and/or reference strains. However, significant discrepancies between reference antisera and field isolates have been observed in serosurveillance of influenza A virus in pig and poultry farms. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of influenza virus genetic and antigenic drift on serological tests using standard HI assays and reference reagents. Low pathogenic AI-H5N2 viruses isolated in Mexico between 1994 and 2008 were used for phylogenetic analysis of AI hemagglutinin genes and for serological tests using antisera prepared with year-specific AI virus isolates. Phylogenetic analysis revealed significant divergence between early LPAI-H5N2 viruses (1994–1998) and more recent virus field isolates (2002–2008). The results of the HI test were significantly affected by the selection of the AI H5N2 virus (year of isolation) used as the reference antigen for the assay. These analyzes indicate that LPAI-H5N2 viruses are subject to ongoing genetic drift in Mexico and that serosurveillance of AI viruses is significantly affected by the antigen or antiserum used for HI testing. Viral reference antigens and/or antisera need to be constantly replaced during AI virus surveillance to keep up with AI antigen drift. This strategy aims to improve the estimation of antigenic differences between circulating AI viruses and the selection of appropriate vaccine strains.
authors: Escorcia, M.;Carrillo-SÃ¡nchez, K.;March-Mifsut, S.;Chapa, J.;Lucio, E.;Nava, G. M.

title: Identification of the novel Newcastle disease virus subgenotype VII-(j) based on the fusion protein
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is the cause of fatal poultry diseases worldwide. The fusion protein (F) plays a key role in viral pathogenesis and is also used for the classification of Newcastle disease virus. In this study, we determined the full coding sequence of the F gene in new velogenic NDV isolates with an intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) of 1.8 and a mean time of death (MDT) of 72 or 48 h. Complete sequences of the F genes of new Iranian isolates were amplified and sequenced in both directions. These isolates were compared with 195 nucleotide sequences from GenBank (available from July 17, 2016). A pedigree was constructed for the F gene using MEGA6 software with statistical analysis based on 500 bootstrap replicates. Evolutionary distances showed that the new virulent isolates from Iran belonged to genotype VII in a new, distinct subgenotype called VII-(j). This new subgenotype showed 3% deviation from genotype VIId. Recombination analysis showed that these new isolates were not recombinant NDVs.
authors: Esmaelizad, M.;Mayahi, V.;Pashaei, M.;Goudarzi, H.

title: Equination (Inoculation of Horsepox): An Early Alternative to Vaccination (Inoculation of Cowpox) and the Possible Role of the Horsepox Virus in the Origin of the Smallpox Vaccine Review
abstract: For nearly 150 years after Edward Jenner published The Inquiry in 1798, the cowpox virus was widely believed to be the vaccine against smallpox. It was not until 1939 that vaccinia, the smallpox vaccine virus, was shown to be serologically related but distinct from the cowpox virus. In the absence of a known natural host, vaccinia has been considered a laboratory virus, possibly derived from mutational or recombination events with vaccinia virus, variolaviruses, or some unknown ancestral orthopoxviruses. A preferred candidate for a vaccinia ancestor was the horsepox virus. Edward Jenner himself hypothesized that cowpox descended from horsepox, and he also believed that "matter" derived from both diseases could be used to prevent smallpox. During the 19th century in Europe, cowpox vaccination (vaccination) was used together with horsepox vaccination (equination) to prevent smallpox. Vaccine manufacturing practices during the 19th century may have led to the use of mixtures of viruses, resulting in various genetic modifications that have led to the vaccinia strains of today. Horsepox, a disease previously only reported in Europe, has been absent from that continent since the early 20th century and now appears to be extinct, although the virus may still be circulating in an unknown reservoir. Genomic sequencing of a horsepox virus isolated in Mongolia in 1976 showed that this horsepox virus, although closely related to vaccinia, contained additional, possibly ancestral, sequences absent in vaccinia. Recent genetic analyzes of existing vaccinia viruses have revealed that some strains contain ancestral horsepox virus genes or are phylogenetically related to the horsepox virus. We recently reported that a commercially manufactured smallpox vaccine, made in the United States in 1902, is genetically very similar to the horsepox virus, providing a missing link in this 200-year-old puzzle.
authors: Esparza, J.;Schrick, L.;Damaso, C. R.;Nitsche, A.

title: Orthopoxvirus DNA: strain differentiation by electrophoresis of restriction endonuclease-fragmented virion DNA
abstract: Methods have been developed to purify intact intracytoplasmic poxvirus particles from infected cells and to isolate DNA from virions by equilibrium centrifugation in sodium diatrizoate density gradients. The buoyant density of twelve closely related orthopoxviruses purified in these gradients was determined to be 1.25 g/ml and that of the isolated virion DNAs to be 1.1 g/ml. Virion DNA from each of the 12 selected prototype and wild-type viruses was digested with three separate site-specific restriction endonucleases, Hind III, Sal I and Bam HI, and the fragments (molecular weights 0.5 x 10 6 to 20 x 10 6 ) were analyzed by agarose gel electrophoresis separated. Characteristic DNA fragment migration patterns observed in the gels enabled the viruses to be classified. By comparing profiles of HindIII digested DNAs, we were able to group the viruses into 4 species: cowpox, vaccinia, monkeypox (2 isolates) and variola (8 isolates). Viruses of a variola major infection could be distinguished from viruses of a variola minor infection. Isolates within species (strains) were also distinguished, primarily by comparing the gel electrophoresis profiles of SalI-digested DNA from the viruses.
authors: Esposito, J. J.;Obijeski, J. F.;Nakano, J. H.

title: Zoonotic poxviruses
abstract: Smallpoxviruses threaten a group of long-known important pathogens, including some zoonotic members, affecting livestock and humans. While analysis of the entire genome sequence began to shed light on the molecular mechanisms underlying host cell infection, viral replication, and virulence, our understanding of the maintenance of smallpoxviruses in nature and their transmission to humans is still poor. Over the last two decades, reports of emerging human monkeypox outbreaks in Africa and North America, the increasing number of cowpox virus infections in cats, exotic animals and humans, and cases of vaccinia virus infections in humans in South America and India have reminded us - the eradicated smallpox virus aside - there are nor other smallpox viruses that can harm men. We are beginning to learn that the host range of some smallpoxviruses is much broader than first thought, and that rodents appear to be the main virus reservoirs. The following overview is intended to provide an up-to-date overview of the epidemiology of zoonotic smallpoxviruses, with a focus on orthopoxviruses. By outlining the current state of knowledge about smallpoxvirus transmission, we hope to raise awareness of how infections are acquired and how to properly diagnose them. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Essbauer, S.;Pfeffer, M.;Meyer, H.

title: Antigenic and genetic relationships between European highly virulent infectious bursal disease viruses and an early West African isolate
abstract: The antigenic and genetic relationships between very virulent (vv) infectious bursal disease viruses (IBDV) from different countries were investigated. Antigenic characterization was performed using an antigen capture ELISA based on a panel of seven neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (Mabs) that probe at least three VP2-located antigenic domains. All of these domains are reactive in the reference strain Faragher 52/70 (F52/70) for the European classic serotype 1 IBDV. Genomic characterization was achieved by reverse transcription, amplification and direct sequencing of a genomic fragment encoding the VP2 variable domain. Eleven vv isolates from France were compared to the British, Dutch and Belgian UK661, DV86 and 849VB viruses and to an early vv isolate obtained in 1988 from Ivory Coast. All viruses displayed antigenic profiles characterized by no binding of Mabs 3 and 4. The lack of binding of Mabs 3 and 4 could therefore be helpful in distinguishing between classic and vvIBDVs. None of the non-French strains resembled French isolates 91168 and 94432, which do not bind Mabs 6, 7 or 8. Genetic analysis revealed a close relationship between all European viruses, differing from each other by no more than 12 nucleotides and 3 amino acids. The African isolate differed significantly from all European viruses, including the F52/70 virus, by at least 22 nucleotides and six amino acids. Phylogenetic analyzes based on the neighbor joining and parsimony methods suggest that the African virus may belong to a genetically distinct lineage of highly pathogenic IBDVs.
authors: Eterradossi, N.;Arnauld, C.;Tekaia, F.;Toquin, D.;Le Coq, H.;Rivallan, G.;Guittet, M.;Domenech, J.;van den Berg, T. P.;Skinner, M. A.

title: Tracing the origin and co-phylogeny of the caliciviruses
abstract: Caliciviruses infect a wide range of mammalian hosts and include the genus Norovirus, the leading cause of foodborne viral gastroenteritis in humans. Using publicly available sequence data and phylogenetic analysis tools, the origins and virus-host co-phylogeny of these viruses have been studied. Evidence is presented here in support of host switching by caliciviruses, but showing that zoonotic transmission does not appear to have occurred in the history of these viruses. The age or demographics of the caliciviruses cannot yet be estimated with any degree of support, but further study of this family as new dated sequences become available could provide key information of relevance to human health and to understanding the origin of foodborne viruses deliver disease.
authors: Etherington, G. J.;Ring, S. M.;Charleston, M. A.;Dicks, J.;Rayward-Smith, V. J.;Roberts, I. N.

title: Antigenic characterization of inclusion body hepatitis virus
abstract: Evidence that chicken inclusion body hepatitis (IBHC) is caused by a virus (IBHV) was provided in 1973. Characterization of IBHV was performed using standard virus classification criteria. The results showed that IBHV is a member of the avian adenovirus group. However, no antigenic relationship was found between IBHV and two other avian adenovirus isolates (CELO and Indiana C) as observed by hemagglutination (HA) and virus-serum neutralization tests. Another adenovirus isolate proved to be serologically distinct from IBHV (Tipton strain) but elicited typical IBHV. This antigen was able to elicit a specific precipitation reaction with sera from chickens previously exposed to IBHV. Repeated embryo passage of IBHV reduced its pathogenicity to susceptible chickens. Protection of chickens against IBHV challenge was achieved by vaccination with high embryo passage IBHV (Tipton strain). It was also found that the subcutaneous administration of the vaccine virus induced a better immune response than the eye drop route, as observed by the virus-serum neutralization index obtained.
authors: Fadly, A. M.;Winterfield, R. W.

title: Reemergence of Peste des Petits Ruminants Virus in 2015 in Morocco: Molecular Characterization and Experimental Infection in Alpine Goats
abstract: Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR) is a transboundary viral disease of small ruminants causing enormous economic losses in Africa, the Middle East and Asia. In Morocco, the first PPR outbreak was reported in 2008.
