Since then, no cases have been reported for seven years, likely due to three consecutive vaccination campaigns between 2008 and 2011 and close surveillance of border areas. In June 2015, the disease resurfaced in Morocco, raising questions about the origin of the virus. The PPR virus was confirmed by qRT-PCR and the virus was isolated from clinical specimens on VeroNectin-4 cells. The disease has been experimentally reproduced in Alpine goats using both ovine and caprine outbreak isolates. Molecular characterization of the 2015 Moroccan PPR isolate confirmed the identity of the virus as lineage IV, closely related to the 2012 isolates from Algeria (KP793696) and 2012 from Tunisia (KM068121), and distinct from the previous PPRV Morocco strain from 2008 (HQ131927). Therefore, this study confirms a new PPR virus outbreak in Morocco in 2015 and underlines the urgency of implementing a joint control strategy to combat PPR in the Maghreb region of North Africa.
authors: Fakri, F.;Embarki, T.;Parida, S.;Bamouh, Z.;Jazouli, M.;Mahapatra, M.;Tadlaoui, K.;Fassi-Fihri, O.;Richardson, C. D.;Elharrak, M.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of bovine viral diarrheal virus in Italy
abstract: The genetic properties of 38 field isolates of bovine viral diarrheal virus (BVDV) collected in 1999 from diseased or healthy and persistently infected cattle from dairy farms in northern Italy were investigated. A partial 5" untranslated region (5" UTR) sequence of each isolate was determined and phylogenetic analysis performed. All isolates were assigned to the BVDV-1 genotype and could be assigned to different BVDV-1 groups, namely BVDV-1b (n=20), BVDV-1d (n=6) and BVDV-1e (n=10). ). Two remaining isolates could be classified as BVDV-1f and BVDV-1h, respectively. These results provide evidence for the genetic heterogeneity of BVDV in Italy and contribute to a better knowledge of the distribution of BVDV strains and their classification.
authors: Falcone, E.;Cordioli, P.;Tarantino, M.;Muscillo, M.;La Rosa, G.;Tollis, M.

title: Incidence of bovine viral diarrhea virus detected in peripheral blood mononuclear cell subpopulations in persistently infected animals and health outcomes
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) cause acute and persistent infections. Acute infection results in generalized immunosuppression characterized by a decrease in circulating lymphocytes as a result of depletion of CD4+ and CD8+ T cell populations. Persistent infection with BVDV is the result of immune tolerance and is not generally associated with lymphocytopenia. The health outcome of persistently infected (PI) calves varies widely; some die from mucosal disease, some succumb to thrift, and others appear normal and survive into adulthood. Detection of BVDV at the single lymphoid cell level is important for studying subpopulations of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) during BVDV infections, however, few methods are available to detect and quantify BVDV at this level. To circumvent this difficulty, a novel flow cytometry-based PrimeFlow RNA assay with in situ detection of BVDV was developed. This assay was used to assess differences in viral distribution within subpopulations of PBMC over time in PI calves carrying either of two different types of BVDV (type 1 and type 2). The calves were sampled at 3 different times approximately one month apart. During the course of the study, a subset of calves died from thrift. No mucosal disease was reported in any of the deaths. Using RNA probes specific to the BVDV N<sup>-E<sup>-E<sup>rns</sup> coding regions for the respective virus, BVDV RNA was isolated in all PBMC from PI detected who appeared clinically healthy. It was found that calves that succumbed to thrift had little or no virus in T cells. Clearance of the virus from T cells suggests a breakdown in immune tolerance in these calves. This is the first report of a pattern observed in viral load in the T cell subpopulations and survival in PI calves.
authors: Falkenberg, S. M.;Dassanayake, R. P.;Walz, P.;Casas, E.;Neill, J. D.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of pseudorabies virus variants isolated from southern China's Guangdong Province between 2013 and 2014
abstract: Pseudorabies (PR) outbreaks have occurred in southern China since late 2011, resulting in significant economic impacts on the swine industry. To identify the cause of PR outbreaks, particularly in vaccinated pigs, 11 field strains of pseudorabies virus (PRV) were isolated in Guangdong province between 2013 and 2014. Their major viral genes (gE, TK, gI, PK, gD, 11K, and 28K) were analyzed in this study. Insertions or deletions were observed in gD, gE, gI and PK genes compared to other PRV isolates from around the world. In addition, sequence alignment revealed that insertions in gD and gE were unique molecular features of the new predominant PRV strains in China. The phylogenetic analysis showed that our isolates were clustered in an independent branch together with other strains isolated from China in recent years and that they showed a closer genetic relationship to earlier isolates from Asia. Our results suggest that these isolates are novel PRV variants with unique molecular signatures.
authors: Fan, J.;Zeng, X.;Zhang, G.;Wu, Q.;Niu, J.;Sun, B.;Xie, Q.;Ma, J.

title: Identification and characterization of a porcine kobuvirus variant isolated from suckling piglets in Gansu Province, China
authors: Fan, S.;Sun, H.;Ying, Y.;Gao, X.;Wang, Z.;Yu, Y.;Li, Y.

title: Analysis of Egg-Adapted Mutations in Influenza A H1N1pdm09 Viruses in Hubei Province of China, 2013-2014
abstract: influenza A H1N1pdm09 virus; chicken embryo; Pedigree; egg adaptation; antigens site; Drug Resistance Website; Abstract: To investigate egg-adapted mutations in influenza A H1N1pdm09 viruses isolated from the Hubei influenza surveillance network, a comparative analysis of three influenza A H1N1pdm09 viruses isolated in chick embryos and the corresponding viruses derived from MDCK cells. Analyzes included examination of phylogenetic tree, evolution rates, amino acid substitutions, egg-adapted mutation and homology modelling. We found differences between the egg-adapted viruses and the MDCK cell-derived viruses based on phylogenetic trees and evolutionary rates; the viruses showed a trend of "NA>HA>MP". Four amino acid substitutions (Q223R, V527I, M19I and H275Y) were found in three egg-adapted viruses. Q223 border V527I were present in hemagglutinin protein while M19I and H275Y were detected in neuraminidase. The Q223R mutation altered the structure of the antigenic sites between Sb and Ca2. H275Y is a classic neuraminidase resistance mutation. The results suggest that the egg-adapted mutations were introduced when influenza viruses were isolated in chick embryos from the Hubei influenza surveillance network. These mutations can affect vaccine candidate selection and vaccine efficacy; Therefore, surveillance of egg-adapted mutations in the influenza surveillance network should be strengthened.
authors: Fang, B.;Liu, L.;Ye, G.;Li, X.;Yu, X.;Jiang, Y.

title: Influenza A virus neuraminidase: Regions of the protein potentially involved in virus-host interactions
abstract: Phylogenetically informative amino acid positions (PIPs) have been identified in influenza A neuraminidases of subtypes N1 and N2. Neuraminidase evolves lineage-specifically when the virus adapts to a new host or changes to evade the host's immune system. Therefore, many PIPs undoubtedly identify positions involved in virus-host interactions. Phylogenetically important regions (PIRs) are defined as multiple PIPs close together. There are 15 PIRs on N1 and 12 on N2, seven of which are shared by the two subtypes. Many PIRs coincide with antigenic or glycosylation sites. Other PIRs may represent additional antigenic sites or may be involved in other aspects of virus-host biology.
authors: Fanning, T. G.;Reid, A. H.;Taubenberger, J. K.

title: Selection of vaccine strains of foot-and-mouth disease virus for use in southern Africa
abstract: In the countries of southern Africa, the types SAT 1, SAT 2 and SAT 3 (SAT: Southern African Territories) of the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus are most widespread, especially the virus SAT 2. Since 1982, studies have been carried out on 139 isolates of these virus types. In the north of this area, other viruses of type O and A were detected. Viral typing and subtyping with the complement fixation (CF) test can be improved through the use of panels of monoclonal antibodies (MAbs), which provide an accurate antigenic profile of a new strain. A total of 33 SAT 2 strains were tested with MAbs and the results allow the viruses to be classified into groups with the same profile. The author presents comparisons of isolates and vaccine viruses using conventional methods of serotyping - CF and virus neutralization (VN) tests - and profiling of the isolates using MAbs. Both types of analysis provide information about the relationships between the viruses. The CF and VN tests provide details of how animals responded to a particular isolate and how that antibody response would recognize a different isolate; from this, the serological relationships can be proposed in terms of how different isolates might induce a humoral immune response. With MAb profiling, details of the antigenic relationships between isolates are obtained, allowing for the identification of individual epitope variations. These analyzes can offer the possibility of classifying different isolates into "antigenic" groups. When comparing to vaccine viruses, one can try to identify the vaccine virus with the most similar profile to the isolate group. Immunological analysis (e.g. using the CF tests used in this document) can provide further information on the relationship between a given vaccine and an antigenic group identified by MAb profiling. Of course, this MAb profiling can provide essential information in a very short time, which is particularly beneficial in an emergency situation. The conclusions from the profiling would then be confirmed by the serological analyses. Such combined analyzes provide a more comprehensive identification of antigenic and immunogenic relationships between FMD virus isolates and between isolates and vaccine viruses.
authors: Fargeaud, D.

title: Intra-epidemic genome variation in highly pathogenic African swine fever virus (ASFV) from the country of Georgia
abstract: BACKGROUND: African swine fever virus (ASFV) causes acute hemorrhagic infection in pigs with a mortality rate of up to 100%. No vaccine is available and the potential for catastrophic diseases in Europe remains elevated due to the ongoing ASF epidemic in Russia and the Baltic countries. To date, no whole genome intraepidemic variation has been reported for ASFV. To provide a more comprehensive basis for genetic variation at the onset of the ASF outbreak, we sequenced two Georgian ASFV samples, G-2008/1 and G-2008/2, derived from domestic pig blood collected in 2008. METHODS: Genomic DNA was extracted directly from low-volume ASFV-PCR-positive porcine blood samples and subjected to next-generation sequencing on the Illumina Miseq platform. De novo and mapped sequence assemblies were performed using CLCBio software. Genomic illustrations, sequence alignments and assembler mappings were generated with Geneious v10.2.4. The sequence repeat architecture was analyzed with DNASTAR GeneQuest 14.1.0. RESULTS: The G-2008/1 and G-2008/2 genomes were distinguished from each other by coding changes in seven additional genes including MGF 110-1L, X69R, MGF 505-10R, EP364R, H233R, E199L and MGF 360 -21R to eight homopolymer tract variations. Genome 2008/2 possessed a new allelic state at a previously undescribed intergenic repeat locus between genes C315R and C147L. The C315R/C147L locus represents the earliest observed variable repeat sequence polymorphism reported in isolates of this epidemic. No sequence variation was observed in conventional ASFV subtyping markers. The two genomes showed complete collinearity and identical gene content to the Georgia 2007/1 reference genome. Approximately 56 unique homopolymeric A/T tract variations were identified that were unique to the Georgia 2007/1 genome. In both 2008 genomes, heterogeneity in reading sequences within the sample was evident at six homopolymeric G/C stretches restricted to the known ~7 kb hypervariable region in the left terminal region of the genome. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first intra-epidemic comparative genomic analysis reported for ASFV and provides insight into the intra-epidemic microevolution of ASFV. The genomes reported here, in addition to the G-2007/1 genome, provide an early basis for future genome-level comparisons and epidemiological tracing efforts.
authors: Farlow, J.;Donduashvili, M.;Kokhreidze, M.;Kotorashvili, A.;Vepkhvadze, N. G.;Kotaria, N.;Gulbani, A.

title: Detection of foreign substances in vaccines - an overview of technical aspects
abstract: The quality and safety of commercial vaccines are of fundamental importance. Despite all precautions and efforts, the use of biological material in vaccine development and manufacture can lead to possible contamination of vaccines with known and unknown foreign substances (EAs), potential active substances that need to be tested in vaccine manufacture. Nevertheless, the detection of known and unknown contaminants in vaccines is a common obligation for manufacturers and authorities in both the veterinary and human fields, who have similar requirements for specific technical approaches. State-of-the-art molecular methods such as randomly primed PCR in combination with massive parallel sequencing (MPS) or microarrays can open up new perspectives in foreign substance testing. The robustness and effectiveness of this technical approach to vaccine control was demonstrated in a human vaccine example when porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) contamination was revealed in Rotarix, a human rotavirus vaccine. The consequences and implications are hereby reviewed from a veterinary point of view. Â© 2012 The International Alliance for Biological Standardization.
authors: Farsang, A.;KulcsÃ¡r, G.

title: Xenosurveillance reflects traditional sampling techniques for identifying human pathogens: A comparative study in West Africa
abstract: Background New surveillance strategies are needed to detect the rapid and continuous emergence of infectious disease agents. Ideally, new sampling strategies should be easy to implement, technologically straightforward, and applicable to areas where flood events are known to occur. To this end, xenosurveillance is a technique that uses blood collected from hematophagous arthropods to monitor and identify vertebrate pathogens. Mosquitoes are largely ubiquitous animals, often found in sizeable populations. Additionally, many native or peridomestic mosquito species preferentially ingest blood meals from humans, making them a unique and largely untapped reservoir for collecting human blood. Methodology/Main results We attempted to exploit this phenomenon by systematically collecting blood-fed mosquitoes during a field trial in northern Liberia to determine whether pathogen sequences from blood-fed mosquitoes accurately reflect those obtained directly from humans. In particular, blood has been collected from humans by finger pricks and by aspiration of blood-feeding mosquitoes from inside houses. Shotgun metagenomic sequencing of RNA and DNA derived from these samples was performed to detect pathogen sequences. Samples obtained from stranger surveillance and fingerstick blood collection yielded a similar number and quality of reads that align with two human viruses, GB virus C and hepatitis B virus. Conclusions/Significance This study represents the first systematic comparison between xenosurveillance and more traditional sampling methods, while demonstrating the viability of xenosurveillance as a tool to sample human blood for circulating pathogens.
authors: Fauver, J. R.;Weger-Lucarelli, J.;Fakoli, L. S.;Bolay, K.;Bolay, F. K.;Diclaro, J. W.;Brackney, D. E.;Foy, B. D.;Stenglein, M. D.;Ebel, G. D.

title: Duck gut viral metagenomic analysis captures a snapshot of viral diversity
abstract: BACKGROUND: Ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) are economically important waterfowl for meat, eggs, and feathers; is also a natural reservoir for influenza A viruses. The emergence of new viruses is attributed to the status of coexistence of multiple types and subtypes of viruses in the reservoir hosts. For effective prediction of future viral epidemics or pandemics, an in-depth understanding of virome status in key reservoir species is critical. METHODS: To obtain an unbiased measure of viral diversity in the intestinal tract of ducks by a viral metagenomic approach, we deeply sequenced the viral nucleic acid extracted from cloacal swabs collected from the flock of 23 ducks sharing the waters with wild ones migratory birds shared. RESULT: A total of 7,455,180 reads with an average length of 146 bases were generated, of which 7,354,300 reads were de novo assembled into 24,945 contigs with an average length of 220 bases and the remaining 100,880 reads were singletons. The duck vioma was identified by sequence similarity comparisons of contigs and singletons (BLASTx E-Score, <10(-3)) to a viral reference database. Numerous duck vioma sequences were homologous to the animal virus of the Papillomaviridae family; and phages from the families Caudovirales, Inoviridae, Tectiviridae, Microviridae and unclassified phages. In addition, several duck virome sequences were homologous with the insect viruses of the families Poxviridae, Alphatetraviridae, Baculoviridae, Densovirinae, Iflaviridae and Dicistroviridae; and plant viruses of the families Secoviridae, Virgaviridae, Tombusviridae, and Partitiviridae, reflecting the diet and colonization of ducks. CONCLUSION: This study advances our understanding of viral diversity and advances knowledge of the spectrum of viruses found in the duck intestinal tract.
authors: Fawaz, M.;Vijayakumar, P.;Mishra, A.;Gandhale, P. N.;Dutta, R.;Kamble, N. M.;Sudhakar, S. B.;Roychoudhary, P.;Kumar, H.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Raut, A. A.

title: Inactivation of viruses from different taxonomic groups by copper sulfate
abstract: Study results on the inactivated effects of copper sulfate on viruses from different taxonomy groups are summarized in the work. Copper sulfate is a simple and reliable means of inactivating viruses of classical swine fever, Aujeszky's disease and infectious bovine rhinotracheitis. Its inactivation effect is based on the ability to reduce the viral genome to low molecular weight fragments. In addition to the inactivation of the virus material, a decrease in the protective antibody determinants is observed when copper sulfate is used in sheep catarrh fever.
authors: Fedorov, D. G.;Balysheva, V. I.;Zhesterev, V. I.;Tsybanov, S. Z.;Zakutskii, N. I.;Slivko, V. V.

title: Role of the mosquitoes Culex pipienis f. Pipiens and Cx. Pipiens f. molestus (Diptera, Culicidae) during the spread of West Nile virus in southern Russia
abstract: Cx. Pipiens is one of the main vectors of West Nile virus in southern Russia and is represented by the autogenous form, molestus, and the non-autogenous form, pipiens. The spatial distribution of its larvae and the food preferences of the females were studied to estimate the potential role of each form in the spread of the virus. The taxonomic status of the mosquitoes was determined based on their ability to be autogenic (543 specimens) and the type of mitochondrial DNA (348 specimens). The Pipiens form mosquitoes were shown to develop in the open urban and rural reservoirs and the females were non-autogenous. Cx. pipiens form molestus was only found in urban biotopes, mainly in flooded basements and in some years also in open reservoirs, where it formed a mixed population with Cx. Pipiens form pipiens. Both autogenous (85-95.2%) and non-autogenous specimens have been identified among females with the molestus mitotype. Genetic analysis of Cx. Pipiens females collected under the Berezantsev bell and in the trap with a bird showed that both forms were attracted to humans and birds. The results suggest that Cx. Pipiens form Pipiens can transmit West Nile Virus to humans both in urban and suburban areas and in Cx. Pipiens can form Molestus only in urban areas.
authors: Fedorova, M. V.;ShaÄ­kevich, E. V.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of human gyroviruses identified in ferret fecal virome
abstract: The recently described novel gyroviruses can infect chickens and/or humans; however, their pathogenic potential is unknown. In our metagenomic study, we detected many of the novel gyroviruses in ferret faecal viromas with enlarged lymph nodes and organs. The complete genomic sequences of selected gyrovirus strains showed 90.7-99.4% similarity to homologous reference gyrovirus strains. This study showed no association between ferret gyrovirus shedding and observed background disease; however, it provides evidence for genetic diversity among gyroviruses and raises the possibility that pet ferrets spread gyroviruses to heterologous hosts, e.g. B. people can transmit.
authors: FehÃ©r, E.;PazÃ¡r, P.;KovÃ¡cs, E.;Farkas, S. L.;Lengyel, G.;Jakab, F.;Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Genomic consequence analysis of characteristic Italian virus is infectious Bursitis
abstract: In a recent study, an emerging infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) genotype (ITA) was detected in live IBDV vaccinated broilers without clinical signs of infectious bursal disease (IBD). VP2 sequence analysis showed that strains of the ITA genotype clustered separately from vaccine strains and other IBDV reference strains, either classical or very virulent. In order to obtain a more comprehensive molecular characterization of the IBDV ITA genotype and to speculate on its origin, genome sequencing of the previously assigned ITA genotype field isolate IBDV/Italy/1829/2011 was performed and the obtained sequences compared to the currently available corresponding sequences . In addition, phylogenetic and recombination analyzes were performed. Interestingly, multiple amino acid (AA) sequence alignments revealed that the IBDV/Italy/1829/2011 strain shared several AA residues with highly virulent IBDV strains as well as some virulence markers, particularly in the VP1 protein. Nevertheless, sequence analysis revealed the presence of several residues typical of IBDV strains at a low level of virulence in the IBDV/Italy/1829/2011 strain. Although homologous recombination and reassortant phenomena can occur naturally between different IBDV strains, no evidence of these events was found in the genome of the IBDV/Ita/1829/2011 strain, which was confirmed to have the genetically characteristic IBDV genotype.
authors: Felice, V.;Franzo, G.;Catelli, E.;Di Francesco, A.;Bonci, M.;Cecchinato, M.;Mescolini, G.;Giovanardi, D.;Pesente, P.;Lupini, C.

title: First evaluation of classical swine fever marker vaccine candidate CP7_E2alf for oral immunization of wild boar under field conditions
abstract: Oral vaccination against classical swine fever (CSF) is an effective tool to control disease outbreaks in wild boar. So far, vaccination campaigns have been carried out with live attenuated vaccines that do not allow any serological differentiation between infected and vaccinated animals (DIVA). Although this disadvantage is acceptable for wild boar, the use of marker vaccines would facilitate disease and vaccination dynamic studies. Recently, the CSF marker vaccine candidate CP7_E2alf was evaluated for oral immunization under laboratory conditions. Promising results led to efforts to study the vaccine candidate under field conditions and in bait formulation. In this context, two oral vaccination campaigns using CP7_E2alf decoy vaccines were carried out in two areas designated as “faunistic hunting farms” in the Umbria region, Italy. One campaign was carried out with single vaccination, the second with the routinely used double vaccination strategy. Both campaigns were carried out before concerted hunting actions were undertaken. Bait intake, vaccine virus detection and antibody responses were assessed along with post-evisceration inspections. As a comparison, seven wild boar were hand-fed with bait under laboratory conditions. In the field, bait uptake ranged from 63.7% to 98.7%, while antibody prevalence reached only 33.3–35.1%. The marker serology showed a strong influence of the sample quality on the test result, altogether 85% of the samples were correctly classified. Vaccination virus was not detectable. Under hand-feeding conditions, six out of seven wild boar ingested at least one bait, and five of them had detectable levels of antibodies seven weeks after vaccination. These results were supplemented by stability tests. Adequate stability of the vaccine virus has been demonstrated under both field and laboratory conditions. Overall, most of the results were in line with our expectations. However, attempts must be made in the future to optimize the DIVA assay. © 2014.
authors: Feliziani, F.;Blome, S.;Petrini, S.;Giammarioli, M.;Iscaro, C.;Severi, G.;Convito, L.;Pietschmann, J.;Beer, M.;De Mia, G. M.

title: Co-localization of and interaction between duck enteritis virus glycoproteins H and L
abstract: Background: Duck enteritis virus (DEV), which belongs to the α-herpesvirus subfamily, is a linear double-stranded DNA virus. Glycoprotein H and L (gH and gL) encoded by UL22 and UL1 are conserved in the herpesvirus family. They play an important role as gH/gL dimers during viral entry into host cells through cell-cell fusion. The interaction between gH and gL has been confirmed in several human herpesviruses such as herpes simplex virus (HSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and human cytomegalovirus (HCMV). In this paper, we investigated the interaction between DEV gH and gL. Results: The recombinant plasmids pEGFP-N-gH and pDsRED-N-gL were successfully constructed. Expressions of both DEV gH and gL were observed after 12 h incubation of COS-7 cells transfected with pEGFP-N-gH and pDsRED-N-gL plasmids, respectively. Also the colocalization of part of gH and gL was detected in the cytoplasm of COS-7 cells after cotransfection for 24 h. Then the recombinant plasmids pCMV-Flag-gL and pCMV-Myc-gH were constructed and co-transfected into COS-7 cells. Both gH and gL have been shown to be tested by co-immunoprecipitation and Western blotting with positive results. Conclusions: Our results showed not only the co-localization of DEV gH and gL in COS-7 cells, but also the interaction between them. It will provide insight for further studies related to protein-protein interaction in DEV.
authors: Feng, D.;Cui, M.;Jia, R.;Liu, S.;Wang, M.;Zhu, D.;Chen, S.;Liu, M.;Zhao, X.;Wu, Y.;Yang, Q.;Yin, Z.;Cheng, A.

title: Analysis of S1 gene of avian infectious bronchitis virus isolated in southern China in 2011-2012
abstract: In 2011-2012, 62 strains of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were isolated from diseased chickens on different farms in southern China, and 66.1% of the isolated strains were associated with typical nephritis. Analysis of the S1 gene sequences amplified from the 62 isolated strains along with 40 reference strains published in Genbank revealed nucleotide homologies ranging from 63.5 to 99.9% and amino acid homologies ranging from 57.9 to 100%. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that all Chinese IBV strains were classified into six distinct genetic groups (I-VI). Most of the isolated strains belonged to group I and the isolation of group V strains was increased compared to a previous monitoring period. The vaccine strains currently used in China (H120, H52, W93, and Ma5) formed the Mass group, which is evolutionarily distant from Chinese isolates. Alignment of the S1 amino acid sequences revealed polymorphic and diverse substitutions, insertions and deletions, and the S1 protein of the major pandemic strains contained 540 amino acids with a cleavage site sequence of HRRRR or RRF(L/S)RR. Further analysis showed that recombination events formed a new subset. Taken together, these results suggest that different IBV variants co-circulated and underwent genetic evolution in southern China during the observation period. Therefore, long-term continuous surveillance is of great importance for the prevention and control of IBV infection. © 2014 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Feng, K.;Xue, Y.;Wang, F.;Chen, F.;Shu, D.;Xie, Q.

title: Induction and suppression of innate antiviral responses by picornaviruses
abstract: The Picornaviridae family consists of small, non-enveloped, positive-strand RNA viruses and contains many human and animal pathogens, including enteroviruses (eg, poliovirus, coxsackievirus, enterovirus 71, and rhinovirus), cardioviruses (eg, encephalomyocarditis virus), hepatitis A virus and foot and mouth disease virus. Picornavirus infections activate a cytosolic RNA sensor, MDA5, which in turn induces a type I interferon response, a critical component of antiviral immunity. In addition, picornaviruses activate the formation of stress granules (SGs), large aggregates of ready-made mRNPs (messenger ribonucleoprotein particles) to temporarily store these molecules during cellular stress. Meanwhile, picornaviruses actively suppress these antiviral responses to ensure efficient replication. In this review, we provide an overview of the induction and suppression of the MDA5-mediated IFN-α/β response and the cellular stress pathway by picornaviruses.
authors: Feng, Q.;Langereis, M. A.;van Kuppeveld, F. J. M.

title: The contribution of a novel recombinant lineage to the coxsackievirus A6-associated hand, foot and mouth disease outbreak in Shanghai, China, 2012-2013
abstract: Since late 2012, coxsackievirus A6 (CVA6) has gradually become the predominant causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in several provinces in China. A total of 626 patients diagnosed with HFMD between January 2012 and September 2013 in Shanghai, China were enrolled in this study. Of these, 292 CVA6-infected cases were analyzed clinically. Whole genome sequencing, recombination and phylogenetic analyzes were also performed. A recombinant monophyletic CVA6 lineage was found during an outbreak of CVA6-associated HFMDs in Shanghai, China in November 2012 and accounted for 21.9% (64/292) of the CVA6 strains during the study period. Recombination analyzes indicated that the 2C gene of the novel CVA6 virus is likely derived from a community-circulating coxsackievirus A4 (CVA4) strain. Clinical observations showed that this recombinant CVA6 virus produced a more generalized skin rash than non-recombinant CVA6 virus. This newly emerged CVA6 lineage was associated with a significant proportion of HFMD cases in Shanghai in 2012-2013 and poses a potential public health threat.
authors: Feng, X.;Guan, W.;Guo, Y.;Yu, H.;Zhang, X.;Cheng, R.;Wang, Z.;Zhang, Z.;Zhang, J.;Li, H.;Zhuang, Y.;Zhang, H.;Lu, Z.;Li, M.;Yu, H.;Bao, Y.;Hu, Y.;Yao, Z.

title: Steppe rabies virus outbreaks in China
abstract: While rabies is a significant public health problem in China, the epidemiology of animal rabies in the northern and northwestern frontier provinces remains unknown. From February 2013 to March 2014, seven outbreaks of domestic animal rabies caused by wild carnivores and brain samples from infected animals by the fluorescent antibody test ( FAT) diagnosed. and RT-PCR. Ten field rabies viruses were obtained. Sequence comparison and phylogenetic analysis based on the full-length N gene (1353 bp) amplified directly from the original brain tissue showed that these ten strains were steppe-type viruses closely related to strains reported in Russia and Mongolia was reported. None had previously been identified in China. The XJ and IM viruses grouped separately into two lineages, reflecting their different geographic distribution. This study emphasizes the importance of wildlife surveillance and interdepartmental collaboration in controlling transboundary rabies transmission.
authors: Feng, Y.;Wang, W.;Guo, J.;Alatengheli;Li, Y.;Yang, G.;Su, N.;Zhang, L.;Xu, W.;Sheng, Z.;Ma, L.;Gui, J.;Dejide;Lin, H.;Tu, C.

title: Next-generation sequencing of five new avian Paramyxovirus 8 isolates from Kazakhstan indicates a low genetic evolution rate over four decades
abstract: Five avian paramyxovirus serotype 8 (APMV-8) were isolated during a wild bird surveillance study in Kazakhstan in 2013 and each was further characterized. Viruses were isolated from three white-fronted geese (Anser albifrons), one whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus) and one lesser smelt (Calidris minuta). Prior to our study, only two complete APMV-8 sequences had been described worldwide since their discovery in the US and Japan in the 1970s. We report the full genome sequences of the newly discovered viruses and analyze the genetic evolution of the APMV-8 viruses over four decades.
authors: Fereidouni, S.;Jenckel, M.;Seidalina, A.;Karamendin, K.;Beer, M.;Starick, E.;Asanova, S.;Kasymbekov, E.;Sayatov, M.;Kydyrmanov, A.

title: Pathogenesis of influenza D virus in cattle
abstract: UNLABELING: Cattle have been proposed as the natural reservoir of a new member of the Orthomyxoviridae virus family, tentatively classified as influenza D virus (IDV). Although IDV has been isolated from diseased animals, it is unclear whether IDV causes clinical disease in cattle. To address this aspect of Koch's postulates, three dairy calves (treatment animals) housed in individual pens were inoculated intranasally with the IDV strain D/bovine/Mississippi/C00046N/2014. One day after inoculation, one seronegative calf (contact animal) was added to each of the treatment animal pens. Cattle in both the treatment and contact groups seroconverted and virus was detected in their airways. Histologically, there was a significant increase in neutrophil tracking in tracheal epithelia of treated calves compared to controls. While infected animals and contact animals showed various symptoms of respiratory infection, they were mild, and calves in the treatment group did not differ from controls in terms of heart rate, respiratory rate, or rectal temperature. To mimic zoonotic transmission, two ferrets were exposed to a plastic toy carrier soaked with infected nasal discharge from the treated calves. These ferrets did not shed or seroconvert the virus. In summary, this study demonstrates that when experimentally infected in cattle, IDV causes mild respiratory disease and can be effectively transmitted between cattle by contact in the barn, but not from cattle to ferrets by carrier exposure. These results support the hypothesis that cattle are a natural reservoir for the virus. IMPORTANT: A novel influenza virus, tentatively classified as influenza D virus (IDV), has been identified in pigs, cattle, sheep and goats. Among these hosts, cattle have been suggested as a natural reservoir. In this study we show that cattle experimentally infected with IDV can shed virus and transmit it to other cattle through direct contact, but not to ferrets via routes of infection. IDV caused minor clinical symptoms in the infected cattle, fulfilling another of Koch's postulates for this new agent, although other objective clinical endpoints did not differ from those of the control animals. Although the observed disease was mild, IDV induced neutrophil tracking and epithelial attenuation in bovine trachea, which could facilitate co-infection with other pathogens and thereby predispose animals to bovine respiratory disease.
authors: Ferguson, L.;Olivier, A. K.;Genova, S.;Epperson, W. B.;Smith, D. R.;Schneider, L.;Barton, K.;McCuan, K.;Webby, R. J.;Wan, X. F.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic characterization based on the complete genome of a virulent pathotype of Newcastle disease virus isolated in Brazil in the 1970s
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is caused by avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV-1) or Newcastle disease virus (NDV), which comprises a diverse group of viruses with a negative-sense single-stranded RNA genome. ND is one of the most important chicken diseases as it severely affects poultry production worldwide. Outbreaks of virulent ND were recorded in Brazil in the 1970s and the APMV-1/Chicken/Brazil/SJM/75 (SJM) strain of NDV was isolated. This strain has been characterized as being highly pathogenic to chickens but not pathogenic to other bird species. Here we present the complete genome of the NDV strain SJM and examine the phylogenetic relationship of this virus to other NDV strains in terms of genome and protein composition, and characterization of its evolutionary process. The NDV strain SJM is categorized as a velogenous virus and the complete genome is 15,192 nucleotides long and consists of six genes in the order 3'-NP-PMF-HN-L-5'. The presence of the major pathogenic determinant of NDV strains (112R-RQK-Râ†“F117) was identified in the fusion protein of NDV strain SJM. Furthermore, the phylogenetic analysis classified the NDV strain SJM as a member of class II, genotype V, showing that this virus helps us in understanding the evolutionary process of strains belonging to this genotype. This study contributes to the growing interest in characterizing NDV isolates to improve our current understanding of the epidemiology, surveillance and evolution of the pathogenic strains. © 2014 The Authors.
authors: Fernandes, C. C.;Varani, A. M.;Lemos, E. G. M.;de Miranda, V. F. O.;Silva, K. R.;Fernando, F. S.;Montassier, M. F. S.;Montassier, H. J.

title: Molecular detection of bovine noroviruses in Argentine dairy calves: circulation of a tentative new genotype
abstract: Bovine noroviruses are enteric pathogens that are detected in fecal samples from both diarrheal and non-diarrheal calves from several countries around the world. However, epidemiological information on bovine noroviruses is still lacking for many important cattle-producing countries in South America. In this study, three bovine norovirus genogroup III sequences were determined by conventional RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing in the faeces of diarrheal dairy calves from Argentina (B4836, B4848 and B4881, all collected in 2012). Phylogenetic studies based on a partial coding region for the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp, 503 nucleotides) of these three samples suggested that two of them (B4836 and B4881) belong to genotype 2 (GIII.2), while the third (B4848) was more closely related to genotype 1 (GIII.1) strains. The capsid region of two of these strains could be determined by deep sequencing. This confirmed the circulation of genotype 1 (B4848) along with the presence of another sequence (B4881) that shares its closest genetic relationship with genotype 1 but is sufficiently distant to form a new genotype. This latter strain was shown to be recombinant in silico: phylogenetic divergence was demonstrated between its RNA-dependent RNA polymerase coding sequence (genotype GIII.2) and its capsid protein coding sequence (genotype GIII.1 or a putative norovirus genotype). According to these data, this strain could be the second recombinant bovine norovirus of genotype GIII.2_GIII.1 to be described in the literature worldwide. Further analysis suggested that this strain might even be a potential norovirus GIII genotype, tentatively named GIII.4. The data provide important epidemiological and evolutionary information about the bovine noroviruses circulating in South America.
authors: Ferragut, F.;Vega, C. G.;Mauroy, A.;Conceicao-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.;Uriarte, E. L.;Bilbao, G.;Bok, M.;Matthijnssens, J.;Thiry, E.;Badaracco, A.;Parreno, V.

title: Oligonucleotide microchip for influenza A virus subtyping
abstract: BACKGROUND: Influenza A viruses are classified into subtypes depending on the antigenic properties of their two outer glycoproteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). Sixteen subtypes of HA and nine of NA are known. Recently, the distribution of some subtypes (H7N7, H5N1) has been closely monitored due to the epidemiological threat they pose. OBJECTIVES: This study evaluates the potential of gel-based microchip technology for rapid and sensitive molecular subtyping of influenza A virus. METHODS: The method uses a microchip composed of gel-based 3D elements containing immobilized probes. Segments of the HA and NA genes are amplified using multiplex RT-PCR and then hybridized to the microchip. RESULTS: The developed microchip was validated against a panel of 21 known reference strains of influenza virus. Selected strains represented different HA and NA subtypes derived from avian, porcine and human hosts. The entire procedure takes 10 hours and allows the identification of 15 subtypes of HA and two subtypes of NA. Forty-one clinical specimens isolated during the Novosibirsk poultry fall (Russia, 2005) were successfully identified using the proposed technique. The sensitivity and specificity of the method were 76% and 100%, respectively, compared to the "gold standard" techniques (virus isolation followed by characterization by immunoassay). CONCLUSIONS: We conclude that the gel-based microchip subtyping method is a promising approach for the rapid detection and identification of influenza A, which could significantly improve surveillance.
authors: Fesenko, E. E.;Kireyev, D. E.;Gryadunov, D. A.;Mikhailovich, V. M.;Grebennikova, T. V.;L'Vov D, K.;Zasedatelev, A. S.

title: Epidemiological study and analysis of non-primate hepacivirus NS5B gene and protein variability in several equine cohorts in Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil
abstract: Among the recently described hepacivirus species, non-primate hepacivirus/hepacivirus A, found in horses and donkeys, is closely related to human hepatitis C virus (HCV). Therefore, the horse is an attractive surrogate large animal model for the study of HCV therapy, pathogenesis, and prophylaxis. Despite worldwide efforts, epidemiological and genetic studies have not elucidated the risk factors, virus distribution or genetic variability of hepacivirus A, which are also important for equine welfare. In Brazil, little information is available about this backdrop. The aim of this study was to investigate potential risk factors associated with hepacivirus A infection in different equine cohorts across Rio de Janeiro State and to assess the diversity of the viral NS5B gene and protein. Hepacivirus A RNA was detected in equine cohorts from all geographic mesoregions, regardless of equine activity or breed studied. The national prevalence ranged from 4.0% to 27.5%. Potential risk factors such as geographic location and age of female horses were significantly associated with the presence of viral RNA. The phylogenetic analysis showed the circulation of subtype 2 in all mesoregions. NS5B gene sequences grouped by geographic origin, while the NS5B fragments did not allow for discriminatory analysis. The predicted NS5B protein showed pronounced conservation, particularly in the thumb domain. In conclusion, the higher frequency of detection of hepacivirus A RNA in horses bred for reproduction and in young bitches suggests a direct link between reproductive practices and the spread of the virus. Additional studies are needed to understand the spread of this genetically conserved hepacivirus.
authors: Figueiredo, A. S.;Lampe, E.;de Albuquerque, Pplf;Chalhoub, F. L. V.;de Filippis, A. M. B.;Villar, L. M.;Cruz, O. G.;Pinto, M. A.;de Oliveira, J. M.

title: Bat astroviruses: To understand the transmission dynamics of a neglected virus family
abstract: Bats belong to the order of the Chiroptera, which is the second largest order of mammals with more than 1200 species and an almost worldwide distribution. Environmental changes and deforestation have greatly impacted many ecosystems and increased contact between wildlife and humans. In recent years, bats have been found to harbor a number of different viruses with zoonotic potential, as well as a large variety of astroviruses for which the question of zoonotic potential remains unresolved to date. Human astroviruses have been identified as causative agents of diarrhea in children and immunocompromised patients. Astroviruses have long been considered strictly species-specific. Recently, however, a large genetic diversity has been discovered among animal and human astroviruses, which may indicate the potential of these viruses to cross species barriers. In addition, our knowledge of the tissue tropism of astroviruses has been extended to some neurotrophic strains that have recently been shown to be responsible for encephalitis in humans and livestock. This review provides an overview of what is known about astroviruses in bats, humans, and livestock, particularly cattle and pigs. Future research activities are proposed to unravel the astrovirus infection dynamics in bat populations to further assess the zoonotic potential of these viruses.
authors: Fischer, K.;dos Reis, V. P.;Balkema-Buschmann, A.

title: A "hot spot" mutation in the M segment of Schmallenberg virus
abstract: In autumn 2011, the Schmallenberg virus (SBV), a novel orthobunyavirus of the Simbu serogroup, was identified by metagenomic analyzes in Germany. Since then, SBV has been detected in ruminants across Europe and investigations into phylogenetic relationships, clinical signs and epidemiology have been carried out. So far, however, only comparative sequence analyzes of SBV genome segments with other species of the Simbu serogroup have been performed, and detailed data on the S and M segments relevant to virus-host-cell interaction are lacking. In this study, we examined the S and M segment sequences of 24 SBV-positive field samples from sheep, cattle and one goat from across Germany. The results obtained showed that the overall genome variability of SBV is neither regional nor dependent on the host species. Nevertheless, we have characterized for the first time a region of high sequence variability (a mutational "hotspot") within the glycoprotein Gc encoded by the M segment. © 2013 SGM.
authors: Fischer, M.;Hoffmann, B.;Goller, K. V.;HÃ¶per, D.;Wernike, K.;Beer, M.

title: Metagenomic rapid diagnostics in suspected onset of severe pneumonia
authors: Fischer, N.;Rohde, H.;Indenbirken, D.;GÃ¼nther, T.;Reumann, K.;LÃ¼tgehetmann, M.;Meyer, T.;Kluge, S.;Aepfelbacher, M.;Alawi, M.;Grundhoff, A.

title: A55 Foot-and-mouth disease virus undergoes extensive viral genomic changes at various stages of infection in cattle
authors: Fish, I.;Stenfeldt, C.;Pauszek, S. J.;Brito, B. P.

title: Rift Valley fever virus
abstract: Rift Valley fever is one of the most important viral zoonoses in Africa. In 2000, Rift Valley fever virus spread across the Arabian Peninsula, causing two simultaneous outbreaks in Yemen and Saudi Arabia. It is transmitted to ruminants and humans by mosquitoes. The viral agent is an arbovirus belonging to the genus Phlebovirus in the Bunyaviridae family. This family of viruses includes more than 300 members grouped into five genera: Orthobunyavirus, Phlebovirus, Hantavirus, Nairovirus, and Tospovirus. Several members of the Bunyaviridae family are responsible for fatal hemorrhagic fevers: Rift Valley fever virus (Phlebovirus), Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (Nairovirus), Hantaan, Sin Nombre and related viruses (Hantavirus), and recently Garissa, now identified as Ngari Virus (Orthobunyavirus). Discusses recent advances in Rift Valley fever virus, its epidemiology, molecular biology, and focus on current data on the interactions between viral and cellular proteins that help to understand the molecular mechanisms used by the virus to to bypass the cellular response of the host. © 2005 Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.
authors: Flick, R.;Bouloy, M.

title: Letter to the editor refuted "Epidemiological patterns of classic Borna disease and regional genetic accumulation of Borna disease viruses indicate the existence of previously unknown endemic reservoir host populations" by Ralf Dürrwald, Jolanta Kolodziejek, Aemero Muluneh, Sibylle Herzog and Norbert Nowotny, Microbes and Infection 8 (2006) 917-929
authors: Flower, R.;Kamhieh, S.

title: Torquetenovirus: the human virus from the bank to the bedside
authors: Focosi, D.;Antonelli, G.;Pistello, M.;Maggi, F.

title: Crane hepatitis herpes viruses
abstract: Comparative studies were performed on crane herpesviruses obtained from two different enzootic species in Austria and France. The viruses studied appear to be identical in their physico-chemical properties, morphology and biological reactions in ovo. The crane viruses are tentatively classified as beta herpesviruses. Crane herpesvirus antisera prepared in rabbits cross-reacted with each other and with a quail-derived herpesvirus in cross-neutralization assays. No reactivity was observed with other avian herpesviruses and with human herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2.
authors: Foerster, S.;Chastel, C.;Kaleta, E. F.

title: Classification and nomenclature of primate immunodeficiency virus
authors: Foley, B. T.;Leitner, T.;Paraskevis, D.;Peeters, M.

title: Influenza D in Italy: to better understand an emerging viral infection in pigs
authors: Foni, E.;Chiapponi, C.;Baioni, L.;Zanni, I.;Merenda, M.

title: The pseudorabies virus can be classified into five genotypes using partial sequences of UL44
abstract: Suid herpesvirus 1 (SuHV-1) is the causative agent of pseudorabies (PR), a disease of major concern due to the enormous losses it causes in the swine industry. The aim of this study was to determine a method for genotyping SuHV-1 based on partial sequences of the gene encoding glycoprotein C (gC) and to elucidate the possible reasons for the variability of this region. A total of 109 gC sequences collected from GenBank were classified into five major groups after reconstruction of a phylogenetic tree by Bayesian inference. Analysis showed that a portion of gC (approximately 671 bp) is under selective pressure at various points coinciding with regions of protein perturbation. It was also possible to subdivide SuHV-1 into five genotypes that evolved under different selection pressures. These genotypes are not specific to countries or continents, possibly due to multiple introduction events related to the import of pigs.
authors: Fonseca, A. A., Jr.;Camargos, M. F.;Sales, M. L.;Heinemann, M. B.;Leite, R. C.;Reis, J. K.

title: Genome analysis of the multihost pathogen Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae reveals extensive recombination and the existence of three generalized clades with wide geographic distribution
abstract: BACKGROUND: Knowledge of how bacterial populations are structured is an important prerequisite for studying their ecology and evolutionary history, and facilitates the study of host specificity, pathogenicity, geographic distribution, and molecular epidemiology. Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is an opportunistic pathogen currently re-emerging in both the swine and poultry industries worldwide. This bacterium causes sporadic deaths in captive marine mammals and has recently been linked to large-scale wildlife extinctions. However, despite its economic importance and wide geographic and host distribution, including zoonotic potential, the global diversity, recombination rates and population structure of this bacterium remain poorly characterized. In this study, we performed a broad genomic comparison of E. rhusiopathiae based on a diverse collection of isolates to fill these knowledge gaps. RESULTS: Eighty-three E. rhusiopathiae isolates from a range of host species and geographic origins, isolated between 1958 and 2014, were sequenced and assembled using reference-based mapping and de novo assembly. We found that a high proportion of the nuclear genome (58%) underwent recombination. Therefore, we used three independent methods robust to the presence of recombination to define the population structure of this species: a phylogenetic tree based on a set of conserved protein sequences, in silico chromosome painting, and network analysis. All three methods showed broad agreement and supported the existence of three distinct clades within the species E. rhusiopathiae. Although we found some evidence of host and geographic aggregation, each clade contained isolates from different host species and from multiple continents. CONCLUSIONS: Using whole genome sequence data, we confirm recent suggestions that E. rhusiopathiae is a weakly clonal species formed largely by homologous recombination. Despite frequent recombination, we can reliably identify three distinct clades that do not clearly separate by host species or geographic origin. Our results provide an essential basis for future molecular-epidemiological, ecological, and evolutionary studies of E. rhusiopathiae and facilitate comparisons with other recombinogenic multi-host bacteria.
authors: Forde, T.;Biek, R.;Zadoks, R.;Workentine, M. L.;De Buck, J.;Kutz, S.;Opriessnig, T.;Trewby, H.;van der Meer, F.;Orsel, K.

title: Genetic diversity among 2009 pandemic influenza viruses isolated from a transmission chain
abstract: BACKGROUND: Influenza viruses such as porcine influenza A(H1N1) virus (A(H1N1)pdm09) generate genetic diversity due to the high error rate of their RNA polymerase, often resulting in mixed genotype populations (intra-host variants) within one single infection. This variation helps influenza respond rapidly to selection pressures such as those imposed by the host immunological response and antiviral therapy. We applied deep sequencing to characterize influenza variation within the host in a chain of transmission consisting of three cases due to oseltamivir-susceptible viruses and one derived oseltamivir-resistant case. METHODS: After detecting the A(H1N1)pdm09 infections, we deeply sequenced the complete NA gene from two of the oseltamivir-sensitive virus-infected cases and all eight gene segments of the viruses causing the remaining two cases. RESULTS: No evidence of the resistance-causing mutation (resulting in a NA H275Y substitution) was observed in the oseltamivir-sensitive cases. In addition, deep sequencing revealed a subpopulation of oseltamivir-sensitive virus in the case carrying resistant virus. We found a higher level of intra-host variation in patients harboring oseltamivir-resistant virus than in patients infected with oseltamivir-susceptible virus. CONCLUSIONS: Oseltamivir resistance was only detected after prophylaxis with oseltamivir, suggesting that the mutation was selected as a result of antiviral intervention. The persistence of the oseltamivir-susceptible virus population in the case where resistant virus was transmitted indicates either that a small proportion survives treatment or that the oseltamivir-susceptible virus is rapidly re-establishing itself in the viral population after the bottleneck. Furthermore, the increased intra-host variation in the oseltamivir-resistant case is consistent with the hypothesis that the population diversity of an RNA virus can increase rapidly after a population bottleneck.
authors: Fordyce, S. L.;Bragstad, K.;Pedersen, S. S.;Jensen, T. G.;Gahrn-Hansen, B.;Daniels, R.;Hay, A.;Kampmann, M. L.;Bruhn, C. A.;Moreno-Mayar, J. V.;Avila-Arcos, M. C.;Gilbert, M. T.;Nielsen, L. P.

title: Detection of hepatitis E virus in samples of animal origin collected in Hungary
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a human pathogenic enterally transmitted virus. HEV infections are mainly associated with acute, self-limited, icteric hepatitis with a median mortality rate of 1%. Animal reservoirs are believed to play an important role in virus maintenance and transmission of HEV to humans. HEV-induced seroconversion has been described in several species, but clinical hepatitis in animals has not been observed to date. Animal HEV strains are genetically closely related to human HEV isolates, supporting opinions on zoonotic transmission of the virus. In this extensive study, the occurrence of HEV in Hungarian wild and domestic animal samples was investigated. HEV RNA was detected by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction in liver samples from wild boar, roe deer and deer. The investigations of domestic pig samples detected HEV in 39% of the investigated Hungarian pig farms. A simultaneous examination revealed no clear difference between liver and faecal samples from domestic pigs in the frequency of HEV positivity. The highest incidence (36%) of HEV infection was found in the 11-16 week old pigs. Domestic cattle and rodent samples collected from pig farms, forests and meadows tested negative for HEV RNA. Phylogenetic analysis of partial sequences amplified within the ORF1 and ORF2 regions of selected strains revealed that the viruses detected belong to three subgroups of the third genogroup of HEV and are closely related to human and porcine HEV strains found in different countries have been demonstrated. The investigations revealed a wide distribution of HEV in Hungarian wild ungulate and domesticated pig populations with considerable genetic diversity among strains. © 2009 Elsevier BV
authors: ForgÃ¡ch, P.;Nowotny, N.;ErdÃ©lyi, K.;Boncz, A.;Zentai, J.;Szucs, G.;Reuter, G.;Bakonyi, T.

title: A real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction to differentiate Massachusetts vaccine and Brazilian field genotypes of infectious avian bronchitis virus
abstract: The infectious avian bronchitis virus is classified into serotypes or genotypes (or both) in different poultry producing countries of the world. In Brazil, the Massachusetts type (Mass), used as a live vaccine, and local Brazilian field variants (genotypes; BR) predominate in commercial poultry flocks. This study describes the development and validation of two real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reactions (RT-qPCR) for the specific detection of Mass and BR genotypes in allantoic fluid and clinical specimens. Genotype-specific primers combined with a generic probe targeting the S1 gene were created in Mass RT-qPCR and BR RT-qPCR specific assays. Analytical sensitivity and linearity of these assays were determined in comparison to a generic IBV real-time RT-PCR based on the 5'-untranslated region (5'UTR RT-qPCR). Mass RT-qPCR detected five mass field isolates, three vaccine samples and one co-infected sample (BR and Mass), while BR-RT-qPCR detected 16 BR field isolates. Both assays were linear (R(2) > 0.98), reproducible and as sensitive as the classic 5'UTR RT-qPCR used to detect IBV. In the analysis of 141 clinical IBV specimens, 8 were positive for Mass RT-qPCR, 76 for BR RT-qPCR and 2 for both assays. Of the remaining 55 samples, 25 were positive for 5'UTR RT-qPCR only and 30 were negative for the three assays. In conclusion, both assays were able to detect Mass and BR genotypes, allowing for fast and easy molecular typing of IBV from allantoic fluids and clinical specimens.
authors: Fraga, A. P.;Ikuta, N.;Fonseca, A. S.;Spilki, F. R.;Balestrin, E.;Rodrigues, C. D.;Canal, C. W.;Lunge, V. R.

title: Discovery of parvovirus-related sequences in an unexpectedly broad range of animals
abstract: Our understanding of the genetic diversity and host range of viruses is patchy. This is particularly true for the Parvoviridae family. Genetic diversity studies of single-stranded DNA viruses within this family have largely focused on arthropod and vertebrate infecting species that cause disease in humans and our domestic animals: a focus that has skewed our perception of parvovirus diversity. While metagenomics approaches could help correct this bias, so could transcriptomics studies. Large amounts of transcriptome data are available for a variety of animal species, and when these data have been inadvertently collected from virus-infected individuals, they may contain detectable viral transcripts. We therefore performed a systematic search for parvovirus-related sequences (PRSs) in publicly available transcript, genomic, and protein databases and eleven new transcriptome datasets. This revealed 463 PRSs in the transcript databases from 118 animals. At least 41 of these PRSs are likely integrated into animal genomes as they have also been found in genome sequence databases. The number of parvoviral sequences discovered in public databases not only sheds light on the ubiquity of parvoviruses, but also reveals numerous previously unknown parvovirus-host combinations; especially in invertebrates. Our results suggest that the host ranges of existing parvoviruses may span the entire animal kingdom.
authors: FranÃ§ois, S.;Filloux, D.;Roumagnac, P.;Bigot, D.;Gayral, P.;Martin, D. P.;Froissart, R.;Ogliastro, M.

title: Classification of vaccinia viruses into several distinct clades and identification of a new lineage
abstract: Cowpox virus (CPXV) has been considered a uniform species within the Orthopoxvirus (OPV) genus. Previous phylogenetic analyzes indicated that CPXV is polyphyletic and isolates can group into different clades, with two of these clades sharing genetic similarities with either variola (VARV) or vaccinia viruses (VACV). Further analyzes were initiated to assess both the genetic diversity and evolutionary background of circulating CPXVs. Here we report the complete sequences of 20 CPXV strains isolated from different animal species and humans in Germany. A phylogenetic analysis of a total of 83 full-length OPV genomes confirmed the polyphyletic character of the species CPXV and suggested at least four distinct clades. The German isolates from this study mainly clustered into two CPXV-like clades, and VARV- and VACV-like strains were not observed. A single strain isolated from a cotton-tipped tamarin clustered far from any other CPXVs and may represent a new and unique evolutionary lineage. The classification of the CPXV strains into clades roughly followed their geographic origin, with the highest clade diversity observed so far for Germany. Furthermore, we found evidence for recombination between OPV clades without significant disruption to the observed cluster formation. In conclusion, this analysis significantly expands the number of available full-length CPXV sequences and confirms the co-circulation of multiple CPXV clades in Germany and provides the first data on a new evolutionary CPXV lineage.
authors: Franke, A.;Pfaff, F.;Jenckel, M.;Hoffmann, B.;HÃ¶per, D.;Antwerpen, M.;Meyer, H.;Beer, M.;Hoffmann, D.

title: Exploratory metagenomic analyzes of pigs affected by failure to thrive syndrome
abstract: Modern pig farming is characterized by the occurrence of several syndromes of unclear etiology or multifactorial origin, including periweaning failure-to-thrive syndrome (PFTS). In fact, its specific etiology remains elusive, although multiple causes have been studied over time. The present study aimed to investigate the potential role of viral pathogens in PFTS-affected and healthy animals by assessing the viroma composition of different organs using a metagenomic approach. This analysis enabled detection of a higher frequency of porcine parvovirus 6 (PPV6) in healthy subjects, while ungulate bocaparvovirus 2 (BoPV2), ungulate protoparvovirus 1 (PPV), and porcine circovirus 3 (PCV-3) were elevated in pigs with PFTS . No difference in frequency of RNA viruses was found between PFTS-affected and control pigs. Remarkably, this is the first molecular characterization of PPV6 and BoPV2 in Spain and one of the few worldwide, supporting their apparent widespread distribution. Interestingly, PCV-3 has recently been identified in several clinicopathological conditions as well as in healthy pigs, while the pathogenic potential of BoPV2 is unknown. Although the results obtained must be considered preliminary, they open the door to further studies on the possible role of these viruses or their combination as predisposing factors for the occurrence of PFTS.
authors: Franzo, G.;Kekarainen, T.;Llorens, A.;Correa-Fiz, F.;SegalÃ©s, J.

title: Subpopulations in aMPV vaccines are unlikely to be the sole cause of reversion to virulence
abstract: Avian metapneumovirus (aMPV) infects the respiratory and reproductive tracts of domestic poultry, often with secondary infections, causing serious economic losses in most parts of the world. While the disease is generally effectively controlled by live vaccines, reversal of the virulence of these vaccines has been demonstrated on several occasions. Consensus sequence mutations involved in the process have been identified in more than one case. In a previous subtype A aMPV candidate vaccine study, small subpopulations were involved. In the current study, the presence of subpopulations in a subtype B vaccine was examined by deep sequencing. Of the 19 positions at which the consensus sequences of the vaccine (strain VCO3/50) and progenitor (strain VCO3/60616) differed, subpopulations at 4 positions were found to have a sequence consistent with the progenitor sequence. However, none of these mutations occurred in a virulent revertant of this vaccine, showing that the majority of the progenitor virus population had not survived the attenuation process and therefore was apparently not involved in a return to virulence. However, a single nucleotide variation was found within the vaccine that matched the consensus sequence of a derived virulent revertant virus, therefore these and other undiscovered, potentially virulent subpopulations may be involved in reversion. Much deeper sequencing of the precursor, vaccine and revertant can clarify whether problematic virulent subpopulations are present and therefore need to be routinely removed during aMPV vaccine preparation prior to registration and release.
authors: Franzo, G.;Naylor, C. J.;Drigo, M.;Croville, G.;Ducatez, M. F.;Catelli, E.;Laconi, A.;Cecchinato, M.

title: The actinic keratosis virus: can we prevent squamous cell carcinoma with a vaccine?
authors: Frazer, I. H.

title: quack leptin
abstract: Background: A LEP transcript that is upregulated in the lungs of ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) infected with avian influenza A virus was recently described in the Nature Genetics manuscript reporting the duck genome. In vertebrates, the LEP gene symbol is reserved for leptin, the key regulator of mammalian energy balance. Results: Beginning a comprehensive search for this gene in the genome data submitted with the duck genome manuscript to the public databases and expanding this search to include all bird genomes in the Whole-Genome Shotgun-Sequencing Database, we were able to start with the first identification of report coding sequences capable of encoding the complete leptin protein precursor in wild birds. Gene structure, synteny and sequence similarity (up to 54% identity and 68% similarity) to reptile leptin evident in hawks (Falco peregrinus and cherrug), tits (Pseudopodoces humilis), finches (Taeniopygia guttata) and pigeons (Columba livia), confirms that the avian leptin was a true ortholog of its mammalian form. However, like other domestic chickens, the LEP gene was not identifiable in ducks. Conclusion: The absence of the LEP gene in poultry suggests that birds that have lost it are particularly suitable for domestication. The identification of an intact avian gene for leptin in wild birds may partially explain the evolutionary conservation of its receptor in leptin-deficient chickens. © 2014 Friedman-Einat and Seroussi; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Friedman-Einat, M.;Seroussi, E.

title: Crystal structure of swine vesicular disease virus and implications for host adaptation
abstract: Swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) is an enterovirus of the family Picornaviridae that causes symptoms indistinguishable from those of foot-and-mouth disease virus. Phylogenetic studies indicate that it is a recently evolved genetic sublineage of the important human pathogenic coxsackievirus B5 (CBV5), and consistent with this, it has been shown to utilize the coxsackie and adenovirus receptor (CAR) for cell entry. The 3.0 Å crystal structure of strain UK/27/72 SVDV (highly virulent) shows the expected similarity in core structure to those of other picornaviruses and shows the closest similarity to the closest available structure to CBV5, that of coxsackievirus B3 (CBV3) . . Features that help glue together and stiffen the protein subunits are enhanced in this virus, possibly explaining its extreme tolerance to environmental factors. Using the large number of capsid sequences available for both SVDV and CBV5, we mapped the amino acid substitutions that may have occurred during the putative adaptation of SVDV to a new host to the structure of SVDV and created a model of the SVDV /CAR complex constructed with reference to the complex of CBV3 and CAR visualized by cryoelectron microscopy. The changes fall into three clusters as follows: one lines the five-fold pore, a second maps the CAR-binding site and partially overlaps the site where decay-accelerating factor (DAF) binds to echovirus 7 (ECHO7), and the third lies in the Proximity to the five-fold axis where the low-density lipoprotein receptor binds to the smaller group of rhinoviruses. Subsequent changes in SVDV (after 1971) belong to the first two clusters and may have improved the virus' adaptation to pigs by optimizing recognition of a porcine CAR and/or DAF homologue.
authors: Fry, E. E.;Knowles, N. J.;Newman, J. W. I.;Wilsden, G.;Rao, Z.;King, A. M. Q.;Stuart, D. I.

title: Molecular detection and typing of duck hepatitis A virus directly from clinical specimens
abstract: To develop a new approach for duck hepatitis A virus (DHAV) detection and typing, a pair of non-degenerate primers were designed to amplify a 250 bp genomic region in the 5-UTR. 3 reference strains and 6 duck embryo isolates from different regions of China with 2 serotypes were successfully amplified with the primer set. A molecular typing method was developed by determining the nucleotide sequence of the amplicon. When isolated sequences were compared to DHAV-5 UTR sequences available in public databases, nucleotide identity was ≥ 94% with homologous serotypes and ≥ 73% with heterologous serotypes. The phylogenetic analysis revealed a monophyletic cluster of 5-UTR sequences of a homologous serotype, leading to the new classification of DHAV (serotype 1 and the two new serotypes recently described in Taiwan and South Korea respectively) into three defined genotypes (A, B and C) confirmed by the capsid coding region. Analysis of the results showed that the primer pair should help in the detection of DHAV and that the amplicon sequence contains type-specific information and can be used for effective and rapid molecular typing. The molecular methods proved their utility by detecting and typing DHAV directly from 28 liver samples collected from dead ducklings during viral hepatitis outbreaks in ducks in different regions of China between 2001 and 2007. The results confirmed the presence of DHAV in all 28 samples and showed that genotypes A (13/28) and C (15/28) of DHAV co-circulate in China. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Fu, Y.;Pan, M.;Wang, X.;Xu, Y.;Yang, H.;Zhang, D.

title: Comparative transcriptome analyzes indicate an improved cellular protection against FMD in PK15 cells pretreated with IFN-γ
abstract: Gamma-interferon (IFN-γ) can induce a host antiviral response to foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus in vivo and in vitro. To elucidate the mechanism of IFN-γ anti-FMD infection in host cells, high-throughput RNA sequencing was analyzed for systemic changes in gene expression profiles in PK15 cells infected with or without IFN-γ pretreatment of FMD. More than 25 million reads covering 1.2 to 1.5 GB were analyzed from each experimental panel. FMDV challenge altered transcription of genes involved in positive and negative regulation of cell death or apoptosis; however, the expected immunosuppressive response was not evident. IFN-γ pretreatment in combination with FMD infection normalized the increase in apoptosis. Furthermore, the transcription factors required for IFN-γ to function, STAT1 and IRF1, were upregulated by IFN-γ pretreatment and downstream IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) stimulated. These induced ISGs are mainly responsible for antigen processing, antigen presentation or antiviral defense. Interestingly, a synergistic effect on some ISGs including OAS1, OAS2, MX1, MX2, RIG-I and IFIT1 was observed in the combined treatment compared to treatment with IFN-γ alone. The proposed effects identified by RNA sequencing were consistent with changes in cell morphology and were confirmed by related protein markers. This is the first report examining transcriptome changes induced by FMD infection with or without IFN-γ pretreatment. The identified key host genes that control cell survival in vitro add to our comprehensive understanding of how IFN-γ inhibits FMD infection and may shed light on the development of improved FMD control approaches.
authors: Fu, Y.;Zhu, Z.;Chang, H.;Liu, Z.;Liu, J.;Chen, H.

title: Molecular characterization of the novel P[14],G8 group A bovine rotavirus, Sun9, isolated in Japan
abstract: In this study, a novel bovine group A (RV-A) rotavirus, Sun9, isolated from calf diarrhea in Tochigi Prefecture, Japan, was genetically characterized by sequence analysis of the genome segments encoding VP4 and VP7. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of the genome segments encoding VP4 and VP7 of Sun9 showed high homology with human and Lapine P[14] RV-As (80.2–88.7% and 90.9–94, 8%) and bovine and human G8 RV-As (83.1-95.5% and 92.3-98.2%). Sun9 has also been classified into P[14] and G8 in phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequences of the genome segments encoding VP4 and VP7. Although previous reports have suggested that P[14], G8 human RV-As isolated to date, result from resorting between human and bovine RV-As or from interspecies transmission of bovine RV-A in humans, no P[14], G8 bovine RV-A has not yet been reported. Sun9 could be a first direct evidence for the above hypothesis. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Fukai, K.;Saito, T.;Inoue, K.;Sato, M.

title: Bovine herpesvirus-1: comparison and differentiation of vaccine and field strains based on genomic sequence variation
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus-1 (BoHV-1) causes significant disease in cattle, including respiratory, fetal, and reproductive tract infections. Control programs usually include vaccination with a modified live viral vaccine (MLV). Occasionally, BoHV-1 strains are isolated from diseased animals or fetuses after vaccination. There are currently no markers to distinguish MLV strains from field strains of BoHV-1. In this study, multiple BoHV-1 strains were sequenced using whole genome sequencing technologies and the data analyzed to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). Strains sequenced included reference strain BoHV-1 Cooper (GenBank Accession JX898220), eight commercial MLV vaccine strains and 14 field strains from cases presented for diagnosis. Based on SNP analysis, the viruses could be divided into groups with similar SNP patterns. The eight MLV strains could be distinguished from one another, although some were closely related. A number of field strains isolated from animals previously vaccinated exhibited SNP patterns similar to those of specific MLV viruses, while other field isolates differed markedly from all vaccine strains. The results indicate that some BoHV-1 isolates from clinically ill cattle/fetuses may be associated with prior MLV vaccination, but more information on the rate of change in the BoHV-1 genomic sequence is needed before irrefutable associations can be made can be drawn. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Fulton, R. W.;d'Offay, J. M.;Eberle, R.

title: Evolutionary analyzes of the HA gene of the H1N1/09 pandemic: early insights
abstract: The HA protein is responsible for the attachment of the influenza virus and the subsequent fusion of viral and cellular membranes. Antigenic drift is driven by an accumulation of point mutations in HA. And the receptor binding specificity of HA is responsible for the restriction of the host range of the virus. In April 2009, large outbreaks of novel H1N1 influenza in the human population were reported in North America. The pandemic H1N1 virus evolved from the swine flu virus. The evolutionary process of the pandemic virus after its introduction into the human population has yet to be elucidated. We performed phylogenetic analyzes by constructing a phylogenetic tree for the HA gene and calculating site-by-site selection pressures. The phylogenetic tree showed that pandemic viruses were not clearly clustered in the phylogenetic tree according to their geographic location or isolation time. The virus has spread worldwide and has been introduced multiple times to most geographic areas. We found 3 positively selected sites in the HA gene for the pandemic H1N1 virus. Below this is position 206 at an antigenic site. We found no significant negative selection at any of the receptor binding sites. The virus evolved under a unique selection pressure.
authors: Furuse, Y.;Suzuki, A.;Oshitani, H.

title: Rearrangement of gene segments between Eurasian and American strains of avian influenza virus in Italy
abstract: All genes of the avian influenza A viruses are phylogenetically divided into two large groups, namely the American and the Eurasian group. Rearrangements between influenza virus gene segments belonging to the two different clades are rare events and have never been described before in poultry in Europe and Asia. This study presents the genetic characterization of two influenza viruses isolated from domestic mallard ducks in Italy in 2004 and 2005. Whole genome phylogenetic analysis showed that these viruses contain mixed gene segments belonging to the American and Eurasian clades. © Springer Verlag 2009.
authors: Fusaro, A.;Monne, I.;Cattoli, G.;de Nardi, R.;Salviato, A.;Martin, A. M.;Capua, I.;Terregino, C.

title: Genetic diversity of highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N8/H5N5) viruses in Italy, 2016-17
abstract: In the winter of 2016-17, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) and A(H5N5) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4 were identified in wild and domestic birds in Italy. We report the occurrence of multiple introductions and describe the identification of 2 novel genotypes in Europe generated by multiple reassortment events.
authors: Fusaro, A.;Monne, I.;Mulatti, P.;Zecchin, B.;Bonfanti, L.;Ormelli, S.;Milani, A.;Cecchettin, K.;Lemey, P.;Moreno, A.;Massi, P.;Dorotea, T.;Marangon, S.;Terregino, C.

title: Unexpected transmission dynamics between farms during a highly pathogenic avian influenza epidemic
abstract: UNMARKED: Next-generation sequencing technology is now being increasingly used to study virus population dynamics within and between hosts. However, information on the development and transmission of the avian influenza virus during a naturally occurring epidemic is still limited. Here we use deep sequencing data from clinical samples from five industrial farms and one backyard farm infected during the 2013 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H7N7 epidemic in Italy to (i) reveal the diversity of the epidemic virus population, (ii) the development of virus pathogenicity and (iii) the routes of virus transmission between different farms and houses. We demonstrate a high level of genetic diversity of HPAI H7N7 viruses within a single farm as a result of separate bottlenecks and founder effects. Specifically, we identified cocirculation in the index case of two virus strains that displayed a different insertion at the hemagglutinin cleavage site, as well as nine nucleotide differences at the consensus level and 92 minority variants.
