To assess transmission between farms, we combined epidemiological and genetic data and identified the index case as the main source of the virus, suggesting the spread of different viral haplotypes from the index farm to the other industrial farms, probably at different times. Our results revealed transmission dynamics between farms that the epidemiological data alone could not decipher, and showed that delays in detection and control of the disease were the main cause of the emergence and spread of the HPAI strain. IMPORTANT: The evolutionary dynamics within and between hosts of a highly pathogenic strain of avian influenza (HPAI) during a naturally occurring epidemic are currently poorly understood. Here, for the first time, we perform an in-depth sequence analysis of all samples collected during an HPAI epidemic and demonstrate the importance of supplementing outbreak investigations with genetic data to reconstruct viral transmission dynamics and assess in-and-between-farm genetic diversity the virus population. We show that the evolutionary transition from the low pathogenic form to the highly pathogenic form occurred within the first infected flocks, where we identified haplotypes with different lengths of hemagglutinin cleavage sites. We also identify the index case as the main source of the virus, indicating that the immediate application of destocking measures is essential to limit the spread of the virus to other farms.
authors: Fusaro, A.;Tassoni, L.;Milani, A.;Hughes, J.;Salviato, A.;Murcia, P. R.;Massi, P.;Zamperin, G.;Bonfanti, L.;Marangon, S.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Development of a pyrosequencing assay for the typing of alphaherpesviruses
abstract: The detection of herpes viruses in biological material is usually done by real-time PCR. With the aim of classifying the identified virus strain, real-time PCR often has to be supported by time-consuming capillary electrophoretic sequence analysis. Here we provide a protocol for the rapid and reliable identification of 5 closely related herpesviruses using the PyroMark Q24 sequencing system. PyroMark performs DNA sequencing analysis using pyrosequencing, a technology based on the detection of released pyrophosphate during DNA elongation [1]. PyroMark is designed to detect changes at specific variable positions in DNA. It can efficiently detect single nucleotide differences in sequences [2]. In the present work we describe a protocol for pyrosequencing of a small polymorphic segment of the US8 gene. Based on the differences identified in the nucleotide sequence, we were able to easily classify the herpesvirus as bovine herpesvirus 1.1, bovine herpesvirus 1.2, bovine herpesvirus 5, bubaline herpesvirus 1, or caprine herpesvirus. The protocol created offers several advantages compared to the commonly used techniques: it requires less than a working day to be worn; it provides the ability to analyze up to 24 samples simultaneously at a reasonable cost; and it allows to detect with great reliability and specificity highly genetically correlated organisms such as the herpesviruses mentioned above. The method can easily be applied to other virus families with appropriate modifications.
authors: Fusco, G.;Amoroso, M. G.;Gesualdi Montesano, N.;Viscardi, M.

title: Temperature-sensitive mutants of the Chandipura virus. II. Phenotypic characteristics of the six complementation groups
abstract: Fifty temperature-sensitive (ts) mutants of rhabdovirus chandipura virus have been classified into six complementation groups, designated ChI through ChVI. Group ChI contains 44 mutants, group ChII contains 2 mutants and the remaining groups each have 1 mutant. Mutants in groups ChI, ChIII, ChIV and ChVI had RNA negative phenotypes in experiments measuring the amplification of RNA synthesis at restrictive temperature. The two mutants in group ChII had RNA-positive phenotypes and the virions were thermolabile. The group ChV mutant ts Ch851 was also RNA positive and the M polypeptide of this mutant appeared to be unstable in cells incubated at restrictive temperature. It is therefore likely that the complementation groups ChII and ChV represent the genes encoding the two viral proteins of the virion envelope. No precise assignment can be made for the four RNA-negative groups, since all mutants examined showed a certain polymerase activity in vitro at a restrictive temperature. An attempt to obtain polymerase mutants by screening for susceptibility to rifampin was unsuccessful. Six temperature-dependent host-range mutants (the tdCE phenotype) of Chandipura virus failed to proliferate in chick embryo cells at restrictive temperature, but otherwise differed in their host-range characteristics from similar vesicular stomatitis virus mutants.
authors: Gadkari, D. A.;Pringle, C. R.

title: Analysis by high-throughput sequencing of specific pathogen-free eggs
abstract: Specific pathogen free (SPF) embryonated eggs are used in the production of many veterinary and human vaccines. We used high-throughput sequencing to examine allantoic fluids and embryos for the presence of encapsulated viral genomes and viral transcripts, respectively. SPF eggs from two different manufacturers were tested. We have detected sequences corresponding to known endogenous retroviruses and avian leukosis virus sequences, but no sequence that might indicate productive infection of eggs with a virus even distant from known viruses. Our results strongly suggest that SPF eggs, as used for this study, represent a safe substrate for vaccine production. (C) 2014 The International Alliance for Biological Standardization. Issued by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Gagnieur, L.;Cheval, J.;Cochet, M.;Breard, E.;Gratigny, M.;Hebert, C.;Muth, E.;Viarouge, C.;Dumarest, M.;Coulpier, M.;Eloit, M.

title: Unbiased analysis by high-throughput sequencing of viral diversity in fetal bovine serum and trypsin used in cell culture
abstract: Fetal bovine serum (FBS) and trypsin are reagents used in cell culture and have been the source of viral contamination of pharmaceutical products. We performed high throughput sequencing (HTS) of two pools of commercial lots of FBS and three commercial lots of trypsin. Taxonomies were assigned by comparing sequences of contigs and singletons to the NCBI's entire nucleic acid and protein databases. The same major virus species was detected between lots of a given reagent, but the proportion of virus reads to total reads varied significantly between samples (from 0.002% to 22.7%). In FBS, the sequences found were mainly from bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) 1 to 3 and bovine parvovirus 3 (BPV3). The FBS-derived BVDV sequences showed only minor discrepancies with primers commonly used for BVDV screening. Viral sequences in trypsin were mainly from porcine circovirus type 2. Other known lower reading viral sequences and potential new viral species (bovine parvovirus and bovine pegivirus) were detected. The load of some known and new viruses detected by HTS could be quantified by qPCR. HTS results provide a framework for assessing the relevance of control measures, including the design of PCRs, bioassays and inactivation procedures. © 2014 The International Alliance for Biological Standardization.
authors: Gagnieur, L.;Cheval, J.;Gratigny, M.;HÃ©bert, C.;Muth, E.;Dumarest, M.;Eloit, M.

title: Genetic characterization and evolutionary analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolated from domestic ducks in South Korea
abstract: Domestic ducks are considered a potential reservoir for the Newcastle disease virus. The study characterized a Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from a domestic duck during surveillance in South Korea. The complete genome of the NDV isolate was sequenced and the phylogenetic relationship to reference strains was examined. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the strain clustered in genotype I of class II ND viruses has high phylogenetic similarity to NDV strains isolated from waterfowl in China, but from the viruses isolated in chickens and the vaccine strains used in South Korea was far away. Pathogenicity experiment on chickens showed that it is a lentogenic virus. The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion protein (F) confirmed that the isolate contained the avirulent motif 112GKQGRL117 at the cleavage site and did not cause overt disease in chickens and ducks. Using a phylogeographic analysis based on fusion genes, we estimate the origin of an ancestral virus of the isolate and its sister strain that was in China around 1998. This underscores the need for continuous surveillance to improve the current understanding of the molecular epidemiology and evolution of the pathogen strains.
authors: Gaikwad, S.;Kim, J. Y.;Lee, H. J.;Jung, S. C.;Choi, K. S.

title: Antiviral activity of tetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinones and related compounds
abstract: 24 derivatives of tetrahydro-2(1 H)-pyrimidinone and related compounds were tested in vitro for their antiviral activity against representatives of six taxonomic virus groups. Screening was performed by a two-step procedure involving the agar diffusion plaque inhibition assay and the one-step growth cycle design. A distinct activity of three mono- and bis-morpholinomethyl derivatives of tetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinone (THP), 1,3-bis(piperidinomethyl)-THP, the 1-morpholinomethyl derivative of tetrahydro-2(1H) -pyrimidinethione (THPT) and the related N,N'-bis(morpholinomethyl)-urea against avian influenza virus. In building the one-step growth cycle, these compounds inhibited 87.5-99.6% yield of infectious virus. Two of the compounds, namely 1-morpholinomethyl derivatives of THP and THPT, also showed potent inhibitory activity on Semliki Forest virus reproduction, exceeding 99.9% in the one-step growth cycle assay. Borderline activity against vaccinia virus and Newcastle disease virus has been observed with some derivatives. The structure-activity relationship of this group of compounds is discussed.
authors: Galabov, A. S.;Velichkova, E.;Karparov, A.

title: Genotyping of African swine fever virus (ASFV) isolates associated with disease outbreaks in Uganda in 2007
abstract: Samples from infected domestic pigs associated with an outbreak of African swine fever (ASF) in three districts of central Uganda in 2007 were identified using P72 gene-based polymerase chain reaction amplification (PCR) as infected with African swine fever virus (ASFV ) infected confirmed. Assay combined with restriction analysis. None of the sera collected from pigs with clinical symptoms were positive in the serological tests prescribed by the OIE. However, seven hema-adsorbing viruses were isolated in macrophage cultures and full-length genotyped by partial p72 and p54 gene sequencing. Four of these viruses were isolated directly from serum samples. All viruses were classified within the domestic swine cycle-associated p72 and p54 genotype IX, which also includes viruses responsible for ASF outbreaks in Kenya in 2006 and 2007 and Uganda in 2003. To define the virus relationships with higher resolution, typing was performed by tetramer analysis of amino acid repeat regions within the central variable region (CVR) of the B602L gene. The sequences of Ugandan isolates showed 100% identity with viruses isolated from outbreaks in Kenya in 2007. The identity was greater than that of the viruses obtained in a previous outbreak in Kenya in 2006. This provides further evidence that genetically similar ASFV viruses within p72 genotype IX may be circulating between Kenya and Uganda. © 2011 Academic Journals.
authors: Gallardo, C.;Ademun, A. R.;Nieto, R.;Nantima, N.;Arias, M.;MartÃ­n, E.;Pelayo, V.;Bishop, R. P.

title: Nanovirus-alpha satellite complex identified at Vicia Cracca in the Rhone Delta region of France
abstract: Nanoviruses are multicomponent, single-stranded, plant-infecting DNA viruses. Using a viral metagenomics-based approach, a novel nanovirus and two associated alphasatellite molecules were identified in an uncultivated asymptomatic Vicia cracca plant in the Rhne region of France. This novel nanovirus genome includes eight genomic components (named DNA-R, DNA-S, DNA-M, DNA-C, DNA-N, DNA-U1, DNA-U2, and DNA-U4) and divides across all components < 66% pairwise sequence identity with other nanovirus genomes. The two associated alpha satellites share 62% identity with each other and < 81% identity will be all other nanovirus-associated alpha satellites.
authors: Gallet, R.;Kraberger, S.;Filloux, D.;Galzi, S.;Fontes, H.;Martin, D. P.;Varsani, A.;Roumagnac, P.

title: Genetic information of mycobacteriophage DNAIII and their anti-tuberculosis potential
abstract: Aim: Understanding the genetic information of the mycobacteriophage DNAIII and exploring its anti-tuberculosis potential. Methods: Mycobacteriophage DNAIII DNA was isolated and purified using the lambda DNA extraction protocol. The shotgun sequences were assembled with Phred and PhraD and edited with Consed, then gaps were filled by sequencing PCR fragments. The general features of the genome were analyzed using the EditSeq software of the DNAStar software package. The genome was scanned for open reading frames using Glimmer 3.0. The genetic information of the mycobacteriophage DNAIII genome was further investigated by colinearity analysis and phylogenetic tree construction. The ability of DNAIII to lyse M. tuberculosis was examined in vitro, and the effects of temperature, alcohol and pH on DNAIII survival were determined. Results: The genome of DNAIII was 39,520 bp in size and linear double-stranded DNA with a G+C content of 66.83%. DNAIII contained 60 predicted protein-encoding genes and did not encode any tRNAs. There was no tandem repeat sequence in the genome of DNAIII. The DNAIII gene 32 encoded integrase, and there was also no gene encoding a repressor. DNAIII was very similar at the nucleotide acid level and colinear to Angel and BPs. At three different time points (Day 1, Day 2 and Day 3), the number of M. tuberculosis in the DNAIII group was significantly lower than in the control group (P<0.05). DNAIII was unstable to temperature, alcohol, and pH values. Conclusion: DNAIII belonging to Cluster G is a mycobacteriophage capable of lysing M. tuberculosis.
authors: Gan, Y. L.;Liu, P.;Wu, T. T.;Guo, S. L.

title: Newcastle disease virus: current status and our understanding
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the highly pathogenic viral diseases of bird species. ND is economically important due to the enormous mortality and morbidity associated with it. The disease is endemic in many third world countries where agriculture serves as the primary source of income. Newcastle disease virus (NDV) belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family and is a well-characterized member among the avian Paramyxovirus serotypes. In recent years, NDV has attracted virologists not only for its pathogenic potential, but also for its oncolytic activity and its use as a human and animal vaccine vector. The NDV-based recombinant vaccine offers a suitable choice for the construction of a live attenuated vaccine due to its modular nature of transcription, minimal frequency of recombination and the lack of a DNA phase during replication. Our current understanding of NDV biology is expanding rapidly due to the availability of modern molecular biology tools and high-throughput whole genome sequencing.
authors: Ganar, K.;Das, M.;Sinha, S.;Kumar, S.

title: A REVIEW ARTICLE ON SWINE INFLUENZA VIRUS A (S-OIV) INFECTION.
authors: Ganguly, S.;Giri, S.;Aseri, G. K.;Yadav, P.;Khare, N. K.

title: Analysis of alternative splicing in chick embryo fibroblasts in response to reticuloendothelosis virus infection
abstract: Alternative splicing (AS) plays an important role in regulating genomic expression at the transcriptional level and is involved in many important biological functions of cells, such that a gene can be spliced into different transcript variants and then translated into many different types of proteins. Reticuloendothelosis virus (REV) is a type of retrovirus that can infect several species of birds, resulting in Runting syndrome, immunosuppression, and oncogenesis. In this present study, we analyzed AS in REV-infected chick embryo fibroblasts (CEFs) vaccinated with second generation REV (group VB) and compared to normal CEFs (group C) by high-throughput RNA sequencing technology. A total of 6,939 genes that were alternatively spliced were detected, with Skipped Exon (SE) being the most common pattern. In addition, 5,607 AS genes have been identified as differentially expressed; compared to group C, group VB has 2,825 significantly upregulated genes and 2,782 significantly downregulated genes. These 5,607 differentially expressed AS genes are involved in many important biological processes. Many of them are involved in apoptosis and tumorigenesis. We also proved by agarose gel electrophoresis that AS events predicted by our study are authentic and AS is closely associated with apoptosis and tumorigenesis in REV-infected CEFs. Our study provides the best analysis to date of the potential association between AS and CEFs in response to REV infection. Research Highlights Transcriptomics analysis of REV-infected CEFs using high-throughput sequencing. Possible association between alternative splicing and CEFs in response to REV infection. Skipped exon is the most common spliced pattern in REV-infected CEFs. Differentially expressed genes mainly involved in apoptosis and tumorigenesis.
authors: Gao, C.;Zhai, J.;Dang, S.;Zheng, S.

title: Classification of a new member of the TBE flavivirus subgroup according to its immunological, pathogenetic and molecular properties: identification of subgroup-specific pentapeptides
abstract: The antigenic, pathogenic and molecular properties of Turkish Sheep Encephalitis (TSE) virus strain TTE80 were compared to other members of the tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) virus complex. Monoclonal antibodies with a defined specificity for the flavivirus envelope glycoprotein differentiated the TSE virus from Luping III (LI), Western or Far Eastern TBE, Langat and Powassan virus in indirect immunofluorescence, haemagglutination inhibition and neutralization tests. On the other hand, TSE virus, which causes LI-like disease in sheep, resembled LI virus in mouse neurovirulence tests. Molecular homology data of all structural genes of the TSE virus compared to other tick-borne flaviviruses showed that the TSE virus is a distinct member of the TBE virus subgroup. The data are consistent with the conclusion that the TSE virus evolved along a separate evolutionary path compared to its close antigenic relatives, the Western European, Far Eastern TBE viruses and the LI virus. By aligning the encoded amino acids in the glycoprotein of the viral envelope of flaviviruses transmitted by mosquitoes and ticks, we have also identified subgroup-specific pentapeptide motifs for subgroups of tick-borne encephalitis, Japanese encephalitis, and dengue viruses of the genus Flavivirus. These pentapeptides have important implications for the evolution, classification, and diagnosis of flaviviruses.
authors: Gao, G. F.;Hussain, M. H.;Reid, H. W.;Gould, E. A.

title: Analysis of viral genome and antiviral drug sensitivity of two patients from a familial cluster caused by influenza A(H7N9) virus in Zhejiang, China, 2013
abstract: Objectives: During the winter of 2013, people were at risk of human-to-human transmission of the reemerging influenza A(H7N9) virus. We report herein the clinical features of two patients from the same family infected with this virus, the genomic sequences of the harboring viruses, and susceptibility to antiviral drugs. Methods: Clinical and epidemiological data from two patients from the same family were collected and analyzed. The viruses isolated from these two patients and an epidemiologically related chicken were sequenced and the sequences of the eight gene segments of the viruses analyzed phylogenetically. The susceptibility of the viruses to antiviral drug treatment was determined by a neuraminidase inhibitor susceptibility test. Results: The two patients from a family cluster had the same symptoms but different outcomes and a strong epidemiological link. Three strains, two from these two patients and one from the chicken, were isolated. Genome sequencing and analysis of phylogenetic trees showed that the two viruses were almost identical. We identified the presence of the PB2 E627K amino acid substitution that was not present in the first wave isolates, as well as two new mutations in the NA gene and six in the PB2 gene. Drug susceptibility testing showed that the new isolates were resistant to oseltamivir but susceptible to peramivir. Conclusions: The two patients from a family cluster were probably cases of human-to-human transmission. The new isolates were susceptible to peramivir but showed reduced susceptibility to oseltamivir.
authors: Gao, H. N.;Yao, H. P.;Liang, W. F.;Wu, X. X.;Wu, H. B.;Wu, N. P.;Yang, S. G.;Zhang, Q.;Su, K. K.;Guo, J.;Zheng, S. F.;Zhu, Y. X.;Chen, H. L.;Yuen, K. Y.;Li, L. J.

title: Integrated analysis of microRNA-mRNA expression in A549 cells infected with influenza A viruses (IAVs) from different host species
abstract: Although multiple miRNAs have been shown to be involved in the influenza virus replication cycle, the identification of miRNAs and mRNAs expressed in A549 cells infected with influenza A viruses (IAVs) from different host species has been poorly explored. To investigate the molecular mechanisms associated with the differential expression of miRNAs during influenza A virus infection, we performed a global miRNA and mRNA expression profile in A549 cells infected with the seasonal influenza A virus H3N2 (Human_Br07 ) of human origin and infected with influenza A virus H1N1 of porcine origin (SW_3861) or influenza A virus H3N2 (AVI_9990) of avian origin. The miRNA and mRNA expression profiles were obtained by microarray and high-throughput sequencing analysis, respectively. Integrated analysis of differentially expressed miRNAs (DEMs) and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) was performed using bioinformatics tools, and expression of miRNAs and mRNAs was validated by real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR). We identified 20 miRNAs (6 upregulated and 14 downregulated) and 1286 mRNAs (935 upregulated and 351 downregulated) that show the same differential expression trends in three infected cell groups compared to an uninfected control. An integrated analysis of these expression profiles identified 79 miRNA-mRNA pairs associated with the influenza A reference pathway and 107 miRNA-mRNA interactions were correlated with defense against the virus. In addition, the obtained results were verified by RT-qPCR analysis of 8 differentially expressed miRNAs (hsa-miR-210-3p, hsa-miR-296-5p, hsa-miR-371a-5p, hsa-miR-762, hsa - miR-937-5p, hsa-miR-1915-3p, hsa-miR-3665 and hsa-miR-1290) and 13 differentially expressed mRNAs (IFNL1, CXCL10, RSAD2, MX1, OAS2, IFIT2, IFI44 L, MX2). , XAF1, NDRG1, FGA, EGLN3 and TFRC). Our results demonstrate that dysregulated miRNA expression plays a crucial role in infections caused by IAVs derived from different species and provide a basis for further investigations into the molecular regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs involved in influenza A virus infection involved.
authors: Gao, J.;Gao, L.;Li, R.;Lai, Z.;Zhang, Z.;Fan, X.

title: De novo assembly and functional annotations of the transcriptome of Metorchis orientalis (Trematoda: Opisthorchiidae)
abstract: Metorchis orientalis is a neglected zoonotic parasite that lives in the gallbladder and bile ducts of poultry and some mammals and humans. Despite its economic and medical importance, information on the M. orientalis transcriptome and genome is limited. In this study, we performed de novo sequencing, transcriptome assembly, and functional annotations of adult M. orientalis and obtained approximately 77.4 million high-quality clean reads, among which transcript contig lengths ranged from 100 to 11,249 nt lay, with a mean length of 373 nt and N50 length of 919 nt. We then assembled 31,943 unigenes, of which 20,009 (62.6%) were annotated by BLASTn and BLASTx searches against the available database. Of these unigens, 19,795 (62.0%), 3,407 (10.7%), and 10,620 (33.2%) had significant similarity in the NR, NT, and Swiss-Prot databases, respectively; 5744 (18.0%) and 4678 (14.6%) unigenes were assigned to GO and COG, respectively; and 9099 (28.5%) unigenes were identified and mapped to 256 pathways in the KEGG Pathway database. In addition, we found that 98 (1.08%) unigenes were associated with bile secretion and 5 (0.05%) with the category of primary bile acid biosynthetic pathways. The characterization of these transcriptomic data has implications for a better understanding of the biology of M. orientalis and will facilitate the development of intervention tools for this and other pathogen flukes of importance to human and animal health.
authors: Gao, J. F.;Gao, Y.;Qiu, J. H.;Chang, Q. C.;Zhang, Y.;Fang, M.;Wang, C. R.

title: Biological heterogeneity, including systemic replication in mice, of human H5N1 influenza A virus isolates in Hong Kong
abstract: An H5N1 avian influenza A virus was transmitted to humans in Hong Kong in 1997. Although the virus causes systemic infection due to the sensitivity of the hemagglutinin to furin and PC6 proteases and is highly lethal in chickens, it is not known whether it also causes systemic infection in humans. Clinical outcomes of the infection in Hong Kong residents ranged from mild respiratory illness to multiple organ failure leading to death. Therefore, to understand the pathogenesis of influenza due to these H5N1 isolates, we examined their virulence in mice. The results identified two distinct groups of viruses: Group 1, where the 50% mouse lethal dose (MLD50) ranged from 0.3 to 11 PFU, and Group 2, where the MLD50 was greater than 103 PFU. One day after intranasal inoculation of mice with 100 PFU of group 1 virus, the titer of virus in the lungs was 107 PFU/g or 3 log units higher than that for group 2 virus. Both virus types had resided in the lungs by day 3 replicated to high titers (>106 PFU/g) and maintained these titers through day 6. More importantly, only the group 1 viruses caused systemic infection and replicated in non-respiratory organs, including the brain. Immunohistochemical analyzes showed replication of a group 1 virus in brain neurons and glial cells as well as in myocardial fibers. Phylogenetic analysis of all viral genes showed that both groups of Hong Kong H5N1 viruses formed a lineage distinct from those of other viruses and that no genetic rearrangement between H5N1 and H1 or H3 human viruses had occurred. Because mice and humans harbor both the furin and PC6 proteases, we propose that the virulence mechanism responsible for avian influenza virus lethality also functions in mammalian hosts. The failure of some H5N1 viruses to elicit systemic infection in our model indicates that several yet-to-be-identified factors contribute to the severity of H5N1 infection in mammals. Furthermore, the ability of these viruses to induce systemic infection in mice and the marked differences in pathogenicity between the isolates examined here indicate that this system represents a useful model for studying the pathogenesis of avian influenza virus infection in mammals.
authors: Gao, P.;Watanabe, S.;Ito, T.;Goto, H.;Wells, K.;McGregor, M.;James Cooley, A.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Deep sequencing analysis of the DF-1 cell transcriptome response to duck Newcastle disease virus infection
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is caused by Newcastle disease virus (NDV) with respiratory and gastrointestinal mucosal bleeding with typical symptoms. It is an acute, highly sociable disease. NDV was able to proliferate in DF-1 cells. NDV of waterfowl differs from previous NDV of chickens, it causes death of waterfowl. But the molecular mechanisms of waterfowl infected with NDV are still poorly understood. In this study, researchers used the Illumina genomic analysis platform to perform genome-wide digital gene expression (DGE), a tag-based high-throughput transcriptome sequencing method to analyze DF-1 cells infected with NDV-YC. Researchers were able to reach a sequencing depth of 5.0-6.1 million tags per library and found more than 8000 genes differentially expressed during NDV-YC infection processes. Specifically, NDV-YC identified genes involved in I-kappaB kinase/NF-kappaB and TGF-beta signaling. Further analysis used Gene Ontology (GO) analyzes of cell parts, binding and biological regulation terms are main points respectively. The data serve to better understand the molecular mechanism of NDV-YC infection and provide a basis for further in vivo studies and clinical trials.
authors: Gao, S. M.;Sun, M. H.;Wang, Z. X.;Li, X. W.;Fan, H. Y.;Ren, T.

title: Whole genome shotgun sequencing revealed highly polymorphic genomic regions and genes in Escherichia coli O157:H7 isolates collected from a single feedlot
abstract: Escherichia coli serotype O157:H7 continues to pose a serious threat to human health. Cattle, a major reservoir of the pathogen, harbor E. coli O157:H7 in their gastrointestinal tract and express varying levels of E. coli O157:H7 to the environment. The genetic characterization of E. coli O157 strains from cattle stalls is of interest to the livestock, food processing and public health communities. In the present study, whole genome shotgun sequencing (WGS) and single nucleotide variant (SNV) calling were used to characterize 279 E. coli O157:H7 strains from cattle stalls isolated from a single feedlot in the Southwestern United States. More than 4,000 SNVs were identified among the phyla and the resulting pedigree showed three main groups. Using the Sakai tribe genome as a reference, more than 2,000 SNVs were annotated and a detailed SNV map was created. The results clearly revealed highly polymorphic loci along the E. coli O157:H7 genome that align with the prophage regions and highly variant genes involved in processing bacterial genetic information. The WGS data were further profiled using a comprehensive virulence factor database (VFDB) to identify virulence genes. Of the 285 virulence genes identified, only 132 were present in all strains. There were six virulence genes unique to individual isolates. Our results suggest that the genome variations of E. coli O157:H7 are mainly due to the dynamics of certain phages and the bacterial strains exhibit different virulence gene profiles despite originating from a single bovine population, which could explain the differences in pathogenicity, host prevalence and transmissibility E. coli O157:H7.
authors: Gao, X.;Yang, X.;Noll, L.;Shi, X.;Worley, J.;Allard, M.;Brown, E.;Nagaraja, T. G.;Meng, J.

title: Koolpinyah: A Kotonkan-related virus of cattle in northern Australia
abstract: Two closely related viruses have been isolated from the blood of cattle near Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia. When studies of virus morphology suggested that they were rhabdoviruses, serological studies were performed. These isolates are closely related or identical and related to, but distinct from, the rabies-related Kotonkan virus. Other serological studies indicated that they are two isolates of a newly recognized virus proposed to be named Koolpinyah virus.
authors: Gard, G. P.;Melville, L. F.;Calisher, C. H.;Karabatsos, N.

title: Genomic characterization of the vinegar hill virus, an Australian nairovirus isolated in 1983 from Argas Robertsi ticks collected from cattle egrets
abstract: This report describes the nearly complete genome sequence and subsequent analysis of Vinegar Hills virus (VINHV; provisional member of the genus Orthonairovirus, family Nairoviridae, order Bunyavirales). VINHV is the second nairovirus reported to have been isolated in mainland Australia and the first to be sequenced and analyzed. Our genetic analysis shows that VINHV belongs to the Dera Ghazi Khan genogroup, a group of viruses previously isolated in other parts of the world including Asia, South Africa and the US. We discuss possible entry routes for nairoviruses into Australia and the need to understand Australian tick virome in the context of new and emerging diseases.
authors: Gauci, P. J.;McAllister, J.;Mitchell, I. R.;Cybinski, D.;St George, T.;Gubala, A. J.

title: Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of bluetongue virus serotype 2 strains isolated in the Americas, including a new strain from the western United States
abstract: Bluetongue is a potentially fatal arboviral disease of domestic and wild ruminants characterized by widespread edema and tissue necrosis. Bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes 10, 11, 13, and 17 are found throughout much of the United States, while serotype 2 (BTV-2) has previously only been detected in the southeastern United States. Since 1998, 10 other BTV serotypes have also been isolated from ruminants in the southeastern United States. In 2010, BTV-2 was first identified in California, and preliminary sequence analysis showed that the virus isolate was closely related to BTV strains circulating in the southeastern United States. In the current study, the entire genome sequence of the Californian BTV-2 strain was compared to that of other BTV-2 strains in America. The results of the analysis indicate a co-circulation of genetically distinct viruses in the southeastern United States and further suggest that the western 2010 isolate is closely related to southeastern BTV strains. While it remains uncertain how this novel virus was transmitted to California, the results of the current study underscore the need for ongoing surveillance of this economically important animal disease.
authors: Gaudreault, N. N.;Mayo, C. E.;Jasperson, D. C.;Crossley, B. M.;Breitmeyer, R. E.;Johnson, D. J.;Ostlund, E. N.;MacLachlan, N. J.;Wilson, W. C.

title: Antigenic relationships between some animal rotaviruses: in vitro virus neutralization and cross-protection in piglets
abstract: The serotype, RNA electropherotype and cross-protective properties of rotaviruses isolated from canine, monkey, pig and human were compared. The bovine strain B:USA:78:1A and the canine strain C:USA:81:2 were adapted to cell culture and cloned in this study. The other viruses, ie, the simian strain S:USA:79:2, the Ohio State University porcine strain P:USA:77:1, and the human strain WA, were already cell culture-adapted, although they were further cloned for this work. The serum neutralization test was used to classify the viruses into serotype groups. Viruses showing a 20-fold or greater difference in neutralization titer were separated into different serotype groups. Four main groups of serotypes were found in this study and these groups were represented by bovine, human, porcine and canine simian strains. In cross-protection studies, these serotype groups were found to differ significantly. With the exception of the porcine strain, none of the viruses used as vaccines protected gnotobiotic piglets from challenge with the Ohio State University virulent porcine rotavirus strain. In addition, the canine virus protected the piglets from infection with the monkey virus. RNA electropherotype confirmed that the dog and monkey strains differed in eight RNA segments, ruling out the possibility that they were the same virus. From these results it was concluded that only viruses belonging to the same serotype group can confer cross-protection and therefore vaccines should be made with the serotypes to which the animal is likely to be exposed.
authors: Gaul, A. K.;Simpson, T. F.;Woode, G. N.;Fulton, R. W.

title: Hematological parameters in the blood of Maedi Visna virus infected and non-infected sheep
abstract: Maedi visna virus (MVV), classified as a lentivirus of the Retroviridae family, causes a very common, economically important disease in sheep in many parts of the world. The presence of the infection in Turkey has been demonstrated by investigations in previous studies. In this study, all blood samples were analyzed using ELISA and PCR to detect MVV antibody and antigen responses, respectively. Hematological findings were monitored and comparison was made of antibody and antigen positive naturally infected (n=5), antibody positive and antigen negative (n=20), antibody and antigen negative (n=20) in sheep accomplished. When infected sheep were compared to control sheep, Hgb and MPV parameters were shown to be statistically different (P<=0.001). These results suggested that MVV infection should be considered an important health risk for sheep flocks and Hgb and MPV blood parameters could be helpful in diagnosing MVV.
authors: Gazyagci, S.;Azkur, A. K.;Aslan, M. E.

title: An overview of influenza A virus receptors
abstract: Influenza A viruses are spherical particles that attach to cells through binding between hemagglutinin and specific cell receptors. Numerous studies conducted recently have shown that sialic acid (SA) is a critical component of influenza A virus receptors. This brief overview summarizes recent advances in our understanding of influenza A virus receptors. The introduction describes the classification of influenza A virus receptors and the review continues with an overview of the distribution of SA in various tissues and hosts. This is followed by research applications of influenza A virus receptors and why receptor studies are so important around the world. © 2011 Informa Healthcare USA, Inc.
authors: Ge, S.;Wang, Z.

title: Genetic diversity of novel circular ssDNA viruses in bats in China
abstract: Novel circular ssDNA genomes have recently been detected in animals and the environment using metagenomic and high-throughput sequencing approaches. In this study, five full-length circular ssDNA genomes were recovered from bat fecal samples using inverse PCR with sequences based on circovirus-related sequences derived from Solexa sequencing data derived from a random amplification method. These five sequences shared a genomic organization similar to that of the circovirus or the recently proposed cyclovirus of the Circoviridae family. The newly obtained circovirus/cyclovirus-like genomes ranged from 1.741 to 21.77 bp and each consisted of two major ORFs, ORF1 and ORF2, encoding putative replicase (Rep) and capsid (Cap) proteins, respectively. The potential stem-loop region was predicted in all five genomes, and three of them had the typical conserved cycloviral nonanucleotide motif. A series of primers targeting the conserved Rep region were designed and used to detect the prevalence of circovirus/cyclovirus sequences in individual bats. Of 199 specimens tested, 47 were positive (23.6%) for the circovirus genome and two (1.0%) were positive for the cyclovirus genome. A total of 48 partial Rep sequences plus the five full-length genomes were obtained in this study. Detailed analysis showed that these sequences are distantly related to known circovirus/cyclovirus genomes and potentially represent 22 new species belonging to the Circoviridae family.
authors: Ge, X. Y.;Li, J. L.;Peng, C.;Wu, L. J.;Yang, X. L.;Wu, Y. Q.;Zhang, Y. Z.;Shi, Z. L.

title: Epidemic of wild-origin H1NX avian influenza virus in Anhui, China
abstract: Background: As natural hosts of avian influenza viruses (AIVs), aquatic and migratory birds provide a gene pool for interspecies and interspecies genetic transfer, forming transient 'genome constellations'. This work describes the phylogenetic dynamics of H1NX based on the full molecular characterization of eight genes from viruses collected in 2014-2015 in Anhui Province, China. Methods: Hemagglutination and hemagglutination inhibition assays were used to determine the hemagglutination (HA) activity of the HA subtypes. The entire genomes of the viruses were sequenced on an ABI PRISM 3500xl DNA Analyzer. The sequences were genetically analyzed to examine their genetic evolution with DNASTAR and MEGA 6. The pathogenic effects of the viruses were assessed using mouse infection models. Results: Seven strains of H1 subtype avian influenza virus were isolated. Phylogenetic analysis showed natural recombination of H1 influenza viruses between the Eurasian lineage and the North American lineage. Some genes had high sequence identity with A/Boan Goose/Korea/220/2011(H9N2), which is a case in point involving a viral rearrangement between the Eurasian lineage and the North American lineage. The results of infection experiments on mice showed that the viruses could acquire the ability to multiply in the respiratory organs of mice without adaptation. Conclusions: These results suggest that continuous surveillance of wild birds, especially migratory birds, is important to provide early warning of potential H1 influenza epidemics and to understand the ecology of the virus.
authors: Ge, Y.;Yao, Q. C.;Wang, X. F.;Fan, Z. Q.;Deng, G. H.;Chai, H. L.;Chen, H. L.;Hua, Y. P.

title: Genetically distinct subtypes of avian influenza A virus with low pathogenicity co-circulate among poultry in Bangladesh
abstract: Influenza virus surveillance, poultry outbreak studies, and genomic sequencing were assessed to understand the ecology and evolution of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) A viruses in Bangladesh from 2007 to 2013. We analyzed 506 bird samples collected from poultry at live bird markets and backyard flocks to identify influenza A virus. Virus isolation-positive specimens (n=50) were subtyped and their coding complete genomes were sequenced. The most commonly identified subtypes among LPAI isolates were H9N2, H11N3, H4N6 and H1N1. Less frequently detected subtypes were H1N3, H2N4, H3N2, H3N6, H3N8, H4N2, H5N2, H6N1, H6N7 and H7N9. Gene sequences were compared to publicly available sequences using phylogenetic inference approaches. Among the 14 subtypes identified, the majority of viral gene segments were most closely related to avian or wild bird viruses, which are commonly found in Southeast Asia, Europe and/or North Africa. LPAI subtypes were distributed across multiple geographic locations in Bangladesh, and surface and internal protein gene segments phylogenetically congested with a variety of viral subtypes, suggesting an extensive rearrangement of these LPAI viruses. Viruses of the H9N2 subtype differed from other LPAI subtypes as genes from these viruses were consistently clustered, suggesting that this subtype is enzootic in Bangladesh. The H9N2 strains identified in Bangladesh were phylogenetically and antigenically related to previous human-derived H9N2 viruses discovered in Bangladesh and a potential source of human infection. In contrast, the circulating LPAI H5N2 and H7N9 viruses were unrelated, both phylogenetically and antigenically, to H5 viruses previously identified in humans in Bangladesh and to H7N9 strains isolated from humans in China. In Bangladesh, domestic fowl sold in live bird markets contained a variety of LPAI virus subtypes and a wide variety of genotypes. These results, combined with the seven-year sampling time frame, indicate continued circulation of these viruses in the country.
authors: Gerloff, N. A.;Khan, S. U.;Zanders, N.;Balish, A.;Haider, N.;Islam, A.;Chowdhury, S.;Rahman, M. Z.;Haque, A.;Hosseini, P.;Gurley, E. S.;Luby, S. P.;Wentworth, D. E.;Donis, R. O.;Sturm-Ramirez, K.;Davis, C. T.

title: Microarray resources for chicken genetic and genomic studies: A review
abstract: The advent of microarray technologies revolutionized the nature and scope of genetic and genomic research in humans and other species, enabling massive parallel analysis of thousands of genomic sites. They have been used for various purposes, e.g. B. for transcriptome analysis, CNV detection, SNP and CNV genotyping, study of DNA-protein interaction and detection of genome methylation. Microarrays have also made invaluable contributions to research in the chicken, which is an important model organism for the study of embryology, immunology, oncology, virology, evolution, genetics and genomics, as well as other avian species. Despite their tremendous contribution to life science research, the future of microarrays is now being questioned with the advent of Massively Parallel Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) technologies that promise to overcome some of the limitations of microarray platforms. In this article, we discuss the various microarray resources that have been developed for chickens and their past and potential future applications. We also discuss the future of microarrays in the NGS era, especially in the context of livestock genetics. We argue that although NGS promises some major benefits - notably the possibility of discovering new elements in the genome - microarrays will continue to be important tools for research and practice in the field of livestock genetics/genomics due to their high affordability, throughput nature, mature mainstream technologies and easy application. Furthermore, NGS and microarrays are expected to complement each other in future life sciences research with the emergence of new microarray technologies such as capture arrays. © 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
authors: Gheyas, A. A.;Burt, D. W.

title: Transforming animal genomics by next-generation sequencing technologies: a decade of challenges and their impact on genetic architecture
abstract: For more than a quarter century, sequencing technologies ranging from the Sanger method to next-generation high-throughput techniques have provided fascinating opportunities in the life sciences. The continued upward trend in sequencing technologies will enhance livestock research and accelerate the development of various new livestock genomic and technological studies. The use of high-throughput technologies in livestock research has increased interest in metagenomics, epigenetics, genome-wide association studies, and the identification of single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variations. Such studies are beginning to provide revolutionary insights into biological and evolutionary processes. Livestock such as cattle, pigs, and horses have served dual roles as economically and agriculturally important animals and as biomedical research models. The first part of this study examines the current state of sequencing methods, many of which are already used in animal genomic studies, and the second part summarizes the state of the art in bovine, porcine, equine and chicken genome sequencing and illustrates its achievements during the last few Years. Finally, we describe several high-throughput sequencing approaches for improved detection of known, unknown, and emerging infectious agents, leading to better diagnosis of infectious diseases. Insights from viral metagenomics and advances in next-generation sequencing will strongly support specific and efficient vaccine development and provide strategies to control transmission of infectious diseases between animal populations and/or between animals and humans. However, future sequencing technologies will require further research and field trials before commercialization.
authors: Ghosh, M.;Sharma, N.;Singh, A. K.;Gera, M.;Pulicherla, K. K.;Jeong, D. K.

title: Genetic Detection and Characterization of Emerging HoBi-Like Viruses in Archived Fetal Bovine Serum Lots
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) are members of the pestivirus genus within the family Flaviviridae. Based on antigen and nucleotide differences, BVDV is divided into two recognized species, BVDV-1 and BVDV-2. More recently, a new putative pestivirus species tentatively named "HoBi-like" has been associated with viral bovine diarrhea. HoBi-like viruses were first identified in fetal bovine serum (FBS) imported from Brazil. Subsequently, a number of HoBi-like viruses were detected as contaminants in FBS or cell cultures and in live ruminants. In order to further investigate the possible pestivirus contamination in commercial FBS batches, 26 FBS batches with different countries of origin were tested for the presence of bovine pestiviruses in this study. All 26 batches were positive by RT-PCR for at least one bovine pestivirus species. HoBi-like viruses were detected in 15 batches. Analysis of the 5'UTR and Npro sequences of 15 newly identified HoBi-like viruses combined with analysis of additional sequences from GenBank identified 4 genetic groups tentatively named 3a-3d. The current study confirmed the presence of the emerging HoBi-like viruses in FBS products labeled with different geographic origins. This finding has obvious implications for the safety of biological products such as cell lines and vaccines.
authors: Giammarioli, M.;Ridpath, J. F.;Rossi, E.;Bazzucchi, M.;Casciari, C.;De Mia, G. M.

title: Current taxonomy of bovine virus diarrhea virus type 1 according to the method of palindromic nucleotide substitutions
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 pestivirus is responsible for cosmopolitan diseases affecting cattle and other ruminants, showing a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations with relevant implications for zootechnical production. Understanding genomic features and virus taxonomy is fundamental to maintaining control and prophylaxis programs. In view of the recent various studies reporting a relatively high number of new strains, especially from Asian countries, four hundred and eighty-two genomic sequences were evaluated in the present study using the palindromic nucleotide substitution method for genotyping. Based on secondary structure orientation and calculation of the genetic distance between strains in the 5 inch untranslated region of pestivirus RNA, the current taxonomy of the species was reviewed. Twenty-two genotypes were identified using a nomenclature based on divergence in the genus.
authors: Giangaspero, M.;Apicella, C.

title: Classification of the peste des petits ruminants virus as the fourth member of the Morbillivirus genus
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is a viral disease of sheep and goats in West Africa. When it was first described, the virus was considered a variant of the rinderpest virus. The biological and physico-chemical properties of the virus indicate a close relationship with measles, rinderpest and canine distemper viruses. These three viruses form the Morbillivirus genus of the Paramyxoviridae. The PPR virus is sufficiently different from these 3 viruses to be considered the fourth member of the Morbillivirus genus.
authors: Gibbs, E. P. J.;Taylor, W. P.;Lawman, M. J. P.;Bryant, J.

title: Phage therapy in methane enhancement in livestock
authors: Gilbert, R. A.;Ouwerkerk, D.;Klieve, A. V.

title: Whole genome sequencing in outbreak analysis
abstract: In addition to the ever-present concern of healthcare professionals about infectious disease epidemics, the relatively easy access and low cost of obtaining, manufacturing, and spreading pathogenic organisms or biological toxins means that bioterrorist activities should also be considered in the event of a disease outbreak. The use of whole genome sequencing (WGS) in outbreak analysis facilitates the rapid and accurate identification of pathogen virulence factors and can be used to identify the route of transmission of the disease within a population and provide information on the likely source. Molecular tools like WGS are being refined and advanced at a rapid pace to provide robust and high-resolution methods for identifying, comparing, and classifying pathogenic organisms. When properly applied, these methods of characterizing pathogens enable an improved public health response, whether an outbreak is triggered by natural events or by accidental or deliberate human activities. The current application of next-generation sequencing technology (NGS) to microbial WGS and microbial forensics will be reviewed.
authors: Gilchrist, C. A.;Turner, S. D.;Riley, M. F.;Petri, W. A.;Hewlett, E. L.

title: Massive depletion of bovine leukemia virus proviral clones residing in genomically transcriptionally active sites during primary infection
abstract: Deltaretroviruses such as human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) and bovine leukemia virus (BLV) induce persistent infection that is generally asymptomatic but can also lead to leukemia or lymphoma. These viruses replicate by infecting new lymphocytes (ie, infection cycle) or by clonal expansion of infected cells (mitotic cycle). The relative importance of these two cycles in viral replication varies during infection. The majority of infected clones are generated early before the onset of an efficient immune response. Later, the main replication pathway is mitotic expansion of pre-existing infected clones. Few data are available on early infection by HTLV-1 due to the lack of available samples and for ethical reasons. We have therefore pursued this question in a comparative BLV model. We used high-throughput sequencing to map and quantify the provirus insertion sites to monitor the clonality of the BLV-infected cell population (i.e. the number of distinct clones and frequency of each clone). We found that BLV proliferation shifts from cellular neoinfection to clonal proliferation within approximately 2 months post-inoculation. Initially, proviral BLV integration favors significantly transcribed regions of the genome. Negative selection then eliminates 97% of the clones detected in seroconversion and discriminates against BLV-infected cells carrying a provirus located near a promoter or gene. Nevertheless, among the surviving proviruses, cloning frequency is positively correlated with the proximity of the provirus to a transcribed region. Two opposing forces are thus at work during primary infection and dictate the fate of long-term clonal composition: (1) initial integration into genes or promoters, and (2) negative host selection that discriminates against proviruses located adjacent to transcribed regions. The outcome of this initial response contributes to the proviral load set point, as clone frequency benefits from carrying a provirus in transcribed regions. © 2013 Gillet et al.
authors: Gillet, N. A.;GutiÃ©rrez, G.;Rodriguez, S. M.;de Brogniez, A.;Renotte, N.;Alvarez, I.;Trono, K.;Willems, L.

title: Small noncoding RNAs of bovine leukemia virus are functional elements that regulate replication and contribute to oncogenesis in vivo
abstract: Retroviruses are not expected to encode miRNAs due to the potential problem of self-cleavage of their genomic RNAs. This assumption has recently been challenged by experiments showing that bovine leukemia virus (BLV) encodes miRNAs from intragenomic Pol III promoters. The BLV miRNAs are abundantly expressed in B-cell tumors in the absence of significant levels of genomic and subgenomic viral RNA. Using deep RNA sequencing and functional reporter assays, we show that miRNAs mediate expression of genes involved in cell signaling, cancer, and immunity. We further show that BLV miRNAs are essential to induce B cell tumors in an experimental model and to promote efficient viral replication in the natural host.
authors: Gillet, N. A.;Hamaidia, M.;de Brogniez, A.;Gutierrez, G.;Renotte, N.;Reichert, M.;Trono, K.;Willems, L.

title: Sequence analysis of bovine herpesvirus type 5 (BHV-5) alpha-trans-inducing factor
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus (BHV), a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily, is divided into neurovirulent and non-neurovirulent subtypes based on different neuropathicities. Transcription of viral immediate-early (IE) genes during alphaherpesvirus gene expression is mediated by a multicomponent immediate-early complex (IEC) mediated by the viral tegument protein alpha-trans-inducing factor (α-tif ), a host cell protein (HCF), and an octamer host protein (Oct). In this paper, we present a sequence analysis of the α-tif of the BHV encephalitic subtype, bovine herpesvirus type 5 (BHV-5). Bovine herpesvirus type 1 (BHV-1) and BHV-5 α-tifs share 98% amino acid sequence homology. However, BHV-5 α-tif is 23 residues shorter at the amino terminus than BHV-1 α-tif. The amino acid alignment of the α-tifs of BHV-1 and BHV-5 with other alphaherpesviruses indicates areas of conserved motifs, but also important differences located mainly at the amino and carboxyl termini.
authors: Gillette, K.;Misra, V.;Bratanich, A.

title: Neuropathotyping: a new system for classifying Marek's disease virus
abstract: statistical approach was used to establish a new classification system of Marek's disease virus (MDV) based on neurological responses. To develop the system, neurological response data from 15 x 7 chickens vaccinated with 30 strains of serotype 1 MDV were statistically analyzed by cluster analysis. The aim was to identify a statistical system that checks whether three neurovirulence groups correlate with the three pathotypes described above. The system was also validated in two other strains of specific pathogen free (SPF) chickens, SPAFAS and line SC (Hy-Vac). The proposed system is based on the analysis of three variables: 1) frequency of birds showing transient paralysis between 9 and 11 days post-inoculation (dpi), (2) mortality before 15 dpi, and (3) frequency of birds that between the 21 and 23 dpi. Using this system, an MDV can be classified into one of three groups, referred to as neuropathotypes A, B and C, which roughly correspond to virulent, very virulent and very virulent plus pathotypes, respectively. However, the correlation between neuropathotype and pathotype was not absolute, and neuropathotyping is an adjunct to the current pathotyping system rather than a replacement for it. Our results indicated that neuropathotyping studies can be performed in two types of commercial SPF chickens using the same variables, although the system would first have to be standardized using prototype viruses. Neuropathotypes can also be estimated with reasonable accuracy using our statistical analysis. Using this analysis, we found that MDV strains can be subdivided into neuropathotypes B and C within the highly virulent pathotype, creating a previously unrecognized pathotypic classification. This finding illustrates how neuropathotyping can augment important information not identified by traditional pathotyping.
authors: Gimeno, I. M.;Witter, R. L.;Neumann, U.

title: Natural transmission and comparative analysis of small ruminant lentiviruses in the Norwegian sheep and goat populations
abstract: Serological testing for small ruminant lentivirus (SRLV) infection has revealed seropositive sheep in several mixed flocks in which sheep are housed with seropositive goats. Here we examined the genetic relationships in LTR, pol, and env surface units (SU) and growth patterns in goat (GSM) and sheep (FOS) synovial membrane cell cultures of SRLV isolates derived from both mixed and single herds of species have been preserved. Phylogenetic analyzes of pol and env SU revealed that Norwegian SRLVs derived from both goats and sheep in mixed flocks are distributed in group C, while isolates derived from unmixed flocks of sheep are distributed in group A along with maedi-visna- similar representatives of the A1 subtype are grouped. In this study it is proposed that transmission of group C virus occurs from goat to sheep. The replication efficiency in GSM and FOS cultures and the cytopathic phenotype induced by the SRLV isolates did not indicate species-specific traits. No specific nucleotide sequences of the LTR-U3 region or env-SU that could be associated with the cytopathic phenotype were identified. This study shows that sheep in Norway harbor SRLVs belonging to phylogenetic groups A and C, and this provides further evidence that cross-species infection is a regular feature of SRLVs, which can be an important source of virus persistence. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Gjerset, B.;Jonassen, C. M.;Rimstad, E.

title: Characterization of microRNAs encoded by the bovine herpesvirus 1 genome
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus 1 (BoHV-1) is a ubiquitous and important pathogen of cattle worldwide. This study reports the identification of 10 microRNA (miRNA) genes, Bhv1-mir-B1-Bhv1-mir-B10, encoded by the BoHV-1 genome, which were processed into 12 detectable mature miRNAs, as determined by ultra-high throughput sequencing -Bioinformatic analysis was determined from small RNA libraries and expression studies. We found that four of the miRNA genes were present as two copies in the BoHV-1 genome, resulting in a total of 14 miRNA-encoding loci. Unique features of the BoHV-1 miRNAs include evidence of bidirectional transcription and a tight association of two miRNA genes with the origin of replication, including one miRNA encoded within the origin of replication. The miRNA gene Bhv1-mir-B5 was encoded on the opposite DNA strand of the latency-associated transcript, possibly resulting in antisense transcripts derived from this locus. The association of herpesvirus miRNAs with latency appears to be a common feature of alphaherpesviruses. Analyzes of the BoHV-5 genome for putative miRNA gene orthologs identified a high degree of evolutionary conservation for nine of the BoHV-1 miRNA genes. The possible roles for BoHV-1 miRNAs in the regulation of known BoHV-1 transcription units and the genetics of BoHV-1 genotypes are also discussed. © 2010 The State of Queensland acts through the Department for Employment, Economic Development and Innovation.
authors: Glazov, E. A.;Horwood, P. F.;Assavalapsakul, W.;Kongsuwan, K.;Mitchell, R. W.;Mitter, N.;Mahony, T. J.

title: Epidemiological and molecular analysis of an outbreak of the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 class 2.3.4.4 in a German zoo: effective disease control with minimal cull
abstract: Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus (HPAIV) subtype H5N8 strain 2.3.4.4 were first reported in South Korea in January 2014. These viruses spread rapidly to Europe and the North American continent in autumn 2014 and caused five outbreaks in poultry farms in Germany up to February 2015. Birds kept in a zoo in north-eastern Germany were also affected. Few individual white storks (Ciconia ciconia) showed clinical symptoms and eventually died in the course of infection, although later detailed diagnostic investigations showed that other birds kept in the same white stork enclosure were acutely positive or had undergone asymptomatic infection with HPAIV H5N8 . An exemption from culling all 500 remaining zoo birds was granted by the competent authority. The containment measures included grouping the zoo birds into eight epidemiological units, in which 60 birds from each unit tested repeatedly negative for H5N8. Epidemiological and phylogenetic investigations indicated that the most likely source of introduction was direct or indirect contact with infected wild birds, as white storks had access to a small pond frequented by wild mallards and other aquatic wild birds over a 10-day period in December 2014. Median network analysis showed that the zoobird viruses segregated into a distinct clade 2.3.4.4 cluster with closest associations to H5N8 isolates recovered from mute swans (Cygnus olor) in Sweden in April 2015. This case shows that there are alternatives to culling to save valuable animals in avifaunistic collections after HPAIV incursions.
authors: Globig, A.;Starick, E.;Homeier, T.;Pohlmann, A.;Grund, C.;Wolf, P.;Zimmermann, A.;Wolf, C.;Heim, D.;SchlÃ¶ÃŸer, H.;Zander, S.;Beer, M.;Conraths, F. J.;Harder, T. C.

title: Subtyping swine influenza viruses using a high-throughput real-time PCR platform
abstract: Influenza A viruses (IAVs) are important human and animal pathogens with significant impacts on human and animal health. In Denmark, a passive surveillance program for IAV in pigs has been in place since 2011, using screening testing and subsequent subtyping by real-time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) with reverse transcription. A disadvantage of the current subtyping system is that multiple assays are required to cover the wide range of circulating subtypes, making the system expensive and time consuming. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to develop a high-throughput method that could improve the surveillance of swine influenza viruses (swIAVs) and reduce the cost of virus subtyping. Twelve qPCR assays specific for different hemagglutinin and neuraminidase gene lines relevant to swIAV and six assays specific for the internal genes of IAV were developed and applied to the high-throughput qPCR platform BioMark (Fluidigm ) optimized. The qPCR assays were validated and optimized to run under the same reaction conditions using a 48.48 dynamic array (48.48 DA). Sensitivity and specificity were evaluated by testing virus isolates and field samples with known subtypes. The results showed swIAV 48.48DA performance similar to conventional real-time analysis and, moreover, the specificity of swIAV 48.48DA was very high with no cross-reactions between assays. This high-throughput system offers a cost-effective alternative to subtyping swIAVs.
authors: Goecke, N. B.;Krog, J. S.;Hjulsager, C. K.;Skovgaard, K.;Harder, T. C.;Breum, S. Ã˜;Larsen, L. E.

title: Potential for co-infection with a mosquito-specific flavivirus, Nhumirim virus, to block transmission of West Nile virus in mosquitoes
abstract: Nhumirim virus (NHUV) is an insect-specific virus phylogenetically related to mosquito-borne two-host flaviviruses. Previous in vitro coinfection experiments showed that prior or simultaneous infection of Aedes albopictus C6/36 mosquito cells with NHUV resulted in a 10,000-fold reduction in West Nile virus (WNV) virus production. This interference between WNV and NHUV was observed herein in an additional Ae. albopictus mosquito cell line, C7-10. A mutant of the WNV 2K peptide (V9M) capable of superinfection with a previously established WNV infection showed a comparable level of interference by NHUV as the parental WNV strain in C6/36 and C7-10 cells . Culex quinquefasciatus and Culex pipiens mosquitoes inoculated intrathoracically with NHUV and WNV or with WNV alone as a control were allowed to extrinsically incubate the viruses for up to nine and 14 days, respectively, and transmissibility and replication of WNV was determined. The proportion of Cx. quinquefasciatus mosquitoes, which can transmit WNV, was significantly lower at seven and nine days post-inoculation (dpi) for the WNV/NHUV group than the WNV control, while no differences in Cx were observed. Pipien's Vaccination Group. By dpi nine, a 40% reduction in transmissibility was observed in mosquitoes from the double vaccination group compared to the WNV-only control group. These data indicate the potential that infection of some Culex spp. Vectors containing NHUV could serve as a barrier for efficient transmissibility of flaviviruses associated with human diseases.
authors: Goenaga, S.;Kenney, J. L.;Duggal, N. K.;Delorey, M.;Ebel, G. D.;Zhang, B.;Levis, S. C.;Enria, D. A.;Brault, A. C.

title: The interplay between MDV and HVT affects viral miRNA expression
abstract: It is well known that herpesviruses encode numerous microRNAs (miRNAs) and that these virally encoded small RNAs play multiple roles in infection. The present study was performed to determine how co-infection of a pathogenic MDV serotype 1 (MDV1) (MD5) strain and a vaccine strain (turkey herpesvirus [HVT]) alters viral miRNA expression in vivo. We first used small RNA depth sequencing to identify MDV1-encoded miRNAs expressed in tumorigenic spleens of MDV1-infected birds. The expression patterns of these miRNAs were then further examined at an early time point (7 days post-infection [dpi]) and a late time point (42 dpi) in birds with and without HVT vaccination using real-time PCR (RT-PCR). In addition, the effect of MDV1 co-infection on HVT-encoded miRNAs was determined using RT-PCR. A diverse population of miRNAs was expressed in MDV-induced tumorigenic spleens at 42 dpi, representing 18 of the 26 known mature miRNAs. Of these, both mdv1-miR-M4-5p and mdv1-miR-M2-3p were the most highly expressed miRNAs. RT-PCR analysis further revealed that nine MDV miRNAs between 7 dpi and 42 dpi were differentially expressed in infected spleens. At 7 dpi, three miRNAs were differentially expressed between the spleens of birds co-infected with HVT and MD5 compared to birds individually infected with MD5, while at 42 dpi nine miRNAs were differentially expressed. At 7 dpi, expression of seven HVT-encoding miRNAs was impaired in the spleens of co-infected birds compared to birds receiving the HVT vaccine alone. At 42 dpi, six HVT-encoded miRNAs were differentially expressed between the two groups. Target prediction analyzes indicate that these differentially expressed viral miRNAs are involved in the regulation of multiple cellular processes, including cell proliferation and the adaptive immune response. © American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Goher, M.;Hicks, J. A.;Liu, H. C.

title: Application of phylogeny reconstruction and character development analysis to derive patterns of directed microbial transmission
abstract: used phylogenetic analyzes to reconstruct patterns of directed interspecific transmission during a 1989 outbreak of pseudorabies virus in Illinois, USA. Isolates were obtained from five species: cattle, sheep, goats, pigs and raccoons (Procyon lotor). I generated DNA sequences for 16 isolates of pseudorabies virus at the glycoprotein C gene, from which I constructed pedigrees. I then used these trees in combination with sparse character development analyzes to infer the frequency and direction of interspecific transference events. Comparison of the derived frequencies and transmission directions with null expectations based on 10,000 random trees showed a significant excess of transmission events from pigs to pigs and a corresponding lack of transmission events from non-pig species. These results are consistent with the known biology and natural history of the pseudorabies virus, and they demonstrate that retrospective phylogeny reconstruction and character evolution analyzes can be used to study the transmission ecology of pathogens. © 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Goldberg, T. L.

title: Bluetongue virus serotype 24 (BTV-24) in Israel: phylogenetic characterization and clinical manifestation of the disease
abstract: Bluetongue (BT), an arthropod-borne viral disease of ruminants, affects sheep worst than other domestic animals. Bluetongue virus serotype 24 (BTV-24) is one of 26 known bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes. In this article we present data from the phylogenetic analysis of 9 viral genes (Seg1, Seg2, Seg3, Seg4, Seg5, Seg6, Seg8, Seg9 and Seg10) from 8 Israeli BTV-24 isolates and refer to the BTV-24 genotype Isolates on their phenotype in terms of clinical manifestations. The high degree of genetic identity (>99.6%) between Seg2, Seg4 and Seg5 in all 8 BTV-24 isolates indicated that these segments shared the same viral ancestor. The phylogenetic analysis of Seg1, Seg3, Seg5, Seg8, Seg9 and Seg10 revealed that the Israeli BTV-24 strains comprised 4 variants. Five of the viruses showed high identity in all 9 segments and represented variant 1. A second variant (BTV24/3027/6/10) isolated in 2010 showed significant deviation from variant 1 in 3 gene segments (VP-1, VP-3 and NS-3 genes). A third variant (BTV24/3027/1/10) showed a significant deviation from variant 1 in 6 segments (VP-1, VP-3, VP-6 and NS-1, NS-2 and NS- 3 genes). a fourth variant (BTV24/2214/1/10) showed a significant deviation from variant 1 in 4 segments (VP-1, NS-1, NS-2 and NS-3 genes). These marked differences in sequence identity indicate that a high level of genetic rearrangement is occurring between co-circulating BTV strains in Israel.
authors: Golender, N.;Panshin, A.;Brenner, J.;Rotenberg, D.;Oura, C.;Khinich, E.;Bumbarov, V.

title: Biological and Molecular Aspects of Bovine Herpesvirus 4 (BHV-4)
abstract: This review article summarizes the latest information on bovine cytomegalovirus BHV-4. The virus is not associated with well-defined clinical entities in cattle. It can be easily isolated in tissue culture and has a broad host range. BHV-4 strains are quite similar in restriction enzyme analysis of their DNAs, but the size of the pr DNAs differs. The genome represents a γ-herpesvirus. Because of its uniqueness, BHV-4 is being discussed as a suitable vector.
authors: Goltz, M.;Ludwig, H.

title: Review article compte rendu viral enteritis in calves
abstract: complex community of bacteria, viruses, fungi, protists and other microorganisms inhabit the gastrointestinal tract of calves and play an important role in gut health and disease. The viral component of the microbiome (the virome) is receiving increasing attention for its role in neonatal calf diarrhea (NCD). Rotavirus and coronavirus have long been associated with noncommunicable diseases, and commercial vaccines against these pathogens have been produced. Recently, several other viruses that may play a role in diarrhea have been detected in calf fecal samples, mainly by sequence-based methods. These viruses include torovirus, norovirus, nebovirus, astrovirus, kobuvirus, and enterovirus. Most studies included epidemiological investigations aimed at showing an association with diarrhea for each virus alone or in combination with potential pathogens. However, determining the contribution of these viruses to calf diarrhea has been challenging, and much uncertainty remains regarding their roles as primary pathogens, co-infectious agents, or commensals.
authors: Gomez, D. E.;Weese, J. S.

title: Genetic diversity of bovine viral diarrhea virus in cattle from Mexico
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) infects cattle populations worldwide and causes significant economic losses through its impact on animal health. Previous studies have reported the prevalence of BVDV species and subgenotypes in cattle from the United States and Canada. We examined the genetic diversity of BVDV strains detected in bovine serum samples from 6 different regions of Mexico. 62 BVDV isolates from Mexico were genetically typed based on a comparison of sequences from the 5 inch untranslated region (5-UTR) of the viral genome. The phylogenetic reconstruction showed that 60 of the samples belonged to the BVDV-1 genotype and 2 to the BVDV-2 genotype. Comparison of partial 5-UTR sequences revealed 49 samples within BVDV-1c, 8 samples within BVDV-1a, 3 samples within BVDV-1b, and 2 samples clustered with the BVDV-2a subgenotypes. Our study, combined with information previously published on the diversity of BVDV field strains in the United States and Canada, benefits the development of effective detection assays, vaccines and control programs for North America.
authors: GÃ³mez-Romero, N.;Basurto-AlcÃ¡ntara, F. J.;Verdugo-RodrÃ­guez, A.;Bauermann, F. V.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Detection of border disease virus in Mexican cattle
abstract: The genus Pestivirus within the Flaviviridae consists of four recognized species, namely Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus 1 (BVDV-1), Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus 2 (BVDV-2), Border Disease Virus (BDV) and Classic Swine Pest Virus (CSFV). . Although BDV primarily infects sheep and goats, it has also been reported in cattle and wild animals. Infections of sheep and goats result in economic losses due to miscarriage and the birth of permanently infected animals that have poor production and reduced life expectancy. In this study, we report the detection of BDV in bovine serum collected as part of the pestivirus surveillance program from six regions of Mexico where a BVDV seroprevalence of 67.1% was previously calculated. Phylogenetic analyzes based on a comparison of the 5-UTR region typed the Mexican strains as BDV-1. Border disease (BD) is listed as an exotic disease in Mexico and the origin of the BDV found in these cattle is unclear. This is the first detection of BDV in Mexican cattle.
authors: GÃ³mez-Romero, N.;Basurto-AlcÃ¡ntara, F. J.;Verdugo-RodrÃ­guez, A.;Lagunes-Quintanilla, R.;Bauermann, F. V.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: A pathologic study of the perisinusoidal unit of the liver in acute African swine fever
abstract: African swine fever is an acute swine hemorrhagic disease that can serve as a model for studying the pathogenesis of other viral hemorrhagic fevers. This article describes an ultrastructural study of the sequence of lesions generated in the perisinusoidal functional unit of the liver of pigs vaccinated with the Malawi '83 strain of African swine fever virus, classified as haemaadsorbent and highly virulent. Virus replication was observed in Kupffer cells and monocytes from three days post-inoculation, in hepatocytes and adipose cells at five and seven days post-inoculation, and in sinusoidal endothelial cells at seven days post-inoculation. Additional observations included intravascular coagulation peaking five days post-inoculation and fibroblast and myofibroblast transformation of fat-storing cells seven days post-inoculation. These results suggest that activated cells of the mononuclear phagocytic system may play a major role in this lesion sequence, and the possible role of the cytokines released by these cells is discussed.
authors: GÃ³mez-Villamandos, J. C.;HervÃ¡s, J.;MÃ©ndez, A.;Carrasco, L.;Villeda, C. J.;Sierra, M. A.;Wilkonson, P. J.

title: Molecular study of bovine viral diarrhea virus infection in yaks (Bos gruniens) from Qinghai, China
abstract: Background: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a pestivirus that infects both domestic and wild animal species worldwide. In China, cattle are often infected with BVDV of different genotypes, but there is very limited knowledge about BVDV infection in Chinese yaks and the genetic diversity of the virus. The aims of this study were to detect viral infection in yaks in Qinghai, China and to determine the genotypes of BVDV based on 5-untranslated region (5-UTR) and N-terminal protease (N <sup>pro </sup>) region. Results: Between 2010 and 2012, 407 blood samples were collected from yaks with or without clinical symptoms in six counties of Qinghai Province. Ninety-eight samples (24%) were positive by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) targeting a conserved region of BVDV-1 and BVDV-2. The nucleotide sequences of the 5-UTR and the complete N<sup>pro</sup> region were determined for 16 positive samples. Phylogenetic reconstructions showed that all 16 samples belong to the subgenotypes BVDV-1b, BVDV-1d and BVDV-1q. Conclusions: This study provides for the first time molecular evidence for BVDV infection in Qinghai yaks involving multiple subgenotypes of BVDV-1. This may have happened under three possible scenarios: transmission between species, natural infection, and use of vaccines contaminated with BVDV. The findings have important implications for yak production and management in China, notably suggesting that unscientific vaccination practices should be stopped and biosecurity increased. © 2014 Gong et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Gong, X.;Liu, L.;Zheng, F.;Chen, Q.;Li, Z.;Cao, X.;Yin, H.;Zhou, J.;Cai, X.

title: Insect retros provide new insight into the origin of hepatitis B virus
abstract: The origin of the hepadnaviruses (Hepadnaviridae), a group of reverse-transcribing DNA viruses that infect vertebrates, remains mysterious. All known retrotransposons are only distantly related to hepadnaviruses. Here we report the discovery of two new lineages of retroelements, which we term the hepadnavirus-like retroelement (HEART1 and HEART2), within insect genomes by screening 1,095 eukaryotic genomes. Both phylogenetic and similarity analyzes indicate that the HEART retroelements represent the closest nonviral relatives of the hepadnaviruses to date.
