The discovery of HEART retroelements bridges the evolutionary gap between hepadnaviruses and retrotransposons and may thus provide unique insights into the origin and evolution of hepadnaviruses.
authors: Gong, Z.;Han, G. Z.

title: Global spread of hemorrhagic fever viruses: predicting pandemics
abstract: As successive epidemics have swept the world, the scientific community has quickly learned from them about the emergence and transmission of communicable diseases. Epidemics usually occur when health systems are unprepared. During an unexpected epidemic, health officials engage in damage control, fear drives action, and the desire to understand the threat is greatest. As humanity recovers, policymakers seek scientific expertise to improve their "preparation" for future events. Examples of the global spread of disease include the spread of yellow fever from Africa to the Americas, the spread of dengue fever by the transcontinental migration of mosquitoes, the relentless influenza virus pandemics, and most recently, the unexpected emergence of the Ebola virus. Spread by motorcycle and long-distance transporters. Other pathogens notable for their epidemic spread are hemorrhagic arenavirus and hantavirus diseases transmitted by rodents over large geographic distances, and arthropod-borne viruses (West Nile, Chikungunya, and Zika) transmitted by ecology and Vector adjustments are made possible. Have we learned from past epidemics? Are we prepared for the worst? The ultimate goal is the development of a resilient global health infrastructure. Along with acquiring treatments, vaccines, and other preventative medicines, biosurveillance is critical to preventing the onset of disease and counteracting its spread. So far, only the western hemisphere has a large and well-established surveillance system; However, diseases continue to occur sporadically, particularly in Southeast Asia and South America, highlighting the inadequacies of our surveillance. Epidemics destabilize fragile governments, devastate the most vulnerable populations and threaten the global community. Pandemic risk calculations use emerging technologies such as computational maintenance of geographic and historical datasets, geographic information systems (GIS), next-generation sequencing and metagenomics to trace the molecular changes in pathogens as they emerge, and mathematical models for risk assessment. Predictions help pinpoint emergence hotspots, populations at risk, and pathogens in genetic evolution. Preparedness anticipates the risks, the needs of the population, the infrastructure capacities, the sources of emergency financing and finally the international partnerships needed to manage a disaster before it occurs. Currently, the world is in an intermediate phase of attempting to narrow health disparities despite exponential population growth, political conflict, migration, world trade, urbanization, and major environmental changes due to global warming. In the interests of humanity, we must focus on developing the necessary capacities for health surveillance, epidemic preparedness, and pandemic response.
authors: Gonzalez, J. P.;Souris, M.;Valdivia-Granda, W.

title: Origin, spread and potential risk factors associated with influenza A virus in pigs in two production systems in Guatemala
abstract: Background: Guatemala is the country with the largest pig production in Central America; However, the detection of influenza A virus (IAV) in pigs has not been clearly defined. Aims: In this study, we analyzed the presence and spatial distribution of IAV in livestock and backyard pig populations. Methods: Samples from two nationwide surveys conducted in 2010 and 2011 were tested with virological (rRT-PCR and virus isolation) and serological (ELISA and hemagglutination inhibition) assays for the detection of IAV. Results: Influenza A virus was detected in 15.7% of the sampled pigs in 2010 (30.6% of the herds) and in 2011 in 11.7% (24.2% of the herds). The proportion of seropositive pigs was 10.6% (16.1% of herds) and 1.4% (3.1% of herds) for each year. Three pandemic H1N1 and one seasonal humanoid H3N2 virus have been isolated. Antibodies against viruses from different genetic clusters have been detected. No reassortant strains with swine viruses were detected. The H3N2 virus was closely related to human viruses circulating in Central America in 2010 and differed from recent human seasonal vaccine lines. Spatial clusters of rRT-PCR positive foci were detected by scan statistics each year. Conclusions: Our results demonstrate the spread of IAV throughout Guatemala and identify commercial farms, animal health status, and age as potential risk factors associated with IAV infection and exposure. The detection of viruses of human origin in pigs suggests a human role in the molecular epidemiology of pig IAV in Guatemala and indicates gaps in local animal and human surveillance.
authors: Gonzalez-Reiche, A. S.;RamÃ­rez, A. L.;MÃ¼ller, M. L.;Orellana, D.;Sosa, S. M.;Ola, P.;Paniagua, J.;OrtÃ­z, L.;Hernandez, J.;CordÃ³n-Rosales, C.;Perez, D. R.

title: Marseille virus, blood safety and the human virome
authors: Goodman, J. L.

title: Similarity of the outer capsid protein VP4 of the Gottfried strain of porcine rotavirus to that of asymptomatic human rotavirus strains
abstract: The genomic segment 4 of the pig Gottfried strain (serotype 4) of porcine rotavirus encoding the outer capsid protein VP4 was sequenced and its deduced amino acid sequence was analyzed. The amino acid homology of porcine rotavirus VP4 with the corresponding protein of asymptomatic or symptomatic human rotaviruses representing serotypes 1 to 4 ranged from 87.1 to 88.1% for asymptomatic strains and from 77.5 to 77.8% for symptomatic tribes. The amino acid homology of the Gottfried strain to simian rhesus rotavirus, simian SA11 virus, bovine Nebraska calf diarrhea virus and porcine OSU strains ranged from 71.5 to 74.3%. Antigenic similarities of VP4 epitopes between Gottfried strain and human rotavirus were detected by plaque reduction neutralization assay with hyperimmune antisera raised against Gottfried strain or a reassortant Gottfried (10 genes) x human DS-1 rotavirus (VP7 gene) were produced that exhibited serotype 2 neutralization specificity. In addition, a panel of six anti-VP4 monoclonal antibodies capable of neutralizing human rotavirus belonging to serotypes 1, 3 or 4 were able to neutralize the Gottfried strain. These observations suggest that the Gottfried rotavirus outer capsid protein VP4 is more closely related to human rotaviruses than to animal rotaviruses.
authors: Gorziglia, M.;Nishikawa, K.;Hoshino, Y.;Taniguchi, K.

title: Molecular phylogenetics of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from vaccinated flocks during outbreaks in southern India reveal the circulation of a new subgenotype
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is an economically important, contagious viral disease in poultry that is reported worldwide. In India, ND is endemic and episodes of ND outbreaks despite strict vaccination are not uncommon. We isolated and characterized seven NDviruses from vaccinated commercial poultry farms during major disease outbreaks in Tamil Nadu, southern India between April 2015 and June 2016. All seven isolates were classified as virulent based on mean time of death (48-54 h). in embryonated chicken eggs. In addition, their sequences carried the virulence signature of multibasic amino acid residues in their fusion protein cleavage site (RRQ/RR/KRF). Phylogenetic and evolutionary distance analyzes revealed the circulation of a new subgenotype of genotype XIII, class II ND viruses, proposed here as subgenotype XIIIe. The genetic divergence between the circulating virulent strains and the vaccine strains could possibly explain the disease outbreak in the vaccinated flocks. In addition, our study points to the need to conduct routine epidemiological surveillance and to reconsider the current vaccination program.
authors: Gowthaman, V.;Ganesan, V.;Gopala Krishna Murthy, T. R.;Nair, S.;Yegavinti, N.;Saraswathy, P. V.;Suresh Kumar, G.;Udhayavel, S.;Senthilvel, K.;Subbiah, M.

title: Updated information on hepatitis E virus
abstract: From its first description, hepatitis E infection was considered to have an epidemiological pattern related to consumption of sewage and contaminated food, similar to that of hepatitis A infection. The prevalence of hepatitis E is higher in areas with poor sanitation. The use of molecular techniques has helped to obtain valuable information on the epidemiology of hepatitis E in developed countries. In these areas, hepatitis E virus infection shows a different pattern and has been associated with contact with domestic animals, particularly pigs. The role of hepatitis E in industrialized countries as a possible zoonosis implies a new and interesting approach to this disease. This overview summarizes the current state of knowledge on the biology, structure and transmission of the virus and on the diagnosis of the infection. In addition, this review describes the current status of HE infection in areas with low incidence of acute hepatitis E and the role of animals as potential reservoirs for HEV.
authors: Gracia, M. T. P.

title: Detection and genome characterization of bovine polyomaviruses in beef muscle and minced beef samples from Germany
abstract: Polyomaviruses are small, non-enveloped, circular, double-stranded DNA viruses. Some polyomaviruses can cause tumors and cancer under certain circumstances. The bovine polyomaviruses (BPyV) 1-3 have only been studied to a limited extent. It has been hypothesized that eating beef containing polyomaviruses could contribute to the development of human cancer. In order to assess the distribution of the BPyV genome in meat from Germany, 101 beef muscle samples and 10 ground beef samples were analyzed here. A specific sample preparation method combined with or without rolling circle amplification (RCA) and BPyV-specific PCRs was developed and applied. BPyV-1 DNA was detected in 1/101 (1%) beef samples and in 2/10 (20%) ground beef samples. BPyV-2 DNA was detected in 3/10 (30%) ground beef samples while BPyV-3 was not detected in the samples. The use of RCA did not increase the detection rate in ground beef samples. Sequence analysis of the PCR products revealed the presence of BPyV-1, BPyV-2a and BPyV-2b. The entire genome of a ground beef BPyV-1 strain showed 97.8% sequence identity with the BPyV-1 reference strain and that of a ground beef BPyV-2a strain showed 99.9% sequence identity with strain 2aS11. It can be concluded that BPyV genomes can often be detected in ground beef samples, although higher sample numbers should be examined in the future to confirm this finding. Further studies should focus on the infectivity, tumorigenicity and heat resistance of the contained viruses to assess the risk of cancer induction from consumption of BPyVs contained in beef products. (C) 2016 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Grafe, D.;Ehlers, B.;Made, D.;Ellerbroek, L.;Seidler, T.;Johne, R.

title: Advances in antiviral vaccine development
abstract: Antiviral vaccines are the most successful biomedical intervention to prevent epidemic viral diseases. Vaccination against smallpox in humans and rinderpest in cattle has been the basis for eradicating the disease, and recent advances in eradicating polio are promising. Although early vaccines were developed empirically by passage in live animals or eggs, newer vaccines have been developed due to the advent of new technologies, particularly cell culture and molecular biology. Recent technological advances in gene delivery and expression, nanoparticles, protein manufacturing and adjuvants have created the potential for new vaccine platforms that may provide solutions for vaccines against viral pathogens for which no interventions currently exist. In addition, the technological convergence of human monoclonal antibody isolation, structural biology and high-throughput sequencing offers new opportunities for atomic-level immunogen design. The selection of human monoclonal antibodies can identify immunodominant antigenic sites associated with neutralization and provide reagents to stabilize and resolve the structure of viral surface proteins. Understanding the structural basis for neutralization can guide vaccine target selection. Deep sequencing of the antibody repertoire and definition of the ontogeny of desired antibody responses can reveal the requirements for junctional recombination and somatic mutation for B cell recognition and affinity maturation. Taken together, this information will provide new strategic approaches for the selection of vaccine antigens, formulations and schemes. In addition, it creates the potential for rational vaccine design and the establishment of a catalog of vaccine technology platforms that would be effective against any family or class of viral pathogens and improve our preparedness to address emerging viral threats. Published 2013. This article is a US government work and is in the US public domain.
authors: Graham, B. S.

title: Genital zoster infection: the big scam
abstract: Herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2), and varicella zoster virus (VZV) are taxonomically closely related viruses that cause clinically distinct diseases but share common infectious characteristics. HSV-1 and HSV-2 both produce primary cutaneous and mucocutaneous infections followed by reactivation disease occurring at the same or a nearby anatomical site. The VZV primary infection, also known as chickenpox, is usually a childhood disease that causes smallpox-like skin lesions spread throughout the body. Reactivation VZV infection, often referred to as herpes zoster, generally occurs later in life but, unlike HSV disease, produces smallpox-like lesions at a different anatomical site, typically along dermatomes. Therefore, the clinical differential diagnosis of HSV reactivation infection and zoster is generally based on the anatomical location and appearance of the lesion(s). The recent availability of molecular assays has led to the unexpected diagnosis of zoster infections in both male and female patients presenting with genital lesions. The purpose of this article is to provide a brief overview of HSV and VZV infections and to report on a laboratory experience that led to the diagnosis of zoster infections using a molecular assay in which nearly 10% of the 282 positives VZV samples were from genital sites.
authors: Granato, P. A.

title: Metagenomic detection of viral pathogens in Spanish honey bees: co-infection by aphid palsy, acute Israel palsy, and Sea Sinai viruses
abstract: The situation of honey bees in Europe has become progressively worse in recent years, with steady population decline and/or catastrophic winter losses. This has been largely attributed to the emergence of a variety of known and "unknown" emerging diseases. Previous studies have shown that colonies can often harbor more than one pathogen, making pathogen identification difficult using classical methods. By using an unbiased metagenomic approach that allows for the detection of both unexpected and previously unknown infectious agents, detection of three viruses, Aphid Lethal Paralysis Virus (ALPV), Israel Acute Paralysis Virus (IAPV) and Lake Sinai Virus (LSV), in honey bees from Spain is reported in this article. The existence of a subgroup of ALPV with the ability to infect bees has only recently been reported and this is the first identification of such a strain in Europe. Similarly, LSV appears to be an as yet unclassified group of viruses with unclear colony health implications, and these viruses have not yet been identified outside of the United States. In addition, our study also shows that these bees carried a plant virus, turnip ringspot virus (TuRSV), which may serve as an important vector organism. Taken together, these results demonstrate the new possibilities opened up by high-throughput sequencing and metagenomic analysis to study emerging new diseases in domestic and wild animal populations, including honey bees. © 2013 Granberg et al.
authors: Granberg, F.;Vicente-Rubiano, M.;Rubio-Guerri, C.;Karlsson, O. E.;Kukielka, D.;BelÃ¡k, S.;SÃ¡nchez-VizcaÃ­no, J. M.

title: Whole genome sequence comparison of vtx2 converting phages from enteroaggregative hemorrhagic Escherichia coli strains
abstract: BACKGROUND: Enteroaggregative hemorrhagic E. coli (EAHEC) is a novel pathogenic group of E. coli characterized by the presence of a vtx2 phage integrated into the genomic backbone of enteroaggregative E. coli (EAggEC). Four different EAHEC serotypes have been described so far, causing a small outbreak and six sporadic cases of HUS in the period 1992-2012 in addition to the major outbreak in Germany in 2011. In the present work, we determined the entire genome sequence of the vtx2 phage, called Phi-191, present in the first described EAHEC O111:H2, isolated in France in 1992, and compared it with those of the vtx phage whose sequences were available. RESULTS: The entire genome sequence of the Phi-191 phage was identical to that of the vtx2 phage P13374 present in strain EAHEC O104:H4 isolated 20 years later during the German outbreak. In addition, it was also almost identical to those of other previously described vtx2 phages from EAHEC O104:H4 strains. Conversely, the Phi-191 phage appeared to be distinct from the vtx2 phage carried by the EAHEC O111:H21 isolated in Northern Ireland in 2012. Typical verocytotoxin-producing E. coli strains showed the presence of a 900 bp sequence that is uniquely associated with EAHEC phage and encodes a tail fiber. CONCLUSIONS: At least two distinct vtx2 phages, both characterized by the presence of a peculiar tail fiber-encoding gene, were involved in the generation of EAHEC. The finding of an identical vtx2 phage in two isolated EAggEC strains after 20 years despite the high variability described for vtx phages is unexpected and suggests that such vtx2 phages are subject to strong selection pressure. The observation that differential EAHEC infections have been traced in countries where EAggEC infections are endemic and human wastewater treatment is often ineffective suggests that such countries may represent the cradle for the emergence of the EAHEC pathotype. In these regions, EAggEC of human origin can contaminate the environment extensively, where they can encounter free vtx phage, which are likely to be spread through ruminant faeces.
authors: Grande, L.;Michelacci, V.;Tozzoli, R.;Ranieri, P.;Maugliani, A.;Caprioli, A.;Morabito, S.

title: Genetic characterization of tick-borne flaviviruses: new insights into evolution, pathogenetic determinants, and taxonomy
abstract: Here we analyze the complete coding sequences of all recognized tick-borne flavivirus species, including Gadgets Gully, Royal Farm and Karshi virus, seabird-associated flaviviruses, Kadam virus and previously uncharacterized isolates of Kyasanur forest disease virus and Omsk hemorrhagic -fever virus. Significant taxonomic improvements are proposed, e.g. B. the identification of three main groups (mammalian, seabird and kadam tick-borne flavivirus groups), the creation of a new species (Karshi virus) and the assignment of tick-borne encephalitis and louping III viruses a unique species (tick-borne encephalitis virus), including four virus types (ie, western tick-borne encephalitis virus, eastern tick-borne encephalitis virus, Turkish sheep tick-borne encephalitis virus, and Luping III tick-borne encephalitis virus). The analyzes also suggest a complex relationship between viruses that infect birds and those that infect mammals. Ticks that feed on both categories of vertebrates may represent the evolutionary bridge between the three distinct lineages identified. © 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Grard, G.;Moureau, G.;Charrel, R. N.;Lemasson, J. J.;Gonzalez, J. P.;Gallian, P.;Gritsun, T. S.;Holmes, E. C.;Gould, E. A.;de Lamballerie, X.

title: Taxonomy of the caliciviruses
abstract: The International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) recently approved several proposals submitted by the current Caliciviridae study group. These proposals include splitting the family into 4 new genera named Lagovirus, Vesivirus, 'Norwalk-like Viruses' (NLVs) and 'Sapporo-like Viruses' (SLVs); the latter two genera have been assigned temporary names until acceptable names can be determined by the scientific community. The genera have been further subdivided into the following species: feline calicivirus and porcine vesicular rash virus (genus Vesivirus), rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus and European hare syndrome virus (genus Lagovirus), Norwalk virus (genus NLV), and sapporovirus (genus SLV). In addition, the ICTV approved a proposal to remove hepatitis E virus from the Caliciviridae to an "unassigned" classification status.
authors: Green, K. Y.;Ando, T.;Balayan, M. S.;Berke, T.;Clarke, I. N.;Estes, M. K.;Matson, D. O.;Nakata, S.;Neill, J. D.;Studdert, M. J.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Next-generation sequence analysis of the genome of RFHVMn, the macaque homologue of Kaposi's sarcoma (KS)-associated herpesvirus, from a KS-like tumor of a pig-tailed macaque
abstract: The complete sequence of retroperitoneal fibromatosis-associated herpesvirus Macaca nemestrina (RFHVMn), the pig-tailed macaque homologue of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), was determined by next-generation sequence analysis of a Kaposi's sarcoma (KS)-like macaque tumor. Colinearity of genes was observed with the KSHV genome, and the herpesvirus core genes had strong sequence homology to the corresponding KSHV genes. RFHVMn lacked homologues of open reading frame 11 (ORF11) and KSHV ORFs K5 and K6, which appeared to be generated by duplication of ORFs K3 and K4 after KSHV and RFHV divergence. RFHVMn contained positional homologs of all other unique KSHV genes, although some showed limited sequence similarity. RFHVMn contained a number of candidate microRNA genes. Although there was little sequence similarity to KSHV microRNAs, one candidate contained the same seed sequence as the positional homologue kshv-miR-K12-10a, indicating functional overlap. Splicing of RNA transcripts was highly conserved between RFHVMn and KSHV, and strong sequence conservation was found in specific promoters and putative origins of replication, predicting important functional similarities. Sequence comparisons revealed that RFHVMn and KSHV evolved synchronously with the evolution of their hosts over the long term, and both viruses group phylogenetically within the RV1 lineage of Old World primate rhadinoviruses. RFHVMn is the closest homologue of KSHV to be fully sequenced and the first sequenced RV1 rhadinovirus homologue of KSHV from an Old World non-human primate. The strong genetic and sequence similarity between RFHVMn and KSHV, coupled with similarities in biology and pathology, indicate that RFHVMn infection in macaques represents an important and relevant model for the study of KSHV in humans. © 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Gregory Bruce, A.;Ryan, J. T.;Thomas, M. J.;Peng, X.;Grundhoff, A.;Tsai, C. C.;Rose, T. M.

title: A metagenomic analysis of pandemic influenza a (2009 H1N1) infection in patients from North America
abstract: Although metagenomics has been used for pathogen discovery before, its cost and complexity have prevented its use as a practical front-line diagnostic for unknown infectious diseases. Here we demonstrate the utility of two metagenomics-based strategies, a panviral microarray (Virochip) and deep sequencing, to identify and characterize the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus. Using nasopharyngeal swabs collected during the Collected at the earliest stages of the pandemic in Mexico, Canada and the United States (n=17), the Virochip was able to detect a novel virus most closely related to swine influenza viruses without prior information. Deep sequencing revealed reads corresponding to 2009 H1N1 influenza in each sample (percentage of aligned sequences corresponding to H1N1-2009 H1N1 ranging from 0.0011% to 10.9%) with influenza genome coverage of up to 97% in one sample. Detection of 2009 H1N1 by deep sequencing was possible even at titers close to the detection limits for specific RT-PCR, and the percentage of sequence reads was linearly correlated with virus titer. Deep sequencing also provided insight into the upper respiratory tract microbiota and host gene expression in response to H1N1 infection in 2009. An unbiased analysis combining sequence data from all 17 outbreak samples revealed that 90% of the H1N1 genome from 2009 could be assembled de novo without the use of a reference sequence, including the assembly of multiple nearly full-length genomic segments. These results indicate that an optimized metagenomics detection strategy can potentially replace the numerous conventional diagnostic tests required to investigate an outbreak of a novel pathogen and provide a blueprint for comprehensive diagnosis of unexplained acute diseases or outbreaks in clinical and public health settings . © 2010 Greninger et al.
authors: Greninger, A. L.;Chen, E. C.;Sittler, T.;Scheinerman, A.;Roubinian, N.;Yu, G.;Kim, E.;Pillai, D. R.;Guyard, C.;Mazzulli, T.;Isa, P.;Arias, C. F.;Hackett Jr, J.;Schochetman, G.;Miller, S.;Tang, P.;Chiu, C. Y.

title: The complete genome of the class virus - a novel picornavirus in pediatric stool
abstract: Background: Every year, 2 million children worldwide die from diarrhea, but in about 30-50% of cases no etiological agent is found. Picornaviral genera such as Enterovirus, Kobuvirus, Cosavirus, Parechovirus, Hepatovirus, Techovirus and Cardiovirus have all been found in human and animal diarrhea. Modern technologies, particularly deep sequencing, enable rapid, high-throughput screening of clinical samples such as stool for new infectious agents implicated in human diseases. Results: A pool of 141 pediatric gastroenteritis specimens previously found negative for known diarrheal viruses were pyrosequenced. From a total of 937,935 sequence reads, a collection of 849 reads distantly related to Aichi virus was assembled and found to encompass 75% of a new picornavirus genome. The complete genome was subsequently cloned and found to share 52.3% pairwise nucleotide identity and 38.9% amino acid identity with Aichi virus. The low degree of sequence identity suggests a new genus of picornavirus, which we have termed the class virus. A blinded screening of 751 stool specimens from both symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals yielded a second positive case of class virus infection, later found to be from the 11-month-old twin of the index case. Conclusion: We report the detection of human class virus 1, a member of a novel picornavirus genus, in the stool of two Northern California infants. Further characterization and epidemiological studies are needed to determine whether class viruses are significant causes of human infection.
authors: Greninger, A. L.;Runckel, C.;Chiu, C. Y.;Haggerty, T.;Parsonnet, J.;Ganem, D.;DeRisi, J. L.

title: Isolation of a virus strain from Argas persicus ticks
abstract: A previously undescribed virus was isolated from Argas persicus ticks collected on sentinel hens in western Slovakia. The strain was lethal to lactating mice only after intracerebral inoculation. No symptoms were induced in adult mice. The virus strain was insensitive to sodium deoxycholate and resistant to ether treatment. An antigen made from the virus did not agglutinate goose or human O erythrocytes. The single strain obtained in 1976 appeared unrelated to a large number of known arboviruses when tested by the complement fixation reaction.
authors: Gresikova, M.;Nosek, J.;Sekeyova, M.

title: Molecular characterization of H3N2 influenza A virus isolated from Ontario pigs in 2011 and 2012
abstract: Background: Data on the molecular diversity of commonly circulating type A influenza viruses in Ontario pigs are scarce. However, this information is essential for monitoring animal and public health, updating vaccines, and understanding virus evolution and its large-scale spread. Methods: The study population consisted of 21 pig herds with clinical problems due to respiratory diseases. Nasal swabs from individual pigs were collected and tested by virus isolation in MDCK cells and by rtRT-PCR. All eight segments of 10 H3N2 viruses were sequenced and molecularly characterized using high-throughput sequencing. Results: The prevalence within the herd was between 2 and 100%. Structurally, the Ontario H3N2 viruses can be divided into three different groups. Group 1 was most similar to the original 2005 trH3N2 virus. Group 2 was most similar to the H3N2 isolates from the Ontario turkey, with the PB1 and NS genes from the trH3N2 virus and the M, PB2, PA and NP genes from the A(H1N1 )pdm09 virus. All group 3 internal genes were genetically related to A(H1N1)pdm09. Analysis of the antigenic sites of HA1 showed that group 1 had 8 aa changes within 4 antigenic sites, A(1), B(3), C(2) and E(2). Group 2 viruses had 8 aa changes within the 3 antigenic sites A(3), B(3) and C(2), while group 3 viruses had 4 aa changes within the 3 antigenic sites B(1), D(1) and exhibited E(2), compared to cluster IV H3N2 virus [A/swine/Ontario/33853/2005/(H3N2)]. Conclusions: The characterization of Ontario H3N2 viruses clearly indicates a reassortment of gene segments between the North American cluster IV swine trH3N2 and the A(H1N1)pdm09 virus.
authors: GrgiÄ‡, H.;Costa, M.;Friendship, R. M.;Carman, S.;Nagy, Ã‰;Wideman, G.;Weese, S.;Poljak, Z.

title: Prevalence of hepatitis E virus infection in pigs at the time of slaughter, UK, 2013
abstract: Since 2010, reports of hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection have increased in England and Wales. Despite increasing evidence of the zoonotic potential of porcine HEV, there is limited data on its prevalence in pigs in the UK. We examined antibody prevalence, active infection, and virus variation in serum and cecal samples from 629 pigs at slaughter. The prevalence of antibodies to HEV was 92.8% (584/629), and HEV RNA was detected in 15% of cecal contents (93/629), 3% of plasma samples (22/629), and 2% of both (14/629). 629) demonstrated. 629). Although HEV is widespread in pigs in the UK and viremic pigs enter the food chain, most (22/23) viral sequences are clustered separately from the dominant type observed in humans. Therefore, UK reared pigs are unlikely to be the main source of human HEV infection in the UK. Further research is needed to identify the source of these infections.
authors: Grierson, S.;Heaney, J.;Cheney, T.;Morgan, D.;Wyllie, S.;Powell, L.;Smith, D.;Ijaz, S.;Steinbach, F.;Choudhury, B.;Tedder, R. S.

title: Molecular and in vitro characterization of British swine hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection is widespread in the global swine population. Although clinically inapparent in pigs, HEV infection is the cause of hepatitis E in humans and transmission through the food chain has been demonstrated. Following a 2013 study examining the prevalence of HEV infection in pigs of UK slaughter age, samples with the highest viral loads were selected for further characterisation. High throughput sequencing was used to obtain the full coding sequence from five samples. In-frame insertion within the HEV hypervariable region was observed in two samples. Virus isolation and culture was performed to investigate whether this mutation could be the cause of high-level viraemia and fecal shedding as observed in swine specimens. Based on viral growth kinetics, there was no evidence that these insertions affected replication efficiency in vitro, suggesting that as yet undetermined host factors may influence the course of infection and consequently the risk of foodborne transmission.
authors: Grierson, S. S.;McGowan, S.;Cook, C.;Steinbach, F.;Choudhury, B.

title: Genomic epidemiology of methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus via colonization and skin and soft tissue infection
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Staphylococcus aureus skin and skin tissue infections (Sa-SSTI) represent a significant burden on healthcare systems. New Zealand has a high incidence of Sa-SSTI and here most of the morbidity is caused by a polyclonal methicillin-susceptible (MSSA) bacterial population. However, MSSA also asymptomatically colonize the cornified epithelia of about 20% of the population, and their separation between commensalism and pathogenicity is poorly understood. Our goal was to see if MSSA are genetically differentiated across colonization and SSTI; and given the close interactions between humans and domestic animals, whether strains isolated from domestic animals differ from human strains. METHODS: We compared the genomes of co-colonization and clinical MSSA isolates obtained from humans and domesticated animals in New Zealand. RESULTS: Nuclear and accessory genome comparisons revealed a homogeneous bacterial population across colonization, disease, humans and pets. The MSSA colonization rate in dogs was comparatively low (5.4%). CONCLUSIONS: In New Zealand, most Sa-SSTI morbidity is caused by random sampling of the colonizing MSSA population, which is more in line with the opportunistic infection model than the paradigm that discriminates strains according to their pathogenicity. Therefore, studies of the factors that determine colonization and immune escape may be more advantageous than comparative virulence studies. Contact with pets may pose a low zoonotic risk.
authors: Grinberg, A.;Biggs, P. J.;Zhang, J.;Ritchie, S.;Oneroa, Z.;O'Neill, C.;Karkaba, A.;Velathanthiri, N. S.;Coombs, G. W.

title: Identification of potyviruses infecting vanilla by direct sequencing of a short RT-PCR amplicon
abstract: To identify the potyviruses infecting vanilla, a simple one-tube RT-PCR test was used in one step with degenerate primers followed by direct sequencing of a 327 bp coat protein gene fragment. Using this technique, an unequivocal species assignment was achieved for 34 potyvirus-infected vanilla samples collected between 1997 and 2005 in the Indian Ocean and the Pacific. Virus identification was based on BLAST homology and nucleotide identities of 162-327 nt fragments with known potyvirus sequences. Species assignment was confirmed by neighbor joining of the 149 nt common to 32 vanilla sequences and 51 known potyviruses. Pending further identification, these data revealed four other potyvirus species that can infect vanilla: Bean Yellow Mosaic Virus, Cowpea Aphid-borne Mosaic Virus, Ornithogalum Mosaic Virus, and Wisteria Vein Mosaic Virus. The method was fast, inexpensive, easy to use and showed good taxonomic discrimination value. It also enabled the identification of potyviruses in neighboring weeds and thus should contribute to the understanding of potyvirus outbreaks occurring under different epidemiological circumstances.
authors: Grisoni, M.;Moles, M.;Farreyrol, K.;Rassaby, L.;Davis, R.;Pearson, M.

title: On the identity of Ootheca bennigseni Weise, O-mutabilis (Schonherr) and O-meridiana sp n. (Chrysomelidae: Galerucinae), bean and cowpea pests in the Afrotropical region
abstract: Ootheca mutabilis (Schonherr) and O. bennigseni Weise are recognized as two prominent pest species on beans (Phaseolus vulgaris (L.), Fabaceae) in Central and East Africa. These beetles destroy root tissues and seedlings, skeletonize the leaves of plants, and feed on inflorescences, causing severe crop losses. Both species also feed on cowpeas (Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. (Fabaceae). Ootheca mutabilis is known to be the vector of several plant viruses. The current taxonomic status of the African genus Ootheca is discussed and the following species are transmitted from the genus Ergana Chapuis to Ootheca Dejean as new combinations: O. bifrons (Laboissiere), O. bourquii (Laboissiere), O. caerulea (Jacoby), O. fulvipes (Jacoby), O. chapuisi (Jacoby), O. minuta (Laboissire), O nigrilabris (Laboissiere), O. podagrica (Laboissiere), O. proteus (Chapuis), O. semicaerulea (Jacoby), O. variabilis (Laboissiere), and O. vittata (Laboissiere).Ootheca vexa nom.n proposed for Ootheca apicicornis (Laboissiere) comb.n.(from Ergana), a junior homonym of O. apicicornis Laboissire.Ootheca mutabilis and O. bennigseni were studied to provide information and illustrations to facilitate their identification Ootheca meridiana sp.n. will be as new e pest species of bees described ns and cowpeas from southern Africa.
authors: Grobbelaar, E.

title: Varicella zoster virus specific gp140: A highly immunogenic and disulfide-linked structural glycoprotein
abstract: 140,000 dalton disulfide-linked glycoprotein (gp140) specified by varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in infected cultured cells was identified and precipitated by two murine monoclonal antibodies (VZ-151 and VZ-158). When analyzed under reducing conditions by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, gp140 was predominantly cleaved to a lower molecular weight 66,000 product (gp66). This protein was classified as a viral structural component because it was observed in the polypeptide profile of metrizamide gradient-purified enveloped virions. Immunofluorescence analysis using a monoclonal antibody probe documented gp140 expression in cultured cells inoculated with homologous (VZV-Oka) and heterologous (VZV-32) strains as well as in infected human tissues of chickenpox and zoster patients is highly conserved. That the glycoprotein was highly immunogenic was confirmed by the presence of high titre anti-gp140 antibodies in the sera of both hyperimmunized laboratory animals and naturally infected humans. Temporally, the humoral response to gp140 after primary VZV infection preceded that to the other viral glycoproteins. These studies therefore describe an immunogenic disulfide-linked structural viral glycoprotein that must belong to the other five previously described VZV-specific fucosylated species - gp118, gp98, gp88, gp62 and gp45.
authors: Grose, C.;Edwards, D. P.;Weigle, K. A.

title: Epidemic late abortion in pigs - state of the art
abstract: This article briefly describes the PRRS (Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome) that occurred in Germany and other European countries in the winter of 1990. The data are compiled from the literature and personal experience. The clinical picture of this new disease, which has led to significant economic losses, is dominated by 1. an increased rate of shortened gestation periods with late abortion before day 110 or a prolonged gestation period; 2. an increase in stillborn piglets; 3. A greater degree of pre-weaning mortality combined with a higher frequency of secondary infections. Pathologic findings in piglets include subcutaneous edema, fluid accumulation in the body cavities and interstitial pneumonias are sometimes observed. Mononuclear placentitis is present in sows from affected herds that are examined prior to birth. Currently, an unclassified virus isolated by Dutch researchers is proposed as the causative agent, named Lelystad virus.
authors: grosse Beilage, E.;Stockhofe-Zurwieden, N.;SchÃ¶ttker-Wegner, H. H.

title: A next-generation sequencing approach reveals viral transcripts incorporated into poxvirus virions
abstract: It is known that transcripts are incorporated into particles of DNA viruses belonging to the families Herpesviridae and Mimiviridae, but the presence of transcripts in other DNA viruses such as poxviruses has not been analyzed yet. Therefore, we first established a next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based protocol that allows for the unbiased identification of transcripts in virus particles. We then applied our protocol to analyze RNA in an emerging zoonotic member of the Poxviridae family, namely cowpox virus. Our results showed the incorporation of 19 viral transcripts while host identifications were restricted to ribosomal and mitochondrial RNA. Most viral transcripts had an unknown and immunomodulatory function, suggesting that transcript incorporation may be beneficial for poxvirus immune evasion. Remarkably, the most abundant transcript originated from the D5L/I1R gene, which encodes a viral inhibitor of the host's cytoplasmic DNA acquisition machinery.
authors: Grossegesse, M.;Doellinger, J.;Haldemann, B.;Schaade, L.;Nitsche, A.

title: Combined proteomics/genomics approach reveals proteomic changes in mature virions as a novel poxvirus adaptation mechanism
abstract: Like poxviruses, DNA viruses possess a highly stable genome, suggesting that adaptation of viral particles to specific cell types is not limited to genomic alterations. Cowpoxviruses are zoonotic poxviruses with an exceptionally broad host range, demonstrating their adaptive potential in vivo. To elucidate the adaptation mechanisms of poxviruses, we isolated vaccinia virus particles from a rat and passaged them five times in a human and a rat cell line. We then analyzed the proteome and genome of the unpassaged virions and each passage. While the entire viral genome sequence was stable during passage, proteomics revealed several changes in virion composition. Interestingly, increased viral fitness was observed in human cells in the presence of increased immunomodulatory protein levels. Since the only minor variant was localized in a viral RNA polymerase subunit with increasing frequency during passage and, moreover, most minor variants were found in transcription-associated genes, protein levels were presumably regulated at the transcriptional level. This study is the first comparative proteomic analysis of virus particles before and after cell culture propagation, revealing proteomic changes as a novel poxvirus adaptation mechanism.
authors: Grossegesse, M.;Doellinger, J.;Tyshaieva, A.;Schaade, L.;Nitsche, A.

title: Typing of bacteriophage strains by rapid single molecule analysis
abstract: The rapid characterization of unknown biological samples is the focus of many current studies. Here we report a method for screening biological samples by optically mapping their DNA. We use a novel, one-step chemo-enzymatic reaction to covalently attach fluorophores to DNA at the four-base recognition sites of a DNA methyltransferase. Due to the diffraction limit of light, the dense distribution of the labels results in a continuous fluorescence signal along the DNA. The amplitude modulations (AM) of fluorescence intensity along the stretched DNA molecules reveal a unique molecular fingerprint that can be used for identification. We show that this labeling scheme is highly informative and allows for accurate genotyping. We demonstrate the method by labeling the genomes of lambda and T7 bacteriophages, resulting in a consistent, unique AM profile for each genome. These profiles are also used successfully to identify phage from a background phage library. Our method can provide an easy way to screen and type different organisms and has potential applications in metagenomic studies of different ecosystems.
authors: Grunwald, A.;Dahan, M.;Giesbertz, A.;Nilsson, A.;Nyberg, L. K.;Weinhold, E.;Ambjornsson, T.;Westerlund, F.;Ebenstein, Y.

title: Epidemiological survey of pseudorabies in Shandong Province from 2013 to 2016
abstract: In late 2011, a variant of pseudorabies virus (vPRV) emerged in Bartha-K61-vaccinated pig herds, resulting in high morbidity and mortality in piglets in China. Since 2013, the autopsy lesions, histological examinations, virus isolation, phylogenetic analysis and selection pressure analysis of gE gene of vPRV for 395 clinical cases were recorded and 5,033 swine serum samples were detected by PRV gE-coated enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The main clinical symptoms were miscarriages in pregnant sows, fatal neurological symptoms in piglets and respiratory diseases in growing pigs. On histopathological examination, necrotic splenitis, hepatitis and lymphadenitis, hemorrhagic nephritis and nonsuppurative encephalitis were observed. Typical eosinophilic inclusion bodies have been found in the nuclei of liver cells. 110 samples from 395 clinical cases tested positive for the gE gene by PCR. Fifteen vPRV strains were isolated and confirmed by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the gE gene. The strains shared 97.1% to 99.9% nucleotide (nt) and 96.6% to 99.5% amino acid (aa) homology with PRV reference strains. Analysis of selection pressure showed that a site in the codons of glycoprotein E was under positive selection. Of the 5,033 serum samples, 2,909 were positive by ELISA, representing a positive rate of 57.8%. These results indicated that vPRV was still widespread in Shandong province, indicating strong PRV infection pressure. The preparation of new vaccines against PRV is extremely urgent.
authors: Gu, J.;Hu, D.;Peng, T.;Wang, Y.;Ma, Z.;Liu, Z.;Meng, F.;Shang, Y.;Liu, S.;Xiao, Y.

title: Genome sequencing and genetic analysis of a natural reassortant H5N1 subtype avian influenza virus possessing internal H9N2 genes
abstract: Summary: An H5N1 subtype avian influenza virus, A/duck/Shandong/009/2008 (Dk/SD/009/08), was isolated from apparently healthy domestic ducks at a live bird market in eastern China during our epidemiological surveillance. To examine the genetic composition, Dk/SD/009/08 was subjected to genome sequencing. The amino acid motif of the cleavage site was "PLRERRRK-R/GL", consistent with the characterization of the HPAIV. According to H5N1's latest unified nomenclature system, Dk/SD/009/08 has been placed in Clade 2.3.4. The BLAST results showed that four gene segments (HA, NA, NP, and NS) shared the highest nucleotide identities with AIVs of the H5N1 subtype, while the remaining four (PB2, PB1, PA, and M) shared the closest relationship with the H9N2 subtype exhibited. Therefore, Dk/SD/009/08 could be a natural reassortant virus. The phylogenetic analysis further suggested that G1-like H9N2 subtype AIVs, found mainly in southern China quail, might provide the internal genes for Dk/SD/009/08.
authors: Gu, M.;Liu, W. B.;Cao, J. P.;Cao, Y. Z.;Zhang, X. R.;Peng, D. X.;Liu, X. F.

title: Novel variants of clade 2.3.4 highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, China
abstract: We have characterized 7 highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses isolated from poultry in China between 2009 and 2012 and found that they belong to clade 2.3.4 but do not fit into the 3 defined subclades. Antigenic drift in subtype H5N1 variants may reduce the effectiveness of vaccines developed to combat these viruses in poultry.
authors: Gu, M.;Zhao, G.;Zhao, K.;Zhong, L.;Huang, J.;Wan, H.;Wang, X.;Liu, W.;Liu, H.;Peng, D.;Liu, X.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of an orfvirus isolated from an outbreak in a Boer goat in Shanxi Province
abstract: To identify and analyze orf virus in Shanxi province, China, an orf virus strain was successfully isolated from crust materials of a Boer goat with clinical symptoms of mouth pain from a goat farm in Shanxi province by passaging in lamb testicles (LT). . Orf virus was identified by ELISA test (Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay), recurrent infection test, transmission electron microscopy and PCR. The nucleotide and amino acid sequences of two genes of the orf virus were analyzed. The results showed that the virus had typical parapoxvirus virions under electron microscopy and that many eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions were observed by hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining. In the ELISA test, the optical density (OD) readings of the sample showed a positive result, and the virus-infected rabbits showed a typical orf virus-infected appearance. All of these findings proved that the sample was an orf virus. The phylogenetic studies of the Orf B2L and Orf F1L genes showed that the virus clustered in different branches and was closer to the Orf virus Nantou (DQ904351) and the OV-SA00 isolates (AY386264). In addition, the above results could provide insight into the genotype of the etiological agent responsible for the Orf outbreak in Shanxi Province and could also provide a comparative overview of the B2L and F1L genes of parapoxvirus.
authors: Gu, S. P.;Shi, X. T.;Shi, Z. Y.;Wang, Z. B.;Zheng, M. X.

title: Metagenomic analysis of viromas from Sichuan takin fecal samples reveals novel enteroviruses and astroviruses
abstract: The Sichuan takin inhabits the bamboo forests of the eastern Himalayas and is considered a national treasure of China with the highest legal protection and conservation status, listed as Vulnerable according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. In this study, stool samples from 71 Sichuan takins were pooled and deeply sequenced. Of the 103,553 viral sequences, 21,961 were assigned to mammalian viruses. De novo assembly revealed genomes of an enterovirus and an astrovirus, as well as contigs of genogroup I circoviruses and picobirnaviruses evidence of recombination. Sichuan takin astrovirus is a new subtype of bovine astrovirus that probably belongs to a new genogroup in the genus Mamastrovirus. Further studies will show if these viruses are also found in Mishmi Takin and Shaanxi Takin and their pathogenic potential.
authors: Guan, T. P.;Teng, J. L. L.;Yeong, K. Y.;You, Z. Q.;Liu, H.;Wong, S. S. Y.;Lau, S. K. P.;Woo, P. C. Y.

title: Expression of long noncoding RNAs encoded by the pseudorabies virus in epithelial cells and neurons
abstract: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) play important roles in regulating eukaryotic genome replication and gene expression in diverse biological systems. Here we identified lncRNAs transcribed from Pseudorabies virus (PRV) infected PK-15 cells. Based on high-throughput sequencing data, we obtained 87,263,926 and 93,947,628 clean reads from mock-infected and PRV-infected PK-15 cells, respectively. Through a normalized analysis protocol, we identified three new viral lncRNAs. According to an analysis of the differential expression between the mock-infected and PRV-infected cells, 4151 host lncRNAs were significantly upregulated and 2327 host lncRNAs were significantly downregulated in the latter group. Viral lncRNAs and several host lncRNAs were verified by Northern blotting and real-time PCR. The results indicated that the viral lncRNA LDI could regulate the expression of IE180, a potent transcriptional activator of viral genes. Furthermore, we characterized the expression of viral lncRNAs in culture of infected chicken primary dorsal root ganglia (DRG). Overall, the data obtained suggest that PRV generates lncRNAs in both epithelial cells and chick DRG neurons.
authors: Guan, X.;Liu, J.;Jiang, H.;Wu, C. X.;Chen, H. C.;Liu, Z. F.

title: Genetic characterization of an H2N2 influenza virus isolated from a muskrat in western Siberia
abstract: Thirty-two muskrats (Ondatra zibethicus) were captured for avian influenza virus surveillance in wild waterbirds and mammals near Lake Khany, Western Siberia, Russia. A/muskratte/Russia/63/2014 (H2N2) was isolated from an apparently healthy muskrat using chick embryos. Based on a phylogenetic analysis, the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of this isolate have been classified into the Eurasian avian influenza virus phylum and are closely related to low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAIVs) isolated from wild waterfowl in Italy and Sweden, respectively. Other internal genes were also closely related to LPAIVs isolated from Eurasian wild waterfowl. The results suggest that LPAIVs are interspecies transmitted from wild waterfowl to semiaquatic mammals, facilitating the spread and evolution of LPAIVs in wetlands of western Siberia.
authors: Gulyaeva, M.;Sharshov, K.;Suzuki, M.;Sobolev, I.;Sakoda, Y.;Alekseev, A.;Sivay, M.;Shestopalova, L.;Shchelkanov, M.;Shestopalov, A.

title: Detection and characterization of novel bocavirus (genus Bocaparvovirus) and gastroenteritis viruses from asymptomatic pigs in Ireland
abstract: BACKGROUND: Livestock have been the assumed source of several human epidemics in recent years, for example influenza H1N1, rotavirus G8/G9 and MERS-CoV. Surveillance of novel viruses in animals is essential to assess risk to human and animal health and identify economic impacts such as failure to thrive. There is limited data on the detection and characterization of gastroenteritis viruses, particularly novel viruses, in pigs in Ireland. A number of small new porcine DNA viruses have recently emerged worldwide, e.g. B. the torque tenosus virus, the swine bocavirus and the parvoviruses 2 and 4, and little is known about the biology and potential pathogenicity of these viruses. Bocaparvovirus is a genetically diverse group of viruses recently identified in humans and animals. METHODS: In this study, the presence of gastroenteritis viruses (rotavirus A, porcine circovirus, adenovirus and porcine bocavirus) was examined in a selection of archived faecal samples from asymptomatic piglets from a commercial farm in Ireland. A total of 104 samples were pooled and screened using conventional molecular techniques (PCR and RT-PCR), a subset of samples (n=44) were then analyzed individually. Viral diversity was then examined using statistical and phylogenetic techniques. RESULTS: The initial screening showed a high prevalence of PBoV on this herd, with three distinct groups formed in the phylogenetic analysis. Other viruses were also examined in this study with the first report of PCV, PAdV and Lineage I G5 RVA in Ireland. Some samples contained >1 virus, with statistical analysis indicating a strong correlation for mixed infections of PBoV and PAdV on this farm. CONCLUSION: Studying the diversity of circulating enteric viruses in Irish pig farms is important to improve the available prophylactic tools and to facilitate early detection of changes in circulating viruses.
authors: Gunn, L.;Collins, P. J.;Fanning, S.;McKillen, J.;Morgan, J.;Staines, A.;O'Shea, H.

title: H1N1 influenza virus epitopes classified by monoclonal antibodies
abstract: Epitopes play an important role in influenza infections. It may be useful to screen universal influenza virus vaccines by analyzing the epitopes of multiple subtypes of the hemagglutinin (HA) protein. A total of 40 monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) previously derived from influenza virus HA antigens (the development and characterization of 40 mAbs generated using H1N1 influenza virus split vaccines were previously published) were used for detection and ELISA method used to classify mAbs into different influenza virus subcategories. Subsequently, the common contiguous amino acid sequences were identified by multiple sequence alignment analysis using the GenBank database and DNAMAN software for use in predicting the epitopes of the HA protein. Synthesized peptides of these shared sequences were made and used to verify and identify the predicted linear epitopes by localization and distribution analysis. Using these methods, nine linear HA epitopes distributed among different strains of influenza virus were identified, including three from influenza A, four from 2009 H1N1 and seasonal influenza, and two from H1. The present study showed that considering a combination of antigen-antibody reaction specificity, variation in influenza virus HA protein and linear epitopes can represent a useful approach for the development of effective multi-epitope vaccines. In addition, the study aimed to clarify the cause and pathogenic mechanism of influenza virus HA-induced flu and presents a new idea for identifying the epitopes of other pathogenic microorganisms.
authors: Guo, C. Y.;Zhang, H. X.;Xie, X.;Liu, Y.;Sun, L. J.;Li, H. J.;Yu, P. B.;Hu, H. Y.;Sun, J. Y.;Li, Y.;Feng, Q.;Zhao, X. R.;Liang, D. Y.;Wang, Z.;Hu, J.

title: Highly pathogenic influenza A(H5Nx) viruses with altered H5 receptor binding specificity
abstract: The emergence and intercontinental spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5Nx) virus clade 2.3.4.4 is unprecedented. H5N8 and H5N2 viruses have caused major economic losses in the poultry industry in Europe and North America, and fatal human infections with the H5N6 virus have occurred in Asia. Knowledge of the evolution of the receptor binding specificity of these viruses, which could affect the host range, is urgently needed. We report that the emergence of these viruses is accompanied by a change in receptor binding specificity. In contrast to the ancestral clade 2.3.4 H5 proteins, new clade 2.3.4.4 H5 proteins bind to fucosylated sialosides due to the K222Q and S227R substitutions unique to highly pathogenic influenza virus H5 proteins. North American clade 2.3.4.4 virus isolates retained only the K222Q substitution but still bind fucosylated sialosides. Altered receptor binding specificity of H5 proteins of virus type 2.3.4.4 may have contributed to the emergence and spread of H5Nx viruses.
authors: Guo, H.;de Vries, E.;McBride, R.;Dekkers, J.;Peng, W.;Bouwman, K. M.;Nycholat, C.;Verheije, M. H.;Paulson, J. C.;van Kuppeveld, F. J.;de Haan, C. A.

title: Targeting for precision medicine using high-throughput genome engineering
abstract: In recent years, programmable RNA-directed nucleases such as the CRISPR/Cas9 system have ushered in a new era of precise genome editing in various model systems and in human cells. Functional screens using large libraries of RNA guides can interrogate a large hypothesis space to locate specific genes and genetic elements involved in fundamental biological processes and disease-related phenotypes. Here, we review current high-throughput CRISPR screens (e.g., loss-of-function, gain-of-function, and non-coding element targeting) and highlight their potential for uncovering novel therapeutic targets, e.g. B. those involved in cancer resistance to small molecule drugs and immunotherapies, tumor development, infectious diseases, inherited genetic disorders and other therapeutic challenges.
authors: Guo, X.;Chitale, P.;Sanjana, N. E.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of a novel CRESS DNA virus from a calf with severe hemorrhagic enteritis in China
abstract: In this study, a novel circular replication-associated protein (Rep)-encoding single-stranded DNA virus (CRESS) was detected in a diarrhea sample from a calf with severe hemorrhagic enteritis. The virus, named Bo-Circo-like Virus CH, has a circular genome of 3909 nucleotides (nt). Six putative open reading frames (ORFs) were identified, including Rep, Capsid (Cap), and four proteins of unknown function. Both in terms of genome size and the number and organization of the encoded ORFs, Bo circo-like virus CH is most closely related to Po circo-like virus 21, which has been identified in pig faeces. Preliminary testing using Rep region specific primers showed that 5.3% (4/75) of the diarrheal specimens were positive for Bo-circo-like virus and all 42 healthy specimens were negative. Taken together, our results indicate that Bo-circo-like virus CH may represent a novel virus in cattle. Further research is needed to determine the relationship between viral infection and diarrhea.
authors: Guo, Z.;He, Q.;Tang, C.;Zhang, B.;Yue, H.

title: Detection and molecular properties of neboviruses in dairy cows in China
abstract: In this study, 98 diarrheal and 70 non-diarrheal samples were collected from April 2017 to May 2018 from 13 dairy farms in 5 provinces of China. Approximately 41.8% (41/98) of the diarrheal specimens and 5.7% (4/70) of the non-diarrheal specimens were Nebovirus positive based on RT-PCR results, and some specimens with diarrhea were infected with bovine rotavirus ( 73.2%), bovine coronavirus (36.6%) and/or bovine viral diarrhea virus (31.7%) co-infected. A phylogenetic analysis of 23 Nebovirus RdRp fragments showed that these strains were closely related to Nebraska-like (NB-like) strains, but were all in a single large branch. Furthermore, a phylogenetic analysis of the 18 complete VP1 sequences from this study revealed that 14 kindreds belonged to lineage 1 and 4 kindreds to lineage 3. Notably, all four lineage 3 strains shared the same recombination event with a breakpoint within the P1A domain. The full genome of a nebovirus strain, Bo/YLA-2/17/CH, that exhibited a recombination event within the P1A domain of its VP1 was successfully sequenced and found to be 7453 nt in length, potentially representing a novel nebovirus strain based on the phylogenetic analysis of its complete genome sequence. In summary, this study shows that neboviruses are widespread in dairy cows in China and have a unique development of RdRp. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported recombination event within the P1A domain of Nebovirus VP1.
authors: Guo, Z.;He, Q.;Zhang, B.;Yue, H.;Tang, C.

title: Sequence analysis of the Meq oncogene among Indian isolates of Marek's disease herpesvirus
abstract: Marek's disease (MD), caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV), is a highly contagious neoplastic disease in chickens that can be prevented by vaccination. However, in recent years, many cases of vaccination failure have been reported worldwide as chickens develop symptoms of MD despite proper vaccination. Pronounced polymorphism and point mutations in the Meq gene of MDV have been reported to be associated with virulence and oncogenicity. The present study was conducted with the aim of isolating and characterizing field isolates of MDV based on the Meq gene. Twenty-five specimens from suspected MDV cases were collected and processed for virus isolation in duck embryo fibroblast (DEF) primary cultures, where 28% (7 of 25) specimens showed characteristic cytopathic effects of MDV in the form of plaques and syncytia. Additional evidence for the presence of MDV in these samples was confirmed by PCR. To analyze the diversity in all seven isolates of MDV, a polymorphism study was performed by cloning and sequencing the full-length (1020 bp) Meq gene. The sequence homology of 7 isolates with 23 reference strains showed 98.10-99.40% similarity in nucleotides and 95.90-98.50% similarity in amino acid sequences. Six isolates showed 5 repeat sequences of 4 prolines (PPPP), whereas one isolate showed only 4 repeats. In the phylogenetic analysis, these isolates formed a separate cluster showing a close relationship with the Chinese isolates. The study points to a high mutation rate in field isolates of MDV, which could be a likely cause of vaccine failure.
authors: Gupta, M.;Deka, D.;Ramneek

title: Restriction enzyme analysis of bovine herpesvirus 1 DNA from an Indian isolate
abstract: An Indian isolate of BHV-1 was analyzed using several restriction endonucleases. The restriction pattern of BHV-1 DNA containing HindIII, BamHI and EcoRI was found to be similar to other reported restriction endonuclease patterns for BHV-1 respiratory isolates. Thus, this isolate could be grouped under BHV-1.1 (respiratory form of BHV-1). Few restriction endonucleases yielded a different restriction profile of BHV-1 DNA. The total molecular size of the BHV-1 DNA for the isolate examined was also estimated to be 136 kb to 138 kb.
authors: Gupta, P. K.;Rai, A.

title: Genetic diversity in the VP1 gene of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype Asia 1
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequence of the 1D gene (encoding VP1) from 61 Asia I FMD serotype virus isolates recovered from different outbreaks in India between 1985 and 1999, including two currently used vaccine strains, has been determined. The sequences were compared with each other and with those from other Asian countries. Based on the phylogenetic analysis, the viruses could be divided into four genotypes (genotypes I-IV). All 61 isolates from India belong to a single genotype (genotype II) which is further subdivided into three lineages (B1, B2 and B3) under the same genotype. It was found that the B1 and B3 lineage viruses were more common before 1996, while the B2 lineage viruses appeared to be new variants responsible for most of the recent outbreaks. Most B1 lineage isolates lack an amino acid in the VP1 protein (position 44), whereas most B2 and B3 lineage isolates contain it, suggesting the possibility that these lineages evolved independently. The rate of evolution of FMD Asia-1 virus was also estimated and found to be 2.7 x 10(-2) synonymous substitutions per nucleotide per year.
authors: Gurumurthy, C. B.;Sanyal, A.;Venkataramanan, R.;Tosh, C.;George, M.;Hemadri, D.

title: Turkey coronavirus is more closely related to avian infectious bronchitis virus than to mammalian coronaviruses: a review
abstract: Turkey coronavirus (TCoV) is the cause of acute highly contagious enteric disease in turkeys. In recent years, TCoV has been increasingly recognized as an important pathogen in young turkeys in North America, resulting in economic losses due to stunted growth and poor feed conversion. Although the epidemiology and pathogenesis of TCoV have been extensively studied, TCoV remains one of the least characterized known coronaviruses. Avian and mammalian coronaviruses have been divided into distinct antigenic/genotypic groups; However, the classification of TCoV has been controversial. Previous studies showed that TCoV was closely related to bovine and other group 2 mammalian coronaviruses, but recent antigen and genomic sequence analyzes contradict these results and instead provide evidence that TCoV is closely related to avian infectious bronchitis virus ( IBV) is related. In addition, experimental studies have shown that the host range of TCoV, previously thought to be restricted to turkeys, includes chickens. These studies have raised additional questions about the classification of TCoV; specifically, whether IBV and TCoV are taxonomically distinct viruses or whether TCoV is merely a variant of IBV. Sequence analyzes of TCoV have confirmed the notion that TCoV is a variant of IBV, as these studies have shown that TCoV and IBV are very closely related. However, these studies were limited to only three TCoV strains and relatively small parts of the TCoV genome. TCoV is easily distinguished from IBV due to antigenic and biological differences, and these differences suggest that TCoV should be considered a distinct virus species. Additional studies are needed to better define the relationship between TCoV and IBV and to clarify this taxonomic question. Based on our current understanding, it seems prudent to consider TCoV and IBV as distinct virus species that share a close phylogenetic relationship and together form group 3 of the main antigenic groups of coronavirus.
authors: Guy, J. S.

title: H5 avian and H9 swine influenza virus hemagglutinin structures: possible origin of influenza subtypes
abstract: There are 15 subtypes of influenza A virus (H1-H15), all of which are found in bird species. Three caused pandemics in the last century: H1 in 1918 (and 1977), H2 in 1957 and H3 in 1968. In 1997 an H5 avian virus and in 1999 an H9 virus caused outbreaks of respiratory disease in Hong Kong. We have determined the three-dimensional structures of the hemagglutinins (HAs) of H5 avian and H9 swine viruses, which are closely related to the viruses isolated from humans in Hong Kong. We compared them to known structures of the H3-HA from the virus that caused the 1968 H3 pandemic and to the HA-esterase fusion (HEF) glycoprotein from an influenza C virus. Structural and sequence comparisons suggest that HA subtypes may have arisen through diversification of properties affecting the metastability of HAs required for their membrane fusion activities in viral infections.
authors: Ha, Y.;Stevens, D. J.;Skehel, J. J.;Wiley, D. C.

title: The Application of Genomics to Emerging Zoonotic Viral Diseases Review
abstract: The transmission of pathogens between species can lead to the emergence of new infectious diseases in humans, as well as in domestic and wild animals. Genomic tools such as high-throughput sequencing, mRNA expression profiling, and microarray-based analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms offer unprecedented opportunities to analyze the diversity of the genomes of emerging pathogens and the molecular basis of host responses to them. By comparing and contrasting the outcomes of an emerging infection with those of closely related pathogens in different but related host species, we can further delineate the different host pathways that determine the outcome of zoonotic transmission and adaptation to the newly infested species. The ultimate challenge is to link pathogen and host genomic data to the biological outcomes of zoonotic transmission and to translate the integrated data into novel intervention strategies that will ultimately enable the effective control of emerging infectious diseases. [References: 29]
authors: Haagmans, B. L.;Andeweg, A. C.;Osterhaus, A. D.

title: The application of genomics to emerging zoonotic viral diseases
abstract: The transmission of pathogens between species can lead to the emergence of new infectious diseases in humans, as well as in domestic and wild animals. Genomic tools such as high-throughput sequencing, mRNA expression profiling, and microarray-based analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms offer unprecedented opportunities to analyze the diversity of the genomes of emerging pathogens and the molecular basis of host responses to them. By comparing and contrasting the outcomes of an emerging infection with those of closely related pathogens in different but related host species, we can further delineate the different host pathways that determine the outcome of zoonotic transmission and adaptation to the newly infested species. The ultimate challenge is to link pathogen and host genomic data to the biological outcomes of zoonotic transmission and to translate the integrated data into novel intervention strategies that will ultimately enable the effective control of emerging infectious diseases. © 2009 Haagmans et al.
authors: Haagmans, B. L.;Andeweg, A. C.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.

title: Possible sources and routes of infection with the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtype H5N1 in poultry and wild birds in Central Europe in 2007, derived from probability analyses
abstract: In 2007, recurrent outbreaks of H5N1 HPAIV occurred in several Central European countries. In-depth phylogenetic analyzes involving full genome sequences of the viruses involved were performed to elucidate possible invader origins and transmission routes. Tree reconstructions as well as inferences about host shifts and ancestral areas were performed in a maximum likelihood framework. All viruses belonged to a separate subgroup (designated "EMA-3") within Group 2.2 and were therefore distinct from two lineages of HPAIV H5N1 viruses (designated "EMA-1" and "EMA-2") found in of the same geographic area in 2006. Analysis of concatenated coding regions of all eight genome segments significantly improved the resolution and robustness of the reconstructed phylogenies compared to single-gene analyses. At the same time, the methodological limitations of the retrospective establishment of transmission networks in a comparatively small geographical region and over a short period of time became clear when only few corroborating field epidemiological data are available. There are still uncertainties regarding the origin of the EMA-3 viruses from a region that includes south-eastern Germany and the Czech Republic, as well as regarding the routes of spread to other European countries. The AIV surveillance programs for wild birds and poultry in these countries did not show the presence of these viruses in any population. There were several host changes between domestic poultry and wild bird populations. Analysis of eruptions in north-eastern Germany and nearby northern Poland in December 2007 has shown that the geographic and even temporal proximity of eruptions does not necessarily indicate a common source of incidence. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Haase, M.;Starick, E.;Fereidouni, S.;Strebelow, G.;Grund, C.;Seeland, A.;Scheuner, C.;Cieslik, D.;Smietanka, K.;Minta, Z.;Zorman-Rojs, O.;Mojzis, M.;Goletic, T.;Jestin, V.;Schulenburg, B.;Pybus, O.;Mettenleiter, T.;Beer, M.;Harder, T.

title: In vitro isolation, propagation and characterization of duck hepatitis virus type III
abstract: The in vitro isolation, propagation and characterization of duck hepatitis virus type III (DHV-III) is described. This virus, which differs serologically from classic (type I) DHV, multiplied in liver and kidney cell cultures from ducks. Replication was limited in chicken and quail kidney and duck embryo fibroblast cultures. It did not replicate in a variety of other avian or mammalian cell cultures. The virus has been successfully cultured in embryonating duck eggs but not in chickens. DHV-III passed a 50 nm membrane filter, was stable at pH 3.0, and withstood treatment with 5% chloroform. Viral growth was not inhibited by treatment with 5-iodo-2-deoxyuridine. Electron microscopic examination showed crystalline arrangements in the cytoplasm; Virus particles had cubic symmetry and a diameter of about 30 nm. Based on these properties, this virus can be classified as a member of the picornavirus group.
authors: Haider, S. A.;Calnek, B. W.

title: Newly discovered mosquito viruses help fight vector-borne viral diseases
abstract: Many known mosquito-borne viruses, such as dengue, Zika, West Nile, Chikungunya, and Ross River viruses, can be transmitted to vertebrates and are associated with human and animal disease. However, using deep sequencing and other open-minded approaches to detect viruses in mosquitoes has uncovered many new RNA viruses, most of which do not infect vertebrates. The discovery of these 'insect-specific' viruses (ISVs) has redefined the mosquito virus and led to the re-drawing of the boundaries of the taxonomic classification of viruses1,2. Despite their benign phenotype, ISVs have become a hot topic of research, with recent studies suggesting they have significant biotechnology applications.
authors: Hall, R. A.;Jody, H. P.

title: Metagenomic detection of viruses in aerosol samples from workers in animal slaughterhouses
abstract: Published studies have shown that animal slaughterhouse workers are at a higher risk of lung cancer compared to the general population. No specific contributors were identified, and exposure to multiple chemicals was investigated and found unrelated. Evidence points to a biological etiology, as workers exposed to live animals or biological material containing animal faeces, urine, or blood are at greatest risk. To investigate potential biological exposures in animal slaughterhouses, we used a metagenomic approach to characterize the profile of organisms present in an aerosol sample. An aerosol exposure assessment for individual workers was achieved through the collection of personal samples representing the respirable fraction of dust/bioaerosol in the workplace air in both cattle and sheep slaughterhouses. Two sets of nine personal aerosol samples were pooled for the cattle processing and sheep processing areas, respectively, generating a total of 332,677,346 sequence reads and 250,144,492 sequence reads of 85 bp in length, respectively. A eukaryotic genomic sequence was found at both sampling sites, and bovine, ovine, and human sequences were common. WU polyomavirus and human papillomavirus 120 sequences were detected in the metagenomic data set from the bovine processing area and these sequences were confirmed to be present in the original personal aerosol samples. This study represents the first metagenomic description of personal aerosol exposure, and this methodology could be applied to a variety of settings. The detection of two candidate viruses also justifies further investigations in connection with occupational exposure in animal slaughterhouses. © 2013 Hall et al.
authors: Hall, R. J.;Leblanc-Maridor, M.;Wang, J.;Ren, X.;Moore, N. E.;Brooks, C. R.;Peacey, M.;Douwes, J.;McLean, D. J.

title: Detection of arboviruses and other microorganisms in experimentally infected mosquitoes using massively parallel sequencing
abstract: The incidence of human diseases attributed to arbovirus infection is increasing worldwide, with effective control measures limited by issues of sustainability, insecticide resistance, and the lack of effective vaccines. Several promising control strategies are currently being developed, such as B. the release of mosquitoes trans-infected with virus-blocking Wolbachia bacteria. The implementation of any control program depends on effective virus surveillance and a thorough understanding of virus-vector interactions. Massively parallel sequencing has enormous potential for providing comprehensive genomic information that can be used to assess many aspects of arbovirus ecology, as well as evaluate novel control strategies. To demonstrate the proof-of-principle, we analyzed Aedes aegypti or Aedes albopictus experimentally infected with dengue, yellow fever, or chikungunya viruses. Random amplification was used to generate sufficient template for sequencing on the Personal Genome Machine. Viral sequences were present in all infected mosquitoes. In addition, in most cases we were also able to identify the mosquito species and mosquito microorganisms, including the bacterial endosymbiont Wolbachia. Importantly, naturally occurring Wolbachia strains could be distinguished from strains that had been transfected into the mosquito. The method allowed us to assemble almost complete viral genomes and detect other microorganisms in a single reaction without prior knowledge of the sequence. This is a step towards the application of massively parallel sequencing as an arbovirus surveillance tool. It has the potential to provide insights into the dynamics of virus transmission and is applicable for post-release monitoring of Wolbachia in mosquito populations.
authors: Hall-Mendelin, S.;Allcock, R.;Kresoje, N.;van den Hurk, A. F.;Warrilow, D.

title: Metabarcoding analysis of eukaryotic microbiota in the gut of HIV-infected patients
abstract: Research into the relationship between changes in the gut microbiota and human diseases, including AIDS, is a growing area. However, studies on the eukaryotic component of the gut microbiota are just beginning and have not yet been conducted in HIV-infected patients. In addition, the profiling of the eukaryotic community is influenced by using different methods at each step of culture-independent techniques. Herein, four DNA extraction protocols were first compared to test the efficiency of each method in recovering eukaryotic DNA from stool samples. Our results showed that the recovery of eukaryotic components from stool samples differs significantly between DNA extraction methods. Subsequently, the composition of the intestinal eukaryotic microbiota in HIV-infected patients and healthy subjects was examined by clone sequencing, high-throughput sequencing of nuclear ribosomal internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS1) and 2 (ITS2) amplicons, and real-time PCRs. Our results showed that not only the richness (Chao-1 index) and alpha diversity (Shannon diversity) differ between HIV-infected patients and healthy volunteers, depending on the molecular strategy used, but also the composition of the global eukaryotic community, with few overlapping taxa found between techniques. Furthermore, our results based on cloning libraries and ITS1/ITS2 metabarcoding sequencing revealed significant differences in fungal composition between HIV-infected patients and healthy volunteers, but with no clear clusters separating the two groups.
