Malassezia restricta was significantly more common in stool samples from HIV-infected patients according to cloning libraries, while operative taxonomic units (OTUs) of Candida albicans and Candida tropicalis were significantly more common in stool samples from HIV-infected patients than in healthy subjects in both ITS subregions. Finally, real-time PCR revealed the presence of Microsporidia, Giardia lamblia, Blastocystis and Hymenolepis diminuta in different proportions in stool samples from HIV patients compared to healthy subjects. Our work has shown that using different sequencing approaches can affect perceived outcomes of eukaryotic diversity of the human gut. We also provide a more comprehensive overview of the eukaryotic community in the gut of HIV-infected patients through the complementarity of the different molecular techniques used. The combination of these different methods may provide a gold standard for a more complete characterization of the eukaryotic microbiome in future studies.
authors: Hamad, I.;Abou Abdallah, R.;Ravaux, I.;Mokhtari, S.;Tissot-Dupont, H.;Michelle, C.;Stein, A.;Lagier, J. C.;Raoult, D.;Bittar, F.

title: Using Bayesian network modeling to unravel farm management risk factors for bovine viral diarrhea viral infection
abstract: Understanding the risk factors for bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) transmission is important for planning national disease control programs. However, traditional statistical approaches may miss important features of BVD epidemiology due to the highly correlated nature of many farm-level risk factors. In this cross-sectional study, we used data collected in 2015/2016 from 304 cattle herds in New Zealand to compare the results of multivariate logistic regression versus Bayesian network (BN) analysis. Blood samples from 15 heifers from each herd were pooled and analyzed using an antibody ELISA test to classify BVD virus exposure status. Farmers were asked about their general management practices, knowledge of BVD and risk factors for disease transmission, including on- and off-farm movement, on-farm and inter-farm contacts, and whether they have implemented BVD control measures for their farm bulls. Multiple imputation was used to infer missing values in the dataset prior to statistical analysis. The results showed that 57/116 (49.1%) cattle farms and 95/188 (50.5%) dairy farms were probably actively infected with BVD virus. Almost 60% of the farms had heifers/cows brought onto the farm and 13.8% of the farmers reported contact with cattle from other farms. Multivariable logistic regression results showed that farms with heifers/cows on-site for all or most of the last five years had a higher risk of being BVD seropositive than farms without these movements (OR 2.21, 95% CI 1.29 - 4.24). Farms with occasional or infrequent contact between cattle and cattle from other farms were also at increased risk compared to farms with no animal-to-farm contact (OR 2.63, 95% CI 1.33-5.41), although this association was not frequency-dependent was. Only close animal contacts between farms were directly associated with BVD status in the BN model, however this approach further unraveled other complex relationships between correlated management factors and provided additional important insights into BVD epidemiology. Compared to other countries with intensive production systems, contact across the fence appears to play a more important role in New Zealand's pastoral production systems and should be considered when developing strategies for a national BVD control program.
authors: Han, J. H.;Holter, J.;Moffat, J.;Weston, J. F.;Heuer, C.;Gates, M. C.

title: Genetic recombination between two genotypes of bovine genogroup III (BoNVs) and capsid sequence diversity between BoNVs and Nebraska-like bovine enteric caliciviruses
abstract: To determine the genogroups and genotypes of bovine enteric caliciviruses (BECVs) circulating in calves, we determined the complete capsid gene sequences of 21 BECVs. The nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences were phylogenetically compared to those of known human and animal enteric caliciviruses. Based on these analyses, 15 BECVs belonged to norovirus genogroup III and genotype 2 (GIII/2) and were genetically distinct from human norovirus GI and GII. Six BECVs had capsid gene sequences similar to those of the unclassified Nebraska (NB)-like BECV. The 15 bovine noroviruses (BoNVs) were more closely related to Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK (GIII/2) and other known BoNVs of genotype 2 than to genotype 1 Bo/NLV/Jena/80/DE. The BoNV Bo/CV521-OH/02/US showed high nucleotide and amino acid identities (84 and 94%, respectively) with the capsid gene of Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK, while the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the RNA polymerase genes were more closely related to those from Bo/NLV/Jena/80/DE (77 and 87% identities, respectively) than to those from Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK (69 and 69% identities), suggesting indicates that Bo/CV521-OH/02/US is a genotype 1-2 recombinant. Gene conversion analysis by the recombinant identification program and SimPlot also predicted that Bo/CV521-OH/02/US was a recombinant. Six NB-like BECVs shared 88-92% nucleotide and 94-99.5% amino acid identities with the NB-BECV in the capsid gene. The results of this study demonstrate the genetic diversity in the capsid genes of BECVs circulating in Ohio calf calves, provide new data for co-infections with different BECV genotypes or genogroups, and describe the first natural BoNV genotype 1-2 recombinant , analogous to the previously reported human norovirus recombinant.
authors: Han, M. G.;Smiley, J. R.;Thomas, C.;Saif, L. J.

title: [Metagenomics-based detection of swine viruses]
abstract: There are extreme types of viruses in the environment and in animals, some of which are unknown. However, many unknown viruses are poorly detected using conventional virus isolation and PCR testing. Development of a technology platform for the detection of unknown viruses. We have established the technology based on viral metagenomics in combination with novel molecular diagnostics. The technology consists of host nucleic acid removal, random PCR amplification, large-scale sequencing and bioinformatics. The technology was applied to detect classical swine fever virus (CSFV) infected cells and a tissue sample from a pig infected with porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2). We amplified 13.7% of the sequences from the CSFV genome and 47.2% of the sequences from the PCV2 genome, respectively. In addition, we amplified 16.4% sequences of the simian parainfluenza virus type 5 genome from an unknown viral cell culture using the developed method. Furthermore, with the developed method in combination with high-throughput sequencing, we have detected 1.1% virus sequences including CSFV, PCV2, torque tenosus virus (TTSuV), porcine bocavirus (PBoV) and human adenovirus type 6 (Ad6) of 7 clinical swine specimens with unknown pathogens. The developed metagenomics-based method showed good sensitivity for the detection of both DNA and RNA viruses from different porcine samples and has the potential for universal detection of known and unknown viruses. It could make it easier to diagnose emerging viral diseases.
authors: Han, W.;Luo, Y.;Zhao, B.;Sun, Y.;Li, S.;Qiu, H.

title: Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae – a major cause of severe pneumonia in the Norwegian musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) population.
abstract: The Norwegian musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) population lives on the high mountain plateau of Dovre and descends from animals introduced from Greenland. In the late summers of 2006 and 2012, severe pneumonia occurred with mortality rates of 25-30%. During the 2012 epidemic, high quality samples were obtained from culled diseased animals for microbiological and pathological testing. High-throughput sequencing (pyrosequencing) of pneumonic lung tissue revealed high concentrations of Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae in all six animals examined with this method and Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida in four animals, but no virus sequences could be identified. Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae and P. multocida multocida were also isolated by culture. Using real-time PCR on lung swabs, M. ovipneumoniae was detected in all 19 pneumonic lungs examined. Gross pathological examination revealed severe consolidations mainly in the cranial parts of the lungs and also identified a case of otitis media. Histologically, lung lesions were characterized as acute to subacute mixed exudative and moderately proliferative bronchoalveolar pneumonia. Immunohistochemical (IHC) analysis revealed a high load of M. ovipneumoniae antigens in lung lesions, with particularly intense staining in the neutrophils. Similar IHC findings were observed in archived lung tissue blocks from animals examined during the 2006 epidemic. A M. ovipneumoniae-specific ELISA was performed on muskoxen sera from biobanks of stray muskoxen killed and diseased muskoxen culled in 2004-2013, as well as sera from wild reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) on Dovre and Musk oxen from Greenland applied. Serology and mycoplasma cultivation were also performed on sheep grazing in the musk ox range during the 2012 outbreak. Our results indicated separate introductions of M. ovipneumoniae infections in 2006 and 2012 from infected grazing sheep. Salt licks shared by both species were a possible route of infection.
authors: Handeland, K.;Tengs, T.;Kokotovic, B.;Vikoren, T.;Ayling, R. D.;Bergsjo, B.;Sigurardottir, O. G.;Bretten, T.

title: Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae – A major cause of severe pneumonia in the Norwegian musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) population.
abstract: The Norwegian musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) population lives on the high mountain plateau of Dovre and descends from animals introduced from Greenland. In the late summers of 2006 and 2012, severe pneumonia occurred with mortality rates of 25-30%. During the 2012 epidemic, high quality samples were obtained from culled diseased animals for microbiological and pathological testing. High-throughput sequencing (pyrosequencing) of pneumonic lung tissue revealed high concentrations of Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae in all six animals examined with this method and Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida in four animals, but no virus sequences could be identified. authors: Handeland, K.;Tengs, T.;Kokotovic, B.;Vikoren, T.;Ayling, R. D.;Bergsjo, B.;SigurÃ°ardÃ³ttir Ã“, G.;Bretten, T.

title: Infection with the pathogenic simian immunodeficiency virus is associated with expansion of the enteric vioma
authors: Handley, S. A.;Thackray, L. B.;Zhao, G.;Presti, R.;Miller, A. D.

title: Swine epidemic diarrhea in Europe: Detailed analyzes of disease dynamics and molecular epidemiology
abstract: Porcine epidemic diarrhea (PED) is an acute and highly contagious enteric disease of swine caused by the virus of the same name (PEDV), which belongs to the genus Alphacoronavirus within the family Coronaviridae. After the catastrophic outbreaks in Asia and the United States, PEDV was also discovered in Europe. To better understand the overall situation, the molecular epidemiology and factors that could influence the diverse impacts of the disease; 40 samples of pig feces were collected from different PED outbreaks in Germany and other European countries and sequenced by next-generation shotgun sequencing. A total of 38 new complete PEDV coding sequences were generated. In a global comparison, all examined sequences from central and south-eastern Europe formed a fairly homogeneous PEDV-S-INDEL cluster, indicating recent reintroduction. However, detailed analyzes revealed two new clusters and putative ancestral tribes. Based on the available background data, no connections could be made between clusters and location, farm type or clinical picture. In addition, the influence of secondary infections was examined using metagenomic datasets. While several co-infections were observed, no association with disease progression was found. However, in addition to the PEDV genomes, ten complete viral coding sequences were reconstructed from nine different datasets, each representing new virus strains. Specifically, three Pasivirus A strains, two Astroviruses, a porcine Sapelovirus, a Kobuvirus, a porcine Torovirus, a Posavirus, and an Enterobacteria phage were almost completely sequenced.
authors: Hanke, D.;Pohlmann, A.;Sauter-Louis, C.;HÃ¶per, D.;Stadler, J.;Ritzmann, M.;Steinrigl, A.;Schwarz, B. A.;Akimkin, V.;Fux, R.;Blome, S.;Beer, M.

title: High diversity of picornaviruses in rats from different continents revealed by deep sequencing
abstract: Outbreaks of zoonoses in humans and livestock are not uncommon, and rapid and reliable diagnosis is an important component in containing such emerging viral diseases. Such methods are often PCR-based and therefore require the availability of pathogen sequence data. Rattus norvegicus (R. norvegicus) is a known reservoir for important zoonotic pathogens. Transmission can be direct through contact with the animal, for example through contact with its faeces, or indirectly through arthropod vectors. Here we examined the virus content in rat faeces (n=29) collected from two continents by analyzing 2.2 billion next-generation sequencing reads derived from both DNA and RNA. Among other virus families, we found sequences from members of the Picornaviridae that are abundant in the microbiome of all samples. Here we describe the diversity of picornavirus-like contigs, including nearly complete genomes, closely related to Boone cardiovirus and Theiler encephalomyelitis virus. From this study we conclude that picornaviruses are more diverse within R. norvegicus than previously thought. The virome of R. norvegicus should be further studied to assess the full potential for transmission of zoonotic viruses.
authors: Hansen, T. A.;Mollerup, S.;Nguyen, N. P.;White, N. E.;Coghlan, M.;Alquezar-Planas, D. E.;Joshi, T.;Jensen, R. H.;Fridholm, H.;KjartansdÃ³ttir, K. R.;Mourier, T.;Warnow, T.;Belsham, G. J.;Bunce, M.;Willerslev, E.;Nielsen, L. P.;Vinner, L.;Hansen, A. J.

title: Human sapoviruses: genetic diversity, recombination and classification
abstract: The family Caliciviridae contains four genera Sapovirus, Norovirus, Lagovirus, and Vesivirus, which include Sapporovirus (SaV), Norwalk Virus (NoV), Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease Virus (RHDV), and Feline Calicivirus (FCV), respectively. SaV is a causative agent of gastroenteritis in children and adults. SaV can be divided into five genogroups (GI-GV), of which GI, GII, GIV and GV are known to infect humans while SaV GIII infects swine species. Detection methods include ELISA, RT-PCR and real-time RT-PCR. Because few SaV studies have been conducted, it is difficult to draw any correlations between or inferences about incidence rates, detection, and overall prevalence. However, most studies agree that SaV infection occurs more frequently in young children than in adults, and that infection in children almost always occurs by the age of 5 years. In addition, children in day-care centers and institutions are most at risk of SaV-associated infection and transmission. A number of important insights into human SaV have recently been discovered. SaV strains have been detected in water samples including raw wastewater samples, treated wastewater samples and river samples. SaV strains have also been detected in shellfish samples destined for human consumption, and recombinant SaV strains have been identified in a number of different countries. The purpose of this review was to highlight the current knowledge of human SaV, which appears to be an increasingly important virus causing gastroenteritis in humans. Copyright © 2007 John Wiley & Sons,Ltd.
authors: Hansman, G. S.;Oka, T.;Katayama, K.;Takeda, N.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of a novel parvovirus distantly related to human bufavirus in domestic swine
abstract: In this study, a novel parvovirus (pig strain/Zsana3/2013/HUN, KT965075) was detected in domestic pigs and genetically characterized by viral metagenomics and PCR methods. The novel parvovirus was distantly related to human bufaviruses and was detected in 19 (90.5%) of 21 and five (33.3%) of 15 fecal samples collected from animals with and without cases of posterior paraplegia of unknown etiology in five were affected companies or a control company in Hungary. Swine/Zsana3/2013/HUN is widespread in domestic pigs and may represent a new parvovirus species in the subfamily Parvovirinae.
authors: Hargitai, R.;Pankovics, P.;KertÃ©sz, A. M.;BÃ­rÃ³, H.;Boros, Ã;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Close phylogenetic relationship between egg drop syndrome virus, bovine adenovirus serotype 7 and ovine adenovirus strain 287
abstract: cloned egg drop syndrome (EDS) virus genomic DNA fragment containing the protease gene was identified and the complete nucleotide sequence of the protease and partial nucleotide sequence of the hexon genes were determined. Phylogenetic analysis of the protease gene has shown that EDS virus is genetically more closely related to bovine adenovirus type 7 (BAV-7) and ovine adenovirus isolate 287 (OAV287) than either of these two viruses with other members the genus Mastadenovirus or EDS virus belongs to another member of the genus Aviadenovirus. The three viruses share further similarities in that they have a high percentage of AT in their genome and are characterized by having more compact genomes than other adenoviruses. The protease gene from all three viruses contained active site residues (H55-D72-C122 triad) and C104 (which provides a disulfide bond to cofactor pVIc). However, P137, which is found in all other members of the Mastadenovirus genus and is believed to be involved in trafficking, was absent from the protease of EDS virus, BAV-7 and OAV287. These results suggest that EDS virus should be classified in a separate taxon along with BAV-7 and OAV287.
authors: Harrach, B.;Meehan, B. M.;BenkÃ¶, M.;Adair, B. M.;Todd, D.

title: The strange, expanding world of animal hepaciviruses
abstract: Hepaciviruses and Pegiviruses form two closely related sister genera of the family Flaviviridae. In the last five years, the known phylogenetic diversity of the hepacivirus genera has exploded. What was once an isolated infection in humans (and possibly other primates) has now spread to horses, rodents, bats, colobus monkeys, cows and, more recently, catsharks, shedding new light on the genetic diversity and host range of throws hepaciviruses. Interestingly, despite the identification of these many animal and primate hepaciviruses, equine hepaciviruses remain the closest genetic relatives of human hepaciviruses, providing an intriguing clue to the zoonotic source of hepatitis C virus. This review article summarizes the importance of these studies and discusses current thinking about the origin and evolution of animal hepaciviruses and their potential use as surrogate models for the study of hepatitis C virus.
authors: Hartlage, A. S.;Cullen, J. M.;Kapoor, A.

title: Comparative analysis of selected genes of the entopoxvirus Diachasmimorpha longicaudata and other poxviruses
abstract: Diachasmimorpha longicaudata entopoxvirus (DlEPV) is the first symbiotic EPV described from a parasitic wasp. The DlEPV is introduced into the larval host of the tephritid fruit fly along with the wasp egg during oviposition. We sequenced a shotgun genomic library of DlEPV DNA and analyzed and compared the predicted protein sequences of eight ORFs with those of selected poxviruses and other organisms. BlastP searches revealed that five of these are homologous to putative poxvirus proteins, such as metalloprotease, a putative membrane protein, later transcription factor-3, virion surface protein, and the regulatory small subunit of poly(A) polymerase (PAP). Three of these are similar to those found in other organisms, such as Arabidopsis thaliana gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT), Caenorhabditis briggsae eukaryotic initiation factor 4A (eIF4A), and Enterococcus faecium lambda phage integrase (γ-Int). Transcriptional motifs for early (TGA, A/T, XXXXA) or late (TAATG, TAAT, or TAAAT) gene expression that are conserved in poxviruses were identified using these ORFs. Phylogenetic analysis of multiple alignments of five ORFs and 20 poxvirus homologous sequences and a chaining of multiple alignments suggested that DlEPV probably diverged from the parent node between fowlpox virus and the genus B, Lepidoptera and Orthoptera EPVs, to which Amsacta moorei and Melanoplus sanguinipes EPV belong. The putative DlEPV GGT, eIF4A and κ-Int contained many conserved domains that typified these proteins. These homologues may be involved in either viral pathogenicity or parasitism enhancement via the gamma-glutamyl cycle and compensation of eIF4A levels in the parasitized fly, or via the integration of part of the viral genome into the wasp and/or parasitized fly be. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Hashimoto, Y.;Lawrence, P. O.

title: Genetic diversity of chicken anemia virus after cell culture passage in MSB-1 cells
abstract: chicken anemia virus (CAV) isolate passaged 60 in MSB-1 cells (SMSC-1/P60, 3-1/P60) was shown to acquire 33-66 nucleotide substitutions in the coding region, which was to 13-16 amino acid changes compared to the only 5-fold passaged CAV isolates in MSB-1 cells (SMSC-1 and 3-1) (Chowdhury et al., Arch. Virol. 148, 2437-2448, 2003) . In this study we found that low passage CAV (BL-5) and high passage CAV (BL-5/P90) differed by only 15 nucleotide substitutions, resulting in 11 amino acid changes. The phylogenetic analysis based on VP1 also revealed that both isolates were close to each other but not to other CAV isolates from Malaysia namely SMSC-1 and 3-1.
authors: Hasmah, M. S.;Omar, A. R.;Wan, K. F.;Hair-Bejo, M.;Aini, I.

title: The outbreaks of Newcastle disease in Sudan from 2003 to 2006 were caused by genotype 5d viruses
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is a serious neurological and respiratory disease in poultry that affects all species of birds but has traditionally not caused symptoms in wild waterfowl, the natural hosts. In the late 1990s, a new genotype, viz. 5d, which is pathogenic to all bird species including waterfowl, originated in China and has since spread from East Asia to parts of Europe, the Middle East and Africa. We performed a phylogenetic analysis of the fusion protein gene of isolates from ND outbreaks in Sudan and found that all contemporary strains isolated between 2003 and 2006 were of genotype 5d and contained the virulent fusion protein cleavage site (F0) motif 112RRQKRF117 included. Introduction via a trading partner in the Middle East is likely the source of infection as phylogenetic analysis ruled out the possibility of introduction from western and southern Africa. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Hassan, W.;Khair, S. A. M.;Mochotlhoane, B.;Abolnik, C.

title: Transmission patterns of human enterovirus 71 in, from and between European countries, 2003 to 2013
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV-71) is implicated in hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) epidemics and is believed to occur in East and Southeast Asia with severe neurological complications. In other geographical areas, the transmission of this virus is poorly known. We used large sequence datasets (of the gene encoding viral protein 1, VP1) and a Bayesian phylogenetic approach to characterize the molecular epidemiology and geographic distribution patterns of EV-71 subgenogroups B4, B5, C1, C2, and C4 in Europe relative to compare other parts of the world. European countries considered for the study were the Member States of the European Union (EU) as well as Iceland, Norway and Switzerland. Viruses of subgenogroups B4, B5 and C4 circulate mainly in East and Southeast Asia. Sporadic introductions of these subgenogroups are observed in Europe, but C1 and C2 viruses predominate. The phylogenies have shown evidence of multiple spread events involving C1 and C2 viruses in Europe since the mid-1990s. Two waves of sporadic C2 infections also occurred in 2010 and 2013. The C2 outbreak in the Netherlands in 2007 and the emergence of B5 and C4 infections in the EU between 2004 and 2013 occurred while the circulation of C1 -Viruses was low. A chain of transmission involving a C4 virus was traced from Japan to the EU and then on to Canada between 2001 and 2006. Recent events in which viruses were spread from, to and within Europe appear to be implicated in the long-term survival of EVs -71, highlighting the need for increased surveillance of this virus.
authors: Hassel, C.;Mirand, A.;Lukashev, A.;Terletskaia Ladwig, E.;Farkas, A.;Schuffenecker, I.;Diedrich, S.;Huemer, H. P.;Archimbaud, C.;Peigue-Lafeuille, H.;Henquell, C.;Bailly, J.

title: Borna disease
abstract: Borna disease virus, a reclassified, non-segmented, negative-strand RNA virus with an international distribution, infects a wide range of warm-blooded animals, from birds to primates. The infection causes movement and behavioral disorders reminiscent of some neuropsychiatric syndromes. The virus has not been clearly linked to a human disease; However, an association between infection with the virus and selected neuropsychiatric disorders has been suggested. We reviewed recent advances in Borna disease virus research, focusing on the detection of infection in humans.
authors: Hatalski, C. G.;Lewis, A. J.;Lipkin, W. I.

title: Detection of Campylobacter jejuni in rectal swab specimens from Rousettus amplexicaudatus in the Philippines
abstract: Bats are the second largest mammal species and are widespread around the world. They are regarded as reservoirs and transmitters of zoonotic pathogens. However, there are hardly any reports on the detection of pathogenic bacteria kept in bats. Accurate knowledge of the pathogenic bacteria in the microbiota of bats is important for the control of zoonoses. Therefore, a metagenomic analysis targeting the V3-V4 region of the 16S rRNA of the rectal microbiota in Rousettus amplexicaudatus was performed using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that 103 genera of bacteria including Camplyobacter were detected. Campylobacter was the second most common genus, and Campylobacter coli and Campylobacter jejuni have been identified in the microbiome of R. amplexicaudatus. Campylobacteriosis is one of the serious bacterial diarrhea in humans and the species most commonly involved as the causative agent of campylobacteriosis is C. jejuni. Therefore, we investigated the prevalence of C. jejuni in 91 wild bats using PCR. As a result of a PCR assay targeting the 16S-23S intergenic spacer, a partial C. jejuni genome was detected in only five R. amplexicaudatus. This is the first report that C. jejuni has been detected in rectal swab specimens from bats. C. jejuni is the most common cause of campylobacteriosis in humans, transmitted through water and contact with livestock. This result indicated that R. amplexicaudatus could be a carrier of C. jejuni.
authors: Hatta, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Katayama, Y.;Taniguchi, S.;Masangkay, J. S.;Puentespina, R.;Eres, E.;Cosico, E.;Une, Y.;Yoshikawa, Y.;Maeda, K.;Kyuwa, S.;Mizutani, T.

title: Use of reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction to detect avian leukosis virus vaccine contamination
abstract: reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for avian leukosis virus (ALV) was developed to detect contamination of vaccines prepared in chicken embryonated eggs and cell cultures. ALV is highly pathogenic and causes a wide range of diseases in infected animals. ALV can be divided into five subgroups (AE). The envelope glycoprotein (env gp85) is the major antigenic determinant and responsible for subgroup classification. Viral RNA from all subgroups (AE) was isolated and amplified using three sets of primers. Subsequently, restriction endonuclease analysis confirmed product identity and distinguished between subgroups. In specific pathogen-free (SPF) eggs experimentally vaccinated with ALV, viral RNA has been found in allantoic fluids as well as in vaccines spiked with various subgroups of ALV. No adventitious virus was detected in commercially available preparations. This system provides a rapid and specific in vitro method for the detection of ALV RNA as a foreign substance and can be used for quality control of avian vaccines.
authors: HÃ¤uptli, D.;Bruckner, L.;Ottiger, H. P.

title: Virus detection by metagenomic sequencing of nasal and rectal swabs from pigs
abstract: Advances in DNA sequencing have increased our ability to generate large amounts of sequence data at lower cost. These developments have enabled microbial detection and characterization directly from clinical specimens, known as metagenomic sequencing. Viral metagenomic sequencing was performed on five nasal and five fecal swab pools collected respectively from two primary and two secondary market slaughterhouses and one club pig purchaser in the southeastern United States. The sequences were assembled de novo and analyzed by BLASTN to identify viruses present in the samples. 27 different viruses were identified. Readouts resembling a diverse family of single-stranded circular DNA viruses were identified in almost every sample (47 out of 50). Other viruses identified at all five sampling sites and in more than half of the samples were bocavirus, torovirus, posavirus, torque tenovirus, IAS virus, picobirnavirus and techovirus. Viruses identified at multiple sites in more than 20% of samples included enterovirus, parvovirus, influenza A virus, sapelovirus, and senecavirus A. Other significant swine viruses detected less frequently were porcine circovirus type 2 , Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus and Porcine Deltacoronavirus. Taken together, these results suggest that metagenomic sequencing is a powerful tool for virus detection and characterization.
authors: Hause, B.;Duff, J. W.;Scheidt, A.;Anderson, G.

title: Bovine rhinitis viruses are common in US cattle with bovine respiratory disease
abstract: Bovine rhinitis viruses (BRV) are established etiologic agents of the bovine respiratory disease complex, however little research on their epidemiology and ecology has been published over several decades. Only bovine rhinitis A virus 1 (BRAV1) has been identified in the US, while bovine rhinitis A virus 2 (BRAV2) and bovine rhinitis B virus (BRBV) have previously only been identified in England and Japan, respectively . Metagenomic sequencing of a nasal swab from a bovine respiratory disease (BRD) diagnostic submission from Kansas identified contigs with approximately 90% nucleotide similarity to BRAV2 and BRBV. A combination of de novo and template assemblies using reference genomes yielded nearly complete BRAV2 and BRBV genomes. The nearly complete genome of bovine rhinitis A virus 1 (BRAV1) was also determined from a historical isolate to enable further molecular epidemiological studies. A 5' nuclease reverse transcription PCR assay targeting the 3D polymerase gene was developed and used to screen 204 archived BRD clinical specimens. Thirteen (6.4%) were positive. Metagenomic sequencing of six positive specimens identified mixed BRAV1/BRAV2, BRAV1/BRBV, and BRAV2/BRBV infections for five specimens. One sample showed only infection with BRAV1. Seroprevalence studies with a cell culture-adapted BRBV revealed that immunofluorescence assay-reactive antibodies were common in the analyzed flocks. Taken together, these results indicate that BRV infection is common in cattle with respiratory disease and that BRAV1, BRAV2 and BRBV co-circulate in US cattle and show high similarity to viruses isolated more than 30 years ago from different locations.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Collin, E. A.;Anderson, J.;Hesse, R. A.;Anderson, G.

title: Characterization of a novel bovine and porcine influenza virus: Proposal for a new genus in the family Orthomyxoviridae
abstract: We recently reported the isolation of a novel virus, provisionally designated C/swine/Oklahoma/1334/2011 (C/OK), with an overall homology of 50% to human influenza C viruses (ICV) from a pig in Oklahoma. Deep RNA sequencing of C/OK virus revealed a matrix 1 (M1) protein expression strategy that differed from that of ICV. The novelty of the C/OK virus prompted us to investigate whether the C/OK virus could exist in a non-porcine species. Significantly, we found that C/OK virus was widespread in US cattle herds as shown by reverse transcription (RT)-PCR and serological assays. Genome sequencing of three bovine viruses isolated from two herds in different states further confirmed these results. To determine whether porcine/bovine C/OK viruses can be reassorted with human ICV and to clarify the taxonomic status of C/OK, in vitro reassortment and serological typing by agar gel Immunodiffusion (AGID) performed. In vitro resorting using two human ICV and two porcine and bovine C/OK viruses demonstrated that human ICV and C/OK viruses were unable to resort and give rise to viable progeny to produce. Antigenically, no cross-recognition of detergent-cleaved virions between human and non-human viruses was observed in AGID using polyclonal antibodies reactive with related antigens. Taken together, these results demonstrate that C/OK virus is genetically and antigenically distinct from ICV. The classification of the new virus in a separate genus of the Orthomyxoviridae family is proposed. The finding of C/OK virus in pigs and cattle indicates that this new virus can spread and cause infection in other mammals, including humans. © 2014 Heimat et al.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Collin, E. A.;Liu, R.;Huang, B.;Sheng, Z.;Lu, W.;Wang, D.;Nelson, E. A.;Li, F.

title: Discovery of a new putative atypical porcine pestivirus in pigs in the United States
abstract: Pestiviruses are some of the most important pathogens affecting ruminants and swine. Here we assembled an 11,276 bp contig encoding a predicted porcine serum 3635 aa polyprotein with 68% pairwise identity to that of a recently partially characterized Rhinolophus affinis pestivirus (RaPV) and about 25–28% pairwise identity to those of other pestiviruses , the virus was tentatively named atypical porcine pestivirus (APPV), metagenomic sequencing of 182 serum samples identified four additional APPV-positive samples, positive samples originated from five states, and ELISAs using recombinant tests APPV Erns found cross-reactive antibodies in 94% of a collection of Pig serum samples, indicating widespread distribution of APPV in the US swine herd. The molecular and serological results suggest that APPV is a novel, highly divergent porcine pestivirus that is widespread in US swine.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Collin, E. A.;Peddireddi, L.;Yuan, F.;Chen, Z.;Hesse, R. A.;Gauger, P. C.;Clement, T.;Fang, Y.;Anderson, G.

title: Identification of a novel Picornavirales virus distantly related to Posavirus in pig faeces
abstract: De novo assembly of metagenomic sequencing reads from the faeces of a clinically normal pig identified two approximately 9 kb contigs, each consisting of a single large open reading frame. While one contig encoded a predicted 2990 amino acid protein with 83% identity to the recently reported posavirus 1, the other contig encoded a predicted 2942 amino acid protein with only 25% identity restricted to the genomic region encoding the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp ) from posavirus 2. In addition to RdRp, searching the conserved domain database identified domains associated with picornavirus capsid proteins, but failed to identify picornavirus helicase and proteinase domains. In addition, a domain representing a family of mycoplasma and ureaplasma immunoglobulin-blocking virulence proteins was identified near the 5″ terminus. Phylogenetic analysis revealed a distant relationship between this novel virus, tentatively named posavirus 3, and the unclassified posaviruses and fisavirus, which are believed to represent distinct genera in a novel family of picornaviruses.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Hesse, R. A.;Anderson, G. A.

title: An inactivated influenza D virus vaccine partially protects cattle from respiratory disease caused by homologous challenge
authors: Hause, B. M.;Huntimer, L.;Falkenberg, S.

title: Senecavirus A in pigs, USA, 2015
authors: Hause, B. M.;Myers, O.;Duff, J.;Hesse, R. A.

title: Wild boar viromes are dominated by single-stranded DNA viruses and contain a novel orthopneumovirus that circulates in both wild and domestic pigs
abstract: Wild boar are known reservoirs for various pathogens that can harm domestic animals. To assess the viral ecology of wild boar in the US, metagenomic sequencing was performed on 100 pooled nasal swabs. The virome was dominated by small ssDNA viruses belonging to the families Circoviridae, Anelloviridae and Parvovirinae. Only four RNA viruses have been identified: porcine kobuvirus, porcine sapelovirus, atypical porcine pestivirus, and a new orthopneumovirus, tentatively named swine orthopneumovirus (SOV). SOV shared approximately 90% nucleotide identity with murine pneumonia virus (MPV) and canine pneumovirus. A modified, commercially available ELISA for MPV revealed that approximately 30% of sera from wild and domestic pigs were positive for antibodies cross-reactive with MPV. Quantitative reverse transcription PCR identified two (2%) and four (5.0%) positive nasal swab pools from feral and domestic pigs, respectively, confirming that SOV is circulating in both herds.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Padmanabhan, A.;Pedersen, K.;Gidlewski, T.

title: Very diverse posaviruses in pig faeces are of aquatic origin
abstract: Posaviruses are a group of very diverse viruses that have been identified in pig feces and are distantly related to other members of the order Picornaviruses. Eighteen posavirus genomes were assembled from 10 of 25 (40%) fecal swab pools collected from healthy adult pigs. Phylogenetic analysis of the conserved RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (Pol) domain revealed that posaviruses form a large, highly diverse, monophyletic phylum that includes similar viruses endemic in human (Husavirus) and fish (Fisavirus) faeces and gut contents, respectively have been identified. Quantitative reverse transcription-PCR analysis of water samples from commercial pig houses revealed that four of 19 (21%) samples were positive using a 5-nuclease assay targeting the pol region of Posavirus 1. ICPD assays (immunoprecipitation coupled to PCR detection) to examine Serological evidence of posavirus infection yielded only a single positive sample, suggesting that posaviruses do not normally infect pigs, and taken together these results suggest a likely aquatic host.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Palinski, R.;Hesse, R.;Anderson, G.

title: Complete genome sequence of a porcine polyomavirus from nasal swabs from pigs with respiratory diseases
abstract: Metagenomic sequencing of pooled nasal swabs from pigs with unexplained respiratory disease identified a large number of reads that were mapped to a previously uncharacterized porcine polyomavirus. Sus scrofa polyomavirus 2 was most closely related to betapolyomaviruses, which were frequently detected in mammalian respiratory specimens.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Smith, C.;Bishop, B.;Stewart, C.;Simonson, R.

title: The pseudo-vaccinia virus genome: comparison of a reindeer isolate and a reference strain
abstract: Parapoxviruses (PPV) from the Poxviridae family cause pustular skin disease in sheep and goats (Orf virus, ORFV) and cattle (pseudocowpoxvirus, PCPV and bovine papular stomatitis virus, BPSV). Here we present the first genomic sequence of a reference strain of PCPV (VR634) together with the genomic sequence of a PPV (F00.120R) isolated from reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) in Finland. The F00.120R and VR634 genomes are 135 and 145 kb in length and contain 131 and 134 putative genes, respectively, with genome organization similar to that of other PPVs. The predicted proteins from F00.120R and VR634 have an average amino acid sequence identity of over 95%, while sharing only 88% and 73% amino acid identity with the ORFV and BPSV proteomes, respectively. The most notable differences were found near the ends of the genome. F00.120R is missing six and VR634 is missing three genes, seen near the right terminus of other PPVs. Four genes at the left end of F00.120R and one in the middle of both genomes appear to be fragmented paralogues of other genes within the genome. VR634 has larger than expected inverted terminal repeats, possibly as a result of genomic rearrangements. The high G+C content (64%) of these two viruses together with amino acid sequence comparisons and whole genome phylogenetic analyzes support the classification of PCPV as a separate species within the genus Parapoxvirus and provide evidence that the virus is responsible for an outbreak of contagious stomatitis in reindeer in the winter of 1999-2000 can be classified as PCPV. © 2010 SGM.
authors: Hautaniemi, M.;Ueda, N.;Tuimala, J.;Mercer, A. A.;LahdenperÃ¤, J.;McInnes, C. J.

title: History of prions and transmission of protein misfolding
abstract: Since J. Cuillé and PL Chelle in 1936 successful scrapie between sheep by experimental inoculation and DC Gajdusek-Kuru and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in 1966 respectively remains a mystery. In 1982, S. Prusiner named them "PRIONs" (for "PROteinaceous Infectious Particles") because they appeared to lack the nucleic acids that would classify them as viruses. Although infectious or genetic mechanisms have rarely been identified, most of the rare human PRION diseases are 'sporadic'. They shared many clinical and neuropathological features with human neurodegenerative diseases (slow development, prominent nervous system involvement, amyloid deposits, poor immune response), the mechanism of which was not usually considered to be infectious. In 1991, H. Braak showed the low spread of neuropathological tau-associated lesions along anatomical pathways in the brain of Alzheimer's disease. They appear long before the clinical signs. It is believed that the abnormally misfolded proteins characteristic of many neurodegenerative diseases aggregate after initial seeding. This leads to their transmission and cell-to-cell spread via neuronal and extraneuronal pathways, the unexpected extent of which is currently being investigated. Whether the seed is contagious or not remains a matter of debate. This new paradigm for understanding their natural history and phenotypic diversity, which has already led to assessing the diagnostic value of skin biopsy, should open the door to new therapeutic approaches.
authors: Hauw, J. J.;Haik, S.;Brandel, J. P.

title: Detection of Salmonella Typhimurium microevolution during a series of egg-associated outbreaks associated with a single chicken farm
abstract: BACKGROUND: The bacterium Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (S. Typhimurium) is one of the most common causes of foodborne gastroenteritis outbreaks. Between 2005 and 2008, a series of S. Typhimurium outbreaks occurred in Tasmania, Australia, all of which were traced to eggs from a single chicken farm. We sequenced the genomes of 12 isolates associated with these outbreaks to study the microevolution of a pathogenic S. Typhimurium clone in a natural, spatiotemporally limited population. RESULTS: The isolates, which shared a phage type similar to DT135, known locally as 135@ or 135a, formed a clade within the S. Typhimurium population with close similarity to the reference genome SL1334 (160 single nucleotide polymorphisms or SNPs). Ten of the isolates belonged to a single clone (<23 SNPs between isolate pairs) that likely represents the population of S. Typhimurium circulating on the chicken farm; the other two were from sporadic cases and genetically distinct from this clone. Divergence dating showed that all 12 isolates diverged from a common ancestor in the mid-1990s and the clone began to diversify in 2003-2004. This clone entered the human population several times between 2005 and 2008, during which time it continued to accumulate SNPs at a constant rate of 3-5 SNPs per year, or 1x10-6 substitutions site-1 year-1, faster than the longer-term ( ~50 years) rates previously estimated for S. Typhimurium. Our data indicate that approximately half of the non-synonymous substitutions are rapidly removed from the S. Typhimurium population, after which purifying selection is no longer important and the remaining substitutions become fixed in the population. The S. Typhimurium 135@ isolates were almost identical to SL1344 in terms of gene content and virulence plasmids. Their phage contents were similar to SL1344 except that they carried a different variant of Gifsy-1, they lacked the P2 residue found in SL1344, and they carried a new P2 phage, P2-Hawk, instead of SL1344's P2 phage SopEphi . DT135 lacks P2 prophage. Two additional plasmids were identified in the S. Typhimurium 135® isolates, pSTM2 and pSTM7. Both plasmids were IncI1, but phylogenetic analysis of the plasmids and their bacterial hosts shows that these plasmids are genetically distinct and result from independent plasmid acquisition events. CONCLUSIONS: This study provides a high-resolution insight into the short-term microevolution of the important human pathogen S. Typhimurium. It shows that purifying selection occurs rapidly (<= 6 years) and then declines in this population, and provides an estimate for the short-term substitution rate. The latter is likely to be more relevant for investigating foodborne outbreaks than previous estimates based on longer time periods.
authors: Hawkey, J.;Edwards, D. J.;Dimovski, K.;Hiley, L.;Billman-Jacobe, H.;Hogg, G.;Holt, K. E.

title: Diversity demonstrated in VP3, NSP3 and NSP4 of rotavirus B in Japanese cattle
abstract: Bovine rotavirus B (RVB) is an etiological agent of diarrhea, mainly in adult cattle. At present, a few viral protein (VP)1, 2, 4, 6, and 7 and nonstructural protein (NSP)1, 2, and 5 sequences of bovine RVB are available in the DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank databases, and none of these have been identified for VP3 , NSP3 and NSP4 reported. To fill this gap in the genetic characterization of bovine RVB strains, we used a metagenomic approach and sequenced and analyzed the complete coding sequences (CDS) of VP3, NSP3 and NSP4 genes, as well as the partial or complete CDS of other genes of RVBs detected in Japanese cattle. VP3, NSP3 and NSP4 from bovine RVBs shared low nucleotide sequence identities (63.3-64.9% for VP3, 65.9-68.2% for NSP3 and 52.6-56.2% for NSP4) with those of murine , human, and porcine RVBs, suggesting that bovine RVBs belong to a new genotype. In addition, significantly low amino acid sequence identities for NSP4 (36.1-39.3%) were observed between bovine RVBs and the RVBs of other species. In contrast, hydrophobic plot analysis of NSP4 revealed profiles similar to those of RVBs from other species and rotavirus A (RVA) strains. Phylogenetic analyzes of all gene segments showed that bovine RVB strains formed a cluster that branched away from other RVBs. These results suggest that bovine RVBs evolved independently from other RVBs, but in a manner similar to other rotaviruses. These results provide insights into the evolution and diversity of RVB strains.
authors: Hayashi-Miyamoto, M.;Murakami, T.;Minami-Fukuda, F.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Kishimoto, M.;Sano, K.;Naoi, Y.;Asano, K.;Ichimaru, T.;Haga, K.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Aoki, H.;Shirai, J.;Ishida, M.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Single-stranded genomic RNA from turkey enterovirus-like virus
abstract: Previously, we described a disease syndrome in young turkeys caused by an enterovirus-like virus. The virus has been termed an enterovirus-like virus based on the size, morphology, and intracytoplasmic crystalline arrangements of the virus. In the present study, further characterization of the virus was performed to determine its classification. The virus has a buoyancy density of 1.33 g/ml in CsCl and a single-stranded RNA genome of approximately 7.5 kilobases. These combined properties indicate that this agent is an enterovirus.
authors: Hayhow, C. S.;Parwani, A. V.;Saif, Y. M.

title: Analysis of HIV-1 subtype B third variable region peptide motifs for induction of neutralizing antibodies against HIV-1 primary isolates
abstract: The HIV-1 gp120 V3 loop is a potent inducer of neutralizing antibodies for T-cell lineage-adapted HIV-1, but less so for primary isolates. We hypothesized that peptides representative of the diversity of natural HIV-1 V3 loop variants could capture elements of conserved higher order structures and thus stimulate broadly reactive neutralizing antibodies. We designed a panel of 29 subtype B V3 sequences postulated to reflect the range of V3 diversity. These peptides were used to immunize guinea pigs. The most potent peptide (62.19) clustered around the B-subtype consensus sequence and induced antibodies that reproducibly neutralized 31% of the B-subtype HIV-1 primary isolates evaluated but limited cross-neutralization of non-B-subtype HIV-1 strains exhibited. Taken together, these data indicated that the narrowed neutralization profile of antibodies induced by optimal subtype B V3 motifs likely represents the maximal breadth of neutralization of subtype B HIV-1 primary isolates induced by anti-V3 peptide -antibodies can be reached. © 2005 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Haynes, B. F.;Ma, B.;Montefiori, D. C.;Wrin, T.;Petropoulos, C. J.;Sutherland, L. L.;Scearce, R. M.;Denton, C.;Xia, S. M.;Korber, B. T.;Liao, H. X.

title: Group A rotaviruses in Chinese bats: Genetic composition, serology, and evidence for transmission and reassortment from bats to humans
abstract: Bats are natural reservoirs for many disease-causing viruses, and increasing evidence supports the idea that bats may also harbor group A rotaviruses (RVAs), important causative agents of diarrhea in children and young animals. To date, 8 RVA strains have been identified from African and Chinese bats, which possess entirely new genotype constellations or possibly genotypes derived from other mammals. However, all data were mainly based on the detection of RVA RNA, which is only present during acute infections, which does not allow an assessment of the actual exposure of a bat population to RVA. To systematically examine the genetic diversity of RVAs, 547 anal swabs or gut samples from bats and 448 bat sera were collected from five southern Chinese provinces. Specific reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) screening revealed four RVA strains. Strain GLRL1 possessed an entirely new genotype constellation, while the other three possessed a constellation consistent with the MSLH14-like genotype, a newly characterized group of viruses widespread in Chinese insectivorous bats. Among the latter, strain LZHP2 provided strong evidence for cross-species transmission of RVAs from bats to humans, while strains YSSK5 and BSTM70 were likely reassortants between typical MSLH14-like RVAs and human RVAs. RVA-specific antibodies were detected in 10.7% (48/448) of bat sera by indirect immunofluorescence assay (IIFA). Bats in Guangxi and Yunnan had higher RVA-specific antibody prevalence than those in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces. These observations provide evidence for the cross-species transmission of MSLH14-like bat RVAs to humans and underscore the public health implications of bats as reservoirs of RVAs. IMPORTANCE Bat viruses such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), Ebola, Hendra and Nipah viruses are major pathogens causing outbreaks of severe emerging infectious diseases. However, little is known about bat viruses that can cause gastroenteritis in humans, although 8 group A viruses (RVAs) have been identified in bats to date. Another 4 RVA strains were identified in this study, one of which provides strong evidence for zoonotic transmission from bats to humans. Serological studies have also shown that RVA infection in bats is far more common than expected based on the detection of viral RNA.
authors: He, B.;Huang, X. H.;Zhang, F. Q.;Tan, W. L.;Matthijnssens, J.;Qin, S. M.;Xu, L.;Zhao, Z. H.;Yang, L. E.;Wang, Q. X.;Hu, T. S.;Bao, X. L.;Wu, J. M.;Tu, C. C.

title: Virome profiling of Myanmar bats through metagenomic analysis of tissue samples reveals additional novel mammalian viruses
authors: He, B.;Li, Z.;Yang, F.;Zheng, J.;Feng, Y.;Guo, H.;Li, Y.

title: Characterization of a novel G3P[3] rotavirus isolated from a lesser horseshoe bat: a distant relative of feline/canine rotaviruses
abstract: Bats are considered important animal reservoirs for many human-pathogenic viruses. A viral metagenomics-based approach was used to examine gut samples from 78 insectivorous bats in Yunnan Province, China. 74 reads were found to be related to group A rotavirus (RVA). Further reverse transcription PCR screening and virus isolation on cell cultures confirmed the presence of a novel strain of RVA named RVA/Bat-tc/MSLH14/2012/G3P[3] in 1 (6%) of 16 lesser horseshoe bats. Complete genomic sequence analyzes showed that MSLH14 possessed the genotype constellation G3-P[3]-I8-R3-C3-M3-A9-N3-T3-E3-H6, which is similar to human and animal rotaviruses, which are thought to be they come from cats. dog origin. Phylogenetic analysis showed that VP7 was most closely related to bovine RVA strains from India, while VP4 was most closely related to an uncommon human RVA strain, CMH222, whose animal characteristics were isolated in Thailand. The remaining gene segments were only distantly related to a number of animal RVA strains, most of which are believed to be related to feline/canine RVAs. Experimental infections showed that the bat RVA strain MSLH14 was highly pathogenic to lactating mice and caused 100% mortality when inoculated orally at a titer as low as 5 x 102 50% tissue culture infecting doses. Since this virus is not closely related to any known RVA strain, it is tempting to speculate that it is a true bat RVA strain rather than a virus transmitted between species. However, further screening of bat populations, preferably juveniles, will be crucial to determine whether or not this virus is widespread in the bat population.
authors: He, B.;Yang, F.;Yang, W.;Zhang, Y.;Feng, Y.;Zhou, J.;Xie, J.;Feng, Y.;Bao, X.;Guo, H.;Li, Y.;Xia, L.;Li, N.;Matthijnssens, J.;Zhang, H.;Tu, C.

title: Genome-wide mapping of hypersensitive DNase I sites and association analysis with gene expression in MSB1 cells
abstract: DNase I hypersensitive sites (DHSs) mark different classes of cis-regulatory regions, such as promoters and enhancers. MSB-1, derived from chick Marek's disease (MD) lymphoma, is an MDV-transformed CD4+ T cell line for MD studies. Previously, DNase IHS sites were mainly studied in mammalian human cell types. To capture the regulatory elements specific to MSB1 cells and to investigate the molecular mechanisms of T cell transformation induced by MDV in MD, we generated a high-quality DHS map and gene expression profile for functional analysis in the MSB1 cell line. A total of 21,724 significant peaks of DHSs were identified from around 40 million short reads. The DHS distribution varied between the chromosomes and they accumulated preferentially in the gene-rich chromosomes. More interestingly, DHS accumulation appeared to be scarce in regions with many CpG islands. Furthermore, we integrated DHSs into the gene expression data and found that DHSs tended to enrich for highly expressed genes in entire gene regions, while DHSs showed no significant changes for weakly and silently expressed genes. In addition, the correlation of DHSs with lincRNAs expression was also calculated, implying that enhancer-associated lincRNAs are likely to originate from enhancer-like regions of DHSs. Taken together, our results showed that DNase I HS sites strongly correlate with active gene expression in MSB1 cells, suggesting that DHSs can be viewed as markers to identify the cis-regulatory elements associated with chicken Marek's disease are. © 2014 Er, Carrillo, Luo, Ding, Tian and Song.
authors: He, Y.;Carrillo, J. A.;Luo, J.;Ding, Y.;Tian, F.;Song, J.

title: Whole genome sequencing of Newcastle disease genotype VI viruses from formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded feral pigeon tissue reveals continuous evolution and previously unrecognized genetic diversity in the US
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is highly contagious and causes disease in both wild birds and poultry. A pigeon-adapted variant of genotype VI NDV, often referred to as pigeon paramyxovirus 1, is commonly isolated from columbids in the United States and worldwide. Complete genomic characterization of these genotype VI viruses circulating in wild columbids in the United States is limited, and failure of rapid diagnostic detection has been reported due to the genetic variability of the virus. Therefore, in this study, formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples were subjected to next-generation sequencing (NGS) to identify and characterize these circulating viruses, providing valuable genetic information. NGS allows parallel deep sequencing of multiple samples. When applied to FFPE samples, this methodology allows for retrospective studies on infectious organisms. Methods: Tissue samples from FFPE feral pigeons (kidney, liver and spleen) from 10 US deaths between 2010 and 2016 were analyzed by NGS to detect and sequence NDV genomes from randomly amplified total RNA. The results were compared to previously published immunohistochemistry (IHC) results performed on the same samples. In addition, phylogenetic analyzes of the complete and partial fusion gene and the complete genome coding sequences were performed. Results: 23 out of 29 IHC-positive FFPE pigeon samples were identified as positive for NDV by NGS. Positive samples revealed an average genome coverage of 99.6% and an average median depth of 199. A previously described subgenotype (VIa) and a new subgenotype (VIn) of NDV were identified as causative agents of 10 pigeon mortality events in the US from 2010 to 2016. The Distribution of these viruses from the North American lineages is consistent with the distribution of Eurasian collared pigeons and rock pigeons in the US FFPE wild bird samples. There are at least two distinct US lines of genotype VI NDV kept in feral pigeons that are continuously evolving independently and have no apparent epidemiological links to viruses circulating abroad. These results support the hypothesis that columbids serve as a reservoir for virulent NDV in the US
authors: He, Y.;Taylor, T. L.;Dimitrov, K. M.;Butt, S. L.;Stanton, J. B.;Goraichuk, I. V.;Fenton, H.;Poulson, R.;Zhang, J.;Brown, C. C.;Ip, H. S.;Isidoro-Ayza, M.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Electrostatic variation of hemagglutinin as a hallmark of avian influenza virus evolution
abstract: Avian influenza virus is a zoonotic agent that has a significant impact on public health and the poultry industry. Monitoring virus development and spread is critical for surveillance and tracing programs currently based on serological or DNA sequencing phylogenetic analysis. However, virus-host interactions, antigenic drift, and spread of viral clades are highly dependent on variations in the surface features of capsid proteins. We report here that in silico comparative structural analyzes of hemagglutinin can reveal relevant evolutionary fingerprints, especially when integrated with sequence-based analyses. Phylogenetic analyzes of H9 virus strains from wild birds and poultry, performed using different methods, reliably lead to clusters of viruses in five main groups. Subsequent comparison of structural features revealed congruence between such clustering and electrostatic fingerprints on the surface. These latter fingerprints relate group-specific variations in electrostatic charges and isocontours to well-known hemagglutinin sites involved in modulation of immune escape and host specificity. This work suggests that integrating structural and sequence comparisons can improve the study of trends and relevant mechanisms in viral evolution.
authors: Heidari, A.;Righetto, I.;Filippini, F.

title: MChip, a low-density microarray, distinguishes between seasonal human H1N1, North American swine H1N1, and the 2009 pandemic H1N1
abstract: Please cite this work as follows: Heil et al. (2010) MChip, a low-density microarray, distinguishes between seasonal human H1N1, North American swine H1N1, and the 2009 pandemic H1N1. Influenza and other respiratory viruses 4(6), 411-416. Background The MChip uses data from the hybridization of amplified viral RNA to 15 different oligonucleotides targeting the influenza A matrix (M) gene segment. An artificial neural network (ANN) automates the interpretation of subtle differences in the fluorescence intensity patterns of the microarray. The complete process from clinical sample to identification, including viral RNA amplification, can be completed in less than 8 hours for less than $10. Aims The work presented here represents an attempt to extend and test the capabilities of the MChip to discriminate influenza A/H1N1 from different species. Methods The MChip ANN was trained to recognize fluorescence image patterns of a variety of known influenza A viruses, including examples of human H1N1, human H3N2, porcine H1N1, 2009 pandemic influenza A H1N1, and a variety of avian, equine, , canine and swine flu viruses. The robustness of the MChip ANN was assessed using 296 blinded isolates. Results Training of the ANN was augmented by the addition of 71 well-characterized influenza A isolates and resulted in relatively high accuracy (low misclassification) in distinguishing distinct H1N1 strains: nine human A/H1N1 (88 9% correct), 35 human A/H3N2 (97·1% correct), 31 North American swine A/H1N1 (80·6% correct), 14 2009 pandemic A/H1N1 (87·7% correct), and 23 negative specimens (91·3% correct ). Genetic diversity among porcine H1N1 isolates may have contributed to the lower success rate for these viruses. Conclusions The current study shows that the MChip has the ability to discriminate the genetic variations between influenza viruses with appropriate ANN training. Further selective enrichment of the ANN will improve its ability to rapidly and reliably characterize influenza viruses of unknown origin. © 2010 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Heil, G. L.;McCarthy, T.;Yoon, K. J.;Liu, S.;Saad, M. D.;Smith, C. B.;Houck, J. A.;Dawson, E. D.;Rowlen, K. L.;Gray, G. C.

title: Molecular characterization of avian reovirus isolates in Tunisia
abstract: Background: Genotype analyzes of avian reoviruses isolated from organ samples from chickens with suspected clinical symptoms between 1997 and 2008 were based on sequences for both ÏƒC and ÏƒB genes and were aligned with those published in Genbank, allowing studies to be conducted enabled molecular classification and relationships. methods. The full length of the known variable protein ÏƒC and part of the ÏƒB-encoding genes were amplified by RT-PCR using conserved primers. PCR products were sequenced and the sequences were analyzed and aligned with avian reovirus sequences from the Genbank database. Results: The sequences of the ÏƒC-encoding genes of all isolated strains showed their close relationship with the American, Chinese and Indian strains. Taking the American strain S1133 as a reference, the two Tunisian isolates 97.1 and 97.2 showed some nucleotide substitutions. In isolate 97.1 the substitution was silent, whereas in strain 97.2 the mutation was at the first position of the corresponding codon and induces substitution of the encoded amino acid. For the βB-encoding gene, the sequences of the Tunisian strains showed mutations at positions two or three of the corresponding codons, resulting in amino acid substitutions at these positions. The phylogenetic trees based on ÏƒC and ÏƒB encoding genes revealed a closer relationship between Tunisian, American and Taiwanese genotype I isolates. Conclusion: Our study describes the genotype of avian reoviruses, which are not yet genetically well characterized. The characterization and classification of these viruses could be important for understanding the epidemiology of malabsorption syndrome and viral arthritis and improve our knowledge of the genotype of the strains circulating in Tunisian herds. In addition, studying their variable pathogenicity could be extremely important in choosing the appropriate vaccine strain to combat the disease. © 2013 Hellal Kort et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Hellal Kort, Y.;BourogÃ¢a, H.;Gribaa, L.;Scott-Algara, D.;Ghram, A.

title: Isolates of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype C from India belong to a separate, previously undescribed lineage
abstract: Complete 1D gene sequences of 13 field isolates of type C Indian foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus and one vaccine strain (C-Bombay/64) were determined. All field isolates showed greater genetic homogeneity (95-100%) among themselves and differed from the vaccine strain by 19.7-21.2%. In the phylogenetic analysis, the Indian field isolates formed a separate lineage (lineage VII) distinct from the previously identified six lineages (lineages I-VI) in type C FMDV [J. virol. 66 (1992) 3557]. The vaccine strain was grouped with the European line (line II). A comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences of antigenic sites A and C of field isolates showed no significant divergence from the vaccine strain. The serological one-way relationship determined in the ELISA showed an antigenic proximity of the field isolates to C-Bombay/64. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Hemadri, D.;Sanyal, A.;Tosh, C.;Venkataramanan, R.;Pattnaik, B.

title: Emergence of a new strain of foot-and-mouth disease virus type O: Its phylogenetic and evolutionary relationship with the PanAsia pandemic strain
abstract: In India, foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) serotype O has been associated with more than 75% of outbreaks. Previous studies with this serotype have shown that the viruses circulating in India belong to a single genotype. Recent (February 2001) FMD epidemics in Europe have drawn worldwide attention to the source of the virus and has been traced to a strain, PanAsia (serotype O), present in India since 1990. In this study, pertinent to further characterizing the isolates of the Pan-Asian strain, we sequenced the complete VP1-encoding (1D) gene for 71 isolates of FMDV serotype O from India recovered from field outbreaks during the past 4 decades (1962-2001). . All isolates in the tree were distributed into three main branches (designated A, B and C); branch C is further divided into four groups (I-IV), of which group IV belongs to the PanAsia tribe. In addition, we show that the PanAsia strain has been endemic in circulation since 1982 (not 1990 as previously reported) and has been the most dominant outbreak strain in recent years, spreading to at least 17 states in the country. During 2001, another new group (Group III) of viruses with a genetic divergence of 5.4-11.1% at the nucleotide level was found co-circulating endemic to the PanAsia strain and slowly replacing it. At the amino acid level, this strain differed from the PanAsia strain at five amino acid positions in VP1. Although these strains differ at the nucleotide level, they retained a good antigenic relationship with one of the country's widespread vaccine strains (IND R2/75). Given the PanAsia virus' ability to persist, spread and outperform other strains, the current trend could be a cause for serious concern as the emerging virus replaces it. If so, then there is another strain as different as PanAsia that could pose a serious threat to the global dairy and meat industry.
authors: Hemadri, D.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Venkataramanan, R.

title: Genetic analysis of foot-and-mouth disease virus type O isolates responsible for field outbreaks in India between 1993 and 1999
abstract: Partial nucleotide sequences at the 3″ end of the 1D gene (encoding VP1) from 90 foot-and-mouth disease virus type O isolates recovered from field outbreaks in India between 1993 and 1999 were determined. The sequences were compared with each other and with reference viruses. The published sequences of 15 type O isolates obtained from different parts of Asia, as well as one isolate (O1BFS) from Europe and one from Egypt (O1/Sharquia/Egypt/72) were also included in the analysis for comparison. Based on the phylogenetic analysis, the viruses could be divided into four different genotypes (genotypes I-IV). All 90 isolates from India were genotype I, as were the reference isolates from Bangladesh, China, Egypt, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Turkey. Genotype I isolates have been further divided into 16 subgenotypes. The Indian isolates were found to be extremely heterogeneous in nature and have been classified into 12 distinct genetic groups. In genotype I, the nucleotide sequence difference observed between isolates ranged from 0-11.6%, while in Indian isolates it ranged from 0-8.8%. Viruses of similar genetic groups are circulating in India, Bangladesh and Middle Eastern countries. Genotype-II and -III are represented by isolates from Lebanon (O1/Southern Lebanon) and Europe (O1-BFS), respectively. Genotype IV is made up of isolates from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. The present study shows the emergence of viruses belonging to multiple genetic groups over a short period of time and the persistence of a single genetic group in the same geographic area over several years. This is consistent with the endemic nature of the disease in the country.
authors: Hemadri, D.;Tosh, C.;Venkataramanan, R.;Sanyal, A.;Samuel, A. R.;Knowles, N. J.;Kitching, R. P.

title: MERS coronavirus in a dromedary camel herd, Saudi Arabia
abstract: A prospective study of a dromedary camel herd during the 2013-14 calving season demonstrated Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus infection in calves and adults. Virus has been isolated from the nose and feces, but more commonly from the nose. Pre-existing neutralizing antibody did not appear to protect against infection.
authors: Hemida, M. G.;Chu, D. K.;Poon, L. L.;Perera, R. A.;Alhammadi, M. A.;Ng, H. Y.;Siu, L. Y.;Guan, Y.;Alnaeem, A.;Peiris, M.

title: Comparison of the biological properties of St. Louis encephalitis and Rio Bravo viruses
abstract: St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) virus, an arbovirus, and Rio Bravo (RB) virus, a non-arthropod transmitted virus, and flaviviruses, which cross-react in neutralization assays. Several of their biological properties have been compared. Viral growth curves showed that >99% of infectious SLE (Paton) virus remained cell-associated in Vero cells but was slowly released into the medium of infected BHK-21 cells. In contrast, RB (M-64) virus was released into the fluids of Vero and BHK-21 cell cultures upon maturation. Forty-fold more SLE virus than RB virus adsorbs to monolayer cultures of Aedes dorsalis cells. SLE but not RB virus replicated and reached high titers (108 pfu/ml) in Ae. dorsalis cell cultures maintained in media expected to improve recovery of RB virus. Furthermore, SLE but not RB virus replicated in cultured bat epithelial cells and primary duck embryo cells incubated at 42°C. The prototype strains of RN and SLE viruses are clearly different viruses. Both the classification of the RB virus in the Flavivirus genus and the antigenic relationship between RB and SLE viruses require further clarification.
authors: Hendricks, D. A.;Hardy, J. L.;Reeves, W. C.

title: Human biliary glycoproteins act as receptors for interspecies transmission of mouse hepatitis virus
abstract: variant of mouse hepatitis virus (MHV), designated MHV-H2, was isolated by serial passage in mixed cultures of permissive DBT cells and non-permissive Syrian hamster kidney (BHK) cells. MHV-H2 efficiently replicated in hamster, mouse, primate kidney (Vero, Cos 1, Cos 7) and human adenocarcinoma (HRT) cell lines, but failed to replicate in testis (ST), feline kidney (CRFK) and canine kidney (MDCK) -cells. To understand the molecular basis for cross-species coronavirus transmission into human cell lines, the replication of MHV-H2 in hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2) cells expressing high levels of the human homologue of the normal murine receptor, biliary glycoprotein (Bgp), was investigated. . MHV-H2 replicated efficiently in human HepG2 cells, at low levels in breast cancer cells (MCF7) and poorly, if at all, in human colon adenocarcinoma cell lines (LS 174T) expressing high levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). These data suggested that MHV-H2 might use the human Bgp homologue as a receptor for entry into HepG2 cells. To further investigate the utilization of the MHV H2 receptor in human cell lines, blockade experiments were performed with a variety of monoclonal or polyclonal antisera directed against the human CEA genes. Pretreatment of HepG2 cells with a polyclonal antiserum directed against all members of the CEA family or with a monoclonal antibody, Kat4c (cd66abde), directed against Bgp1, CGM6, CGM1a, NCA and CEA reduces viral replication and the capacity of MHV-H2 to significantly infect HepG2 cells. Using a different panel of monoclonal antibodies with more limited cross-reactivities between the human CEAs, Col-4 and Col-14 but not B6.2, B1.13, Col-1, Col-6 and Col-12 blocked MHV-H2 Infection HepG2 cells. These antibodies did not block Sindbis virus (SB) replication in HepG2 cells and did not block SB, MHV-A59, or MHV-H2 replication in DBT cells. The monoclonal antibodies Col-4, Col-14 and Kat4c (cd66abde) all reacted strongly with human Bgp and CEA, but showed variable binding patterns with other CEA genes. Upon expression of human Bgp in normally non-permissive porcine testicular (ST) and feline kidney (CRFK) cells, the cells became susceptible to MHV-H2 infection. These data suggested that phylogenetic homologues of viral receptors represent natural channels for viral xenotropism and interspecies transmission.
authors: Hensley, L. E.;Baric, R. S.

title: Metagenomic identification, seasonal dynamics, and potential mechanisms of transmission of a Daphnia-associated single-stranded DNA virus in two temperate lakes
abstract: We used a metagenomic approach to identify viruses potentially involved in the ecology of Daphnia spp. involved. in Lakes Oneida and Cayuga (upstate New York). We identified several well-represented putative eukaryotic circular single-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) viral genomes. Among these, we discovered a genotype similar in both sequence and genomic architecture to a virus previously reported from a hyperthermal lake that exhibits characteristics of both single-stranded ribonucleic acid (RNA) and single-stranded DNA viruses . We used quantitative polymerase chain reactions to study the prevalence and viral load of both positive and negative strains of Daphnia mendotae-associated (Cladocera) hybrid virus (DMClaHV) over a summer season in Oneida and Cayuga Lakes. DMClaHV had a high prevalence within Daphnia populations where viral loads and the proportion of virus-positive individuals were higher prior to host population decline. The DMClaHV viral load was different between two species of daphnia (D. mendotae and D. retrocurva), and the dynamics between viruses and their hosts varied between the two lakes. We have detected DMClaHV in eggs (Ephippia) collected from sediments of Lake Oneida with an estimated age of 30 years. Using transmission electron microscopy, we observed small (20 nm diameter) virus-like particles in daphnia that were distant from gut tissue and not associated with intracellular parasites. As Daphnia play a crucial role in many lake ecosystems, DMClaHV can have important impacts on the herbivores and thus the carbon flux through the lake ecosystem.
authors: Hewson, I.;Ng, G.;Li, W. F.;LaBarre, B. A.;Aguirre, I.;Barbosa, J. G.;Breitbart, M.;Greco, A. W.;Kearns, C. M.;Looi, A.;Schaffner, L. R.;Thompson, P. D.;Hairston, N. G.

title: Application of high-resolution melting curve analysis to classify infectious bronchitis viruses in field samples
abstract: Aim: A real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR)/high-resolution melting curve analysis (HRM) protocol was developed in our laboratory to differentiate reference strains of infectious bronchitis (IB) virus. In the current study, this method was used to detect and classify IB viruses in field submissions. Procedure: Over an 11 month period, samples were received from 40 cases suspected of having IB virus and 17 submissions were positive for IB virus by polymerase chain reaction. HRM curve analysis classified each strain as a subgroup 1, 2, or 3 strain (12 submissions) or a strain that could not be classified (5 submissions). The 3' untranslated region (UTR) and partial S1 gene nucleotide sequences for the 17 IB virus strains were determined and their identities compared to those of the relative reference strains to confirm the classifications generated using HRM curve analysis. Results: Of the 12 IB field viruses classified as subgroup 1, 2, or 3 by HRM curve analysis, the 3'UTR and S1 gene nucleotide sequences had ≥ 99% identities with the reference strain of each subgroup. Analysis of the 3'UTR and S1 gene nucleotide sequences for the five IB virus strains that could not be classified indicated that four belonged to one of the subgroups and one was a potential recombinant strain (between the 2nd and 3rd subgroup strains). and 3). A new recombinant strain was also discovered. Conclusion: HRM curve analysis can rapidly assign the majority of IB viruses present in field submissions to known subgroups. Importantly, the HRM curve analysis also identified aberrant genotypes that require further investigation. © 2010 The Authors. Australian Veterinary Journal © 2010 Australian Veterinary Association.
authors: Hewson, K. A.;Browning, G. F.;Devlin, J. M.;Ignjatovic, J.;Noormohammadi, A. H.

title: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus: sequence analysis of the small RNA segments from a collection of viruses worldwide
abstract: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFv) is a member of the genus Nairovirus in the Bunyaviridae family. It has a tripartite, negative-polarity, single-stranded RNA genome composed of large (L), medium (M), and small (S) segments. CCHF virus is enzootic in livestock and wildlife in many parts of the Middle East, Asia and Africa, and is also recognized in south-eastern Europe. Serious illnesses, which manifest themselves as hemorrhagic fever and high mortality rates (up to 50%), are only known in humans. We have determined the complete sequence of the small genomic RNA segment of several strains of CCHF virus from outbreaks in Pakistan in 2000, Baghdad in 1976 and Uzbekistan in 1967 that they can be divided into seven subtypes. Superimposed on this pattern are connections between distant geographic locations, suggesting the existence of a global reservoir of CCHFv. In some cases, these links can result from livestock trade and long-distance transmission of viruses or infected ticks during bird migration. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Hewson, R.;Chamberlain, J.;Mioulet, V.;Lloyd, G.;Jamil, B.;Hasan, R.;Gmyl, A.;Gmyl, L.;Smirnova, S. E.;Lukashev, A.;Karganova, G.;Clegg, C.

title: Guinea pig model of infectious diseases - viral infections
authors: Hickey, A. J.

title: Coat protein gene sequences of five strains of peanut streak virus (PStV) from Thailand and their evolutionary relationship to other sequences of bean common mosaic virus
abstract: The coat protein gene and part of the 3' non-coding region of five strains of peanut streak virus (PStV) from Thailand have been cloned and sequenced.
