Phylogenetic comparisons of these strains known as T1, T3, T5, T6 and T7 and related sequences indicated that these strains are indeed PStV strains. In addition, PStV strains appear to be related to each other in terms of geographic origin. That is, the Thai strains are more closely related to each other than to strains from the US or Indonesia, despite the variety of symptoms caused by these strains and the overlap of symptom types between strains from different locations. Like other PStV strains, PStV-Thai can be considered a strain of Bean Common Mosaic Virus (BCMV), but can be distinguished from bean-infecting BCMV and Blackeye Cowpea Mosaic Virus (B1CMV) strains by sequence and host range. No evidence was found that PStV Thai strains, in contrast to PStV-Ib, are recombinants of PStV and B1CMV, although the T3 strain could be a recombinant of different PStV sequences. Phylogenetic analyzes of BCMV group viruses suggest that acquisition of the ability to infect peanuts may have occurred only once.
authors: Higgins, C. M.;Cassidy, B. G.;Teycheney, P. Y.;Wongkaew, S.;Dietzgen, R. G.

title: High-Throughput Sequencing Methods for Microbiome Profiling: Application to Food Animal Systems Review
abstract: Analysis of microbial communities using high-throughput sequencing methods began in the mid-2000s, enabling the production of 1000 to 10,000 sequence reads per sample and megabases of data per sequence run. This depth of sequencing, unprecedented at the time, enabled the discovery of the “rare biosphere” in environmental samples for the first time. The technology was quickly applied to studies involving multiple human subjects. Perhaps these early studies served as a reminder that while the microbes inhabiting mammals are known to outnumber host cells by an order of magnitude or more, most of them are unknown members of our second genome, or microbiome (as suggested by Joshua Lederberg embossed). because of our inability to cultivate them. High-throughput microbial 16S ribosomal RNA gene and whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing methods have now begun to reveal the composition and identity of archaeal, bacterial, and viral communities at many sites in and on the human body. Surveys of the microbiota of food producing animals have been published in recent years, and future studies should benefit from protocols and tools developed from large-scale studies of the human microbiome. Nevertheless, production animal-related resources such as improved host genome assemblies and an increased number and diversity of host-specific microbial reference genome sequences are needed to enable meaningful and robust analysis of 16S rDNA and WGS sequence data.
authors: Highlander, S. K.

title: Influenza transmission reflects the seasonality of wild birds in the annual cycle
abstract: Influenza A viruses (IAV) in nature have to overcome changing transmission barriers caused by the mobility of their main host, migratory wild birds, which change in the annual cycle. Using a phylogenetic network of viral sequences from North American wild birds (2008-2011), we demonstrate a shift from intraspecific to interspecific transmission that, along with rearrangement, allows IAV to achieve viral flux across consecutive seasons from summer to winter. Our study supports amplification of IAV during summer breeding seeded by overwintering viruses that persist locally and viruses introduced from a variety of latitudes. As birds migrate from breeding sites to lower latitudes, they become involved in transmission networks with greater connectivity to other bird species, with transmission of reassortant viruses between species peaking in winter. We propose that switching transmission dynamics could be a crucial strategy for pathogens infecting mobile hosts inhabiting regions with strong seasonality.
authors: Hill, N. J.;Ma, E. J.;Meixell, B. W.;Lindberg, M. S.;Boyce, W. M.;Runstadler, J. A.

title: Microbial ecology along the gastrointestinal tract
abstract: The human gastrointestinal (GI) tract ecosystem goes through a range of environmental, chemical and physical conditions as it runs from the oral cavity to the anus. These differences in conditions along with food or other ingested substrates affect the composition and density of the microbiota, as well as their functional roles, selecting those best suited to that environment. Previous studies have primarily focused on bacteria, with the number of studies on Archaea, Eukarya, and Viruses being limited despite their important roles in this ecosystem. Furthermore, due to the challenges associated with sampling directly from inside humans, many studies are still exploratory and mainly focus on the composition of microbiomes. Therefore, mechanistic studies to investigate functions in animal models are performed. However, differences in physiology and microbiomes need to be elucidated to support the translation of animal model findings into the human context. This review will highlight bacteria, archaea, fungi, and viruses, discuss differences along the gastrointestinal tract of healthy humans, and make comparisons with three common animal models: rats, mice, and pigs.
authors: Hillman, E. T.;Lu, H.;Yao, T.;Nakatsu, C. H.

title: TTV, a novel human virus with a single-stranded circular DNA genome
abstract: The TT virus (TTV) was found in a hepatitis patient without virus markers in 1997. However, the actual impact of TTV on liver disease is uncertain to this day. Due to the lack of appropriate cellular systems to support the growth of TTV, the biology of TTV is still unclear. This overview attempts to summarize the current status of TTV on aspects other than taxonomic diversity of TTV. TTV was the first human virus with a single-stranded circular DNA genome. TTV has been considered a member of the Circoviridae, but others have suggested that it belongs to a new family. TTV differs from ambisense viruses of the genus circovirus in that the former genome is negative stranded. The genome structure of TTV is more closely related to chicken anemia virus of the genus Gyrovirus, however the sequence similarity is minimal, except for a short stretch at 3816-3851 of TA278. Currently, the working group proposes the full name for TTV as TorqueTenoVirus and the TTV-like minivirus as TorqueTenoMiniVirus (TTMV) in a new genus Anellovirus (ring). TTVs are widespread in nonhuman primates and human TTV can cross-infect chimpanzees. Furthermore, TTV sequences have been detected in chickens, pigs, cows and sheep. TTV can be transmitted through mother-to-child infection. However, within one year after birth, the prevalence reaches the same level for children born to both TTV-positive and TTV-negative mothers, even without breastfeeding. The non-coding region surrounding a short 113 nt GC-rich stretch and occupying about one-third of the genome is thought to contain the putative origin of replication. Three mRNAs are expressed by TTV, 3.0 and 1.2 and 1.0 kb species. A protein translated from the 3.0 kb mRNA is considered to be the main capsid protein as well as a replicase. The nature of the proteins translated from the other two mRNAs is still conjectural. Copyright © 2002 John Wiley & Sons,Ltd.
authors: Hino, S.

title: Torque Teno Virus (TTV): Current Status
abstract: Torque tenovirus (TTV), currently classified in the Circoviridae family, genus Anellovirus, has been identified for the first time in a patient with non-AE hepatitis. TTV has a single-stranded circular DNA of ∼3.8 kb. TTVs are extremely diverse, encompassing five groups including SANBAN and SEN viruses. The torque teno minivirus (TTMV) with a ∆2.9 kb genome also has broad variants. Two related 2.2 and 2.6 kb species recently joined this community. Recombinations between variants are common. This extensive TTV variety remains unexplained; It is unclear how TTVs could be viable and why they require such genetic variation. A clear culture system is not yet available. TTVs are ubiquitous in >90% of adults worldwide, but the human pathogenicity of TTV has not been fully established. Epidemiological studies must specify the variants being studied, clinical targets, and calibrate the sensitivity of the assay used. Potentially interesting observations include higher viral loads in patients with severe idiopathic inflammatory myopathies, cancer and lupus. Active replication has also been found in infants with acute respiratory disease. TTV/TTMV-related viruses have been found in chimpanzees, apes, African monkeys and tupaias, as well as in chickens, pigs, cows, sheep and dogs. Experimentally, rhesus monkeys were persistently infected by TTV, but only 1/53 chimpanzees. TTV transcribes three types of mRNAs, 3.0-, 1.2- and 1.0-kb in the ratio of 60:5:35. Recently, at least three mRNAs have been detected in chicken anemia virus. The genomic region -154/-76 contains a critical promoter. TTV appears to have at least three proteins; However, the precise functions of these proteins await further research. Copyright © 2006 John Wiley & Sons,Ltd.
authors: Hino, S.;Miyata, H.

title: Relationship of torque teno virus to chicken anemia virus
abstract: This chapter examines the correlation between torque teno virus (TTV) and chicken anemia virus (CAV). Each has a circular single-stranded (ss)DNA genome with each of its known open reading frames (ORF) on its antigenomic strand. This structure differs from that of circoviruses. The genomic sizes of TTV and CAV are different, 3.8 kb and 2.3 kb respectively. While the spectrum of the TTV genome is enormously diverse, that of the CAV genome is quite narrow. Although a 36 nt stretch near the origin of replication of TA278-TTV has more than 80% similarity to that of CAV, the sequence of the other genomic regions shows no significant similarity. Nonetheless, the relative assignment of ORFs on each frame in these viruses mimic each other. In both, three or more messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are generated by transcription. The structural protein with the replicase domain is encoded by frame 1 in each virus, and a nonstructural protein with a phosphatase domain is encoded by frame 2. A protein on frame 3 in each virus induces apoptosis in transformed cells. Recently, we confirmed that apoptin is required for CAV replication. It has been suggested that TTV forms a new family, Anelloviridae. Given these similarities and differences between CAV and TTV, it seems more reasonable to place CAV, the sole member of the genus Gyrovirus, together with TTV in Anelloviridae or in a new independent family. © 2009 Springers.
authors: Hino, S.;Prasetyo, A. A.

title: Conservation of L and 3C proteinase activities in distantly related aphtoviruses
abstract: The leader (L) proteinase of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) is an important virulence determinant in FMD infection. It has two distinct catalytic activities: (i) C-terminal processing at the L/VP4 junction; and (ii) induction of cleavage of the translation initiation factor eIF4G, an event that inhibits Cap-dependent translation in infected cells. The only other member of the aphthovirus genus, equine rhinitis A virus (ERAV), also encodes an L protein, but this shares only 32% amino acid identity with its FMDV counterpart. Another more distantly related picornavirus, equine rhinitis B virus (ERBV), which is not classified as an aphthovirus, also encodes an L protein. Using in vitro transcription and translation analysis, we have shown that both ERAV and ERBV-L proteins have C-terminal processing activity. Furthermore, expression of ERAV-L, but not ERBV-L, in BHK-21 cells resulted in efficient inhibition of Cap-dependent translation in these cells. We have shown that the EBAV and FMDV-L proteinases induce eIF4GI cleavage at very similar or identical positions. Interestingly, ERAV 3C also induces eIF4GI cleavage and in turn produces distinct products that co-migrate with those induced by FMDV 3C. ERBV L-proteinase does not induce eIF4GI cleavage, consistent with its inability to turn off Cap-dependent translation. We have also shown that another unique feature of FMDV L, stimulation of enterovirus internal ribosome entry site (IRES) activity, is also shared by ERAV L proteinase but not by ERBV L. The functional preservation of the divergent ERAV and FMDV proteinases suggests the likelihood of a similar and important role for these enzymes in the pathogenesis of infections caused by these distantly related aphtoviruses.
authors: Hinton, T. M.;Ross-Smith, N.;Warner, S.;Belsham, G. J.;Crabb, B. S.

title: Epidemiology of vampire bat-borne rabies virus in Goias, central Brazil: reassessment based on the GL intergenic region
abstract: BACKGROUND: Rabies associated with vampire bats harms both the livestock industry and the public health sector in central Brazil. The geographic ranges of vampire bat-borne variants of the rabies virus are limited by mountain ranges. These findings were elucidated by analyzing a highly conserved nucleoprotein gene. This study aims to elucidate the detailed epidemiological features of vampire bat-borne rabies virus by phylogenetic methods based on the 619-nt sequence including the non-conserved GL intergenic region. RESULTS: The rabies virus isolates transmitted by vampire bats classified into 8 phylogenetic lineages in the previous nucleoprotein gene analysis were classified into 10 phylogenetic lineages with significant bootstrap values. The distribution of most variants was again confirmed as limited by mountain ranges. In addition, variants in undulating areas have narrow distributions and are apparently separated by ridges. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that the 619 nt sequence including the GL intergenic region is more useful for a state-level phylogenetic analysis of rabies virus than the partial nucleoprotein gene, and at the same time that the distribution of vampire bat-transmitted RABV variants tends to be separated not only by mountain ranges but also by ridges, suggesting that the diversity of RABV variants transmitted by vampire bats was limited by geographic waves.
authors: Hirano, S.;Itou, T.;Carvalho, A. A.;Ito, F. H.;Sakai, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of a novel neurotropic bovine astrovirus identified in a Japanese black ox with nonsuppurative encephalomyelitis in Japan
abstract: While neurotropic bovine astroviruses (BoAstVs) have been identified in North America and Europe, their occurrence has never been reported in Asia. In this study, we detected BoAstV in the brain of an ox with neurological signs. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the identified virus belongs to the Virginia/Human-Mink-Ovine Glade, which contains most of the neurotropic astroviruses including the neurotropic BoAstVs. The similarity plot analysis showed that the virus was closely related to the American BoAstV-NeuroS1 strain in terms of the ORF regions and to the European BoAstV-CH13 strain in the 3'-untranslated region, indicating the occurrence of intra-genotypic recombination events indicates.
authors: Hirashima, Y.;Okada, D.;Shibata, S.;Yoshida, S.;Fujisono, S.;Omatsu, T.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Phylogeny and natural history of the primate lentiviruses, SIV and HIV
abstract: Studies of the phylogeny of primate lentivirus over the past decade have identified at least five related but genetically distinct groups of simian immunodeficiency viruses (SIV), each derived from a different African primate species. The hypothesis that HIV-2 (and SIVmac) arose from cross-species transmission of sooty mangabeys (Cercocebus atys) was strengthened by a more detailed characterization of the SIVsm/SIVmac/HIV-2 virus group. SIV from all four African green monkey (SIVagm) subspecies were characterized with an apparent chimeric genome structure of West African green monkey SIVagm. Although these naturally infected primates remain healthy, cross-species transmission to other primate species can lead to immunodeficiency, such as that caused by SIVsm infection of macaques (Macaca sp.) and recently by SIVagm infection of pig-tailed macaques (M. nemestrina). . Studies of variation within infected individuals have been facilitated by adapting the techniques of heteroduplex analysis and single-stranded conformational polymorphism of PCR-generated fragments.
authors: Hirsch, V. M.;Dapolito, G.;Goeken, R.;Campbell, B. J.

title: The relationship of the receptors of a new strain of virus to those of the mumps-NDV influenza group
abstract: The interrelationships of the cellular receptors and hemagglutinin inhibitors of a novel strain of virus (1233) with members of the mumps-Newcastle disease influenza group were examined. It was found this strain. 1233 does not destroy the receptors or inhibitors of the other group, nor does the latter destroy 1233 receptors or inhibitors. The only exception to this statement was a moderate destruction of the 1233 inhibitor in protein by the Newcastle disease virus. The classification of strain 1233 has been discussed in light of this evidence, evidence which tends to place strain 1233 in a different category than any other strain in the MNI group.
authors: Hirst, G. K.

title: Establishment of the concept of prion diseases
abstract: The history of prion diseases derives from 18th-century descriptions of scrapie in sheep and goats. In 1920, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease was reported as the first human case of prion disease, which was recognized as subacute spongiform encephalopathy, one of the neurodegenerative diseases. After that, many transmission experiments were conducted, leading to the establishment of the basic concept of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE). The infectious agent was supposed to be a novel virus, so TSE was classified as a slow viral infection. In 1982, Prusiner studied the infectious fraction of scrapie-infected brain homogenate, defined the infectious agent as proteinaceous infectious particles that resist inactivation by methods that modify nucleic acids, and renamed the prion after virion in viral infections.
authors: Hizume, M.;Mizusawa, H.

title: Book Review: Poultry Diseases
authors: Hoerr, F. J.

title: Novel orthobunyavirus in cattle, Europe, 2011
abstract: In 2011, an unidentified disease was reported in cattle in Germany and the Netherlands. Clinical symptoms included fever, decreased milk production, and diarrhea. A metagenomic analysis identified a novel orthobunyavirus, which was subsequently isolated from the blood of affected animals. Surveillance has been initiated to test malformed newborn animals in the affected region.
authors: Hoffmann, B.;Scheuch, M.;HÃ¶per, D.;Jungblut, R.;Holsteg, M.;Schirrmeier, H.;Eschbaumer, M.;Goller, K. V.;Wernike, K.;Fischer, M.;Breithaupt, A.;Mettenleiter, T. C.;Beer, M.

title: Differences in viral receptor for feline infectious peritonitis virus type I and type II
abstract: Feline infectious peritonitis viruses (FIPVs) are divided into serogroups type I and type II. Here we report that feline aminopeptidase N (APN), a cell surface metalloprotease on intestinal, lung, and renal epithelial cells, is a receptor for type II FIPV but not for type I FIPV. A monoclonal antibody (MAb) RG-4, which blocks infection of Felis catus (fcwf-4) fetal whole cells by type II FIPV, was obtained by immunizing mice with fcwf-4 cells, which are highly susceptible to FIPV . This MAb also blocked infection of fcwf-4 cells by feline enteric coronavirus type II (FECV), canine coronavirus (CCV), and transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV). On the other hand, it did not block infection by type I FIPVs. MAb RG-4 recognized a polypeptide with a molecular weight of 120-130 kDa in feline intestinal brush border membrane (BBM) proteins. The polypeptide possessed aminopeptidase activity and the first 15 N-terminal amino acid sequences were identical to those of feline APN. BBM proteins from feline gut and the polypeptide reacted with MAb RG-4 (feline APN) inhibited the infectivity of type II FIPV, type II FECV, CCV and TGEV to fcwf-4 cells, but inhibited not the infectivity of type I FIPVs.
authors: Hohdatsu, T.;Izumiya, Y.;Yokoyama, Y.;Kida, K.;Koyama, H.

title: Characterization of monoclonal antibodies against feline infectious peritonitis virus type II and antigenic relationship between feline, porcine and canine coronavirus
abstract: Seven monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) with neutralizing activity against feline infectious peritonitis virus (FIPV) strain 79-1149 (type II) were prepared. When the polypeptide specificity recognized by these monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) was examined by Western immunoblotting, all of the MAbs reacted with the peplomer glycoprotein (S) of the virus. It was determined by a competitive binding assay that these MAbs recognize at least 3 different epitopes. The reactivity of these MAbs with 6 viruses identified as FIPV type I (UCD-1, UCD-2, UCD-3, UCD-4, NW-1 and Black), feline enteric coronavirus (FECV) type II, strain 79-1683 , canine coronavirus (CCV) strain 1-71 and transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) strains TO-163 and SH were examined by neutralization tests. All MAbs neutralized FECV strain 79-1683, CCV strain 1-71 and TGEV strains TO-163 and SH, while not neutralizing the 6 FIPV type I viruses. In addition, the MAb against TGEV strain TO-163, which has potent neutralizing activity against 7 TGEV viruses, neutralized CCV strain 1-71, FECV strain 79-1683 and FIPv strain 79-1146, however, did not neutralize the 6 FIPV type I viruses. These results indicated that at least 3 epitopes are involved in the neutralization of FIPV type II strain 79-1146 and that these epitopes are not present in FIPV type I viruses but are present in FECV strain 79-1683 who does not induce feline infection peritonitis, TGEV strains TO-163 and SH and CCV strain 1-71. These results suggest the presence of 2 serotypes of FIPV that can be clearly distinguished by the neutralization assay using MAbs.
authors: Hohdatsu, T.;Okada, S.;Koyama, H.

title: Nipah virus classification via fractal dimension and Shannon entropy
authors: Holden, T.;Gadura, N.;Cheung, E.

title: Discovery of the phylodynamics of RNA viruses
authors: Holmes, E. C.;Grenfell, B. T.

title: Tembusu-like flavivirus (Perak virus) as a cause of neurological disease outbreaks in young pekin ducks
abstract: neurological condition in young Pekin ducks characterized by ataxia, lameness and paralysis was observed at several duck farms in Malaysia in 2012. Gross pathologic lesions were absent or inconsistent in most cases, but severe and consistent microscopic lesions were found in the brain and spinal cord, characterized by nonsuppurative panencephalomyelitis. Several virus isolates were obtained in embryonated duck eggs and in cell cultures (Vero and DF-1) inoculated with brain homogenates of affected ducks. After exclusion of other viruses, isolates were identified as flavivirus by flavivirus-specific reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assays. Subcutaneous or intramuscular inoculation of 2-week-old pekin ducks with a flavivirus isolate resulted in typical clinical symptoms and histological lesions in the brain and spinal cord. The inoculated virus was detected by RT-PCR from organ samples from ducks with clinical signs and histological lesions. The disease was also observed in commingled contact control birds with a delay of a few days. Phylogenetic analysis of the NS5 and E gene sequences proved that the isolates were representatives of a new phylogenetic group within clade XI (Ntaya virus group) of the Flavivirus genus. This Malaysian duck tembusu virus (DTMUV), named Perak virus, shares moderate genomic RNA sequence similarity with a related DTMUV identified in China. In our experiment, the Malaysian DTMUV strain could be transmitted in the absence of mosquito vectors. These findings may have implications for the control and prevention of this emerging group of flaviviruses.
authors: Homonnay, Z. G.;KovÃ¡cs, E. W.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Albert, M.;FehÃ©r, E.;MatÃ³, T.;TatÃ¡r-Kis, T.;Palya, V.

title: The high genetic variation of viruses of the genus Nairovirus reflects the diversity of their predominant tick hosts
abstract: The genus Nairovirus (family Bunyaviridae) contains seven serogroups consisting of 34 mostly tick-borne viruses, including several associated with serious diseases in humans and livestock [e.g. B. Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) or Nairobi sheep disease (NSD). No comparative genetic studies or molecular detection tests for this virus genus were developed prior to this report. To characterize at least one representative from each of the seven serogroups, reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) primers were designed that target the L-polymerase coding region of the RNA genome of these viruses based on conserved ones Amino acid motifs present in the predicted catalytic core region. Sequence analysis showed that the nairoviruses are a very diverse group, showing up to 39.4% and 46.0% nucleotide and amino acid identity differences, respectively. Viral genetic relationships correlated well with serological groupings and with tick host associations. The hosts of these viruses include both hard (family Ixodidae) and soft (family Argasidae) ticks. Virus phylogenetic analysis reveals two major monophyletic groups: hard tick and soft tick vector viruses. In addition, viruses transmitted by ticks of the Ornithodoros, Carios, and Argas genera also form three separate monophyletic lineages. The striking similarities between tick and nairovirus phylogenies are consistent with a possible coevolution of the viruses and their tick hosts. Fossil and phylogenetic data locating the divergence between hard and soft ticks between 120 and 92 million years ago point to an ancient origin for viruses of the genus Nairovirus. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Honig, J. E.;Osborne, J. C.;Nichol, S. T.

title: Rapid detection, characterization and enumeration of foodborne pathogens
abstract: As food safety management evolves, microbiological testing will continue to play an important role in assessing whether food safety goals are being met. However, traditional microbiological culture-based methods are limited, particularly in their ability to provide timely data. This paper discusses the reasons for the increasing interest in rapid methods, current developments in the field, research needs and future trends. The advent of biotechnology has introduced new technologies that have led to the emergence of rapid diagnostic methods and changing food testing practices. Rapid methods encompass many different detection technologies, including specialized enzyme substrates, antibodies and DNA, ranging from simple differential plating media to the use of sophisticated instrumentation. The use of non-invasive sampling techniques in live animals came into focus particularly with the outbreak of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in the 1990s, which has been linked to the outbreak of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans. Serology remains an important tool to prevent foodborne pathogens from entering the human food supply via animal meat and milk. One of the primary uses of rapid methods is for the rapid screening of large numbers of samples, most of which are likely to test negative, resulting in faster product release for sale. This has been the main strength of rapid methods such as real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Enrichment PCR, in which a primary culture broth is tested in PCR, is the most common rapid testing approach. Recent reports show that it is possible to both enrich and enumerate a sample by pathogen-specific real-time PCR if the enrichment time is short. This can be particularly useful in situations where food manufacturers ask about the level of pathogens in a contaminated product. Another key issue is automation, where miniaturization and multiple testing are the main drivers, meaning that not only is one instrument flexible enough to test for many pathogens, but many pathogens can also be detected with one test. The review is mainly based on the author's scientific work which has contributed with the following new developments in this field: (i) serological tests for large-scale screening, surveillance or eradication programmes, (ii) same-day detection of Salmonella which would otherwise be classified as difficult to achieve, (iii) pathogen counting after a short log-phase enrichment, (iv) detection of foodborne pathogens in air samples, and finally (v) biotracing of pathogens based on mathematical modelling, even without an isolate. Rapid methods are discussed in a broad perspective of global health, international food supply and improving quantitative microbial risk assessment. The need for quantitative sample preparation techniques, culture-independent metagenomic detection, online monitoring, and a global validation infrastructure was emphasized. The cost and ease of use of rapid assays remain challenging barriers to overcome. © 2011 The Author. APMIS © 2011 APMIS.
authors: Hoorfar, J.

title: Biological and biochemical characterization of sheep scrapie in Japan
abstract: Due to the apparent lack of a pathogen-specific nucleic acid genome, scrapie strains cannot be classified by genomic characterization, which is commonly used to classify many viruses. However, scrapie strains can be distinguished to some extent by biological properties, such as transmissibility to experimental animals and the distribution of neuropathological lesions, and by biochemical properties, such as molecular mass and relative protease resistance of the disease-specific prion protein (PrPSc) isoform. . To tentatively characterize the predominant scrapie strains in Japan, we analyzed the transmissibility of ovine scrapie isolates to mice and the relative proteinase K (PK) resistance of the corresponding PrPSc. The results indicate that Japanese scrapie strains can be classified into at least three groups based on their biological and biochemical characteristics. The first group includes isolates that cause disease in mice with an incubation period of ≥ 400 days and possess relatively high PK resistance PrPSc. The second group isolates contain PrPSc, which is highly resistant to PK digestion but is poorly transmitted to mice. The final group consists of isolates that cause disease in mice with an incubation period of less than 300 days and are associated with PrPSc with reduced PK resistance. Sheep scrapie has occurred sporadically in Japan since 1982, with only 60 officially reported cases to date. However, the diversity of scrapie strains in the field suggested by our data raises concern that a scrapie strain similar to the parent pathogen of bovine spongiform encephalopathy might exist or emerge in Japan. Therefore, continuous surveillance for scrapie is required to prevent the further spread of scrapie not only among the sheep population but also to other species and to eliminate any potential risk of sheep scrapie to public health.
authors: Horiuchi, M.;Nemoto, T.;Ishiguro, N.;Furuoka, H.;Mohri, S.;Shinagawa, M.

title: Rabies in Iraq: trends in human cases 2001-2010 and characterization of animal strains of rabies from Baghdad
abstract: Rabies control requires a steady supply of reliable resources, constructive collaboration between veterinary and public health authorities, and systematic surveillance. These are challenging under any circumstances, but especially during a conflict. Here we describe available human rabies surveillance data from Iraq, animal rabies resampling results, and the first genetic characterization of circulating rabies strains from Iraq. Human rabies is notifiable, with an increase in reported cases since 2003 and a significant increase in Baghdad between 2009 and 2010. These changes coincide with an increasing number of reported dog bites. There is no laboratory confirmation of the disease or virus characterization and no systematic surveillance for rabies in animals. To address these issues, brain samples from pets in the greater Baghdad area were collected and tested for rabies. Three of 40 brain samples were positive using fluorescent antibody test and hemi-nested RT-PCR for rabies virus (RABV). Bayesian phylogenetic analysis using partial nucleoprotein gene sequences derived from the samples showed that the viruses belong to a single virus variant and share a common ancestor with viruses from neighboring countries 22 (95% HPD 14-32) years ago. These include countries to the west, north and east of Iraq, some of which also have other virus variants circulating at the same time. These results suggest a possible multiple introduction of rabies into the Middle East and regular cross-border transmission of disease. Although 4000 years have passed since the rabies disease was originally described, animals and humans are still dying from this preventable and neglected zoonosis. © 2013 Horton et al.
authors: Horton, D. L.;Ismail, M. Z.;Siryan, E. S.;Wali, A. R. A.;Ab-dulla, H. E.;Wise, E.;Voller, K.;Harkess, G.;Marston, D. A.;McElhinney, L. M.;Abbas, S. F.;Fooks, A. R.

title: A new family of vertebrate viruses: Toroviridae
abstract: The proposed family Toroviridae is characterized by coated, peplomer-bearing particles containing an elongated, tubular nucleocapsid with helical symmetry. The capsid can bend into an open torus, giving the virion a biconcave disc or kidney-shaped morphology (maximum diameter 120–140 nm), or the capsid can be straight, resulting in a rod-shaped particle (35 × 170 nm). Morphogenesis occurs by budding of preformed nucleocapsids through membranes mainly of the Golgi system and rough endoplasmic reticulum. The Berne virus proposed as a family prototype contains a single strand of infectious positive-sense RNA, M(r) approximately 6.5 x 106, which is polyadenylated. The RNA is surrounded by the major nucleocapsid phosphoprotein (M(r) approximately 20,000), which in turn is enveloped by a membrane containing a major protein (M(r) 22,000) and a phosphoprotein (M(r) 37,000). The approximately 20 nm long viral peplomers carry determinants for neutralization and hemagglutination; they are formed from a polydisperse N-glycosylated protein (M(r) 75,000-100,000). Four subgenomic polyadenylated RNAs with M(r)s of 3.0, 0.71, 0.46 and 0.26 x 106 were identified in infected cells. Torovirus replication is inhibited by actinomycin D, alpha-amanitin, and pre-irradiation of the host cell with UV light. All toroviruses identified to date cause enteric infections and are probably transmitted faecal-orally. Serological relationships between equine, bovine and human toroviruses have been demonstrated.
authors: Horzinek, M. C.;Flewett, T. H.;Saif, L. J.

title: Prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus in dairy herds in eastern China
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a worldwide pestivirus affecting cattle and other ruminants; However, there are few reports of epidemiological investigations of BVDV in east China. In this study, tank milk from 36 dairy herds in eastern China was subjected to serological testing, and 77.8% of the herds were positive for BVDV antibodies. The individual animal status in two herds was further examined by collecting blood samples, the positive ratio was 49.74% and 24.64%, and the average positive ratio of calves, heifers and lactating cows was 15.94%, 40.16 % and 41.7%, respectively. In addition, 8170 dairy cows from 36 herds were clinically examined for diarrhea syndrome, respiratory problems and reproductive disorders and the pathogens of all clinical cattle were further investigated. The results showed that BVDV was one of the main pathogens infecting animals in combination with various other viruses. Then nine BVDV strains were isolated; phylogenetic analyzes showed that the BVDV subtypes currently circulating in eastern China were BVDV 1a and BVDV 1c. In addition, of 377 cows tested, 1.86% were positive for the BVDV antigen. This study formed the basis for further studies on vaccination and control strategies of BVDV in eastern China.
authors: Hou, P.;Zhao, G.;Wang, H.;He, H.

title: Transcriptome analysis of rabbit spleen infected with porcine cholera lapin virus based on high-throughput sequencing technology
abstract: In the current study, rabbit spleens were analyzed at 12 h, 24 h, 30 h, 36 h and 48 h after infection with swine cholera lapinvirus (C strain) using high-throughput sequencing. The rabbit genome was used as a reference to identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs) at different time points after infection. The top 10 DEGs were filtered by significance and we searched for their biological functions in the Uniprot and NCBI databases. The first three time points have 10 co-expressing genes, many of which are related to immunity and inflammation. The last two time points for the top 10 DEGs are identical, and B2 M, RLA-DR-ALPHA, CD74 and IGJ are involved in the antiviral immune response. The GO functional annotation showed that in biological processes at any time point except 24 hours after infection, the immune response has the most terms, followed by metabolism and regulation. According to the KEGG database, the DEGs for 24 h post-infection were enriched for the RIG-I-like receptor signaling pathway, and the DEGs for 30 h post-infection were found to express a focal adhesion and ECM receptor interaction pathway exhibit. Furthermore, for 36 hands 48 h post-infection, the DEGs exhibit seven identical signaling pathways that are directly or indirectly related to the antiviral response. These signaling pathways included proteasome, lysosome, ribosome, chemokine signaling pathways, B-cell receptor signaling pathway, antigen processing and presentation pathway, and the Fc-gamma-R-mediated phagocytosis pathway C-strain infection, and provide a theoretical basis for the further understanding of the molecular mechanisms by which rabbits adapt to C strain infection.
authors: Hou, Y.;Zhao, D.;Liu, G.;He, F.;Liu, B.;Fu, S.;Hao, Y.;Zhang, W.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic analyzes of a novel amphotropic murine leukemia virus (MuLV-1313)
abstract: Background: The amphotropic murine leukemia viruses (MuLV-A's) are naturally occurring, exogenously acquired gammaretroviruses native to wild Southern California mice. These viruses replicate in a variety of cell types, including human cells in vitro, and can cause both hematological and neurological disorders in both wild and inbred laboratory mice. Because MuLV-A's also exhibit discrete interference and neutralization properties, the coat proteins of these viruses have been extremely useful for studying virus-host cell interactions and as vehicles for the transfer of foreign genes into a variety of hosts, including human cells. However, the genomic structure of any of the several known MuLV-A's has not been established, and the evolutionary relationship of amphotropic retroviruses to the numerous exogenous or endogenous MuLV strains remains elusive. Here we present a complete genetic structure of a new amphotropic virus, designated MuLV-1313, and show that this retrovirus, along with other MuLV-A, belongs to a distinct molecular, biological, and phylogenetic class among MuLV strains, composed of a large Number of laboratory inbred or feral mice isolated. Results: The host range of MuLV-1313 is similar to that of previously isolated MuLV-A, except that this virus replicates efficiently in both mammalian and chick cells. Compared to ENV proteins of other MuLV-A's (4070A, 1504A and 10A-1), the gp70 protein of MuLV-1313 shows differences in its signal peptides and the proline-rich hinge regions. However, the MuLV-1313 envelope protein is entirely independent of those present in a wide range of murine retroviruses isolated from various inbred and wild mice worldwide. Genetic analysis of the entire MuLV-1313 genome by dot plot analysis, comparing each nucleotide of one genome to the corresponding nucleotide of another, revealed that the genome of this virus is more closely related to the , with the exception of the env gene biologically distinct Ecotropic wild mouse retrovirus (Cas-Br-E) isolated from a different region of Southern California than any of the 15 MuLV strains whose full-length sequences are present in GenBank. This finding was confirmed by phylogenetic analysis and hierarchical grouping of the entire genomic sequence of MuLV-1313, which also placed all MULV-A in a genetically distinct category within the large family of retroviruses isolated from numerous mouse strains worldwide. Likewise, the construction of separate dendrograms for each of the Gag, Pol, and Env proteins of MuLV-1313 showed that the amphotropic retroviruses belong to a phylogenetically exclusive group of gammaretroviruses compared to all known MuLV strains. Conclusion: The molecular, biological, and phylogenetic properties of amphotropic retroviruses including MuLV-1313 are distinct from a large family of exogenously or endogenously transmitted ecotropic, polytropic, and xenotropic MuLV strains of laboratory and wild mice. Furthermore, both the naturally occurring amphotropic retrovirus and a biologically distinct ecotropic retrovirus of wild mice of southern California are more closely related on the evolutionary tree than any other mammalian gammaretrovirus, suggesting a common origin for these viruses. This is the first report of a full genome analysis of a unique group of phylogenetically distinct amphotropic viruses. © 2006 Howard et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Howard, T. M.;Sheng, Z.;Wang, M.;Wu, Y.;Rasheed, S.

title: Avian hepatitis E virus in chickens, Taiwan, 2013
abstract: A previously unidentified strain of avian hepatitis E virus (aHEV) is now endemic among chickens in Taiwan. Analysis showed that the virus is 81.5% to 86.5% similar to other aHEVs. In Taiwan, HEV infection was reported in chickens with no HEV exposure, suggesting transmission through asymptomatic cases or repeated introduction from unknown common source(s).
authors: Hsu, I. W.;Tsai, H. J.

title: Detection of various novel astroviruses in small mammals in China
abstract: Astroviruses infect humans and many animal species, causing gastroenteritis. To fully understand the distribution and genetic diversity of astroviruses in small mammals, we tested 968 anal swabs from 39 animal species, most of which were bats and rodents. We have detected various astroviruses in 10 bat species, including known bat astroviruses and a large number of novel viruses. Meanwhile, new groups of astroviruses have been identified in three wild rodent species, and a remarkably high genetic diversity of astroviruses has been discovered in Eothenomys cachinus. We have detected astroviruses in captive bred porcupines and a nearly complete genome sequence has been determined for one strain. Phylogenetic analysis of the full ORF2 sequence suggested that this strain may share a common ancestor with porcine astrovirus type 2. In addition, to our knowledge, this study reports the first detection of astroviruses in shrews and pikas. Our results provide new insights into understanding these small mammals as natural reservoirs of astroviruses.
authors: Hu, B.;Chmura, A. A.;Li, J. L.;Zhu, G. J.;Desmond, J. S.;Zhang, Y. Z.;Zhang, W.;Epstein, J. H.;Daszak, P.;Shi, Z. L.

title: Monitoring of avian influenza virus and Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in a commercial breeding farm in China and characterization of class I NDV isolates
abstract: To determine the true prevalence of avian influenza virus (AIV) and Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in ducks in Shandong Province, China, extensive surveillance studies were conducted in breeding ducks from an intensive farm from July 2007 to September 2008. Cloacal and tracheal swabs were taken monthly from 30 randomly selected birds that appeared healthy. All swabs were negative for influenza A virus recovery, while 87.5% of tracheal swabs and 100% of cloacal swabs collected in September 2007 were positive for Newcastle disease virus isolation. Several NDV isolates were obtained from tracheal and cloacal swabs from apparently healthy ducks. All isolates were apathogenic according to MDT and ICPI. The HN gene and the variable region of the F gene (nt 47-420) from four randomly selected isolates were sequenced. A 374 bp region of the F gene and the full length HN gene were used for phylogenetic analysis. Four isolates were identified as the same isolate based on 99.2-100% nucleotide sequence identities, indicating a closer phylogenetic relationship to lentogenic class I viruses. There were 1.9-9.9% nucleotide differences between the isolates and other class I viruses in the variable region of the F gene (nt 47-420), whereas there were 38.5-41.2% nucleotide differences between the isolates and class II viruses. The amino acid sequences of the F protein cleavage sites in these isolates were 112-ERQERL-117. The full length HN gene of these isolates was 1851 bp and encoded 585 amino acids. The homology analysis of the nucleotide sequence of the HN gene showed that there were 2.0-4.2% nucleotide differences between the isolates and other class I viruses, whereas there were 29.5-40.9% differences between the isolates and class I viruses. II viruses existed. The results indicate that these isolates are phylogenetically unrelated to the vaccine strain (LaSota). This study contributes to the understanding of the ecology of influenza and Newcastle disease viruses in ducks and emphasizes the need for constant surveillance in times of a prolonged and spreading epidemic of AIV and NDV. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Hu, B.;Huang, Y.;He, Y.;Xu, C.;Lu, X.;Zhang, W.;Meng, B.;Yan, S.;Zhang, X.

title: Genetic diversity and positive selection analysis of the envelope protein gene E2 of classical swine fever virus in eastern China under C-strain vaccination
abstract: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) causes an economically important and highly contagious disease in swine worldwide. Vaccination against strain C is one of the most effective ways to control this disease. Since 2014, there have been sporadic outbreaks of CSF in some C-strain vaccinated provinces in China. To decipher the disease etiology, 25 CSFV E2 genes from 169 clinical specimens were cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all 25 isolates belonged to subgenotype 2.1. Twenty-three of the 25 isolates were clustered into a newly defined subgenotype, 2.1d, and shared some consistent molecular characteristics. To determine whether the entire E2 gene was under positive selection pressure, we used site-by-site analysis to identify specific codons that underwent evolutionary selection and found seven positively selected codons. Three positively selected sites (amino acids 17, 34 and 72) were identified in the antigenicity-relevant domains B/C of the amino-terminal half of the E2 protein. In addition, another positively selected site (amino acid 200) showed a polarity change from hydrophilic to hydrophobic, which may alter CSFV antigenicity and virulence. The results show that the circulating CSFV strains in Shandong province were mainly clustered in subgenotype 2.1d. Furthermore, identifying these positively selected sites could help unveil molecular determinants of virulence or pathogenesis and clarify the driving force of CSFV evolution in eastern China.
authors: Hu, D.;Lv, L.;Gu, J.;Chen, T.;Xiao, Y.;Liu, S.

title: Virome analysis to identify novel mammalian viruses in bats from Southeast China
authors: Hu, D.;Zhu, C.;Wang, Y.;Ai, L.;Yang, L.;Ye, F.;Ding, C.

title: Deep sequencing of the mouse lung transcriptome reveals a distinct long non-coding RNA expression associated with the high virulence of the H5N1 avian influenza virus in mice
abstract: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) play several key regulatory roles in various biological processes. However, their role in the pathogenicity of influenza A virus (IAV) remains largely unexplored. Here, using next-generation sequencing, we systemically compared the response of the mouse lung whole transcriptome compared to either the highly pathogenic (A/Chicken/Jiangsu/k0402/2010, CK10) or the nonpathogenic (A/Goose/Jiangsu/k0403 / 2010, GS10) H5N1 virus. A total of 126 significantly differentially expressed (SDE) lncRNAs from three replicates were identified as being associated with high virulence of CK10, while 94 SDE lncRNAs were related to GS10. Functional category analysis indicated that the CK10-regulated SDE-lncRNAs-coexpressed mRNAs were highly associated with aberrant and uncontrolled inflammatory responses. Further analysis of the canonical pathway also confirmed that these targets for inflammatory signaling pathways were highly enriched. In addition, 9 lncRNAs and 17 lncRNAs-coexpressed mRNAs associated with a large number of target genes were successfully verified by qRT-PCR. A targeted lncRNA (NONMMUT011061) that was clearly activated and correlated with a large number of mRNAs was selected for further in-depth analysis, including prediction of transcription factors, potentially interacting proteins, genomic localization, encoding ability, and secondary structure construction. More importantly, NONMMUT011061 was also markedly stimulated during highly pathogenic H5N8 virus infection in mice, suggesting a possible universal role of NONMMUT011061 in the pathogenesis of various H5 IAVs. Taken together, these results provide a subset of lncRNAs that may play an important role in influenza virus pathogenesis, and add the lncRNAs to the vast repertoire of host factors used by IAV for infection and persistence.
authors: Hu, J.;Hu, Z.;Wang, X.;Gu, M.;Gao, Z.;Liang, Y.;Ma, C.;Liu, X.;Hu, S.;Chen, S.;Peng, D.;Jiao, X.;Liu, X.

title: Cloning and sequence analysis of Hubei brown duck hepatitis B virus genome
abstract: Seventy serum samples were collected from adult brown ducks in Hubei to clarify natural duck hepatitis B virus (DHBV) infection and to characterize the genome structure of DHBV. The complete genome of the DHBV strain was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and cloned into a T-vector and sequenced. The results showed that the natural infection rate of DHBV in Hubei was 10%. The DHBV genome isolated by PCR (GenBank accession number DQ276978) had 3024 nucleotides with three overlapping reading frames encoding the surface, core and polymerase proteins, respectively. The comparison of the genome sequences of this strain with those of 17 DHBV strains from the GenBank showed an identity of 89.3% to 93.5% at the nucleotide level. The amino acid sequences of S protein, core protein and functional domain of Pol protein were highly reserved among all these DHBV strains. This Hubei strain was found to share more characteristic amino acids in the polymerase genes with the "Chinese" DHBV strains than with those of the "Western" country strains. This finding was also confirmed by a pedigree analysis. Therefore, this Hubei DHBV strain should be classified as a subtype of the Chinese strains.
authors: Hu, Q.;Lei, Y. C.;Zhang, Z. Z.;Tian, Y. J.;Zhang, Z. M.;Li, L.;Xia, J. B.;Lu, M. J.;Yang, D. L.

title: Computational study of the interdependence between hemagglutinin and neuraminidase of the 2009 H1N1 pandemic
abstract: Influenza type A viruses are divided into subtypes based on their two surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). The HA protein facilitates viral attachment and entry into a host cell, and the NA protein aids in the release of viral progeny from the infected cell. The complementary roles of HA and NA entail their collaboration, which has important implications for viral replication and fitness. The HA protein from pig H1N1 early strains of the 2009 pandemic preferentially binds to human-type receptors, with weak binding to avian-type receptors. This virus caused several human deaths in Texas, USA in December 2013, prompting us to investigate the changes in genetic traits that might contribute to the increased virulence of the virus. Our time-series analysis of the strains of this virus collected from 2009 to 2013 implied that the HA-binding preference of this virus in the US, Europe and Asia is the trait of the swine H1N1 virus since 2009. However, it is a trait of seasonal human H1N1 and its binding avidity for avian-type receptors were both steadily increasing and had significant increases in 2013, with American strains showing the largest increases. The first change could improve virus transmission and replication in humans, and the second could increase their ability to cause infection deep in the lungs, which could be responsible for recent human deaths in Texas. Given the co-adaptation of HA and NA and evolutionary interactions, we also examined the NA activity of this virus to elucidate the functional balance between HA and NA during virus evolution. Finally, we identified amino acid substitutions in the virus HA and NA that were critical to the observed evolution.
authors: Hu, W.

title: A multiplex PCR for the simultaneous detection of three zoonotic parasites Ancylostoma ceylanicum, A. caninum and Giardia lamblia Assemblage A
abstract: Ancylostoma ceylanicum, A. caninum and Giardia lamblia assemblage A are common intestinal parasites of dogs and cats; They can also infect humans and cause parasitic zoonoses. In this study, a multiplex PCR method was developed for the simultaneous identification and detection of these three zoonotic parasites. Three pairs of specific primers were designed based on the ITS sequence from A. ceylanicum and A. caninum and the TPI gene from G. lamblia available in GenBank. The multiplex PCR reaction system was established by optimizing the reaction conditions, and a series of sensitivity, specificity and clinical application tests were also carried out.
authors: Hu, W.;Wu, S.;Yu, X.;Abullahi, A. Y.;Song, M.;Tan, L.;Wang, Z.;Jiang, B.;Li, G.

title: Rapid genome sequencing and characterization of the novel influenza A H7N9 virus of avian origin directly from a clinical specimen by semiconductor sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent outbreaks of severe pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome, have attracted significant public interest. Rapid and accurate diagnosis of the pathogen is key to adequately responding to suspected outbreaks. OBJECTIVES: We report a case that highlights the potential of semiconductor sequencing for the rapid determination of the novel viral genome sequences. STUDY DESIGN: We developed a method for rapid de novo assembly of the novel influenza A H7N9 virus genome directly from a patient's tracheal aspirate using a solid-state sequencer without culture and prior sequence information. In addition, characteristic amino acids were analyzed and phylogenetic analyzes were performed for key influenza A virus genes. RESULTS: Deep sequencing revealed 435,239 reads associated with H7N9 virus with an average length of 172 bp, representing 18.6% of all reads (2,339,680). The complete genome of the virus was obtained within 2 days by the de novo assembly method. The genomic average depth of coverage of the Ion Torrent PGM was up to 5679x. Selected characteristic amino acids were observed, and phylogenetic analyzes showed that the new H7 virus was genetically close to the 2011 Zhejiang duck H7N3 viruses. The new N9 sequences were most closely related to gene sequences of N9 derived from duck H11N9 in 2011 in Jiangxi and H2N9 sequences from Hong Kong in 2010 in China and therefore they may have a common ancestor. CONCLUSIONS: Sequence-independent semiconductor sequencing is a powerful tool to study the outbreak of a novel pathogen.
authors: Hu, Y.;Ren, X.;Li, L.;Xiao, Y.;Dong, J.;Sun, L.;Zhu, Y.;Yang, F.;Zhang, X.;Jin, Q.

title: Different microRNA alterations contribute to different outcomes after EV71 and CA16 infections: Insights from high-throughput sequencing in rhesus monkey peripheral blood mononuclear cells
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) are the predominant pathogens of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). Although these viruses share genetic homology, the clinical manifestations caused by the two viruses show some discrepancies. Furthermore, the underlying mechanisms leading to these differences remain unclear. microRNAs (miRNAs) are involved in numerous biological or pathological processes, including host responses to viral infections. Here we focused on differences in miRNA expression patterns in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) of rhesus monkeys infected with EV71 and CA16 at different time points using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that 106 known and 13 novel miRNAs showed significant differences and 32 important miRNAs among them for target prediction showed opposite trends in the EV71 and CA16 infected samples. GO and pathway analysis of the predicted targets showed enrichment in 14 biological processes, 10 molecular functions, 8 cellular components and 104 signaling pathways. Subsequently, regulatory networks of miRNA transcription factors, miRNA-predicted targets, miRNA GOs, and miRNA pathways were constructed to reveal the complex regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during the infection phase. Finally, we analyzed hierarchical GO categories of predicted targets involved in immune system processes, indicating that innate and adaptive immunity may be remarkably different after EV71 and CA16 infections. In summary, this report is the first to describe miRNA expression profiles in PBMCs with EV71 and CA16 infections using high-throughput sequencing. Our results could provide a valuable basis for further studies on the regulatory role of miRNAs in the context of the different immune responses induced by EV71 and CA16 infections.
authors: Hu, Y.;Song, J.;Liu, L.;Li, J.;Tang, B.;Wang, J.;Zhang, X.;Zhang, Y.;Wang, L.;Liao, Y.;He, Z.;Li, Q.

title: Comparative analysis of microRNAs in response to EV71 and CA16 infection in human bronchial epithelial cells by high-throughput sequencing to reveal different mechanisms of infection
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), mainly caused by enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) infections, which presented significantly different clinical manifestations. However, the factors underlying these differences remain unclear. Recently, the functions of microRNAs (miRNAs) in pathogen-host interactions have been highlighted. Here we performed comprehensive miRNA profiling in EV71- and CA16-infected human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE) at multiple time points using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that 154 known and 47 new miRNAs showed notable differences in expression. Of these, 65 miRNAs, including 58 known and 7 novel miRNAs, showed opposite trends in EV71- and CA16-infected samples. We then focused primarily on the 56 known differentially expressed miRNAs by further examining them for target prediction. GO and pathway analysis of these targets showed that 18 biological processes, 7 molecular functions, 1 cellular component and 123 pathways were enriched. Among these signaling pathways, cadherin signaling, Wnt signaling and angiogenesis showed significant changes. The regulatory networks of these miRNAs with predicted targets, GOs, signaling pathways, and transcription factors have been determined, suggesting that miRNAs exhibit intricate regulatory mechanisms during the infection phase. Consequently, we specifically analyzed the hierarchical GO categories of the predicted targets involved in adhesion. The results indicated that the differential changes induced by EV71 and CA16 infection might be partially related to airway epithelial barrier function. Taken together, our data provide useful insights that help elucidate the various host-pathogen interactions following EV71 and CA16 infection and may provide new therapeutic targets for these infections.
authors: Hu, Y.;Song, J.;Liu, L.;Li, J.;Tang, B.;Zhang, Y.;Wang, J.;Wang, L.;Fan, S.;Feng, M.;Li, Q.

title: Characterization of the genes encoding the complete US10, SORF3 and US2 proteins of duck enteritis virus
abstract: Based on the understanding that analysis of the unique short (US) region of duck enteritis virus (DEV) could help identify the molecular characterization and evolution of DEV, the study used a 5,121 bp fragment containing three genes encoding complete US10, unique short region open reading frame (SORF) 3 and US2 proteins were amplified from the DEV (C-KCE) genome. The transcriptional orientation of US10 and SORF3 was tail to tail, and SORF3 and US2 were the same. Potential core promoters and polyadenylation sites (poly(A)) were predicted for US10, SORF3 and US2 and further confirmed by polymerase chain reaction. Phylogenetic analysis of the three complete coding sequences showed that DEV was more closely related to avian herpesviruses, particularly Mardivirus, and should be assigned to a separate genus in the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Hu, Y.;Zhou, H.;Yu, Z.;Chen, H.;Jin, M.

title: MicroRNA expression profiles of a swine kidney-15 cell line infected with swine epidemic diahorrea virus
abstract: To study the effect of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV) on the microRNA expression profiles of pig kidney-15 (PK-15) cells, total RNA was isolated from PK-15 cells with or without PEDV infection. Then we obtained the miRNAs using Solexa sequencing technology and analyzed these differentially expressed miRNAs. Heat map cluster analysis and GO (ontology, GO) (gene function, MF, molecular) analysis were performed on the significant differences in the expression of the miRNA, and 10 significant differences in the expression of the miRNA were selected by RT-qPCR. The result showed that the expression levels of 214 types of microRNAs (miRNAs) were significantly different in PEDV-infected cells compared to normal PK-15 cells. Among them, 175 types of miRNAs were significantly upregulated, while 39 types of miRNAs were significantly downregulated. In addition, the qPCR results of miRNA expression trends were similar to those of Solexa sequencing. Heat map cluster analysis showed that the vast majority of viral groups were differentially expressed in miRNA compared to the control group. Go analysis showed that miRNAs are extensively involved in combining, binding of proteins, protein kinase activity, transfer enzyme activity, transfer of phosphorus-containing radicals, phosphotransferase enzyme activity and other biological effects. RT-qPCR expression trends verified by miRNA were consistent with high-throughput sequencing results. The results showed that swine epidemic virus infection had a significant impact on the level of miRNA expression in PK-15 cells, which provided a new idea for further study of miRNA preparation for treatment of PEDV.
authors: Huang, J.;Lang, Q.;Li, X.;Xu, Z.;Zhu, L.;Zhou, Y.

title: Pseudorabies viral replication is inhibited by a new target of miR-21
abstract: Pseudorabiesvirus (PRV) is a porcine virus classified as a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily of Herpesviridae. Recent studies have confirmed that viruses regulate gene expression in host cells. Commonly affected genes include oxidative stress response genes, genes involved in phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase/protein kinase B (PI3K/Akt) signaling, and interferon- and interleukin-related genes. However, the post-transcriptional regulation of host genes after PRV infection is still unclear. In this study, we used miRNA microarray approaches to assess miRNA expression in the PRV-infected porcine kidney-15 cell line (PK-15) and observed that miR-21 was expressed 12 h after infecting the cells with PRV was expressed at high levels. In addition, we identified chemokine (CXC motif) ligand 10 (CXCL10), also termed interferon-γ-inducible protein-10 (IP-10), as a novel target gene of miR-21. IP-10 was downregulated 4 h after PRV infection. PRV replication was significantly inhibited by IP-10 overexpression. © 2014 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Huang, J.;Ma, G.;Fu, L.;Jia, H.;Zhu, M.;Li, X.;Zhao, S.

title: Detection of a novel porcine parvovirus, PPV4, in Chinese pig herds
abstract: In order to determine whether the novel porcine parvovirus type 4 (PPV4) recently reported in America is widespread in China, a set of specific primers was developed and used for the molecular study of PPV4 among those reported in various countries between 2006 and 2010 Clinical specimens collected from China's provinces are used. The results showed that PPV4 is present in Chinese pig herds at a rate of 2.09% (12/573) among the clinical samples examined and at 0.76% (1/132) among the samples collected from healthy animals. We also found that PPV4 was not detected in samples collected prior to 2009. Analysis of the coding sequences revealed that the Chinese and American PPV4 genome sequences are closely related with greater than 99% nucleotide sequence identity. Similar to a previous study, viral genomes were detected in a head-to-tail configuration with different lengths of the non-coding region. Our results confirmed that PPV4 is a unique virus recently discovered in pigs. Phylogenetically, PPV4 is most closely related to bovine parvovirus 2 (BPV2, which is not a bocavirus and is not assigned to any Parvovirinae genus) and shares limited amino acid identity with ORF1 (33.6%) and ORF2 (24.5%). In terms of genome structure and organization, PPV4 encodes an ORF3 in the middle of the viral genome that is similar to the Bocavirus genus. However, the PPV4 ORF3-encoded protein shares minimal amino acid identity with the ORF3-encoded proteins of the Bocavirus genus. © 2010 Huang et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Huang, L.;Zhai, S. L.;Cheung, A. K.;Zhang, H. B.;Long, J. X.;Yuan, S. S.

title: Differences in the intestinal microbiota between uninfected piglets and piglets infected with Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus
abstract: The swine epidemic, a devastating gastrointestinal disease, causes great financial losses due to its high infectivity, morbidity and mortality in suckling piglets, despite the development and application of various vaccines. In this study, high-throughput sequencing was used to examine differences in gut microbiota between uninfected piglets and piglets infected with Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV). The results showed that the small intestinal microbiota of PEDV-infected suckling piglets was low in diversity and dominated by Proteobacteria (49.1%). In addition, the composition of the small intestine microbiota of PEDV-infected suckling piglets showed significant differences to that of non-infected piglets. Some of the taxa that showed differences in abundance between uninfected piglets and PEDV-infected piglets were associated with cellular transport and catabolism, energy metabolism, biosynthesis of other secondary metabolites, and amino acid metabolism, as determined by predicting microbial function based on the bacterium 16S rRNA gene. Therefore, adapting the gut microbiota could be a promising method to prevent or treat PEDV.
authors: Huang, M. Z.;Wang, S. Y.;Wang, H.;Cui, D. A.;Yang, Y. J.;Liu, X. W.;Kong, X. J.;Li, J. Y.

title: A selective bottleneck shapes the evolutionary mutant spectra of enterovirus A71 during viral spread in humans
abstract: RNA viruses accumulate mutations to rapidly adapt to environmental changes. Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) causes various clinical manifestations with occasional severe neurological complications. However, the mechanism by which EV-A71 develops in the human body is unclear. Using deep sequencing and haplotype analyzes of viruses from different tissues of an autopsy patient, we attempted to define the evolutionary pathway by which enterovirus A71 develops the ability to invade the human central nervous system. A broad spectrum of mutants with different mutations were observed at the initial sites of infection in the respiratory and digestive systems. After viral invasion, we identified a haplotype switch and a dominant haplotype with glycine at VP1 residue 31 (VP1-31G) in virus particles that spread to the integumentary and central nervous systems. In vitro viral growth and fitness analyzes showed that VP1-31G conferred growth and a fitness advantage in human neuronal cells, while VP1-31D conferred enhanced replication in human colorectal cells. A higher proportion of VP1-31G was also found in fatalities, suggesting that it may facilitate central nervous system infection in humans. Our data provide a first glimpse into the EV-A71 quasi-species from oral tissues to the human central nervous system and show broad implications for the surveillance and pathogenesis of this re-emerging viral pathogen.IMPORTANT EV-A71 persists continues to be a global public health burden. Although EV-A71 is the main etiological agent of hand, foot and mouth disease, it can also cause neurological pulmonary edema, encephalitis and even death, particularly in children. Understanding selection processes that enable dispersal and accurately estimating EV-A71 diversity during human invasion are critical for applications in viral pathogenesis and vaccine studies. Here we define a selection bottleneck that occurs in respiratory and digestive tissues. The glycine substitution at VP1 residue 31 helps viruses break the bottleneck and enter the central nervous system. This substitution is also beneficial for replication in neuronal cells in vitro. Considering that fatal cases contain an enhanced glycine substitution at VP1-31, we propose that the increased prevalence of VP1-31G alters viral tropism and central nervous system invasion can support. Our results provide new insights into a dynamic mutant spectral switch that is active during acute viral infection with emerging viral pathogens.
authors: Huang, S. W.;Huang, Y. H.;Tsai, H. P.;Kuo, P. H.;Wang, S. M.;Liu, C. C.;Wang, J. R.

title: Dual ATPase and GTPase activity of beak and feather disease virus replication-associated protein (Rep).
abstract: Background: Parrot beak and feather disease affects parrots and results in an immunosuppressive disease often characterized by an abnormal shape and growth of the animal's beak, feathers and claws. Beak and feather disease virus (BFDV) is a single-stranded circular DNA virus and is classified as a member of the Circoviridae family. It is known that two large open reading frames (ORFs) encode the replication-associated (Rep) protein and the capsid-associated (Cap) protein. Methods: The BFDV Rep and Cap genes were fused to tags and then expressed and purified, respectively. Both the ATPase and GTPase activities of the recombinant Rep protein are measured. Substrate and ion preference, optimal conditions, effects of ATPase and GTPase inhibitors, and the presence of Cap protein on Rep protein ATPase and GTPase activity are examined. Finally, the effects of the Walker A motif, the Walker B motif and a new GYDG motif of the Rep protein on the ATPase and GTPase activities by different mutants are examined. Results: The recombinant Rep protein could show ATPase activity and GTPase activity. The Rep protein was able to hydrolyze both deoxyribonucleotides and ribonucleotides. Among the nucleoside triphosphates and deoxynucleoside triphosphates, the order of substrate preferences was found to be ATP > GTP > CTP >= UTP and dATP > dGTP > dTTP > dCTP, respectively. Both the ATPase and GTPase activities of the BFDV Rep protein required magnesium ions, and the presence of calcium ions significantly inhibited the ATPase and GTPase activities of the Rep protein. The optimal temperatures for ATPase activity and GTPase activity were both 56 degrees C, while their optimal pH values were both pH 7.5. Both the ATPase activity and the GTPase activity of the BFDV Rep protein were significantly downregulated by polynucleotides and the 36 bp dsDNA (located at the origin of replication) of the BFDV genome. The ATPase activity of the BFDV Rep protein was found to be more sensitive to sodium azide than to sodium orthovanadate and N-ethylmaleimide. Linoleic acid inhibited the GTPase activity of the Rep protein more than Dynasore. This suggested that the BFDV Rep protein should be classified as an F-type ATPase and a polyunsaturated fatty acid sensitive GTPase. In the presence of 10 ng of the Cap protein, the ATPase activity and GTPase activity of the BFDV Rep protein was significantly increased. In addition, the BFDV Rep protein contains the Walker A motif, the Walker B motif, and a new GYDG motif. Both the ATPase activity and the GTPase activity of various deletion and site-directed mutants of the Rep protein affecting these motifs were significantly reduced, suggesting that all three motifs contribute to the ATPase and GTPase activities; special. In addition, the ATPase activity and GTPase activity of the Rep protein deletion mutants were reversed in the presence of the Cap protein. This is the first example of dual ATPase and GTPase activity reported in the BFDV Rep protein. (C) 2015 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Huang, S. W.;Liu, H. P.;Chen, J. K.;Shien, Y. W.;Wong, M. L.;Wang, C. Y.

title: Co-infection with multiple strains of bovine papular stomatitis virus
abstract: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (BPSV) infects cattle and, professionally, humans. Predominant subclinical infections, frequent reinfections, and virus persistence in healthy animals complete a poorly understood but likely complex scenario of BPSV perpetuation and transmission in nature. Here we report the isolation of multiple BPSV strains co-infecting a single animal. Whole genome analysis of isolated BPSV strains revealed genomic variability that likely influences the virulence and infectivity of the virus. In addition, incongruent phylogenetic relationships between viruses suggested genomic recombination. These findings have important implications for the biology of parapoxvirus infection and viral evolution in nature.
authors: Huang, T.;Tulman, E. R.;Diel, D. G.;Khatiwada, S.;Sims, W.;Edwards, J. F.;Wen, X.;Kutish, G. F.;Rock, D. L.;Delhon, G.

title: Perpetuation and rearrangement of gull influenza A viruses in Atlantic North America
abstract: Gulls are important hosts of avian influenza A viruses (AIVs), and gull AIVs often contain gene segments of mixed geographic and host lineage origin. In this study, the prevalence of AIV in gulls in Newfoundland, Canada, from 2008 to 2011 was analyzed. The overall prevalence was low (30/1645, 1.8%), but there was a clear peak of infection in autumn. AIV seroprevalence was high in Newfoundland Gulls, with 50% of gulls sampled showing evidence of prior infection. Sequences of 16 gull AIVs were determined and analyzed to shed light on the transmission, reassortment, and persistence dynamics of gull AIVs in Atlantic North America. A reorganization of the intercontinental and waterfowl lines was widespread. Of particular note was an all-Eurasian AIV and another with an intercontinental reassortant virus of the waterfowl lineage. These patterns of geographic and inter-host-group transmission underscore the importance of characterizing gull AIVs as part of attempts to understand global AIV dynamics.
authors: Huang, Y.;Wille, M.;Benkaroun, J.;Munro, H.;Bond, A. L.;Fifield, D. A.;Robertson, G. J.;Ojkic, D.;Whitney, H.;Lang, A. S.

title: A 4-year study of avian influenza virus prevalence and subtype diversity in ducks in Newfoundland, Canada
abstract: The island of Newfoundland, Canada is located on the eastern edge of North America and has migratory bird connections to the mainland and across the North Atlantic. Here we report a 4-year epidemiological study of avian influenza virus (AIV) in ducks in the St. John's area of Newfoundland. The overall prevalence of AIV detection in ducks during this study was 7.2%, with American Black Ducks contributing the majority of the samples collected and the AIV positives. The juvenile ducks showed a significantly higher AIV detection rate (10.6%) compared to adult ducks (3.4%). Seasonally, AIV prevalence rates were higher in autumn (8.4%), but positive results were also found in winter (4.6%). Preliminary serological tests showed a high incidence of previous AIV infection (20/38, 52.6%). A total of 43 viruses were characterized for their HA-NA or HA subtypes, showing a large diversity of AIV subtypes and a low recurrence of subtypes from year to year. Examination of the movement patterns of ducks in this region indicated that it is a largely non-migratory duck population, which could contribute to the observed pattern of high AIV subtype turnover. Phylogenetic analysis of 4 H1N1 and one H5N4 AIVs showed that these viruses closely resembled other low pathogenic AIV sequences from waterfowl in North America and all gene segments were assigned to American avian clades. In particular, the H1N1 viruses identified in consecutive years possessed homologous genomes. Such detection of homologous AIV genomes over years is rare, but points to the role of the environmental reservoir in viral perpetuation.
authors: Huang, Y.;Wille, M.;Dobbin, A.;Robertson, G. J.;Ryan, P.;Ojkic, D.;Whitney, H.;Lang, A. S.

title: Genetic, pathogen and antigenic diversity of Newcastle disease viruses in Shandong Province, China
abstract: Thirty-one Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) isolated from domestic and wild birds in Shandong Province, China (2006-2014) were characterized genetically, pathogenically, and antigenically. Phylogenetic analysis classified the viruses into a single genotype under Class I and four genotypes under Class II. The nineteen viruses assigned to Class II genotype VII were velogenic, while the other viruses were either mesogenic or lentogenic to chickens. Some NDV isolates (17/23) did not show neutralizing reactivity with a monoclonal antibody raised against the LaSota strain HN protein, reflecting mutation at the cognate antigenic epitope. When challenged with two genotype VII NDV isolates, LaSota vaccinated SPF chickens prevented disease development, but virus shedding was detected for at least 5 days post challenge. Circulation of the same NDV isolate for up to 13 years suggested the role of an environmental reservoir in NDV perpetuation and reinforced the importance of stringent biosecurity measures in addition to vaccination for disease control.
authors: Huang, Y.;Yang, S.;Hu, B.;Xu, C.;Gao, D.;Zhu, M.;Huang, Q.;Zhang, L.;Wu, J.;Zhang, X.;Khan, M. I.

title: Molecular Characterization of a Highly Pathogenic Pig: Virus Variant of Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome in Hubei, China
abstract: The Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is considered to be one of the most important pathogens in pigs worldwide. In 2006, more than 10 provinces in China experienced an epizootic outbreak of swine disease, characterized by high fever, flushed skin, and high morbidity and mortality. From June 2006 to April 2007, we examined some clinical samples in Hubei Province by RT-PCR and cloned several major genes, N, GP5 and NSP2 gene, which are shown in this study. The phylogenetic analysis of these genes revealed that the highly pathogenic PRRSV variant ZB was responsible for the 2006 outbreak of swine disease in Hubei Province, similar to the variants isolated in 2006 from other provinces in China, and belongs to the NA-type PRRSV. In the PRRSV variants, N and GP5 share about 90% identity with the prototypical ATCC VR-2332 and some typical Chinese NA-type isolates, with the exception of the 2850 bp NSP2 gene (shares only 65% identity with ATCC VR-2332) . But they all share more than and 97% identity with other highly pathogenic Chinese PRRSV strains. In addition, there are extensive amino acid (aa) mutations in the GP5 protein and 2 deletions in the Nsp2 protein compared to the previous isolates.
