Most of the variants found in the 2006 swine disease outbreak in China were the most phylogenetically distant variants from the typical NA-type PRRSV, and these differences may account for the differences in pathogenicity found between these variants and the original Chinese PRRSV strains have been observed. Â© Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag GmbH 2009.
authors: Huang, Y.;Zhang, B.;Fu, Z. F.;Rayner, S.;Zheng, F. L.;Liang, W. W.;Yang, K. L.;Xu, D. P.;Wang, H. Z.

title: Clinical features and phylogenetic analysis of coxsackievirus A9 in northern Taiwan in 2011
abstract: Background: Coxsackievirus A9 (CA9) was one of the most prevalent enteroviral infection serotypes in Taiwan in 2011. After several patient series were reported in the 1960s and 1970s, few studies have focused on the clinical manifestations of CA9 infection. Our study examines and deepens the current understanding of CA9. METHODS: We analyzed the clinical presentations of 100 culture-proven CA9-infected patients in 2011 by reviewing their medical records and plotting the CA9 pedigree. Results: Of the 100 patients with culture-proven CA9 infections, the mean (SD) age was 4.6 (3.4) years and the male to female ratio was 1.9. Of the clinical manifestations, 96 patients (96%) had fever and the mean (SD) duration of fever was 5.9 (3.4) days. Sixty-one patients (61%) developed a rash, and the predominant pattern was a generalized, nonpruritic maculopapular rash without vesicular changes. While most patients had a throat injection, mouth ulcers were found in only 19 cases (19%), 6 of which were diagnosed as herpangina. Complicated cases included: aseptic meningitis (n=8), bronchopneumonia (n=6), acute cerebellaritis (n=1), and polio-like syndrome (n=1). The phylogenetic analysis for current CA9 strains is closest to CA9 isolate 27-YN-2008 from the border area of mainland China and Myanmar. Conclusions: The most common feature of CA9 during the 2011 epidemic in Taiwan is a generalized febrile rash rather than herpangina or hand, foot and mouth disease. Because persistent fever and some complications are possible, caution should be exercised both in patient assessment and in predicting clinical outcome. © 2013 Huang et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Huang, Y. C.;Chu, Y. H.;Yen, T. Y.;Huang, W. C.;Huang, L. M.;Cheng, A. L.;Wang, H. Y.;Chang, L. Y.

title: Porcine torque tenovirus multiple infection in a single pig and characterization of the complete genomic sequences of four US prototype PTTV strains: implication for PTTV genotyping
abstract: Porcine torque teno virus (PTTV) has recently been shown to contribute in part to the experimental induction of porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome and post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome in pigs in the United States. We report here the identification of four distinct full-length genomic sequences of PTTV strains from a single pig in Virginia. Detailed analyzes of the genomic organization, degree of variability and properties of conserved nucleotide and amino acid motifs of PTTV were performed. The results showed that these four prototype US strains of PTTV identified from the same pig represent different genotypes or subtypes, and a revised classification system for PPTV is subsequently proposed. This is the first study to document multiple PTTV infections with different genotypes or subtypes in a single pig. The identification of new porcine PTTV strains in the United States also paves the way for future disease characterization and genotyping of PTTV. © 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Huang, Y. W.;Ni, Y. Y.;Dryman, B. A.;Meng, X. J.

title: The Newcastle disease virus hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein determines tropism and virulence
abstract: The Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV) hemagglutinin neuraminidase (HN) protein plays a critical role in the infection process. However, the exact contribution of the HN gene to NDV pathogenesis is not known. In this study, the role of the HN gene in NDV virulence was examined. Using reverse genetics methods, the HN genes of a virulent recombinant NDV strain, rBeaudette C (rBC), and an avirulent recombinant NDV strain, rLaSota, were swapped. The hemadsorption and neuraminidase activities of the chimeric viruses showed significant differences from those of their parental strains, but heterotypic F and HN pairs were equally effective in promoting fusion. It turned out that the tissue tropism of the viruses depends on the origin of the HN protein. The chimeric virus with the virulent virus-derived HN protein showed tissue preference similar to that of the virulent virus and vice versa. The chimeric viruses with reciprocal HN proteins either gained or lost virulence as determined by a standard chick intracerebral pathogenicity index assay and by mean time of death in chick embryos (a measure used to classify these viruses), indicating that virulence is a function of is the amino acid differences in the HN protein. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that the virulence of NDV is multigenic and that F protein cleavage alone does not determine the virulence of a strain.
authors: Huang, Z.;Panda, A.;Elankumaran, S.;Govindarajan, D.;Rockemann, D. D.;Samal, S. K.

title: Comparison of microbiomes between populations of fowl red mite (Dermanyssus gallinae): predominance of Bartonella-like bacteria
abstract: Blood-sucking fowl red mites (RPM) serve as vectors of pathogenic bacteria and viruses among vertebrate hosts, including wild birds, poultry, mammals, and humans. The RPM microbiome has not yet been studied by high-throughput sequencing. Samples of RPM eggs, larvae and stuffed adults/nymphs obtained in four poultry houses in the Czech Republic were used for microbiome analysis by Illumina amplicon sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene V4 region. A laboratory RPM population was used as a positive control for transcriptome analysis by pyrosequencing with identification of bacterial-derived sequences. Samples from swollen adult/nymph stages had 100-fold more copies of 16S rRNA gene copies than samples from eggs and larvae. The composition of the microbiome showed differences between the four poultry houses and between the observed developmental stages. In the adult microbiome, 10 OTUs comprised 90 to 99% of all sequences. Bartonella-like bacteria covered between 30 and 70% of the sequences in the RPM microbiome and 25% of the bacterial sequences in the transcriptome. The phylogenetic analyzes of 16S rRNA gene sequences revealed two distinct groups of Bartonella-like bacteria forming sister groups: (i) symbionts of ants; (ii) genus Bartonella. Cardinium, Wolbachia and Rickettsiella sp. were found in the microbiomes of all stages tested, while Spiroplasma eriocheiris and Wolbachia were identified in the laboratory's RPM transcriptome. The microbiomes of eggs, larvae and engorged adults/nymphs differed. Bartonella-like symbionts were found in all stages and sampling sites. Bartonella-like bacteria were the most diverse group within the RPM microbiome. The presence of identified putative pathogenic bacteria is relevant in terms of human and animal health, while the identification of symbiotic bacteria may lead to new control methods aimed at destabilizing the arthropod host.
authors: Hubert, J.;Erban, T.;Kopecky, J.;Sopko, B.;Nesvorna, M.;Lichovnikova, M.;Schicht, S.;Strube, C.;Sparagano, O.

title: ISOLATION AND CLASSIFICATION OF VIRUSES FROM BOVINE IN OUTBREAKS OF
authors: Huck, R. A.;Cartwright, S. F.

title: Documentation and classification of oncogenic viruses
authors: Huebner, R. J.

title: Cowpox virus isolate, which is virulent in humans, shows an attenuated phenotype in mice
abstract: We cultured cowpox virus (CPXV) from skin lesion material from a human patient in Austria. The phylogenetic comparison of the HA gene revealed a fairly homogeneous accumulation with other local isolates from recent years, the A36R gene was mainly related to elephant-derived strains from Germany. Surprisingly, although the isolate AT/Carinthia/788/07 causes disease in humans, it showed greatly reduced virulence in BALB/c mice after intranasal inoculation compared to vaccinia virus, even at high titers. This is in contrast to previous reports of other CPXV isolates. Shotgun DNA sequencing revealed multiple insertions and deletions in genes thought to be involved in host range, immune regulation, and established virulence factors. These preliminary data could indicate that CPXV strains with demonstrated human pathogenicity may have reduced virulence in mice and vice versa. In addition, strains with reduced virulence may have an advantage in surviving in less dense rodent populations. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Huemer, H. P.;Lassnig, C.;Nowotny, N.

title: Oral fluids as a live animal sample source to assess cross-reactivity and cross-protection following intranasal influenza A virus vaccination in pigs
abstract: Numerous antigenically distinct H1 influenza A virus (IAV) variants are currently circulating in North American swine, making vaccine development difficult due to the inability to formulate a vaccine that provides broad cross-protection. Experimentally, live attenuated influenza virus vaccines (LAIV) show increased cross-protection compared to inactivated vaccines. However, there is no standardized assay to predict cross-protection after LAIV vaccination. Hemagglutination-inhibiting (HI) serum antibody is the gold-standard correlate of protection following IAV vaccination. LAIV vaccination does not induce a robust serum HI antibody titer; however, a local mucosal antibody response is elicited. Therefore, a live animal sample source is needed that could be used to assess LAIV immunogenicity and cross-protection. Here we evaluated the use of oral fluids (OF) and nasal washes (NW) collected after IAV inoculation as a live animal sample source in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) to predict cross-protection compared to traditional serology. Both live virus exposure and LAIV vaccination provided heterologous protection, although protection against phylogenetically more closely related viruses was greatest. IAV-specific IgA was detected in NWand OF samples and was cross-reactive with representative IAV from each H1 cluster. Endpoint titers of cross-reactive IgA in OF from pigs exposed to live virus were associated with heterologous protection. While LAIV vaccination provided significant protection, LAIV immunogenicity was reduced compared to live virus challenge. These data suggest that OF from pigs vaccinated with wild-type IAV with surface genes consistent with the LAIV seed strain could be used in an ELISA to assess cross-protection and antigenic relatedness of circulating and emerging IAV in evaluate pigs.
authors: Hughes, H. R.;Vincent, A. L.;Brockmeier, S. L.;Gauger, P. C.;Pena, L.;Santos, J.;Braucher, D. R.;Perez, D. R.;Loving, C. L.

title: The capsid protein properties of cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus and black-eyed broad bean mosaic virus confirm the existence of two major subgroups of aphid-borne, legume-infecting potyviruses
abstract: study of the capsid proteins of various legume-infecting potyviruses using specific monoclonal antibodies on immunoblots of crude extracts from infected plants revealed that Cowpea Aphid-borne Mosaic Virus (CAMV) and Blackeye Cowpea Mosaic Virus (BlCMV) coat protein M(r). Values of 32K and 35K respectively. Immunoblot comparisons of BlCMV, Peanut Stripe Mosaic Virus (PStV), Bean Common Mosaic Virus (BCMV) and Azuki Bean Mosaic Virus (AzMV) showed equal reactivity of their 35K envelope proteins. Similar comparisons between CAMV and the necrotic BCMV strain (isolate NL3) revealed a serological relationship between their 32K envelope proteins, with the results providing the first evidence of a possible similarity between CAMV and BCMV NL3. Peptides from trypsin digests of the coat proteins of several of these legume-infecting potyviruses were analyzed by HPLC. The comparison of the peptide profiles confirmed the serological results in distinguishing the two subgroups. The coat protein peptide profiles of BICMV, PStV, AzMV and BCMV were nearly identical, suggesting that they could be considered strains of one virus. In contrast, the peptide profiles of different CAMV serotypes and BCMV NL3 differed from the first group and showed limited similarities to each other.
authors: Huguenot, C.;Furneaux, M. T.;Hamilton, R. I.

title: Evidence that cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus and black-eyed kidney bean mosaic virus are two different potyviruses
abstract: The immunoreactivity of a panel of polyclonal antibodies and monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) raised against African isolates of cowpea and African yam potyviruses was examined in ELISAs. A serological study with reference isolates, followed by further characterization in different hosts, led to the separation of the potyviruses into two distinct serogroups, one containing black-eyed cowpea mosaic virus (B1CMV) and the other cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CAMV). Using biotin-labeled MAbs, the B1CMV isolates were further divided into two serotypes and the CAMV isolates into five serotypes. Since both B1CMV and CAMV cause a very similar mosaic disease in cowpeas, different ELISA methods using mixed MAbs were evaluated and a single protocol was developed, which allowed a reliable diagnosis of both viruses.
authors: Huguenot, C.;Furneaux, M. T.;Thottappilly, G.;Rossel, H. W.;Hamilton, R. I.

title: The Pacific Ocean Virome (POV): a marine viral metagenomic data set and associated protein clusters for quantitative viral ecology
authors: Hurwitz, B. L.;Sullivan, M. B.

title: Addressing global agricultural challenges for ruminants by understanding the rumen microbiome: past, present and future
abstract: The rumen is a complex ecosystem of anaerobic bacteria, protozoa, fungi, methanogenic archaea and phages. These microbes interact closely to break down plant matter that humans cannot digest, while providing metabolic energy to the host and, in the case of archaea, producing methane. As a result, ruminants produce meat and milk rich in quality protein, vitamins and minerals, contributing to food security. With the world population projected to reach approximately 9.7 billion by 2050, an increase in ruminant production is necessary to meet global protein needs despite limited land availability, while ensuring that environmental impact is minimized. While these goals are challenging, they can be achieved, but depend on our understanding of the rumen microbiome. Attempts to manipulate the rumen microbiome to benefit global agricultural challenges have been ongoing for decades with limited success, mainly due to the lack of detailed understanding of this microbiome and our limited ability to culture most of these microbes outside of the rumen. The potential to manipulate the rumen microbiome and address global challenges in livestock husbandry through animal husbandry and the introduction of early-life nutritional interventions has recently emerged as a promising new technology. Our inability to phenotype ruminants at high throughput has also hampered progress, although the recent increase in 'omic' data may allow the advancement of mathematical models and rumen microbial gene biomarkers as proxies. Advances in computational tools, high-throughput sequencing technologies, and culture-independent “omics” approaches continue to revolutionize our understanding of the rumen microbiome. This will ultimately provide the knowledge framework needed to solve current and future challenges in ruminant livestock husbandry.
authors: Huws, S. A.;Creevey, C. J.;Oyama, L. B.;Mizrahi, I.;Denman, S. E.;Popova, M.;MuÃ±oz-Tamayo, R.;Forano, E.;Waters, S. M.;Hess, M.;Tapio, I.;Smidt, H.;Krizsan, S. J.;YÃ¡Ã±ez-Ruiz, D. R.;Belanche, A.;Guan, L.;Gruninger, R. J.;McAllister, T. A.;Newbold, C. J.;Roehe, R.;Dewhurst, R. J.;Snelling, T. J.;Watson, M.;Suen, G.;Hart, E. H.;Kingston-Smith, A. H.;Scollan, N. D.;Do Prado, R. M.;Pilau, E. J.;Mantovani, H. C.;Attwood, G. T.;Edwards, J. E.;McEwan, N. R.;Morrisson, S.;Mayorga, O. L.;Elliott, C.;Morgavi, D. P.

title: Sample size calculations for Bayesian prediction of viral diarrhea virus infection in cattle in cattle herds
abstract: We used a Bayesian classification approach to predict the infection status of a flock with bovine viral diarrhea virus when the prevalence of persistently infected animals in such flocks is very low (e.g., <1%). An example of the approach is presented using data from cattle herds in Wyoming, USA. The approach uses previous covariate information (serum neutralization titers collected from animals in 16 flocks) within a predictive model to classify a future observable flock. Simulations to estimate misclassification probabilities for different misclassification costs and prevalences of infected flocks can be used as a guide to the sample size needed to classify a future flock. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Huzurbazar, S.;Van Campen, H.;McLean, M. B.

title: High diversity and potential translocation of DNA viruses in ballast water
abstract: Ballast water is a common vector for transporting invasive species into new marine and aquatic environments. We used a metagenomic approach to study the composition and diversity of viral communities in the ballast water of ships from Mexico, Saudi Arabia, New York and Panama, and in the water from the port of their destination in Busan, Korea. Myoviridae was the most common virus family in ballast water, followed by Podoviridae and Siphoviridae. We also identified viruses infecting invertebrates, amoebas and algae in Busan's ballast water and harbor water. Interestingly, several viruses infecting humans or other animals (swinepox virus, raccoonpox virus, suid herpesvirus, and human endogenous retrovirus) were found in the samples from New York and Panama. In addition, giant viruses were found in all ballast water samples, notably Megavirus chilensis in New York and Panama and Pandoravirus salinus in Mexico and Saudi Arabia. These results provide detailed descriptions of the properties of viruses present in ballast water, document significant viral diversity, and indicate the potential translocation of viruses across ballast water.
authors: Hwang, J.;Park, S. Y.;Lee, S.;Lee, T. K.

title: Molecular identification of three novel herpesviruses found in Australian farmed saltwater crocodiles (Crocodylus porosus) and Australian freshwater crocodiles (Crocodylus johnstoni).
abstract: As part of a larger investigation of three emerging disease syndromes characterized by conjunctivitis and pharyngitis, systemic lymphoid proliferation and encephalitis, and lymphonodular skin infiltrates in farmed saltwater crocodiles (Crocodylus porosus), and an emerging syndrome of systemic lymphoid proliferation in captive freshwater crocodiles (Crocodylus johnstoni) cytopathic effects (CPE), including syncytial cell formation, were observed in primary crocodile cell lines exposed to cleared tissue homogenates from affected crocodilians. Ten cell cultures with CPE were then screened for herpesviruses using two broadly reactive herpesvirus PCRs. Amplicons were obtained from 9 out of 10 cell cultures and sequenced. Three new herpesviruses were discovered, and phylogenetic analysis of these viruses showed a 63 percent Bayesian posterior probability value for these viruses clustering with the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae and a 100 percent posterior probability for clustering with a group containing which contains Alphaherpesvirinae and other unassigned reptilian herpesviruses. It is proposed to name them Crocodyline Herpesvirus (CrHV) 1, 2 and 3. CrHV1 and 2 were only isolated from saltwater crocodiles and CrHV3 only from freshwater crocodiles. A duplex PCR was developed that could detect these herpesviruses in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue, a sample type in which none of the broadly reactive PCRs could detect these herpesviruses. This work describes the isolation, molecular detection and phylogeny of these novel herpesviruses, but the association they have with the emerging disease syndromes warrants further investigation.
authors: Hyndman, T. H.;Shilton, C. M.;Wellehan, J. F., Jr.;Davis, S.;Isberg, S. R.;Phalen, D.;Melville, L.

title: Indigenous hepatitis E in England and Wales from 2003 to 2012: Evidence of an emerging new phylotype of virus
abstract: Background. Since 2003, increased surveillance and molecular characterization studies of hepatitis E virus (HEV) have been carried out in England and Wales. The dynamics of hepatitis E have changed recently with an increase in the number of native cases and an observed virus shift. methods. HEV antibody and RNA data were analyzed to determine annual number of acute infections, HEV genotype disposition, and viral phylogeny. This data was examined in the context of collected travel histories and demographic data. Results. A total of 2713 acute hepatitis E cases were diagnosed, of which 1376 were local infections. Travel-associated cases remained stable and were mainly associated with genotype 1 infections. In contrast, large variations in domestically acquired cases were noted, with a dramatic year-on-year increase between 2010 and 2012. Molecular characterization showed that native infections cluster into two distinct phylogenetic groups, with the emergence of a new group of genotype 3 viruses coinciding with the recent rise in cases. Conclusions. HEV infection rates are dynamic in England and Wales and are influenced by changing trends in indigenous cases. The recent increase in native cases and the emergence of native viruses that were not widely circulating prior to 2010 suggest that the risk of contracting HEV has changed.
authors: Ijaz, S.;Said, B.;Boxall, E.;Smit, E.;Morgan, D.;Tedder, R. S.

title: Identification of bovine enteric caliciviruses (BEC) from cattle in Baden-Württemberg
abstract: Caliciviruses are known to cause various diseases in many animal species. Bovine enteric caliciviruses (BEC) are associated with diarrhea in cattle. These viruses have been classified in the genus Norovirus and are closely related to human norovirus, the main cause of gastroenteritis in humans. This has raised questions about zoonotic transmission and an animal reservoir for the human viruses. Two samples out of 41 stool samples collected for diagnostic purposes from diarrheal cattle in Aulendorf, Germany tested positive for BEC. The samples were amplified with new degenerate BEC-specific primers that amplify a 263 bp portion of the RNA polymerase region. Analysis of the nucleotide sequences showed that these viruses are most closely related to genogroup III/2 (Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK) norovirus viruses.
authors: Ike, A. C.;Roth, B. N.;BÃ¶hm, R.;Pfitzner, A. J.;Marschang, R. E.

title: Herd immunity and fatal cases of influenza among the population exposed to poultry and wild birds in Russian Asia in 2013-2014
abstract: total of 1,525 blood serum samples were collected in October 2013 in Russian Asia from people living in areas with a high risk of occurrence of influenza viruses with pandemic potential. The presence of antibodies against influenza viruses in the sera was tested in the hemagglutination inhibition test. None of the samples gave positive results with the antigens A/H5 and A/H7. Twelve strains of influenza A(H1N1pdm09) virus were isolated from people suspected to have died of influenza during the 2013-2014 epidemic season. All strains were similar to vaccine strain A/California/07/09 in terms of their antigenic properties and susceptibility to anti-neuraminidase drugs (oseltamivir and zanamivir). Genetic analysis revealed that all strains belong to group 6, subgroup 6B of influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. Substitutions in HA1: S164F adds E235K as well as E47G, A86V, K331R, N386K, N397K in NA and K131E, N29S in NS1 and N29S, R34Q in NEP separate the studied strains into two groups: 1. Group-A/Chita/1114/ 2014, A/Chita/1115/2014, A/Chita/853/2014, A/Barnaul/269/2014 and 2nd group-A/Chita/655/2014, A/Chita/656/2014, A/Chita/ 709/2014, A/Chita/873/2014. The mutation D222G in HA1, which is often associated with high morbidity of the disease, was present in strain A/Novosibirsk/114/2014. Substitution N386K in NA removes a potential N-glycosylation site in neuraminidases from A/Chita/1114/2014, A/Chita/1115/2014, A/Chita/853/2014, A/Barnaul/269/2014, A/Novosibirsk/ 114/2014 and A/Blagoveshensk/252/2014.
authors: Ilyicheva, T.;Abdurashitov, M.;Durymanov, A.;Susloparov, I.;Goncharova, N.;Kolosova, N.;Mikheev, V.;Ryzhikov, A.

title: Molecular identification of enteroviruses from cattle and goat faeces and environment in Thailand
authors: Income, N.;Kosoltanapiwat, N.;Taksinoros, S.

title: Variations of the major envelope glycoprotein GP5 of Czech strains of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus
abstract: The major envelope glycoprotein genes (ORF5) of seven Czech isolates of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) were amplified and their nucleotide sequences determined. ORF5 showed nucleotide and amino acid identities of 87*5-100% and 87*6-100% among isolates, respectively. In a pedigree, all European isolates were grouped in a genotype different from that of the American reference strains (VR-2332, IAF-Klop). Two distinct clades have been identified among European isolates. Two Czech isolates (V-501 and V-503) and the Italian strain PRRSV 2156 fell into one group. The remaining European tribes formed the second group. Surprisingly, two separately clustered strains (V-501 and V-516) were isolated from the same herd. In addition, the possible effect of in vitro cultivation on the nucleotide sequence was analyzed. Nine point mutations in the ORF5 region result from 152 in vitro passages of the V-502 isolate in MARC-145 cells.
authors: Indik, S.;Valicek, L.;Klein, D.;Klanova, J.

title: Bats are an untapped system for understanding mammalian microbiome evolution
abstract: Mammals evolved in a microbial world, and consequently microbial symbionts have played a role in their evolution. An exciting new sub-discipline of metagenomics addresses the ways in which microbes, particularly those in the gut, have facilitated ecological and phylogenetic irradiation of mammals. However, the vast majority of these studies focus on pets, laboratory models, or charismatic megafauna (e.g., pandas and chimpanzees). The result is a plethora of studies covering only a few taxa across the mammalian tree of life, leaving broad patterns of microbiome function and development unclear. Microbiome research in wildlife urgently needs a model system in which to test hypotheses about metagenomic involvement in host ecology and evolution. We propose that bats (order: Chiroptera) represent an ideal model system for comparative microbiome research, offering opportunities to study host phylogeny, diet, and other natural history traits related to the evolution of the gut microbiome.
authors: Ingala, M. R.;Simmons, N. B.;Perkins, S. L.

title: Genetic heterogeneity between parapoxviruses isolated from ovine, bovine and Japanese sera (Capricornis crispus).
abstract: Standard strains of four parapoxviruses and seven unclassified Japanese strains isolated from ovine, bovine and wild Japanese sera (Capricornis crispus) were compared molecularly. Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis of viral DNA, indirect immunofluorescence assays using monoclonal antibodies, partial nucleotide sequencing of the envelope gene, phylogenetic analysis and PCR-RFLP were performed. These analyzes revealed that the parapoxviruses were divided into four groups and the region sequenced in this study was highly conserved within each group. Each of the Japanese isolates was assigned to one of these groups. These findings also indicated that parapoxvirus infections among wild Japanese sera appear to be caused by at least two different parapoxviruses, bovine papular stomatitis virus and orf virus. The methods presented here are useful for the genetic characterization and classification of parapoxviruses.
authors: Inoshima, Y.;Murakami, K.;Yokoyama, T.;Sentsui, H.

title: Identification and characterization of Highlands J virus from a Mississippi sandhill crane using unbiased next-generation sequencing
abstract: Advances in massively parallel DNA sequencing platforms, commonly referred to as next-generation sequencing technologies (NGS), have significantly reduced the time, effort, and cost of DNA sequencing. Thus, NGS has become a routine tool for the discovery of new viral pathogens and is likely to become the standard for routine laboratory diagnostics of infectious diseases in the near future. This study demonstrated the application of NGS for the rapid identification and characterization of a virus isolated from the brain of an endangered Mississippi sandhill crane. This bird was part of a population recovery effort and was found in an emaciated condition a few days after Hurricane Isaac swept over the Mississippi refuge in 2012. Consistent with a togavirus isolated from the bird's brain, an arboviral etiology was strongly suspected. Because single molecular assays were negative for several known arboviruses, unbiased Illumina MiSeq NGS was used to definitively identify and characterize the causative viral agent. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis determined the viral isolate to be Highlands J virus, a known avian pathogen. This study demonstrates the use of unbiased NGS for the rapid detection and characterization of an unidentified viral pathogen and the application of this technology to wildlife disease diagnosis and conservation medicine.
authors: Ip, H. S.;Wiley, M. R.;Long, R.;Palacios, G.;Shearn-Bochsler, V.;Whitehouse, C. A.

title: Viral pathotype and deep sequencing of the HA gene of a low pathogenicity H7N1 avian influenza virus causing death in turkeys
abstract: Low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) viruses of the H7 subtype generally cause mild disease in poultry. However, the evolution of an LPAI virus into a highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) results in the generation of a virus that can cause serious illness and death. The classification of these two pathotypes is based in part on morbidity and death in chickens as determined in an intravenous pathogenicity assay, but the effect of LPAI viruses in turkeys is less well understood. During an investigation of LPAI virus infection in turkeys, groups of three-week-old birds vaccinated with A/chicken/Italy/1279/99 (H7N1) showed severe signs of disease and died or were euthanized within 7 days of infection. The virus has been detected in many internal tissues and organs of culled birds. To investigate the possible evolution of the infecting virus into a highly pathogenic form in these turkeys, a sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene cleavage site was performed by analyzing multiple cDNA amplicons from swabs and tissue sample extracts using Sanger and Next Generation Sequencing. In addition, an RT-PCR assay was developed to detect the HPAI virus. There was no evidence of the presence of HPAI virus in either the virus used as an inoculum or in swabs taken from infected birds. However, a small fraction (<0.5%) of the virus contained in individual trachea or liver samples contained a molecular signature at the HA cleavage site typical of an HPAI virus. All signature sequences were identical and resembled HPAI viruses collected during the 1999/2000 Italian animal epidemic. We assume that the detection of HPAI virus in tissue samples after infection with A/Chicken/Italy/1279/99 reflects the amplification of a virus present at very low levels in the mixed inoculum, but remarkably we did not observe any new ones HPAI virus signatures in amplified DNA analyzed by deep sequencing.
authors: Iqbal, M.;Reddy, K. B.;Brookes, S. M.;Essen, S. C.;Brown, I. H.;McCauley, J. W.

title: The pig gut microbiome
authors: Isaacson, R.;Kim, H. B.

title: Genetic analysis of ORF5 in swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in Japan
abstract: No reports of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) genetic information have been published in recent years with a focus on Japan. To clarify the influence of time on PRRSV genomic development, we sequenced open reading frame 5 (600 or 603 bases) obtained from Japanese PRRSV isolates for three periods (1992-1993, 2000-2001 and 2007-2008). was, and compared their phylogeny relationships. Assessment of the mean pairwise homology of nucleotide sequences of PRRSV isolates showed a trend toward increasing heterogeneity over time. In addition, we newly discovered a virus classified in Cluster IV, indicating increasing genetic variation of PRRSV in Japan. © 2011 The Societies and Blackwell Publishing Asia Pty Ltd.
authors: Iseki, H.;Takagi, M.;Miyazaki, A.;Katsuda, K.;Mikami, O.;Tsunemitsu, H.

title: The B genome segment encoding the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase protein VP1 of the highly virulent infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) is phylogenetically distinct from that of all other IBDV strains
abstract: full length cDNA clone of segment B of highly virulent infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) strain BD 3/99 was constructed and the full length nucleotide sequence was determined. The nucleotide sequence encoding VP1, an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, from BD 3/99 was aligned to that of 17 other IBDV strains, including six very virulent, three classically virulent, five classically attenuated, one antigenic variant and two Serotype 2 strains. The VP1 genes of all very virulent strains were 97.5% to 99.8% identical. With the exception of one atypical Australian strain, 002-73, all of the classic virulent or attenuated and antigenic variant strains were also 97.5% to 100% identical. Serotype 2 strains showed only 4-6% divergence from classically virulent or attenuated serotype 1 strains; in contrast, however, the very virulent strains differed by 10.5% to 12.5% from the classic virulent or attenuated strains and serotype 2 strains. Analysis of the deduced amino acid sequence of VP1 revealed 17 common, including 8 unique, amino acid substitutions in the very virulent strains. In the phylogenetic tree, the very virulent strains formed a distinct cluster and all other strains, including classically virulent, attenuated and antigenic variant strains and even serotype 2 strains, were grouped together. It is hypothesized that the VP1 of highly virulent IBDV is phylogenetically distinct from that of all other IBDV strains and likely originates from a previously unidentified source.
authors: Islam, M. R.;Zierenberg, K.;Muller, H.

title: A whole genome analysis of porcine astroviruses detected in Japanese pigs reveals genetic diversity and possible intra-genotypic recombination
abstract: Porcine astroviruses (PoAstVs) are ubiquitous porcine enteric viruses that are distributed in several countries worldwide. Because PoAstVs are detected in apparently healthy pigs, the clinical significance of the infection is unknown. However, AstVs have recently been implicated in a serious neurological disorder in animals, including humans, and zoonotic potential has been suggested. So far, little is known about the epidemiology of PoAstVs in the pig population in Japan. In this report, we present an analysis of near-complete genomes of 36 PoAstVs detected in Japanese pig feces by a metagenomic approach. Based on phylogenetic analysis and pairwise sequence comparison, 10, 5, 15, and 6 sequences were classified as PoAstV2, PoAstV3, PoAstV4, and PoAstV5, respectively. Co-infection with two or three strains was found in individual faecal samples from eight pigs. The ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2 pedigrees of PoAstV2 and PoAstV4 showed differences in their topology. The PoAstV3 and PoAstV5 strains shared high sequence identities within each genotype in all ORFs; however, one PoAstV3 strain and one PoAstV5 strain showed significant sequence divergence from the other PoAstV3 and PoAstV5 strains, respectively, in ORF2. Recombination analysis using whole genomes revealed evidence for multiple possible recombination events within the genotype in PoAstV2 and PoAstV4, suggesting that recombination may have contributed to genetic diversity and played an important role in the evolution of Japanese PoAstVs.
authors: Ito, M.;Kuroda, M.;Masuda, T.;Akagami, M.;Haga, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Kishimoto, M.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Aoki, H.;Ichimaru, T.;Mukono, I.;Ouchi, Y.;Yamasato, H.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Analysis of the whole genome of Japanese bovine toroviruses shows natural recombination between porcine and bovine toroviruses
abstract: Bovine toroviruses (BToVs) belong to the subfamily Toroviridae within the family Coronaviridae and are pathogens that cause enteric diseases in cattle. In Japan, BToVs are common across the country and cause gastrointestinal infections in calves and cows. In the present study, full genome sequences of two Japanese BToVs and partial genome sequences of two Japanese BToVs and a porcine torovirus (PToV) from distant regions in Japan were determined and genetic analyzes were performed. Pairwise nucleotide comparison and phylogenetic analysis revealed that Japanese BToVs shared a high level of identity with each other and showed high similarities to the BToV Breda1 strain in the S, M, and HE coding regions. Japanese BToVs showed high similarities to porcine toroviruses in the ORF1a, ORF1b and N coding regions and the 5' and 3' untranslated regions, indicating a natural recombination event. Recombination analyzes mapped the putative recombinant breakpoints at the 3' ends of the ORF1b and HE regions. These results suggest that the interspecies recombinant nature of Japanese BToVs led to a closer relationship between BToV Breda1 and PToVs.
authors: Ito, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Otomaru, K.;Sato, M.;Masuda, T.;Haga, K.;Oka, T.;Yamasato, H.;Omatsu, T.;Sugimura, S.;Aoki, H.;Furuya, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: The potyvirus associated with the spotted fruit of Passiflora edulis in Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan, is the third strain of the proposed new species East Asian Passiflora virus (EAPV) that is phylogenetically distinct from passion fruit woodiness virus strains
abstract: potyvirus (isolate IB) causing mottled or faded fruit and leaf mosaic symptoms of purple passion fruit has been found at the University of Kagoshima Botanical Garden, Japan. This isolate differed in host range from passion fruit woodiness virus (PWV)-AO isolates previously reported to cause "woodiness" in Japan. Isolates IB and AO had 83% amino acid identity in their envelope proteins (CPs). In phylogenetic analysis, East Asian isolates IB, AO, and PWV-Taiwan clustered and were distinguishable from Australian PWV and Brazilian mosaic virus isolates transmitted by the cowpea aphid, which also cause "woodiness" in passion fruit. We propose the name "East Asian Passiflora virus (EAPV)" for the new potyvirus species. © Springer Verlag 2005.
authors: Iwai, H.;Yamashita, Y.;Nishi, N.;Nakamura, M.

title: Novel bioinformatic strategies to predict directed sequence changes in influenza virus genomes and to monitor potentially dangerous strains
abstract: Background: With the remarkable increase in microbial and viral sequence data obtained from high-throughput DNA sequencers, new tools for the comprehensive analysis of large sequence data are needed. We have developed a "Batch-Learning Self-Organizing Map (BLSOM)" that can characterize very many, even millions, of genomic sequences at one level. The influenza virus belongs to the zoonotic viruses and shows a clear host tropism. Important topics for bioinformatic studies of influenza viruses are the prediction of genomic sequence changes in the near future and the monitoring of potentially dangerous strains. Methods: To characterize sequence changes in influenza virus genomes after invasion into humans from other animal hosts, we applied BLSOMs to analyzes of mono -, di-, tri- and tetranucleotide compositions in all genome sequences of influenza A and B viruses and found a clear host-dependent clustering (self-organization) of the sequences. Results: Viruses isolated from humans and birds differed from each other in the mononucleotide composition. In addition, host-dependent oligonucleotide compositions that could not be explained in terms of host-dependent mononucleotide composition were revealed by oligonucleotide BLSOMs. Retrospective time-dependent directional changes of mono- and oligonucleotide compositions visualized on BLSOMs for human strains could provide predictive information about sequence changes in newly invaded viruses from other animal hosts (e.g. the swine-borne pandemic H1N1/09). Conclusions: Based on the host-dependent oligonucleotide composition, we proposed a strategy to predict viral sequence directional changes and to monitor potentially dangerous strains when introduced into human populations from non-human sources. Millions of genomic sequences of infectious microbes and viruses have become available due to their medical and social importance, and BLSOM can characterize the large amounts of data and support efficient knowledge discovery. © 2013 Iwasaki et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Iwasaki, Y.;Abe, T.;Wada, Y.;Wada, K.;Ikemura, T.

title: Arboviruses: inclusion in a general system of virus classification
authors: J, Casals

title: Molecular properties of infectious bursal virus from asymptomatic broiler flocks in Europe
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) exists in several different antigenic and pathogenic forms. Immunosuppression in young chickens caused by this virus is not always associated with clinical signs of disease. The antigenic virus variants originally described in the USA do not typically cause any clinical symptoms, but can cause significant immunosuppression by destroying B lymphocytes. Using a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, we conducted a screening of asymptomatic broiler flocks in Europe for IBDV. Restriction fragment length polymorphisms in the viral protein 2 (VP2) gene of four isolates from Spain and four isolates from France suggested that they may differ from the classical and highly virulent (vv) IBDV strains found across Europe. Nucleotide sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the hypervariable region of the VP2 gene showed that all eight viruses were more similar to US variant viruses than to classical viruses. In two viruses, one from France and one from Spain, threonine was found at amino acid position 222 and serine at position 254. These two substitution mutations are characteristic of Delaware variant viruses. In addition, all eight viruses had a mutated amino acid position 318 from glycine to aspartic acid, another substitution mutation commonly found in US variant viruses. Although import restrictions prevented us from directly testing the antigenicity of these viruses, their nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences suggest that they may be antigenic distinct compared to classical and vvIBDV commonly found in Europe. Confirming the presence of antigenic variants of IBDV strains in Europe requires additional immunological studies to elucidate the precise nature of the viral epitopes. Our data support the need for these immunological studies.
authors: Jackwood, D. J.;Cookson, K. C.;Sommer-Wagner, S. E.;Le Galludec, H.;De Wit, J. J.

title: Diversity of the B genome segment of infectious bursal disease viruses in the United States
abstract: Several phylogenetic lineages of the B genome segment of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) have been identified. Although this genome segment has been shown to contribute to virulence, little is known about the genetic lineages that exist in the United States. The nucleotide genome segment B sequences of 67 IBDV strains collected from 2002 to 2011 in the United States were examined. Despite hailing from nine different states, the majority (47) of these viruses originated in California. A 722 base pair region near the 5' end of genome segment B, beginning at nucleotide 168 and ending at 889, was examined and compared to sequences available in GenBank. Nucleotide sequence alignment showed that mutations were frequently observed and that they were evenly distributed across the region. When the predicted amino acids were aligned, it was found that the amino acids at positions 145, 146, and 147 change frequently. Six different amino acid triplets were observed and the very virulent (vv) IBDV strains (based on the presence of the vvIBDV genome segment A sequence) all had the T145, D146 and N147 triplet. None of the non-vvIBDV strains had this TDN triplet. Phylogenetic analysis of the 67 nucleotide sequences revealed four significant lineages of genome segment B among US viruses. One of these included the B genome segment typically found in vvIBDV, and three contained non-vvIBDV genome segment B sequences. When the available sequences in GenBank were added for analysis, two additional lineages that did not contain US viruses were observed ; one contained virus from China and the other contained virus from Ivory Coast. Although the samples tested did not represent all poultry-producing regions in the United States, serotype 1 viruses from states outside of California all belonged to a genomic segment B lineage. The other three lineages observed in the United States were colonized with viruses unique to California, with the exception of the serotype 2 line in which the type strain was an Ohio serotype 2 virus. The data provide further evidence of the importance of identifying genomic segment B during routine molecular diagnosis of all IBDV strains. © 2012 American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Jackwood, D. J.;Crossley, B. M.;Stoute, S. T.;Sommer-Wagner, S.;Woolcock, P. R.;Charlton, B. R.

title: Different evolutionary pathways of vaccine-controlled and uncontrolled avian infectious bronchitis viruses in commercial poultry
abstract: To determine the genetic and epidemiological relationship of commercial poultry infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) isolates with live attenuated IBV vaccines, we performed a phylogenetic network analysis of the full S1 sequence for Arkansas (Ark), Massachusetts (Mass) and Delmarva/1639 (DMV/1639) type viruses isolated in 2015 from clinical cases from 3 different diagnostic laboratories. Phylogenetic network analysis of Ark isolates revealed two predominant groups linked by 2 mutations, consistent with subpopulations found in commercial vaccines for this IBV type. In addition, a number of satellite clusters around the two predominant populations for Ark-type virus were observed, likely due to mutations related to the nature of this vaccine to persist in flocks. Phylogenetic network analysis of mass-type viruses reveals two groupings corresponding to vaccine sequences from different manufacturers. No satellite groups were observed for mass-type viruses, consistent with the lack of persistence of this vaccine type in the field. No vaccine against DMV/1639 viruses was used at the time of collection and phylogenetic network analysis showed a scattered network, indicating no clear change in genetic distribution. Selection pressure analysis showed that the DMV/1639 and Mass-type strains evolved under negative selection, whereas the Ark-type viruses had evolved under positive selection. These data support the hypothesis that the use of live attenuated vaccines plays a role in the genetic profile of similar IB viruses in the field and phylogenetic network analysis can be used to identify vaccine and vaccine origin isolates, which is important for our understanding of the role of live vaccines play a role in the evolutionary trajectory of these viruses.
authors: Jackwood, M. W.;Lee, D. H.

title: The delta hepatitis pathogen: "Viral hepatitis, type D"
abstract: The Δ agent has been sufficiently characterized to merit its designation as a virus and the standardization of its nomenclature. Therefore, as suggested by Rizzetto and co-workers, the following conventions are adopted: the γ-agent is referred to as hepatitis D virus (HDV), its antigen as hepatitis D antigen (HDAg), and the disease associated with the infection as viral hepatitis denoted , type D
authors: Jacobson, I. M.;Dienstag, J. L.

title: Genetic analysis of avian influenza A viruses isolated from native waterfowl at live bird markets in Hanoi, Vietnam, which preceded fatal human H5N1 infections in 2004
abstract: The first known cases of human infection with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus in Vietnam occurred in late 2003. However, HPAI H5N1 and low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) H5N2 and H9N3 viruses were isolated in live birds from domestic waterfowl market surveillance (LBM) in Vietnam in 2001 and 2003. To explore the possible role of these early viruses in the genesis of H5N1 -strains that infect humans, we performed sequencing and molecular characterization. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the hemagglutinin (HA) genes of two goose HPAI-H5N1 strains belonged to clade 3 and their surface glycoprotein and replication complex genes were most closely related to A/duck/Guangxi/22/01 (98.5 -99.7% homologous). (H5N1) virus discovered simultaneously in southern China, while the M and NS genes are derived from an A/duck/Hong Kong/2986.1/00 (H5N1)-like virus. The H5-HA gene of duck HPAI-H5N1 strain belonged to clade 5 and acquired a gene constellation of A/quail/Shantou/3846/02 (H5N1), A/teal/China/2978.1/02 (H5N1) and A /partridge/ Shantou/2286/03 (H5N1)-like viruses. The phylogenetic analysis also showed that all eight gene segments of the goose and duck viruses HPAI H5N1 and LPAI H5N2 differed from those of the H5N1 clade 1 viruses, which have been known to cause fatal human infections since late 2003 caused by Vietnam. The duck H9N3 isolates derived genes from waterfowl influenza viruses and their H9 HA belonged to the Korean lineage. The PB2 gene of A/duck/Vietnam/340/01 (H9N3) virus had lysine at position 627. Based on molecular characterization of specific surface amino acid residues and relevant internal protein-coding genes, Vietnamese H5N1 and H9N3 virus isolates demonstrated specificity for the avian cell surface receptor and sensitivity to currently approved anti-influenza A virus chemotherapeutic agents. Our results suggest that the H5N1 and H5N2 viruses that circulated between geese and ducks in LBMs in Hanoi, Vietnam in 2001 and 2003 were not the immediate ancestors of the clade 1 viruses associated with fatal infections been associated with humans in Vietnam. The clade 1 HPAI H5N1 viruses were independently introduced into Vietnam.
authors: Jadhao, S. J.;Nguyen, D. C.;Uyeki, T. M.;Shaw, M.;Maines, T.;Rowe, T.;Smith, C.;Huynh, L. P.;Nghiem, H. K.;Nguyen, D. H.;Nguyen, H. K.;Nguyen, H. H.;Hoang, L. T.;Nguyen, T.;Phuong, L. S.;Klimov, A.;Tumpey, T. M.;Cox, N. J.;Donis, R. O.;Matsuoka, Y.;Katz, J. M.

title: Genetic Analysis of Avian Influenza Viruses: Cocirculation of Avian Influenza Viruses with Allelic A and B Nonstructural Genes in Northern Pintail (Anas acuta) Ducks Wintering in Japan
abstract: The 1918 (H1N1), 1957 (H2N2), 1968 (H3N2), and 2009 (H1N1) pandemic influenza virus strains have genes related to avian influenza viruses (AIVs). The nonstructural (NS) gene of AIVs plays an important role in the host-virus interaction. However, little is known about the degree of diversity of this gene in pintail ducks (Anas acuta) wintering in Japan. This study describes the characteristics of H1N1, H1N2, H1N3, H5N2, H5N3, H5N9 and H7N7 viruses derived from pintails. Most of the viruses turned out to be from avian strains unrelated to pandemic and seasonal flu strains. Nonetheless, the NP genes of 62.5% (5/8) viruses were found to be closely related to an A/pig/Korea/C12/08, suggesting an exchange of genetic material and ongoing mammalian-associated evolution of AIVs. In addition, all viruses except Aomori/422/07 H1N1 contain the PSIQSRGLF motif, which is normally found in avian, porcine and human H1 strains. The Aomori/422/07 H1N1 has a PSVQSRGLF motif identical to a North American strain. These findings connected to an important intercontinental, Asian-American biogeographical interface. Phylogenetically, all viruses were clustered in Eurasian lineage. The co-circulation of allelic A and B viruses (NS gene) was evident in the study, suggesting the existence of a wide reservoir of influenza A viruses in overwintering pintails in Japan. © 2012 Alam Jahangir et al.
authors: Jahangir, A.;Ruenphet, S.;Sultana, N.;Shoham, D.;Takehara, K.

title: Isolation and characterization of H9N2 influenza virus isolates from outbreaks of respiratory disease in poultry
abstract: The present study reports the isolation and characterization of the H9N2 virus responsible for a disease characterized by symptoms including difficulty breathing, head swelling, nasal discharge, reduced food intake, cyanotic crest, reduced egg production and mortality. Virus isolation from allantoic fluid inoculated with tracheal aspirates and whole genome sequencing of two isolates were performed on an Ion Torrent sequencer. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the two H9N2 isolates are reassortant viruses sharing a G1-like lineage for HA, NA and NP, a Hok/49/98-like lineage for PB1 and PA, and a PK/UDL-01/05 -like lineage for PB2, IL/90658/00-like lineage for the NS and an unknown lineage for the M gene. Analysis of the HA cleavage site revealed a sequence of (333PARSSRGL340), indicating that these isolates are of low pathogenicity. Isolate 2 has leucine at amino acid position 226, a substitution associated with mammalian adaptation of avian influenza virus. Isolate 1 has the S31N substitution in the M2 gene, which has been linked to drug resistance, and R57Q and C241Y mutations in the NP gene, which have been linked to human adaptation. The result reported here provides a deep insight into the H9N2 viruses circulating in Indian domestic poultry and supports the policy of active efforts to control and manage H9N2 infection in Indian poultry.
authors: Jakhesara, S. J.;Bhatt, V. D.;Patel, N. V.;Prajapati, K. S.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Emergence of a genotype I variant of infectious avian bronchitis virus from the northern part of India
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is one of the main causes of continued economic strain on the poultry industry worldwide. IBV belongs to the genus Gammacoronavirus within the family Coronaviridae. IBV infection causes respiratory and nephrogenic symptoms in broilers. In addition, its infection leads to reduced fertility and hatchability in layer birds. We have determined the first full genome sequence of an IBV variant from an outbreak in Haryana state, northern India, using next-generation sequencing. In phylogenetic analysis of the IBV isolate, it clustered with genotype I lineage 1 (GI-1). The deduced amino acid sequence of the S gene from IBV isolates showed a high degree of identity with strains isolated from Tamil Nadu and the reference vaccine strains. Our result suggests that the IBV virus isolated from unvaccinated chicken flocks in northern India may be a revertant strain that originally evolved from the live attenuated vaccine strains used in the region. Determining the full genome sequence of additional IBV isolates from India is necessary to understand the epidemiology of IBV in India.
authors: Jakhesara, S. J.;Nath, B.;Pal, J. K.;Joshi, C. G.;Kumar, S.

title: Pathotypic and sequence characterization of Newcastle disease viruses from vaccinated chickens showing genotypes II, IV and XIII circulating in India
abstract: Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV) causes a highly contagious disease that plagues the global poultry industry. The nature and molecular epidemiology of NDVs that have been prevalent in recent outbreaks in India are poorly understood. This study aimed to characterize NDVs prevalent in vaccinated herds in India using whole genome sequencing and biological pathotyping. Twelve field isolates were collected from outbreaks occurring in different parts of India and characterized as velogen based on their intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) and amino acid sequence at the F protein cleavage site. All 12 field isolates and five commonly used vaccine strains were selected for whole genome sequencing using Ion Torrent PGM technology, yielding complete genome sequences for ten field isolates and all vaccine strains. The genomes of all isolates were found to be 15 192 nt in length and show a high level of conservation across multiple genomic traits with APMV-I viruses. Phylogenetic analysis and evolutionary distance calculations assigned the isolates to genotypes II, IV, and XIII. Revisiting other recently reported strains provided preliminary evidence for genotypes VI, VII, and XVIII circulating in India. Comparison between the field and vaccine virus sequences revealed unique genomic and amino acid differences in key antigenic regions of the F and hemagglutinin neuraminidase (HN) genes that can be targeted for site-directed mutagenesis to assess the impact of these substitutions on viral pathogenicity. This study underscores the need to evaluate current vaccines through systematic protective testing to determine protective efficacy against field isolates.
authors: Jakhesara, S. J.;Prasad, V. V.;Pal, J. K.;Jhala, M. K.;Prajapati, K. S.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Porcine delta coronavirus, Thailand, 2015
authors: Janetanakit, T.;Lumyai, M.;Bunpapong, N.;Boonyapisitsopa, S.;Chaiyawong, S.;Nonthabenjawan, N.;Kesdaengsakonwut, S.;Amonsin, A.

title: Sequence analysis of the S1 glycoprotein gene of infectious bronchitis viruses: identification of a new phylogenetic group in Korea
abstract: Between 2001 and 2003, twelve Korean infectious bronchitis viruses (IBVs) were isolated from chickens suspected to be carriers of infectious bronchitis analyzed by restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis. These Korean IBV isolates were divided into three groups according to their RFLP patterns obtained using the restriction enzyme HaeIII. Half of the 12 isolates resembled the KM91 RFLP pattern, which is a common pattern in Korea. Three other isolates were related to the Arkansas strain pattern, but with some unique variations. The other three viruses showed different RFLP patterns. Amplified PCR products from the twelve isolates were cloned and sequenced for comparison to the published sequences for non-Korean IBV strains. The Korean IBV field isolates had 71.2-99.7% nucleotide sequence homology with each other and 45.9-80.7% nucleotide sequence homology with non-Korean IBV strains. In terms of deduced amino acid sequence, the Korean IBV isolates had 71.5-99.3% similarity among themselves and 44.9-80.3% similarity with non-Korean IBV strains. Phylogenetic tree analysis revealed that some of the IBV isolates appear to belong to a new group distinct from the non-Korean IBV strains or from previously isolated Korean IBV strains. In particular, the new Korean IBV isolates K10217-03, K3-3 and K1255-03 represented a separate group. These results suggest that Korean IBVs appear to be constantly evolving.
authors: Jang, J. H.;Sung, H. W.;Song, C. S.;Kwon, H. M.

title: Antigenic and genetic analysis of foot-and-mouth disease virus type A isolates to select a candidate vaccine strain indicates the emergence of a virus variant responsible for recent outbreaks in India
abstract: Recent reports indicate the presence of two antigenic and genetic groups (genotypes VI and VII) of foot and mouth disease virus (FMD) type A in India and differ from the vaccine strains. To select suitable field isolates as candidate vaccine strains, antisera will be tested against representative isolates from both genotypes and two vaccine strains in use in a neutralization assay. Two candidate vaccine strains from both genotypes are selected with close antigenic matches to the field isolates. From the result it can be seen that IND 81/00 (genotypes VII) gave better antigenic coverage (antigenic relationship (r) value > 0.40 in 79% of isolates from 2002-2003) than IND 258/99 (genotype VI ; r-value > 0.40 in 42% of isolates from 2002-2003). Phylogenetic analysis based on the P1 genomic region assigned all recent isolates (2001–2003) to genotype VII, with the emergence of a new virus variant (VIIb-VP359del) with an amino acid deletion at an antigenically critical residue (VP359), indicating a large evolutionary leap likely due to immune selection. Although very limited in scope, these data indicate an apparent dominance of genotype VII over genotype VI and underscore the need to continue further molecular-epidemiological studies to substantiate this finding. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Jangra, R. K.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Bandyopadhyay, S. K.

title: Statoviruses, a new taxon of RNA viruses found in the gastrointestinal tract of various mammals
abstract: Next-generation sequencing has advanced our understanding of the viral populations that make up the mammalian virome. We describe a new taxon of viruses, called statoviruses, for stool-associated tombus-like viruses present in several metagenomic datasets. These viruses define a new group phylogenetically related to the RNA virus families Tombusviridae and Flaviviridae. Five different statovirus types have been identified in gastrointestinal tract samples from humans, macaques, mice and cows. The prototype Statovirus A genome has been commonly identified in stool samples from macaques from several geographically diverse cohorts. Another genome, Statovirus C1, was discovered in a stool sample from a human child with a fever, cough and rash. Further experimental data will clarify whether these viruses are infectious to mammals or whether they originate from another source present in the mammalian gastrointestinal tract.
authors: Janowski, A. B.;Krishnamurthy, S. R.;Lim, E. S.;Zhao, G.;Brenchley, J. M.;Barouch, D. H.;Thakwalakwa, C.;Manary, M. J.;Holtz, L. R.;Wang, D.

title: Epidemiological investigation of an outbreak of goose parvovirus infection in Sweden
abstract: An outbreak of goose parvovirus (GPV) infection on a Swedish goose farm in spring 2004 increased mortality rates from 2% in the early, unaffected broods to 90% and 99% in the two broods after virus introduction and 40% in goslings, respectively hatched later in the same breeding season. In this article we describe the clinical observations, diagnostic procedures and epidemiological investigations that were carried out to elucidate the source of the infection. The diagnosis was confirmed by serology, virus isolation and sequence analysis of a 493 bp fragment of the VP1 gene. Phylogenetically, the causative virus was closely related to pathogenic GPV strains isolated in 2003 and 2004 from Poland and the UK, respectively. The Swedish isolate showed less homology with pathogenic strains from Hungary and Asia and with attenuated vaccine strains. The epidemiological investigation showed that the virus was first introduced on a contract farm (Farm A) and then transmitted with newly hatched goslings to the farm that submitted the birds for necropsy (index farm). The exact point in time and the source of the introduction of the virus into company A could not be determined with absolute certainty. Possible sources of infection included backyard geese eggs that had been supplied to Farm A for incubation and subcontractor hatching, wild geese visiting the flock of breeding geese in the pasture on Farm A, and a clutch of Canada goose (Branta canadensis) eggs that did so was produced by wild geese and hatched in the same machine as the eggs from farm A.
authors: Jansson, D. S.;Feinstein, R.;Kardi, V.;MatÃ³, T.;Palya, V.

title: A novel bovine papillomavirus (BPV-6) causing true epithelial papillomas of the mammary gland skin: A member of a proposed new BPV subgroup
abstract: papillomavirus was isolated from frond epithelial papillomas of the bovine udder. It is clearly distinguishable from all other bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) on the basis of DNA sequence homology and antigenic properties and is therefore characterized as a new entity designated BPV-6. BPV-6 does not possess an interspecific papillomavirus antigen, its genomic DNA (7.2 kb) is smaller than and shows no sequence homology to BPV-1, BPV-2 or BPV-5, although it is approximately the same length as BPV -3 or BPV-4 with which it shares some sequence homology. The bovine papillomaviruses were divided into two subgroups: subgroup A consisting of BPV-1, BPV-2 and BPV-5, all of which induce fibropapilloma, and subgroup B consisting of BPV-3, BPV-4 and BPV-6, all of which cause true epithelial papillomas.
authors: Jarrett, W. F. H.;Campo, M. S.;O'Neil, B. W.

title: ViQuaS: an improved reconstruction pipeline for viral quasispecies spectra generated by next-generation sequencing
abstract: MOTIVATION: The combined effect of high replication rate and low fidelity of viral polymerase in most RNA viruses and some DNA viruses leads to the formation of a viral quasi-species. Uncovering information about quasi-species populations greatly benefits the study of disease progression, antiviral drug development, vaccine development, and viral pathogenesis. We present a new analysis pipeline called ViQuaS for the reconstruction of viral quasispecies spectra using short next-generation sequencing reads. ViQuaS is based on a novel reference-based de novo assembly algorithm for constructing local haplotypes. A significantly extended version of an existing global strain reconstruction algorithm is also used. RESULTS: Benchmarking results showed that ViQuaS outperformed three other previously published methods called ShoRAH, QuRe and PredictHaplo with improvements of at least 3.1-53.9% in retrieval, 0-12.1% in precision and 0-38 .2% in F-score related to stretch sequence composition and improvements of at least 0.006-0.143 in KL divergence and 0.001-0.035 in root mean square error related to stretch frequency estimation over the next best algorithm under different simulation settings. We also applied ViQuaS to a real read set derived from an in vitro population of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-1, two independent data sets of foot-and-mouth disease virus derived from the same biological sample, and one real HIV-1 data set and showed better results than other available methods.
authors: Jayasundara, D.;Saeed, I.;Maheswararajah, S.;Chang, B. C.;Tang, S. L.;Halgamuge, S. K.

title: Mixed triple: related viruses in unique, recent isolates of the highly virulent type 2 bovine viral diarrhea virus detected by deep sequencing
abstract: WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION: In February 2013, very severe acute clinical symptoms were observed in calves, heifers and dairy cattle on several farms in North Rhine-Westphalia and Lower Saxony, Germany. Deep sequencing revealed the coexistence of three distinct genome variants within novel highly virulent bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2 (BVDV-2) isolates. While the majority (approximately 95%) of the population had a duplication of a 222 nucleotide (nt) segment within the p7 NS2 coding region, the minority reflected the standard structure of a BVDV-2 genome. In addition, unusual mutations were found within the highly conserved p7 protein and near the p7 NS2 cleavage site in both variants. Using a reverse genetic system with a BVDV-2a strain harboring a similar duplication, it could be shown that duplication-free genomes are generated de novo from duplication-containing genomes during replication. The major variant with duplication is compulsorily accompanied by the minor variant without duplication. The prediction of the RNA secondary structure enabled the analysis of the unique but stable mixture of three BVDV variants and also provided the explanation for their formation. Finally, our results suggest that the duplicating variant plays the major role in the highly virulent phenotype. SIGNIFICANCE: This study emphasizes the importance of full genome deep sequencing combined with manual in-depth data analysis for studying viruses in basic research and diagnostics. Here we examined recent highly virulent bovine viral diarrhea virus isolates from a series of outbreaks in 2013. We discovered a unique feature of the viral genome, an unstable 222-nucleotide duplication that is eventually deleted by viral polymerase activity, resulting in an unexpectedly mixed population of viral genomes for all isolates examined. Our study is of great importance to the field, as we show that these insertion/deletion events enable another level of genome plasticity of plus-strand RNA viruses, in addition to the known polymerase-induced single nucleotide variations, which are widely considered to be the most important become the basis for viral adaptation and evolution.
authors: Jenckel, M.;Hoper, D.;Schirrmeier, H.;Reimann, I.;Goller, K. V.;Hoffmann, B.;Beer, M.

title: Identification of two novel reassortant avian influenza A viruses (H5N6) in whooper swans in Korea, 2016
abstract: Background: On November 20, 2016, two new strains of the highly pathogenic H5N6 avian influenza virus (HPAIVs) were isolated from three whooper swans (Cygnus cygnus) in Gangjin Bay, South Jeolla Province, South Korea. The identification of HPAIVs in wild birds is important due to the potential risk of transmission of these viruses to poultry and humans. Results: Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Gangjin H5N6 viruses were classified in the Asian H5 clade 2.3.4.4 lineage and were distinguishable from H5N8 and H5N1 HPAIVs previously isolated in Korea. With the exception of the acid polymerase (PA) gene, the viruses were most closely related to A/duck/Guangdong/01.01SZSGXJK005-Y/2016 (H5N6) (98.90~99.74%). The PA genes of the two novel Gangjin H5N6 viruses were most closely related to AIV isolates previously isolated from Korea, A/hooded crane/Korea/1176/2016 (H1N1) (99.16%) and A/environment/ Korea/W133/2006 (H7N7) (98.65%). The absence of newer viruses according to A/environment/Korea/W133/2006 (H7N7) indicates the need for analysis of new wild bird AIVs isolated in Korea as they may provide further clues to the origin of these novel reassortant H5N6 viruses . Conclusions: Although research into the origins and epidemiology of these infections is ongoing, the most likely route of infection for the whooper swans was direct or indirect contact with reassortant viruses shed by migratory wild birds in Korea. Because H5N6-HPAIV can potentially be transmitted to poultry and humans, continued surveillance of AIV in wild birds will help mitigate this risk.
authors: Jeong, J.;Woo, C.;Ip, H. S.;An, I.;Kim, Y.;Lee, K.;Jo, S. D.;Son, K.;Lee, S.;Oem, J. K.;Wang, S. J.;Kim, Y.;Shin, J.;Sleeman, J.;Jheong, W.

title: Genetic characterization of H1 avian influenza viruses isolated from migratory birds and domesticated ducks in Korea
abstract: H1 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) isolated from migratory birds and domestic ducks from 2003 to 2007 were analyzed to determine their genetic relatedness. A phylogenetic analysis using nucleotide sequences of all eight gene segments showed that 13 H1-AIVs from migratory and domestic ducks belonged to Eurasian bird lineages and were closely related. Compared to H1 swine or human influenza viruses in Korea, there was no evidence of reassortment between human, swine, and avian hosts. Our results show that H1-AIVs isolated in Korea between 2003 and 2007 were genetically stable. However, given the role of migratory birds and domestic ducks as a source of AIVs, continuous monitoring is required. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Jeong, O. M.;Kim, Y. J.;Choi, J. G.;Kang, H. M.;Kim, M. C.;Kwon, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.

title: Detection of Newcastle disease virus and its effect on the development of immunity after vaccination in a commercial flock of laying hens
abstract: The aim of this study was to monitor the level of antibodies against Newcastle disease after vaccination of laying hens at the beginning and at the end of the lay period. The study was conducted in 2008-2010 in a commercial layer flock in Opatovice, Czech Republic. A total of 280 blood sera samples were taken from laying hens in four poultry houses. The sera were tested using the OIE manual haemagglutination inhibition assay. Virological tests were carried out as a result of atypical results of serological tests. RNA of the Newcastle disease virus was detected in the pooled tissue samples from 5 hens, in the intestine samples with ileocaecal tonsils, in the trachea and in a swab sample from the vicinity of a barn using the RT-nested-PCR method. Based on a sequence analysis and a subsequent phylogenetic analysis, the virus was identified as a weakly pathogenic strain of Paramyxovirus (PMV-1). This low pathogenic strain did not affect the health of the laying hens.
authors: Jerabkova, J.;Juranova, R.;Rosenbergova, K.;Kulikova, L.;Hera, A.;Lany, P.;Kubicek, O.;Kolacek, J.

title: A new prototype IIS/IIC/IIG endonuclease methyltransferase TsoI from the thermophilic Thermus scotoductus recognizing 5'-TARCCA(N11/9)-3' sequences
abstract: The Thermus sp. The IIS/IIG/IIC family of enzymes includes the thermostable, bifunctional, fused restriction endonuclease (REase) methyltransferases (MTase): TaqII, Tth111II/TthHB27I, TspGWI, TspDTI, and TsoI. The enzymes are large proteins (about 120 kDa), their enzymatic activities are influenced by S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), they recognize similar asymmetric related sites and cleave at a distance of 11/9 nucleotides (nt). The enzymes share similarities in their amino acid (aa) sequences and catalytic DNA motifs. Thermus sp. Enzymes are an example of functional aa sequence homology between REases that recognize different but related DNA sequences. The family consists of TspGWI and TspDTI subfamilies. TsoI appears to be a non-identical "triplet" related to TspDTI and Tth111II/TthHB27I. The discovery of TsoI purified from Thermus scotoductus is described. This prototype demonstrates a novel specificity that was determined by: (i) cleavage of a reference plasmid and bacteriophage DNA, (ii) cleavage of custom PCR DNA substrates, (iii) run-off sequencing of cleavage products, and (iv) shotgun cloning and sequencing of Bacteriophage lambda (γ) DNA digested with TsoI. The enzyme recognizes a degenerate 5'-TARCCA-3' sequence while cutting DNA strands 11/9 nt downstream. The discovery of the TsoI prototype is of practical importance in biotechnology because it expands the range of cleavage specificities for gene cloning.
authors: Jezewska-Frackowiak, J.;Lubys, A.;Vitkute, J.;Zakareviciene, L.;Zebrowska, J.;Krefft, D.;Skowron, M. A.;Zylicz-Stachula, A.;Skowron, P. M.

title: Characterization of the hemagglutinin gene of avian influenza H9 subtype viruses isolated in China in 2007-2009
abstract: The H9 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) circulating in China have raised concerns about their impact on poultry and their risk to public health. Three studies of the viruses were reported in this report, and the hemagglutinin gene of 55 virus strains isolated in China between 2007 and 2009 were sequenced and analyzed. The results showed that the prevalence of the viruses was increasing in China and most of the H9 AIVs circulating in China over the past decade belonged to the h9.4.2 sublineage. The viruses isolated in China between 2007 and 2009 differed slightly from previous strains (genetic distances >7.1%). A presumably predominant group of the viruses that circulated in China in 2007-2009 has now been identified. Mutation analysis suggests that the viruses have become a major public health risk in recent years. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Ji, K.;Jiang, W. M.;Liu, S.;Chen, J. M.;Chen, J.;Hou, G. Y.;Li, J. P.;Huang, B. X.

title: Transcriptome analysis of the response of sheep oral mucosa to Orf virus infection
abstract: Contagious ecthyma is a highly contagious disease with global distribution caused by orf virus (ORFV), a member of the parapoxvirus. To study the change in host gene expression in response to ORFV infection at the transcriptional level, several young small-tailed Han sheep were inoculated with ORFV and their oral mucosal tissue samples (T0, T3, T7 and T15) were collected on day 0, 3, 7 and 15 after ORFV infection. RNA-seq transcriptome comparisons were performed and showed that 1928, 3219, and 2646 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified among T3 vs T0, T7 vs T0, and T15 vs T0, respectively. Genontologic (GO) analyzes of the DEGs from these comparisons indicated that ORFV could elicit a strong immune response of the host cells in the early stage of infection. Furthermore, GO and network analysis revealed that positive and negative regulatory mechanisms of apoptosis were integrated into the host cells by up- or down-regulating the expression level of DEGs involved in apoptotic signaling pathways to achieve oral mucosal tissue homeostasis during exposure to ORFV -Infection. In summary, our study describes for the first time the direct effects of ORFV on its host's global host gene expression using high-throughput RNA sequencing, which provides a resource for future characterization of the interaction mechanism between the mammalian host and ORFV.
authors: Jia, H.;Zhan, L.;Wang, X.;He, X.;Chen, G.;Zhang, Y.;Feng, Y.;Wei, Y.;Zhang, Y.;Jing, Z.

title: Phylogenetic analysis using the E2 gene of classical swine fever virus reveals a new subgenotype in China
abstract: Outbreaks of classical swine fever (CSF) have caused severe economic consequences in China. Phylogenetic analyzes based on full-length E2 gene sequences showed that five classical swine fever virus (CSFV) isolates collected in Hunan province in 2011 and 2012, along with seven other isolates from neighboring Guangdong provinces (5) and Guangxi (2) these could be classified as a new subgenotype 2.1c, possibly endemic to southern China for at least fourteen years. Isolates of subgenotype 2.1c share 90.2-94.9% and 89.9-93.8% nucleotide sequence similarity separately with those of subgenotypes 2.1a and 2.1b in the E2 gene, which are lower than the nucleotide identities between subgenotypes 2.1a and 2.1b (91.1-95.7%) . Further analysis based on a partial E2 gene sequence (216.nt) showed that isolates of subgenotype 2.1c are also circulating in Thailand. E2 amino acid sequence alignment revealed that isolates of subgenotype 2.1c have SPA. a†'. TPV substitution at positions 777 and 779 compared to subgenotypes 2.1a and 2.1b. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Jiang, D. L.;Gong, W. J.;Li, R. C.;Liu, G. H.;Hu, Y. F.;Ge, M.;Wang, S. Q.;Yu, X. L.;Tu, C.

title: [The Genotyping and Molecular Evolution of Varicella Zoster Virus]
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV, human herpesvirus 3) is a member of the family Herpesviridae and is classified along with HSV-1 and HSV-2 as an alpha subfamily. VZV is the causative agent of chickenpox (varicella), mainly in children, after which it establishes a latency period in the sensory ganglia with the potential for reactivation at a later date to cause shingles (zoster). In recent years, molecular epidemiological studies have increasingly been conducted to monitor mutations in the VZV genome, distinguish vaccine viruses from wild-type viruses, study the phylogeny of VZV strains around the world, and understand the evolution of the different clades of VZV. The advances have major implications for the fields of epidemiology, virology and bioinformatics.
