In this review, the currently available data on the geographic distribution and molecular evolution of VZV clades are discussed.
authors: Jiang, L. F.;Gan, L.;Chen, J. X.;Wang, M. L.

title: Integrative analysis of differentially expressed microRNAs of piglet lung alveolar macrophages during H1N1 swine influenza A virus infection
abstract: H1N1 swine influenza A virus (H1N1 SwIV) is an important subtype of influenza viruses with pandemic potential. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are endogenous small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression. MiRNAs relevant to H1N1 SwIV have rarely been reported. To understand the biological functions of miRNAs during H1N1-SwIV infection, this study profiled differentially expressed (DE) miRNAs in piglet pulmonary alveolar macrophages during H1N1-SwIV infection using a deep sequencing approach validated by real-time quantitative PCR became. Compared to the control group, 70 and 16 DE miRNAs were identified on post-infection day (PID) 4 and PID 7, respectively. 56 DE miRNAs were identified between PID 4 and PID 7. Our results suggest that most host miRNAs are downregulated in defense against H1N1-SwIV infection during the acute phase of swine influenza, while their expression levels gradually return to normal during the recovery phase to avoid the occurrence of too severe lung injury in pigs. In addition, targets of DE miRNAs were also obtained, for which bioinformatic analyzes were performed. Our results would be useful to study the functions and regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs in human influenza, since pigs serve as an excellent animal model to study the pathogenesis of human influenza.
authors: Jiang, P.;Zhou, N.;Chen, X.;Zhao, X.;Li, D.;Wang, F.;Bi, L.;Zhang, D.

title: Transcriptome analysis shows dynamic changes in HEK 293T cells infected with coxsackievirus A16
abstract: BACKGROUND: Coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16) and Enterovirus 71 (EV71) are two of the major causes of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide. Although many studies have focused on infection and pathogenic mechanisms, the host cell transcriptome profile after CVA16 infection is still largely unknown. RESULTS: In this study, we compared the mRNA and miRNA expression profiles of human embryonic kidney 293T cells infected and uninfected with CVA16. We highlighted that the transcription of SCARB2, a cellular receptor for both CVA16 and EV71, was upregulated almost 10-fold in infected cells compared to uninfected cells. CVA16-induced upregulation of SCARB2 transcription may increase the possibility of subsequent infection of CVA16/EV71, resulting in coinfection with two viruses in a single cell. This explanation would partially explain the cocirculation and genetic recombination of a large number of EV71 and CVA16 viruses. Based on a correlation analysis of miRNAs and genes, we speculated that the high expression of SCARB2 is modulated by downregulation of miRNA has-miR-3605-5p. At the same time, we found that differentially expressed miRNA target genes are mainly reflected in the interaction between extracellular membranes (ECM) and receptors and in circadian rhythm signaling pathways, which may be related to clinical symptoms of patients infected with CVA16, such as e.g. B. Aphthous ulcers, cough, myocarditis, drowsiness and possibly meningoencephalitis. The miRNAs hsa-miR-149-3p and hsa-miR-5001-5p can upregulate genes in these morbid signaling pathways associated with CVA16 and cause other clinical symptoms. CONCLUSIONS: The present study elucidated the changes in 293T cells after CVA16 infection at the transcriptome level, which contain upregulated SCARB2 and genes involved in ECM-receptor interaction and circadian rhythm signaling pathways, as well as important miRNAs in the regulation of gene expression. These results provided new insights into the pathogenesis of HFMD induced by CVA16 infection.
authors: Jin, J.;Li, R.;Jiang, C.;Zhang, R.;Ge, X.;Liang, F.;Sheng, X.;Dai, W.;Chen, M.;Wu, J.;Xiao, J.;Su, W.

title: Genetic characterization of a new astrovirus in gouty goslings
abstract: Since early 2016, the Chinese goose industry has experienced severe gout outbreaks; However, the etiological factor of the disease is still unclear. Here we investigated the possible involvement of viral infection in the disease. Using sequence-independent PCR amplification, astrovirus sequences were generated from a gout case. Complete genome sequencing and sequence analysis of three goose astrovirus (GoAstV) strains revealed that they belong to a novel avastrovirus most closely related to viruses classified within the species Avastrovirus 3. The GoAstV was detected in 16/16 gout cases collected in two provinces. Supporting a pathogenic role for the novel avastrovirus.
authors: Jin, M.;Wang, X.;Ning, K.;Liu, N.;Zhang, D.

title: Genome sequencing and characterization analysis of a Beiffing isolate of chicken coronavirus infectious bronchitis virus
abstract: Avian Infectious Bronchitis Virus (AIBV) is classified as a member of the genus Coronavirus in the family Coronaviridae. The enveloped virus has a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genome of approximately 28 kilobases that is 5'-capped and has a 3'-polyadenylation tract. The complete genome sequence of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), Peking isolate, was determined by cloning sequencing and primer walking. The entire genome is 27733 nucleotides long and has ten open reading frames: 5'-orf1a-orf1ab-s-3a-3b-em-6a-6b-n-3'. Alignments of the genome sequence of the IBV Beijing isolate with those of two AIBV strains and one SARS coronavirus were each performed. The genome sequence of the IBV Beijing isolate compared to that of the IBV strain LX4 (incomplete, 19440 bp) was 91.2% similar. However, the full genome sequence of the IBV Beijing isolate was 85.2% identical to that of the IBV strain Beaudette and only 50.8% homologous to that of the SARS coronavirus. The results showed that the genome of IBV shows remarkable variation. And the IBV Beijing isolate is not closely related to the SARS coronavirus. Phylogenetic analyzes based on the entire genome sequence, S protein, M protein and N protein also showed that the AIBV Beijing isolate is a solitary virus in group III and is distant from the SARS coronavirus. In summary, this study will contribute to the IBV diagnosis and disease control studies in China.
authors: Jin, W. W.;Chen, C.;Zhang, Y.;Zhao, Y. Q.;Feng, J. D.;Chen, F. Y.;Wu, Q. M.;Yang, H. C.;Wang, M.;Yu, J. L.;Li, N.;Gong, Y. S.;Sun, Q. X.;Chen, Z. L.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of enteric viruses in breeding turkeys
abstract: The present study was performed to detect and characterize enteric viruses (rotavirus, astrovirus, reovirus and coronavirus) in breeding chicks. Five turkey breeding flocks were selected. Fecal samples were collected from all flocks at 1 week of age and then every two weeks until the chicks reached 9 weeks of age. The fecal samples were pooled in groups of five. Of the 193 pools ("Samples") tested by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction, 47.2%, 30.6% and 10.4% of the Samples were positive for Astrovirus, Rotavirus and Reovirus, respectively. The coronavirus was not detected in any of the samples. A total of 118 (61.1%) specimens were positive for one or more enteric viruses. Of the 118 samples, 70 (59.3%) were positive for a single virus and 48 (40.7%) for a combination of viruses. Phylogenetic analysis based on the polymerase gene showed that astroviruses clustered into two groups with sequence homology ranging from 85.6 to 100% at the nucleotide level. Based on the NSP4 gene sequences, rotaviruses clustered in a group and shared 96.3 to 99.9% sequence homology at the nucleotide level. The reoviruses clustered into a single group based on their S4 gene sequences with 96.9 to 100% sequence homology. Different amino acid sequences of all three viruses can influence the antigenicity and/or pathogenicity of these viruses and require further investigation. The presence of two or three different viruses in combination can affect the dynamics of turkey health and disease. © 2010 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Jindal, N.;Patnayak, D. P.;Chander, Y.;Ziegler, A. F.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Molecular characterization of foot-and-mouth disease virus in Hong Kong in 2001-2002
abstract: Most molecular-epidemiological studies on foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus are based on the comparison of the VP1 gene sequence. In this report the nucleotide sequences of the VP1 coding region of FMDV type O strains O/HKN/3/01, O/HKN/5/01, O/HKN/12/01, O/HKN/7/02 and O /HKN/10/02, isolated from the outbreak that occurred in Hong Kong SAR (Hong Kong SAR) in China in 2001-2002, were determined and compared to the sequences of other FMD viruses. The results showed that the VP1 gene of the five isolates shared the same nucleotide (nt) sequences (639 nt) encoding 213 amino acids and that also at the critical amino acid sites 144 (Val), 148 (Leu), 154 (Lys) and 208 (Pro) within the VP1 protein epitope (amino acids 140-160, 200-213) or in amino acids 145-147 comprising the arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD) sequence, d on adsorption of the virus to the host cell. Analysis of the nucleotide sequence of the VP1 gene revealed that the five isolates examined were most closely related to FMD viruses found in Hong Kong in 1991-1999 and in Taiwan in 1997 the vaccine strain of serotype O,O1/Manisa/Turkey/69 , showed relative conservatism, being genetically distantly related, indicating that there were differences between the predominant Hong Kong FMD strains and the vaccine strain. © Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2006.
authors: Jinding, C.;Mingqiu, Z.;Hui, K. H.;Leung, F. C.

title: One-way traffic of a viral motor channel for double-stranded DNA translocation
abstract: Linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) viruses package their genome into a procapsid using an ATP-driven nanomotor. Here we report that the DNA packaging motor of bacteriophage phi29 exerts a one-way traffic property for dsDNA translocation from N-terminal input to C-terminal output with a valving mechanism in DNA packaging, as shown by voltage rise, electrode polarity switching, and sedimentation force assessment. Without the use of gating control found in other biological channels, the observed unidirectional dsDNA transport provides a novel system with a natural valve to direct dsDNA loading and gene delivery into bioreactors, liposomes, or DNA to control sequencing devices with high throughput.
authors: Jing, P.;Haque, F.;Shu, D.;Montemagno, C.;Guo, P. X.

title: Molecular analysis of hepatitis E virus from farm rabbits in Inner Mongolia, China, and its successful propagation in A549 and PLC/PRF/5 cells
abstract: Rabbit hepatitis E virus (HEV) strains have recently been isolated in several areas of China, as well as in the United States and France. However, the host range, distribution and zoonotic potential of these HEV strains remain unknown, and their propagation in cultured cells has not yet been reported. A total of 211 4-month-old rabbits reared on a farm in Inner Mongolia were tested for the presence of anti-HEV antibodies and HEV RNA. A total of 121 rabbits (57.3%) tested positive for anti-HEV antibodies and 151 (71.6%) had detectable HEV RNA. The 174 HEV strains recovered from these viremic rabbits, including two different strains of 23 rabbits each, differed from each other by up to 13.6% in a 412 nucleotide (nt) sequence within ORF2 and were 89, 3-95.9% identical to reported rabbit HEV strains in other provinces of China. Three representative Inner-Mongolian strains, one each from three phylogenetic clusters whose entire genomic sequences were determined, shared 79.6-96.7% identities with reported rabbit HEV strains within the entire or 242- to 1349-nt partial genomic sequence . Rabbit HEV strains, obtained from liver tissue of rabbits with a high HEV burden, propagated efficiently in human cell lines (A549 and PLC/PRF/5 cells), indicating the potential zoonotic risk of rabbit HEV . © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Jirintai, S.;Jinshan;Tanggis;Manglai, D.;Mulyanto;Takahashi, M.;Nagashima, S.;Kobayashi, T.;Nishizawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Characterization of Fitzroy River virus and serological evidence of infection in humans and animals
abstract: novel arbovirus was detected in mosquitoes during surveillance in North West Australia in 2011 and 2012. Genetic and phenotypic analyzes confirmed that the new flavivirus, named Fitzroy River virus, is related to Sepik virus and Wesselsbron virus in the yellow fever virus group. Most (81%) isolates were from Aedes normanensis mosquitoes, providing circumstantial evidence of the probable vector. In cell culture, Fitzroy River virus replicated in mosquito (C6/36), mammalian (Vero, PSEK and BSR) and avian (DF-1) cells. It also infected intraperitoneally inoculated weaned mice and caused mild clinical disease in 3 intracranially inoculated mice. Specific neutralizing antibodies were found in sentinel horses (12.6%), cattle (6.6%) and chickens (0.5%) in the Northern Territory of Australia and in a subset of humans (0.8%) from the Northern Territory Proven in Western Australia.
authors: Johansen, C. A.;Williams, S. H.;Melville, L. F.;Nicholson, J.;Hall, R. A.;Bielefeldt-Ohmann, H.;Prow, N. A.;Chidlow, G. R.;Wong, S.;Sinha, R.;Williams, D. T.;Lipkin, W. I.;Smith, D. W.

title: Rat hepatitis E virus: geographic accumulation within Germany and serological detection in wild Norwegian rats (Rattus norvegicus)
abstract: Zoonotic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection in developed countries is thought to be caused by transmission from wild boar, domestic pigs, and deer as reservoir hosts. The detection of HEV-specific antibodies in rats and other rodents has suggested that these animals may represent an additional source of transmission of HEV to humans. Recently, a novel HEV (ratHEV) was discovered in Norwegian rats from Hamburg, Germany, which shows the typical genome organization but large nucleotide and amino acid sequence divergence to other mammalian and avian HEV strains. Here we describe the multiple detection of ratHEV RNA and HEV-specific antibodies in Norway rats from other cities in north-east and south-west Germany. Full genome analysis of two novel strains from Berlin and Stuttgart confirmed the association of ratHEV with Norwegian rats. The available data indicate a persistence of this virus in the rat populations from Berlin and Hamburg. Phylogenetic analysis of a short stretch of open reading frame 1 confirmed a geographical clustering of the corresponding sequences. Serological studies using recombinant rat HEV and genotype 3 capsid protein derivatives revealed antigenic differences which could be caused by the high divergence in amino acid sequences in the immunodominant region. The high number of animals showing only ratHEV RNA or anti-ratHEV antibodies indicated a non-persistent infection in the Norwegian rat. Future studies need to demonstrate the transmission routes of the virus in rat populations and its zoonotic potential. The recombinant ratHEV antigen generated here will enable future seroepidemiological studies to differentiate between ratHEV and genotype 3 infections in humans and animals. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Johne, R.;Dremsek, P.;Kindler, E.;Schielke, A.;Plenge-BÃ¶nig, A.;Gregersen, H.;Wessels, U.;Schmidt, K.;Rietschel, W.;Groschup, M. H.;Guenther, S.;Heckel, G.;Ulrich, R. G.

title: Hepeviridae: A growing family of vertebrate viruses
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) was first identified in 1990, although hepatitis E-like illnesses in humans date back as far as the 18th century. HEV genotypes 1-4 were subsequently detected in human hepatitis E cases with different geographic distribution and different modes of transmission. Genotypes 3 and 4 have been identified in parallel in pigs, wild boar and other animal species and their zoonotic potential has been confirmed. Until 2010, these genotypes, along with avian HEV strains that infected chickens, were the only known members of the Hepeviridae family. Subsequently, other HEV-related viruses were detected in wild boar, various HEV-like viruses were identified in rats, rabbits, ferrets, mink, foxes, bats and moose, and a distantly related pathogen was described in closely related salmonids. This review summarizes the properties of the HEV-like viruses known to date, their phylogenetic relationships, host association, and proposed disease involvement. Based on the reviewed knowledge, a proposal for a new taxonomic grouping scheme of viruses within the family Hepeviridae is presented.
authors: Johne, R.;Dremsek, P.;Reetz, J.;Heckel, G.;Hess, M.;Ulrich, R. G.

title: Sequence analysis of the VP6-encoding genome segment of group F and G avian rotaviruses
abstract: Rotavirus groups A through E are primarily defined by antibody reactivity to the capsid protein VP6. In addition, two putative rotavirus groups (F and G) have been identified in birds. Presented here are the first nucleotide sequences of the VP6-encoding genome segment of group F (strain 03V0568) and group G (strain 03V0567) rotaviruses, both of chicken origin. Group F rotavirus is most closely related to group A and D avian rotaviruses with 49.9-52.3% nucleotide and 36.5-39.0% amino acid sequence identity. Group G rotavirus is most closely related to mammalian group B rotaviruses with 55.3-57.5% nucleotide and 48.2-49-9% amino acid sequence identity. The terminal sequences of the genome segment were similar in groups A, D and F and in groups B and G. The results indicate a long-term evolution of rotavirus groups into two separate clades and support the development of a sequence-based classification system for rotavirus groups. © 2011 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Johne, R.;Otto, P.;Roth, B.;LÃ¶hren, U.;Belnap, D.;Reetz, J.;Trojnar, E.

title: Epidemiology of rabies in south-eastern Europe
abstract: Rabies remains endemic in a number of countries in south-eastern Europe, including Romania, Bulgaria and Turkey. With the likely eastward enlargement of the European Union, rabies control programs are likely to be stepped up to reduce the disease burden in the new accession countries. Before launching such programs, a clear understanding of the epidemiology of the virus in this part of Europe is crucial. With the exception of Turkey, the red fox (Vulpes vulpes) is the most important disease reservoir in south-eastern Europe. However, cases of rabies in dogs (Canis familiaris) are reported regularly. In contrast to northern Europe, the raccoon dog (Nyctereutes procyonoides) does not appear to be a vector in the south. This study summarizes the current rabies situation in south-eastern Europe and reveals the phylogenetic relationships between the viruses in a number of countries in the Region. Rabies virus RNA was extracted from original samples and a fragment of the nucleoprotein gene was amplified by reverse transcriptase PCR. Automated sequencing was used to deduce nucleoprotein gene sequences and these were used to construct a molecular phylogeny of rabies viruses in south-eastern Europe. In Bulgaria, the dog is the main vector that brings rabies into contact with humans and livestock. However, other species can also act as a reservoir for the disease, making it difficult to develop elimination strategies. The fox is the main reservoir species for rabies in Romania, although cases in dogs are regularly reported. Despite a gradual decline in canine rabies, urban herds of the disease still exist in many regions of Turkey. In addition, there is some evidence that the fox was an important vector for rabies and may be responsible for the increase in rabies in cattle in the country's Aegean region. There is evidence of cross-border rabies movements by both wild animals and dogs throughout the region.
authors: Johnson, N.;Freuling, C.;Vos, A.;Un, H.;Valtchovski, R.;Turcitu, M.;Dumistrescu, F.;Vuta, V.;Velic, R.;Sandrac, V.;Aylan, O.;MÃ¼ller, T.;Fooks, A. R.

title: The antibiotic Carbadox contained in the feed induces phage gene transcription in the microbiome of the pig intestine
abstract: Carbadox is a quinoxaline di-N-oxide antibiotic that is fed to over 40% of young pigs in the United States and has been shown to induce phage DNA transduction in vitro; However, the effects of carbadox on the functions of the pig microbiome are poorly understood. We investigated the in vivo longitudinal effects of carbadox on microbial gene expression in pig intestines (fecal metatranscriptome) and phage population dynamics (fecal dsDNA viromes). Microbial metagenome, transcriptome and virome sequences were annotated for taxonomic inference and gene function using FIGfam (isofunctional homolog sequences) and SEED subsystem databases. When the beta diversities of FIGfam microbial annotations were compared, the control and carbadox communities were distinct 2 days after carbadox introduction. This effect was driven by carbadox-associated lower expression of FIGfams (n=66) related to microbial respiration, carbohydrate utilization, and RNA metabolism (q<0.1), suggesting bacteriostatic or bactericidal effects within specific populations. Interestingly, treatment with carbadox 2 days after carbadox introduction (q ≤0.07) resulted in greater expression of FIGfams associated with all stages of the phage lytic cycle, suggesting carbadox-mediated induction of prophage and phage DNA recombination suggests. These effects were reduced by 7 days of continuous dietary carbadox, indicating an acute effect. In addition, the viromes contained a few genes encoding resistance to tetracycline, aminoglycoside, and beta-lactam antibiotics, but these did not change in frequency over time or with treatment. Results demonstrate reduced bacterial growth and metabolism, prophage induction and potential transduction of bacterial fitness genes in porcine gut bacterial communities as a result of carbadox administration. IMPORTANCE FDA regulations governing the use of antibiotics in agriculture have focused on antibiotics that are important to human medicine. Carbadox is an antibiotic that is not used in humans but is commonly used on US pig farms. It is important to investigate potential side effects of using Carbadox as it has been shown to promote bacterial evolution, which may indirectly affect antibiotic resistance of clinically important bacteria. Interestingly, the present study shows greater prophage gene expression in the faeces of carbadox-fed animals than in the faeces of non-medicated animals 2 days after the start of carbadox-feeding treatment. Importantly, the phage genetic material isolated in this study contained genes that could confer resistance to antibiotics important in human medicine, suggesting that antibiotic resistance genes relevant to humans are mobile between bacteria via phages. This study highlights the side effects of antibiotics and shows the need to consider different antibiotic effects when using antibiotics or considering new regulations.
authors: Johnson, T. A.;Looft, T.;Severin, A. J.;Bayles, D. O.;Nasko, D. J.;Wommack, K. E.;Howe, A.;Allen, H. K.

title: Illumina MiSeq 16S amplicon sequence analysis of bacteria associated with bovine respiratory disease in lung and mediastinal lymph node tissue
abstract: Background: Bovine respiratory disease (BRD) is caused by the growth of one or more species of pathogenic bacteria in the lung tissue after stress and/or viral infection. Next-generation sequencing of 16S ribosomal RNA gene PCR amplicons (NGS 16S amplicon analysis) is a powerful culture-independent open reference method that has recently been used to advance the understanding of BRD-associated bacteria in the upper respiratory tract of BRD- improve cattle. However, it has not yet been used to study the bovine lower respiratory tract microbiome. The aim of this study was to use NGS 16S amplicon analysis to identify bacteria in postmortem lung and lymph node tissue samples collected from fatal BRD cases and clinically healthy animals. Cranial lobe and corresponding mediastinal lymph node post-mortem tissue samples were collected from calves diagnosed with BRD cases by veterinary laboratory pathologists and from clinically healthy calves. NGS 16S amplicon libraries targeting the V3-V4 region of the bacterial 16S rRNA gene were prepared and sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq. Quantitative insights into microbial ecology (QIIME) were used to determine operational taxonomic units (OTUs) corresponding to 16S rRNA gene sequences. Results: Leptotriciaceae, Mycoplasma, Pasteurellaceae, and Fusobacterium were the most abundant OTUs identified in the lungs and lymph nodes of calves that died from BRD. Leptotriciaceae, Fusobacterium, Mycoplasma, Trueperella, and Bacteroides showed higher relative abundances in postmortem lung specimens collected from fatal cases of BRD in dairy calves compared to clinically healthy calves without lung lesions. Leptotrichiaceae, Mycoplasma and Pasteurellaceae showed higher relative abundances in postmortem lymph node specimens collected from fatal cases of BRD in dairy calves compared to clinically healthy calves without lung lesions. Two Leptotrichiaceae sequence contigs were then assembled from bacterial DNA-enriched shotgun sequences. Conclusions: The microbiomes of the cranial lung lobe and the mediastinal lymph node of calves that died of BRD and of clinically healthy HF calves were characterized. Contigs corresponding to the abundant Leptotriciaceae OTU have been sequenced and found not to be identical to any known genus of bacteria. This indicates that we have identified a new species of bacteria associated with BRD.
authors: Johnston, D.;Earley, B.;Cormican, P.;Murray, G.;Kenny, D. A.;Waters, S. M.;McGee, M.;Kelly, A. K.;McCabe, M. S.

title: Identification of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 in chicken farms in Indonesia
abstract: The avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 (AIV-H9N2) has become established in poultry in Asia and Africa. AIV-H9N2 has not previously been reported in Indonesia. Here we describe the presence of AIV-H9N2 in chicken farms in Indonesia. 99 cases were observed in different provinces of Indonesia. Clinical signs, pathological lesions and egg production were recorded. Confirmation was by virus isolation, reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) and sequencing. To construct the hemagglutinin (HA) phylogeny, the secondary data of the Eurasian lineages were downloaded from GenBank. For neuraminidase, five sequences with the highest similarities to any sequence found in this study were downloaded. The phylogeny was derived using the neighbor joining method in the MEGA6 package. 49 AIV-H9N2 positive cases were observed, of which 35 tested positive for AIV-H9N2 only. The age of the infected chickens was 43.17 ± 16.56 weeks and their egg production was 35.85 ± 17.80% lower than before the outbreak. The BLAST search revealed that the nucleotide sequence of the HA-encoding gene identified in this study shared 98% sequence identity with that of A/musk duck/Vietnam/LBM719/2014(H9N2), while its neuraminidase-encoding gene sequences shared 94% shared 98% and 100% identities with three different influenza viruses. The phylogeny shows that the AIV-H9N2 HA found in this study forms a clear cluster with some sequence data from Vietnam and China. The NA sequence data form three distinct clusters. We conclude that AIV-H9N2 is widespread in many provinces of Indonesia. To reduce economic losses to the poultry industry, flock biosecurity and vaccination against this virus subtype should be implemented quickly. Thorough and rigorous AIV surveillance is paramount to prevent further veterinary and public health consequences from the spread of this virus in Indonesia.
authors: Jonas, M.;Sahesti, A.;Murwijati, T.;Lestariningsih, C. L.;Irine, I.;Ayesda, C. S.;Prihartini, W.;Mahardika, G. N.

title: Molecular identification and characterization of novel coronaviruses infecting gray geese (Anser anser), feral pigeons (Columbia livia) and mallards (Anas platyrhynchos).
abstract: Given the discovery of a previously unknown coronavirus as the etiology of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), it is likely that other coronaviruses than those previously known are circulating in animal populations. The results of a coronavirus screening using universal coronavirus RT-PCR of the bird species greylag goose (Anser anser), wild pigeon (Columbia livia) and mallard (Anas platyrhynchos) are presented here. Corona viruses were found in cloaca swab samples of all three bird species. In the greylag goose, 40 out of 163 birds examined tested positive for coronavirus, while two pigeons out of 100 examined and one mallard duck out of five examined tested positive. The infected greylag geese showed lower body weights compared to virus-negative birds, indicating a clinical importance of the infection. Phylogenetic analyzes performed on the replicase gene and nucleocapsid protein sequences showed that the novel coronaviruses described in the present study all branch from the group III coronaviruses. All of the novel avian coronaviruses contained the conserved s2m RNA structure in their 3-inch untranslated region, like other previously described group III coronaviruses and like the SARS coronavirus. Sequencing of the complete nucleocapsid gene and downstream regions of goose and pigeon coronaviruses revealed the presence of two additional goose coronavirus open reading frames with no sequence similarity to known proteins, but with predicted transmembrane domains for one of the encoded proteins and one additional open reading frame Pigeon coronavirus reading frame with a predicted transmembrane domain downstream of the nucleocapsid gene. © 2005 SGM.
authors: Jonassen, C. M.;Kofstad, T.;Larsen, I. L.;LÃ¸vland, A.;Handeland, K.;Follestad, A.;Lillehaug, A.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Bovine Pestiviruses: Testing the Development of Clinical Symptoms
abstract: This study presents a phylogenetic analysis of 115 bovine pestiviruses. A sequence dataset preceding the 5' untranslated genomic region was analyzed using maximal sparsity, bootstrapping, and sparsity jackknifing. We tested the group's proposed classifications and analyzed the development of symptoms associated with pestivirus infections in cattle. Based on the historical framework provided by our phylogenetic trees, we have also characterized the extent and importance of the contamination of biologics by the virus. Our phylogenetic analyzes showed that the previously defined genotypes are monophyletic. except genotype 1a. Based on our cladograms, we propose the existence of more than 12 monophyletic groups within species BVDV 1. Mapping of clinical symptoms suggests that the appearance of some genotypes may have been caused by an alteration in the pathogenic process. Enteric problems appear to be ancestral, while reproductive and respiratory problems arise with the appearance of genotypes 1b, 1d and the Arg 1 genotype proposed here. The distribution of contaminating strains on the cladograms indicates that pestivirus contamination is a common process and also suggests that a contaminated product could be a vehicle for viral spread. Implications for virus evolution, virus taxonomy, veterinary medicine and biotechnology are discussed. (C) The Willi Hennig Society 2004.
authors: Jones, L. R.;Cigliano, M. M.;Zandomeni, R. O.;Weber, E. L.

title: Homologous Recombination in Bovine Pestiviruses - Phylogenetic and Statistical Evidence
abstract: Bovine pestiviruses (Bovine Viral Diarrea Virus 1 (BVDV 1) and Bovine Viral Diarrea Virus 2 (BVDV 2)) belong to the genus Pestivirus (Flaviviridae), which consists of positive-stranded RNA viruses and causes significant economic losses worldwide. We used phylogenetic and bootstrap analyzes to systematically scan alignments of previously sequenced genomes to further explore the evolutionary mechanisms responsible for virus variation. Previously published data suggest that homologous crossover may be one of the mechanisms responsible for the genomic rearrangements observed in cytopathic (cp) strains of bovine pestiviruses. Nevertheless, homologous recombination involves not only homologous crossings, but also the exchange of a homologous region of the acceptor RNA. Furthermore, cytopathic strains represent dead paths in evolution since they are isolated exclusively from the fatal cases of mucosal disease. Here we report evidence for homologous inter-genotype recombination in the genome of a non-cytopathic (ncp) strain of Bovine Viral Diarrea Virus 1, the type species of the genus Pestivirus. We also show that homologous recombination within the genotype could be a common phenomenon in both types of pestivirus. This evidence shows that homologous recombination contributes to the diversification of bovine pestiviruses in nature. Implications for virus evolution, taxonomy and phylogenetics are discussed. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Jones, L. R.;Weber, E. L.

title: Occurrence of the virulence-associated PB2 E627K substitution in a fatal human case of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A (H7N7) infection as determined by Illumina ultra-deep sequencing
abstract: Bird flu viruses are able to cross species barriers and infect humans. Although evidence of human-to-human transmission of avian influenza viruses is so far limited, the evolution of variants towards more efficient human-to-human transmission could lead to a new influenza virus pandemic. In both avian influenza A (H5N1) and recently emerging avian influenza A (H7N9) viruses, the E627K mutation of the polymerase basic 2 protein (PB2) appears to be critical for human adaptation. During a major outbreak of influenza A(H7N7) virus in the Netherlands in 2003, the A(H7N7) virus isolated from a fatal human case contained the PB2 E627K mutation and a hemagglutinin (HA) K416R mutation . In this study, we sought to determine whether these mutations occurred in the avian or human host by Illumina ultra-deep sequencing of three previously unstudied clinical specimens from the fatal case. In addition, we examined three chicken samples, two of which were obtained from the source farm.
authors: Jonges, M.;Welkers, M. R.;Jeeninga, R. E.;Meijer, A.;Schneeberger, P.;Fouchier, R. A.;de Jong, M. D.;Koopmans, M.

title: Viral infection from bats: A summary of reports from Thailand
abstract: Bat is an interesting mammal that can fly. Human disease related to bats is very interesting but limited mention. There are many viral infections that bats can transmit to humans. These viral infections are usually serious and difficult to treat. In this mini-review, the authors hereby summarize and discuss the bat-associated viral infection in Thailand, a tropical country in Southeast Asia, mentioned in previous publications.
authors: Joob, B.;Wiwanitkit, V.

title: Detection of fowlpox virus carrying different genome segments of reticuloendothelosis virus
abstract: Fowlpox virus (FWPV), the type species of the genus Avipoxvirus family Poxviridae, is a large double-stranded DNA virus that causes fowlpox in chickens and turkeys. Remarkably, avian retroviral reticuloendothelosis virus (REV) sequences are frequently found integrated into the genome of FWPV. While some FWPV strains carry residues of the REV long terminal repeats (LTRs), other strains have been shown to contain nearly full-length inserts of the REV provirus in their genome. In the present study, we discovered heterogeneous FWPV populations carrying the REV-LTR or the almost complete REV provirus genome in a Merriam (Meleagris gallopavo merriami) wild turkey. The bird had papules distributed over the non-feathered areas of the head. Avipoxvirus-like virions were observed in the lesions by transmission electron microscopy and the presence of FWPV was confirmed by DNA sequencing. Metagenomic sequencing performed on nucleic acid extracted from the skin lesions revealed two FWPV genomic populations carrying either a 197 nt remnant of the REV LTR or a 7939 nt fragment encoding the full-length REV provirus is equivalent to. Notably, PCR amplification using primers targeting FWPV sequences flanking the REV insertion site confirmed the natural occurrence of the heterogeneous FWPV genomic populations in an additional clinical specimen from another fowlpox-infested turkey. In addition, sequencing of a historical FWPV isolate obtained from chickens in the US in 2000 also revealed the presence of the two FWPV-REV genome populations. The results here demonstrate distinct FWPV populations that contain variable segments of the REV genome integrated into their genome. These different genomic populations are likely the result of homologous recombination events that take place during FWPV replication.
authors: Joshi, L. R.;Bauermann, F. V.;Hain, K. S.;Kutish, G. F.;ArmiÃ©n, A. G.;Lehman, C. P.;Neiger, R.;Afonso, C. L.;Tripathy, D. N.;Diel, D. G.

title: Lineage 2 West Nile Virus infection in a blood donor from Vienna, Austria, August 2014
abstract: Eastern Austria is neighboring regions with ongoing transmissions of West Nile Virus (WNV). In the last decade, three human WNV infections have been diagnosed in Austria. In June 2014, the blood service of the Austrian Red Cross (ARC-BS) started a first voluntary screening for WNV in blood donors from eastern Austria using nucleic acid testing (NAT). This is also the most extensive WNV surveillance program in humans in Austria to date. In August 2014, an autochthonous WNV infection was detected in a blood donor from Vienna. One in 67,800 whole blood donations has now been found positive for WNV RNA.
authors: Jungbauer, C.;Hourfar, M. K.;Stiasny, K.;Aberle, S. W.;Cadar, D.;Schmidt-Chanasit, J.;Mayr, W. R.

title: Generation of henipavirus nucleocapsid proteins in yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae
abstract: Hendra and Nipah viruses are emerging zoonotic viruses and their genomes share nucleotide and predicted amino acid homologies that place them in the Paramyxoviridae family. Currently, these viruses are classified in the new genus Henipavirus within the subfamily Paramyxovirinae, family Paramyxoviridae. The genes encoding HeV and NiV nucleocapsid proteins were cloned into the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae expression vector pFGG3 under the control of the GAL7 promoter. A high level of expression of these proteins (18-20 mg/l yeast culture) was obtained. Mass spectrometric analysis confirmed the primary structure of both proteins with 92% sequence coverage obtained using MS/MS analysis. Electron microscopy revealed the assembly of typical herringbone structures of purified recombinant nucleocapsid proteins characteristic of other paramyxoviruses. The nucleocapsid proteins showed stability in yeast and can be easily purified by cesium chloride gradient ultracentrifugation. HeV nucleocapsid protein was detected by sera derived from HeV-infected fruit bats, humans and horses, and NiV nucleocapsid protein was immunodetected with sera from fruit bats, humans and pigs. The development of an efficient and inexpensive system for generating henipavirus nucleocapsid proteins could help improve the reagents for virus diagnosis. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Juozapaitis, M.;Serva, A.;Zvirbliene, A.;Slibinskas, R.;Staniulis, J.;Sasnauskas, K.;Shiell, B. J.;Wang, L. F.;Michalski, W. P.

title: The MET gene is a common integration target in chicken hemangiomas caused by avian leukosis virus subgroup j
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) is a simple retrovirus that can cause hemangioma and myeloid tumors in chickens and is currently a major economic problem in Asia. Here we characterize ALV-J strain PDRC-59831, a newly studied US isolate of ALV-J. Five-day-old chick embryos were infected with this virus, and the chicks developed myeloid leukosis and hemangiomas within 2 months of hatching. To investigate the mechanism of pathogenesis, we used high-throughput sequencing to analyze proviral integration sites in these tumors. We found expanded clones with integrations into the MET gene in two of the five hemangiomas examined. This integration site has not been seen in previous work characterizing ALV-J-induced myeloid leukosis. MET is a well-known proto-oncogene that acts through a variety of signaling pathways and is involved in many neoplasms. We show that tumors with MET integrations have strong overexpression of MET mRNA.
authors: Justice, J.;Malhotra, S.;Ruano, M.;Li, Y.;Zavala, G.;Lee, N.;Morgan, R.;Beemon, K.

title: Common viral integration sites identified in avian leukosis virus-induced B-cell lymphomas
abstract: Avian leukosis virus (ALV) induces B-cell lymphoma and other neoplasms in chickens by integrating into or near cancer genes and interfering with their expression. Four genes - MYC, MYB, Mir-155 and TERT - have previously been identified as common integration sites in these virus-induced lymphomas and are believed to play a causative role in tumorigenesis. In this study, we use high-throughput sequencing to identify additional genes that drive tumorigenesis in ALV-induced B-cell lymphomas. In addition to the four previously implicated genes, we identify other genes as common integration sites, including TNFRSF1A, MEF2C, CTDSPL, TAB2, RUNX1, MLL5, CXorf57, and BACH2. We also analyze the genome-wide ALV integration landscape in vivo and find an increased frequency of ALV integration near transcription start sites and within transcripts. Previous work has shown that ALV prefers a weak consensus sequence for integration into cultured human cells. We confirm this consensus sequence for ALV integration in vivo in the chicken genome. IMPORTANCE Avian leukosis virus induces B-cell lymphomas in chickens. Previous studies showed that ALV can induce tumors through insertional mutagenesis, and several genes have been implicated in the development of these tumors. In this study, we use high-throughput sequencing to reveal the genome-wide ALV integration landscape in ALV-induced B-cell lymphomas. We find increased levels of ALV integration near transcription start sites and use joint integration site analysis to greatly expand the number of genes involved in the development of these tumors. Interestingly, we identify several genes targeted by viral insertions that have not previously been shown to be involved in cancer.
authors: Justice, J. F.;Morgan, R. W.;Beemon, K. L.

title: Detection of the hepatitis E virus in archived German wild boar serum samples
abstract: Hepatitis E is a rare human disease in Central Europe that is often imported from endemic areas. In the case of autochthonous infections, zoonotic transmission by pigs, deer and wild boar is assumed. Using three different RT-PCR protocols, hepatitis E virus (HEV) RNA was detected in 10 of 189 (5.3%) serum samples collected from wild boar in Germany in 1995/1996. Sequence analysis indicates a close relationship to porcine and human genotype 3 isolates from the Netherlands and Japan. The results indicate that HEV has been present in Germany for more than 10 years and wild boar may act as a reservoir for HEV. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kaci, S.;NÃ¶ckler, K.;Johne, R.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) isolates from Turkey: identification of a new subgroup in BVDV-1
abstract: The genetic heterogeneity of Turkish ruminant pestiviruses was examined by phylogenetic analysis of complete Npro-coding nucleotide sequences. A total of 30 virus isolates obtained from 15 provinces of the country between 1997 and 2005 were included in the phylogenetic analysis. The virus isolates were mainly from cattle, with one isolate from sheep. The bovine isolates all belonged to BVDV-1, the sheep isolates to BVDV-2. Fifteen isolates formed a new subgroup within BVDV-1, tentatively named BVDV-11. The remaining bovine isolates were typed as BVDV-1a (n=4), BVDV-1b (n=4), BVDV-1d (n=3), BVDV-1f (n=2) and BVDV-1h (n=1). ). The isolates assigned to BVDV-11 came from different geographical regions in different years. There was no correlation between genetic grouping and the locations from which isolates were obtained. Viruses originating from one farm belonged to the same subgroup in most cases (n=5). This study indicates that the newly discovered subgroup BVDV-1l is predominant and widespread in Turkey. In addition, a sheep virus isolate was identified as the first member of BVDV-2 to be reported in Turkey. A serological study with samples from western Turkey showed that BVDV-2 is also present in cattle. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kadir, Y.;Christine, F.;Barbara, B. W.;Zeki, Y.;Feray, A.;Aykut, O.;Ibrahim, B.;Sibilina Cedillo, R.;Heinz-JÃ¼rgen, T.;Matthias, K.

title: Virus propagation in a porcine monocyte cell line
abstract: Propagation of seventeen virus strains, classified into five virus families, in a porcine monocyte cell line (SW/K99) was examined for the production of infectious progeny. The viruses studied were adapted to grow in a porcine epithelial cell line (KSEK6) and were shown to exhibit a prominent CPE in advance. These viruses were successively passaged in the monocyte cultures regardless of the occurrence of CPE. The 3rd passage cultures were titered for infectivity using KSEK6 cells. Of the viruses examined, only Aujeszky's disease virus (ADV) was able to multiply in the monocytes. Four ADV strains, two virulent and two attenuated strains, were compared for growth in two cell lines. The final amount of infectious progeny measured after 72 hours of incubation at 36.5 degrees C was almost in a similar order between 2 cell lines. However, the amount of infectious progeny produced at 24 hours of incubation was higher in SW/K99 cells than in KSEK6 cells. The appearance of CPE was also more evident in SW/K99 cells in an early incubation. The data show that the viral susceptibility of monocytes to ADV is higher than that of the epithelium. Other viruses were abortive in the monocytes.
authors: Kadoi, K.

title: Whole-length infectious clone of an Iranian isolate of chicken anemia virus
abstract: An Iranian field strain of chicken anemia virus (CAV), designated IR CAV, was isolated for the first time in a culture of the Marek's disease virus-transformed lymphoblastoid cell line MDCC-MSB1 (MSB1). The full-length CAV DNA of this strain was cloned into the bacterial plasmid pTZ57R/T to generate the molecular clone pTZ-CAV. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of IR-CAV viral proteins were compared to those of representative CAV sequences, including reference and commercial vaccine strains. IR CAV was not related to vaccine strains and glutamine was also found at positions 139 and 144, confirming previous studies linking such mutations to a slow virus spread rate in cell cultures. pTZ-CAV was digested with PstI to release IR-CAV DNA and then transfected into MSB1 cells by electroporation. The transfected cells showed a cytopathic effect, similar to a virion-initiated infection. Day-old specific pathogen-free chicks were inoculated with the regenerated virus recovered from transfected MSB1 cells and compared to the chicks inoculated with IR CAV. Gross lesions in the birds vaccinated with the regenerated virus illustrated the infectious nature of the regenerated virus from the cloned IR-CAV DNA.
authors: Kaffashi, A.;Eshratabadi, F.;Shoushtari, A.

title: Partial sequence of the DNA-dependent DNA polymerase gene of avian adenoviruses: a reference panel for general diagnostic PCR in poultry
abstract: Adenoviruses are common infectious agents in various poultry species. The traditional serological typing of new isolates by virus neutralization tests is now being replaced by PCR and sequencing. The first PCRs recommended for the detection of adenoviruses were designed to target the gene of the main capsid protein, the hexon. In birds, members of three different genera of the family Adenoviridae can be found. Accordingly, three specific hexon PCRs for the detection of adenoviruses in poultry had to be devised. A much more sensitive PCR targeting the viral DNA-dependent DNA polymerase gene has recently been described. This method proved to be an efficient alternative for the general detection of adenoviruses regardless of their genus. Avian adenoviruses (FAdVs) isolated from chickens to date comprise twelve serotypes classified into five virus species (FAdV-A to E). The polymerase gene sequence has only been determined from three FAdV types representing three species. In the present work, the panel of polymerase gene sequences was completed with those of the other FAdVs. The newly determined sequences will facilitate the identification of new FAdV isolates as an existing species or as a putative new FAdV. Once the polymerase sequence is known, more specific PCRs for amplification of the hexon and other genes can be designed and performed according to the preliminary species classification.
authors: KajÃ¡n, G.;Sameti, S.;Benko, M.

title: Japanese encephalitis in a 114-month-old cow: pathological examination of the affected cow and genetic characterization of the Japanese encephalitis virus isolate
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is classified in the genus Flavivirus in the family Flaviviridae. JEV can cause febrile illness and encephalitis mainly in humans and horses and occasionally in cattle. At the end of September 2010, a 114-month-old cow presented with neurological symptoms similar to those observed in previous cases of bovine Japanese encephalitis (JE); therefore we performed virological and pathological tests on the cow. As a result, JEV was isolated from the cerebrum of the affected cow. We determined the complete genome sequence of the JEV isolate, which we named JEV/Bo/Aichi/1/2010, including the envelope (E) gene region and the 3' untranslated region (3'UTR). Our E region and full genome phylogenetic analyzes indicated that the isolate belongs to JEV genotype 1 (G1). The isolate JEV/Bo/Aichi/1/2010 was most closely related to several JEV G1 isolates in Toyama Prefecture, Japan between 2007 and 2009 according to E region phylogenetic analysis. In addition, nucleotide alignment showed that the deletion in the 3'UTR was the same in JEV/Bo/Aichi/1/2010 and several other JEV G1 isolates identified in Toyama Prefecture in 2008-2009. A haemagglutination inhibition (HI) test was performed to detect anti-JEV antibodies in the affected cow and the test detected 2-mercaptoethanol (2-ME)-sensitive HI antibodies to JEV in the serum of the affected cow. Histopathological examination revealed nonsuppurative encephalomyelitis in the affected cow and immunohistochemical assay detected JEV antigen in the cerebrum. We diagnosed the case as JE in a cow based on the findings of nonsuppurative encephalomyelitis observed in the central nervous system, JEV antigen was detected in cerebrum, JEV was isolated from cerebrum, and 2-ME-sensitive HI antibodies to JEV in serum have been proven. This is the first reported case of JE in a cow over 24 months old.
authors: Kako, N.;Suzuki, S.;Sugie, N.;Kato, T.;Yanase, T.;Yamakawa, M.;Shirafuji, H.

title: Genetic reclassification of porcine enteroviruses
abstract: The genetic diversity of porcine techoviruses (PTVs; previously referred to as porcine enterovirus 1) and most serotypes of porcine enteroviruses (PEVs) has been examined. After determining the major part of the genomic sequence of the PTV reference strain Talfan, the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) region, the capsid VP2 region, and the 3-inch untranslated region ( 3â€²-NTR) were compared between PTVs and PEVs and with other picornaviruses. The sequences were obtained by RT-PCR and 3â€²-RACE with primers based on the sequences from Talfan and available PEV strains. Phylogenetic analysis of RdRp/VP2 and analysis of the predicted RNA secondary structure of the 3-NTR indicated that PEVs should be genetically reclassified into at least three groups, one to be assigned to PTVs and two PEV subtypes to be categorized by phylum PEV- are represented. 8 V 13 and strain PEV-9 UKG4 10/73.
authors: Kaku, Y.;Sarai, A.;Murakami, Y.

title: Influenza vaccine review
abstract: Influenza viruses belong to the Orthomyxoviridae RNA virus family and are classified into three distinct types based on their major antigenic differences; Influenza A, influenza B and influenza C. Influenza viruses cause annual human epidemics, seasonal and pandemics. Seasonal influenza epidemics caused by influenza A and B viruses result in 3-5 million severe cases and thousands of deaths worldwide each year. Influenza pandemics caused by the influenza A virus occur at unpredictable intervals. Influenza A virus will cause epidemics and pandemics due to its spread of migratory birds, pigs, horses and humans. Transmission can occur from person to person through pathogens, coughing and sneezing. Pandemics are responsible for increased morbidity and mortality compared to seasonal influenza. Four such pandemics have occurred in the past century, 1918, 1957, 1968 and 2009. Influenza B causes only human-to-human spread, emphasizing that no other hosts are involved and therefore not involved in pandemics. Influenza C is a mild disease.[1] It causes seasonal influenza episodes such as northern infections when they occur from September to March while southern infections occur from May to September. Due to the variation of viruses responsible for infections in these two seasons; it needs two different sets of vaccines. Influenza generally has an incubation period of 2 days, ranging from 1 to 4 days.
authors: Kalarikkal, S. M.;Jaishankar, G. B.

title: Co-circulation of three clusters of 793/B-like infectious avian bronchitis virus genotypes in Iranian chicken flocks
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis (IB) is an acute and highly contagious viral disease causing severe economic losses in the poultry industry. The 793/B IB virus is an important genotype of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) currently circulating in several countries including Iran. One hundred confirmed IBV samples (between 2014 and 2015; from 15 provinces in Iran) were selected for genotyping based on S1 sequencing. After phylogenetic analysis, it was found that 30% of the IBV isolates belonged to the 793/B genotype. The results showed that the Iranian 793/B-like IBV isolates could be classified into three clusters: 4/91-like (50%), 1/96-like (40%) and IB88-like (10%). The sequence similarity between Iranian 793/B-like IBV isolates is 87.69%-100%. The highest identity is between the 4/91 and IB88 clusters (96.38%) and the lowest similarity is between the 1/96 and IB88 clusters (87.62%). This study provides a comprehensive analysis of 793/B-type IBV in Iran and a characterization of the molecular epidemiology of IBV in the country.
authors: Kalokhoran, A. Y.;Ghalyanchilangeroudi, A.;Hosseini, H.;Madadgar, O.;Karimi, V.;Hashemzadeh, M.;Hesari, P.;Zabihi Petroudi, M. T.;Najafi, H.

title: (Hochpathogene) Vogelgrippe als Zoonoseerreger
abstract: Zoonotic pathogens that challenge the world every year are influenza A viruses. Human pandemics caused by influenza A viruses have occurred periodically in the past. Wild waterfowl are carriers of the full diversity of influenza virus A subtypes and are therefore most likely the natural reservoir of all influenza A viruses. While avian influenza viruses are generally of low pathogenicity (LPAIV) in their natural avian reservoir, some have acquired virulence by mutation after transmission and adaptation to susceptible chicken fowl. These so-called highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIV) then cause mass mortality in susceptible birds and lead to enormous economic losses when poultry is affected. In addition to a number of avian influenza virus subtypes that have sporadically infected mammals, the HPAIV H5N1 Asia has strong zoonotic characteristics and has been transmitted from birds to various mammalian species, including humans. Theoretically, pandemic viruses could be descended directly from avian influenza viruses or arise after genetic rearrangement between avian and mammalian viruses. So far, HPAIV H5N1 already fulfills two conditions for a pandemic virus: as a new subtype, it has not yet appeared in the human population and has infected at least 438 people and caused severe illness and high mortality in 262 people to date (August 2019 2009). Acquiring efficient human-to-human transmission would complete the emergence of a new pandemic virus. Therefore, tackling H5N1 at its source is a prerequisite to reducing the pandemic risks posed by this virus. Other influenza viruses considered pandemic candidates are of the H2, H7, and H9 subtypes, all of which have infected humans in the past. Here we provide a comprehensive overview of avian influenza viruses in terms of their zoonotic potential. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kalthoff, D.;Globig, A.;Beer, M.

title: Serological classification of feline caliciviruses by plaque reduction, neutralization and immune diffusion
abstract: Serological classification of 14 feline calicivirus isolates was performed using plaque reduction neutralization assays. 60 to 200 plaque-forming virus units were plated against 20 antibody units of hyperimmune goat antisera prepared for individual isolates. The results showed that these viruses were related to varying degrees, but no 2 were identical. Ranking in order of strongest intergroup responses yielded essentially 1 serotype, with the exception of 1 virus which showed 1-way neutralization responses with heterologous isolates. Geographic origin, site of virus isolation, or plaque size were unrelated to neutralization pattern. The F9 isolate, which showed the strongest intergroup reactions, was suggested as a possible reference virus. Viruses were indistinguishable using gel diffusion analysis against feline antisera.
authors: Kalunda, M.;Lee, K. M.;Holmes, D. F.;Gillespie, J. H.

title: Evidence of the co-circulation of enteric viruses in wastewater and in the population of Greater Cairo
abstract: Aims: To characterize the major enteric viruses (Enterovirus, Rotavirus, Norovirus, Astrovirus and Adenovirus) in Greater Cairo wastewater and to compare the results with clinical data collected during the same period. METHODS AND RESULTS: Seventy-two wastewater samples from two wastewater treatment plants were collected from April 2006 to February 2007. Enteroviruses, noroviruses (NoVs) and rotaviruses (RVs) were detected by RT-PCR in 22%, 18% and 8x, respectively. 3% of samples. No adenovirus and astrovirus were detected. G2P[8], G9P[8], G1P[8], G2P[4] and rare G12 RV isolates as well as one bovine RV have been identified in the environment. The environmental NoV strains mostly belonged to genogroup I (84%). Rotavirus and some of the NoVs were similar to those found in the clinical specimens at the same time. Conclusions: Comparison of environmental and clinical data suggests that similar RV and NoV isolates were circulating in the environment and in the population over the same time period. Importance and Impact of Study: Few studies have examined the prevalence and epidemiology of RVs and NoVs in Cairo. This work is the first to establish a correlation between viral gastroenteritis and the coexistence of enteric viruses in the environment for Greater Cairo, where combined environmental and clinical assessments should help prevent infection by these major pathogens. Â© 2009 The Society for Applied Microbiology.
authors: Kamel, A. H.;Ali, M. A.;El-Nady, H. G.;Aho, S.;Pothier, P.;Belliot, G.

title: A simple method for parallel deep sequencing of whole influenza A genomes
abstract: Given the major threat to human and animal health posed by influenza A and its ability to evolve rapidly through mutation and rearrangement, tools that enable its timely characterization are needed to help monitor its evolution and spread. For this purpose, deep sequencing can be a very valuable tool. This study reports a comprehensive method that enables deep sequencing of the whole genome of influenza A subtypes using the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx (GAIIx). Using this method, the entire genomes of nine viruses were sequenced in parallel, encoding the 2009 pandemic H1N1 virus, the human H5N1 virus, and the porcine H1N1 virus, in a single lane of a GAIIx flow cell to an average depth of 122 -fold represent . This technique can be applied to cultured and uncultured viruses. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Kampmann, M. L.;Fordyce, S. L.;Ãvila-Arcos, M. C.;Rasmussen, M.;Willerslev, E.;Nielsen, L. P.;Gilbert, M. T. P.

title: Nucleotide sequence of avian carcinoma virus MH2: Two potential onc genes, one related to avian virus MC29 and the other related to murine sarcoma virus 3611
abstract: The 5.2 kilobase (kb) avian carcinoma virus MH2 RNA genome has the genetic structure 5'-γgag (0.2 kg)-mhg (1.2 kg)-myc (1.4 kb)-c (0, 4kg)-poly)A) (0.2kb)-3'. γgag is a partial retroviral core protein gene, mht and myc are cell-derived MH2-specific sequences, and c is the 3'-terminal retroviral vector sequence. Here we determined the nucleotide sequence of 3.5 kb from the 3' end of γg to the 3' end of the molecularly cloned MH2 proviral DNA to elucidate the genetic structure of the virus and compare it to other mht- and myc-containing ones oncogenic virus and the chicken protomyc gene. The following results were obtained: (i) γgag-mht forms a hybrid gene with a contiguous reading frame of 2682 nucleotides ending with a stop codon near the 3' end of MHT. The 3,969 nucleotides from mht to the stop codon are 80% sequence related to the onc-specific raf sequence of murine sarcoma virus 3611 (94% homologous at the deduced amino acid level). (ii) The myc sequence is preceded by an RNA splice acceptor site shared with the cellular proto-myc gene and is linked up to a 3' termination codon and 40 non-coding nucleotides with the avian myc sequences. Retrovirus MC29 and chicken colinear proto-myc. Thus, myc forms a second MH2-specific gene together with a 5' retroviral exon. (iii) myc is followed by the 3'-terminal c-region of approximately 400 nucleotides, which is collinear with that of Rous sarcoma virus except for one Substitution near the 5' end of the long terminal repeat. It is concluded that MH2 contains two genes with oncogenic potential, the γgag-mht gene, which is closely related to the MSV 3611 γgag-raf transforming gene, and the myc gene, which is related to the MSV 3611 transforming gene MC29. Furthermore, it can be concluded that the cellular proto-onc genes, which become viral onc genes upon sequence transfer, are a small group, since out of the 19 known onc sequences, 5 are shared by different taxonomic groups of viruses, from which the mht/raf The homology has so far been determined most closely.
authors: Kan, N. C.;Flordellis, C. S.;Mark, G. E.

title: Impact of emergence of coxsackievirus A6 on hand, foot and mouth disease epidemic in Osaka City, Japan
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute febrile illness characterized by fever; Sore throat; and blistering rash on hands, feet and oral mucosa. Until 2010, HFMD in Japan was predominantly associated with enterovirus (EV) A71 and coxsackievirus (CV) A16. In 2011, CV-A6 emerged as the primary pathogen, causing the largest HFMD epidemic in Japan since 1981. Since then, CV-A6 has caused major HFMD epidemics every 2 years. Phylogenetic analysis of complete viral protein 1 (VP1) sequences revealed that most of the CV-A6 strains detected in Osaka City from 2011 to 2015 were placed in a different clade than the CV-A6 strains identified by 1999 to 2009 were detected. The A6 strains detected in 2011 and most of the CV-A6 strains detected between 2013 and 2015 have been mainly divided into two distinct genetic groups. Each epidemic strain carried unique amino acid substitutions in the putative DE, EF, and GH loops of the VP1 protein exposed on the virion's surface. There is a possibility that the occurrence of substitutions on the surface of the virion and an accumulation of a susceptible population are significant factors in recent HFMD epidemics.
authors: Kanbayashi, D.;Kaida, A.;Yamamoto, S. P.;Hirai, Y.;Kubo, H.;Fujimori, R.;Hakui, N.;Hirokawa, H.;Iritani, N.

title: Genetic characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza A H5N8 viruses isolated from wild birds in Egypt
abstract: newly emerged H5N8 flu virus was isolated from green-winged teal in Egypt in December 2016. In this study, we provide a detailed characterization of the full genome of Egyptian H5N8 viruses and some virological features. Genetic analyzes showed that the Egyptian H5N8 viruses are highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the genome of Egyptian H5N8 viruses was related to recently characterized clade 2.3.4.4 reassortant H5N8 viruses isolated from various Eurasian countries. Several peculiar mutations have been characterized in the Egyptian H5N8 viruses, which likely allow transmission and virulence of these viruses in mammals. The Egyptian H5N8 viruses preferentially bind to avian-like receptors over human-like receptors. The Egyptian H5N8 viruses were also fully susceptible to amantadine and neuraminidase inhibitors. Chicken sera raised against commercial inactivated avian influenza H5 vaccines showed no or very little reactivity with the currently characterized H5N8 viruses, consistent with genetic dissimilarity. Surveillance of avian influenza in waterfowl provides early warning of particular threats to poultry and human health and should therefore be continued.
authors: Kandeil, A.;Kayed, A.;Moatasim, Y.;Webby, R. J.;McKenzie, P. P.;Kayali, G.;Ali, M. A.

title: Reassortant swine influenza viruses isolated in Japan contain genes from the 2009 pandemic A(H1N1).
abstract: In 2013, three reassortant swine influenza viruses (SIVs) - two H1N2 and one H3N2 - were isolated from symptomatic pigs in Japan; each contained genes from the 2009 pandemic virus A(H1N1) and endemic SIVs. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the two H1N2 viruses, A/swine/Gunma/1/2013 and A/swine/Ibaraki/1/2013, were reassortants containing genes from the following three distinct lineages: (i) H1 and Nucleoprotein (NP) genes derived from a classic porcine H1-HA lineage uniquely circulating among Japanese SIVs; (ii) neuraminidase (NA) genes from H1N2 porcine human-like viruses; and (iii) other genes from pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 viruses. The H3N2 virus, A/swine/Miyazaki/2/2013, comprised genes from two sources: (i) hemagglutinin (HA) and NA genes derived from H3N2 swine human and human-like viruses and (ii) other genes from Pandemic A( H1N1) 2009 viruses. The phylogenetic analysis also indicated that each of the reassortants could have arisen independently in Japanese pigs. A/swine/Miyazaki/2/2013 was found to have strong antigenic reactivities with antisera generated for some seasonal human lineage viruses isolated during or before 2003, while A/swine/Miyazaki/2/2013 reactivities with antisera against viruses isolated after 2004 were significantly weaker. In addition, antisera against some strains of seasonal human H1 viruses did not react with either A/swine/Gunma/1/2013 or A/swine/Ibaraki/1/2013. These results indicate that the emergence and spread of these reassortant SIVs pose a potential public health risk. © 2014 The Societies and Wiley Publishing Asia Pty Ltd.
authors: Kanehira, K.;Takemae, N.;Uchida, Y.;Hikono, H.;Saito, T.

title: Genetic analyzes of avian influenza viruses in Mongolia, 2007–2009, and their relationships to Korean domestic and wild bird isolates
abstract: The present study was conducted to monitor wild birds based on fears that they could spread the avian influenza virus (AIV) between Mongolia and Korea, which share the same migration route. From 1,528 stool samples analyzed between 2007 and 2009, 21 low pathogenic AIV were isolated. Nineteen AIV-positive stool specimens were identified as Anseriformes by DNA barcoding. The most commonly isolated subtype was H3 (61.9%) and the most common hemagglutinin/neuraminidase combination was H3N8 (52.4%). A phylogenetic analysis was performed to assess their genetic relationships with those of domestic and wild birds in Korea. The H3 and H7 surface genes belonged to the Eurasian lineage and clustered together in a group with Korean wild birds and poultry. Most of the N8 genes grouped phylogenetically with viruses isolated in Eurasia, while one of the Mongolian viruses and some Korean viruses belonged to the North American lineage. The internal gene acid polymerase protein was indistinguishable from the highly pathogenic H5N1-AIV of goose/Guangdong/1/1996 (gs/gd)-like virus. Our study suggests that Mongolian AIV isolates have evolved with genetically multiple genotypes and are closely related to those of AIV in poultry as well as wild birds in Korea. © 2011 Poultry Science Association Inc.
authors: Kang, H.;Kim, M.;Choi, J.;Batchuluun, D.;Erdene-Ochir, T.;Paek, M.;Sodnomdarjaa, R.;Kwon, J.;Lee, Y.

title: Isolation of a reassortant H13N2 virus from a faecal sample of a mallard duck in South Korea
abstract: Background: The virus subtype H13N2, A/mallard/Kr/SH38-45/2010 (H13N2), was first isolated from a faecal sample of a mallard duck in South Korea. Results: Phylogenetic analysis of all eight viral genes revealed that this virus arose through genetic mixing between Eurasian and North American gene pools and possibly between wild ducks and gulls. The H13 and N2 surface genes clustered together in a group with Eurasian isolates from gulls and wild birds, respectively. The PB2, PA, NP, M and NS segments belonged to the Eurasian lineage, whereas the PB1 gene was clustered in the North American lineage. In addition, they showed a bird-dependent pattern in phylogenetic analysis: the M gene resembled viruses of the H13 subtype in seagulls, while other segments resembled the avian influenza viruses of other wild duck subtypes. Conclusions: The data suggest that the new reassortant H13N2 virus isolated in South Korea may have arisen through genetic rearrangement between intercontinental and interspecies transmission in wild birds. © 2012 Kang et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Kang, H. M.;Choi, J. G.;Kim, M. C.;Kim, H. R.;Oem, J. K.;Bae, Y. C.;Paek, M. R.;Kwon, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.

title: Isolation of avian influenza virus (H9N2) from emu in China
abstract: This is the first reported isolation of avian influenza virus (AIV) from an emu in China. An outbreak of AIV infection occurred at an emu farm housing 40 four-month-old birds. Varying degrees of hemorrhage have been detected in the tissues of affected emus. Cell degeneration and necrosis were observed microscopically. Electron microscopy showed round or oval virions, 80 nm to 120 nm in diameter, surrounded by a spiked shell. The virus has been classified as low pathogenic AIV (LPAIV) according to OIE standards. It was called A/Emu/HeNen/14/2004(H9N2)(Emu/HN/2004). The HA gene (168315p) was amplified by RT-PCR and compared to other animal H9N2 AIV sequences in GenBank, the US National Institutes of Health's genetic sequence database. The results suggest that Emu/HN/2004 may have originated from an avian influenza (H9N2) virus from southern China.
authors: Kang, W. H.;Pang, W. Y.;Hao, J. F.;Zhao, D. M.

title: Phylogenetic relationships and pathogenicity variations of two Newcastle disease viruses isolated from domestic ducks in southern China
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is an OIE listed disease caused by virulent strains of avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV-1), which is enzootic and causes large economic losses in the poultry sector. NDV genotype VII and genotype IX viruses have been the predominant circulating genotypes in China, which could potentially be responsible for disease outbreaks in chicken flocks in recent years. While ducks and geese usually presented inapparent infections. methods. In the present study, we examine the complete genome sequence, clinicopathological characterization, and transmission of two virulent Newcastle disease viruses, SS-10 and NH-10, isolated from domestic ducks in southern China in 2010. Results: F and complete gene sequences based on phylogenetic analysis showed that SS-10 (genotype VII) and NH-10 (genotype IX) belong to class II. The deduced amino acid sequence was <sup>(112)</sup>RRQK/RRF<sup>(117)</sup> at the fusion protein cleavage site. Animal experimental results showed that the SS-10 virus isolated from ducks was highly pathogenic to chickens and geese, but weakly pathogenic to ducks. It could be detected in the spleen, lungs, kidneys, trachea, small intestine, bursa, thymus, pancreas and cecal tonsils, oropharyngeal and cloacal swabs and transferred to the naive contact birds. In addition, it could be transmitted to chickens, ducks and geese through naive contact. However, the NH-10 virus isolated from ducks was able to infect some chickens, ducks and geese, but only resulted in the death of chickens. Also, it could be transmitted to the naïve contact chickens, ducks and geese. Conclusion: The two NDV isolates showed different biological properties in terms of pathogenicity and transmission in chickens, ducks and geese. Therefore, there is no species preference for fowl, duck, or goose viruses, and more attention should be paid to transmission of VII-NDVs between ducks, geese, and chickens between ducks, geese, and chickens for the control and eradication of ND.
authors: Kang, Y.;Li, Y.;Yuan, R.;Li, X.;Sun, M.;Wang, Z.;Feng, M.;Jiao, P.;Ren, T.

title: Phylogenetic and pathotypic characterization of Newcastle disease viruses circulating in southern China and transmission in different birds
abstract: Although Newcastle disease virus (NDV) with high pathogenicity has been frequently isolated in poultry in China since 1948, the mode of its transmission among avian species is still largely unknown. Since various wild bird species are potential sources of transmission, in this study we genotypically and pathotypically characterized 23 NDV isolates collected from chickens, ducks and pigeons at live bird markets (LBMs) in southern China as part of an H7N9 surveillance program from December 2013 to February 2014. To simulate the natural transmission of different animal species in LBMs, we selected three representative NDVs namely GM, YF18 and GZ289 isolated from different birds to assess the pathogenicity and transmission of the indicated viruses in chickens, ducks and pigeons. In addition, to study the replication and shedding of NDV in poultry, we inoculated the chickens, ducks and pigeons with 106 EID50 of each virus via intraocular and intranasal routes. Eight hours after infection, the naïve contact groups were matched with those who had been vaccinated with each of the viruses to monitor contact transmission. Our results showed that genetically distinct viruses circulate in LBMs in southern China's Guangdong province, and that NDV from different birds exhibit different tissue tropisms and host ranges when transmitted to different birds. We therefore propose continuous epidemiological surveillance of LBM to prevent the spread of these viruses in different birds, especially chickens, and emphasize the need for virus-host relationship studies.
authors: Kang, Y.;Xiang, B.;Yuan, R.;Zhao, X.;Feng, M.;Gao, P.;Li, Y.;Li, Y.;Ning, Z.;Ren, T.

title: Isolation and characterization of a parapoxvirus from sheep with papular stomatitis
abstract: An outbreak of papular stomatitis occurred in a flock of sheep in Hokkaido, Japan. Histological examination, immunohistochemistry, electron microscopic observation and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were performed. The lesions were characterized by epithelial hyperplasia, acanthosis, ballooning degeneration of the spinous layer and stratum granulosum. A parapox virus was isolated from the skin lesion of affected sheep and characterized genetically and antigenically. Restriction endonuclease analysis of the PCR product revealed an ORF virus (ORFV) specific pattern and the isolate reacted with monoclonal antibodies against ORFV. The partially deduced amino acid sequence of the viral envelope gene was identical to that of the major Japanese ORFVs. These results indicated that the outbreak was due to infection with the parapox virus. The isolated virus could be classified as an ORFV and was closely related to the major Japanese ORFVs but not to foreign ORFVs or other parapoxviruses.
authors: Kanou, Y.;Inoshima, Y.;Shibahara, T.;Ishikawa, Y.;Kadota, K.;Ohashi, S.;Morioka, K.;Yoshida, K.;Yamada, S.

title: Classification of the Dutch and German avian reoviruses by ÏƒC protein sequencing
abstract: We have amplified, cloned and sequenced (part of) the open reading frame of the S1 segment encoding the Ïƒ C protein of avian reoviruses isolated from chickens with different disease states in Germany and the Netherlands between 1980 and 2000 . These avian reoviruses were analyzed phylogenetically and compared to sequences of avian reoviruses in the Genbank database. The avian reoviruses could be grouped into 5 different genotyping clusters and this classification was identical when comparing the sequences of the 5'-end, the 3'-end or the entire β-C protein open reading frame. Therefore, sequencing of both parts of the gene encoding β-C protein seems reliable for classification. We have been unable to identify a correlation between ÏƒC sequences of avian reoviruses and the disease state from which they were isolated. The sequences found in the Netherlands and Germany, like those in Taiwan, are more dispersed than the known avian reovirus Ïƒ C sequences in the US and Australia. We found no temporal or geographic differences in the avian reoviruses studied.
authors: Kant, A.;Balk, F.;Born, L.;Van Roozelaar, D.;Heijmans, J.;Gielkens, A.;Ter Huurne, A.

title: Hepatitis E virus in young pigs in Finland and characterization of the isolated partial genomic sequences of genotype 3 HEV
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections occur in pigs worldwide. Swine infection is usually subclinical, but HEV genotypes 3 and 4 are zoonotic agents that cause sporadic, indigenous human cases of hepatitis E. The aim of this study was to investigate the occurrence and dynamics of HEV infections in young pigs by analyzing a total of 273 faecal samples collected from six farrowing farms in order to genetically characterize the obtained HEV isolates and the phylogenetic relationships of HEV -to study isolates found in different pig farms in Finland. Fecal shedding of HEV of individual piglets was followed in two farms selected from five farms identified as HEV RNA positive. Excretion of HEV was found in 87.5% of the piglets. Piglets developed primary HEV infection 3-8 weeks after weaning, and at the time of transfer to fattening farms, virtually all (96.6%) of the pigs with a sample available at that time were still shedding the virus. According to phylogenetic analysis, all HEV isolates obtained belonged to HEV genotype 3, subtype e, and a separate farm-specific isolate was from 10 out of 11 farms examined. The results of our study indicate that HEV infection is very common in young pigs and HEV RNA positive pigs allow HEV transmission from farrowing to fattening farms, posing a potential risk of infection for pig farmers, and that genetic variation in HEVs from different originate farms arise.
authors: Kantala, T.;Heinonen, M.;Oristo, S.;Von Bonsdorff, C. H.;Maunula, L.

title: Supersize me: How whole genome sequencing and big data are changing epidemiology
