abstract: In epidemiology, identifying "who infected whom" allows us to quantify key characteristics such as incubation times, heterogeneity in transmission rates, duration of contagiousness, and the presence of high-risk groups. Although invaluable, the existence of many plausible routes of infection makes this difficult and epidemiological contact tracing either unsafe, logistically prohibitive, or both. The recent advent of next-generation sequencing technology is enabling the identification of traceable differences in the pathogen genome that are transforming our ability to understand high-resolution disease transmission, sometimes even down to the host-to-host scale. We review current examples of using whole genome sequencing of pathogens for the purpose of forensically tracing transmission routes, focusing on the particular problems where evolutionary dynamics are complemented by epidemiological information on the most likely timing of events as well as possible transmission routes got to . We also discuss potential pitfalls of overinterpreting this data and highlight the ways in which a confluence of this technology with sophisticated mathematical and statistical approaches has the potential to bring about a paradigm shift in our understanding of infectious disease transmission and control. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Kao, R. R.;Haydon, D. T.;Lycett, S. J.;Murcia, P. R.

title: Next-generation sequencing technologies: tool to study avian virus diversity
abstract: Increasing globalization, climatic changes and the interface between wildlife and livestock have led to the emergence of novel viral pathogens or zoonoses, which have become a serious problem for bird, animal and human health. High biodiversity and bird migration facilitate the spread of the pathogen and provide reservoirs for emerging infectious diseases. Current classical diagnostic methods, which are designed to be virus specific or aim to be limited to a group of viral agents, impede the identification of new viruses or viral variants. Recently developed next-generation sequencing (NGS) approaches provide culture-independent methods useful for understanding viral diversity and discovering new viruses, thereby enabling better diagnosis and disease control. This review discusses the different possible steps of an aNGS study using sequence-independent amplification, high-throughput sequencing, and bioinformatic approaches to identify novel avian viruses and their diversity. NGS led to the identification of a wide range of new viruses such as picobirnavirus, picornavirus, orthoreovirus and avian gamma-coronavirus associated with fulminant disease in guinea fowl and is also used to describe viral diversity among avian species. The review also briefly discusses areas of virus-host interaction and disease-associated causalities in newly identified avian viruses.
authors: Kapgate, S. S.;Barbuddhe, S. B.;Kumanan, K.

title: Avian parvovirus: classification, phylogeny, pathogenesis and diagnosis
abstract: Avian parvoviruses, identified in the early 1980's, are found in the intestines of young birds with enteric disease syndromes as well as healthy birds worldwide. Chicken parvovirus (ChPV) and turkey parvovirus (TuPV) belong to the genus Aveparvovirus within the subfamily Parvovirinae. Avian parvoviruses are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses composed of three open reading frames, the first two encoding nonstructural protein (NS) and nuclear phosphoprotein (NP), and the third encoding viral capsid proteins 1 (VP1 and VP2). Unlike other parvoviruses, the VP1 unique region does not contain the phospholipase A2 sequence motif. Recent experimental studies have suggested that the parvoviruses are the candidate pathogens in cases of enteric disease syndrome. Current diagnostic methods for avian parvovirus detection include PCR, real-time PCR, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay using recombinant VP2 or VP1 capsid proteins. Furthermore, sequence-independent amplification techniques combined with next-generation sequencing platforms have enabled rapid and simultaneous detection of parvovirus from affected and healthy birds. There is no commercial vaccine; Therefore, the development of an effective vaccine to contain the spread of infection should be a priority. This overview presents the current state of knowledge on avian parvoviruses with a focus on taxonomy, phylogenetic relationships, genome analysis, epidemiology, pathogenesis and diagnostic methods.
authors: Kapgate, S. S.;Kumanan, K.;Vijayarani, K.;Barbuddhe, S. B.

title: Several new astrovirus species in human stool
abstract: Diarrhea remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in developing countries, where numerous cases remain with no identified etiology. Astroviruses are a recently identified cause of gastroenteritis in animals, which currently includes two species suspected of causing diarrhea in humans. Using pan-astrovirus RT-PCR, we analyzed human stool samples from different continents for astrovirus-related RNA sequences. We identified variants of the two known human astrovirus species and, based on genetic distance criteria, three new astrovirus species, all distantly related to mink and ovine astroviruses, which we tentatively named HMOAstV species AC. The complete genome of species A showed all the conserved features of mammalian astroviruses. Each of the three groups of astroviruses now found in human stool (HAstV, AstV-MLB, and HMOAstV) were more closely related to animal astroviruses than to each other, suggesting that human astroviruses may periodically arise from zoonotic transmissions. Based on the pathogenic effect of their closest phylogenetic relatives in animals, further investigations into the role of HMOAstV, identified so far in Nigeria, Nepal and Pakistan, in human gastroenteritis are warranted. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Kapoor, A.;Li, L.;Victoria, J.;Oderinde, B.;Mason, C.;Pandey, P.;Zaidi, S. Z.;Delwart, E.

title: A newly identified bocavirus species in human stool
abstract: Viral metagenomic analysis was used to identify a previously uncharacterized parvovirus species, "HBoV2", whose closest phylogenetic relative is human bocavirus (HBoV). HBoV2 has a genomic organization identical to that of HBoV, but has only 78%, 67%, and 80% identity with the latter's NS1, NP1, and VP1/VP2 proteins, respectively. The study used polymerase chain reaction to detect HBoV2 sequences in 5 of 98 stool samples from Pakistani children and 3 of 699 stool samples from Edinburgh. Nearly complete genome sequencing revealed the presence of 3 HBoV2 genotypes and evidence of recombination between genotypes. Further studies are needed to identify anatomical sites of HBoV2 replication and possible associations with clinical symptoms or disease.
authors: Kapoor, A.;Slikas, E.;Simmonds, P.;Chieochansin, T.;Naeem, A.;Shaukat, S.;Alam, M. M.;Sharif, S.;Angez, M.;Zaidi, S.;Delwart, E.

title: Detection of non-polio enteroviruses in Hungary 2000-2008 and molecular epidemiology of enterovirus 71, coxsackievirus A16 and echovirus 30
abstract: Human enteroviruses are associated with a variety of clinical syndromes, ranging from mild febrile illnesses to severe, potentially fatal conditions such as aseptic meningitis, paralysis, myocarditis, and neonatal enteroviral sepsis. Between June 2000 and August 2008, Echovirus (E) types 2, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11, 13, 25, 30, Coxsackievirus (CV) -A16, -A19, -B5 and Enterovirus 71 (EV71) were reported in Hungary. In this study, 29 previously enterovirus-positive specimens from 28 patients diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease, meningitis and encephalitis were molecularly typed. The genetic relationships of the identified serotypes CV-A16, EV71 and E30 were assessed by direct sequencing of the genomic region encoding the capsid protein VP1. The sequences were compared to each other and sequences from other geographic regions in the gene bank were owned. The phylogenetic analysis of CV-A16 revealed that the viruses were predominantly of Far Eastern or Asia-Pacific origin. Typing of EV71 showed that one virus from 2000 belonged to genotype C1 and five viruses observed in 2004 and 2005 were identified as genotype C4. The 11 echovirus 30 strains showed homology with those of neighboring European countries. Molecular analysis of E30 revealed that three separate lineages circulated in Hungary in 2000, 2001 and 2004-2006. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2009.
authors: Kapusinszky, B.;Szomor, K. N.;Farkas, A.;TakÃ¡cs, M.;Berencsi, G.

title: Supplement to the international catalog of arboviruses, including certain other vertebrate viruses
abstract: The first edition was issued in 1967 and represented the working catalog at a time, February 1967, when it contained information on 204 registered viruses. Thirty-seven additional viruses registered up to June 1970 were published in a November 1970 supplement. A second update supplement was released in November 1971 with 14 newly registered viruses. A second edition of the catalog was published in 1975 and included information on 359 viruses registered in the working catalog since December 1974. This present report is the first supplement to the second edition of the catalog published and contains 30 additional virus registrations. With the withdrawal of Samford virus, which was identified as a strain of Ainovirus, the number of registered viruses is now 388. The 30 new registrations in this supplement contain information on 17 viruses isolated from arthropods and 2 from humans , and 11 isolated from other vertebrates. Both human viruses (ROC, EBO) have been associated with serious human diseases. One of the arthropod isolates (ORU) and a virus isolated from a mule (VSA) have also been implicated in human disease, and rabbit SSH virus has been found to cause subclinical infections in humans. Three viruses isolated from cattle and a mule (BEF, IBA, VSA) cause widespread disease in domestic animals. The ACAV Arthropod-Transmitted Status Evaluation Subcommittee (SEAS) has classified only one (SSH) of these newly registered viruses as a detected arbovirus, based on experimental evidence of mosquito-borne transmission. Another (ORU) was classified as probable arbovirus; a third (EBO) probably no arbovirus; and the remainder as possible arboviruses pending further definitive information on arthropod infection and transmission.
authors: Karabatsos, N.

title: A novel method for multiplex target enrichment of next-generation MinION sequencing libraries using PCR-generated decoys
abstract: Enrichment of target regions within complex next-generation sequence libraries commonly uses biotinylated decoys to capture the desired sequences. This method results in high read coverage over the targets and their flanking regions. Oxford Nanopore Technologies recently released a sequencer with USB3.0 interface, the MinION. To date, no particular method for enriching MinION libraries has been standardized. Here we describe a simple and efficient way to multiplex enrichment of MinION libraries using biotinylated PCR-generated decoys in a novel approach, overcoming technical limitations related to the chemistry of the sequencing adapters and the length of the DNA fragments. Using phage lambda and Escherichia coli as models, we selectively enrich for specific targets, significantly increase corresponding read coverage, and eliminate unwanted regions. We show that by capturing genomic fragments containing the target sequences, we recover reads that expand the target regions and thus can be used to determine potentially unknown flanking sequences. By pooling enriched libraries derived from two different E. coli strains and analyzing them in parallel, we demonstrate the efficiency of this method in multiplex format. Crucially, we have evaluated the optimal decoy size for large fragment libraries and are the first to describe a standardized method for target enrichment in the MinION platform.
authors: Karamitros, T.;Magiorkinis, G.

title: Genetic characterization of H3N2 influenza viruses isolated from swine in North America, 1977-1999: evidence for fully human and reassortant virus genotypes
abstract: Since 1998, H3N2 viruses have caused epizootic respiratory disease in swine in major swine producing regions of the United States. These outbreaks are notable because previously swine flu in North America was almost exclusively caused by the H1N1 virus. We sequenced the full-length protein-coding regions of all eight RNA segments from four H3N2 viruses isolated between March 1998 and March 1999 from swine in the Midwestern United States, H3N2 viruses isolated in January 1997 and from one piglet in Canada were recovered from a pig in Colorado in 1977. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the 1977 Colorado and 1997 Ontario isolates are entirely human influenza viruses. However, the viruses isolated from swine in the Midwestern United States since 1998 include reassortant viruses containing the hemagglutinin, neuraminidase, and PB1 polymerase genes from human influenza viruses, matrix, nonstructural, and nucleoprotein genes from classical swine viruses, and PA and avian PB2 polymerase genes contain viruses. The HA proteins of the reassortant Midwestern swine viruses can be distinguished from those of the 1995 lineage of human H3 viruses by 12 amino acid mutations in HA1. In contrast, the Sw/ONT/97 virus, which did not spread from pig to pig, lacks 11 of these mutations. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Karasin, A. I.;Schutten, M. M.;Cooper, L. A.;Smith, C. B.;Subbarao, K.;Anderson, G. A.;Carman, S.;Olsen, C. W.

title: Characterization of H3N3 and H1N1 avian influenza A viruses isolated from swine in Canada
abstract: H3N3 and H1N1 influenza A viruses were isolated from Canadian pigs in 2001 and 2002. These viruses are phylogenetically related to waterfowl viruses and are antigenically distinct from reference swine influenza viruses. The isolation of these viruses again underscores the potential for transmission of influenza viruses between species of aquatic birds to swine in North America.
authors: Karasin, A. I.;West, K.;Carman, S.;Olsen, C. W.

title: The intestinal eukaryotic vioma in healthy and diarrhea-sick newborn piglets
abstract: Neonatal swine diarrhea of unclear etiology has been reported from a number of European countries. The aim of the present study was to use viral metagenomics to investigate a possible viral involvement in this diarrhea and to describe the intestinal virome with a focus on eukaryotic viruses. Samples from the distal jejunum of 50 diarrheal and 19 healthy piglets from 10 affected herds were analyzed. The viral fraction of the samples was isolated and nucleic acids (RNA and DNA fractions) subjected to a sequence-independent amplification. Samples from piglets with diarrhea from the same herds were pooled, while samples from healthy piglets were analyzed individually. A total of 29 clinical samples as well as two negative controls and one positive control consisting of a mock metagenome were sequenced using the Ion Torrent platform. The resulting sequence data was subjected to taxonomic classification using Kraken, Diamond and HMMER. Eight different mammalian virus families were detected in the healthy samples (Adenoviridae, Anelloviridae, Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picornaviridae and Reoviridae) compared to four in the pooled diarrheal samples (Anelloviridae, Circoviridae, Picornaviridae and Reoviridae). It was not possible to assign a specific virus family to the diarrhea examined. In conclusion, this study does not support the hypothesis that the investigated diarrhea was caused by known mammalian viruses. However, the results indicate that known mammalian viruses were present in the gut as early as 24–48 hours after birth, suggesting immediate postpartum or possibly transplacental infection.
authors: Karlsson, O. E.;Larsson, J.;Hayer, J.;Berg, M.;Jacobson, M.

title: A severe pediatric infection with a novel Enterovirus A71 strain, Thuringia, Germany
abstract: Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) infection is an important cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). Outbreaks, including severe cases with neurological and cardiopulmonary complications, have been reported from Southeast Asia in particular. In Europe, the epidemiology of EV-A71 is not well understood. In the summer of 2015, a two-year-old girl from Thuringia presented with rhombencephalitis/cerebral encephalitis, which was associated with severe neurological and cardiopulmonary complications. EV-A71 was detected in stool and almost the entire viral genome was amplified and sequenced. While the VP1 coding region of the capsid protein belongs to the EV-A71 subgenogroup C1, the 3D polymerase coding region represents a unique lineage. Thus, the data suggest that the Thuringian EV-A71 sequence likely represents a recombinant. The case underscores the importance of intensified EV-A71 surveillance in Germany and Europe, including analysis of full genome data.
authors: Karrasch, M.;Fischer, E.;Scholten, M.;Sauerbrei, A.;Henke, A.;Renz, D. M.;Mentzel, H. J.;Boer, K.;Bottcher, S.;Diedrich, S.;Krumbholz, A.;Zell, R.

title: Understanding the evolutionary relationship of the hemagglutinin protein of influenza viruses using phylogenetic and molecular modeling studies
abstract: The existing H1N1 swine flu (2009) is pandemic in nature and is responsible for worldwide economic losses and deaths. Among the eight gene segments of H1N1, hemagglutinin (HA) plays an important role in virus attachment to the host cell surface, and entry of viral RNA into the host cell leads to infection. In this study, the sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the H1N1 (2009) HA from Mexico City were examined along with 1952 sequences from different subtypes of the pandemic influenza A virus, and the results showed that the closest relative of strain H1N1 ( 2009) from Mexico with tribe H1N1 (2009) consisted tribe H1N1 (2007) Mallard Norway. The analysis of the secondary structures predicted from the protein sequence revealed that in the years 2005 to 2010 a reduction in size of the alpha helices was observed in many regions of the sequences. Conversely, an analysis at the structural level is required to critically assess the functional importance. Therefore, for the above proteins, a structural level study was performed by constructing the 3D structure of these proteins through homology modelling. The models were validated and structural level similarities were assessed by overlay. Subsequently, docking studies were performed to find out the binding mode of sialic acid (SA) with influenza HA. Molecular dynamics simulations were performed to study the interactions of the SA molecule with the HA. Energetic analysis shows that the van der Waal interaction is more favorable for the binding of HA with SA of whole influenza virus. Binding pocket analysis shows that H-bond donor and acceptor intensities are higher in H1N1 (2009). © 2013 © 2013 Taylor & Francis.
authors: Karthikeyan, M.;Kirubakaran, P.;Singh, K. D.;Sampath, B.;Krishnasamy, G.

title: Potential risks from porcine single-stranded DNA virus associated with xenotransplantation
abstract: Routine large-scale xenotransplantation from pigs to humans is approaching clinical reality thanks to several cutting-edge technologies, most notably the ability to rapidly produce genetically defined pigs. However, the use of porcine organs in humans carries risks, including the unwanted cross-species transmission of viruses and the adaptation of these porcine viruses to the human organ recipient. Recent developments in the field of virology, including the advent of metagenomic techniques to characterize whole viromes, have led to the identification of a plethora of viruses in many niches. Single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) viruses are the largest group prevalent in mammalian viroma studies. In particular, the ssDNA viral genomes are characterized by a high rate of nucleotide substitution, which confers a propensity for adaptation to new hosts and cross-species barriers. Porcine-associated ssDNA viruses include torque tenosus virus (TTSuV) in the Anelloviridae family, porcine parvoviruses (PPV) and porcine bocaviruses (PBoV), both in the Parvoviridae family, and porcine circoviruses (PCV) in the family of the Circoviridae, some of which have been shown to be pathogenic to pigs. The risks of these viruses to the human recipient during xenotransplantation procedures are relatively unknown. Due to the limited knowledge available about the prevalence, predilection and pathogenicity of swine-associated ssDNA viruses, careful screening and monitoring is required. In the event of a positive identification, risk assessments and strategies to eliminate these viruses from xenotransplantation pig herds may be required.
authors: Karuppannan, A. K.;Opriessnig, T.

title: Phylogenetic relationships of the G gene sequence of bovine ephemeral fever virus isolated in Japan, Taiwan and Australia
abstract: The G gene, which encodes the neutralization antigen of Bovine Ephemeral Fever Virus (BEFV), has been characterized to define the molecular epidemiology of the virus in Japan and the genetic relationships between the Japanese, Taiwanese and Australian isolates. The nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the gene were highly conserved among the Japanese strains regardless of the year of isolation and were closely related to the Taiwanese strains. Through phylogenetic analysis, the Japanese and Taiwanese strains have been clearly classified into three chronological clusters: 1966, 1984-1989, and 1996-2004, suggesting that the bovine ephemeral fever epidemics in both countries may occur almost simultaneously through the same genotype. On the other hand, the Australian tribes were distantly related to these East Asian tribes and were placed in the independent fourth cluster of the phylogenetic tree. Three amino acid substitutions at residues 224, 271 and 499 in the neutralizing epitopes, two of which create new glycosylation sequences, are thought to be responsible for antigenic variations in bovine ephemeral fever virus. The cross-neutralization test with bovine ephemeral fever virus isolated in Japan showed that the vaccine developed on the basis of the oldest Japanese strain, YHL, seems to still be effective in combating bovine ephemeral fever in Japan. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kato, T.;Aizawa, M.;Takayoshi, K.;Kokuba, T.;Yanase, T.;Shirafuji, H.;Tsuda, T.;Yamakawa, M.

title: Infection of common carp (Cyprinus carpio) with cyprinid herpesvirus 3 (CyHV-3) - an update
abstract: Infection of carp (Cyprinus carpio) with cyprinid herpesvirus 3 (CyHV-3) – an update Carp and koi (Cyprinus carpio) are intensively bred worldwide, both as livestock and as ornamental fish, with a steadily growing circle of enthusiasts. Since the late 1990s, the species has been threatened by a novel virus recently classified as a herpesvirus. The virus, now known as Cyprinid Herpesvirus 3 (CyHV-3) or Koi Herpesvirus (KHV), causes massive losses in both industries every year. The aim of this review is to give a general overview of the current knowledge about the disease and the causative agent and to describe why CyHV-3 is still a serious problem in both the carp and koi fish farming 14 years after its discovery. represents aquaculture.
authors: Kattlun, J.;Gotesman, M.;Bergmann, S. M.;El-Matbouli, M.

title: Analysis of the evolution of codon usage patterns in avian rotaviruses and their preferred host
abstract: Rotavirus infections are a worldwide problem with the occurrence of very different viruses classified into 8 types (AH). We report here the evolutionary assessment of virus–host codon usage patterns in avian rotavirus (AvRV) of species RVA, RVD, RVF, and RVG (preferably affecting birds). Values of nucleotide content, codon usage bias (CUB), relative synonymous codon usage (RSCU) and effective number of codons (ENCs) were examined with the aim of overexpressing the major viral inner capsid protein (VP6) of this AvRV species. The results confirm that evolutionary traits influence rotavirus (RV) genetic diversity and the impact of host natural selection on AvRVs codons. Synonymous codon usage patterns were evaluated using multivariate statistical methods on all available AvRV-encoding gene sequences. RSCU trees harbored all AvRV species and preferred host sequences in one topology, confirming a greater close proximity of AvRVs to the host chick cell genes. Similarly, the Codon Adaptation Index (CAI) results also showed higher adaptation of AvRVs to its chicken host. Codon preference analysis of RVs revealed that the VP6 gene is better expressed in the yeast system, while codon optimization may be required for effective expression in Escherichia coli and Homo sapiens. The results provide fundamental clues on the dynamics of AvRV evolution and their host adaptation, which could be used for further research on avian species in the future.
authors: Kattoor, J. J.;Malik, Y. S.;Sasidharan, A.;Rajan, V. M.;Dhama, K.;Ghosh, S.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Kobayashi, N.;Singh, R. K.

title: CRISPRs from Enterococcus faecalis and E. hirae isolates from pig feces have species-specific repeats but share some common spacer sequences
abstract: Clustered regular interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR) are currently a topic of interest in microbiology because of their role as a prokaryotic immune system. Previous studies on the distribution and characterization of CRISPR have focused on pathogenic bacteria, while less is known about CRISPR in commensal bacteria, where they may play an important role in the ecology of human and other animal microbiota and serve as a record of interactions between bacteria and viruses. A combination of PCR and sequencing was used to determine the prevalence and distribution of CRISPR arrays in Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus hirae isolates from feces of healthy pigs. Both type II CRISPR-Cas and orphan CRISPR (without Cas genes) were detected in the 195 isolates examined. CRISPR-Cas was detected in 52 (46/88) and 42% (45/107) E. faecalis and E. hirae isolates, respectively. The prevalence of orphan CRISPR arrays was higher in E. faecalis isolates (95%, 84/88) than in E. hirae isolates (49%, 53/107). Species-specific repeat sequences were identified in orphan CRISPR arrays, and 42 unique spacer sequences were identified. Only two spacers matched previously characterized porcine virome sequences, and many apparently derived from enterococcal chromosomal sequences. Surprisingly, 17 (40%) of the spacers were detected in both species. Shared spacer sequences are evidence of a lack of species specificity in the agents and mechanisms responsible for spacer integration, and the abundance of spacer sequences corresponding to bacterial chromosome sequences reflects interspecific interactions within the gut microbiota.
authors: Katyal, I.;Chaban, B.;Ng, B.;Hill, J. E.

title: Insights into the plasmidome of the bovine rumen
abstract: Plasmids are self-replicating genetic elements capable of mobilization between different hosts. Plasmids often serve as mediators of lateral gene transfer, a process thought to be a powerful and shaping evolutionary force in microbial environments. Our aim was to characterize the entire plasmid population in the vicinity of the bovine rumen, which harbors a complex and dense microbiota of enormous importance to humans. We developed a method to isolate total rumen plasmid DNA, called rumen plasmidoma, and subjected it to deep sequencing using Illumina's paired-end protocol and analysis using public and custom bioinformatics tools. A large number of plasmidoma contigs aligned with plasmids from rumen bacteria isolated from different locations and at different times, suggesting that not only the bacterial taxa but also their plasmids are defined by the ecological niche. The bacterial strain distribution of the plasmidoma differed from that of the rumen bacterial taxa. However, both shared a dominance of Phyla Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria. Apparently, the rumen plasmidome is of a highly mosaic nature capable of interbreeding with phyla. Interestingly, when we compared the functional profile of the rumen plasmidome to two plasmid databases and two recently published rumen metagenomes, it became clear that the rumen plasmidome encodes functions that are enriched in the rumen ecological niche and might confer advantages on their hosts, suggesting that the functional profiles of mobile genetic elements are associated with their environment, as previously implied for viruses.
authors: Kav, A. B.;Sasson, G.;Jami, E.;Doron-Faigenboim, A.;Benhar, I.;Mizrahi, I.

title: Circulation of reassortant influenza A(H7N9) virus in poultry and humans, Guangdong Province, China, 2013
abstract: Influenza A(H7N9) virus emerged in eastern China in February 2013 and continues to circulate in that region, but its ecology is poorly understood. In April 2013, the Guangdong Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) introduced surveillance of environmental and human syndromes for the virus. Environmental samples from poultry markets in 21 city CDCs (n=8,942) and respiratory samples from individuals with influenza-like illness or pneumonia (n=32,342) were tested; Viruses isolated from 6 environmental samples and 16 patients were sequenced. Sequence analysis revealed a co-circulation of 4 influenza A(H7N9) virus strains that evolved through reassortment with avian influenza A(H9N2) viruses circulating in this region. In addition, an increase in human cases from late 2013 has coincided with an increase in isolates of influenza A H7 virus detected by environmental surveillance. The co-circulation of several avian influenza viruses that can infect humans underscores the need for increased surveillance of poultry and potential environmental sources.
authors: Ke, C.;Lu, J.;Wu, J.;Guan, D.;Zou, L.;Song, T.;Yi, L.;Zeng, X.;Liang, L.;Ni, H.;Kang, M.;Zhang, X.;Zhong, H.;He, J.;Lin, J.;Smith, D.;Burke, D.;Fouchier, R. A.;Koopmans, M.;Zhang, Y.

title: Characterization of emerging Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Taiwan between 2002 and 2008
abstract: To elucidate the epidemiological relationships between ND outbreaks and genetic lineages, a portion of the F gene (535 bp) and full-length HN gene (1922 bp) from Taiwanese NDVs recently isolated in 2002-2008 was reverse-transcribed (RT) amplified. -Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and sequenced. Only a portion of the above amplified PCR products of the F and HN genes (374 and 1713 bp) and their deduced amino acid residues were compared to the other 60 NDVs retrieved from GenBank. Most (29/30) of the youngest Taiwanese isolates were classified as subgenotype VIIe, while only one isolate was classified as subgenotype VIIc. All 29 isolates of subgenotype VIIe were further subclassified and provisionally designated as sub-subgenotypes VIIe2 (13 isolates), VIIe3 (5 isolates) and VIIe4 (11 isolates). Isolates of subsubgenotype VIIe2, possessing the 112R-RQKR-F117 motif and amino acid residue substitutions at positions 23 (L to F) and 90 (T to A), were collected between 2002 and 2005. Isolates of sub-subgenotype VIIe3 carrying the 112R-RKKR-F117 motif and amino acid residue substitutions at positions 74 (E to G) and 75 (A to G) within the epitopes and 114 (Q to K) within the cleavage site of the F- Proteins were collected in 2003-2006. The subsubgenotype VIIe4 isolates with the motif 112R-RQKR-F117 and amino acid substitutions at positions 23 (L to F), 26 (I to T) and 90 (T to A) were collected between 2007 and 2008. All NDV isolates in this study showed a high intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), they were all classified as velogenic NDV types. Viruses of sub-genotypes VIIe2 and VIIe4 are now dominant and have been implicated in most of the recent ND outbreaks in Taiwan. Phylogenetic analysis of these isolates indicated that they may have evolved from previously reported local strains (VIIe1). This finding is critical to improving disease control strategies and developing vaccines for ND. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Ke, G. M.;Yu, S. W.;Ho, C. H.;Chu, P. Y.;Ke, L. Y.;Lin, K. H.;Tsai, Y. C.;Liu, H. J.;Lin, M. Y.

title: Baculovirus infection of the armyworm (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) feeding on leaf blades of spiny or smooth-edged grass (Festuca spp.).
abstract: The susceptibility of the armyworm Mythimna unipuncta (Haworth) to infection by a baculovirus (NPV) isolated from an armyworm population in Kentucky was compared in two putative fescue progenitors, Festuca mairei and Festuca arundinacea subsp. fenas, with spiny leaf margins intact or removed, to test whether leaf spines abrade or puncture the peritrophic matrix (PM) and facilitate passage of virions to sites of infection in midgut tissue. PCR amplification and sequencing of selected genes from the virus and phylogenetic inference from aligned sequences were performed to identify and classify the virus. Marginal spines had no effect on the percentage of infection or days to death of newly molted 5th instars infected with spiny or smooth-edged F. mairei leaf blades 24 h before and after drop-feeding at doses of 10(8) or 10(9). OBs ml were fed (1). Fifth instar that were fed spiny or smooth-edged blades of grass had similarly undamaged PMs when viewed with a scanning electron microscope. Fourth instar fed virus treated F. arundinacea subsp. fenas leaf blades with intact or removed spiny margins did not differ in ratio of infection or days to death. The food bolus moves in a liquid medium within the PM, and Frass dissections showed that marginal spines were often located within a food bolus separated from the PM by non-spinous plant material, rather than adjacent to the PM; Therefore, the friction of the edge spikes with the PM may have been low. These results suggest that armyworms are no less susceptible to baculovirus infection when feeding on smooth-edged tall fescue cultivars planted for improved livestock performance compared to those feeding on standard cultivars with smooth leaf margins prickly edges feed. We believe this is the first study to examine the effects of a natural physical structure on the disruption of PM and infection by a baculovirus. (C) 2012 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Keathley, C. P.;Harrison, R. L.;Potter, D. A.

title: Porcine circovirus 2 genetic variability in vaccinating and non-vaccinating commercial farms
abstract: Vaccines against porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) are now widely used to control diseases caused by the virus. Although the vaccines protect pigs from the disease, they do not confer sterilizing immunity and therefore PCV2 infections continue on farms. PCV2 is expected to be able to rapidly adapt to environmental stresses such as vaccination due to its high evolutionary rate. The aim of this study was to elucidate the molecular variation of PCV2 in relation to vaccination. PCV2 variability was assessed using samples from infected pigs from five never-vaccinated and two herds where the pigs had been vaccinated for at least two years. For genetic analysis, whole PCV2 genomes were amplified and then pooled by vaccination status from serum from eight vaccinated infected pigs and 16 non-vaccinated infected pigs. The variability of the virus populations was quantified using next-generation sequencing and subsequent bioinformatic analysis. The number of segregation sites was similar in the unvaccinated (n=109) and vaccinated pools (n=96), but the distribution of these sites in the genome was different. Most notably, in the capsid gene, the number of segregation sites was only observed in the unvaccinated population. Based on the structural analysis, some low-frequency amino acids are expected to result in viruses with biologically low fitness. In contrast, D294 in Replicase represents a novel amino acid that was dominant and unique in the vaccinated pool. This work showed that different PCV2 populations circulated in commercial farms and that this variability was different in samples obtained from vaccinating and non-vaccinating farms.
authors: Kekarainen, T.;Gonzalez, A.;Llorens, A.;Segales, J.

title: Sequencing and molecular modeling identify candidate members of the Caliciviridae family in bats
abstract: Emerging viral diseases pose a constant challenge in the globalized world, and bats represent a vast, partially explored reservoir of potentially zoonotic viruses. Caliciviruses are important human and animal pathogens and, as observed with human noroviruses, can impact human health worldwide. During screening of fecal samples from bats in Hungary, calicivirus RNA was identified in samples from Myotis daubentonii and Eptesicus serotinus bats. In order to characterize the bat caliciviruses in more detail, large parts of the genome sequence of the viruses were determined. Phylogenetic analyzes and molecular modeling unequivocally identified the two viruses as possible members within the Caliciviridae family, with one calicivirus strain resembling members of the Sapovirus genus and the other bat calicivirus more closely related to porcine caliciviruses of the proposed genus Valovirus. These data are used in an effort to identify reservoir hosts for potentially emerging viruses and to identify important evolutionary connections.

title: The microbiome of the porcine soft palate
authors: Kernaghan, S.;Bujold, A. R.;MacInnes, J. I.

title: Genetic characterization of Indian plague small ruminant virus (PPRV) by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of fusion protein and nucleoprotein gene segments
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an important viral disease in sheep and goats endemic to India. The study was conducted to characterize the local PPRV by sequencing of fusion protein (F) and nucleoprotein (N) gene segments and phylogenetic analysis to focus on genetic variation in the field viruses. Selected regions of the PPRV genome were amplified from clinical specimens collected from 32 sheep and goats by RT-PCR and the resulting amplicons were sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. The phylogenetic tree based on the 322 bp F gene sequences of PPRV from five different loci grouped them together with other Asian isolates in lineage 4. While the 425 bp N gene sequences showed a different branching pattern, three resulted different clusters for Nigerian, Turkish and Indian isolates. Thus, the classification of PPRV into lineages based on the N gene sequences appeared to provide a better picture of the molecular epidemiology for PPRV. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Kerur, N.;Jhala, M. K.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Comparison of Schmallenberg virus sequences isolated from mammalian host and arthropod vector
abstract: The Schmallenberg virus (SBV) belongs to the Peribunyaviridae family, which includes pathogens important for human and veterinary medicine. The virus is only transmitted between animals and mainly by mosquitoes of the genus Culicoides. This study was performed to determine the genetic diversity of SBV and to elucidate host-vector adaptation. All three viral segments were analyzed for sequence variability and phylogenetic relationships. The Polish SBV strains, obtained from acute infections in cattle, congenital cases in sheep and from Culicoides mosquitoes, were sequenced using Sanger and next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods. The sequences obtained were genetically similar (99.2-100% identity) to the first detected strain BH80/11-4 of German cattle. The year of sampling and the origin of the Polish sequences did not affect the molecular diversity of SBV. Considering all analyzed Polish and European sequences, the sheep-derived sequences were the most variable, while those from mosquitoes were more conserved and included unique substitutions mainly localized in the nonstructural protein S. SBV sequences isolated from Culicoides are the first to be submitted and reported to GenBank.
authors: Kesik-Maliszewska, J.;Antos, A.;Rola, J.;Larska, M.

title: Cygnet River Virus, a novel orthomyxovirus from Ducks, Australia
abstract: A novel virus called Cygnet River Virus (CyRV) has been isolated in embryonated eggs of musk ducks in South Australia. CyRV is morphologically similar to arenaviruses; however, sequencing identified CyRV as an orthomyxovirus. The high mortality rate in ducks co-infected with Salmonella suggests that CyRV may be pathogenic either alone or in conjunction with other infections.
authors: Kessell, A.;Hyatt, A.;Lehmann, D.;Shan, S.;Crameri, S.;Holmes, C.;Marsh, G.;Williams, C.;Tachedjian, M.;Yu, M.;Bingham, J.;Payne, J.;Lowther, S.;Wang, J.;Wang, L. F.;Smith, I.

title: Epidemiology of human and animal kobuviruses
abstract: Kobuviruses belong to the Picornaviridae family. Initially, members of the genus Kobuvirus were named after their host species. The viruses found in humans are referred to as "Aichi virus", the viruses from bovines are referred to as "bovine kobuvirus" and the viruses isolated from pigs are referred to as "porcine kobuvirus". Currently, a taxonomy of kobuviruses has been proposed and the virus species have been renamed. "Aichi virus" was renamed "Aichivirus A", "bovine kobuvirus" was renamed "Aichivirus B", and "porcine kobuvirus" was changed to "Aichivirus C". Among Aichivirus A, three distinct members including Aichivirus 1 (human Aichivirus), canine Kobuvirus 1 and murine Kobuvirus 1 have been described. Aichi virus 1 is distributed worldwide in humans and has been identified with a low incidence (0–3%) in sporadic cases of acute gastroenteritis. Aichi virus 1 has been reported to be associated with various types of clinical diseases, including diarrhea, vomiting, fever, purulent conjunctivitis, and respiratory symptoms. The studies from Japan, Spain, Germany and Tunisia showed that a high prevalence of antibodies against Aichi virus 1 was found in the population. Aichivirus B, or formerly known as bovine kobuvirus, was first reported in 2003. Since then, Aichivirus B has also been reported from several countries worldwide. The overall prevalence of Aichivirus B varies from 1 to 34.5%, and the highest prevalence was found in cattle with diarrhea in Korea. Aichivirus C, or porcine kobuvirus, is widespread in pigs. Aichivirus C has been found in both diarrheal and healthy pigs and the positive rate of this virus varies from 3.9 to 100%. It has been reported that Aichivirus C was found with high prevalence in wild boar in Hungary. The data collected from the biological, pathological and epidemiological studies on kobuviruses are still limited. Comprehensive global studies of prevalence and diversity are needed and will be helpful to gain further insight into pathogenicity, genetic heterogeneity, transmission between species and global distribution of kobuviruses.
authors: Khamrin, P.;Maneekarn, N.;Okitsu, S.;Ushijima, H.

title: Novel genetic group of nonstructural protein 4 in porcine rotavirus
authors: Khamrin, P.;Okitsu, S.;Ushijima, H.;Maneekarn, N.

title: A multicenter study to evaluate the performance of high-throughput sequencing for virus detection
abstract: The ability of high-throughput sequencing (HTS) to detect known and unknown viruses makes it a powerful tool for comprehensive microbial investigations, such as B. the evaluation of novel cell substrates that can be used for the development of new biological products. However, like any new assay, regulatory applications of HTS require method standardization. Therefore, our three laboratories initiated a study to evaluate the performance of HTS for the potential detection of viral adventitious agents by spiking model viruses into different cell matrices to mimic putative materials for biologics manufacture. Four model viruses were chosen based on different physical and biochemical properties and commercial availability: human respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), feline leukemia virus (FeLV), and human reovirus (REO). In addition, the porcine circovirus (PCV) was tested by a laboratory. Independent samples were prepared for HTS by adding intact virus or extracted viral nucleic acids, individually or mixed, to various HeLa cell matrices (resuspended whole cells, cell lysate, or total cellular RNA). Data were obtained using different sequencing platforms (Roche 454, Illumina HiSeq1500 or HiSeq2500). Bioinformatic analyzes were performed independently by each laboratory using available tools, pipelines, and databases. The results showed that comparable virus detection was achieved in the three laboratories, independent of sample processing, library preparation, sequencing platform and bioinformatic analysis: Between 0.1 and 3 viral genome copies per cell were detected for all model viruses used. This study underscores the potential of using HTS for the sensitive detection of adventitious viruses in complex biological samples with a cellular background. IMPORTANT Recent investigations into high-throughput sequencing (HTS) have led to unexpected discoveries of known and new viruses in a variety of sample types, including research materials, clinical materials, and biological products. Therefore, HTS can be a powerful tool to complement current methods for detecting the absence of adventitious or unwanted viruses in biological products, especially when using a new cell line. However, HTS is a complex technology with different platforms that needs to be standardized to evaluate biologics. This collaborative study was conducted to examine the detection of different virus types with two different HTS platforms. The results of the independently conducted studies showed similar sensitivity of virus detection regardless of the different sample preparation and processing methods and bioinformatic analyzes performed in the three laboratories. The comparable HTS detection of different virus types supports the future development of reference virus materials for the standardization and validation of different HTS platforms.
authors: Khan, A. S.;Ng, S. H. S.;Vandeputte, O.;Aljanahi, A.;Deyati, A.;Cassart, J. P.;Charlebois, R. L.;Taliaferro, L. P.

title: Sequence data to clarify the taxonomic position of common bean mosaic virus and black-eyed bean mosaic virus isolates
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of the coat protein genes and 3'-untranslated regions (3'-NTRs) of three isolates of common bean mosaic virus (NL1, NL3 and NY15) and one isolate of black-eyed cowpea mosaic virus (W) were determined. Comparison of these sequences revealed that the envelope proteins of NL1, NY15 and W were identical in size (287 amino acids) and shared overall sequence similarity (94-97%) and 84-98% in their N-terminal regions. In addition, their 3' NTRs were very similar in length [253 to 256 nucleotides (nt)] and sequence (93 to 96% similarity). In contrast, the coat protein of NL3 had only 261 amino acids and showed 87-89% similarity to NL1, NY15 and W, while its N-terminal region showed only 46-61% similarity. The NL3 3'-NTR also showed significant differences, both in length (240 nt) and in sequence (56-63% similarity). These results, combined with previous serological findings, justify the conclusion that NL1, NY15 and W should be considered as strains of the same virus, i.e. Bean Common Mosaic Virus, and that NL3 is a strain of another potyvirus, for which the name "Bean Black Root Virus” proposed.
authors: Khan, J. A.;Lohuis, D.;Goldbach, R.;Dijkstra, J.

title: Distinguishing strains of Bean Common Mosaic Virus and Blackeye Cowpea Mosaic Virus using antibodies against N-terminal and C-terminal or N-terminal peptide domains of envelope proteins
abstract: Previous attempts to serologically distinguish Bean Common Mosaic Virus (BCMV) strains NL1, NL3 and NY15 and Blackeye Cowpea Mosaic Virus (B1CMV) strain W were unsuccessful. Antibodies directed against N- and C- or N-terminal peptide regions of the coat proteins of the above strains enabled discrimination between B1CMV-W, BCMV-NY15 and BCMV-NL3 in electroblot immunoassay and in ELISA. The discrimination was better for antibodies directed against N-termini than for those against N- and C-termini. BCMV strain NL1 reacted with both B1CMV-W and BCMV-NY15, but not with BCMV-NL3. Taxonomic implications of these results are discussed.
authors: Khan, J. A.;Lohuis, H.;Goldbach, R. W.;Dijkstra, J.

title: Molecular characterization of isolates of classical swine fever virus from India in 2012–14
abstract: Classical swine fever is a highly contagious and economically important viral disease of pigs. Outbreaks of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) were recorded in various locations in the Kamrup district of Assam, India between 2012 and 2014. The nucleotide sequences of the 10 CSFV isolates were analyzed based on the partial nucleotide sequences of E2, 5'NTR and NS5B genes. The phylogenetic analysis showed the dominance of the 2.2 subgroup along with 2.1 tribes in the northeastern part of India. The variation in the nucleotide sequences of the CSFV E2, 5'NTR and 3'NS5B genes allows for the tracking of changes in the virus population over time. The study will provide epidemiological information useful for the assessment of CSFV circulating genogroups in India.
authors: Khatoon, E.;Barman, N. N.;Deka, M.;Rajbongshi, G.;Baruah, K.;Deka, N.;Bora, D. P.;Kumar, S.

title: Viral diversity and clonal evolution from unphased genomic data
abstract: Background: Clonal expansion is a process by which a single organism reproduces asexually, resulting in a diversifying population. It is inherently ubiquitous, from pathogen development within the host to the outbreak of infectious diseases. Standard phylogenetic tools rely on full-length genomes of individual pathogens or population consensus sequences (phased genotypes). Although high-throughput sequencing technologies are capable of examining population diversity, their inherent short sequence reads preclude assessing whether two reads are from the same clone (out-of-phase genotypes). This obstacle severely limits the application of phylogenetic methods and the study of host dynamics of acute infections using this rich data source. Methods: We introduce two diversity measures to study the evolution of clonal populations using aphased genomic data, eliminating the need to construct full-length genomes. Our method follows a maximum likelihood approach to estimate evolutionary rates and times to the most recent common ancestor based on a relaxed molecular clock model; independent of a growth model. Deviations from neutral development indicate the presence of selection and bottleneck events. Results: We evaluated our methods in silico and then compared them to existing approaches using the well-characterized 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic. We then applied our method to high-throughput genome data from Marburg virus-infected non-human primates and deduced the timing of infection and the rate of evolution within the host and identified purifying selection in virus populations. Conclusions: Our method is able to take advantage of smaller variants, present in less than 1% of the population, and capture genomic diversification within days of infection, making it an ideal tool for studying the dynamics of acute RNA virus infections.
authors: Khiabanian, H.;Carpenter, Z.;Kugelman, J.;Chan, J.;Trifonov, V.;Nagle, E.;Warren, T.;Iversen, P.;Bavari, S.;Palacios, G.;Rabadan, R.

title: Genetic characterization and pathogenicity assessment of Newcastle disease virus isolated from wild peacock
abstract: The continued spread and emergence of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) poses a potential threat to the domestic poultry industry around the world. Mainly, wild bird species have always been considered as a natural reservoir for virus and the spread of the disease. In the present study, we report the isolation of Newcastle disease virus (NDV/Peacock/India/2012) in a necropsy brain tissue sample from wild peafowl from northern India. The full genome of the virus was found to be 15,186 nucleotides (nts) with six genes in the order 3-N-PMF-HN-L-5, followed by a 55-nts leader region at the 3-inch Region delimited are ² end and a 114 nts trailer sequence at the 5 inch end. Sequence analysis of the fusion protein revealed the <sup>112</sup>RRQKRF<sup>117</sup> dibasic amino acid cleavage site, a characteristic motif of the virulent virus. Phylogenetic analysis placed the isolate in genotype II of Newcastle disease virus and showed the lowest mean percentage deviation (6%) with other genotype II counterparts intracerebral pathogenicity index (1.40) in day-old chicks as mesogenic (intermediate pathotype). The report emphasizes the dynamic ecology of NDV strains circulating in a wild bird host during the 2012 outbreak in northern India. In addition, the genotypic and pathotypic characterizations of the isolate could be helpful in the development of a homologous vaccine against the NDV strain circulating in the bird population.
authors: Khulape, S. A.;Gaikwad, S. S.;Chellappa, M. M.;Mishra, B. P.;Dey, S.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the fusion protein cleavage site of field isolates of Newcastle disease virus from Iran
abstract: Nine isolates of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) from outbreaks of Newcastle disease (ND) in different regions of Iran have been characterized at the molecular level. Sequence analysis showed that the isolates shared two pairs of arginine and a phenylalanine at the N-terminus of the fusion protein (F) cleavage site, similar to other velogenic isolates of NDV previously characterized. Eight of the nine isolates shared the same amino acid sequence as VOL95, a 1995 Russian NDV isolate. However, one isolate, MK13, had 5 amino acid substitutions, 3 of which have been reported for other velogenic NDV isolates. These results suggest that the origin of the ND eruptions in different parts of Iran in 1995-1998 is VOL95.
authors: Kianizadeh, M.;Aini, I.;Omar, A. R.;Yusoff, K.;Sahrabadi, M.;Kargar, R.

title: Classification of avian paramyxoviruses by immunodiffusion based on the antigenic specificity of their M protein antigens
abstract: Seventeen avian paramyxoviruses, consisting of ten reference strains and seven more recent isolates, were classified into six species by immunodiffusion based on the antigenic specificity of their M protein (MP) antigens. The species were represented by the following viruses. (1) Newcastle disease virus, (2) chicken/California/Yucaipa/56, (3) turkey/Wisconsin/68, (4) duck/Mississippi/75, (5) pigeon/Otaru/76, and (6) Budgie/ Kunitachi/1/74. The differences in HN antigens between viruses classified into the same species based on the antigenic specificity of their MP antigens may provide a basis for their classification into types.
authors: Kida, H.;Yanagawa, R.

title: Complete genome sequence of Mannheimia haemolytica strain Mh10517 isolated from sheep in South Africa
abstract: Respiratory diseases caused by Mannheimia haemolytica are a major problem in the cattle and small livestock industry worldwide. This problem arises due to the interaction of numerous contributing factors, including physical stresses associated with weaning, transport, inclement weather, and overcrowding associated with viral and bacterial infections. The entire genome of M. haemolytica strain Mh10517 was analyzed using an Illumina MiSeq high-throughput sequencing platform. The genome size is 2.67 MB with 2,879 predicted gene sequences. The availability of this genome sequence will advance studies on various aspects of M. haemolytica biology in Africa and around the world.
authors: Kidanemariam Gelaw, A.;Bihon, W.;Faranani, R.;Mafofo, J.;Rees, J.;Madoroba, E.

title: Genetic variability in hepatitis B virus
abstract: In 1988 it was reported that the complete nucleotide sequences of 18 strains of hepatitis B virus (HBV) were divided into four genetic groups (A to D) with more than 8% variation between groups. This classification of strains based on genome sequence has since proven to be an important tool in understanding HBV epidemiology and evolution and has been expanded to include three additional genotypes. In parallel to the HBV genotypes described in humans, HBV strains isolated from various primates and hepadnaviruses occurring in woodchucks, ground squirrels, ducks and herons were examined. Sequence differences between HBV genotypes can result in structural differences at the pregenome level and also dramatic differences at the translational level when specific and common mutations occur. There is growing evidence that the clinical picture, response to treatment and long-term prognosis may differ depending on which genotype infected the patient. Therefore, consideration of conventional serological patterns in a patient must take into account the genotype of the infecting strain. Nucleotide variability between HBV strains has been used in several studies to follow transmission pathways, and as it becomes increasingly clear that the differences between HBV genotypes are important, the need for reliable and simple methods for differentiating HBV genotypes has arisen. This review summarizes the knowledge of HBV genotypes in terms of their genetic, structural and clinically significant differences and their origin and evolution in the context of hepadnaviruses in general.
authors: Kidd-Ljunggren, K.;Miyakawa, Y.;Kidd, A. H.

title: Identification of plant protein kinases in response to abiotic and biotic stress using superSAGE
abstract: Plants are stationary organisms that are exposed to many environmental influences. To survive, they must perceive and respond to biotic and abiotic stress efficiently. Protein kinases are essential for the perception of environmental stimuli and trigger signaling cascades. Kinases are among the largest and most important gene families for biotechnology purposes and pose many challenges for bioinformaticians due to the combination of conserved domains alongside diversified regions. Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp.] is an important legume crop adapted to different agroclimatic conditions such as drought, humidity and different temperatures. For this culture, coupling the SuperSAGE method with high-throughput sequencing technology would generate reliable transcriptome profiles with millions of tags counted and statistically analyzed. An approach to assess biotic and abiotic stress was performed, generating over 13 million cowpea SuperSAGE tags extracted from leaves/roots of plants under abiotic (mechanical injury and salinity) or biotic (CABMV, cowpea aphid mosaic virus) stress were available. The annotation and identification of tags linked by BlastN to previously well-characterized ESTs enabled subsequent identification of kinases. The annotation efficiency depended on the database used, with the KEGG proving to be a good source for annotated ESTs, especially when supplemented with independent geneontological categorization as well as the gene index using selected species. The use of different approaches allowed the identification of 1,350 kinase candidates considering biotic libraries and 2,268 regarding abiotic libraries, based on a combination of appropriate descriptions and GO terms. Additional searches of kinase-specific databases allowed the identification of a relatively small number of additional kinases, revealing the paucity of kinase databases for non-model organisms, particularly plants. Regarding the kinase families, a total of 713 potential kinases were divided into 13 families of the CMGC and STE groups. Regarding the differentially expressed kinases, 169 of the 713 potential kinases were identified (p<0.05), 100 up- and 69 down-regulated when comparing different libraries, allowing the generation of a comprehensive panel of differentially expressed kinases under biotic and abiotic stress in a non- Model plant like cowpea. © 2011 Bentham Science Publishers.
authors: Kido, E. A.;de AraÃºjo Barbosa, P. K.;Neto, J. R. C. F.;Pandolfi, V.;Houllou-Kido, L. M.;Crovella, S.;Molina, C.;Kahl, G.;Benko-Iseppon, A. M.

title: Predicting the global spread of H5N1 avian influenza
abstract: The spread of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza in Asia, Europe and Africa is having an enormous impact on the poultry industry and poses a significant threat to human health. The ways in which the virus has spread and will spread between countries have been discussed at length, still need to be analyzed comprehensively and quantitatively. We integrated data on phylogenetic relationships of virus isolates, migratory bird movements, and trade in poultry and wild birds to determine the pathway for 52 individual introduction events into countries and predict future spread. We show that 9 out of 21 H5N1 introductions to Asian countries were most likely from poultry and 3 out of 21 were most likely from migratory birds. In contrast, dispersal to most (20/23) countries of Europe was most likely by migratory birds. Distribution in Africa was probably partly by fowl (2/8 introductions) and partly by migratory birds (3/8). Our analyzes predict that H5N1 is more likely to be introduced to the mainland by infected poultry in the Western Hemisphere and subsequent movements of migratory birds from neighboring countries to the United States than from eastern Siberia. These results underscore the potential synergies between trade and wildlife movements in the emergence and pandemic spread of pathogens and demonstrate the value of predictive models for disease control. © 2006 by the US National Academy of Sciences.
authors: Kilpatrick, A. M.;Chmura, A. A.;Gibbons, D. W.;Fleischer, R. C.;Marra, P. P.;Daszak, P.

title: Characterization of a complete genome of a circular single-stranded DNA virus from pig feces in Korea
abstract: Circular single-stranded porcine DNA viruses have just been identified in porcine feces in Korea. This virus has been mentioned as a bovine stool-associated circular DNA virus (BoSCV)-like virus discovered from pig feces. However, the thorough properties of the virus have not been identified. Therefore, this research focuses on finding a complete genome sequence and analyzing the genetic characteristics of the virus. The virus, now called Porcine Stool-associated Circular DNA Virus (PoSCV Kor) in Korea, consists of 2,589 bases that form a circular structure. It has two major ORFs encoding replicase and capsid protein inversely, with each stem-loop structure lying between the 5' and 3' ends of the two putative ORFs. These properties are the same as PoSCV in New Zealand, but differ from chimpanzee stool-associated circular viruses (ChiSCVs) and BoSCV, which have a stem-loop structure. Therefore, it would be certain that PoSCV Kor is very similar to PoSCV in terms of genetic aspect; the same number of nucleotide bases and amino acid identity of replicase and capsid proteins (96 and 93%, respectively). This fact could be confirmed by finding that PoSCV Kor and PoSCV are in the same cluster by phylogenetic analysis based on comparison with full sequences of other circular ssDNA viruses.
authors: Kim, A. R.;Chung, H. C.;Kim, H. K.;Kim, E. O.;Nguyen, V. G.;Choi, M. G.;Yang, H. J.;Kim, J. A.;Park, B. K.

title: Detection of bat coronaviruses similar to severe acute respiratory syndrome, Middle East respiratory syndrome and group H rotavirus in feces of Korean bats
abstract: Bat species around the world have recently been recognized as the main reservoir of several zoonotic viruses such as In this study, consensus primer-based reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reactions (RT-PCRs) and high-throughput sequencing were performed to examine viruses in bat faecal samples collected from July to December 2015 at 11 natural bat habitats in Korea. Various coronaviruses have been detected for the first time in the feces of Korean bats, including alphacoronaviruses, SARS-CoV-like and MERS-CoV-like betacoronaviruses. In addition, we have identified a new bat rotavirus belonging to group H rotavirus, previously only described in humans and pigs. Therefore, our results indicate the need for continuous surveillance and additional virological studies in house bats.
authors: Kim, H. K.;Yoon, S. W.;Kim, D. J.;Koo, B. S.;Noh, J. Y.;Kim, J. H.;Choi, Y. G.;Na, W.;Chang, K. T.;Song, D.;Jeong, D. G.

title: H5N1 subtype, highly pathogenic avian influenza virus isolated from healthy mallard duck captured in South Korea
abstract: On December 7, 2010, the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus was isolated from a healthy mallard duck caught on the Mankyung River in South Korea. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that this virus was classified in clade 2.3.2 and is closely related to H5N1 viruses isolated from wild birds in Mongolia, Russia and China in 2009 and 2010. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kim, B. S.;Bae, Y. C.;Moon, O. K.;Oem, J. K.;Kang, H. M.;Choi, J. G.;Lee, O. S.;Lee, Y. J.

title: Molecular characterization of infectious chicken anemia viruses detected in breeding and broiler chickens in South Korea
abstract: In South Korea, 32 sequences of the Chicken Infectious Anemia Virus (CIAV) from different flocks of breeding and productive chickens were genetically characterized for the first time. Phylogenetic analysis of the viral protein 1 gene, including a hypervariable region of the CIAV genome, showed that Korean CIAV strains were divided into Groups II, IIIa and IIIb. Strains were commonly identified in great-grandparents' and grandparents' breeding farms, as well as in commercial chicken farms. In the field, breeder farm CIAV strains showed no clinical effects, but commercial farm strains have been associated with depression, growth retardation, and anemia regardless of the group from which the strains originated. In addition, we identified 7 CIAV genomes that were similar to vaccine strains from vaccinated and non-vaccinated breeding herds. These data suggest that further studies on the pathogenicity and efficacy of the vaccine against the different CIAV groups are needed, along with continuous CIAV surveillance and genetic analysis in breeding herds. © 2010 Poultry Science Association Inc.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kwon, Y. K.;Bae, Y. C.;Oem, J. K.;Lee, O. S.

title: Characterization of outbreaks of avian encephalomyelitis in South Korea from 2006 to 2013
abstract: This study was conducted to characterize avian encephalomyelitis (AE) viruses originating from different flocks of breeding chickens and commercial chickens in South Korea. Young chickens less than 4 weeks old showing neurological signs were diagnosed between 2006 and 2011 as typical AE infection. The phylogenetic analysis of viral protein 2 genes of AE viruses showed that all tested AE field viruses were genetically similar to the vaccine strain [Calnek 1143]. In the embryo inoculation test via the yolk sac, only a field strain and a commercial vaccine were embryo-adapted. The results showed that the AE outbreaks in South Korea were caused by strains genetically similar to the vaccine strain, indicating the possibility of vaccine degradation or persistence in the chicken population.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kwon, Y. K.;Lee, H. S.

title: Ostrich (Struthio camelus) infected with the highly pathogenic H5N8 avian influenza virus in South Korea in 2014
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) of subtype H5N8 was isolated from a young ostrich in South Korea in March 2014. Clinical symptoms characterized by anorexia, depression and signs of nervousness were observed. The isolated virus A/Strauss/Korea/H829/2014 (H5N8) had a cleavage site motif containing several basic amino acids typical of the HPAI virus. The pedigree of the hemagglutinin gene of H5-HPAI virus showed that this ostrich H5N8 virus belongs to clade 2.3.4.4 viruses along with H5N8 strains isolated from ducks and wild birds in South Korea in 2014. Pathologic reddening of the pancreas, spleen enlargement and hemorrhage, fragility of the brain, and hydropericardium were prominently found. Histological legions were observed in pancreas, spleen, liver, lung, heart and brain, and influenza A nucleoproteins were detected in the same organs by immunohistochemistry. Other ostriches kept together in open camps were not infected with HPAI virus based on the serological and virological tests. The results indicate that ostriches are susceptible to the H5N8 HPAI virus, but this virus does not spread efficiently among ratites.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kwon, Y. K.;Lee, Y. J.;Kang, H. M.;Lee, E. K.;Song, B. M.;Jung, S. C.;Lee, K. H.;Lee, H. K.;Baek, K. H.;Bae, Y. C.

title: Identification of a picornavirus from chickens with transmissible viral proventriculitis using metagenomic analysis
abstract: Transmissible viral proventriculitis (TVP), an infectious disease affecting chickens, is responsible for economic losses in the commercial poultry industry. However, the main etiological agent is unknown. Using metagenomics, we compared viral diversity in proventriculus samples from herds diagnosed with TVP to healthy herds in South Korea between 2003 and 2012. Each sample had a mean of 21,538,726 sequence reads determined by high-throughput Sequencing were generated, with a mean length of 160 nt. Enrichment of viral sequences indicated that at least three viruses were present in each TVP sample. Although we could not identify a causative agent of TVP that matched the known morphology, picornavirus sequences were present in all five disease samples, suggesting an association with TVP. The five samples yielded 1045-1720 bp contigs with 81-84% nt sequence identity to turkey hepatitis virus (accession number: HM751199). Whole genome analysis showed that the novel picornavirus QIA01 strain was similar to turkey hepatitis virus in the P2 and P3 regions (82.7% nt and 95.5% aa sequence identity), but differed in the structural region and partial 2A peptides (56.2% nt and 23.9% aa sequence identity). In addition, QIA01 virus was similar (87.0% nt and 95.6% aa sequence identity) to chicken Megrivirus, which was recently detected in chickens with malabsorption syndrome in Hungary. Our results are useful to understand the genetic diversity of avian picornaviruses and to classify chicken megrivirus as a pathogen affecting the digestive tract of chickens.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Yoon, S. J.;Lee, H. S.;Kwon, Y. K.

title: Characterization and phylogenetic analysis of varicella zoster virus strains isolated from Korean patients
abstract: The varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a causative agent of chickenpox in primary infection and shingles after its reactivation from the latency period. Complete or nearly complete genomic DNA sequences for various VZV strains have been reported. Recently, clinical VZV strains have been isolated from Korean patients whose genomes have been sequenced using high-throughput sequencing technology. In this study, we analyzed the single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) of VZV strains to genetically characterize Korean clinical isolates. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that three Korean strains, YC01, YC02, and YC03, were linked to clade 2. Extensive SNP analysis identified 86 sites specific to the 5 VZV clades. VZV strains isolated from Korea did not form a phylogenetic cluster. Rather, YC02 and YC03 clustered strongly with the Chinese tribe 84-7 within clade 2, more specifically cluster 2a. Signature sequences for cluster 2a were identified and found to play an important role in separating cluster 2a strains from other clade 2 strains as demonstrated in substitution studies. Further genetic analysis with additional strains isolated from Japan, China and other Asian countries would provide new insight into the importance of two distinct subclades within clan 2.
authors: Kim, M. H.;Jeon, J. S.;Kim, I. K.;Park, J. S.;Park, H.;Shin, O. S.;Lee, C. H.

title: Efficient Selection of Antibodies Responding to Homologous Epitopes on Human and Mouse Hepatocyte Growth Factors by Next-Generation Sequencing-Based Analysis of the B-Cell Repertoire
abstract: YYB-101 is a humanized rabbit anti-human hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) neutralizing antibody currently in clinical investigation. To test the effect of HGF neutralization with antibodies on anti-cancer T cell immunity, we generated surrogate antibodies reactive with the mouse homologue of the epitope targeted by YYB-101. First, we immunized a chicken with human HGF and monitored changes in the B cell repertoire by next generation sequencing (NGS). We then extracted the VH gene repertoire from the NGS data, clustered it into components according to sequence homology, and classified the components according to the change in the number of unique VH sequences and the frequency of VH sequences within each component after immunization. These changes should accompany the preferential proliferation and somatic hypermutation or gene conversion of B cells encoding HGF-reactive antibodies. One component showed significant increases in the number and frequency of unique VH sequences and harbored genes encoding human HGF-responsive antibodies that competed with YYB-101 for HGF binding. Some of the antibodies also reacted to mouse HGF. The selected VH sequences shared 98.3% identity and 98.9% amino acid similarity. It is therefore likely that the antibodies they encode all respond to the epitope targeted by YYB-101.
authors: Kim, S.;Lee, H.;Noh, J.;Lee, Y.;Han, H.;Yoo, D. K.;Kim, H.;Kwon, S.;Chung, J.

title: The prevalence and genetic characteristics of porcine circovirus types 2 and 3 in Korea
abstract: BACKGROUND: Porcine circovirus-associated diseases (PCVAD), caused by porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2), are threatening the swine industry worldwide. Five genotypes of PCV2 have recently been identified: PCV2a, PCV2b, PCV2c, PCV2d and PCV2e. In addition, a novel porcine circovirus was identified from a case of a sow with dermatitis, nephropathy syndrome and reproductive disorders based on metagenomic analysis and classified as porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3). Therefore, the current study was conducted to determine the prevalence and genetic properties of PCV2 and PCV3 in clinical samples. RESULTS: A total of 471 specimens (161 lung and lymph node tissue samples from 34 sites and 310 serum samples from 47 sites) were tested for PCV2. Among them, 171 samples from 59 PCV2 positive farms were genotyped. An additional 690 specimens (296 lung and lymph node tissue specimens from 91 sites, 108 aborted fetal specimens from 26 sites and 286 serum samples from 47 sites) were tested for PCV3. Based on the results of PCV2 genotyping, PCV2d was the most common genotype (107 out of 171 samples) and co-infections with combinations of PCV2a, 2b and 2d were identified in 48 samples from 17 farms. A total of 14 samples from 11 farms were also positive for both PCV2 and PCV3. For PCV3, 57 samples (9.8%) from 32 farms (23.2%) were positive. Of the 108 aborted fetuses from 26 farms, only 2 samples were positive for PCV3. Based on sequence comparisons, PCV2d shares 89.6-91.0% and 93.2-94.3% homology with PCV2a and PCV2b, respectively; 98.6-100% homology is shared by the PCV2d strains. The PCV3 strains identified in this study show 98.0-99.5% homology. CONCLUSIONS: Our study concludes that PCV2d has become the predominant genotype in Korea. PCV3 has also been identified in clinical specimens, although no significant association with clinical symptoms was observed in PCV3 positive cases.
authors: Kim, S. C.;Nazki, S.;Kwon, S.;Juhng, J. H.;Mun, K. H.;Jeon, D. Y.;Jeong, C. G.;Khatun, A.;Kang, S. J.;Kim, W. I.

title: Complete genome sequence of a novel Newcastle disease virus: Strain isolated from a chicken in West Africa
abstract: The full genome sequence of an African Newcastle disease (NDV) virus strain isolated from a chicken in Togo in 2009 has been determined. The genome is 15,198 nucleotides (nt) long and is classified in genotype VII in the class II cluster. Compared to conventional vaccine strains, the African strain contains a previously described 6-nt insert in the downstream untranslated region of the N gene and a new 6-nt insert in the HN-L intergenic region. Differences in genome length are a marker for the natural history of NDV. This is the first description of a class II NDV strain with a 15,198 nt genome and a 6 nt insert in the HN-L intergenic region. The sequence divergence compared to vaccine strains was significant, likely a contributor to outbreaks, and illustrates the continued development of new NDV strains in West Africa. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Kim, S. H.;Nayak, S.;Paldurai, A.;Nayak, B.;Samuel, A.;Aplogan, G. L.;Awoume, K. A.;Webby, R. J.;Ducatez, M. F.;Collins, P. L.;Samal, S. K.

title: Genetic diversity and pathogenic potential of low pathogenic H7 avian influenza viruses isolated from wild migratory birds in Korea
abstract: To detect the circulation of H7 avian influenza viruses, we characterized H7 viruses found in migratory birds and live poultry markets of South Korea from 2005 to 2014. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all viruses clustered in the Eurasian lineage of H7 avian viruses, at least 12 different genotypes were represented. Most H7 viruses contained at least one gene segment of the highly pathogenic A/Sck/Hong Kong/YU100/02(H5N1)-like avian virus, and they could be divided into at least two antigenic groups. Although we did not detect any genetically identical strains, the HI test showed close cross-reactivity of some isolates with the H7N9 viruses from China. Animal experiments showed that most genotypes could replicate in the lungs of mice and chickens without prior adaptation and some, particularly the subtypes H7N4 and H7N7, caused mortality in mice. These findings add to the growing concerns about a pandemic related to the recent H7 viruses and underscore the importance of continuous surveillance of avian influenza viruses in the wild.
authors: Kim, Y. I.;Kim, S. W.;Si, Y. J.;Kwon, H. I.;Park, S. J.;Kim, E. H.;Kim, S. M.;Lee, I. W.;Song, M. S.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Genetic and phylogenetic characterizations of a novel genotype of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 viruses 2016/2017 in South Korea
abstract: During the 2016 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N6 viruses in South Korea, novel H5N8 viruses were also isolated from migratory birds. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the HA gene of these H5N8 viruses belonged to clade 2.3.4.4, similar to the newer H5Nx viruses, and descended from A/Brk/Korea/Gochang1/14(H5N8), a tributary of H5N8, which appeared in 2014 and then disappeared. At least four reassortment events occurred in different subtypes (H5N8, H7N7, H3N8 and H10N7) and a challenge study in chickens showed that they were classified as HPAI viruses according to the OIE criteria.
authors: Kim, Y. I.;Park, S. J.;Kwon, H. I.;Kim, E. H.;Si, Y. J.;Jeong, J. H.;Lee, I. W.;Nguyen, H. D.;Kwon, J. J.;Choi, W. S.;Song, M. S.;Kim, C. J.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Foot and Mouth Disease Virus: A Review
abstract: Foot and mouth disease has long been a major animal health nuisance but is now almost a thing of the past, at least in Europe. The effective, but expensive and not entirely harmless vaccination was discontinued in 1991 in all countries of the European Union. However, research on this virus, one of the most studied viruses, both in the field of basic virology and animal health, continues to bring new data on still little-known aspects of its biology such as cell penetration, RNA translation, replication and capsid assembly. These different aspects are checked. The development of biotechnology has allowed the rise of new vaccines, if not more efficient, but at least fully secured.
