The intrinsic mutational properties of this virus still pose a major challenge to its complete eradication.
authors: Kim, Y. J.;Remond, M.

title: Analysis of the diversity and evolution of rotavirus species, including the newly determined full-length genome sequences of rotavirus F and G
abstract: Rotaviruses are a major cause of viral acute gastroenteritis in humans and animals. Eight distinct rotavirus (AH) species have been defined based on antigenicity and nucleotide sequence identities of the VP6 gene. The first complete genome sequences of rotavirus F (strain 03V0568) and G (strain 03V0567) with lengths of 18,341 and 18,186 bp, respectively, are described here. Both viruses have open reading frames for the rotavirus proteins VP1 to VP7 and NSP1 to NSP5 located at the 11 genome segments. Nucleotide sequence identities with other rotaviruses ranged from 29.8% (NSP1 gene) to 61.7% (VPI gene) for rotavirus F and from 29.3% (NSP1-2 gene) to 65.9% (NSP2 gene ) for rotavirus G, confirming their classification as separate virus species. Encoded proteins showed remarkable sequence differences between rotavirus species. In contrast, the 5'-terminal non-coding sequences of genomic segments are highly conserved among all rotavirus species. Different 3'-terminal consensus sequences are found between rotavirus A/D/F, rotavirus C and rotavirus B/G/H. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed a segregation of rotaviruses into two major clades consisting of rotavirus A/C/D/F and rotavirus B/G/H. Within these clades, rotavirus F mainly grouped with rotavirus D and rotavirus G with rotavirus B. In addition, differentiation between mammalian and avian rotavirus A strains, host-specific evolution of rotavirus B and C, and an ancient reassortment event between avian rotavirus A and D are given by the phylogenetic data. These results underscore the high diversity of rotaviruses as a result of a complex evolutionary history. (C) 2012 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kindler, E.;Trojnar, E.;Heckel, G.;Otto, P. H.;Johne, R.

title: Investigating the intra-host and intra-herd sequence diversity of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Because of the poor fidelity of the enzymes involved in RNA genome replication, foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus samples contain unique polymorphic populations. In this study, deep sequencing was used to characterize the diversity of FMD virus (FMD) populations in 6 infected cattle present on a single farm during the 2007 UK outbreak series. A novel RT-PCR method was developed to amplify a 7.6 kb nucleotide fragment encompassing the polyprotein-coding region of the FMDV genome. Illumina sequencing of each sample identified the subtle polymorphic structures at each nucleotide position, ranging from consensus-level changes to variants present at a frequency of 0.24%. These data were used to study FMD population dynamics at both the herd and host levels, to assess host effects on virus swarm structure, and to identify transmission links with viruses detected on other farms in the same series of outbreaks. A total of 5 consensus variants were identified in 7 samples from 6 different animals, in addition to 104 sub-consensus variants, 22 of which were shared by 2 or more animals. Further analysis revealed differences in the swarm structures of samples collected from the same animal, suggesting the presence of different virus populations developing independently at different lesion sites within the same infected animal.
authors: King, D. J.;Freimanis, G. L.;Orton, R. J.;Waters, R. A.;Haydon, D. T.;King, D. P.

title: Rapid serotyping of infectious bronchitis virus isolates using the hemagglutination inhibition test
abstract: The hemagglutination inhibition (HI) test was evaluated as a method for typing recent isolates of suspected infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). Hemagglutination (HA) antigen was prepared from each isolate by phospholipase C treatment of virus concentrated from allanto-amniotic fluids of infected chick embryos. A HI test was performed with the HA antigen of each isolate against a battery of 17 antisera raised against different IBV strains classified by virus neutralization (VN). The HI test identified Ark 99 and Holland isolates similar to strains previously classified by VN. Two isolates included in this study were not inhibited by any of the reference antisera and therefore appeared to be antigenically distinct. The isolates were also evaluated by VN and the results of the VN and HI methods were consistent. Therefore, the results suggest that the HI test may be useful for rapid, presumptive identification of new IBV isolates.
authors: King, D. J.;Hopkins, S. R.

title: Improved bioinformatic profiling of VIDISCA libraries for virus detection and discovery
abstract: VIDISCA is a next-generation sequencing (NGS) library preparation method designed to enrich for viral nucleic acids from samples before performing high-multiplex, low-depth sequencing. Reliable detection of known viruses and discovery of novel divergent viruses from NGS data requires specialized analysis tools that are both sensitive and accurate. Existing software was used to design a new bioinformatics workflow for high-throughput virus detection and discovery from VIDISCA data. The workflow leverages the molecular biology of VIDISCA library preparation, specifically the use of the Mse1 restriction enzyme, which produces biologically replicated library inserts from identical genomes. The workflow performs a full metagenomic analysis to classify non-viral sequences including parasite and host, and performs virus-specific analyzes separately. The ribosomal RNA sequence is removed to increase downstream analysis speed and remaining reads are clustered at 100% identity. Known and new viruses are sensitively detected by comparison to a virus-only protein database and false positives are removed. A new cluster profiling analysis takes advantage of the viral biological replicates produced by Mse1 digestion and uses read clustering to characterize the presence of short genomes at very high copy number. Importantly, this analysis ensures that highly repeated sequences are identified even when no homology is detected, as demonstrated here with detection of a novel gokushovirus genome from human feces. The workflow was validated using reading data obtained from serum and fecal samples from HIV-1 positive adults and serum samples from pigs infected with the atypical porcine pestivirus.
authors: Kinsella, C. M.;Deijs, M.;van der Hoek, L.

title: The genome structure of a new chicken virus identifies it as a parvovirus
abstract: The nucleic acid from chicken parvovirus-like particles showed sensitivity to DNase and S1 nuclease treatment and resistance to RNase digestion. Viral DNA readily served as a template for self-primed conversion in vitro to a double-stranded form of approximately 5200 base pairs. There was no evidence of encapsulation of opposite polarity strands. These findings support the taxonomic classification of chicken parvovirus-like particles as avian parvovirus type 1 within the parvovirus genus Parvoviridae.
authors: Kisary, J.;Avalosse, B.;Miller-Faures, A.;Rommelaere, J.

title: Recent findings on the review article on Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus
abstract: The genus Pestivirus is one of the most intensively studied groups of animal viruses. Detailed studies of pestiviruses also necessitate reclassification of the genus. The recent study summarized the latest knowledge on bovine diarrhea virus (BVDV). Current taxonomic issues were also discussed, namely the two BVDV genotypes and the new, host-independent classification of pestiviruses. The morphological and physical characterization of the virus has not been addressed. Genome structure (Fig.1) Genome organization, proteins that are responsible for the cytopathogenic effect were discussed according to the current state of knowledge. The differences between the two biotypes of BVDV - cytopathogenic (cp, Fig. 2) and non-cytopathogenic (ncp) viruses - have also been discussed, with the classification being based on recombinative events to which the viral genome is exposed. For now, based on the results of recent research, it appears that the recombinative events of the amino terminus of the p80 non-structural enzyme protein of BVDV (Fig. 3) are mainly responsible for the transformation of ncp BVDV - mainly present in nature - to cp BVDV and thus to the development of mucosal diseases, MD.
authors: Kiss, I.;Kecskemeti, S.

title: Recovery of divergent avian bornaviruses from cases of ventricular dilatation disease: identification of an etiological candidate
abstract: BACKGROUND: Proventricular dilatation disease (PDD) is a deadly disease threatening domestic and wild parrots worldwide. It is characterized by lymphoplasmic infiltration of the ganglia of the central and peripheral nervous system, resulting in central nervous system dysfunction and impaired enteric motility and associated wasting. A viral etiology for PDD has been suspected for nearly 40 years, but to date no etiological drug candidate has been reproducibly linked to the disease. RESULTS: Analysis of 2 PDD case-control series collected independently on different continents using panviral microarray revealed Bornavirus hybridization signature in 62.5% of PDD cases (5/8) and in none of controls (0/8). Ultra high throughput sequencing was used to obtain the complete viral genomic sequence from one of the virus positive PDD cases. A Bornavirus-like genome organization with a high degree of sequence deviation from all previous Bornavirus isolates was found for this pathogen. We propose the name Avian Bornavirus (ABV) for this pathogen. Further specific ABV-PCR analysis of an additional set of independently collected PDD cases and controls revealed a significant difference in ABV detection rate in PDD cases (71%, n=7) compared to controls (0%, n= 14) (P = 0.01 ; Fisher's exact test). A partial sequence analysis of a total of 16 ABV isolates that we have now obtained from these and an additional group of cases reveals at least 5 distinct ABV genetic subgroups. CONCLUSION: These studies clearly demonstrate the existence of an avian reservoir of remarkably diverse Bornaviruses and provide a compelling candidate for the search for an etiological agent of PDD.
authors: Kistler, A. L.;Gancz, A.;Clubb, S.;Skewes-Cox, P.;Fischer, K.;Sorber, K.;Chiu, C. Y.;Lublin, A.;Mechani, S.;Farnoushi, Y.;Greninger, A.;Wen, C. C.;Karlene, S. B.;Ganem, D.;DeRisi, J. L.

title: Sustained circulation of African swine fever virus in Tanzania, 2010–2012
authors: Kitambi, A.;Council, K. D.

title: Current Knowledge on Porcine Circovirus 3 (PCV-3): A novel virus with as yet unknown implications for swine industry auditing
abstract: Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV-3) is a recently described virus belonging to the Circoviridae family. It is the third member of the circovirus genus capable of infecting pigs, along with PCV-1, which is considered non-pathogenic, and PCV-2, one of the most economically relevant viruses for the global swine industry. PCV-3 was originally identified by metagenomic analysis in 2015 in tissues from pigs suffering from swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome, reproductive failure, myocarditis and multisystemic inflammation. The lack of other common pathogens as potential infectious agents of these diseases raised the suspicion that PCV-3 might be etiologically involved in the occurrence of the disease. Subsequently, viral genome was detected in apparently healthy pigs, and retrospective studies showed that PCV-3 was present in pigs as early as the early 1990s. In fact, current evidence suggests that PCV-3 is a fairly widespread virus worldwide. Recently, viral DNA was also found in wild boar, extending the susceptibility to infection in the Suidae family; in addition, the potential reservoir role of this species for the domestic pig has been suggested. Phylogenetic studies using available partial and full PCV-3 sequences from around the world have revealed high nucleotide identity (>96%), although two main groups and several subclusters have also been described. In addition, the existence of a common ancestor, dated to around 50 years ago, has been suggested. Considering the economic importance and known impact of PCV-2 on the swine industry, a new member of the same family as PCV-3 should not be neglected. Studies on epidemiology, pathogenesis, immunity and diagnostics are guaranteed in the coming years. Therefore, this review will update current knowledge and future research trends on PCV-3.
authors: Klaumann, F.;Correa-Fiz, F.;Franzo, G.;Sibila, M.;Nunez, J. I.;Segales, J.

title: Occurrence and phylogenetic analysis of bovine respiratory syncytial virus in respiratory disease outbreaks in Norway
abstract: Bovine respiratory syncytial virus (BRSV) is one of the major pathogens involved in the bovine respiratory disease (BRD) complex. The seroprevalence of BRSV in Norwegian cattle herds is high, but its role in respiratory disease epidemics is unclear. The aim of the study was to investigate the etiological role of BRSV and other respiratory viruses in BRD epidemics and to perform a phylogenetic analysis of Norwegian BRSV strains. BRSV infection was detected either serologically and/or virologically in 18 (86%) of 21 outbreaks and in most cases as a single viral agent. When serology indicated the presence of bovine coronavirus and/or bovine parainfluenza virus 3, the number of BRSV positive animals in the herd was always higher, supporting the view that BRSV is the main pathogen. G-gene sequencing of BRSV-positive specimens showed that the currently circulating Norwegian BRSVs belong to genetic subgroup II along with other northern European isolates. An isolate from an outbreak in Norway in 1976 was also studied. This tribe formed a separate branch in subgroup II, distinctly different from the current Scandinavian sequences. The currently circulating BRSV could be divided into two distinct strains co-occurring in the same geographic area. The sequence variations between the two strains were in an antigenically important part of the G protein. The results showed that BRSV is the main etiological agent of BRD epidemics in Norway and that it often acts as the sole viral agent. Phylogenetic analysis of the Norwegian BRSV strains and several previously published isolates supported the theory of BRSV geographical and temporal aggregation.
authors: Klem, T. B.;Rimstad, E.;Stokstad, M.

title: Reliable classification and recombination analysis of porcine endogenous retroviruses
abstract: Preventing cross-species infection with porcine endogenous retroviruses (PERV) is critical to xenotransplantation. Previous studies have described the potential risk of infection for PERV γ1 subfamilies A, B, and C. Replication competent PERV γ1 proviruses assigned to a specific subfamily and hybrid viruses derived from retroviral recombination events between subfamilies have been observed. Future porcine genome sequencing projects will uncover several novel PERV proviruses from additional breeds and animals. An assessment of these viral genomes must be performed to assess the potential risk of cross-species retroviral infection. In this study, we tested common sequence comparison methods for PERV sequence classification and hybrid clone detection. The examination of the polymorphic nucleotide positions has proven to be the most suitable method. We describe a fast and simple method using bioinformatic software tools that can also be applied to analogous analyzes of other viral genomes. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Klymiuk, N.;Aigner, B.

title: Effects of enteroviruses and parechoviruses on public health
abstract: Enteroviruses (EV) include viruses originally classified into a number of groups based on cell culture replication patterns and clinical manifestations: poliovirus, coxsackievirus A, coxsackievirus B, and ECHOvirus. The closely related genus Parechovirus has recently been implicated in human disease. EVs are common commensals of the human gut that are often found with no adverse effects on the individual but are also associated with a variety of diseases and syndromes including nonspecific skin rashes, hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), conjunctivitis, meningitis and encephalitis, myocarditis and polio. This results in a significant disease burden worldwide, often attributed to a specific EV genotype. An estimated 1 billion people become infected with EV each year.
authors: Knippenberg, B.;Ferson, M. J.

title: serological classification of bovine enteroviruses
abstract: Cross virus neutralization (VN), complement fixation (CF) and immunoprecipitation (IP) assays were used to compare the seven currently recognized bovine enterovirus (BEV) serotypes with seven serologically distinct strains previously isolated in the UK and two other BEV compare to the UK. Based on criteria used to distinguish other human and animal picornavirus serotypes, it was discovered that BEV types 1, 4, 5 and 6 are related and may be contained within a single serotype. Types 3 and 7 turned out to be identical and related to serotype 2. All other nine BEV were contained in either serotype 1 or 2. Not all strains in each serotype were identical and antigenic variants were designated as subtypes. Antigenic relationships not revealed by VN were detected in CF and IP tests. Bovine enterovirus strains whose antisera exhibited the broadest intratypical reactivity were proposed as prototypes. The two proposed BEV serotypes could also be distinguished by their ability to agglutinate erythrocytes. Guinea pig erythrocytes were agglutinated by both serotypes, while sheep red blood cells reacted only with serotype 1.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Barnett, I. T. R.

title: Classification of porcine enteroviruses by antigen analysis and cytopathic effects in tissue culture: description of 3 new serotypes
abstract: Porcine enteroviruses isolated in the UK between 1972 and 1976 were compared to the previously described 8 serotypes and to human coxsackie B virus types 1 to 6 for their ability to grow in different cell lines. This allowed all strains to be classified into 3 broad groups according to the type of cytopathic effect in IBRS-2 cells and further subdivision based on the production of cytopathic effect in BHK 21, HeLa and VERO cells. None of the porcine enterovirus strains were neutralized by antisera to human enteroviruses (Lim Benyesh-Melnick pools), with the exception of swine vesicular disease virus, which was neutralized by Coxsackie B5 antiserum. Antisera raised in either gnotobiotic pigs or in guinea pigs against the 8 porcine enterovirus serotypes failed to neutralize 9 isolates, which could be classified into 3 new serotypes for which nos. 9, 10 and 11 are proposed. Guinea pig sera could be used as an alternative to gnotobiotic swine sera for type differentiation.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Buckley, L. S.;Pereira, H. G.

title: A study of antigenic variants of foot-and-mouth disease virus by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of their structural polypeptides
abstract: Twenty-nine strains of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) type A virus, previously serologically classified as distinct subtypes, were analyzed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) to determine the extent of variation in the pattern of structural polypeptides and to evaluate the technique as an aid to existing subtyping techniques. The majority of the subtypes examined had different polypeptide patterns, however, some variation between strains within a subtype also occurred. The position of VP2(1B) and VP3(1C) was unchanged in different strains within a subtype and between geographically related subtypes, often over long periods of time. Changes in the position of VP1(1D) were also observed within a subtype. The technique was considered valuable in screening isolates prior to conventional serological methods and in tracing the possible origin of foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Hedger, R. S.

title: VP1 sequencing protocol for the molecular epidemiology of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Nucleotide sequences of field strains of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) contribute to our understanding of the distribution and evolution of viral lineages circulating in different regions of the world. This paper outlines a practical reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and sequencing strategy that can be used to generate RNA sequences encoding the VP1 (1D) region of FMDV. The protocol includes a set of PCR and sequencing primers that can be chosen to characterize genetically diverse isolates representing all seven FMD serotypes. A list of sequences is also provided that includes prototype sequences for all proposed FMDV topotypes to provide a framework for phylogenetic analysis. The technical details and prototype sequences provided in this document can be used by FMD reference laboratories and others in an approach to harmonize the molecular epidemiology of FMD.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Wadsworth, J.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;King, D. P.

title: A porcine enterovirus G associated with enteric disease contains a novel papain-like cysteine protease
abstract: Identification of unknown pathogens in pigs with enteric disease is difficult due to the wide variety of bacterial and viral species found in fecal samples. Current methods often require isolation of bacteria or viruses, or testing only a limited number of known species using quantitative PCR analysis. Herein, feces from two 25-day-old piglets with diarrhea from Texas, USA, were analyzed by next-generation metagenomic sequencing to rapidly identify potential pathogens. Our analysis included a bioinformatics pipeline for rapid short-read classification and de novo genome assembly, which led to the identification of a porcine enterovirus G (EV-G), a complete genome with significant nucleotide differences (>30%) between current sequences and a novel nonstructural protein that is similar in sequence to the torovirus papain-like cysteine protease (PLpro). This discovery led to the identification and proliferation of an EV-G with a novel PLpro in the US that had not previously been reported.
authors: Knutson, T. P.;Velayudhan, B. T.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Gentian Mosaic Virus: A new species in the genus Fabavirus
abstract: SUMMARY A viral isolate, designated N-1, obtained from a gentian plant (Gentiana scabra) exhibiting mosaic-like symptoms was mechanically transmitted to nine plant species in six families. These plants are known to be hosts of fabaviruses. The N-1 isolate consisted of isometric particles, 30 nm in diameter, and contained two RNA molecules of approximately 6.0 and 3.6 kb in length, as estimated by agarose gel electrophoresis. The RNAs were encapsulated separately in two of the three particle types. Each particle contained two different proteins with Mr values of 39.3 x 10(3) and 26.6 x 10(3) as determined by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Analysis of complete nucleotide sequences of the RNAs indicated that each encoded a single large polyprotein in which putative functional proteins were arranged in a manner similar to that in broad bean wilt virus 1 (BBWV-1) and broad bean wilt virus 2 (BBWV-2), which are members of the genus Fabavirus (family Comoviridae). Analysis of the deduced amino acid sequences of the proteins showed that those from isolate N-1 shared 38 to 66% identity with those of BBWV-1 and BBWV-2, but only 16 to 42% identity with those of a comovirus, cowpea mosaic virus. Phylogenetic analysis based on RNA polymerase amino acid sequences placed isolate N-1 in a separate lineage from BBWV-1 and BBWV-2. In the indirect enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, isolate N-1 showed a distant serological relationship to BBWV-1, BBWV-2, and the mild Lamium mosaic virus, another fabavirus. Our results suggest that N-1 represents a new type of fabavirus. We propose the name gentian mosaic virus for this new species.
authors: Kobayashi, Y. O.;Kobayashi, A.;Hagiwara, K.;Uga, H.;Mikoshiba, Y.;Naito, T.;Honda, Y.;Omura, T.

title: Bovine Diarrhea Virus: ein Update
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a pathogen of cattle, a member of the family Flaviviridae, genus Pestivirus, which also includes classical swine fever virus (CSFV or porcine choleravirus) and ovine border disease virus (BDV). It causes significant economic losses, mainly associated with reproductive disorders. Pestiviruses are small enveloped viruses about 40 nm in diameter. The nucleocapsid is probably icosahedral. The genome consists of a single-stranded positive RNA encoding approximately 430 kD protein product. Gene expression consists of the synthesis of a polyprotein that is processed co- and post-translationally. According to its behavior "in vitro" two biotypes can be distinguished: non-cytopathic (ncp) and cytopathic (cp), most likely derived from ncp by mutations and/or recombination. BVDV can cross the placenta and infect the fetus, causing a variety of problems from fetal death to the birth of a persistently infected (P) calf, depending on the age of the fetus at the time of infection. PI animals are immunotolerant to the virus and shed it in all secretions. Only the ncp biotype was isolated from PI animals. Superinfection of a PI animal with a cp strain causes mucosal disease, which is always fatal. Since 1993, outbreaks of a serious, sometimes hemorrhagic disease caused by ncp BVDV have occurred in Canada and the United States. Genomic and serological differences between the "traditional" strains and the viruses isolated from these outbreaks led to the subdivision of BVDV into subtypes I and II, both including cp and ncp strains. Analyzes of the 5'-UTR non-coding zone of the genome of pestiviruses from different species (bovine, ovine, porcine) suggest that there are at least 3 genotypes within the genus. A new classification of these viruses based on genomic sequence rather than species of origin has been proposed. Genomic heterogeneity exists in the BVDV genome, which has 3 hypervariable zones, 2 of them in the major neutralizing protein. In Argentina, the prevalence of BVDV antibodies in the cattle population is 70% and the prevalence of persistent infections is about 1%.
authors: Kobrak, A.;Weber, E. L.

title: Influenza A viruses isolated from migratory ducks in Oklahoma
abstract: Nine type A influenza viruses were isolated from migratory and wintering ducks in Oklahoma in 1976-77. The antigenic classification of the isolated viruses resulted in three different subtypes: Hav1 Nav2, Hws N1 and Hav6 N2. No transmission of influenza viruses from wild ducks to sentinel birds (McGraw mallards) on the same lakes was found.
authors: Kocan, A. A.;Hinshaw, V. S.;Daubney, G. A.

title: Genomic comparison of bovine papillomavirus 1 isolates from bovine, equine, and asinine lesion tissue samples
abstract: Several attempts have been made to categorize equine and bovine specific bovine papillomavirus 1 (BPV1) isolates based on sequence tags. This study includes newly determined sequence information from 33 BPV1 isolates from horses, asinins and bovines and examines sequence biases due to host species. Twenty of the viral genomes were sequenced over their entire length and a further thirteen were sequenced, including flanking sequences, at two specific sites, the LCR and the E5 ORF. Alignment and analysis of the sequences revealed no statistically significant spatial differences between the bovine and equine sequences. None of the proposed points of divergence noted by other authors had significant species-specific features. Our results indicate that BPV1 is shared between horses, asinins and cattle and that virus transmission between cattle and equidae is a repeated and ongoing phenomenon.
authors: Koch, C.;Ramsauer, A. S.;Drogemuller, M.;Ackermann, M.;Gerber, V.;Tobler, K.

title: Metagenomics-Driven Virome: Current Techniques and New Additions
authors: Kohl, C.;Nitsche, A.;Kurth, A.

title: Using RNALater® Conservation for Virome Sequencing in Outbreak Situations
authors: Kohl, C.;Wegener, M.;Nitsche, A.;Kurth, A.

title: Phylogenetic and recombination analysis of the herpesvirus of the genus Varicellovirus
abstract: BACKGROUND: The varicelloviruses comprise a genus within the alphaherpesvirus subfamily and infect both humans and other mammals. Recently, next-generation sequencing has been used to generate genomic sequences of several members of the varicellovirus genus. Here, currently available varicellovirus genome sequences were used for phylogenetic, recombination, and genetic distance analyses. RESULTS: A phylogenetic network encompassing genomic sequences of individual species was generated and suggested a possible restriction between ungulate and non-ungulate viruses. Genetic distances within species were higher for ungulate viruses (pseudorabiesvirus (SuHV-1) 1.65%, bovine herpesvirus type 1 (BHV-1) 0.81%, equine herpesvirus type 1 (EHV-1) 0.79%, equine herpesvirus type). 4 (EHV-4) 0.16%) as non-ungulate viruses (feline herpesvirus type 1 (FHV-1) 0.0089%, canine herpesvirus type 1 (CHV-1) 0.005%, varicella zoster virus (VZV) 0.136% ). The G+C content of the ungulate viruses was also higher (SuHV-1 73.6%, BHV-1 72.6%, EHV-1 56.6%, EHV-4 50.5%) compared to the non-ungulate viruses ( FHV-1 45.8%, CHV-1 31.6%, VZV 45.8%), suggesting a possible link between G+C content and genetic diversity within the species. Varicellovirus clade nomenclature is variable across species, and we propose standardization based on genomic-genetic distance. A recent study reported no recombination between sequenced FHV-1 strains, however in the present study both split tree, bootscan and PHI analysis indicated recombination. We also found that the recently sequenced Brazilian CHV-1 strain BTU-1 may harbor a genetic signal in the UL50 gene of an unknown varicellovirus. CONCLUSION: Together, the data contribute to a better understanding of varicellovirus genomics, and we also propose a new clade nomenclature scheme based on genetic distances.
authors: Kolb, A. W.;Lewin, A. C.;Moeller Trane, R.;McLellan, G. J.;Brandt, C. R.

title: African swine fever virus, Siberia, Russia, 2017
abstract: African swine fever (ASF) is probably the most dangerous and most widespread swine disease worldwide. ASF is a serious problem for the swine industry. The first ASF case in Russia was reported in 2007. We report an ASF outbreak in Siberia, Russia, in 2017.
authors: Kolbasov, D.;Titov, I.;Tsybanov, S.;Gogin, A.;Malogolovkin, A.

title: Genetic typing of the bovine viral diarrhea virus from Austrian field samples
abstract: Twenty-five bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) positive field samples were typed into the 5' UTR by sequencing of PCR products amplified using universal 324/326 pestivirus primers. All viruses were classified as BVDV-1, no BVDV-2 isolates were identified. Fourteen viruses were typed as BVDV-1f, six viruses as BVDV-1b, four viruses as BVDV-1h and one virus fell into the BVDV-1g group. The comparison of the data presented in this work with data from other BVDV isolates originating from Austria suggests that the BVDV-1f subgenotype is predominant in Austrian cattle herds.
authors: Kolesarova, M.;Franz, S.;Jackova, A.;Vilcek, S.;Mostl, K.;Benetka, V.;Schopf, K.;Schoder, G.;Hofer, J.;Baumgartner, W.

title: The genetic clustering of natural animal isolates, laboratory and vaccine strains of Borna disease virus strongly reflects their regional geographic origin
abstract: The aim of this study was to gain more detailed insights into the genetic evolution and variability of the Borne Disease Virus (BDV). Phylogenetic analyzes were performed on field viruses derived from naturally infected animals, the BDV vaccine strain "Dessau", four widespread laboratory strains and the new BDV subtype No./98. Four regions of the BDV genome were analyzed: the complete p40, p10 and p24 genes and the 5' untranslated region of the X/P transcript. BDV isolates from the same geographic area showed a significantly higher degree of identity to each other than to BDV isolates from other regions, regardless of host species and year of isolation. Five different clusters could be formed within the endemic areas, which correspond to the geographic regions from which the viruses originate: (i) a Swiss, Austrian and Liechtenstein Rhine Valley group, closely related to the geographically adjacent Baden-Württemberg and Bavaria II group (ii) im west of Germany; (iii) a third group, called Group Bavaria I, restricted in occurrence to Bavaria; (iv) a southern Saxony-Anhalt and adjacent northern group of Saxony bound to the territories of those states in the eastern part of Germany; and (v) a mixed group consisting of samples from different areas of Germany; however, these came mainly from the federal states of Thuringia and Lower Saxony. Within these groups, the laboratory strains and the vaccine strain were grouped according to their geographic origin. All field and laboratory strains, as well as the vaccine strain, clearly separated from the recently described and highly divergent BDV strain No./98, which originates from an area in Austria where Borna disease is not endemic.
authors: Kolodziejek, J.;Durrwald, R.;Herzog, S.;Ehrensperger, F.;Lussy, H.;Nowotny, N.

title: West Nile Virus-positive blood donation and subsequent entomological examination, Austria, 2014
abstract: Detection of West Nile Virus (WNV) nucleic acid in a blood donation from Vienna, Austria, and in Culex pipiens pupae and egg rafts collected near the donor's home is reported. Complete genomic sequences of human and mosquito-derived viruses were identified, genetically compared and phylogenetically analyzed. The viruses were not identical but were closely related to each other and to more recent Czech and Italian isolates, suggesting a co-circulation of related WNV strains within a limited geographic area. The detection of WNV in a blood donation from an area with low human WNV prevalence (only three serologically diagnosed cases between 2008 and 2014) is surprising and underscores the importance of WNV nucleic acid testing of blood donations even in such areas of active mosquito surveillance programs.
authors: Kolodziejek, J.;Seidel, B.;Jungbauer, C.;Dimmel, K.;Kolodziejek, M.;Rudolf, I.;HubÃ¡lek, Z.;Allerberger, F.;Nowotny, N.

title: Whole genome analysis of human and bovine G8P-1 rotavirus strains isolated in Nigeria provides evidence for direct interspecies transmission from bovine to humans
abstract: Group A bovine rotavirus (RVA) G8P[1] strains have rarely been detected in humans. Two Nigerian G8P[1] strains, HMG035 (RVA/Human-tc/NGA/HMG035/1999/G8P[1]) and NGRBg8 (RVA/Cow-tc/NGA/NGRBg8/1998/G8P[1]), were previously suggested the VP7, VP4 and NSP1 genes to be of bovine origin. In order to obtain detailed information about the origin and evolution of these G8P[1] strains, the complete nucleotide sequences of the entire genome of the HMG035 and NGRBg8 strains were determined and analyzed in the present study. Analysis of the whole genome revealed that strains HMG035 and NGRBg8 are very closely related in all 11 segments and have a bovine RVA-like genotype constellation (G8-P[1]-I2-R2-C2 -M2-A11- N2-T6-E2-H3). In addition, each of the 11 genes in strains HMG035 and NGRBg8 appeared to be of bovine origin on phylogenetic analysis. Therefore, it was suggested that the HMG035 and NGRBg8 strains derive from a common origin, and the NGRBg8 strain was assumed to represent an example of bovine RVA strains transmitted to humans. Our results provide clear evidence for the direct transmission of RVA strains between cattle and humans.
authors: Komoto, S.;Adah, M. I.;Ide, T.;Yoshikawa, T.;Taniguchi, K.

title: Reassortment of human and animal rotavirus gene segments into novel DS-1-like G1P 8 rotavirus strains
abstract: Recently, the emergence and rapid spread of novel DS-1-like human G1P[8] rotaviruses in Japan has been reported. More recently, such reassortant intergenogroup strains have been identified in Thailand, suggesting the continued spread of unusual rotavirus strains in Asia. During rotavirus surveillance in Thailand, three DS-1-like reassortant intergenogroup strains with G3P[8] (RVA/Human-wt/THA/SKT-281/2013/G3P[8] and RVA/Human-wt/THA /SKT- 289/2013/G3P[8]) and G2P[8] (RVA/Human-wt/THA/LS-04/2013/G2P[8]) genotypes were identified in stool samples from hospitalized children with acute gastroenteritis. In this study, we sequenced and characterized the complete genomes of strains SKT-281, SKT-289 and LS-04. On analysis of the whole genome, all three strains showed unique genotype constellations, including genogroup 1 and 2 genes: G3-P[8]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2 for strains SKT -281 and SKT-289 and G2-P[8]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2 for strain LS-04. With the exception of the G genotype, the unique genotype constellation of the three phyla (P[8]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2) is commonly shared with the DS-1-like G1P[8]. ] Tribes. In the phylogenetic analysis, nine of the 11 genes of strains SKT-281 and SKT-289 (VP4, VP6, VP1-3, NSP1-3, and NSP5) appeared to originate from DS-1-like G1P[8] strains, while the remaining VP7 and NSP4 genes appeared to be equine and bovine, respectively. Thus, strains SKT-281 and SKT-289 appeared to be reassortant strains for DS-1-like G1P[8], animal-derived human and/or animal rotaviruses. On the other hand, seven of the eleven genes of strain LS-04 (VP7, VP6, VP1, VP3, and NSP3-5) appeared to originate from locally circulating DS-1-like G2P[4] rotaviruses, while three were thought to be genes (VP4, VP2 and NSP1) are derived from DS-1-like G1P[8] strains. Notably, the remaining NSP2 gene of strain LS-04 appeared to be bovine. Therefore, strain LS-04 was assumed to be a multiple reassortment strain for DS-1-like G1P[8], locally circulating DS-1-like G2P[4], bovine-like human and/or bovine rotavirus. Overall, the large genomic diversity among the DS-1-like G1P[8] strains appeared to have been generated by a reassortment with human and animal strains. To our knowledge, this is the first report of whole-genome-based characterization of DS-1-like intergenogroup-like reassortant strains with G3P[8] and G2P[8] genotypes that have emerged in Thailand. Our observations will provide important insights into the evolutionary dynamics of new DS-1-like G1P[8] strains and related reassortants.
authors: Komoto, S.;Tacharoenmuang, R.;Guntapong, R.;Ide, T.;Tsuji, T.;Yoshikawa, T.;Tharmaphornpilas, P.;Sangkitporn, S.;Taniguchi, K.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of H9N2 swine influenza virus from sick pigs in southern China in 2010
abstract: In January 2010, before pigs were infected with foot-and-mouth disease in Guangdong, some pigs showed flu-like symptoms; coughing, sneezing, runny nose and fever. The researchers collected as many nasopharyngeal swabs from all the sick pigs as possible. An H9N2 influenza virus was isolated from the swine population. The full genome of an isolate designated A/Swine/Guangdong/L1/2010(H9N2) was sequenced and compared to the sequences available in GenBank. Analysis results showed that the sequence of A/Swine/Guangdong/L1/2010(H9N2) was similar to that of several avian influenza viruses. According to phylogenetic analysis of the complete gene sequences, A/Swine/Guangdong/L1/2010(H9N2) possibly originates from the reassortment of avian influenza viruses.
authors: Kong, W. L.;Huang, L. Z.;Cao, N.;Qi, H. T.;Zhao, M. M.;Guan, S. S.;Wang, W. H.;Zao, F. R.;Qi, W. B.;Jiao, P. R.;Zhang, G. H.

title: Varicella-zoster virus induces apoptosis in vitro in subpopulations of primary human peripheral blood mononuclear cells
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), a member of the Herpesviridae, subfamily α-Herpesvirinae, is pathogenic only in humans. Chickenpox is the result of primary infection with VZV. During the viraemic stage, VZV infects peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and spreads to the periphery. In skin cells it causes typical lesions. Apoptosis has been demonstrated in various cell types from other α-herpesviruses. In this in vitro study, VZV-infected T-lymphocytes, B-lymphocytes and monocytes were examined using flow cytometry, immunofluorescence and electron microscopy. All infected cell types showed signs of apoptosis: reduced DNA content, DNA fragmentation, loss of membrane integrity, and altered nuclear morphology. The observed results led to the assumption that VZV can induce apoptosis during infection in vivo in the PBMC subpopulations. Â© 2003 Editions scientifiques et medicales Elsevier SAS. All rights reserved.
authors: KÃ¶nig, A.;HÃ¶mme, C.;HaurÃ¶der, B.;Dietrich, A.;Wolff, M. H.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of foot-and-mouth disease viruses isolated in Argentina
abstract: We analyzed complete or partial VPI sequences of 31 foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) viruses of serotypes A, O, and C to determine the genetic relatedness of field strains of FMD virus (FMD) circulating in Argentina between 1961 and 1961 , to be determined in 1994. A phylogenetic analysis, which also included 15 previously published Argentine sequences and six reference strains, revealed that (i) FMD type A strains exhibited the highest genetic heterogeneity and in five lineages with a sequence divergence of 0.9 -18.5% between strains (ii) most O-type FMD viruses grouped into two clusters (within a cluster sequence divergence ranging from 0.2% to 6.0%) occurring since the circulating in Argentina in the early 1960s, and (iii) type C FMD viruses were grouped into two clusters with a 13.4% nucleotide sequence divergence between each cluster. The availability of sequence data for many more field isolates from the region will allow us to understand the genetic relationships between FMD strains and quickly trace the source of an FMD outbreak for epidemiological surveillance.
authors: KÃ¶nig, G.;Blanco, C.;Knowles, N. J.;Palma, E. L.;Maradei, E.;Piccone, M. E.

title: Molecular epidemiology of foot-and-mouth virus types A and O isolated in Argentina during the 2000-2002 animal epidemic
abstract: In 2000-2002, Argentina was hit by a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) disease that spread across the country and resulted in more than 2,500 outbreaks. To study the evolution of foot-and-mouth disease viruses (FMD) and to aid in disease control measures, genetic characterization and phylogenetic analysis of 43 field isolates representative of the animal disease was performed. The nucleotide sequence of the VP1 coding region was determined for the viruses and used in this study. Two serotype A lines, A/Arg/00 and A/Arg/01 (1000/1000 bootstrap) and two distinct serotype O/Arg/00 lines (848/1000 bootstrap) were identified. Phylogenetic analysis indicated that viruses A/Arg/01 and O/Arg/00 may be related to earlier South American isolates, while the origin of A Argentina 2000 viruses remains unclear. Comparison of the amino acid sequences to vaccine reference strains revealed differences at critical antigenic sites for the resulting strains A/Arg/00 and A/Arg/01, leading to a change in the current vaccine formulation. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: KÃ¶nig, G. A.;Palma, E. L.;Maradei, E.;Piccone, M. E.

title: Heterogeneity of ruminant pestiviruses: academic interest or important basis for vaccine and diagnostic development?
abstract: Pestiviruses cause economically important diseases in livestock. Members of the pestiviruses are bovine virus diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1), BVDV-2, classical swine fever virus (CSFV), and border disease virus (BDV). Phylogenetic analyzes based on the entire nucleic acid sequence encoding Npro allow a statistically significant separation of established species and of subgroups within the species. BVDV-1 strains isolated in Germany can be assigned to at least five different subgroups. In contrast, all BVDV-2 isolates detected in Germany to date are closely related and belong to a subgroup. A group of virus isolates from sheep and zoo animals differs markedly from established pestivirus species and can be designated BDV-2. The antigenetic relationship of pestiviruses was examined using defined virus isolates and antisera in cross-neutralization assays. Six antigenic groups were distinguished according to the genetic clusters BVDV-1, BVDV-2, CSFV, BDV-1, BDV-2 and Giraffe-1. A significant antigenic difference was also observed between members of subgroups 1a and 1b of BVDV-1. Studies of the genetic and antigenic heterogeneity of pestiviruses are important for the development of new vaccines, diagnostic tests, and eradication programs.
authors: KÃ¶nig, M.;Cedillo Rosales, S.;Becher, P.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Characterization and identification of Oya virus, a virus of the Simbu serogroup of the genus Bunyavirus, isolated from a pig suspected of having Nipah virus infection
abstract: virus called Oya virus was isolated in Vero cell culture from the lungs of a pig suspected of having Nipah virus infection. The virus appeared as a spherical, enveloped RNA virus with a diameter of 79 nm. RT-PCR was used to identify Oya virus. A common primer set for S-RNA of genus Bunyavirus Simbu serogroup was able to amplify a cDNA of Oya virus RNA. The product's sequence data showed that the partial gene of Oya virus S-RNA segment shared 65-70% homology with published cDNA sequences of Simbu serogroup viruses. The phylogenetic analysis of the data showed that the Oya virus is classified in the Simbu serogroup but is genetically distinct from the molecularly analyzed serogroup viruses. Serological tests showed that the virus was widespread and dense in Malaysia.
authors: Kono, Y.;Yusnita, Y.;Mohd Ali, A. R.;Maizan, M.;Sharifah, S. H.;Fauzia, O.;Kubo, M.;Aziz, A. J.

title: Virological and pathological characterization of an avian H1N1 influenza A virus
abstract: Gene segments from avian H1N1 influenza A viruses have been recombined with other influenza viruses over the past century to create pandemic strains. Nevertheless, little effort has been expended to understand the properties of the avian H1N1 influenza viruses. Here we present the genome sequence and a molecular and virological characterization of an avian influenza A virus, A/Wildvogel/Korea/SK14/2014 (A/SK14, H1N1), isolated from migratory birds in South Korea during the 2014-2015 winter season. Full genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis revealed that the virus belongs to the Eurasian bird lineage. Although retaining the avian receptor binding preference, the A/SK14 virus also displayed detectable human-like receptor binding and was able to replicate in differentiated primary normal human bronchial epithelial cells. In animal models, A/SK14 virus was moderately pathogenic in mice and the virus was detected in nasal washes of vaccinated guinea pigs but not in direct contact guinea pigs. Although A/SK14 showed moderate pathogenicity and no evidence of transmission in a mammalian model, our results suggest that the dual receptor specificity of A/SK14-like virus could allow for more rapid adaptation to mammals, highlighting the importance of further continuous surveillance and Monitoring underscores risk assessment activities.
authors: Koo, B. S.;Kim, H. K.;Song, D.;Na, W.;Song, M. S.;Kwon, J. J.;Wong, S. S.;Noh, J. Y.;Ahn, M. J.;Kim, D. J.;Webby, R. J.;Yoon, S. W.;Jeong, D. G.

title: Evolution of thymidine and thymidylate kinases: the possibility of independent capture of TK genes by different groups of viruses
abstract: The phylogenetic analysis of viral and cellular thymidine and thymidylate kinases was performed using computational methods. Several alignments and preliminary phylogenetic trees have been constructed for the two families of these enzymes, including a) mammalian thymidine kinases (TK), poxviruses, African swine fever virus, E. coli, and bacteriophage T4; and b) thymidylate kinases (ThyK) from yeast and poxviruses and distantly related herpesvirus proteins with both enzymatic activities. Analysis of the alignment of the first family TKs highlighted three highly conserved segments. Two of these corresponded to the A and B motifs of the purine NTP binding pattern. The third, C-terminal segment that showed the highest conservation comprised a modified Zn finger motif. It is speculated that this motif may be involved in TK oligomerization. Phylogenetic trees constructed using three different methods suggested that cellular TK genes could be captured independently by T4 bacteriophage, African swine fever virus, fowlpox virus, and the other smallpox viruses. The observed tree topologies appear to contradict popular schemes of virus-host coevolution and imply that different subdivisions of smallpoxviruses diverged at earlier stages of evolution than their hosts. Bacteriophage T4 deoxynucleoside monophosphate kinase has been shown to be related to the ThyK family. Phylogenetic analyzes suggested that ThyK genes were likely acquired independently from phage T4, poxviruses, and herpesviruses.
authors: Koonin, E. V.;Senkevich, T. G.

title: Characterization of the RKZ isolate of ovine herpesvirus 1
abstract: cytopathic effect (CPE), characterized mainly by rounded cell foci, was observed in cultures of primary choroid plexus cells from healthy lambs after cryopreservation. By co-cultivation with infected cells, the infectious agent could be transferred to other primary cells of ovine origin. Indirect immunofluorescence microscopy revealed that a high percentage of sheep (65-80% in 3 different flocks from Slovakia) are infected with this infectious agent. Electron microscopy of cells with CPE showed the presence of herpesvirus particles. Viral DNA was isolated from infected cells using pulsed field gel electrophoresis and further used as a probe in Southern blot analysis. The probe reacted specifically only with DNA from cells infected with ovine herpesvirus 1 (OvHV-1), but not with DNA from other ruminant herpesviruses. Some of the HindIII restriction fragments of the DNA of the resulting OvHV-1 isolate, designated RKZ, were cloned. A portion of the H9 clone was sequenced, identifying a gene encoding a polypeptide homologous to the conserved herpesvirus VP23 structural protein. From comparison of the sequence of this clone with VP23 sequences of other herpesviruses, it was deduced that OvHV-1 could be classified within the Rhadinovirus genus of the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily. The sequencing of the H9 clone of the DNA of the RKZ isolate enabled the establishment of a sensitive and highly specific polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay for the detection of OvHV-1.
authors: KopÃ¡Äek, J.;RejholcovÃ¡, O.;KoptidesovÃ¡, D.;ÄŒiampor, F.;Rijsewijk, F. M.;Reid, H. W.;Pastorek, J.;ZelnÃ­k, V.

title: Molecular genetic properties of the velogenous strains of Newcastle disease virus isolated in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan
abstract: The F gene fragment of 79 Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains isolated from native and synanthropic birds in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Ukraine and Russia between 1993 and 2007 was analyzed comparatively. Phylogenetic analysis of test isolates and reference NDV strains obtained from GenBank was performed by polymerase chain reaction followed by sequencing and comparative analysis of 154 bp nucleotide sequences in the major functional region of the F gene. All newly characterized isolates belong to three subgroups of NDV genotype VII: Vila, VIIb, VIId. The results indicate that there is a need to monitor isolated NDV strains in the CIS countries, as the spread of NDV among migratory birds and synanthropes (pigeons, crows and jackdaws) poses a serious threat to the commercial poultry industry.
authors: Korotetsky, I. S.;Bogoyavlensky, A. P.;Prilipov, A. G.;Usachev, E. V.;Usacheva, O. V.;Turmagambetova, A. S.;Zaitseva, I. A.;Kydyrmanov, A.;Shakhvorostova, L. I.;Kh Sayatov, M.;Borisov, V. V.;Pchelkina, I. P.;Gerilovich, A. P.;Berezin, V. E.

title: Differentiation of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) strains using monoclonal antibodies against structural glycoproteins
abstract: Two panels of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against the envelope glycoproteins E2 (12 mAbs) and EO (11 mAbs) of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) were established and tested by an immunoperoxidase binding assay against 135 pestivirus strains and isolates. Binding pattern variability was demonstrated for CSFV and also for bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) strains and isolates. The panels of mAbs against E2 and EO resulted in very different patterns of reactivity. Certain mAbs against E2 reacted with (i) all CSFV isolates, (ii) only 4 of 126 CSFV isolates, or (in) about 90% of the CSFV isolates tested and 78% of the ruminant pestivirus isolates. Anti-CSFV EO mAbs enabled the detection of greater variability among CSFV strains and isolates than the anti-E2 mAbs. None of the 11 anti-EO mAbs recognized an epitope conserved for CSFV or showed cross-reactivity with ruminant pestiviruses. Using both panels of mAbs against two CSFV structural glycoproteins resulted in the discrimination of 21 antigenic types of CSFV strains and isolates. The panels described can be used to trace the origin of CSFV after disease outbreaks.
authors: Kosmidou, A.;Ahl, R.;Thiel, H. J.;Weiland, E.

title: Phylogenetic correlation of Greek and Italian orf virus isolates based on the VIR gene
abstract: Thirteen orf virus isolates obtained from crusted scab lesions of nine sheep and four goats from different geographic areas of Greece and Italy suspected of contagious ecthyma infection between 1995 and 2004 were analyzed. The DNA of all isolates was successfully amplified by PCR with primers 045F-045R and identified as parapoxvirus. A partial DNA sequence of the orf virus interferon resistance (VIR) gene, a phylogenetic analysis of the available isolates, and an amino acid comparison of the interferon resistance protein encoded by this genomic region were performed. According to the results of the present report, an accurate characterization of the examined genome region could provide clues to the genetic variation and movement of the circulating orf virus strains. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kottaridi, C.;Nomikou, K.;Teodori, L.;Savini, G.;Lelli, R.;Markoulatos, P.;Mangana, O.

title: Phylogenetic evolution of the porcine human influenza virus: A 2009 H1N1 pandemic
abstract: Knowing the genome constellation of the 2009 H1N1 pandemic influenza A virus from different countries and different hosts is valuable for monitoring and understanding the evolution and migration of these strains. The complete genome sequences of selected global influenza A viruses are publicly available, and longitudinal genomic studies of human, avian, and swine influenza A viruses are scarce. All downloadable influenza A virus SIV sequences available on the Global Initiative on Sharing Avian Influenza Data (GISAID) platform were first analyzed via the NCBI Influenza Virus Resource web servers. A phylogenetic study of the circulating human pandemic H1N1 virus revealed that the new variant possesses a distinctive evolutionary trait. There is no way the H1N1 pandemic acquired new genes from other distinguishable viruses that have recently been circulating in local human, swine, or domestic fowl populations from different geographic regions. The extensive genetic diversity among entire segments present in the pandemic H1N1 genome suggests that multiple introductions of the virus occurred over the period 1999-2009. The initial interspecies transmission may have occurred in the distant past, and thereafter the reassortant steps result in three lineages: classical SIV prevalent in North America, avian SIV in Europe, and avian, related SIV in Asia. This analysis adds to the evidence that pigs are not the only hosts playing the role of 'mixing vessels', as has been claimed for many years.
authors: Kowalczyk, A.;Markowska-Daniel, I.

title: Biological and molecular characterization of chicken anemia virus isolates from Slovenia
abstract: The presence of chicken anemia virus (CAV) in Slovenia was confirmed by inoculation of 1-day-old chickens without antibodies against CAV and isolation of the virus on MSB1 line of Marek's disease chicken cells and by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Experimental inoculation of 1-day-old chickens resulted in lower hematocrit values, atrophy of the thymus and atrophy of the bone marrow. CAV was confirmed by PCR in thymus, bone marrow, Fabricius bursa, liver, spleen, ileocecal tonsils, duodenum and proventriculus. The nucleotide sequence of the gene for the entire viral protein (VP)1 was determined by direct sequencing. The alignment of the VP1 nucleotide sequences of Slovenian CAV isolates (CAV-69/00, CAV-469/01 and CAV-130/03) showed 99.4% to 99.9% homology. VP1 nucleotide sequence alignment of Slovenian isolates with 19 other CAV strains showed 94.4% to 99.4% homology. Slovenian isolates shared the highest homology with the BD-3 isolate from Bangladesh. Alignment of the deduced VP1 amino acids showed that the Slovenian isolates shared 100% homology and had an amino acid sequence most similar (99.6%) to the Bangladeshi BD-3 strain and 99-1% to the G6 strain from Japan was similar to strain L-028 from the United States. The Slovenian isolates were the least similar (96.6%) to strain 82-2 from Japan. A phylogenetic analysis based on the arrangement of the VP1 amino acids showed that the CAV isolates used in the study formed three groups, indicating the possible existence of genetic groups among the CAV strains. The CAV isolates were grouped independently of their geographic origin and pathogenicity.
authors: KrapeÅ¾, U.;BarliÄ-Maganja, D.;Toplak, I.;Hostnik, P.;Rojs, O. Z.

title: Circulation of infectious bronchitis virus strains of genotypes Italy 02 and QX in Slovenia between 2007 and 2009
abstract: Fourteen infectious bronchitis viruses (IBVs) detected in broiler, broiler parent and layer flocks in Slovenia between 2007 and 2009 were molecularly analyzed using reverse transcription PCR and direct sequencing of the S1 gene. Phylogenetic analyzes based on partial S1 gene sequences revealed that seven strains were classified as genotype Italy 02, a genetic group of IBV previously undetected in Slovenia. Another seven strains were classified as QX genotype. The results of phylogenetic analyzes and epidemiological investigations revealed that the genetic classification correlates with the geographical origin of the IBV strains. Greater genetic variability (maximum nucleotide and amino acid divergences were 4.8% and 9.9%, respectively) was observed in the Slovenian strains of the Italy 02 genotype detected between 2007 and 2009 than in strains of the QX genotype isolated in 2008 and 2009 (1st .2% and 1.3% respectively). The Slovenian strains classified as Italy 02 genotype form a separate genetic cluster. These strains shared five specific amino acid substitutions that were fixed during the monitoring period. Strains of the QX genotype that share a particular amino acid substitution also form a separate genetic cluster. © 2011 American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: KrapeÅ¾, U.;Slavec, B.;Rojs, O. Z.

title: Importance of structure for classification of avian viruses
authors: Krauss, H.

title: Metagenomics - a new approach to studying our microbial neighbors
abstract: Background: In our time, the information society, computer-aided technologies, including data analysis methods, are part of every area of life. Bioinformatics offers approaches to acquiring and updating knowledge that were unthinkable two decades ago. Metagenomics is the field of bioinformatics that helps improve our knowledge of the composition of microbial species in production of pets, humans, or the environment. Aims: This thesis describes the essential steps of a metagenomics analysis. As an example, the metagenomic study of swine dysentery as an important animal disease is shown. Material and Methods: Intestinal contents were collected from three different intestinal sections (ie caecum, colon and rectum) from three clinically affected fattening pigs. All DNA was extracted from the samples and then sequenced using next-generation sequencing technology. The 1,782,466 reads produced were pooled and analyzed. The reads were matched against archea, bacterial and viral genome databases by the octopus bioinformatics tool. The results of the alignments were visualized using the Krona tool. Results and Discussion: The presented case study helps the reader to understand how metagenomics studies work and provides new professional knowledge about the microbiome of selected organs in different living beings. The proportions of the different taxa provide insight into the microbial communities of the gut of diseased animals. In addition, a brief overview is given to show the possible applications of metagenomics in the field of animal health. Bioinformatics is an emerging field and it is very important to know about the methods, their possible outcomes and limitations – for both clinicians and researchers. This work provides a simple introduction to metagenomics in the language of veterinarians.
authors: Kriko, E.;Farkas, R.;Adorjan, A.;Makrai, L.;Solymosi, N.

title: Deep sequencing analysis reveals temporal microbiota changes associated with the development of bovine digital dermatitis
abstract: Bovine digital dermatitis (DD) is a leading cause of lameness in dairy cattle worldwide. Despite 35 years of research, the definitive etiological agent associated with the disease process is still unknown. Previous studies have shown that several species of bacteria are associated with lesions, with spirochetes being the most reliably identified organism. This study describes the deep sequencing-based metagenomic analysis of 48 staged DD biopsy specimens collected during a three-year longitudinal study of disease progression. Over 175 million sequences were evaluated using shotgun and 16S metagenomics techniques. Based on the results of shotgun sequencing, there was no evidence of a fungal or DNA virus etiology. The bacterial microbiota of biopsy specimens undergoes a systematic series of changes that correlate with the novel morphological lesion scoring system developed within this project. This scoring system was validated because the microbiota of each stage differed statistically significantly from those of other stages (P<0.001). The microbiota of the control biopsy specimens were the most diverse and became less diverse as lesions developed. Although Treponema spp. predominant in the advanced lesions, they were at relatively low frequency in the newly described early lesions associated with the initiation of the disease process. The consortium of Treponema spp. identified early in the disease changes significantly as the lesions progress through the identified morphologic stages. The results of this study support the hypothesis that DD is a polybacterial disease process and provide unique insights into the temporal changes in bacterial populations during lesion development. © 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Krull, A. C.;Shearer, J. K.;Gorden, P. J.;Cooper, V. L.;Phillips, G. J.;Plummera, P. J.

title: Molecular classification of enteroviruses not identified by neutralization tests
abstract: We isolated six viruses from patients diagnosed with aseptic meningitis or hand, foot and mouth disease. The cytopathic effect of these viruses on cultured cells was similar to that of enteroviruses. However, virus neutralization tests against standard antisera were negative. Phylogenetic analysis with the complete VP4 nucleotide sequences of these 6 viruses and 29 serotypes of enteroviruses classified 3 of the viruses as serotype Echovirus Type 18 (EV18) and 3 as serotype Human Enterovirus 71 (HEV71). These results were confirmed by remicroneutralization tests with HEV monospecific antisera or additional phylogenetic analysis with the complete VP4 nucleotide sequences. Phylogenetic analysis using complete VP4 genes is more useful in identifying enterovirus serotypes than neutralization tests using enterovirus serotype-specific antisera.
authors: Kubo, H.;Iritani, N.;Seto, Y.

title: Novel influenza viruses in bats and cattle: "Pushing the envelope" of influenza infection
authors: Kuchipudi, S.;Nissly, R.

title: Whole genome characterization of a Chelonian orthoreovirus strain identifies significant genetic diversity and can classify reptilian orthoreoviruses into different species
abstract: In this study, we report the sequence and phylogenetic characterization of an orthoreovirus strain, CH1197/96, isolated from a African spurred tortoise (Testudo graeca) on chick embryo fibroblast cells. The 23,957 bp genome sequence was obtained through the combined use of semiconductor and capillary sequencing. Although genomic characterization showed that the virus most closely resembled bush viper reovirus strain 47/02, and in phylogenies performed on all segments, the two strains formed a monophyletic group, nucleotide (48.4–70, 3%) and amino acid (39.2 -80.7%) sequence identity values between the two reptilian reoviruses were moderate. Based on our results and existing classification criteria for the genus Orthoreovirus, the tortoise reovirus strain CH1197/96 may be the first representative of a novel orthoreovirus species of reptilian origin.
authors: Kugler, R.;Marschang, R. E.;IhÃ¡sz, K.;Lengyel, G.;Jakab, F.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Farkas, S. L.

title: Next Generation Sequencing (NGS): Analysis of fecal samples from pigs with diarrhea
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are a major breakthrough in the field of infectious disease diagnostics, as they enable the detection of novel pathogens without prior sequence knowledge, enabling simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens, whole genome studies, and metagenome studies. The aim of this study was to determine the value of NGS in detecting pathogens in clinical specimens, namely specimens from diarrheal pigs. Fecal samples from four pigs with severe diarrhea were analyzed. NGS libraries were made from sample suspensions and used for Ion torrent sequencing. A total of 396,486 reads were assembled into 1,537 contigs. Taxonomy units were assigned 786 contigs while 751 contigs remained unassigned. All four specimens were positive for Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PED). Viruses of the genus Picobirnavirus and porcine Astrovirus were also detected in two samples, while one sample was positive for virus of the genus Torovirus. In addition to viral sequences, sequences from bacteria, archaea, nematodes, protista and amoebas were also detected in the samples examined. Based on these results, we can conclude that NGS technology is a powerful tool for infectious disease diagnostics, allowing us to simultaneously detect multiple pathogens in complex samples.
authors: Kuhar, U.;Kusar, D.;Papic, B.;Toplak, I.

title: Virus nomenclature below the species level: A standardized nomenclature for laboratory animal-adapted strains and variants of viruses belonging to the family Filoviridae
abstract: The International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) organizes the classification of viruses into taxa, but is not responsible for the nomenclature of taxa members. International expert groups such as the ICTV Study Groups recommend the classification and naming of viruses and their strains, variants and isolates. The ICTV Filoviridae Study Group recently introduced an updated classification and nomenclature for filoviruses. Subsequently, together with numerous other filovirus experts, a unified nomenclature for their natural genetic variants and isolates was developed, aiming at simplifying the retrieval of sequence data from electronic databases. This is an important first step towards a viral genome annotation standard as envisaged by the US National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). Here, this work is extended to include filoviruses obtained in the laboratory by artificial selection by passage in laboratory hosts. The previously developed template for naming natural filovirus genetic variants (<virus name> <isolation host suffix>/<country of sampling>/<year of sampling>/<genetic variant name>-<isolate name>) is retained, but it it is proposed to adapt the type of information added to each field for variants adapted to laboratory animals. For example, the full name of a Mayinga variant of the Ebola virus adapted at the State Research Center for Virology and Biotechnology would be "Vector", which is said to cause diseases in guinea pigs after seven passages, similar to "Ebola virus VECTOR/C.porcellus-lab /COD/ 1976/Mayinga-GPA-P7". As suggested for the names of natural filovirus variants, we recommend using the full name in databases and in the methods section of publications. Abbreviated names (e.g. "EBOV VECTOR/C.por/COD /76/May-GPA-P7") and abbreviations (e.g. "EBOV/May-GPA-P7") may be used in further text depending on the importance of conveying information that is full-length in the name "EBOV" would suffice if only one EBOV strain/variant/isolate is addressed © 2013 Springer-Verlag Vienna (outside US).
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;Bao, Y.;Bavari, S.;Becker, S.;Bradfute, S.;Brister, J. R.;Bukreyev, A. A.;CaÃ¬, Y.;Chandran, K.;Davey, R. A.;Dolnik, O.;Dye, J. M.;Enterlein, S.;Gonzalez, J. title: Nyamiviridae: Proposed new family in the order Mononegavirales
abstract: Nyamanini virus (NYMV) and Midway virus (MIDWV) are unclassified tick-borne pathogens that infect terrestrial birds and seabirds, respectively. Recent molecular characterization of both viruses confirmed their already known close serological relationship and revealed that they are non-segmented, single-stranded and negative-stranded RNA viruses uniquely related to members of the order Mononegavirales (Bornaviruses, Filoviruses, Paramyxoviruses and Rhabdoviruses). A third pathogen, soybean cyst nematode virus 1 (SbCNV-1, previously named soybean cyst nematode nyavirus), was recently identified as an additional member of this new virus group. Here we review current knowledge of all three viruses and propose to classify them as members of a new mononegaviral family, Nyamiviridae. © 2013 Springer-Verlag Vienna (outside the USA).
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;Bekal, S.;CaÃ¬, Y.;Clawson, A. N.;Domier, L. L.;Herrel, M.;Jahrling, P. B.;Kondo, H.;Lambert, K. N.;Mihindukulasuriya, K. A.;Nowotny, N.;Radoshitzky, S. R.;Schneider, U.;Staeheli, P.;Suzuki, N.;Tesh, R. B.;Wang, D.;Wang, L. F.;Dietzgen, R. G.

title: Taxonomic reorganization of the family Bornaviridae
abstract: Knowledge of bornaviruses has increased significantly over the past decade. A possible reservoir of mammalian Borna disease virus has been identified, distinct Bornaviruses have been identified in birds and reptiles, and endogenous Bornavirus-like elements have been discovered in the genomes of several vertebrate species. Previous sequence comparisons and alignments have shown that the members of the current Bornaviridae family are phylogenetically diverse and not adequately classified in the existing Bornavirus taxonomy supported by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV). We provide an update of these analyzes and describe their impact on the taxonomy. We propose keeping the surname Bornaviridae and the genus Bornavirus, but reorganizing the species classification. PAirwise Sequence Comparison (PASC) of Bornavirus genomes and Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) comparison of genome and protein sequences combined with other previously published phylogenetic analyzes and known biological properties of Bornaviruses indicate that this genus contains at least five species should include : Mammalian 1 bornavirus (classic borna disease virus and divergent borna disease virus isolate #/98), Psittaciform 1 bornavirus (bird/psittazine bornavirus 1, 2, 3, 4, 7), Passeriform 1 bornavirus (Avian/Canary Bornavirus C1, C2, C3, LS), Passeriform 2 Bornavirus (Estrildid Finch Bornavirus EF) and Waterbird 1 Bornavirus (Avian Bornavirus 062CG). This classification is also consistent with the biological properties of these viruses and their vertebrate hosts. A snake bornavirus to be designated Loveridge's garter snake virus 1 should be classified as a member of another species (Elapid 1 bornavirus) not assigned to any genus in the Bornaviridae family. Avian Bornaviruses 5, 6, MALL and another 'Reptilian Bornavirus' ('Gaboon Viper Virus') should remain unclassified until further information is available. Finally, where necessary, we suggest new virus names and abbreviations to achieve clear distinction and unique identification.
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;DÃ¼rrwald, R.;BÃ o, Y.;Briese, T.;Carbone, K.;Clawson, A. N.;deRisi, J. L.;Garten, W.;Jahrling, P. B.;Kolodziejek, J.;Rubbenstroth, D.;Schwemmle, M.;Stenglein, M.;Tomonaga, K.;WeissenbÃ¶ck, H.;Nowotny, N.

title: Reorganization and expansion of the nidoviral family Arteriviridae
abstract: The Arteriviridae family currently includes a single genus, Arterivirus. This genus includes four species as taxonomic homes for Equine Arteritis Virus (EAV), Lactate Dehydrogenase Elevating Virus (LDV), Porcine Respiratory and Reproductive Syndrome Virus (PRRSV), and Simian Hemorrhagic Fever Virus (SHFV), respectively . A revision of this classification is urgently needed to take into account the recent description of eleven very different simian arteriviruses in various African non-human primates, a novel arterivirus in an African forest opossum, and a novel arterivirus in common bushtails in New Zealand. In addition, the current arterivirus nomenclature is inconsistent with the latest version of the International Code of Virus Classification and Nomenclature. Here we outline an updated, modified, and improved arterivirus taxonomy based on current data. Taxon-specific sequence cutoffs are constructed based on a newly established phylogeny of the 1b open reading frame and pairwise sequence comparison (PASC) of encoding complete arterivirus genomes. As a result, the current genus Arterivirus is replaced by five genera: Equartevirus (for EAV), Rodartevirus (LDV + PRRSV), Simartevirus (SHFV + simian arteriviruses), Nesartevirus (for the opossum arterivirus), and Dipartevirus (common brushtail arterivirus). The current species Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus is divided into two species to reflect the marked divergence of the European and American "types" of PRRSV, both of which are now given viral status. The current species of simian hemorrhagic fever virus is divided into nine species to accommodate the twelve known simian arteriviruses. Non-Latinized binomial species names are introduced to replace all current species names to clearly distinguish them from virus names, which remain largely unchanged.

title: Genomic Characterization of the Genus Nairovirus (Family Bunyaviridae)
abstract: Nairovirus, one of five Bunyavirus genera, includes seven species. Genomic sequence information is limited for members of the Dera Ghazi Khan, Hughes, Qalyub, Sakhalin, and Thiafora nairovirus species. We used next-generation sequencing and historical viral culture samples to determine 14 full-length and nine coding full-length nairoviral genome sequences to further characterize these species. Viruses not previously sequenced include Abu Mina, Clo Mor, Great Saltee, Hughes, Raza, Sakhalin, Soldado, and Tillamook viruses. In addition, we present genomic sequence information on additional isolates of previously sequenced Avalon, Dugbe, Sapphire II and Zirqa viruses. Finally, we identify Tunis virus, previously thought to be a phlebovirus, as an isolate of Abu Hammad virus. Phylogenetic analyzes indicate the need for reassignment of Sapphire II virus to Dera Ghazi Khan nairovirus and reassignment of Hazara, Tofla and Nairobi sheep disease viruses to new species. We also propose new species for the Kasokero group (Kasokero, Leopards Hill, Yogue viruses), the Ketarah group (Gossas, Issyk-kul, Keterah/Soft tick viruses) and the Burana group (WÄ“ nzhÅ u tick virus, Huángpí) before tick virus 1, TÇŽchéng tick virus 1). Our analyzes emphasize the sister relationship of Nairoviruses and Arenaviruses and indicate that several Nairo-like viruses (ShÄ yáng spider virus 1, XÄ«nzhÅ u spider virus, SÄnxiá water strider virus 1, South Bay virus, WÇ“há n centipede virus 2) require the establishment of new genera in a larger nairovirus arenavirus supergroup.
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;Wiley, M. R.;Rodriguez, S. E.;BÃ o, Y.;Prieto, K.;Travassos da Rosa, A. P. A.;Guzman, H.;Savji, N.;Ladner, J. T.;Tesh, R. B.;Wada, J.;Jahrling, P. B.;Bente, D. A.;Palacios, G.

title: Occurrence of endogenous viral genes in two strains of white Leghorn chickens selected for egg production and susceptibility or resistance to Marek's disease
abstract: Endogenous viral (ev) genes related to avian leukosis virus were classified in two differentially selected Leghorn strains to investigate whether such genes affect production traits. Strain K had been selected for resistance to Marek's disease (MD) and for high egg production and egg weight, while strain S had been selected only for MD sensitivity. Aside from the fact that the founders of phylum K included some commercial birds, both phyla were derived from a common genetic base. DNA restriction fragment length analyzes of 110 strain K and 94 strain S birds revealed the presence of 8 different ev genes, 6 of which were identical to previously identified loci. This result was confirmed by testing for group specific antigen (gs antigen), the product of the gag region of the ev genes. The levels of gs antigen in the birds closely followed the predictions from data obtained from previously described ev genes. Both strains had a similar average number of ev genes per bird (3.5 and 3.2 for strains S and K, respectively). However, strain K carried only five different ev genes, while strain S carried seven. Four of these loci were present in both strains. Among the ev genes absent or less common in strain K were those encoding either infectious endogenous virus (ev-10 and possibly ev-19) or the internal viral gag proteins (ev-3). Only those ev genes that are transcriptionally silent or that encode the viral envelope gene were present at increased frequency in strain K. The results indicate that selection for egg traits and/or resistance to Marek's disease reduces the abundance of ev genes that produce endogenous virus or the viral gag proteins.
authors: Kuhnlein, U.;Gavora, J. S.;Spencer, J. L.;Bernon, D. E.;Sabour, M.

title: Natural viral infection by pest des petits ruminants: novel pathologic findings resembling other morbillivirus infections
abstract: The present study describes pathological and virological findings in 15 sheep and 6 goats that died in Turkey from natural infection with Petits ruminant virus plague. Pathologic findings included erosive-ulcerative stomatitis, fibrino-necrotic tracheitis, bronchointerstitial pneumonia, multifocal coagulative necrosis in the liver, and severe lymphocytolysis in the lymphatic tissue. Syncytial cells were prominent, particularly in the oral mucosa, alveoli, liver and lymphatic tissue. In addition to the typical tissue distribution, eosinophilic intracytoplasmic and/or intranuclear inclusions have been observed in epithelial cells lining the renal pelvis and abomasal mucosa. Immune labeling of the viral antigen was observed in addition to the more typical sites in kidney, brain, rumen, abomasum, heart and myocytes of the tongue. In this study, we report and describe in detail the first small ruminant plague endemic to Kirikkale Province, Central Anatolia of Turkey.
