In conclusion, these previously unreported pathological findings in natural viral infection with small ruminant plague provide a basis for similarity to other morbillivirus infections, such as. B. Canine distemper and marine mammal distemper. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction analyzes showed that the 448 bp genomic fragment was amplified in 18 cases (18/21, 85.7%). Phylogenetic analysis showed that the viruses belong to lineage 4 in the common phylogenetic tree of small ruminant plague virus.
authors: Kul, O.;Kabakci, N.;Atmaca, H. T.;Ã–zkul, A.

title: Emergence of novel reassortant H6N2 avian influenza viruses in ducks in India
abstract: Recent reports of human infection by avian influenza virus (AIV) subtype H6, which is widespread in terrestrial poultry, indicate the virus' evolution into a possible pandemic strain. Here we report the antigenic and genetic characterization of two H6N2 viruses isolated from apparently healthy domestic ducks in Kerala and Assam, India, in 2014 and 2015, respectively. The hemagglutination inhibition assay demonstrated antigenic divergence between the two isolates, confirmed by amino acid differences at 55 positions (15.98%) between their hemagglutinin (HA) 1 pathogenic to poultry and susceptible to oseltamivir. However, Kerala14 had a V27I mutation marker for amantadine resistance in M2. Assam15 virus had additional N-linked glycosylation on HA2 (position 557) compared to Kerala14 virus. The phylogenetic analysis of the HA gene revealed that both viruses belonged to different lineages (Eurasian and Asiatic II). The phylogeny of neuraminidase and internal gene segments revealed that both viruses are novel reassortants and are genetically distinct with different gene constellations. The results suggest that independent introductions of the two H6N2 viruses to India and migratory wild birds on the Central Asian flyway could be the source of H6N2 viruses in ducks in India. Therefore, continued AIV surveillance in poultry and wild birds is essential to early detect the emergence of new strains with pandemic potential and to control their spread.
authors: Kumar, M.;Nagarajan, S.;Murugkar, H. V.;Saikia, B.;Singh, B.;Mishra, A.;Tripathi, S. K.;Agarwal, S.;Shukla, S.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Singh, V. P.;Tosh, C.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of an orf virus from sheep in Makhdoom, India
abstract: Orf (contagious ecthyma) is an exanthematous disease caused by a parapox virus and occurs mainly in sheep and goats with zoonotic consequences. In the present study, an orf outbreak in the Muzzaffarnagari sheep flock at the Central Institute for Research on Goats (CIRG), Makhdoom, Mathura, Uttar Pradesh, India was investigated. Primary goat testicle cell culture was first used to isolate orf virus (ORFV). The identity of the virus was confirmed by amplification and sequence analysis of the major envelope glycoprotein (B2L) gene and designated ORFV/sheep/India/2012/CIRG. In the phylogenetic analysis of the B2L protein gene, it clustered with the ORFV strains from China, suggesting that different ORFV strains circulate in India. Comparing nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequence analysis (n=63), a unique 126S residue was observed in ORFV/Sheep/India/2012/CIRG. Upon further sequence analysis (B2L) of different ORFV strains (n=63), some conserved amino acid residues were identified as host-specific (sheep, human, camel, takin and musk ox) and pooled. © 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Kumar, N.;Wadhwa, A.;Chaubey, K. K.;Singh, S. V.;Gupta, S.;Sharma, S.;Sharma, D. K.;Singh, M. K.;Mishra, A. K.

title: Hepatitis E Virus: The Current Scenario
abstract: Hepatitis E infection, caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV), is a common cause of acute hepatitis in developing countries with poor sanitation and hygiene. The virus is divided into four genotypes (1-4) with one serotype. Genotypes 1 and 2 exclusively infect humans, while genotypes 3 and 4 also infect other animals, particularly pigs. Large outbreaks of acute hepatitis caused by genotype 1 or 2 viruses are common in endemic areas due to fecal-oral transmission, usually through contamination of drinking water. With a high relapse rate in young adults (aged 15 to 45 years), the disease is particularly severe (20 to 30% mortality) in pregnant women. HEV appears to be a zoonotic disease transmitted by swine, wild boar, and deer, or through food. Chronic infections are rare, except in immunocompromised individuals, such as B. Recipients of organ transplants. A subunit vaccine has been shown to be effective in preventing clinical disease but is not yet commercially available. Our understanding of HEV has changed significantly in recent years and in this article we review the information currently available regarding the molecular biology, pathobiology and epidemiology of HEV infection. We also review current therapeutic interventions and strategies used to control HEV infection, with a focus on potential approaches that could be used to develop an effective vaccine against HEV. © 2012 International Society for Infectious Diseases.
authors: Kumar, S.;Subhadra, S.;Singh, B.;Panda, B. K.

title: Complete sequencing and genomic characterization of Bagaza, Kedougou and Zika viruses
abstract: Many members of the Flavivirus genus are causative agents of important human, livestock, and wildlife diseases. A complete genome sequence is not currently available for the three African viruses Bagaza, Zika and Kedougou viruses, each of which represents a separate virus subgroup according to the latest virus classification. In this study, we obtained a complete genome sequence from each of these three viruses and characterized the open reading frames (ORFs) in terms of gene sizes, cleavage sites, potential glycosylation sites, distribution of cysteine residues, and unique motifs. The sequences of the three viruses were then scanned for genetic relatedness across the entire length of the ORF against available sequences from other African flaviviruses and selected reference viruses. Overall, the data showed that Kedougou virus was close but distinct from dengue viruses, while Bagaza virus shared genetic relatedness with West Nile virus in several genomic regions. In the non-coding regions, it was found that a particular pattern of organization of conserved sequences in the 37prime; Terminal region generally correlated with current virus grouping. © 2007 Springer Verlag.
authors: Kuno, G.;Chang, G. J. J.

title: Muscovy Duck Reovirus ÏƒC protein is atypically encoded by the smallest genome segment
abstract: Although musk duck reovirus (DRV) shares characteristics with the reovirus isolated from chickens, commonly referred to as avian reovirus (ARV), the two virus species are antigenically distinct. Similar to the previously identified DRV βB-encoding gene (1201 bp long), the three other small double-stranded RNA genomic segments of DRV have been cloned and sequenced. They were 1325, 1191, and 1124 bp, respectively, and contained conserved terminal sequences common to ARVs. They encoded individual expression products except for the smallest (S4) which contained two overlapping open reading frames (ORF1 and ORF2). BLAST analysis revealed that the proteins encoded by the 1325 and 1191 bp genes shared high levels of identity with ARV ÏƒA and ÏƒNS, respectively, and to a lesser extent with other orthoreovirus counterparts. No homology was found for the S4 ORF1-encoded p10 protein. The 29.4 kDa product encoded by S4 ORF2 appeared to be 25% identical to ARV S1 ORF3-encoded κC, a cell-binding oligomer that induces type-specific neutralizing antibodies. The introduction of large gaps in the N-terminal part of the DRV protein was necessary to improve the amino acid sequence alignment of DRV and ARV ÏƒC. However, a leucine zipper motif was conserved, and secondary structure analysis predicted a three-stranded α-helical coiled-coil function at this amino moiety. Thus, despite extensive sequence discrepancies, DRV ΔC has been proposed to be structurally and probably functionally related to ARV ΔC. This work provides evidence for the diversity of the polycistronic S-class genes of reoviruses isolated from avians and raises the question of the relative classification of DRV in the orthoreovirus genus.
authors: Kuntz-Simon, G.;Le Gall-ReculÃ©, G.;de BoissÃ©son, C.;Jestin, V.

title: Comparative metagenomic profiling of symbiotic bacterial communities associated with Ixodes persulcatus, Ixodes pavlovskyi, and Dermacentor reticulatus ticks
abstract: Ixodes persulcatus, Ixodes pavlovskyi, and Dermacentor reticulatus ticks living in western Siberia are responsible for transmitting a number of pathogens that cause tick-borne diseases in humans and animals. Since these ticks are plentiful in the suburbs of large cities, agricultural areas and popular tourist spots, and often infest humans and livestock, data on the microbiome of these organisms are needed. Using 16S metagenomic profiling, we assess bacterial communities associated with I. persulcatus, I. pavlovskyi, and D. reticulatus ticks collected from the Novosibirsk region of Russia. A total of 1214 ticks were used for this study. DNA extracted from the ticks was pooled by tick species and sex. Sequencing of the V3-V5 domains of 16S rRNA genes was performed using the Illumina Miseq platform. The following bacterial genera were common in the studied communities: Acinetobacter (all three tick species), Rickettsia (I. persulcatus and D. reticulatus) and Francisella (D. reticulatus). B. burgdorferi sensu lato and B. miyamotoi sequences have been detected in I. persulcatus and I. pavlovskyi but not in D. reticulatus ticks. The pooled samples of all tick species examined contained bacteria from the Anaplasmataceae family, although their abundance was low. DNA from A. phagocytophilum and Candidatus Neoehrlichia mikurensis was first observed in I. pavlovskyi ticks. Significant interspecies differences were observed in the number of bacterial taxa as well as in intraspecies diversity associated with tick sex. The bacterial communities associated with the I. pavlovskyi ticks showed higher biodiversity compared to those of the I. persulcatus and D. reticulatus ticks. Bacterial community structure was also diverse among the tick species studied, as shown by permutation analysis of variance using the Bray-Curtis dissimilarity metric (p=0.002). The variation between sexes was confirmed by PERMANOVA tests in I. persulcatus (p=0.042) and I. pavlovskyi (p=0.042) ticks. Our study showed that 16S metagenomic profiling could be used to rapidly estimate the abundance of medically important bacteria in tick populations inhabiting different natural biotopes, and thus the epidemic hazard of studied flocks.
authors: Kurilshikov, A.;Livanova, N. N.;Fomenko, N. V.;Tupikin, A. E.;Rar, V. A.;Kabilov, M. R.;Livanov, S. G.;Tikunova, N. V.

title: Genetic diversity and intergenogroup recombination events of sapoviruses detected in pig feces in Japan
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaV) are enteric viruses that infect humans and animals. SaVs are very diverse and are divided into several genogroups based on structural protein sequences (VP1). SaVs detected in pigs belong to eight genogroups (GIII, GV, GVI, GVII, GVIII, GIX, GX, and GXI), but little is known about the distribution of SaV genogroups in the Japanese pig population. In the present study, 26 nearly complete genomes (> 6000 nucleotides: nt) and three partial sequences (2429 nt, 4364 nt and 4419 nt length, including the entire VP1 coding region) of SaV were obtained from one diarrhea patient and 15 non-patients - Diarrheal pig feces in Japan via a metagenomic approach. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete VP1 amino acid sequence (aa) revealed that 29 porcine SaVs were classified into seven genogroups; GIII (11 strains), GV (1 strain), GVI (3 strains), GVII (6 strains), GVIII (1 strain), GX (3 strains) and GXI (4 strains). This manuscript presents the first nearly complete genome sequences of GX and GXI and demonstrates novel recombination events between genogroups.
authors: Kuroda, M.;Masuda, T.;Ito, M.;Naoi, Y.;Doan, Y. H.;Haga, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Kishimoto, M.;Sano, K.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Aoki, H.;Ichimaru, T.;Sunaga, F.;Mukono, I.;Yamasato, H.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Oka, T.;Nagai, M.

title: A rapid and robust method for full genome sequencing of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) type 1 and type 2
abstract: PRRSV is a positive-sense RNA virus with a high degree of genetic variability among isolates. Monitoring the genetic diversity of PRRSV is essential for diagnostic sensitivity and vaccine design. However, only a few complete genome sequences of PRRSV isolates have been made publicly available to date. In the present study, rapid and robust methods for long-range RT-PCR amplification and subsequent next-generation sequencing (NGS) were developed and validated on nine type 1 and nine type 2 PRRSV viruses. The methods generated robust and reliable sequences on both primary material and cell culture-adapted viruses, and the protocols performed well on all three NGS platforms tested (Roche 454 FLX, Illumina HiSeq2000, and Ion Torrent PGMTM Sequencer). These methods will greatly facilitate the generation of more complete PRRSV genome sequences worldwide.
authors: Kvisgaard, L. K.;Hjulsager, C. K.;Fahnoe, U.;Breum, S. O.;Ait-Ali, T.;Larsen, L. E.

title: Molecular epidemiology of Newcastle disease in the Republic of Korea
abstract: 23 Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains isolated in the Republic of Korea between 1988 and 1999 were examined by partial nucleotide sequencing of the fusion gene (F) and phylogenetic analysis. Most Korean strains formed a distinctive cluster in genotype VI and were genetically distant (4.0-8.7%) from other subtypes (a, b, c, d, and e) and tentatively designated VIf. Some Korean strains isolated in 1995 were grouped into genotype VIIa and they were closer to Taiwanese strains than western Europeans. The results indicate that genotype VIf strains have been maintained by enzootic infections over the past decade, while genotype VIIa appears to have been introduced into the Republic of Korea only recently. © 2003 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kwon, H. J.;Cho, S. H.;Ahn, Y. J.;Seo, S. H.;Choi, K. S.;Kim, S. J.

title: Molecular epizootiology of recurrent low pathogenic avian influenza caused by H9N2 subtype virus in Korea
abstract: The first outbreak of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI), H9N2 virus subtype, in 1996 triggered an eradication effort, but LPAI returned to Korea in 1999. The relationship between the first and the recurring viruses is unclear. To determine the molecular epizootiology of recurrent LPAI, we performed a phylogenetic analysis using partial nucleotide sequences of four gene segments (HA, NA, NP, and PB2) from eight H9N2 viruses of chicken origin. The H9N2 recurrent viruses showed greater nucleotide similarity in the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes to the 1996 Korean isolates than other Eurasian viruses, and formed a clear cluster with the early Korean isolates and some isolates from migratory and domestic ducks in Japan and China. Phylogenetic analyzes using internal genes showed that some Korean isolates formed a cluster with other subtypes such as H5N1, H6N1 and H6N2 in China and Taiwan. These results suggest that the recurrent viruses are descendants of early Korean H9N2 isolates, but further studies are needed to explain their phylogenetic relationship to viruses in China. © 2006 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Kwon, H. J.;Cho, S. H.;Kim, M. C.;Ahn, Y. J.;Kim, S. J.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza a(H5N8) viruses reintroduced to South Korea in 2014-2015 by migratory waterfowl
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) viruses were isolated from migratory waterfowl in South Korea in fall 2014 to winter 2015, a reemergence after initial introduction in winter 2014. These reemerged viruses were phylogenetically distinct from isolates circulating in poultry farms in South Korea .
authors: Kwon, J. H.;Lee, D. H.;Swayne, D. E.;Noh, J. Y.;Yuk, S. S.;Erdene-Ochir, T. O.;Hong, W. T.;Jeong, J. H.;Jeong, S.;Gwon, G. B.;Song, C. S.

title: Prevalence of novel porcine circovirus 3 in Korean swine populations
abstract: Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV3) is a novel porcine circovirus that has been identified in pigs with porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome, reproductive failure and multisystemic inflammation. However, the distribution and genetic characteristics of the emerging PCV3 in Korea remain unclear. In this study, we determined the nationwide prevalence and genetic characteristics of PCV3 using pen saliva samples. The overall prevalence of PCV3 in individual samples and at the farm level was 44.2% (159/360) and 72.6% (53/73), respectively. Korean PCV3 conferred 99.2 ± 0.2% (98.9-99.8%) and 98.6 ± 0.5% (97.9-99.8%) nucleotide identity in the full genome and ORF2 in comparison, respectively those of US tribes. These data suggest that PCV3 is widespread in Korean swine populations.
authors: Kwon, T.;Yoo, S. J.;Park, C. K.;Lyoo, Y. S.

title: Different vaccination routes affect the infectivity and pathogenesis of H5N1 infection with the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus in chickens and domestic ducks
abstract: Classified as Qinghai-like virus (clade 2.2), H5N1 type A influenza viruses are a unique lineage of type A influenza viruses with the ability to cause significant disease and fatality in gallinaceous and anseriform birds, including domestic and wild ducks. The aim of this study was to determine the susceptibility and pathogenesis of chickens and domestic ducks to highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) A/Whooper Swan/Mongolia/224/05 (H5N1) when administered via the respiratory tract or diet. The chickens and ducks were more susceptible to H5N1 HPAI virus, as evidenced by low infectious and lethal virus doses, when exposed intranasally compared to dietary routes of vaccination (intragastric or orally fed infected chicken meat). In the dietary exposure pathogenesis study, pathological changes included hemorrhage, necrosis and inflammation associated with virus detection. These changes were generally observed in most chicken visceral organs between 2 and 4 days post-inoculation (DPI) and resemble lesions and viral localizations observed in birds in natural cases or in experimental studies using intranasal administration. Dietary exposure to the virus caused the ducks to develop a systemic infection characterized by moderate lymphocytic encephalitis, necrotized hepatitis, and pancreatitis with corresponding virus detection within the lesions. In both chickens and ducks with food exposure, lesions, virus, or both, were first detected in the upper alimentary tract at 1 DPI, suggesting that the alimentary tract was the first site to be affected after ingestion of infected meat or gavage of virus in liquid medium was affected . However, as shown in the chicken infectivity study, dietary infection required higher exposure doses to induce infection compared to intranasal exposure in chickens. These data suggest that upper respiratory exposure to the H5N1 HPAI virus in birds is more likely to result in virus infection and transmission than consumption of infected meat, unless the latter contains high levels of virus, such as those found in cannibalized infected carcasses are found. © American Association of Avian Pathologists 2010.
authors: Kwon, Y. K.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Virological surveillance and preliminary antigenic characterization of influenza viruses in pigs in five European countries from 2006 to 2008
abstract: This study presents the results of virological surveillance of swine influenza viruses (SIVs) in Belgium, UK, Italy, France and Spain from 2006 to 2008. Our main objectives were to clarify the occurrence of the three SIV subtypes - H1N1, H3N2 and H1N2 - at regional level for the identification of new reassortant viruses and for the antigenic comparison of SIVs with human H1N1 and H3N2 influenza viruses. Lung tissue and/or nasal swabs from outbreaks of acute respiratory disease in pigs were examined by virus isolation. The subtypes of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) were determined using standard methods. Out of a total of 169 viruses, 81 were classified as "bird-like" H1N1, 36 as human-like H3N2 and 47 as human-like H1N2. Only five new reassortant viruses were identified: two H1N1 viruses had human-like HA and three H1N2 viruses had avian-like HA. All three SIV subtypes have been detected in Belgium, Italy and Spain, while only H1N1 and H1N2 viruses have been detected in the UK and north-west France. Cross-hemagglutination inhibition (HI) testing with hyperimmune sera against selected older and newer human influenza viruses revealed a strong antigenic relationship between 1980s human H1N1 and H3N2 viruses and H1N2 and H3N2 humanoid SIVs, confirming their common origin. However, antisera to human viruses isolated during the last decade did not react with currently circulating H1 or H3 SIVs, suggesting that young people in particular may be susceptible to some degree of SIV infection. © 2009 Blackwell Verlag GmbH.
authors: Kyriakis, C. S.;Brown, I. H.;Foni, E.;Kuntz-Simon, G.;Maldonado, J.;Madec, F.;Essen, S. C.;Chiapponi, C.;Van Reeth, K.

title: Deep Sequencing to Assess the Genetic Stability of Influenza A/California/07/2009 (H1N1) Vaccine Viruses
abstract: Viral growth during the manufacture of influenza vaccines can lead to mutations that alter the antigenic properties of the virus and thus compromise the protective efficacy of the vaccine. Various reassortants of pandemic "swine" H1N1 influenza A vaccine viruses (121XP, X-179A and X-181) and wild-type strains A/California/07/2009(H1N1) and A/PR/8/34 have been identified propagated embryonated eggs and used for Illumina HiSeq and MiSeq DNA/RNA sequencing. The RNA sequences of these viruses published in the NCBI were used as references for aligning the sequencing reads generated in this study. Consensus sequences of these viruses differed from the NCBI deposited sequences at several nucleotides. 121XP strain obtained by reverse genetics was more heterogeneous than X-179A and X-181 strain produced by conventional reassortant technology. The passaged 121XP virus contained four non-synonymous mutations in the HA gene. One of these mutations (Lys226Glu) was in the antigenic Ca site of HA (present in 18% of the population). Two non-synonymous mutations were present in HA from viruses derived from X-179A: Pro314Gln (18%) and Asn146Asp (78%). The latter mutation, located in the Sa antigenic site, was also detected at a low level (11%) in wild-type A/California/07/2009(H1N1) virus and was present as a complete substitution in those X-181-derived Viruses present from the X-179A virus. In the passaged X-181 viruses, two mutations occurred in HA: a silent mutation A1398G (31%) in one batch and G756T (Glu252Asp, 47%) in another batch. The latter mutation was localized in the conservative region of the Ca antigenic site. The RNA sequencing protocol proved to be robust, reproducible and suitable for monitoring the genetic consistency of influenza vaccine seed stocks.
authors: Laassri, M.;Zagorodnyaya, T.;Plant, E. P.;Petrovskaya, S.;Bidzhieva, B.;Ye, Z.;Simonyan, V.;Chumakov, K.

title: Genomic and phylogenetic characterization of viruses contained in the Manzanilla and Oropouche species complexes of the genus Orthobunyavirus, family Bunyaviridae
abstract: thorough characterization of the genetic diversity of viruses present in vector and vertebrate host populations is essential for the early detection of and response to emerging pathogenic viruses, yet the genetic characterization of many important virus groups remains incomplete. The Simbu serogroup of the genus Orthobunyavirus, family Bunyaviridae is an example. The Simbu serogroup currently consists of a very diverse group of related arboviruses that infect both humans and economically important livestock species. Here we report complete genome sequences for 11 viruses within this group, with a focus on the large and poorly characterized Manzanilla and Oropouche species complexes. Phylogenetic and pairwise divergence analyzes revealed the presence of high genetic diversity within these two species complexes, consistent with that of the five other species complexes in the Simbu serogroup. Based on previously reported interspecies divergence thresholds, the data suggested that these two complexes should indeed be divided into at least five species. Together these five species formed a distinct phylogenetic clade apart from the rest of the Simbu serogroup. Pairwise sequence divergences between viruses in this group and viruses in other species complexes of the Simbu serogroup were similar to the degrees of divergence between the other orthobunyavirus serogroups. The genetic data also suggested a relatively high level of natural rearrangement, with three potential rearrangement events present, including two well-documented events involving viruses known to infect humans.
authors: Ladner, J. T.;Savji, N.;Lofts, L.;da Rosa, A. T.;Wiley, M. R.;Gestole, M. C.;Rosen, G. E.;Guzman, H.;Vasconcelos, P. F. C.;Nunes, M. R. T.;Kochel, T. J.;Ian Lipkin, W.;Tesh, R. B.;Palacios, G.

title: Diversity of viruses detected by deep sequencing in pigs with a common background
abstract: Although advances in nucleic acid sequencing have enabled the discovery of many infectious agents, challenges remain for scientists and veterinary diagnosticians attempting to design animal studies with a minimum of variables and to interpret laboratory results. To evaluate the pyrosequencing technology as a potential screening method to predict vioma in pigs, fecal samples were collected from 4 pigs from a group of 175 pigs reared together since birth. A number of viruses were detected, demonstrating the application of this technology to determine "background noise" in the pigs. However, pyrosequencing also revealed the diversity of viruses within an animal group and how this can confuse experimental design and obscure a definitive diagnosis. © 2012 The author(s).
authors: Lager, K. M.;Ng, T. F.;Bayles, D. O.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E. L.;Cheung, A. K.

title: Characterization of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated from domestic poultry in China
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) H5N1 has caused several outbreaks in domestic poultry. Despite great efforts to contain the spread of this virus, it is evolving and poses a significant public health threat due to a high mortality rate. In this study, we sequenced entire genomes of eight H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated from domestic fowl in eastern China, and compared them to those of typical influenza virus strains. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that all eight genomes belonged to clade 2.3.2.1 and clade 7.2, the two main circulating clades in China. Viruses clustered in clade 2.3.2.1 shared a high degree of homology with H5N1 isolates from East Asia. Isolates accumulating in clade 7.2 have been found to circulate across China, with an east-west density gradient. Pathogenicity studies in mice showed that these isolates replicate in the lungs and clade 2.3.2.1 viruses have a significantly higher level of virulence compared to clade 7.2 viruses. Our results contribute to the elucidation of the biological characterization and pathogenicity of HPAI H5N1 viruses.
authors: Lai, C. C.;Wang, K. Y.;Chen, R.;Zhang, A. J.;Gu, H. J.;Yin, Y. B.;Wang, D. D.;Liu, L. L.;Xing, L.;Tong, Y. G.;Ma, Z. J.;Yang, P. H.;Wang, X. L.

title: Serological characterization of Buffalopox virus
abstract: Buffalopox virus has been classified as a member of the variola vaccinia subgroup of poxviruses based on a number of biological properties and serological tests. A recent study showed differences in electrophoretic behavior between buffalo and vaccinia virus antigens. The present study was conducted to extend previous knowledge of the close relationship of buffalo, vaccinia, and cowpox viruses using gel diffusion, immunoelectrophoresis, and complement fixation assays. All of these observations indicate that buffalo opoxvirus is a separate entity, closely related to vaccinia and vaccinia viruses, and support the inclusion of buffalo opoxvirus in subgroup I of the poxviruses.
authors: Lal, S. M.;Singh, I. P.

title: Real-time PCR method for the simultaneous detection, quantification and differentiation of capripox viruses
abstract: The genus Capripoxvirus (CaPV) comprises three members, namely sheeppox virus (SPPV.), goatpox virus (GTPV) and lumpy skin disease virus (LSDV), affecting sheep, goats and cattle, respectively. CaPV infections produce similar symptoms in sheep and goats, and the three viruses cannot be distinguished serologically. As there are conflicting opinions on the host specificity of CaPVs, particularly for goatpox and ovinepox viruses, the development of rapid genotyping tools will enable more accurate disease diagnosis and surveillance for better management of capripox outbreaks. This paper describes a species-specific real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) based on unique molecular markers found in the G protein-coupled chemokine receptor (GPCR) gene sequences of CaPVs, using dual hybridization probes for their simultaneous detection, quantification and genotyping. The assay can differentiate between CaPV strains based on differences in melting point temperature (Tm) obtained after fluorescence melting curve analysis (FMCA). It is highly sensitive and has low intra- and inter-run variation. This real-time PCR assay will make a significant contribution to CaPV diagnosis and better understanding of CaPV epidemiology by enabling rapid genotyping and gene-based classification of viral strains and unambiguous identification of isolates. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Lamien, C. E.;Lelenta, M.;Goger, W.;Silber, R.;Tuppurainen, E.;Matijevic, M.;Luckins, A. G.;Diallo, A.

title: Circulation of several subtypes of bovine viral diarrheal virus type 1 without evidence of HoBi-like pestivirus in cattle herds in southern Italy
abstract: Bovine pestiviruses include Bovine Virus Diarrhea 1 (BVDV-1) and 2 (BVDV-2) and an emerging group called HoBi-like pestivirus. In the present work, the results of an epidemiological study of pestiviruses circulating in cattle in southern Italy are presented. Molecular testing performed on a total of 924 bovine samples identified 74 BVDV strains, including 73 BVDV-1 and 1 BVDV-2 virus. A phylogenetic analysis performed on partial 5-UTR and Npro sequences revealed the presence of 6 different subtypes of BVDV-1 and a single BVDV-2c strain. BVDV-1 showed a high level of genetic heterogeneity, which may have both prophylactic and diagnostic implications. Furthermore, the detection of BVDV-2c underscores the need for continuous monitoring for the emergence of new pestivirus strains in cattle ranches in southern Italy.
authors: Lanave, G.;Decaro, N.;Lucente, M. S.;Guercio, A.;Cavaliere, N.;Purpari, G.;Padalino, I.;Larocca, V.;Antoci, F.;Marino, P. A.;Buonavoglia, C.;Elia, G.

title: Novel orthopoxvirus and fatal disease in cats, Italy
abstract: We report the detection and full genome characterization of a novel orthopoxvirus (OPXV) responsible for a fatal infection in a cat. The virus induced skin lesions characterized histologically by leukocyte infiltration and eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. Various PCR approaches could not assign the virus to any defined OPXV species. Large amounts of typical brick-shaped virions morphologically related to OPXV were observed by electron microscopy. This OPXV strain (Italy_09/17) was isolated on cell cultures and embryonated eggs. Phylogenetic analysis of 9 concatenated genes showed that this virus was distantly related to vaccinia virus, more closely related to ectromelia virus, and belonged to the same OPXV cluster recently isolated from captive macaques in Italy. Comprehensive epidemiological surveillance in cats and rodents will assess whether cats are adventitious hosts and whether rodents are the main reservoir of the virus. The zoonotic potential of this novel virus also deserves further investigation.
authors: Lanave, G.;Dowgier, G.;Decaro, N.;Albanese, F.;Brogi, E.;Parisi, A.;Losurdo, M.;Lavazza, A.;Martella, V.;Buonavoglia, C.;Elia, G.

title: Neuartige Bocaparvoviren bei Kaninchen
abstract: Bocaparvovirus is a newly established genus within the Parvoviridae family and has been identified as a possible cause of enteric, respiratory, reproductive/neonatal and neurological diseases in humans and several animal species. In this study, metagenomic analysis was used to identify and characterize a novel bocaparvovirus in feces of rabbits with enteric disease. To assess the prevalence of the novel virus, rectal swabs and fecal samples from rabbits with and without diarrhea were screened using a specific PCR assay. The complete genome sequence of the novel parvovirus has been reconstructed. The virus was distantly related to other bocaparvoviruses; the three ORFs shared 53%, 53%, and 50% nucleotide identity, respectively, with homologous genes from porcine bocaparvoviruses. Virus was detected in 8/29 (28%) and 16/95 (17%) specimens from rabbits with and without diarrhea, respectively. Sequencing of the capsid protein fragment targeted by diagnostic PCR identified two distinct Bocaparvovirus populations/subtypes with 91.7-94.5% nucleotide identity to each other. Incorporating these novel parvoviruses into rabbit disease diagnostic algorithms could help inform their potential pathogenic role and impact on rabbit production and virological profiles of laboratory rabbits.
authors: Lanave, G.;Martella, V.;Farkas, S. L.;Marton, S.;FehÃ©r, E.;Bodnar, L.;Lavazza, A.;Decaro, N.;Buonavoglia, C.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Avian Flu - Eradication in commercial poultry is still nowhere in sight
abstract: Avian influenza viruses are highly contagious microorganisms that mainly affect birds. Nonetheless, they have also been isolated from a number of mammals, including humans. The avian flu virus can cause great economic losses to the poultry industry due to its high mortality rate. Although there are pathogenic variants with low virulence, which usually cause only mild or no clinical symptoms, subtypes H5 and H7 can mutate from a low virulence to a high virulence (pathogenic) virus and should be considered in eradication strategies. The primary source of infection for farmed poultry is direct and indirect contact with wild birds, with waterfowl being a natural reservoir of the virus. Live poultry markets, exotic birds and ostriches also play a significant role in avian influenza epidemiology. Secondary transmission (ie between poultry farms) of the avian influenza virus is mainly attributed to fomites and humans. Airborne transmission is also important, and the virus can be spread in humans through aerosols. Diagnostic tests detect viral proteins and genes. Virus-specific antibodies can be detected by serological testing, with virus isolation and identification being complementary methods. The number of bird flu outbreaks seems to be increasing - in the last 5 years outbreaks have been reported from Italy, Hong Kong, Chile, Netherlands, South Korea, Vietnam, Japan, Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, China, Pakistan, United States of America, Canada, South Africa and Malaysia. In addition, a growing number of human cases of avian influenza, some fatal, have been occurring in parallel with outbreaks in commercial poultry. There is great concern about the possibility that a new virus subtype with pandemic potential could emerge from these outbreaks. From a human health perspective, eradicating the virus in poultry is imperative; However, the large number of small-scale poultry farms, lack of control experience and resources, and international scale of transmission and infection make rapid control and long-term prevention of recurrence difficult. In the western world, renewed interest in free-range farming poses a threat to future outbreaks. The growing ethical objections to large-scale bird culling call for a different approach to eradicating avian influenza.
authors: Landman, W. J. M.;Schrier, C. C.

title: Three novel canine papillomaviruses support the formation of taxonomic clades
abstract: More than 100 human papillomaviruses (HPVs) have been identified and their entire genomes sequenced. Most of these HPVs can be divided into three different genera, the alpha, beta, and gamma papillomaviruses (PVs). It should be noted that only one or a small number of PVs were identified for each individual animal species. However, four canine PVs (CPVs) (COPV, CPV2, CPV3 and CPV4) have been described and their entire genomic sequences published. Because of their sequence similarities, they belong to three different clades. In the present study, circular viral DNA was amplified from three dogs showing evidence of pigmented plaques, endophytic papilloma, or squamous cell carcinoma in situ. Analysis of the DNA sequences suggested that these are three new viruses (CPV5, CPV6 and CPV7) whose genomes contain all the conserved sequence elements of known PVs. The genomes of these seven CPVs were compared to properly classify them. Interestingly, phylogenetic analysis as well as pairwise sequence alignments of the putative amino acid sequences showed that CPV5 grouped well with CPV3 and CPV4, while CPV7 grouped with CPV2, but neither group matched other classified PVs. However, CPV6 groups with COPV, a lambda PV. Based on this evidence, therefore, the assignment of CPVs to three different clades could be supported. Therefore, similar to HPVs, it could be that the known and currently unknown CPVs are related and form only a few clades or genera. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Lange, C. E.;Tobler, K.;Ackermann, M.;Panakova, L.;Thoday, K. L.;Favrot, C.

title: Tick-borne viruses: an overview from a therapeutic perspective
abstract: Worldwide, several important human diseases are caused by tick-borne viruses. These diseases have become major public health concerns in recent years. The tick-borne viruses that cause disease in humans mainly belong to three families: Bunyaviridae, Flaviviridae, and Reoviridae. In this review, we focus on therapeutic approaches for some of the more important tick-borne viruses from these 3 families. These viruses are Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHF) and the newly discovered tick-borne phleboviruses known as thrombocytopenia syndrome virus (SFTSV), heartland virus and bhanja virus of the Bunyaviridae family, tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV ), Powassan virus (POWV), Louping ill virus (LIV), Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus (OHFV), Kyasanur forest disease virus (KFDV) and Alkhurma hemorrhagic fever virus (AHFV) from the Flaviviridae family. To date, there is no effective antiviral drug against most of these tick-borne viruses. Although antiviral drugs such as ribavirin are commonly used to treat CCHF in some countries, there are concerns that ribavirin may not be as effective against CCHF as initially thought. Here we also discuss the availability of vaccines to combat these viral infections. The lack of treatment and prevention approaches for these viruses is highlighted and we hope this review can increase public health awareness of the threat posed by this group of viruses. © 2014 Elsevier GmbH.
authors: Lani, R.;Moghaddam, E.;Haghani, A.;Chang, L. Y.;AbuBakar, S.;Zandi, K.

title: Habitat and genome structure of the marine Pseudoalteromonas siphovirus B8b isolated from the northwest Mediterranean
abstract: Marine viruses (phages) alter bacterial diversity and evolution with implications for marine biogeochemical cycles, and yet few well-developed model systems limit the possibilities for hypothesis testing. Here we isolate Mediterranean phage B8b using Pseudoalteromonas sp. QC-44 as a host and characterize it using myriad techniques. Morphologically, phage B8b has been classified as a member of the Siphoviridae family. One-step growth analysis showed that this siphovirus had a latency period of 70 min and released 172 new virus particles per cell. Host range analysis against 89 bacterial host strains revealed that phage B8b encoded 3 Pseudoalteromonas strains (52 tested, >99.9% nucleotide identity of 16S rRNA gene) and 1 non-Pseudoaltermonas strain related to Alteromonas sp. (37 strains from 6 genera tested), helping to limit the phylogenetic distance possible in a phage-mediated horizontal gene transfer event. The genome size of Pseudoalteromonas phage B8b was 42.7 kb, with clear structural and replication modules, the former being delineated by exploiting the identification of 16 structural genes by virion structural proteomics, only 4 of which showed any similarity to known structural proteins. In nature, this phage was widespread in coastal marine environments in both photic and aphotic layers (found in 26.5% of available viral metagenomes), but was not abundant in any sample (average abundance per sample was 0.65% of reads ). Together, these data improve our understanding of siphoviruses in nature and provide fundamental information for a new "rare virosphere" phage-host model system.
authors: Lara, E.;Holmfeldt, K.;Solonenko, N.;Sa, E. L.;Ignacio-Espinoza, J. C.;Cornejo-Castillo, F. M.;Verberkmoes, N. C.;Vaque, D.;Sullivan, M. B.;Acinas, S. G.

title: Blood transcriptomes reveal novel parasitic zoonoses circulating in Madagascar's lemurs
abstract: Zoonoses are an imminent threat to the world's population, and nearly 75% of emerging infectious diseases can spread among wild animals, domestic animals and humans. A One World, One Health perspective provides us with an ideal framework to understand and potentially contain the spread of zoonoses, and the island of Madagascar serves as a natural laboratory for conducting these studies. Rapid habitat degradation and climate change on the island are contributing to more frequent contact between humans, livestock and wildlife, and increasing the potential for disease spread. Given Madagascar's long geographic isolation, coupled with the recent and repeated introduction of agricultural and invasive species, it is likely that a number of circulating pathogens in lemur populations remain uncharacterized. Therefore, it is imperative that new approaches for de novo pathogen discovery are implemented. To this end, we used non-targeted deep sequencing of blood transcriptomes from two species of critically endangered wild lemurs (Indri indri and Propithecus diadema) to characterize blood-borne pathogens. Our results reveal several undescribed vector-borne parasites circulating in lemurs, some of which can cause disease in wildlife, livestock, and humans. We anticipate that advanced methods for de novo identification of unknown pathogens will have broad utility in characterizing other complex disease transmission systems.
authors: Larsen, P. A.;Hayes, C. E.;Williams, C. V.;Junge, R. E.;Razafindramanana, J.;Mass, V.;Rakotondrainibe, H.;Yoder, A. D.

title: Characterization of a novel potyvirus that naturally infects chickpeas
abstract: During the growing seasons from 1999 to 2001, symptoms consisting of mosaic formation, stunting, yellowing, wilting, internodal shortening and phloem discoloration were observed in chickpeas (Cicer arietinum) grown in Chuquisaca Department, southern Bolivia. In some fields, around 10% of the plants showed virus-like symptoms and suffered from severely reduced seed yields. Lentils (Lens culinaris) were also observed to be infected, but not peas (Pisum sativum) or broad beans (Vicia faba) growing in nearby fields. Infected chickpea tissue reacted positively to the potyvirus group-specific monoclonal antibody (MAb), but there was no serological reaction with antisera to the yellow bean mosaic virus, yellow clover vein virus, cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus, pea seed-borne mosaic virus, bean common mosaic virus, or bean potyviruses -Common Mosaic Necrosis Virus. Western blots of total protein extracts probed with the potyvirus MAb revealed a single band of approximately 32 kDa. Comparative sequence analysis of cDNA clones generated from the putative coat protein gene consisted of 282 amino acids (31.9 kDa) and showed moderate identities of 67, 66, 163, 63 and 61% with the coat proteins of potyvirus Pepper Severe Mosaic Virus , Pepper Yellow Mosaic Virus, Potato Virus Y, Plum Pox Virus and Pepper Mottle Virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the coat protein amino acid sequence revealed that this virus is a unique member of the family Potyviridae and is phylogenetically most closely related to a group of Solanaceae-infecting potyviruses and not to other legume-infecting potyviruses. The proposed name for the new pathogen is Chickpea Yellow Mosaic Virus.
authors: Larsen, R. C.;Kaiser, W. J.;Wyatt, S. D.;Buxton-Druffel, K. L.;Berger, P. H.

title: Recent developments in research with BHV-4
abstract: Type 4 bovine herpesvirus is widespread in cattle herds around the world. Although the virus is not a direct pathogen, its role in secondary infections makes it an important pathogen for research purposes. The paper summarizes the results of foreign and domestic laboratories over the past five years. The main results of foreign research groups were the identification of a protein that plays a role in virus-cell interaction, some data on the replication cycle and a detailed study of viral DNA, which provided new clues for the classification of this virus in the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily. Ever since the first BHV-4 strain was isolated in Hungary (BARTHA, 1963), this virus has always been one of the main targets of their research activities. In animal experiments, they examined the spread, distribution, viremia and latency of the virus using various methods such as polymerase chain reaction, immunohistochemistry and virus isolation. The virus shares some characteristics of beta and gamma herpesviruses. During infection, the virus binds mainly to the respiratory and immune systems, persists in leukocytes for a very long time, periodically appears in blood serum and establishes persistent infection in nerve and nerve cells. immune tissue. By reducing the mitotic activity of leukocytes in vitro, the virus may play a role in inhibiting some immune functions.
authors: Laszlo, E.

title: Bats harbor various parvoviruses as a possible origin of mammalian dependoparvoviruses and a source of transmission between bats and swine
authors: Lau, S. K. P.;Ahmed, S. S.;Tsoi, H. W.

title: The discovery and sequence analysis of four avian deltacoronaviruses in the Middle East reveals interspecies hopping with recombination as a potential mechanism for bird-to-bird and bird-to-mammal transmission
abstract: The emergence of respiratory syndrome in the Middle East has once again demonstrated that animal coronaviruses (CoVs) are a potential source of human epidemics. To investigate deltacoronavirus diversity in animals in the Middle East, we tested fecal samples from 1,356 mammals and birds in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Four novel deltacoronaviruses were detected in eight birds from four species by reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR): FalCoV UAE-HKU27 from a hawk, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 from a Houbara bustard, PiCoV UAE-HKU29 from a pigeon, and QuaCoV UAE -HKU30 of five quail. Full genome sequencing showed that FalCoV UAE-HKU27, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 and PiCoV UAE-HKU29 belong to the same CoV species, suggesting recent interspecies transmission between hawks and their prey, Houbara bustards and pigeons, possibly along the food chain. Western blotting detected specific anti-FalCoV-UAE-HKU27 antibodies in 33 (75%) of 44 hawk serum samples, supporting true infection in hawks after virus ingestion. QuaCoV UAE-HKU30 belongs to the same CoV species as porcine coronavirus HKU15 (PorCoV HKU15) and sparrow coronavirus HKU17 (SpCoV HKU17), previously discovered in pigs and tree sparrows, respectively, and supporting bird-to-pig transmission. Recombination involving the spike protein is common in deltacoronaviruses, which may facilitate transmission between species. FalCoV UAE-HKU27, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 and PiCoV UAE-HKU29 originate from the recombination between white eye coronavirus HKU16 (WECoV HKU16) and magpie robin coronavirus HKU18 (MRCoV HKU18), QuaCoV UAE-HKU30 from recombination between PorCoV HKU15/SpCoV HKU17 and Munia coronavirus HKU13 (MunCoV HKU13) and PorCoV HKU15 from the recombination between SpCoV HKU17 and bulbul coronavirus HKU11 (BuCoV HKU11). Birds in the Middle East are hosts for various deltacoronaviruses with potential for transmission between species.IMPORTANT In an attempt to study deltacoronavirus diversity among mammals and birds in Dubai, four new deltacoronaviruses were identified in fecal samples from eight detected birds of four different species: FalCoV UAE-HKU27 from a falcon, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 from a Houbara bustard, PiCoV UAE-HKU29 from a pigeon and QuaCoV UAE-HKU30 from five quails. Genome analysis revealed evidence of recent interspecies transmission between hawks and their prey, Houbara bustards and pigeons, possibly along the food chain, as well as transmission from bird to pig. Recombination, which is known to be common in some coronaviruses, was also common in these deltacoronaviruses and occurred predominantly in the spike region. Such recombination, involving the receptor-binding protein, can contribute to the emergence of new viruses capable of infecting new hosts. Birds in the Middle East are hosts for various deltacoronaviruses with potential for transmission between species.
authors: Lau, S. K. P.;Wong, E. Y. M.;Tsang, C. C.;Ahmed, S. S.;Au-Yeung, R. K. H.;Yuen, K. Y.;Wernery, U.;Woo, P. C. Y.

title: Chickens harbor various picornaviruses derived from possible interspecies transmission using recombination
abstract: While chickens are an important reservoir for emerging pathogens such as avian influenza viruses, little is known about the diversity of picornaviruses in poultry. We have discovered a previously unknown variety of picornaviruses in chickens in Hong Kong. Picornaviruses were detected in 87 cloacal and 7 trachea samples from 93 out of 900 chickens by reverse transcription-PCR, and their partial 3Dpol gene sequences constitute five distinct clades (I to V) among the known picornaviruses. Analysis of eight genomes from different strains revealed seven different picornaviruses, including six new picornavirus species (ChPV1 from strain I, ChPV2 and ChPV3 from strain II, ChPV4 and ChPV5 from strain III, ChGV1 from strain IV) and one existing species (bird -encephalomyelitis virus). from group V). The six novel chicken picornavirus genomes presented distinct phylogenetic locations and genomic features distinct from related picornaviruses, supporting their classification as separate species. In addition, ChPV1 may potentially belong to a new genus, with low sequence homologies to related picornaviruses, particularly in the P1 and P2 regions, including the predicted L and 2A proteins. Nevertheless, these novel picornaviruses were most closely related to picornaviruses from other avian species (ChPV1 related to Passerivirus A, ChPV2 and ChPV3 to Avisivirus A and Duck Hepatitis A virus, ChPV4 and ChPV5 to Melegrivirus A, ChGV1 to Gallivirus A). In addition, ChPV5 represented a potential recombinant picornavirus whose P2 and P3 regions may be derived from melegrivirus A. Chickens are an important reservoir for various picornaviruses that can cross avian species barriers through mutation or recombination. © 2014 The Authors.
authors: Lau, S. K. P.;Woo, P. C. Y.;Yip, C. C. Y.;Li, K. S. M.;Fan, R. Y. Y.;Bai, R.;Huang, Y.;Chan, K. H.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of a novel porcine astrovirus: relationship to other astroviruses
abstract: Emerging viruses pose a constant threat to human health and livestock, as evidenced by multiple outbreaks of influenza, henipavirus and SARS. Knowledge of the diversity of viromes present in reservoir species can lead to a better understanding of the origin of emerging pathogens. In this study, we advance the knowledge of porcine astrovirus diversity by reporting the genetic characterization of an unknown astrovirus lineage. Phylogenetic analyzes provided evidence that this porcine astrovirus lineage is unique and appears to share no common ancestor with any known mamastrovirus. The data reported in this study extends the number of porcine astrovirus lineages to a total of five, all of which most likely represent different species from different origins. Â© 2011 Her Majesty the Queen in the Right of Canada, represented by the Minister for the Environment.
authors: Laurin, M. A.;Dastor, M.;L'Homme, Y.

title: Molecular variation in the nucleoprotein gene (ORF7) of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV)
abstract: The nucleoprotein gene (ORF7) of 15 European isolates of the Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) was sequenced and compared with corresponding sequences of other PRRSV isolates (2 European and 13 American) and one isolate each of other arteriviruses (lactate dehydrogenase increasing). virus (LDV), monkey hemorrhagic fever virus (SHFV) and equine arteritis virus (EAV)). Their phylogenetic relationships were established using neighbor joining and parsimony methods. Four lineages (PRRSV, LDV, SHFV and EAV) were distinguished. Two genotypes of PRRSV, European and American, could be further identified. The European PRRSV genotype was highly conserved. Analysis of the nucleotide and amino acid substitutions in PRRSV ORF7 revealed four stable regions that are conserved, probably because of their requirement for nucleocapsid function and/or structure. No constant accumulation of mutations in ORF7 could be pinpointed when examining either synonymous or non-synonymous mutations. The passage of European PRRSV in vivo had little impact on the ORF7 sequence: only a small number of synonymous substitutions in ORF7 were detectable, confirming its low variability. Copyright (C) 1998 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Le Gall, A.;Legeay, O.;Bourhy, H.;Arnauld, C.;Albina, E.;Jestin, A.

title: Biochemical and genomic characterization of musk duck parvovirus
abstract: duck parvovirus (DPV), isolated from musk ducks during the 1989 animal epidemic in France, was purified from inoculated allanto-amniotic fluids by CsCl density gradient centrifugation and characterized. For full and empty non-enveloped icosahedral virus particles, banding was observed at densities of 1.39-1.42 and 1.38, respectively, with a diameter of 22-23 nm. Viral proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and the estimated molecular weights of the 3 major proteins were 91, 78 and 58 kDa. The nucleic acid was shown to be a single-stranded DNA of approximately 5,300 bases terminated by palindromic hairpins. These results confirm the earlier classification of the virus in the family Parvoviridae by Jestin et al. [14] based on morphological and serological principles. The DPV DNA was reannealed indicating that complementary DNA strands were encapsulated. A partial restriction endonuclease map was also generated. This work represents the first biochemical and genomic description of a musky duck parvovirus.
authors: Le Gall-Recule, G.;Jestin, V.

title: Molecular characterization of foot-and-mouth disease serotype A viruses circulating in Vietnam in 2009
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) has been one of the main causes of endemic outbreaks in Vietnam in recent years. In this work, six foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) serotype A viruses collected during endemic outbreaks in January and February 2009 in four different provinces of Vietnam were genetically characterized with regard to their complete genome sequences. Genetic analysis based on the complete viral genome sequence showed that they were closely related, sharing 99.0-99.8% amino acid (aa) identity. Genetic and derived AS analyzes of the capsid-encoding gene VP1 showed that the six Vietnamese strains were all classified into genotype IX out of a total of 10 major genotypes worldwide, sharing 98.1-100% AS identity. They were most closely related to the type A strains recently isolated in Laos (A/LAO/36/2003, A/LAO/1/2006, A/LAO/6/2006, A/LAO/7/2006 and A / LAO/8/2006), Thailand (A/TAI/2/1997 and A/TAI/118/1987) and Malaysia (A/MAY/2/2002), the 88.3-95.5% nucleotide (nt ) identities. In contrast, Vietnamese type A strains showed low nt identities with the two ancient type A FMDVs isolated in Thailand in 1960 (a15thailand iso43) and in the Philippines in 1975 (aphilippines iso50), ranging from 77.3 to 80 .9% nt identity was enough. A multiple alignment based on the deduced amino acid sequences of the capsid VP1-encoding gene of type A FMDV revealed three amino acid substitutions between Vietnamese strains and the strains of other Southeast Asian countries (Laos, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines). Valine was substituted for alanine at residue 24, arginine for asparagine at residue 85, and threonine for serine at residue 196. In addition, type A FMDV strains recently isolated in Vietnam, Laos, Thailand and Malaysia all have an amino acid deletion at residue 140 of the capsid VP1 protein compared to the two ancient type A FMDV strains from Thailand and the Philippines, as well as most other Type A representatives worldwide. This article is the first to report the comprehensive genetic characterization of type A foot-and-mouth disease virus circulating in Vietnam. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Le, V. P.;Nguyen, T.;Lee, K. N.;Ko, Y. J.;Lee, H. S.;Nguyen, V. C.;Mai, T. D.;Do, T. H.;Kim, S. M.;Cho, I. S.;Park, J. H.

title: Heterogeneity and genetic variations of foot-and-mouth disease viruses of serotypes O and Asia 1 isolated in Vietnam
abstract: Six field foot-and-mouth disease viruses (FMDVs), including four strains of serotype O and two strains of serotype Asia 1, were collected from endemic outbreaks in 2005, 2006 and 2007 in four different provinces of Vietnam. The viruses were isolated and genetically characterized with regard to their complete genome sequences. Genetic analysis based on the complete genomic coding sequences revealed that the four serotype O FMDVs were related and shared 95.2% nucleotide (nt) identity and 97.5-97.6% amino acid (aa) identity . Genetic analysis and a pedigree based on the FMDV VP1 gene showed that the four present Vietnamese serotype O strains share a high degree of identity with other serotype O members of the Mya-98 lineage of the Southeast Asian (SEA) topotype exhibit. The four viruses were all clustered into the Mya 98 lineage of the SEA topotype and shared 92.3-95.6% nt and 93.4-96.7% aa identity. This finding of the Mya-98 lineage differed from previous reports that the Vietnamese serotype O strains belonged to the Cam-94 lineage of the SEA topotype and two other topotypes, Middle East South Asia (ME-SA) and Cathay. For the two serotype Asia 1 FMDVs, genetic analysis based on the complete genomic coding sequences as well as the VP1 gene revealed that they belonged to two genogroups, IV and V. Of note, the As1/VN/QT03/2007 strain of genogroup V, isolated in 2007, was very closely related to the pandemic Asia-1 strain that caused 2005 FMD outbreaks in China (Asia1/WHN/CHA/06, FJ906802) and Mongolia (Asia1/MOG/05, EF614458), and shared 99.0-99.3% nt and 99.5-100% aa identity. In contrast, the second genogroup IV strain As1/VN/LC04/2005 isolated in 2005 was closely related to all referenced Vietnamese serotype strains Asia 1 found in the GenBank databases, sharing 86.4– 100% nt and 90.9-100% aa identity with each. This study is the first description of the full genomic sequence of Vietnamese FMD serotypes O and Asia 1 and may provide evidence of the co-proliferation of different serotypes and subtypes of FMD in Vietnam in recent years. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Le, V. P.;Nguyen, T.;Park, J. H.;Kim, S. M.;Ko, Y. J.;Lee, H. S.;Nguyen, V. C.;Mai, T. D.;Do, T. H.;Cho, I. S.;Lee, K. N.

title: The human virus: new tools and concepts
authors: Lecuit, M.;Eloit, M.

title: Sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin gene of H9N2 Korean avian influenza viruses and assessment of the pathogenic potential of isolate MS96
abstract: Sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of five Korean H9N2 avian influenza virus (AIV) isolates showed that these viruses were closely related and may have come from the same source. HA1 subunit phylogenetic analysis of H9 subtype isolates revealed that Korean AIV isolates differed from isolates from Hong Kong poultry markets in 1997. None of the Korean AIVs had multiple basic amino acids at the HA cleavage site, conferring high pathogenicity on some H5 and H7 AIVs. Nucleoprotein and matrix gene phylogenetic analysis showed that Korean isolates cluster with AIVs of Eurasian origin. The pathogenic potential of one of the isolates (MS96) was evaluated after multiple passages in 14-day-old embryonated chicken eggs (ECE). Fourteen-day-old ECE derivatives of MS96 showed increased HA titer and increased embryo mortality in eggs; this was evident after the third passage in the 14 day old ECE. Sequence analysis of the MS96 cleavage site after the third and tenth passage in 14-day-old ECE revealed no changes in the amino acid sequence. The pathogenicity of MS96 after the tenth passage in 14-day-old eggs (MS96p10(ECE14)) was tested in 4-week-old specific pathogen-free chickens. The 14-day-old derivative MS96p10(ECE14) showed a broader tissue tropism and induced more severe clinical symptoms than the parent virus. Furthermore, after intranasal inoculation of 86-week-old broiler breeders and 30-week-old laying hens, the MS96p10(ECE14) derivative induced more severe signs of depression than the parental virus and a transient decline in egg production.
authors: Lee, C. W.;Song, C. S.;Lee, Y. J.;Mo, I. P.;Garcia, M.;Suarez, D. L.;Kim, S. J.

title: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza Viruses and the Generation of Novel Reassortants, USA, 2014-2015
abstract: Asian highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N8) spread to North America during autumn migration in 2014. A full genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of 32 H5 viruses identified new H5N1, H5N2, and H5N8 viruses that arose in late 2014 through a resort with low pathogenicity North American avian influenza viruses.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Bahl, J.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;Ip, H. S.;DeLiberto, T. J.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Characterization of Korean avian influenza viruses H5 and H7 with low pathogenicity in chickens
abstract: So far it has been known that all isolated highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAI) causing a systemic infection with a high mortality rate in poultry species belong to either the H5 or H7 subtypes. The HPAI viruses can arise due to the insertion of several basic amino acids at the cleavage site of the hemagglutinin protein after the low pathogenic H5 and H7 viruses were introduced into poultry. In the present study, we examined the phylogenetic characteristics of the low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAI) H5 (n=4) and H7 (n=3) isolated from wild birds in Korea by analyzing nucleotide sequences of all 8 gene segments of the viral genome. We also examined the infectivity, transmissibility and pathogenic potential of these viruses in chickens. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all viruses used in the study were in the Eurasian lineage and were similar to viruses isolated in Asian countries that share the East Asian-Australasian migratory bird flight path. Our H5N2 isolates failed to replicate and transfer to chickens, but the H7N8 isolates replicated and transferred to contact chickens efficiently. Additionally, since our H7N8 isolates caused watery diarrhea in chickens, these viruses may not only serve as progenitors of new strains of HPAI, but may also cause clinical disease in poultry. Although there have been no reports of LPAI mutations to HPAI in these regions, surveillance efforts in wild birds should focus on surveillance for introduction and transmission of HPAI H5N1 and LPAI H5 and H7 viruses. © 2012 Poultry Science Association Inc.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Kwon, J. H.;Park, J. K.;Lee, Y. N.;Yuk, S. S.;Lee, J. B.;Park, S. Y.;Choi, I. S.;Song, C. S.

title: Novel Reassortant Clade 2.3.4.4 Avian influenza A(H5N8) virus in wild waterfowl, Russia, 2016
abstract: The emergence of new avian influenza viruses in migratory birds is of concern as the virus may be spread during autumn migration. We report the identification of new highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype H5N8, clade 2.3.4.4 and their reassortment with other avian influenza viruses in aquatic and coastal birds of Siberia.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Sharshov, K.;Swayne, D. E.;Kurskaya, O.;Sobolev, I.;Kabilov, M.;Alekseev, A.;Irza, V.;Shestopalov, A.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H7N9) virus, Tennessee, USA, March 2017
abstract: In March 2017, the highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H7N9) was detected on 2 poultry farms in Tennessee, USA. Surveillance data and genetic analysis indicated multiple introductions of low pathogenicity avian influenza virus before mutation with high pathogenicity and transmission between farms. Monitoring of poultry should continue as low pathogenicity viruses are circulating and spreading to commercial poultry.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;Berhane, Y.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Reemergence of avian influenza A(H5N2) virus clade 2.3.4.4 in wild birds, Alaska, USA, 2016
abstract: We report the reemergence of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N2) virus clade 2.3.4.4 in a wild mallard duck in Alaska, USA, in August 2016. The identification of this virus in a migratory species confirms its low persistence in North America and that Potential for virus re-spreading during the 2016 autumn migration.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;DeLiberto, T. J.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Deep sequencing of H7N8 avian influenza viruses from the surveillance zone supports H7N8 avian influenza with high pathogenicity was confined to a single outbreak farm in Indiana in 2016
abstract: In mid-January 2016, there was an outbreak of the highly pathogenic H7N8 avian influenza virus (HPAIV) in commercial turkeys in Indiana. Surveillance within the 10 km control zone identified low pathogenicity H7N8 avian influenza virus (LPAIV) in nine surrounding flocks of turkeys but no other HPAIV-affected farm. We sequenced four of the H7N8 HPAIV isolated from the single farm and nine LPAIV identified during control zone surveillance. The assessment included a phylogenetic network analysis that suggested a close relationship between HPAIV and LPAIV, and that progenitor H7N8 LPAIV spread among affected Indiana turkey farms, followed by spontaneous mutation to HPAIV on a single premise through the acquisition of three basic ones Amino acids at the hemagglutinin cleavage side? site. Deep sequencing of available viruses failed to identify subpopulations in HPAIV or LPAIV, suggesting that mutation to HPAIV likely occurred in a single herd and that HPAIV has not spread to epidemiologically related LPAIV-affected herds.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Molecular epidemiological study of Newcastle disease virus in domestic ducks in Korea
abstract: To advance the epidemiological understanding of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV) virus found in domestic ducks in Korea, 14 NDV isolates from apparently healthy domestic ducks were characterized biologically and genetically. 13 and 1 isolate of NDV were classified as lentogenic and velogenic viruses, respectively, on the basis of in vivo pathogenicity tests. Twelve lentogenic viruses showed HA activity against horse erythrocytes, while 1 lentogenic virus and the velogenic virus were negative. Lentogenic viruses (n=13) had sequence motifs of 112ERQERL117 (n=1) or 112GRQGRL117 (n=12) at the F0 cleavage site, while velogenic virus (n=1) had a sequence motif of 112RRQKRF117 at the same site. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that at least three different genotypes can exist in domestic ducks in Korea; one class I genotype (genotype 2) and two class II genotypes (genotypes I and VII). The class I virus was most closely related to genotype 2 strains isolated in birds from the US, Germany and Denmark. Twelve class II lentogenic viruses were grouped into genotype I and then subdivided into at least three clusters, namely Aomori-like, Ulster2C-like and V4-like. Class II velogene virus has been assigned to genotype VII, which represents viruses responsible for recent epidemics in many Asian countries, including Korea. The epidemiological significance of domestic duck isolates of NDV in Korea is discussed. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lee, E. K.;Jeon, W. J.;Kwon, J. H.;Yang, C. B.;Choi, K. S.

title: Genetic diversity of isolates of infectious avian bronchitis virus in Korea between 2003 and 2006
abstract: Thirty-three field isolates of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were obtained from commercial chicken flocks in Korea between 2003 and 2006 and characterized phylogenetically by nucleotide sequence analysis of the hypervariable region of the IBV S1 gene. Our phylogenetic analysis revealed that recent field isolates of IBV formed at least three different phylogenetic types including KI, K-II and K-III. KI type IBV consisted of 13 native IBV isolates that developed from the Kr-EJ/95 strain and then split into the type K-Ia and type K-Ib lineages. K-II type IBV isolates (n=19) were closely related to nephropathogenic IBV variants from China and Japan. The K-III type isolate (Kr/D064/05) first identified in this study was closely related to enteric IBV variants of the Chinese strains that cause proventriculitis. Sequence comparisons revealed >27.5% amino acid differences between IBV types. The molecular epidemiological properties of IBV field isolates are briefly discussed.
authors: Lee, E. K.;Jeon, W. J.;Lee, Y. J.;Jeong, O. M.;Choi, J. G.;Kwon, J. H.;Choi, K. S.

title: The genome sequence of the Yaba-like disease virus, a yatapoxvirus
abstract: The genome sequence of Yaba-like disease virus (YLDV), an unclassified member of the genus Yatapoxvirus, has been determined. Excluding the terminal hairpin loops, the YLDV genome is 144,575 bp in length and contains inverted terminal repeats (ITRs) of 1883 bp. Within 20 nucleotides from the termini there is a sequence conserved in other poxviruses that is required for the resolution of concatemeric replicative DNA intermediates. The nucleotide composition of the genome is 73% A+T, but the ITRs are only 63% A+T. The genome contains 151 tightly packed open reading frames (ORFs) that are either ≤180 nucleotides in length or conserved in other poxviruses. ORFs within 23 kb of each end are transcribed toward the termini, while ORFs within the central region of the genome are encoded on each DNA strand. In the central region, ORFs have a conserved position, orientation, and sequence compared to vaccinia virus ORFs, and encode many enzymes, transcription factors, or structural proteins. In contrast, ORFs near the termini are more divergent and in seven cases have no counterparts in other poxviruses. The YLDV genome encodes several predicted immunomodulators; Examples include two proteins similar to CC chemokine receptors and predicted secreted proteins similar to MHC class I antigen, OX-2, interleukin-10/mda-7, poxvirus growth factor, serpins, and a type I interferon binding protein. Phylogenetic analysis showed that YLDV is very closely related to Yaba monkey tumor virus, but outside the yatapoxvirus genus, YLDV is more closely related to swinepoxvirus and leporipoxviruses than to other chordopoxvirus genera. © 2001 Academic Press.
authors: Lee, H. J.;Essani, K.;Smith, G. L.

title: Generation of reassortant influenza viruses within the non-industrial poultry system
abstract: We compared the genetic and biological properties of 35 influenza viruses with different epidemiological backgrounds in Korea, including canine influenza virus H3N2 (CIV). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that chicken-adapted H9N2 viruses (A/chicken/Korea/96006/96 [CK/Kor/96006-like]) acquired aquatic avian gene segments through reassortment, and these reassorted H9N2 viruses were more frequently detected from smaller poultry species than of farm poultry. Conversely, gene segments from CK/Kor/96006-like viruses were also detected in most domestic duck viruses. Interestingly, in contrast to wild waterfowl, domesticated ducks harbored close relatives of all eight gene segments of H3N2 CIV that preferred binding to avian receptors. Therefore, bi-directional virus transmission events between landfowl and waterfowl are believed to have occurred, particularly within the non-industrial poultry system. These events contributed to the generation of a novel reassortant, H3N2 CIV. To avoid generating other reassortants capable of interspecies transmission, gene movements in the non-industrial poultry systems should be elucidated and managed. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Lee, H. J.;Lee, D. H.;Lee, Y. N.;Kwon, J. S.;Lee, Y. J.;Lee, J. B.;Park, S. Y.;Choi, I. S.;Song, C. S.

title: Survival of prototype strains of somatic coliphage families in environmental aquatic environments and when exposed to monochromatic low-pressure UV radiation or heat
abstract: The potential use of specific taxonomic groups of somatic coliphages as viral indicators based on their aquatic persistence and prevalence was investigated. Representative type strains of the 4 major taxonomic groups of somatic coliphages were seeded into test water and an ambient surface water source of drinking water, and the survival of the seeded phages was measured over 90 days at temperatures of 23-25 and 4°C. The viruses Microviridae (strain type PhiX174), Siphoviridae (strain type Lambda) and Myoviridae (strain type T4) were the most persistent in the water at the tested temperatures. The Microviridae (type strain PhiX174) and the Siphoviridae (type strain Lambda) were the most resistant viruses to UV radiation, and the Myoviridae (type strain T4) and the Microviridae (type strain PhiX174) were the most resistant viruses to heat. Because of their longer persistence in water and their relative resistance to heat and/or UV radiation, the Myoviridae (type strain T4), the Microviridae (type strain PhiX174), and the Siphoviridae (type strain Lambda) were the preferred somatic coliphage candidates as aquatic faecal indicator viruses, the Microviridae (type strain PhiX174) being the most resistant to these conditions overall. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Lee, H. S.;Sobsey, M. D.

title: Genome-wide analysis of influenza virus RNA and nucleoprotein association
abstract: The genomes of the influenza A virus (IAV) consist of eight single-stranded RNA segments surrounded by viral nucleoprotein (NP) molecules. Classically, the interaction between NP and viral RNA (vRNA) is represented as a uniform pattern of “pearls on a string”. Using high-throughput sequencing of RNA isolated by cross-linking immunoprecipitation (HITS-CLIP), we identified the NP vRNA-binding profiles for two H1N1 IAV strains in virions. Contrary to the dominant model for vRNA packaging, NP in strains A/WSN/1933 and A/California/07/2009 does not bind vRNA uniformly, rather each vRNA segment has a unique binding profile that contains enriched or poor sites in the NP association. Interestingly, despite extensive sequence conservation, both H1N1 strains have similar but different NP-binding profiles. Peaks identified by HITS-CLIP were verified as true NP binding sites based on insensitivity to DNA antisense oligonucleotide-mediated RNase H digestion. Furthermore, analysis of the nucleotide content of NP peaks revealed that these sites are relatively G-rich and U-poor compared to the genome-wide nucleotide content, indicating a yet unidentified sequence bias for NP association in vivo. Taken together, our genome-wide study of NP-vRNA interaction has implications for understanding influenza vRNA architecture and genome packaging.
authors: Lee, N.;Le Sage, V.;Nanni, A. V.;Snyder, D. J.;Cooper, V. S.;Lakdawala, S. S.

title: First detection of a novel enterovirus G recombining a torovirus papain-like protease gene associated with diarrhea in pigs in South Korea
authors: Lee, S.;Lee, C.

title: Attenuated vaccines can recombine into virulent field viruses
abstract: Under experimental conditions, recombination between herpesviruses was observed in vitro and in vivo. This has raised safety concerns about the use of attenuated herpesvirus vaccines in human and veterinary medicine, and adds to other known concerns associated with their use, including reversal of virulence and disease arising from recurrent reactivation of a lifelong chronic infection. We used high-throughput sequencing to study the relationships between emergent field strains and vaccine strains of infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV, Gallid herpesvirus 1). We show that independent recombination events between different attenuated vaccine strains resulted in virulent recombinant viruses that became the dominant strains responsible for widespread diseases in Australian commercial poultry flocks. These results underscore the risks of using multiple different attenuated herpesvirus vaccines or vectors in the same populations.
authors: Lee, S. W.;Markham, P. F.;Coppo, M. J.;Legione, A. R.;Markham, J. F.;Noormohammadi, A. H.;Browning, G. F.;Ficorilli, N.;Hartley, C. A.;Devlin, J. M.

title: First complete genome sequence of infectious laryngotracheitis virus
abstract: Background: Infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV) is an alphaherpesvirus that causes acute respiratory disease in chickens worldwide. So far, only a complete genomic sequence of ILTV has been reported. This sequence was generated by concatenating subsequences from six different ILTV strains. Therefore, the complete genomic sequence of a single (individual) ILTV strain has not been previously determined. This study aimed to use high-throughput sequencing technology to determine the complete genomic sequence of a live attenuated vaccine strain of ILTV. Results: The complete genomic sequence of the ILTV Serva vaccine strain was determined, annotated and compared to the concatenated ILTV reference sequence. The genome size of the Serva strain was 152,628 bp, with a G+C content of 48%. A total of 80 predicted open reading frames were identified. The Serva strain had 96.5% DNA sequence identity with the concatenated ILTV sequence. Notably, the concatenated ILTV sequence was found to lack four major regions of sequence, including 528 bp and 594 bp of sequence in the UL29 and UL36 genes, respectively, and two copies of a 1563 bp sequence in the repeat regions. Significant differences in the size of the predicted translation products of 4 other genes (UL54, UL30, UL37 and UL38) were also identified. More than 530 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) have been identified. Most of the SNPs were located within three genomic regions corresponding to the sequence of the SA-2 ILTV vaccine strain in the ILTV concatenated sequence. Conclusions: This is the first complete genomic sequence of a single ILTV strain. This sequence will facilitate future comparative genomic studies of ILTV by providing a convenient reference sequence for sequence analysis of other ILTV strains. © 2011 Lee et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
