authors: Lee, S. W.;Markham, P. F.;Markham, J. F.;Petermann, I.;Noormohammadi, A. H.;Browning, G. F.;Ficorilli, N. P.;Hartley, C. A.;Devlin, J. M.

title: Dicer-2 and Piwi-mediated RNA interference in mosquito cells infected with Rift Valley fever virus
abstract: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a phlebovirus (family Bunyaviridae) transmitted by mosquitoes. It infects humans and ruminants and causes dramatic epidemics and animal diseases in Africa, Yemen and Saudi Arabia. While recent studies have demonstrated the importance of the nonstructural protein NSs as a major component of virulence in vertebrates, little is known about mosquito vector infection. Here we examined RVFV infection in three different mosquito cell lines, Aag2 cells from Aedes aegypti and U4.4 and C6/36 cells from Aedes albopictus. In contrast to mammalian cells, where NSs form nuclear filaments, U4.4 and Aag2 cells downregulated NSs expression such that NSs filaments were never formed in nuclei of U4.4 cells, and in the case of Aag2 cells, to one disappeared early after infection. In contrast, in C6/36 cells, NSs core filaments were visible throughout the course of infection. Analysis of virus-derived small interfering RNAs (viRNAs) by deep sequencing showed that production of viRNAs in C6/36 cells known to be Dicer-2 deficient was very low, but expressed some viRNAs bearing a Piwi signature . In contrast, Aag2 and U4.4 cells produced high levels of viRNAs that predominantly matched the S segment and displayed Dicer-2 and Piwi signatures. While 21 nucleotide (nt) Dicer-2 viRNAs were predominant during early infection, the population of 24- to 27-nt Piwi RNAs (piRNAs) progressively increased and later became prevalent during acute infection and during persistence. In Aag2 and U4.4 cells, the combined effects of the Dicer-2 and Piwi pathways elicited an efficient antiviral response, allowing, among other things, the suppression of NS filament formation and the establishment of persistence. In C6/36 cells, Piwi-mediated RNA interference (RNAi) appeared to be sufficient to elicit an antiviral response against secondary infection with a superinfecting virus. This study provides new insights into the role of Dicer and Piwi in mosquito antiviral defense and the development of the antiviral response in mosquitoes.
authors: Leger, P.;Lara, E.;Jagla, B.;Sismeiro, O.;Mansuroglu, Z.;Coppee, J. Y.;Bonnefoy, E.;Bouloy, M.

title: Exploring the contribution of bacteriophages to antibiotic resistance
abstract: Bacteriophages (phages) are the most abundant and diverse biological entities on our planet. They infect susceptible bacterial hosts, where they either multiply or persist. In the latter case, phages can transfer new functions to their hosts through gene transfer, thus contributing to their adaptation (short-term) and evolution (long-term). In this regard, the role of phages in the spread of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) among bacterial hosts in natural environments is not well understood. Here we perform a comprehensive analysis of 33 viromas from different habitats to investigate whether phage harbor ARGs. Our results indicate that while human-associated viromes do not or rarely carry ARGs, viromes from non-human sources (e.g., pig feces, raw sewage, and freshwater and marine environments) contain a large reservoir of ARGs, indicating that phage might play a part on the spread of antibiotic resistance. With this in mind, the role of phages should not be underestimated and should be considered when developing strategies to address the global antibiotic resistance crisis.
authors: Lekunberri, I.;Subirats, J.;Borrego, C. M.;BalcÃ¡zar, J. L.

title: First detection of mammalian orthoreovirus type 3 in pigs with diarrhea in Europe
abstract: Mammalian orthoreoviruses 3 (MRV3) have been described in pigs suffering from diarrhea from the USA and Asia. We first detected MRV3 in Europe (Italy) in piglets showing severe diarrhea associated with porcine epidemic diarrhea. The virus was phylogenetically related to European reoviruses of human and bat origin, and to US and Chinese porcine MRV3.
authors: Lelli, D.;Beato, M. S.;Cavicchio, L.;Lavazza, A.;Chiapponi, C.;Leopardi, S.;Baioni, L.;De Benedictis, P.;Moreno, A.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis and expression of recombinant vectors show that the binding protein G of bovine respiratory syncytial virus differs from that of human respiratory syncytial virus
abstract: Bovine respiratory syncytial (BRS) virus causes severe lower respiratory tract disease in calves, similar to the disease caused by human respiratory syncytial (HRS) virus in children. While there is antigenic cross-reactivity between the other important viral structural proteins, the major glycoprotein G of the BRS virus and that of the HRS virus are antigenically different. The G glycoprotein has been implicated as a binding protein for the HRS virus. We have performed a molecular comparison of the BRS virus glycoprotein G with its HRS virus counterparts. cDNA clones corresponding to BRS virus G glycoprotein mRNA were isolated and analyzed by dideoxynucleotide sequencing. BRS virus G-mRNA contained 838 nucleotides excluding poly(A) and had a large open reading frame encoding a polypeptide of 257 amino acid residues. The deduced amino acid sequence of the BRS virus G polypeptide revealed only 29-30% amino acid with the G protein of either HRS virus subgroup A or B. Despite this low level of identity, however, there were strong similarities in the predicted hydropathy profiles of the G BRS virus and HRS virus proteins. A cDNA molecule containing the complete G open reading frame of BRS virus G was inserted into the vaccinia virus thymidine kinase gene by homologous recombination, and a recombinant virus containing the BRS virus G protein gene was isolated. This recombinant virus expressed the BRS virus G protein as shown by Western immunoblot analysis and immunofluorescence of infected cells. The BRS virus G protein expressed from the recombinant vector was transported to infected cells and expressed on their surface. Antisera against BRS virus G protein prepared using the recombinant vector to immunize animals recognized BRS virus attachment protein but not HRS virus G protein and vice versa, indicating the lack of an antigenic Cross-reactivity confirmed between the BRS and HRS virus attachment proteins. Based on the data presented here, we conclude that BRS virus should be classified within the genus Pneumovirus in a separate group from HRS virus and that it is no more closely related to HRS virus subgroup A than to subgroup B of the HRS virus.
authors: Lerch, R. A.;Anderson, K.;Wertz, G. W.

title: Real-time PCR for simultaneous detection and genotyping of bovine viral diarrheal virus
abstract: Since two bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) genotypes occur in Belgian herds, their distinction is important for disease surveillance. A real-time quantitative PCR assay was developed to detect and classify genotypes I and II bovine viral diarrhea viruses. A pair of primers specific for highly conserved regions of the 5-UTR and two TaqMan probes were designed. The FAM and VIC-tagged probe sequences differed by three nucleotides, allowing differentiation between genotype I and II. Assay detectability of genotype I and II real-time PCR assays was 1000 and 100 copies, respectively. Very reproducible data was obtained, since the coefficients of variation of the threshold cycle values in the runs were less than 2.2%. The correct classification of genotype I and II viruses was assessed using reference strains and characterized field isolates of both genotypes. The applicability in clinical diagnostics was evaluated on pooled blood samples by measuring the FAM- and VIC-associated fluorescence after the run. 100% agreement with conventional RT-PCR method confirmed that this new technique could be used for routine detection of persistently infected immunotolerant animals. © 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Letellier, C.;Kerkhofs, P.

title: Detection and Genotyping of Bovine Diarrhea Virus by Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Amplification of the 5'-Untranslated Region
abstract: reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was developed to distinguish Bovine Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) from other pestiviruses and to genotype BVDV isolates. For this purpose, primer pairs in the 5' untranslated region (5'UTR) were chosen. Primers B(E) and B2 were in highly conserved regions and were pestivirus specific. Two primer pairs called B3B4 and B5B6 were specific for BVDV genotypes I and II, respectively. Using this technique, an amplification product of the expected size was obtained with either the B3B4 or the B5B6 primer pairs for the 107 BVDV isolates tested, but not for BDV or CSFV. For some isolates assigned to genotype II, sequence analysis of the PCR fragments confirmed their assignment to this genotype.
authors: Letellier, C.;Kerkhofs, P.;Wellemans, G.;Vanopdenbosch, E.

title: Surveillance of Avian Influenza Virus in Wild Birds in Georgia: 2009-2011
abstract: The Caucasus, on the border between Europe and Asia, is important for the migration and wintering of wild waterfowl. Three air routes, the Central Asian, the East African-West Asian and the Mediterranean/Black Sea air route converge in the Caucasus region. Therefore, the Caucasus region could serve as a migratory bridge for influenza virus transmission when birds accumulate in high concentrations during the post-breeding, migratory, and wintering seasons. Since August 2009, we have established a wild bird influenza virus surveillance network using five sampling areas geographically spread across suitable habitats in east and west Georgia. We took pairs of tracheal and cloacal swabs and fresh fecal samples. We collected 8343 swabs from 76 species belonging to 17 families in 11 avian orders, of which 84 were positive for avian influenza virus (AIV) by real-time RT-PCR. No highly pathogenic AIV (HPAIV) H5 or H7 viruses were detected. The overall AIV prevalence was 1.6%. We observed a peak prevalence in large gulls during autumn migration (5.3-9.8%), but a peak prevalence in black-headed gulls in spring (4.2-13%). In ducks, we observed an increased AIV prevalence during the autumn post-moult aggregation and migratory arrest period (6.3%), but at lower levels than in other more northerly post-moult areas in Eurasia. We observed another peak in prevalence during the wintering period (0.14-5.9%). Serological and virological surveillance of a breeding colony of Armenian gulls showed that adult birds were seropositive upon arrival at the breeding colony, but juveniles remained serologically and virologically negative for AIV throughout their time on the breeding grounds, in contrast to AIV data from gulls from elsewhere geographical areas regions. We show that close phylogenetic relatives of viruses isolated in Georgia originate from a wide geographic range across western and central Eurasia and from areas represented by several different flight routes likely connecting different host subpopulations. © 2013 Lewis et al.
authors: Lewis, N. S.;Javakhishvili, Z.;Russell, C. A.;Machablishvili, A.;Lexmond, P.;Verhagen, J. H.;Vuong, O.;Onashvili, T.;Donduashvili, M.;Smith, D. J.;Fouchier, R. A. M.

title: The evolution of foot-and-mouth disease virus: effects of recombination and selection
abstract: Foot-and-mouth disease virus is an economically important animal virus that exhibits extensive genetic and antigenic heterogeneity. To examine the evolutionary forces that have influenced the population dynamics of foot-and-mouth disease virus, single genes and the encoding genomes for the Eurasian (Asia1, A, C, and O) serotypes were analyzed for phylogenetic relatedness, recombination, and genetic diversity, and Selection. Our analyzes show that paraphyletic relationships between serotypes are not as prevalent as previously thought and suggest that convergent evolution may be obscuring the phylogenetic relationships. We provide evidence that the identification of recombinant sequences and recombination breakpoint patterns between and within serotypes is highly dependent on the level of genetic diversity and convergent traits present in a given dataset, as well as the methods used to detect recombination. Here we also examine the effects of adaptive positive selection on the capsid proteins and nonstructural genes 2B, 2C, 3A, and 3Cpro to identify genomic regions involved in genetic diversity and antigenic variation. Two different categories of positive selection at the amino acid level were examined; conservative (stabilizing) selection, which retains certain phenotypic properties of an amino acid residue and radical (destabilizing), and selection, which dramatically alters the phenotype and possibly the functional and/or structural features of the protein. Approximately 29% of the residues in the capsid proteins were under positive selection. Of these, 64% were under the influence of destabilizing selection, 80% under the influence of stabilizing selection, and 44% had phenotypic traits influenced by both types of selection. The majority of residues selected (74%) were outside of known antigenic sites; suggesting additional uncharacterized epitopes and genomic regions involved in antigenic drift. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lewis-Rogers, N.;McClellan, D. A.;Crandall, K. A.

title: Close relationship between the 2009 H1N1 virus and South Dakota AIV strains
abstract: Although previous publications suggest that the 2009 pandemic influenza A virus (H1N1) was rearranged from swine viruses of North America and Eurasia, the immediate ancestry always remains due to the large evolutionary distance between the 2009 H1N1 virus and the previously isolated strains still elusive. Since the H1N1 flu was unveiled in 2009, influenza has attracted a great deal of interest and as a result a large number of influenza virus sequences have been deposited in the public sequence databases. Blast analysis showed that the recently submitted South Dakota 2007 avian influenza virus strains and other North American avian influenza strains contained genetic segments very closely related to the 2009 H1N1 virus, suggesting that these avian influenza viruses are very closely related to the H1N1 virus are from 2009. Phylogenetic analyzes also indicate that the 2009 H1N1 viruses are associated with the avian and swine influenza viruses circulating in North America. Since the migratory wild birds are preferable to pigs as carriers to spread the influenza viruses over long distances, it is highly likely that birds played an important role in the intercontinental evolution of the 2009 H1N1 virus. It is important to understand the evolutionary path of the emerging influenza virus to find a way to prevent further emerging cases. This study points to the close relationship between the 2009 pandemic virus and North American avian viruses and highlights the increased surveillance of avian influenza to understand the evolution of the 2009 pandemic influenza. © 2011 Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Li, C.;An, X. P.;Mi, Z. Q.;Liu, D. B.;Jiang, H. H.;Pan, B.;Wang, S.;Chen, B.;Tong, Y. G.

title: Rumen microbiome related to feed efficiency and host genetics in beef cattle
authors: Li, F.

title: Origin, genetic diversity, and evolutionary dynamics of the novel porcine circovirus 3
abstract: Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV3) is a novel virus associated with acute PDNS-like clinical signs (porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome) identified by metagenomic sequencing of pigs. Its high abundance can pose a potential threat to the swine industry worldwide. The processes leading to the formation and spread of PCV3 are still poorly understood. Herein, the probable origin, genotypes, and evolutionary dynamics of PCV3 are determined based on available genomic sequences. The closest ancestor of PCV3 is found in clade 1 bat histories. Using various phylogenetic methods, two main genotypes are identified, PCV3a and PCV3b. The effective population size of PCV3 was found to have increased rapidly between late 2013 and early 2014 and this is associated with the diversification of PCV3a and PCV3b. Compared to other single-stranded DNA viruses, a relatively high value for the effective reproduction number (Re) and a higher evolutionary rate were found, and positive selection at codons 122 and 320 (24 of ORF2) was identified. It is hypothesized that this, together with the prediction of a possible change in an antigenic epitope at position 320, may have allowed PCV3 to evade the host immune response. Overall, this study has important implications for understanding ongoing PCV3 cases worldwide and will guide future efforts to develop effective prevention and control measures.
authors: Li, G.;He, W.;Zhu, H.;Bi, Y.;Wang, R.;Xing, G.;Zhang, C.;Zhou, J.;Yuen, K. Y.;Gao, G. F.;Su, S.

title: Comparative analysis of genes UL1 to UL7 of duck enteritis virus and other herpesviruses of the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of eight open reading frames (ORFs) located at the 5 inch end of the unique long region of clone 03 strain Duck Enteritis Virus (DEV) have been determined. The identified genes have been designated as UL1, UL2, UL3, UL4, UL5, UL6, and UL7 homologues of herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1). Located between UL3 and UL4, DEV UL3.5 had no homologue in HSV-1. The arrangement and transcriptional orientation of the eight genes was collinear with their homologues in HSV-1. Phylogenetic trees were constructed based on the deduced amino acid alignments of eight proteins with their homologues in 12 alpha-herpesviruses. In the UL1, UL3, UL3.5, UL5 and UL7 protein trees, the branches were more closely related to the genus Mardivirus. However, the phylogenetic trees of the UL2, UL4, and UL6 proteins showed a large distance from Mardivirus, suggesting that the DEV evolved differently from other viruses in the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily and formed a single branch within that subfamily. Copyright © 2009, Sociedade Brasileira de Genetica.
authors: Li, H.;Liu, S.;Han, Z.;Shao, Y.;Chen, S.;Kong, X.

title: Characterization of the genes encoding UL24, TK and gH proteins from duck enteritis virus (DEV): Evidence for the classification of DEV
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is assigned to the Herpesviridae family, but has not yet been assigned to any genus. Four overlapping fragments were amplified from the DEV genome using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The combined length of the four fragments was 6202 bp, containing the genes encoding unique long (UL) 24, thymidine kinase (TK), and glycoprotein H (gH) proteins. UL24 overlapped TK by 64 nucleotides (nt) in a head-to-head transcriptional orientation, and TK and gH had the same transcriptional orientation. Comparison of the amino acid sequences of these 3 derived DEV proteins with other 12 alphaherpesviruses revealed 5 highly conserved sites in UL24 as well as another 5 consensus regions in TK and 4 consensus regions in gH. The RNA polymerase II transcription control elements were identified in all DEV UL24, TK and gH. These elements included core promoters, TATA motifs and polyadenylation sites. The phylogenetic analysis for the genetic classification of DEV in the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily with other 12 alphaherpesviruses was calculated. The result showed that DEV was more closely related to avian herpesviruses than to other alphaherpesviruses, with the exception of infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV). After the phylogeny-based analysis and the homology comparison of the functional domains of UL24, TK and gH, DEV should finally be assigned to a separate genus of the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae in the family Herpesviridae. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Li, H.;Liu, S.;Kong, X.

title: Avian influenza virus, subtype H9N2, affects gut microbiota, barrier structure injury and inflammatory bowel disease in the ileum of chickens
abstract: The H9N2 subtype avian influenza virus (H9N2 AIV) has caused significant losses to the poultry industry due to the high mortality associated with secondary infections attributable to E. coli. This study attempts to investigate the underlying secondary mechanisms after H9N2-AIV infection. Initially, nine-day-old specific pathogen-free chickens were assigned to control (uninfected) and H9N2-infected groups, respectively. Using Illumina sequencing, histological examination, and real-time quantitative PCR, H9N2 AIV was found to cause gut microbiota disruption, injury, and inflammatory damage to the gut mucosa. Notably, five days post-infection (dpi), Escherichia genera, particularly E. coli, were significantly increased (p<0.01), while Lactobacillus, Enterococcus, and other probiotic organisms were significantly reduced (p<0.01). At the same time, mRNA expression of tight junction proteins (ZO-1, claudin 3 and occludin), TFF2 and Muc2 was significantly reduced (p<0.01), indicating disruption of tight junctions of intestinal epithelial cells and damage to the mucin layer Construction. In addition, mRNA expression of the pro-inflammatory cytokines IFN-gamma, IL-22, IFN-alpha and IL-17A was significantly upregulated in gut epithelial cells, resulting in an inflammatory response and gut injury. Our results may provide a theoretical basis for observed gastroenteritis-like symptoms such as diarrhea and secondary E. coli infection after H9N2-AIV infection.
authors: Li, H.;Liu, X.;Chen, F.;Zuo, K.;Wu, C.;Yan, Y.;Chen, W.;Lin, W.;Xie, Q.

title: Avian adenovirus species C serotype 4 is attributed to the occurrence of hepatitis hydropericardial syndrome in chickens in China
abstract: Since July 2015, an emerging infectious disease hepatitis hydropericardium syndrome (HHS) has been widespread in chicken flocks in China. In order to confirm the causative agent and examine the epidemiology of the disease, a total of 38 flocks of chickens, including 187 samples, from Jilin, Liaoning, Heilongjiang, Henan, Anhui, Hubei, Jiangxi, Xinjiang, Shandong and Hunan provinces in China were collected and determined by PCR -Detection, sequencing, phylogenetic analysis and virus isolation. 81 samples (positive rate of samples, 81/187, 43.3%) spread over 33 chicken flocks (positive rate of chicken flocks, 33/38, 86.8%) were detected as positive for avian adenovirus (FAdV) by the PCR method by of which 30 were identified as FAdV species C, 41 as species D, 9 as species E, and 1 as virus species by phylogenetic analysis, implying that at least three species (C, D, and E) of FAdVs were prevalent in China and the Types C and D were predominantly the predominant virus strains. Interestingly, our results showed that two types of FAdV (C and D) coexisted in a herd, leading to complex conditions for disease prevalence. In addition, 13 viral strains of FAdV-C were isolated from different geographic areas and one of the isolates from Henan province, designated HN/151025 strain, was inoculated into 40-day-old specific pathogen-free chickens via intramuscular or oral route to evaluate the pathogenicity. It was found that 90% (9/10) chickens in the intramuscular injection group died and 30% (3/10) birds in the oral infection group died after challenge. Histopathological examination showed that pathology was limited to liver, kidney, spleen and heart. These results indicated that the virus was a highly virulent strain.
authors: Li, H.;Wang, J.;Qiu, L.;Han, Z.;Liu, S.

title: Diagnosis of Peste des Petits ruminants in wild and domestic animals in Xinjiang, China, 2013–2016
abstract: In late 2013, Peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV) reemerged in China and then quickly spread to 22 provinces through movements of live goats and sheep. In this study, 96 domestic animal and 13 wild animal samples were analyzed by ELISA or RT-PCR for the presence of PPRV infection. Of 96 samples from sheep and goats, 91 were PPRV positive, while all 13 samples from three wild species, ibex (Capra ibex sibirica), argali (Ovis ammon) and goitered gazelle (Gazella subgutturosa) were positive. Five wild animal isolates from the above samples were identified as lineage IV by multiple alignment of the partial sequences in the N gene.
authors: Li, J.;Li, L.;Wu, X.;Liu, F.;Zou, Y.;Wang, Q.;Liu, C.;Bao, J.;Wang, W.;Ma, W.;Lin, H.;Huang, J.;Zheng, X.;Wang, Z.

title: Analysis of microRNAs expression profiles in Madin-Darby bovine kidney cells infected with caprine parainfluenza virus type 3
abstract: Caprine parainfluenza virus type 3 (CPIV3) is an emerging respiratory pathogen that infects both young and adult goats and was identified in eastern China in 2013. Cellular microRNAs (miRNAs) have been reported to be important modulators of intricate viral-host interactions. To elucidate the role of miRNAs in Madin-Darby bovine kidney (MDBK) cells during CPIV3 infection. In this study, we performed high-throughput sequencing technology to analyze small RNA libraries in CPIV3-infected and mock-infected MDBK cells. The results showed that a total of 249 known and 152 novel candidate miRNAs were differentially expressed in MDBK cells after CPIV3 infection, and 22,981 and 22,572 target genes were predicted, respectively. In addition, an RT-qPCR assay was used to further confirm the expression patterns of 13 of these differentially expressed miRNAs and their mRNA targets. Functional annotation analysis showed that these up- and down-regulated target genes are mainly involved in MAPK pathway, Jak-STAT pathway, Toll-like receptor pathway, p53 pathway, focal adhesion, NF-kappa B pathway, and apoptosis, etc. involved Al. To our knowledge, this is the first report on the comparative expression of miRNAs in MDBK cells after CPIV3 infection. Our result provides information about the expression profile of miRNAs in response to CPIV3 infection and offers clues to identify potential candidates for antiviral therapies against CPIV3.
authors: Li, J.;Mao, L.;Li, W.;Hao, F.;Zhong, C.;Zhu, X.;Ji, X.;Yang, L.;Zhang, W.;Liu, M.;Jiang, J.

title: Metagenomic identification, genetic characterization and genotyping of porcine sapoviruses
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaVs), belonging to the genus Sapovirus of the family Caliciviridae, have been known as enteric pathogens causing acute gastroenteritis. SaVs have been detected in humans and several animals, including pigs, and some porcine SaVs showed close sequence relatedness to human strains, suggesting the possibility of interspecies transmission. Here we sequenced the genomes of two porcine SaVs (strain names p38 and SH1703) using the metagenomic analyzes and traditional RT-PCR methods. Phylogenetic trees were constructed based on the full-length genome, VP1 nucleotide and amino acid sequences to group these two strains. The two porcine SaV strains, p38 and SH1703, detected in this study were classified as genogroup III and genogroup VII, respectively. These two strains showed similar genomic organization to other SaVs. We first divided SaVs into 51 genotypes within 19 genogroups. Our data are useful for the genetic characterization and classification of newly discovered SaVs worldwide.
authors: Li, J.;Zhang, W.;Cui, L.;Shen, Q.;Hua, X.

title: Fecal excretion of rotavirus vaccine in Chinese children after vaccination with Lanzhou lamb rotavirus vaccine
abstract: Lanzhou lamb rotavirus vaccine (LLR) is a live, attenuated oral vaccine first approved in China in 2000. To date, over 60 million LLR doses have been distributed to children. However, very little is known about the fecal excretion of LLR in children. Therefore, in September-November 2011/2012, faecal samples (n = 1,184) were collected from 114 children for 15 days after vaccination. Fecal output and viral load were determined using an enzyme immunoassay kit (EIA) and real-time RT-PCR. The complete genome was sequenced and the vaccine strain isolated by culture in MA104 cells. Approximately 14.0% (16/114) of the children had rotavirus-positive samples from EIA for at least 1 day after vaccination. Viral loads in EIA positive specimens ranged from < 1.0 x 103 to 1.9 x 108 copies/g. Fecal excretion occurred as early as day 2 post-vaccination and as late as day 13 post-vaccination, peaking at days 5-10. peak day after vaccination. An LLR strain was isolated by culture in MA104 cells. Sequence analysis showed 99% identity with the LLR prototype strain. Fecal excretion of LLR in faeces is common within 15 days after LLR vaccination, suggesting that vaccine strains can replicate in human intestinal tissues.
authors: Li, J. S.;Cao, B.;Gao, H. C.;Li, D.;Lin, L.;Li, L. L.;Liu, N.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Partial nucleotide sequencing of hepatitis E virus detected in sera from patients with hepatitis E from 14 cities in China
abstract: objective. Investigation of hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes detected in sera from patients from different regions of China. methods. The partial open reading frame 2 (ORF2) genomes (nt6461-6860, nt5994-6294) of 45 HEV strains detected in 14 cities in China were amplified and sequenced using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and direct sequencing. Results. Forty-one of 45 strains (91%) share the same genotype with HEV Burma strain (B), with greater than 98% nucleotide identities with the representative Chinese HEV strain. Only 4 HEV strains differ significantly from the 3 prototype HEV strains, with nucleotide identities of 77%-80% with the Burmese/Chinese HEV strain, 74%-76% with the Mexican strain, and 74%-77% with the neu discovered HEV US/pig strain. Phylogenetic analysis suggests that these 4 strains may represent 2 distinct subtypes belonging to a new genotype of HEV that differs significantly from the prototype strains from Mexico, Burma and US/pigs. Conclusion. Among the patients with hepatitis E in China, most are infected with the Chinese prototype HEV and only a small proportion with the new genotype HEV.
authors: Li, K.;Zhuang, H.;Zhu, W.

title: Identification and genome analysis of two duck-derived Tembusu virus strains in southern China
abstract: Since the winter of 2010, flocks of egg-laying ducks in southern China's Guangdong province have been suffering from a widespread infectious disease with abrupt egg laying and death. However, the causative agent was not known. We obtained two independent virus isolates named FS and JM from the diseased layer flocks and identified them as duck-originated Tembusu virus by PCR detection, sequencing the full-length open reading frames (ORFs). Both isolates, FS and JM, shared high sequence similarity with isolates of duck-derived Tembusu virus, which first emerged in April 2010 in eastern China. Blast analysis shows that the entire ORF sequences of FS and JM have the highest similarity ([99%) to BYD-1 (the first reported duck tembusuvirus) and JS804 (the first reported geese tembusuvirus ), indicating that full-length genomes were highly conserved in aquatic Tembusuviruses. The present study suggests that duck-originated Tembusuviruses spread rapidly from eastern China to southern China and caused widespread infections. The high conservation of duck-derived Tembusu virus strains provides the genomic basis for selecting strains for vaccine production to better protect against this new viral infection. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Li, L.;An, H.;Sun, M.;Dong, J.;Yuan, J.;Hu, Q.

title: Virom analysis of antiretroviral-treated HIV patients shows no correlation between T-cell activation and anellovirus levels
authors: Li, L.;Deng, X.;Costa, A. C. Da;Bruhn, R.;Deeks, S. G.

title: Divergent astrovirus associated with bovine neurological diseases
abstract: Using viral metagenomics of brain tissue from a young adult mongrel with acute onset neurological disease, we sequenced the entire genome of a novel astrovirus (BoAstV-NeuroS1) phylogenetically related to an ovine astrovirus. In a retrospective analysis of 32 cases of bovine encephalitis of unknown etiology, 3 additional infected animals were identified using PCR and in situ hybridization for viral RNA. Viral RNA has been restricted to the nervous system and has been detected in the cytoplasm of affected neurons in the spinal cord, brainstem and cerebellum. Microscopically, the lesions consisted of extensive neuronal necrosis, microgliosis, and perivascular cuffing, distributed preferentially in the gray matter and most severely in the cerebellum and brainstem, with increasing intensity caudally along the spinal cord. These results suggest that infection with BoAstV-NeuroS1 is a possible cause of bovine neurological diseases.
authors: Li, L.;Diab, S.;McGraw, S.;Barr, B.;Traslavina, R.;Higgins, R.;Talbot, T.;Blanchard, P.;Rimoldi, G.;Fahsbender, E.;Page, B.;Phan, T. G.;Wang, C.;Deng, X.;Pesavento, P.;Delwart, E.

title: Several different circoviruses infect livestock and are commonly found in human and chimpanzee feces
abstract: Circoviruses are known to infect birds and pigs and can cause a wide range of severe symptoms with significant economic implications. Using viral metagenomics, we identified circovirus-like DNA sequences and characterized 15 circular viral DNA genomes in stool samples from humans in Pakistan, Nigeria, Tunisia, and the United States, and from wild chimpanzees. Strong genomic features and phylogenetic analysis indicate that some viral genomes were part of a previously unrecognized genus in the family Circoviridae, which we tentatively named "cyclovirus", with genetic diversity comparable to that of all known species in the genus Circovirus. Circoviridae detection in the stool of adult US Americans was limited to porcine circoviruses, which were also found in most US pork products. To determine whether the divergent cycloviruses found in human stools outside the US are dietary, we compared them genetically to the cycloviruses found in muscle tissue samples from commonly consumed livestock in Pakistan and Nigeria. Limited genetic overlap between cycloviruses in human stool samples and local meat samples from cows, goats, sheep, camels and chickens suggested that the majority of the 25 cyclovirus species identified could be human viruses. We show that the genetic diversity of small circular DNA virus genomes in different mammals, including humans, is significantly greater than previously thought, and that frequent exposure through meat consumption and contact with animal or human faeces provides numerous opportunities for cyclovirus transmission. Determining the role of cycloviruses, found in 7% to 17% of human stool outside the US and 3% to 55% of tested meat samples outside the US, in human and animal disease is now facilitated by knowledge of their genomes. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Li, L.;Kapoor, A.;Slikas, B.;Bamidele, O. S.;Wang, C.;Shaukat, S.;Masroor, M. A.;Wilson, M. L.;Ndjango, J. B. N.;Peeters, M.;Gross-Camp, N. D.;Muller, M. N.;Hahn, B. H.;Wolfe, N. D.;Triki, H.;Bartkus, J.;Zaidi, S. Z.;Delwart, E.

title: A gyrovirus infects a seabird
abstract: We have characterized the genome of a highly divergent gyrovirus (GyV8) in the spleen and uropygic glandular tissues of a diseased northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis), a pelagic bird stranded in San Francisco, California. No other exogenous viral sequences could be identified using viral metagenomics. The small circular DNA genome shared no significant nucleotide sequence identity and only 38-42% amino acid sequence identity in VP1 with any of the previously identified gyroviruses. GyV8 is the first member of the third major phylogenetic group of this virus genus and the first gyrovirus detected in an avian species other than chicken.
authors: Li, L.;Pesavento, P. A.;Gaynor, A. M.;Duerr, R. S.;Phan, T. G.;Zhang, W.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Bat guano virome: predominance of insect and plant foodborne viruses plus novel mammalian viruses
authors: Li, L.;Victoria, J. G.;Wang, C.;Jones, M.;Fellers, G. M.

title: Isolation and genetic analysis revealed no predominant new strains of infectious avian bronchitis virus circulating in southern China between 2004 and 2008
abstract: Twenty-seven strains of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were isolated between 2004 and 2008 from dead or diseased chickens at different chicken farms in southern China, from which the S1 gene was sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 gene sequences of the isolated 27 strains along with 29 published strains in the Genbank revealed that all IBV strains except one isolated and one published were grouped into six distinct genotypes I-VI. 26 isolated strains belong to genotypes I, II, and III, forming a large phylogenetic branch with no new dominant strains, while all five vaccine strains belong to genotype V, which is evolutionarily distant from genotypes I, II, and III. Examination of the protease cleavage motif within the S1 protein revealed 12 different cleavage motifs, of which 3 motifs are shared by both isolated and published strains, 2 motifs are unique to isolated strains and 7 motifs are unique to published strains, leading to the notion of further supports no new dominant tribes. Alignment analysis of the S1 amino acid sequences showed that the amino acid substitutions, insertions and deletions are polymorphic and diverse and show no evidence of predominant genetic changes among the isolated strains. Overall, no dominant new strain circulated in southern China between 2004 and 2008. Nonetheless, circulating IBV strains have continuously evolved with genetic compositions distant from vaccine strains; this explains why there have been consistent but rare outbreaks in commercial herds in southern China between 2004 and 2008. To guard against the sudden emergence of new predominant strains, continuous monitoring of IBV strains circulating in the field is of utmost importance. © 2009 Elsevier BV
authors: Li, L.;Xue, C.;Chen, F.;Qin, J.;Xie, Q.;Bi, Y.;Cao, Y.

title: Research into the virome of diseased horses
abstract: Metagenomics has been used to characterize viral genomes in clinical specimens from horses with various organ-specific diseases of unknown etiology. A novel parvovirus and a previously described hepacivirus closely related to human hepatitis C virus and equine herpesvirus 2 have been identified in the cerebrospinal fluid of horses with neurological symptoms. Four co-infecting picobirnaviruses, including an unusual genome with fused RNA segments, and a divergent anellovirus were found in the plasma of two febrile horses. A novel cyclovirus genome has been characterized from the nasal discharge of another febrile animal. Finally, a small circular DNA genome containing a Rep gene from a virus we call Kirkovirus was identified in the liver and spleen of a horse with fatal idiopathic hepatopathy. This study expands the number of viruses found in horses and characterizes their genomes to support future epidemiological studies on their transmission and possible association with various equine diseases.
authors: Li, L. L.;Giannitti, F.;Low, J.;Keyes, C.;Ullmann, L. S.;Deng, X. T.;Aleman, M.;Pesavento, P. A.;Pusterla, N.;Delwart, E.

title: A novel bocavirus in canine liver
abstract: Background: Bocaviruses are classified as a genus within the Parvoviridae family of single-stranded DNA viruses and are pathogenic in some mammalian species. Two types have previously been reported in dogs, Minute Virus of Canines (MVC), which are associated with neonatal disease and fertility problems; and canine bocavirus (CBoV), which is associated with respiratory disease. Results: In this study, we identified and characterized a novel bocavirus, which we termed canine bocavirus 3 (CnBoV3), using deep sequencing of enriched viral particles from the liver of a dog with severe hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, necrotizing vasculitis, granulomatous lymphadenitis, and anuric renal failure. The three major ORFs of CnBoV3 (NS1, NP1 and VP1) shared less than 60% AS identity with those of other bocaviruses, qualifying them as a new species based on the ICTV criteria. Inverse PCR demonstrated the presence of concatemerized or circular forms of the genome in the liver. Conclusions: We have genetically characterized a bocavirus in a canine liver that is very different from previous canine bocaviruses found in respiratory and fecal samples. Its role in this animal's complex disease has yet to be determined.
authors: Li, L. L.;Pesavento, P. A.;Leutenegger, C. M.;Estrada, M.;Coffey, L. L.;Naccache, S. N.;Samayoa, E.;Chiu, C.;Qiu, J. M.;Wang, C. L.;Deng, X. T.;Delwart, E.

title: Viruses found in dogs with diarrhea include novel kobuviruses and sapoviruses
abstract: Dogs' close interactions with humans and surrounding wildlife provide frequent opportunities for cross-species virus transmission. To initiate an unbiased characterization of eukaryotic viruses in the canine gut, this study used deep sequencing of partially purified viral capsid-protected nucleic acids from the feces of 18 diarrheal dogs. Known canine parvoviruses, coronaviruses and rotaviruses have been identified, and the genomes of the first reported canine kobuviruses and sapoviruses have been characterized. Canine kobuvirus, the first canine picornavirus to be sequenced and the closest genetic relative to the diarrhea-causing human Aichivirus, has been found at high frequency in the faeces of both healthy and diarrheal dogs. The canine sapovirus formed a new genogroup within the genus Sapovirus, a group of viruses also implicated in human and animal diarrhea. These results underscore the high frequency of detection of new viruses possible even in well-studied animal species using metagenomics approaches, and provide viral genomes for further study of disease associations.
authors: Li, L. L.;Pesavento, P. A.;Shan, T. L.;Leutenegger, C. M.;Wang, C. L.;Delwart, E.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus in wild migratory birds, Qinghai Lake, China
abstract: In May 2016, a highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N8) virus strain caused the death of 3 species of wild migratory birds in Qinghai Lake, China. Genetic analysis showed that the novel reassortant virus belongs to the H5N8 group B viruses and that the reassortment events likely occurred in early 2016.
authors: Li, M.;Liu, H.;Bi, Y.;Sun, J.;Wong, G.;Liu, D.;Li, L.;Liu, J.;Chen, Q.;Wang, H.;He, Y.;Shi, W.;Gao, G. F.;Chen, J.

title: Genetic Characterization of Evolving Highly Pathogenic H5N6 Influenza Viruses in China, 2012-2016
abstract: H5N6 is a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) and zoonotic disease causing recurrent endemics in East Asia. At least 155 H5N6 outbreaks have been reported in China, including 15 human infections. These repeated outbreaks have increased concerns that the H5N6 virus could spread to humans and cause a pandemic. In February 2016, peacocks at a breeding farm were infected with a highly contagious disease. Post-mortem studies, including RT-PCR and virus isolation, confirmed that the highly pathogenic H5N6 influenza virus was the causative agent and the strain was named A/Pavo Cristatus/Jiangxi/JA1/2016. In animal studies, it showed high pathogenicity in chickens and an estimated mean lethal dose in mice of ~104.3 TCID50. A phylogenetic analysis showed that JA1/2016 was clustered in the H5 clade 2.3.4.4. The FG594-like H5N6 virus from Guangdong Province was the likely predecessor of JA1/2016, and the estimated time of departure was June 2014. Furthermore, we found that H5N6 influenza viruses can be divided into the following two groups: Group 1 and Group 2. Group 2 influenza viruses have not been detected since late 2014, while group 1 influenza viruses have continuously evolved and rearranged with the "gene pool" circulating in southern China, leading to the emergence of new subtypes of this influenza virus. An increase in the number of its identified hosts, the expanding range, and the continued evolution of H5N6 AIVs increase the risk of an H5N6 virus spreading to other continents and causing a pandemic.
authors: Li, M.;Zhao, N.;Luo, J.;Li, Y.;Chen, L.;Ma, J.;Zhao, L.;Yuan, G.;Wang, C.;Wang, Y.;Liu, Y.;He, H.

title: The isolation and characterization of the novel goose parvovirus-related virus demonstrates the evolution of waterfowl parvovirus
abstract: Short Beak and Dwarfism Syndrome (SBDS) has been erupting in China since 2015. It is caused by a novel goose parvovirus-related virus (NGPV) and can severely limit the growth of ducks. In this study, seven NGPV stainings from different regions of China were isolated between 2015 and 2016. To better understand the correlation between NGPV and goose parvovirus (GPV), we performed full genome sequencing and an extensive analysis of the NGPV genome. Phylogenetic and alignment analysis showed that NGPV is a branch of GPV sharing 92.2%-97.1% nucleotide identity with GPV. Compared to classic GPV, five consensus nucleotide mutations and two 14 nucleotide pair deletions in six NGPV isolates were found in the inverted terminal repeats in all seven NGPV isolates, twelve and eight synchronous amino acid changes were found in the replication protein and capsid protein of NGPV, the may be important for viral gene regulation, humoral immune responses, and host transfer. In particular, SDLY1602 was shown to be a recombinant strain, with the potential major parental GPV vaccine strain 82-0321v and the minor parental GPV wild strain GDaGPV. This is the first report showing that recombination between two classical GPV strains has produced a naturally circulating NGPV strain. This study will advance our understanding of NGPV molecular biology and help elucidate the evolutionary features of GPV.
authors: Li, P.;Lin, S.;Zhang, R.;Chen, J.;Sun, D.;Lan, J.;Song, S.;Xie, Z.;Jiang, S.

title: A series of UV-inducible autolytic vectors for high-throughput screening
abstract: high-throughput screening scheme is often a prerequisite for the directed evolution of enzymes or metagenomic analysis of DNA samples. Testing of intracellular enzymes of interest (e.g. when Escherichia coli is used) often requires chemical or enzymatic cell lysis, which can be lengthy and expensive. In this study, a series of UV-inducible autolytic vectors were constructed to provide a simpler means of cell lysis free of additional fluid handling. The SRRz lysis gene cassette from bacteriophage lambda was cloned downstream of a UV-inducible promoter, the recA promoter or the umuDC promoter, and further inserted into the backbone of pUC18 and transformed into E. coli BL21 cells. SRRz expression and cell lysis was induced by UV irradiation. For both the RecA and UmuDC promoters, the lysis efficiency was found to be consistent at 30°C and exceed 60% as measured with β-galactosidase as a reporter. However, at 37°C, lysis profiles were found to be erratic. UV lysis in 96-well plates also produced consistent lysis results comparable to those obtained by lysozyme treatment, demonstrating the utility of these autolytic vectors in high-throughput screening. This set of artificial SRRz autolytic units should be transferrable to other vectors. Surprisingly, it was found that E. coli BL21(DE3) was also partially destroyed under UV irradiation, with a lysis efficiency of 44.5% at 30°C and 22.5% at 37°C. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Li, S.;Xu, L.;Hua, H.;Ren, C.;Lin, Z.

title: Probing the termini of the viral genome by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: The analysis of genomic tails was an important step in studies of viral DNA replication and packaging mechanisms. However, traditional methods for studying genomic terms are challenging due to the time-consuming protocols and their inefficiency, where critical details are easily lost. Recent advances in next-generation sequencing (NGS) have made it a powerful tool for studying genomic terms. In this study, we used NGS to sequence an iridovirus genome and twenty phage genomes and confirmed for the first time that the high frequency sequences (HFSs) found in the NGS reads are in fact the terminal sequences of viral genomes. In addition, we established a criterion to distinguish the type of term and the mode of viral packaging. We also got additional terminal details like terminal repeats, multi-termini, asymmetric termini. Using this approach, we were able to simultaneously detect details of genome ends and obtain the full sequence of bacteriophage genomes. In theory, this application can be extended to analyze larger and more complicated genomes of plant and animal viruses. This study proposed a novel and efficient method to explore viral replication, packaging, terminase activity, transcriptional regulation and host cell metabolism.
authors: Li, S. S.;Fan, H.;An, X. P.;Fan, H. H.;Jiang, H. H.;Chen, Y. B.;Tong, Y. G.

title: Genome comparison of a novel classical swine fever virus isolated in China in 2004 with other CSFV strains
abstract: The genome of a novel classical swine fever virus (CSFV), SWH/CA/2004, isolated from a pig pen in Henan province, central China, is 12296 nucleotides (nt) long. It consists of a 373-nt long 5-terminal non-translated region (NTR), a 11697-nt long open reading frame (ORF) encoding a polyprotein of 3898 amino acids (aa), and a 226-nt long 3-inch -Region. NTR. The genome comparison of the SWH/CA/2004 isolate (GenBank Accession: DQ127910) with other known CSFV isolates was performed and analyzed. Corresponding segments from SWH/CA/2004 and other reported strains shared 80.4-99.8% identity at the nucleotide level and 89.5-99.8% identity at the amino acid level. From an evolutionary perspective, isolate SWH/CA/2004 is closely related to highly virulent isolate cF114/CA/2001, with a pairwise distance of 0.013; and distantly related to the moderately virulent isolate GXWZ02/CA/2003, with a pairwise distance of 0.170. The phylogenetic trees of the full-length genome and the following region E rns, E1, E2 and NS5B-based Neighbor-Joining (NJ) method were constructed and roughly classified into different genetic groups according to avirulence, intermediate virulence and high virulence. while other region-based NJ trees showed sequence conservation between these groups. The four genomic regions may represent important criteria for genetic typing of different CSFV isolates. Based on these analyses, the isolate SWH/CA/2004 was assigned to the group of highly virulent isolates. However, SWH/CA/2004 also contains a 14 U deletion in the 3â€² NTR characteristic of avirulent isolates. These analyzes represent a comprehensive study of the phylogenetics of CSF based on specific regions of the genome and may form the basis for future molecular epidemiological research to identify outbreaks of virulent strains and trigger the implementation of appropriate control measures. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Li, X.;Xu, Z.;He, Y.;Yao, Q.;Zhang, K.;Jin, M.;Chen, H.;Qian, P.

title: Differential expression of microRNAs in porcine parvovirus-infected porcine cell lines
abstract: Background: Porcine parvovirus (PPV), a member of the Parvoviridae family, causes large economic losses in the swine industry worldwide. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of non-protein-coding genes that play many different and complex roles in viral infections. Result: To determine the effects of PPV infection on the cellular miRNAome, we used high-throughput sequencing to sequence two miRNA libraries derived from porcine kidney 15 (PK-15) cells under normal conditions and during PPV -Infection were produced. There was differential miRNA expression between the uninfected and infected cells: 65 miRNAs were upregulated and 128 miRNAs were downregulated. We have demonstrated expression of miR-10b, miR-20a, miR-19b, miR-181a, miR-146b, miR-18a and other previously identified immune-related miRNAs. Gene ontology analyzes and KEGG functional annotations of the host's target genes indicated that the miRNAs are involved in complex cellular signaling pathways, including cellular metabolic processes, immune system processes and gene expression. Conclusions: These data suggest that a large group of miRNAs are expressed in PK-15 cells and that some miRNAs were altered in PPV-infected PK-15 cells. A number of microRNAs play important roles in regulating immune-related gene expression. Our findings should aid in the development of new control strategies to prevent or treat PPV infections in pigs.
authors: Li, X.;Zhu, L.;Liu, X.;Sun, X.;Zhou, Y.;Lang, Q.;Li, P.;Cai, Y.;Qiao, X.;Xu, Z.

title: Genetic analysis of two pig reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses isolated in China with different virulence
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) strains S1 and SY0608 were individually isolated in 1997 and 2006 and had variable pathogenicity in pigs. To understand their genomic properties, the full-length genomes of the S1 and SY0608 isolates were sequenced and analyzed. The results showed that their genome composition differed significantly, sharing only 88.5% nucleotide identity. The genetic variation and amino acid substitutions were not randomly distributed in the genome and were mainly concentrated in ORF1a, ORF3 and ORF5. The SY0608 strain with high pathogenicity had a 30 amino acid deletion at amino acid positions 480 and 532-560 compared to the S1 strain. Alignment of the amino acid sequence of Nsp1-Nsp8, GP2-GP5, M and N of S1 and SY0608 with other PRRSV isolates showed that variations were mainly found in the Nsp2, GP3 and GP5 proteins. Compared to the S1 strain, the SY0608 strain showed some potential glycosylation site mutations in GP5 at amino acid positions between 26 and 39, possibly associated with viral antigenicity. The phylogenetic analysis showed that the two strains belonged to two different branches, indicating no differences in pathogenicity. Interestingly, the deletion strains recently isolated in China formed a new side branch that revealed the same evolutionary trend. © 2008 Springer Verlag.
authors: Li, Y.;Wang, X.;Jiang, P.;Chen, W.;Wang, X.

title: From Discovery to Distribution: The Evolution and Phylogeny of Getah Virus
abstract: Getah virus (GETV) was first isolated in Malaysia in 1955. Since then, epidemics in horses and pigs caused by GETV have resulted in enormous economic losses. At present, GETV has spread throughout Eurasia and Southeast Asia, including mainland China, Korea, Japan, Mongolia, and Russia. The data show that the GETV Most Recent Common Ancestor (MRCA) existed about 145 years ago (95% HPD: 75–244) and gradually evolved into four distinct evolutionary populations: Groups I–IV. The MRCA of GETVs in Group III, which includes all GETVs isolated from mosquitoes, pigs, horses and other animals since the 1960s (from 19°N to 60°N latitude), existed about 51 years ago (95% HPD : 51″). "72). Group III is responsible for most viral epidemics in domestic animals. Analysis of the sequence and structure of the GETV E2 protein revealed seven common amino acid mutation sites. These sites are responsible for the structural and electrostatic differences found between widespread group III isolates and the prototype strain MM2021. These differences may account for the recent geographic spread of the virus. Given the economic importance of GETV infection in pigs and horses, we recommend conducting rigorous viral screening and surveillance programs.
authors: Li, Y. Y.;Liu, H.;Fu, S. H.;Li, X. L.;Guo, X. F.;Li, M. H.;Feng, Y.;Chen, W. X.;Wang, L. H.;Lei, W. W.;Gao, X. Y.;Lv, Z.;He, Y.;Wang, H. Y.;Zhou, H. N.;Wang, G. Q.;Liang, G. D.

title: MicroRNA-23b promotes replication of avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) by targeting IRF1
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) can cause various leukemia-like proliferative diseases in the hematopoietic system of chickens. Here we examined the transcriptome profiles and miRNA expression profiles of ALV-J infected and uninfected chicken spleens to identify the genes and miRNAs associated with ALV-J invasion. A total of 252 genes and 167 miRNAs were differentially expressed in ALV-J infected spleens compared to uninfected control spleens. miR-23b expression was upregulated in ALV-J-infected spleens compared to control spleens, and transcriptome analysis revealed that interferon regulatory factor 1 (IRF1) expression was upregulated in ALV-J-infected spleens compared to uninfected spleens spleens were downregulated. A dual luciferase reporter assay showed that IRF1 was a direct target of miR-23b. miR-23b overexpression significantly (P=0.0022) decreased IRF1 mRNA levels and suppressed IRF1 3'-UTR reporter activity. In vitro experiments showed that miR-23b overexpression enhanced ALV-J replication, while miR-23b loss of function inhibited ALV-J replication. IRF1 overexpression inhibited ALV-J replication and IRF1 knockdown enhanced ALV-J replication. Furthermore, IRF1 overexpression significantly increased (P = 0.0014) IFN-β expression. Taken together, these results suggest that miR-23b may play an important role in ALV-J replication by targeting IRF1.
authors: Li, Z.;Chen, B.;Feng, M.;Ouyang, H.;Zheng, M.;Ye, Q.;Nie, Q.;Zhang, X.

title: Evidence that porcine haemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus induced nonsuppurative encephalitis as the cause of death in piglets
abstract: In China, there was an acute outbreak of porcine haemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (PHEV) infection in piglets, which was characterized by neurological symptoms, vomiting, diarrhea and wasting. Coronavirus-like particles were observed by electron microscopy in the homogenized tissue suspensions of the brains of dead piglets, and a wild strain of PHEV was isolated, characterized and designated PHEV-CC14. Histopathological examination of the dead piglets showed features of nonsuppurative encephalitis, and some neurons in the cerebral cortex were degenerated and necrotic, and neuronophagia. Similarly, mice vaccinated with PHEV-CC14 were found to exhibit central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction with symptoms of depression, bulging waists, erect and vellicating front claws. Furthermore, PHEV-positive labeling of neurons in cortices of dead piglets and infected mice supported viral infections of the nervous system. Then the major structural genes of PHEV-CC14 were sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically, and the strain shared 95%-99.2% nt identity with the other PHEV strains available in GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis has clearly established that the wild strain is clustered in a subclade with an HEV JT06 strain. These findings suggested that the virus had a strong tropism for the CNS and thus caused nonsuppurative encephalitis as a cause of death in piglets. At the same time, the predicted risk of widespread transmission showed some variation among the PHEV strains currently circulating worldwide. Most importantly, the information presented in this study can not only provide a good reference for the experimental diagnosis of PHEV infection for pig breeding, but also promote the development of new effective vaccines.
authors: Li, Z.;He, W.;Lan, Y.;Zhao, K.;Lv, X.;Lu, H.;Ding, N.;Zhang, J.;Shi, J.;Shan, C.;Gao, F.

title: MicroRNAs in the immune organs of chickens and ducks indicate a divergence in immunity to H5N1 avian influenza
abstract: Chickens are susceptible to the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of avian influenza virus (HPAIV), while ducks are not. Here, we used high-throughput sequencing to analyze microRNA expression in Fabricius spleen, thymus, and bursa of H5N1-HPAIV-infected and uninfected chickens and ducks. We annotated the genomic positions of duck microRNAs and compared the microRNA repertoires of chickens and ducks. Our results showed that the microRNA expression patterns in the homologous immune organs of specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens and ducks differ significantly. In addition, there was a greater divergence between microRNA expression patterns in immune organs from HPAIV-infected chickens than in HPAIV-infected ducks. Together, our results could help elucidate the role of microRNAs in the differential immunity of chickens and ducks against H5N1 HPAIV.
authors: Li, Z.;Zhang, J.;Su, J.;Liu, Y.;Guo, J.;Zhang, Y.;Lu, C.;Xing, S.;Guan, Y.;Li, Y.;Sun, B.;Zhao, Z.

title: Novel avian coronavirus and fulminant disease in guinea fowl, France
abstract: French guinea fowl have been affected by fulminant enteritis of unclear origin for decades. Using metagenomics, we identified a novel avian gamma-coronavirus associated with this disease, which is distantly related to turkey coronaviruses. Deadly respiratory diseases in humans are recently caused by corona viruses of animal origin.
authors: Liais, E.;Croville, G.;Mariette, J.;Delverdier, M.;Lucas, M. N.;Klopp, C.;Lluch, J.;Donnadieu, C.;Guy, J. S.;Corrand, L.;Ducatez, M. F.;GuÃ©rin, J. L.

title: systematic analysis of the miRNA transcriptome in Marek's disease virus-induced lymphoma reveals new and differentially expressed miRNAs
abstract: Marek's disease is a lymphoproliferative neoplastic disease of chickens that poses a serious threat to poultry health. Marek's disease virus (MDV)-induced T-cell lymphoma is also an excellent biomedical model for neoplasia research. Recently, miRNAs have been shown to play a crucial role in mediating neoplastic transformation. To examine host miRNA expression profiles in the tumor transformation phase of MDV infection, we performed deep sequencing in two MDV-infected samples (tumorous spleen and MD lymphoma from the liver) and two uninfected controls (uninfected spleen and lymphocytes). through. A total of 187 and 16 known miRNAs were identified in chicken and MDV, respectively, and 17 new chicken miRNAs were further confirmed by qPCR. We identified 28 down-regulated miRNAs and 11 up-regulated miRNAs in MDV-infected samples by bioinformatic analysis. Of nine others tested by qPCR, seven were verified. gga-miR-181a, gga-miR-26a, gga-miR-221, gga-miR-222, gga-miR-199* and gga-miR-140* were downregulated and gga-miR-146c was found in MDV- infected tumorous spleens and MD lymphomas upregulated. In addition, 189 putative target genes were predicted for seven differentially expressed miRNAs. Luciferase reporter gene assay demonstrated gga-miR-181a interactions with MYBL1, gga-miR-181a with IGF2BP3, and gga-miR-26a with EIF3A. The differential expression of miRNAs and their predicted targets strongly suggests that they contribute to MDV-induced lymphomagenesis.
authors: Lian, L.;Qu, L.;Chen, Y.;Lamont, S. J.;Yang, N.

title: Cloning, Sequencing, and Polymorphism Analysis of Novel Classical MHC Class I Alleles in Northern Pig Monkeys (Macaca leonina)
abstract: The northern hog-tailed macaque (Macaca leonina) has been confirmed to be an independent species from the group of hog-tailed macaques of Old World monkeys. We have previously reported that the northern hog macaques were also susceptible to HIV-1. To make this animal a potential HIV/AIDS model and to discover the mechanism of viral control, we here attempted to examine the role of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I-restricted immune responses on HIV-1 infection-related viral replication and disease progression. As a first step, we first cloned and characterized the classical MHC class I gene of northern hog-tailed macaques. In this study, we identified 39 MHC class I alleles, including 17 MHC A and 22 MHC B alleles. Of these identified alleles, 30 were new and 9 were identical to alleles previously reported from other macaque species. The MHC-A and MHC-B loci were both duplicates as rhesus monkeys and southern hog monkeys. Furthermore, we have also demonstrated the patterns of positive selection in northern hog-tailed macaques and demonstrated the existence of equilibrium selection with 20 positive selection sites in the peptide-binding region. Analysis of B and F peptide-binding pockets in northern and southern pig-tailed macaques and rhesus macaques suggested that they would likely share some common peptides for presentation. Thus, this study provides important information on MHC immunogenetics and adds value to the northern hog-tailed macaque as a promising HIV/AIDS model.
authors: Lian, X. D.;Zhang, X. H.;Dai, Z. X.;Zheng, Y. T.

title: Arboviruses and Their Related Infections in China: A Comprehensive Field and Laboratory Review Over the Last 3 Decades
abstract: Extensive field and laboratory investigation has been carried out across China since the 1980s, and a total of 29 virus species belonging to 7 families and 13 genera have been identified by virological, morphological and immunological methods, as well as whole genome sequencing and molecular genetic analysis. Most virus isolates belong to 9 genera in the families Flaviviridae, Bunyaviridae, Togaviridae and Reoviridae. Among them, 4 genera (Orthobunyavirus, Bunyavirus, Phlebovirus, and Nairovirus) belong to the Bunyaviridae family, and 3 genera (Seadonavirus, Orbivirus, and Cypovirus) belong to the Reoviridae family. Analysis of the relationship between viruses and human/animal diseases showed that Japanese encephalitis virus, dengue virus, severe fever with thrombocytopenic syndrome virus, tick-borne encephalitis virus, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, West Nile virus and Tahyna virus can cause human and animal infections and disease epidemics in China. This review systematically presents the current status of arbovirus and vector diversity and geographic distribution in China. In addition, our findings provide strong technical support for arboviral disease prevention and control, epidemic treatment, and disease early warning and prediction, and are therefore significant for arboviral disease control and prevention in Asia and around the world.
authors: Liang, G.;Li, X.;Gao, X.;Fu, S.;Wang, H.;Li, M.;Lu, Z.;Zhu, W.;Lu, X.;Wang, L.;Cao, Y.;He, Y.;Lei, W.

title: Outbreaks of Newcastle disease in western China were caused by genotypes VIIa and VIII
abstract: Twelve Newcastle disease (NDV) viral strains were isolated from chickens involved in Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks in western China (Shaanxi, Gansu, Xinjiang, Qinghai and Guangxi provinces) between 1979 and 1999. All strains were determined to be velogenic by plaque formation, mean time to death (MDT) of embryonated oocytes, and intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI). The acidic guanidinium thiocyanate method was used to prepare viral RNA. A 908 bp nucleotide fragment was amplified by RT-PCR starting at the N-terminus of the F gene and the PCR segments were cloned into the PGEM-T vector and sequenced. The similarities of the nucleotide sequences (1-519 bp) and the predicted amino acid sequences of the F gene (1-125) were analyzed by comparing the 12 NDV isolates with the NDV vaccine strains Lasota, B1, H1 and V4 with classical NDV strains were and newer strains of animal diseases. The phylogenetic analysis showed that all strains were of two new genotypes; the NDV strains that caused the 1998-1999 outbreak of ND in western China were of genotype VIIa, while the strains from Qinghai Province (1979-1985) were of genotype VIII, found predominantly in southern Africa. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liang, R.;Cao, D. J.;Li, J. Q.;Chen, J.;Guo, X.;Zhuang, F. F.;Duan, M. X.

title: Provirus variants of bovine leukemia virus in naturally infected cattle from Argentina and Japan
abstract: serological subgroup of bovine leukemia virus (BLV) has not been identified, while genetic diversity among BLVs has been reported by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP). To examine the distribution of BLV provirus variants, 42 isolates from Argentina and Japan were analyzed for a portion of the env gene by nested PCR, followed by DNA sequencing. The nucleotide sequences were compared to other previously characterized BLV variants from different geographical areas (Belgium, France, Italy, North America, Australia, Japan and Argentina). The majority of the segments analyzed showed a tendency towards nucleotide substitution without changing the amino acid. The constructed phylogenetic tree showed the relationships and differences between and within proviruses. Most of the samples in Argentina formed a cluster. The samples from Japan were also clustered except for one and some of them showed high homology with the isolates from Australia and the USA. Looking at the sequence analysis of env-PCR products of all Japanese and Argentine samples and comparing them to the other previously isolated sequences, the variation was up to 3.5% and was geographically characterized in each area. © 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Licursi, M.;Inoshima, Y.;Wu, D.;Yokoyama, T.;GonzÃ¡lez, E. T.;Sentsui, H.

title: Taxonomy of viruses in etiological relation to gastroenteritis in man, bovine and swine
authors: Liebermann, H.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Taiwan between 2003 and 2006
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from chicken cases were obtained between 2003 and 2006 at various locations in Taiwan and analyzed genotypically using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) with primers encoding the gene for viral fusion protein (F) specific (534 bp). A portion of the amplified F protein DNA product (nucleotide sequence 47-418) and the deduced amino acid sequences were phylogenetically compared to those of strains previously reported in Taiwan and other geographic regions. Our results showed that all Taiwanese isolates (n=20) collected between 2003 and 2006 belong to genotype VIId according to the pedigree. In addition, all six Taiwanese isolates obtained in 2003 carry the 112R-RQK-R116 motif and have the amino acid L23 replaced with F23 (assigned as Group 1). On the other hand, 12 of the 14 Taiwanese isolates obtained between 2004 and 2006 possess the 112R-RKK-R116 motif and the amino acid G74 instead of E74 (assigned as group 2). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported VIId isolate possessing the sequences of G74/112R-RKK-R116 within the F0 protein. Since high mortality, severe clinical symptoms, typical postmortem lesions and high intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) were observed in the NDV-infected chickens, these isolates acquired between 2003 and 2006 are considered to be velogenous type. Group 2 viruses have become prevalent in recent years and are responsible for most outbreaks in Taiwan. Based on our phylogenetic analysis, it can be postulated that these isolates arose from previously reported local strains and that the group 2 family emerged last in genotype VIId. The information is fundamental to improving the efficiency of control strategies and vaccine development for NDV. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lien, Y. Y.;Lee, J. W.;Su, H. Y.;Tsai, H. J.;Tsai, M. C.;Hsieh, C. Y.;Tsai, S. S.

title: Live attenuated nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis vaccine provides broad cross-protection against novel strain variants
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) infections are causing major economic losses to the poultry industry worldwide and the emergence of new variant strains is making disease control more difficult. The present study examined the genetic and protectotypic traits of newly emerged Korean IBV strains. A phylogenetic analysis showed that several recent isolates formed two distinct clusters (new clusters 1 and 2) distinct from other pre-existing clusters. The new cluster 1 IBV strains represented recombinants between the Korean nephropathogenic strain KM91 and the QXIBV strain. New cluster 2 IBV strains showed low amino acid homology (<58.7%) compared to previous isolates. We evaluated the protective effect of commercial IBV vaccines (H120 and K2 strain) against these new isolates. In cross-protection studies, the H120 strain did not provide adequate protection against these variants. However, the highly attenuated nephropathogenic IBV vaccine, K2 strain, provided significantly higher levels of protection against variants compared to H120 vaccinated chickens (P<0.05 or better). These results indicate that the K2 vaccine could be helpful in reducing the economic losses caused by emerging IBV recombinants (novel cluster 1) and variants (novel cluster 2). © 2012 Poultry Science Association Inc.
authors: Lim, T. H.;Kim, M. S.;Jang, J. H.;Lee, D. H.;Park, J. K.;Youn, H. N.;Lee, J. B.;Park, S. Y.;Choi, I. S.;Song, C. S.

title: Fecal viromes of healthy chickens display a rich diversity of the eukaryotic viral community, including novel circular ssDNA viruses
abstract: This study focuses on the identification of fecal virome from healthy chickens reared on high-density, export-oriented poultry farms in Brazil. After high-throughput sequencing, a total of 7743 de novo assembled contigs were constructed and compared to known nucleotide/amino acid sequences from the GenBank database. Analysis with BLASTx revealed that 279 contigs (4%) were related to eukaryotic virus sequences. Viral genome sequences (full or partial) indicative of members of recognized virus families including Adenoviridae, Caliciviridae, Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae and Reoviridae have been identified, some of which represent novel genotypes. In addition, a number of circular replication-associated proteins encoding DNA viruses have also been identified. The characterization of healthy chicken faecal vioma described here not only provides a description of the viruses encountered in such a niche, but should also provide a basis for future studies comparing virus populations in healthy and diseased chicken flocks. In addition, it may also be relevant to human health, as chickens make up a significant proportion of the animal protein consumed worldwide.
authors: Lima, D. A.;Cibulski, S. P.;Finkler, F.;Teixeira, T. F.;Varela, A. P. M.;Cerva, C.;Loiko, M. R.;Scheffer, C. M.;Dos Santos, H. F.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: The intestinal virome of affected and unaffected broilers with malabsorption syndrome by shotgun metagenomics
abstract: Malabsorption syndrome (MAS) is an economically important disease of commercial reared young broilers characterized by growth retardation, defective feather development and fecal diarrhea. Several viruses have been tentatively linked to such a syndrome. In order to investigate possible associations between enteric viruses and MAS, the fecal viromas of 70 stool samples from diseased (n = 35) and healthy (n = 35) chickens from seven flocks were characterized and compared. After high-throughput sequencing, a total of 8,347,319 paired-end reads averaging 231 nt were generated. Analysis of de novo assembled contigs identified 144 contigs >1000 nt matching eukaryotic virus sequences as determined from the GenBank database. A number of known and unknown representatives of Adenoviridae, Anelloviridae, Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae and Reoviridae as well as new, uncharacterized CRESS DNA viruses were identified. However, the distribution of sequence reads of viral genomes identified in diseased or healthy birds did not show statistically significant differences. These findings indicate no connection between the occurrence of MAS and enteric viruses. The viral genomes reported in the present study, including a variety of novel viruses, appear to be part of the normal chicken gut microbiota.
authors: Lima, D. A.;Cibulski, S. P.;Tochetto, C.;Varela, A. P. M.;Finkler, F.;Teixeira, T. F.;Loiko, M. R.;Cerva, C.;Junqueira, D. M.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Ocular vaccinia infection in dairy workers, Brazil
abstract: We studied a clinical case of vaccinia virus causing an ocular manifestation in a dairy worker in Brazil. Biological and molecular analyzes identified co-infection with 2 isolates from different phylogenetic groups of Brazilian vaccinia virus.
authors: Lima, M. T.;Oliveira, G. P.;Assis, F. L.;Bretas de Oliveira, D.;Vaz, S. M.;Trindade, G. S.;Abrahao, J. S.;Kroon, E. G.

title: Nucleotide sequence of genes encoding Gb, Gc and Gd homologues of canine herpesvirus
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the genes encoding the gB, gC and gD homologues of canine herpesvirus (CHV) has been determined. These genes are predicted to encode polypeptides of 879, 459, and 345 amino acids, respectively. A comparison of the predicted amino acid sequences of CHV gB, gC and go with the homologous sequences of other herpesviruses shows that CHV is an alphaherpesvirus, a conclusion consistent with the earlier classification of this virus based on biological properties. The alignment of the homologous gB, gC, and gD amino acid sequences indicates that most cysteine residues are conserved, suggesting that these glycoproteins share similar tertiary structures. The nucleotide sequence of the open reading frame downstream of the CHV gC gene was also determined. The predicted amino acid sequence of this putative polypeptide appears to be homologous to a family of proteins encoded in most, if not all, alphaherpesviruses downstream of the gC gene.
authors: Limbach, K. J.;Limbach, M. P.;Conte, D.;Paoletti, E.

title: High prevalence of hepatitis e virus in Swedish moose - a phylogenetic characterization and comparison of the virus from different regions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infects a number of species including humans, pigs, wild boar and deer. Zoonotic transmission may contribute to the high HEV seroprevalence in the human population of many countries. A novel divergent HEV from moose (Alces alces) in Sweden was recently identified by partial genome sequencing. Because only one strain was found, its classification within the HEV family, prevalence in moose, and zoonotic potential were unclear. We therefore analyzed samples from 231 moose in seven Swedish provinces for HEV and sequenced a nearly complete moose HEV genome. A phylogenetic analysis was performed to classify this virus within the family Hepeviridae and to examine possible host-specific determinants. METHODS AND RESULTS: HEV prevalence in elk was determined by PCR (marker of active infection) and serological assays (marker of past infection) of sera and 51 faecal samples from 231 Swedish elk. Markers of active and past infection were found in 67 (29%) animals, while 34 (15%) were positive for HEV RNA, 43 (19%) were seropositive for anti-HEV antibodies, and 10 (4%) had both markers . The number of young HEV RNA positive individuals was greater than that of the elderly, and the number of anti-HEV antibody positive individuals increased with age. The high-throughput sequenced elk HEV genome was 35-60% identical to existing HEVs. Partial ORF1 sequences from 13 elk strains showed high similarity between them, forming a distinct monophyletic clade with a common ancestor of the HEV genotype 1-6 clade, which includes members known for zoonotic transmission. CONCLUSIONS: This study shows a high frequency of HEV in moose in Sweden, with markers for current and past infection detected in 30% of the animals. Moose are thus an important animal reservoir of HEV. The phylogenetic relationship indicated that the elk HEV belonged to the group of genotypes 1-6, which includes strains that also infect humans, and therefore could indicate potential for zoonotic transmission of this HEV.
authors: Lin, J.;Karlsson, M.;Olofson, A. S.;Belak, S.;Malmsten, J.;Dalin, A. M.;Widen, F.;Norder, H.

title: High prevalence of hepatitis E virus in Swedish moose - A phylogenetic characterization and comparison of the virus from different regions
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infects a number of species including humans, pigs, wild boar and deer.
