Zoonotic transmission may contribute to the high HEV seroprevalence in the human population of many countries. authors: Lin, J.;Karlsson, M.;Olofson, A. S.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Malmsten, J.;Dalin, A. M.;WidÃ©n, F.;Norder, H.

title: Evidence from nature: interspecies spread of heron hepatitis B viruses
abstract: Heron hepatitis B viruses (HHBVs) in three subspecies of free-ranging gray herons (Ardea herodias) from Florida, USA have been identified and characterized. Eight of 13 samples were positive in all assays used, while sera from herons, which also belong to the Ardeidae family, were negative in the same assays. Comparative phylogenetic analyzes of viral DNA sequences from the preS/S region of previously reported and new HHBV strains isolated from captive gray herons (Germany) and free-ranging gray herons (USA), respectively, showed high conservation (95% sequence similarity) with two separate clusters, suggesting a common ancestor of all tribes. Our data show for the first time that several heron subspecies are infected with HHBV and that these infections occur in non-captive birds. Phylogenetic analyzes and the fact that the different heron species are geographically isolated populations suggest that lateral transmission, viral adaptation, and environmental factors all play roles in the spread and evolution of HHBV.
authors: Lin, L.;Prassolov, A.;Funk, A.;Quinn, L.;Hohenberg, H.;Frolich, K.;Newbold, J.;Ludwig, A.;Will, H.;Sirma, H.;Steinbach, F.

title: Influenza A(H9N2) virus, Myanmar, 2014-2015
abstract: Routine influenza A virus surveillance was conducted in Myanmar in 2014-2015. Influenza A(H9N2) virus was isolated in Shan State in Upper Myanmar. Whole genome sequencing showed that the H9N2 virus from Myanmar was closely related to the H9N2 clade 4.2.5 virus from China.
authors: Lin, T. N.;Nonthabenjawan, N.;Chaiyawong, S.;Bunpapong, N.;Boonyapisitsopa, S.;Janetanakit, T.;Mon, P. P.;Mon, H. H.;Oo, K. N.;Oo, S. M.;Mar Win, M.;Amonsin, A.

title: Molecular epidemiology of avian leukosis virus subgroup J isolated from meat-type chickens in southern China between 2013 and 2014
abstract: Members of avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) cause various diseases associated with tumor formation and reduced fertility, resulting in large economic losses in the poultry industry worldwide. To assess the status of ALV-J infection in meat chickens in southern China, the molecular epidemiology of ALV-J strains was examined. A total of 265 clinical specimens collected in southern China from 2013 to 2014 were tested for the presence of ALV-J in this study, resulting in 12 virus isolates. Phylogenetic analysis showed that 91.7% (11/12) of ALV-J isolates had high homology to Chinese strata isolates and belonged to a subgroup. One of the ALV isolates (designated GD1411-1) was relatively closely related to the ALV-J broiler isolates, suggesting that the GD1411-1 isolate may be a transitional strain. Several unique nucleotide substitutions in gp85 and the U3 region were detected in all 12 ALV-J isolates. This study provides some interesting information on the molecular characterization of ALV-J isolates. These findings will be useful in understanding the pathogenic mechanism of ALV-J infection.
authors: Lin, W.;Li, X.;Dai, Z.;Zhang, X.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.;Zhang, H.;Chen, F.;Xie, Q.

title: Genetic and pathobiological characterization of H3N2 canine influenza virus isolated in 2009-2010 in Jiangsu province of China
abstract: The emerging canine influenza virus (CIV) is a cause of significant veterinary and public health concern. In 2009-2010, six strains of H3N2 influenza virus were isolated from dogs in Jiangsu Province, China. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of eight gene segments revealed that the six viruses most closely resembled a canine influenza virus of the H3N2 subtype recently isolated in cats from South Korea, which originated from an avian strain. By comparing the deduced amino acid sequences of the hemagglutinin 1 (HA1) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of the six Jiangsu isolates with the most similar avian strains, we found that all isolates shared several mutations at the receptor binding sites, potential glycosylation sites, and cleavage sites in HA1 and antigenic sites in both the HA1 and NA segments. Significantly, a unique two amino acid insertion was found in the NA stalk. Experimental infection of BALB/c mice showed that viral RNA could be detected in major rodent organs such as brain, heart, spleen, kidney, liver and intestine, and lung. All organs removed from infected mice showed significant lesions and viral antigen staining. This study underscores the potential of domesticated animals to become a reservoir for influenza viruses and the need for surveillance programs to detect transmission between species. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Lin, Y.;Zhao, Y.;Zeng, X.;Lu, C.;Liu, Y.

title: Detection and characterization of viruses causing hand, foot and mouth disease in children in Seri Kembangan, Malaysia
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral infection in infants and children. The main causative agents of HFMD are Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and Coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16). Coxsackievirus A6 (CVA6) infections have recently been reported in neighboring countries. Infected infants and children may have a fever, mouth/throat ulcers, skin rashes, and blisters on hands and feet. In addition, EV71 infection can cause fatal neurological complications. Since 1997, EV71 has caused fatalities in Sarawak and Peninsular Malaysia. The purpose of this study was to identify and classify the viruses detected in patients with clinical signs and symptoms of HFMD in Seri Kembangan, Malaysia. From December 2012 to July 2013, a total of 28 samples were collected from patients with clinical case definition of HFMD. The HFMD viruses were detected using semi-nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (snRT-PCR). The positive snRT-PCR products were sequenced and virus phylogenetic analyzes were performed. 12 of 28 samples (42.9%) were positive by snRT-PCR, seven were CVA6 (58.3%), two were CVA16 (16.7%) and three were EV71 (25%). Based on phylogenetic analysis studies, EV71 strains have been identified as subgenotype B5; CVA16 strains classified as subgenotype B2b and B2c; CVA6 strains closely related to strains in Taiwan and Japan. In this study, HFMD in Seri Kembangan was caused by different types of enteroviruses, namely EV71, CVA6 and CVA16.
authors: Ling, B. P.;Jalilian, F. A.;Harmal, N. S.;Yubbu, P.;Sekawi, Z.

title: Hypothesis about the source, transmission and characteristics of infection with avian influenza A (H7N9) virus - based on analysis of epidemiological field studies and gene sequence analysis
abstract: Summary: On March 31, 2013, the National Health and Family Planning Commission announced that human influenza A virus (H7N9) infections had occurred in the provinces of Shanghai and Anhui, China. H7N9 cases were later discovered in Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces. It was estimated that the virus first spread north along the route of migratory birds and then spread to neighboring provinces through the sale of poultry. Epidemiological studies were conducted on samples from the external environment of infected cases, routes of transmission, farmers' markets and live poultry markets. A phylogenetic study of viral sequences of human and avian infections in Zhejiang showed that those from Shanghai and Jiangsu provinces along Lake Taihu were highly homologous with those from the outer environment. This suggests that avian viruses transmitted by waterfowl combine with the virus transmitted by migratory birds, resulting in the H7N9 avian influenza virus, which is highly pathogenic to humans. It is possible that the virus was spread from domestic wild fowl to domestic fowl and then to humans, or was further spread by trading in wholesale poultry markets. As the weather has gotten warmer and measures have been taken to end the poultry trade and facilitate health communication, the epidemic has been kept under control in the first half of the year. However, the source of infection in the Taihu Lake triangle area remains. The H7N9 epidemic is likely to hit the area later in the year and next spring when migratory birds return, and possibly even spread to other areas. Therefore, great importance should be attached to the wildfowl in Taihu Lake as a repository and spreader of the virus: the study and investigation of this population is essential.
authors: Ling, F.;Chen, E.;Liu, Q.;Miao, Z.;Gong, Z.

title: Turkey rhinotracheitis virus: in vivo and in vitro polypeptide synthesis
abstract: Turkey rhinotracheitis (TRT) virus is a paramyxovirus associated with recent outbreaks of acute respiratory disease in turkeys. According to morphological criteria, it resembles pneumoviruses more than other members of the paramyxovirus family. In this communication we report the identification of five virus-induced polypeptides in TRT virus-infected BS-C-1 cells. The Mr of these polypeptides was estimated to be 38K, 35K, 30K, 19K, and 15K based on their electrophoretic mobility in 6-15% SDS-polyacrylamide gradient gels. The virus specificity of four (the 38K, 35K, 30K and 19K Mr polypeptides) of these five was confirmed by their predominance as products of in vitro translation of mRNA from TRT virus-infected BS-C-1 cells . An additional virus-specific polypeptide with an estimated Mr of 22K was revealed by in vitro translation and may be either a non-structural polypeptide or a minor structural protein. All six polypeptides were immunoprecipitated by a murine antiserum. Three other polypeptides (129K, 57K and 45K) were also immunoprecipitated. The 57K, 45K, and 15K Mr polypeptides have been glycosylated, and the 57K glycopolypeptide may be a disulfide-bonded dimer of the 45K and 15K glycopolypeptides. Another important 83 K Mr glycopolypeptide was observed, but its virus specificity could not be confirmed. Taken together, our results tentatively identify eight or nine TRT virus-specific polypeptides and are consistent with the classification of TRT virus as a new member of the genus Pneumovirus.
authors: Ling, R.;Pringle, C. R.

title: Viral metagenomics reveals significant viruses in the genital tract of apparently healthy dairy cows
abstract: Virome was characterized in genital tract secretion samples collected from 80 dairy cows in Shanghai, China. Viruses detected included members of the families Papillomaviridae, Polyomaviridae, Hepeviridae, Parvoviridae, Astroviridae, Picornaviridae, and Picobirnaviridae. A member of a new species within the genus Dyoxipapillomavirus and six viral genomes encoding circular Rep have been fully sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. The prevalence of bovine polyomaviruses 1 and 2 was measured by PCR at 10% (8/80) and 6.25% (5/80), respectively. The PCR screening also showed that the novel papillomavirus ujs-21015 and bovine herpesvirus 6 were present in three and two of the 80 samples, respectively.
authors: Ling, Y.;Zhang, X.;Qi, G.;Yang, S.;Jingjiao, L.;Shen, Q.;Wang, X.;Cui, L.;Hua, X.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Zhang, W.

title: The faecal vioma of children with hand, foot, and mouth disease that tested negative for pathogenic enterovirus by PCR
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) affects infants and young children. A viral metagenomic approach was used to identify the eukaryotic viruses in stool samples from 29 Thai children with a clinical diagnosis of HFMD collected during the 2012 outbreak. These children had previously tested negative for enterovirus 71 and coxsackievirus A16 and A6 by PCR. Deep sequencing revealed nine virus families: Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Parvoviridae, Caliciviridae, Paramyxoviridae, Adenoviridae, Reoviridae, Picobirnaviridae and Polyomaviridae. The highest number of viral sequences belonged to human rhinovirus C, astrovirus-MLB2 and coxsackievirus A21. Our study provides an overview of the viral community and highlights a wide variety of viruses found in the feces of children with HFMD. Copyright ©:
authors: Linsuwanon, P.;Poovorawan, Y.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Vongpunsawad, S.;Delwart, E.

title: Influenza (H5N1) Viruses in Poultry, Russian Federation, 2005-2006
abstract: We studied 7 influenza (H5N1) viruses isolated from poultry in western Siberia and the European part of the Russian Federation from July 2005 to February 2006. Complete genome sequences showed high homology to Qinghai-like influenza (H5N1) viruses. The phylogenetic analysis not only showed a close genetic relationship between the H5N1 strains isolated from poultry and wild migratory waterfowl, but also indicated a genetic rearrangement among the analyzed isolates. Analysis of the deduced amino acid sequences of the M2 and neuraminidase proteins showed that all isolates are potentially sensitive to currently available antiviral drugs. Pathogenicity tests showed that all viruses examined were highly pathogenic in chickens; pathogenicity was heterogeneous in 3 isolates tested in mice and 2 in ferrets. Pathogenicity in mammalian models was generally correlated with Lys at residue 627 of polymerase basic protein 2.
authors: Lipatov, A. S.;Evseenko, V. A.;Yen, H. L.;Zaykovskaya, A. V.;Durimanov, A. G.;Zolotykh, S. I.;Netesov, S. V.;Drozdov, I. G.;Onishchenko, G. G.;Webster, R. G.;Shestopalov, A. M.

title: Viral surveillance and detection
abstract: The field of virus discovery has seen investment in, and recognition of, global microbial surveillance spanning both wild and domestic animals as well as humans, with the advent of high-throughput sequencing platforms and bioinformatics programs that enable rapid identification and molecular characterization of known and novel pathogens Viruses can be involved in both chronic and acute diseases. Here we discuss methodologies for virus surveillance and detection, strategies and pitfalls in linking discoveries to disease, and identify opportunities for improvements in instrument sequencing and analysis, the use of social media and medical informatics that will further advance clinical medicine and public health will advance. © 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lipkin, W. I.;Firth, C.

title: Genetic characterization and mutational analysis of Qihe547-Aujeszky disease virus in China
abstract: Background: Aujeszky's disease virus (ADV) can cause neurological disorders in young pigs, respiratory disorders in older pigs, and abortion or delivery of mummified fetuses or stillborn newborns. The recurrence of Aujeszky's disease (AD) in pig farms vaccinated with live vaccine (Bartha-K61) has caused significant economic losses to the Chinese swine industry since late 2011. A field ADV, named Qihe547, was isolated from pigs suspected of having AD presenting with clinical symptoms. To better understand the genetic properties and mutations of Qihe547 ADV, the entire genome was sequenced and analyzed. Results: The genomic length of Qihe547 ADV was 143,404 bp, with 73.59% G+C content. A phylogenetic analysis based on the whole genome of ADV strains revealed that Chinese ADV strains belonged to a group with three subgroups. Qihe547 ADV was closely related to these new ADV strains isolated in China since 2012. Qihe547 showed numerous hypervariable regions compared to foreign ADV strains. Amino acid (AA) insertion or deletion was observed in 34 genes of Qihe547 ADV. In addition, numerous AA mutations were found in the major protective antigen genes (gB, gC and gD genes). The differences of potential antigenic peptides in the major protective antigens between Qihe547 ADV and ADV Bartha were detected in the dominant antigenic regions of gB (AA59-AA126, AA507-AA734), the extracellular region of gC and gD. Conclusion: High diversity was observed between Qihe547 and foreign ADV isolates. The AA variations and potential antigenic peptide differences in the key functional regions of the major protective antigen (gB, gC, and gD) of ADV Qihe547 may contribute to virus immune evasion and may be in part the reason the virus evades vaccination of the Bartha K61 vaccine. In a word, the effect of the variations obviously requires further research.
authors: Liu, C.;Liu, Y.;Tian, Y.;Wei, X.;Zhang, Y.;Tian, F.

title: First report of feline bocavirus associated with severe enteritis in cats in Northeast China, 2015
abstract: Feline bocavirus (FBoV) is a newly identified feline bocavirus of the family Parvoviridae. A novel FBoV HRB2015-LDF was first identified in a cat with severe enteritis in northeast China, with an overall positive rate of 2.78% (1/36). Full genome phylogenetic and homologous analysis showed that FBoV HRB2015-LDF was clustered into the FBoV branch and closely related to other FBoVs with 68.7-97.5% identities. And the genes of VP1, NPA and NS1 shared 70.7-97.6, 72.4-98.6 and 67.2-98.0% nucleotide identities with other FBoVs, respectively. The results suggested that the FBoVs could be divided into two distinct lineages and the difference in nucleotide identities between the lineages was >20-30%.
authors: Liu, C. G.;Liu, F.;Li, Z. G.;Qu, L. D.;Liu, D. F.

title: Emerging multiple reassortant H5N5 aviäre Influenzaviren bei Enten, China, 2008
abstract: Three highly pathogenic H5N5 avian influenza viruses (HPAI), A/duck/Guangdong/wy11/2008 (WY11), A/duck/Guangdong/wy19/2008 (WY19) and A/duck/Guangdong/wy24/2008 (WY24) were identified in April Isolated from ducks in southern China in 2008. Here we characterized these viruses by performing sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of their viral genes, assessed their virulence in ducks and mice, and performed cross-protection experiments in chickens. Sequence analysis revealed that the HA genes of these H5N5 viruses showed 97.1-97.8% homology to A/Wild Duck/Hunan/211/2005 (H5N1) influenza virus and their NA genes 96.4-96 Exhibited .8% nucleotide identity with the NA gene of A/duck/Hunan/5613/2003 (H6N5) influenza virus belonging to the Eurasian lineage. Genotypic analyzes showed that these H5N5 viruses were multiple reassortants among H5N1, H5N2, H6N2 and H6N5 viruses. Analysis of the HA clade showed that these H5N5 viruses cluster in clade 2.3.4. In animal studies, these H5N5 viruses caused 50% mortality in ducks and 100% mortality in chickens. In cross-protection experiments, the Clade 2.3.2 avian influenza vaccine in chickens was only able to provide 75% protection against H5N5 virus challenge. In addition, the H5N5 virus efficiently replicated in the lungs of mice, suggesting that the H5N5 viruses have the potential to infect mammalian hosts. Because ducks have served as reassorting vessels that play a key role in the generation of new influenza virus subtypes, it is important to monitor the emergence of this novel influenza virus subtype in aquatic birds to understand their ecology and evolution, and to control the spread of new viruses viruses. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, C. G.;Liu, M.;Liu, F.;Lv, R.;Liu, D. F.;Qu, L. D.;Zhang, Y.

title: Development of a reverse genetics system for small ruminant morbillivirus: rescuing recombinant virus to express Echinococcus granulosus EG95 antigen
abstract: Small ruminant plague and cystic hydatidosis may be endemic in a given area at the same time. Their pathogens are the small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV) or Echinococcus granulosus (E. granulosus). SRMV, formerly known as peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV), is classified in the genus Morbillivirus in the family Paramyxoviridae. This virus is an ideal vaccine vector to deliver immunogenic proteins. In this study, a reverse genetics system was developed to rescue a recombinant SRMV (strain Nigeria 75/1) expressing E. granulosus EG95 antigen in vitro. The recombinant SRMV, although replicating more slowly than its parent virus, was able to efficiently express the EG95 antigen in cells by Western blot, indirect immunofluorescence and mass spectrometry analyses. An EG95 subunit vaccine has been widely used in some areas of China for the prevention of cystic hydatidiasis. The EG95-expressing SRMV, if shown in a future animal study to elicit effective immune responses against both diseases, would become a potential candidate for a bivalent vaccine.
authors: Liu, F.;Li, L.;Liu, Y.;Sun, C.;Liu, C.;Wu, X.;Wang, Z.

title: Rescue of the eGFP-expressing small ruminant morbillivirus to identify the susceptibility of eight mammalian cell lines to its infection
abstract: Small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV), formerly called peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV), is classified in the genus Morbillivirus in the family Paramyxoviridae. If genetically modified using reverse genetics, the SRMV would be a useful vector to express foreign proteins in vitro and in vivo. In this study, a recombinant SRMV was rescued by reverse genetics to efficiently express an enhanced green fluorescent protein (eGFP) in vitro. Based on green fluorescence-tracked characteristics of recombinant SRMV, eight mammalian cell lines (BHK-21, F81, MDBK, RK13, MDCK, PK15, Vero, and GT) were selected to identify their susceptibility to SRMV infection. The result showed that all cell lines could be infected with the recombinant SRMV, but with different efficiencies. The Vero and PK15 cell lines showed the highest and lowest susceptibility to their infection, respectively, when comparing only the proportions of green fluorescence-emitting cells among eight cell monolayers.
authors: Liu, F.;Zhang, Y.;Li, L.;Zuo, Y.;Sun, C.;Xiaodong, W.;Wang, Z.

title: Identification and Analysis of Novel Viral and Host Dysregulated MicroRNAs in PK15 Cells Infected with Pseudorabies Virus
abstract: Pseudorabies (PR) is one of the most devastating diseases in the swine industry. To identify changes in microRNA (miRNA) expression and post-transcriptional regulatory responses to PRV infection in porcine renal epithelial (PK15) cells, we sequenced a small RNA (sRNA) library prepared from infected PK15 cells and compared them to a library made from uninfected cells using Illumina deep sequencing. Here we found 25 novel viral miRNAs by high-throughput sequencing and 20 of these miRNAs were confirmed by stem-loop RT-qPCR. Interestingly, these novel viral miRNAs are present throughout the PRV genome like β-herpesviruses, in contrast to the usual miRNAs encoded by the α-herpesviruses, which are abundant in the Large Latency Transcript (LLT). Viral miRNAs are predicted to target multiple genes and form a complex regulatory network. GO analyzes on host targets of viral miRNAs have been implicated in complex cellular processes including the metabolic pathway, biological regulation, stimulus response, signaling process, and immune response. Furthermore, 13 host miRNAs were expressed with significant difference after infection with PRV: 8 miRNAs were upregulated and 5 miRNAs were downregulated, which may affect viral replication in the host cell. Our results provided new insights into the characteristics of miRNAs in response to PRV infection, which is important for further investigating the function of these miRNAs.
authors: Liu, F.;Zheng, H.;Tong, W.;Li, G. X.;Tian, Q.;Liang, C.;Li, L. W.;Zheng, X. C.;Tong, G. Z.

title: The genetic diversity of the VP1 gene of duck hepatitis virus type I (DHV-I) isolates from Southeast China is related to isolate attenuation
abstract: The complete sequence of an isolate (ZJ-V) of duck hepatitis virus I (DHV-I) originally collected from the field in Southeast China has been determined. It was 7691 nucleotides long and had 5- and 3-terminal noncoding regions of 626 and 315 nucleotides, respectively. The poly(A) tail contained at least 22 residues and the single open reading frame encoded a polypeptide of 2249 amino acids. The VP1 gene was also sequenced from nine Southeast China field isolates and three attenuated DHV-I vaccine strains. On phylogenetic analysis of the isolates and other published sequences, attenuated and tissue-matched isolates (including ZJ-V) amassed as genotypes that differed significantly from the field isolates that had not been passaged in chick/duck embryos. There were two consistent amino acid substitutions (E129 → V129 and A142 → S142) between all field isolates and all tissue-matched. The carboxy-terminal region was generally the most variable, and here the four attenuated Chinese isolates showed six consistent differences from the field isolates (S181 → L181, H183K184 → R183G1841, N193 → D193, E205 → K205, R217 → K217, N235 → D235). It seems likely that at least some of these differences are due to mutations leading to attenuation of the isolate. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, G.;Wang, F.;Ni, Z.;Yun, T.;Yu, B.;Huang, J.;Chen, J.

title: Complete genomic sequence of a Chinese duck hepatitis virus isolate
abstract: The complete genomic sequence of the duck hepatitis virus 1 (DHV-1) ZJ-V isolate was sequenced and analyzed to a length of 7,691 nucleotides (nt) with a 5-terminal untranslated region (UTR) of 626 nt and determined a 3 -terminal UTR of 315 nt (without poly(A) tail). Within the genome (nt 627 to 7373) a large open reading frame (ORF) encoding a polypeptide of 2249 amino acids was found. Our data also showed that the poly(A) tail of DHV-1 is at least 22 Å. Sequence comparison revealed significant homology (from 91.9% to 95.7%) between the protein sequences of the ZJ-V isolate and those of 21 reference isolates. Although DHV-1 was classified as an unassigned virus in the Picornaviridae family, its genome displayed some unique properties. DHV-1 contains 3 copies of the 2A gene and only 1 copy of the 3B gene, and its 3″ NCR is longer than that of other picornaviruses. Phylogenetic analysis to perform sequence homology based on the VP1 protein sequences showed that the ZJ-V isolate shares high sequence homology (from 92.9% to 99.2%) with the reported DHV-1 isolates, indicating suggests that DHV-1 is genetically stable.
authors: Liu, G. Q.;Wang, F.;Ni, Z.;Yun, T.;Yu, B.;Huang, J. G.;Chen, J. P.

title: Genomic characterization of the first Newcastle disease class I virus isolated from mainland China
abstract: The complete genomic sequence of Newcastle disease virus (NDV), strain NDV08-004, isolated from domestic ducks in China was determined in this study. The genome is 15198 nucleotides (nt) long, follows the "Rule of Six" and contains a 55 nt leader sequence at the 3" end and a 114 nt trailer sequence at the 5" end. Compared to the complete genome sequences of the NDV class II strains, the NDV08-004 isolate has a 12-nt insertion (TGGGA GACGGGG) in the phosphoprotein gene between nucleotides 2381 and 2382 of the genome (numbered according to the genomic sequence of the La Sota tribe consisting of 15186 nt). Strain NDV08-004 exhibits the 112E-QQER-L117 motif at the fusion protein cleavage site typical of lentogenic NDV strains, consistent with the results of pathogenicity tests based on mean death time (MDT) and the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI). The phylogenetic analysis based on the full genome revealed that all NDV strains examined could be divided into two distinct clades, namely class I and class II, and the NDV08-004 isolate characterized in this study was grouped into class I. Further phylogenetic analysis based on a 374 bp fragment of the F gene in class I strains of NDV showed that NDV08-004 belongs to genotype 3 and should therefore be similar to the strains that have entered live markets in recent years Birds were purchased in Hong Kong. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Liu, H.;Chen, F.;Zhao, Y.;Zheng, D.;Li, J.;Xu, T.;Qi, L.;Wang, Z.

title: Isolation and molecular and phylogenetic analyzes of wild boar encephalomyocarditis virus in central China
abstract: Encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) can infect many host species and cause acute myocarditis and respiratory failure in piglets and reproductive failure in pregnant sows. In this study, an EMCV strain, designated JZ1202, was isolated from semi-captive wild boar suffering from acute myocarditis and sudden death in central China. It has been identified by hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assay, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and genome sequencing. Subsequent results indicated that the virus could exert a specific cytopathic effect on BHK cells and induce clinical symptoms and pathological changes in mice. Full genome sequencing and multiple sequence alignment showed that the JZ1202 strain was 81.3% to 99.9% identical to other isolates worldwide. Phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome, ORF, VP3/VP1 and 3D genes using neighbor joining method revealed that the JZ1202 isolate was grouped into lineage 1. The results of this study confirmed that an EMCV strain JZ 1202 isolated from wild boar in central China was lethal to mice and provided new epidemiological data on EMCV in China.
authors: Liu, H.;He, X.;Song, X.;Xu, L.;Zhang, Y.;Zhou, G.;Zhu, W.;Chang, C.;Yin, Z.;Shi, Y.;Wang, C.;Chang, H.

title: Complete genome sequences and phylogenetic analysis of encephalomyocarditis virus strains isolated from pigs and rats
abstract: To assess the genetic variability of encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV), the entire genomes of six EMCV field isolates derived from pigs and rats and originating from different regions of central China were analyzed phylogenetically and comparatively. Phylogenetic analysis of the entire genome sequences, open reading frame (ORF), capsid coding region (CCR) and VP3/VP1 using neighbor joining analysis revealed that these isolates belonged to lineage 1. The nucleotide sequences of six isolates showed more than 99% pairwise identity rates, and the sequences of porcine and boar isolates in the same region were completely identical to each other, with no genetic deletion or insertion. From the comparative analysis of the variability of each coding region of the EMCV protein, the 3D and VP3 regions showed the highest average identity rates and were confirmed to be highly conserved. In contrast, it was confirmed that the protein coding regions 3A and 3B are highly variable regions with the lowest average identity rate. Our data confirmed that the EMCV strains isolated from pigs and rats showed high homology between each other, implying that rats may play an important role in EMCV transmission between domestic pigs and wild boar.
authors: Liu, H.;Li, Y.;Zhang, G.;Sang, S.;Wang, C.;Chang, H.

title: Japanese encephalitis virus in mosquitoes and swine in Yunnan Province, China 2009–2010
authors: Liu, H.;Lu, H. J.;Liu, Z. J.;Jing, J.;Ren, J. Q.;Liu, Y. Y.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated from waterfowl in China
abstract: Ten representative isolates of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) recovered from outbreaks in waterfowl (geese and ducks) in China since 1997 have been characterized both pathotypically and genotypically. Mean time of death and intracerebral pathogenicity index were used to assess the virulence of the isolates. Pathogenicity tests showed that all 10 isolates were velogen strains. The 535 nucleotide major functional region of the F gene was amplified by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and sequenced. The deduced amino acid sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site in all 10 isolates was 112RRQKRF117, which is a typical sequence of velogenic strains and consistent with the results of in vivo pathogenicity tests. A pedigree based on nucleotides 47-435 of the F gene was constructed for genotyping. Phylogenetic analysis showed that most isolates were of genotype VII virus. Only one strain, WG, was found to be genotype IX virus. This strain was closest to F48E9, which was isolated in China in 1946 and used as a standard challenge strain in vaccine evaluation in China. So genotype IX virus still causes sporadic infections in geese in China. Further phylogenetic analysis of genotype VII strains revealed that all of these strains can be divided into 5 subgenotypes and most of the isolates (8 strains) were classified as VIId, a predominant genotype responsible for most Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks. has been responsible since the end of the past century in China. Only 1 strain, NDV03-053, has been shown to be genotype VIIc virus. The results show that the VIId NDV genotype strains are the main pathogens responsible for most outbreaks of ND in waterfowl in China since 1997.
authors: Liu, H.;Wang, Z.;Wang, Y.;Sun, C.;Zheng, D.;Wu, Y.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of novel Newcastle disease virus isolates from mainland China
abstract: Seventy-nine velogenetic Newcastle disease (NDV) virus isolates were obtained from infected chicken flocks during the 2006 Newcastle disease (ND) outbreak in various regions of mainland China. The F gene fragment (535 bp, from nt 47 to 581 of F gene) encoding the main functional region of F protein was obtained by RT-PCR and sequenced. All sequences obtained in this study were submitted to GenBank. All isolates have the 112R-RQ/RK/RR-F117 motif at the cleavage site of the fusion protein, which is typical for velogenic NDV isolates. For genotyping, a pedigree was constructed based on nucleotides 47-435 of the F gene and the 79 isolates could be divided into two genotypes, viz. VIId and III. Most isolates turned out to be of genotype VIId; only two isolates were of genotype III. Genotype VIId NDV was the predominant pathogen responsible for most outbreaks of Newcastle disease in China. According to studies on the molecular epidemiology of NDV in China from 2002 to 2006, the proportion of isolates of genotype VIId NDV shows an increasing trend. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, H.;Wang, Z.;Wu, Y.;Wu, Y.;Sun, C.;Zheng, D.;Xu, T.;Li, J.

title: Molecular epidemiological analysis of the Newcastle disease virus isolated in China in 2005
abstract: 83 strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) were isolated from outbreaks in chickens, pigeons, geese and ducks in China in 2005 and genotypically characterized. The major functional region of the F gene (535 nucleotides) was amplified and sequenced. A phylogenetic tree based on nucleotides 47-435 of the F gene was constructed using sequences from 83 isolates and representative NDV sequences obtained from GenBank. The phylogenetic analysis showed that all newly characterized strains belonged to six genetic groups: I, II, III, VIb, VIIc and VIId. All isolates belonging to Groups I and II (14 in total) were lentogenic according to the amino acid sequences of the fusion protein cleavage site and were either V4 or LaSota type depending on the vaccines used. Most of the isolates (64 in total) have been assigned to group VIId, a predominant genotype responsible for most outbreaks of Newcastle disease since the end of the last century. One strain, NDV05-055, was in Group VIIc, three pigeon strains were in Group VIb, and one isolate, NDV05-041, was in Group III and was characterized as a velogen strain. This study found that genotype VIId was the main NDV strain responsible for the ND epizoonosis that emerged in China in 2005. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, H.;Wang, Z.;Wu, Y.;Zheng, D.;Sun, C.;Bi, D.;Zuo, Y.;Xu, T.

title: Phylogenetic characterization and virulence of two Newcastle disease viruses isolated from wild birds in China
abstract: Wild birds are considered a natural reservoir of Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV). However, there is no information on the IX NDV genotype of wild birds, particularly Columbiformes. In this study, two genotype IX NDV viruses were isolated from wild birds. One was from Eurasian Blackbird while the other was from Spotted-necked dove. After purification by plaque technique, complete genomes of both viruses were sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the partial fusion gene (F) and the full genome showed that both strains belonged to genotype IX. Based on the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), the Eurasian blackbird virus was a velogenic virus while the spotted pigeon strain was a lentogenic virus. However, both strains showed a velogenic cleavage site. In addition, the Eurasian blackbird strain showed greater replication ability and generated larger foci of fusion in vitro than the spotted pigeon strain. Comparing all the corresponding protein sequences of both strains, there were only 9 different amino acid residues between them. Furthermore, after analyzing these differences, the information on lentogenic NDV with multibasic cleavage site was presented.
authors: Liu, H.;Zhang, P.;Wu, P.;Chen, S.;Mu, G.;Duan, X.;Hao, H.;Du, E.;Wang, X.;Yang, Z.

title: Rapid characterization of avian reoviruses using phylogenetic analysis, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, and restriction enzyme fragment length polymorphism
abstract: reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction is described that amplified the full length sigmaC-encoding and sigmaNS-encoding genes of avian reovirus (ARV). DNA fragments of 1022 and 1152 base pairs, respectively, were amplified among the ARV isolates, indicating that there were no obvious deletions or insertions in these regions. Fragments amplified from vaccine strains and field isolates were digested with five different restriction enzymes Bcn I, Hae III, Taq I, Dde I and Hinc II, respectively. Restriction fragment profiles observed on polyacrylamide gels showed heterogeneity between vaccine and Taiwanese isolates. All ARV isolates tested showed different restriction enzyme cleavage patterns and could be clearly distinguished. Strain typing based on the cleavage sites in the ARV sigmaC-encoding gene showed that viruses could be divided into four different groups. A phylogenetic tree based on the nucleotide sequences of the sigmaC-encoding gene revealed that Taiwanese ARV isolates were classified into four distinct groups, indicating that genotyping is consistent with typing based on the restriction enzyme fragment length polymorphism of the sigmaC-encoding gene of ARV matches. Results suggested that polymerase chain reaction followed by restriction enzyme analysis provided a simple and rapid approach to characterize ARV isolates. It can also be used to determine if a new strain variant has been introduced into a flock or if a particular virus strain has spread from one flock to another.
authors: Liu, H. J.;Lee, L. H.;Shih, W. L.;Li, Y. J.;Su, H. Y.

title: Complete genome sequence of goose parvovirus Y strain isolated from Muscovy ducks in China
abstract: goose parvovirus (GPV) Y strain was isolated from Muscovy ducks in Anhui Province, China. Its complete genomic sequence was determined by the polymerase chain reaction method to be 5,106 bp, consisting of 444 bp inverted terminal repeat, 1,844 bp nonstructural protein, and 2,199 bp capsid protein (VP) regions. Then its sequence was matched to the sequences of GPV and Muscovy Duck Parvovirus published in GenBank using the neighbor-joining method. The phylogenetic analyzes based on the VP3 gene sequences revealed that the GPV-Y strain belonged to subgroup IIb along with those from Taiwan, while other GPV strains of muscovy ducks belonged to subgroup Ib and most other GPV strains, isolated in mainland China were clustered in subgroup IIa. The absence of the deduced 703-705NRT glycosylation site in the VP region may explain the host specificity of the GPV Y strain. The complete genomic sequence of Muscovy duck GPV Y strain will help to understand the molecular and evolutionary characteristics of GPV. © Springer Science+Business Media 2013.
authors: Liu, H. M.;Wang, H.;Tian, X. J.;Zhang, S.;Zhou, X. H.;Qi, K. Z.;Pan, L.

title: Construction of a phylogenetic tree and sequence analysis of the BDV p24 gene in both livestock and hosts in Ningxia
authors: Liu, J.;Liu, Y.;Wang, Z. H.;Xie, P.

title: Interregional transmission of H2 influenza virus internal protein genes in migratory ducks from North America to Eurasia
abstract: The H2 flu virus caused a pandemic in 1957 and has the potential to cause outbreaks in the future. To assess the evolutionary characteristics of H2 influenza viruses isolated from migratory ducks congregating in Hokkaido, Japan, on their migration route from Siberia in 2001, we examined the phylogenetic relationships between these viruses and the avian and human viruses previously described. The phylogenetic analysis showed that the PB2 gene of Dk/Hokkaido/107/01 (H2N3) and the PA gene of Dk/Hokkaido/95/01 (H2N2) belonged to the American lineage of avian virus and that the other genes of the isolates belonged to Eurasian descent. These results indicate that the internal protein genes could be transferred from American to Eurasian bird hosts. Thus, it further confirms that interregional transmission of influenza viruses between North American and Eurasian birds occurred. The fact that reassortants could be generated in the migratory ducks between North American and Eurasian avian virus lineages further underscores the importance of global surveillance among migratory ducks.
authors: Liu, J.;Okazaki, K.;Bai, G.;Shi, W.;Mweene, A.;Kida, H.

title: Recombination in lineages 1, 3, 5 and 8 of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses in China
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most important viral swine diseases, causing immense economic losses in Chinese swine industry. There are currently four main lines circulating in China: Line 1 (NADC30-like), 3 (QYYZ-like), 5.1 (VR2332-like), and 8.7 (JXA1-like) of Type 2 PRRSV (North American Type) based on classification system that have raised concerns about the potential for viral recombination. In the present study, a novel variant of the PRRSV strain named FJLIUY-2017 was isolated from an abortion rate (25%) in pregnant gilts in Fujian Province, China, in 2017. To advance our knowledge of the novel virus strain, we characterized the full genome of FJLIUY-2017. Comparison with PRRS sequences in GenBank confirmed the absence of close relatives (<92%), but suggested that FJLIUY-2017 belonged to NADC30-like PRRSV. The full length of FJLIUY-2017 was determined to be 15017 nucleotides (nt), without the poly(A) tail, and shared 86.2-86.6% identity with JXA1-like strains (JXA1, TJ, and FJYR), 88 .9-90.6% with NADC30-like PRRSVs (NADC30, FJZ03 and CHsx1401), 86.4-86.5% with VR2332-like (VR2332, RespPRRS MLV and BJ-4) and only 60.8% with LV (European type). Recombination analysis revealed genomic breakpoints in structural (ORF3, ORF4, and ORF7) and nonstructural (Nsp1, Nsp2, Nsp6, Nsp9, Nsp11, and Nsp12) regions of the genome with evidence for recombination events between lineages 1, 3, 5.1, and 8.7. Overall, the results of our study provide further confirmation that PRRSV is susceptible to recombination events. Therefore, it is of crucial importance to monitor the development of PRRSV in China and to develop an effective strategy to control PRRS.
authors: Liu, J.;Wei, C.;Lin, Z.;Fan, J.;Xia, W.;Dai, A.;Yang, X.

title: Genetic characterization of VP4-VP2 from two coxsackieviruses A4 isolated from patients with hand, foot, and mouth disease
abstract: AIM: To study the genetic characteristics of VP4-VP2 of coxsackievirus A4 (CVA4) isolated from clinical specimens from patients with hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in Gansu in 2008. METHODS: Two clinical specimens were obtained from HFMD patients taken in outpatient service, and then virus isolation was performed by inoculation of RD cells. The VP4-VP2 region from two viral isolates was amplified using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction methods and then the PCR products were sequenced; molecular typing was used to identify the serotype of these two viral isolates. Finally, the phylogenetic tree was constructed between these two Gansu virus isolates and 16 CVA4 strains downloaded from GenBank database. RESULTS: Two viruses were isolated from clinical specimens collected from two HFMD patients by inoculation of RD cells and were identified as CVA4 using molecular typing methods. The homology of the nucleotide sequences in the VP4-VP2 region between the two Gansu CVA4 strains was 94.6% and the homology of the amino acid sequences was 100%. Compared with the prototype strain of CVA4 (Strain High Point/USA/1948), the homologies of nucleotide sequences and amino acid sequences were 85.5%-85.8% and 99.3%, respectively. Two Gansu CVA4 tribes were shown to lie within the independence group. CONCLUSION: Compared with CVA4 strains isolated in Japan and Mongolia downloaded from GenBank database, two Gansu CVA4 strains were found to have large differences in VP4-VP2 region, and phylogenetic analysis revealed, that they belong to an independent line of evolution.
authors: Liu, J. F.;Zhang, Y.;Li, H.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of H9N2 viruses isolated from migratory ducks
abstract: Genetic analyzes showed that wild waterfowl-derived strains of pandemic influenza harbor viruses of 15 hemagglutinin (HA) and 9 antigenic neuraminidase (NA) subtypes. Surveillance studies have shown that H9N2 subtype viruses are present in domestic poultry worldwide and could infect mammalian species including humans. Here we genetically analyzed the HA and NA genes of five H9N2 viruses isolated from migratory ducks in Hokkaido, Japan, the migratory route from Siberia between 1997 and 2000. The results showed that the HA and NA genes of these viruses belong to the same lineages, respectively. Compared to those of A/Quail/Hongkong/G1/97-like and A/duck/Hongkong/Y280/97-like viruses, HA and NA of the migratory duck isolates were closely related to those of H9N2 viruses isolated from the chicken in Korea, suggesting that the Korea H9N2 viruses may have originated from the migratory ducks. The NA genes of the five isolates were in the same cluster as those of N2 viruses that caused a human pandemic in 1968, suggesting that the NA genes of the earlier pandemic strains are still circulating in waterfowl reservoirs. The present results further emphasize the importance of conducting molecular epidemiological surveillance of H9N2 viruses in wild ducks to provide more information for future human influenza pandemic preparedness.
authors: Liu, J. H.;Okazaki, K.;Shi, W. M.;Kida, H.

title: Identification of a novel bufavirus in domestic swine by a viral metagenomic approach
abstract: Bufavirus is a single-stranded DNA virus belonging to the genus Protoparvovirus. This study reports the identification and characterization of a swine bufavirus through a metagenomic approach and a limited epidemiological survey of bufavirus in six swine farms. A comparative genome analysis showed a similarity of 93% to a Hungarian porcine bufavirus. Bayesian and maximum likelihood analyzes of genomic sequences revealed a close relationship of porcine bufaviruses to human and simian bufaviruses. Molecular dating of the most recent common ancestors supported a recent introduction of bufaviruses into human and swine populations, respectively. A real-time PCR method was developed to screen 60 fecal samples for porcine bufavirus DNA and eight positive samples were found in two neighboring farms, indicating a relatively low prevalence (13.3%). No direct transmission of porcine bufaviruses between two neighboring farms was detected, suggesting that bufaviruses may have spread widely in different geographic regions.
authors: Liu, L.;Schwarz, L.;Ullman, K.;Ahola, H.;Qiu, Y.;Ma, Z.;Hennig-Pauka, I.

title: Phylogeny, classification, and evolutionary insights into pestiviruses
abstract: The genus Pestivirus includes four established species: bovine viral diarrhea viruses 1 (BVDV-1) and 2 (BVDV-2), border disease virus (BDV) and classical swine fever virus (CSFV); and an interim species, the giraffe pestivirus. Additional pestiviruses have been identified and proposed for recognition as new subgroups/species. To obtain a reliable phylogeny as a basis for pestivirus classification, a molecular dataset of 56 pestiviruses and 2089 traits, encompassing the 5-UTR, complete Npro and E2 gene regions, was combined with the maximum likelihood and Bayesian approach analyzed. An identical, robust tree topology was derived, identifying seven well-supported monophyletic clades and two highly divergent lineages. Dating of the most recent common ancestor has been estimated for the major pestivirus lineages and their evolutionary histories have been revealed. Accordingly, a new proposal is presented to classify pestiviruses into nine species: BVDV-1, BVDV-2, BVDV-3 (atypical bovine pestiviruses), giraffe pestivirus, CSFV, BDV, Tunisian sheep virus (TSV; previously called " Tunisian isolates "), antelope and Bungowannah. © 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, L.;Xia, H.;Wahlberg, N.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Baule, C.

title: Characterization of clade 7.2 H5 avian influenza viruses continuing to circulate in chickens in China
abstract: The H5N1 avian influenza viruses emerged in Southeast Asia in the late 20th century and have evolved into multiple phylogenetic clades based on their genes encoding hemagglutinin (HA). Clade 7.2 viruses were first detected in chickens in northern China in 2006, and clade-specific vaccines have been developed and used in poultry in China since 2006-2014 carrying the clade 7.2 HA genes. Here we conducted extensive studies to understand how the clade 7.2 H5 viruses evolved in chickens in China. A full genome sequence analysis revealed that the seven viruses formed two subtypes (four H5N1 viruses and three H5N2 viruses) and four genotypes by deriving genes from other influenza viruses. All viruses had antigenically diverged from the clade 7.2 viruses isolated in 2006. Pathogenicity studies of four viruses, one from each genotype, showed that all viruses are highly pathogenic in chickens, but none of them could replicate in ducks. The four viruses bound exclusively to avian-type receptors and replicated only in mouse turbinates and/or lungs; none of them were lethal to mice at a dose of 10<sup>6</sup> 50% egg infective doses (EID<sub>50</sub>). Our study shows that while vaccination has not eradicated clade 7.2 viruses from poultry, it has not become more dangerous to other animals (e.g. ducks and mice) and humans. IMPORTANT: Animal influenza viruses can acquire the ability to infect and kill humans. The H5N1 viruses have been of concern over the past few decades because of their clear pandemic potential. We have divided H5N1 influenza viruses into different phylogenetic classes based on their HA genes. The clade 7.2 viruses were detected in chickens in several provinces of northern China in 2006. Vaccines against these viruses were subsequently developed and have since been used to combat infection in poultry. Here we analyzed the genetic and biological properties of seven clade 7.2 viruses isolated from chickens between 2011 and 2014. We found that after nearly 9 years of circulation in chickens, clade 7.2 viruses still bind exclusively to avian-type receptors and are of low pathogenicity for mice, suggesting that these H5 viruses pose a low public health risk represent people.
authors: Liu, L.;Zeng, X.;Chen, P.;Deng, G.;Li, Y.;Shi, J.;Gu, C.;Kong, H.;Suzuki, Y.;Jiang, Y.;Tian, G.;Chen, H.

title: Genotypic and pathotypic characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated from carrier pigeons in China
abstract: This study characterized a Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from an outbreak in carrier pigeons in China. The complete gene of the NDV isolate was sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically. Pathogenicity experiments were performed on pigeons, chickens and ducks. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the strain clustered with the class II viruses is phylogenetically very similar to the NDV strains isolated from pigeons in China, but was far removed from the virus prevalence in chickens and the vaccine strains used in China. The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion protein (F) confirmed that the isolate contained the virulent motif (112)RRQKRF(117) at the cleavage site, but it did not cause disease in chickens and ducks. However, the isolate was virulent in pigeons, resulting in severe nervous signs and high mortality. Pigeons have been considered a potential source of NDV infection and disease for commercial poultry flocks. Therefore, new vaccines should be developed as soon as possible to prevent the NDV infection in the pigeon flocks, and strict biosecurity measures should be taken to reduce the risk of Pigeon Newcastle Disease outbreaks.
authors: Liu, M.;Qu, Y.;Wang, F.;Liu, S.;Sun, H.

title: High reversal potential of a cell-adapted vaccine candidate against the highly pathogenic reproductive and respiratory syndrome in swine
abstract: Modified live vaccine (MLV) based on the highly pathogenic porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (HP-PRRSV) is prone to rapid reversion of virulence when circulating in host animals. The aim of this study was to assess the virulence reversion potential of HP-PRRSV MLV and to identify elements within the HP-PRRSV genome that contribute to this phenomenon. An attempt was made to attenuate an HP-PRRSV strain JX143 isolated during the atypical PRRS outbreak in 2006 using a blind passage cell adaptation strategy to balance safety and efficacy in 4-week-old piglets (unpublished data). Two studies were conducted in which candidates were tested for reversion to virulence by five reverse passages in susceptible piglets (age 21 +/- 3 days). Both study results showed a significant increase in clinical symptoms, fever and lung lesions, and reduced average daily weight gain from passage 3 in susceptible pigs, and indicated that both candidates regained virulence regardless of the level of passage. The increase in the corresponding parameters was accompanied by an increase in viraemia in piglets: JXM87 virus titer increased from passage 1 (P1) 4.40 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub>/mL to P4 5.75 Lg TCID<sub> 50</sub>/ml and the JXM105 virus titer increased from P1 3.78 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub>/ml to P4 6.42 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub>/ml. Next generation sequencing (NGS) was performed on clinical samples (serum, lung tissue) from P4 animals. Sequence analysis comparing P4 materials to their parental strains revealed 10 amino acid mutations in 4 proteins for JXM87 and 14 amino acid mutations in 9 proteins for JXM105, respectively. Interestingly, five amino acid mutations were identical in the two candidates located in the nsp1beta, GP5a and nsp10 coding regions, suggesting that nsp1beta, GP5a and nsp10 may contribute to virulence in HP-PRRSV.
authors: Liu, P.;Bai, Y.;Jiang, X.;Zhou, L.;Yuan, S.;Yao, H.;Yang, H.;Sun, Z.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of 626 hepatitis E virus (HEV) isolates from humans and animals in China (1986-2011) showing genotype diversity and zoonotic transmission
abstract: Hepatitis E is considered a public health problem in China. In order to determine the general molecular epidemiology of hepatitis E virus (HEV) and to analyze the situation of cross-species transmission between humans and swine in China in the last 25 years (1986-2011), 626 complete and partial HEV sequences ( 89 isolates identified by our group) isolated from humans and animals in China were retrieved from GenBank and subjected to phylogenetic analysis. In China, three genotypes and 11 subgenotypes of HEV were predominant. In addition, rabbit HEVs, whose genotype is disputed, are also widespread in China. Genotype 1 was the most isolated genotype before 2000 and was mainly detected in Xinjiang, Beijing and eastern China. However, genotype 4, which has been identified in most regions of China over the past 10 years, has overtaken genotype 1 in frequency of isolation nationwide. HEV genotype 3 strains were only found in eastern China and were thought to have been imported from Japan. Both genotypes 3 and 4 have been found in humans and pigs, and cross-species transmission of the two genotypes from pigs to humans may have occurred in Northeast, Northwest, North, East, and South China. These results indicate that HEV strains with considerable genetic diversity are widespread and zoonotic transmission between pigs and humans appears to be ubiquitous in China. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, P.;Li, L.;Wang, L.;Bu, Q.;Fu, H.;Han, J.;Zhu, Y.;Lu, F.;Zhuang, H.

title: Characterization of a highly pathogenic H5N1 clade 2.3.4 avian influenza virus isolated from a tree sparrow
abstract: The spread of the H5N1 virus to a variety of avian and mammalian species may facilitate the adaptation of the virus to human populations. In the present study, an examination of the avian influenza virus was carried out in tree sparrows and an HPAI H5N1 virus (A/Tree Sparrow/Jiangsu/1/08) was isolated. The H5N1 virus was found to be a variant of genotype V belonging to strain 2.3.4 that emerged in southern China in 2005. Genetic analysis showed that it was closely related to A/Jiangsu/1/07 (H5N1), which was blamed in 2007 for likely limited person-to-person transmission in a family cluster in China. Pathogenicity studies showed that the virus was highly virulent when experimentally inoculated into chickens, tree sparrows and mice. Since clade 2.3.4, the genotype V variant of the H5N1 virus, was responsible for most of the human deaths in China between 2005 and 2008, the presence of such H5N1 variants in tree sparrows underscores the potential threat of this type of infection to wild birds veterinary medicine and public health. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, Q.;Ma, J.;Kou, Z.;Pu, J.;Lei, F.;Li, T.;Liu, J.

title: Systematic review of severe fever with thrombocytopenic syndrome: virology, epidemiology, and clinical features
abstract: SUMMARY: Severe fever with thrombocytopenic syndrome (SFTS) was first detected in China in 2010, followed by multiple reports from many other countries worldwide. The SFTS virus (SFTSV) has been identified as the causative agent of the disease and recognized as a public health threat. This novel bunyavirus belongs to the genus Phlebovirus in the family Bunyaviridae. This review also describes the various aspects of virology, pathogenesis, epidemiology and clinical symptoms based on the published article surveillance data and phylogenetic analyzes of large, medium and small segment virus sequences retrieved from the database using Mega 5.05, Simplot 3.5. 1, network 4.611 and epi information system 3.5.3 software. SFTS presents with fever, thrombocytopenia, leukocytopenia, and marked changes in several serum biomarkers. The disease has a mortality rate of 10 to 15%, often due to multiple organ dysfunction. SFTSV is mainly reported in the rural areas of central and northeast China, with the seasonal occurrence from May to September mostly targeting individuals ≥50 years of age. A wide range of domestic animals including sheep, goats, cattle, pigs, dogs and chickens have been shown to be seropositive for SFTSV. Ticks, especially Haemaphysalis longicornis, are suspected to be potential carriers, and they have a wide range of animal hosts worldwide. Further studies are needed to elucidate the vector-animal-human ecological cycle, pathogenic mechanisms in high-level animal models, and vaccine development. © 2013 The Authors. Reviews in Medical Virology published by John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
authors: Liu, S.;Chai, C.;Wang, C.;Amer, S.;Lv, H.;He, H.;Sun, J.;Lin, J.

title: Identification of the avian infectious bronchitis coronaviruses with mutations in gene 3
abstract: The sequence of a 6.0 kb fragment was compared in the 3″ coding region of the genome in 27 strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). All of these strains have the same S-3-M-5-N gene order as found in other IBVs. However, the sizes of the corresponding open reading frames (ORFs) of some genes varied between virus strains. Phylogenetic analyzes and sequence alignments indicated that recombination events occurred in the origin and evolution of strains CK/CH/LSD/03I and CK/CH/LLN/98I and that the putative recombinant junctions could be located at the 3c and M genes , respectively The normal product of ORF 3a is 57 amino acids long, while a 43 bp deletion was detected at the 3' end of the CK/CH/LSD/03I 3a gene, resulting in a frameshift event and a C-terminal truncated protein resulted in 47 amino acids. A comparison of the viability in embryos and the replication and pathogenicity in chickens with IBV carrying the normal 3a gene showed that this deleted sequence in the 3a gene of CK/CH/LSD/03I is not relevant either in vitro or in vitro for the viral pathogenesis and replication required was alive. The occurrence of a mutation at the corresponding position of the CK/CH/LLN/98I start codon in the 3a gene resulted in the absence of ORF 3a in this virus, resulting in a new genomic organization in the 3 coding regions: S -3b, 3c-M-5a, 5b-N. A comparison with other viruses carrying the normal 3a gene showed that CK/CH/LLN/98I had in vivo replication and pathogenic abilities similar to other IBVs; however, its viability in embryos was lower, although the relationship between the lower viability and the ORF 3a defect needs further confirmation. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, S.;Zhang, Q.;Chen, J.;Han, Z.;Shao, Y.;Kong, X.;Tong, G.

title: Porcine epidemic diarrheal virus infection caused the imbalance of gut microbiota in piglets
abstract: Epidemic swine diarrhea (PED) is a devastating disease in the livestock industry. Most previous studies related to PED have focused on the pathology and etiology of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV). Little was known about the status of the gut microbiota after PEDV infection in piglets. In this study, gut microbiota profiles in feces of viral diarrhea (VD) and viral control (VC) piglets were examined using metagenome sequencing technology. The results showed that the frequency of four dominant phyla (Fusobacteria, Actinobacteria, Verrucomicrobia and Proteobacteria) in faeces was strongly influenced by epidemic diarrhea in pigs. In particular, the frequency of Fusobacteria was higher in VD piglets (36%) than in VC piglets (5%). In contrast, verrucomicrobia was detected in lower distribution proportions in VD piglets (about 0%) than in VC piglets (20%). In addition, 25 genera differed significantly between VC and VD piglets at the genera level. Among the 25 genera, Leptotrichia belonging to Fusobacteria was remarkably rarer in VC piglets than in VD piglets. Akkermansia belonging to Verrucomicrobia was higher in VC piglets than in VD piglets. Our results implied that the gut microbiota associated with PED provided significant insight into the pathology and physiology of PED.
authors: Liu, S.;Zhao, L.;Zhai, Z.;Zhao, W.;Ding, J.;Dai, R.;Sun, T.;Meng, H.

title: Identification of natural recombination in duck hepatitis B virus
abstract: Because of its close similarity to human hepatitis B virus (HBV), duck HBV (DHBV) is often used as an important model for HBV research. While intergenotypic recombination is common in HBV, it has not been reported in DHBV. In this study, 32 non-redundant full DHBV genomes were analyzed using phylogenetic methods and classified into two clusters corresponding to the Chinese and Westland branches previously reported based on geographic distribution. A "Chinese" branch tribe has been isolated in Australia and three "western country" branch tribes have been isolated in China, suggesting a geographical spanning distribution of both branches. Recombination analyzes of the 32 DHBV genomes identified two possible high-confidence intergenotypic recombination events. These recombination events occurred between the lineages represented respectively by Chinese isolate GD3 (AY536371, "Chinese" branch) and American isolate DHBV16 (K01834, "Western country" branch), resulting in two Chinese recombinant isolates CH4 (EU429324 ) led. and CH6 (EU429326). The identification of intergenotypic recombination among circulating DHBV isolates suggests the utility of DHBV as a model to study the mechanism of HBV recombination. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, W.;Zhai, J.;Liu, J.;Xie, Y.

title: Genome sequencing and analysis of a small ruminant plague virus isolate, China/Tib/07
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants virus is a member of the morbillivirus Paramyxoviridae. The complete genome of a Peste des Petits Ruminants Virus (PPRV) isolate, China/Tib/07, was sequenced and the molecular characteristics analyzed. The internal sequences of the virus genome were amplified by RT-PCR with primers designed according to published data in GenBank, while the sequences of the 3' and 5' ends of the genome were determined by RACE. Amplification products were directly sequenced, assembled and analyzed with DNAStar4.0. The results showed that the China/Tib/07 genome was 15,948 nucleotides in length and encoded six structural proteins and two nonstructural proteins, in common with other known PPRV genomes. Phylogenetically, the viral genome shared 91.6% to 98.1% homology with Southwest Asian isolates among PPRV strains and the highest homology with rinderpest virus among Morbillivirus members at 64.3%.
authors: Liu, W. H.;Bao, J. Y.;Wu, X. D.;Wang, Z. L.

title: Molecular phylogenetic and positive selection analysis of Japanese encephalitis virus strains isolated from pigs in China
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is one of the major viruses causing encephalitis. This disease is most prevalent in southern, southeastern and eastern Asia. In this study, two JEV strains named JEV/SW/GD/01/2009 and JEV/SW/GZ/09/2004 were isolated from aborted fetuses and semen of pigs in China. To determine the characteristics of these virus isolates, the virulence of two new JEV isolates was examined, the result showed that the JEV/SW/GD/01/2009 did not kill mice, while the JEV/SW/GZ/09/2004 did became neurovirulence at 0.925log10 pfu/LD50. In addition, the full genome sequences of JEV were determined and compared to other known JEV strains. The results showed that the genomes of two JEV isolates were 10,976 nucleotides (nt) in length. Compared to the Chinese vaccine strain SA14-14-2, JEV/SW/GD/01/2009 and JEV/SW/GZ/09/2004 showed 99.7% and 97.5% identity at the nucleotide level, 99.6% and 96, 7% identity at the amino acid level. Phylogenetic analysis based on the full-length genome revealed that two JEV isolates were all assigned to genotype III compared to the reference strains. Furthermore, selection analyzes revealed that the dominant selection pressure acting on the JEV genome purges selection. Four sites under positive selection were identified: codon 521 (amino acid E-227), 2296 (amino acid NS4b-24), 3048 (amino acid NS5-521), and 3055 (amino acid NS5-528). Amino acid E-227 has been shown to be associated with neurovirulence. Taken together, the molecular epidemiology and function of positively selected amino acid sites of two new JEV isolates were fully understood, which could be helpful in predicting possible changes in virulence. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, W. J.;Zhu, M.;Pei, J. J.;Dong, X. Y.;Liu, W.;Zhao, M. Q.;Wang, J. Y.;Gou, H. C.;Luo, Y. W.;Chen, J. D.

title: Identification and analysis of porcine microRNA in porcine cytomegalovirus-infected macrophages using deep sequencing
abstract: Porcine cytomegalovirus (PCMV; genus Cytomegalovirus, subfamily Betaherpesvirinae, family Herpesviridae) is an immunosuppressive virus that mainly inhibits the immune function of T lymphocytes and macrophages, which has caused significant damage in agriculture. In this study, we obtained the miRNA expression profiles of PCMV-infected porcine macrophages via high-throughput sequencing. The comprehensive analysis of the miRNA profiles showed that 239 annotated from the miRNA database and 355 novel porcine miRNAs were discovered. Of these, 130 miRNAs showed a significant differential expression between the PCMV-infected and uninfected porcine macrophages. The 10 differentially expressed porcine-encoded miRNAs were further determined by stem-loop reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, and the results were consistent with high-throughput sequencing. Genontological analyzes of the target genes of miRNAs in PCMV-infected pig macrophages showed that the differentially expressed miRNAs are mainly involved in immune and metabolic processes. This is the first report of the miRNA transcriptome in porcine macrophages and an analysis of miRNA regulatory mechanisms during PCMV infection. Further research into the regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs in immunosuppressive viral infections should contribute to the treatment and prevention of immunosuppressive viruses.
authors: Liu, X.;Liao, S.;Xu, Z.;Zhu, L.;Yang, F.;Guo, W.

title: MicroRNA transcriptome analysis of porcine vital organ responses to porcine immunosuppressive cytomegalovirus infection
abstract: Background: Porcine cytomegalovirus (PCMV) is an immunosuppressive virus that primarily inhibits the immune functions of T lymphocytes and macrophages; it has significantly damaged the agricultural industry. Although recent studies have shown that miRNAs play an important role in immune responses, the regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during immunosuppressive viral infection remain unclear. Methods: In this study, porcine small RNA transcriptomes from PCMV-infected and uninfected vital organs were first characterized by high-throughput sequencing. The miRDeep2 software was used to predict novel porcine miRNAs. To verify the accuracy of the high-throughput sequencing results, a stem-loop qRT-PCR was performed on 12 significant DE miRNAs. The physical and functional interactions between the immune-related target genes of the DE miRNAs in PCMV-infected organs were analyzed using the STRING database. Results: A total of 306 annotated and 295 new miRNAs from PCMV-infected and non-infected pig organs were identified by comparison with known Sus scrofa pre-miRNAs. A total of 92, 107, 95, 77 and 111 miRNAs were significantly differently expressed in lung, liver, spleen, kidney and thymus after PCMV infection. According to the gene ontology enrichment analysis, target genes of the differentially expressed miRNAs, which are related to processes of the immune system, the regulation of biological processes and metabolic processes, were enriched in each sample. An integrated expression analysis of the differentially expressed miRNAs and their target mRNAs in PCMV-infected thymus showed that under the pressure of PCMV infection in central immune organs, the significant differential expression of specific miRNAs disrupted the expression of genes involved in important immune-related signaling pathways, thereby promoting viral infection. Conclusions: This is the first comprehensive analysis of the responses of host small RNA transcriptomes to PCMV infection in porcine vital organs. It provides new insights into the regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during infection by immunosuppressive viruses.
authors: Liu, X.;Wei, H.;Liao, S.;Ye, J.;Zhu, L.;Xu, Z.

title: Characterization of a highly pathogenic H5N1 clade 2.3.2 influenza virus isolated from swans in Shanghai, China
abstract: In spring 2009, a strain of the H5N1 clade 2.3.2 virus was isolated from wild swans in Shanghai, indicating the importance of the wild swan in the ecology of this highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) in eastern China. Pathogenicity experiments performed in this study indicated that the virus was highly pathogenic to chickens but low pathogenic to mammalian hosts, as evidenced by reduced infection of mice. Analysis of full genome sequences and genetic evolution indicated that A/Swan/Shanghai/10/09 (SW/SH/09) may have descended from strain A/silky chicken/Shantou/475/2004 (CK/ST/04). , which is homologous to the influenza viruses isolated in 2007 from chicken, duck, pika, egret, swan, mandarin duck and bar-headed goose in China Hunan, China Qinghai, Mongolia, Russia, Japan, Korea, Laos and Hong Kong. 2011, suggesting that the virus has retro-infected various wild birds from chickens and that significant spread of the virus through overlapping migration routes is ongoing. Based on molecular analysis, we also found that there was a glycosylation site (NSS) deletion at amino acid 156 of the hemagglutinin (HA) protein compared to the other clade 2.3.2 viruses isolated between 2007 and 2011. More importantly is that the sequence analysis of the SW/SH/09 virus revealed the drug-resistant mutations on the matrix protein (M2) and neuraminidase (NA) genes. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
authors: Liu, X.;Zhao, G.;Zhong, L.;Lu, X.;Hu, J.;Gu, X.;Kai, Y.;Song, Q.;Sun, Q.;Liu, J.;Peng, D.;Wang, X.;Liu, X.

title: The response of the porcine microRNA transcriptome to transmissible gastroenteritis virus infection
abstract: The transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV; family Coronaviridae) causes enormous economic losses in the swine industry. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play a regulatory role in viral infections and may be involved in mammalian immune responses. Here we report a comprehensive analysis of host miRNA expression in TGEV-infected porcine testis (ST) cells. Deep sequencing generated 3,704,353 and 2,763,665 reads from uninfected ST cells and infected ST cells, respectively. The reads were compared to known Sus scrofa pre-miRNAs in miRBase 19, identifying 284 annotated miRNAs. Certain miRNAs were differentially regulated during TGEV infection. 59 unique miRNAs showed significantly different expression between the normal and TGEV-infected ST cell samples: 15 miRNAs were significantly upregulated and 44 were significantly downregulated. Stem-loop RT-PCR was performed to determine the expression levels of specific miRNAs in the two samples and the results were consistent with sequencing. Genetic ontology enrichment analysis of host target genes revealed that the differentially expressed miRNAs are involved in regulatory networks including cellular, metabolic, and immune system processes. This is the first report on the identification of ST cell miRNAs and the comprehensive analysis of the miRNA regulatory mechanism during TGEV infection, revealing the molecular miRNA regulatory mechanisms for viral infection, viral gene expression, and immune-related gene expression. The results presented here will support research into the prevention and treatment of viral diseases.
authors: Liu, X.;Zhu, L.;Liao, S.;Xu, Z.;Zhou, Y.

title: Complete genome sequence analysis of a strain of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) prevalent in China.
abstract: Infectious bronchitis (IB) is one of the most common diseases in poultry flocks around the world caused by the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). In the study, the full genome sequence of strain A2, which was a predominant IBV strain in China, was sequenced and analyzed. The results showed that mutations, insertions and deletions were distributed throughout the genome. The A2 virus had the highest full genome identity with S14 and BJ while showing a further distance to Massachusetts strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the A2 isolate was clustered with most Chinese strains. The results of this study suggest that strain A2 may play an important role in the evolution of IBV and A2-like IBVs are the predominant strains in China. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Liu, X. L.;Su, J. L.;Zhao, J. X.;Zhang, G. Z.

title: Phylogenetic diversity and genotypic complexity of H1N1 subtype swine influenza viruses isolated in mainland China
abstract: Background: After the emergence of the H1N1 pandemic in 2009, H1N1 subtype swine influenza viruses (H1N1-SIV) have received much attention from scientific circles in many countries. A large-scale sequence analysis of the NCBI Influenza Virus Resource Database was performed on H1N1 SIVs submitted between 1992 and 2011 mainly by scientists in China. The objectives of this study were to elucidate the genetic and evolutionary characteristics of H1N1 SIVs, to identify and unify the lineages and genetic characteristics of the H1N1 SIVs isolated in mainland China. Results: Most strains were isolated in Guangdong and Shandong provinces, China, in the period 2008-2010. Based on the phylogenetic and genotypic analyses, all H1N1 SIV strains can be classified into 8 lineages and 10 genotypes. All strains had the characteristics of low pathogenic influenza viruses. The viruses of different lineages are characterized by different amino acid residues at the receptor binding sites. Viruses containing PB2 genes from the classical pig, early seasonal human, and newer seasonal human lineages may be more infectious to humans. Some genotypes were directly related to human influenza viruses, including strains that contained human influenza virus-derived genes. Conclusions: Phylogenetic diversity and complexity existed in H1N1 SIVs isolated in mainland China. These H1N1 SIV strains were closely related to other influenza virus subtypes, particularly human influenza viruses. In addition, it has been shown that new lineages and genotypes of H1N1 SIVs have recently emerged in mainland China. These results provided new and essential information for further understanding of the genetic and evolutionary traits and surveillance of H1N1 SIVs in mainland China. © 2012 Liu et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Liu, Y.;Wang, J.;Ji, J.;Chang, S.;Xue, C.;Ma, J.;Bi, Y.;Xie, Q.

title: Application of a molecular method to classify human enteroviruses and their correlation with clinical manifestations
abstract: Background/Purpose: A new molecular classification scheme has recently been introduced that groups all enteroviruses into four types, designated human enterovirus A (HEV-A) through D. In this study, we attempted to show the correlation between this molecular classification scheme and clinical manifestations in patients. METHODS: We reclassified enterovirus clinical isolates from the previous 4.5 years in our virology laboratory using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and reviewed the clinical manifestations of 138 pediatric patients. Results: We reclassified 23 isolates from the five serotypes to the HEV-A group, 110 isolates from 16 serotypes to the HEV-B group, five isolates to the HEV-C group, and no isolate to the HEV-D group. HEV-A species caused significantly more hand, foot and mouth disease (p<0.001), herpangina (p=0.029), and myoclonic jerks (p<0.001) compared to HEV-B species. However, HEV-B species caused significantly more pharyngitis (p=0.043), respiratory tract infections (p=0.046), nausea and vomiting (p=0.007), and aseptic meningitis (p=0.001). The only death in our report was caused by coxsackievirus A16, which belonged to the HEV-A group. Conclusion: The relationship between the molecular classification of enteroviruses and related diseases is an important finding. We propose that under certain circumstances, such as B. limited availability of antisera or questionable serotyping results, could be used in a clinical laboratory as an alternative method to identify the untypable isolates. Â© 2010 Taiwan Society of Microbiology.
authors: Lo, C. W.;Wu, K. G.;Lin, M. C.;Chen, C. J.;Ho, D. M. T.;Tang, R. B.;Chan, Y. J.

title: Origin and development of the Nipah virus
abstract: Nipah virus, a member of the Paramyxoviridae family, is classified as a Biosafety Level 4 pathogen and a Category C priority pathogen. Nipah virus disease is endemic in South Asia and outbreaks have been reported in Malaysia, Singapore, India and Bangladesh. Bats of the genus Pteropus appear to be the natural reservoir of this virus. The aim of this study was to examine the genetic diversity of the Nipah virus, to estimate the date of origin and the spread of the infection. The mean evolution rate of the Nipah virus N gene was 6.5 x 10-4 substitution/site/year (95% HPD: 2.3 x 10-4-1.18 x 10-3).
