Time-scaled phylogenetic analysis showed that the root of the tree emerged in 1947 (95% HPD: 1888-1988) when the virus invaded Southeast Asian regions. The division of the sequences into two major clades (I and II) indicates that Nipah virus had two distinct introductions: one in 1995 (95% HPD: 1985–2002) corresponding to clade I, and the other in Year 1985 (95% HPD: 1985-2002). 1971-1996) corresponding to Clade II. The phylogeographic reconstruction showed that the epidemic followed two different routes to spread to the other locations. Trade in infected pigs may have played a role in spreading the virus. Bats of the genus Pteropus, which can travel great distances, may have helped spread the infection. Negatively selected sites could, with statistical support, reflect the stability of the viral N protein.
authors: Lo Presti, A.;Cella, E.;Giovanetti, M.;Lai, A.;Angeletti, S.;Zehender, G.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: Comparative genomics reveal multiple pathways to reciprocity for tick-borne pathogens
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several important human and animal pathogens use ticks as their primary host vectors. It is currently unknown whether this mode of infection of a host occurred once or many times during evolution. RESULTS: To answer this question, we performed a comparative genomic analysis on a panel of bacterial pathogens from seven genera - Borrelia, Rickettsia, Anaplasma, Ehrlichia, Francisella, Coxiella and Bartonella, including species from three different host vectors - ticks, lice and fleas . The last set of 102 genomes used in the study encoded a total of 120,046 protein sequences. We found that no genes or metabolic pathways were present in all tick-borne bacteria. However, we found that some genes and signaling pathways were present in subsets of tick-borne organisms, while they were absent in bacteria transmitted by lice or fleas. Conclusion: Our analysis suggests that the ability of pathogens to be transmitted by ticks has evolved multiple times over the course of evolution. To our knowledge, this is the most comprehensive study of tick transmissibility to date.
authors: Lockwood, S.;Brayton, K. A.;Broschat, S. L.

title: A universal protocol for generating consensus-level genome sequences for foot-and-mouth disease virus and other positive-sense polyadenylated RNA viruses using Illumina MiSeq
abstract: BACKGROUND: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is revolutionizing molecular epidemiology by providing new approaches to perform whole genome sequencing (WGS) in diagnostic settings for a variety of human and veterinary pathogens. Previous sequencing protocols have been subject to biases such as those encountered during PCR amplification and cell culture, or are limited by the need for large amounts of starting material. We describe here a simple and robust method to generate whole genome sequences on the Illumina MiSeq. This protocol is specific for foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) or other polyadenylated RNA viruses and circumvents both the use of PCR and the requirement for large amounts of initial template. RESULTS: The protocol was successfully validated using five FMDV positive clinical specimens from the 2001 UK epidemic and a panel of representative viruses of all seven serotypes. In addition, this protocol was successfully used to recover 94% of an FMDV genome previously identified as cell culture negative. Genomic sequences of three other non-FMDV polyadenylated RNA viruses (EMCV, ERAV, VESV) were also obtained with minor protocol changes. We calculated that a minimum depth of coverage of 22 reads was required to generate an accurate consensus sequence for FMDV O. This was achieved in 5 FMDV/O/UKG isolates and the type O FMDV from the serotype panel except for the 5' genome termini and region immediately flanking the poly(C) region. CONCLUSIONS: We have developed a universal WGS method for FMDV and other polyadenylated RNA viruses. This method works successfully with a limited amount of starting material and eliminates the need for genome-specific PCR amplification. This protocol has the potential to generate consensus-level sequences within a routine high-throughput diagnostic environment.
authors: Logan, G.;Freimanis, G. L.;King, D. J.;Valdazo-Gonzalez, B.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Sanderson, N. D.;Knowles, N. J.;King, D. P.;Cottam, E. M.

title: Unbiased characterization of Anopheles mosquito blood meals by targeted high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Understanding mosquito host choice is important to assess vector competence or identify disease reservoirs. Unfortunately, the availability of an unbiased method for comprehensively assessing the composition of insect blood meals is very limited, as most current molecular assays only test for the presence of a few preselected species. These approaches also have a limited ability to identify the presence of multiple mammalian hosts in a single blood meal. Here we describe a novel high-throughput sequencing method that allows the simultaneous analysis of 96 mosquitoes and provides a comprehensive and quantitative perspective on the composition of each blood meal. We have validated in silico that universal primers targeting the mammalian mitochondrial 16S ribosomal RNA genes (16S rRNA) should amplify greater than 95% of the mammalian 16S rRNA sequences present in the NCBI nucleotide database. We applied this method to 442 female Anopheles punctulatus sl mosquitoes collected in Papua New Guinea (PNG). While human (52.9%), dog (15.8%) and pig (29.2%) were the most frequently identified hosts in our study, we also detected DNA from mice, a marsupial species and two bat species. Our analyzes also revealed that 16.3% of mosquitoes fed on more than one host. Analysis of human mitochondrial hypervariable region I in 102 human blood meals showed that 5 (4.9%) of the mosquitoes clearly fed on more than one individual. Overall, the analysis of PNG mosquitoes illustrates the potential of this approach to identify unexpected hosts and characterize mixed blood meals, and shows how this approach can be adapted to assess inter-individual differences between human blood meals. Furthermore, this approach can be applied to any disease-transmitting arthropod and easily adapted to study non-mammalian host sources.
authors: Logue, K.;Keven, J. B.;Cannon, M. V.;Reimer, L.;Siba, P.;Walker, E. D.;Zimmerman, P. A.;Serre, D.

title: Virus particles in the cochlear spiral ganglion of guinea pigs
abstract: All spiral ganglia examined from several guinea pig populations of different breeds showed intracytoplasmic viruses in some granular spiral ganglion cells. According to their localization and morphology, we assign these viruses to the oncorna group. This does not correspond to the classification of other authors. Apparently there is a latent virus infection in guinea pigs worldwide. We found an accumulation of lysosomes next to the virus particles, which indicates a locally increased lysosomal activity of the infected ganglion cells. Further influences on the infected cells can neither be proven nor denied.
authors: Lohle, E.;Kistler, G. S.;Riede, U. N.;Merck, W.

title: Columbide circoviruses detected in free-range pigeons from southern Brazil: insights into PiCV evolution
abstract: Pigeon circovirus (PiCV) is taxonomically classified as a member of the circovirus genus, family Circoviridae. The virus contains a single-stranded DNA genome of approximately 2 kb with slight differences in length between different isolates. The occurrence of PiCV infections in pigeons (Columba livia) has been documented worldwide over the last 20 years; However, there have not yet been any reports of PiCV detection in Brazil. This study identifies seven PiCV genomes obtained from domestic pigeons from southern Brazil by high-throughput sequencing and demonstrates a high frequency of PiCV infection by real-time quantitative PCR. The phylogenetic classification was performed by maximum likelihood analysis of the complete genomes ORF V1 (Rep) and ORF C1 (Cap). Results show that either full genome or Cap-based analysis allowed PiCV classification into five major clades (groups A to E), with Brazilian sequences classified as A, C, or D. Recombination analyzes were performed using Simplot and RDP4 and the results show that both Rep and Cap ORFs contain multiple recombination hotspots, indicating an important role for such events in PiCV evolution.
authors: Loiko, M. R.;Junqueira, D. M.;Varela, A. P. M.;Tochetto, C.;Scheffer, C. M.;Lima, D. A.;Morel, A. P.;Cerva, C.;Paim, W. P.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Fecal virus from red foxes from suburban areas
abstract: Red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) are the most common carnivore species in the northern hemisphere. As their populations are well established in peri-urban and urban areas, they represent a potential reservoir of viruses transmitted from wild animals to humans or domestic animals. In this study, we evaluated faecal virome of juvenile and adult foxes from peri-urban areas in central Croatia. The dominant mammalian viruses were fox picobirnavirus and parvovirus. The highest number of viral reads (N = 1412) was attributed to a novel fox circovirus, and the complete viral genome was assembled de novo from the high-throughput sequencing data. Fox circovirus is very similar to canine circoviruses identified in diseased dogs in the US and Italy and a recently discovered circovirus from foxes with neurological disorders from the UK. Our fox picobirnavirus was more closely related to the porcine and human picobirnaviruses than to known fox picobirnaviruses.
authors: LojkiÄ‡, I.;Bidin, M.;PrpiÄ‡, J.;Å imiÄ‡, I.;KreÅ¡iÄ‡, N.;BedekoviÄ‡, T.

title: The study of the apathogenic influenza virus A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 (H6N2) isolated in Moscow.
abstract: Influenza virus A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 (H6N2) was isolated in the autumn of 2006 from the droppings of seagulls in the Moscow districts. The nucleotide sequence of the complete genome (GenBank, EU152234-EU152241) and genotype (K, G, D, 6B, F, 2D, F, 1E) for this virus has been determined. Phylogenetic analyzes indicate that the H6N2 virus arose from numerous rearrangements between viruses circulating among different birds in Europe since 1999 and in Southeast Asia in recent years (NA gene). It is likely that migratory birds introduced some of these viruses from Southeast Asia in the past. Strain A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 is nonpathogenic to chick embryos and mice and induces specific antibody production in mice. Similar to all avian influenza viruses A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006, it binds to Neu5Ac(2-3Gal receptors), but in contrast to the duck viruses it shows a higher affinity for fucosylated sialosugars (SLex) as shown in the receptor specificity test and based on the Modeling of adaptation of SLex to the receptor binding site of duck and gull influenza virus haemagglutinin clarified.
authors: Lomakina, N. F.;Gambarian, A. S.;Boravleva, E. I.;Kropotkina, E. A.;Kirillov, I. M.;Lavrent'ev, M. V.;Iamnikova, S. S.

title: Character of the non-pathogenic influenza viruses found in Moscow, Russia
abstract: Influenza virus A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 (H6N2) was isolated in the autumn of 2006 from the droppings of seagulls in the Moscow districts. Complete genome nucleotide sequence (GenBank, EU152234-EU152241) and genotype (K, G, D, 6B, F, 2D, F, 1E) determined for this virus. Phylogenetic analyzes indicate that the H6N2 virus arose from numerous rearrangements between viruses circulating among different birds in Europe since 1999 and in Southeast Asia in recent years (NA gene). Some of these viruses were probably introduced earlier by migratory birds from Southeast Asia. Strain A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 is nonpathogenic to chick embryos and mice and induces specific antibody production in mice. Similar to all avian influenza viruses, A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 binds to Neu5Ac alpha 2-3Gal receptors, but in contrast to the duck viruses, it shows a higher affinity for fucosylated sialosugars (SLex), as shown in the receptor specificity assay and has been clarified for Modeling of uptake of SLex into the receptor-binding site of duck and gull influenza virus hemagglutinin.
authors: Lomakina, N. F.;Gambaryan, A. C.;Boravleva, E. Y.;Kropotkina, E. A.;Kirillov, I. M.;Lavrient'ev, M. V.;Yamnikova, S. S.

title: Specificity of the antibody against the viral polymerase RD 114
abstract: The use of antiserum against the RNA-dependent DNA polymerase (RDP) of type C viruses has allowed these enzymes to be distinguished from cellular enzymes capable of using RNA templates for DNA synthesis. Such sera have also allowed some degree of subclassification of the viruses themselves and also discrimination between other RDP-containing viruses. Thus, within the type C family, viper, avian, and mammalian viruses are readily distinguished, while within the mammalian group, the polymerases of two recent primate isolates, woolly monkeys and gibbon monkeys, appear to be distinct from lower mammalian viruses. The newly described virus RD 114, which is currently being considered as a human candidate virus, could also be distinguished from viruses of lower mammals by polymerase inhibition tests. The main internal protein of the RD 114 virus differs from all other type C viruses both antigenically and because of a unique isoelectric point. In the absence of other criteria for species classification, it has been suggested that polymerase inhibition tests could provide evidence of a primate virus group that would hopefully include RD 114. If this were the case, it would provide strong circumstantial evidence for the human origin of RD 114. Experiments with a hyperimmune guinea pig antiserum raised against purified RD 114 RDP are described in this report. The RD 114 RDP appears to be more closely related to the RDP of two primate viruses than to the RDP of viruses from lower mammalian and non-mammalian species. The enzyme also differs from an RD cell activity that can use RNA templates.
authors: Long, C.;Sachs, R.;Norvell, J.

title: Naturally occurring picornavirus infection of domestic mink
abstract: Isolation and preliminary characterization of a virus from domestic mink is reported. The virus has been tentatively classified as a member of the Picornaviridae family based on its physicochemical properties. Mink virus was not neutralized by antiserum against some known members of the calicivirus genus, which included nine serotypes of porcine virus vesicular rash, ten serotypes of San Miguel sea lion virus and feline calicivirus. Seroepidemiological studies showed that the incidence of mink virus infection was widespread in native mink populations. Although the virus was isolated from mink farms with a history of hemorrhagic pneumonia (Pseudomonas pneumonia), no specific disease process could be attributed to the viral infection.
authors: Long, G. G.;Evermann, J. F.;Gorham, J. R.

title: Bacteria, phages and swine: The effects of in-feed antibiotics on the microbiome at different sites in the gut
abstract: Disruption of the beneficial microbial community in the gut is a potential side effect of antibiotics, which have many uses in animal husbandry (treating or preventing disease and improving feed efficiency). Understanding the effects of antibiotics on bacterial communities at different sites in the gut is critical to realizing the full benefits and consequences of antibiotics in feed. In this study, we defined the lumenal and mucosal bacterial communities from the small intestine (ileum) and large intestine (caecum and colon) plus feces and characterized the effect of antibiotics in the diet (chlortetracycline, sulfamethazine and penicillin (ASP250)) on these communities. 16S rRNA gene sequence and metagenomic analyzes of bacterial affiliation and functions revealed dramatic differences between small and large intestine localizations, including an enrichment of Firmicutes and phage-encoding genes in the ileum. The microbiota of the colon encoded numerous genes for breaking down components of the plant cell wall, and these genes were absent in the ileum. The mucosa-associated ileum microbiota harbored a greater bacterial diversity than the lumen but a similar affinity to the colon mucosa, suggesting that most gut microbes can associate with the mucosa and could serve as an inoculum for the lumen. Adverse effects on the microbiota of animals fed antibiotics differed from those of controls, with notable changes in the increase in ileal Escherichia coli populations, Lachnobacterium spp. in all intestinal localizations and resistance genes to non-administered antibiotics. Characterizing the different metabolic capacities and response to disturbances at different sites in the gut will inform strategies to improve gut health and food safety.
authors: Looft, T.;Allen, H. K.;Cantarel, B. L.;Levine, U. Y.;Bayles, D. O.;Alt, D. P.;Henrissat, B.;Stanton, T. B.

title: The porcine gut microbiota: localized adaptations and responses to antibiotics in the feed
authors: Looft, T. P.

title: Automated classification of tailed bacteriophages according to their neck organization
abstract: Background: The genetic diversity observed in bacteriophages remains a major obstacle to homologue identification and comparison of their functional modules. Although several classes of homologous proteins contributing to head and tail structure can be identified, in structural module proteins of the head-to-tail junction (or neck) are generally more divergent. However, molecular analyzes of some tailed phages belonging to different morphological classes suggested that only a limited number of structural solutions are used to produce a functional virion. To challenge this hypothesis and analyze protein diversity at the virion neck, we developed a specific computational strategy to cope with sequence divergences in phage proteins. We searched for homologues of a set of proteins encoded in the structural module using a phage learning database. Results: We show that, using a combination of iterative profile-profile comparison and gene context analysis, we can identify a range of head, neck and tail proteins in most of the tail bacteriophages in our database. Classification of phages based on neck protein sequences describes 4 types corresponding to known morphological subfamilies. Further analysis of the most abundant Type 1 reveals 10 clusters characterized by consistent sets of head, neck, and tail proteins. We have developed Virfam, a web server that automatically identifies proteins of the phage head-neck-tail module and assigns phage to the closest related phage cluster. This server was tested against 624 new phages from the NCBI database. 93% of the tailed and unclassified phage could be assigned to our head-neck-tail based categories, underlining the high representativeness of the identified virion architectures. Types and clusters describe consistent subsets of Caudovirales that correlate with multiple virion properties. Conclusions: Our method and web server are able to automatically classify most tailed phages, recognize their structural module, assign a function to a set of their head, neck, and tail genes, provide their morphological subtype, and classify these phages within a " It should allow the analysis of large sets of phage genomes. In particular, it should contribute to the classification of the numerous unknown viruses found on assembled contigs of metagenomic samples.
authors: Lopes, A.;Tavares, P.;Petit, M. A.;Guerois, R.;Zinn-Justin, S.

title: Mapping of the subset epitopes of the rotavirus protein VP6
abstract: VP6, the most abundant protein of rotaviruses, contains epitopes that allow these viruses to be classified into four subgroups (SG) depending on the presence or absence of two epitopes called I and II. The subgroup-specific epitopes are conformational and appear trimeric but not monomeric VP6. We have identified some of the amino acids on VP6 that determine the reactivity of subgroup-specific mAbs 255/60 and 631/9. A single amino acid mutation at positions 172 (Met to Ala) or 305 (Asn to Ala) was sufficient to change the subgroup specificity of the human rotavirus Wa-VP6 protein from SGII to SGI/II, since each of these mutations alters the protein to be recognized by SGI mAb 255/60 while retaining its ability to interact with SGII mAb 631/9. In the case of the SGII epitope, mutation of two consecutive amino acids (Ala305 Asn306 to Asn305 Ala306) in the porcine rotavirus YM-VP6 protein (SGI) enabled the protein to be efficiently recognized by the SGII mAb 631/9, while simultaneously protecting the YM-VP6 protein to increase its ability to interact with mAb 255/60. These results suggest that both subset mAbs interact with an antigenic domain in VP6 consisting of at least two regions of the protein that, although distant in linear sequence, may be in close proximity in the VP6 structured trimer.
authors: Lopez, S.;Espinosa, R.;Greenberg, H. B.;Arias, C. F.

title: First detection and analysis of a fish circovirus
abstract: Circoviruses are found in birds and pigs worldwide, but their occurrence in fish has not yet been reported. Recently, increased mortality in barbel fry (Barbus barbus) was observed in Hungary. This work reports the detection of previously unknown circular viral DNA genomes in barbel using a circovirus-specific wide-range nested PCR. Analysis of two complete genomes (Barbel circovirus, BaCV1 and BaCV2) showed that they belonged to a new genetic group within the Circoviridae family, distinct from known circoviruses and circovirus-like genomes. Their genome size was 1957 bases and contained two major ORFs similar to the circovirus capsid and replication-associated protein genes. A connection between the presence of the virus and clinical manifestations of the infection could not be demonstrated.
authors: Lorincz, M.;Csagola, A.;Farkas, S. L.;Szekely, C.;Tuboly, T.

title: Bluetongue virus serotypes 1 and 4 in Sardinia in autumn 2012: new idea or reinfection with old strains?
abstract: Since 2000, there have been multiple outbreaks of bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes 1, 2, 4, 8 and 16 in Sardinia (Italy). In October 2012 new outbreaks of BT were reported by BTV-1 and BTV-4. Almost 500 flocks were infected and 9238 sheep died from the infection. When sequenced, Seg-10 of both strains shared 99% similarity at the nucleotide level to BTV strains circulating in the Mediterranean basin in recent years. Similarly, the newly isolated Sardinian strains BTV-1 and BTV-4 have identical Seg-5 sequences and cluster together with the recently circulating Mediterranean basin BTV-1 and the BTV-4 strains isolated in Tunisia in 2007 and 2009. These BTV-4 strains are distinct from those circulating in Europe between 2003 and 2005 and appear to be reassortant strains. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Lorusso, A.;Sghaier, S.;Carvelli, A.;Di Gennaro, A.;Leone, A.;Marini, V.;Pelini, S.;Marcacci, M.;Rocchigiani, A. M.;Puggioni, G.;Savini, G.

title: Innate immune recognition of smallpox vaccine vectors
abstract: The study of smallpox viruses pioneered the field of vaccinology after Jenner's remarkable discovery that "vaccination" with the phylogenetically related vaccinia virus conferred immunity against the devastating disease smallpox. The study of smallpox viruses continues to enrich the field of virology, as the worldwide eradication of smallpox provides a unique example of the effectiveness of effective immunization. Other poxviruses have since been developed as vaccine vectors for clinical and veterinary applications and include modified vaccinia virus strains such as modified vaccinia Ankara and NYVAC, as well as the avipox viruses, fowlpox virus and canarypox virus. Despite the empirical development of smallpoxvirus-based vector vaccines, it is only now becoming apparent that we need to better understand how the innate arm of the immune system drives adaptive immunity against smallpoxviruses and how this information is relevant to vaccine design strategies, the topics discussed in this article. © 2011 Expert Reviews Ltd.
authors: Lousberg, E. L.;Diener, K. R.;Brown, M. P.;Hayball, J. D.

title: Diversity and evolution of classical swine fever virus
abstract: By analyzing the nucleotide sequence data generated from both the E2 (gp55) and NS5B genes of classical swine fever virus (CSFV), in addition to the previously published data from the 5'NCR, we were able to separate 115 CSFV isolates into two Major isolates subdivide into groups, five subgroups and two distinct isolates. A further differentiation was possible by analysis of sequence data from the E2 region. The three sequencing-based methods were compared to monoclonal antibody (MAb) typing and restricted restriction enzyme (RE) mapping. Although both the MAb and RE methods confirmed the previous classification, the resolution was worse. We estimated an approximate rate of evolution for CSFV from an analysis of viral variation observed in a single geographic area over a 6-year period. Applying this proposed rate to each of our derived CSFV subgroups allowed us to calculate the approximate drift dates for each subgroup.
authors: Lowings, P.;Ibata, G.;Needham, J.;Paton, D.

title: Evaluation of a monoclonal antibody panel for lyssavirus typing in Mexico
abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the ability of a panel of eight antinucleocapsid monoclonal antibodies developed in Europe to identify different strains of rabies virus isolated from a variety of animal species from different geographical areas in Mexico. Fifty-one virus-positive brain tissue samples from various animal species and humans were examined. Material from these samples was used to infect mice whose brains were later probed by indirect immunofluorescence using the monoclonal antibodies described above. Virus strains showing antigenic variations were sent to the Pasteur Institute in Paris for confirmation of the results. No mouse brain sample showed a pattern of antigenic reactivity indicative of the presence of Lyssavirus other than classical rabies virus. However, four antigenic variations of classical rabies serotype 1 have been identified. The antibody panel was judged useful for rapid classification of rabies virus in Mexico. It is possible that autochthonous antigenic variations exist among the strains circulating in this country, a scenario that could explain some of the errors observed with certain vaccines. For this reason there is a need for the production of antinucleocapsid monoclonal antibodies with strains of rabies virus native to this area.
authors: Loza-Rubio, E.;Vargas, R.;HernÃ¡ndez, E.;Batalla, D.;Aguilar-SetiÃ©n, A.

title: Novel bovine hepacivirus in dairy cattle, China
authors: Lu, G.;Jia, K.;Ping, X.;Huang, J.;Luo, A.

title: In vitro and in vivo identification of structural and sequence elements in the 5' untranslated region of Ectropis obliqua picorna-like virus required for internal initiation
abstract: Ectropis obliqua picorna-like virus (EoPV) is a newly described insect virus classified as a putative member of the genus Iflavirus. The virus possesses a large, positive RNA genome encoding a single polyprotein that shares physicochemical properties with those of its members of the Picornaviridae family. The 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR) plays an important role in the initiation of picornavirus translation as it contains an internal ribosome entry site (IRES) that mediates cap-independent translation. To study translation in EoPV, a wide range of mutations were engineered within the 5'-UTR and the effects of these changes were studied in vitro and in vivo using a bicistronic construct. Results showed that deletions within the first 63 nt had little effect on IRES activity while core IRES function was contained in stem loops C and D, as their removal significantly abolished IRES activity. In contrast to these findings, removal of Stem-Loop G, which contained two cryptic AUGs, caused a remarkable increase in IRES activity, which was further probed by site-directed mutagenesis at these two positions. It was also confirmed that initiation of protein synthesis occurs at AUG6 (position 391-394) and not at the AUG immediately downstream of the polypyrimidine tract. Polypyrimidine tract mutation (CCTTTC) had a slight impact on EoPV IRES activity. Furthermore, mutations in the RAAA motif resulted in an approximately 40% decrease in IRES activity in vitro, but these results were not supported by in vivo experiments. In summary, this study shows that the EoPV IRES element is unique, although it shares features with the type II IRES.
authors: Lu, J.;Zhang, J. M.;Wang, X. C.;Jiang, H.;Liu, C. F.;Hu, Y. Y.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of eight genes of H9N2 subtype influenza virus: A mainland China strain possessing the genes of early isolates that were circulating
abstract: The H9N2 subtype influenza virus is widespread worldwide and in China. Previous studies showed that at least three sublineages had been established in terrestrial fowl of Eurasian birds. In this presentation, eight full-length genes from an H9N2 strain, A/Chicken/Shanghai/F/98 (Ck/SH/F/98), were obtained. Sequence analysis and phylogenetic studies were performed by comparing eight genes to those of all available GenBank H9N2 strains. The results showed that four genes (HA, NA, M and NS genes) of Ck/SH/F/98 were incorporated into the sublineage carried by early mainland China strain Ck/BJ/1/ 94 is represented. However, the other four RNP genes of Ck/SH/F/98 did not show a close relationship with those of the three known sublineage viruses. Therefore, Ck/SH/F/98 was a natural reassortant between different sublineages. In addition, the comparison indicated that Ck/SH/F/98 could be a putative progenitor of a later isolate from southern China, Dk/ST/1605/01, with at least six genes from both being closely related, suggesting genes from Ck /SH indicates /F/98 and early isolates were ever in circulation. Further comparison in terms of molecular markers of species specificity of HA1 revealed that DK/ST/1605/01 also resembled Ck/SH/F/98 more than a common earlier duck strain. The results supported the idea of cross-transmission between terrestrial and aquatic birds, which emphasized the importance of raising concerns about the natural evolution of all eight genes of the H9N2 avian influenza viruses. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Lu, J. H.;Liu, X. F.;Shao, W. X.;Liu, Y. L.;Wei, D. P.;Liu, H. Q.

title: Microbial community structure and functional gene diversity of turkey feces revealed by 16S rRNA gene and metagenomic sequences
abstract: The main aim of this study was to better understand the microbial composition and functional genetic diversity associated with turkey faecal communities. To achieve this, 16S rRNA gene and metagenomic clone libraries from turkey fecal samples were sequenced. Analysis of 382 16S rRNA gene sequences showed that the most abundant bacteria were closely related to Lactobacillales (47%), Bacillales (31%) and Clostridiales (11%). Actinomycetales, Enterobacteriales and Bacteroidales sequences were also identified but represented a smaller part of the community. Analysis of 379 metagenomic sequences showed that most clones were similar to bacterial protein sequences (58%). Bacteriophage (10%) and avian virus (3%) sequences were also represented. Of all metagenomic clones potentially encoding bacterial proteins, most Gram-positive low G+C bacterial proteins were similar, particularly from Lactobacillales (50%), Bacillales (11%) and Clostridiales (8%). Bioinformatic analyzes indicated the presence of genes encoding membrane proteins, lipoproteins, hydrolases and functional genes related to the metabolism of nitrogen and sulfur containing compounds. The results of this study further confirmed the dominance of Firmicutes in the gut of birds and underscore the value of coupling 16S rRNA gene and metagenome sequencing data analyzes to study the microbial composition of bird dropping microbial communities.
authors: Lu, J. R.;Domingo, J. S.

title: Goose genome sequence provides insights into waterfowl evolution and susceptibility to fatty liver
abstract: Background: Geese were domesticated over 6,000 years ago, making them one of the first domesticated poultry species. Capable of rapid growth, disease resistance and high liver fat storage capacity, geese can easily be fed roughage. Here we sequence and analyze the whole genome sequence of an economically important goose breed in China and compare it to that of terrestrial bird species. Results: A draft sequence of the entire goose genome was obtained by shotgun sequencing, and 16,150 protein-coding genes were predicted. Comparative genomics show that there are significant differences between the goose genome and that of other terrestrial bird species, particularly with respect to the major histocompatibility complex, myxovirus resistance, retinoic acid-inducible gene I, and other genes associated with disease resistance in geese. In addition, analysis of transcriptome data reveals a potential molecular mechanism involved in geese's susceptibility to fatty liver disease and associated symptoms, including high levels of unsaturated fatty acids and low cholesterol levels. The results of this study indicate that the deletion of the Gänselep gene could be the result of positive selection, allowing the liver to take over energy storage mechanisms for long-distance migration. Conclusions: This is the first report describing the complete goose genome sequence and contributes to genomic resources available for the study of waterfowl. The results of this study are not only useful for genetic breeding programs, but also for the study of lipid disorders.
authors: Lu, L.;Chen, Y.;Wang, Z.;Li, X.;Chen, W.;Tao, Z.;Shen, J.;Tian, Y.;Wang, D.;Li, G.;Chen, L.;Chen, F.;Fang, D.;Yu, L.;Sun, Y.;Ma, Y.;Li, J.;Wang, J.

title: Subtypes of genotype 3 hepatitis E virus in pigs
abstract: The prevalence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) RNA in fecal and bile samples from pigs in slaughterhouses in east and south-west China from 2006 to 2011 was determined by reverse transcriptase PCR. HEV-3 was detected in 4/5952 (0.07%) pigs and HEV-4 was detected in 287/5952 (4.8%) pigs. Two HEV-3 subtype 3a strains from southwest China shared 87.1-89.7% sequence identity. Two HEV-3 subtype 3b strains from eastern China shared 91.8-93.8% sequence identity and were similar to strains previously reported in eastern and central China. The different subtypes of HEV-3 in different regions of China suggested multiple origins of HEV infection. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Lu, Y. H.;Qian, H. Z.;Qin, X.;Jiang, Q. W.;Zheng, Y. J.

title: Beyond the Whole Genome Consensus: Unraveling PRRSV Phylogogenesis Using Next-Generation Sequencing Technologies Review
abstract: The highly heterogeneous Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is the causative agent of an economically important swine disease with the characteristic symptoms of reproductive losses in breeding sows and respiratory diseases in young piglets. The virus can be roughly divided into European and North American genotypes 1 and 2, respectively. In addition to this intra-strain variability, the influence of coexisting viral quasi-species on disease development has recently attracted much attention; This is largely due to the advent of next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies. Genomic data derived from the vast sequencing capabilities of NGS has enabled the study of PRRSV with unprecedented speed and detail. In contrast to traditional sequencing methods that require knowledge of conserved regions, NGS allows de novo assembly of the entire viral genome. Evolutionary variations derived from different genotypic strains provide valuable insight into functionally important regions of the virus. Along with the advancement of sophisticated bioinformatics tools, ultra-deep NGS technologies enable the detection of co-evolving low-frequency quasi-species. This brief review provides an overview, including a proposed workflow, of using NGS to explore PRRSV genetic diversity at both the macro- and microevolutionary levels.
authors: Lu, Z. H.;Archibald, A. L.;Ait-Ali, T.

title: Genome variation in macrophage-cultured European swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus Olot/91 revealed by ultra-deep next-generation sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) is a disease with major economic impact worldwide. The causative agent of this disease is the PRRS virus (PRRSV). Accumulating evidence suggests that microevolution within a coexisting quasispecies population can result in high sequence heterogeneity in PRRSV. RESULTS: We developed a pipeline based on the ultra-deep next generation sequencing approach to first construct the full genome of a European PRRSV strain Olot/9 cultured on macrophages and then the rare variants to collect data that are representative of the mixed quasispecies population. Olot/91 differs from the Lelystad reference strain by about 5% and a total of 88 variants were detected in the mixed population with a frequency of only 1%. These variants included 16 nonsynonymous variants focused on the genes encoding structural and nonstructural proteins; including glycoprotein 2a and 5. CONCLUSION: Using ultra deep sequencing methodology, the complete genome of Olot/91 was constructed without prior knowledge of the sequence. Rare variants representing smaller fractions of the heterogeneous PRRSV population were successfully identified to allow further exploration of microevolutionary events.
authors: Lu, Z. H.;Brown, A.;Wilson, A. D.;Calvert, J. G.;Balasch, M.;Fuentes-Utrilla, P.;Loecherbach, J.;Turner, F.;Talbot, R.;Archibald, A. L.;Ait-Ali, T.

title: Wuhan Large Pig Roundworm Virus Identified in Human Feces in Brazil
abstract: We report here the complete genome sequence of a bipartite virus, designated here WLPRV/human/BRA/TO-34/201, from a sample collected in 2015 from a two-year-old child in Brazil with acute gastroenteritis. The virus is 98-99% identical (segments 2 and 1, respectively) to Wuhan large swine roundworm virus (unclassified RNA virus) recently discovered in the stomach of pigs from China. This is the first report of a Wuhan swine roundworm virus detected in human specimens and the second genome described worldwide. However, further sequence data generation and further functional studies are required to fully understand the ecology, epidemiology and evolution of this new unclassified virus.
authors: Luchs, A.;Leal, E.;Komninakis, S. V.;de PÃ¡dua Milagres, F. A.;Brustulin, R.;da Aparecida Rodrigues Teles, M.;Gill, D. E.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Sabino, E. C.;da Costa, A. C.

title: Identification of viruses with bi- and tri-segmented double-stranded RNA genome in stool of children with gastroenteritis
abstract: Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of nucleic acids extracted from fecal samples from children with diarrheal diseases revealed the presence of group A rotavirus in 50 (23.4%) samples and group C rotavirus in 1 (0.5%) of 214 tested Rehearse. Another sample showed the presence of three bands (with apparent lengths of 2.92, 2.37 and 1.32 kbp) which were shown by enzymatic digestion analysis to consist of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA). The sample was shown by electron microscopy to contain virus particles with a diameter of 32-34 nm. Due to its morphology and genomic characteristics, this virus closely resembles a virus previously found only in chickens by Leite et al. in 1990 and tentatively named "picotrnavirus". A sample containing a "picobirnavirus" was also identified from the same group of 214. Therefore, small icosahedral viruses with a bi- or tri-segmented dsRNA genome appear to infect humans. However, their pathogenic potential has yet to be determined.
authors: Ludert, J. E.;Liprandi, F.

title: Foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype diversity in livestock with no history of vaccination in the Far North region of Cameroon
abstract: Little information is available about the natural cycle of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) without control measures such as vaccination. Cameroon offers a unique opportunity for epidemiological studies as FMD vaccination is not practiced. We conducted a prospective study encompassing serological, antigenic and genetic aspects of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) infections in different animal husbandry systems in far north Cameroon to gain insight into the natural ecology of the virus. We found serological evidence of FMD infection in over 75% of the animals sampled, with no significant prevalence differences observed between the sampled groups (ie market, sedentary, transboundary and mobile). In addition, we found antibodies reactive against five of the seven FMDV serotypes (A, O, SAT1, SAT2 and SAT3) in the examined animals. Finally, we were able to genetically characterize viruses derived from clinical and subclinical FMD infections in Cameroon. Serotype O viruses grouped into two topotypes (West and East Africa). SAT2 viruses grouped with viruses from Central and North Africa, particularly within the sublineage that caused the major North African epidemic of 2012, suggesting a common origin for these viruses. This research will guide future FMD control interventions such as improved diagnostics, vaccine formulation guidance and epidemiological understanding to support the ongoing control of FMD in Cameroon.
authors: Ludi, A.;Ahmed, Z.;Pomeroy, L. W.;Pauszek, S. J.;Smoliga, G. R.;Moritz, M.;Dickmu, S.;Abdoulkadiri, S.;Arzt, J.;Garabed, R.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Close genetic relationship of picornaviruses from European and Asian bats
abstract: Our analysis of 1004 fecal samples from European bats for picornaviruses by broadly reactive nested reverse transcription PCR found picornaviral RNA in 28 samples (2.8%). Phylogenetic analysis of the partial 3D genomic region suggested that a bat virus belonged to the species Enterovirus G (EV-G, formerly Porcine Enterovirus B). Bat infection was supported by relatively high EV-G concentrations of 1.1 × 106 RNA copies per gram of feces. All other bat viruses belonged to either the bat-associated genus Mischivirus or to an unclassified Picornaviridae group distantly related to the genus Sapelovirus. Members of this unclassified sapelovirus-related group had RNA secondary structures in their 3-inch untranslated regions that were typical of enteroviruses and resembled structures found in bat-associated coronaviruses, suggesting ancient recombination events. Based on sequence distances, several picornaviruses from European and Chinese bats were likely conspecific, suggesting connectivity of virus populations. Because of their high mutation rates and diversity, picornaviruses can be useful tools for studying bat and virus ecology.
authors: Lukashev, A. N.;Corman, V. M.;Schacht, D.;Gloza-Rausch, F.;Seebens-Hoyer, A.;Gmyl, A. P.;Drosten, C.;Drexler, J. F.

title: Evolutionary relationships between parvoviruses: virus-host coevolution between autonomous primate parvoviruses and links between adeno-associated and avian parvoviruses
abstract: The current classification of parvoviruses is based on virus host range and dependence on helper viruses, while little data is available on evolutionary relationships between viruses. We identified and analyzed 472 parvovirus sequences, including (almost) complete genomes of all 41 viruses currently recognized as individual species within the Parvoviridae family. Our phylogenetic analysis of full-length genomes and open reading frames distinguished three evolutionary groups of vertebrate parvoviruses: (i) human helper-dependent adeno-associated virus (AAV) serotypes 1 through 6 and the autonomous avian parvoviruses; (ii) the bovine, chipmunk and autonomic primate parvoviruses, including human viruses B19 and V9; and (iii) the parvoviruses of rodents (other than chipmunks), carnivores and swine. Each of these three evolutionary groups could be further subdivided, reflecting both virus-host coevolution and multiple cross-species transmissions in parvovirus evolutionary history. No invertebrate parvoviruses clustered with vertebrate parvoviruses. Our analysis provided evidence for negative selection among parvoviruses, the independent evolution of their genes, and recombination between rodent parvoviruses. The topology of the phylogenetic tree of autonomous human and simian parvoviruses closely matched the topology of the primate phylogenetic tree based on analysis of mitochondrial primate DNA. Viruses belonging to the AAV group were evolutionarily associated not with other palmate parvoviruses but with the parvoviruses of birds. The two lineages of human parvoviruses may have emerged from independent ancient zoonotic infections. Our results provide an argument for a reclassification of Parvovirinae based on evolutionary relationships between viruses.
authors: Lukashov, V. V.;Goudsmit, J.

title: Evolutionary relationships between Astroviridae
abstract: To study the evolutionary relationships between astroviruses, all available sequences for members of the family Astroviridae were collected. The phylogenetic analysis distinguished two ingrained groups: one comprised mammalian astroviruses, with ovine astroviruses being an outlier, and the other comprised avian astroviruses. All virus species as well as human astrovirus serotypes represented individual lineages within the family tree. All human viruses cluster together and separately from non-human viruses, arguing for their common evolutionary origin and against sustained animal-to-human transmission. The branching order of mammalian astroviruses was exactly opposite to that of their host species, suggesting at least two cross-species transmissions involving pigs, cats and humans, possibly through intermediate hosts. Analysis of synonymous (Ds) versus non-synonymous (Da) distances revealed that negative selection is dominant in astrovirus evolution, with Ds:Da ratios as high as 46 for the comparisons of the most closely related viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of all open reading frames (ORFs) based on Ds resulted in the loss of tree structures, with viral species—and even human astrovirus serotypes in ORF2—branching from virtually a single node, suggesting their ancient separation. The strong selection against nonsynonymous substitutions, the small number of which is therefore not evidence of a recent interlineage separation, together with the position of the oldest available human Astrovirus strain (1971) far from the common node of its serotype 4 , suggest that the intraserotype diversification is from an earlier date.
authors: Lukashov, V. V.;Goudsmit, J.

title: In silico identification of plant miRNAs in exosomes from mammalian breast milk—a small step forward?
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression by inhibiting protein translation or by targeting mRNA cleavage. They play many important roles in living organism cells; However, knowledge of the functions of miRNAs has increased following their identification in biological fluids and recent reports on the abundance of miRNAs of plant origin in human plasma and serum. Taking these results into account, we performed a rigorous bioinformatics analysis of publicly available raw data from high-throughput sequencing studies on miRNA composition in human and porcine breast milk exosomes to identify the proportion of food-derived miRNAs. Multiple processing and filtering steps have been applied to increase accuracy and avoid false alarms. Through the above analysis, 35 and 17 miRNA species were identified, belonging to 25 and 11 MIR families, respectively. In the human samples, ath-miR166a, pab-miR951, ptc-miR472a, and bdi-miR168 were found with the highest frequency, while in the pig breast milk exosomes, zma-miR168a, zma-miR156a, and ath-miR166a were identified in the largest amounts. The consensus prediction and annotation of potential human targets for selected plant miRNAs suggest that the above molecules can interact with mRNAs encoding multiple transcription factors, protein receptors, transporters, and immune-related proteins, and thus potentially affect the human organism. Taken together, the presented analysis demonstrates the detection of abundant plant miRNAs in exosomes of mammalian breast milk, while pointing to the new opportunities arising from this discovery.
authors: Lukasik, A.;Zielenkiewicz, P.

title: Infectious bursal disease virus: growth and characterization in cell cultures
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) was adapted to chick embryo bursal (CEB) and kidney (CEK) cells. The virus did not replicate in the kidney cells until 4 serial passages of the virus were performed in bursal cells. The virus produced plaques in CEK cells within 3 to 5 days. Virus replication was not altered by 5-iodo-2'-deoxyuridine, suggesting that it is a ribovirus. Virus infectivity was not destroyed with chloroform and was stable at 56°C for 90 min. Virus adhered to the CEK cell monolayer maximally in 75 min and had an eclipse period of 9-10 hours before virus maturation and release. Immunofluorescence studies on infected cells showed that the first antigen was detected 6 hours after infection and all fluorescent antigen was restricted to the cytoplasm. All of these properties support the classification of IBDV into the diplornavirus group of riboviruses.
authors: Lukert, P. D.;Davis, R. B.

title: Phylogenetic position of an uncharacterized Brazilian bovine papillomavirus strain in the genus Xipapillomavirus based on L1 open reading frame sequencing
abstract: The use of degenerate primer PCR assays has suggested the existence of numerous as yet uncharacterized bovine papillomaviruses (BPV). Despite the endemic nature of BPV infections, identification of BPV types in Brazilian cattle is still sporadic. However, in a recent analysis of a partial segment of the L1 gene, we observed a remarkable diversity among the detected BPV types. The aim of this study was to determine the phylogenetic position of the previously identified wild strain BPV/BR-UEL2, recorded in the state of Paraná, Brazil. Because previous analysis of the partial L1 sequence had shown that this strain was most closely related to BPV type 4, genus-specific primers were designed. Phylogenetic analysis using complete L1 ORF sequences revealed that BPV/BR-UEL2 was related to BPV types classified in the genus Xipapillomavirus and the highest L1 nucleotide sequence similarity to BPV type 4 (78% ) showed. This finding suggests that BPV/BR-UEL2 should be classified as a potential new BPV type in the genus Xipapillomavirus. © 2010, Sociedade Brasileira de Genetica.
authors: Lunardi, M.;Claus, M. P.;Alfieri, A. A.;Fungaro, M. H. P.;Alfieri, A. F.

title: Outbreak of acute bovine viral diarrhea in Brazilian cattle: Clinicopathologic findings and molecular characterization of a wild-type BVDV strain subtype 1b
abstract: When bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) was first described in 1946, it was characterized as an acute communicable disease associated with severe leucopenia, high fever, depression, diarrhea, gastrointestinal erosion, and bleeding. Recently, the severe acute form has only been associated with some hypervirulent BVDV-2 strains. This article reports the detection of BVDV-1b associated with an acute and fatal outbreak of BVD in a Brazilian cattle herd. Depression, anorexia, watery diarrhoea, sialorrhea and weakness were observed in six steers. One of these animals was examined for laboratory, clinical and pathological changes. Laboratory findings were nonspecific; clinically the animal was weak, with dehydration and erosive oral lesions. Pathologic changes were predominant in the tongue, esophagus, and rumen. An RT-PCR assay using primers to partially amplify the 5 inch untranslated region (5-UTR) of the BVDV genome was performed and BVDV was identified in all clinical samples analyzed. Phylogenetic analysis of lymph node-derived BVDV revealed that this strain was clustered within BVDV subtype 1b. This differentiation was only possible by molecular characterization since both the clinical presentation and the pathological findings of BVDV-2 infection were similar. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Lunardi, M.;Headley, S. A.;LisbÃ´a, J. A. N.;Amude, A. M.;Alfieri, A. A.

title: Hierarchical molecular tagging to resolve long continuous sequences through massively parallel sequencing
abstract: Here we demonstrate the use of short-read massive sequencing systems to actually achieve longer read lengths through hierarchical molecular tagging. We demonstrate how indexed and PCR-amplified targeted libraries are mined, subsampled, and paused at timed intervals to obtain pools of different average lengths, each of which is indexed with a new tag. Through this process, indices of sample origin, molecular origin, and degree of degradation are integrated to achieve a nested hierarchical structure that is later used in data processing to organize reads over a longer distance than the sequencing system originally allows. With this protocol, we show how continuous regions beyond 3000 bp can be decoded by an Illumina sequencing system, and we illustrate the potential applications by naming variants of the lambda genome, analyzing TP53 in cancer cell lines, and targeting a canine mitochondrial variable region .
authors: Lundin, S.;Gruselius, J.;Nystedt, B.;Lexow, P.;KÃ¤ller, M.;Lundeberg, J.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 glycoprotein gene of infectious bronchitis viruses isolated in China in 2009-2010
abstract: As part of our ongoing surveillance program, 40 field strains of avian infectious bronchitis (IBV) virus were isolated from dead or diseased chicken flocks in different areas of China between 2009 and 2010. The S1 glycoprotein genes of these strains were sequenced and analyzed with 38 strains published in GenBank. S1 genes of these isolated strains and the vaccine strains showed nucleotide homologies ranging from 65.2 to 82% and amino acid homologies ranging from 58.4 to 81.9%. Meanwhile, in this study, isolated Chinese IBV strains that were mainly nephropathogenic could be divided into six distinct lineages (CH I-CH VI), and the vaccine strains currently used in China formed a mass variant lineage evolutionarily distant from Chinese isolates is. In addition, CK/CH/GD/NC10, CK/CH/GD/KP10 and our earlier isolates TC07-2 formed the CH VI lineage, which showed greater evolutionary distances from other strains. Taken together, these results suggest that while different variants of lineages are now co-circulating in China and appear to be constantly evolving, alternative native vaccines are indeed needed for effective control of IB in China. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
authors: Luo, H.;Qin, J.;Chen, F.;Xie, Q.;Bi, Y.;Cao, Y.;Xue, C.

title: Serological evidence for high prevalence of influenza D virus in cattle, Nebraska, USA, 2003-2004
authors: Luo, J.;Ferguson, L.;Smith, D. R.;Woolums, A. R.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the E2 gene of classical swine fever virus from southern China's Guangxi province
abstract: In this study, specimens suspected of having classical swine fever (CSF) from Guangxi Province, China, were collected from pigs with acute CSF, aborted fetuses, newborn pigs that died at 1-2 days of age, tonsils from healthy pigs, and leukocytes from immunized pigs Sows in the period 2001-2009. Approximately 92 out of 775 samples were found positive by RT-PCR and 41 isolates were obtained. Phylogenetic analysis was performed on the 31 isolates by sequencing of the E2 gene and it was found that the isolates group into two groups: (1) isolates from aborted fetuses (except GXGZ02), deceased newborn baby pigs, tonsils from healthy pigs and leukocytes from immunized sows belonged to group 1.1, together with the vaccine strain HCLV and the virulent standard strain Shimen from China, and (2) 20 isolates from pigs with acute CSF belonged to group 2.1, of which 13 were co-grouped into subgroup 2.1b Isolates from other provinces of China, and 7 of these were clustered in subgroup 2.1a with isolates from Italy and Germany. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Luo, T. R.;Liao, S. H.;Wu, X. S.;Feng, L.;Yuan, Z. X.;Li, H.;Liang, J. J.;Meng, X. M.;Zhang, H. Y.

title: Pathogenicity and genomic characterization of a pseudorabies virus variant isolated from a Bartha-K61 vaccinated pig population in China
abstract: Pseudorabies (PR) or Aujeszky's disease (AD), caused by pseudorabies virus (PRV), is an economically important viral disease worldwide. Recently, PR outbreaks occurred in a large number of Bartha-K61 vaccinated pig herds in many regions of China. Here we isolated a PRV variant called TJ strain from a Bartha-K61-vaccinated pig farm in China, assessed the pathogenicity of the TJ strain in susceptible animals, and analyzed its complete genomic sequence obtained by 454 pyrosequencing. Vaccination challenge experiments in sheep showed that the classic Bartha-K61 vaccine could not provide complete protection against challenge with the PRV-TJ strain. In mice, the 50% lethal dose (LD<inf>50</inf>) of the TJ strain (10<sup>2.3</sup> TCID<inf>50</inf>) was lower than that of the classic PRV SC strain (10<sup>3.0</sup> TCID<inf>50</inf>). In addition, the TJ strain showed higher mortality for pigs compared to the SC strain. The genome of the PRV-TJ strain was determined to be 143,642 bp in length and encodes 67 open reading frames. The TJ strain, along with some recent PRV isolates in China, was grouped into an independent branch in the phylogenetic tree, relatively remote from earlier PRV isolates. The TJ strain displayed unique variations in the viral proteins that play key roles in the viral replication cycle. Taken together, the TJ strain is a highly pathogenic PRV variant with unique molecular signatures. Further studies are needed to investigate the relevance of the sequence differences for the virulence change of the PRV variant.
authors: Luo, Y.;Li, N.;Cong, X.;Wang, C. H.;Du, M.;Li, L.;Zhao, B.;Yuan, J.;Liu, D. D.;Li, S.;Li, Y.;Sun, Y.;Qiu, H. J.

title: A molecular epidemiological study based on VP2 gene sequences shows that a novel genotype of infectious bursal disease virus is predominant in Italy
abstract: characteristic infectious bursal disease (IBD) virus (ITA) genotype was detected in live IBD vaccinated broilers in Italy with no clinical signs of IBD. It was isolated in specific pathogen-free eggs and molecularly characterized in the hypervariable region of viral protein (VP) 2. The phylogenetic analysis showed that ITA strains were obtained separately from other homologous reference sequences from IBDVs, either classic or very virulent GenBank or previously reported in Italy, and from vaccine strains. The new genotype exhibits unique molecular features affecting charged or potentially glycosylated amino acids at key positions in the hypervariable region of VP2, which are practically linked to important changes in viral properties. The characterization of 41 IBDV strains detected in Italy between 2013 and 2014 showed that ITA appears in densely populated poultry areas of Italy, accounting for 68% of IBDV detections during routine diagnostic activities over a two-year period, despite the immunity induced accounts for large-scale vaccination. In addition, four very virulent strains (DV86) and one classic strain (HPR2) as well as eight vaccine strains were detected. The currently available epidemiological and clinical data do not allow determining the degree of pathogenicity of the ITA genotype. Only experimental in vivo pathogenicity studies, carried out under safe isolation conditions, through the assessment of clinical signs and macro/microscopic lesions, will definitively clarify the virulence of the new Italian genotype.
authors: Lupini, C.;Giovanardi, D.;Pesente, P.;Bonci, M.;Felice, V.;Rossi, G.;Morandini, E.;Cecchinato, M.;Catelli, E.

title: Accurate and precise real-time RT-PCR assays for the identification of Astrovirus-associated encephalitis in cattle
authors: LÃ¼thi, R.;Boujon, C. L.;Kauer, R.;Koch, M. C.;Bouzalas, I. G.

title: Genetic evolution of Gallid herpesvirus 2 isolated in China
abstract: Gallid herpesvirus 2 (GaHV-2), which causes Marek's disease in chickens and has caused significant economic losses, has recently developed increased virulence in China. To better understand the genetic basis of the altered pathogenic properties and increased virulence, we sequenced the genomes of six novel GaHV-2 strains (LCC, LTS, WC/1203, JL/1404, CC/1409, and HS/1412). , isolated from immunization-failed chickens, and a previously isolated Chinese GaHV-2 strain, J-1. Based on a multiple sequence alignment, several characteristic point mutations in the open reading frames of the Chinese isolates were detected. In addition, two deletions and one insertion were identified at the junctions of the unique short region and the terminal short repeat region in Chinese isolates, and the insertion was a feature of the new Chinese isolates. According to a phylogenetic analysis, the GaHV-2 genome has diverged significantly in China over the past two decades. Based on the long region of internal repeat, the new isolates were closely related to very virulent or very virulent plus strains. In addition, the new Chinese isolates differed from the previously isolated strains J-1 and 814. Taken together, our results provide evidence that Chinese GaHV-2 strains contain distinctive sequences, particularly the new isolates. The observed genetic divergence in the new Chinese GaHV-2 strains over the past two decades may be related to observed changes in pathogenic properties and virulence.
authors: Lv, H.;Zhang, Y.;Sun, G.;Bao, K.;Gao, Y.;Qi, X.;Cui, H.;Wang, Y.;Li, K.;Gao, L.;Pan, Q.;Wang, X.;Liu, C.

title: Gene expression analysis of porcine whole blood cells infected with foot-and-mouth disease virus using high-throughput sequencing technology
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) is a single-stranded positive RNA virus belonging to the Picornaviridae family. FMD infects cloven-hoofed animals such as swine, sheep, goats, cattle and various wildlife species and remains a major threat to livestock industries worldwide. In this study, a transcriptome analysis of whole blood from pigs infected with FMD was performed using the paired-end Illumina sequencing technique to understand the interactions between the pathogen and its host cells. A total of 120 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified during infection with FMDV, including 110 upregulated genes and 10 downregulated genes. To further investigate the DEGs involved in the interactions between the virus and its host, annotations to gene ontology (GO) and an enrichment of the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) were performed. GO annotation showed that a number of DEGs were enriched in categories involved in host-virus interactions such as B. Response to stimulus, immune system process and regulation of biological processes. KEGG enrichment analysis showed that the DEGs were mainly involved in ribosome signaling and immune-related signaling pathways. Ten DEGs, including the immune-related genes BTK1, C1QB, TIMD4 and CXCL10, were selected and validated by quantitative PCR, showing that the expression patterns of these genes are consistent with the results of in silico expression analysis. In conclusion, this study represents the first transcriptome analysis of FMD-infected porcine whole blood cells, and the results obtained in this study advance our understanding of FMD-host cell interactions and diagnosis and control of FMD.
authors: Lv, J.;Ding, Y.;Liu, X.;Pan, L.;Zhang, Z.;Zhou, P.;Zhang, Y.;Hu, Y.

title: Taxonomic status of Burana virus (BURV) (Bunyaviridae, Nairovirus, Tamdy group) isolated from ticks Haemaphysalis punctata Canestrini et Fanzago, 1877 and Haem. concinna Koch, 1844 (Ixodidae, Haemaphysalinae) in Kyrgyzstan]
authors: L'Vov D, K.;Al'khovskiÄ­, S. V.;Shchelkanov, M. Iu;Shchetinin, A. M.;Deriabin, P. G.;Gitel'man, A. K.;Aristova, V. A.;Botikov, A. G.

title: West Nile Virus and Other Zoonotic Viruses in Russia: Examples of Emergence and Reemergence Situations
abstract: Studies on the interactions of vertebrates, viruses and arthropod vectors of these viruses were monitored in relation to different ecological groups of viruses transmitted by mosquitoes and ticks in northern Eurasia over an area of more than 15 million km2. About 90 viruses have been isolated, including 24 new to science. Newly recognized infections in vertebrates, including humans, have been described. Many unusual epidemic situations have been analyzed. Constant efforts have been made to prevent bioterrorist activities and their consequences. Large-scale epidemic outbreaks of West Nile fever (WNF; ie fever caused by West Nile virus) and Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) with unusually high mortality have occurred in southern Russia over the past four years. We have determined infection rates in humans, domestic and wild animals, mosquitoes and ticks from natural and synanthropic communities [Editor's note: "Synanthropic" roughly means all species living with (cf. lice, fleas) or in the vicinity of humans , e.g. in houses (cf. house mice), parks (cf. Rattus spp.), and the like, more like "peridomestic" but not strictly so; "Biocenosis" is the biome, the "entirety of living populations in a given habitat, which is itself only a part of the ecosystem".]. CCHF virus strains were phylogenetically similar to strains isolated in this area 35 years ago, but differed from Central-South Asian and African strains. Before the start of the current outbreak of the WNF epidemic, three genetic variants of this virus had been isolated in the USSR, two African and one Indian. Phylogenetic analysis of full genome sequences of disease strains showed considerable similarity with strains from USA and Israel and differences with strains isolated 20-30 years ago in the same areas of USSR. In addition to the genotype 1 strains, we isolated second and third lineage strains and one strain of a fourth genetic variant. The nucleotide differences of these strains from all three genotypes were about 30%. The emerging WNF situation in Russia in the last 4 years was probably the result not only of natural and social factors but also of the introduction of more virulent strains or the evolution of the virus.
authors: Lvov, D. K.;Butenko, A. M.;Gromashevsky, V. L.;Kovtunov, A. I.;Prilipov, A. G.;Kinney, R.;Aristova, V. A.;Dzharkenov, A. F.;Samokhvalov, E. I.;Savage, H. M.;Shchelkanov, M. Y.;Galkina, I. V.;Deryabin, P. G.;Gubler, D. J.;Kulikova, L. N.;Alkhovsky, S. K.;Moskvina, T. M.;Zlobina, L. V.;Sadykova, G. K.;Shatalov, A. G.;Lvov, D. N.;Usachev, V. E.;Voronina, A. G.

title: Razdan virus, a new ungrouped bunyavirus isolated from Dermacentor marginatus ticks in Armenia
abstract: virus called Razdan was isolated from Dermacentor marginatus ticks in the Armenian SSR in 1973. Complement fixation tests revealed no antigenic relationships to 74 tick-borne arboviruses. The size of the virus is about 100 nm; it agglutinates goose erythrocytes at pH 5.5-7.0, is pathogenic to neonatal, 14-day-old and adult white mice, and proliferates in primary and continuous cell cultures. Morphological properties of the virus allow its classification as a member of the Bunyaviridae family.
authors: Lvov, D. K.;Gromashevsky, V. L.;Zakaryan, V. A.;Skvortsova, T. M.;Berezina, L. K.;Gofman, Y. P.;Klimenko, S. M.;Chubkova, A. L.

title: Batken virus, a new arbovirus isolated from ticks and mosquitoes in the Kyrgyz SSR Summary Report
abstract: Three virus strains were isolated in 1970. Two of these (LEIV 300 K and LEIV 306 K) were isolated from Hyalomma plumbeum plumbeum Panz., 1795, ticks isolated from sheep in the Batken region, Oshsk province, and a virus strain from mixed pools of Aedes caspius caspius Pallas, 1771, and Culex (Neoculex) hortensis Ficalb, 1889, mosquitoes were caught in Leninsk region, Ozhsk province, Kyrgyz USSR. The ticks were collected in the semi-desert foothills of the Turkestan mountains near the village of Batken, 700 m above sea level (40° 04' N, 70° 51' E). A total of 146 ticks were examined virologically. The mosquitoes were collected from the rice fields in the Naryn River valley, 650 m above sea level (41°N, 72°E). A total of 20,000 mosquitoes of the two species were examined virologically. Virus isolation experiments were performed in 1-2 day old white sucking mice. Antigens were prepared from the brains of diseased suckling mice by the sucrose-acetone method. Immune Ascites Fluids (IAF) were prepared. The serological identification of the isolates was performed in complement fixation tests (CFT) by a macro method with a set of 57 IAF to arboviruses. Since all isolates were serologically identical, the prototype strain LEIV 306 K could be examined in detail. Examination of the virus antigen in CF tests revealed that it did not react with any of the IAFs used. The data collected, together with the isolation of the virus from ticks and mosquitoes, suggest that the virus is a novel, unclustered arbovirus. It is named Batken virus after the location of its first isolation.
authors: Lvov, D. K.;Karas, F. R.;Tsyrkin, Y. M.

title: Antigenic cross-reactivity between avian pneumoviruses of subgroups A, B and C at the matrix but not at the nucleocapsid proteins
abstract: Previous results from our laboratory, based on analysis of nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequence identities of 15 avian pneumoviruses (APVs) isolated from the United States (subgroup C), showed that the viruses were phylogenetically distinct from the European subgroups A and B viruses was. Here we examined whether viruses from the three subgroups were cross-reactive by testing field sera positive for each of the APV subgroups in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test using recombinant matrix (M) and nucleoprotein (N) proteins that from tested an APV isolate from Minnesota (APV/MN2A). Sera from turkeys infected with APV subgroups A, B or C reacted with recombinant M protein derived from APV/MN2A. In contrast, recombinant N protein from the APV/MN2A virus was reactive with sera from virus subtypes A and C, but not with virus subtype B. The results illustrate that viruses of the three APV subtypes share antigenic homology and the M protein-based ELISA is suitable for monitoring APV outbreaks but not for distinguishing between different subtypes.
authors: Lwamba, H. C. M.;Halvorson, D. A.;Nagaraja, K. V.;Turpin, E. A.;Swayne, D.;Seal, B. S.;Kariuki Njenga, M.

title: Porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) studies in vaccine-related and other cell lines
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) is widespread in pigs and has recently been reported in some rotavirus vaccines. Since raw materials of animal origin such as cells, trypsin and serum can be a major source for introducing virus contamination into biological products, we have studied PCV1 in several cell lines obtained from ATCC and widely applied in research, diagnostics or vaccine development. It is assumed that these cell lines were exposed to bovine and porcine viruses during their establishment and passage history due to the use of serum and trypsin that were not qualified according to current test guidelines or processed with new virus inactivation methods. This study showed that Vero, MRC-5 and CEFs, which are cell substrates used in some US-approved vaccines, and other cell lines used in investigational vaccines such as MDCK, HEK-293, HeLa and A549 were negative for PCV1 were using a nested PCR assay: some were also confirmed negative by infectivity analysis. However, MDBK cells used for some animal vaccines contained PCV1 sequences, although no virus was isolated. Although the results indicated that PCV infection may not have occurred under previous culture conditions, recent cases of vaccine contamination underscore the need for continued efforts to reduce the likelihood of virus introduction from animal material used in product manufacture. Issued by Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Ma, H. L.;Shaheduzzaman, S.;Willliams, D. K.;Gao, Y. M.;Khan, A. S.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of Coxsackie virus B5 that caused viral encephalitis outbreak in Henan area
abstract: Objective: Identify the pathogen that caused an outbreak of viral encephalitis in Henan region in 2011. Phylogenetic analysis was performed on Coxsackie virus B5 (CVB5) isolated during this outbreak. METHODS: Five throat swab, 21 stool, and 14 CSF samples were collected from 29 hospitalized patients during this outbreak. Virus isolation and real-time RT-PCR were then performed for all samples. Enterovirus 71 (EV71), coxsackievirus A 16 (CA16) and pan-Enterovirus (PE) viral nucleic acids were detected by real-time RT-PCR. A phylogenetic tree based on complete VP1 sequences was constructed among CVB5 isolates from 2 stool and 3 CSF samples from 5 inpatients and other published data retrieved from GenBank. Results: The real-time RT-PCR results showed that the PE nucleic acid positive rates of throat swab, stool and CSF samples were 60.0% (3/5), 61.9% (13/21) and 85, 7% (12/14) were . All of these samples were negative for EV71 and CA16. The isolation rates of throat swab, stool, and CSF specimens were 20.0% (1/5), 25.0% (5/21), and 29.0% (4/14), respectively. BLAST with both VP1 and 5' UTR sequences and molecular typing showed that CVB5 was the major pathogen. Analysis among the 5 positive isolates based on the complete VP1 sequences showed 97.9%-99.5% homology. Data from homologous comparisons showed that these isolates had the highest nucleotide acid identity with the Changchun CVB5 CC10/10/Changchun strain (97.1% - 98.1%) that caused the 2010 Changchun outbreak of hand, foot, and mouth disease ( HFMD) and lower identity (89.0% - 89.6% and 91.8% - 92.5%) with strain COXB5/Henan/2010 and 03001N isolated from Pingdingshan, Henan in 2010 and 2012, respectively became. The pedigree in the VP1 region showed that isolates from this outbreak belonged to genotype D, the same clade as the Changchun strain. Conclusion: CVB5 was the main etiologic agent correlated with this outbreak. The shift in the predominant genotype could serve as one of the causes of these outbreaks. Copyright © 2012 by the Chinese Medical Association.
authors: Ma, H. X.;Mu, Y. J.;Li, X. L.;Kang, K.;Huang, X. Y.;Tang, X. Y.;Wei, W.;Xu, B. L.

title: A nanoparticle-assisted sensitivity-enhancing PCR assay for the rapid detection and differentiation of wild-type pseudorabies virus and gene-deleted vaccine strains
abstract: Nanoparticle-assisted polymerase chain reaction (nanoPCR) is a novel method for rapid amplification of DNA and has been adopted for virus detection due to its simplicity, rapidity, and specificity. A nanoPCR assay was developed to detect and differentiate wild-type and gene-deleted pseudorabies virus (PRV). Three primer pairs for nanoPCR designed in this study were selected from conserved regions of PRV and produced specific amplicons of 431.bp (gB), 316.bp (gE), and 202.bp (gG). The sensitivity of this assay using purified plasmid constructs containing the specific gene fragments was 100- to 1000-fold higher than conventional PCR. The PRV nanoPCR assay did not amplify porcine parvovirus, porcine circovirus type 2, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus, porcine technovirus, or African swine fever virus, but produced three bands of the expected size with PRV and two bands of the expected size with the gene-deleted PRV-Bartha-K61. Of 110 clinical specimens collected from seven provinces in China, 53% and 48% were positive for wild-type PRV by nanoPCR assay and virus isolation, respectively. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Ma, X.;Cui, Y.;Qiu, Z.;Zhang, B.;Cui, S.

title: Completion of sequence analysis and comparisons of genome segment 2 (encoding the outer capsid protein VP2) from representative isolates of the 24 bluetongue virus serotypes
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is a non-contagious, arthropod-borne viral disease of domestic and wild ruminants. It is caused by bluetongue virus (BTV), a double-stranded (ds) RNA virus classified in the genus Orbivirus, family Reoviridae. There are at least twenty-four BTV serotypes worldwide, five of which (1, 2, 4, 9 and 16) have recently been identified in Europe. BTV infects ruminants and its spread in temperate and tropical regions of the world depends on the activity and abundance of certain vector-competent Culicoides mosquito species. The BTV outer capsid protein VP2 is an important protective antigen and the primary determinant of virus serotype. For the first time, the authors have completed the sequence analysis of full-length VP2 genes from the reference strains of each of the 24 BTV serotypes and deduced their amino acid sequences. Multiple alignment of VP2 gene (protein) sequences revealed that the degree of nucleotide (amino acid) sequence variation between serotypes ranged from 29% (23%) to 59% (73%), confirming that Segment 2/VP2 most variable is BTV gene/protein. The phylogenetic analysis of VP2 grouped the BTV types known to serologically cross-react. Little identity between the types was demonstrated for specific regions within the VP2 amino acid sequences that have been shown to be antigenic and play a role in virus neutralization. The sequence data marks the completion of an important step in the creation of a comprehensive BTV sequence database that will support faster molecular methods for diagnosing and identifying BTV 'types', as well as continuing molecular epidemiology and surveillance studies of BTV.
authors: Maan, S.;Maan, N. S.;Samuel, A. R.;O'Hara, R.;Meyer, A. J.;Rao, S.;Mertens, P. P.

title: Development of reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction based assays and sequencing for typing of European bluetongue virus strains and differential diagnosis of field and vaccine strains
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) is a double-stranded (ds) RNA virus belonging to the genus Orbivirus of the family Reoviridae and causes bluetongue disease (BT), an infectious non-contagious disease in ruminants. The virus exists in 24 different serotypes that are currently being identified by virus isolation and serum neutralization assays. The most variable outer capsid protein VP2 (encoded by genome segment 2) is the primary determinant of the BTV serotype. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assays based on segment 2 amplification were used to identify the five European BTV types (BTV-1, BTV-2, BTV-4, BTV-9 and BTV - 16). Primer pairs specific to each BTV serotype were designed. The resulting RT-PCR assay was both sensitive and specific, providing BTV typing within 24 h. Perfect agreement was recorded between the RT-PCR and virus neutralization assays. The primers for each serotype were able to successfully amplify the BTV isolates of that serotype from different regions and showed no cross-amplification of the most closely related BTV serotypes. RT-PCR primers were also developed for distinguishing field and vaccine strains of BTV serotypes currently circulating in Europe. The primer pairs, capable of amplifying field and vaccine strains of BTV-1, BTV-2, BTV-4 and BTV-9, were validated with multiple isolates of each serotype from different geographic origins around the world and their type specificity was retested with the closest related serotypes. Overall, these RT-PCR assays provide a rapid and reliable method for identifying and differentiating field and vaccine strains of different BTV types.
