The primers used in this study are listed on the Institute for Animal Health, Pirbright website.
authors: Maan, S.;Maan, N. S.;Singh, K. P.;Samuel, A. R.;Mertens, P. P.

title: Genome-wide identification and quantification of cis- and trans-regulated genes that respond to Marek's disease viral infection by analysis of allele-specific expression
abstract: Marek's disease (MD) is a commercially important neoplastic disease of chickens caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV), a naturally occurring oncogenic alphaherpesvirus. Selection for increased genetic resistance to MD is a control strategy that can enhance vaccine control measures. To identify MD resistance candidates with high confidence, we performed a genome-wide allele-specific expression (ASE) screen among F(1) offspring from two inbred chick lines that differ significantly in MD resistance. High-throughput sequencing was initially used to profile transcriptomes from pools of uninfected and infected individuals 4 days post-infection to identify all genes displaying ASE in response to MDV infection. RNA sequencing identified 22,655 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), of which 5,360 in 3,773 genes showed a significant allelic imbalance. Illumina GoldenGate assays were then used to quantify regulatory variations controlled at the gene (cis) and elsewhere in the genome (trans) by measuring differences in expression between F(1) individuals and artificial F(1 )-RNA pools were examined over six time periods in 1,536 of the most significant SNPs identified by RNA sequencing. Allelic imbalance resulting from cis-regulatory changes was confirmed in 861 of the 1,233 GoldenGate assays successfully tested. In addition, we identified seven genes that show transregulation only in infected animals and ~500 SNPs that show a complex interaction between cis and transregulatory changes. Our results demonstrate that ASE analyzes are a powerful approach to identify regulatory variations responsible for differences in transcript abundance in genes underlying complex traits. And the genes with SNPs showing ASE provide a strong basis to further study the causative polymorphisms and genetic mechanisms for MD resistance. Finally, the methods used here to identify specific genes and SNPs have practical implications for applying marker-assisted selection to complex traits that are difficult to measure in agricultural species when expression differences are expected to control some of the phenotypic variance.
authors: Maceachern, S.;Muir, W. M.;Crosby, S. D.;Cheng, H. H.

title: Potential strategies to combat bluetongue, an emerging global Culicoides-borne viral disease of ruminant and wild animals
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is a non-zoonotic arboviral disease of certain wild and domestic even-toed ungulate species. The causative agent, bluetongue virus (BTV), is spread by mosquitoes of the genus Culicoides in temperate and tropical regions of the world. Control of BTV infection is complicated by the variety of virus serotypes and the ubiquity and opportunistic feeding behavior of its mosquito vector. The global distribution of BTV infection has changed recently, possibly due in part to climatic influences on mosquito species living in different regions. The aim of this review is to assess realistic strategies that could be employed to control or prevent future outbreaks of BT and other Culicoides-borne diseases. Importantly, optimal control of emerging, rapidly evolving arbovirus diseases such as BT will require integrated countermeasures that mitigate all aspects of the virus' transmission cycle. This is best achieved through preventative rather than purely reactive strategies. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Maclachlan, N. J.;Mayo, C. E.

title: Sequence analysis of American-type Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus collected from Danish swine herds
abstract: Vaccine-like virus of the American type Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) was detected in serum samples by RTPCR. Viruses were analyzed by nucleotide sequencing of the genomic region encoding open reading frames 2-7. During the ongoing investigation of Danish isolates of PRRSV using nucleotide sequencing, RT-PCR reactions and subsequent nucleotide sequencing, the presence of American-type PRRSV in Danish breeding herds was revealed. Most likely, these atypical viruses originated from boars vaccinated with live American-type vaccine (MLV RespPRRS), taken to artificial insemination centers and placed there with unvaccinated boars already in the centres. The nucleotide sequences of three Danish viruses of the American type PRRSV were compared with those of known PRRSV isolates. The nucleotide sequence identities of the atypical Danish isolates were between 99.299.5% with the vaccine virus RespPRRS and 99.0-99.3% with VR2332, the parent virus of the vaccine virus. Phylogenetic analysis, which included American-type field isolates, supports the conclusion that the introduction of American-type PRRSV into Denmark was due to vaccine virus spread.
authors: Madsen, K. G.;Hansen, C. M.;Madsen, E. S.;Strandbygaard, B.;BÃ¸tner, A.;SÃ¸rensen, K. J.

title: New molecular mechanisms of virus-mediated carcinogenesis: oncogenic transformation of cells by the retroviral structural protein envelope
abstract: RNA tumor viruses, classified as retroviruses, have been isolated and identified to induce tumors in a variety of animals, including chickens, mice, and rats, or even humans, over the last 100 years since the first report was made in 1908. The RNA tumor viruses have historically been divided into two groups, acute transforming RNA tumor viruses and non-acute RNA tumor viruses. Acutely transforming RNA tumor viruses are inherently replication defective and rapidly induce tumors by expressing the captured viral oncogenes from the cellular genome in host cells. The first oncogene derived from Rous sarcoma virus was the src non-receptor tyrosine kinase, which was identified as playing the significant role in signal transduction. On the other hand, non-acute RNA tumor viruses, which consist only of gag, pro, pol, and env regions but do not carry oncogenes, are replication competent and could activate the cellular proto-oncogenes by inserting the viral long terminal repeat close to the Proto-oncogenes to induce tumors with a long incubation period, termed promoter insertion. These molecular mechanisms have been hypothesized to induce tumors. Recently, however, several reports have described that the retroviral structural protein Envelope could directly induce tumors in vivo and transform cells in vitro. These are very unusual examples of native retroviral structural proteins with transformational potential. In this review, we review the history of oncogenic retrovirus research and summarize recent advances in our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of oncogenic transformation by retrovirus envelope proteins.
authors: Maeda, N.;Yoshikai, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of Orf virus in goats in Gabon, Central Africa
abstract: Background: Orf, or contagious ecthyma, is a zoonotic viral infection with a potentially serious health threat to the small ruminant industry as well as humans. It is currently appearing in new areas. Results: Eight suspected clinical cases of pustular dermatitis in goats were reported in January 2013 in the rural area of Tebe in south-eastern Gabon. Orf virus (ORFV) was detected by high-throughput sequencing on sera, cheek swabs, and scab pool samples. It was confirmed in six out of eight diseased goats using specific PCR targeting the major envelope protein (B2L) and orf virus interferon resistance (VIR) genes. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the Gabonese strain and the South Korean strains evolved from a common ancestor, suggesting an Asian origin of the Gabonese strain of ORFV. Conclusions: This study provides molecular evidence of the ORFV strain involved in cases of pustular dermatitis in goats and highlights its distribution in Gabon.
authors: Maganga, G. D.;Relmy, A.;Bakkali-Kassimi, L.;Ngoubangoye, B.;Tsoumbou, T.;Bouchier, C.;N'Dilimabaka, N.;Leroy, E. M.;Zientara, S.;Berthet, N.

title: Transmission of Peste des Petits Ruminants virus from domesticated to wild ruminants in the Serengeti ecosystem, Tanzania
abstract: We tested wildlife areas near domestic animals, pastures and water sources in Ngorongoro District in the Serengeti ecosystem of northern Tanzania and found 63% seropositivity for small ruminant plague virus. Sequencing of the viral genome of diseased sheep in the area confirmed lineage II virus circulation.
authors: Mahapatra, M.;Sayalel, K.;Muniraju, M.;Eblate, E.;Fyumagwa, R.;Shilinde, L.;Mdaki, M.;Keyyu, J.;Parida, S.;Kock, R.

title: Surveillance of H5N1 subtype avian influenza virus in backyard animals and its introduction in Bali, Indonesia
abstract: Epidemiological studies of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 (HPAIV-H5N1) in companion animals and livestock are limited. Here we provide serological and virological evidence of infection in various household animals in Bali, Indonesia in 2005 and 2006. Serum and swab samples from poultry, pigs, dogs and cats were collected using a stratified random sampling design. Antibodies to HPAIV-H5 were detected in sera using the standard haemagglutination inhibition assay and the presence of HPAIV-H5N1 in swabs was confirmed using an egg inoculation technique, haemagglutination assay and molecular methods. Phylogeny and virus distribution were inferred using BEAST and SPREAD software. Results showed that seroprevalence varied significantly (P<0.001) from village chickens to waterfowl, from poultry to pigs, and in the provincial study year. The seroprevalences in dogs and cats were 1.85% and 7.50%, respectively. In addition, HPAIV-H5N1 has been isolated from all species except cats. Isolation rates varied between species and also between monitoring years. Virus spread analysis showed that isolates from Bali were divided into two main groups with good statistical support. Given these results, HPAIV surveillance should be extended to all poultry and mammal species found in backyard environments.
authors: Mahardika, G. N.;Adi, A. A. A. M.;Besung, N. K.;Dharmawan, N. S.;Kencana, G. A. Y.;Rompis, A. L. T.;Sampurna, P.;Setiasih, L. E.;Suardana, W.;Suardana, I. B. K.;Suarjana, G. K.;Suartha, N.;Suartini, G. A. A.;Suwiti, N. K.;Utama, I. H.

title: Genetic analysis of bovine viral diarrheal viruses from Australia
abstract: Eighty-nine bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) from Australia were genetically typed by sequencing the 5″-untranslated region (5″-UTR) and, for selected isolates, the Npro region of the viral genome. Phylogenetic reconstructions showed that all samples examined were grouped within the BVDV type 1 genotype. Of the 11 BVDV-1 genetic groups previously described, 87 of the samples examined in this study were clustered with BVDV-1c, while two samples were clustered with BVDV-1a. Based on these analyses, there appears to be limited genetic variation within Australian BVDV field isolates. In addition, the phylogenetic reconstructions indicate that the accumulation of Australian BVDV in the phylogenetic trees is not due to geographic isolation. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Mahony, T. J.;McCarthy, F. M.;Gravel, J. L.;Corney, B.;Young, P. L.;Vilcek, S.

title: Introduction and history of foot and mouth disease virus
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) has been recognized as a major epidemic disease threatening the cattle industry since the 16th century and was shown in the late 19th century by Loeffler and Frosch to be caused by a submicroscopic, filterable transmissible pathogen . smaller than all known bacteria. The foot-and-mouth disease pathogen was thus the first vertebrate virus to be detected from plants shortly after the discovery of the tobacco mosaic virus. It was not until 1920 that Waldmann and Pape established a convenient animal model for the study of FMD virus using guinea pigs, and with the later development of in vitro cell culture systems for the virus, the chemical and physical properties of FMD virus were studied throughout the remainder of the 20th Century elucidated, culminating in 1989 with a complete description of the three-dimensional structure of the virion. FMD virus is classified as a species in the genus Aphthovirus of the family Picornaviridae. The virus is acid labile and the genome RNA contains a characteristic polyC stretch located about 360 nucleotides from the 5' end. Seven main serotypes and numerous subtypes exist worldwide. The World Reference Laboratory for FMD is based in Pirbright, Surrey, UK and monitors FMD epidemics by both serotyping and genotyping isolates of the virus. A major FMD epidemic occurred in the UK in 2001 and was caused by a virulent strain of FMD virus originating in Asia. The advantages and some disadvantages of controlling FMD outbreaks through vaccination are discussed.
authors: Mahy, B. W. J.

title: Detection and phylogenetic characterization of Columbid circoviruses in Chaharmahal va Bakhtiari Province, Iran
abstract: The virus genus Circovirus belongs to the family Circoviridae and contains virus species with circular single-stranded DNA genomes. The viruses are known to infect vertebrate species including pigs, dogs, pigeons and ducks. In this study, a nested polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was applied to investigate the prevalence of circoviruses in pigeons in Chaharmahal va Bakhtiari Province, Iran. A total of 50 fecal samples were subjected to nucleic acid extraction, PCR amplification and DNA sequencing. Nested PCR primers were designed to amplify a 508 base pair segment of the pigeon circovirus (PiCV) capsid gene. Of the 50 fecal samples examined, 12 (24%) produced the expected DNA amplicons with identical DNA sequences. Phylogenetic analysis has grouped the viruses with those classified as group A circoviruses. The viruses were closely related to PiCVs found in Poland, Northern Ireland, the US, Nigeria and Hungary. To the authors' knowledge, this is the first report on the molecular detection and genomic characterization of PiCV from Iran.
authors: Mahzounieh, M.;Heidari Khoei, H.;Ghasemi Shamsabadi, M.;Dastjerdi, A.

title: The detection and phylogenetic analysis of porcine deltacoronavirus from Guangdong province in southern China
abstract: Porcine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV) is a newly discovered coronavirus that causes diarrhea, vomiting and dehydration in suckling and suckling piglets. It was first reported in Hong Kong in 2012 and has since been spotted in the United States, Canada, South Korea, mainland China, Thailand and Laos. PDCoV has been experimentally proven to cause diarrhea in pigs and has been positively tested in pigs in Guangdong, southern China. In our study, 252 faecal and intestinal samples from suckling piglets and sows with diarrhea were examined for common intestinal viruses. We found a prevalence of PDCoV (21.8%), porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (65.5%), transmissible gastroenteritis virus (0%), rotavirus group A (25.0%) and porcine kobuvirus (68.7%) . We isolated 13 PDCoV strains and found that PDCoV infections were often co-infections with Kobuvirus and not with the commonly associated porcine epidemic diarrheal virus. Phylogenetic analysis of S gene and N gene revealed that 11 out of 13 PDCoV strains belonged to Chinese ancestry. In the two strains on the left, a single strain (CHN-GD16-05) belonged to American and Korean lineages, while another strain (CHN-GD16-03) was similar to a Thai strain but only in the S gene. This suggested a possible recombination event between the Thai and the newly described Chinese strain.
authors: Mai, K.;Feng, J.;Chen, G.;Li, D.;Zhou, L.;Bai, Y.;Wu, Q.;Ma, J.

title: [Virosphere and Giraffes]
abstract: New insights and concepts in the field of virology, especially related to virosphere and giraffes - a group of large nuclear-cytoplasmic deoxyriboviruses - are briefly summarized. Key taxonomic features and viral pathogenicity, including African swine fever, are interpreted in the context of the new understanding.
authors: Makarov, V. V.

title: Avian flu virus review
abstract: Influenza viruses are classified as A, B, or C based on the antigenicity of their nucleoproteins and matrix proteins. Influenza A viruses are further classified into subtypes based on the antigenicity of two of their surface proteins, hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. All bird flu viruses are type A viruses. While most avian influenza viruses are avirulent, viruses of a limited number of subtypes cause severe disease in birds. This difference in pathogenicity between avian influenza viruses is primarily determined by the amino acid sequence at the viral hemagglutinin cleavage site. Since 1997 there have been several reports of human infection with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses. Acquiring the ability to cause human-to-human transmission of avian influenza viruses will confront the human population with a pandemic influenza crisis. Here we review the molecular basis of the pathogenicity of avian influenza viruses in humans. [References: 8]
authors: Makino, A.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Profiling human microRNAs in response to influenza A viruses (subtypes pH1N1, H3N2, and H5N1)
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play an important role in regulating gene silencing and are involved in many cellular processes, including inhibiting the replication of infected viruses. This study examined cellular miRNA expression profiles acting in response to influenza virus at an early stage of infection, which could be useful for understanding and controlling viral infection. A549 cells were infected with different subtypes of influenza virus (pH1N1, H3N2 and H5N1). After 24 h post-infection, miRNAs were extracted and then used to construct a DNA library. All DNA libraries with different indices were pooled at the same concentration, followed by high-throughput sequencing based on the MiSeq platform. The miRNAs were identified and counted from the sequencing data using the MiSeq reporter software. The miRNAs expressions were classified into upregulated and downregulated miRNAs compared to those in uninfected cells. Most often, each subtype of influenza A virus elicited the upregulated responses in miRNA expression profiles. Hsa-miR-101, hsa-miR-193b, hsa-miR-23b and hsa-miR-30e* were upregulated when infected with all three influenza A virus subtypes. The results of the target prediction showed that viral infection can trigger genes in cellular processes, metabolic processes, developmental processes and biological regulation. This study provided some insight into cellular miRNA profiling in response to different subtypes of influenza A viruses that are circulating and have caused outbreaks in the human population. The regulated miRNAs could be involved in virus-host interaction or host defense mechanism, which should be studied for effective antiviral therapeutic interventions.
authors: Makkoch, J.;Poomipak, W.;Saengchoowong, S.;Khongnomnan, K.;Praianantathavorn, K.;Jinato, T.;Poovorawan, Y.;Payungporn, S.

title: Need for new technologies to detect adventitious active substances in vaccines and other biological products
abstract: From an industrial perspective, the conventional in vitro and in vivo assays used to detect viral contaminants have shown their limitations, as illustrated by the unfortunate detection of porcine circovirus contamination in an approved rotavirus vaccine. This contamination event illustrates the gaps within the existing random drug strategy and the potential use of new broad molecular detection methods. This paper serves to summarize current testing approaches and challenges as well as opportunities for the use of these new technologies.
authors: Mallet, L.;Gisonni-Lex, L.

title: Non-specific immune stimulation against viruses
abstract: trypsinized preparation of a chromogenically selected strain of Mycobacterium phlei (NSI) non-specifically stimulated the recipient's immune system against a variety of viruses, viz. Rabies virus (RNA virus), Marek's disease (DNA virus), and foot-and-mouth disease virus (RNA virus) in phylogenetically diverse hosts such as mice, chicks, and guinea pigs, respectively. Examining the mechanisms of such non-specific immune stimulation revealed that there was induction of strong cell-mediated immune response (CMIR) against both specific and non-specific viral antigens as shown by LMIT, lymphokine (LyIF) assay and lymphocyte transformation test, etc. There was induction of an appreciable amount of "anti-infective substance(s)" (IIS) other than the classical antibody (Ig) in the serum of NSI-inoculated animals and birds. This substance(s) neutralized FMD, IBR, rabies and Newcastle disease virus in cell cultures, mice and fertilized eggs. Electrophoretic separation of the NSI-induced serum revealed an increase in the β-fraction of globulin.
authors: Mallick, B. B.;Kishore, S.;Das, S. K.;Garg, A.

title: Proof of the occurrence of isolation and characterization of porcine circovirus 2 in Kazakhstan
abstract: This report describes the first isolation and characterization of porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) in the Republic of Kazakhstan. The virus was isolated from a dead piglet, showing no typical clinical signs of porcine circovirus disease, at a pig factory in North Kazakhstan Oblast (region). The isolated virus belongs to genotype 2 (PCV2) and shares 96.6% sequence homology with one isolate and two strains from China and two French strains in group 1, cluster 1ab, and 96.4% homology with two strains isolated in China and one tribe from Hungary. Electron microscopy showed that the isolated virus had the typical morphological structure of PCV. This is evidence of the occurrence of porcine circovirus 2 isolation and characterization in Kazakhstan.
authors: Mambetaliyev, M.;Yesimbekova, N. B.;Strochkov, V. M.;Tabynov, K. K.;Sultankulova, K. T.;Abduraimov, Y. O.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of Murray Valley encephalitis virus and West Nile virus (Kunjin subtype) from a 2011 equine arbovirus disease outbreak in Victoria, Australia
abstract: The virus was detected in the central nervous system (CNS) tissue of 11 Victorian horses infected with West Nile Virus subtype Kunjin (WNVKUN) that died with neurological symptoms in an outbreak in Australia in 2011. Analysis of partial sequence information of the NS5 and E genes showed that the MVEVs in the samples were very homogeneous and all belonged to lineage I, which is enzootic in the tropical regions of northern Australia. Likewise, analysis of partial NS5 and E gene and full genome sequences showed that the WNVKUN within samples were also highly homogeneous and clustered with WNV lineage 1 clade b, consistent with other WNVKUN isolates. Whole genomes of 1 MVEV isolate and 2 WNVKUN isolates were sequenced and characterized. The genome sequences of Victorian WNVKUN are nearly identical (3 amino acid differences) to those of the recently sequenced WNV isolate WNVNSW2011. Metagenome sequencing directly from CNS tissue identified the presence of WNVKUN and MVEV in infected CNS tissue. © 2013 The author(s).
authors: Mann, R. A.;Fegan, M.;O'Riley, K.;Motha, J.;Warner, S.

title: Investigation of the diversity of the 18S SSU rRNA hypervariable region of Theileria in cattle and Cape buffalo (Syncerus caffer) from southern Africa using a next-generation sequencing approach
abstract: The molecular classification and systematics of Theileria is based on the analysis of the 18S rRNA gene. Reverse line blot or traditional sequencing approaches have drawbacks in studying 18S rRNA diversity, and a next-generation 454 sequencing approach has been explored. The 18S rRNA gene was amplified using RLB primers coupled to 96 unique sequence identifiers (MIDs). Theileria positive specimens from African buffalo (672) and southern African cattle (480) were combined in batches of 96 and sequenced using the GS Junior 454 sequencer to generate 825711 informative sequences. Sequences were extracted based on MIDs and analyzed to identify Theileria genotypes. Genotypes observed in buffalo and cattle were confirmed in the current study, while no new genotypes were discovered. Genotypes showed specific geographic distributions, most likely associated with vector distributions. The host specificity of buffalo and bovine specific genotypes has been confirmed and prevalence data and relative parasitemia trends indicate a preference for different hosts. Mixed infections are common in African buffalo, which carry more genotypes compared to cattle. Associative or exclusive co-infection profiles were observed between genotypes, which may have implications for speciation and systematics: in particular, that there may be more Theileria species in cattle and buffalo than currently thought. Analysis of the primers used for Theileria parva diagnostics shows that no new genotypes are amplified by the current primer sets, confirming their specificity. T. parva SNP variants residing in the hypervariable region of 18S rRNA have been confirmed. A next-generation sequencing approach is useful to obtain comprehensive knowledge of 18S rRNA diversity and prevalence for Theileria, allowing for the evaluation of systematic and diagnostic assays based on the 18S gene.
authors: Mans, B. J.;Pienaar, R.;Ratabane, J.;Pule, B.;Latif, A. A.

title: Microbiomes associated with animals: implications for livestock husbandry and animal production
authors: Mantovani, H. C.;Lopes, D. R. G.;Bento, C. B. P.

title: Infectious particles, stress, and induced prion amyloids: A unifying perspective
abstract: Many believe that transmissible encephalopathies (TSEs) arise from spontaneous conversion of the host's prion protein (PrP) into an infectious amyloid (PrP-res, PrPSc) without nucleic acid. Many TSE agents are found in the environment, with infection controlled by public health measures. These include the disappearance of kuru with the end of ritual cannibalism, the dramatic reduction in epidemic bovine encephalopathy (BSE) from the removal of contaminated feed, and the absence of endemic scrapie in geographically isolated Australian sheep with susceptible PrP genotypes. While the modeling of prion proteins has generated an intense focus on common modes of protein misfolding and amyloid formation in various organisms and diseases, the biological properties of infectious TSE agents and their recognition by the host as foreign bodies raise several fundamental new directions for fruitful investigations such as: ( 1) unrecognized microbial agents in the environmental metagenome that can cause latent neurodegenerative diseases, (2) the evolutionary social and protective functions of various amyloid proteins in diverse organisms from bacteria to mammals, and (3) amyloid formation as a benefit of innate immune responses to stress (infectious and non-infectious ). However, once initiated, this innate process can become unstoppable as neuronal aging accelerates. © 2013 Landes Bioscience.
authors: Manuelidis, L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of influenza virus M genes isolated from free-flying waterfowl from their Northern Territory to Hokkaido, Japan
abstract: In 2000-2007, 218 influenza viruses of 28 different combinations of subtypes HA (H1-H13) and NA (N1-N9) were isolated from faecal samples from free-flying waterfowl at two remote lakes in Hokkaido, Japan. Phylogenetic analysis of the matrix (M) genes of 67 strains selected on the basis of their subtype combinations revealed that A/Duck/Hokkaido/W95/2006 (H10N8) was a reassortant whose M gene was related to North American belonged to non-seagulls. avian and the other seven genes to Eurasian non-gull avian lineages. The M genes of the other 65 strains belonged to Eurasian non-gull bird and those to Eurasian gull lines. The M genes of 65 strains were grouped into three distinct sublineages, suggesting that influenza viruses circulating in different populations of free-flying aquatic birds evolved independently in nature. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Manzoor, R.;Sakoda, Y.;Mweene, A.;Tsuda, Y.;Kishida, N.;Bai, G. R.;Kameyama, K. I.;Isoda, N.;Soda, K.;Naito, M.;Kida, H.

title: Identification of Clade E avipoxvirus, Mozambique, 2016
abstract: Analysis of scab samples collected from poultry during the 2016 fowlpox outbreak in Mozambique revealed the presence of clade E avipoxviruses. Infected poultry came from flocks vaccinated against fowlpox virus. These results require an urgent re-evaluation of vaccine formula and control strategies in this country.
authors: Mapaco, L. P.;Lacerda, Z.;Monjane, I. V. A.;Gelaye, E.;Sussuro, A. H.;Viljoen, G. J.;Dundon, W. G.;Acha, S. J.

title: Development of RT-qPCR assays for the specific identification of two major genotypes of infectious avian bronchitis virus
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (Gammacoronavirus, Coronaviridae) is a genetically variable RNA virus (27.6 kb) that causes one of the most intractable respiratory diseases in poultry. The virus is divided into genotypes with different epidemiological relevance and clinical implications. The present study reports on the development and validation of specific RT-qPCR assays for the detection of two important IBV genotypes: South America I (SAI) and Asia/South America II (A/SAII). The SAI genotype is an exclusive and widespread South American lineage, while the A/SAII genotype is distributed in Asia, Europe and South America. Both identification assays use TaqMan probes that hybridize to unique sequences in the spike glycoprotein gene. The assays successfully detected all assessed strains belonging to both genotypes and demonstrated high specificity and lack of cross-reactivity. Using serial dilutions of in vitro transcribed RNA, we obtained acceptable detection coefficients, PCR efficiencies, and relatively low intra- and inter-assay variability. The assays showed a wide dynamic range between 101-107 and 102-107 RNA copies/reaction for SAI and A/SAII strains, respectively. The ability to characterize large numbers of samples quickly, sensitively and reproducibly makes these techniques suitable tools for routine testing, IBV control and epidemiological research in poultry.
authors: Marandino, A.;TomÃ¡s, G.;HernÃ¡ndez, M.;Panzera, Y.;Craig, M. I.;Vagnozzi, A.;Vera, F.;Techera, C.;Grecco, S.;Banda, A.;HernÃ¡ndez, D.;PÃ©rez, R.

title: Whole genome characterization of Uruguayan strains of infectious avian bronchitis virus reveal extensive recombination between the two major South American lineages
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (gammacoronavirus, Coronaviridae) is a genetically variable RNA virus that causes one of the most intractable respiratory diseases in poultry. The virus is divided into genotypes and lineages with different epidemiological relevance. Two lineages of the GI genotype (11 and 16) have been widespread in South America for decades. GI-11 is an exclusive South American line, while the GI-16 line is distributed in Asia, Europe and South America. Here we obtained the entire genome of two Uruguayan strains of the GI-11 and GI-16 lines using Illumina high-throughput sequencing. The strains sequenced here are the first to be obtained for the infectious bronchitis virus in South America and provide new insights into the origin, distribution and evolution of viral variants. The full genomes of the GI-11 and GI-16 strains are 27,621 and 27,638 nucleotides, respectively, and share the same genomic organization. The phylogenetic mismatch analysis shows that both strains share a mosaic genome that arose by recombination between Eurasian strains of the GI-16 lineage and ancestral South American GI-11 viruses. The recombination occurred in South America and produced two viral variants that retained the full S1 sequences of the parent lines but are extremely similar in the rest of their genomes. These recombinant viruses have been extremely successful and have existed for several years on the continent with a notoriously wide geographic distribution. Our results demonstrate unique viral dynamics and emphasize the importance of full genomic characterization to understand the emergence and evolutionary history of viral variants.
authors: Marandino, A.;TomÃ¡s, G.;Panzera, Y.;Greif, G.;Parodi-Talice, A.;HernÃ¡ndez, M.;Techera, C.;HernÃ¡ndez, D.;PÃ©rez, R.

title: A novel approach to study host-pathogen interactions in bovine digital dermatitis, a model of complex polymicrobial infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Polymicrobial infections pose a major challenge for elucidating disease etiology and developing comprehensive diagnostic or therapeutic tools, especially for fastidious and difficult-to-cultivate bacteria. Using bovine digital dermatitis (DD) as a disease model, we present a new strategy to study the pathogenesis of complex infections. RESULTS: The strategy combines meta-transcriptomics with high-density peptide microarray technology to search for in vivo expressed microbial genes and host antibody response at the site of infection. Bacterial expression patterns supported the assumption that treponemes were the main DD pathogens, but also indicated the active involvement of other phyla (mainly Bacteroidetes). Bacterial genes involved in chemotaxis, flagellar synthesis, and protection from oxidative and acidic stress were among the major factors defining the disease. CONCLUSIONS: The extraordinary diversity observed in bacterial expression, antigens and host antibody responses between individual cows suggested microbial variability as a hallmark of DD. Persistence of infection and DD reinfection in the same individual is common; Therefore, high microbial diversity may undermine the host's ability to mount an efficient immune response and maintain immunological memory against DD. The common antigenic markers identified here using a high-density peptide microarray address this issue and may be useful for future preventive measures against DD.
authors: Marcatili, P.;Nielsen, M. W.;Sicheritz-Ponten, T.;Jensen, T. K.;Schafer-Nielsen, C.;Boye, M.;Nielsen, M.;Klitgaard, K.

title: Characterization of the h5n1 influenza virus isolated during an outbreak among wild birds in Russia (Republic of Tuva) in 2010
abstract: study of the basic biological properties of the H5N1 subtype strain isolated during an outbreak among wild birds in Russia in 2010 is presented. The study was conducted using conventional methods in accordance with WHO recommendations. The H5N1 influenza virus isolated in Siberia belonged to clade 2.3.2 of the hemagglutinin gene and a phylogenetic analysis was performed. The antigenic properties and the basic genetic markers of biological properties have been studied. All strains were found to be highly pathogenic to chickens and white mice. The 2010 H5N1 virus, which is phylogenetically closely related to Asian variants, was shown to cause animal diseases in wild birds in Russia. The potential danger of this variant of the virus for humans has been confirmed by various methods. We discussed the possibility of formulating the natural focus of the H5N1 flu. © 2011 Allerton Press, Inc.
authors: Marchenko, V. Yu;Sharshov, K. A.;Silko, N. Yu;Susloparov, I. M.;Durymanov, A. G.;Zaykovskaya, A. V.;Alekseev, A. Yu;Smolovskaya, O. V.;Stefanenko, A. P.;Malkova, E. M.;Shestopalova, A. M.

title: Nairobi sheep disease virus, an important tick-borne pathogen of sheep and goats in Africa, is also found in Asia
abstract: Nairobi Sheep Disease (NSD) virus is the prototype of the tick-borne NSD serogroup, genus Nairovirus, family Bunyaviridae. It is highly pathogenic to sheep and goats, causes disease in humans, and is widespread throughout East Africa. Ganjam virus has caused disease in goats and humans in India. Due to their occurrence on different continents and the association with different ticks, these viruses were considered to be independent despite serological cross-reactivity. Their S-RNA genomic segments and encoded nucleocapsid proteins were found to be 1590 nucleotides and 482 amino acids in length and differed by only 10 and 3% at the nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. Genetic and serological data indicate that ganjam virus is an Asian variant of NSD virus. These viruses were phylogenetically more closely related to Hazara virus than to Dugbe virus. © 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).
authors: Marczinke, B. I.;Nichol, S. T.

title: A highly virulent infectious Bursa disease virus genotype predominantly associated with recurrent outbreaks of infectious Bursa disease in Tunisian vaccinated herds
abstract: Outbreaks of infectious bursal disease (IBD) continue to plague the Tunisian poultry industry, even in flocks where the vaccination program is strictly applied. To characterize the viruses that evade protection by vaccination, field isolates of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) from vaccinated flocks that have experienced repeated episodes of IBDV outbreaks were isolated from bursal specimens by reverse transcription coupled with polymerase chain reaction and dideoxynucleotide sequencing , analyzes VP2 hypervariable region. Although sequence data was obtained from samples collected from three different flocks over a 3 year period, only limited variation in sequence was observed. The few nucleotide changes were silent and the deduced amino acid sequences were identical. Thus, the virus population predominant in the field appears to represent a homogeneous antigen pool. When compared to the VP2 sequences of several IBDV strains, this predominant pool was found to be closely related to the very virulent (vv) IBDV viruses described in Europe and Asia. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the precursor polyprotein coding sequence of a representative Tunisian isolate further confirmed its assignment to the vv genotype. The deduced amino acid sequence of the entire polyprotein of the Tunisian isolate was found to be identical to a South Korean IBDV strain. Alignment of the polyprotein amino acid sequence of 35 IBDV strains identified additional mutations outside of the VP2 variable domain that are common in vv strains. Based on this comparative analysis, the set of amino acid residues that should represent a typical vv profile includes Ala222, Ile242, Ile256, Ile294, Leu451, Tyr680, N685, Ser715, Asp751, Val990, and Ala1005. Such a combination of amino acid changes has been observed for the majority of vvIBDV strains that define a particular phylogroup.
authors: Mardassi, H.;Khabouchi, N.;Ghram, A.;Namouchi, A.;Karboul, A.

title: Complete genome sequences of pigeon adenovirus 1 and duck adenovirus 2 expand the number of species within the genus Aviadenovirus
abstract: Whole genomes of the first isolates of pigeon adenovirus 1 (PiAdV-1) and musk duck adenovirus (duck adenovirus 2, DAdV-2) were sequenced. The PiAdV-1 genome is 45,480. bp long and has a gene organization most similar to turkey adenovirus 1. The left end of the genome lacks ORF0, ORF1A, ORF1B and ORF1C and possesses ORF52, while six new genes were found at the right end. The DAdV-2 genome is 43,734. bp long and has a gene organization similar to that of goose adenovirus 4 (GoAdV-4). It lacks ORF51, ORF1C and ORF54 and has ORF55A and five other new genes. PiAdV-1 and DAdV-2 genomes contain two and one fiber gene, respectively. Genome organization, G+C content, molecular phylogeny, and host type confirm the need to establish two new species (pigeon aviadenovirus A and duck aviadenovirus B) within the genus Aviadenovirus. Phylogenetic data show that DAdV-2 is most closely related to GoAdV-4. © 2014 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Marek, A.;KajÃ¡n, G. L.;Kosiol, C.;Harrach, B.;SchlÃ¶tterer, C.;Hess, M.

title: Two fiber genes of nearly equal length are a common and characteristic feature of fowl adenovirus C members
abstract: The complete genome or genomic region containing the two fiber genes from two reference strains and one field isolate representing both fowl adenovirus C serotypes was sequenced. Two fiber genes were discovered in the genomes of all three isolates. Fiber 1 and fiber 2 genes of several fowl adenovirus C isolates were also sequenced. Both serotypes 4 and 10 have two fiber genes. The genomic region containing the fiber gene was also sequenced for the fowl adenovirus B reference strain. Only one fiber gene was detected in this strain. Predicted amino acid sequences were compared to previously published fiber sequences of various adenovirus isolates, and an amino acid substitution within fiber-2 was detected in all fowl adenovirus C isolates isolated from chickens with hepatitis hydropericardium syndrome compared to apathogenic isolates. Phylogenetic analyzes provided insight into the evolution of fiber genes in avian adenoviruses and their genetic relationships.
authors: Marek, A.;Nolte, V.;Schachner, A.;Berger, E.;Schlotterer, C.;Hess, M.

title: When African swine fever plays at home - description of an outbreak in Namibia
abstract: Introduction - African swine fever (ASF) is considered the most serious public health threat to the global swine industry and is caused by a complex linear double-stranded DNA virus (ASF virus, ASFV) that is currently classified as the only member of the family Asfarviridae. Objective - To describe an ASF outbreak that occurred in Namibia and was managed during the international collaboration there conducted by the Istituto Zooprofilattico Experimentale dell'Abruzzo e Molise "G. Caporale" (Teramo, Italy). Materials and Methods - The ASF outbreak occurred in Omaruru District (Namibia) and affected a small pig herd of about 100 pigs. The herd belonged to a hunting farm and was very close to a small slaughterhouse where warthogs had recently been slaughtered. Clinical symptoms appeared suddenly and affected pigs of different age groups. Two pigs were autopsied for diagnostic purposes: histopathology, direct immunofluorescence and polymerase chain reaction. Results - At autopsy, all pigs examined showed generalized hemorrhagic lesions. Predominantly new haemorrhages were observed microscopically, together with severe lymphocytolysis in all lymphoid tissues. Laboratory tests confirmed the diagnosis of ASF. The outbreak was eventually resolved by rooting out. Discussion - In Africa, ASFV infection is strictly dependent on the "sylvatic cycle" involving warthogs and ticks of the Ornithodoros moubata complex. Transmission mechanisms from wild animals and domestic pigs are still unclear, but ticks most likely play a key role. Therefore, the ASF outbreak described here could represent the prototype of ASF in southern Africa. ASFV eradication does not appear to be achievable in this region and ASF control should focus on biosecurity measures. As in the present report, acute ASF usually occurs with very high morbidity and mortality, at least in previously unexposed pigs. On the contrary, subclinical and chronic infections are more common in endemic areas. Pathological findings are extremely useful to diagnose and counteract ASF. A number of hemorrhagic diseases should be considered in the differential diagnosis. Anamnestic and epidemiological data prove to be helpful to properly approach the diagnostic process. Conclusions - The recent outbreak in Eastern Europe further confirms that ASF is a serious transboundary disease that is still negatively impacting the swine industry worldwide. The epidemiological and pathological features described herein are of diagnostic value and are important to promptly counteract the spread and economic impact of the disease.
authors: Marruchella, G.;Maseke, M.;Scacchia, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of rabies viruses from Sudan provides evidence for a viral clade with a unique molecular signature
abstract: Rabies is endemic to Sudan and remains a continuing public health threat as transmission to humans is primarily through dogs. In addition, large-scale livestock losses occur every year, creating economic and social dilemmas. In this study, we analyzed a cohort of 143 rabies viruses circulating in Sudan collected from 10 different animal species between 1992 and 2006. Partial nucleoprotein sequence data (400 bp) were obtained and compared to available African classical rabies virus (RABV) sequence data. isolated. The Sudanese sequences formed a discrete cluster within the Africa 1a group, including a small number of sequences that clustered with sequences from Ethiopian RABV. These latter sequences share an aspartic acid at position 106 (Asp106) with all other members of the Africa 1a group, in contrast to the remaining Sudanese strains which encode glutamic acid at this position (Glu106). In addition, as representatives of other African and European lineages have been assimilated, Glu106 is unique to Sudan, supporting the concept of a single distinct virus strain circulating in Sudan. The high sequence identity in all Sudanese isolates examined indicates the presence of a single rabies virus biotype for which the main reservoir is the domestic dog. Crown Copyright © 2009.
authors: Marston, D. A.;McElhinney, L. M.;Ali, Y. H.;Intisar, K. S.;Ho, S. M.;Freuling, C.;MÃ¼ller, T.;Fooks, A. R.

title: Zoonotic aspects of rotaviruses
abstract: Rotaviruses are important intestinal pathogens in humans and animals. Group A rotaviruses (GARVs) are responsible for the deaths of up to 1 million children each year, mostly in developing countries, and human vaccines are now available in many countries. Rotavirus-associated enteritis is a major problem in livestock, particularly in young calves and piglets. At the beginning of the epidemiological studies of GARV in humans, either sporadic cases or epidemics due to atypical, animal-like GARV strains were described. Whole genome sequencing of human and animal GARV strains has revealed remarkable genetic heterogeneity in the 11 double-stranded RNA segments across different rotavirus strains and provided evidence for frequent overlaps between human and animal rotavirus evolution as a result of multiple, repeated events of transmission between species and subsequent adaptation. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Matthijnssens, J.;Buonavoglia, C.;Ciarlet, M.

title: Enteric viral infections in lambs or kids
abstract: Diarrhea in lambs and kids is often a complex, multifactorial syndrome. Common infectious causes of diarrhea in lambs and kids in the first month of life are bacterial or parasitic in nature. However, despite noticeable improvements in management practices and prevention and treatment strategies over the past few decades, diarrhea is still a common and costly syndrome affecting newborn small ruminants. Recent advances in diagnostics and metagenomic studies of the gut environment have enabled the discovery of a number of new viruses, although their pathobiological properties are still largely unknown. A more in-depth assessment of the impact of these viruses on the health and production of these livestock is needed and requires the development of accurate diagnostic tools and updating of diagnostic algorithms for enteric pathological conditions.
authors: Martella, V.;Decaro, N.;Buonavoglia, C.

title: Novel parvovirus associated with primate bufaviruses in dogs
abstract: new protoparvovirus species genetically related to human bufaviruses has been identified in dogs with respiratory symptoms. Canine bufavirus was distantly related to the well-known canine protoparvovirus, canine parvovirus type 2, and shared low amino acid identities in nonstructural protein 1 (40.6%) and capsid protein 1 (33.4%). When screening fecal, nasal and oropharyngeal samples from juvenile dogs (<= 1 year), canine bufavirus DNA was identified as a common component of canine viromea. The virus was commonly found in stool samples from dogs with or without intestinal disease and in nasal and oropharyngeal swab samples from dogs with respiratory symptoms. However, the virus was not detected in nasal and oropharyngeal swab specimens from animals without clinical symptoms.
authors: Martella, V.;Lanave, G.;Mihalov-Kovacs, E.;Marton, S.;Varga-Kugler, R.;Kaszab, E.;Di Martino, B.;Camero, M.;Decaro, N.;Buonavoglia, C.;Banyai, K.

title: Rapid detection, full genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of porcine deltacoronavirus
abstract: In February 2014, porcine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV) was identified in the United States. We developed a PDCoV real-time reverse transcription PCR that identified PDCoV in 30% of the samples tested. Four additional PDCoV genomes from the United States have been sequenced; these had =99%-100% nt similarity to the other US PDCoV strains.
authors: Marthaler, D.;Raymond, L.;Jiang, Y.;Collins, J.;Rossow, K.;Rovira, A.

title: Widespread rotavirus H in commercial pigs, USA
abstract: We examined the presence of rotavirus H (RVH) in US pigs, which has been identified in pigs in Japan and Brazil. From 204 samples collected between 2006 and 2009, we identified RVH in 15% of stool samples from 10 US states, suggesting that RVH has been circulating in the United States since 2002, but probably longer.
authors: Marthaler, D.;Rossow, K.;Culhane, M.;Goyal, S.;Collins, J.;Matthijnssens, J.;Nelson, M.;Ciarlet, M.

title: VP6 genetic diversity, reassortment, intragenic recombination and classification of rotavirus B in American and Japanese swine
abstract: Rotavirus B (RVB) has been identified as the causative agent of diarrhea in rats, humans, cattle, lambs and pigs. Recently, 20 RVB VP7 genotypes were determined based on an 80% nucleotide percent cutoff. In this study, we sequenced the RVB VP6 gene segment from 80 RVB-positive swine specimens from the United States and Japan. Phylogenetic analyzes using GenBank's 30 available RVB VP6 sequences and our 80 new RVB VP6 sequences revealed a high genetic diversity of RVB strains, mainly in pigs. For classification purposes, pairwise identity frequency analyzes yielded a cut-off value of 81% nucleotide percent, resulting in 13 RVB VP6(I) genotypes. In addition, an intragenic recombinant RVB-VP6 segment from Japan was identified. In addition, the data indicate frequent rearrangement events that occurred between the porcine RVB VP7 and VP6 gene segments. © 2014 The Authors.
authors: Marthaler, D.;Suzuki, T.;Rossow, K.;Culhane, M.;Collins, J.;Goyal, S.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Ciarlet, M.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Pestivirus infections at the interface between wild and domestic ruminants in the French Southern Alps
abstract: In the alpine pasture, transmission between species has recently been implicated in the epidemiology of pestivirus infection. The aim of this study was to investigate pestivirus infections in wild and domestic ruminants sharing pastures in the southern French Alps. Animal sera were screened for pestivirus antibodies to the pestivirus NS3 protein by a commercial blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). All 38 household stock tested were positive for pestivirus-specific antibodies. Individual seroprevalence reached 76.5% (95% confidence interval [95% CI]: [74.2-78.8%]) of the 1383 sheep tested. In wild ruminants, 38.7% (95% CI: [33.8-43.9%]) of the 369 chamois tested, 28.7% (95% CI: [17.4-38.1%]) of the 72 Roe deer and 22.2% (95% CI: [6.5-37.9%]) of the 27 mouflon were seropositive. Virus screening was performed on spleen samples from hunted wild animals (.n=.160) and from 15 domestic ruminants (clinically suspected persistently infected animals) by conventional reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Three pestivirus strains were isolated from the RT-PCR positive sheep samples. The viruses were divided into the genotypes BDV-3, BDV-Tunisia and BDV-6. For the first time, a strain (strain RUPI-05) was isolated from an alpine chamois and clustered in the BDV-6 genotype, showing 92% identity in the 5'UTR region with the sheep isolate from the same area. Active circulation of pestiviruses has been demonstrated in both wild and domestic ungulates from the southern French Alps. The results suggest that interspecies transmission is likely to occur between sheep and chamois.
authors: Martin, C.;Duquesne, V.;Adam, G.;Belleau, E.;Gauthier, D.;Champion, J. L.;Saegerman, C.;ThiÃ©ry, R.;Dubois, E.

title: Recombination in eukaryotic single-stranded DNA viruses
abstract: Although single-stranded (ss)DNA viruses that infect humans and their domesticated animals do not generally cause major diseases, arthropod-borne ssDNAviruses of plants do, and as a result severely limit food production in most temperate regions of the world. In addition to the well-known ssDNA viruses that infect plants and animals, recent metagenomic studies of ssDNA molecules have revealed that a large number of other diverse ssDNA viruses also exist in almost all terrestrial and aquatic environments. The host ranges of these viruses likely span the tree of life and they are likely important components of global ecosystems. Various lines of evidence indicate that a key evolutionary process during the generation of this global ssDNA viral diversity was likely genetic recombination. High rates of homologous recombination, non-homologous recombination, and reassortment of genome components are known to occur within and between different ssDNA virus species, and we consider here the different roles that these different types of recombination can play, both in everyday biology and the longer-term evolution of these viruses. We specifically focus on the ecological, biochemical, and selective factors underlying the patterns of genetic exchange detectable between the ssDNA viruses and discuss how all of these should be considered when considering the adaptive value of recombination during evolution of the ssDNA virus is assessed. © 2011 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Martin, D. P.;Biagini, P.;Lefeuvre, P.;Golden, M.;Roumagnac, P.;Varsani, A.

title: Course of a BVDV-2 infection in a dairy herd. A case study
abstract: Aim: A case of severe, acute clinical disease after infection with BVDV-2, which causes high economic losses in a dairy herd, is described and the course of infection is followed. Material and methods: The affected herd consisted of 25 German Fleckvieh cows and their offspring. The farm was BHV-1 free and average annual milk production was 6500 kg. Cases of illness and clinical findings from September 2002 to April 2003 were collected and evaluated. BVDV antibodies were detected using indirect antibody ELISA. BVDV antigens were detected using antigen ELISA and immunofluorescence flow cytometry. The viruses isolated were classified as BVDV-2 using monoclonal antibodies and PCR. Results: Six cows and one heifer developed haemorrhagic enteritis. Two of these cows were euthanized and one cow died during the course of the disease. Six cows aborted or calved prematurely. In addition, four calves died and three calves born weak or suffering from severe diarrhea were euthanized. Two calves remained persistently infected. An infection of the herd with BVDV-2 was diagnosed as the cause of the disease. Conclusion and clinical relevance: The results show that the herd was BVDV-2 naïve prior to infection. The virus must have been circulating in the herd for some time, even without the presence of persistently infected animals.
authors: Martin, R.;Kuhne, S.;Mansfeld, R.

title: Genomic characterization of a G8P[1] rotavirus found in a child with diarrhea shows direct animal-to-human transmission
abstract: Group A rotavirus is a major cause of severe gastroenteritis in children and young animals. During a retrospective analysis of specimens collected from Paraguayan children under 5 years of age with diarrhea and previously negative for rotavirus and norovirus, we discovered the presence of bovine rotavirus sequences by viral metagenomics. Nucleic acid was extracted directly from the stool sample and determined as G8P[1]. Genome analyzes revealed that the strain has an artiodactyl-like genome (G8-P[1]-I2-R2-C2-M1-Ax-N2-T6-E12-H3), indicating direct animal-to-human transmission .
authors: Martinez, M.;Phan, T. G.;Galeano, M. E.;Russomando, G.;Parreno, V.;Delwart, E.;Parra, G. I.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic analysis of bovine coronavirus based on the spike glycoprotein gene
abstract: Bovine coronavirus has been associated with diarrhea in newborn calves, dysentery in adult cattle, and respiratory infections in calves and beef cattle. BCoV was first reported in Cuba in 2006. Since then there have been sporadic outbreaks. This study aimed to deepen the knowledge of the evolution, molecular markers of virulence and epidemiology of BCoV in Cuba. A total of 30 samples collected between 2009 and 2011 were used for PCR amplification and direct sequencing of the partial or full S gene. Sequence comparisons and phylogenetic studies have been performed using partial or full S gene sequences as phylogenetic markers. All Cuban bovine coronavirus sequences were in a single cluster, supported by 100% bootstrap and 1.00 posterior probability values. Cuban bovine coronavirus sequences have also been clustered with USA BCoV strains corresponding to GenBank accession numbers EF424621 and EF424623, suggesting a common origin for these viruses. This phylogenetic cluster was also the only group of sequences in which no recombination events were detected. Of the 45 amino acid changes found in the Cuban strains, four were unique. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: MartÃ­nez, N.;BrandÃ£o, P. E.;de Souza, S. P.;Barrera, M.;Santana, N.;de Arce, H. D.;PÃ©rez, L. J.

title: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus isolates vary in their susceptibility to neutralization
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is highly heterogeneous. This heterogeneity affects the antigenic composition of PRRSV and may result in differences in susceptibility to neutralization between isolates. Susceptibility to neutralization could be an important characteristic of PRRSV isolates, since neutralization-resistant isolates are likely to pose a significant challenge to the development of vaccines that elicit broad protective immunity. However, little information is available to understand or categorize the viral neutralization phenotype of PRRSV isolates. Consequently, the main purpose of this study was to determine whether PRRSV isolates differ in their susceptibility to neutralization and whether they can be classified into different categories based on their neutralization phenotype. For this purpose, a panel of 39 PRRSV isolates and a panel of 30 hyperimmune monospecific sera were used in cross-neutralization assays. The results of this study demonstrate that PRRSV isolates vary in their neutralization susceptibility, and the k-means cluster system allowed the isolates to be classified into four distinct categories according to their neutralization phenotype: highly susceptible, susceptible, moderately susceptible, and neutralization-resistant. Further analyzes with two other clustering systems, which considered individual data for the classification of the isolates, confirmed that the classification by k-means is correct in most cases and only less stringent in a few cases. Sequences of GP3, GP4 and GP5 were analyzed but no correlation could be found between the sequence of previously identified neutralizing epitopes or the number of N-linked glycosylation sites in different proteins and the neutralization phenotype of the isolates. These data provide the first systematic assessment of the overall neutralization susceptibility of a panel of different PRRSV isolates. Isolate classification provides a useful tool to facilitate the systematic characterization of neutralizing antibody production elicited by new vaccine candidates. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: MartÃ­nez-Lobo, F. J.;DÃ­ez-Fuertes, F.;Simarro, I.;Castro, J. M.;Prieto, C.

title: Whole genome sequencing of a rare rotavirus from an archived stool sample reveals an independent zoonotic origin of human G8P[14] strains in Hungary
abstract: Human genotype P[14] rotaviruses are thought to be zoonotic strains derived from bovine or ovine host species. Only a few strains of genotype P[14] have been identified in Hungary in the last 30 years, altogether <0.1% of all genotyped human rotaviruses. In this study, we report the genome sequence and phylogenetic analysis of a strain of human genotype G8P[14], RVA/Human-wt/HUN/182-02/2001/G8P[14]. The entire genome constellation (G8-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A11-N2-T6-E2-H3) of this strain was crossed with another Hungarian zoonotic G8P[14] strain, RVA/Human-wt, shared /HUN/BP1062/2004/G8P[14], although phylogenetic analyzes indicated that the two rotaviruses likely had different progenitors. Overall, our results indicate that the human G8P[14] rotavirus previously detected in Hungary originated from independent zoonotic events. Further studies are needed to assess the public health risk associated with infection from different animal rotavirus strains.
authors: Marton, S.;DÃ³rÃ³, R.;FehÃ©r, E.;ForrÃ³, B.;IhÃ¡sz, K.;Varga-Kugler, R.;Farkas, S. L.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Characterization of H9N2 influenza A virus isolated from chicken products imported to Japan from China
abstract: We characterized eleven H9N2 influenza A viruses isolated from chicken products imported from China. Genetically, they have been classified into six different genotypes, including five known genotypes and one new genotype. This suggested that such multiple genotypes of the H9N2 virus may already be widespread and have become endemic in China. Two isolates have amino acid substitutions conferring resistance to amantadine in the M2 region and this supported evidence that this mutation could be a result of the widespread use of amantadine to treat avian influenza in China. These results underscore the importance of surveillance of avian influenza virus in this region and quarantine of imported chicken products as potential sources of influenza virus introduction. © 2006 Cambridge University Press.
authors: Mase, M.;Eto, M.;K, I. Mai;Tsukamoto, K.;Yamaguchi, S.

title: Genetic diversity of avian infectious bronchitis viruses in Japan based on analysis of the S2 glycoprotein gene
abstract: To understand the genetic diversity of the S2 gene of infectious bronchitis viruses (IBV) isolated in Japan, we determined the nucleotide sequences of these IBVs using the reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction method coupled with direct sequencing. IBV isolated in Japan have been classified into six distinct groups by phylogenetic analysis based on the S2 gene. However, the classification based on the S2 gene of the IBV isolated in Japan differed for some of the strains from that obtained with our previous analysis of the S1 gene. This indicated that genetic recombination between virus strains classified into different genetic groups had occurred in poultry and that recombinant viruses might be epidemic in Japan.
authors: Mase, M.;Inoue, T.;Yamaguchi, S.;Imada, T.

title: Genetic comparison of H5N1 influenza A virus isolated from chickens in Japan and Korea
abstract: Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) caused by the H5N1 virus occurred in Korea and Japan in 2003-2004. The H5N1 viruses isolated in both countries were genetically similar with >99% identity in the nucleotide sequences of all eight RNA segments, suggesting that they belong to genotype V and differ from the HPAI viruses distributed in Southeast Asia, which belong to the genotype belong to Z. These results indicate that the H5N1 viruses that caused HPAI outbreaks in both Korea and Japan descended from a common ancestor.
authors: Mase, M.;Kim, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.;Tsukamoto, K.;Imada, T.;Imai, K.;Yamaguchi, S.

title: Analysis of the fusion protein gene of Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Japan
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequences of the fusion (F) protein gene of Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) isolated in Japan from 1930 to 2007 (total 45 strains) were determined and genetically analyzed. In the deduced amino acid sequences of the fusion protein, the 5 potential asparagine-linked glycosylation sites and 10 cysteine residues were all conserved in the NDV examined in this study. The major epitopes involved in virus neutralization are conserved in most of the NDV strains isolated in Japan, with the exception of a few strains. No major antigenic differences were observed between representative strains of each genotype in Japan in the virus neutralization test. All chickens vaccinated with the B1 strain survived without clinical signs after challenge with 2 NDV strains isolated in Japan (Velogen strains, JP/Ibaraki/2000 and JP/Kagoshima/91) which have amino acid substitutions involved in virus neutralization in the F protein gene involved.
authors: Mase, M.;Murayama, K.;Karino, A.;Inoue, T.

title: Viral metagenomics shows that domestic pigs are a potential reservoir for Ndumu virus
abstract: Background: The increasing demand for pork has led to a massive expansion of pig production in Uganda. This has led to increased contact between humans and pigs. Pigs can serve as a reservoir for emerging infectious diseases. Therefore, the identification of potential zoonotic agents is important for public health surveillance. In this study, domestic pigs from Uganda were screened for the presence of RNA and DNA viruses using a high-throughput pyrosequencing method during routine general surveillance for African swine fever. Results. Serum samples from 16 domestic pigs were collected from five regions of Uganda and pooled accordingly. Genomic DNA and RNA were extracted and sequenced on the 454 GS-FLX platform. Of the sequences assigned to a taxon, 53% were assigned to the domestic pig (Sus scrofa). African swine fever virus, torque tenoviruses (TTVs), and porcine endogenous retroviruses have been identified. Interestingly, two pools (B and C) of RNA origin had sequences that showed 98% sequence identity with Ndumu virus (NDUV). None of the reads were identical to the class Insecta, suggesting that these sequences are unlikely to result from contamination with mosquito nucleic acids. Conclusions: This is the first report of the domestic pig as a vertebrate host for Ndumu virus. NDUV had previously only been isolated from Culicine mosquitoes. NDUV therefore represents a potential zoonotic agent, especially given the increasing risk of human-livestock-mosquito contact. © 2012 Masembe et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Masembe, C.;Michuki, G.;Onyango, M.;Rumberia, C.;Norling, M.;Bishop, R. P.;Djikeng, A.;Kemp, S. J.;Orth, A.;Skilton, R. A.;StÃ¥hl, K.;Fischer, A.

title: The molecular biology of the swinepox virus. II. The cycle of infection
abstract: Studies based on low-stringency hybridizations of radiolabeled swinepoxvirus (SPV) DNA to Southern blots containing DNA from representative members of the genera Orthopoxvirus, Leporipoxvirus, and Avipoxvirus and the Entomopoxvirus subfamily have revealed no DNA homology at this level of resolution. Antigenic relatedness between SPV and vaccinia was also analyzed using immunoprecipitations and showed little if any cross-reactivity. The growth characteristics of SPV in tissue culture were examined by light microscopy and revealed both delayed and different cytopathology from that of vaccinia virus. SPV causes foci in pig kidney cells that are not evident until at least 4 days after infection, while vaccinia rapidly forms plaques on these cells. The kinetics of SPV DNA accumulation, protein expression, and RNA transcription have been examined and indicate that each of these facets of the SPV growth cycle is also significantly retarded compared to vaccinia virus. Our data show that swinepoxvirus is unique from other poxviruses characterized to date and supports the classification of swinepoxvirus into a separate genus, suipoxvirus, within the poxvirus family.
authors: Massung, R. F.;Moyer, R. W.

title: Identification of novel bovine rotavirus strain G15P[14] group A from animal disease diarrhea of adult cows by de novo sequencing with a next-generation sequencer
abstract: There are few reports describing diarrhea in adult cattle caused by group A rotavirus. Here we report the identification of a novel group A bovine rotavirus from diarrhea in adult cows. A group A rotavirus was detected in an epizootic outbreak of diarrhea in adult cows with a decline in milk production in Japan in 2013. The extensive genomic analyzes of fecal samples by viral metagenomics using a next-generation sequencer revealed that it had an unreported genotype combination G15P[14]. The genome constellation of this strain, namely RVA/Cow-wt/JPN/Tottori-SG/2013/G15P[14], was G15-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A3-N2-T6-E2-H3 represents VP7-VP4-VP6-VP1-VP2-VP3-NSP1-NSP2-NSP3-NSP4-NSP5, respectively. Each gene segment of Tottori-SG was most closely related to group A rotaviruses of Japanese cattle, suggesting that Tottori-SG may originate from multiple reassortment events of group A rotavirus strains circulating among Japanese cattle. No other diarrheal pathogen in adult cattle was detected by routine diagnostics and metagenomics. Viral metagenomics using a next-generation sequencer is useful to characterize group A rotavirus from stool samples and provides unbiased comprehensive studies of pathogens. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Masuda, T.;Nagai, M.;Yamasato, H.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishiura, N.;Sassa, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Koyama, S.;Shirai, J.;Taniguchi, K.;Fujii, Y.;Todaka, R.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of a novel picornavirus related to the enterovirus/sapelovirus supergroup from pig feces in Japan
abstract: novel virus related to the enterovirus/sapelovirus supergroup in the family Picornaviridae was identified in healthy pig feces in Japan using a metagenomic approach. The genome of the virus, named Sapelo-like Porcine Picornavirus Japan (SPPVJ) Pig/Isi-Im1/JPN/2016, had an internal ribosomal type IV entry site and carried a 6978 nucleotide single open reading frame encoding a 2326 amino acid (aa) Polyprotein precursor. The coding sequence region consisted of leader protein (68 aa), a structural protein region P1 (824 aa), and non-structural protein regions P2 (672 aa) and P3 (762 aa). Among the representative picornaviruses, the P1, 2C and 3CD regions of SPPVJ had the highest aa identities of 64.4%, 61.9% and 73.3%, respectively, with the corresponding regions of the sapelo-like bat picornavirus BtVs -PicoV/SC2013. Sequence analysis of the RT-PCR products derived from the 5'-untranslated and 3D regions revealed the presence of SPPVJ in 17.8% (19/107) of faeces from healthy pigs and pigs with diarrhea in 12 farms in the years 2015-2016. Further studies are needed to determine the origin and pathogenic potential of SPPJV in pigs and other mammals.
authors: Masuda, T.;Sunaga, F.;Naoi, Y.;Ito, M.;Takagi, H.;Katayama, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Oba, M.;Sakaguchi, S.;Furuya, T.;Yamasato, H.;Shirai, J.;Makino, S.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Genomic integration of the lambda EG10 transgene in gpt-delta transgenic rodents
abstract: Background: Transgenic gpt-delta mouse and rat models have been developed to perform gpt and Spi assays for in vivo mutagenicity testing. The animals were established by integrating lambda EG10 phage DNA as a transgene into the genome. The inserted position of the transgene on the chromosome was determined by fluorescence in situ hybridization and Southern blot analyses; however, the exact position and sequence of the inserted compound were not known. To identify the site and pattern of genomic integration of the transgene copies, genomic DNAs extracted from C57BL/6J gpt delta mice and F344 gpt delta rats were applied to whole genome sequencing and partnered pair analysis. Results: The result confirmed that multi-copy lambda EG10 transgenes are inserted at a single position in mouse chromosome 17. The junction contains 70 bp of overlapping genomic sequences and shares short homology at both ends. Copy number analysis suggested that the inserted transgenes might contain 41 head-to-tail junctions and 16 junctions of other types, such as rearranged abnormal junctions. It suggested that the number of intact copies could be a maximum of about 40. In the F344 gpt delta rats, transgenes are inserted at a single position in rat chromosome 4. The junction contains no overlapping sequence, but a 72 kb genomic sequence, including a gene, has been deleted. The inserted transgenes may contain 15 head-to-tail junctions and two rearranged junctions. It has been suggested that the number of intact copies could be a maximum of 14. A germline base substitution in the gpt gene derived from gpt-delta rats has been characterized. Conclusions: The exact inserted positions of the lambda EG10 transgene in the genome of gpt-delta transgenic rodents have been identified. Transgene copy number and location were analyzed. PCR primers for rapid genotyping of gpt delta mice and rats were developed.
authors: Masumura, K.;Sakamoto, Y.;Kumita, W.;Honma, M.;Nishikawa, A.;Nohmi, T.

title: A new duck circovirus sequence detected in the velvet duck (Melanitta fusca) supports the high diversity of this virus species
abstract: Background: The aim of this study was to investigate the presence of circoviruses in wild bird populations in Poland. Circoviruses possess immunosuppressive properties and can affect the health of wild birds. Method: 83 birds belonging to 23 species were tested by wide-range nested PCR. The resulting PCR products were sequenced and new primers designed to analyze the full-length viral genome. A phylogenetic analysis was performed to find a relationship to known circoviruses. Results: The circovirus DNA sequence was found in 4 birds. All samples were from the velvet duck (Melanitta fusca), a sea duck from the subfamily Merginae. Birds that tested positive for the circovirus have been found dead in fishing nets off the Baltic Sea coast. At autopsy, the carcasses of two scoters showed only slight emaciation, while the other two birds appeared healthy. The full-length circovirus sequence obtained showed 1,988 nucleotides and the presence of typical features (ie Cap, Rep and ORF3). The nucleotide similarity with other duck circoviruses was 84 to 86%. Phylogenetic analysis of the full genome and cap gene showed that the new circovirus is related to known duck circoviruses, specifically to subtypes sometimes referred to as duck circovirus genotype 1 but not genotype 2. Conclusions: In In this study, we reported a new duck circovirus sequence detected in the velvet duck, a species of sea duck. Sequence comparison and phylogenetic analysis of the novel virus sequence supports previous reports that duck circovirus (DuCV) is a species with a high degree of diversity. The virus sequence obtained from the velvet duck suggests that DuCV can infect birds from the Anatinae subfamily. Further studies are needed to prove whether the velvet duck and other sea ducks act as a reservoir for DuCV.
authors: Matczuk, A. K.;Krawiec, M.;Wieliczko, A.

title: African horse sickness virus serotype 4 B-cell epitopes recognized by immune equine sera
abstract: The identification of antigenic proteins and the mapping of their epitopes is important for the development of diagnostic reagents and recombinant vaccines. African horse disease virus (AHSV) B-cell epitopes have previously been mapped to VP2, VP5, VP7 and NS1 using mouse, rabbit and chicken monoclonal antibodies. A comprehensive study of the humoral immune response of five vaccinated horses to AHSV-4 antigenic peptides was performed. A fragmented genome phage display library was constructed that expresses a repertoire of AHSV-4 peptides spanning the entire genome. The library was affinity selected for binding to immobilized polyclonal immunoglobulin G (IgG) isolated from horse serum collected before and after immunization with an attenuated monovalent AHSV-4 vaccine. The DNA insert-binding phage were sequenced using Illumina high-throughput sequencing. Data were normalized using preimmune IgG selected sequences. More sequences have been assigned to the genes encoding NS3, VP6 and VP5 than to the other genes. However, VP2 and VP5 each had more antigenic regions than any of the other proteins. This study identified a number of epitopes to which the equine humoral immune system responds during immunization with AHSV-4.
authors: Mathebula, E. M.;Faber, F. E.;Van Wyngaardt, W.;Van Schalkwyk, A.;Pretorius, A.;Fehrsen, J.

title: The human parvovirus 4 "PARV4" remains elusive despite decades of studies
abstract: Human parvovirus 4 ('PARV4') is a small DNA tetraparvovirus that was first reported in 2005. In some populations, PARV4 infection is uncommon and evidence of exposure is found only in individuals with risk factors for parenteral infection associated with other blood-borne viruses. In other settings, seroprevalence studies suggest an endemic, age-associated transmission pattern, independent of specific risk factors. The clinical implications of PARV4 infection remain uncertain, but reported disease associations include influenza-like syndrome, encephalitis, accelerated HIV disease and hydrops fetalis. In this review, we aim to report progress updates from the recent literature, focusing on examining cohorts in different geographic settings, now including insights from Asia, the Middle East, and South America, and discussing whether attributes of virus or host populations are present underpin the striking differences in epidemiology. We review advances in understanding viral phylogeny and biology, diagnostic approaches, and insights that could be gained from studies of closely related animal pathogens. Critical questions about pathogenicity remain unanswered, but we highlight new evidence supporting a possible association between PARV4 and encephalitis syndrome. The unequivocal evidence that PARV4 is endemic in certain populations should fuel ongoing research efforts to understand risk factors and modes of transmission, and to provide new insights into the impact of this virus on human health.
authors: Matthews, P. C.;Sharp, C.;Simmonds, P.;Klenerman, P.

title: Complete genome-based classification of rotaviruses reveals a common origin between human wa-like and porcine rotavirus strains and human DS-1-like and bovine rotavirus strains
abstract: The group A rotavirus classification is currently based on the molecular properties of the two outer layer proteins, VP7 and VP4, and the middle layer protein, VP6. Because the rearrangement of all 11 rotavirus gene segments plays a key role in generating rotavirus diversity in nature, a classification system based on all rotavirus gene segments is desirable to determine which genes control rotavirus restriction, replication, and virulence. affect the host range, such as for the study of rotavirus epidemiology and evolution. To establish such a classification system, gene sequences encoding VP1 to VP3, VP6 and NSP1 to NSP5 were determined for human and animal rotavirus strains belonging to different G and P genotypes in addition to those available in databases and they have been used to phylogenetically define relationships between all rotavirus genes. Based on these phylogenetic analyses, appropriate identity cutoff values were determined for each gene. For the VP4 gene, a nucleotide identity cutoff of 80% fully correlated with the 27 established P genotypes. For the VP7 gene, an 80% nucleotide identity cutoff was broadly consistent with the established G genotypes, but identified four additional distinct genotypes consisting of murine or avian rotavirus strains.
