Phylogenetic analyzes of genes VP1 to VP3, VP6 and NSP1 to NSP5 revealed the existence of 4, 5, 6, 11, 14, 5, 7, 11 and 6 genotypes, respectively, based on nucleotide identity cutoff values of 83%, 84% , 81%, 85%, 79%, 85%, 85%, 85% and 91%, respectively. In accordance with these data, a revised nomenclature of rotavirus strains is proposed. The novel classification system allows for the identification of (i) distinct genotypes that likely followed separate evolutionary paths; (ii) interspecies transmissions and a plethora of rearrangement events; and (iii) certain gene constellations showing (a) a common origin between human Wa-like rotavirus strains and porcine rotavirus strains and (b) a common origin between human DS-1-like rotavirus strains and bovine rotaviruses . These close evolutionary links between human and animal rotaviruses underscore the need for close simultaneous surveillance of animal and human rotaviruses. Copyright © 2008, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Matthijnssens, J.;Ciarlet, M.;Heiman, E.;Arijs, I.;Delbeke, T.;McDonald, S. M.;Palombo, E. A.;Iturriza-GÃ³mara, M.;Maes, P.;Patton, J. T.;Rahman, M.;Van Ranst, M.

title: Complete molecular genome analyzes of equine rotavirus strains from different continents reveal several new genotypes and a largely conserved genotype constellation
abstract: In this study, the complete genome sequences of seven equine group A rotavirus (RVA) strains (RVA/Horse-tc/GBR/L338/1991/G13P[18], RVA/Horse-wt/IRL/03V04954/2003/G3P[ 12] and RVA/Horse-wt/IRL/04V2024/2004/G14P[12] from Europe, RVA/Horse-wt/ARG/E30/1993/G3P[12], RVA/Horse-wt/ARG/E403/2006 /G14P[12] and RVA/Horse-wt/ARG/E4040/2008/G14P[12] from Argentina and RVA/Horse-wt/ZAF/EqRV-SA1/2006/G14P[12] from South Africa). Several new genotypes were identified and genotype numbers assigned by the Rotavirus Classification Working Group: R9 (VP1), C9 (VP2), N9 (NSP2), T12 (NSP3), E14 (NSP4), and H7 and H11 (NSP5). The L338 genotype constellation was unique: G13-P[18]-I6-R9-C9-M6-A6-N9-T12-E14-H11. The six remaining RVA horse strains showed a largely conserved genotype constellation: G3/G14-P[12]-I2/I6-R2-C2-M3-A10-N2-T3-E2/E12-H7, which differs greatly from others not known -equine RVA genotype constellations. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that the sequences of these equine RVA strains are distantly related to non-equine RVA strains and that at least three lineages exist within equine RVA strains. A small number of reassortment events were observed. Interestingly, the three RVA strains from Argentina possessed the E12 genotype, while the three RVA strains from Ireland and South Africa possessed the E2 genotype. The unusual E12 genotype has previously only been described in Argentina among RVA strains collected from guanaco, cattle and horses, suggesting a geographic isolation of this NSP4 genotype. This conserved genetic configuration of equine RVA strains could be useful for future vaccine development or improvement of currently used equine RVA vaccines. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Matthijnssens, J.;MiÃ±o, S.;Papp, H.;Potgieter, C.;Novo, L.;Heylen, E.;Zeller, M.;Garaicoechea, L.;Badaracco, A.;Lengyel, G.;Kisfali, P.;Cullinane, A.;Collins, P. J.;Ciarlet, M.;O'Shea, H.;ParreÃ±o, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Barrandeguy, M.;van Ranst, M.

title: Pathogenic properties of six bovine picornavirus isolates in mice
abstract: Six bovine picornavirus isolates were classified by mouse pathogenicity. Of the 6 isolates, 4 (6727 nm, 4155 nm, 3039 and 7109) produced lesions and 3 (6727 nm, 4155 nm and 3039) caused death in lactating mice. Microscopic lesions included necrosis in the brain, heart, lung, liver and kidney. A correlation was found between mouse pathogenicity and haemagglutination, suggesting that properties of haemagglutination may be helpful in classifying picornaviruses.
authors: Mattson, J. M.;Vorhies, M. W.;Reed, D. E.

title: Cowpox Virus: What's in a Name?
abstract: Traditionally, viral taxonomy has relied on phenotypic traits, however, sequence-based viral taxonomy has become imperative since a species has recently been required to exhibit monophyly. The cowpox virus species did not meet this requirement, necessitating a re-examination of this species. Here we report the genomic sequences of nine vaccinia viruses and, by combining them with the available data from 37 additional genomes, confirm vaccinia virus polyphysis and find statistical support based on genetic data for more than a dozen species. These results are discussed in light of the current species definition of the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses and the immediate and future implications for smallpox virus taxonomic classification schemes. The data support the recognition of five monophyletic groups of vaccinia viruses as valid species.
authors: Mauldin, M. R.;Antwerpen, M.;Emerson, G. L.;Li, Y.;Zoeller, G.;Carroll, D. S.;Meyer, H.

title: Investigating the molecular evolution and epidemiological relationships of Newcastle disease virus isolates from 1995 to 2016 in Iran
abstract: In the case of Newcastle disease virus, it has been suggested that multiple factors such as host adaptation, evasion of the immune response, and selective pressure lead to the evolution of viruses and the emergence of genetic variants. Several studies on virus classification and global epidemiological relationships have provided consistent data. Here we conducted a molecular analysis study on circulating Newcastle disease viruses in Iran (1995-2016). According to evolutionary divergences, isolates of the subgenotypes VIg, VIj, VIIj, VIId, XIIIa and XIIId have been circulating in the country for 21 years. Based on data analysis, VIg isolates shared the highest sequence identity with Russian and Polish VIg subgenotype isolates, while VIj subgenotype isolates (2012) were most similar to a virus isolated in 2015 in India. Analysis of the evolutionary divergence of the VIIj subgenotype suggests that Chinese and Ukrainian viruses may have played a crucial role in the emergence of VIIj isolates. Studies on evolutionary differences also indicated that XIIIa isolates circulating in Iran may have caused the emergence of adapted variants of subgenotype XIIId. Therefore, we propose that the evolutionary and epidemiological study of virulent Newcastle disease viruses could help provide accurate molecular data on variants circulating in the region, thus aiding the development of more efficient recombinant vaccines.
authors: Mayahi, V.;Esmaelizad, M.

title: Protective efficacy of a recombinant bacterial artificial chromosomal clone of a highly virulent Marek's disease virus containing a long terminal repeat of reticuloendothelosis virus
abstract: Marek's disease virus (MDV), an alphaherpesvirus, causes Marek's disease (MD), a lymphoproliferative disorder in poultry characterized by T-cell lymphoma, nerve lesions, and mortality. Vaccination is used worldwide to control MD, but increasingly virulent field strains can overcome this protection, necessitating the development of new vaccines. Previous studies showed that insertion of the reticuloendothelosis virus (REV) long terminal repeat (LTR) into a bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clone of a highly virulent MDV strain, Md5, resulted in a recombinant virus, rMd5 REV-LTR BAC fully attenuated in maternal antibody-positive (Mab+) chickens at passage 40. In the current study, the protective efficacy of rMd5 REV-LTR BAC was evaluated. First, passage 70 was identified as being fully attenuated in maternal antibody-negative chickens and selected as the optimal passage level for use in protective studies. Second, three protective efficacy studies were conducted comparing the rMd5 REV-LTR p70 BAC to the CVI988/rispens vaccine. Groups of Mab+ and Mab 15I5-71 chickens were vaccinated in ovo 18 days after embryonation or intra-abdominal on the day of hatch and challenged with vv+MDV strain 686 5 days after hatch. Vaccination on the day of hatch and in ovo with rMd5 REV-LTR p70 BAC protected chickens from MDV-induced bursal and thymic atrophy but did not provide the same level of protection against MD tumors as provided by the commercial vaccine CVI988/rispens .
authors: Mays, J. K.;Black-Pyrkosz, A.;Spatz, S.;Fadly, A. M.;Dunn, J. R.

title: Comparison of sample sequences of the Salmonella typhi genome with the sequence of the complete Escherichia coli K-12 genome
abstract: Raw sequence data representing the bulk of a bacterial genome can be obtained at a tiny fraction of the cost of a full sequence. To demonstrate the utility of such a resource, 870 single-stranded M13 clones from a shotgun library of the Salmonella typhi Ty2 genome were sequenced. The sequence reads over 400 bases on average and the genome was scanned at an average spacing of once every 5,000 bases. A total of 339,243 unique sequence bases were generated (about 7% representation). The sample of 870 sequences was compared to the full genome of Escherichia coli K-12 and the rest of the GenBank database, which can also be viewed as a collection of sequence samples. Despite the incomplete S. typhi data set, interesting categories could be easily identified. Sixteen percent of the sequences determined from S. typhi had close homologues among known Salmonella sequences (P < 1e-40 in BlastX or BlastN), reflecting the proportion of these genomes that had previously been sequenced; 277 sequences (32%) had no apparent orthologs in the complete E. coli K-12 genome (P > 1e-20), of which 155 sequences (18%) did not show high similarity to any sequence in the database (P > 1e -5). Eight of the 277 sequences shared similarities with genes in other strains of E. coli or plasmids, and six sequences showed evidence of new phage lysogens or sequence residues from phage integrations, including a member of the lambda family (P<1e-15). Twenty-three sample sequences had significantly greater similarity to a sequence in the database from organisms other than the E. coli/Salmonella clade (which includes Shigella and Citrobacter). These sequences are novel candidates for lateral transfer events on the S. typhi lineage or deletions on the E. coli K-12 lineage. Eleven putative junctions of insertion/deletion events greater than 100 bp were observed in the sample, indicating that well over 150 such events can distinguish S. typhi from E. coli K-12. The need for automated methods to use sample sequences more effectively is discussed.
authors: McClelland, M.;Wilson, R. K.

title: Evaluation of cells and biological reagents for adventitious agents using degenerate primer PCR and massively parallel sequencing
abstract: We used a massively parallel sequencing (MPS)-based approach to test reagents and model cell substrates including Chinese hamster ovary (CHO), Madin-Darby dog kidney (MDCK), African green monkey (Vero) kidney, and high- Five random agent insect cell lines. RNA and DNA were extracted either directly from the samples or from viral capsid-enriched preparations and then subjected to MPS-based non-specific virus detection using degenerate oligonucleotide primer (DOP)-PCR. MPS by 454, Illumina MiSeq, and Illumina HiSeq were compared to independent samples. Virus detection with these methods was achieved reproducibly. Unclassified sequences from CHO cells represented cellular sequences that have not yet been submitted to the databases typically used for sequence identification. The sensitivity of MPS-based virus detection corresponded to theoretically expected limits based on the dilution of virus in cellular nucleic acids. The capsid preparation increased the number of viral sequences detected. Potential viral sequences were detected in several samples; in each case, these sequences were either artificial or (based on additional studies) shown not to be associated with replication competent viruses. Virus-like sequences were more likely to be identified in BLAST searches using virus-specific databases that did not contain cellular sequences. Viral sequences detected included previously described retrovirus and retrovirus-like sequences in CHO, Vero, MDCK and High Five cells, as well as nodavirus and endogenous bracovirus sequences in High Five insect cells. Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus, Bovine Hocovirus, and Porcine Circovirus sequences have been detected in some reagents. A recently described Parvo-like virus present in some nucleic acid extraction resins was also identified in cells and extraction controls from some samples. The present study helps to illustrate the potential of MPS-based strategies in assessing the presence of viral nucleic acids in different sample types, including cell culture substrates and vaccines.
authors: McClenahan, S. D.;Uhlenhaut, C.;Krause, P. R.

title: Disruption of cytokine networks by poxviruses - lessons from the myxoma virus
abstract: Myxomavirus is an infectious poxvirus agent that induces a virulent systemic disease called myxomatosis in European rabbits. The disease is rapidly and uniformly fatal in susceptible rabbits and is characterized by generalized dysfunction in cellular immunity and multiple disruptions in the host cytokine network. Viral genes are classified as virulence factors because viral constructs carrying targeted gene disruptions induce attenuated disease symptoms. Many of these genes encode proteins that directly interact with effector elements of the host immune system. These immunosubversive viral proteins include secreted mimetics of host ligands or regulators (virokines) and homologues of cellular cytokine receptors (viroceptors). Five examples of these myxomavirus-encoded immunomodulator proteins are reviewed: (1) myxoma growth factor, a member of the epidermal growth factor ligand superfamily; (2) SERF-1, a secreted serine proteinase inhibitor; (3) M11L, a receptor-like surface protein; (4) T2, a tumor necrosis factor receptor homologue; and (5) T7, an interferon gamma receptor homologue. The origin of viral strategies designed to subvert immune regulation by host cytokines is considered in the context of myxomavirus biology in immunocompetent hosts.
authors: McFadden, G.;Graham, K.;Ellison, K.;Barry, M.;Macen, J.;Schreiber, M.;Mossman, K.;Nash, P.;Lalani, A.;Everett, H.

title: Sequence analysis of the S1 glycoprotein-encoding gene of New Zealand infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains
abstract: Four new strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) (T6, K32, K43 and K87) have been isolated from clinically infected chickens in New Zealand. These strains were compared to four strains (A, B, C, and D) circulating 25 years previously by sequencing the gene encoding the S1 subunit of the spike glycoprotein. Analysis of the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences revealed that the eight strains from New Zealand are genetically related, sharing more than 82.8% nucleotide and 79% amino acid homology within the S1 region. Strains T6, K43 and K87 were more than 99% homologous to previously described strains C and D. A fourth new strain (K32) was most closely related to the previously described B strain. The phylogenetic analysis of the tribes revealed that New Zealand tribes were more closely related to Australian than European or North American tribes. The New Zealand A strain shared 99.5% nucleotide and 98.7% amino acid homology with the Australian Vic S strain. The deduced amino acid sequence of the S1 glycoprotein showed differences between strains that were generally consistent with virus neutralization patterns. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: McFarlane, R.;Verma, R.

title: Tracing the origins of Louping III virus through molecular phylogenetic analysis
abstract: The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of Louping III (LI) virus isolates collected from representative regions of the British Isles and Norway were determined for either the entire envelope gene (20 isolates) or for a portion of the envelope gene encompassing a hypervariable Region and contains a LI virus specific marker sequence (53 isolates). Phylogenetic analysis shows the presence of three major geographic populations of LI virus in the British Isles viz. Irish, Welsh and British LI viruses, all of which cause encephalomyelitis in animals, mainly sheep, and are found in the same tick population. British LI virus is found throughout Scotland, England, Ireland and Norway. Irish and Welsh LI viruses are only found in Ireland and Wales respectively. Phylogenetic analysis also predicts that LI virus originated in Ireland and that a descendant was introduced into Britain via Wales and then transported to the borders of Scotland, from where it was spread throughout Scotland, northern England and Norway. British LI virus has recently been reintroduced to Ireland and also to the south-west of England. Lineage data calculated from the synonymous substitution rate indicate that LI virus appeared in the British Isles less than 800 years ago and most of the LI virus spread occurred in the last 300 years. By combining this data with historical records, it appears that livestock movements may be linked to the spread of LI virus.
authors: McGuire, K.;Holmes, E. C.;Gao, G. F.;Reid, H. W.;Gould, E. A.

title: Type-specific antigenicity of avian reoviruses
abstract: The type specificity of the neutralizing activity in chicken antiserum against avian reoviruses was influenced by the method of antiserum preparation. The neutralizing activity produced in response to viral infection had a higher type specificity than that produced by immunization with inactivated virus emulsified in an adjuvant. Using reassortant viruses, it has been shown that induction of a type-specific neutralizing activity is associated with the virion protein Sigma C (sigmaC). An antigenic classification of virus strains based on immunoprecipitation of the sigmaC protein by chicken antiserum was attempted and the results were similar to those obtained by reciprocal serum neutralization tests. A one-way immunoprecipitation of sigmaC protein by antisera against some heterologous viruses, similar to that reported in reciprocal neutralization assays, complicated the assignment of individual viruses to serogroups and indicated that the type specificity of sigmaC protein was not absolute. The neutralizing activity of monoclonal antibodies against the sigmaC protein of the RAM1 strain of avian reovirus suggested that there were separate type- and group-specific antigenic domains on the sigmaC protein and that the group-specific domains might be associated with the induction of antibodies against heterologous viruses.
authors: Meanger, J.;Wickramasinghe, R.;Enriquez, C. E.;Robertson, M. D.;Wilcox, G. E.

title: Canine distemper virus infection in a small community (Galictis cuja): first report and virus pedigree
abstract: Megid J, Teixeira CR, Cortez A, Heinemann MB, Antunes JMAP, Fornazari F, Rassy FB & Richtzenhaim LJ 2013. Canine distemper virus infection in a smaller Graubünden (Galictis cuja): first report and virus pedigree. Pesquisa Veterinaria Brasileira 33(2):247-250. Departamento de Higiene Veterinaria e Saude Publica, Faculdade de Medicina Veterinariae Zootecnia, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Distrito de Rubiao Jr s/n, Botucatu, SP 18618-970, Brazil. Email: jane@fmvz.unesp.br Infectious diseases in wild animals are increasing due to habitat changes and closer contact with domestic animals. Canine distemper virus (CDV) has been reported in several species of wild carnivores and poses a threat to species conservation. We have described the first case of canine distemper virus infection in Graubünden (Galictis cuja). A free-ranging individual with no visible clinical signs died suddenly after one day in captivity. Molecular diagnosis of CDV infection was performed using whole blood collected by postmortem intracardiac puncture, which was positive. Virus phylogeny suggested that domestic dogs were the likely source of infection.
authors: Megid, J.;Teixeira, C. R.;Cortez, A.;Heinemann, M. B.;Antunes, Jmap;Fornazari, F.;Rassy, F. B.;Richtzenhain, L. J.

title: Localization of VZV in the saliva of zoster patients
abstract: Varicella zoster virus (VZV) in the saliva of six herpes zoster patients and one chickenpox patient was found exclusively associated with epithelial cells using confocal microscopy. VZV localization with antibodies specific for VZV glycoprotein E has been detected mainly on the membrane but also within the cell. One in two zoster patients tested still had VZV epithelial cells in their saliva after 10 months of recovery. Saliva from healthy controls (patients without shingles, n=5) showed no evidence of VZV by polymerase chain reaction or by confocal microscopy. No VZV was found in the liquid fraction of the saliva. Further work is needed to understand the movement of VZV in the salivary cells of infected patients.
authors: Mehta, S. K.;Nelman-Gonzalez, M.;Tyring, S. K.;Tong, Y.;Beitman, A.;Crucian, B. E.;Renner, A. N.;Pierson, D. L.

title: Antibody titers against bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) in bulk milk samplers from Bavaria, Germany
abstract: total of 5204 bulk milk samples were tested for antibodies against Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV), which is classified according to the Alenius scheme. 45% of the samples from 2002 were classified in class 0 and class 1, 55% in class 2 and 3. Of 6420 bulk milk samples from 1997 in an independent study 65.6% were in class 0 and 1 and 34.4 % classified. in class 2 and 3. In class 0 and class 1 farms, persistent viremic animals were found only very rarely, while in class 2 and 3 their presence is very likely. Our studies with unselected sera have defined serological screening of bulk milk samples as a promising tool for a possible BVDV eradication program in Bavaria.
authors: Meier, N.;Meier, B.;Banzhaf, K.;Wittkowski, G.;Schmitt, D.;Truyen, U.

title: Molecular epidemiological study and phylogenetic analysis of bovine influenza D virus in Japan
abstract: Influenza D virus, a new member of the Orthomyxoviridae family, is predominantly found in cattle. Although viral pathology and clinical disease appear mild in cattle, this virus plays an important role as a causative agent of bovine respiratory disease (FRD). BRD is a costly disease worldwide. Therefore, epidemiological surveys of the influenza D virus are necessary. Here we conducted a molecular epidemiological study for influenza D virus in healthy and respiratory diseased cattle in Japan. We found that 2.1% (8/377) of cattle were infected with influenza D. The cattle with and without respiratory symptoms had approximately equal virus levels. A complete genome sequence analysis revealed that the influenza D virus isolated in Japan formed an individual cluster distinct from the strains found in other countries. These results suggest that this virus may have evolved uniquely in Japan over a long period of time and that the viral pathology of Japanese strains may differ from strains found in other countries. Continuous surveillance is required to determine the importance of this virus and to characterize its evolution.
authors: Mekata, H.;Yamamoto, M.;Hamabe, S.;Tanaka, H.;Omatsu, T.;Mizutani, T.;Hause, B. M.;Okabayashi, T.

title: The discovery of enteroviruses and the classification of poliovirus among them
abstract: The history of enteroviruses is described and how poliovirus was recognized as the prototype of the genus, a subgroup of the Picornaviridae family. Albert Sabin was one of the main people responsible. He isolated several enterovirus types and established them as causative agents of human diseases. Enteroviruses were discovered only after new methods of working with viruses were introduced. They are now recognized as one of the genera of the picornavirus family. Pico-rna-virus stands for viruses that are small (pico) and have an RNA genome. The enterovirus genus includes the polioviruses, the coxsackieviruses and the echoviruses of humans as well as a number of enteroviruses of lower animals (e.g. monkeys, cattle, pigs, mice). Over 100 serotypes have now been identified, the first being the poliovirus.
authors: Melnick, J. L.

title: Phylogenetic classification and clinical aspects of a new putative delta papillomavirus associated with skin lesions in cattle
abstract: Bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) are thought to cause benign and malignant tumors in cattle. Thirteen species of BPVs have been described and classified into three different genera. Divergences in the nucleotide sequence of the L1 gene are used to identify new virus types through the use of degenerate primer PCR assays. In the present study, a method for identifying BPVs based on PCR-RFLP and DNA sequencing enabled the identification of a new putative delta papillomavirus designated JN/3SP (JQ280500.1). Analysis of the L1 gene showed that this strain was most closely related to BPVs -1, -2, -13 and OaPV1 (71-73% genetic similarity). In this study we describe the detection of this new putative delta papillomavirus type and verify its phylogenetic position within the genus. © FUNPEC-RP.
authors: Melo, T. C.;Carvalho, R. F.;Mazzucchelli-de-Souza, J.;Diniz, N.;Vasconcelos, S.;Assaf, S. L. M. R.;Araldi, R. P.;Ruiz, R. M.;Kerkis, I.;BeÃ§ak, W.;Stocco, R. C.

title: Whole genome sequencing and biological characterization of Duck/JS/10, a novel lentogenic class I virus of Newcastle disease
abstract: lentogenic Newcastle disease (NDV) virus, Duck/JS/10 (JS10), was isolated from an unvaccinated duck in China. The full genome of the virus contained 15,198 nucleotides. Based on the length of the genome and a partial sequence of the F gene, the virus was classified as class I genotype 4 NDV. The antigenicity of the virus was compared to that of the NDV strain La Sota via hemagglutination inhibition (HI), virus neutralization test (VN) and animal experiments. Our results show that JS10 produces higher HI and VN titers than La Sota against virulent NDV class I and II strains. Animal studies show that virus shedding of chickens vaccinated with JS10 is significantly reduced compared to chickens vaccinated with La Sota. Overall, this study strongly suggests that JS10 could qualify as a new vaccine candidate against Newcastle disease. © 2012 Springer Verlag.
authors: Meng, C.;Qiu, X.;Jin, S.;Yu, S.;Chen, H.;Ding, C.

title: Potential of Newcastle disease genotype VII viruses to cause differential infections in chickens and ducks
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND), caused by ND virus (NDV), is one of the most contagious and economically significant diseases affecting the poultry industry worldwide. While infections have been reported in a variety of bird species, the pathogenicity of virulent chicken NDV isolates in ducks remains elusive. In this study, two strains of NDV were isolated from an outbreak in chickens and apparently healthy ducks and characterized biologically and genetically. Pathogenicity assessment indices, including mean time of death (MDT), intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), and cleavage motifs in the fusion protein (F), indicated that both isolates were velogenic in nature. Interestingly, while these isolates exhibited pathogenic properties, they displayed differential pathogenicity in ducks. The chicken-derived isolate caused high (70%) mortality, while the duck-derived virus caused low (20%) mortality in 4-week-old ducks. Interestingly, both isolates showed comparable disease pathologies in chickens. Complete genome sequence analysis showed that the viral genome contains 15,192 nucleotides and exhibits features characteristic of velogenic NDV strains. A phylogenetic analysis revealed that both isolates clustered in class II and genotype VII. However, there were multiple mutations in the functionally important regions of the fusion (F) and hemagglutinin neuraminidase (HN) proteins that may account for the differential pathogenicity of these viruses in ducks. Taken together, these results suggest that NDV strains with the same genotype show different pathogenicity in chickens and ducks. In addition, virulent NDVs derived from chickens are more pathogenic to ducks than viruses derived from ducks. These results suggest that chickens play a role in the development of viral pathogenicity and potential genetic resistance of ducks to avian viruses.
authors: Meng, C.;Rehman, Z. U.;Liu, K.;Qiu, X.;Tan, L.;Sun, Y.;Liao, Y.;Song, C.;Yu, S.;Ding, Z.;Nair, V.;Munir, M.;Ding, C.

title: Viroma analysis of tick-borne viruses in Heilongjiang Province, China
abstract: Ticks are involved in the transmission of various human and animal pathogens worldwide. This study aimed to understand the geographic distribution of tick species along with tick-associated viruses in Heilongjiang Province, northeast China. Molecular methods were used to classify tick species, using next-generation sequencing and polymerase chain reaction-based analysis to assess tick viromes from four representative sampling sites in the Greater Khingan Mountains. Five species of Ixodid ticks have been identified, including Ixodes persulcatus, Dermacentor nuttalli, Dermacentor silvarum, Haemaphysalis longicornis, and Haemaphysalis concinna. Of the 1102 ticks, 3,568,561 high-quality reads were obtained through next-generation sequencing. After trimming, 302,540 reads were obtained, of which 6,577 (2.16%) reads were annotated with viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the viral sequences were closely related to orthonairovirus, phlebovirus, deer tick Mononegavirales-like virus and Jingmen tick virus sequences, but the relevance of these newly identified tick-borne viruses to human and animal health requires further investigation. The results of this study not only provide a basis for further studies on the link between ticks and tick-borne viruses, but also for the prevention of future tick disease outbreaks through vector control.
authors: Meng, F.;Ding, M.;Tan, Z.;Zhao, Z.;Xu, L.;Wu, J.;He, B.;Tu, C.

title: Deep sequencing reveals significant diversity between dominant variants and evolutionary dynamics of avian leukosis viruses in two infectious ecosystems
abstract: BACKGROUND: As a typical retrovirus, the evolution of avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) in different infectious ecosystems is uncharacterized, what we do know is that there is a cloud of different variants, namely quasi-species with considerable genetic diversity. This study aims to investigate the selection of infectious ecosystems for dominant variants and their evolutionary dynamics of ALV-J between DF1 cells and specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens. High-throughput sequencing platforms offer an approach to more fully discern the diversity of quasi-species. RESULTS: An average of approximately 20,000 valid reads were obtained from two variable regions of the gp85 gene and the LTR-U3 region from each sample in different infectious ecosystems. The top 10 dominant variants among ALV-J from chicken plasma, DF1 cells and liver tumor were completely different. Also, there was a difference between Shannon entropy and global selection pressure values (Ï‰) in different infectious ecosystems. In the plasmas of two chickens, a large fraction of the quasispecies contained a 3-peptide "LSD" repeat insertion that was only less than 0.01% in DF1 cell culture supernatants. In parallel studies, the LTR-U3 region of chick plasma ALV-J showed more variants with mutations in its transcriptional regulatory elements than that from DF1 cells. CONCLUSIONS: Our data taken together suggest that the molecular epidemiology based on isolated ALV-J in cell culture may not represent the true evolution of the virus in chicken flocks in the field. The biological significance of the "LSD" insert and mutations in LTR-U3 needs further investigation.
authors: Meng, F.;Dong, X.;Hu, T.;Chang, S.;Fan, J.;Zhao, P.;Cui, Z.

title: Analysis of Avain Leukosis Virus Subgroup J quasispecies using Sanger and high-throughput sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: Avian leukosis viruses subgroup J (ALV-J) exist as a complex mixture of distinct but closely related genomes, termed quasi-species, which are subject to continuous change according to the principles of Darwinian evolution. METHOD: The present study attempts to compare conventional Sanger sequencing with deep sequencing using the MiSeq platform to examine the quasi-species dynamics of ALV-J. RESULTS: The accuracy and reproducibility of MiSeq sequencing was determined better than Sanger sequencing by performing each experiment in duplicate. According to the mutation rate of a single position and the ability to distinguish dominant quasispecies with two sequencing methods, the conventional Sanger sequencing technique showed high randomness due to fewer sequencing samples, while deep sequencing could more accurately reflect the composition of the quasispecies. Meanwhile, exploration of quasi-species was simulated by Sanger sequencing and analyzed using a resampling strategy replacing 1000-fold repeats from high-throughput sequencing data that indicated that the higher the antibody titer, the higher the sequence entropy, the more rigorous analysis with conventional Sanger sequencing resulted in lower ratios of dominant variants. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, deep sequencing is better suited to comprehensively detect rare variants. The simulation of Sanger sequencing proposed here will also help to standardize quasi-species research under different selection pressures based on next-generation sequencing data.
authors: Meng, F.;Dong, X.;Hu, T.;Liu, Y.;Zhao, Y.;Lv, Y.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.;Cui, Z.

title: Characterization of subgroup Java leukosis virus isolated from native Chinese chickens
abstract: Background: Although the purification of laying hens and broilers from avian leukemia virus (ALV) has achieved remarkable success, infection with ALV in native Chinese chickens has still been severe. Methods: To assess the epidemic status of avian leukosis virus in domestic chickens in China, 10 new strains of ALV subgroup J (ALV-J), named JS16JH01 to JS16JH10, were isolated and analyzed by virus isolation and immunofluorescence antibody assays from a Chinese local breeding farm with sporadic occurrence of tumors. To further understand their virological properties, the proviral genome of ENV-LTR was sequenced and compared to the reference strains. Results: The gp85 gene homology between the ten ALV-J strains and NX0101 ranged from 89.7-94.8% at the nuclear acid level. In addition, their gp85 genes were quite different, with 92-98% identities with themselves at the nuclear acid level. There were multiple snp and indel sites in the amino acid sequence of gp85 genes when compared to other reference strains of ALV. Interestingly, a new insertion in the gp85 region was found in two strains, JS16JH01 and JS16JH07 compared to NX0101 and HPRS-103. Discussion: At present, due to the large-scale purification of ALV in China, laying hens and broilers with ALV infection are rarely detected, but ALVs are still frequently detected in the native chickens, suggesting that more efforts should be made in purification of ALV from native ones chickens.
authors: Meng, F.;Li, Q.;Zhang, Y.;Zhang, Z.;Tian, S.;Cui, Z.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.

title: [Isolation and Identification of Arboviruses from Mosquito Pools in Some Regions of Liaoning Province, China]
abstract: Isolation and identification of arboviruses from mosquito pools in some regions of Liaoning Province. Mosquitoes were collected in 2006 in the cities of Shenyang, Yingkou, Panjin, Jinzhou and Dandong in Liaoning Province. Viruses were isolated by inoculating samples onto C6/36 and BHK-21 cells. The new isolates were identified using serological and molecular biological methods. A total of 5410 mosquitoes were collected in the five cities. Three isolates produced CPE in C6/36 cells and five isolates produced CPE in both C6/36 and BHK-21 cells. Three isolates (LN0684, LN0688 and LN0689) were identified as Banna virus and one isolate (LN0636) as Getah virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the three bannavirus strains were clustered in the same evolutionary branch as the other Chinese isolates. The nucleotide sequence identity ranged from 91.2% to 94.7% compared to other bannavirus strains. The newly isolated Getah virus has been clustered in the same branch with the South Korean strain (pigs). The identity of the nucleotide sequence was 99.2% compared with the strain from South Korea and 95% to 99% with the strains from Russia, Mainland China and the Taiwan region. Conclusion Eight virus isolates, including three Banna viruses, one Getah virus and four unknown virus strains, were isolated from mosquitoes in Liaoning Province. Banna virus and Getah virus were first reported in Liaoning province, while Getah virus had the highest nucleotide homology with the South Korean strains.
authors: Meng, W. S.;Zhang, J. B.;Sun, X. H.;Liu, Q. N.;Chen, Z.;Zhai, Y. G.;Fu, S. H.;Cao, Y. X.;Wang, H. Y.;Ding, J.;Chu, F. J.;Li, Z.;Zhang, L. T.;Zhao, Y. J.;Liang, G. D.

title: Porcine hepatitis E virus: cross-species infection and risk in xenotransplantation
abstract: Porcine hepatitis E virus (porcine HEV), a ubiquitous pathogen recently discovered in pigs, is antigenically and genetically closely related to human HEV. Swine HEV infection generally occurs in pigs at about 2-3 months of age, and about 80%-100% of pigs on commercial farms in the US were infected. Pig HEV infections have now been identified in pigs in many other countries around the world. Interspecies transmission has been documented because porcine HEV infects nonhuman primates and some human HEV strains infect pigs. Recent seroepidemiological studies have shown that pig veterinarians and other pig farmers are at higher risk of HEV infection compared to normal blood donors. In addition, new human HEV strains obtained from hepatitis patients in the United States, Japan and Taiwan are genetically more closely related to porcine HEV strains from the respective countries than to other human HEV strains. The ubiquitous nature of the virus in pigs and the demonstrated ability to infect across species raises a potential concern for porcine HEV infection in porcine organ xenotransplantation. This chapter discusses recent advances in HEV research with a focus on potential zoonosis and xenozoonosis.
authors: Meng, X. J.

title: Molecular cloning and nucleotide sequencing of the 3'-terminal genomic RNA of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus
abstract: The genomic RNA of a porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) isolate from the USA, VR 2385 (ATCC), was copied into cDNA after priming with oligo(dT) and cloned into the lambda phage. The cDNA clones representing the 3'-terminal genomic RNA of the virus were isolated and sequenced. The genome is a positive-stranded, polyadenylated RNA with an estimated size of 15 kb. Analysis of the resulting sequence identified three complete open reading frames (ORFs) with the potential to yield polypeptides with predicted M(r)s of 22.2K (ORF 5), 19.1K (ORF 6), and 13.6K (ORF 7) to encode. ORF 7, closest to the 3' end, is proposed to encode a highly basic nucleocapsid protein that shares 58% amino acid identity with the corresponding protein of Lelystad virus (LV), a European PRRSV isolate. ORFs 6 and 5, which precede ORF 7, are predicted to each encode proteins containing multiple hydrophobic domains that are thought to be membrane-associated. The VR 2385 ORF 6 protein is the most highly conserved structural protein. It shares 78% amino acid identity with the equivalent LV protein and ORF 5 shares only 54% of its amino acid sequence. Northern blot analysis revealed a 3'-coterminally nested set of six subgenomic RNAs in VR 2385 virus-infected CRL 11171 cells. Our results show that VR 2385, like LV, is a member of the newly proposed group of arteriviruses. However, the striking genetic variation and difference in pathogenicity between LV and VR 2385 suggest that the viruses causing PRRS in the US and Europe are highly variable and may represent distinct genotypes.
authors: Meng, X. J.;Paul, P. S.;Halbur, P. G.

title: Sequence comparison of open reading frames 2 to 5 of low and high virulence US isolates of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus
abstract: The sequences of ORFs 2 through 5 of five United States (US) porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) isolates of different virulence were determined. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of these isolates were compared to those of other known PRRSV isolates. The amino acid sequence identity between seven US PRRSV isolates was 91-99% in ORF 2, 86-98% in ORF 3, 92-99% in ORF 4 and 88-97% in ORF 5. The US low virulence isolate had the highest sequence variation in ORFs 2 to 4 compared to the other US isolates. A hypervariable region with antigenic potential was identified within the major envelope glycoprotein. Phylogenetic analysis of ORFs 2 through 7 revealed the existence of at least three minor genotypes within the main US genotype. The low virulence US isolate formed a branch distinct from the other US isolates. The results of this study have implications for both PRRSV taxonomy and vaccine development.
authors: Meng, X. J.;Paul, P. S.;Halbur, P. G.;Morozov, I.

title: Oncorna-like virus particles in the cochlear spiral ganglion of guinea pigs
abstract: Virus particles in the spiral ganglion cells of the guinea pig are usually assigned to the herpes viruses. The purpose of this study was to evaluate this classification of viruses and their impact on cell morphology. Healthy adult guinea pigs were studied. The spiral ganglion was serially sectioned and examined by electron microscopy. All spiral ganglia examined from several guinea pig populations of different breeds showed intracytoplasmic viruses in some granular spiral ganglion cells. According to their localization and morphology, these viruses are assigned to the group of oncorna viruses, which does not agree with the classification of other authors. Apparently there is a latent virus infection in guinea pigs worldwide. The accumulation of lysosomal-like vacuoles around the virus indicates increased local lysosomal activity of the infected ganglion cells. Considering the otherwise normal ultrastructure of the infected cells, an additional influence of these viruses on the intracellular metabolism can neither be proven nor denied.
authors: Merck, W.;Kistler, G. S.;Riede, U. N.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from chicken, wildfowl, pigeon and quail in Mexico
abstract: Velogenic Newcastle disease has threatened the Mexican poultry industry since 1946. Seven strains of velogenic Newcastle disease virus were isolated from poultry and other bird species in central and northern Mexico from 1998 to 2006 and subjected to phylogenetic analysis and biological characterization using standard pathogenicity assays and Challenge underwent trials. The phylogenetic analysis showed that all velogenetic strains belonged to genetic group V and are clearly divided into two lineages, since the phylogenetic similarities between the groups are only 93-94%. The 1998-2001 isolates are closely related to the strain responsible for the 2000-year outbreak in the La Laguna region (Torreon strain) and are phylogenetically distinct from the viruses isolated between 2004-2006, which are genetically linked to the Chimalhuacan strain isolated in 1973. All viruses from both the Chimalhuacan and Torreon groups contained a virulent fusion protein cleavage site represented by the motif "GGRRQKRF", indicating that evolutionary changes occurred at a different site. The mean time to death of chick embryos was shorter for the Chimalhuacan-like virus (43.9 hours) compared to the 1998-2001 average (54.3 hours). The mean ICPI value was higher (1.92) for viruses isolated between 2004 and 2006 than for viruses isolated before 2001 (1.74). Microscopic evaluation of Fabricius' bursa and thymus of 5 w-o broilers challenged with 106 LD50/0.2 ml showed that the Chimalhuacan-like isolate had more severe lesions at 48 hpi in bursa and 72 and 96 hpi in thymus caused as a Torreon-like isolate. Together with the MDT, ICPI and microscopic results, our results suggest that some selective pressure on the highly virulent Chimalhuacan strain isolated in the early 1970s led to the emergence of the still velogenous but less virulent new group (Torreon-like) might have led to the mid-1990s. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media BV
authors: Merino, R.;Villegas, H.;Quintana, J. A.;Calderon, N.

title: Evaluation of phenotypic markers in full genome sequences of avian influenza isolates from California
abstract: We evaluated phenotypic markers in full genome sequences of avian influenza isolates to identify avian strains with increased potential for transmission and pathogenicity in mammals. Of 149 markers examined, 67 were positive in the consensus sequences of 206 bird isolates. Analysis of deep sequencing data in a subset of 24 isolates revealed that 344 subpopulations occurred at marker positions. Markers in subpopulations were significantly more likely to be negative (258/344) than positive (86/344), but almost all marker-positive subpopulations (78/86) were associated with marker-negative consensus sequences. Our analysis revealed significant differences in key markers among avian isolates and indicated that consensus sequences do not fully reflect an isolate's potential for increased transmissibility and pathogenicity in mammals.
authors: Mertens, E.;Dugan, V. G.;Stockwell, T. B.;Lindsay, L. L.;Plancarte, M.;Boyce, W. M.

title: The first "virus hunters"
abstract: The history of virology is a history of conceptual and technological inventions and breakthroughs. The development of filters made of porcelain or diatomaceous earth towards the end of the 19th century that retained bacteria made it possible to identify infectious agents that were smaller than bacteria and could not be cultivated on the bacterial culture media known at the time. Even finer-grained filters led to the observation that the invisible novel infectious agents are actually particulate in nature. Plant and animal infections were the first to be attributed to these tiny creatures. Detection was by experimental infection of the natural hosts (including humans). Thus, of the first 30 viruses identified, 20 are veterinary viruses, ie infectious agents of poultry and livestock. The discovery that bacteria also have viruses in the 1910s expanded the viral universe that continues to this day. Filterability and ultravisibility remained a hallmark of viral identification until the advent of the electron microscope in the late 1930s, marking another technological breakthrough in virology. Cell culture techniques allowed the virus to multiply outside of the infected organism. In recent decades, the emergence and development of molecular biology has fueled further innovations that result in the rapid and accurate determination of the genomic material of a wide variety of living things, including viruses, at a speed and depth previously unknown, using next-generation sequencing and metagenomic analyzes culminated. It is therefore not surprising that new viruses are constantly being discovered, including specimens of unprecedented size and shape. Virologists agree that the viral universe is immense and only a small fraction has been explored.
authors: Mettenleiter, T. C.

title: Transmission of influenza virus between species
abstract: Influenza is an infection of humans and several animal species. It is caused by influenza viruses belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Type A influenza viruses are the most important because they cause serious epidemics and are responsible for important pathological problems. Type A influenza viruses are divided into different subtypes depending on the nature of their surface glycoproteins: hemagglutinin (H) and neuraminidase (N). The nature of the genome and mode of replication of influenza viruses explains the high variability of these two proteins responsible for immunity against the virus. The continuous occurrence of point mutations in the gene coding for the H protein leads to the progressive emergence of new virus strains. This event, known as antigenic drift, makes it necessary to review the composition of the human influenza vaccine annually. Genetic reassortment is another mechanism of antigenic variation. If the gene coding for the H protein, or if both genes coding for H and N proteins are involved in the genetic rearrangement, a new viral subtype emerges, replacing the precedent. This event, called the antigenic shift, occasionally occurs every 10 to 30 years and is responsible for the major human pandemics. The role of animals and in particular the importance of pigs and poultry in the emergence of these new viruses is discussed.
authors: Meulemans, G.

title: Isolation of orthoreoviruses from parrots
abstract: Orthoreoviridae have been regularly isolated from imported parrots in the absence of other pathogens or in combination with Salmonella. These viruses grew in embryonated eggs, in chicken embryo fibroblasts and in liver cell cultures. The virus isolates were classified as Orthoreoviridae based on their morphological and physicochemical properties.
authors: Meulemans, G.;Dekegel, D.;Charlier, G.;Froyman, R.;Van Tilburg, J.;Halen, P.

title: Characterization of proteins encoded by ORFs 2 to 7 of Lelystad virus
abstract: The genome of Lelystad virus (LV), a positive-strand RNA virus, is 15 kb in length and contains 8 open reading frames (ORFs) encoding putative viral proteins. ORFs 2 through 7 were cloned into plasmids downstream of the Sp6 RNA polymerase promoter, and translation of in vitro generated transcripts yielded proteins that could be immunoprecipitated with porcine anti-LV serum. Synthetic polypeptides of 15 to 17 amino acids were selected from the amino acid sequences of ORFs 2 to 7 and antipeptide sera were grown in rabbits. Antisera were obtained which immunoprecipitated the in vitro translation products of ORFs 2 to 5 and 7. Sera containing antibodies directed against peptides from ORFs 3 to 7 reacted positively with LV-infected lung alveolar macrophages in the immunoperoxidase monolayer assay. Using these antipeptide sera and the porcine anti-LV serum, we identified three structural proteins and assigned their corresponding genes. Virions were found to contain a 15 kDa nucleocapsid protein (N), an 18 kDa unglycosylated membrane protein (M) and a 25 kDa glycosylated membrane protein (E). The N protein is encoded by ORF7, the M protein is encoded by ORF6 and the E protein is encoded by ORF5. The E protein in virus particles contains one or two N-glycans that are resistant to endo-β-N-acetyl-D-glucosaminidase H. This finding indicates that the high-mannose glycans are processed into complex glycans in the Golgi compartment. The protein composition of LV virions further confirms that LV is evolutionarily related to equine arteritis virus, monkey hemorrhagic fever virus, and lactate dehydrogenase-elevating virus.
authors: Meulenberg, J. J. M.;Besten, A. P. D.;De Kluyver, E. P.;Moormann, R. J. M.;Schaaper, W. M. M.;Wensvoort, G.

title: Characterization of orthopoxviruses isolated from humans and animals in Germany
abstract: 14 orthopoxvirus strains isolated from humans, cats, a dog, a cow and an elephant in Germany were characterized. All were classified as vaccinia virus based on hemorrhagic lesions induced on the chorioallantoic membrane of chicken eggs and the reactivity of a 160 kDa protein with anti-A type inclusion protein hyperimmune serum in a Western blot. A more detailed comparison of the isolates by restriction endonuclease mapping using HindIII and XhoI showed a close relationship between all the isolates and confirmed them as vaccinia viruses. However, some minor differences between isolates were noted, which turned out to be of epidemiological value. A panel of five closely related isolates contained a unique 4.0 kb HindIII fragment. In a Southern blot, this fragment did not hybridize to other vaccinia virus isolates, including the reference strain.
authors: Meyer, H.;Schay, C.;Mahnel, H.;Pfeffer, M.

title: Comprehensive phylogenetic reconstructions of African swine fever virus: Proposal for a new classification and molecular dating of the virus
abstract: African swine fever (ASF) is a highly fatal disease of domestic swine caused by the only known DNA arbovirus. It was first described in Kenya in 1921 and since then many isolates have been collected worldwide. Although several phylogenetic studies have been conducted to understand the relationships between the isolates, molecular dating analyzes have not been performed to date. In this article, extensive phylogenetic reconstructions were performed using newly generated, publicly available sequences from hundreds of ASFV isolates over the past 70 years. The analyzes focused on the genes B646L, CP204L and E183L from 356, 251 and 123 isolates, respectively. Phylogenetic analyzes were performed using maximum likelihood and Bayesian coalescence methods. A new lineage-based nomenclature is proposed to denote 35 distinct clusters. In addition, dating of the ASFV origin was performed from the molecular datasets. To avoid bias, diversity due to positive selection or recombination events was neutralized. Molecular clock analyzes showed that the currently circulating ASFV strains evolved over 300 years, with a time to the most recent common ancestor (TMRCA) in the early 18th century. © 2013 Michaud et al.
authors: Michaud, V.;Randriamparany, T.;Albina, E.

title: Henipaviruses in their natural animal hosts
abstract: Hendra virus (HeV) and Nipah virus (NiV) form a separate genus Henipavirus within the family Paramyxoviridae and are classified as biosafety level 4 pathogens due to their high mortality rate after infection in humans and the lack of effective vaccines or therapies . Both viruses emerged from their natural reservoirs in the last decade of the 20th century, causing severe disease in humans, horses and pigs, and infecting a number of other mammalian species. The current review summarizes our current understanding of the pathology and pathogenesis in the natural reservoir species, the Pteropus bat, and in the spill-over species of horses and pigs. © 2012 Springer Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Middleton, D. J.;Weingartl, H. M.

title: Rotavirus Vaccines: An Overview
abstract: The development of rotavirus vaccines has focused on the oral route of administration of live attenuated rotavirus strains. The initial "Jennerian" approach with candidate bovine (RIT4237, WC3) or rhesus (RRV) rotavirus vaccines showed that these vaccines were safe, well tolerated and immunogenic, but induced very different levels of protection against rotavirus diarrhea. The goal of a rotavirus vaccine is to prevent serious diseases that can cause dehydration in infants and young children in both developed and developing countries. These studies led to the concept that a multivalent vaccine representing each of the four epidemiologically important VP7 serotypes may be required to induce protection in young infants, the target population for vaccination. Human-animal rotavirus reassortants whose gene encoding VP7 was derived from their human rotavirus parent but whose remaining genes were derived from the animal rotavirus parent were developed as vaccine candidates. The greatest experience with a multivalent vaccine to date has been gained with the quadrivalent preparation containing RRV (VP7 serotype 3) and human RRV reassortants of specificity VP7 serotypes 1, 2 and 4. Preliminary results from efficacy studies in the United States have been promising, while a study in Peru has shown limited protection. Human bovine reassortant vaccines, including a candidate containing the VP4 gene of a human rotavirus (VP4 serotype 1A), are also being investigated.
authors: Midthun, K.;Kapikian, A. Z.

title: The faecal virome of domesticated animals
abstract: Next-generation sequencing is a new research tool in our hands, helping us to explore still unknown areas of human and veterinary virology. Metagenomic analysis has enabled the discovery of putative new pathogens and the identification of the etiological agents of several diseases, thereby solving long-standing mysteries caused by different viruses. This approach has been used in several studies examining fecal samples from livestock and companion animal species to provide information on animal fecal virus diversity, help elucidate the etiology of diarrheal diseases in animals, and identify potential zoonotic and emerging viruses.
authors: Mihalov-KovÃ¡cs, E.;FehÃ©r, E.;Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Farkas, S. L.

title: Nyamanini and Midway viruses define a new taxon of RNA viruses in the order Mononegavirales
abstract: Here we report the sequencing and classification of Nyamanini virus (NYMV) and Midway virus (MIDWV), two antigenically related viruses first isolated in 1957 and 1966, respectively. Although these viruses have been repeatedly cultured from cattle egrets, seabirds and their ticks, attempts to classify them taxonomically using conventional serological and electron microscopy approaches have utterly failed. We used a random shotgun sequencing strategy to define the genomes of NYMV and MIDWV. Contigs of 11,631 and 11,752 nucleotides representing the complete NYMV genome and the nearly complete MIDWV genome, respectively, were assembled. Each viral genome was predicted to carry six open reading frames (ORFs). BLAST analysis showed that only two of the ORF proteins of each virus, the putative nucleocapsid and the polymerase, shared any detectable sequence similarity to known viral proteins. The phylogenetic analysis of these ORF proteins showed that the closest relatives of NYNV and MIDWV are negative-strand RNA viruses in the order Mononegavirales. Because of their very limited sequence similarity to known viruses, we propose that NYMV and MIDWV define a new genus, Nyavirus, in that order. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Mihindukulasuriya, K. A.;Nguyen, N. L.;Wu, G.;Huang, H. V.;Travassos Da Rosa, A. P. A.;Popov, V. L.;Tesh, R. B.;Wang, D.

title: A first look at the Oxford Nanopore MinION sequencer
abstract: Oxford Nanopore's third-generation single-molecule sequencing platform promises to reduce reagent and instrument costs. After a two-year hiatus from the initial announcement, the first devices were released as part of an Early Access program. We examine the performance of this platform by resequencing the genome of lambda phage and amplicon from a snake venom gland transcriptome. Although the MinION portable sequencer can generate more than 150 megabases of raw data in one run, at most a quarter of the resulting reads are assigned to the reference, with less than an average of 10% identity. Much of the sequence consists of insertion/deletion errors or appears dissimilar to the original. Using the lambda phage data as an example, although the reads are long, averaging 5 kb, at best 890 ± 1932 bases per matched read could be matched to the reference without soft truncation. Over the course of a 36 hour run on the MinION it was possible to resequence the 48 kb lambda phage reference at 16x coverage. Significantly larger projects could not currently be implemented with the MinION. Without an increase in the fidelity required for applications such as genome scaffolding and phasing, the current usefulness of the MinION seems limited. Library preparation requires access to a molecular laboratory and is of similar complexity and cost to other next-generation sequencing platforms. The MinION is an exciting step in a new direction for single-molecule sequencing, although it will require a dramatic reduction in error rates before it delivers on its promises.
authors: Mikheyev, A. S.;Tin, M. M.

title: Vaccine immune pressure affects the viral population complexity of avian influenza virus during infection
abstract: Vaccines are useful tools for controlling influenza A virus infection in poultry, but they need to be reformulated periodically to ensure adequate protection against infection and to limit virus replication and circulation, which could favor the emergence of new variants. In this study, a deep sequencing approach was used to characterize and follow the evolution of the hemagglutinin of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus population in infected animals vaccinated with two vaccines conferring different levels of protection.
authors: Milani, A.;Fusaro, A.;Bonfante, F.;Zamperin, G.;Salviato, A.;Mancin, M.;Mastrorilli, E.;Hughes, J.;Hussein, H. A.;Hassan, M.;Mundt, E.;Terregino, C.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Different interactions between isolates of peanut stunt cucumovirus and its satellite RNA
abstract: The interactions of seven isolates of peanut stunt cucumovirus (PSV) originating from North America, Europe and Africa and two variants of PSV satellite RNA (sat RNA) were analyzed. Electrophoretic and immunoblot analysis of the Coat Protein (CP) and Northern blot hybridization analysis of the viral RNAs showed that isolates PSV F352, 1339 and 1507 belonged to subgroup I and isolates PSV W, Su and B to subgroup II. The seventh isolate , Robinia mosaic virus (RoMV), clustered with subgroup isolates by CP analysis, but was related to both subgroups by RNA hybridization analysis. The ability to support the accumulation of two newly described sat RNA variants, P4 and P6 sat RNAs, was unrelated to the classification of PSV isolates: neither PSV W nor RoMV were helper viruses for these PSV sat RNAs. Symptom modulation by both sat RNAs was the same: the presence of sat RNA did not modify the symptoms induced by subgroup I isolates, but exacerbated the symptoms induced by subgroup II isolates in both tobacco and cowpea. The sat RNAs P4 and P6 contained 393 nucleotides and differed only in three nucleotide substitutions. This resulted in marked differences in infectivity, level of accumulation, and relative encapsulation between the two sat RNAs. Accumulation levels and relative encapsulation of sat RNAs were also affected by the helper virus isolate.
authors: MilitÃ£o, V.;Moreno, I.;RodrÃ­guez-Cerezo, E.;GarcÃ­a-Arenal, F.

title: Newcastle disease: evolution of genotypes and associated diagnostic challenges
abstract: Since the discovery of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in 1926, nine class I virus genotypes and ten class II virus genotypes have been identified, representing a diverse and constantly evolving group of viruses. The emergence of new virulent genotypes from global animal diseases and the observed year-to-year changes in the genomic sequence of low and high virulence NDV suggest that different genotypes of NDV are evolving simultaneously in different geographic locations around the world. This tremendous genomic diversity may be favored by the wide variety of bird species susceptible to NDV infection and the availability of highly mobile wild bird reservoirs. The genomic diversity of NDV increases the possibility of diagnostic failures leading to unidentified infections. Constant epidemiological surveillance and proactive characterization of circulating strains are required to ensure that the immunological and PCR reagents are effective in identifying NDV circulating worldwide. For example, in the United States, the widely used real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) matrix gene test used to identify NDV frequently fails to detect low-virulence APMV-1 from aquatic birds, while the RRT-PCR Fusion genetic testing used to identify virulent isolates often fails to detect specific virulent NDV genotypes. A new matrix polymerase multiplex test has recently been developed that detects most viruses currently circulating worldwide and a modified fusion test to identify virulent pigeon viruses circulating in the US and Europe. For newly isolated viruses with unknown sequences, recently developed random priming sequencing methods need to be added to the diagnostic arsenal. In addition, the current system for classifying NDV into genotypes or lineages is inadequate. Here we review the molecular epidemiology and recent diagnostic problems related to viral evolution of NDV and explain why a new system based on objective criteria is needed to categorize genotypes.
authors: Miller, P. J.;Decanini, E. L.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Common evolutionary origin of hepatitis B virus and retroviruses
abstract: Although hepatitis B virus (HBV) has been classified as a double-stranded DNA virus, it has recently been shown to replicate by reverse transcription of an RNA intermediate. The putative viral polymerase was also found to share amino acid homology with retroviral reverse transcriptase. Using computational DNA and protein sequence analysis, we examined the genomes of 13 hepadnavirus isolates (nine humans, two ducks, one woodchuck, and one ground squirrel) and found that other conserved regions of the hepadnavirus genome share homology with corresponding regions of the hepadnavirus genomes of type -C-retroviruses and retrovirus-like endogenous human DNA elements. In particular, the most highly conserved sequence of the HBV genome, positioned at or near the site of initiation for first strand HBV DNA synthesis, is over 67 nucleotides homologous to the U5 region, a comparable region in long terminal repeats of retroviruses. Within a highly conserved (ie, 90%) 16-nucleotide sequence, a heptanucleotide sequence CCTTGGG is 97% homologous between 27 virus isolates. In addition, we found that the highly conserved HBV core or nucleocapsid protein shares 41% homology over 98 amino acids with the carboxyl-terminal region of the p30 gag nucleocapsid protein of type C retroviruses. In both cases, as with the previously reported polymerase homology, HBV is most homologous to the murine leukemia/sarcoma retroviruses. Further analysis revealed additional similarities between hepadnavirus and retroviral genomes. Taken together, our results suggest that HBV and retroviruses share a common evolutionary origin, with HBV arising by a deletion process from a retrovirus or retrovirus-like progenitor.
authors: Miller, R. H.;Robinson, W. S.

title: Detection of bovine group A rotavirus using rapid antigen detection kits, RT-PCR and next-generation DNA sequencing
abstract: We evaluated the sensitivity of human rotavirus rapid antigen detection (RAD) kits, RT-PCR, and next-generation DNA sequencing (NGS) for the detection of bovine rotavirus group A (RVA). The dipstick 'Eiken' Rota (Dipstick) demonstrated the highest sensitivity of the seven RAD kits against all selected strains in limited dilution analyses, consistent with previously reported results for equine rotavirus. RT-PCR had a 100-103 fold higher sensitivity than the dipstick. NGS using thirteen RT-PCR negative stool samples revealed that all samples gave RVA reads and in particular that two of them covered all 11 genome segments. In addition, mapping reads to reference sequences enabled genotyping. The NGS would be sensitive and useful for analysis of less dependent specific primers and screening of genotypes. Â© 2013 The Japanese Society for Veterinary Medicine.
authors: Minami-Fukuda, F.;Nagai, M.;Takai, H.;Murakami, T.;Ozawa, T.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishiura, N.;Sassa, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Koyama, S.;Shirai, J.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Fujii, Y.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.

title: A systematic review of the natural virome of the Anopheles mosquito
authors: Minkeu, F. Nanfack;Vernick, K.

title: Rapid development of the human enteric virus
authors: Minot, S.;Bryson, A.;Chehoud, C.

title: Conservation of gene cassettes among different human intestinal viruses
abstract: Viruses are a crucial part of the human microbiome, but large population sizes, high sequence diversity, and high abundance of new genes have hampered genome analysis by high-throughput sequencing. Here, we examine metagenomic assembly approaches to probe genome structure in a sample of 5.6 GB of viral gut DNA sequence from six individuals. Tests showed that a new pipeline based on the DeBruijn graph assembly delivered longer contigs that could recruit more reads than the corresponding unoptimized single-pass approach. To characterize gene content, the database of viral RefSeq proteins was compared to the assembled viral contigs, creating a bipartite diagram with functional cassettes linking viral contigs together, revealing a high degree of connectivity between different genomes at which multiple genes of the same functional class were involved. In a second step, open reading frames were grouped according to their co-occurrence on contigs in a database-independent manner, revealing conserved cassettes with co-oriented ORFs. These methods show that free-living bacteriophage, although they usually differ at the nucleotide level, often share significant similarity at the level of encoded amino acid motifs, gene order, and gene orientation. These results thus link contemporary metagenomic analysis with classical studies of bacteriophage genomic cassettes. Software is available at https://sourceforge.net/projects/optitdba/.
authors: Minot, S.;Wu, G. D.;Lewis, J. D.;Bushman, F. D.

title: Phylogenetic evidence for a recent spread of two human enterovirus 71 populations in European countries
abstract: Human enterovirus 71 (EV-71) is a cause of seasonal epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease and less common but serious neurological manifestations. Uncertainty remains regarding the circulation of virus populations in multiple geographic areas and the timeframe of their spread. We determined EV-71 sequences at loci 1D (VP1 capsid protein) and 3CD (nonstructural proteins) in 86 strains derived from Austria, France and Germany and performed an evolutionary genetic study of existing virus populations. Phylogenetic analyzes positioned 78 of the 86 sequences within two clades under subgenogroups C1 and C2. A minor sequence cluster has been assigned to subgenogroup C4. Analyzes involving the available sequences estimated the substitution rate in genogroup C to be 3.66 × 10-3 and 4.46 × 10-3 substitutions per Year-1 site for loci 1D and 3CD, respectively, using a relaxed molecular clock model for sequence evolution was accepted. Most "European" phyla belonged to clades C1b and C2b, which arose in 1994 [95% CI, 1992.7-1995.8] and 2002 (95% CI, 2001.6-2003.8), respectively. Estimates of divergence times for site 3CD agreed with those measured for site 1D. The interconnectedness between clades representing EV-71 subgenogroups and clades corresponding to other enterovirus types (particularly early coxsackievirus A prototype strains) in 3CD phylogeny is a strong indication of ancestral recombination events. Incongruent phylogenetic patterns estimated for loci 1D and 3CD indicate that a single tree cannot model the epidemic history of circulating EV-71 populations. The evolutionary timescale of genogroup C estimated for both loci was measured in decades only, indicating a recent distribution. © 2010 SGM.
authors: Mirand, A.;Schuffenecker, I.;Henquell, C.;Billaud, G.;Jugie, G.;Falcon, D.;Mahul, A.;Archimbaud, C.;Terletskaia-Ladwig, E.;Diedrich, S.;Huemer, H. P.;Enders, M.;Lina, B.;Peigue-Lafeuille, H.;Bailly, J. L.

title: Genetic diversity of bovine diarrhea and mucosal disease virus
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is classified as a member of the pestivirus genus of the Flaviviridae family. BVDV is one of the most important viral pathogens affecting ruminants worldwide, causing severe economic losses. Infection leads to a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations, ranging from mild respiratory diseases to fetal death and mucosal diseases. The virus particles are small and contain a single-stranded, positive RNA molecule of approximately 12.3 kb with a large open reading frame flanked by two untranslated regions (5'UTR and 3'UTR). The polyprotein is proteolytically cleaved by viral and host proteases, resulting in the formation of mature viral proteins. It is well known that BVDV strains exhibit considerable genetic diversity. BVD viruses are classified into two types: BVDV-1 and BVDV-2. A new putative species, BVDV-3, was recently discovered. The viruses exist as one of two biotypes: cytopathic or non-cytopathic based on their activity in cell culture. Phylogenetic analysis of the 5'UTR and Npro region has revealed at least 21 distinct subtypes of BVDV-1 and 4 subtypes of BVDV-2. The genetic diversity of BVD viruses has serious clinical implications such as immune evasion, increase in virulence, change in host range, and also affects the effectiveness of vaccination programs and diagnostic procedures.
authors: MirosÅ‚aw, P.;Antos, A.;Polak, M.

title: VARV B22R homolog as a phylogenetic marker gene for capripoxvirus classification and divergence time dating
abstract: Sheeppox disease is associated with significant losses in sheep production worldwide. Sheeppox virus, goatpox virus and lumpy skin disease virus cannot be distinguished by conventional serological tests. Identification of these pathogens requires molecular methods. In this study, seven genes, viz. EEV maturation protein - F12L, virion protein - D3R, RNA polymerase subunit - A5R, virion core protein - A10L, EEV glycoprotein - A33R, VARV B22R homologue and calyx-like protein - A55R covering the beginning, Mid , and end of the genome were selected. These genes were amplified, cloned and sequenced from the Romanian Fanar vaccine strain and the virulent Jaipur strain. Analysis with the available database sequences identified the VARV B22R homologue as a marker for phylogenetic reconstruction to classify ungulate vaccinia viruses. Furthermore, temporal divergence dating with the VARV B22R gene accurately predicted the onset of varicella disease with the virulent Jaipur strain.
authors: Mishra, B.;Mondal, P.;Patel, C. L.;Zafir, I.;Gangwar, R.;Singh, N.;Sonowal, J.;Bisht, D.;Sahu, A. R.;Baig, M.;Sajjanar, B.;Singh, R. K.;Gandham, R. K.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the sheeppoxvirus (SPPV) virion core protein P4a gene revealed extensive sequence conservation among capripoxviruses
abstract: In the present study, the virion core protein P4a gene was PCR amplified from the Jaipur isolate of sheep pox virus (SPPV) and the Romanian Fanar (RF) vaccine strain, which was adapted and propagated in lamb testes/Vero cells . Gene specific primers were designed for the amplification of the P4a gene. The amplified P4a gene fragment was sequence characterized and the 808 bp sequence was compared to the SPPV, GTPV and LSDV isolates available in the GenBank database, revealing an overall sequence conservation of 97% to 100% within the poxvirus groups. The Jaipur isolate of varicella virus was found in close proximity to the Romanian Fanar (RF) and TU isolates. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of the P4a gene sequence revealed three distinct clusters of Capripox viruses, interestingly with GTPV being placed close to the LSDV group.
authors: Mishra, B.;Ravi Kumar, G.;Sonal;Patel, C. L.;Chaturvedi, V. K.

title: Molecular characterization of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2 derived from a native Indian sheep (Ovies aries).
abstract: The widespread prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 (BVDV-1) in cattle and the recent identification of BVDV-2 in goats in India justified pestivirus surveillance in sheep. Nested reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used to detect BVDV-2 in one of 1561 blood samples randomly collected from 78 flocks of sheep in 11 states of India. Antigenic characterization of the isolated pestivirus using polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies typed the isolate as BVDV-2. When analyzed at the genetic level in Npro (N-terminal autoprotease) and the entire gene region encoding structural proteins, namely capsid (C) protein and envelope proteins Erns (ribonuclease secreted), the genomic organization of E1 and E2 for all pestiviruses was the same, the nucleic acid and amino acid sequences showed the highest similarity to those of BVDV-2. When compared to the BVDV-2 isolate 890, the sequence homology was 83.7% for C, 84.6% for Erns and E1, and 81.5% for E2. The C/Erns cleavage site was found to be fully conserved, while Npro/C was conserved only from the C-terminus of Npro, the Erns/E1 site was conserved only from the C-terminus of Erns, and the E1/E2 site was conserved only from the C -terminus of E1 has been conserved. Phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequences in the 5 inch untranslated regions (UTR), the Npro, E2, NS3 and NS5B regions placed the sheep isolate in a separate group within the BVDV-2 subtype b. This was supported by the presence of unique mutations in the structural protein coding regions adjacent to NS3 and NS5B. To our knowledge, this is the first report of sequence analysis of the entire structural gene coding region of a BVDV-2b isolate. This is also the first occurrence of BVDV-2 subtype b in sheep, providing evidence that this subtype may also occur in species other than bovine. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Mishra, N.;Rajukumar, K.;Vilcek, S.;Tiwari, A.;Satav, J. S.;Dubey, S. C.

title: Metagenomic characterization of virome associated with bovine respiratory disease identified new viruses and suggests an etiologic role...
authors: Mitra, N.;Cernicchiaro, N.;Torres, S.;Li, F.

title: The metagenomic characterization of the virome associated with bovine respiratory disease identified new viruses and suggests an etiological role for influenza D virus
abstract: Bovine respiratory disease (BRD) is the most costly disease affecting the cattle industry. The pathogenesis of BRD is complex and includes contributions from microbial pathogens as well as host, environmental, and animal management factors. In this study, we used viral metagenomic sequencing to examine virome of nasal swab specimens obtained from April to October 2015 from beef cattle with acute BRD and asymptomatic stallmates at six and four fattening farms, respectively, in Mexico and the United States. Twenty -one viruses were detected, with bovine rhinitis A (52.7%) and B (23.7%) virus and bovine coronavirus (24.7%) being identified most frequently. Emerging influenza D virus (IDV) tended to be significantly (P=0.134; odds ratio=2.94) associated with the disease, while viruses commonly associated with BRD, such as 3 viruses, were less frequently detected . The detection of IDV was further confirmed using a real-time PCR assay. Nasal swabs from symptomatic animals had significantly more IDV RNA than those collected from healthy animals (P=0.04). In addition to known viruses, new genotypes of bovine rhinitis B virus and enterovirus E have been identified and a newly proposed species of bocaparvovirus, ungulate bocaparvovirus 6, has been characterized. To our knowledge, ungulate tetraparvovirus 1 was also detected for the first time in North America. These results illustrate the complexity of the virome associated with BRD and underscore the need for further research on the contribution of other viruses to BRD pathogenesis.
authors: Mitra, N.;Cernicchiaro, N.;Torres, S.;Li, F.;Hause, B. M.

title: Molecular characterization of Indian isolates of broiler infectious bursa disease virus
abstract: The present study was performed to characterize recent field isolates of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and partial sequencing of the VP2 gene. The virus was detected in 17 out of 20 field samples from broilers in the Indian state of Haryana and in all four vaccine strains.
