Nucleotide sequences of four field isolates and one vaccine strain were compared to 10 reported IBDV strains from different parts of the world. Nucleotide substitutions at 795G, 827T, 833C, 857C, 897A, 905T, 908T, 1011A and 1094G specific for very virulent (vv) strains were retained in all four field isolates. However, unique nucleotide substitutions at 806A-G, 851C-T, 1010 TC, 1019T-C and 1082T-C revealed further divergence of these isolates from previously reported vvIBDVs. Derived amino acid substitutions at 222P-A, 256V-I, 279N-D, 294L-I and 299N-S specific for vvIBDV strains were also present in all four isolates. The vaccine strain exhibited an amino acid change 279D-N, a feature of attenuated vaccine strains. The phylogenetic analysis showed that all field isolates in the present study were closely related to the reported field isolates from Great Britain (UK661) and Japan (OKYM). All four field IBDV strains of the present study were closely related but distinct from previously reported vvIBDVs from India. Based on nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis, it is very likely that strains causing IBD in this part of India are very virulent in character and are still undergoing changes at the genetic level. © 2006 Informa UK Ltd.
authors: Mittal, D.;Jindal, N.;Gupta, S. L.;Kataria, R. S.;Singh, K.;Tiwari, A. K.

title: Complete genomic sequence analysis of novel subtype 3k hepatitis E virus isolates with 99.97% nucleotide identity obtained from two consecutive patients with acute hepatitis in a city in northeastern Japan
abstract: Complete hepatitis E virus (HEV) genomic sequences obtained from two consecutive cases of acute self-limited hepatitis E in a city in northeastern Japan have been determined. Interestingly, two HEV isolates from each patient shared 99.97% nucleotide identity at 7,225 nucleotides, and phylogenetic analysis showed that they formed a cluster of Japanese isolates, which is considered a novel HEV subtype 3k. The high similarity of the HEV sequences of two isolates from these patients in this study indicated that an HEV subtype 3k strain had spread via a foodstuff commonly distributed in the city, possibly pork liver.
authors: Miura, M.;Inoue, J.;Tsuruoka, M.;Nishizawa, T.;Nagashima, S.;Takahashi, M.;Shimosegawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Isolation of chuzan virus, a new member of the palyam subgroup of the genus Orbivirus, from cattle and Culicoides oxystoma in Japan
abstract: Five virus strains with identical antigenic properties were isolated from 3 RBC suspensions obtained from 2 healthy sentinel calves and from 2 pools of Culicoides oxystoma in cultures of a hamster lung cell line (HmLu-1). The virus was tentatively named Chuzan virus. Chuzan virus has been classified as a new member of the palyam subgroup of the genus Orbivirus based on its physicochemical, morphological and antigenic properties.
authors: Miura, Y.;Goto, Y.;Kubo, M.;Kono, Y.

title: Pestiviruses: a review review
abstract: Pestiviruses comprise a group of economically important animal pathogens, namely swine cholera, bovine viral diarrhea and border disease viruses. The viruses are closely related serologically and share a common host range, namely pigs and numerous domestic and wild ruminants. Transmission between species is common. Despite some commonalities in their natural hosts, the pathogenesis of pestivirus-induced disease is complex; in particular, some aspects of the highly fatal bovine mucosal disease remain enigmatic. Pestiviruses are among the smallest enveloped single-stranded RNA viruses with an icosahedral nucleocapsid. They are currently classified as Togaviridae. However, due to recent advances in the molecular characterization of the viruses, their taxonomic relocation seems inevitable. Viral RNAs studied to date have a large open reading frame and no subgenomic RNA is detectable in infected cells. Structural proteins are encoded by genes located at the 5' end of RNA. Most of the genome encodes 2-3 nonstructural proteins. Virions consist of a major and a minor envelope glycoprotein with molecular weights of 53 and 48 kD, respectively. The core consists of a small protein with a molecular weight of 20 kD. Analysis of viral proteins with monoclonal antibodies has revealed detailed information about the antigenic composition of both structural and non-structural proteins. [References: 102]
authors: Moenning, V.

title: Defects in the barrier function and morphology of the small intestinal epithelium associated with failure to thrive before weaning syndrome (PFTS) in pigs
authors: Moeser, A. J.;Borst, L. B.;Overman, B. L.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of bovine kobuvirus in calves in Egypt
abstract: Kobuviruses are small non-enveloped RNA viruses that are likely to cause diarrhea in cattle and swine. Since its discovery in 2003, few studies have looked at bovine kobuvirus (BKoV; a species of Aichivirus B) infection. BKoV has been reported in Europe, Asia, and South America, indicating a global distribution. To investigate the presence of BKoV in Egypt, 36 fecal samples from diarrhea calves in two different Egyptian provinces (Cairo and Sharkia) were analyzed by RT-PCR and 24 (66.7%) were found positive for BKoV. RNA from one of the positive samples (BKoV/Egy-1/KY407744) was subjected to next-generation sequencing to determine the complete BKoV genomic sequence. Compared to the single recorded BKoV genome sequence (BKoV/U-1/AB084788), the strain examined showed 94 amino acid (aa) substitutions throughout its polyprotein (2463 aa), one nucleotide (nt) insertion and one nt deletion in the 2B gene and 4 nt deletions in the UTRs (2 each). In addition, five VP1 and seven 3D sequences were obtained from other samples using RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing. A discrepancy in the phylogenetic topography of VP1 and 3D was observed, with the Egyptian VP1 sequences being classified as a separate cluster within the proposed lineage 1 (genotype A), which also contained strains from Britain, Brazil and Japan. While the Cairo 3D sequences were related to those of Chinese tribes, in contrast to those of Sharkia, which were closer to Korean tribes. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first detection and genomic characterization of BKoV in Egypt or even Africa.
authors: Mohamed, F. F.;Mansour, S. M. G.;Orabi, A.;El-Araby, I. E.;Ng, T. F. F.;Mor, S. K.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Effect of phylogenetic diversity of velogenous Newcastle disease virus challenge on virus shedding after homologous and heterologous DNA vaccination in chickens
abstract: Newcastle Disease (ND) is an extremely devastating disease for the poultry industry as it causes high economic losses. In this present study, a DNA vaccine containing the F and HN surface antigens of a highly virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV), NDV/1/Chicken/2005 (FJ939313), was successfully prepared. The cell transfection assay showed that the vaccine expressed the F and HN genes in Hep-2 cells. The main aim of this study was to compare the level of protection induced by DNA vaccination after homologous and heterologous NDV challenge, as determined by the amount of NDV shedding after challenge. NDV antibody-negative chickens were vaccinated either once, twice or three times intramuscularly at 7, 14 and 21 days of age and 14 days post-vaccination with one of the two homologous viruses (vaccine-matched velogenic viscerotropic Newcastle disease virus (vvNDV ) strain, FJ939313). , phylogenetically related to group VII, or a phylogenetically divergent heterologous virus (unmatched vvNDV strain, AY968809) belonging to genogroup VI and showing 84.1% nucleotide similarity to the NDV sequences of the DNA vaccine. Our data show that birds that received a single dose of the DNA vaccine were poorly protected and only 30-40% of these birds survived after challenge with a high titer of virus shedding. Multiple administrations of the DNA vaccine induced high protection rates of 70-90% with reduced virus shedding compared to the unvaccinated and the challenged birds. In general, the homologous challenge resulted in decreased tracheal and cloacal detachment compared to the heterologous vvNDV strain. This study offers a promising approach for the control of ND in chickens using DNA vaccines that are phylogenetically closely related to the circulating field strains.
authors: Mohamed, M. H.;Abdelaziz, A. M.;Kumar, S.;Al-Habib, M. A.;Megahed, M. M.

title: Full genome sequence of a virulent Newcastle disease virus isolated from an outbreak in chickens in Egypt
abstract: The complete genome sequence of a virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from chickens in Egypt was determined and compared to the sequence of NDV strains isolated from different parts of the world. The genome is 15,186 nucleotides (nt) long and consists of 6 genes in the order 3″-NPMF-HN-L-5″. The genome contains a 55 nt leader region at the 3 inch end and a 114 nt trailer region at the 5 inch end. Interestingly, the phylogenetic analysis showed that the Egypt strain is closely related to the NDV strains isolated in China. In addition, the sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site of the Egypt strain was identical to that of the NDV strain recently isolated in Mali. The determination of complete genome sequences of other NDV strains from Africa is necessary to understand the epidemiology of the viruses currently circulating in Africa. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Mohamed, M. H. A.;Kumar, S.;Paldurai, A.;Megahed, M. M.;Ghanem, I. A.;Lebdah, M. A.;Samal, S. K.

title: Application of molecular biology techniques for the detection of epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus (EHDV-318) recovered from a sentinel calf in central Sudan
abstract: Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease Virus (EHDV) isolate 318 (EHDV-318), an untyped virus recovered from a sentinel calf herd at the Khartoum University farm in central Sudan, was characterized using molecular biology techniques. Using the dot blot hybridization technique, a cDNA probe derived from genome segment 6 of EHDV-2 (Alberta strain) hybridized with RNA of EHDV-318. Application of serogroup-specific EHDV polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to EHDV-318 RNA resulted in specific amplification of a 387 bp PCR product. The amplification product was visualized on ethidium bromide stained agarose gel. The specificity of the PCR products was confirmed by chemiluminescence hybridization with a non-radiolabeled internal probe. No amplification product or hybridization signal was detected when the serotype-specific EHDV-1 or EHDV-2 PCR-based assays were applied to EHDV-318 RNA. Scientific data presented in this study indicate that cDNA probes and serogroup-specific PCR-based assays can be used to classify the virus as a member of the EHDV serogroup and as serotypically distinct from EHDV-1 and EHDV-2.
authors: Mohammed, M. E. H.;Aradaib, I. E.;Mukhtar, M. M.;Ghalib, H. W.;Riemann, H. P.;Oyejide, A.;Osburn, B. I.

title: Analysis of the leader proteinase (Lpro) region of foot-and-mouth disease virus type A with due emphasis on the phylogeny and evolution of the nascent VP359 deletion lineage from India
abstract: The genotype-inclusive grouping of Indian type A isolates as observed in the 1D region-based phylogeny was skewed throughout the Lpro region, where the VP359 deletion group lineages of genotype VII differ from both genotypes VII and VI removed grouped, which confirms its uniqueness and independent evolution from Lpro and 1D area. Similar to the 1D region, even in the L region, this deletion group gradually diverges genetically, forming a larger number of lineages, and the distance between the lineages in the L region is considerably larger than that in the 1D region. The deletion group is restricted to India only, as none of the exotic sequences cluster within this group. Notably, L protein showed variability comparable to external capsid proteins, as evidenced by its high dN/dS ratio (0.105), number of variable amino acid positions (41%), low Ts/Tv ratio (3.47), and the Alignment shows that the N-terminal region, β2-sheet and C-terminal extension are highly variable. Basic residues on P1, P3 and only leucine on P2 were predicted to provide an optimal autocatalytic cleavage site on the L/P1 junction. All eight sites identified as positively selected displayed aa substitutions with different physicochemical properties, and lineage-specific signatures were observed at two positions, supporting the claim that lineages evolve under different selection pressures to adapt to the different ecological adapt environment. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Mohapatra, J. K.;Priyadarshini, P.;Pandey, L.;Subramaniam, S.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Pattnaik, B.

title: Genetic variability of group H porcine rotavirus VP6, VP7, VP4 and NSP4 genes detected in Brazil
abstract: Rotavirus (RV) is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis in humans and animals. Despite the seven groups/species of RV (AG), the creation of a new RV group/species H (RVH) based on VP6 sequence analysis has recently been proposed. In this study, we determined the VP6, VP7, VP4, and NSP4 nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of 6 (BR59-BR64) RVH-positive stool samples obtained from piglets with diarrhea in Mato Grosso do Sul, Central-West Region of Brazil were 2012, using the RT-PCR assay. Based on the high sequence identities (>99%) of the VP6, VP4, VP7, and NSP4 genes in 5 of the stool samples examined (BR59-BR63), they are considered to be the same local rotavirus strain, designated RVH/BRA-1 . In contrast, the stool sample BR64, as soon as it showed a relatively high difference (81.6% nt identity and 83.4% aa identity) in the VP7 sequence compared to the other 5 samples, was classified as RVH/BRA- 2-stem denoted. Comparative phylogenetic analyzes showed that the 6 RVH strains do not group together with any available sequences from members of the established RV groups (RVA-RVG), but appear to be related to RVB and RVG. These results confirm the occurrence of RVH in Brazil, demonstrate their genetic diversity and provide new data that will help to understand viral phylogeny and epidemiology, as well as explain patterns of viral evolution and biological properties of RVH.
authors: Molinari, B. L. D.;Alfieri, A. F.;Alfieri, A. A.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Pigeon Paramyxovirus Type-1 Identified in Mourning-collared Pigeons (Streptopelia decipiens) in Namibia, Africa
abstract: We generated the full sequence of the fusion protein gene (F) from six pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1) isolated between 2016 and 2017 from Mourning Collared-Doves (Streptopelia decipiens) in Namibia, Africa. All isolates had an F gene cleavage motif from 112RRQKRF117 characteristic of virulent viruses. A phylogenetic analysis using the full F gene sequence revealed that the viruses belonged to genotype VIa and were epidemiologically related to PPMV-1 from Asia, Europe and North America.
authors: Molini, U.;Aikukutu, G.;Khaiseb, S.;Cattoli, G.;Dundon, W. G.

title: The genome of the chicken bursal lymphoma cell line DT40
abstract: The chicken DT40 cell line is a widely used model system in the study of multiple cellular processes due to the efficiency of homologous gene targeting. The cell line was derived from a bursal lymphoma induced by an avian leukosis virus infection. In this study, we characterized the genome of the cell line using whole genome shotgun sequencing and single nucleotide polymorphism array hybridization. The results show that wild-type DT40 has a relatively normal karyotype, except for the increase in copy number throughout the chromosome, and no intra-herd variability in karyotype. Comparing two domestic chicken genomes and the Gallus gallus reference genome, we found no unique mutational processes shaping the DT40 genome, except for a slight increase in insertion and deletion events, particularly deletions at tandem repeats. We mapped coding sequence mutations unique to the DT40 genome; Mutations that inactivate the PIK3R1 and ATRX genes likely contributed to oncogenic transformation. In addition to a known avian leukosis virus integration into the MYC gene, we discovered additional integration sites that likely deregulate gene expression. The new findings support the hypothesis that DT40 is a typical transformed cell line with a relatively intact genome; hence, it is well suited to the role of a model system for DNA repair and related processes. The sequence data generated by this study, including a searchable de novo genome array and annotated lists of mutant genes, will support future research using this cell line.
authors: MolnÃ¡r, J.;PÃ³ti, A.;Pipek, O.;Krzystanek, M.;Kanu, N.;Swanton, C.;TusnÃ¡dy, G. E.;Szallasi, Z.;Csabai, I.;SzÃ¼ts, D.

title: Altered virome and bacterial microbiome in human immunodeficiency virus-associated acquired immunodeficiency syndrome
authors: Monaco, C. L.;Gootenberg, D. B.;Zhao, G.;Handley, S. A.

title: Viruses isolated from reptiles: identification of three new members of the family Rhabdoviridae
abstract: The growth of four viruses isolated from lizards in Brazil (Marco, Chaco, and Timboviruses) and Australia (Almpiwarvirus) were studied in a variety of continuous mammalian, reptilian, amphibian, and fish cell lines. Although replication was found in certain cell lines derived from cold-blooded species, the cytopathic effect (CPE) was absent or minimal, and growth was less than or equal to that in mammalian cells. These observations appear to limit the value of poikilothermic cells for the primary isolation of viruses from field-collected cold-blooded vertebrates or arthropods that feed on them. The four reptilian viruses turned out to be naturally occurring, temperature-sensitive pathogens with a growth optimum of around 30°C. Electron microscopic studies showed that three of the viruses (Marco, Chaco and Timbo) are new members of the Rhabdoviridae family. Marco virus particles were conical in shape and resembled bovine ephemeral fever virus and two lyssaviruses (Kotonkan and Obodhaing). Chaco and Timbo viruses were cylindrical viruses resembling other rhabdoviruses with particle lengths longer than the prototype VSV. No serological relationships were found between these viruses, Marco virus and 34 other rhabdoviruses in cross-complement fixation tests.
authors: Monath, T. P.;Cropp, C. B.;Frazier, C. L.

title: Detection of orf virus from an outbreak in goats and its genetic relationship to other parapoxviruses
authors: Mondal, B.;Bera, A. K.;Hosamani, M.;Tembhurne, P. A.;Bandyopadhyay, S. K.

title: Comparison of four regions in the replicase gene of heterologous infectious bronchitis virus strains
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) produces six subgenomic (sg) mRNAs, each containing a 64 nucleotide (nt) leader sequence derived by a discontinuous process from the 5 inch end of the genome. Several putative functional domains such as a papain-like proteinase (PLpro), major protease (Mpro), RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), and RNA helicase encoded by the replicase gene are important for viral replication. We sequenced four regions of the replicase genes corresponding to the 5-terminal sequence, PLpro, Mpro, and RdRp domains of 20 heterologous IBV strains and compared them to previously published coronavirus sequences. All of the coronavirus 5-termini and PLpro domains were distinct, in contrast to the Mpro and RdRp domains, which were highly conserved with 28% and 48% residues conserved, respectively. In the IBV strains, the 5'' untranslated region including the leader sequence was highly conserved (>94% identical); whereas the N-terminal coding region and PLpro domains were highly variable, ranging from 84.6% to 100% and 77.6% to 100% identity, respectively. The IBV Mpro and RdRp domains were highly conserved with 82.7% and 92.7% residues conserved, respectively. The BJ strain differed most from other IBVs in all four regions of the replicase. Phylogeny-based clustering based on replicase genes was identical to antigen-based classification of coronaviruses into three groups. However, IBV strain classification based on replicase gene domains did not correlate with that of type-specific antigenic groups. The replicase gene sequences of many IBVs recovered from infected chickens were identical to those of vaccine viruses, regardless of serotype, suggesting that either genetic material was exchanged between vaccine and field isolates or that there was convergent evolution to a particular replicase genotype gave . There was no correlation between genotype of any region of the replicase gene and pathotype, suggesting that replicase is not the sole determinant of IBV pathogenicity. © 2004 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Mondal, S. P.;Cardona, C. J.

title: Molecular Characterization of Bovine Rotavirus Strains Circulating in Northern Italy, 2003-2005
abstract: total of 232 faecal samples from calves infected with rotavirus in herds in northern Italy from 2003 to 2005 were examined. Rotavirus G and P types were determined using nested RT-PCR. G6 was the most prevalent genotype, accounting for 78.5% of samples, G10 accounted for 9.9% of samples, and G8-type viruses were found in 4.7% of samples. Viruses were not classified in 3% of the samples due to co-infection with multiple G-type strains, while viruses could not be characterized in 3.9% of the samples with any of the G-specific primers used in this study. The most common P types were P[11] and P[5], accounting for 65.1% and 25%, respectively. Samples with multiple P-specific primers reacted in 2.6% of cases; no P[1] serotype was identified. The G6P[11] combination was predominant throughout the study period, ie 52.5% in 2003, 50% in 2004 and 40% in 2005. The incidence of G6P[5] increased from 13.1% per year 2003 to 27% in 2004 and 25.5%. in 2005. The G10P[11] combination decreased significantly from 18% in 2003 to 2.6% in 2004 and increased again to 7.3% in 2005. G8P[11] viruses were similarly present in 2003 (5%) and 2004 (4.3%). , declining slightly in 2005 (1.8%). © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Monini, M.;Cappuccini, F.;Battista, P.;Falcone, E.;Lavazza, A.;Ruggeri, F. M.

title: Reassortant avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses containing the H9N2-PB1 gene in poultry, Bangladesh
abstract: Bangladesh has reported high numbers of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) (H5N1) in poultry. We identified a natural reassortant HPAI (H5N1) virus containing an H9N2 PB1 gene in poultry in Bangladesh. Our results underscore the risks of prolonged co-circulation of avian influenza viruses and the need to monitor their evolution.
authors: Monne, I.;Yamage, M.;Dauphin, G.;Claes, F.;Ahmed, G.;Giasuddin, M.;Salviato, A.;Ormelli, S.;Bonfante, F.;Schivo, A.;Cattoli, G.

title: Immunomodulatory effects of heat stress and lipopolysaccharide on the bursal transcriptome in two different chicken lines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Exposure to heat stress suppresses the immune response of poultry, which may increase susceptibility to infectious diseases and thereby amplify the negative effects of heat on poultry welfare and performance. Identifying genes and signaling pathways that are affected by high temperature, particularly heat-induced changes in immune response, could provide targets for improving disease resistance in chickens. This study used RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) to examine the transcriptome responses in Fabricius bursa, a primary immune tissue, after exposure to acute heat stress and/or subcutaneous immune stimulation with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in a 2 x 2 factorial design: Thermoneutral + Saline, Heat + Saline, Thermoneutral + LPS, and Heat + LPS. All treatments were studied in two chicken lines: a relatively heat and disease resistant Fayoumi line and a more susceptible broiler line. RESULTS: Differential expression analysis revealed that heat + saline had a limited effect on gene expression (N=1 or 63 genes) in broilers or Fayoumi bursa. However, Thermoneutral + LPS and Heat + LPS produced many expression changes in Fayoumi Bursa (N=368 and 804 genes). It was predicted that thermoneutral + LPS would increase immune-related cell signaling and cell migration, while heat + LPS would activate mortality-related functions and decrease expression in WNT signaling pathways. Further comparisons between treatments in the Fayoumi line showed that heat stress prevented many of the expression changes caused by LPS. Although less significant expression changes were observed in the broiler bursa after exposure to either thermoneutral + LPS (N = 59 genes) or heat + LPS (N = 146 genes), both treatments were predicted to increase cell migration. Direct comparison between the lines (broilers with Fayoumi) confirmed that each line had different responses to the treatment. CONCLUSIONS: Transcriptome analysis identified genes and signaling pathways involved in bursal responses to heat stress and LPS and revealed that these effects were greatest with the combined treatment. The interaction between estrus and LPS was lineage dependent, with suppressive expression changes mainly in the Fayoumi lineage. Potential target genes, particularly those involved in cell migration and immune signaling, may inform future research on heat stress in poultry and prove useful to improve disease resistance.
authors: Monson, M. S.;Van Goor, A. G.;Ashwell, C. M.;Persia, M. E.;Rothschild, M. F.;Schmidt, C. J.;Lamont, S. J.

title: Genetic analysis of avian influenza virus from migratory waterfowl in Mexico
abstract: This study describes the genetic characterization of avian influenza virus from aquatic birds in Mexico. Partial sequences of two H5, one H6 and one H9 haemagglutinin (HA) gene were determined. The deduced amino acid sequences showed that they were low pathogenic viruses (LPAI). Phylogenetic analysis of H5- and H6-HA indicate a North American lineage closely related to contemporary California isolates, and H9-HA was closer to the Korean-like lineage. These results demonstrate the introduction of a diverse genetic pool of subtypes into the Sonoran estuaries by the circulation of carrier bird species from the Pacific Flyway.
authors: Montalvo-Corral, M.;Hernandez, J.

title: Genetic grouping of avian infectious bronchitis virus isolated in Brazil based on RT-PCR/RFLP analysis of S1 gene
abstract: Twelve Brazilian isolates and a reference vaccine strain of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were propagated in embryonating chicken eggs. The entire S1 glycoprotein gene of these viruses was analyzed by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment length polymorphism (RT-PCR-RFLP) using the restriction enzymes HaeIII, XcmI and Bstyl. The RFLP patterns led to the classification of these isolates into five different genotypes: A, B, C, D and Massachusetts. Five out of twelve isolates were grouped into Massachusetts genotypes and the remaining seven viruses were grouped into four different genotypes: A(2), B(2), C(2), or D(1). Such genotyping classification was consistent with previous immunological analyzes for most of these viruses, highlighting the occurrence of relevant variability among IBV strains circulating in Brazilian commercial poultry flocks.
authors: Montassier, M. D. S.;Brentano, L.;Montassier, H. J.;Richtzenhain, L. J.

title: Detection and genetic identification of pestiviruses in Brazilian batches of fetal bovine serum collected from 2006 to 2014
abstract: The present study performed a genetic identification of pestiviruses contaminating the genome of fetal bovine serum (FBS) batches produced in Brazil from 2006 to 2014. Thirty-nine lots (53.4%) were positive for pestivirus RNA and one contained infectious virus. Nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the 5'-UTR identified 34 lots (46.6%) containing bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 (BVDV-1) RNA, namely 23 BVDV-1a (5'-UTR identity 90, 8-98.7%), eight BVDV-1b (93.9-96.7%) and three BVDV-1d (96.2-97.6%). Six batches (8.2%) contained BVDV-2 (90.3-100% UTR identity), two of which were BVDV-2a; three BVDV-2b and one undetermined. Four FBS lots (5.5%) were contaminated with HoBi-like virus (98.3 to 100%). Five batches (6.8%) contained more than one pestivirus. The high frequency of contamination of FBS with pestivirus RNA reinforces the need for systematic and updated guidelines to monitor this product to reduce the risk of biological agent contamination and introduction of contaminants into vacant areas.
authors: Monteiro, F. L.;Cargnelutti, J. F.;Braunig, P.;Folgueras-Flatschart, A. V.;Santos, N. C.;Pituco, E. M.;Weiblen, R.;Flores, E. F.

title: Circulation of hepatitis E virus in Italy: phylogenetic and evolutionary analysis
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E virus (HEV), a major cause of acute viral hepatitis in developing countries, has been classified into four major genotypes and a number of subtypes. New genotypes have recently been identified in various mammals, including HEV genotype 3, which is distributed worldwide. It is widespread among pigs in developed countries. Aims: This study investigated the genetic diversity of HEV in humans and pigs in Italy. The emergence date and demographic history of the HEV were also estimated. Materials and Methods: A total of 327 porcine and human HEV sequences from Italy were downloaded from the National Center for Biotechnology Information. Three different data sets were created. The first and second sets of data were used to confirm the genotype of the analyzed sequences. The third dataset was used to estimate the mean evolutionary rate and to determine time-scaled phylogeny and demographic history. Results: The Bayesian maximumclade credibility tree and the time of the most common estimates of the most recent ancestors showed that the root of the tree dates back to 1907 (95% HPD: 1811 - 1975). Two main clades were found, divided into two subclades. Skyline plot analysis, performed separately for human and pig sequences, showed the presence of a bottleneck only in the skyline plot of the pig sequences. The selective pressure analysis revealed only negatively selected areas. Conclusions: This study supports the hypothesis that humans are likely to become infected after exposure to porcine sources. The results underline the importance of verifying the country of origin of pigs and improving sanitary control measures from a veterinary point of view in order to prevent the spread of HEV infection in Italy.
authors: Montesano, C.;Giovanetti, M.;Ciotti, M.;Cella, E.;Lo Presti, A.;Grifoni, A.;Zehender, G.;Angeletti, S.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: Viral interactions with the host and microbiota in the gut
abstract: This review article examines the recent advances made in our understanding of the interactions between host viruses in the gut. Technological advances have allowed the initial definition of enteric vioma in a number of species, including humans. Important advances in our knowledge of the host response to viral infection have revealed that interferon lambda plays a role that is unique to type I interferons in the gut. Finally, our understanding of virally induced phenotypes has been enhanced by new studies showing that bacteria can play an important role in the outcome of a viral infection in the gut. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Moon, C.;Stappenbeck, T. S.

title: Sequence comparison of S1 glycoproteins of Florida serotype infectious avian bronchitis virus and five variant isolates from Georgia and California
abstract: The spike glycoprotein S1 subunit of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is required to initiate infection and contains virus-neutralizing and serotype-specific epitopes. The nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences of the S1 gene for strain Florida 18288 and isolates GA-92, CV-56b, CV-9437, CV-1686 and 1013 are reported. These sequences were compared to previously published gene sequences from IBV strains . and phylogenetic relationships are reported. The SI amino acid sequence of Florida 18288 was 94.9% similar to strain Connecticut and GA-92 was 92.8% similar to strain Arkansas 99. The S1 amino acid sequences of Californian variants CV-56b, CV-9437 and CV -1686 were 97.6-99.3% similar and only 76.6-76.8% similar to the Arkansas-type strains. Isolate 1013, also from California, was 84.0% similar to Ark DPI and 77.9% similar to CV-56b. When comparing 19 viruses isolated from the United States, sequence variations were observed between amino acids 55-96, 115-149, 255-309 and 378-395. Similar regions are reported to be involved in virus neutralizing and/or serotype specific epitopes. These data show that different IBV strains continue to emerge and unique variants can circulate among poultry in geographically isolated areas.
authors: Moore, K. M.;Bennett, J. D.;Seal, B. S.;Jackwood, M. W.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin genes of 12 H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from chickens in Iran from 2003 to 2005
abstract: In the present study, the hemagglutinin genes of 12 influenza viruses of the subtype H9N2 from 2003 to 2005 were isolated from chicken flocks in different provinces of Iran, amplified and sequenced. All 12 isolates displayed similar sequences at the RSSF/GLF cleavage site, bearing eight potential glycosylation sites and sharing the characteristic deduced amino acid residues alanine-190, glutamine-226 and glutamine-227 at the receptor binding site. Ten of these 12 isolates had leucine at position 226, which predominates in the sequences found in human H2 and H3 strains. Overall, the presence in these Iranian avian animals of H9N2 viruses of the sequence known to bind to human-type receptors and the presence of antibodies to H9N2 in the human population of Iran indicated that it is possible that in the Iran circulating H9N2 avian influenza viruses infect humans. Therefore, comprehensive surveillance of H9N2 in this country is strongly recommended. © 2010 American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Moosakhani, F.;Shoshtari, A. H.;Pourbakhsh, S. A.;Keyvanfar, H.;Ghorbani, A.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of porcine Astrovirus strains associated with swine diarrhea
abstract: Astrovirus has been reported to be associated with diarrhea in pigs. The current study was performed to detect and molecularly characterize astroviruses in diarrheal pigs submitted to the University of Minnesota Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory. The intestinal contents of 269 pigs were examined by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and 62% were found positive for astrovirus. Of the positive specimens, 20% were positive for astrovirus only, while astrovirus with rotavirus was detected in 58% of the specimens. The remaining 22% showed the presence of astrovirus along with porcine haemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus, transmissible gastroenteritis virus, or porcine circovirus-2. Capsid gene sequencing of 56 randomly selected samples confirmed that they were porcine astrovirus type 4 (PAstV-4) with 58-100% nucleotide identity within these viruses. The phylogenetic analysis revealed 2 possible subgroups. The results show that PAstV is present on swine farms in the United States and can be associated with diarrhea either alone or in combination with other enteric viruses. Further studies are needed to determine strain diversity among porcine astroviruses so that appropriate control strategies can be developed and implemented. © 2012 The author(s).
authors: Mor, S. K.;Chander, Y.;Marthaler, D.;Patnayak, D. P.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Molecular characterization of L-class genome segments of a newly isolated turkey arthritis reovirus
abstract: Seven strains of turkey arthritis reovirus (TARV) isolated from turkey arthritis cases were characterized based on their class L genomic segment sequences, which were then compared to those of enteric turkey reovirus (TERV) and chicken reovirus (CRV) were compared. All three L-class gene segments of TARVs and TERVs and their encoded proteins ΔA, ΔB and ΔC were similar in size to those of the CRV reference strain S1133. The conserved motifs such as C2H2 zinc binding motif and conserved polymerase region were present in κA and κB, respectively. A conserved motif for the ATP/GTP binding site and an S-adenosyl-. l-Methionine (SAM) binding pocket for methyltransferase were observed in the κC protein of TARVs and TERVs with only one substitution compared to CRV. We propose a new genotype classification system for avian reoviruses (ARVs) based on the nt identity cutoff for each of the L classes. Based on this new genotype classification, all ARVs have been grouped into six, seven, and eight genotypes in L1, L2, and L3 genes, respectively. Interestingly, TARVs and TERVs with three CRVs (two arthritic strains from Taiwan and one enteric strain from Japan) in the L1-I genotype clustered and formed a different genotype (L2-I, L3-I) than CRVs in the L2 and L3 genes Maximum nucleotide divergence was observed in the genotypes of the L1 and L2 genes, but less at the amino acid level indicates that most of the changes were of the synonymous type. Compared to the L1 and L2 genes, the non-synonymous changes were more in the L3 gene. Point mutations and possible reassortments between TARVs, TERVs and CRVs have also been observed. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Mor, S. K.;Sharafeldin, T. A.;Porter, R. E.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Characterization of canine fecal virome in healthy dogs and dogs with acute diarrhea using shotgun metagenomics
authors: Moreno, P. S.;Wagner, J.;Mansfield, C. S.;Stevens, M.

title: Concise and broadly applicable method for determining the genomic sequences of North American porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses in different clusters
abstract: We have developed a concise and broadly applicable method for the accurate genomic sequencing of North American genotype (NA-type) porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses (PRRSVs) that overcomes the high genetic variability of the viruses. The method, termed "combination consensus oligonucleotide reverse transcription and multiple displacement amplification" (CORT-MDA), involves reverse transcription of viral RNA followed by post-amplification shotgun sequencing using only 11 degenerate oligonucleotide primers ; these primers were designed against consensus regions within the open reading frames of the 124 NA-type PRRSV strains with reported full-length genomic sequences. Sequencing of the 192 shotgun clones generated per virus showed 80% to 94% coverage of the reported PRRSV genomic sequence, leaving only 2 or 3 unread regions to be resequenced after PCR amplification using custom primers. Direct sequencing of RT-PCR products confirmed the absolute agreement between the sequences determined by the CORT-MDA method and those from RT-PCR. These results suggest that our method is applicable to various NA-type viruses.
authors: Morozumi, T.;Iseki, H.;Toki, D.;Takagi, M.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Uenishi, H.

title: Genomic evolution, recombination, and diversity between strains of Chelonid alphaherpesvirus 5 from Florida and Hawaii green sea turtles with fibropapillomatosis
abstract: Chelonid alphaherpesvirus 5 (ChHV5) is a herpesvirus associated with fibropapillomatosis (FP) in sea turtles worldwide. Single locus typing has previously demonstrated differentiation between Atlantic and Pacific strains of this virus, with little variation within each geographic group. However, a lack of genomic sequence data for multiple loci hampers understanding the rate and mechanisms of ChHV5 evolutionary divergence and how these genomic changes may contribute to differences in disease manifestation. To assess genomic variation in ChHV5 in five Hawaiian and three Florida green sea turtles, we used high-throughput short-read sequencing of long-range PCR products amplified from tumor tissue using primers derived from the only available ChHV5 reference genome was developed from a Hawaiian Green Sea turtle. This strategy recovered sequence data from both geographic regions for approximately 75% of the predicted ChHV5 coding sequences. The average nucleotide divergence between geographic populations was 1.5%; Most substitutions were fixed differences between regions. Protein divergence was generally low (mean 0.08%), ranging from 0 to 5.3%. Several atypical genes originally identified and annotated in the reference genome have been confirmed in ChHV5 genomes from both geographic locations. Clear recombination events have been identified between geographic regions, and the accumulation of private alleles indicates the prevalence of recombination in ChHV5 evolutionary history. This study significantly increased the amount of available sequence data of ChHV5 strains, allowing informed selection of loci for future population genetic and natural history studies and suggesting the (possibly latent) co-infection of individuals by well-differentiated geographic variants.
authors: Morrison, C. L.;Iwanowici, L.;Work, T. M.;Fahsbender, E.;Breitbart, M.;Adams, C.;Iwanowiczi, D.;Sanders, L.;Ackermann, M.;Cornman, R. S.

title: Myeloid and erythroid neoplastic responses to avian leukemia viruses in chickens and quail
abstract: comparative study of the oncogenic potential of two avian leukemia viruses (DLVs) shows that avian erythroblastosis virus induces myeloid leukemia in quail and confirms that E26 causes erythroid leukemia in chickens. These results indicate that the response of birds to these two DLVs depends on the host species and suggest that the classification of DLVs based only on in vitro studies may not be definitive.
authors: Moscovici, C.;Samarut, J.;Gazzolo, L.;Moscovici, M. G.

title: A next-generation, universal sequencing protocol for generating non-infectious barcode cDNA libraries from high-containment RNA viruses
abstract: Several biosafety level 3 and/or 4 (BSL-3/4) pathogens are single-stranded RNA viruses of high consequence, and their genomes are infectious when introduced into permissive cells. In addition, many of these viruses are Select Agents (SAs) and their genomes are also considered SAs. For this reason, cDNAs and/or their derivatives must be tested for the absence of infectious virus and/or viral RNA prior to transfer from the BSL-3/4 and/or SA laboratory. This severely limits the capacity to conduct viral genomics research, particularly the application of next-generation sequencing (NGS). Here we present a sequence-independent method to rapidly amplify viral genomic RNA while abolishing both viral and genomic RNA infectivity across multiple single-stranded positive-sense RNA (ssRNA+) virus families. The method generates barcoded DNA amplicons ranging in length from 300 to 1,000 bp that cannot be used to rescue a virus and are stable for transport at room temperature. Our barcode approach allows up to 288 barcode samples to be pooled into a single library and run on different NGS platforms without potential viral genome reconstitution. Our data demonstrate that this approach yields full-length genomic sequence information not only from high-titer virion preparations, but also recovers specific viral sequences from samples with limited starting material in the cellular RNA background and can be used to identify pathogens from unknown samples. In summary, we describe a rapid, standard, universal working procedure that generates high-quality NGS libraries free of infectious virus and infectious viral RNA. IMPORTANT This report establishes and validates a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for selected Active Substances (SAs) and other Biosafety Level 3 and/or 4 (BSL-3/4) RNA viruses to rapidly generate barcoded non-infectious cDNA used for the next-generation sequencing (NGS). This removes the burden of testing all processed samples derived from high-consequence pathogens before transferring them from high-containment labs to low-containment facilities for sequencing. Our established protocol can be scaled up for high-throughput sequencing of hundreds of samples simultaneously, which can drastically reduce the cost and effort of NGS library creation. NGS data from this SOP can provide full genome coverage from viral stocks and also detect virus-specific reads from limited starting material. Our data suggest that the procedure can be implemented by institutional biosafety committees in research laboratories and can be easily validated.
authors: Moser, L. A.;Ramirez-Carvajal, L.;Puri, V.;Pauszek, S. J.;Matthews, K.;Dilley, K. A.;Mullan, C.;McGraw, J.;Khayat, M.;Beeri, K.;Yee, A.;Dugan, V.;Heise, M. T.;Frieman, M. B.;Rodriguez, L. L.;Bernard, K. A.;Wentworth, D. E.;Stockwell, T. B.;Shabman, R. S.

title: RNA2DMut: a web tool for the design and analysis of RNA structural mutations
abstract: With the widespread application of high-throughput sequencing, new RNA sequences are being discovered at amazing speeds. However, the analysis of the function lags behind. Secondary structure (2D base pairing) plays an essential regulatory role in both the cis and transregulatory functions of RNA. To test RNA function, it is important to be able to design and analyze mutations that can affect structure. This was the motivation for the development of the web tool RNA2DMut. RNA2DMut allows users to input RNA sequences for analysis, restrict mutations to specific residues, or limit changes to purines/pyrimidines. The sequence is analyzed at each base to determine the impact of each possible point mutation on the 2D structure. The metrics used in RNA2DMut are based on the calculation of the Boltzmann structure ensemble and do not require a robust 2D model of RNA structure to design mutations. This tool can facilitate a wide range of applications involving RNA: for example, designing and evaluating mutants for biological assays, querying RNA-protein interactions, identifying key regions to alter in SELEX experiments, and improving RNA Folding and crystallization properties for structural biology. Additional tools are available to help users introduce other mutations (e.g. indels and substitutions) and assess their impact on RNA structure. Example calculations are shown for five RNAs that require a 2D structure for their function: the MALAT1 mascRNA, an influenza virus splicing regulatory motif, the viral EBER2 non-coding RNA, the Xist lncRNA repA region, and the human YRNA 5. RNA2Dmut can be accessed at https://rna2dmut.bb.iastate.edu/.
authors: Moss, W. N.

title: Virus detection by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: We used a high-throughput sequencing platform, Ion PGM, for virus detection in fecal samples from adult cows collected in Hokkaido, Japan. Random RT-PCR was performed to amplify RNA extracted from 0.25 ml stool samples (N=8) and more than 5 μg of cDNA was synthesized. High-throughput unbiased sequencing using the 318 v2 semiconductor chip of these eight samples yielded 57-580K (average: 270K, after data analysis) reads in a single run. As a result, viral genome sequences were detected in each sample. In addition to bacteriophages, viruses originating from mammals and insects, partial genome sequences of plant, algal and protozoal viruses have been detected. Therefore, this metagenomic analysis of fecal samples could be useful to comprehensively understand intestinal viral populations and food sources in animals.
authors: Motooka, D.;Nakamura, S.;Hagiwara, K.;Nakaya, T.

title: Hepatitis E in three immunocompromised children in south-eastern France
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) causes an emerging autochthonous disease in developed countries where links to a porcine viral reservoir have been identified. In addition, chronic HEV infection and associated cirrhosis have been described in severely immunocompromised patients. However, few studies worldwide have focused on pediatric HEV infection, and only four autochthonous cases in children in developed countries have been reported. We describe here acute hepatitis E in three immunocompromised children. Case #1 was a 9-year-old girl who received a liver transplant who was diagnosed with 2009 H1N1 influenza concomitantly with hepatitis E. case no. 2 was a 12-year-old boy with early medullary relapse of type B lymphoblastic leukemia and HEV RNA detected for 29 weeks. Case #3 was a 9-year-old boy with a rare primary immunodeficiency due to XIAP deficiency. HEV infections were all autochthonous and involved different viruses classified as subtypes f, c and e of genotype 3, which have been described in autochthonous cases in Europe. These three observations prompt consideration of HEV as a causative agent of hepatitis in children in developed countries, and testing for HEV particularly in severely immunocompromised individuals who may develop chronic hepatitis E. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Motte, A.;Roquelaure, B.;Galambrun, C.;Bernard, F.;Zandotti, C.;Colson, P.

title: The blood DNA virus in 8,000 people
authors: Moustafa, A.;Xie, C.;Kirkness, E.;Biggs, W.;Wong, E.

title: Epidemiological study of enteric viruses in wild boar in the Czech Republic: first evidence of a close relationship between wild boar and human rotavirus A strains
abstract: The population of wild boar is increasing across Europe, the animals are migrating close to human habitats, which greatly increases the possibility of natural transmission between domestic animals or humans and wild boar. The aim of the study was to estimate the prevalence of enteric viral pathogens, namely rotavirus groups A and C (RVA and RVC), Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) in the population of free-ranging wild boar in the Czech Republic members of the Coronaviridae family ( Transmissible Gastroenteritis Virus - TGEV, Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus - PEDV, Porcine Respiratory Coronavirus - PRCV and Porcine Hemagglutination Encephalomyelitis Virus - PHEV) and Picornaviridae, (Teschovirus A - PTV, Sapelovirus A - PSV and Enterovirus G - EV-G). In our study, faecal samples from 203 wild boar culled during the 2014–2015 hunting season (October to January) were analyzed by RT-PCR. RVA was detected in 2.5% of the samples tested. Nucleotide analysis of the VP7, VP4, and VP6 genes revealed that four RVA strains belong to the genotypes G4P[25]I1, G4P[6]I5, G11P[13]I5, and G5P[13]I5, and phylogenetic analyses indicated a close relationship with pigs and human RVAs. The prevalence of RVC in the wild boar population reached 12.8%, PTV was detected in 20.2%, PSV in 8.9% and EV-G in 2.5% of the samples. Neither PRRSV nor coronaviruses were detected during our study. Our study provides the first evidence of RVC prevalence in feral pigs and suggests that feral pigs may contribute to the genetic variability of RVA and also serve as an important reservoir for other enteric viruses.
authors: MoutelÃ­kovÃ¡, R.;DufkovÃ¡, L.;Kamler, J.;Drimaj, J.;Plhal, R.;ProdÄ›lalovÃ¡, J.

title: Defining an emerging disease
abstract: Defining an emerging disease is not easy as there are different types of disease occurrence. For example, there may be a 'real' emergence of a brand new disease, like the emergence of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in the 1980s, or a geographic emergence in a previously unaffected area, like the emergence of bluetongue in northern Europe in 2006. In addition, there may be Diseases occur in species not previously thought to be affected, e.g. B. the occurrence of bovine tuberculosis in wildlife species since 2000 in France. There may also be an unexpected increase in the incidence of disease in a known area and species, or there may simply be an increase in our knowledge or awareness of a particular disease. What all of these emerging diseases have in common is that human activities often play a role in their development. For example, bovine spongiform encephalopathy is likely to have arisen as a result of changes in the manufacture of meat and bone meal, bluetongue was able to spread to cooler climes due to the uncontrolled trade in animals, and relaxation of controls and surveillance for bovine tuberculosis allowed the resurgence of the Disease in areas where the number of cases has been drastically reduced. Globalization and population growth will continue to influence the epidemiology of diseases in the years to come, and ecosystems will continue to evolve. In addition, new technologies such as metagenomics and high-throughput sequencing are constantly identifying new microorganisms. Change is the only constant and diseases will continue to occur and we must consider the causes and different modes of occurrence when dealing with these diseases in the future.
authors: Moutou, F.;Pastoret, P. P.

title: Stem loop recognition by DDX17 facilitates miRNA processing and antiviral defense
abstract: DEAD box helicases play an essential role in RNA metabolism across species, but new data suggest they have additional roles in immunity. Through RNAi screening, we identify an evolutionarily conserved and interferon-independent role for the DEAD-box helicase DDX17 in limiting Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV), a mosquito-borne virus of the Bunyavirus family that occurs in Causes severe morbidity and mortality in humans and livestock. Loss of Drosophila DDX17 (Rm62) in cells and flies enhanced RVFV infection. Similarly, depletion of DDX17, but not the related helicase DDX5, increased RVFV replication in human cells. Using crosslinking immunoprecipitation high throughput sequencing (CLIP-seq), we show that DDX17 binds the stem loops of the host pri-miRNA to facilitate its processing and also an essential stem loop in bunyaviral RNA to restrict infection. Thus, DDX17 has a dual role in stem loop recognition: in the nucleus for endogenous microRNA (miRNA) biogenesis and in the cytoplasm for surveillance against non-self structured elements. © 2014 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Moy, R. H.;Cole, B. S.;Yasunaga, A.;Gold, B.;Shankarling, G.;Varble, A.;Molleston, J. M.;Tenoever, B. R.;Lynch, K. W.;Cherry, S.

title: Phylogeographic analysis of African swine fever virus based on the p72 gene sequence
abstract: Outbreaks of African swine fever virus (ASFV) have been recognized as a recurrent disease for almost a century. Diagnostically, a simple polymerase chain reaction and sequence-based molecular detection could be used for both viral identification and genotyping. This study established a novel phylogenetic analysis and epidemiological comparison based on 205 bp of p72 gene sequences. Based on this partial p72 fragment, an updated list of 44 different genotypes was generated from a total of 516 ASFV sequences compiled by GenBank. The nucleotide diversity was 0.04325 ± 0.00231. Analysis of spatial genetic variation divided the ASFV populations of the African continent into four clades (clade A: central and upper eastern Africa; clade B: eastern Africa; clade C: eastern and southern Africa; and clade D: southern Africa). These results and the developed protocol could serve as useful molecular tools for ASFV diagnosis from degraded DNA or decayed samples and also provide the phylogeographic perspective to identify the origin of virus outbreaks, facilitating decision planning to limit their spread.
authors: Muangkram, Y.;Sukmak, M.;Wajjwalku, W.

title: "Next-generation surveillance": An epidemiological perspective on the use of molecular information in decision-making in food safety and animal health
abstract: Advances in the availability and affordability of molecular and genomic data are transforming human healthcare. Surveillance aimed at supporting and improving food safety and animal health is likely to undergo a similar transformation. We propose a definition of “molecular surveillance” in this context, arguing that molecular data complement rather than replace sound epidemiological studies and surveillance approaches. Specific considerations are made regarding sampling, as well as the importance of the relationship between the speed of the molecular clock of genetic markers and the spatiotemporal extent of surveillance activity, which may be control or strategy oriented. The development of standards for study design and assessment of the properties of molecular surveillance systems is required, along with the development of an interdisciplinary competence base covering both molecular and epidemiological principles.
authors: Muellner, P.;StÃ¤rk, K. D. C.;Dufour, S.;Zadoks, R. N.

title: Molecular epidemiology and a loop-mediated isothermal amplification method for the diagnosis of rabies virus infection in Zambia
abstract: The National Livestock Epidemiology and Information Center (NALEIC) in Zambia reported 132 cases of rabies in dogs diagnosed with the direct fluorescent antibody test (DFAT) from 2004 to 2009. In this study, the ancestry of rabies virus (RABV) in Zambia was determined by phylogenetic analysis of nucleoprotein (N) and glycoprotein (G) gene sequences. Total RNA was extracted from 87 DFAT brain samples, of which only 35 (40%) were nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) positive for each gene and 26 were positive for both genes. Positive samples for genes N (n=33) and G (n=35) were used for phylogenetic analysis. Phylogenetic analysis of the N gene revealed two phylogenetic clusters in Zambia belonging to the Africa 1b lineage, found in eastern and southern Africa. While one cluster included exclusively Zambian strains, the other was more heterogeneous in terms of RABV origins and included strains from Tanzania, Mozambique, and Zambia. Phylogenetic analysis of the G gene revealed similar RABV strains in different hosts and regions of Zambia. We designed primers for the RT-LAMP (Reverse Transcription Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification) assay from the consensus sequence of the N gene to improve the molecular diagnosis of RABV in Zambia. The specificity and reproducibility of the RT-LAMP assay has been confirmed using actual clinical specimens. Therefore, the RT-LAMP assay presented in this study could prove useful for the routine diagnosis of rabies in Zambia. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Muleya, W.;Namangala, B.;Mweene, A.;Zulu, L.;Fandamu, P.;Banda, D.;Kimura, T.;Sawa, H.;Ishii, A.

title: A polyoma-like virus associated with an acute disease in young budgerigars (Melopsittacus undulatus).
abstract: virus previously isolated from young budgerigars (Melopsittacus undulatus) suffering from an acute disease was purified and the structural properties were determined. The virions, with an buoyant density of 1.34 g/mL, are non-enveloped icosahedral particles approximately 46-48 nm in diameter. Their DNA genome has a molecular weight of approximately 3.3 x 106 d and exists as supercoiled circular, relaxed circular, and linear molecules. There are eight structural proteins, the most common of which have a molecular weight of about 42,000 d. Empty capsid shells with buoyant densities of 1.31 g/mL are similar in size and shape but lack DNA and histone-like polypeptides. Virus replication in chick embryo cells leads to cytopathic changes characterized by rounding and enlargement of the nucleus and formation of intranuclear inclusion bodies. All of these properties justify the classification of the virus as polyoma-like.
authors: Muller, H.;Nitschke, R.

title: Genomic characterization of feline sarcoid-associated papillomavirus and proposed classification as Bos taurus papillomavirus type 14
abstract: Feline sarcoids are rare mesenchymal neoplasms of domestic and exotic cats. Previous studies have consistently identified short DNA sequences of a papillomavirus (PV) termed feline sarcoid-associated papillomavirus (FeSarPV) in these neoplasms. The FeSarPV sequence has never been detected in a non-sarcoid specimen from cats, but has been amplified from bovine skin, suggesting that feline sarcoids are caused by cross-species infection with a bovine papillomavirus (BPV). The aim of the present study was to determine the genome of the PV containing the FeSarPV sequence. Taking advantage of the circular nature of PV DNA, four specially designed "outward" primers were used to amplify two approximately 4,000 bp segments of DNA from a feline sarcoid. The two PCR products were sequenced using next-generation sequencing, and the complete genome of the PV, consisting of 7,966 bp, was assembled and analyzed. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the PV was closely related to species 4 delta BPVs-1, -2, and -13, but distantly related to any carnivorous PV genus. These results are consistent with feline sarcoids being caused by a BPV type, and we propose a classification of BPV-14 for this novel PV. Preliminary analysis suggests that the BPV-14 E5 protein, like other delta-BPVs, might cause mesenchymal proliferation by binding to the beta-receptor of platelet-derived growth factor. Interestingly, BPV-14 was not detected in any equine sarcoid, suggesting that BPV-14 has a host range restricted to bovines and felids.
authors: Munday, J. S.;Thomson, N.;Dunowska, M.;Knight, C. G.;Laurie, R. E.;Hills, S.

title: Transcriptome sequencing reveals a complete genome sequence of cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus from passion fruit in Kenya
abstract: Analysis of transcriptome sequencing (RNA-Seq) data revealed a complete genome of cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV) from virus-infected passion fruit in Kenya. We compared it to six full CABMV genomes, one each from Zimbabwe and Uganda and two each from Brazil and India. The Zimbabwean isolate CABMV-Z was the closest with 83.0% nucleotide identity.
authors: Munguti, F.;Maina, S.;Nyaboga, E. N.;Kilalo, D.;Kimani, E.;Macharia, M.;Holton, T.

title: Transcriptional response of avian cells to infection with Newcastle disease virus
abstract: Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV) causes widespread disease in poultry and wild birds around the world. cDNA microarray analysis was used to study the effect of NDV infection on host cell transcription. The results indicate that NDV infection causes apparent repression of interferon response genes during the early stages of infection. In addition, the results demonstrate transcriptional silencing of cytoskeletal proteins such as the α-, β- and β-types of actin and down-regulation of the thioredoxin gene, a likely mediator of apoptosis with possible implications for NDV pathogenesis. Comparative analyzes show that a majority of the genes transcriptionally regulated during infection with another common respiratory pathogen of poultry, avian pneumovirus, remained unaltered during NDV infection, suggesting that even phylogenetically related viruses have unique or "characteristic" Patterns of host transcriptional profiles evoke during infection of host cells. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Munir, S.;Sharma, J. M.;Kapur, V.

title: Molecular epidemiological study of infectious Bursa disease viruses in broiler farms raised in different vaccination programs
abstract: Over a period of almost 4 years, 246 bursa tissue samples were collected from commercial Brazilian broiler flocks (Gallus gallus) nationwide and printed on sample collection cards (Flinders Technology Associates (FTA) cards). A total of 75 strains of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) were successfully detected from the FTA map prints and submitted for further identification and molecular characterization. Nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences of the IBDV surface protein VP2 were used to identify virus strains and place them into phylogenetic groups. The amino acids in the hypervariable region of VP2 in this study varied, but approximately half of all positive specimens were classified as vaccine virus. The IBD viruses fell into 3 categories: IBDV variant, classic IBDV (vaccine) and very virulent (vv) IBDV. The samples were collected according to the 3 different vaccination strategies used in broilers: vector vaccine, antigen-antibody complex vaccine and conventional live vaccine. The genetic profile and frequency of strains recovered from the herds were highly dependent on the vaccination program. This information helps us better understand the current IBD landscape in Brazil and provides additional scientific data to support the selection of the most effective vaccination strategies, products and practices to prevent disease.
authors: Muniz, E. C.;Verdi, R.;Jackwood, D. J.;Kuchpel, D.;Resende, M. S.;Mattos, J. C. Q.;Cookson, K.

title: Classical swine fever virus vs. classical swine fever virus: the superinfection exclusion phenomenon in experimentally infected wild boar
abstract: Two groups of three wild boars each were used: group A (animals 1 to 3) served as controls and group B (animals 4 to 6) were persistently infected postnatally with the Cat01 strain of CSFV (primary virus). The six-week-old and clinically healthy animals were inoculated with the virulent strain Margarita (secondary virus). A specific qRT-PCR assay was developed for the exclusive detection of the Margarita strain, which showed no cross-reactivity with the Cat01 strain. The feral pigs persistently infected with CSFV were protected from superinfection by the virulent CSFV Margarita strain, as evidenced by the absence of clinical signs and the absence of Margarita RNA detection in serum, swab and tissue samples. Furthermore, only the primary infecting viral RNA (Cat01 strain) could be detected in PBMCs, a known target for CSFV viral replication, even after isolation in ST cells, demonstrating SIE at the tissue level in vivo. Furthermore, data analysis of Margarita qRT-PCR using calculated ΔCt values supported that PBMCs from persistently infected animals were essentially protected from superinfection after in vitro inoculation with the Margarita virus strain, while this virus was able to spread to infect naïve PBMCs efficiently. In parallel, IFN-α levels were undetectable in the sera of animals in group B after inoculation with the CSFV Margarita strain. Furthermore, these animals were unable to elicit adaptive humoral (no E2-specific or neutralizing antibodies) or cellular (relative to IFN-γ-producing cells) immune responses after vaccination with the second virus. Finally, sequence analysis failed to detect CSFV Margarita RNA in the Group B samples tested. Our results suggested that the SIE phenomenon might be involved in virus evolution and phylogeny, as well as in CSFV control by vaccination. To the best of our knowledge, this study was one of the first to show effective suppression of superinfection in animals, particularly in the absence of IFN-α, which could be related to the lack of innate immune mechanisms.
authors: MuÃ±oz-GonzÃ¡lez, S.;PÃ©rez-SimÃ³, M.;Colom-Cadena, A.;CabezÃ³n, O.;BohÃ³rquez, J. A.;Rosell, R.;PÃ©rez, L. J.;Marco, I.;LavÃ­n, S.;Domingo, M.;Ganges, L.

title: Electron microscopic studies on bovine herpesviruses isolated in Tanzania that do not form syncytia
abstract: The morphology of 4 viruses recently isolated from cattle with very different clinical symptoms is described. The morphological features of the isolates are characteristic of the herpesvirus group and thus confirm the preliminary classification of virus strains based on their biological and serological behavior. The findings also indicate that a differential diagnosis of herpesviruses based on morphological criteria does not seem possible.
authors: Munz, E.;Goebel, E.;Rweyemamu, M. M.

title: Variations in the viral genome and biological properties of wild-type bovine leukemia virus strains
abstract: The bovine leukemia virus (BLV) is the causative agent of enzootic bovine leukosis (EBL), which causes enormous economic losses in livestock farming worldwide. In order to reduce the economic loss caused by BLV infection, it is important to clarify the characteristics associated with BLV transmissibility and pathogenesis in cattle. In this study, we focused on viral characteristics and investigated spontaneous mutations in the virus and viral properties through analysis of whole genome sequences and BLV molecular clones derived from cows with and without EBL. Genome analysis showed that all 28 strains contained limited genetic variation but no deletion mutations allowing classification into three groups (A, B and C), with the exception of one strain. Some nucleotide/amino acid substitutions were specific for a particular group. On the other hand, these genetic variations were not associated with the host bovine leukocyte antigen DRB3 allele, which is known to be related to BLV pathogenesis. Viral replication activity in vitro was high, moderate, and low in groups A, B, and C, respectively. In addition, the proviral load associated with BLV transmissibility and pathogenesis was high in cows infected with group A strains and low in cows infected with group B/C strains. Therefore, these results suggest that limited genetic variation might affect viral properties related to transmissibility and pathogenesis of BLV.
authors: Murakami, H.;Uchiyama, J.;Suzuki, C.;Nikaido, S.;Shibuya, K.;Sato, R.;Maeda, Y.;Tomioka, M.;Takeshima, S. N.;Kato, H.;Sakaguchi, M.;Sentsui, H.;Aida, Y.;Tsukamoto, K.

title: Physicochemical and morphological relationships of some arthropod-transmitted viruses to bluetongue virus - a new taxonomic group. Electron microscopic investigations
authors: Murphy, F. A.;Borden, E. C.;Shope, R. E.;Harrison, A.

title: Molecular and biophysical characterization of the TT virus: evidence for a new family of viruses infecting humans
abstract: The recent isolation of a new DNA virus from the serum of a Japanese patient (TT) has provided the latest possible candidate virus implicated in cryptogenic hepatitis. In the present study, we report the full nucleotide sequence of this virus (TTV) isolated from the serum of a West African man. Based on PCR studies designed to amplify overlapping regions of the viral genome and susceptibility to mung bean nuclease digestion, the vital genome is circular and negative-stranded and comprises 3,852 nt, which is 113 nt longer than the prototype isolate from Japan. Cesium chloride density gradient centrifugation showed banding of virus at 1.31-1.34 g/ml; Filtration studies showed that TTV had a particle size of 30-50 nm. These results suggest that the virus is similar to the Circoviridae, viruses known to infect plants and vertebrates (eg, birds and pigs); However, sequence similarity searches of available databases revealed no identity between TTV and other viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of a 260 nt region from 151 globally distributed isolates revealed the existence of three major TTV genotypes. Several individuals at high risk of infection with parenterally transmitted viruses were infected with more than one genotype. There was no correlation between genotype and geographical origin. Finally, intravenous inoculation of TTV-positive human serum into chimpanzees demonstrated that TTV can be transmitted to primates; No biochemical or histological evidence of hepatitis was obtained. The distinct biophysical and molecular properties of TTV suggest that it is a member of a new family of viruses that we have tentatively named Circinoviridae.
authors: Mushahwar, I. K.;Erker, J. C.;Muerhoff, A. S.;Leary, T. P.;Simons, J. N.;Birkenmeyer, L. G.;Chalmers, M. L.;Pilot-Matias, T. J.;Dexai, S. M.

title: Avian influenza virus surveillance of wild birds in the Azov and Black Sea regions of Ukraine (2010-2011)
abstract: The Azov and Black Sea basins are part of the transcontinental migratory routes of wild birds from northern Asia and Europe to the Mediterranean, Africa and Southwest Asia. These regions form a transit area, stopping during migration and nesting for many different species of birds. A wild bird surveillance study was conducted in these regions from September 2010 to September 2011 to identify avian influenza viruses. Biological samples, consisting of cloacal and tracheal swabs and faecal samples, were collected from wild birds of various ecological groups, including waterfowl and seabirds and terrestrial birds, at sites of mass aggregation of birds in Sivash Bay and the Utlyuksky and Molochniy estuaries. The sampling included the following biological cycles of wild birds: autumn migration, wintering, spring migration, breeding season and post-breeding period. A total of 3634 samples from 66 different bird species were collected. During the autumn migration, 19 haemagglutinating viruses were isolated, 14 of which were identified as low pathogenicity avian influenza virus subtypes H1N?, H3N8, H5N2, H7N?, H8N4, H10N7 and H11N8. 45 haemagglutinating viruses were isolated from the overwintering samples, 36 of which were classified as LPAI virus subtypes H1N1, H1N? H1N2, H4N?, H6N1, H7N3, H7N6, H7N7, H8N2, H9N2, H10N7, H10N4, H11N2, H12N2 and H15N7. Only three viruses were isolated during spring migration, nesting and post-nesting seasons (serotypes H6, H13 and H16). The HA and NA genes were sequenced from the isolated H5 and N1 viruses, and phylogenetic analysis revealed possible ecological links between the Azov and Black Sea regions and Europe. The LPAI viruses were mainly isolated from mallards, but also from ducks, shovelers, teals and pale-fronted geese. The rest of the 14 isolated hemagglutinating viruses were identified as different serotypes of avian paramyxoviruses (APMV-1, APMV-4, APMV-6 and APMV-7). This information advances our understanding of the ecology of avian influenza viruses in wild bird species.
authors: Muzyka, D.;Pantin-Jackwood, M.;Spackman, E.;Stegniy, B.;Rula, O.;Shutchenko, P.

title: Prevalence and molecular characterization of hepatitis E virus in pork products marketed in Canada
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections are very common worldwide. HEV causes acute viral hepatitis with approximately 20 million cases per year. While HEV genotypes 1 and 2 cause large waterborne and foodborne outbreaks with significant mortality in developing countries, genotypes 3 and 4 are more common in developed countries with transmission being primarily zoonotic. HEV has been increasingly detected in pigs in North America and Europe, and exposure to pigs and pork products is considered the main source of infection. Therefore, we set out to investigate the prevalence of HEV in retail pork products available in Canada by examining meal-sized portions of pork pies, raw pork sausages, and raw pork liver. The presence of the HEV genomes was determined by RT-PCR and viral RNA was quantified by digital droplet PCR. Overall, HEV was detected in 47% of the sampled pork pies and 10.5% of the sampled raw pork livers, but not in the sampled pork sausages, and sequencing confirmed that all HEV strains belonged to genotype 3. Further phylogenetic analysis revealed that all but one isolate clustered with subtype 3d belonged to subtype 3a. Amino acid variations between isolates were also observed in the sequenced capsid region. In conclusion, the prevalence of HEV in pâté and raw pork liver observed in this study is consistent with the current HEV distribution in pork products reported in other industrialized countries.
authors: Mykytczuk, O.;Harlow, J.;Bidawid, S.;Corneau, N.;Nasheri, N.

title: Single primer isothermal amplification (SPIA) combined with next-generation sequencing provides complete coverage of the bovine coronavirus genome and greater sequence depth compared to sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA)
abstract: Corona viruses are of great importance for human and animal health. With the emergence of novel coronaviruses such as SARS and MERS, the need for rapid genome characterization becomes more important. In addition, techniques for deep sequence and full-length viral genome analysis are needed to understand the impact of quasi-species of these viruses in terms of biology. In the present study, we compared the efficiency of two sequence-independent approaches [sequence-independent single-primer amplification (SISPA) and single-primer isothermal amplification (SPIA, represented by the Ovation kit)] in conjunction with high-throughput sequencing to to generate the full-length genome of bovine coronavirus (BCoV) from a nasal swab. Both methods achieved high genome coverage (100% for SPIA and 99% for SISPA), however there was a clear difference in the percentage of reads that mapped to BCoV. While approximately 45% of Ovation reads mapped to BCoV (sequence depth of 169-284,944), only 0.07% of SISPA reads (sequence depth of 0-249) mapped to the reference genome. Although BCoV was the focus of the study, we also identified a bovine rhinitis B virus (BRBV) in the datasets. The trend for this virus was similar to that observed for BCoV in relation to Ovation vs. SISPA, however fewer sequences were mapped to BRBV due to a lower abundance of this virus. In summary, the SPIA approach used in this study yielded full BCoV (high copy number) and BRBV (low copy number) coverage and high sequence/genome depth compared to SISPA. Although this is a limited study, the results indicate that the Ovation method could be a preferred approach for whole genome sequencing when low copy number viral RNA is expected and when high sequence depth is desired.
authors: Myrmel, M.;Oma, V.;Khatri, M.;Hansen, H. H.;Stokstad, M.;Berg, M.;BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of bovine viral diarrhea viruses using five different genetic regions
abstract: phylogenetic analysis of the five distinct regions (5' non-coding region (5'NCR), Npro, E2, NS3 and NS5B-3'NCR) of 48 Japanese and reported BVDV bovine viral diarrhea virus genomes was performed. Japanese BVDVs have been subdivided into BVDV1, subdivided into six subgroups, and BVDV2. One isolate, So CP/75, isolated in 1975 and previously proposed as subgroup 1e based on its 5-NCR sequence, was quite unique and formed an independent lineage in each region's pedigree. Another isolate, 190CP, obtained from an experimental case of mucosal disease, was classified as subgroup 1e, defined by Becher et al. in the 5-NCR, Npro and E2 regions, while in the NS5B-3 NCR region it was classified as subgroup 1a. The genomic sequences of the American isolates ILLC and ILLNC obtained from the GenBank database have been assigned to subgroup 1b in the 5'NCR, Npro, E2 and NS5B-3'NCR regions, while in the NS3 region of the subgroup 1a were assigned. suggesting that recombination between the virus strains classified into different subgroups had occurred in one animal. These findings suggest that phylogenetic analysis of multiple genetic regions is useful for further characterization of field BVDV isolates. © 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Nagai, M.;Hayashi, M.;Sugita, S.;Sakoda, Y.;Mori, M.;Murakami, T.;Ozawa, T.;Yamada, N.;Akashi, H.

title: Genomic and serological diversity of bovine viral diarrhea virus in Japan
abstract: The genomic properties of 62 field isolates of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) collected in Japan between 1974 and 1999 were examined. The 5 inch untranslated region (UTR) was amplified by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and the nucleotide sequences from 244 to 247 bases were determined. The serological properties were also characterized by the cross-neutralization test using antisera against the representative strain of the classified genotype. Using pedigree analysis, BVDV 1 was divided into two major clusters, BVDV-1a (29 isolates) and BVDV-1b (27 isolates). In group 1a, 3 differed from the other viruses and were placed in a branch assigned as 1a". However, 4 isolates (So CP/75, 190 CP, 190 NCP and KS86-1-NCP) could not be assigned to group 1a or 1b. Compared to the published sequence data, KS86-1-NCP, 190 CP and 190 NCP were similar to the Southern African isolates recently proposed as BVDV 1c. The 5-UTR sequence of So CP/75 was unique among those of BVDV 1, suggesting that the isolate should be assigned to a new genotype.
