Only 2 of 62 isolates collected in 1989 and 1990 were identified as BVDV 2. The results of the cross-neutralization test strongly supported these data, indicating a close correlation between the 5-UTR sequence and the antigenicity of BVDV.
authors: Nagai, M.;Ito, T.;Sugita, S.;Genno, A.;Takeuchi, K.;Ozawa, T.;Sakoda, Y.;Nishimori, T.;Takamura, K.;Akashi, H.

title: Identification and full genome analysis of a novel bovine picornavirus in Japan
abstract: We identified novel viruses in the faeces of cattle with diarrhea collected in 2009 in Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan, using a metagenomic approach and determining the (almost) complete sequences of the virus. Sequence analyzes revealed that they had a standard organization of the picornavirus genome, i.e. 5' untranslated region (UTR) - L-P1 (VP4-VP3-VP2-VP1) - P2 (2A-2B-2C) - P3 (3A-3B -3C -3D) - 3'UTR-poly(A). They are closely related to other unclassified Chinese picornaviruses; Group 1-3 bat picornaviruses, feline picornavirus and canine picornavirus, 45.4-51.4% (P1), 38.0-44.9% (P2) and 49.6-53.3, respectively % (P3) share amino acid identities. The phylogenetic analyzes and detailed genomic characterization showed that they clustered together with the unclassified Chinese picornaviruses for the P1, 2C, 3CD, and VP1 coding regions. These viruses had conserved features (eg, predicted protein cleavage sites, presence of a leader protein, functional 2A, 2C, 3C, and 3D domains) suggesting that they share a common ancestor. Reverse transcription PCR assays using specific primers designed from the 5'UTR sequence of these viruses showed that 23.0% (20/87) of faecal samples from cattle with diarrhea were positive, indicating the prevalence This picornavirus in Japanese cattle indicates population in Hokkaido Prefecture. However, further studies are needed to investigate the pathogenic potential and etiological role of these viruses in cattle.
authors: Nagai, M.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Kaku, Y.;Belsham, G. J.;Haga, K.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Umetsu, M.;Shiokawa, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Furuya, T.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of bovine astrovirus from bovine fecal samples in Japan: identification of possible interspecies transmission of bovine astrovirus
abstract: viral metagenomics approach was used to study fecal samples from Japanese calves with and without diarrhea. Of the various viral pathogens detected, read counts revealed nearly complete Astrovirus-related RNA sequences in 15 of the 146 stool samples collected in three different areas (Hokkaido, Ishikawa, and Kagoshima prefectures) between 2009 and 2015. Due to the lack of genetic information on bovine astroviruses (BoAstVs) in Japan, these sequences were analyzed in this study. Nine of the 15 Japanese BoAstVs were closely related to Chinese BoAstVs and grouped into one lineage (tentatively named Lineage 1) in all phylogenetic trees. Three of 15 strains were phylogenetically distinct from lineage 1, showing low sequence identities, and instead clustered with an American strain isolated from cattle with respiratory disease (tentatively named lineage 2). Interestingly, two out of 15 strains clustered with lineage 1 in the open reading frame (ORF)1a and ORF1b regions, while clustering with lineage 2 in the ORF2 region. Notably, one of 15 strains showed low amino acid sequence similarity to other BoAstVs and was separately clustered with porcine astrovirus type 5 and ovine astrovirus in the ORF2 region in all trees, suggesting earlier interspecies transmission.
authors: Nagai, M.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Otomaru, K.;Uto, T.;Koizumi, M.;Minami-Fukuda, F.;Takai, H.;Murakami, T.;Masuda, T.;Yamasato, H.;Shiokawa, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Furuya, T.;Shirai, J.;Mizutani, T.

title: GiRaF: Robust, computational identification of influenza resorts by graph mining
abstract: Reassortments in the influenza virus - a process by which strains exchange genetic segments - have been implicated in two out of three pandemics of the 20th century and the 2009 H1N1 outbreak. While advances in sequencing have led to an explosion in the number of available whole genome sequences, an understanding of the rate and distribution of reassortments and their role in viral evolution is still lacking. A key factor here is the lack of automated tools to reliably identify reassorts from sequence data due to the challenges of analyzing large, uncertain viral phylogenies. We describe here a novel computational method called GiRaF (Graph-incompatibility-based Reassortment Finder) that reliably identifies reassortments in a fully automated manner, taking into account uncertainties in the derived phylogenies. The algorithms behind GiRaF search large collections of Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sample trees for groups of incompatible splits using a fast biclique enumeration algorithm coupled with multiple statistical tests to find groups of taxa with different phylogenetic placement to identify. GiRaF correctly finds known rearrangements in human, avian, and swine flu populations, including the evolutionary events that led to the recent "swine flu" outbreak. GiRaF also identifies several previously unreported resorts across whole genome studies to catalog events in H5N1 and swine influenza isolates. © The author(s) 2010. Published by Oxford University Press.
authors: Nagarajan, N.;Kingsford, C.

title: Novel reassortant highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (H5N8) in zoos, India
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N8) viruses were detected in waterfowl in two zoos in India in October 2016. Both viruses were distinct 7:1 reassortants of H5N8 viruses isolated from wild birds in the Russian Federation and China in May 2016, suggesting that the virus spread during the birds' southern winter migration.
authors: Nagarajan, S.;Kumar, M.;Murugkar, H. V.;Tripathi, S.;Shukla, S.;Agarwal, S.;Dubey, G.;Nagi, R. S.;Singh, V. P.;Tosh, C.

title: Genetic analysis of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype A of Indian origin and evidence of positive selection and recombination in leader protease and capsid coding regions
abstract: The leader protease (Lpro) and capsid coding sequences (P1) make up approximately 3 kb of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD). We examined the phylogenetic relatedness of 46 serotype A FMDV isolates of Indian origin collected in the period 1968-2005 and eight vaccine strains using neighbor joining tree and Bayesian tree methods. The viruses have been divided into three main groups - Asian, European-South American and European. The Indian isolates formed a distinct genetic group among the Asian isolates. The Indian isolates were further classified into different genetic subgroups (<5% variation). Post-1995 isolates were divided into two subgroups, while some isolates originating from Andhra Pradesh in 2005 formed a separate group. These isolates were closely related to the 1970s isolates. The FMDV isolates appear to undergo reverse mutation or convergent evolution, with sequences identical to the ancestors being present in the circulating isolates. The eight vaccine strains included in the study were unrelated and belonged to different genetic groups. Recombination was detected in the Lpro region in one isolate (A IND 20/82) and in the VP1-encoding 1D region in another isolate (A RAJ 21/96). A positive selection was identified at aa positions 23 in Lpro (P<0.05, 0.046*) and at aa 171 in the capsid protein VP1 (P<0.01, 0.003**). © 2009 Indian Academy of Sciences.
authors: Nagendrakumar, S. B.;Madhanmohan, M.;Rangarajan, P. N.;Srinivasan, V. A.

title: Novel real-time PCR-based patho- and phylotyping of potentially zoonotic H5 subtype avian influenza viruses at risk of entering Europe in 2017
abstract: Since November 2016, Europe has been witnessing another wave of incursion of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) A(H5) of the Asian-origin goose/Guangdong (gs/GD) lineage. Group 2.3.4.4b H5 virus infections affect wild bird and poultry populations. Clade 2.2, 2.3.1.2c and 2.3.4.4a H5 viruses were previously detected in Europe in 2006, 2010 and 2014. Clades 2.2.1.2 and 2.3.2.1.c are endemic to Egypt and West Africa, respectively, and have caused human deaths. There is evidence of their co-circulation in the Middle East. Low pathogenicity H5 subtype (LPAI) viruses are endemic to migratory wild bird populations. They may mutate into highly pathogenic phenotypes after transmission to poultry farms. So far, however, only the gs/GD H5 line has had an impact on human health. Rapid and specific diagnosis is the cornerstone for the control and eradication of HPAI viral infections. We present the development and validation of five real-time RT-PCR (RT-qPCR) assays that allow sequencing-independent pathotype- and clade-specific differentiation of the major gs/GD-HPAI-H5 virus clades and the currently circulating Eurasian LPAI viruses . Together with an influenza A virus generic RT-qPCR, the assays significantly accelerate time to diagnosis and shorten response times in a OneHealth approach to containing the spread of gs/GD-HPAI viruses.
authors: Naguib, M. M.;Graaf, A.;Fortin, A.;Luttermann, C.;Wernery, U.;Amarin, N.;Hussein, H. A.;Sultan, H.;Al Adhadh, B.;Hassan, M. K.;Beer, M.;Monne, I.;Harder, T. C.

title: Full genome sequence analysis of a newly emerged QX-like infectious bronchitis virus from Sudan reveals clear recombination points
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) infections continue to cause economically important diseases in poultry, while various genotypes and serotypes continue to circulate worldwide. Two infectious bronchitis viruses (IBV) have been isolated from chickens with respiratory disease in Sudan. Sequence analysis of the hypervariable regions of the S1 gene revealed a close relationship to the QX-like genotype previously undetected in Sudan. Whole genome analysis of isolate IBV/Ck/Sudan/AR251-15/2014 by next-generation sequencing revealed a genome size of 27,646 nucleotides with 13 open reading frames: 5'-1a-1b-S-3a-3b-EM-4b-4c- 5a-5b-N-6b-3'. The highest 93% nucleotide sequence identity for the whole genome was found with the Chinese IBV strain Ck/CH/LHLJ/140906, the Italian IBV isolate ITA/90254/2005 and the vaccine strain 4/91. Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 gene revealed that isolate IBV/Ck/Sudan/AR251-15/2014 was clustered with viruses of the GI-19 lineage. The recombination analysis revealed different patterns of origin of the RNA in the Sudanese isolate in several genes. Multiple recombination sites were scattered throughout the genome, suggesting that the Sudan-QX-like strain emerged as a unique recombinant from multiple recombination events from parental viruses of genotypes 4/91, H120, and ITA/90254/2005. The Sudanese QX-like isolate is plausibly genetically distinct from IBV strains previously reported in Africa and elsewhere.
authors: Naguib, M. M.;Hoper, D.;Arafa, A. S.;Setta, A. M.;Abed, M.;Monne, I.;Beer, M.;Harder, T. C.

title: Sequence analysis of the porcine adenovirus serotype 5 fiber gene: evidence for recombination
abstract: The nucleic acid and deduced amino acid sequence of the fiber gene of the HNF-61 strain of porcine adenovirus serotype 5 (PAdV-5) was determined and compared to that of the HNF-70 strain of the same serotype (Nagy et al., J Gen Virol 82, 525-529, 2001) and also to adenovirus fiber genes from the genera Mastadenovirus and Atadenovirus. The putative HNF-61 and HNF-70 proteins were similar to each other with 90% amino acid identity. Conserved amino acid sequences described for mastadenovirus fiber shafts were identified in the shaft regions of both PAdV-5 fibers, with the exception of the so-called TLWT motif. The head regions of the PAdV-5 fiber did not resemble any of the known mastadenovirus fiber heads, but they did show features of the fiber head protein sequences of viruses grouped in the proposed genus Atadenovirus (Benko et al., Virus Taxonomy, Seventh Report of the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses, Academic Press, New York, San Diego, 2000, pp. 227-238). The results indicated recombination between viruses of different adenovirus genera.
authors: Nagy, M.;Nagy;Tuboly, T.

title: Dynamic evolution of endogenous retrovirus-derived genes expressed in bovine conceptions during the time of placentation
abstract: In mammalian evolution, it is known that some of the essential genes for placental development are retroviral in origin, since syncytin-1, derived from an envelope gene (env) of an endogenous retrovirus (ERV), promotes cell fusion of the human placenta. Although the placenta performs the same function in all placental mammals, env-derived genes responsible for trophoblast cell fusion and maternal immune tolerance differ between species and remain largely unidentified in bovine species. To comprehensively investigate env-derived genes that play a role in bovine placental development, we determined the transcriptome profiles of bovine concepts during three crucial implantation windows using a high-throughput sequencer. The sequence reads were mapped into the bovine genome, where ERV candidates were annotated with RetroTector© (7,624 and 1,542 for ERV-derived and env-derived genes, respectively). Theming reads showed that approximately 18% (284 genes) of the env-derived genes in the genome were expressed during placental formation and approximately 4% (63 genes) were detected on all days examined. We have verified three env-derived genes expressed in trophoblast cells by polymerase chain reaction. Of these three, the sequence of the env-derived gene with the longest open reading frame (termed BERV-P env) showed high levels of expression in trophoblastic cell lines and was similar to that of the syncytin-Car1 genes found in dogs and cats, despite their different origins. These results suggest that placentation depends on various retrovirus-derived genes that may have replaced endogenous ancestors during evolution. © 2013 The author(s).
authors: Nakagawa, S.;Bai, H.;Sakurai, T.;Nakaya, Y.;Konno, T.;Miyazawa, T.;Gojobori, T.;Imakawa, K.

title: Identification of isolates of European-type hepatitis E virus subtype 3e in Japanese wild boar: molecular tracking of HEV from swine to wild boar
abstract: Nucleotide sequences of hepatitis E virus (HEV) isolates infecting wild boar in Mie Prefecture, which is located in the central region of Japan and far from the most prevalent regions of HEV infection in Japan, have been determined and characterized . Of 144 wild boar serum samples collected in Mie Prefecture, 7 were positive for HEV RNA. The nucleotide sequence of almost the entire genome was determined for 4 of the 7 positive samples. Pedigree analysis showed that among the 7 isolates, 6 samples were subtype 3e and 1 subtype 3a. We identified indigenization of subtype 3e isolates in Japanese wild boar. In addition, 5 subtype 3e isolates were closely related and located in the peripheral branch of subtype 3e isolates from European countries in the pedigree. The structure showed that the ancestor of the 5 subtype 3e isolates came from Europe. The phylogenetic structure and coalescence analyzes suggested that the subtype 3e isolates entered Japan around 1966 through the importation of large breed pigs from Europe. The results also showed that several lineages of subtype 3e spread to a wide area of Japan around 1992 and 1 of the lineages was settled in wild boar in Mie Prefecture between 1992 and 2009. The occurrence of a wild boar cluster in the peripheral branch in the phylogenetic lineage may indicate the direction of gene flow of HEV subtype 3e from swine to wild boar. Clarifying the direction or route of transmission should be helpful in preventing future endemic or epidemic HEV infection. © 2013 Elsevier BV.
authors: Nakano, T.;Takahashi, K.;Arai, M.;Okano, H.;Kato, H.;Ayada, M.;Okamoto, H.;Mishiro, S.

title: Dysfunction of the endogenous bovine retroviral K2 envelope glycoprotein is related to unsuccessful intracellular transport
abstract: Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are the remnants of retroviral infection of ancestral germ cells. Mutations introduced into ERVs halt production of infectious agents, but their impact on retroviral protein function is not fully understood. Retroviral envelope glycoproteins (Envs) are used in membrane fusion during virus entry, and we recently identified intact coding sequences for endogenous bovine retrovirus K1 (BERV-K1) and BERV-K2 envs. The amino acid sequences of BERV-K1 Env (also called Fematrin-1) and BERV-K2 Env are similar and both viruses are classified in the genus Betaretrovirus. While fematrin-1 plays an important role in cell-to-cell fusion in bovine placenta, the BERV-K2 envelope gene is poorly expressed in vivo and its recombinant Env protein is low due to inefficient surface (SU) cleavage of membrane fusion defective. and transmembrane subunits. Here, we performed chimeric analyzes of fematrin-1 and BERV-K2 envs and showed that defective maturation of BERV-K2 env contributed to failed intracellular transport. Fluorescence microscopy and flow cytometric analysis indicated that, unlike fematrin-1 env, BERV-K2 env could not be transported from the endoplasmic reticulum to the trans-Golgi network, where cellular proteases required for processing retroviral envs are located . We also identified that one of the responsive regions of this phenomenon was within a 65 amino acid region of BERV-K2 SU. This is the first report identifying that retroviral Env SU is involved in the regulation of intracellular transport and it may help elucidate the maturation process of fematrin-1 and other related Envs. © 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Nakaya, Y.;Miyazawa, T.

title: A metagenomic study of rumen virome in domesticated caprids
abstract: This project aimed to study the native caprid rumen vioma by using a robust protocol for isolating and enriching viral DNA (using membrane filtration, ultracentrifugation, overnight PEG treatment and nuclease treatment) and using RSD-PCR and high-throughput -Sequencing Techniques (HTS) was developed. 3.53% of the reads obtained were analogous to those of viruses denoting Siphoviridae, Myoviridae, Podoviridae, Mimiviridae, Microviridae, Poxviridae, Tectiviridae and Marseillevirus. Most of the sequenced rumen reads resembled those of phage, which are critical to keeping rumen microbial populations below carrying capacity. Although identified in the rumen, most of these viruses have also been reported in other environments. Improvements in the viral DNA enrichment and isolation protocol are required to obtain data that are more representative of the rumen vioma. The obtained 102,130 unknown reads (92.31%) for the goat and 36,241 unknown reads (93.86%) for the sheep may represent new genomes that need further study.
authors: Namonyo, S.;Wagacha, M.;Maina, S.;Wambua, L.;Agaba, M.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of hepatitis E virus in a Canadian swine production network
abstract: Virus contamination along the production chain is a significant problem for both food safety and animal health. Pigs have been reported to act as reservoirs of zoonotic viruses, sometimes emerging, and epidemiological studies have shown direct links between consumption of undercooked pork offal and cases of hepatitis caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotype 3 in humans will. The presence of HEV in pig herds has been reported, but its prevalence in pork production environments is still unknown. To investigate viral sources of contamination in the swine industry, 452 environmental and faecal samples, including samples from livestock transport vehicles, were collected from ten farms and one slaughterhouse over a period of 11 months, which together represent a single production network. Hepatitis E virus RNA was detected by nested RT-PCR in 32 samples both inside and outside farm buildings, on trucks and mainly from germ carriers collected at the slaughterhouse yard, e.g. B. on a commercial vehicle. Phylogenetic analysis showed a high diversity of genotype 3 HEV strains, similar to previously found human and pig strains. According to the results of this study, the movements of trucks and commercial vehicles could play an important role in the spread of HEVs on a slaughterhouse site and throughout the network.
authors: Nantel-Fortier, N.;Letellier, A.;Lachapelle, V.;Fravalo, P.;Lâ€™Homme, Y.;Brassard, J.

title: Genetic predisposition to acquire a polybasic cleavage site for the highly pathogenic avian influenza hemagglutinin
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses with H5 and H7 hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes evolve from low pathogenic progenitors by acquiring multiple basic amino acid residues at the HA cleavage site. Although this mechanism has been observed to occur naturally only in these HA subtypes, little is known about the genetic basis for acquisition of the polybasic HA cleavage site. Here we show that consecutive adenine residues and a stem-loop structure commonly found in the viral RNA region encodes amino acids around the cleavage site of low pathogenic H5 and H7 viruses isolated from waterfowl reservoirs for nucleotide -Insertions in this are important RNA region. A reporter assay to detect non-template nucleotide insertions and deep sequence analysis of viral RNAs revealed that increased number of adenine residues and enlarged stem loop structure in the RNA region accelerated multiple adenine and/or guanine insertions leading to Formation of codons required for basic aminos are acids. Interestingly, nucleotide insertions associated with the HA cleavage site motif were mainly not observed in the viral RNA of other subtypes tested (H1, H2, H3 and H4). Our results suggest that RNA editing-like activity is the key mechanism for nucleotide insertions, providing a clue as to why acquisition of the polybasic HA cleavage site is restricted to the specific HA subtypes.<b>IMPORTANT< /b> Influenza A viruses are classified into subtypes based on the antigenicity of the viral surface glycoproteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase. Of the 16 HA subtypes (H1 to -16) maintained in aquatic bird reservoirs of influenza A viruses, H5 and H7 viruses often become highly pathogenic by acquiring multiple basic amino acid residues at the HA cleavage site. Although this mechanism has been known since the 1980s, the genetic basis for nucleotide insertions has remained unclear. This study shows the potential role of viral RNA secondary structure for nucleotide insertions and demonstrates a key mechanism that explains why acquisition of the polybasic HA cleavage site in nature is restricted to specific HA subtypes. Our results will contribute to a better understanding of influenza A virus ecology and will also be useful for the development of genetically modified vaccines against H5 and H7 influenza A viruses with increased stability.
authors: Nao, N.;Yamagishi, J.;Miyamoto, H.;Igarashi, M.;Manzoor, R.;Ohnuma, A.;Tsuda, Y.;Furuyama, W.;Shigeno, A.;Kajihara, M.;Kishida, N.;Yoshida, R.;Takada, A.

title: Characterization and phylogenetic analysis of a novel picornavirus from pig feces in Japan
abstract: study of fecal porcine viruses using a metagenomic approach identified a novel picornavirus in the faeces of a healthy two-month-old pig. This virus, named Porcine Picornavirus Japan (PPVJ), had a standard picornavirus genome organization, including the L protein region. The 5' untranslated region contained a type II internal ribosomal entry site. This virus was most closely related to lesavirus 1 (amino acid sequence identity: 38.2%) in P1, equine rhinitis A virus (25.8%) in P2 and the lesavirus 2 (40.9%) in P3. According to the genus delineations for the family Picornaviridae (less than 40%, 40%, and 50% amino acid sequence identity in P1, P2, and P3, respectively), PPVJ represents a new genus in the family Picornaviridae. PPVJ was detected in 23.3% of faecal samples (from 58.3% of farms in a large area) from pigs under four months of age by reverse transcription PCR using specific primers designed from the 3D sequence followed by a sequencing. The host range and pathogenic potential of this virus in animals remains to be determined.
authors: Naoi, Y.;Kishimoto, M.;Masuda, T.;Ito, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Sano, K.;Yamasato, H.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Furuya, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Okada, T.;Shirai, J.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Six-year surveillance of Newcastle disease virus in wild birds in north-eastern Spain (Catalonia)
abstract: As Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the main threats to the poultry industry, testing for Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in fatalities in wild birds (passive surveillance) has been carried out in Catalonia since 2010. The aim is to provide an early warning system to prevent infection of poultry. Since 2010, 35 wild bird deaths have been attributed to NDV infection. During this time, NDV gradually spread to new areas, with an increase in deaths, although it is not clear whether they were the result of the spread of the virus or improved surveillance. Phylogenetic analyzes indicate that two distinct sublineages of NDV, 4a and 4b, circulated in Catalonia. Both sublineages appear to be endemic in the wild bird population, affecting mainly Eurasian collared pigeons with a clear pattern in terms of their spatial distribution (consistent with the distribution of this species) and temporal distribution (with most cases falling between September and February). To date, endemicity in wild birds has not resulted in outbreaks of ND in poultry. However, there are still many uncertainties as to whether NDV can expand to new areas of Catalonia (with higher poultry densities), for example, or what threat the seemingly novel subline 4a could pose. Therefore, efforts should be made to promote measures to prevent infection of poultry farms (especially in high-risk areas and times) and to maintain surveillance.
authors: Napp, S.;Alba, A.;Rocha, A. I.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;Rivas, R.;MajÃ³, N.;Perarnau, M.;Massot, C.;Miguel, E. S.;Soler, M.;Busquets, N.

title: Genotypic and epitopic properties of group A porcine rotavirus strains circulating in Canada
abstract: Surveillance of rotavirus A (RVA) infection in North American swine populations is limited and not conducted over a significant period of time to properly assess the diversity of RVA strains in swine. The VP7(G) and VP4(P) genes of 32 Canadian RVA strains circulating between 2009 and 2015 were sequenced, with G3P[13], G5P[7], G9P[7], G9[ 13] and G9[ 19] genotype combinations. The Canadian RVA strains were compared to the RVA strains present in the porcine ProSystems RCE rotavirus vaccine. The comparison revealed several amino acid differences in the antigenic G and P epitopes independent of the G and P genotypes, but specifically in the Canadian G3, P[13] and P[19] genotypes. Our study further characterizes the development of RVA and disease reduction in swine, which may optimize target vaccine design and thereby minimize RVA disease in this economically important animal population.
authors: Naseer, O.;Jarvis, M. C.;Ciarlet, M.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Long-term evolution of viruses: A Janus-faced equilibrium
abstract: The popular textbook image of viruses as harmful and selfish genetic parasites grossly underestimates the beneficial contribution of viruses to the biosphere. Given viruses' critical dependence on reproducing in an intracellular environment, viruses that kill excessively (lyse) may cause their cellular hosts to become extinct and not survive. The lytic mode of viral replication must therefore be mitigated and balanced by non-lytic modes of viral latency and symbiosis. Here we review current bioinformatics and metagenomic studies to argue that viral endogenization and domestication may be more common mechanisms of virus persistence than lysis. We use a triangle diagram to explain the three main virus persistence strategies that explain the global scope of virus-cell interactions, including lysis, latency, and virus-cell symbiosis. This paradigm may help identify new directions in virology research where scientists could artificially gain control over switching between lytic and beneficial viral lifestyles.
authors: Nasir, A.;Kim, K. M.;Caetano-Anolles, G.

title: Biological and molecular characterization of chicken anemia virus isolates of Indian origin
abstract: In the present study, four isolates of chicken anemia virus (CAV) (CAV-A, -B, -E and -P) from different geographic regions of India were characterized. The CAV genome of a 1766 bp nucleotide region containing the entire coding region of the VP2 and VP3 proteins and a partial coding region of the VP1 protein were sequenced. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of the Indian CAV isolates were aligned and compared to CAV isolates of European, Asian, American and Australian origin. A phylogenetic analysis of the Indian CAV isolates was also performed based on the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences. The results showed that Indian isolates were genetically engineered from different parts of the world. The Indian isolate CAV-A was found to be closely related to the European Cux-1 strain, CAV-B and -P were closely related to the Bangladeshi BD-3 strain, and CAV-E was closely related to the Australian strain 704. The pathogenicity of the four CAV isolates was investigated in day-old chicks that were specifically pathogen-free (SPF). One day old SPF chicks (n=50) were divided into five groups consisting of 10 chicks in each group. Group 1 was kept as a control and groups 2-5 were infected with each CAV isolate separately. The chicks were infected intramuscularly at a dose of 1 ml cell culture fluid (104.5 TCID50/0.1 ml) per bird. Clinical symptoms, mortality and packed cell volume (PCV) and body weight gain were recorded on days 5, 10 and 15 post-infection. On day 15, all birds were sacrificed and various organs, namely thymus, bone marrow, spleen, liver and bursa were examined for gross and microscopic changes. The pathogenicity study showed that all CAVs except CAV-B were capable of inducing clinical disease and immunosuppression in young chicks, while isolate CAV-B did not induce clinical disease but only induced immunosuppression, which was confirmed by microscopic examination of the lymphatic organs was revealed. The study provided valuable information on the molecular epidemiological status of CAV isolates prevalent in India for the first time. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Natesan, S.;Kataria, J. M.;Dhama, K.;Rahul, S.;Baradhwaj, N.

title: Comparison of exosomes purified by ultracentrifugation (UC) and Total Exosome Isolation (TEI) reagent from serum of Marek's disease virus (MDV) vaccinated and tumor-bearing chickens
abstract: Extracellular vesicles (EVs) is a collective term for microparticles, exosomes, and apoptotic bodies produced by a variety of cells and released into interstitial spaces and body fluids. Serum exosomes can serve as invaluable biomarkers containing m/miRNAs, lipids and proteins indicative of various conditions. There are currently limited studies on the characterization and mutual consensus of biomarker profiles of serum exosomes purified by different methods. Here we compared the advantages and disadvantages of two commonly used serum exosome purification methods, including ultracentrifugation (UC) and Total Exosome Isolation (TEI) reagent, by analyzing exosome size distribution, concentration, morphology, and miRNA expression profiles. Serum was obtained from Marek's disease virus (MDV) infected chickens that were either vaccinated against Marek's disease (MD) and thus protected, or unvaccinated and bearing MDV-induced tumors. Nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were performed to assess particle size, concentration, and morphological integrity, respectively. Our results show that the size distribution of the particles purified by both methods is consistent with that of exosomes (30-150 nm). The TEI reagent produced higher yields and co-isolated additional EV populations that are slightly larger (ca. 180 nm). Based on the miRNA expression profiles from a previous high-throughput sequencing experiment with small RNAs from exosomes, we selected six cellular and four MDV1 miRNAs to validate their expression in UC- and TEI-purified exosomes. The miRNA expression profiles showed relative correlation between the two methods, but marked differences were observed aplenty in TEI-purified exosomes, which showed higher miRNA expression consistent with higher yield than those purified by UC. TEI-purified exosomes from vaccinated chickens showed higher expression of tumor suppressor miRNA, gga-mir-146b, and the lowest expression of oncomiR, gga-mir-21 compared to those obtained from tumor-bearing chickens. We propose that gga-mir-146 and -21 may serve as serum exosome biomarkers for vaccine-induced protection and MD tumors, respectively.
authors: Nath Neerukonda, S.;Egan, N. A.;Patria, J.;Assakhi, I.;Tavlarides-Hontz, P.;Modla, S.;MuÃ±oz, E. R.;Hudson, M. B.;Parcells, M. S.

title: Origins of the new influenza A(H1N1) virus: time for action
abstract: To gain insight into the possible origins of the 2009 novel influenza A(H1N1) outbreak, we performed two independent analyzes of the genetic evolution of the novel influenza A(H1N1) virus. First, protein homology analyzes of more than 400 sequences indicated that this virus most likely evolved from extant swine viruses. Second, phylogenetic analyzes of 5,214 protein sequences from influenza A(H1N1) viruses (avian, porcine and human) that have been circulating in North America over the past two decades (from 1989 to 2009) showed that the new influenza A(H1N1) Virus possesses a distinctive feature evolutionary feature (genetic distinctness). This appears to be a distinctive feature of swine-human transmission of influenza A. Thus, these analyzes contribute to establishing the role of swine populations as "mixing vessels" for influenza A(H1N1) viruses.
authors: Nava, G. M.;Attene-Ramos, M. S.;Ang, J. K.;Escorcia, M.

title: Genetic and antigenic analysis of foot-and-mouth disease type A viruses isolated in India between 1987 and 1996
abstract: Antigenic and genetic analysis was performed on 23 field isolates of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) type A, collected from different outbreaks in India between 1987 and 1996. The isolates showed a close antigenic relationship to the current vaccine strain (IND 17/77) in the microneutralization test using a vaccine strain (IND 17/77) antiserum and a peptide (aa 136-151 of the VP1 protein of the A22/Azerbaijan/65 strain) antiserum. However, the isolates showed minor antigenic differences in their reactivity with three neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) that recognize trypsin-sensitive conformation-independent epitopes of the vaccine virus strains. The phylogenetic relationship between the isolates was performed using a portion of the ID gene (168 nucleotides at the 3' end). An additional seven Type A Indian field isolates previously reported were included in the analysis. The percentage similarity between the Indian isolates varied from 82.7% to 99.4% at the nucleotide level and from 83.9% to 100% at the amino acid level. These observations clearly show the genetic heterogeneity of the field isolates. The current vaccine strain IND 17/77 showed a deviation of 9.7% at the nucleotide level and 5.6% at the amino acid level from isolate A22 Iraq 24/64. The field strains deviated from the vaccine strain IND 17/77 by 5.6%-14.6% and 3.7%-13.7% at the nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. In the pedigree, the isolates were divided into 21 genetic groups. The accumulation pattern of isolates in the phylogenetic tree did not reveal a specific distribution pattern of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreaks in relation to their geographic locations, caused by unrestricted animal movements and endemic nature of the disease.
authors: Nayak, B.;Pattnaik, B.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Patil, S. S.;Venkataramanan, R.

title: Detection of novel porcine bocaviruses in fecal samples from asymptomatic pigs in Cameroon
abstract: Improvements and widespread use of nucleic acid amplification and sequencing methods have led to the detection of new viral diversity in various domestic animals, including pigs. In this study, we used either virus species-specific or broadly reactive PCR assays to characterize the abundance and genetic diversity of selected DNA viruses of the families Adenoviridae, Circoviridae, Anelloviridae, and Parvoviridae in Cameroonian pigs. Fecal samples were collected in spring 2011. Adenoviruses, circoviruses and anelloviruses were not detected, however, a high prevalence and remarkable genetic diversity was observed within the identified parvoviruses and particularly within the bocaviruses. PPV4 was the most prevalent virus (20%), followed by PBoV3 (18%), PBoV4 (18%), PBoV5 plus 6V/7V (16%), and PBoV1 plus PBoV2 (6%). The frequency of mixed infections with different combinations of these virus species reached 20%. Genetic analysis of the identified viruses showed that the capsid gene of the PBoV1 and PBoV2 strains shared up to 91% and 94%. nt sequence similarities to reference PBoV1 and PBoV2 strains, respectively. The identified PBoV3 and PBoV4 strains shared ≥95% and ≥98%. nt identities with reference PBoV3 and PBoV4 strains respectively along the NS gene, while the PBoV5 strains shared 86%. nt identities with Hungary and 87%. nt identities with Chinese PBoV5 strains along the capsid gene. In addition, a single PBoV5-like strain shared ≥71%. nt sequence identity with other PBoV5 strains. This is the first study to provide evidence of the spread of bocavirus in Africa and adds to our understanding of the impact of globalization on the spread of new and emerging viruses. © 2013.
authors: Ndze, V. N.;Cadar, D.;CsÃ¡gola, A.;Kisfali, P.;KovÃ¡cs, E.;Farkas, S.;Ngu, A. F.;Esona, M. D.;DÃ¡n, T.;Tuboly, T.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Avian leukosis virus activation of an antisense RNA upstream of TERT in B-cell lymphomas
abstract: UNLABELING: Avian leukosis virus (ALV) induces tumors by integrating its proviral DNA into the chicken genome and altering the expression of neighboring genes via powerful promoter and enhancer elements. Viral integration sites that contribute to oncogenesis are selected in tumor cells. Deep sequencing analysis of B-cell lymphoma DNA confirmed that the telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) gene promoter is a common ALV integration target. Twenty-six unique proviral integration sites have been mapped between 46 and 3,552 nucleotides (nt) upstream of the TERT transcription start site, predominantly in the opposite transcriptional orientation to TERT from TERT in the opposite orientation, suggesting that the TERT promoter is bidirectional. This transcript appears to be an uncharacterized antisense RNA. We have previously shown that TERT expression is upregulated in tumors with integrations into the TERT promoter region. We now report that the viral promoter drives expression of a chimeric transcript containing viral sequences spliced to exons 4 to 7 of this antisense RNA. Clonal expansion of cells with ALV integrations driving overexpression of TERT antisense RNA suggests that it may play a role in tumorigenesis. IMPORTANT: The data suggest that ALV integrations in the TERT promoter region drive overexpression of a novel antisense RNA and contribute to the development of lymphoma.
authors: Nehyba, J.;Malhotra, S.;Winans, S.;O'Hare, T. H.;Justice, J. t;Beemon, K.

title: Molecular biology of bovine viral diarrheal virus
abstract: Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) is arguably the most important viral agent of ruminants worldwide and can cause severe economic losses. Clinical symptoms of disease caused by BVDV range from subclinical to severe acute hemorrhagic syndrome, with disease severity being strain dependent. These viruses are classified as members of the pestivirus genus Flaviviridae. BVDV are thought to be primarily cattle pathogens but can infect most ruminant species. The virus particle consists of a lipid bilayer membrane surrounding the encapsulated genomic RNA. Inserted into the outer membrane are two virus-encoded glycoproteins that contain the virus' major antigenic determinants, as well as receptor-binding and cell-fusion functions. A third glycoprotein is weakly associated with the virion but also possesses unique features that play an important role in suppressing innate immunity. The viral proteins are encoded in a single, large open reading frame. The viral proteins are proteolytically cleaved from the polyprotein by various proteases. The structural proteins are processed by cellular signal peptidases, while the nonstructural proteins are processed by the viral serine protease. The virus is assembled and matures in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi bodies of the cell. The virus is released by exocytosis, in which viral proteins are not exposed on the cell's surface. © 2012.
authors: Neill, J. D.

title: Simultaneous rapid sequencing of multiple RNA virus genomes
abstract: The comparison of sequences of archived viruses collected over many years with the present allows the study of viral evolution and contributes to the design of new vaccines. However, these studies have been hampered by the difficulty, time, and expense of individually generating full-length sequences from each archived sample. Next-generation sequencing technologies have been used to analyze clinical and environmental samples to identify viral pathogens that may be present. This has led to the discovery of many new, uncharacterized viruses from a range of virus families. The use of these sequencing technologies would be beneficial in studying viral evolution. In this study, a sequencing method was used to simultaneously and rapidly sequence multiple archived samples using a single standard protocol. This method used primers consisting of 20 bases of known sequence with 8 random bases at the 3' end, which also served as an identifying barcode allowing differentiation of each viral library after pooling and sequencing. This conferred sequence independence through random priming of both first and second strand cDNA synthesis. Viral stocks were treated with a nuclease cocktail to reduce the presence of host nucleic acids. Viral RNA was extracted, followed by double-stranded cDNA synthesis with single-tube random priming. The resulting cDNAs were amplified by primer-specific PCR, pooled, size-fractionated, and sequenced on the Ion Torrent PGM platform. The individual virus genomes were readily assembled by both de novo and template-assisted assembly methods. This method consistently resulted in near full-length, if not full-length, genomic sequences and has been used to sequence multiple rinderpestivirus and coronavirus isolates simultaneously.
authors: Neill, J. D.;Bayles, D. O.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Genetic relationship of caliciviruses: San Miguel sea lions and porcine virus vesicular rash form a single genotype within the Caliciviridae
abstract: San Miguel sea lion viruses (SMSV) and swine vesicular rash (VESV) are morphologically and antigenically related, but little has been done to determine their genotypic relationship to each other and to other caliciviruses. To examine this relationship, reverse transcriptase PCRs were performed using oligonucleotide primer sets designed to amplify portions of the 2C RNA helicase-like and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase regions with total cellular RNA purified from virus-infected cell cultures as die were developed. The 2C RNA helicase primers directed amplification of this region from eight SMSV serotypes, five VESV serotypes, and four related viruses. The RNA polymerase primer captures amplified products from all but one of these viruses. The phylogenetic comparison of the caliciviruses showed that SMSV, VESV and four related viruses are closely related but distinct from feline calicivirus, human caliciviruses (small round-structured viruses) and rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus and should be classified as one virus only genotype within the Caliciviridae.
authors: Neill, J. D.;Meyer, R. F.;Seal, B. S.

title: Donor infections and risk of infection in xenotransplantation and allotransplantation
abstract: Post-transplant infections are common in allograft recipients and should be expected in all immunocompromised hosts. Based on the need for immunosuppression in xenotransplantation, procedures developed to increase safety in allotransplantation may be applied in future xenotransplantation clinical trials. Standardized approaches can be developed to guide the evaluation of common infectious syndromes in xenograft recipients. The opportunity created by the screening of pigs intended as xenograft donors is equally applicable to allografts - particularly broader screening strategies for allograft donors, such as: Treatment considerations for allograft and xenograft-associated infections are largely the same. Experience in xenotransplantation will continue to inform thinking about donor infections in allotransplantation. We anticipate that experience in managing complex allograft recipients will be similarly incorporated into xenotransplantation clinical trials.
authors: Nellore, A.;Fishman, J. A.

title: Influenza A(H3N2) reassortant viruses of human origin in swine, southeastern Mexico
abstract: The genetic diversity of influenza A viruses circulating in pigs in Mexico complicates animal control efforts and poses a threat to humans, as demonstrated by the influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. To describe the evolution of swine influenza A viruses in Mexico and to evaluate strains for vaccine development, we sequenced the genomes of 59 viruses and performed antigenic mapping on strains from 5 regions. We found that genetic and antigenic diversity was particularly high in southeastern Mexico, as viruses were repeatedly introduced to other regions of Mexico from humans and pigs. We identified novel reassortant H3N2 viruses with genome segments derived from two different viruses introduced independently into pigs from humans: pandemic H1N1 viruses and seasonal H3N2 viruses. The Mexican swine viruses are antigenically distinct from US swine lines. US viral vaccines are unlikely to provide protection against these viruses and would require the development of new vaccines specifically targeting these different strains.
authors: Nelson, M. I.;Souza, C.;Trovao, N. S.;Diaz, A.;Mena, I.;Rovira, A.;Vincent, A. L.;Torremorell, M.;Marthaler, D.;Culhane, M. R.

title: Evolutionary pathways of N2 neuraminidases from porcine and human influenza A viruses: origin of the neuraminidase genes of two reassortants (H1N2) isolated from pigs.
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequences of the neuraminidase (NA) genes of two reassortants (H1N2) and two H3N2 influenza A viruses isolated from pigs were determined, and phylogenetic relationships between these and previously reported N2 NA genes were examined . Based on pairwise nucleotide sequence identity, the NA genes of two reassortants, A/sw/Kanagawa/2/78 and A/sw/Ehime/1/80, were most closely related to those of the human influenza A virus strains encoded in were isolated in 1972 or the earliest available swine H3N2 influenza A viruses. Pedigrees showed that the NA genes can be divided into three groups, including lineages for (i) porcine strains, (ii) the earliest human strain, and (iii) more recent human strains. The evolutionary tree for the 11 nucleotide and amino acid sequences suggested that the NAs of A/sw/HK/4/76 and A/sw/Kanagawa/2/78 belong to the lineage for newer human viruses. In contrast, the NA genes of the A/sw/HK/3/76 and H1N2 reassortant A/sw/Ehime/1/80 viruses were found to be of porcine origin. The porcine virus NA genes were further characterized by the co-circulation of two distinct lineages. Although the rates of synonymous (silent) substitutions for the porcine and human viruses were nearly identical (0.00946 to 0.00884 per site per year), the rate of non-synonymous (amino acid altering) substitutions for porcine virus NA- About 60% of the genes for the human virus.
authors: Nerome, K.;Kanegae, Y.;Yoshioka, Y.;Itamura, S.;Ishida, M.;Gojobori, T.;Oya, A.

title: Approved and experimental countermeasures against pestivirus diseases: bovine viral diarrhea, classical swine fever and border disease
abstract: The pestiviruses, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), classical swine fever (CSFV) and border disease virus, are important pathogens affecting livestock in many countries, but current vaccines do not completely prevent the spread of infection. Control of pestivirus diseases is particularly difficult due to the constant viraemia and viral shedding of persistently infected (PI) animals, which must be identified and eliminated to prevent disease transmission. Existing vaccines are limited by the delay between vaccination and the onset of protection, the difficulty in distinguishing serologically between vaccinated and naturally infected animals, and the need for broad vaccine cross-protection against different virus strains. Antiviral therapy could potentially complement vaccination by providing immediate protection in the event of an outbreak. Numerous compounds with in vitro antiviral activity against BVDV have been identified through its role as a surrogate for the hepatitis C virus. Fewer drugs active against CSFV have been identified, but many compounds active against BVDV are likely to inhibit CSFV due to their similar genomic sequences. While in vitro research has been promising, the lack of animal efficacy studies has hampered the commercial development of effective antiviral drugs against the pestiviruses. In this article, we summarize the clinical syndromes and transmission routes of BVD, CSF, and border disease, discuss currently approved vaccines, review efforts to develop antiviral therapies for use in outbreak control, and suggest promising directions for future research. © 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Newcomer, B. W.;Givens, M. D.

title: Characterization of a rotavirus
abstract: Acute gastroenteritis is one of the most common causes of disease in children, calves and piglets and causes severe economic losses in domestic animals. Although some outbreaks of gastroenteritis are associated with bacterial pathogens, particularly Escherichia coli, until recently no known pathogens had been isolated from a significant proportion of outbreaks, other than viruses with a distinct morphology and antigen similarity associated with diarrhea in piglets, calves and children were found . These viruses are important pathogens and viruses isolated from humans have also been shown to be contagious to pigs. Originally, these viruses were described as reovirus-like, but the names rotavirus and duovirus were later proposed. They differ morphologically and antigenically from both reoviruses and orbiviruses, and also differ from them in some of their physicochemical properties. Studies on the structure of rotaviruses have been limited to the nucleic acid of calf virus and related infant mouse epizootic diarrhea virus (EDIM). Both viruses have been shown to contain RNA, and it has been suggested that calf virus RNA may be double-stranded. The results of the experiments described here indicate that calf rotavirus possesses some of the features characteristic of the Reo and bluetongue viruses and should be classified with them. Although calf rotavirus has a smaller sedimentation coefficient and differs morphologically from the Reo and bluetongue viruses, the segmented and double-stranded nature of its RNA and the number and molecular weight of the RNA and polypeptides suggest that it should be considered a member of the group of Reo and bluetongue viruses. However, its exact relationship to the other members of the group will require extensive cross-hybridization studies of the viral RNAs.
authors: Newman, J. F. E.;Brown, F.;Bridger, J. C.;Woode, G. N.

title: Oral papillomatosis caused by Enhydra lutris papillomavirus 1 (ElPV-1) in southern sea otters (Enhydra lutris nereis) in California, USA
abstract: The southern sea otter (Enhydra lutris nereis) is an endangered marine warden. During postmortem examinations of stranded sea otters from 2004 to 2013 in California, USA, papillomas in the oral cavity of at least seven otters were detected by autopsy and histopathology. Next-generation sequencing of virus particles purified from a single papilloma revealed a novel papillomavirus, Enhydra lutris papillomavirus 1 (ElPV-1). The genome of ElPV-1 was obtained, representing the first fully sequenced southern sea otter viral genome. Phylogenetic analysis of the entire L1 gene, as well as a diagram of the chained protein identities of all papillomaviral genes, revealed that ElPV-1 is a β-papillomavirus related to a raccoon papillomavirus (Procyon lotor papillomavirus type 1) and a canine oral papillomavirus is. Immunohistochemical staining using a bovine papillomavirus cross-reactive antibody suggested that ElPV-1 is present in intranuclear inclusions and intracytoplasmic keratin grains. Virus-infected cells were scattered throughout the granular and spinal stratum of the gingival and buccal papillomas. Using ElPV-1 specific PCR, we confirmed viral DNA in oral papillomas from all seven-stranded sea otters with identical L1 sequences. This virus is associated with the development of oral papillomatosis in southern sea otters.
authors: Ng, T. F.;Miller, M. A.;Kondov, N. O.;Dodd, E. M.;Batac, F.;Manzer, M.;Ives, S.;Saliki, J. T.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Metagenomic identification of a novel anellovirus in Pacific harbor seal (Phoca vitulina richardsii) lung samples and its detection in samples over several years
abstract: To study viral pathogens potentially involved in a 2000 death of 21 Pacific harbor seals (Phoca vitulina richardsii) in California, viral metagenomics was performed directly on lung samples from five individuals. Metagenomics revealed a novel seal anellovirus (SealAV) that phylogenetically aggregates with anelloviruses from California sea lions and domestic cats. Using specific PCR, SealAV was identified in lung tissue from two out of five animals involved in the 2000 fatality and in one out of 20 seal samples examined postmortem in 2008. The identification of SealAV over several years shows that this virus is persistent in the seal population. SealAV is the second anellovirus to be reported in the lungs of pinnipeds, suggesting that anellovirus infections are common in marine mammals and that more research is needed to understand the role of these viruses in marine mammal health and disease.
authors: Ng, T. F.;Wheeler, E.;Greig, D.;Waltzek, T. B.;Gulland, F.;Breitbart, M.

title: A metagenomics and case-control study to identify viruses implicated in bovine respiratory disease
abstract: Bovine Respiratory Disease (BRD) is a common health problem for both dairy and beef cattle, resulting in significant economic losses. To identify viruses associated with BRD, we used a metagenomic approach to enrich for and sequence viral nucleic acids in nasal swabs from 50 young dairy cows with symptoms of BRD. Numerous known and previously uncharacterized viruses were identified after deep sequencing, de novo assembly, and similarity searches for translated protein sequences. Bovine adenovirus 3, bovine adeno-associated virus, bovine influenza D virus, bovine parvovirus 2, bovine herpesvirus 6, bovine rhinitis A virus, and several bovine rhinitis B virus genotypes have been identified . The genomes of a previously uncharacterized astrovirus and picobirnaviruses have also been partially or fully sequenced. Real-time PCR was used to compare the detection rates of the eight viruses generating the most reads in the nasal secretions of 50 animals with BRD versus 50 site-matched healthy controls. Viruses were detected in 68% of the BRD-affected animals compared to 16% of the healthy control animals. 38% of the sick animals compared to 8% of the control animals were infected with several respiratory viruses. Significantly associated with BRD were bovine adenovirus 3 (P<0.0001), bovine rhinitis A virus (P=0.005), and the recently described bovine influenza D virus (P=0.006), which either Animals with BRD were detected alone or in combination in 62% of cases. A metagenomics and real-time PCR detection approach in carefully matched cases and controls can provide a rapid means of identifying viruses associated with a complex disease, paving the way for further confirmatory testing and ultimately effective intervention strategies.
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Kondov, N. O.;Deng, X.;Van Eenennaam, A.;Neibergs, H. L.;Delwart, E.

title: Discovery of a novel single-stranded DNA virus from a sea turtle fibropapilloma using viral metagenomics
abstract: Viral metagenomics, consisting of viral particle purification and shotgun sequencing, is a powerful technique for discovering viruses associated with diseases without a definitive etiology, viruses that share limited homology with known viruses, or viruses that cannot be cultured . Here, we used viral metagenomics to study viruses associated with sea turtle fibropapillomatosis (FP), a debilitating neoplastic disease affecting sea turtles worldwide. A novel single-stranded DNA virus, sea turtle tornovirus 1 (STTV1), was discovered by purification and shotgun sequencing of the viral community directly from the fibropapilloma of a Florida green sea turtle. The single-stranded, circular genome of Sâ€²lâ€²lâ€²Vl was approximately 1,800 nucleotides long. Sâ€²lâ€²lâ€²Vl shows only weak identities at the amino acid level (25%) with the chicken anemia virus in short regions of its genome; therefore STTV1 could represent the first member of a new virus family. A total of 35 healthy turtles and 27 turtles with FP were tested for STTV1 by PCR, and only 2 turtles severely affected by FP were positive. The affected turtles were systemically infected with Sâ€²lâ€²lâ€²Vl since STTV1 was found in the blood and all major organs. Sâ€²lâ€²lâ€²Vl exists as a quasi-species, with multiple genome variants identified in the fibropapilloma of each positive turtle, suggesting rapid evolution of this virus. The STTV1 variants were identical over most of their genomes but contained a hypervariable region with strong divergence. This study demonstrates the potential of viral metagenomics to discover novel viruses directly from animal tissue, which may improve our understanding of viral evolution and diversity. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Manire, C.;Borrowman, K.;Langer, T.;Ehrhart, L.;Breitbart, M.

title: Feline Fecal Virome Reveals Novel and Widespread Enteric Viruses
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Mesquita, J. R.;Nascimento, M. S. J.

title: Novel anellovirus discovered in one fatality in captive California sea lions
abstract: viral metagenomic study was conducted to investigate potential viral pathogens associated with a death in three captive California sea lions (Zalophus californianus). This study identified a novel California sea lion anellovirus (ZcAV) with 35% amino acid identity in the ORF1 region to feline anelloviruses. The double-stranded replicative form of ZcAV has been detected in lung tissue, suggesting that ZcAV replicates in sea lion lungs. Specific PCR showed the presence of ZcAV in the lung tissue of all three sea lions involved in the fatality, but not in three other sea lions from the same zoo. In addition, ZcAV has been detected at low frequency (11%) in the lungs of wild sea lions. The higher prevalence of ZcAV and the presence of the double-stranded replicative form in sea lion lungs due to fatality suggests that ZcAV has been associated with the death of these animals.
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Suedmeyer, W. K.;Wheeler, E.;Gulland, F.;Breitbartt, M.

title: Development and evaluation of a non-ribosomal random PCR and next-generation sequencing-based assay for the detection and sequencing of hand, foot and mouth disease pathogens
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) has become a major public health problem in Asia-Pacific and is commonly caused by enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) and coxsackievirus A6 (CV-A6), CV -A10 and created CV-A16. Generating entire genome sequences of pathogens is essential for understanding their evolutionary biology. The frequent exchange between EV serotypes and a limited number of available whole genome sequences hinder the development of overlapping PCRs for whole genome sequencing. We have developed and evaluated a next-generation non-ribosomal randomized PCR (rPCR) and sequencing-based assay for sequence-independent whole genome amplification and sequencing of HFMD pathogens. A total of 16 EV-A71/CV-A6/CV-A10/CV-A16 PCR-positive rectal/pharyngeal swabs (Cp values: 20.9-33.3) were used for the assay interpretation. RESULTS: Our assay apparently outperformed conventional rPCR in terms of total number of EV-A71 reads and percentage of EV-A71 reads: 2.6% (1275/50,000 reads) vs. 0.1% (31/50,000 ) and 6% (3008/50,000) vs. 0.9% (433/50,000) for two samples with Cp values of 30 and 26, respectively. In addition, the assay was able to detect genomic sequences with 94-100% coverage from 4 different Generate enterovirus serotypes in 73% of the samples tested, representing the first full genome sequences of CV-A6/10/16 from Vietnam, and was able to correctly assign serotyping results in 100% of the 24 samples tested. For all but three, the consensus results obtained from two replicates of the same sample were 100% identical, indicating that our assay is highly reproducible. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, we have successfully developed a next-generation non-ribosomal rPCR and sequencing-based assay for the sensitive detection and direct sequencing of the whole genome of HFMD pathogens from clinical specimens.
authors: Nguyen, A. T.;Tran, T. T.;Hoang, V. M.;Nghiem, N. M.;Le, N. N.;Le, T. T.;Phan, Q. T.;Truong, K. H.;Le, N. N.;Ho, V. L.;Do, V. C.;Ha, T. M.;Nguyen, H. T.;Nguyen, C. V.;Thwaites, G.;van Doorn, H. R.;Le, T. V.

title: Development of highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) virus populations in Vietnam between 2007 and 2010
abstract: We report the genetic analysis of 213 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses H5N1 isolated from poultry in Vietnam between 2007 and 2010. Phylogenetic analyzes of the viral genomes revealed 38 different viral genotypes, 29 were new and 9 were reported in Vietnam or neighboring countries in recent years. Viruses from only six genotypes persisted beyond a season or a year. Therefore, most reassortant viruses were transient, suggesting that these genotypes lacked significant fitness advantages. Viruses with clade 2.3.2.1 HA were reintroduced into Vietnam in 2009 and their prevalence increased sharply towards the end of 2010. Clad 2.3.4-like viruses (genotype V) were prevalent in North Vietnam and caused the majority of zoonotic infections. while clade 1.1 (genotype Z) viruses have only been detected in the Mekong Delta region of southern Vietnam. Antigenic analysis of representative viruses from the four clades showed considerable drift. © 2012.
authors: Nguyen, T.;Rivailler, P.;Davis, C. T.;Thi Hoa, D.;Balish, A.;Hoang Dang, N.;Jones, J.;Thi Vui, D.;Simpson, N.;Thu Huong, N.;Shu, B.;Loughlin, R.;Ferdinand, K.;Lindstrom, S. E.;York, I. A.;Klimov, A.;Donis, R. O.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of a novel porcine parvovirus (PPV6) in China
abstract: Background: Parvoviruses are divided into two subfamilies based on their host range: the Parvovirinae, which infect vertebrates, and the Densovirinae, which mainly infect insects and other arthropods. In recent years, a number of new parvoviruses belonging to the subfamily Parvovirinae have been identified in various animal species and humans, including human parvovirus 4 (PARV4), porcine hokovirus, ovine partetravirus, porcine parvovirus 4 (PPV4) and porcine Parvovirus 5 (PPV5). Methods: A novel parvovirus within the subfamily Parvovirinae, distinct from all known parvoviruses, was identified by sequence-independent single-primer amplification (SISPA) and five full-length genomic sequences were determined and analyzed. Results: A novel porcine parvovirus, tentatively named PPV6, was originally identified in aborted pig fetuses in China. Retrospective studies showed that the prevalence of PPV6 appeared to be higher in aborted pig fetuses and piglets (50% and 75%, respectively) than in finishers and sows (15.6% and 3.8%, respectively). In addition, the prevalence of PPV6 in finishers in affected and unaffected herds was similar (ie 16.7% vs. 13.6%-21.7%). This finding indicates that the age of the animals, possibly due to increased innate immune resistance, strongly influences the level of PPV6 viremia. Whole genome sequencing and multiple alignments have shown that the nearly complete genome sequence was approximately 6,100 nucleotides in length and shared 20.5%-42.6% DNA sequence identity with other members of the Parvovirinae subfamily. Phylogenetic analysis showed that PPV6 was significantly different from other known parvoviruses and was most closely related to PPV4. Conclusion: Our results and review of published parvovirus sequences suggested that a novel porcine parvovirus is currently circulating in China and could potentially be placed in the novel genus Copiparvovirus within the subfamily Parvovirinae. However, the clinical manifestations of PPV6 are still unknown as the prevalence of PPV6 was similar in a retrospective epidemiological study between healthy pigs and diseased pigs. The identification of PPV6 within the Parvovirinae subfamily provides further insight into the viral and genetic diversity of parvoviruses.
authors: Ni, J.;Qiao, C.;Han, X.;Han, T.;Kang, W.;Zi, Z.;Cao, Z.;Zhai, X.;Cai, X.

title: hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a non-enveloped, positive-sense RNA virus that is currently being classified into a new family, Hepeviridae genus hepevirus (single-stranded RNA viruses). The genome (7.2 kb) contains three open reading frames (ORF) encoding non-structural (ORF1) and structural proteins (ORF2 & ORF3). HEV infection has been implicated as a major cause of epidemic acute hepatitis transmitted by the faecal-oral route in developing countries. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis have been reported in Western countries with no history of travel to endemic areas. Phylogenetic analysis of different geographic HEV identified four main genotypes: Genotype I collecting Asian (I1) and African (I2) isolates, Genotype II found in Mexico and Nigeria, Genotype III found in US humans and US pigs and genotype IV in Taiwan. Other genotypes have been described in non-HEV endemic areas (Greece, Italy, Argentina). Isolation of HEV in pets supports an environmental reservoir of HEV. Current diagnosis of HEV infection involves molecular tools to detect the virus in stool or serum samples and serological tests to identify anti-HEV Ig G and Ig M.
authors: Nicand, E.;Grandadam, M.

title: Occurrence of adenovirus field strains in birds infected with Marek's disease virus
abstract: Adenovirus strains were isolated from 356 birds with clinical form of Marek's disease and co-infection with adenoviruses. A hexon gene fragment encoding the L1 loop of adenovirus strains was sequenced and the data obtained were analyzed using BLAST, Geneious 5.3 and MEGA5 software by comparison with nucleotide sequences of reference strains of avian adenoviruses (FAdV-1-FadV-12) , two turkey adenoviruses analyzed and two goose adenovirus strains. On this basis, serotypes of adenovirus strains were determined. Sequences of all adenovirus strains isolated from birds infected with Marek's disease virus were classified into six serotypes representing four species. Mainly the serotypes FAdV-7, FAdV2/11 and FAdV-8a were found.
authors: Niczyporuk, J. S.;Samorek-Salamonowicz, E.;Czekaj, H.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of hepatitis E virus from mongooses in Okinawa, Japan
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection has previously been reported in wild mongooses on the island of Okinawa; To date, however, only one HEV RNA sequence has been identified in a mongoose. Therefore, this study was conducted to detect HEV RNA in 209 wild mongooses on the island of Okinawa. Six (2.9%) specimens tested positive for HEV RNA. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that 6 HEV RNAs belonged to genotype 3 and were classified into groups A and B. In group B, the mongoose-derived HEV sequences were very similar to the mongoose HEV previously detected on the island of Okinawa and that of a pig. This study highlighted the possibility that the mongoose is a reservoir animal for HEV on the island of Okinawa. © 2012 Japanese Society of Veterinary Medicine.
authors: Nidaira, M.;Takahashi, K.;Ogura, G.;Taira, K.;Okano, S.;Kudaka, J.;Itokazu, K.;Mishiro, S.;Nakamura, M.

title: Genetic characterization of H5N1 influenza viruses isolated from chickens in Indonesia in 2010
abstract: Since 2003, the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses have caused outbreaks among poultry in Indonesia every year and claimed the highest number of human lives worldwide. However, little is known about the H5N1 influenza virus that has been circulating there in recent years. We therefore conducted surveillance studies and isolated eight H5N1 viruses from chickens. Phylogenetic analysis of their hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes revealed that all eight viruses belonged to clade 2.1.3. However, based on nucleotide differences, these viruses could be divided into two groups. Other viruses closely related genetically to these two virus groups were all Indonesian isolates, suggesting that these new isolates evolved within Indonesia. Among these viruses, two different viruses circulated in the Kalimantan Islands during the same season in 2010. Our data show the continuous evolution of H5N1 viruses in Indonesia. © The author(s) 2012.
authors: Nidom, C. A.;Yamada, S.;Nidom, R. V.;Rahmawati, K.;Alamudi, M. Y.;Kholik;Indrasari, S.;Hayati, R. S.;Iwatsuki Horimoto, K.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Near-complete genome sequencing of swine vesicular disease virus using the Roche GS FLX sequencing platform
abstract: Swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) is an enterovirus closely related, both genetically and antigenically, to human coxsackievirus B5 within the Picornaviridae family. SVDV is the causative agent of a highly contagious (though rarely fatal) vesicular disease in pigs. We report a rapid method suitable for sequencing the complete protein coding sequences of SVDV isolates in which the RNA is relatively intact. The approach couples a single PCR amplification reaction, using only a single set of PCR primers to amplify the nearly complete SVDV genome, with deep sequencing using a small fraction of the capacity of a Roche GS FLX sequencing platform. Sequences were initially verified by one of two criteria; either a match between a de novo array and a reference map, or a match between all five different reference maps performed against a fixed set of starting reference genomes with significant genetic distances within the same virus species. All reference assignments used an iterative method to avoid bias. Further verification was achieved through phylogenetic analysis using published SVDV genomes and additional enterovirus B sequences. This approach allows for high confidence in the consensus sequences obtained and provides sufficiently high and evenly distributed sequence coverage to allow for future studies of within-host variation. © 2014 Nielsen et al.
authors: Nielsen, S. C. A.;Bruhn, C. A. W.;Samaniego, J. A.;Wadsworth, J.;Knowles, N. J.;Gilbert, M. T. P.

title: Complete genome sequences of C rotaviruses of the Japanese swine species show a high diversity of genotypes of single genes and will contribute to a comprehensive, generally accepted classification system
abstract: Porcine rotavirus C (RVC) is distributed worldwide and is considered to be the causative agent of diarrheal diseases in piglets. Although the VP7, VP4, and VP6 gene sequences of Japanese swine RVCs are currently available, there are no whole genome sequence data from Japanese RVCs. In addition, only one to three sequences are available for porcine RVC VP1-VP3 and NSP1-NSP3 genes. Therefore, we determined almost complete genome sequences of nine Japanese porcine RVCs from seven piglets with diarrhea and two healthy pigs and compared them to published RVC sequences from a database. The VP7 genes of two Japanese RVCs from healthy pigs differed greatly from other known RVC strains and were tentatively classified as G12 and G13 based on the 86% nucleotide identity cutoff. Pairwise sequence identity calculations and phylogenetic analysis revealed that candidates for novel Japanese swine RVC genotypes were identified in the genes encoding NSP1, NSP2, and NSP3, respectively. Furthermore, VP3 of Japanese pig RVCs was shown to be closely related to human RVCs, suggesting gene rearrangement between pig and human RVCs and earlier interspecies transmission. The present study demonstrated that porcine RVCs exhibit greater genetic diversity among strains than human and bovine RVCs.
authors: Niira, K.;Ito, M.;Masuda, T.;Saitou, T.;Abe, T.;Komoto, S.;Sato, M.;Yamasato, H.;Kishimoto, M.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Tuchiaka, S.;Okada, T.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Aoki, H.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Taniguchi, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Different RNA splicing mechanisms contribute to different infection sequences of classical swine fever viruses of different virulence: insights from deep sequencing data in porcine umbilical vein endothelial cells
abstract: Molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of RNA splicing in response to viral infection are poorly understood. Classical swine fever (CSF), one of the most economically important and highly contagious swine diseases worldwide, is caused by the classical swine fever virus (CSFV). Here we used high-throughput sequencing to obtain the digital gene expression (DGE) profile in porcine umbilical vein endothelial cells (SUVEC) to identify different response genes for CSFV using both Shimen and C strains. The number of clean tags obtained from the control and both CSFV-infected libraries was 3,473,370, 3,498,355, and 3,327,493, respectively. When comparing between the control, CSFV-C and CSFV-Shimen groups, 644, 158 and 677 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were confirmed in the three groups. Pathway enrichment analyzes showed that many of these DEGs were enriched in spliceosome, ribosome, proteasome, ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis, cell cycle, focal adhesion, Wnt signaling pathway, etc., with processes differing between CSFV strains of different virulence. To further elucidate important mechanisms related to differential infection by the CSFV-shimen and -C strains, we identified four possible profiles to assess the significantly expressed genes only by the CSFV-shimen or CSFV-C strain . GO analysis showed that infection with CSFV Shimen and C strains disrupted SUVEC 'RNA splicing', resulting in differential 'gene expression' in SUVEC. The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) was identified as a significant response regulator contributing to the impact on SUVEC function for CSFV shimen. This computational study suggests that CSFV of different virulence could induce changes in RNA splicing regulation in the host cell to alter cellular metabolism, leading to acute bleeding and pathologic damage or infectious tolerance.
authors: Ning, P.;Zhou, Y.;Liang, W.;Zhang, Y.

title: Whole genome analysis of fifteen torque teno midi virus variants classifiable in a third group of the genus Anellovirus
abstract: Recently, we identified a novel human virus with a 3.2 kb circular DNA genome, tentatively named torque teno midi virus (TTMDV), with a genomic organization similar to that of torque teno virus ( TTV) of 3.8-3.9 kb and Torque-Teno-Mini resembles virus (TTMV) of 2.8-2.9 kb. To examine the extent of genomic variability of TTMDV genomes, the full-length sequence was determined for 15 TTMDV isolates obtained from viremic individuals in Japan. The 15 TTMDV isolates ranged in length from 3175-3230 bases and shared 67.0-90.3% identities with each other and were only 68.4-73.0% identical to the 3 reported TTMDV isolates across the entire genome. TTMDV possessed a four open reading frame (ORF1-ORF4) genomic organization with characteristic sequence motifs and stem and loop structures with high GC content, similar to TTV and TTMV. The total of 18 TTMDV genomes differed in the amino acid sequence of ORF1 (658-677 amino acids) by up to 60.7% from each other, but phylogenetically separated into the same cluster distantly related to the TTVs and TTMVs. These results show that TTMDV, with a circular DNA genome of 3.2 kb, has an extremely high degree of genomic variability and is classifiable into a third group in the genus Anellovirus.
authors: Ninomiya, M.;Takahashi, M.;Shimosegawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Monoclonal antibodies against the HN glycoprotein of Newcastle disease virus. Biological characterization and use for strain comparisons
abstract: We have isolated nine hybridomas secreting monoclonal antibodies directed against the HN glycoprotein of the D26 strain of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) and divided them into three groups based on their biological reactivities. Group I antibodies from six clones had high hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and neutralization titers and demonstrated neuraminidase inhibition (NI) activity with substrates, both bovine fetuin and N-acetylneuramine lactose, although levels of maximal inhibition were greater with the former substrate . Group II antibodies from two clones also had high HI activity, but displayed a highly substrate-dependent NI with efficient inhibition against fetuin and a complete lack of inhibition against neuraminactose. These antibodies had neutralizing capacity, but the titers were much lower than those of group I antibodies. One clone (Group III) secreted antibodies showing HI and NI with each substrate but no detectable neutralizing activity. The frequency of isolation of antigenic variants and competitive binding assays have shown that group I and group II antibodies can recognize different regions that do not overlap, whereas antibodies placed in each of the two groups go to the same overlapping regions belong. The group III site appeared close to or overlapping the group I determinant but distinct from the group II region. Using the isolated monoclonal antibodies, we compared seven heterologous strains by HI and neutralization assays and by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The results indicated that the regions recognized by group I antibodies were conserved among strains, while those of the other two antibody groups could undergo considerable variation.
authors: Nishikawa, K.;Isomura, S.;Suzuki, S.

title: Production of monoclonal antibodies against classical swine fever virus and their use for antigenic characterization of Japanese isolates
abstract: Twenty monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) were prepared against the virulent ALD or vaccine-GPE strains of classical swine fever virus (CSF). The MAbs were classified into 7 groups based on the difference in response spectrum to various CSF and bovine viral diarrheal mucosal disease viruses (BVD-MD).
