The panel of MAbs was able to classify 20 CSF viruses into 6 types and could distinguish not only between CSF and BVD-MD viruses but also between the vaccine strain GPE and field isolates of CSF virus. The results showed that the MAbs were useful for the diagnosis and study of CSF viruses.
authors: Nishimori, T.;Yamada, S.;Shimizu, M.

title: Identification and full genome characterization of novel circoviruses in masked palm civets (Paguma larvata)
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes a large group of small, circular, single-stranded DNA viruses and is divided into two genera: circovirus and cyclovirus. They have a high genetic diversity and a wide host range. In this study, three novel circovirus genomes from wild-caught Masked Civets (Paguma larvata) in Japan were identified and classified as new species within the genus Circovirus based on the demarcation criteria of the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. Notably, the presence of two predicted introns at the 5' terminus of the rep gene in the Paguma larvata circovirus genomes has been proposed.
authors: Nishizawa, T.;Sugimoto, Y.;Takeda, T.;Kodera, Y.;Hatano, Y.;Takahashi, M.;Okamoto, H.

title: Relationship of von Theiler's murine encephalomyelitis viruses to the cardiovirus genus of picornaviruses
abstract: Sequence analysis of VP1 in the DA strain of Theiler murine encephalomyelitis virus (TMEV) revealed that 13 of the first 23 N-terminal amino acids were identical to those in the corresponding encephalomyocarditis virus protein. There was little similarity to the corresponding VP1 sequences of poliovirus types 1, 2, and 3, coxsackievirus B3, human rhinoviruses 2 and 14, human hepatitis A virus, or foot-and-mouth disease virus. These results, together with serological relationships demonstrated by immunoblotting, suggest that the TMEV are more closely related to the cardioviruses than to the enteroviruses with which they are currently classified. This newly recognized relationship suggests potential for recombinant infectious cDNA studies between TMEV and cardioviruses.
authors: Nitayaphan, S.;Omilianowski, D.;Toth, M. M.

title: Epidemiological study of H9 avian influenza virus, Newcastle disease virus, Tembusu virus, goose parvovirus and goose circovirus infection in geese in China
abstract: To deepen the knowledge of epidemic prevalence in the field of goose farming, a triplex PCR assay was developed and 478 samples were collected from Chinese goose farms in 11 provinces in China. The results of this epidemiological survey showed that the incidence rates of H9 avian influenza and goose circovirus were highest among the five infectious diseases studied. In addition, the triplex PCR assay has demonstrated remarkable sensitivity, speed, and versatility compared to other diagnostic methods. Dual infections accounted for a large fraction of co-infections in the field, with the combinations of H9/Tembusu, H9/goose circovirus, and goose circovirus/tembusu co-infected cases occurring more frequently. Epidemics were more severe in winter and spring. In addition, significant differences in the prevalence of these infectious diseases associated with different age groups were observed. In addition, a phylogenetic analysis determined by the neighbor joining method was performed to examine the evolution of these viruses during the study period. For the most part, the virus strains isolated during the study were consistent with most strains from geese origins isolated from mainland China in recent years. However, mutations between isolated H9 avian influenza virus strains and sequences available from GenBank have been observed that should attract much attention.
authors: Niu, X.;Wang, H.;Wei, L.;Zhang, M.;Yang, J.;Chen, H.;Tang, Y.;Diao, Y.

title: Metapneumoviruses in birds and humans
abstract: Avian pneumovirus (APV, Turkey Rhinotracheitis Virus) and human metapneumovirus (hMPV) are avian and human pathogens associated with upper respiratory tract infections, respectively. Based on their different genomic organization and poor nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) identity with paramyxoviruses of the genus Pneumovirus, APV and hMPV have been placed in a new genus termed metapneumovirus. APV strains were first isolated in the 1970s and have since been isolated in Europe, Africa, the Middle East and the United States (USA) and classified into four subgroups based on nt, APV/A, APV/B, APV/C and APV /D and predicted AS sequence identity. Although it was first isolated in 2001, serological evidence suggests that hMPV has been present in the human population since the 1950s. To date, there is only one subset of hMPV whose nt and aa sequence identity indicate that it is more closely related to APV/C than to APV/A, APV/B, or APV/D. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Njenga, M. K.;Lwamba, H. M.;Seal, B. S.

title: Isolation of Fukuoka virus, a member of the core canyon serogroup viruses of the family Rhabdoviridae, from bovine
abstract: Four virus strains with identical antigenic properties were isolated from blood samples from 4 febrile sentinel calves and leukopenes in cultures of HmLu-1 cells derived from baby hamster lungs. Based on its antigenic properties, the virus was identified as Fukuoka virus, which has been classified as a member of the core canyon serogroup of viruses of the family Rhabdoviridae.
authors: Noda, M.;Inaba, Y.;Banjo, M.;Kubo, M.

title: Pestivirus infection in cattle dairy farms: E2 glycoprotein ELISA demonstrates the presence of bovine viral diarrheal virus type 2 in north-western Italy
abstract: Background: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) types 1 and 2 are members of the pestivirus genus of the Flaviviridae family. This genus also includes the HoBi-like virus, tentatively classified as BVDV type 3. BVDV-1 is widespread in Italy despite the extensive use of BVDV-1 based vaccines, while BVDV-2 and HoBi-like pestivirus have been occasionally detected. Monitoring for the emergence of sporadic or atypical pestiviruses is a useful approach to assessing the need for additional vaccine strains that can be used in BVDV control programs. Results: In this study we developed a multiwell antibody ELISA based on the recombinant E2 protein of the three bovine pestiviruses. We evaluated the applicability of the assay for monitoring purposes using pooled milk samples each prepared from a maximum of 35 lactating cows and collected from 176 dairy herds. As expected, the majority of the pooled samples reacted more strongly against the BVDV-1 E2 antigen. However, all three milk pools from a single farm reacted to the BVDV-2 antigen. Further analysis using spot testing, antigen detection and 5' UTR region sequence analysis confirmed the presence of five persistently infected calves carrying a BVDV-2a strain. Conclusions: This study underscores for the first time that sporadic circulation of BVDV-2 can be predicted by immunoenzymatic methods without specific vaccination.
authors: Nogarol, C.;Decaro, N.;Bertolotti, L.;Colitti, B.;Iotti, B.;Petrini, S.;Lucente, M. S.;Elia, G.;Perona, G.;Profiti, M.;Buonavoglia, C.;Rosati, S.

title: Genetic analysis of a bovine viral diarrhea virus 2 isolate from Slovakia
abstract: Identification and genetic characterization of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolate 17237, detected in western Slovakia, is described. Analysis of the 5'' untranslated region (5''-UTR), the autoprotease (N pro) gene and the structural genes (C, Erns, E1, E2) was performed. The percentage of nucleotide and deduced amino acid identity in the genes analyzed implied that the isolate was closely related to bovine viral diarrhea virus 2 (BVDV-2). In addition, phylogenetic analysis revealed that this isolate belongs to the BVDV-2b subtype, which is sporadically found in Europe. The cleavage sites between viral proteins were similar to those of a reference strain of BVDV-2.
authors: NovÃ¡ÄkovÃ¡, M.;JackovÃ¡, A.;KolesÃ¡rovÃ¡, M.;VilÄek, Å

title: Rotavirus-associated diarrhea in foals in Greece
abstract: Severe outbreaks of diarrheal syndrome occurred in young foals at the same stud in two consecutive breeding seasons, spring 2006 and spring 2007. Rotavirus-like particles were detected by electron microscopy in the feces of affected foals, and group A rotavirus infection was confirmed by reverse - Transcription (RT)-PCR with selected sets of rotavirus-specific primers. Sequence analysis of the genes encoding the rotavirus outer capsid proteins VP7 and VP4 allowed the viruses to be classified as G3AP[12] and showed that the viruses were very similar to equine rotavirus strains recently circulating in Europe. All Greek equine rotavirus isolates were genetically identical, suggesting that the same virus strain persisted in the stud farm over the two consecutive foaling periods. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Ntafis, V.;Fragkiadaki, E.;Xylouri, E.;Omirou, A.;Lavazza, A.;Martella, V.

title: Differential Expression of Porcine MicroRNAs in African Swine Fever Virus-Infected Pigs: A Proof-of-Concept Study
abstract: Background: African swine fever (ASF) is a re-emerging devastating viral disease that is currently threatening the swine industry worldwide. MicroRNAs are a class of 17-25 nucleotide non-coding RNAs that have been shown to have critical functions in a variety of biological processes, such as B. cell differentiation, cell cycle regulation, carcinogenesis, apoptosis, regulation of immunity and virus infections by cleavage or translational repression of mRNAs. However, there is no information on miRNA expression in ASFV infection. Methods: In this proof-of-concept study, we analyzed miRNAs expressed in spleens and submandibular lymph nodes of experimentally infected pigs with a virulent (E75) or a derived attenuated (E75CV1) ASFV strain and at various time points post-infection were expressed -infection with the virulent strain by high-throughput sequencing of small RNA libraries. Results: In ASPV infection, the spleen showed a more differentiated expression pattern than the lymph nodes. Of the most abundant miRNAs, 12 were differentially expressed in both tissues at two different time points in animals infected with the virulent strain. Of these, miR-451, miR-145-5p, miR-181a and miR-122 showed upregulation late in time after infection, while miR-92a, miR-23a, miR-92b-3p, miR-126-5p , miR-126-3p, miR-30d, miR-23b and miR-92c showed downregulation. Of the 8 differentially expressed miRNAs identified at the same time post-infection in animals infected with the virulent strain compared to animals infected with its attenuated strain, miR-126-5p, miR-92c, miR-92a, miR-30e-5p and miR-500a-5p showed upregulation, while miR-125b, miR-451 and miR-125a were downregulated. All of these miRNAs have been shown to be associated with cellular genes involved in signaling pathways related to immune response, virus-host interactions, as well as several viral genes. Conclusion: Studying miRNA expression will contribute to a better understanding of African swine fever virus pathogenesis, which is essential for the development of any disease control strategy.
authors: NÃºÃ±ez-HernÃ¡ndez, F.;PÃ©rez, L. J.;MuÃ±oz, M.;Vera, G.;Accensi, F.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;RodrÃ­guez, F.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.

title: Identification of microRNAs in pigs subclinically infected with PCV2 by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) is the major etiological infectious agent of PCV2 systemic disease and has been associated with other swine diseases, all collectively known as porcine circovirus diseases. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a new class of small noncoding RNAs that regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally. miRNAs play an increasing role in many biological processes. The study of miRNA-mediated host-pathogen interactions has evolved over the past decade because of the important role miRNAs play in antiviral defense. The aim of this study was to identify the miRNA expression pattern in pigs subclinically infected and uninfected with PCV2. For this purpose, an experimental PCV2 infection was performed and small RNA libraries were constructed from tonsils and mediastinal lymph nodes (MLN) of infected and uninfected pigs. High-throughput sequencing determined differences in miRNA expression in MLN between infected and uninfected, while a highly conserved pattern was observed in tonsils. In MLN, miRNA 126-3p, miRNA 126-5p, let-7d-3p, mir-129a, and mir-let-7b-3p were upregulated, while mir-193a-5p, mir-574-5p, and mir-34a were upregulated down regulated. Functional analysis prediction indicated that these miRNAs may be involved in signaling pathways related to the immune system and in processes related to PCV2 pathogenesis, although functional assays are needed to support these predictions. This is the first study of miRNA gene expression in PCV2-infected pigs using a high-throughput sequencing approach in which multiple host miRNAs were differentially expressed in response to PCV2 infection.
authors: NÃºÃ±ez-HernÃ¡ndez, F.;PÃ©rez, L. J.;MuÃ±oz, M.;Vera, G.;TomÃ¡s, A.;Egea, R.;CÃ³rdoba, S.;SegalÃ©s, J.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.

title: African swine fever virus does not express viral microRNAs in experimentally infected pigs
abstract: Background: African swine fever virus (ASFV) is the causative agent of African swine fever (ASF), a recurrent devastating and highly fatal hemorrhagic viral disease. microRNAs (miRNAs) are a new class of small noncoding RNAs that regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally. The discovery of virus-specific miRNAs has increased in both number and importance in recent years. We recently described the differential expression of several porcine miRNAs during in vivo infection with attenuated and virulent ASFV strains. Here we extended these studies to identify the presence of viral miRNAs encoded by ASFV in swine infection in vivo. Results: Sixteen small RNA libraries were analyzed from spleens and submandibular lymph nodes obtained from eight pigs, seven of which were infected with either the virulent E75 ASFV strain or its attenuated counterpart E75CV1, or from pigs infected with the E75CV1 Survived infection and challenged with BA71 (heterologous challenge) with an uninfected negative control. Samples were taken at different time points after infection. Libraries were analyzed by next-generation sequencing. First, some viral miRNA candidates that did not correspond to the porcine miRNAs were identified. Further structural analysis was performed to confirm whether they met the conformational requirements to be considered viral miRNA. Conclusions: Analysis of sixteen small RNA libraries prepared from two different tissues from pigs experimentally infected with E75, E75CV1, or with E75CV1 plus BA71 revealed the presence of six potential miRNA sequences, but none of them matched the requirements to be considered viral miRNAs. From this we can conclude that ASFV does not express miRNAs in vivo, at least under the experimental conditions described here.
authors: NÃºÃ±ez-HernÃ¡ndez, F.;Vera, G.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;RodrÃ­guez, F.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.

title: PRODUCTION OF THE NUCLEOCAPSID PROTEIN OF A PIG
authors: Nviine, Coli;Ongs, T. I. N.

title: Discovery of the genome of an immunodeficiency-associated virus-like virus from pig feces in Japan
authors: Oba, M.;Katayama, Y.;Tsuchiaka, S.

title: Metagenomic identification and sequence analysis of a Techovirus A-related virus in pig feces in Japan, 2014–2016
abstract: Porcine teschoviruses (PTVs) are associated with polioencephalomyelitis and various diseases, including reproductive and gastrointestinal diseases, of pigs and wild boar, and are also found in the faeces of healthy pigs. The genus Teschovirus contains a single species Teschovirus A, which currently includes 13 serotypes. In the present study, we identified novel PTVs distantly related to Teschovirus A found in fecal samples from pigs with and without diarrhea in Japan. Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid (aa) sequences of the entire coding region revealed that these newly identified viruses were not clustered with PTV strains or other strains within picornavirus supergroup 1, suggesting that the viruses may not have belonged to Teschovirus A or either other genus belong to the family Picornaviridae. These novel PTVs share an internal Type IV ribosomal entry site and conserved characteristic motifs in the coding region, but exhibit 62.2-79.0%, 86.6-92.8%, 77.1-81.0% and 84.3-86.7%. aa identities with PTV strains in P1, 2C, 3C, and 3D regions, respectively. In contrast, Teschovirus A PTV 1–13 strains share 76.5–92.1%, 88.1–99.7%, 93.2–100%, and 95.8–100% aa identities in P1, 2C, 3C and 3D within the species. These data imply that the newly identified viruses belong to the Techoviruses and may represent a new species in the Techovirus genus.
authors: Oba, M.;Naoi, Y.;Ito, M.;Masuda, T.;Katayama, Y.;Sakaguchi, S.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Yamasato, H.;Sunaga, F.;Makino, S.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: A new comprehensive method for the detection of livestock-related disease-causing viruses using a target enrichment system
abstract: We tested the utility of a SureSelect target enrichment system, a comprehensive viral nucleic acid detection method, for the rapid identification of viral pathogens in fecal samples from cattle, pigs, and goats. This system enriches for nucleic acids from target viruses in clinical/field samples using a library of biotinylated RNAs with sequences complementary to the target viruses. The enriched nucleic acids are amplified by PCR and subjected to next-generation sequencing to identify target viruses. In many samples, the SureSelect target enrichment method increased the efficiency in detecting the viruses listed in the biotinylated RNA library. Furthermore, this method allowed us to determine the near-full-length genome sequence of porcine parainfluenza virus 1 and the greatly increased width, a value indicating the ratio of the mapping consensus length in the reference genome, in porcine samples. Our data demonstrated the utility of the SureSelect target enrichment system for comprehensive analysis of the genomic information of various viruses in field samples.
authors: Oba, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Otomaru, K.;Hirata, T.;Aoki, H.;Murata, Y.;Makino, S.;Nagai, M.;Mizutani, T.

title: COMPLETE GENOMICAL SEQUENCE OF THE VIRUENT PIGEON PARAMYXOVIRUS IN LAUGHING PIGEONS (STREPTOPELIA SENEGALENSIS) IN KENYA
abstract: Following the mass die-off of Laughing Doves (Streptopelia senegalensis) at various locations across Kenya, internal organs obtained at autopsy from two dying birds were removed and analyzed by next-generation sequencing. We isolated the virulent pigeon paramyxovirus type-1 (PPMV-1) strain, PPMV1/Laughing Dove/Kenya/Isiolo/B2/2012, which had a characteristic fusion gene motif (110)GGRRQKRF(117). We obtained a partially complete genome of 15,114 nucleotides. The phylogenetic relatedness based on the fusion gene and genomic sequence grouped our isolate as genotype VI class II, a group of viruses commonly isolated from wild birds but potentially lethal to chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus). The fusion gene isolate clustered with PPMV-I strains from pigeons (Columbidae) in Nigeria. The full genome showed a basal and highly divergent ancestry to American, European, and Asian phyla, indicating a divergent evolutionary pathway. The isolated strain is highly virulent and appears to be species specific for Laughing Doves in Kenya. The risk of transmission of such a strain to poultry is potentially high, while epizootic disease in pigeons poses a threat to the conservation of wild Columbidae in Kenya.
authors: Obanda, V.;Michuki, G.;Jowers, M. J.;Rumberia, C.;Mutinda, M.;Lwande, O. W.;Wangoru, K.;Kasiiti-Orengo, J.;Yongo, M.;Angelone-Alasaad, S.

title: Cross-hybridization and relatedness of different papillomavirus DNAs at different levels of stringency
abstract: Cloned DNAs from 21 different papillomaviruses that naturally infect mammals and one avian papillomavirus were compared for relative homology by Southern blot hybridization. Blots were performed under low (T(m)-40°), medium (T(m)-33°), and high (T(m)-22°) stringency conditions. At higher stringency, human papillomaviruses cross-hybridized with each other, reflecting species-specific similarities. Bovine papillomavirus types 1, 2, 5, European elk papillomavirus, and deer papillomavirus were also cross-hybridized at higher stringencies, likely reflecting the association of these viruses with fibroblast-rich lesions. The hybridization data presented here may be useful in future classification attempts. They are also useful as a guide in the selection of papillomavirus DNA probes for the analysis of extracts from warts and tumors.
authors: O'Banion, M. K.;Sundberg, J. P.;Reszka, A. A.;Reichmann, M. E.

title: Molecular evolution of human enteroviruses: correlation of serotype with VP1 sequence and application to picornavirus classification
abstract: Sixty-six human enterovirus serotypes have been identified by serum neutralization, but the molecular determinants of the serotypes are unknown. Since the picornavirus VP1 protein contains a number of neutralization domains, we hypothesized that the VP1 sequence should correspond to the neutralization (serotype) and thus to the phylogenetic ancestry. To test this hypothesis and analyze the phylogenetic relationships among human enteroviruses, we determined the full length VP1 sequences of prototype strains of 47 human enterovirus serotypes and 10 antigenic variants. Our sequences, together with those available from GenBank, form a database of complete VP1 sequences for all 66 human enterovirus serotypes plus additional strains of seven serotypes. Phylogenetic trees constructed from full VP1 sequences produced the same four major clusters as published trees based on partial VP2 sequences; however, in contrast to the VP2 trees, strains of the same serotype were always monophyletic in the VP1 trees. In pairwise comparisons of complete VP1 sequences, enteroviruses of the same serotype were clearly distinguished from those of heterologous serotypes, and the limits of intraserotypic divergence appeared to be around 25% nucleotide sequence difference or 12% amino acid sequence difference. Pairwise comparisons suggested that coxsackieviruses A11 and A15 should be classified as strains of the same serotype, as should coxsackieviruses A13 and A18. Pairwise identity scores also discriminated between enteroviruses of different clusters and enteroviruses of picornaviruses of different genera. The data suggest that VP1 sequence comparisons may be valuable in enterovirus typing and in picornavirus taxonomy, aiding in genus assignment of unclassified picornaviruses.
authors: Oberste, M. S.;Maher, K.;Kilpatrick, D. R.;Pallansch, M. A.

title: Genomic evidence that simian virus 2 and six other simian picornaviruses represent a new genus of Picornaviridae
abstract: Analysis of the VP1 capsid protein coding region of simian virus (SV) 2, SV16, SV18, SV42, SV44, SV45 and SV49 shows that they are distinct from members of the enterovirus genus and from members of other existing picornavirus genera. To further characterize this group of viruses and clarify their classification within the Picornaviridae, we determined the complete genomic sequence of SV2 (8126 nucleotides). The genome was typical of members of the Picornaviridae and encoded a single open reading frame. The putative polyprotein contained typical picornavirus protease cleavage sites, resulting in mature proteins homologous to each of the known picornavirus proteins. SV2 contained an amino-terminal extension of the reading frame analogous to the leader protein of members of the genera Aphthovirus, Cardiovirus, Erbovirus, Kobuvirus and Teschovirus, but there was no significant amino acid homology with any of these known leader proteins. The 2A protein also matched poorly with the 2A proteins of other picornaviruses. The deduced amino acid sequences of the structural and non-structural SV2 proteins were related to, but phylogenetically distinct from, those of enteroviruses and human rhinoviruses. The key distinguishing features of SV2 were the presence of a type 2 internal ribosomal entry site in the 5-NTR, a putative leader protein encoded upstream by the structural proteins, and an unusually large 2A protein. Based on the molecular analysis, we propose that SV2, SV16, SV18, SV42, SV44, SV45, SV49 and porcine enterovirus 8 be classified as members of a new genus in Picornaviridae and that SV2 (strain 2383) be designated as the species strain . © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Oberste, M. S.;Maher, K.;Pallansch, M. A.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrheal virus in cattle on Irish farms
abstract: The aim was to perform a phylogenetic study of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) circulating in Irish cattle herds from 2011 to 2014. 325 viruses from 267 herds were subtyped by nucleotide sequence analysis of the 5-UTR and/or the Npro regions. All viruses examined in this study belonged to the species BVDV-1 with BVDV-1a as the prominent subtype (97%). Also the subtypes BVDV-1b, BVDV-1d and BVDV-1e were first identified in Ireland. Pairwise alignments of 225 viruses with complete sequences for the 5-UTR and the Npro region were performed to determine a low conflict threshold for viral strain differentiation. One hundred and seventy seven unique viral strains have been identified. The study found a significant level of herd aggregation of strains, but no geographic or temporal aggregation. Similar virus strains have been identified in different counties, provinces and years, indicating the potential to study the epidemiology of the disease by combining sequence analysis with animal movement data.
authors: O'Brien, E.;Garvey, M.;Walsh, C.;Arkins, S.;Cullinane, A.

title: High-throughput genome sequencing of bioaerosols in broiler production facilities
abstract: Chronic inhalation exposure to agricultural dust promotes the development of chronic respiratory diseases in poultry workers. Poultry dust consists of dander, chicken feed, litter and microbes. However, the microbial composition and abundance has not been fully elucidated. Genomic DNA was extracted from settled dust and personal inhalable dust collected while performing garbage sampling or collection tasks. DNA libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500 using a paired-end sequencing-by-synthesis approach. < 2% of all reads). Staphylococcus sp. AL1, Salinicoccus carnicancri and Lactobacillus crispatus were the most abundant bacterial species in personal exposure samples of inhalable dust. Settled dust showed moderate relative abundances of these species, as well as Staphylococcus lentus and Lactobacillus salivarius. There was a statistical difference between the microbial composition of aerosolized and settled dust. In contrast to the composition of the deposited dust, the composition of the aerosolized dust showed minor deviations between the samples. These data provide a comprehensive analysis of the microbial composition and relative abundance of personal inhalable poultry dust and deposited poultry dust.
authors: O'Brien, K. M.;Chimenti, M. S.;Farnell, M.;Tabler, T.;Bair, T.;Bray, J. L.;Nonnenmann, M. W.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of bovine viral diarrhea virus in Mongolian cattle and yaks
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is classified into two species, namely bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 and bovine viral diarrhea virus 2, and affects cattle worldwide, resulting in significant economic losses. The prevalence of BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 infections and their genotypes in Mongolian animals have not been studied. In this study, we investigated BVDV infection in dairy cattle and yaks from Bornuur and Bulgan counties by RT-PCR, and the average infection rate at the sampling sites was 15.8% and 20.0%, respectively. In addition, molecular features of the 5'-UTR region of the BVDV genome in Mongolian cattle and yaks have been identified as belonging to subtypes BVDV-1a and BVDV-2a, respectively. Determining the prevalence, geographic distribution and molecular diversity of BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 in different host species in Mongolia is important for further studies and process control programs.
authors: Ochirkhuu, N.;Konnai, S.;Odbileg, R.;Odzaya, B.;Gansukh, S.;Murata, S.;Ohashi, K.

title: Characterization and spread of a potyvirus associated with passion fruit wood disease in Uganda
abstract: This article describes the incidence and etiology of a passion fruit viral disease in Uganda. Symptoms, including those characteristic of passion fruit wood disease (PWD), were observed in 32% of crops in growing areas. Electron microscopic observations of infected tissue showed flexible filaments of approximately 780 nanometers. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays indicated a serological relationship to cowpea aphid mosaic virus (CABMV) and passion fruit ringspot virus (PFRSV). In host range studies, only species of the families Solanaceae and Chenopodiaceae were susceptible, and neither Vigna unguiculata nor Phaseolus vulgaris were infected. Coat protein (CP) gene sequences from eight isolates showed typical potyvirus characteristics and were very similar (88 to 100% identity). However, the sequences shared limited sequence identity with CP genes from two of the three potyviruses reported to cause PWD: East Asian Passiflora Virus and Passion Fruit Woodiness Virus (PWV). Deduced amino acid sequences for the CP from Uganda isolates had the highest identity with Bean Common Mosaic Necrosis Virus (BCMNV) (72 to 79%, with evolutionary divergence values between 0.17 and 0.19) and CABMV (73 to 76%, with divergence values between 0.21 and 0.25). Based on these results and in accordance with the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses criteria for species differentiation in the family Potyviridae, we conclude that a previously unreported virus causes viral disease in passion fruit in Uganda. The name "Ugandan Passiflora virus" is proposed for this virus.
authors: Ochwo-Ssemakula, M.;Sengooba, T.;Hakiza, J. J.;Adipala, E.;Edema, R.;Redinbaugh, M. G.;Aritua, V.;Winter, S.

title: Bovine viral diarrhea virus genomic associations in mucosal disease, enteritis, and generalized dermatitis outbreaks in Argentina
abstract: The aim of the present work is to describe outbreaks caused by Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) in commercial cattle ranches in Argentina. Genetic affiliation and its association with clinical manifestation were analyzed using five BVDV isolates from an outbreak of mucosal disease (MD) (outbreak #1), acute enteritis (outbreaks #2 and #3), and generalized dermatitis (outbreaks #4 and #5). On genetic analysis, the CP-BVDV isolate from Outbreak #1 was too closely clustered with BVDV Oregon (genotype 1). BVDV isolates from outbreaks of generalized dermatitis (outbreaks #4 and #5) were within genotype 1 near BVDV Osloss. Immunohistochemical identification of BVDV in exudative dermatitis indicates the epithelial cell tropism of the virus. Phylogenic characterization of BVDV from outbreaks #2 and #3 locates them as BVDV-2. The 5-UTR sequence of these viruses showed 88% and 90% homology with BVDV-890 (genotype 2) and 77% and 75% with BVDV-SD1 (genotype 1), respectively. The association of BVDV-2 with severe disease indicates the presence of highly virulent strains. Data from natural outbreaks in which BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 were isolated showed that the pathology overlaps and does not allow unequivocal differentiation between genotypes based on gross or microscopic lesions. Therefore, further virological and molecular studies are necessary for a definitive diagnosis. Furthermore, the results of this work focused on the origin and consequences of genetic variations of BVDV in terms of pathogenesis and suggest the association between genotype and a defined clinical syndrome. © 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: OdeÃ³n, A. C.;Risatti, G.;Kaiser, G. G.;Leunda, M. R.;Odriozola, E.;Campero, C. M.;Donis, R. O.

title: African Swine Fever Virus Georgia 2007 with a deletion of the virulence-associated gene 9GL (B119L) results in viral attenuation in swine when administered at low doses and induces potent protection against homologous challenges
abstract: WITHOUT LABELING: The African swine fever virus (ASFV) is the causative agent of an often fatal disease in domestic pigs. Disease control strategies have been hampered by the unavailability of vaccines against ASFV. Since its introduction in the Republic of Georgia, a highly virulent virus, ASFV Georgia 2007 (ASFV-G), has caused an animal disease that quickly spread to Eastern European countries. No vaccines to combat ASFV-G are currently available or under development. In the past, genetically engineered ASFVs harboring deletions of virulence-associated genes have been shown in pigs to be attenuated, inducing protective immunity against challenge with homologous parental viruses. The deletion of the gene 9GL (open reading frame [ORF] B119L) in the highly virulent ASF Malawi-Lil-20/1 resulted in an attenuated phenotype even when pigs were administered 10(6) 50% doses of hemadsorption (HAD50). Here we report the construction of a genetically modified ASFV-G strain (ASFV-G-DELTA9GLv) containing a deletion of the 9GL (B119L) gene. Like Malawi-Lil-20/1-DELTA9GL, ASFV-G-DELTA9GL showed limited replication in primary porcine macrophages. However, intramuscular vaccination of pigs with 10(4) HAD50 of ASFV-G-DELTA9GL produced a virulent phenotype which, in contrast to Malawi-Lil-20/1-DELTA9GL, induced a fatal disease like the parental ASFV-G in pigs. Interestingly, lower doses (10(2) to 10(3) HAD50) of ASFV-G-DELTA9GL did not induce a virulent phenotype in pigs and protected pigs from the disease when challenged. A dose of 10(2) HAD50 of ASFV-G-DELTA9GLv conferred partial protection when pigs were challenged at either 21 or 28 days post-infection (dpi). An ASFV-G-DELTA9GL HAD50 of 10(3) provided partial and full protection at 21 and 28 dpi, respectively. The information provided here supplements our recent report on the first trials of experimental ASFV-G vaccines. IMPORTANT: The main problem in combating ASF is the lack of vaccines. Studies on ASFV virulence led to the production of genetically engineered attenuated viruses that are protective in pigs, but only against homologous virus challenges. Here we produced a recombinant ASFV lacking the virulence-associated gene 9GL in an attempt to produce a vaccine against the virulent ASFV-G, a highly virulent virus isolate discovered in the Caucasus region in 2007 and now spreading to the Caucasus region and Eastern Europe . Unlike other ASFV isolates, the 9GL deletion did not completely attenuate ASFV-G. However, when administered once at low doses, recombinant ASFV-G-DELTA9GL induces protection in pigs against parental ASFV-G. Protection against ASFV-G is highly effective at 28 days post-vaccination, while at 21 days post-vaccination the animals survived the lethal challenge but showed signs of ASF. Here we report the design and development of an experimental vaccine that induces protection against virulent ASFV-G.
authors: O'Donnell, V.;Holinka, L. G.;Krug, P. W.;Gladue, D. P.;Carlson, J.;Sanford, B.;Alfano, M.;Kramer, E.;Lu, Z.;Arzt, J.;Reese, B.;Carrillo, C.;Risatti, G. R.;Borca, M. V.

title: Isolation and characterization of orf viruses from Korean black goats
abstract: Between 2010 and 2011, five cases of orf virus infection in Korean black goats were diagnosed in our laboratory. An orf virus (ORF/2011) was isolated from an ovine testicular cell line (OA3.Ts) for use as a vaccine candidate. Sequences of the major coat protein and orf virus interferon resistance genes were determined and compared to published reference sequences. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that orfviruses from Korean black goats were most closely related to an isolate (ORF/09/Korea) from dairy goats in Korea. This result indicates that orfviruses may have been introduced into the Korean black goat population from dairy goats. Â© 2013 The Korean Veterinary Science Society.
authors: Oem, J. K.;Chung, J. Y.;Kim, Y. J.;Lee, K. K.;Kim, S. H.;Jung, B. Y.;Hyun, B. H.

title: Complete genome sequences of three rabies viruses isolated from rabid raccoon dogs and a cow in Korea
authors: Oem, J. K.;Kim, S. H.;Kim, Y. H.;Lee, M. H.;Lee, K. K.

title: Rabies resurgence in the southern Han River region, Korea
abstract: Recently, 11 cases of animal rabies were reported in the southern region (Cities of Suwon and Hwaseong) of Gyeonggi Province, South Korea. Cases were separated in time into two cases in dogs (Canis lupus familiaris) in spring 2012 and nine cases in domestic and wild animals in winter 2012-13. All cadavers were submitted for histopathological examination and viral antigen identification. Sequences of the glycoprotein, nucleoprotein and glycoprotein large polymerase protein intergenic non-coding loci of the 11 strains were determined and compared to published reference sequences. All the rabies strains were closely related to the Gangwon strains isolated in 2008-09, suggesting that the rabies virus strains isolated in Gyeonggi were introduced from Gangwon Province.
authors: Oem, J. K.;Kim, S. H.;Kim, Y. H.;Lee, M. H.;Lee, K. K.

title: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (BPSV) infections in native Korean cattle
abstract: In April 2012, an outbreak of a disease with parapox-like symptoms was reported in South Korea. Three out of 45 native Korean cattle aged 20 to 24 months were affected. Parapoxviruses have been detected and identified by electron microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). To determine the genetic characteristics of the Korean strains, the sequence of the major coat protein (B2L) was determined and compared to published reference sequences. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the parapoxvirus strains were closely related not only to isolates from Japan but also to isolates from Germany, Sudan and the United States. This is the first reported outbreak and molecular characterization of BPSV in Korea. Â© 2013 The Japanese Society for Veterinary Medicine.
authors: Oem, J. K.;Lee, E. Y.;Lee, K. K.;Kim, S. H.;Lee, M. H.;Hyun, B. H.

title: Novel kobuvirus species identified in black goat with diarrhea
authors: Oem, J. K.;Lee, M. H.;Lee, K. K.;An, D. J.

title: Foot-and-mouth disease in Asiatic black bears (Ursus thibetanus)
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is a highly contagious, debilitating, and globally important viral disease that typically affects hoof hosts. The diagnosis of foot-and-mouth disease in bears in Vietnam is described. The current study describes a confirmed case of foot-and-mouth disease in a bear species and clinical signs consistent with foot-and-mouth disease in a Malaysian sun bear. Apparently 13 Asiatic black bears (Ursus thibetanus) and 1 Malayan sun bear (Helarctos malayanus) were affected. In August 2011, an adult bear became lethargic and developed footpad blisters. Within 15 days, 14 out of 17 bears developed similar signs; the remaining 3 co-housed bears and another 57 resident bears did not. All affected bears developed blisters on all footpads and most were lethargic for 24-48 hours. Nasal and oral lesions were noted in 6 and 3 cases, respectively. Within 1 month everything looked normal. Foot and mouth disease virus (FMD) was detected by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction, classified as serotype O, and isolated by virus isolation procedures. Phylogenetic analysis showed an accumulation of 3 bear isolates in a branch distinct from other FMD type O isolates. The outbreak likely occurred through indirect contact with livestock and was favored by the high density of bear captures. It showed that Asiatic black bears are capable of contracting foot-and-mouth disease and developing clinical disease, and the virus spreads easily between bears in close contact.
authors: Officer, K.;Lan, N. T.;Wicker, L.;Hoa, N. T.;Weegenaar, A.;Robinson, J.;Ryoji, Y.;Loukopoulos, P.

title: Two new subfamilies of DNA mismatch repair proteins (MutS) that are particularly abundant in the marine environment
abstract: MutS proteins are ubiquitous in cellular organisms and play an important role in the repair or recombination of DNA mismatches. In the viral world, it is known that the amoeba-infecting Mimivirus, as well as the recently sequenced Cafeteria roenbergensis virus, encode a MutS related to the homologues found in octocorall and epsilon proteobacteria. To investigate the presence of MutS proteins in other viral genomes, we performed a genomic study of four giant viruses ("girus") (Pyramimonas orientalis virus (PoV), Phaeocystis pouchetii virus (PpV), Chrysochromulina ericina virus (CeV) and Heterocapsa circularisquama by DNA virus (HcDNAV)) infecting unicellular seaweed. Our analysis revealed the presence of a close homologue of mimivirus MutS in all giraffes analyzed. These viral homologues possess a specific domain structure, including a C-terminal HNH endonuclease domain, that defines the new MutS7 subfamily. We confirmed the presence of conserved mismatch recognition residues in all members of the MutS7 subfamily, suggesting their role in DNA mismatch repair rather than DNA recombination. PoV and PpV were found to contain an additional type of MutS, which we propose to be MutS8. The MutS8 proteins in PoV and PpV were found to be closely related to homologues of 'Candatus Amoebophilus asiaticus', an obligate intracellular amoeba symbiont belonging to the Bacteroidetes. Furthermore, our analysis revealed that MutS7 and MutS8 are abundant in marine microbial metagenomes and that a large majority of these environmental sequences are likely to be of Girus origin. Giruses therefore appear to represent a major source of the understudied diversity of the MutS family in the microbial world. The ISME Journal (2011) 5, 1143-1151; doi:10.1038/ismej.2010.210; Posted online January 20, 2011 Subject category: Evolutionary Genetics
authors: Ogata, H.;Ray, J.;Toyoda, K.;Sandaa, R. A.;Nagasaki, K.;Bratbak, G.;Claverie, J. M.

title: Remarkable sequence similarity between the dinoflagellate-infecting marine girus and the terrestrial African swine fever pathogen
abstract: Heterocapsa circularisquama DNA virus (HcDNAV; previously referred to as HcV) is a giant virus (girus) with a 356 kbp double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome. HcDNAV lytically infects the mussel-killing marine dinoflagellate H. circularisquama and is currently the only DNA virus isolated from dinoflagellates, one of the most abundant protists in marine ecosystems. Its morphological characteristics, genomic type, and host range previously suggested that HcDNAV might be a member of the Nucleo-Cytoplasmic Large DNA Viruses (NCLDVs) family Phycodnaviridae, although no supporting sequence data was available. NCLDVs currently include two families found in aquatic environments (Phycodnaviridae, Mimiviridae), one that mainly infects terrestrial animals (Poxviridae), another that is isolated from fish, amphibians and insects (Iridoviridae), and the last (Asfarviridae ), which is represented exclusively by the animal pathogen African swine fever virus (ASFV), the causative agent of a fatal hemorrhagic disease in domestic pigs. In this study, we determined the complete sequence of the HcDNAV type B DNA polymerase (PolB) gene. The viral PolB was transcribed at least 6 h after inoculation (hpi), indicating its critical role in viral replication. Most unexpectedly, the HcDNAV PolB sequence was found to be closely related to the ASFV PolB sequence. In addition, the amino acid sequence of HcDNAV PolB revealed a rare amino acid substitution within a motif containing a highly conserved motif: YSDTDS was found in HcDNAV PolB instead of YGDTDS in most dsDNA viruses. Together with the previous observation of ASFV-like sequences in the Sorcerer II Global Ocean Sampling metagenomic datasets, our results support the assumption that terrestrial ASFV has its evolutionary origin in marine environments. © 2009 Ogata et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Ogata, H.;Toyoda, K.;Tomaru, Y.;Nakayama, N.;Shirai, Y.;Claverie, J. M.;Nagasaki, K.

title: Complete genome and phylogenetic position of bovine papillomavirus type 7
abstract: Six bovine papillomavirus (BPV) types and 16 putative BPV types have been previously described. Here, the complete genome sequence of BAPV6, a novel putative BPV type isolated from cattle in Japan, was determined using multiple primed rolling circle amplification. The genome consisted of 7412 bp (G+C content of 46 mol%) encoding five early (E1, E2, E4, E6 and E7) and two late (L1 and L2) genes, but not the E5 gene encoded. The E6 protein contained a mismatched CxxC(x)33CxxC and a matched CxxC(x)29CxxC zinc binding domain, and the E7 protein lacked the LxCxE motif. The nucleotide sequence of the L1 open reading frame (ORF) was most closely (57-58%) related to the L1 ORF of members of the genera Betapapillomavirus, Gammapapillomavirus and Pipapillomavirus. A phylogenetic analysis based on the full L1 ORF suggests that BAPV6 should be classified as BPV-7 in a new genus in the Papillomaviridae family. © 2007 SGM.
authors: Ogawa, T.;Tomita, Y.;Okada, M.;Shirasawa, H.

title: The human intestinal virus: a multifaceted majority
authors: Ogilvie, L. A.;Jones, B. V.

title: The human gut virus: form and function
authors: Ogilvie, L. A.;Jones, B. V.

title: Isolation of Maedi/Visna virus from a sheep in Japan
abstract: Maedi/Visna (MV) is a lentiviral disease in sheep caused by Maedi/Visna virus (MVV). Although MV is widespread in many countries, it has not been reported in Japan. However, in 2011, three sheep in northern Japan were reported as seropositive to the MVV antigen, indicating persistent MVV infection. In the present study, we isolated MVV from a sheep to confirm MVV infection and performed genomic classification of the virus. Co-culture of leukocytes from a seropositive sheep with fetal goat lung cells resulted in the formation of syncytial cells and the amplification of a long terminal repeat of MVV by polymerase chain reaction. Based on a phylogenetic analysis of the gag gene sequence, the isolate was confirmed to be MVV and not caprine arthritis encephalitis virus. Although the sheep was asymptomatic, nonsuppurative meningitis and demyelination were found in the spinal cord. These were considered to be early lesions associated with pathogenic MVV infection. Therefore, the present study showed that MVV is distributed in Japan. Â© 2014 The Japanese Society for Veterinary Medicine.
authors: Oguma, K.;Tanaka, C.;Harasawa, R.;Kimura, A.;Sasaki, J.;Goryo, M.;Sentsui, H.

title: Evidence of an antigenic shift between orbiviruses of the palyam serogroup
abstract: The Japanese isolates of viruses of the palyam serogroup isolated from 1985 to 2001 were examined for the genome sequence of segments 2 and 7 and analyzed phylogenetically in comparison to Australian and African isolates of the same serogroup. Segment 7 nucleotide sequences were highly conserved within Japanese isolates (95.1 to 100%) and between Japanese and Taiwanese isolates (96.0 to 100%), while identities were fairly conserved between Japanese and Taiwanese isolates and Australian and African isolates (84.2 to 100%). 92.0%). Phylogenetic analysis based on segment 7 revealed three clusters by geographic origin. As a result of nucleotide sequence analysis of segment 2 encoding a serotype-specific antigen, Japanese isolates were divided into two groups according to genome length and nucleotide identity. Four of the nine Japanese isolates were placed in the same group as Chuzan virus prototype strain K-47, and the remaining isolates were placed in the same group as D'Aguilar virus and Nyabira virus. Phylogenetic analysis based on segment 2 revealed two clusters, the cluster with Chuzan virus and the cluster with D'Aguilar and Nyabira viruses. To examine the antigenic relationship between viruses classified into different clusters, we performed a cross-neutralization assay. KSB-29/E/01 isolated in Japan in 2001 was neutralized by antiserum not only against D'Aguilar virus strain B8112 but also against Chuzan virus. These results indicated that the genetically and antigenically unique properties of KSB-29/E/01 were attributed to a segment 2 genetic rearrangement between Chuzan virus and D'Aguilar virus.
authors: Ohashi, S.;Matsumori, Y.;Yanase, T.;Yamakawa, M.;Kato, T.;Tsuda, T.

title: Sequence analysis of an Asian isolate of canine minutevirus (canine parvovirus type 1)
abstract: Minute virus of canines (MVC), also known as canine parvovirus (CPV) type 1, is an autonomous parvovirus that infects domestic dogs worldwide and is responsible for clinical problems in newborns and pregnant bitches. It has been tentatively described that MVC differs both antigenically and genetically from the later developed type 2 CPV. However, much of MVC is still unclear as only a limited number of MVC isolates were available for study. MVC infections in Japanese and Korean dogs were epidemiologically investigated in the previous study, and several MVC isolates could be cultured in vitro. In the present study, an almost complete nucleotide sequence of a Korean MVC strain HM-6 was obtained and analyzed in comparison to that of the recently characterized American MVC strain GA3. The genome structure of the HM-6 strain was similar to that of the GA3 strain, showing 96.4% identity in nucleotide sequence. Each of the deduced amino acid sequences of NS1, NP-1 and VP1/2 showed 96.5%, 92.5% and 97.5% homology between strains HM-6 and GA3. Compared to other parvovirus species, the HM-6 strain was most closely related to bovine parvovirus (BPV) as described for the GA3 strain. These results suggest that MVC may be placed in a new clade in the Parvovirinae subfamily along with BPV. © 2004 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
authors: Ohshima, T.;Kishi, M.;Mochizuki, M.

title: First isolation and genetic characterization of bovine pseudocowpoxvirus in Japan
abstract: Background: Pseudocowpox virus (PCPV) infects cattle worldwide with zoonotic potential but has not been isolated in Japan. Therefore, the epidemiological status of PCPV infection in cattle is undetermined. Results: In May 2016, a cow in a farm in Yamaguchi Prefecture presented with white vesicles and hyperemia in the mucosa under the surface of the tongue, but not on the teats and coronary pads. A parapoxvirus was isolated from the oral lesion swab and genetically characterized based on the complete sequence of the B2L gene encoding the viral envelope. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the isolated virus was classified as PCPV. Conclusion: This case indicates its potential spread in Japan. This is the first report of isolation of PCPV in Japan.
authors: Ohtani, A.;Yokoyama, A.;Narushige, H.;Inoshima, Y.

title: Genetic characterization and classification of human and animal sapoviruses
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaVs) are enteric caliciviruses that have been identified in several mammalian species including humans, pigs, mink, dogs, sea lions, chimpanzees and rats. They show a high diversity. A SaV genome typically encodes seven nonstructural proteins (NSs), including the RNA polymerase protein NS7, and two structural proteins (VP1 and VP2). We classified human and animal SaVs into 15 genogroups (G) based on available VP1 sequences, including three newly characterized genomes from this study. We sequenced the full-length genomes of a novel genogroup V (GV) porcine SaV, a GVII, and a GVIII using long-range RT-PCR, including newly designed forward primers located in the conserved motifs of the putative NS3, and also 5-RACE methods. We also determined the 5″ and 3″ ends of sea lion GV-SaV and canine GXIII-SaV. Although the full genomic sequences of GIX-GXII and GXV-SaVs are not available, common features of the SaV genomes include: 1) "GTG" at the 5' end of the genome and a short (9-14 nt) 5-inch ²-untranslated area; and 2) the first five amino acids (M[A/V]S[K/R]P) of the putative NS1 and the five amino acids (FEMEG) surrounding the putative cleavage site between NS7 and VP1 were conserved in the chimpanzee, two from five genogroups from pigs (GV and GVIII), sea lions, dogs and human SaVs. In contrast, these two amino acid motifs were markedly different in three genosets of porcine (GIII, GVI, and GVII) and bat SaVs. Our results indicate that several animal SaVs share genetic similarities with human SaVs. However, the ability of SaVs to be transmitted between humans and animals is uncertain.
authors: Oka, T.;Lu, Z.;Phan, T.;Delwart, E. L.;Saif, L. J.;Wang, Q.

title: Bovine rotavirus G and P types and sequence analysis of the VP7 gene of two G8 bovine rotaviruses from JPN
abstract: From 1987 to 2000, a total of 1481 fecal samples were collected from diarrhea calves under 1 month old from 29 dairy and cattle farms in 11 prefectures in Japan. These calves and their dams were not vaccinated against rotavirus. One hundred forty-two bovine rotaviruses were isolated on MA-104 cell cultures and detected by a latex agglutination test. They were divided into 18 G6P[1] (11.2%), 53 G6P[5] (37.3%), 15 G6P[11] (10.6%), 12 G10P[5] (8.5%) , 42 G10P[11] (29.6%) and 1 G8P[11] (0.7%) by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. A G8 serotype virus was not typable for the P genotype, indicating a new type of bovine origin. The least common G8 serotype viruses were isolated from samples from farms in Niigata and Tokushima prefectures. The VP7 gene sequences of the two isolates showed a high degree of homology as previously reported G8 viruses with 93.3-98.8% identity of the deduced amino acids. A phylogenetic analysis of the VP7 gene of the two G8 viruses and 13 previously reported G8 viruses by neighbor joining method showed that the two newly isolated G8 rotaviruses shared a common origin and they were assigned to a new unequal cluster. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Okada, N.;Matsumoto, Y.

title: Isolation and characterization of a new type of rotavirus species A in sugar gliders (Petaurus breviceps)
abstract: To assess the risk of interspecies transmission of rotavirus type A (RVA) from exotic domestic animals to other mammalian species, the prevalence of RVA in sugar gliders (Petaurus breviceps) was investigated. RVAs were detected in 10 of 44 sugar gliders by reverse transcription (RT)-seminested PCR. These viruses have been classified as G27P[3] and G27P[36] genotypes, with G27 and P[36] being new genotypes assigned by the Rotavirus Classification Working Group. To characterize Sugar Glider RVA in detail, a strain, RVA/SugarGlider-tc/JPN/SG385/2012/G27P[36] (SG385-tc), was isolated. All genes of the strain were classified as new genotypes (G27-P[36]-I19-R10-C10-M9-A20-N11-T13-E17-H12). The enterotoxin domain in NSP4, which is important for diarrhea induction, was conserved between SG385-tc and previously described mammalian strains, suggesting the potential of sugar glider RVA to cause diarrhea in mammalian species. Indeed, seven out of nine lactating mice orally vaccinated with 3.9 x 10(4) ffu of SG385-tc strain had diarrhea, and the 50% diarrhea-inducing dose (DD50) of SG385-tc strain in lactating mice was 1.2 x 10( 4) ffu Our results suggest that Sugar Glider RVA is infectious and possibly pathogenic to other mammalian species.
authors: Okadera, K.;Abe, M.;Ito, N.;Mitake, H.;Okada, K.;Nakagawa, K.;Une, Y.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Sugiyama, M.

title: The genetic and antigenic diversity of avian influenza viruses isolated from domestic ducks, musk ducks and chickens in North and South Vietnam, 2010-2012
abstract: To estimate the prevalence of avian influenza virus infection in Vietnam, domestic and wild birds from households, live bird markets, slaughterhouses and bird sanctuaries in Vietnam were monitored between October 2010 and October 2012. Of the 4,550 samples collected, 226 influenza A virus isolates were obtained from domestic ducks, musk ducks and chickens. Of these, 25 and 22 highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses (HPAIVs) were isolated from apparently healthy domestic ducks at live bird markets and slaughterhouses in North and South Vietnam, respectively. The HA genes of H5 viruses isolated from birds in North Vietnam belonged phylogenetically to genetic class 2.3.2.1 and those in South Vietnam belonged to genetic class 1.1. In addition, 39 H3, 12 H4, 1 H5, 93 H6, 2 H7, 18 H9, 3 H10 and 11 H11 viruses were isolated. Phylogenetic and antigenic analyzes of the H6 and H9 viruses revealed that they are closely related to the isolates obtained from domestic poultry in China. Phylogenetic analysis of internal gene segments from these isolates revealed that these viruses circulated in both domestic and wild birds in Asia and that rearrangements had occurred frequently. Therefore, it is important to continue surveillance and strict controls on the movement and trade of poultry and poultry products to eradicate H5N1 HPAIV from Asia. © 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Okamatsu, M.;Nishi, T.;Nomura, N.;Yamamoto, N.;Sakoda, Y.;Sakurai, K.;Chu, H. D.;Thanh, L. P.;Van Nguyen, L.;Van Hoang, N.;Tien, T. N.;Yoshida, R.;Takada, A.;Kida, H.

title: Characterization of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza Virus A(H5N6), Japan, November 2016
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIVs) A(H5N6) were introduced simultaneously to several remote regions of Japan in November 2016. These viruses have been placed in genetic clade 2.3.4.4c and were genetically closely related to H5N6 HPAIVs recently isolated in South Korea and China. In addition, these HPAIVs showed further antigenic drift.
authors: Okamatsu, M.;Ozawa, M.;Soda, K.;Takakuwa, H.;Haga, A.;Hiono, T.;Matsuu, A.;Uchida, Y.;Iwata, R.;Matsuno, K.;Kuwahara, M.;Yabuta, T.;Usui, T.;Ito, H.;Onuma, M.;Sakoda, Y.;Saito, T.;Otsuki, K.;Ito, T.;Kida, H.

title: Genetic variability and evolution of hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is the only member of the genus Hepevirus in the family Hepeviridae. HEV is mainly transmitted via the faecal-oral route, and waterborne epidemics are characteristic of hepatitis E in many developing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America where sanitary conditions are suboptimal. Evidence is accumulating that HEV-associated hepatitis also occurs domestically in individuals in industrialized countries, that there are animal reservoirs of HEV such as domestic and wild pigs, and that hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease. Based on the extensive genomic variability among HEV isolates, HEV sequences have been classified into four genotypes: genotype 1 consists of epidemic strains in developing countries in Asia and Africa; Genotype 2 has been described in Mexico and several African countries; Genotype 3 HEV is widespread and has been isolated from sporadic cases of acute hepatitis E and/or domestic pigs in many countries around the world, with the exception of countries in Africa; and genotype 4 contains strains isolated from humans and/or domestic pigs exclusively in Asian countries. This paper provides an overview of the current knowledge on the genomic variability, geographic distribution and zoonotic aspects of HEV, as well as on the clinical significance of HEV genotype and evolution. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Okamoto, H.

title: Characteristics of hepatitis E virus infection in Japan
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a major cause of acute hepatitis in many developing countries. HEV is transmitted primarily by the faecal-oral route, and waterborne epidemics are characteristic of hepatitis E. Recently, there is increasing consensus that HEV-associated hepatitis also occurs in individuals in developed countries who have had no prior travel to endemic areas . A zoonotic spread of HEV was suspected since human and porcine HEV strains are genetically closely related and experimental cross-species infection of porcine HEV to a chimpanzee and that of human HEV to pig has been demonstrated. This review describes the clinical, epidemiological and virological features of domestic HEV infection in Japan, the genetic relationship of Japanese human and swine HEV strains and possible transmission routes of HEV, emphasizing that HEV is considered in the diagnosis of acute or fulminant hepatitis should be non-A, non-B, non-C etiology even in patients who have not traveled abroad.
authors: Okamoto, H.;Takahashi, M.;Nishizawa, T.

title: Characterization of sporadic acute hepatitis E and comparison of hepatitis E virus genomes in patients with acute hepatitis and edible pork liver in Mie, Japan
abstract: Aim: To characterize hepatitis E in Mie Prefecture and to investigate whether raw pork liver sold as food in Mie is contaminated with hepatitis E virus (HEV) strains similar to those obtained from patients. METHODS: Seventeen patients with sporadic acute hepatitis E treated from 2004 to 2012 were studied. A total of 243 packages of raw pork liver from local grocery stores were tested for the presence of HEV RNA. The partial genomic sequences of human and porcine HEV isolates were determined and subjected to phylogenetic analyses. Results: The HEV isolates obtained from the 17 patients were separated into genotype 3 (n=15) and genotype 4 (n=2), and 15 genotype 3 isolates were further separated into 3e (n=11) and 3b (n=4) separately. Pig liver samples from 12 (4.9%) of the 243 packs had detectable HEV RNA. All 12 porcine HEV isolates were grouped into genotype 3 (3a or 3b). Although no 3e strains were isolated from porcine liver samples, two porcine 3b strains were 99.5-100% identical within 412 nt partial sequences to two HEV strains obtained from hepatitis patients. Conclusion: 3e-HEV was widespread in hepatitis E patients. HEV RNA has been detected in approximately 5% of pork liver sold as food. The presence of identical HEV strains between hepatitis patients and pig liver indicated that pigs play an important role as a reservoir for HEV in humans in Mie. Further studies are needed to clarify the source of 3e-HEV in animal and environmental reservoirs.
authors: Okano, H.;Takahashi, M.;Isono, Y.;Tanaka, H.;Nakano, T.;Oya, Y.;Sugimoto, K.;Ito, K.;Ohmori, S.;Maegawa, T.;Kobayashi, M.;Nagashima, S.;Nishizawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Application of antisense molecules in poultry production
abstract: Antisense molecules, which are single-stranded nucleic acids complementary to a specific mRNA, target and bind to the mRNA, interfering with and preventing translation of mRNA encoding a specific protein. Recently, phosphorothioate antisense oligodeoxynucleotides, originally developed as nuclease-resistant alternatives to phosphodiester oligomers, and protein nucleic acids have been used to prevent antisense molecules from nucleases. The delivery system for antisense molecules is basically the same as the DNA delivery system. Traditionally, DNA delivery systems have been classified as viral vector-mediated systems and non-viral vector-mediated systems. Because the importance of current methodology is attributed to the limitation of viral vector-mediated delivery, non-viral vector-mediated systems, particularly synthetic DNA delivery systems, have become increasingly desirable. The possibility of using antisense protein nucleic acids against leptin mRNA was discussed to stimulate the appetite of poultry. Antisense phosphorothioate oligodeoxynucleotide against insulin-like growth factor-binding protein-2 mRNA successfully repressed its hepatic gene expression in chicken. Protein synthesis of chick embryo myoblasts was decreased by administration of antisense phosphorothioate oligodeoxynucleotide against myostatin mRNA, indicating the reduction of protein degradation by antisense administration.
authors: Okumura, J.;Kita, K.

title: Distribution of gene segments of the 2009 pandemic virus line A(H1N1) in swine populations
abstract: Swine influenza viruses (SIVs) are not only important for pig farming, but also for public health. Indeed, the 2009 A(H1N1) pandemic viruses [A(H1N1)pdm09] were derived from SIVs. Therefore, timely characterization of locally circulating SIVs is necessary to understand the global status of SIVs. To genetically characterize SIVs circulating in Japanese pig populations, we isolated 24 SIVs of three subtypes (17 H1N1, four H1N2, and three H3N2 strains) from 14 pig farms in Japan from 2013 to 2016. Genetic analyzes revealed that hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes from 17 H1N1 and the HA gene from one H1N2, A/swine/Aichi/02/2016 (H1N2), SIVs belonged to the A(H1N1)pdm09- Line. More importantly, all remaining six gene segments (i.e., PB1, PB1, PA, NP, M, and NS) of the 24 SIVs, regardless of HA and NA subtype, were also classified as belonging to A(H1N1)pdm09 ancestry. These results demonstrate that gene segments from the A(H1N1)pdm09 lineage are widely distributed in SIVs circulating in Japanese pig populations. In addition, the NA gene of A/swine/Aichi/02/2016 (H1N2) shared less than 88.5% nucleotide identity with that of the closest relative A/swine/Miyagi/5/2003 (H1N2), which isolates in Japan in 2003 became. These results indicate the continued circulation of classic H1N2-derived SIVs with remarkable NA gene diversity in Japanese pig populations. These results underscore the need for both intensive biosecurity systems and active SIV surveillance in swine populations worldwide for animal and public health.
authors: Okuya, K.;Matsuu, A.;Kawabata, T.;Koike, F.;Ito, M.;Furuya, T.;Taneno, A.;Akimoto, S.;Deguchi, E.;Ozawa, M.

title: Molecular characterization of canine kobuvirus in wild carnivores and domestic dogs in Africa
abstract: Knowledge of kobuvirus (family Picornaviridae) infection in carnivores is limited and has not been described in domestic or wild carnivores in Africa. To fill this knowledge gap, we used RT-PCR to examine fresh feces from several African carnivores. We have detected kobuvirus RNA in samples from domestic dogs, golden jackals, side-striped jackals, and spotted hyenas. Using next-generation sequencing, we obtained a complete kobuvirus genomic sequence from each of these species. Our phylogenetic analyzes revealed canine kobuvirus (CaKV) infection in all four species and placed CaKVs from Africa together and separately from CaKVs from other countries. Wild carnivore tribes were more closely related to each other than to those of domestic dogs. We found that the secondary structure model of the IRES of the Aichivirus-like IRES subclass was similar and conserved among African strains. We describe the first CaKVs from Africa and extend the known CaKV host range.
authors: Olarte-Castillo, X. A.;Heeger, F.;Mazzoni, C. J.;Greenwood, A. D.;Fyumagwa, R.;Moehlman, P. D.;Hofer, H.;East, M. L.

title: Characterization of infectious US laryngotracheitis virus isolates by polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment length polymorphism of multiple genomic regions
abstract: Infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT) is an acute viral respiratory disease primarily in chickens. Economic losses attributable to ILT are affecting many poultry producing areas in the United States (USA) and around the world. Despite efforts to control the disease through vaccination, ongoing ILT epidemics remain a threat to the poultry industry. Previous epidemiological and molecular evidence suggested that outbreaks in the US are caused by vaccine-related strains. In this study, polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) of four genomic regions were used to characterize 25 isolates from commercial poultry and backyard flocks from the US. Combinations of PCR-RFLP patterns classified the ILT virus isolates into nine groups. Backyard herd isolates were divided into three separate groups. The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) ILT virus reference strain and tissue culture derived (TCO) vaccine strain were divided into two separate groups. Twenty-two isolates from commercial poultry were divided into four groups: one group of six isolates showed patterns identical to the chick embryo (CEO) vaccines; a second group of nine isolates differed from the CEO vaccines in only one pattern; a third group consisting of two isolates differed from the TCO vaccine in only one pattern; a fourth group consisting of five isolates differed in six and nine patterns from the CEO and TCO vaccines, respectively. The results obtained from this study clearly showed that most commercial poultry isolates (17 out of 22 isolates) were closely related to the vaccine strains. However, isolates other than the vaccine strains have also been identified in commercial poultry. © 2007 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Oldoni, I.;GarcÃ­a, M.

title: Epidemiological study in flocks of single species from Poland shows extended genetic and antigenic diversity of small ruminant lentiviruses
abstract: Small ruminant lentiviruses (SRLV) are widespread in Poland and circulating subtypes A1, A12, A13, B1 and B2 have been identified. The present work aimed to extend previous studies based on the analysis of larger numbers of animals from single-species herds. Animals were selected for genetic analysis based on serological reactivity to a panel of recombinant antigens derived from viral Gag and Env proteins. Phylogenetic analysis revealed the existence of subtypes B2 and A12 in both goats and sheep, and subtypes A1 and B1 only in goats. In addition, two new subtypes, A16 and A17, were found in goats. Coinfections with strains of different subtypes within the A and B groups were detected in 1 sheep and 4 goats from four flocks. Although the reactivity of serum samples towards the recombinant antigens confirmed the immunological relatedness between Gag epitopes of different subtypes and the cross-reactive nature of Gag antibodies, eleven serum samples did not react with antigens representing all subtypes detected in Poland to date, which is worth emphasizing The borders of serological diagnostics. These data demonstrated the complex nature of the SRLV subtypes circulating in sheep and goats in Poland and the need to improve SRLV-related diagnostic capacities.
authors: Olech, M.;Valas, S.;KuÅºmak, J.

title: Porcine B cells recognize epitopes conserved between the structural proteins of American and European-type porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses
abstract: By selecting phage display libraries with immune sera from experimentally infected pigs, porcine B cell epitopes in the open reading frame (ORF) 2, 3, 5 and 6 proteins of the European type of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) were identified . The sequences of all epitopes were well conserved in European-type PRRSV and even between European- and American-type PRRSV. Accordingly, sera from pigs infected with American-type PRRSV cross-reacted with the European-type epitopes. Thus, this study demonstrated for the first time the presence of highly conserved epitopes in the matrix protein and envelope glycoproteins of PRRSV. ORF5 and 6 epitopes localized to protein portions predicted to be latent in PRRSV virions. In contrast, ORF2 and 3 epitopes localized to putative protein ectodomains. Due to the interesting localization, the sequence around the epitopes ORF2 and 3 was examined in more detail. A heptad motif, VSRRIYQ, present in a single copy in ORF2 and 3 proteins has been identified; this arrangement is fully conserved in all available European-type PRRSV sequences. The VSRRIYQ repeat motif closely colocalizes with one of the ORF2 epitopes, and secondary structure modeling indicated that this segment of the ORF2 protein could form an amphipathic helix. Interestingly, a mutation associated with the virulence/attenuation of an American vaccine strain of PRRSV also localized this ORF2 protein segment and affected the hydrophobic face of the predicted amphipathic helix. Further work is needed to determine whether these findings delineate a functional domain in the ORF2 protein of PRRSV.
authors: Oleksiewicz, M. B.;BÃ¸tner, A.;Normann, P.

title: Determination of the sequence of the complete open reading frame and the 5'NTR of the Paderborn isolate of the classical swine fever virus
abstract: The classical swine fever (CSF) epidemic in the Netherlands lasted 14 months in 1997-1998, killing 429 infected and 1300 vulnerable herds at an estimated economic cost of US$2 billion. Despite the overwhelming scale of the animal disease, the strain of CSF virus (CSFV) that caused the outbreak has remained largely uncharacterized. The Dutch animal disease is epidemiologically linked to a small outbreak of CSF in 1997 in Paderborn, Germany. E2 and partial 5-NTR sequencing has shown that the Index Paderborn isolate and several Dutch isolates taken during the 1997-1998 epizootic are virtually identical, confirming that the Paderborn isolate caused the Dutch outbreak and moreover shows that this single isolate was stable throughout the Dutch outbreak (the above reviewed in [C. Terpstra, AJ de Smit, Veterinary Microbiol. 77 (2000) 3-15]). We determined the nucleotide sequence of the 5'NTR (by 5'RACE) and the complete open reading frame of the Paderborn isolate (GenBank AY072924). Our sequence was identical to previously published partial 5-NTR and E2 sequences for Index isolates Paderborn 1997 and Dutch 1997 (Venhorst), confirming the identity of the virus we sequenced. Phylogenetic analyzes based on the full open reading frame showed that Paderborn is genetically very different from common European laboratory reference strains. Neutralization studies showed that Paderborn is also antigenically very different from common laboratory strains such as Alfort 187. Paderborn is the only recent European CSFV field isolate for which a complete sequence is available, and given Paderborn's genetic and antigenic uniqueness, the Paderborn sequence may be of practical use for the development of diagnostic and vaccine antigens. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Oleksiewicz, M. B.;Rasmussen, T. B.;Normann, P.;Uttenthal, Ã…

title: Screening for viral foreign matter in live attenuated avian vaccines using microbial microarray and sequencing
abstract: The absence of Extraneous Substances (EA) in the raw materials and finished products used for manufacturing is one of the most important safety elements related to all medicinal products of biological origin, such as e.g. B. live attenuated vaccines. The aim of this study was to investigate the applicability of the Lawrence Livermore Microbial Detection Array Version 2 (LLMDAv2) in combination with whole genome amplification and sequencing for screening for viral EAs in live attenuated vaccines and specific pathogen-free (SPF) eggs. We detected positive microarray signals for the avian endogenous retrovirus EAV-HP and several viruses of the genus Alpharetrovirus in all vaccines and SPF eggs analyzed. We used a microarray probe mapping approach to assess the presence of intact retroviral genomes which, in addition to PCR analysis, revealed that several of the positive microarray signals were most likely due to cross-hybridization with EAV-HPDELTApol and ALV-E ev1, ev3 and were due to ev6 loci sequences derived from the chicken genome. Sequencing of the vaccines on a MiSeq instrument confirmed the microarray results and showed similar cross-hybridization. Our results suggest that genomic microarrays and sequencing of attenuated avian vaccines can be used in assays for EA.
authors: Olesen, M. L.;Jorgensen, L. L.;Blixenkrone-Moller, M.;Sandberg, E.;Frandsen, P. L.;Ostergaard, E.;Baekdahl, E. R.;Fridholm, H.;Fomsgaard, A.;Rosenstierne, M. W.

title: Genetic variability of HEV isolates: inconsistencies of the current classification
abstract: Many HEV and HEV-like sequences, including isolates, have been reported in recent years, potentially representing a number of potential new genera, new genotypes, or new subtypes within the Hepeviridae family. Difficulties in establishing subtypes have been reported using the most common classification system. In addition, the importance of subtype classification for epidemiology can be questioned. In this study, we performed phylogenetic analyzes based on the entire capsid gene and complete HEV genomic sequences to assess the current classification of HEV at the genotype and subtype level. The results of our analyzes modify the current genotype 3 taxonomy and refine the established system for typing HEV. In addition, we propose a classification for hepeviruses recently isolated from bats, ferrets, rats, and wild boar. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Oliveira-Filho, E. F.;KÃ¶nig, M.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Virological and serological surveillance for human, swine, and avian influenza virus infection in pigs in the northern and central United States
abstract: Influenza virus infection in swine is both an animal health problem and a public health problem. Therefore, the surveillance and characterization of porcine influenza viruses is important to the veterinary community and should be part of human pandemic preparedness planning. Studies in 1976/1977 and 1988/1989 showed that pigs in the US were commonly infected with classic swine H1N1 viruses, while human H3 and avian influenza virus infections were very rare. In contrast, human H3 and avian H1 viruses have been frequently isolated from pigs in Europe and Asia over the past two decades. From September 1997 to August 1998, we isolated 26 influenza viruses from swine in the north-central United States at the point of slaughter. All 26 isolates were H1N1 viruses, and phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin and nucleoprotein genes of 11 representative viruses indicated that they were classic porcine H1 viruses. However, monoclonal antibody analyzes revealed antigenic heterogeneity between the HA proteins of the 26 viruses. Serologically, 27.7% of 2,375 pigs tested had anti-haemagglutination antibodies to classical swine H1 influenza virus. Of particular importance, however, the seropositivity rates for avian H1 (7.6%) and human H3 viruses (8.0%) were significantly higher than in previous studies.
authors: Olsen, C. W.;Carey, S.;Hinshaw, L.;Karasin, A. I.

title: Characterization of a porcine reassortant H1N2 influenza virus isolated from a wild duck in the United States
abstract: An H1N2 influenza virus (A/Duck/North Carolina/91347/01) (Dk/NC) was isolated in 2001 from a wild duck in the United States. Genetic analyzes showed that this duck virus has the same human/classical swine/avian reassortant genotype as the H1N2 viruses isolated from swine and turkeys in the United States since 1999. Phylogenetic analysis of each gene segment further confirmed that Dk/NC virus is closely related to domestic H1N2 isolates. In particular, Dk/NC is most closely related to a porcine H1N2 virus also isolated in North Carolina. These two viruses and a phylogenetically defined subset of other porcine H1N2 viruses share a common mutation in the Sb antigenic site of the hemagglutinin protein. The recovery of Dk/NC from a wild bird raises concerns about further widespread dissemination of these H1N2 viruses via waterfowl migration. © 2003 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Olsen, C. W.;Karasin, A.;Erickson, G.

title: Genetic changes in pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 induced by serial passage in chickens and microscopic lesions induced by the virus in different avian hosts
abstract: Introduction: Genotype VI of avian avulavirus 1 (AAvV-1) has pigeons as a reservoir and is often referred to as pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1).
