The pathogenesis of PPMV-1 infection in poultry is largely unclear. It is known that PPMV-1 requires a series of passages in chickens before being adapted to broilers. Material and methods: Alterations in the genome of PPMV-1 were analyzed after serial passages in specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens using high-throughput sequencing. In addition, histopathological lesions induced by PPMV-1 in experimentally vaccinated pigeons, chickens and turkeys were evaluated. Results: After six passages of PPMV-1 in chickens, 10 non-synonymous substitutions were found, including one (in the NP protein) that dominated the viral quasi-species genetic pool. Histopathological changes induced by the post-passaged PPMV-1 strain were more prominent than the changes induced by the pre-passaged PPMV-1 strain, and the lesions were most intense in pigeons, followed by chickens and turkeys. Conclusion: PPMV-1 is highly adapted to pigeons, and passage through chickens leads to the acquisition of new amino acids in the polymerase complex that may alter the virus' pathogenic potential.
authors: Olszewska-Tomczyk, M.;Dolka, I.;ÅšwiÈ©toÅ„, E.;Åšmietanka, K.

title: Occurrence and phylogenetic studies of chicken anemia virus from Polish broiler flocks
abstract: Chicken anemia virus (CAV) is a widespread chicken pathogen of significant economic importance. In 2013, broiler flocks in Poland were examined for the presence of CAV and a phylogenetic relationship between the strains was found. Ten cloacal swabs from each of 106 broiler flocks (birds aged 3-6 weeks) were collected in different regions of the country and tested using real-time PCR (all samples) and conventional PCR (the samples were positive in real-time PCR)- assays. The presence of CAV was detected in 16 of the herds tested. The phylogenetic analysis clearly confirmed the existence of genetic diversity within the group of circulating CAV strains and their differentiation from the vaccine strains used in Poland.
authors: Olszewska-Tomczyk, M.;ÅšwiÄ™toÅ„, E.;Minta, Z.;Åšmietanka, K.

title: Application of phylogenetic analysis to livestock viral diseases: Beyond molecular typing
abstract: Changes in animal husbandry systems in recent years have altered the appearance of many diseases, leading to the need for more sophisticated control measures. At the same time, new molecular assays have been developed to aid in the diagnosis of viral diseases in animals. Nucleotide sequences generated by these diagnostic techniques can be used in phylogenetic analysis to infer phenotypes through sequence homology and to conduct molecular epidemiological studies. In this overview, some key elements of phylogenetic analysis are highlighted, such as choosing the appropriate neutral phylogenetic marker, the right phylogenetic method, and various techniques to test the reliability of the resulting tree. Examples of current and future applications of phylogenetic reconstructions in livestock viral diseases are given. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Olvera, A.;Busquets, N.;Cortey, M.;Deus, N. d;Ganges, L.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.;Peralta, B.;Toskano, J.;Dolz, R.

title: Detection of the enterovirus genome sequence from goat diarrheal faeces
abstract: Diarrheal faeces from goats were subjected to metagenomic analysis by next-generation sequencing. Nucleotide sequences with homology to enteroviruses were obtained. Primers for RT-PCR were designed based on the nucleotide sequence of these sequences in the 5'' untranslated region, and we determined 563 bp nucleotide sequences that showed homology to bovine-like and ovine enteroviruses (77-87%). We have named the virus detected in this study goat enterovirus G1 (GEV-G1). In the phylogenetic analysis, GEV-G1 belonged to a cluster containing ovine enteroviruses. To our knowledge, this is the first report of nucleotide sequences of an enterovirus infecting Japanese goats. © Springer Science+Business Media 2014.
authors: Omatsu, T.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Hirata, T.;Shiroma, Y.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishiura, N.;Sassa, Y.;Furuya, T.;Nagai, M.;Ochiai, H.;Tamaki, S.;Mizutani, T.

title: Influenza A Virus: Phylogeny of Neuraminidase Primers and Amplification of Polymerase Basic Protein 2 and Neuraminidase Genes
authors: Omega, M.;Lai, R.;Hein, H.

title: Massively parallel sequencing: a new tool in virus discovery and vaccine safety
abstract: The advent of new sequencing technologies is revolutionizing virus discovery and providing a new means to demonstrate vaccine safety. Because these methods do not depend on prior assumptions about the types of virus that may be present, they have detected viruses that other methods such as degenerate or family-specific PCRs have missed. We used Massively Parallel Sequencing (MP-Seq) to detect novel viruses in bovine serum and animal faeces. When applied to transcriptome sequencing, MP-Seq can reveal latent or silent infections. While sequencing technology is impressive, bioinformatics is key to its successful application.
authors: Onions, D.

title: Ensuring the safety of seed cell substrates through massively parallel transcriptome sequencing
abstract: Massively parallel deep transcriptome sequencing coupled with algorithmic analysis for random drug identification (MP-SeqTM) is an important complement to ensure the safety of cells used in vaccine production. Such cells can harbor new viruses whose sequences are unknown or latent viruses that are expressed only after the cells have been stressed. MP-Seq is an unbiased and comprehensive method for identifying such viruses and other adventitious pathogens without prior knowledge of the nature of these pathogens. Here we demonstrate its utility as part of an integrated approach to identify and characterize potential contaminants in commonly used virus and vaccine production cell lines. Through this analysis, combined with more traditional approaches, we excluded the presence of porcine circoviruses in the ATCC-Vero cell bank (CCL-81), however, we found that a full-length beta retrovirus related to SRV was present in these cells can be expressed. a factor that may be important in the manufacture of certain vaccines. Similarly, insect cells are proving valuable for the production of virus-like particles and subunit vaccines, but they can harbor a range of latent viruses. We show that after MP-Seq of the Trichoplusia ni transcriptome (High Five cell line) we were able to detect a contaminating latent nodavirus and identify an expressed errantivirus genome. Overall, these studies have strengthened the role of MP-Seq as an integral tool for identifying contaminating agents in vaccine cell substrates.
authors: Onions, D.;Cote, C.;Love, B.;Toms, B.;Koduri, S.;Armstrong, A.;Chang, A.;Kolman, J.

title: Revealing vector, parasite, blood meal and microbiome patterns from mixed DNA samples of the Chagas disease vector Triatoma dimidiata
abstract: Chagas disease, considered a neglected disease by the World Health Organization, is caused by the protozoal parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and is transmitted by >140 triatomic species across the Americas. In Central America, the main vector is Triatoma dimidiata, an opportunistic bloodmeal feeder that inhabits both native and Sylvatic ecotopes. Given the diversity of interacting biological agents involved in the epidemiology of Chagas disease, simultaneous information on the dynamics of the parasite, the vector, the vector's gut microbiome, and the blood meal source would facilitate the identification of important biotic factors associated with disease risk are associated with T. cruzi transmission. In this study, we developed a RADseq-based analysis pipeline to examine mixed DNA species extracted from the abdomen of T. dimidiata. To assess the effectiveness of the method across spatial scales, we used a nested spatial sampling design ranging from individual villages in Guatemala to large biogeographical regions of Central America. Information from each biotic source was distinguished with bioinformatics tools and used to determine the prevalence of T. cruzi infection and the predominant Discrete Typing Units (DTUs) in the region, the genetic population structure of T. dimidiata, the microbial diversity in the gut and to evaluate the blood meal history. An average of 3.25 million reads per sample were obtained, with approximately 1% attributed to the parasite, 20% to the vector, 11% to bacteria, and 4% to putative blood meals. Using a total of 6,405 T. cruzi SNPs, we discovered nine infected vectors harboring two distinct DTUs: TcI and a second unidentified strain, possibly TcIV. Vector samples were sufficiently variable for population genomic analyses, with a total of 25,710 T. dimidiata SNPs in all samples, sufficient to demonstrate geographic genetic structure at both local and regional scales. We observed a diverse microbiotic community with significantly higher bacterial species richness in infected T. dimidiata abdomens than in uninfected ones. The Unifrac analysis suggests a co-aggregation of bacteria associated with infection occurring along with the typical gut microbial community derived from the local environment. We identified vertebrate blood meals from five abdomens of T. dimidiata, including chicken, dog, duck and human; However, additional detection methods would be required to reliably identify blood meal sources from most samples. Overall, our study shows that this method is effective to simultaneously generate genetic data on vectors and associated parasites, along with ecological information on feeding patterns and microbial interactions, which can be followed up with complementary approaches such as PCR-based parasite detection, 18S eukaryotes, and can be 16S bacteria barcoding.
authors: Orantes, L. C.;Monroy, C.;Dorn, P. L.;Stevens, L.;Rizzo, D. M.;Morrissey, L.;Hanley, J. P.;Rodas, A. G.;Richards, B.;Wallin, K. F.;Helms Cahan, S.

title: Host-independent evolution and a genetic classification of the hepadnavirus family based on nucleotide sequences
abstract: molecular phylogeny analysis was performed to investigate whether the evolution of the hepadnavirus family is host dependent. Using the nucleotide sequences of 18 strains, we constructed pedigrees. The trees obtained show that all 12 hepatitis B virus strains can be divided into four subgroups that are not compatible with conventional subtypes. We estimated the rate of synonymous (silent) substitution for hepatitis B virus to be 4.57 x 10-5 per site per year. Applying this rate to the phylogenetic tree, we estimated that duck hepatitis B virus split from a common ancestor about 30,000 years ago at the earliest, woodchuck hepatitis virus and ground squirrel hepatitis virus about 10,000 years ago years and the hepatitis B virus within the last 3000 years. Since these viral divergence times are much younger than those of the host species, this suggests that the hepadnavirus family evolved independently of host species divergence.
authors: Orito, E.;Mizokami, M.;Ina, Y.;Moriyama, E. N.;Kameshima, N.;Yamamoto, M.;Gojobori, T.

title: Degenerate primers for PCR amplification and sequencing of the avian influenza A neuraminidase gene
abstract: This study describes the design of degenerate primers and their use for full-length avian influenza A-neuramindase (NA) synthesis. Each reaction was performed using either two forward primers and one reverse primer or one forward primer and one reverse primer. Both primer combinations had comparable amplification efficiencies for all NA subtypes (1-9). A total of 115 virus strains, including both field isolates and reference strains, were successfully amplified using these degenerate primer sets. Of the amplified sequences, 108 strains (93.9%) gave rise to nearly full-length NA cDNAs after two reads with one forward primer and one reverse primer. Of the remaining sequences, five strains (4.3%) provided reads with sufficient information for subtype categorization by BLAST, although they were of insufficient quality for assembly. One strain (0.9%) yielded different subtypes from both sequence reads, while the other (0.9%) could not be assembled and subtyped. This successful demonstration of these degenerate primers for the amplification and sequencing of all avian NA subtypes suggests that these primers could be used in the avian influenza surveillance program, as well as in studies of antiviral resistance, virus ecology, or viral phylogeny.
authors: Orozovic, G.;Latorre-Margalef, N.;Wahlgren, J.;Muradrasoli, S.;Olsen, B.

title: In vitro surrogate models to support the development of antivirals to contain foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks
abstract: Foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) is a highly pathogenic member of the Aphthovirus genus (family Picornaviridae) that is restricted to manipulation in high-security facilities, making research and discovery of antiviral strategies against the virus difficult. Bovine rhinitis B virus (BRBV) and equine rhinitis A virus (ERAV), which are phylogenetically most closely related to FMD, have been investigated as surrogates for FMD in antiviral studies. Although no efficient cell culture system for BRBV has been reported to date, we show that infection of primary bovine kidney cells resulted in extensive but rather poorly reproducible induction of the cytopathic effect (CPE). Madin-Darby bovine kidney cells, on the other hand, supported viral replication in the absence of CPE. Antiviral assays were developed for ERAV in Vero A cells using a viral RNA reduction assay and a CPE reduction assay; the latter has a Z' factor of 0.83. ±. 0.07. The BRBV and ERAV models were next used to assess the anti-aphthovirus activity of two broad-spectrum antiviral agents, 2'-C-methylcytidine (2CMC) and ribavirin, and the enterovirus-specific inhibitor enviroxim. The effects of the three compounds in the CPE reduction (ERAV) and viral RNA reduction assays (BRBV and ERAV) were comparable. Similar to 2CMC, Compound A, a recently discovered non-nucleoside pan-serotype FMDV inhibitor, also inhibited replication of both BRBV and ERAV, while enviroxime had no activity. The BRBV and ERAV surrogate models described here can be manipulated in BSL-2 laboratories and could facilitate studies to elucidate the mechanism of action of new FMDV inhibitors. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Osiceanu, A. M.;Murao, L. E.;Kollanur, D.;Swinnen, J.;De Vleeschauwer, A. R.;Lefebvre, D. J.;De Clercq, K.;Neyts, J.;Goris, N.

title: The spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1 subtype) clades in Bangladesh, 2010 and 2011
abstract: Since the global spread of the highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu in 2005-2006, control programs have been successfully implemented in most affected countries. HPAI H5N1 was first reported in Bangladesh in 2007 and since then 546 outbreaks have been reported to the OIE. The disease has apparently become endemic in Bangladesh. Spatiotemporal information on 177 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks that occurred in Bangladesh between February 2010 and April 2011 and 37 of those outbreaks in which isolated H5N1 viruses were phylogenetically characterized as a clade were analyzed. Three clades were identified, 2.2 (21 cases), 2.3.4 (2 cases) and 2.3.2.1 (14 cases). Clade 2.2 was identified throughout the period and was widespread in a southeast-northwest orientation. Clade 2.3.2.1 appeared later and was generally confined to central Bangladesh in a north-south orientation. Based on a directional test, Clade 2.2 viruses spread in a southeast-northwest direction, while Clade 2.3.2.1 spread in a west-east direction. The extent of clade 2.3.2.1 spread was greater compared to clade 2.2 (angular concentration 0.2765 versus 0.1860). In both cases, the first outbreaks were identified as early outliers, but in addition, early outbreaks (one each) of clade 2.2 in central Bangladesh and north-west Bangladesh at considerable distances from each other were also identified. The spread of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza in Bangladesh is characterized by reported long-distance translocations. This poses a challenge to disease control efforts. Increased biosecurity enforcement and control of movements between affected farms and susceptible farms, as well as better monitoring and reporting are needed. Although movement of poultry and equipment seems a more likely explanation for the patterns identified, the relative contribution of trade and the market chain compared to wild birds in the spread of the disease needs further investigation. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Osmani, M. G.;Ward, M. P.;Giasuddin, M.;Islam, M. R.;Kalam, A.

title: Some Viral Zoonoses Transmitted by Domestic Animals (author's translation) Dutch
abstract: Besides dogs and cats, various other animals are more or less popular as pets in the Netherlands. It is important for the veterinarian to know which diseases can be transmitted from these animals to humans. From the viral zoonoses. Rabies poses a threat to humans where dogs and, to a lesser extent, cats provide a link between humans and free-roaming wildlife. Another viral zoonosis that has been the focus of interest in recent years is lymphocytic choriomeningitis (LCM), which is caused by a virus that is often latent in mice but can also be detected in young hamsters. A human disease caused by a pathogen that should not be attributed to viruses is chlamydiosis (psittacosis, ornithosis), which is usually transmitted to humans by parrots or pigeons. The pathogens, the symptoms in humans and animals, the transmission path and possible preventive and therapeutic measures are discussed. Finally, the risk of transmission of viral zoonoses through less common "pets" is emphasized.
authors: Osterhaus, A. D.

title: Epidemiology and molecular characterization of chicken anemia virus from commercial and domestic chickens in Taiwan
abstract: Chick infectious anemia (CIA) is a disease with significant economic impact in the poultry industry. The infected chickens are characterized by aplastic anemia and extreme immunosuppression, followed by increased susceptibility to secondary infectious agents and suboptimal immune responses for vaccination. Commercially available CIA vaccines are routinely used by breeders in Taiwan to protect their offspring with maternal-derived antibodies. However, CIA cases still occur and little is known about the genetic properties of Taiwanese chicken anemia viruses (CAVs). In this study, CAV DNA was detected in 72 out of 137 flocks collected between 2010 and 2015. Among the PCR-positive samples, the coding regions of 51 CAVs were sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 gene revealed that although most Taiwanese CAVs belonged to genotypes II and III, some isolates have been clustered into a new genotype (genotype IV). In addition, a Taiwanese isolate in this new genotype IV appeared to be derived from a recombination event between genotypes II and III viruses. Five Taiwanese CAV isolates were very similar to vaccine strains 26P4 or Del-Ros. Taken together, these results indicate that the sequences of CAVs are variable in Taiwan and intergenotypic recombination between viruses of different genotypes has occurred. In addition, vaccine-like strains could induce clinical signs of CIA in chickens. Our results could be useful to understand the evolution of CAVs and design a better control strategy for CIA.
authors: Ou, S. C.;Lin, H. L.;Liu, P. C.;Huang, H. J.;Lee, M. S.;Lien, Y. Y.;Tsai, Y. L.

title: Phylogenetic variations of highly pathogenic H5N6 avian influenza viruses isolated from wild birds in the Izumi Plains, Japan, during the 2016–17 winter season
abstract: During the 2016–2017 winter season, we isolated 33 highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIVs) of the H5N6 subtype and three low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAIVs) from weakened or dead wild birds, duck feces, and environmental water samples collected in the Izumi Plains, a wintering area for Migratory birds in Japan. Genetic analyzes of the H5N6 HPAIV isolates revealed previously unreported phylogenetic variations in the PB2, PB1, PA, and NS gene segments and allowed us to propose two new genotypes for today's H5N6 HPAIVs. Furthermore, analysis of the four gene segments identified close phylogenetic relationships between our three LPAIV isolates and the contemporary H5N6 HPAIV isolates. Our results implicated the co-circulation and co-evolution of HPAIVs and LPAIVs within the same wild bird populations, thereby underscoring the importance of avian influenza surveillance targeting not only HPAIVs but also LPAIVs.
authors: Ozawa, M.;Matsuu, A.;Khalil, A. M.;Nishi, N.;Tokorozaki, K.;Masatani, T.;Horie, M.;Okuya, K.;Ueno, K.;Kuwahara, M.;Toda, S.

title: The genome of Theiler virus is closely related to that of encephalomyocarditis virus, the prototype of the cardiovirus
abstract: Theiler virus causes persistent demyelinating infection of the mouse central nervous system. Our investigation of the molecular mechanism of persistence led us to sequence 1925 nucleotides located at the 3' end of the viral genome. We observed extensive homologies between this region and the corresponding region of encephalomyocarditis virus, the prototype cardiovirus, and only some homologies with the 3' ends of the foot-and-mouth disease virus, rhinovirus, and poliovirus genomes.
authors: Ozden, S.;Tangy, F.;Chamorro, M.;Brahic, M.

title: Genetic and epidemiological insights into the origin of the Peste des Petits Ruminants virus (PPRV) in Asia and Africa
abstract: Small ruminants are an important part of the livelihood of millions of households in many parts of the world. The spread of the highly contagious plague of small ruminants (PPR) caused by an RNA virus, PPRV, in Asia and Africa remains a major concern. The present study investigated the evolutionary and epidemiological dynamics of PPRV by analyzing partial N gene and F gene sequences of the virus. All four previously described PPRV lineages (I-IV) diverged from their common ancestor during the late 19th to early 20th centuries. Among the four lineages, PPRV-IV showed distinct genetic patterning across the region; however, the sharing of haplotypes between geographic regions, together with the presence of multiple genetic clusters within a country, points to the possibility of frequent mobility of diseased individuals within the region. The gradual decline in effective infection numbers suggests limited genetic variation, which may be due to effective vaccination practiced since the 1990s. However, movement of infected animals in the region likely contributes to the spread of PPRV-IV. There was no evidence of positive selection from this study.
authors: Padhi, A.;Ma, L.

title: Time-dependent selection pressure on two arthropod-transmitted RNA viruses of the same serogroup
abstract: Understanding the genetic basis of viral adaptation to taxonomically distinct groups of host species living in different ecoclimatic zones is critical to discovering factors underpinning the successful establishment of these infectious pathogens in new hosts/environments. To gain insight into the dynamics of non-synonymous (dN) and synonymous substitutions (dS) and the relationship between the two (Ï‰ = dN/.dS), we analyzed the full nucleotide-coding sequence data of the M segment, the Glycoproteins of encode two negative-sense RNA viruses, Akabane virus (AKV) and Schmallenberg virus (SBV), which belong to the same serogroup. While AKV is relatively older, having been circulating in ruminant populations since the 1970s, SBV was first reported in 2011. The Ï‰ has been estimated at 1.67 and 0.09 for SBV and AKV, respectively, and the estimated mutation rate of SBV is at least 25 times higher than that of AKV. Given the different evolutionary stages of the two viruses, most of the mildly deleterious mutations were likely removed from the AKV genome or kept at low frequency, while positive selection along with the accumulation of mildly deleterious mutations could contribute to such an inflated mutation rate in SBV. Evolutionary distance (d) is nonlinear and negatively correlated with Ï‰ but positively correlated with dN and dS. Overall, the different patterns in Ï‰, dN, dS, and d between AKV and SBV identified in this study provide empirical evidence for a time-dependent selection pressure.
authors: Padhi, A.;Ma, L.

title: Detection and characterization of a novel porcine astrovirus 4 genotype from nasal swabs from pigs with acute respiratory disease
abstract: Metagenomic sequencing of three nasal swabs from 10- to 21-day-old pigs with unexplained acute respiratory disease from two different commercial production facilities in Oklahoma identified a novel Porcine Astrovirus 4 (PAstV-4) genotype. The genomes shared only about 75% nucleotide sequence identity with previously characterized PAstV-4 isolates, while the capsid-encoding ORF2 shared only about 53% amino acid sequence identity with reference strains. A TaqMan assay targeting the novel ORF2 gene revealed an incidence of 21% and 19% in nasal and stool swabs submitted for independent diagnostic testing, respectively. PAstV-4 RNA levels were significantly higher in nasal swabs (P=0.04), suggesting possible atypical respiratory tropism.
authors: Padmanabhan, A.;Hause, B. M.

title: Serological and molecular biological study of the prevalence of Aujeszky's disease in wild boar (Sus scrofa) in the subregions of the Pantanal wetland, Brazil
abstract: The wild boar (FS) is descended from the domestic pig and is found throughout the Brazilian wetland plain (the Pantanal). Aujeszky's disease (AD) was first serologically confirmed in 2001 in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul (MS); However, there was no viral confirmation. The aim of this study was to examine antibodies against SuHV-1 in the sera of wild boar in the examined areas, to detect SuHV-1 by PCR and to classify the viral genome. Of the 218 animals examined, 186 were analyzed by ELISA, resulting in 88 (47.3%) reactive samples. In the serum neutralization test (SN), 57/179 (31.8%) samples showed antibodies against the AD virus (SuHV-1). Nested PCR extracted 104 DNA samples for analysis and confirmed by amplification of a fragment of glycoprotein B (gB) in five samples. The SuHV-1 was detected in 12 samples using glycoprotein E (gE) primers and the viral genome was classified as type I by partial ul44 sequencing. The amplification of SuHV-1 glycoprotein fragments in the fetuses of seropositive sows indicates that vertical transmission helps maintain SuHV-1 in a free-roaming wild boar population. The origin of AD in the wild boar populations of the Pantanal is unknown, however, determination of viral latency, vertical transmission of the antigen through amplification of SuHV-1 glycoprotein fragments in the fetuses of seropositive sows, and genome typing help elucidate the epidemiology of this disease in the Wetlands of MS, Brazil. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Paes, R. D. C. D. S.;Fonseca, A. A.;Monteiro, L. A. R. C.;Jardim, G. C.;Piovezan, U.;Herrera, H. M.;Mauro, R. A.;Vieira-da-Motta, O.

title: Cardiac and skeletal muscle inflammation in farmed salmon is associated with infection with a novel reovirus
abstract: Mariculture of Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar L.) has been linked to epidemics of infectious diseases, threatening not only local production but also wild fish coming near and fish escaping from sea enclosures. Inflammation of the heart and skeletal muscle (HSMI) is a frequently fatal disease of farmed Atlantic salmon. HSMI was first identified on a farm in Norway in 1999[1] and has subsequently been implicated in outbreaks on other farms in Norway and the UK[2]. Although pathology and disease transmission studies have suggested an infectious basis, efforts to identify an active ingredient have been unsuccessful. Here we provide evidence that HSMI is associated with piscine reovirus (PRV) infection. PRV is a novel reovirus identified by unbiased high-throughput DNA sequencing and a bioinformatics program focused on nucleotide abundance and sequence alignment and motif analysis. The formal implication of PRV in HSMI requires isolation in cell culture and fulfillment of Koch's postulates or prevention or modification of the disease through the use of specific drugs or vaccines. However, since our data suggest that a causal relationship is plausible, action needs to be taken to control PRV not only because it threatens domestic salmon production but also because of the possibility of transmission to wild salmon populations. © 2010 Palacios et al.
authors: Palacios, G.;Lovoll, M.;Tengs, T.;Hornig, M.;Hutchison, S.;Hui, J.;Kongtorp, R. T.;Savji, N.;Bussetti, A. V.;Solovyov, A.;Kristoffersen, A. B.;Celone, C.;Street, C.;Trifonov, V.;Hirschberg, D. L.;Rabadan, R.;Egholm, M.;Rimstad, E.;Lipkin, W. I.

title: High prevalence of turkey parvovirus in Turkish flocks from Hungary suffering from enteric disease syndromes
abstract: Samples collected in 2008 and 2009 from 49 flocks of turkeys aged 6 to 43 days with clinical signs of enteric disease and high mortality were tested by polymerase chain reaction and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction for the presence of viruses currently associated with enteric disease in Are associated (ED) syndromes: astrovirus, reovirus, rotavirus, coronavirus, adenovirus and parvovirus. Turkey astroviruses were found in 83.67% of cases and turkey astrovirus 2 (TAst-2) in 26.53% of cases. The studies directly demonstrated the high prevalence of turkey parvovirus (TuPV) in 23 flocks (46.9%) with evidence of ED, making this pathogen the second most commonly identified pathogen after astroviruses. Phylogenetic analysis of a 527 base pair region of the NS1 gene revealed two major clusters, a chicken parvovirus (ChPV) and a TuPV group, but also the presence of a divergent branch of strains tentatively named "TuPV-like ChPV". The 23 Hungarian TuPV strains were positioned in two groups separately from the American sequences of origin in the TuPV cluster. An AvaII-based restriction fragment length polymorphism assay was also developed for the rapid differentiation of TuPV, ChPV, and divergent TuPV-like ChPV strains. Since most detected enteric viruses have also been directly detected in healthy turkey flocks, the epidemiology of this disease complex remains unclear, suggesting that a specific combination of pathogens, environmental factors, or both is required for the development of clinical symptoms. © American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Palade, E. A.;Demeter, Z.;HornyÃ¡k, A.;Nemes, C.;Kisary, J.;Rusvai, M.

title: Metagenomic screening and molecular characterization of cowpea-infecting viruses in Burkina Faso
abstract: Cowpea, (Vigna unguiculata L. (Walp)) is an annual tropical grain legume. Often referred to as 'poor man's meat', the cowpea is one of the most important subsistence legumes grown in West Africa due to the high protein content of its seeds. However, African cowpea production can be seriously hampered by viral diseases that reduce yields. While twelve cowpea-infecting viruses have been reported from Africa, only three of them have so far been reported from Burkina Faso. Here we use a virion-associated nucleic acid (VANA)-based metagenomics method to screen plants collected from the three agroclimatic zones of Burkina Faso for the presence of cowpea viruses. In addition to the three cowpea-infecting virus species previously reported from Burkina Faso (cowpea aphid Borne mosaic virus [family Potyviridae], blackeye cowpea mosaic virus - a strain of common bean mosaic virus - [family Potyviridae] and cowpea mottle virus [family Tombusviridae]), five other viruses have been identified: southern cowpea mosaic virus (genus Sobemovirus), two previously uncharacterized polerovirus-like species (family Luteoviridae), one previously uncharacterized tombusvirus-like species (family Tombusviridae), and one previously uncharacterized mycotymovirus-like species (family Tymoviridae). Overall, potyviruses were the most prevalent cowpeaviruses (detected in 65.5% of samples) and the South Sudanese zone of Burkina Faso was found to have the greatest virus diversity and virus prevalence. Partial genome sequences of the two novel polerovirus-like and tombusvirus-like species were determined and RT-PCR primers were designed for use in Burkina Faso to routinely detect all these cowpea-related viruses.
authors: Palanga, E.;Filloux, D.;Martin, D. P.;Fernandez, E.;Gargani, D.;Ferdinand, R.;ZabrÃ©, J.;Bouda, Z.;Neya, J. B.;Sawadogo, M.;Traore, O.;Peterschmitt, M.;Roumagnac, P.

title: A new porcine circovirus, distantly related to known circoviruses, has been implicated in porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome and reproductive failure
abstract: Porcine circovirus-associated disease (PCVAD) is clinically manifested by postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS), respiratory and enteric disorders, reproductive failure, and porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome (PDNS). Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) is an essential component of PCVAD, although an etiologic role in PDNS is not well established. Here, a novel circovirus termed porcine circovirus 3 (PCV3) was identified in sows that died acutely with PDNS-like clinical symptoms. The PCV3 capsid and replicase proteins are only 37% and 55% identical to PCV2 and bat circoviruses, respectively. Aborted fetuses from sows with PDNS contained high levels of PCV3 (7.57 × 107 genome copies/ml) and no other viruses were detected by PCR and metagenomic sequencing. Immunohistochemical (IHC) analysis of sow tissue specimens identified PCV3 antigen in skin, kidney, lung and lymph node specimens localized in typical PDNS lesions including necrotizing vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, granulomatous lymphadenitis and bronchointerstitial pneumonia. Further examination of archival PDNS tissue samples negative for PCV2 by IHC analysis identified 45 of 48 positive for PCV3 by quantitative PCR (qPCR), with 60% of a subset also testing positive for PCV3 by IHC analysis . qPCR analysis of 271 samples for the diagnosis of porcine respiratory disease identified 34 PCV3 positive cases (12.5%) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay detection of anti-PCV3 capsid antibodies in serum samples revealed that 46 (55 %) of 83 samples tested positive were positive. These results suggest that PCV3 is commonly circulating in US pigs and may play an etiological role in reproductive failure and PDNS. Due to the high economic impact of PCV2, this novel circovirus warrants further studies to elucidate its importance and role in PCVAD.
authors: Palinski, R.;PiÃ±eyro, P.;Shang, P.;Yuan, F.;Guo, R.;Fang, Y.;Byers, E.;Hause, B. M.

title: Discovery of a new parvovirinae virus, porcine parvovirus 7, by metagenomic sequencing of porcine rectal swabs
abstract: Parvoviruses are a diverse group of viruses, including some of the smallest known species, capable of infecting a wide range of animals. Metagenomic sequencing of pooled adult swine rectal swabs identified a 4103 bp contig composed of two large open reading frames encoding proteins of 672 and 469 amino acids (aa) in length. BLASTP analysis of the 672-aa protein revealed 42.4% identity with fruit bat (Eidolon helvum) parvovirus 2 (EhPV2) and 37.9% with turkey parvovirus (TuPV) TP1-2012/HUN NS1 proteins. The 469-aa protein bore no significant similarity to known proteins. Genetic and phylogenetic analyzes suggest that PPV7, EhPV2 and TuPV represent a new genus in the Parvoviridae family. Quantitative PCR screening of 182 porcine diagnostic specimens yielded a total of 16 positives (8.6%). Taken together, these data suggest that PPV7 is a highly divergent novel parvovirus prevalent in US swine.
authors: Palinski, R. M.;Mitra, N.;Hause, B. M.

title: Molecular cloning and sequence analysis of the duck enteritis virus UL5 gene
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is a herpesvirus that causes an acute, contagious, and fatal illness. In the present article, the DEV-UL5 gene was cloned from a vaccine virus and sequenced. Degenerate oligonucleotide primers were designed according to the consensus sequence of the herpesvirus UL5 and UL3 gene and used in the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify DNA products with a size of 4577 bp. DNA sequence analysis revealed an open reading frame (ORF) of 2568 bp encoding an 855 amino acid polypeptide homologous to herpesvirus UL5 proteins. The DEV-UL5 gene has a basic composition of 769 adenine (29.95%), 556 cytosine (21.65%), 533 guanine (20.76%) and 710 thymine (27.65%). The sequence comparison revealed that the nucleotide sequence of the DEV-UL5 gene was very similar to that of other alphaherpesviruses. Phylogenetic tree analysis showed that the fifteen herpesvirus viruses analyzed fell into four major groups, and duck enteritis virus itself branched and was most closely related to the meleagrid herpesvirus 1, gallid herpesvirus 2, and gallid herpesvirus 3 subtrees. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Pan, H.;Cao, R.;Liu, L.;Niu, M.;Zhou, B.;Chen, P.;Hu, J.

title: Molecular characterization of the UL4 gene of duck enteritis virus
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is a herpesvirus that causes an acute, contagious, and fatal illness. In the present article, the DEV-UL4 gene was cloned from a vaccine virus and sequenced. A degenerate oligonucleotide primer for the consensus site of the herpesvirus UL3 gene and a specific primer located in UL5 were used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to generate a DNA product of 2086 bp in size amplify. DNA sequence analysis revealed that a 714 bp DEV open reading frame (ORF) encoding a 237 amino acid polypeptide is homologous to the herpesvirus UL4 family of proteins and was therefore characterized as a DEV UL4 gene. Alignment of the DEV-UL4 protein sequence with that of other alphaherpesviruses showed that 10 amino acid residues are completely conserved. The phylogenetic tree analysis showed that the seventeen alphaherpesviruses analyzed were divided into four major groups, and duck enteritis virus was separately branched, closely related to the mardivirus group, the gallid herpesvirus 2 (GaHV-2), gallid herpesvirus 3 (GaHV-3) and includes meleagrid herpesvirus 1 (MeHV-1). The present study showed that the evolutionary relatedness of the UL4 protein could be used to classify alphaherpesviruses. Â© Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag GmbH 2009.
authors: Pan, H. Q.;Wang, N.;Liu, L.;Liu, L.;Hu, J. C.;Chen, P. Y.;Wang, S. J.;Cao, R. B.

title: Genetic diversity and phylogenetic analysis of the glycoprotein GP85 of ALV-J isolates from mainland China between 1999 and 2010: coexistence of two extremely different subgroups in strata
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J), first isolated in 1989, preferentially infects meatfowl. However, laying hen flocks in China have seen outbreaks of this virus since 2008. To understand the genetic diversity of ALV-J in Chinese laying hens, we compared and analyzed the GP85 gene sequences of 106 ALV-J isolates isolated between 1999 and 2010 in mainland China. The GP85 gene sequences from 41 laying hen isolates collected in 9 provinces of China between 2008 and 2010 belonged to two separate, very different subgroups and were distinguished from meaty chicken isolates. Compared to all meaty isolates from China, subgroup 1 contained only current layer isolates and appeared to be dominant; All of the isolates in this subgroup displayed gene diversity and many unique amino acid mutations were present. In contrast, the viruses in subgroup 2 were perfectly conserved and shared high identity with the meat-type prototype chicken ALV-J strain HPRS-103. The two subgroups contained only two simultaneous mutations at the same position. Furthermore, most of the isolates in subgroup 1 had two additional glycosylation sites (at positions 101 and 191) compared to those in subgroup 2. Our study provides evidence for the coexistence of two extremely different ALV-J subgroups in Chinese layers from 2008 to 2010 to support the need to develop vaccines and cleanup measures to prevent ALV-J infection in laying hens in China. © 2011.
authors: Pan, W.;Gao, Y.;Qin, L.;Ni, W.;Liu, Z.;Yun, B.;Wang, Y.;Qi, X.;Gao, H.;Wang, X.

title: Modulation of the host miRNAs transcriptome in the lungs and spleen of sheep and goats infected with ruminant plague des petits virus
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is one of the highly contagious viral diseases characterized by fever, mouth soreness, conjunctivitis, gastroenteritis and pneumonia, affecting mainly sheep and goats. Reports indicate a variable host response in goats and sheep, and this host response to the expression of microRNAs (miRNAs) has not been studied. Here, miRNAs were sequenced and proteomics data generated to identify the role of differentially expressed miRNA (DEmiRNA) in PPR virus (PPRV)-infected ovine and caprine lung and spleen tissues. In lungs, 67 and 37 DEmiRNAs were identified in goats and sheep, respectively. Similarly, in the spleen, 50 and 56 DEmiRNAs were identified in goats and sheep, respectively. A total of 20 and 11 miRNAs were found to be differentially expressed in both species in PPRV-infected spleen and lung, respectively. Six DEmiRNAs—miR-21-3p, miR-1246, miR-27a-5p, miR-760-3p, miR-320a, and miR-363—were selected based on their role in viral infection, apoptosis, and fold change. Target prediction analysis of these six selected DEmiRNAs from the generated proteomic data revealed the involvement of a greater number of genes in goat lungs and spleen than in sheep. Genome analysis of host target genes revealed that these DEmiRNAs regulate multiple signaling pathways of the immune response. It was observed that the pathways i.e. T cell receptor signaling, Rap1 signaling, Toll-like receptor signaling and B cell receptor signaling controlled by DEmiRNAs were more disrupted in goats than in Sleep. The data suggest that PPRV-induced miR-21-3p, miR-320a and miR-363 could act cooperatively to enhance viral pathogenesis in the lung and spleen of sheep by downregulating multiple immune response genes. The study provides important insight into the molecular pathogenesis of PPR by identifying that the PPRV Izatnagar/94 isolate elicits a stronger host response in goats than in sheep.
authors: Pandey, A.;Sahu, A. R.;Wani, S. A.;Saxena, S.;Kanchan, S.;Sah, V.;Rajak, K. K.;Khanduri, A.;Sahoo, A. P.;Tiwari, A. K.;Mishra, B.;Muthuchelvan, D.;Mishra, B. P.;Singh, R. K.;Gandham, R. K.

title: Genomic diversity and adaptation of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium from the analysis of six genomes of different phage types
abstract: Background: Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (or simply Typhimurium) is the most common serovar in both human and livestock infections in Australia and many other countries. Typhimurium is a broad host-range serovar, but has also evolved into host-adapted variants (i.e. isolated from a specific host such as pigeons). Six Typhimurium strains of different phage types (defined by patterns of susceptibility to lysis by a panel of bacteriophage) were analyzed using Illumina high-throughput genomic sequencing. Results: Between-strain variations were mainly due to single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with an average of 611 SNPs per strain ranging from 391 SNPs to 922 SNPs. There were seven insertions/deletions (indels) with full or partial gene deletions, four inactivation events due to an IS200 insertion, and 15 pseudogenes due to premature termination. Four of these inactivated or deleted genes may be related to virulence. Nine prophages or prophage residues were identified in the six strains. Gifsy-1, Gifsy-2 and the phage residues sopE2 and sspH2 were present in all six genomes, while Fels-1, Fels-2, ST64B, ST104 and CP4-57 were differentially present. Four strains carried the 90 kb plasmid pSLT, which contains several known virulence genes. However, two strains were found to lack the plasmid. In addition, one strain had a new plasmid similar to plasmid pHCM2 from Typhi strain CT18. Conclusion: The genomic data suggest that between-strain variations are mainly due to the accumulation of SNPs, some of which led to gene silencing. Unique genetic elements common between host-adapted phage types were not found. This study advanced our understanding of Typhimurium evolution and adaptation at the genomic level. © 2013 Pang et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Pang, S.;Octavia, S.;Feng, L.;Liu, B.;Reeves, P. R.;Lan, R.;Wang, L.

title: Detection of a mammalian-like astrovirus in European roller (Coracias garrulus)
abstract: Astroviruses are small, non-enveloped viruses with positive-sense single-stranded RNA genomes. The Astroviridae family includes two genera, Mamastrovirus and Avastrovirus, which, to the best of our knowledge, infect mammals and birds, respectively. However, a recent seroprevalence study showed that humans with contact with turkeys can develop serological reactions to turkey astrovirus and mink may have been infected with avastrovirus. These data suggest that the "host species/astrovirus genus" association should be permeable; However, mamastrovirus infection has not yet been reported in bird species. In this study, a novel astrovirus was identified by viral metagenomics and RT-PCR methods in 2 (11%) of 19 fecal samples collected from a wild, carnivorous bird species, the European roller (Coracias garrulus) from two breeding sites in Hungary. The complete genome sequence of Astrovirus Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 (KP663426) was 7025 nt in length and exhibited some unique genomic features, including an unusually long spacer between the subgenomic RNA promoter and the ORF2 initiation codon. Using the BLASTp Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011, the highest AS identities were 35%, 61% and 34% to MAstV 32 (JF713710, host: pig), to MAstV 23 (JF729316, host: rabbit) and to unclassified porcinem Astrovirus ( JX684071) in ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2. The same proteins from Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 had 25%, 66% and 33% aa identities with the corresponding proteins of murine astrovirus (JX544743) as the closest strain. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis showed that Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 represents the first member of a new mamaztrovirus species. The data suggest that both mammals and birds may have been exposed to mamastroviruses and avastroviruses, offering opportunities for cross-species infection and viral adaptation with cross-class astroviruses, particularly in carnivorous animals. Further investigation is needed to determine the origin, natural host range, distribution, and vertebrate distribution of Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, A.;Kiss, T.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: First detection of Nebovirus (Caliciviridae) in a faecal sample from calves suffering from diarrhea in Hungary
abstract: Neboviruses are the youngest members of the family Calicivirdae in the genus Nebovirus, which can be etiological agents of diarrhea and intestinal diseases in calves (Bos taurus). The genus has two prototypes: the viruses Newbury-1 (Bo/Newbury1/1976/UK, DQ013304) and Nebraska (BEC/NB/80/US, AY082891). Based on the viral capsid protein (VP1), neboviruses are divided into 4 phylogenetic lineages (lineage 1-4). The authors' aims were the detection, genetic characterization and phylogenetic classification of neboviruses from 1-1 faecal samples from diarrheal calves living on two different cattle farms in Hungary. After routine bacteriological and virological diagnostics, the nebovirus was detected and the complete genome determined using molecular biological methods (454 pyrosequencing, RT-PCR, 5'/3' RACE RT-PCR and Direct Chain Terminated Sequencing). Using the pyrosequencing method, the contigs of the nebovirus sequences from one of the faecal samples were aligned and the complete viral genome was expanded using an additional 4 RT-PCR reactions. The genome of Nebovirus strain Bo/M3641/2011/HUN (JX018212) - 5'UTR (74nt)/ORF1 (6630nt)/ORF2 (677nt)/3'UTR(67nt) - was 7453nt long and is almost 95 in length % nucleotide match with strain Bo/BEC/Penrith140/2000/UK virus. Strain Bo/M3641/2011/HUN virus can be classified phylogenetically in lineage 1; Newbury-1-like phylogenetic group. In this study, the authors report the first detection, characterization, and phylogenetic analysis of Nebovirus in Hungary, which are alleged to be pathogenic agents, were already present in Hungarian cattle herds, and may contribute to calf diarrhea of unknown origin.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, A.;Nemes, C.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Molecular characterization of a novel picobirnavirus in a chicken
abstract: Picobirnaviruses (PBVs) are bipartite viruses with a wide geographic and host species distribution. The number of new PBV sequences has increased with the help of viral metagenomics. A new strain of picobirnavirus, pbv/CHK/M3841/HUN/2011, was identified by viral metagenomics; the complete sequences of segment 1 (MH327933) and 2 (MH327934) were obtained by RT-PCR from a cloacal sample of a diseased broiler breeder in Hungary. Although the conserved nucleotide (e.g. ribosome binding site) and amino acid motifs (e.g. ExxRxNxxxE, S-domain of the viral capsid and motifs in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase) were identifiable in the chick picobirnavirus genome, this was demonstrated putative segment 1 shared low (<30%) amino acid sequence identity with the corresponding proteins of marmot and dromedary PBVs, while segment 2 exhibited higher (<70%) amino acid sequence identity with a wolf PBV protein sequence. This is the first full genome picobirnavirus sequence from a broiler breeder chicken, but the pathogenicity of this virus is still in question.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, Ã;Nemes, C.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: A novel Passerivirus (family Picornaviridae) in an outbreak of enteritis with high mortality in African finches (Uraeginthus sp.)
abstract: An enteric outbreak with high mortality (34/52, 65.4%) was recorded in Hungary in 2014 in home-reared finches (Estrildidae). A novel passerivirus was identified in a diseased waxy purple-eared waxbill using viral metagenomics and confirmed by RT-(q)PCR. The complete genome of finch picornavirus strain Waxbill/DB01/HUN/2014 (MF977321) showed the highest amino acid sequence identity of 38.9%, 61.6%, 69.6% in P1cap, 2Chel and 3CproDpol, respectively, with Passerivirus A1 (GU182406 ). A high viral load (6.58 × 1010 genomic copies/ml) was measured in a cloacal sample and in the tissues (spinal cord, lung and gut) of two other affected finches. In addition to intestinal symptoms (diarrhea), the presence of extraintestinal viruses suggests a generalized infection in this deadly disease, for which Passerivirus could be a causative agent.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, Ã;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Enteric viruses detected by molecular methods in commercial chicken and turkey flocks in the United States between 2005 and 2006
abstract: Gut samples collected in 2005 and 2006 from 43 commercial broiler and 33 commercial turkey flocks from all regions of the United States were analyzed for the presence of astrovirus, rotavirus, reovirus, and coronavirus by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and for the presence of Astrovirus, Rotavirus, Reovirus and Coronavirus tests for the presence of group 1 and 2 adenovirus by PCR. A phylogenetic analysis was performed to further characterize the viruses and to assess species association and geographic patterns. Astroviruses were identified in samples from 86% of chicken flocks and 100% of turkey flocks. Both chicken astrovirus and avian nephritis virus (ANV) have been identified in chicken samples, and often both viruses have been detected in the same flock. Turkey astrovirus type 2 and turkey astrovirus type 1 were found in 100% and 15.4% of turkey flocks, respectively. In addition, 12.5% of the turkey flocks were positive for ANV. Rotavirus was present in 46.5% of chicken flocks tested and 69.7% of turkey flocks tested. Chicken and turkey rotaviruses were species-sorted based on the NSP4 gene sequence of rotavirus. The rotaviruses originating from Turkey are also sorted by geographic location. Reoviruses were identified in 62.8% and 45.5% of chicken and turkey flocks, respectively. Based on the reovirus S4 gene segment, the chicken and turkey-derived viruses were sorted separately and they differed from all previously reported avian reoviruses. Corona viruses were detected in the intestinal contents of chickens, but not turkeys. Adenoviruses were not detected in any chicken or turkey flock. Of a total of 76 chicken and turkey flocks tested, only three chicken flocks were negative for all viruses targeted in this study. Most herds were positive for two or more of the viruses, and overall no clear pattern of geographic virus distribution was evident. This study provides updated enteric virus prevalence data for the United States using molecular methods and confirms that enteric viruses are widespread in poultry in the United States, although the clinical significance of most of these viruses remains unclear.
authors: Pantin-Jackwood, M. J.;Day, J. M.;Jackwood, M. W.;Spackman, E.

title: Regular monitoring of commercial turkeys for enteric virus indicates the continued presence of astrovirus and rotavirus in the farms
abstract: Using molecular detection methods, a longitudinal study was carried out on the detection of enteric viruses in the intestinal contents of turkeys in eight commercial farms and one research facility. Intestinal contents were collected from turkeys prior to placement, with each flock being resampled at 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 weeks of age. Samples were screened for astrovirus, rotavirus, reovirus and turkey coronavirus (TCoV) by reverse transcriptase and polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and for adenovirus groups 1 and 2 by PCR. Rotavirus was the only virus detected prior to placement (7 out of 16 samples examined). All commercial flocks were positive for rotavirus and astrovirus from 2 to 6 weeks of age and most were intermittently positive until 12 weeks of age when the birds were processed. Of the 96 samples collected from birds on the farms, 89.5% were positive for astrovirus and 67.7% positive for rotavirus. All flocks were negative for TCoV, reovirus and adenovirus group 1 at all time points and positive for adenovirus group 2 (hemorrhagic enteritis virus) at 6 weeks of age. All monitored flocks were assessed as healthy or normal by field personnel. Turkeys reared in experimental facilities that had been vacant for months and thoroughly cleaned had higher body weight and lower feed conversion rates than turkeys reared in commercial farms at 5 weeks of age. Intestinal samples taken from these turkeys at 1, 2 and 3 weeks of age were free of enteric virus. This report shows that astrovirus and rotavirus can be present throughout the life of a turkey flock. Comparison of infected birds with a group of turkeys negative for enteric virus by the methods used here suggests that astrovirus and/or rotavirus may affect production. The full impact on herd performance remains to be determined.
authors: Pantin-Jackwood, M. J.;Spackman, E.;Day, J. M.;Rives, D.

title: Molecular characterization and typing of chicken and turkey astroviruses circulating in the United States: diagnostic implications
abstract: Avian astroviruses were detected by reverse transcriptase and polymerase chain reaction in gut contents collected from commercial chickens and turkeys in the United States in 2003-2005. Astroviruses have been detected in birds from both healthy and underperforming flocks, with or without enteric disease. Phylogenetic analysis was performed using polymerase (ORF-1b) gene sequence data from 41 Turkey-derived astroviruses and 23 chicken-derived astroviruses. All currently available avian astrovirus sequence data and selected mammalian astrovirus sequence data were included in the analysis. Four groups of avian astroviruses were observed by phylogenetic analysis: turkey astrovirus type 1 (TAstV-1)-like viruses, turkey astrovirus type 2 (TAstV-2)-like viruses, both detected in turkeys; Avian nephritis virus (ANV)-like viruses identified in both chickens and turkeys; and a new group of chicken astroviruses (CAstV). For these four groups, amino acid identity ranged from 50.1% to 73.8% and was a maximum of 49.4% for all avian isolates compared to the mammalian astroviruses. There were several phylogenetic subgroups within the TAstV-2, ANV, and CAstV groups based on 9% nucleotide sequence divergence. Phylogenetic analysis did not result in a clear sorting by geographic region or isolation date. Furthermore, no correlation was observed between the detection of a specific astrovirus and the presence of intestinal disease or poor performance. Based on these data, a revision of the current taxonomic classification for avian astroviruses within the Avastrovirus genus is warranted.
authors: Pantin-Jackwood, M. J.;Spackman, E.;Woolcock, P. R.

title: Two oncogenes in avian carcinoma virus MH2: myc and mht
abstract: The 5.2 kilobase (kb) RNA genome of the avian carcinoma virus MH2 has the genetic structure 5'-delta gag (0.2 kb)-mht (1.2 kb)-myc (1.4 kb)-c(0 ,4kb)-poly (A)(0.2kb)-3'. delta gag is a partial retroviral core protein, mht and myc are cell-derived MH2-specific sequences, and c is the 3'-terminal retroviral vector sequence. the following results were obtained from the complete nucleotide sequences of the mht and myc genes in MH2. (i) delta gag-mht forms a hybrid gene with a contiguous reading frame of 2682 nucleotides ending with a stop codon near the 3' end of the mht gene. The 3,969 nucleotides from mht to the stop codon are 80% sequence related to the onc-specific raf sequence of murine sarcoma virus 3611 (MSV 3611) (94% homologous at the deduced amino acid level). (ii) The myc coding region in MH2 is preceded by 181 nucleotides derived from the intron immediately upstream of the second exon of the cellular chicken protomyc gene, followed by an RNA splicing acceptor site shared with the protomyc gene, followed by an RNA splice acceptor site shared with the protomyc beyond which it is collinear up to a 3' termination codon and 40 noncoding nucleotides with the myc sequences of avian retrovirus MC29 and chicken protomyc. Thus, myc forms a second MH2-specific gene together with a 5' retroviral exon. It is concluded that MH2 contains two genes with oncogenic potential, the delta-gag-mht gene, which is closely related to the delta-gag-raf transforming gene of MSV 3611 and the myc gene related to the transforming gene of MC29. Furthermore, it can be concluded that the cellular proto-onc genes, which become viral onc genes upon sequence transduction, are a small group, since out of the 19 known onc sequences, 5 are shared by different taxonomic groups of viruses, from to which the mht/raf homology is so far closest.
authors: Papas, T. S.;Kan, N. C.;Watson, D. K.;Flordellis, C.;Lautenberger, J. A.;Psallidopoulos, M. C.;Rovigatti, U. G.;Samuel, K. P.;Ascione, R.;Duesberg, P. H.

title: Classification and characterization of a laboratory chicken rotavirus strain carrying G7P[35] neutralizing antigens on the genotype 4 backbone gene configuration
abstract: The laboratory rotavirus strain BRS/115 has been used to monitor rotavirus in certain pathogen-free laying hen flocks for more than two decades. However, the virus strain has not been characterized in detail. Therefore, we aimed at characterizing the molecular properties of BRS115 by using random primed reverse transcription PCR of genomic RNA followed by massive parallel sequencing using semiconductor sequencing technology. Over 64,000 trimmed reads mapped to reference sequences from GenBank. The strain was classified as a species Rotavirus A according to the guidelines of the Rotavirus Classification Working Group and genotyped as G7-P[35]-I4-R4-C4-M4-A16-N4-T4-E11-H4. Phylogenetic analysis identified common traits with chicken, turkey and pigeon rotaviruses. This study demonstrates the robustness of next-generation sequencing in characterizing reference viral materials used in specialized laboratories.
authors: Papp, H.;Marton, S.;Farkas, S. L.;Jakab, F.;Martella, V.;Malik, Y. S.;Palya, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Phylogenetic tracing of current Pocine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV) strains in the Philippines
abstract: In order to trace the possible route of introduction of the Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV), the phylogenetic relationships of PEDV strains in the epidemic areas in the Philippines to PEDV strains endemic in other countries were examined. Partial nucleotide sequences of the S1 spike gene were determined from the PEDV-positive samples and compared with S1 sequences from other countries. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that PEDV strains in the Philippines split into two groups. Group 1 members are related to tribes from the United States, Taiwan, Japan, and Canada, while Group 2 members are related to tribes from China and Vietnam.
authors: Paraguison-Alili, R.;Domingo, C. Y.

title: Ten years (2004-2014) of influenza surveillance in Northern Italy
abstract: As a regional influenza reference center operating within the Italian network InfluNet, we report here data on influenza virological and epidemiological surveillance and vaccination rates achieved in Lombardy (northern Italy) over 10 consecutive winter seasons (2004-2014). . . Over the past 10 years, influenza vaccination has declined in both the general population (from 15.7% in 2004-2005 to 11.7% in 2013-2014) and in the vaccine target population of persons aged ≥ 65 years (from 65.3% in 2004-2005 to 48.6% in 2013-2014) and is well below the planned minimum threshold (75%). The highest rates of influenza-like illness (ILI) were recorded during the 2004-2005 and 2009-2010 epidemics (peak incidence: 12.04 and 13.28, respectively). Both seasons were marked by the introduction of new virus strains: A/Fujian/411/2002(H3N2) (a drifted hemagglutinin variant) and A/California/7/2009(H1N1) pandemic virus (a quadruple reassortant from pigs), respectively. . Since antigenic agreement between vaccine and circulating strains was good in both seasons, a relevant proportion of cases could have been prevented by vaccination. A different situation was observed during the 2011-2012 season, when ILI morbidity rates in individuals aged ≥ 65 years were 1.5 to 6 times higher than in the other epidemics studied. The higher morbidity resulted from the circulation during the 2011-2012 season of an A/Victoria/361/2011(H3N2)-like variant that showed lower genetic similarity to the A(H3N2) strain included in the 2011-2012 vaccine composition was included. Continuous monitoring of the characteristics of circulating viruses is an essential tool to monitor their compliance with seasonal vaccine strains. Strategies to increase coverage rates are warranted.
authors: Pariani, E.;Amendola, A.;Piatti, A.;Anselmi, G.;Ranghiero, A.;Bubba, L.;Rosa, A. M.;Pellegrinelli, L.;Binda, S.;Coppola, L.;Gramegna, M.;Zanetti, A.

title: Molecular detection and genetic characterization of kobuviruses in fecal samples from diarrheal cattle in Korea
authors: Park, S. J.;Kim, H. K.;Song, D. S.;Moon, H. J.

title: Whole genome analysis of a novel adenovirus from the southern polar skua (Catharacta maccormicki) in Antarctica
abstract: Adenoviruses have been identified in humans and a variety of vertebrates, but not previously from the polar region. Here we report the entire 26,340 bp genome of a novel adenovirus detected by PCR in tissues from six of nine south polar skuas (Catharacta maccormicki) collected from 2007 to 2009 at Lake King Sejong, King George Island, Antarctica became. The South Polar Skua Adenovirus (SPSAdV) DNA polymerase, penton base, hexon and fiber genes showed 68.3%, 75.4%, 74.9% and 48.0% nucleotide sequence similarity to their counterparts in hemorrhagic enteritis virus of Turkey. Whole-genome phylogenetic analyzes revealed that SPSAdV belongs to the genus Siadenovirus, family Adenoviridae. This is the first detection of a novel adenovirus, SPSAdV, from a large polar seabird (family Stercorariidae) in Antarctica.
authors: Park, Y. M.;Kim, J. H.;Gu, S. H.;Lee, S. Y.;Lee, M. G.;Kang, Y. K.;Kang, S. H.;Kim, H. J.;Song, J. W.

title: Focus: Microbiome: An ecological framework of the human virome provides a classification of current knowledge and identifies future areas...
authors: Parker, M. T.

title: Characterization of Wongorr virus, an Australian orbivirus
abstract: Sequence analyzes of VP3 gene segments from Wongorr virus isolates from the Northern Territory of Australia were compared to the related gene segments from Picola and Paroo River viruses. Previous serological studies had shown some relationships between these viruses, however VP3 gene sequence and phylogenetic analyzes placed these viruses in the same serogroup, distinct from other orbivirus serogroups described. A polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was developed to detect this serogroup and used to identify and determine partial sequence data for other isolates of the virus. Wongorr virus and the other tick- and mosquito-borne orbiviruses (Kemerovo and Corriparta) were more closely related than the Culicoides-borne orbiviruses, such as bluetongue disease (BTV) and African horse disease virus (AHSV), which have been shown to be on a separate branch locations of the orbivirus pedigree.
authors: Parkes, H.;Gould, A. R.

title: Rumen virome: an assessment of viral communities and their functions in the rumen of an Indian buffalo
abstract: Viruses play a key role in compensating for the bacterial population in every ecosystem on earth. Rumen, a very diverse ecosystem, is still understudied for viral communities and their metabolic capabilities. We performed shotgun sequencing of enriched virus particles from rumen fluid collected from an Indian buffalo. The study found that well-assembled Newbler and Velvet contigs received the majority of viral domain assignments, further revealing Caudovirales as an important order. A majority of Firmicutes bacteriophage was found in the study, which also confirms the presence of conserved domains such as peptidases against Firmicutes phage.
authors: Parmar, N. R.;Jakhesara, S. J.;Mohapatra, A.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Development of cDNA probes for typing group A bovine rotavirus based on VP4 specificity
abstract: Dot and Northern (RNA) blot hybridization assays were developed for P-typing of group A bovine rotavirus (BRV) using cDNA probes prepared from gene segment 4. The probes were prepared by polymerase chain reaction amplification of hyperdivergent regions (nucleotides 211 to 686) of BRV strains UK, IND, NCDV and Cr VP4 cDNA using specific oligonucleotide primers. The probes were P-type specific (VP4) and showed little or no cross-reactivity with double-stranded RNA from heterologous rotavirus P-types. Our studies indicate that among the seven BRV isolates tested, at least three P-types, as defined by polymerase chain reaction-derived VP4 gene probes from the UK, NCDV and Cr strains, are present.
authors: Parwani, A. V.;Rosen, B. I.;McCrae, M. A.;Saif, L. J.

title: Complete genome sequence analysis of chicken astrovirus isolate from India
abstract: Objective: Chicken astroviruses are known to cause severe disease in chickens, resulting in increased mortality and the "white chick" condition. Here we want to characterize the causative agent of visceral gout with suspected astrovirus infection in broiler breeders. Methods: Total RNA isolated from allantoic fluid of SPF embryos passaged with infected chicken samples was sequenced by whole genome shotgun sequencing using an Ion Torrent PGM platform. The sequence was analyzed for the presence of coding and non-coding features, its similarity to reported isolates, and an epitope analysis of the capsid structural protein. Results: The consensus length of the 7513 bp genomic sequence of the Indian isolate of chicken astrovirus was obtained after assembling 14,121 high quality reads. The genome consisted of 13 bp 5-UTR, three open reading frames (ORFs) including ORF1a encoding serine protease, ORF1b encoding RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) and ORF2 encoding capsid protein, and 298 bp 3- UTR containing two coronavirus stem loop II-like "s2m" motifs and a 19 nucleotide poly-A stretch. The genetic analysis of CAstV/INDIA/ANAND/2016 showed the highest sequence similarity of 86.94% with the chicken astrovirus isolate CAstV/GA2011, followed by 84.76% with CAstV/4175 and 74.48% with CAstV/Poland /G059/2014 isolates. The capsid structural protein of CAstV/INDIA/ANAND/2016 showed 84.67% similarity to the chicken astrovirus isolate CAstV/GA2011, 81.06% to CAstV/4175 and 41.18% to CAstV/Poland/G059/2014 -Isolates. However, the capsid protein sequence showed a high degree of sequence identity at the nucleotide level (98.64-99.32%) and at the amino acid level (97.74-98.69%) with reported sequences from Indian isolates, indicating their common origin and limited sequence divergence . Epitope analysis by SVMTriP identified two unique epitopes in our isolate, seven common epitopes among Indian isolates, and two common epitopes among all isolates except the Polish isolate, which all carried different epitopes.
authors: Patel, A. K.;Pandit, R. J.;Thakkar, J. R.;Hinsu, A. T.;Pandey, V. C.;Pal, J. K.;Prajapati, K. S.;Jakhesara, S. J.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Metagenome of clinically diseased and healthy broilers affected by respiratory disease
abstract: In the recent past, respiratory infection has become a major challenge for poultry farmers. Various pathogens including avian pneumovirus (APV), avian influenza virus (AIV), infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) and Newcastle disease virus (NDV), Avibacterium paragallinarum, Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale (ORT), Mycoplasma synoviae (MS), Mycoplasma gallisepticum (MG ) and avian pathogen Escherichia coli (APEC) are involved in the avian respiratory disease complex [1], [2] (Bradbury, 1984; Roussan et al., 2008). Therefore, respiratory disease complex is the most serious disease affecting poultry, causing severe economic losses in the poultry industry worldwide [3] (Murthy et al., 2008). In recent years, metagenomics has emerged as a powerful analytical tool for detecting pathogens directly from clinical samples without prior knowledge of the organism in a given sample [4], [5] (Schuster, 2008; Pereira et al., 2010). High-throughput next-generation sequencing technology was used to sequence the isolated genomic DNA. These data provide insight into the taxonomic and functional status of microorganisms responsible for causing respiratory infections in broilers. Data from these metagenomes are available on the BioSample Submission Portal as Bioproject PRJNA339659 and SRA accession numbers SRR5997823, SRR5992854, SRR6037376, SRR6024702, SRR6012248 and SRR6008913.
authors: Patel, J. G.;Patel, B. J.;Patel, S. S.;Raval, S. H.;Parmar, R. S.;Joshi, D. V.;Chauhan, H. C.;Chandel, B. S.;Patel, B. K.

title: Equine Herpesviruses 1 (EHV-1) and 4 (EHV-4) - Epidemiology, Disease and Immunoprophylaxis: A Brief Review
abstract: This review article focuses on the epidemiology, latency and pathogenesis, and approaches to control equine herpesvirus type 1 (EHV-1) and 4 (EHV-4) infection in horses. Although both viruses can cause febrile rhinopneumonitis, EHV-1 is the leading cause of abortion, paresis and neonatal death. The lesion central to these three conditions is necrotizing vasculitis and thrombosis resulting from lytic infection of endothelial cells lining blood capillaries. The initiation of infection in these lesions is probably due to reactivated EHV-1 from latently infected leukocytes. However, the host factors responsible for reactivation are still poorly understood. While the development of vaccines against these important equine viruses using classical and modern approaches has been ongoing for over five decades, progress has been slow compared to other alpha-herpesviruses of veterinary importance affecting cattle and swine. However, recent data with a temperature-sensitive live EHV-1 vaccine are promising. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Patel, J. R.;Heldens, J.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the NS5B gene of classical swine fever virus isolates indicates a plausible Chinese origin of the Indian subgroup 2.2 viruses
abstract: Twenty-three CSFV isolates recovered from field outbreaks in different parts of India in 2006-2009 were used for genetic analysis in the NS5B region (409 nts). Seventeen of these have previously been studied [16] in the 50UTR region. Phylogenetic analyzes showed the continued dominance of subgroup 1.1 strains in the country. A detailed analysis of a subgroup 2.2 virus showed the plausible Chinese origin of this subgroup in India and provided indirect evidence of the CSFV movement routes within the Southeast Asia region. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
authors: Patil, S. S.;Hemadri, D.;Veeresh, H.;Sreekala, K.;Gajendragad, M. R.;Prabhudas, K.

title: A proposed subdivision of the pestivirus genus using monoclonal antibodies supported by cross-neutralization assays and genetic sequencing
abstract: 66 ruminant and porcine pestiviruses were analyzed using a panel of 76 monoclonal antibodies raised against 9 different viruses. Reactivity was used to construct epitope similarity maps for all viruses. Four major virus subgroups have been identified. One subgroup corresponded to classical swine fever virus (CSFV) and included most porcine pestiviruses but none from ruminants. A second subset contained viruses mainly of bovine origin, including reference bovine viral diarrhea (BVDV) viruses such as NADL; but viruses from pigs and sheep were also represented. A third subgroup, represented by border disease virus (BDV) reference strains, comprised mainly ovine isolates but also porcine viruses. The fourth and last defined subgroup contained no reference strains of CSFV, BVDV or BDV, but included atypical viruses from bovine, ovine and porcine. The subgrouping scheme was supported by genetic comparisons between representative viruses from the 4 subgroups and by virus neutralization with polyclonal sera.
authors: Paton, D. J.;Sands, J. J.;Lowings, J. P.;Smith, J. E.;Ibata, G.;Edwards, S.

title: Foot and Mouth Disease Control Options: Knowledge, Skills and Policy
abstract: Foot-and-mouth disease can be controlled by zoosanitary measures and vaccination, but this is difficult due to the existence of multiple serotypes of the causative virus, multiple host species including wild animals, and extreme contagiousness. Although the disease is unbearable for modern high-production livestock systems, it is not usually fatal and is often not a priority for control in many developing countries, which remain a reservoir for virus spread. The phylogenetic analysis of viruses circulating worldwide reveals seven main reservoirs, each requiring a tailored regional control strategy. Countries that eradicate the disease reap significant trade benefits, but in addition to regional cooperation, achieving and maintaining that status with current tools takes a lot of time, money and effort. Therefore, a progressive approach is needed that can provide intermediate benefits on the way to ultimate eradication. Research is needed to understand and predict patterns of virus persistence and emergence and to improve vaccine selection. Better diagnostic methods and, above all, better vaccines could significantly improve control in both free and affected parts of the world. In particular, vaccines with improved thermostability and longer immunity would facilitate control and make them less dependent on advanced veterinary infrastructure. © 2009 The Royal Society.
authors: Paton, D. J.;Sumption, K. J.;Charleston, B.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of Indian field isolates of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype O as shown by partial sequencing of the 1D gene
abstract: The sequence of 165 nucleotides at the 3' end of the 1D gene determined from RT-PCR amplified cDNA fragments of 25 type O strains isolated between 1987 and 1995 from different parts/regions of India and the vaccine strain (R2/75) currently used in India have been subjected to a phylogenetic analysis. An isolate from neighboring Nepal was also included in the study. The virus/field strains showed a high degree of genetic heterogeneity among themselves with a percentage divergence in the nucleotide sequence ranging from 1.2 to 19.4%. The Indian strains were far removed (13.3-20.6%) from the exotic type O strains of O1BFS, O1K, and O1Campos. The type O strains analyzed were classified into three genotypes based on the degree of observed divergence in nucleotide sequence. The vaccine virus type O (R2/75) differed >7% (7.3-15.2%) from the field strains, demonstrating significant (>5%) genetic heterogeneity between the two. The phylogenetic analysis identified three distinct lineages, namely (i) lineage 1, represented by the exotic tribes, (ii) lineage 2, represented by 25 of the field tribes, grouped into seven subgroups/sublineages (2a-2g), and (iii ) line 3, represented by a unique field isolate that shared the branch/origin with the vaccine strain. Lineage 2, consisting of 25 of the 26 type O field strains analyzed, was placed almost equidistant to lines 1 and 3 in the phylogenetic tree. The vaccine strain was closer to the viruses in line 2. Although there was no specific distribution pattern of sequences in different geographic regions of India, the viruses/sequences in subgroup 2f appeared to be restricted to the southern states. Comparison of the deduced amino acid sequence in the immunodominant regions 133-160 and 200-208 of the 1D gene product (VP1) showed that the two lineage 3 viruses had unique amino acid residues at positions 138 (D), 139 (G). , 144 (I) and 158 (A) compared to the rest of the tribes, including the exotic ones. Comparison of the amino acid residues at critical positions 144, 148, 149, 151, 153, 154 and 208 showed similarity between the type O strains analyzed. The virus stocks showed a variation (V/L/I) at position 144. One field strain showed a replacement of Q149â†'E and another of P208â†'L. Thus, the study found that the FMD type O virus populations circulating and causing disease outbreaks in India are genetically very heterogeneous but related in the immunodominant region of the VP1 polypeptide, and that it is present in almost every region of the There is more than one genetically distinct virus population in the country, which is possible due to the unrestricted movement of animals in the country. The involvement of the vaccine virus in disease outbreaks was excluded since the field strains (with the exception of strain 3) were phylogenetically distinct. Copyright (C) 1998 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Pattnaik, B.;Venkataramanan, R.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Samuel, A. R.;Knowles, N. J.;Kitching, R. P.

title: Isolation of a bovine rotavirus with a “super short” RNA electrophoresis pattern from a calf with diarrhea
abstract: rotavirus with a "super short" RNA electropherotype was isolated from a calf with diarrhea and designated the VMRI strain. Segments 10 and 11 of this rotavirus migrated more slowly than those of bovine rotavirus strains NCDV, B641 and B223. The electrophoretic pattern of the VMRI strain was similar to that reported for rotavirus with supershort RNA electropherotypes from humans and rabbits. Northern (RNA) blot hybridization showed that gene 11 of the VMRI strain was altered and migrated between gene segments 9 and 10. The subgroup of the VMRI strain was shown to be subgroup I.
