The VMRI strain of bovine rotavirus was neutralized by polyclonal antisera, antibodies against rotavirus serotype 6 (bovine serotype I) strains NCDV and B641, and by ascites fluid containing monoclonal antibodies directed against VP7 of rotavirus serotype 6. The VMRI strain was not neutralized by either polyclonal or monoclonal antibodies against strain B223 (bovine rotavirus serotype II). Accumulated data on neutralization of the VMRI strain with monoclonal antibodies and polyclonal antibodies suggests that this virus is a member of the NCDV group (serotype 6) of rotaviruses (bovine rotavirus serotype I).
authors: Paul, P. S.;Lyoo, Y. S.;Woode, G. N.;Zheng, S.;Greenberg, H. B.;Matsui, S.;Schwartz, K. J.;Hill, H. T.

title: Characterization of the full-length genomic sequences of cocal and alagoas vesicular stomatitis viruses
abstract: In Brazil and Argentina, vesicular stomatitis (VS) is caused by several virus strains that are serologically related to Indiana classic vesicular stomatitis virus (VSIV), namely VS Indiana-2 (VSIV-2) and VS Indiana-3 (VSIV- 3). Here we describe the full-length genomic sequences and organization of the prototype strains of VSIV-2 cocal virus (COCV) and VSIV-3 alagoas virus (VSAV). These viruses displayed similar genomic organization to VSIV field isolates, except that the nonstructural C'/C proteins, which were markedly conserved in all vesiculoviruses, were absent in VSAV. Phylogenetic analyzes consistently grouped COCV, VSAV, and VSIV in a monophyletic group distinct from VSNJV, supporting the classification of these viruses within the Indiana serogroup.
authors: Pauszek, S. J.;Allende, R.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Genetic and antigenic relationships of vesicular stomatitis viruses from South America
abstract: Vesicular stomatitis (VS) viruses have been classified into two serotypes: New Jersey (VSNJV) and Indiana (VSIV). Here we have characterized field isolates causing vesicular stomatitis in Brazil and Argentina over a 35-year period. Cluster analysis based on either serological relatedness as derived from virus neutralization and complement fixation assays or nucleotide sequences from two separate genes (phosphoprotein or glycoprotein) grouped the field isolates into two distinct monophyletic groups within the Indiana serogroup. One group included seven viruses from Brazil and Argentina that were serologically classified as Indiana-2 and Cocal virus (COCV). The other group contained three viruses from Brazil serologically classified as Indiana-3 and the prototype of this group, Alagoas virus (VSAV). Interestingly, two vesiculoviruses isolated from insects but which do not cause disease in animals, one from Brazil (Maraba virus; MARAV) and the other from Colombia (CoAr 171638), have been divided into two separate genetic lineages within the Indiana serotype. Our data support the classification of viruses causing clinical VS in livestock in Brazil and Argentina into two distinct groups: Indiana-2 (VSIV-2) and Indiana-3 (VSIV-3). We recommend using a nomenclature for these viruses that includes serotype, year and site of emergence, and affected host. This nomenclature is consistent with that currently used to describe field isolates of VSNJV or VSIV in the scientific literature. © 2011 Springer-Verlag (outside the US).
authors: Pauszek, S. J.;del Barrera, J. C.;Goldberg, T.;Allende, R.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is responsible for enterally transmitted acute hepatitis in humans with two distinct epidemiological patterns. Large waterborne epidemics affecting thousands of people have been observed in endemic areas, while sporadic cases have been described in non-endemic areas. Although contaminated water is well documented as a source of infection in endemic areas, the transmission pathways in non-endemic areas are much less known. HEV is a single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus classified in the family Hepeviridae with at least four known major genotypes (1-4) of mammalian HEV and one avian HEV. HEV is unique among known hepatitis viruses in that it has an animal reservoir. Unlike humans, pigs and other mammalian species infected with HEV generally remain asymptomatic, whereas chickens infected with avian HEV can develop a disease known as hepatitis splenomegaly syndrome. HEV genotypes 1 and 2 are found exclusively in humans, while genotypes 3 and 4 are found in both humans and other mammals. Several lines of evidence indicate that animal-to-human transmission occurs in some cases with HEV genotypes 3 and 4. In addition, people who have direct contact with animals are at a higher risk of HEV infection. Cross-species infections with HEV genotypes 3 and 4 have been demonstrated experimentally. However, not all sources of human infection have been identified to date, and in many cases the origin of HEV infection in humans is unknown. © INRA, Computational Sciences, 2010.
authors: Pavio, N.;Meng, X. J.;Renou, C.

title: A new subgroup of exogenous avian leukosis virus in chickens
abstract: A broad-host-range avian leukosis virus belonging to a novel chicken subgroup has been isolated from beef chicken lines. The virus, prototyped by the HPRS-103 strain, was of low oncogenicity in chickens but appeared to behave like an exogenous leukosis virus. Neutralizing antibodies to the virus were found in three out of five meat-type chicken lines, but not in seven-layer lines. The virus and its Rous sarcoma virus pseudotype did not replicate or transform in mammalian cells.
authors: Payne, L. N.;Brown, S. R.;Bumstead, N.;Howes, K.;Frazier, J. A.;Thouless, M. E.

title: Host range of Rous sarcoma virus pseudotype RSV (HPRS-103) in 12 avian species: support for a new envelope subgroup of avian retroviruses designated J
abstract: The host ranges of Rous sarcoma virus (RSV) pseudotype RSV(HPRS-103), a novel avian leukosis virus (ALV), strain HPRS-103, and representative RSV pseudotypes of subgroups A to F were determined in embryo fibroblasts of 12 bird species. Domestic fowl, red junglefowl, Sonnerat junglefowl and turkey were susceptible to infection by RSV (HPRS-103); Ring pheasant, Japanese green pheasant, golden pheasant, Japanese quail, guinea fowl, Peking duck, musk duck and goose were resistant. The host range pattern of RSV (HPRS-103) differs from that of subgroups A through G and I viruses and supports the placement of the HPRS-103 strain of ALV into a new envelope subgroup, designated J.
authors: Payne, L. N.;Howes, K.;Gillespie, A. M.;Smith, L. M.

title: Limited evidence for transhemispheric movement of avian influenza viruses among contemporary North American shorebird isolates
abstract: Migration routes of gulls, terns and shorebirds (Charadriiformes) are known to cross hemispheric boundaries and intersect with outbreak areas of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). Previous assessments of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) in species of this taxonomic order have provided some evidence of transhemispheric movement of viral genes. Specifically, to clarify the role of shorebird species in the transhemispheric movement of influenza viruses, to assess the temporal variation in Eurasian lineages previously observed in North American shorebirds, and to assess the need for continued sampling of these birds for HPAI in North America, we performed a phylogenetic analysis of >700 contemporary sequences isolated between 2000 and 2008. Evidence for transhemispheric rearrangement among North American wader LPAI gene segments was less (0.88%) than previous assessments and occurred only in eastern North American isolates. In addition, half of the reassortment events occurred in only two isolates. The unique phylogenetic placement of these specimens suggests secondary infection and/or involvement of other migratory species such as gulls. Eurasian lineages observed in North American shorebirds before the year 2000 have not been detected in contemporary samples, suggesting temporal variation in LPAI lineages.
authors: Pearce, J. M.;Ramey, A. M.;Ip, H. S.;Gill, R. E., Jr.

title: Viral recombination blurs taxonomic boundaries: studying single-stranded DNA viruses in a sewage treatment plant
abstract: Understanding the structure and dynamics of microbial communities, especially those of economic interest, is of paramount importance for maintaining healthy and efficient microbial communities on agricultural sites and large industrial crops, including bioprocessors. Sewage treatment plants are large bioprocessors that receive water from multiple sources and become reservoirs for the accumulation of many virus families that infect a wide range of hosts. To study this complex collection of viruses, full genomes of circular ssDNA viruses were isolated from a wastewater treatment plant using a combination of sucrose gradient sizing and rolling circle amplification and sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq. Single-stranded DNA viruses are among the least understood groups of microbial pathogens due to genomic biases and difficulties in cultivation, especially when compared to the larger, more commonly studied dsDNA viruses. However, the group contains several notable, well-studied examples, including agricultural pathogens that infect both livestock and crops (Circoviridae and Geminiviridae) and model organisms for genetic and evolutionary studies (Microviridae). Examination of the collected virus DNA provided evidence for 83 unique genotypic groupings that were genetically distinct from known virus types and showed great diversity within the community. In addition, although these genomes share similarities with known viral families such as Circoviridae, Geminiviridae, and Microviridae, many are so diverse that they may represent new taxonomic groups. This study demonstrated the effectiveness of the protocol in separating bacteria and large viruses from the targeted ssDNA viruses and the ability to use this protocol to obtain an in-depth analysis of the diversity within this group.
authors: Pearson, V. M.;Caudle, S. B.;Rokyta, D. R.

title: First demonstration of genetic and antigenic diversity in 1b BVDV isolates from Argentina
abstract: Bovine viral diarrheavirus (BVDV) infection in cattle results in a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations ranging from mild respiratory illness to fetal death and mucosal disease, depending on the virulence of the virus and the immune and reproductive status of the host. In this study, 30 Argentinian BVDV isolates were characterized by phylogenetic analysis. The isolates were genotyped based on comparison of the 5' untranslated region (5' UTR) and the E2 gene. In both pedigrees, 76% of the viruses were assigned to BVDV 1b, with BVDV 1a, 2a and 2b also being found. Eight of the BVDV 1b isolates were further characterized by cross-neutralization assays using guinea pig antisera and sera from cattle vaccinated with two different commercial vaccines. The results demonstrated the existence of marked antigenic diversity among Argentinian BVDV isolates and suggest the need to include BVDV 1b isolates in diagnostic strategies. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Pecora, A.;Malacari, D. A.;Ridpath, J. F.;Perez Aguirreburualde, M. S.;Combessies, G.;OdeÃ³n, A. C.;Romera, S. A.;Golemba, M. D.;Wigdorovitz, A.

title: Neuraminidase inhibition assay to identify influenza A virus neuraminidase subtype or neuraminidase antibody specificity
abstract: The neuraminidase inhibition (NI) test is a laboratory method for identifying the neuraminidase (NA) glycoprotein subtype in influenza viruses or the NA subtype specificity of antibodies to influenza viruses. A serological method for subtyping the NA glycoprotein is critical for the identification and classification of avian influenza (AI) viruses. The macro method was first described in 1961 by D. Aminoff et al. described. [2] and was later used by Van Deusen et al. modified to a microtiter plate method (micro-NI). [4]. The micro NI method reduces the amount of reagents required, allows for antigenic classification of many isolates simultaneously, and eliminates spectrophotometric interpretation of results. Although the macro NI has proven to be more sensitive than the micro NI, the micro NI test is very useful for testing sera for the presence of NA antibodies and has proven to be a convenient and rapid method for virus classification. This chapter provides an overview of the USDA-validated micro NI method for identifying subtype-specific NA in AIV and antibodies.
authors: Pedersen, J. C.

title: Phylogenetic relationships between virulent Newcastle disease virus isolates from the 2002–2003 outbreak in California and other recent outbreaks in North America
abstract: Isolates from the 2002-2003 outbreak of virulent Newcastle disease virus (v-NDV) in southern California, Nevada, Arizona and Texas in the United States were compared with recent v-NDV isolates from Mexico and Central America and reference birds Paramyxovirus -Type 1 strains. Nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes were performed on a 1,195 base genomic segment composed of the 3 inch region of the matrix (M) protein gene and a 5 inch portion of the fusion (F) protein gene including the intergenic MF region exists. This includes coding sequences for the M protein nuclear localization signal and the F protein cleavage activation site. A dibasic amino acid motif was present at the predicted F protein cleavage activation site in all v-NDVs, including isolates from California 2002-2003, Arizona, Nevada, Texas, Mexico and Central America. Phylogenetic analysis showed that viruses California 2002-2003, Arizona, Nevada and Texas were most closely related to isolates from Mexico and Central America. A Texas isolate obtained in 2003 appeared to represent a separate introduction of v-NDV into the United States, since this virus was even more closely related to the Mexico 2000 isolates than were the California, Arizona, and Nevada viruses. The close phylogenetic relationship between recent US v-NDV isolates from 2002-2003 and these viruses from countries near the United States warrants continuous surveillance of commercial and non-commercial poultry for early detection of highly virulent NDV.
authors: Pedersen, J. C.;Senne, D. A.;Woolcock, P. R.;Kinde, H.;King, D. J.;Wise, M. G.;Panigrahy, B.;Seal, B. S.

title: Emerging and re-emerging enterovirus diseases: from poliomyelitis to hand, foot and mouth disease
abstract: Several picornaviruses (Picornaviridae) are currently attracting interest without having to be 'emergent'. The parechovirus genus, validated 40 years after the discovery of the first two members ("echoviruses 22 and 23"), includes neurotropic viruses whose molecular diagnosis showed involvement in infant meningitis and neonatal sepsis, particularly type 3 respiratory infections - thanks the AH1N1pdm2009 influenza pandemic - showed that rhinoviruses can be involved in severe forms. The risk of poliomyelitis recurrence in Europe after an 11-year elimination period is a serious threat due to the spread of wild-type poliovirus in the Middle East and Africa due to conflict, population displacement and poverty. The current widespread epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease and/or enterovirus 71 meningitis infection with fatal encephalitis and cardiopulmonary failure are clear evidence of its occurrence in Southeast Asia. Although uncommon in Europe and less commonly implicated than coxsackieviruses A6 and A10 in hand, foot and mouth disease, EV71 poses a real risk for the future prevent occurrence/recurrence.
authors: Peigue-Lafeuille, H.;Mirand, A.;Archimbaud, C.;Bailly, J. L.;Henquell, C.

title: Co-circulation of avian H9N2 and contemporary "human" H3N2 influenza A viruses in pigs in southeast China: potential for genetic rearrangement?
abstract: Pigs are tolerant to both human and avian influenza viruses and have been suggested as intermediate hosts for the emergence of pandemic influenza viruses through reassortment or adaptation of avian viruses. Prospective virological surveillance performed in Hong Kong, SAR, People's Republic of China between March 1998 and June 2000 on pigs imported from Southeast China provides the first evidence of interspecies transmission of avian H9N2 viruses in pigs and documents their co-circulation with contemporary human ones H3N2 viruses (A/Sydney/5/97-like, Sydney97-like). All gene segments of porcine H9N2 viruses were closely related to viruses similar to chicken/Beijing/1/94 (H9N2), duck/Hong Kong/Y280/97 (H9N2) and the progeny of the latter virus lineage. Phylogenetic analyzes indicated that there had been repeated interspecies transmissions from the bird host to pigs. The Sydney97-like (H3N2) viruses isolated from pigs were closely related to contemporary human H3N2 viruses in all gene segments and had not undergone any genetic rearrangement. The co-circulation of avian H9N2 and human H3N2 viruses in swine provides an opportunity for genetic rearrangement leading to the emergence of viruses with pandemic potential.
authors: Peiris, J. S. M.;Guan, Y.;Markwell, D.;Ghose, P.;Webster, R. G.;Shortridge, K. F.

title: The origin of the novel avian influenza a (H7N9) and the mutational dynamics for its human-to-human transmissibility
abstract: In February 2013, H7N9 (A/H7N9/2013-China), a novel bird flu virus, broke out in eastern China, causing human deaths. Discovering its origin and when it becomes transmissible between humans is a global priority. We present here an interdisciplinary method to trace the origin of the H7N9 virus in China and to establish an evolutionary dynamics model for its human-to-human transmission through mutations. After comparing influenza viruses from China since 1983, we constructed an evolutionary phylogenetic tree of A/H7N9/2013 China virus and found that the human viral infections were avian in origin and coalesced into an independent lineage. Comparing hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) gene sequences of A/H7N9/2013 China virus with all human-to-human, avian and swine flu viruses in China over the past 30 years, we found that A/H7N9/ 2013 China viruses originated from Baer's Pochard H7N1 virus of Hu Nan province 2010 (HA gene, EPI: 370846, similarity with H7N9 is 95.5%) and duck influenza virus of Nanchang city 2000 (NA gene , EPI: 387555, similarity to H7N9 is 97%) by genetic rearrangement. Comparison of the HA and NA gene sequences showed that A/H7N9/2013 China virus was dissimilar to human-to-human influenza viruses. To simulate the evolutionary dynamics required for human-to-human transmission mutations of the H7N9 virus, we used the Markov model. The result of this calculation showed that the virus would acquire characteristics for human-to-human transmission in 11.3 years (95% confidence interval (CI): 11.2-11.3, HA gene). © 2014 Peng et al.
authors: Peng, J.;Yang, H.;Jiang, H.;Lin, Y. X.;Lu, C. D.;Xu, Y. W.;Zeng, J.

title: Whole genome analysis of thirteen TT virus variants, classified into fourth and fifth genetic groups, isolated from viremic infants
abstract: TT virus (TTV) DNA in serum samples obtained from 24 TTV-infected infants was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) with inverse primers derived from the untranslated region. The amplified PCR products were molecularly cloned; six clones each were analyzed. Seventy-six (53%) of the 144 TTV clones were classified into Group 4 (YONBAN isolates) and 22 (15%) into a new genetic group (Group 5). The TTV clones in group 4 were classified into 9 types and those in group 5 into 4 types. The entire nucleotide sequence of each representative clone from the 13 types was determined; they were 3570-3770 nucleotides long and had low homology to group 1-3 TTVs (TA278, PMV and SANBAN isolates). A phylogenetic tree based on the entire nucleotide sequence of open reading frame 1 confirmed the presence of five distinct clusters separated by a bootstrap value of 100%. Analysis of 13 TTV variants showed conservation of genomic organization and transcriptional profile in all TTV groups. TTV group 4 was detected in 54% and 72% of 7- to 12-month-old infants in Japan and China, respectively, which is comparable to that in adults in each country, indicating early and frequent acquisition of this TTV group in infancy.
authors: Peng, Y. H.;Nishizawa, T.;Takahashi, M.;Ishikawa, T.;Yoshikawa, A.;Okamoto, H.

title: Maedi Visna virus infection in sheep: a review
abstract: Maedi Visna virus (MVV) is classified as a lentivirus in the Retroviridae family. The MVV genome comprises three genes: gag, which encodes group-specific antigens; pol, which encodes reverse transcriptase, integrase, RNAse H, protease, and dUTPase, and env, the gene that encodes the surface glycoprotein responsible for receptor binding and entry of the virus into its host cell. Like other lentiviruses, the genome also contains genes for regulatory proteins, ie vif, rev and tat. The coding regions of the genome are flanked by long terminal repeats (LTRs), which play critical roles in viral genome replication and provide binding sites for cellular transcription factors. The target organs of MVV are, in descending order of importance, the lungs, mammary glands, joints and brain. In these organs, the virus replicates in mature macrophages and induces slowly progressive inflammatory lesions containing B and T lymphocytes. The clinical signs of MVV infection, ie dyspnea, weight loss, mastitis and arthritis, are related to the location of these lesions. Infection with MVV induces the formation of antibodies that can be detected by agar gel immunodiffusion, ELISA and the serum neutralization assay. With no antiviral treatment or vaccine available, diagnostic testing forms the backbone of most measures to prevent the spread of MVV. However, since today's serological assays still lack sensitivity and specificity, molecular biological methods are being developed that enable the detection of viruses in peripheral blood, milk and tissue samples. Future research must focus on both the development of new diagnostic tests and a better understanding of the pathogenesis of MVV infection.
authors: PÃ©pin, M.;Vitu, C.;Russo, P.;Mornex, J. F.;Peterhans, E.

title: Identification and molecular characterization of Orf virus in Argentina
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV) is the causative agent of contagious ecthyma (CE), a pustular dermatitis in sheep and goats. Outbreaks of ORFV have been observed in all geographical regions of the world, including Argentina. The origin and identity of Argentine ORFVs are unknown, and no comparative or phylogenetic studies of these viruses have been performed. In this study, we described the sequencing and analysis of five ORFV molecular markers: a partial B2L gene (ORF011), VIR (ORF020), a mature envelope protein (ORF109), vIL10 (ORF127), and GIF (ORF117) of two specific ones Argentine CE outbreaks.
authors: Peralta, A.;Robles, C.;MartÃ­nez, A.;Alvarez, L.;Valera, A.;Calamante, G.;KÃ¶nig, G. A.

title: Avian influenza virus isolated in wild aquatic birds in Argentina: Evidence of a possibly unique phylogenetic lineage in South America
abstract: Avian influenza (AI) viruses have been isolated sporadically in South America. The most recent reports come from an outbreak in commercial poultry in Chile in 2002 and its putative ancestor in a wild bird in Bolivia in 2001. Extensive surveillance of wild birds was carried out in Argentina between 2006 and 2007. Using RRT-PCR, 12 AI positive detections were made from cloacal swabs. One of these positive samples yielded an AI virus isolated from a wild kelp gull (Larus dominicanus) caught off the south Atlantic coast of Argentina. Further characterization by nucleotide sequencing shows that it belongs to the H13N9 subtype. Phylogenetic analysis of the 8 viral genes suggests that the 6 internal genes are related to the Chilean and Bolivian isolates. The analysis also suggests that a cluster of phylogenetically related AI viruses from South America may have evolved independently and with minimal gene sharing from influenza viruses at other latitudes. The data obtained from our investigations are valuable contributions to the study of AI viruses in South America. © 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Pereda, A. J.;Uhart, M.;Perez, A. A.;Zaccagnini, M. E.;La Sala, L.;Decarre, J.;Goijman, A.;Solari, L.;Suarez, R.;Craig, M. I.;Vagnozzi, A.;Rimondi, A.;KÃ¶nig, G.;Terrera, M. V.;Kaloghlian, A.;Song, H.;Sorrell, E. M.;Perez, D. R.

title: Isolation and complete genomic characterization of pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza viruses from Cuban swine herds
abstract: The emergence of the H1N1/2009 pandemic influenza virus poses a potential global threat to human and animal health. In this study, we performed pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza virus surveillance in pig herds in Cuba to determine whether the virus spread among pig populations circulated. As a result, we describe for the first time the detection of the pandemic influenza virus H1N1/2009 in pig herds in Cuba. In addition, phylogenetic analyzes and molecular characterizations of three viral isolates were performed. Phylogenetic relationships confirmed that all eight genes from the three isolates originate from the H1N1/2009 pandemic virus. The Cuban isolates formed an independent cluster within the pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza strains. Various molecular markers previously described in H1N1/2009 pandemic influenza viruses and associated with adaptive evolution, viral escape from the host immune response, virulence and dissemination were also present in H1N1/2009 isolates of the Cuban pandemic. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: PÃ©rez, L. J.;Perera, C. L.;Vega, A.;FrÃ­as, M. T.;Rouseaux, D.;Ganges, L.;NuÃ±ez, J. I.;DÃ­az de Arce, H.

title: Hepatitis E: An Emerging Disease
abstract: Infection with the hepatitis E virus is currently the most common cause of acute hepatitis and jaundice worldwide. According to WHO estimates, around two billion people, which corresponds to one third of the world's population, live in HEV-endemic areas and are therefore at risk of infection. In developed countries, the circulation of the virus has been confirmed in both human and animal (pig, wild boar, deer) sewage; However, the incidence rate is low compared to developing countries, where faecal-oral transmitted outbreaks of acute hepatitis originate, more often in the flood season or after natural disasters associated with poor sanitation conditions. There are currently 4 known genotypes of HEV. Genotypes 1 and 2 are isolated in all human epidemic outbreaks in developing countries, while genotypes 3 and 4 are isolated not only in humans but also in animals in both developing and developed countries. These data support genotypes 3 and 4 to be zoonotic in nature. The diagnosis of this disease is based on the detection of anti-HEV IgG and IgM in blood serum using enzyme-linked immunosorbent methods. However, the best confirmation of diagnosis is RT-PCR, which detects HEV RNA in blood serum and also provides the genotype. The clinical course is generally that of acute hepatitis, which in some cases may require hospitalization and may progress to chronic hepatitis in transplant recipients or HIV-infected people. In addition, the virus poses a significant risk to pregnant women. Hepatitis E can present with a wide spectrum of symptoms, from a subclinical case to a chronic liver disease with extrahepatic manifestations. For this reason, the diagnosis is demanding if no differential diagnosis is made. There is no specific antiviral drug for hepatitis E, but satisfactory results have been observed in some patients treated with pegylated interferon alfa2a and/or ribavirin.
authors: PÃ©rez-Gracia, M. T.;Suay, B.;Mateos-Lindemann, M. L.

title: The Y155H amino acid substitution in influenza A(H1N1)-pdm09 viruses does not confer a phenotype of reduced susceptibility to neuraminidase inhibitors
abstract: The Y155H amino acid substitution in the neuraminidase gene (NA) has previously been associated with greatly reduced inhibition by neuraminidase inhibitors in the seasonal H1N1 influenza A virus that was circulating in humans prior to the 2009 pandemic. During the 2012/13 epidemic season in Spain, two A(H1N1)-pdm09 viruses with the specific Y155H substitution in the NA were detected and isolated from two patients diagnosed with severe respiratory syndrome and pneumonia who were susceptible to exposure to the intensive care unit was required. In contrast to what was observed with the seasonal A(H1N1) viruses, none of the Y155H A(H1N1) pdm09 viruses described here showed a phenotype of reduced inhibition by NAIs, as determined by the neuraminidase enzyme inhibition assay (MUNANA) definitely. High-throughput sequencing of the NA of both Y155H viruses showed that they consisted of >99% H155 variants. We believe that this report may contribute to a better understanding of the biological significance of amino acid substitutions in the neuraminidase protein in terms of influenza virus susceptibility to neuraminidase inhibitors. This is of crucial importance for the optimal treatment of patients with influenza diseases.
authors: Perez-Sautu, U.;Pozo, F.;Cuesta, I.;Monzon, S.;Calderon, A.;Gonzalez, M.;Molinero, M.;Lopez-Miragaya, I.;Rey, S.;Canizares, A.;Rodriguez, G.;Gonzalez-Velasco, C.;Lackenby, A.;Casas, I.

title: Molecular characterization of the glycoprotein genes of H5N1 influenza A viruses isolated during the 2006 outbreaks in Israel and the Gaza Strip
abstract: Highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza A (AIV) viruses have caused outbreaks in domestic poultry and wild waterfowl in many Asian, European and African countries since 1997. In March 2006, an avian H5N1 influenza A virus was isolated from poultry in Israel. In the present study, we molecularly characterized the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of eleven H5N1 viruses isolated from domestic fowl in Israel and Gaza in March-April 2006. Viruses were closely related to viruses isolated in 2006 were isolated in Egypt. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Perk, S.;Banet-Noach, C.;Golender, N.;Simanov, L.;Rozenblut, E.;Nagar, S.;Pokamunski, S.;Pirak, M.;Tendler, Y.;GarcÃ­a, M.;Panshin, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin, neuraminidase, and nucleoprotein genes of H9N2 avian influenza viruses isolated during the 2000-2005 animal epidemic in Israel
abstract: The first two isolates of H9N2 influenza virus in Israel were collected from turkeys and chickens in May 2000. The real epizootic of the H9N2 virus started in December 2001, after a 1.5 year period of silence, and is still ongoing. In total, more than 500 turkeys and chickens were isolated during the outbreaks. The present study has revealed some genetic peculiarities among the local isolates, namely: All the isolates belong to the same G1-like phylogenetic lineage, within which they form a single group, which in turn is divided into three subgroups in the cases of the HA and NP genes and two subsets in the case of the NA gene. The results provide a basis to propose the existence of two parallel evolutionary trends originating from the same local "prototype" isolate. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Perk, S.;Golender, N.;Banet-Noach, C.;Shihmanter, E.;Pokamunsky, S.;Pirak, M.;Tendler, Y.;Lipkind, M.;Panshin, A.

title: Utilization and tropism of the henipavirus receptor
abstract: Nipah (NiV) and Hendra (HeV) viruses are the deadliest human pathogens within the Paramyxoviridae family, which includes human and animal pathogens of global biomedical importance. In humans, NiV and HeV infections cause respiratory and encephalitic diseases with high mortality rates. Henipaviruses (HNV) are the only paramyxoviruses classified as biosafety level 4 (BSL4) pathogens due to their extreme pathogenicity, potential for bioterrorism, and lack of approved vaccines and therapeutics. HNV use ephrin-B2 and ephrin-B3, highly conserved proteins, as viral entry receptors. This likely explains their unusually broad species tropism and also provides opportunities to study how receptor utilization, cellular tropism, and end-organ pathology are related to the pathobiology of HNV infection. The clinical and pathological manifestations of NiV and HeV virus infections are discussed in the chapters by Wong et al. and Geisbert et al. in this matter. Here we will discuss the biology of the HNV receptors and how receptor utilization is related to HNV cell tropism in vitro and in vivo. © 2012 Springer Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Pernet, O.;Wang, Y. E.;Lee, B.

title: Biological and phylogenetic characterization of the virulent Newcastle disease virus circulating in Mexico
abstract: In 2002-2003, outbreaks of velogenic Newcastle disease virus, closely related to the Mexican isolates, were confirmed in the United States (USA) in southern California, Arizona, Nevada and Texas. In this report, virulent NDVs isolated in Mexico between 1998 and 2006 were subjected to biological characterization using standard pathogenicity assays and phylogenetic analysis. Test results for mean time to death (MDT) of chick embryos ranged from 39.7 to 61.5 hours, and intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) values ranged from 1.59 to 1.94, compared to a possible maximum of 2.0. These isolates displayed a dibasic amino acid motif at the fusion protein cleavage site sequence required for host systemic replication. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that the Mexican virulent NDVs belong to the class II genotype V viruses and can be clearly divided into two groups as follows: isolates from 1998 to 2001 with close epidemiological relationship to the recent NDV outbreaks in the US and phylogenetically distinct viruses isolated from 2004 to 2006 that exhibited higher virulence. Assessing the evolution of viruses from Mexico and other neighboring countries will assist US surveillance efforts to early detect highly virulent NDV.
authors: Perozo, F.;Merino, R.;Afonso, C. L.;Villegas, P.;Calderon, N.

title: The antigen-specific cell-mediated immune response in mice is suppressed by infection with pathogenic lyssaviruses
abstract: The responsiveness of T cells (RTC) was examined in BALB/c mice infected intramuscularly with various lyssaviruses. After infection by this peripheral route, two types of viruses could be classified according to their effects: 1) pathogenic viruses, including the fixed rabies Pasteur virus (serotype 1) and wild viruses belonging to serotype 1 (from a rabid fox in France and from a cow infected by a vampire bat in Brazil) or serotype 5 (European bat Lyssavirus 1); and 2) non-pathogenic viruses, including Mocola virus (serotype 3). RTC was tested by analyzing in vitro the ability of spleen T cells from infected BALB/c mice to produce cytokines after antigenic (purified lyssavirus antigens) or polyclonal (concanavalin A) stimulation. Cytokine production was followed by examination of interleukin-2 biological activity and assays for interleukin-2, interleukin-4 and interferon-γ (IL2, IL4 and IFNγ) messenger RNAs (mRNA) by transcription into complementary DNA and amplification through the polymerase chain reaction. Initial production of biologically active IL2 and cytokine mRNA was observed in mice infected with pathogenic or non-pathogenic lyssaviruses. Only symptomatic mice (infected with pathogenic viruses) lost the ability to produce cytokines in vitro after antigen-specific stimulation. No such loss was observed after polyclonal stimulation. No loss was observed in mice peripherally infected with non-pathogenic viruses after stimulation with lyssavirus antigens. Thus, infection with pathogenic lyssaviruses peripherally in BALB/c mice induces a loss of T-cell responsiveness after antigen activation, but not after polyclonal activation.
authors: Perrin, P.;Tino De Franco, M.;Jallet, C.;Fouque, F.;Morgeaux, S.;Tordo, N.;Colle, J. H.

title: Conserved presence of G-quadruplex-forming sequences in the lentivirus long terminal repeat promoter
abstract: G-quadruplexes (G4s) are secondary structures of nucleic acids that epigenetically regulate cellular processes. In human immunodeficiency lentivirus 1 (HIV-1), dynamic G4s reside in the unique viral LTR promoter. The folding of HIV-1 LTR G4s inhibits viral transcription; Stabilization by G4 ligands enhances this effect. Cellular proteins modulate viral transcription by inducing/unfolding LTR G4s. We have here extended our investigation into the presence of LTR G4s to all lentiviruses. G4s in the 5'LTR-U3 region were fully conserved in primate lentiviruses. A G4 was also present in a bovine infecting lentivirus. All other non-primate lentiviruses showed evidence of less stable G4s. In primate lentiviruses, the ability to fold into G4s was highly conserved among strains. LTR-G4 sequences were very similar in phylogenetically related primate viruses, while becoming increasingly different in viruses that diverged early from a common ancestor. A strong correlation between primate lentivirus LTR G4s and Sp1/NFκB binding sites was found. All LTR G4s folded: their complexity was assessed by a polymerase stop assay. Our data support a role of the lentivirus 5'-LTR-G4 region as a control center of viral transcription, where folding/unfolding of G4s and multiple recruitment of factors based on both sequence and structure can occur.
authors: Perrone, R.;Lavezzo, E.;PalÃ¹, G.;Richter, S. N.

title: To compare and contrast genes and biological signaling pathways responsive to Marek's disease virus infection using allele-specific expression and differential expression in broilers and layers
abstract: Background: Marek's disease (MD) is a commercially important neoplastic disease of chickens caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV), a naturally occurring oncogenic alphaherpesvirus. Improving genetic resistance to MD is desirable to improve current vaccines and other interventions to combat MD. High-throughput sequencing was used to profile spleen transcriptomes from single F1 offspring infected with MDV at 4 days of age, from both outbred broiler (meat-type) and inbred layer (egg-type) chicken lines that were migrating differentiated in genetic MDV resistance. The resulting information was used to identify SNPs, genes, and biological signaling pathways that exhibit allele-specific expression (ASE) in response to MDV infection in each chicken species. In addition, we compared and contrasted the results of pathway analyzes (ASE and differential expression (DE)) between chicken types to provide information on the biological response to MDV infection. Results: With 7 high-performing individuals per line and treatment group, we identified 6,132 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 4,768 genes and 4,528 SNPs in 3,718 genes in broilers and layers, respectively, showing ASE in response to MDV infection. In addition, it was found that 548 and 434 genes showed DE in broilers and layers, respectively, after MDV infection. Comparing the datasets, only 72 SNPs and 850 genes for ASE and 20 genes for DE were shared between the two bird species. Although the chicken types used in this study were genetically distinct, at the signaling level, both TLR receptor and JAK/STAT signaling pathways were enriched and showed a high proportion of ASE genes, especially at the beginning of the two regulatory pathways mentioned above. Conclusions: RNA sequencing using adequate biological replicates is a powerful approach to identify with high fidelity SNPs, genes, and signaling pathways associated with the transcriptional response to MDV infection. In addition, the SNPs exhibiting ASE in response to MDV infection provide a strong basis for determining the extent to which variation in expression affects MD incidence and provide genetic markers for genomic selection. However, given the low overlap between ASE-SNP sets (broilers vs. layers), it is likely that separate screens will need to be integrated for each population. Finally, comparison of gene lists obtained between these two different chicken types shows that TLR and JAK/STAT signaling are conserved when responding to MDV infection and can be altered by selection of genes affecting ASE exhibit found at the beginning of each signaling pathway. © 2013 Perumbakkam et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Perumbakkam, S.;Muir, W. M.;Black-Pyrkosz, A.;Okimoto, R.;Cheng, H. H.

title: Outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease due to an exotic serotype A virus lineage (A/AFRICA/G-IV) in Algeria in 2017
abstract: This study describes the genetic characterization of serotype A viruses collected during outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in Algeria in 2017. These are the first reports of clinical cases due to this serotype in the country since 1977. One full genomic sequence (spanning 8,119 nucleotides) and three additional near full genomic sequences have been generated. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that these viruses were placed in the A/AFRICA/G-IV lineage, which is most closely related to viruses that circulated in Nigeria between 2009 and 2015. These unexpected findings motivate further studies to define the precise pathways this viral lineage is being introduced in North Africa to understand the risks of future disease outbreaks in the region.
authors: Pezzoni, G.;Bregoli, A.;Grazioli, S.;Barbieri, I.;Madani, H.;Omani, A.;Sadaoui, H.;Bouayed, N.;Wadsworth, J.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Knowles, N. J.;King, D. P.;Brocchi, E.

title: Natural reservoirs for hepatitis C virus homologues
abstract: The hepatitis C virus is recognized as a major public health problem, infecting 2 to 3% of the human population. Infection with hepatitis C virus causes acute and chronic liver disease, including chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. In fact, hepatitis C virus infection is the most common indication for liver transplantation, and a vaccine is not available. Hepatitis C virus exhibits narrow host species tropism and naturally infects only humans, although chimpanzees are also susceptible to experimental infection. To date, there is no evidence of an animal reservoir of viruses closely related to the hepatitis C virus, which may have crossed species barriers to cause disease in humans and led to the current pandemic. In fact, due to this limited host range, a robust immunocompetent small animal model is still lacking, hampering the mechanistic analysis of viral pathogenesis, immune control, and prophylactic vaccine development. Recently, several studies have discovered new viruses related to hepatitis C virus, belonging to the genera Hepacivirus and Pegivirus, in small wild mammals (rodents and bats) and domesticated animals that live in close contact with humans (dogs and horses). The genetic and biological characterization of these newly discovered hepatitis C virus-like viruses that infect various mammals will contribute to our understanding of the origins of the hepatitis C virus in humans and improve our ability to predict pathogenesis and immune responses using manageable animal models to investigate. In this review article, we begin with an introduction to the genetic diversity of the hepatitis C virus and then focus on the newly discovered viruses that are closely related to the hepatitis C virus. Finally, we discuss possible theories about the origin of this important human viral pathogen. © 2014 SSCC. All rights reserved.
authors: Pfaender, S.;Brown, R. J. P.;Pietschmann, T.;Steinmann, E.

title: A novel astrovirus associated with encephalitis and ganglionitis in domestic sheep
abstract: In June 2013, a 4-year-old Welsh Mountain ewe and in March 2014, a 10-day-old lamb of the same breed and flock presented progressive neurological symptoms including decreased sensorium, tremors and unusual behavior. Neuropathological examination of the brain and spinal cord revealed nonsuppurative polioencephalomyelitis and dorsal ganglionitis characteristic of a neurotrophic virus in both sheep. The metagenomic analysis of different tissue samples from both animals identified a novel ovine astrovirus (OvAstV). The presence of viral genome in the central nervous system was confirmed by RT-qPCR. Although the cases were nine months apart, the identified OvAstV shared nearly identical sequences, differing in only three nucleotide positions across the genome. The phylogenetic analysis revealed a close relationship of OvAstV with bovine neurotrophic astroviruses and an enteric OvAstV. In summary, these are the first reported cases of astrovirus infections in domestic sheep that have been associated with encephalitis and ganglionitis.
authors: Pfaff, F.;Schlottau, K.;Scholes, S.;Courtenay, A.;Hoffmann, B.;HÃ¶per, D.;Beer, M.

title: Porcine bocavirus infection associated with encephalomyelitis in a pig, Germany
authors: Pfankuche, V. M.;Bodewes, R.;Hahn, K.;Puff, C.;Beineke, A.;Habierski, A.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;BaumgÃ¤rtner, W.

title: The fecal vioma of South and Central American children with diarrhea contains small circular DNA viral genomes of unknown origin
abstract: Viral metagenomics of feces collected from 58 Peruvian children with unexplained diarrhea revealed multiple small circular ssDNA genomes. Two genomes related to sequences previously reported in the feces of chimpanzees and other mammals, and recently named smacoviruses, were characterized and then identified by PCR in 1.7% (1/58) and 19%, respectively ( 11/58) of the diarrhea samples. Another three genomes from a distinct small circular ssDNA virus group, tentatively named pecoviruses, encoded Cap and Rep proteins with <35% identity to those in related genomes reported in human, seal, pig, and dromedary camel feces became. Pecovirus DNA was detected in 15.5% (9/58), 5.9% (3/51), and 3% (3/100) of stool specimens from unexplained diarrhea in Peru, Nicaragua, and Chile, respectively. Feces containing these ssDNA genomes also contained known human enteric viral pathogens. The cellular origins of these circular ssDNA viruses, whether human cells, ingested plants, animals, or fungi, or residents of the gut microbiome, are currently unknown.
authors: Phan, T. G.;da Costa, A. C.;Del Valle Mendoza, J.;Bucardo-Rivera, F.;Nordgren, J.;O'Ryan, M.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: A new gyrovirus in human feces
abstract: novel gyrovirus genome found in the feces of an adult with diarrhea is described. The genome shows the three expected major ORFs encoding a structural protein (VP1), a nonstructural protein (VP2) and an apoptin protein (VP3), which have 41, 42 and 38% identities with those of the most closely related gyrovirus proteins shared. resp. Given the large divergence in its genome, this gyrovirus can be regarded as a prototype for a new virus species (GyV9) in the genus Gyrovirus. Since the closest relatives of this gyrovirus infect chickens, a possible dietary origin for the presence of this virus in human feces is debated.
authors: Phan, T. G.;da Costa, A. C.;Zhang, W.;Pothier, P.;Ambert-Balay, K.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Detection of a novel circovirus PCV3 in pigs with cardiac and multisystemic inflammation
abstract: Background: Porcine circovirus 2 causes various clinical syndromes that result in significant economic losses in the pork industry. Three pigs with unexplained cardiac and multiorgan inflammation that tested negative for PCV2 and other known swine pathogens were further analyzed. METHODS: Histology was used to identify microscopic lesions in multiple tissues. Metagenomics has been used to detect viral sequences in tissue homogenates. In situ hybridization has been used to detect viral RNA expression in cardiac tissue. Results: In all three cases, we characterized the genome of a new circovirus, which we named PCV3, with a replicase and capsid proteins that showed 55 and 35% identities to and even further from the genetically closest proteins of a bat faecal-associated circovirus removed were porcine circovirus 1 and 2. Common microscopic lesions included nonsuppurative myocarditis and/or cardiac arteriolitis. Viral mRNA was detected intralesionally in cardiac cells. Deep tissue sequencing also revealed the presence of porcine astrovirus 4 in all three animals, as well as isolated cases of rotavirus A, porcine cytomegalovirus, and porcine haemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus. Conclusion: The pathogenicity and molecular epidemiology of this new circovirus alone or in the context of co-infections warrant further investigation.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Giannitti, F.;Rossow, S.;Marthaler, D.;Knutson, T.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Resende, T.;Vannucci, F.;Delwart, E.

title: Sesavirus: Prototype of a new genus of parvovirus in sea lion feces
abstract: We describe the nearly complete genome of a highly divergent parvovirus, tentatively named Sesavirus, from the faeces of a California sea lion (Zalophus californianus) pup suffering from malnutrition and pneumonia. The 5,049 base long genome contained two major ORFs encoding a 553 amino acid nonstructural protein and a 965 amino acid structural protein, which have the closest amino acid identities of 25 and 25 cows, respectively. Given the low degree of similarity, Sesavirus could be considered a prototype for a new genus with a proposed name Marinoparvovirus in the subfamily Parvovirinae.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Gulland, F.;Simeone, C.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: The faecal viral flora of wild rodents
abstract: The frequent interactions of rodents with humans make them a common source of zoonotic infections. To obtain a first unbiased measure of viral diversity in the intestinal tract of wild rodents, we sequenced partially purified, randomly amplified viral RNA and DNA in the feces of 105 wild rodents (mouse, vole, and rat) collected in California and Virginia. We identified sequences of decreasing frequency related to the mammalian virus families Circoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Parvoviridae, Papillomaviridae, Adenoviridae and Coronaviridae. Seventeen small circular DNA genomes containing one or two replicase genes distantly related to the Circoviridae and representing several potentially novel virus families have been characterized. Two new candidate genera and a close genetic relative of the human pathogenic Aichi virus have been characterized in the Picornaviridae family. Fragments of the first murine sapelovirus and picobirnaviruses have been identified and the first murine astrovirus genome has been characterized. A mouse papillomavirus genome and fragments of a novel adenovirus and adenovirus-associated virus have also been sequenced. The second largest fraction of rodent fecal viromes was related to insect viruses in the families Densoviridae, Iridoviridae, Polydnaviridae, Dicistroviridae, Bromoviridae, and Virgaviridae, followed by plant virus-related sequences in the Nanoviridae, Geminiviridae, Phycodnaviridae, Secoviridae, Partitiviridae, Tymoviridae, Alphaflexiviridae, and Tombus -Families reflecting the mainly insect and plant diet of rodents. Phylogenetic analyzes of complete and partial viral genomes therefore revealed many previously unreported viral species, genera, and families. The close genetic similarities found between some rodent and human viruses may reflect previous zoonoses. This study advances our understanding of viral diversity in wild rodents and highlights the large number of yet uncharacterized viruses in mammals.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Kapusinszky, B.;Wang, C. L.;Rose, R. K.;Lipton, H. L.;Delwart, E. L.

title: A third species of gyrovirus in human feces
abstract: Until 2011, the genus Gyrovirus in the family Circoviridae consisted of a single virus (chicken anemia virus or CAV) that caused a common immunosuppressive illness in chickens, when a second gyrovirus (HGyV) was reported on the skin of 4% of healthy humans. HGyV is very closely related to a recently described chicken gyrovirus, AGV2, suggesting that they belong to the same virus species. During a viral metagenomic analysis of 100 human feces from children with diarrhea in Chile, we identified several known human pathogens (adenovirus, enterovirus, astrovirus, sapovirus, norovirus, parechovirus, and rotavirus) and a new gyrovirus species that we named GyV3 and the one Similarity of <63% shows other gyrovirus proteins with evidence of recombination with CAV in their UTR. Consensus PCR of Gyroviridae showed a high prevalence of CAV DNA in diarrhea and normal faeces from Chilean children and faeces from US cats and dogs, which may reflect consumption of CAV-infected/vaccinated chickens. Whether GyV3 can infect humans and/or chickens needs further study. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Li, L.;O'Ryan, M. G.;Cortes, H.;Mamani, N.;Bonkoungou, I. J. O.;Wang, C.;Leutenegger, C. M.;Delwart, E.

title: New astrovirus in human feces from Burkina Faso
abstract: Background: A significant proportion of cases of diarrhea, one of the leading causes of child mortality worldwide, remain unexplained. Objectives: Identify viruses in unexplained cases of diarrhea using an unbiased metagenomic approach. Study design: Viral nucleic acids were enriched from the faeces of 48 cases of unexplained diarrhea from Burkina Faso, sequenced and compared to all known viral genomes. Results: The entire genome of a highly divergent Astrovirus was sequenced in a sample co-infected with Parechovirus 1. RT-PCR identified a single Astrovirus infection in these 48 patients, indicating a low prevalence. Human astrovirus BF34 was most closely related to human Mamastrovirus species 8 and 9, with which it shared 62%, 74%, and 57% of amino acid identities via its protease, RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, and capsid proteins, respectively. Conclusions: The Burkina Faso astrovirus is proposed as a prototype for a new species in the genus Mamastrovirus, tentatively referred to herein as Mamastrovirus 20, representing the fifth human Astrovirus species. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Phan, T. G.;Nordgren, J.;Ouermi, D.;Simpore, J.;Nitiema, L. W.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Acute diarrhea in West African children: Diverse enteric viruses and a novel parvovirus genus
abstract: Parvoviruses cause a variety of mild to severe symptomatic or asymptomatic infections in humans and animals. During a viral metagenomic analysis of feces from children with acute diarrhea in Burkina Faso, we identified nucleic acids from anelloviruses, dependoviruses, sapoviruses, enteroviruses, bocaviruses, noroviruses, adenoviruses, parechoviruses, rotaviruses, cosavirus, astroviruses and hepatitis B virus in decreasing prevalence. Also detected was sequences from a highly divergent parvovirus, tentatively named bufavirus, whose NS1 and VP1 proteins shared <39% and <31% identities to those of previously known parvoviruses. Four percent of the stool samples were PCR positive for this new parvovirus, including a related bufavirus species that showed only 72% identity in VP1. The high degree of genetic divergence of these related genomes from those of other parvoviruses indicates the presence of a proposed new Parvoviridae genus containing at least two species. Studies of the tropism and pathogenicity of these new parvoviruses are facilitated by the availability of their genome sequences.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Vo, N. P.;Bonkoungou, I. J. O.;Kapoor, A.;Barro, N.;O'Ryan, M.;Kapusinszky, B.;Wang, C. L.;Delwart, E.

title: The viruses of wild pigeon droppings
abstract: Birds are common sources of emerging human infectious diseases. Virus particles were enriched from the faeces of 51 feral city pigeons (Columba livia) from Hong Kong and Hungary, their nucleic acids were randomly amplified and then sequenced. We identified sequences of known and new species from the virus families Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picornaviridae, Reoviridae, Adenovirus, Astroviridae and Caliciviridae (listed in decreasing number of reads), as well as plant and insect viruses likely derived from ingested foods. The nearly complete genome of a new species of a proposed parvovirus genus, tentatively named Aviparvovirus, contained an unusually long intermediate ORF that bears faint resemblance to an ORF of unknown function from an avian adenovirus. Picornaviruses found in both Asia and Europe, distantly related to turkey megrivirus and containing a highly divergent 2A1 region, have been termed mesiviruses. All eleven segments of a new rotavirus subgroup related to a chicken rotavirus in group G were sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. This study provides a first assessment of enteric virome in the faeces of pigeons, a feral urban species with frequent human contact. © 2013 Phan et al.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Vo, N. P.;Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Reuter, G.;Li, O. T. W.;Wang, C.;Deng, X.;Poon, L. L. M.;Delwart, E.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis of a novel canary circovirus and its relationship to other members of the genus Circovirus of the family Circoviridae
abstract: The circular, single-stranded DNA genome of a new canary circovirus, tentatively named canary circovirus (CaCV), has been cloned and sequenced. Sequence analysis showed that the genome was 1952 nucleotides (nt) in size and had the potential to encode three viral proteins including the putative capsid and replication-associated (Rep) proteins. The CaCV genome shared the greatest sequence similarity (58.3% nt identity) with the newly characterized columbid circovirus (CoCV) and was more distant with the two porcine circovirus strains PCV1 and PCV2, beak and feather disease virus (BFDV) and a recently isolated virus related goose circovirus (GCV) isolate (46.8-50.9% nt identity). As with other members of the circovirus genus, several nt structures and amino acid motifs have been identified on the putative viral strain that are thought to be involved in viral replication. Phylogenetic analysis of both the capsid and Rep protein coding regions provided further evidence that CaCV is more closely related to CoCV and BFDV and more distantly to GCV, PCV1 and PCV2.
authors: Phenix, K. V.;Weston, J. H.;Ypelaar, I.;Lavazza, A.;Smyth, J. A.;Todd, D.;Wilcox, G. E.;Raidal, S. R.

title: Wild bird's-eye view of the phylogenetic evolution of influenza virus A(H1N1).
abstract: Wild bird fecal samples collected and characterized by the USDA as part of a national surveillance effort were sequenced to examine the genetic relationships of the H1 and N1 subtypes of birds, pigs and humans. Our results indicate that the 2009 human H1N1 outbreak is closely related to swine virus but falls into different clades of the H1 and N1 trees. In addition, there is evidence of multiple viral genetic exchange between birds and pigs. Ongoing research across host species contributes to the understanding of the circulation of influenza viruses.
authors: Piaggio, A. J.;Clark, L.;Franklin, A. B.;Kolokotronis, S. O.

title: Complete genome sequence-based comparative study of wild-type and vaccine strains of infectious laryngotracheitis virus from Italy
abstract: Infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT) is an acute and highly contagious respiratory disease in chickens caused by an alphaherpesvirus, infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV). Complete genome sequences of wild-type and vaccine strains have recently been determined worldwide, but none originated in Europe. The aim of this study was to determine and analyze the complete genome sequences of five ILTV strains. The sequences were also compared to reveal strain similarity over time and to distinguish between wild-type and vaccine strains. Genomes of three ILTV field isolates from outbreaks that occurred in Italy in 1980, 2007 and 2011, and two commercial vaccines of chick embryo origin (CEO) were sequenced using 454 Life Sciences technology. Comparison with the Serva genome showed that 35 open reading frames (ORFs) differed across the five genomes. A total of 54 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and 27 amino acid differences in 19 ORFs and two insertions in the UL52 and ORFC genes were identified. The similarity between field strains and between field and seed strains ranged from 99.96% to 99.99%. The phylogenetic analysis also revealed a close relationship between them. This study provided data on genomic variation among Italian ILTV strains, showing that although genome genetic variability is well conserved over time and between wild-type and vaccine strains, some mutations help differentiate between them and possibly at the ILTV -Virulence involved /dampening. The results of this study may contribute to the understanding of the molecular basis of ILTV pathogenicity and provide genetic markers to distinguish between wild-type and vaccine strains.
authors: Piccirillo, A.;Lavezzo, E.;Niero, G.;Moreno, A.;Massi, P.;Franchin, E.;Toppo, S.;Salata, C.;PalÃ¹, G.

title: Evidence for a putative feline origin of sporadic G6P[9] rotaviruses in humans
abstract: Rotaviruses of species A are very diverse and have a significant impact on human and animal health. Transmission between livestock, companion animals, and humans is commonly observed, but the distribution of animal-like rotaviruses within the human population is limited. During ongoing surveillance of rotavirus strains in Germany, an unusual G6P[9] rotavirus strain was detected in a child's feces. The complete rotavirus coding sequences revealed a unique G6-P[9]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A3-N2-T3-E2-H3 genotype constellation. The virus was phylogenetically related to feline G3P[9] strains and other human G6P[9] rotaviruses presumably of zoonotic origin. Analysis of the primer binding sites of G6-specific genotyping provided further evidence for a feline G6P[9] reservoir. In addition, significant shortcomings of conventional semi-nested PCR genotyping approaches in detecting contemporary G6P[9] have been revealed. The GER29-14 rotavirus strain most likely resulted from direct or recent interspecies transmission from a cat to a human. Further studies could evaluate feline rotavirus nucleic acid sequences and genotype constellations to confirm the likely feline origin of sporadic human G6P[9] strains.
authors: Pietsch, C.;Liebert, U. G.

title: The low pathogenic avian influenza virus A/Turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1) is the precursor to the highly pathogenic A/Turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9)
abstract: The first confirmed outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) infection in North America was caused by A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9); However, the phylogeny of this virus is largely unknown. This study performed genomic sequence analysis of 11 avian influenza isolates from 1956 to 1979 for comparison to A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9). Phylogenetic and genetic analyzes have included these viruses in combination with all known complete genome sequences of avian viruses isolated before 1981. A low pathogenic avian influenza virus, A/turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1), was shown to have been isolated 3 months earlier and was the closest known genetic relative, with six genome segments of common ancestry encoding the polymerase subunits PB2, PB1 and PA encode nucleoprotein (NP), hemagglutinin (HA), and nonstructural (NS) proteins. The lineages of these genome segments included a resort with other North American turkeyviruses, all rooted in North American wild waterfowl, with the HA gene derived from the H5N2 serotype. The phylogenies showed adaptation of North American wildfowl to turkeys with possible involvement of native waterfowl. The turkey isolate A/turkey/Wisconsin/1968 (H5N9) was the second closest related avian isolate after A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9) and shared five common lineage genome segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA and neuraminidase). Virus A/turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1) was more virulent than A/turkey/Wisconsin/68 (H5N9) to chick embryos and mice, indicating greater biological similarity to A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 ( H5N9). Thus, A/turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1) has been identified as the closest known ancestral relative of HPAI A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9), which will serve as a useful reference virus for characterizing early genes and biological Properties associated with the occurrence of pathogenic avian influenza strains. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Ping, J.;Selman, M.;Tyler, S.;Forbes, N.;Keleta, L.;Brown, E. G.

title: Evaluation of a droplet digital polymerase chain reaction format for DNA copy number quantification
abstract: Droplet digital polymerase chain reaction (ddPCR) is a new technology that has recently been commercialized to enable accurate quantification of target nucleic acids in a sample. ddPCR measures absolute amounts by counting nucleic acid molecules encapsulated in discrete, volumetrically defined water-in-oil droplet partitions. This novel ddPCR format offers a simple workflow capable of generating a highly stable partition of DNA molecules. In this study, we evaluated the key performance parameters of the ddPCR system. A linear ddPCR response to DNA concentration was obtained from 0.16% to 99.6% saturation in a 20,000 droplet assay, corresponding to more than 4 orders of magnitude of target DNA copy number per ddPCR. Analysis of simplex and duplex assays targeting two different loci in the lambda DNA genome using the ddPCR platform agreed, within their expanded uncertainties, with values obtained using a microfluidic chamber-based digital PCR (cdPCR ) were obtained with lower density. Using ddPCR, a relative extended uncertainty below 5% was achieved for the copy number concentration. This level of uncertainty is much lower than the values typically observed for quantification of specific DNA target sequences using currently commercially available real-time and digital cdPCR technologies. © 2011 American Chemical Society.
authors: Pinheiro, L. B.;Coleman, V. A.;Hindson, C. M.;Herrmann, J.;Hindson, B. J.;Bhat, S.;Emslie, K. R.

title: Development of generic Taqman-PCR and RT-PCR assays for the detection of DNA and mRNA of β-actin coding sequences in a variety of animal species
abstract: As a member of the European Virus Archive (EVA) consortium, our laboratory develops and maintains a large collection of viruses. This collection implies the use of a panel of cell lines derived from different animal species. To facilitate handling of such a large panel of cell lines, broad-spectrum real-time PCR and RT-PCR assays were developed to allow detection and quantification of DNA and mRNA of β-actin, one of the most commonly used eukaryotic ones household genes. Using two degenerate primers and a unique probe, these two assays have been shown to detect nucleic acids from a range of vertebrate and invertebrate cell lines commonly used in animal virology. This panel included human, monkey, rodent, canine, porcine, fish, Batrachia, mosquito, and tick cell lines. Furthermore, the two assays successfully amplified β-actin coding sequences from sand flies. The sensitivity assessment performed on synthetic DNA and RNA sequences showed that the two assays were very sensitive and suitable for accurate quantification. The two assays together form a convenient method that is suitable for multiple purposes. For example, they can be used to estimate the amount of contaminating cellular genetic material prior to sequence-independent amplification of viral genomes, which is achieved prior to high-throughput sequencing, to assess the efficiency of DNase and/or RNase treatments performed on cell extracts, and to check nucleic acids, acid extraction using β-actin coding sequences as an endogenous control. This assay will provide a valuable tool for virologists working with multiple cell lines or animal models. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Piorkowski, G.;Baronti, C.;de Lamballerie, X.;de Fabritus, L.;Bichaud, L.;Pastorino, B. A.;Bessaud, M.

title: Transmission of pestivirus infection in a population of Pyrenean chamois
abstract: Outbreaks of a previously unknown disease have recently affected populations of the Pyrenean chamois (Rupicapra pyrenaica pyrenaica) across the mountains. A pestivirus has been hypothesized to be the cause of this emerging disease, and this type of virus can cross the species barrier and be transmitted to or from wild animals. We have characterized the virus and analyzed its transmission through an epidemiological survey carried out in Orlu, France, from 1995 to 2004. Phylogenetic analysis of viral sequences and virus neutralization tests showed that the virus belonged to the newly described border disease virus 4 group. The increase in seroprevalence with age showed that infection can occur at any age and resulted in lifelong immunity. A total of 70.3% of 323 specimens were positive for anti-p80 antibodies and 10.2% of 167 specimens demonstrated viraemia as determined by either a positive ELISA antigen test or RT-PCR. The infection has therefore been widespread in this population since 1995, with no mass mortality or clinical symptoms observed. Incidence and seroprevalence varied seasonally and with the number of individuals under 2 years of age in the population, so virus transmission was dependent on the age structure of the host population. We propose that the virus is now endemic in this population and is likely to be harmful to reproduction and hatchlings. Further research is needed to assess the impact of the pestivirus on host population dynamics and the risk of cross-transmission to farm animals. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Pioz, M.;Loison, A.;Gibert, P.;Dubray, D.;Menaut, P.;Le Tallec, B.;Artois, M.;Gilot-Fromont, E.

title: Influenza A viruses detected in pigs in southern Germany after the H1N1 pandemic in 2009
abstract: Influenza A virus (IAV) infections are widespread in swine populations and stable co-circulation of at least three lineages was well documented in European pigs – up until 2009. However, since the emergence of the human pandemic pdmH1N1 virus in 2009, the world's ( again) was introduced into individual pig herds, the situation has changed. These variations in the respective IAV pools within swine populations are of great interest and the zoonotic potential of putative emerging viruses needs to be assessed. Since data on recent IAV in pigs from southern Germany were relatively sparse, the aim of this study was to determine the main IAV subtypes actually occurring in this region. For this purpose, 1417 nasal swabs or lung tissue samples from pigs with respiratory diseases were examined for IAV genomes from 2010 to 2013. In total, IAV genomes were detected in 130 farms using real-time RT-PCR against the matrix protein gene. For further analysis, several PCR protocols were adapted to quickly subtype between H1, pdmH1, H3, N1 and N2 sequences. Taken together, the co-circulation of the three stable European IAV lines for Bavaria was confirmed. H1N1 sequences were diagnosed in 59, H1N2 genomes in only 14 and H3N2 in 9 of the analyzed farms. However, pdmH1 was detected in combination with N1 in 2010, 2012 and 2013, confirming the presence, albeit at low prevalence, of pdmH1N2 reassortant viruses as well. Interestingly, isolated cases of coinfection with more than one subtype have been diagnosed. Partial genome sequences were determined and phylogenetic analyzes were performed. In contrast to the human population, classically circulating IAVs were not displaced by pdmH1N1 in Bavarian pigs. However, some interesting viruses have been discovered. Further monitoring of these viruses in the Bavarian pig population will be of great importance to monitor future developments.
authors: Pippig, J.;Ritzmann, M.;BÃ¼ttner, M.;Neubauer-Juric, A.

title: Classification principles illustrated by the problem of virus classification
authors: Pirie, N. W.

title: High turnover leads to longer persistence of influenza in managed pig herds
abstract: Pigs have long been thought to play a central role in the emergence of novel human influenza A virus (IAV) strains by serving as mixing vessels for mammalian and avian variants. However, the key issue of viral persistence in swine populations at different scales is poorly understood. We close this gap using epidemiological models calibrated using seroprevalence data from Dutch fattening pigs to estimate the 'critical herd size' (CHS) for IAV persistence. We then examine the viral phylogenetic evidence for persistence by comparing human and porcine IAV. Models indicate a CHS of around 3000 pigs, above which influenza would likely persist, ie orders of magnitude lower than the persistence thresholds for IAV and other human acute viruses. At national and regional levels, we found much stronger empirical signatures of prolonged persistence of IAV in pigs compared to human populations. This remarkable persistence in small populations is driven by the high recruitment rate of susceptible piglets and has significant implications for pig management and for overall patterns of IAV genetic diversity.
authors: Pitzer, V. E.;Aguas, R.;Riley, S.;Loeffen, W. L. A.;Wood, J. L. N.;Grenfell, B. T.

title: Bioaerosol sampling for airborne respiratory viruses at a medical pig treatment pilot facility in Singapore
authors: Poh, M. K.;Ma, M.;Nguyen, T. T.;Su, Y. C. F.

title: Virus shepherds in a herd that has been vaccinated against bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) infection without prior testing for the presence of persistently infected animals
abstract: Introduction: Bovine viral diarrhea (BVD), caused by the bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV), is one of the most important cattle diseases worldwide. The aim of the study was to determine the BVDV infection status in a dairy herd vaccinated against BVD. Before vaccination began in 2008, there was no prior identification or removal of the possible source of infection (persistently infected animals). It was expected that vaccination itself would allow elimination of virus shepherds in the long term. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Serological screening for antibodies to BVDV with determination of antibody titers, BVDV antigen and presence of the viral genome with phylogenetic analysis of positive specimens in the flock was performed, although no clinical problems indicated the possible presence of BVDV infection. Results: 19 individuals persistently infected with BVDV were identified in calves and heifers, but not in adult cattle. All virus shepherds were antibody negative and the genotype of the virus isolated was BVDV-lb, indicating a single source of infection. The vaccine used in the herd consisted of the BVDV-Ia strain. In each of the stables tested, the antibody titers against BVDV-lb were higher than against BVDV-la (median values). Conclusion: Despite a long-term vaccination program and a relatively high sequence homology of vaccine and field strains of BVDV (83.6%), it was not possible to avoid transplacental infections of fetuses and the birth of persistently infected calves from vaccinated heifers despite protection from clinical disease was completed.
authors: Polak, M. P.;Antos, A.;Rola, J.;Zmudzinski, J. F.

title: Risk factors and molecular characterization of acute sporadic symptomatic hepatitis E virus infection in Thailand
abstract: Aim: To report clinical outcomes and viral genotypes of acute symptomatic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection in Thailand. METHODS: Forty patients with acute symptomatic HEV infection were recruited between 2009 and 2013. Clinical, demographic and laboratory data were collected. Diagnosis was made by detecting anti-HEV IgM and/or HEV RNA in serum or stool. HEV genotypes were classified by direct sequencing of RT-PCR products and phylogenetic analysis. Results: The high-risk group, consisting of immunocompromised patients with liver cirrhosis and very old (>80 years) patients (17 cases), had higher serum alkaline phosphatase values at presentation than the low-risk group. Two fatal cases resulted from acute hepatitis E in the high-risk group. The initial clinical presentation showed no statistically significant differences. In six cases (6/40) the virus could be detected in the serum or stool by means of RT-PCR and sequencing. On molecular characterization, the viruses were classified as HEV genotype 3f and were in the same cluster as Thai swine HEV. Conclusions: Our data showed that acute HEV infection has diverse clinical presentations and outcomes. Higher levels of serum alkaline phosphatase have been observed in high-risk patients. All viruses isolated were identified as HEV genotype 3f, possibly of porcine origin. © 2014 Hainan Medical College.
authors: Poovorawan, K.;Jitmitrapab, S.;Treeprasertsuk, S.;Thongmee, T.;Theamboonlers, A.;Tangkijvanich, P.;Komolmit, P.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Description of silent human virome with emphasis on giant viruses
authors: Popgeorgiev, N.;Temmam, S.;Raoult, D.;Desnues, C.

title: Molecular detection of hepatitis E virus in a wild boar population in eastern Romania
abstract: In industrialized countries, hepatitis E is a recognized zoonosis, with wild boar and pigs being the main reservoirs of the HEV-3 zoonotic genotype in Europe. Data on HEV infection in the wild boar population in Romania are limited to serological surveys. Therefore, our main goal was to determine the HEV prevalence in the wild boar population and to characterize the HEV strains circulating in Romania. Using the TaqMan real-time RT-PCR assay, we analyzed the presence of RNA-HEV in 45 liver samples and five spleen samples from 50 wild boar. Samples were collected during the 2013–2015 hunting season. Nine out of 50 samples tested positive for HEV RNA, resulting in an overall prevalence of 18%. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the isolates clustered into different monophyletic HEV-3 groups depending on the country of sampling. This is the first study to signal the presence of HEV in a wild boar population from Romania based on molecular analysis. Furthermore, in this study we report the detection of HEV in spleen tissue from wild boar.
authors: Porea, D.;Anita, A.;Demange, A.;Raileanu, C.;Oslobanu, L.;Anita, D.;Savuta, G.;Pavio, N.

title: The basis of arbovirus classification
abstract: The biologically defined group of arboviruses contains well over 300 separate viruses that have been divided into approximately 40 serological groups based on antigenic cross-reactivity. More than three quarters of all arboviruses can now be classified into one of the following five major taxonomic genera based on the basic characteristics of the virion: Alphavirus, Flavivirus, Orbivirus, Rhabdovirus, Bunyavirus. There are 20 alphaviruses representing serological group A and 57 flaviviruses in serological group B; both of these genera fall into the family Togaviridae. The 40 orbiviruses of the family Reoviridae include about 8 serological groups, and the 8 rhabdoviruses of the family Rhabdoviridae include another 3 groups. About 160 bunyaviruses, family Bunyaviridae, can be divided into 20 serological groups, 10 of which cross-react within the group in the Bunyamwera supergroup. One arbovirus contains DNA, namely African swine fever virus; this is classified as an iridovirus or icosahedral cytoplasmic deoxyvirus. Nodamura virus, which was classified as a picornavirus, needs to be reclassified based on evidence that it has a divided genome. A number of arboviruses remain taxonomically unclassified. The absence of arbovirus representatives in several major genera, such as the adenoviruses and the myxoviruses, is interesting.
authors: Porterfield, J. S.

title: Systemic virus distribution and host responses in the brain and gut of chickens infected with low-pathogenic and high-pathogenic avian influenza virus
abstract: Background: Avian influenza virus (AIV) is classified into two pathotypes, low pathogenic (LP) and high pathogenic (HP), based on virulence in chickens.
