Differences in pathogenicity between HPAIV and LPAIV could potentially be related to specific characteristics of strains and tissues, tropism and host responses. METHODS: To investigate differences in disease development between HPAIV and LPAIV, we examined the initial appearance and eventual load of viral RNA in multiple organs, as well as host responses in the brain and gut of chickens infected with two closely related H7N1 HPAIV or LPAIV strains were infected. Results: Both H7N1 HPAIV and LPAIV spread systemically in chickens after a combined intranasal/intratracheal inoculation. In the brain, large differences in host viral RNA load and gene expression were found between H7N1 HPAIV and LPAIV infected chickens. Brain cell culture studies using chick embryos showed that both HPAIV and LPAIV could infect cultured embryonic brain cells, but consistent with the lack of the necessary proteases, LPAIV replication was limited. In addition, the TUNEL assay only demonstrated apoptosis in the brains of HPAIV-infected chickens. In the gut, where endoproteases are available that cleave HA from LPAIV, we found minimal differences in the amount of viral RNA and a large overlap in transcription responses between HPAIV- and LPAIV-infected chickens. Interestingly, the brain and ileum differed markedly in the cellular pathways that were regulated during AI infection. Conclusions: Although both H7N1 HPAIV and LPAIV RNA have been detected in a wide range of tissues beyond the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract, our observations indicate that differences in pathogenicity and mortality between HPAIV and LPAIV are due to differences Vital organs such as the brain could be due to viral replication and resulting host responses.
authors: Post, J.;Burt, D. W.;Cornelissen, J. B. W. J.;Broks, V.;van Zoelen, D.;Peeters, B.;Rebel, J. M. J.

title: Classical swine fever virus isolates from Cuba form a novel subgenotype 1.4
abstract: The identification and classification of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) based on nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis has become an important tool to study the epidemiology and control of CSF disease. After phylogenetic analyzes of short sequences from the 5' untranslated region (150nt) and the E2 (190nt), most CSFV isolates from South and Central America were assigned to subgenotypes 1.1 and 1.3, while CSFV isolates from Cuba were assigned to subgenotype 1.2. Here we show that the determination and comparison of full-length E2 sequences and sequences encoding Npro, C, Erns, E1 and E2 (3361nt) do not support segregation of Cuban CSFV isolates to subgenotype 1.2. Indeed, our analysis showed that the Cuban isolates are more divergent from other previously known CSFV subgenotype 1 isolates, forming a new separate subgenotype to be termed subgenotype 1.4. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Postel, A.;Schmeiser, S.;Perera, C. L.;RodrÃ­guez, L. J. P.;Frias-Lepoureau, M. T.;Becher, P.

title: Viroma definition in the cerebrospinal fluid of patients with neurological complications after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
authors: Pou, C.;Barrientos-Somarribas, M.;Marin-Juan, S.

title: Cowpea mosaic virus: effects on host cell processes
abstract: SUMMARY Taxonomy: Cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV) is a type member of the Comoviridae and bears a strong resemblance to animal picornaviruses, both in gene organization and in the amino acid sequence of replication proteins. Little systematic work has been done to compare isolates of the virus from different parts of the world. Physical Properties: Purified virus preparations contain three centrifugal components; empty protein shells without RNA (T) and two nucleoprotein components (M and B) containing 24% and 34% RNA, respectively. The icosahedral particles have a diameter of 28 nm, consist of 60 copies of two envelope proteins and are heat-stable. Hosts: CPMV causes one of the most commonly reported viral diseases of cowpea (Vigna unguiculata), in which it produces chlorotic spots with diffuse borders in inoculated primary leaves. Trifoliate leaves develop a light yellow or light green mosaic of increasing severity in younger leaves. The host range is fairly limited and few hosts are known outside of the Leguminosae. The virus is transmitted by various beetles with biting mouthparts. Reported in Africa, the Philippines and Iran. Apparently absent in North and South America. Useful website: http://mmtsb.scripps.edu/viper/1cpmv.html (structure); http://image.fs.uidaho.edu/vide/descr254.htm (general information).
authors: Pouwels, J.;Carette, J. E.;Van Lent, J.;Wellink, J.

title: Development of an epitope-blocking ELISA for the universal detection of antibodies against human H5N1 influenza viruses
abstract: Background: Human infections with highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses have generally been confirmed by molecular amplification or culture-based methods. Serological surveillance has potential benefits that have not yet been realized because rapid and specific serological tests to detect H5N1 infection are not widely available. Methodology/Main Results: Here we describe an epitope-blocking ELISA for the detection of specific antibodies against H5N1 viruses in human or animal sera. The assay relies on a novel monoclonal antibody (5F8) that binds to an epitope spanning amino acid residues 274-281 (CNTKCQTP) in the HA1 region of H5-hemagglutinin. A database search analysis of publicly available sequences revealed that this epitope is conserved in 100% of the 163 H5N1 viruses isolated from humans. The sensitivity and specificity of the epitope-blocking ELISA for H5N1 were evaluated using chicken antisera against multiple virus clades and other influenza subtypes and serum samples from individuals naturally infected with H5N1 or seasonal influenza viruses. The epitope-blocking ELISA results were compared to those of hemagglutinin inhibition (HI) and microneutralization assays. Antibodies to H5N1 were readily detected in sera from immunized animals or convalescent humans by the epitope-blocking ELISA, while samples containing antibodies to other influenza subtypes gave negative results. The assay showed higher sensitivity and specificity compared to HI and microneutralization. Conclusions/Relevance: The epitope-blocking ELISA based on a unique 5F8 mAb enabled highly sensitive and 100% specific detection of antibodies against H5N1 influenza virus in human sera.
authors: Prabakaran, M.;Ho, H. T.;Prabhu, N.;Velumani, S.;Szyporta, M.;He, F.;Chan, K. P.;Chen, L. M.;Matsuoka, Y.;Donis, R. O.;Kwang, J.

title: New crane hepatitis B virus with an unexpectedly broad host range
abstract: All hepadnaviruses known to date have a very limited host range, restricted to their natural hosts and a few closely related species. This is believed to be mainly due to sequence variations in the large coat protein and species-specific differences in host components essential for virus replication. Here we report infection of cranes with a novel hepadnavirus, termed CHBV, which has an unexpectedly broad host range and is evolutionarily only distantly related to avihepadnaviruses of related hosts. Direct DNA sequencing of amplified CHBV DNA, as well as sequencing of cloned viral genomes, revealed that CHBV is most closely related to, although distinct from, Ross goose hepatitis B virus (RGHBV), and somewhat less closely related to duck hepatitis B virus (DHBV). . Phylogenetically, cranes are very distant from geese and ducks and are most closely related to herons and storks. Naturally occurring hepadnaviruses of the latter two species differ greatly in sequence from RGHBV and DHBV and do not or only slightly infect ducks. In contrast, CHBV from crane sera and recombinant CHBV produced from LMH cells infected primary duck hepatocytes almost as efficiently as DHBV. This is the first report of a fairly broad host range of an avihepadnavirus. Our data implicate either the use of similar or identical entry pathways and receptors by DHBV and CHBV, unusual host and viral adaptation mechanisms, or differential evolution of the host genomes and cellular components required for viral replication.
authors: Prassolov, A.;Hohenberg, H.;Kalinina, T.;Schneider, C.;Cova, L.;Krone, O.;FrÃ¶lich, K.;Will, H.;Sirma, H.

title: Genomic characterization of pestiviruses isolated from lambs and kids in southern Italy
abstract: nested polymerase chain reaction was used to identify 13 pestivirus strains isolated from small ruminants in several mixed flocks (sheep and goats) in southern Italy and for classification as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) type 1, BVDV type 2 and Border disease virus (BDV) genotypes. Of the nine sheep isolates, two were characterized as BVDV type 1 and seven as BVDV type 2. The four pestiviruses isolated from children belong to BVDV type 1. None of the pestivirus strains tested could be classified as “true” BDV (genotype 3). Although BVDV type 2 has been rarely described in Europe, the characterization of strain BD/90-1M as BVDV type 2, isolated in Italy in 1990, shows that this genotype has been circulating in Italy since the 1990s. © 2001 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Pratelli, A.;Martella, V.;Cirone, F.;Buonavoglia, D.;Elia, G.;Tempesta, M.;Buonavoglia, C.

title: Isolation and comparative study "in vitro" of five strains of contagious ecthyma in sheep
abstract: Five scab specimens from sheep bred in different countries clinically affected by contagious ecthyma revealed infectious agents that caused a cytopathic effect on primary cultures of lamb kidney cells. The 5 "in vitro" infectious agents showed similar stability properties in the presence of different physical and chemical agents. These properties relate to viruses of the poxvirus group and identify them as ecthymaviruses. The study of the 5 agents by serum neutralization made it possible to express quantitatively their respective kinship and dominance characters. Applying to these characteristics the proposed serological definition of strains, types and subtypes for foot-and-mouth disease viruses, it appears that 4 of the pathogens can be classified within the same antigenic subtype, while the 5th is very close to the other 4 , since it may be borderline classified as another subtype. The 5 active substances are very close to each other serologically, but their different dominance properties could be interesting when choosing one as a vaccine.
authors: Precausta, P.;Stellmann, C.

title: Host response to probiotics determined by nutritional status of rotavirus-infected neonatal mice
abstract: Aims: Beneficial microbes and probiotics are promising tools for prevention and treatment of enteric and diarrheal diseases in children; however, little is known about their in vivo mechanisms of action. We used a neonatal mouse model of rotavirus diarrhea to gain insight into how probiotics relieve acute gastroenteritis. Methods: Rotavirus-infected mice were treated with 1 of 2 strains of human-derived Lactobacillus reuteri. We assessed gut microbiome composition using 16S metagenome sequencing, enterocyte migration and proliferation using 5-bromo-2'-deoxyuridine, and antibody and cytokine levels using multiplex analysis of gut explant cultures. Results: Probiotics reduced diarrhea duration, improved gut histopathology, and increased gut microbiome richness and phylogenetic diversity. The extent to which probiotics reduced diarrhea was strain-specific and influenced by nutritional status. L reuteri DSM 17938 reduced the duration of diarrhea by 0, 1 and 2 days in underweight, normal weight and overweight puppies, respectively. The magnitude of reduction in diarrhea duration correlated with increased enterocyte proliferation and migration. ATCC PTA 6475 strain reduced diarrhea duration by 1 day in all mice without increasing enterocyte proliferation. Both probiotic strains decreased levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including macrophage inflammatory protein I alpha a and interleukin-I beta, in all animals and increased rotavirus-specific antibodies in all but the underweight animals. Body weight also influenced the host response to rotavirus in terms of diarrhea duration, enterocyte turnover, and antibody production. Conclusions: These data suggest that probiotic enhancement of enterocyte proliferation, villus repopulation and virus-specific antibodies may contribute to resolution of diarrhea and that nutritional status influences host response to beneficial microbes and pathogens.
authors: Preidis, G. A.;Saulnier, D. M.;Blutt, S. E.;Mistretta, T. A.;Riehle, K. P.;Major, A. M.;Venable, S. F.;Barrish, J. P.;Finegold, M. J.;Petrosino, J. F.;Guerrant, R. L.;Conner, M. E.;Versalovic, J.

title: Whole genome of a novel genotype 3 hepatitis E virus strain obtained from domestic pigs in Japan
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) causes acute or chronic hepatitis in humans and can be transmitted faecal-orally. Pigs are one of the main reservoirs for this infection. Sixty pigs aged 4 to 5 months in a herd in Japan had detectable anti-HEV IgG antibodies, and five (8.3%) of them had persistent infection with HEV genotype 3. Five HEV strains that obtained from the viremic pigs shared 98.8-100% nucleotide identity, and a representative strain (swHE1606845) whose entire genomic sequence was determined in this study differed by 14.1-19.6% from the reported HEV strains of subtypes 3a-3k and by 14.7-19.1% from other HEV genotype 3 strains whose subtypes have not yet been assigned. swHE1606845 showed a higher nucleotide p-spacing value of ≤0.143 in HEV strains of genotype 3 subtypes 3a-3k and ≤0.152 in other genotype 3 strains of unassigned subtypes. A SimPlot analysis revealed a lack of recombination events. These results indicate that swHE1606845 is a candidate member of a novel genotype 3 subtype. Further efforts to identify the swHE1606845-like new strain are warranted to clarify the origin of this strain and to determine the full nucleotide sequences of two additional swHE1606845-like strains for assignment of a new subtype.
authors: Primadharsini, P. P.;Miyake, M.;Kunita, S.;Nishizawa, T.;Takahashi, M.;Nagashima, S.;Tanggis;Ohnishi, H.;Kobayashi, T.;Nishiyama, T.;Jirintai, S.;Okamoto, H.

title: Viral taxonomy at the XIth International Congress of Virology, Sydney, Australia, 1999
authors: Pringle, C. R.

title: Diagnosis of EDS-76 infection by filter paper strip method
abstract: Egg drop syndrome - 7E5 (EDS - 76) virus is classified in group III of the genus Avisadenovirus in the family Adenoviridae. The virus is not closely related to other avian adenoviruses while it is closely related to bovine and ovine adenoviruses. The disease caused by EDS-76 virus is one of the major problems causing huge economic losses in the poultry industry. The hemagglutination inhibition (HI) test is recognized as a rapid, reliable, and economical diagnostic test for this disease. Nobuto (1967) and Brugh and Beard (1980) reported that blood can be absorbed and dried on filter paper strips without affecting antibody activity. Therefore, the present study was performed to evaluate the suitability of whole blood dried on filter paper strips for the quantitative determination of HI antibodies against the EDS-76 virus.
authors: Priya, P. M.;Nair, G. K.;Mini, M.;Jayaprakash, V.

title: Analysis of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) S1 gene reveals alterations in IBV gene groups circulating in southern Thailand
abstract: The new variants of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) cause a range of symptoms and cause economic losses to the poultry industry worldwide. We examined the S1 glycoprotein of 24 recent IBV isolates from chickens and showed that between 2008 and 2013 two predominant genetic groups circulating in southern Thailand, variants isolated from 2009 to 2013 were classified in QX-like group II. In addition, a single isolate from a broiler was categorized as Massachusetts type and an isolate from a layer belonged to type 4/91 virus. Interestingly, both IBV groups I and II were isolated from native chickens (62.5%) and caused a range of symptoms. Our results show that the QX-like viruses were predominant after 2009, replacing the THA001-type viruses. In addition, native chickens may contribute to the epidemiology of IB.
authors: Promkuntod, N.;Thongmee, S.;Yoidam, S.

title: Wild bird migration across the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau: A transmission route for the highly pathogenic H5N1
abstract: Background: Lake Qinghai in central China has been the focus of debate over whether wild birds play a role in the circulation of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus. In 2005, an unprecedented wildlife outbreak at Lake Qinghai killed more than 6,000 migratory birds, including over 3,000 bar-headed geese (Anser indicus). H5N1 subsequently spread to Europe and Africa and reappeared several times in the following years in wild birds along the migration route in Central Asia. METHODS/MAIN RESULTS: To better understand the potential involvement of wild birds in the spread of H5N1, we analyzed the movements of GPS satellite-tagged bar-headed geese at Lake Qinghai in relation to virus outbreaks and disease risk factors. We discovered a previously undocumented migratory trail between Qinghai Lake and the Lhasa Valley in Tibet, where 93% of the 29 geese tagged wintered. From 2003 to 2009, sixteen outbreaks in poultry or wild birds were confirmed in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and most were within geese migratory routes. The spatial and temporal correspondence between geese movements and three potential H5N1 virus sources (poultry farms, a captive striped-head goose facility, and H5N1 outbreak sites) indicated that there were numerous opportunities for viral spread and infection of migratory geese in the wintering grounds. Its potential as an H5N1 vector was supported by the rapid migratory movements of some geese and the genetic relatedness of the H5N1 virus isolated from geese in Tibet and Lake Qinghai. Conclusions/Importance: This is the first study to compare the phylogenetics of the virus with the spatial ecology of its host, and the combined results suggest that wild birds play a role in the spread of H5N1 in this region. However, the strength of the evidence would be enhanced with additional sequences from both poultry and wild birds in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, where H5N1 has a clear stronghold.
authors: Prosser, D. J.;Cui, P.;Takekawa, J. Y.;Tang, M.;Hou, Y.;Collins, B. M.;Yan, B.;Hill, N. J.;Li, T.;Li, Y.;Lei, F.;Guo, S.;Xing, Z.;He, Y.;Zhou, Y.;Douglas, D. C.;Perry, W. M.;Newman, S. H.

title: ICTV virus taxonomy profile: Hepeviridae
abstract: The Hepeviridae family includes enterally transmitted small non-enveloped positive-sense RNA viruses. It includes the genera Piscihepevirus, members of which infect fish, and Orthohepevirus, members of which infect mammals and birds. Members of the Orthohepevirus genus include hepatitis E virus, which is responsible for self-limiting acute hepatitis in humans and several mammalian species; in immunocompromised individuals, the infection can become chronic. Extrahepatic manifestations of Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuralgic amyotrophy, glomerulonephritis and pancreatitis have been described in humans. Avian hepatitis E virus causes hepatitis splenomegaly syndrome in chickens. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the taxonomy of the Hepeviridae, available at www.ictv.global/report/hepeviridae.
authors: Purdy, M. A.;Harrison, T. J.;Jameel, S.;Meng, X. J.;Okamoto, H.;Van Der Poel, W. H. M.;Smith, D. B.

title: Characterization of Marek's disease virus and phylogenetic analyzes of the meq gene from an outbreak in poultry in Meghalaya, north-eastern India
abstract: The aim of the present study was to characterize the virus from the lesions and histopathology of organs associated with mortality in Kuroiler birds (dual-use poultry variety developed and marketed by Keggfarms Pvt. Ltd, India) where Marek's disease is suspected. Among 1047 birds from two farms at different locations with 5.5 and 34% mortality, two types of lesions were observed at necropsy; Tumors in vital organs - liver, spleen, kidney, lung and ovaries and generalized small nodular tumor in abdominal cavity. Molecular characterization based on detection of the ICP4 gene demonstrated the presence of Marek's disease virus (MDV) from tissues and cell culture-adapted isolates in Madin Darby canine kidney cell lines. Histopathological examination revealed an infiltration of multinucleated immature lymphoid cells into the organs. Phylogenetic analysis of the isolates based on the meq gene showed that the isolates belong to the Cluster I genotype of MDV. This is the first time that MDV virus has been marked by an outbreak in a farmer's field poultry flock, affecting production in Meghalaya state in northeastern India.
authors: Puro, K. U.;Bhattacharjee, U.;Baruah, S.;Sen, A.;Das, S.;Ghatak, S.;Doley, S.;Sanjukta, R.;Shakuntala, I.

title: Genotype characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated from commercial chicken flocks in West Java, Indonesia
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is a highly contagious poultry disease worldwide caused by Newcastle disease virus (NDV). Despite vaccination, ND outbreaks have been regularly reported in Indonesia's commercial chicken flocks. Our study aimed to determine the genotype of isolates and genetic relatedness to other Indonesian NDVs published on GenBank. Four NDV isolates were recovered from vaccinated flocks in West Java, Indonesia in 2011, 2014, 2015. Two NDVs belong to the virulent strain and the other two belong to the avirulent strain. Phylogenetic analyzes of the F gene revealed that NDV/Ck/BGR/11 and NDV/Ck/GS/14 belong to subgenotypes (h) and (i) of genotype VII; while NDV/Ck/CJR/15 and NDV/Ck/BGR/15 belong to genotype II. The virulent NDVs were clustered in the same genotype and closely related to earlier Indonesian NDVs isolated in 2007, 2009 and 2010. The result of the current study showed that newer NDVs of subgenotype VIIh and VIIi circulating in commercial chicken farms in West Java, Indonesia show high similarity to NDVs isolated in Indonesia in 2007 and 2010. Our results may be valuable for future studies to develop improved control and diagnostic strategies of ND.
authors: Putri, D. D.;Handharyani, E.;Soejoedono, R. D.;Setiyono, A.;Mayasari, N. L. P. I.;Poetri, O. N.

title: The ecology and age structure of a highly pathogenic avian influenza virus outbreak in wild mute swans
abstract: The first UK outbreak of highly pathogenic (HP) H5N1 influenza in wild birds occurred in 2008 in a population of mute swans, which have been the subject of ornithological studies for decades. Here we use an innovative combination of ornithological, phylogenetic, and immunological approaches to study the ecology and age structure of HP H5N1 in nature. We screened swan and waterfowl samples by PCR and sequenced HP H5N1 positive samples. The origin of the outbreak was investigated by linking bird count data with molecular clock analysis of virus sequence samples. We used ringing records to reconstruct the age structure of onset mortality and we estimated the age distribution of past exposure to avian influenza. The onset mortality was low and all HP H5N1 positive mute swans in the affected population were < 3 years old. Only the youngest age groups contained a significant number of subjects with no detectable antibody responses to viral nucleoprotein. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the outbreak strain circulated locally for about a month before it was discovered, arriving when the immigration rate of migratory waterfowl was highest. Our data are consistent with the hypothesis that HP H5N1 plagues in wild swans have limited mortality due to the immune protection resulting from previous exposure. Our study population can provide a valuable resource for studying the natural ecology and epidemiology of avian influenza.
authors: Pybus, O. G.;Perrins, C. M.;Choudhury, B.;Manvell, R. J.;Nunez, A.;Schulenburg, B.;Sheldon, B. C.;Brown, I. H.

title: Molecular characterization of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated from raccoon dogs in China
abstract: Background: The highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 can infect a wide range of animals and poses a continuing threat to human and animal health. While many genotypes of the H5N1 virus can be found in chickens, few are associated with infecting mammals . Characterizing the genotypes of viral strains in animal populations is important to understand the distribution of different viral strains in different hosts. This also facilitates the monitoring and detection of possible emergence of highly pathogenic strains of specific genotypes from unknown hosts or hosts not previously reported to be carriers of these genotypes. METHODS/MAIN RESULTS: Two H5N1 isolates were obtained from lung samples from two raccoon dogs that had died of respiratory disease in China. Pathogenicity tests showed that the isolates were highly pathogenic for chickens. In order to characterize the genotypes of these viruses, their genomic sequences were determined and analyzed. The genetic contents of these isolates are virtually identical and they may have originated from the same progenitor virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the isolates were genetically closely related to the H5N1 genotype V virus, first isolated in China in 2003, and distinct from the dominant virus genotypes (eg, genotype Z) of recent years. The isolates also contain a polybasic amino acid motif at their HA cleavage sites and have an E residue at position 627 of the PB2 protein, similar to the avian viruses previously identified. Conclusions/Relevance: This is the first report that the H5N1 genotype V virus has been found to be associated with a mammalian host. Our results strongly suggest that genotype V H5N1 virus has the ability to cross species barriers to infect mammals. These results further underscore the risk that the H5N1 avian influenza virus poses to mammals and humans, who can be infected by specific genotypes not known to infect these hosts. © 2009 Qi et al.
authors: Qi, X.;Li, X.;Rider, P.;Fan, W.;Gu, H.;Xu, L.;Yang, Y.;Lu, S.;Wang, H.;Liu, F.

title: Genetic characterization of H1N1 swine influenza A viruses isolated in eastern China
abstract: Three influenza H1N1 viruses were isolated in 2005 from pigs with respiratory diseases on a farm in east China. The three isolates were characterized to determine their probable origin. Each of the eight genes in the isolates was most closely related to the corresponding gene in the classical swine H1N1 virus. In addition, phylogenetic analysis further confirmed that each of the eight genes in the isolates was closely related to the classical porcine H1N1 viruses, particularly those isolated in China. The HA1 proteins of the three isolates were identical to those of A/Swine/Guangdong/1/01, a virus isolated in China in 2001, although three nucleotide differences were observed. These results further support the concept that pigs may serve as a reservoir of genetically stable influenza viruses. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Qi, X.;Pang, B.;Lu, C. P.

title: MicroRNA expression profile of peripheral goat blood mononuclear cells in response to peste des petits ruminants virus infection
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV) belongs to the genus Morbillivirus and causes an acute and highly contagious disease in goats and sheep. Viral infection can trigger the alteration of the cellular microRNA (miRNA) expression profile, which plays an important post-transcriptional regulatory role in gene expression and can profoundly affect viral replication and pathogenesis. Here, we used deep sequencing technology to determine the cellular miRNA expression profile in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from goats infected with Nigeria 75/1 vaccine virus, a widely used vaccine strain for mass vaccination programs against Peste des petits ruminants . Expression analysis showed that PPRV infection can elicit 316 significantly differentially expressed (DE) miRNAs, including 103 known and 213 novel miRNA candidates, in infected PBMC at 24 hours post-infection (hpi) compared to a sham control. Target prediction and functional analysis of this DEmiRNA revealed significant enrichment for multiple signaling pathways including TLR signaling, PI3K-Akt, endocytosis, viral carcinogenesis, and JAK-STAT signaling. This study provides a valuable basis for further investigating the role of miRNA in PPRV replication and pathogenesis.
authors: Qi, X.;Wang, T.;Xue, Q.;Li, Z.;Yang, B.;Wang, J.

title: Identification of genes critical for resistance to West Nile virus infection using RNA-Seq analysis
abstract: West Nile Virus (WNV) is an emerging infection that gives rise to biodefense and there are no available treatments or vaccines. Here we used a high-throughput method based on a novel gene expression analysis, RNA-Seq, to give a global picture of differential gene expression by primary human macrophages from 10 healthy donors infected with WNV in vitro. From a total of 28 million reads per sample, we identified 1,514 transcripts that were differentially expressed after infection. Both predicted and novel gene changes were discovered, as were gene isoforms, and while many of the genes were expressed by all donors, some were unique. Degrading genes previously not known to be associated with WNV resistance identified their critical role in controlling viral infections. Our study distinguishes both common gene pathways and novel cellular responses. Such analyzes are valuable for translational studies of susceptible and resistant individuals—and for targeted therapeutics—in multiple biological settings. © 2013 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Qian, F.;Chung, L.;Zheng, W.;Bruno, V.;Alexander, R. P.;Wang, Z.;Wang, X.;Kurscheid, S.;Zhao, H.;Fikrig, E.;Gerstein, M.;Snyder, M.;Montgomery, R. R.

title: Molecular characterization of glycoprotein genes and phylogenetic analysis of two porcine paramyxoviruses isolated from the United States
abstract: Two porcine paramyxoviruses (SPMV)-(81-19252 (Texas-81) and 92-7783 (ISU-92)) were isolated from pigs with encephalitis in the United States in 1981 and 1992. Antigenic, morphological, and biological properties of these two viruses were essentially similar to members of the Paramyxoviridae family. Antigenic analysis by indirect fluorescent antibodies, immunoblot, and one-way cross-neutralization assays associated these viruses with bovine parainfluenza 3 (BPIV3) viruses. Purified virions were 50 in size -300 nm and morphologically indistinguishable from other paramyxoviruses. These two viruses hemagglutinated red blood cells and had neuraminidase activity intergenic trinucleotide regions similar to other Paramyxoviridae. The F gene of ISU-92 was longer than Texas-81 due to the insertion of a 24 nucleotide "U"-rich 3 untranslated gene region. Structure-based sequence alignment of glycoproteins of these two SPMVs showed that they are essentially similar in structure and function to parainfluenza viruses. The Texas-81 strain was closely related to the BPIV3 Shipping Fever (SF) strain at the nucleotide and amino acid level, while the ISU-92 strain was more closely related to the BPIV3 910N strain. The envelope glycoproteins of ISU-92 shared only about 92% and about 96% identity with the BPIV3-SF strain at the nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. The high sequence identities to BPIV3 indicated a cross-species infection in pigs. Phylogenetic analyzes based on both the F protein and the HN protein suggested the classification of these viruses into the subfamily Paramyxovirinae, genus Respirovirus and genotype A of BPIV3. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Qiao, D.;Janke, B. H.;Elankumaran, S.

title: Viral communities associated with respiratory diseases in pigs in intensive commercial farms in Sichuan Province, China
abstract: Porcine Respiratory Disease Complex (PRDC), a common piglet disease, causes significant economic losses in pig farming. To investigate the viral diversity associated with PRDC, viral communities in serum and nasal swabs from 26 PRDC-affected piglets were analyzed using metagenomics. Deep sequencing and de novo assembly identified 17 viruses in two pooled libraries (16 viruses from serum, nine from nasal swabs). Porcine circovirus (PCV)-2, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), and pseudorabies virus, all commonly associated with PRDC, were identified in the two pooled samples by metagenomics, but most viruses included small linear and circular ones DNAs (e.g. parvoviruses, bocaviruses and circoviruses). PCR was used to compare the detection rates of each virus in the serum samples from 36 PRDC-affected piglets with 38 clinically healthy controls with matched positions. The average virus category per sample was 6.81 for the PRDC-affected piglets and 4.09 for the controls. Single or co-infections with PCV-2 or PRRSV had very high detection rates in the PRDC-affected piglets. Interestingly, porcine parvovirus (PPV)-2, PPV-3, PPV-6 and torque tenosus virus 1a were significantly associated with PRDC. These results illustrate the complexity of viral communities in PRDC-affected piglets and highlight associated candidate viruses.
authors: Qin, S.;Ruan, W.;Yue, H.;Tang, C.;Zhou, K.;Zhang, B.

title: Full genome sequence of the first bluetongue virus serotype 21 (BTV-21) isolated from China: Evidence of genetic rearrangement between BTV-21 and bluetongue virus serotype 16 (BTV-16)
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is one of the most important insect-borne, non-contagious viral diseases of ruminants and can cause serious illness and death in sheep. Its causative agent, bluetongue virus (BTV), has a double-stranded RNA genome composed of 10 segments that offers field and vaccine strains of different serotypes the opportunity to reassort and infect the same animal at the same time. For the first time we report the complete genome sequence of a BTV serotype 21 (5149E) strain isolated in 2015 from sentinel cattle in Guangxi Province of China -6 from an isolate of BTV-16 originating in Japan. This study aims to provide more understanding about the origin and epidemiology of BTV.
authors: Qin, S.;Yang, H.;Zhang, Y.;Li, Z.;Lin, J.;Gao, L.;Liao, D.;Cao, Y.;Ren, P.;Li, H.;Wu, J.

title: A tick-borne segmented RNA virus contains genome segments derived from unsegmented viral ancestors
abstract: Although segmented and unsegmented RNA viruses are commonplace, the evolutionary links between these two very different forms of genome organization are unclear. We report the discovery and characterization of a tick-borne virus—Jingmen tick virus (JMTV)—that reveals an unexpected association between segmented and unsegmented RNA viruses. The JMTV genome comprises four segments, two of which are related to the nonstructural protein genes of the genus Flavivirus (family Flaviviridae), while the remaining segments are unique to this virus, have no known homologs and contain a number of features pointing to a structure indicate protein genes. Notably, the homology search revealed that JMTV-related sequences were present in the Toxocara canis (dog roundworm; Nematoda) cDNA library and that they shared strong sequence and structural similarities. Epidemiological studies showed that JMTV is widespread in tick populations across China, particularly in Rhipicephalus and Haemaphysalis spp., and that host switching and genomic reassortments occur frequently. To our knowledge, JMTV is the first example of a segmented RNA virus with a genome derived in part from unsegmented viral ancestors.
authors: Qin, X. C.;Shi, M.;Tian, J. H.;Lin, X. D.;Gao, D. Y.;He, J. R.;Wang, J. B.;Li, C. X.;Kang, Y. J.;Yu, B.;Zhou, D. J.;Xu, J.;Plyusnin, A.;Holmes, E. C.;Zhang, Y. Z.

title: Animal influenza virus subtyping using general multiplex RT-PCR and Liquichip high-throughput (GMPLex)
abstract: This study developed a multiplex RT-PCR integrated with Luminex technology to rapidly subtype multiple influenza viruses simultaneously. Primers and probes were designed to amplify the NS and M genes of influenza A viruses HA genes of subtypes H1, H3, H5, H7, H9 and the NA gene of subtypes N1 and N2. Universal superprimers were introduced to establish multiplex RT-PCR (GM RT-PCR). It involved three stages of RT-PCR amplification, and then the RT-PCR products were further tested with a LiquiChip probe, which was combined to yield a rapid, high-throughput influenza virus (IV) subtyping test, known as called GMPLex. The IV GMPLex High Throughput Rapid Subtyping Test has the following characteristics: High throughput, capable of subtyping 9 target genes in subtypes H1, H3, H5, H7, H9, N1 and N2 of influenza A virus to determine at the same time; fast, completing influenza subtyping within 6 hours; High specificity, ensuring the specificity of the different subtypes by using two nested degenerate primers and a probe, no cross-reaction between the subtypes, no non-specific reactions with other pathogens and high sensitivity. When used separately to detect the product of a single GM-RT-PCR for a single H5 or N1 gene, the GMPLex assay showed a sensitivity of 10-5 (= 280ELD50) for both assays and the Luminex qualitative ratio results were consistent 3.08 and 3.12, respectively. When used simultaneously to detect the product of GM-RT-PCR for H5N1 strain, both showed a sensitivity of 10-4 (=2800 ELD50). The GMPLex high-throughput rapid subtyping test can meet the needs of rapid influenza testing.
authors: Qin, Z. F.;Sun, J.;Lu, T. K.;Zeng, S. L.;Hua, Q. Y.;Ling, Q. Y.;Chen, S. K.;Lv, J. Q.;Zhang, C. H.;Cheng, B.;Ruan, Z. X.;Bi, Y. Z.;Giambrone, J. J.;Wu, H. Z.

title: Extensive transcriptome analyzes reveal competing endogenous RNA networks during avian leukosis virus subgroup J-induced tumorigenesis in chickens
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) is an avian oncogenic retrovirus that induces myeloid tumors and hemangiomas in chickens and causes severe economic losses in commercial layers and broilers. High-throughput sequencing followed by real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction and bioinformatic analyzes were performed to improve understanding of regulatory networks associated with differentially expressed noncoding RNAs and mRNAs that facilitate ALV-J infection. We examined the expression of mRNAs, long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs), and miRNAs in the spleens of 20-week-old chickens infected with ALV-J and uninfected chickens. We found that 1723 mRNAs, 7883 lncRNAs and 13 miRNAs were differentially expressed in the spleen between the uninfected and infected groups (P<0.05). Transcriptome analysis showed that chicken lncRNAs shared relatively fewer exon numbers and shorter transcripts compared to mRNA. Through competitive endogenous RNA and coexpression network analyses, we identified several tumor-associated or immune-related genes and lncRNAs. Among the transcripts whose expression levels decreased significantly in both ALV-J-infected spleen and tumor tissues, BCL11B showed the greatest change. These results suggest that BCL11B may be mechanistically involved in chick tumorigenesis and neoplastic disease, related to the immune response, and potentially be a novel biomarker for ALV-J infection. Our results provide new insights into the pathology of ALV-J infection and a high-quality transcriptome resource for an in-depth study of epigenetic influences on disease resistance and the immune system.
authors: Qiu, L.;Chang, G.;Li, Z.;Bi, Y.;Liu, X.;Chen, G.

title: Discovery of novel long noncoding RNAs induced by avian leukosis virus subgroup J infection in chickens
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) is an avian oncogenic retrovirus that has caused severe economic losses in the poultry industry in China in recent decades. Here, a set of 4804 novel long non-coding transcripts and numerous differentially expressed long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) were identified using high-throughput transcriptome sequencing of HD11 and CEF cells infected with ALV-J. We also found that they share relatively shorter transcripts and fewer exon numbers compared to mRNA. Correlation analyzes suggested that many lncRNAs could activate gene expression in ways other than transcriptional regulation in an enhancer-like manner. In vivo analyzes of the expression level showed that three lncRNAs (NOGGAT001975.2, NOGGAT005832.2 and NOGGAT009792.2) are potentially related to the regulation of the immune response and could act as novel biomarkers for ALV-J infection. Our results provide new insights into the pathological process of ALV-J infection and should serve as a valuable resource for further research into epigenetic influences on disease resistance breeding, as well as for immune system and genomic studies.
authors: Qiu, L.;Li, Z.;Chang, G.;Bi, Y.;Liu, X.;Xu, L.;Zhang, Y.;Zhao, W.;Xu, Q.;Chen, G.

title: Detection of viromas of RNA viruses using next-generation sequencing libraries created with three methods
abstract: Virome detection (viral megagenomics) using next-generation sequencing is widely used in virology, but its methods remain complicated and need to be optimized. In this study, we detected the viromes of RNA viruses from a mock sample, a pooled duck feces sample, and a pooled mink feces sample on the Personal Genome Machine platform using the sequencing libraries created by three methods. The sequencing primers were generated by random hybridization and ligation to fragmented viral RNA using an RNA-Seq kit in Method 1, by random reverse transcription (RT) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in Method 2 developed in our laboratory, and by added hybridization and ligation to fragmented amplicons of random RT-PCR using a single primer in Method 3. Although the results of these three samples (nine libraries) all showed that more classified virus families and genera were identified using Methods 2 and 3 than with method 1, and more classified viral families and genera were identified with method 2 than with method 3, most of the differences were not statistically significant. In addition, this study identified 11 mammalian viral genera in mink, possibly for the first time.
authors: Qiu, Y.;Chen, J. M.;Wang, T.;Hou, G. Y.;Zhuang, Q. Y.;Wu, R.;Wang, K. C.

title: Evolutionary genomics of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza viruses (pH1N 1v)
abstract: Background: In April 2009, a new strain of the human H1N1 influenza A virus broke out, causing a worldwide pandemic. The present study attempts to estimate a temporal rearrangement history of the 2009 H1N1 viruses by phylogenetic analysis based on a total of 394 sequences of H1N1 viruses isolated from swine, human and avian. Results: Phylogenetic trees of eight gene segments showed that human-derived viruses formed a well-supported clade, while porcine and avian lineages were intermixed. A new divergent porcine sublineage containing gene segments from 2009 H1N1 viruses was characterized that was closely related to porcine viruses expressed in six segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP, and NS) between 2004 and 2007 in the USA and South Korea versus swine viruses isolated in NA and M from Thailand between 2004 and 2005. The substitution rates varied drastically between eight segments, and the mean substitution rate was generally higher for H1N1 2009 than for porcine and human viruses (F 2.23 = 5.972, P<0.01). Similarly, higher dN/dS substitution ratios were identified in 2009 H1N1 than in porcine and human viruses with the exception of the M2 gene (F2, 25 = 3.779, P<0.05). The 2009 H1N1 viruses were estimated to be around 0.1 to 0.5 years old, while their common ancestors with the most closely related swine viruses existed between 9.3 and 17.37 years. Conclusion: Our results implied that at least four reassortments or transmissions likely occurred prior to 2009 H1N1 viruses. A first rearrangement occurred in 1976, and bird-like Eurasian swine viruses emerged. The second transmission took place in Asia and North America between 1988 and 1992 and mainly affected six segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP and NS). The third reassortment occurred between North American swine and avian viruses between 1998 and 2000, involving PB2 and PA segments. In 2004-2005 reassortments from birds to swine, Eurasian and classical swine viruses occurred. South Korea, Thailand and the US were identified as locations where reassortments were most likely to have taken place. The co-circulation of several sublineages of pigs and the specific lifestyle in Asia may have facilitated the mixing of different influenza viruses, leading to the creation of a new virus strain. © 2011 Qu et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Qu, Y.;Zhang, R.;Cui, P.;Song, G.;Duan, Z.;Lei, F.

title: The complex microbiota of raw milk
abstract: Here we review what is known about the microorganisms present in raw milk, including milk from cows, sheep, goats and humans. Milk can support a rich microbiota due to its high nutrient content. These microorganisms enter milk from a variety of sources and once in milk can play a number of roles such as: B. Facilitate milk fermentation (e.g. Lactococcus, Lactobacillus, Streptococcus, Propionibacterium and fungal populations), cause spoilage (e.g. Pseudomonas, Clostridium, Bacillus). and other spore-forming or thermoduric microorganisms), health-promoting (e.g. lactobacilli and bifidobacteria) or pathogenic (e.g. listeria, salmonella, Escherichia coli, campylobacter and mycotoxin-producing fungi). There is also concern that the presence of antibiotic residues in milk will lead to the development of resistance, particularly in pathogenic bacteria. Here we discuss these issues comprehensively and compare the approaches, both culture-dependent and culture-independent, that can be used to study the microbial composition of milk. © 2013 Federation of European Microbiological Societies.
authors: Quigley, L.;O'Sullivan, O.;Stanton, C.;Beresford, T. P.;Ross, R. P.;Fitzgerald, G. F.;Cotter, P. D.

title: A direct high-throughput in-cell ELISA to measure the infectivity of cytopathic and non-cytopathic bovine viral diarrhea virus strains to determine antiviral activity
abstract: Screening of antiviral compounds against multiple field strains requires low-cost, high-throughput methods applicable to any virus strain. For this purpose, colorimetric cell viability assays are used as long as the viruses are cytopathic (CP) in the cell culture. However, the Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) strains circulating in the field are mostly non-cytopathic (NCP). An in-cell ELISA to measure viral infectivity by detecting a conserved protein produced during viral replication (non-structural protein 3, "NS3") was developed. The ELISA is performed directly on the 96-well culture plate without harvesting the cells. NS3 In Cell-ELISA was tested for its ability to assess the BVDV-specific antiviral activity of bovine type I and III recombinant IFNs. The results correlated with those measured by qRT-PCR and virus titration. The NS3 in-cell ELISA was also efficient in estimating the IC50 of two compounds with different antiviral activity. Estimation of the 50% inhibitory dose of each IFN using six BVDV strains of different biotype and genotype showed that CP strains were more susceptible to both IFNs than NCP, while NCP type 2 viruses were more sensitive to IFN-I. The in cell ELISA format using a detector antibody against a conserved nonstructural protein can potentially be applied to accurately measure the infectivity of any virus strain.
authors: Quintana, M. E.;Barone, L.;Forlenza, M. B.;Trotta, M. V.;Turco, C.;Mansilla, F. C.;Cardoso, N. P.;Capozzo, A. V.

title: Genome dynamics and molecular epidemiology of infection of multidrug-resistant Helicobacter pullorum isolates from broiler and free-range chickens in India
abstract: Some life-threatening, foodborne, and zoonotic infections are transmitted by poultry birds. Inappropriate and indiscriminate use of antimicrobials in livestock farming has led to an increased prevalence of multidrug-resistant bacteria with epidemic potential. Here we present a functional molecular epidemiological analysis involving the phenotypic and sequence-based characterization of the whole genome of 11 H. pullorum isolates from broiler and free-range chickens collected from retail wet markets in Hyderabad City, India. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing demonstrated that all isolates were resistant to multiple classes of antibiotics including fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins, sulfonamides and macrolides. The isolates were also shown to be extended spectrum β-lactamase producers and even resistant to clavulanic acid. Whole genome sequencing and comparative genomic analysis of these isolates revealed the presence of five or six well-characterized antimicrobial resistance genes, including those encoding one or more resistance nodular division efflux pumps. Phylogenetic analysis combined with pangenomic analysis revealed a remarkable level of genetic diversity among free-range chicken isolates; in contrast, a high level of genetic similarity was observed in broiler isolates. Comparative genomic analyzes of all publicly available H. pullorum genomes, including our isolates (n=16), together with the genomes of 17 other Helicobacter species, revealed a large number (8,560) of H. pullorum-specific protein-coding genes, with an average of 535 such genes per isolate. The in silico virulence screen identified 182 important virulence genes and also demonstrated high strain-specific gene content in isolates from free-range chickens (average 34) compared to broiler isolates. A significant prevalence of prophages (ranging from 1 to 9) and a significant presence of genomic islands (0 to 4) were observed in free range and broiler isolates. Taken together, these observations provide significant baseline data for the functional molecular epidemiology of infection of non-pyloric Helicobacter species such as H. pullorum, unraveling their evolution in chickens and their possible zoonotic transmission to humans. IMPORTANT: The poultry industry is expanding worldwide with an ever-growing consumer base for chicken meat. Against this background, the foodborne transmission of multidrug-resistant bacteria is an important public health issue. Our study includes a critical baseline approach aimed at the genome sequence-based epidemiology and transmission dynamics of H. pullorum, an avian pathogen with proven zoonotic potential. We believe our studies would facilitate the development of surveillance systems that would ensure food safety for humans and guide public health policy regarding the use of antibiotics in animal feed in countries like India. In this study, we sequenced 11 novel H. pullorum genomes. These genomes would be of great value in addition to ongoing comparative genomic studies of Helicobacter.
authors: Qumar, S.;Majid, M.;Kumar, N.;Tiwari, S. K.;Semmler, T.;Devi, S.;Baddam, R.;Hussain, A.;Shaik, S.;Ahmed, N.

title: Identification of bovine papillomavirus 10 in bovine teat warts by DNase-SISPA
abstract: Papillomaviruses are detected and identified by PCR using consensus primers designed from human papillomavirus sequences. These and other primers failed to detect papillomavirus in bovine teat wart specimens despite repeated attempts. DNase-SISPA, a metagenomic virus identification method, was able to identify bovine papillomavirus type 10 in bovine teat nipples. Sequence comparison between consensus primers and bovine papillomavirus type 10 sequences revealed many differences between consensus primers and BPV-10 sequences. We propose that DNase-SISPA can be used as an alternative method for papillomavirus diagnosis when PCR does not identify papillomaviruses. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Rai, G. K.;Saxena, M.;Singh, V.;Somvanshi, R.;Sharma, B.

title: Overview of psittacine beak and feather disease and its impact on endangered Australian species
abstract: BACKGROUND: Parrot beak and feather disease (PBFD) has been recognized as the dominant viral pathogen of parrot birds in Australia since it was first described in the early 1980s. Our aim was to assess and verify the impact of PBFD and its position as a critical threat process for Australian parrot bird species. We investigate the origin/evolutionary pathways and potential threat of PBFD to vulnerable populations of parrotbirds and captive-bred flocks. CONCLUSIONS: Recent phylogenetic analyzes of beak and feather disease virus (BFDV) indicate that all endangered Australian parrotbird species are susceptible to and equally likely to be infected by BFDV genotypes from a range of host parrot species. Management of the disease in captive breeding programs has relied on testing and culling, which has proven costly. The risk of PBFD should be very carefully considered by management teams considering establishing breeding stocks for endangered species. Alternative disease prevention tools, including vaccination, which are increasingly used in wildlife health, should be considered more seriously to manage and prevent PBFD in captive flocks of critically endangered species.
authors: Raidal, S. R.;Sarker, S.;Peters, A.

title: Functional characterization of a novel holin-like antibacterial protein encoding the tmp1 gene from the goat skin surface metagenome
abstract: We have identified a holin-like gene from a goat skin surface metagenome. The ORF designated tmp1, which encodes 34 amino acids that share sequence similarity with putative holin-like toxin genes. To analyze the antibacterial activity of the tmp1-encoded protein, this ORF was cloned and expressed in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3). The expressed gene product Tmp1 showed antibacterial activity against gram-positive bacteria but not against gram-negative bacteria. A single transmembrane domain (TMD) was identified within Tmp1, and deletion analysis of the N-terminal region and TMD revealed that TMD is responsible for antibacterial activity. TMD-dependent antibacterial activity was validated using a synthetic peptide with the amino acid sequence of TMD. Besides antibacterial activity, Tmp1 also complemented the function of holin in a lysis-defective bacteriophage lambda. To expand the spectrum of antibacterial activity, a mutant library of tmp1 was generated by random mutagenesis. Four mutants with amino acid substitutions at the N-terminus of Tmp1 showed increased antibacterial activity against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria and were not hemolytic. Enhanced activity of these mutant proteins is attributed to their increased hydrophobicity. © 2011 Springer Verlag.
authors: Rajesh, T.;Anthony, T.;Saranya, S.;Pushpam, P. L.;Gunasekaran, P.

title: Sequence Analysis of Infectious Bursal Disease Virus Isolates from India: Phylogenetic Relationships
abstract: The prevalence of Infectious Bursial Disease (IBD) in chickens in different parts of Tamil Nadu, India was studied by taking bursial samples from suspected flocks and performing reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) to amplify a specific product out of 474 bp from the variable region of the VP2 gene. Of 53 bursa samples examined by RT-PCR, 40 showed a positive reaction. The amplified products were subjected to nucleotide sequencing and the sequences obtained were compared to those of the Georgia IBD virus (IBDV) vaccine strain, the classical virulent strain 52/70 and the very virulent Japanese OKYM strain. Nucleotide homology data showed that all of the isolates from Tamil Nadu showed a range of 91 to 99.6% homology among themselves. Four isolates clustered with this strain compared to the very virulent Japanese OKYM strain. The majority of the isolates clustered with the very virulent OKYM strain as indicated by the phylogenetic analysis performed using the MEGA program. A comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences of IBDV isolates with those of the vaccine strain Georgia, the classical virulent strain 52/70 and the very virulent strain OKYM also revealed the presence of a conserved serine-rich heptapeptide sequence in most of the isolates. The results of this study indicate that most IBDV isolates are highly virulent, as evidenced by the high mortality reported in few poultry flocks despite regular vaccination.
authors: Ramadass, P.;Thiagarajan, V.;Parthiban, M.;Senthil Kumar, T. M. A.;Latha, D.;Anbalagan, S.;Krishnakumar, M.;Nachimuthu, K.

title: Differentiation of bovine herpesvirus 1 subtypes based on UL0.5 gene sequencing
abstract: Infectious bovine rhinotracheitis/infectious pustular vulvovaginitis is one of the most economically important cattle diseases and is caused by bovine herpesvirus 1 (BoHV1). Based on restriction endonuclease fingerprinting of viral DNA, BoHV1 can be divided into three subtypes namely BoHV1.1, 1.2a and 1.2b. Because this method requires pure viral DNA, it is time consuming and labor intensive. In the current study, UL0.5 gene-based PCR sequencing was used for BoHV1 subtyping. Of five isolates, four had BoHV1-like signatures and one isolate had BoHV1.2-like signatures. In addition, these viruses group phylogenetically under the respective subtypes. These results indicate that UL 0.5 gene-based PCR sequencing could be used as an alternative method to subtype BoHV1.
authors: Ramakrishnan, M. A.;Pundkar, C. Y.;Fayaz, A.;ChandraSekar, S.;Mageswary, R.;Ashokkumar, D.;Bano, R.;Muthuchelvan, D.;Nandi, S.;Gupta, V. K.

title: Molecular signature of high yielding (growth) influenza A virus reassortants produced as vaccine candidates
abstract: Background:Human influenza virus isolates generally grow poorly in embryonated chicken eggs. Therefore, gene reassortment of wild-type (wt) influenza A viruses using a highly egg-adapted donor virus, A/Puerto Rico/8/1934 (PR8), will be performed to obtain the viral "seeds" of the High Yield Reassortant (HYR) provide for the vaccine production. HYR must contain the genes for wt virus hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) and one to six “internal” genes of PR8. Most studies on wt influenza and HYRs have focused on the HA gene. The main objective of this study is to identify the molecular signature in all eight gene segments of candidate influenza A-HYR vaccine seeds associated with high growth in ovo. Methodology: The genomes of 14 wt parental viruses, 23 HYRs (5 H1N1; 2, 1976 H1N1-SOIV; 2, 2009 H1N1pdm; 2 H2N2 and 12 H3N2) and PR8 were analyzed using the high-throughput sequencing pipeline with Big Dye Terminator Chemistry sequences M gene exception. The PR8-derived M gene was invariant in all 23 HYRs, underscoring the critical role of PR8 M in the high-yielding phenotype. None of the wt virus-derived internal genes showed any silent alteration(s), with the exception of the PB1 gene in X-157. The highest number of recurrent silent and coding mutations was found in NS. Regarding the surface antigens, the majority of HYRs had mutations in HA coding for them; only 2 HYRs had coding mutations in NA. Significance: In the age of applying reverse genetics to alter the influenza A virus genome, the mutations identified in the HYR gene segments associated with high growth in ovo may have great practical utility to modify PR8 and/or wt virus gene sequences for improved growth of vaccine "seed" viruses. © 2013 Ramanunninair et al.
authors: Ramanunninair, M.;Le, J.;Onodera, S.;Fulvini, A. A.;Pokorny, B. A.;Silverman, J.;Devis, R.;Arroyo, J. M.;He, Y.;Boyne, A.;Bera, J.;Halpin, R.;Hine, E.;Spiro, D. J.;Bucher, D.

title: Genetic diversity and mutation of avian paramyxovirus serotype 1 (Newcastle disease virus) in wild birds and evidence of intercontinental spread
abstract: Avian paramyxovirus serotype 1 (APMV-1), or Newcastle disease virus, is the causative agent of Newcastle disease, one of the most economically important diseases affecting poultry production worldwide and a cause of periodic animal diseases in wild birds in North America. In this study, we examined the genetic diversity of APMV-1 isolated from migratory birds collected in Alaska, Japan, and Russia, and evaluated the evidence for intercontinental virus spread using phylogenetic methods. In addition, we predicted viral virulence using deduced amino acid residues for the fusion protein cleavage site and estimated mutation rates for the fusion gene of migratory class I and class II isolates. All 73 isolates sequenced in this study were most closely related to virus genotypes previously reported in wild birds; however, five class II genotype I isolates formed a monophyletic clade that exhibited previously unreported genetic diversity and met the criteria for designating a new subgenotype. Phylogenetic analysis of wild bird isolates provided evidence for intercontinental virus spread, particularly viral lineages of APMV-1 class II genotype I subgenotypes Ib and Ic. This result supports migratory bird movement as a possible mechanism for APMV-1 redistribution. None of the predicted deduced amino acid motifs for the fusion protein cleavage site of APMV-1 strains isolated from migratory birds in Alaska, Japan and Russia matched those of previously identified virulent viruses. Therefore, these data do not provide support that these strains contribute to the emergence of avian pathogens. The estimated mutation rates for fusion genes from class I and class II wild bird isolates were faster than those previously reported for non-virulent APMV-1 strains. Taken together, these results provide new insights into the diversity, distribution, and evolution of APMV-1 in wild birds.
authors: Ramey, A. M.;Reeves, A. B.;Ogawa, H.;Ip, H. S.;Imai, K.;Bui, V. N.;Yamaguchi, E.;Silko, N. Y.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Evidence for a common ancestry between viruses isolated from wild birds in Beringia and highly pathogenic intercontinental reassortant H5N1 and H5N2 influenza A viruses
abstract: The highly pathogenic clade 2.3.4.4 H5N8, H5N2, and H5N1 influenza A viruses were first detected in wild, captive, and domestic birds in North America in November-December 2014. First detection of clade 2.3.4.4 H5 influenza A viruses in North America to assess the evidence for: (1) migratory bird spread of highly pathogenic influenza A viruses from East Asia to North America via Alaska, and (2) ancestral origins of clade 2.3.4.4 H5 reassortant viruses in Beringia. Although we did not detect any highly pathogenic influenza A viruses in our sample collection from western Alaska, we identified viruses containing gene segments that shared recent common ancestors with H5N2 and H5N1 intercontinental reassortant viruses.
authors: Ramey, A. M.;Reeves, A. B.;TeSlaa, J. L.;Nashold, S.;Donnelly, T.;Bahl, J.;Hall, J. S.

title: Fecal viromatic composition of migratory wild duck species
abstract: Fecal vioma includes a complex variety of eukaryotic viruses, phages and viruses that infect the host. However, little is known about the intestinal community of viruses present in wild waterfowl, and the structure of this community in wild ducks has not been studied. Thus, the faecal virome compositions of six species of wild plant ducks and one species of wild diving ducks were analyzed. Fecal samples were taken directly from the rectums of 60 ducks donated by hunters. DNA and RNA virus particles were purified and sequenced using the MiSeq Illumina platform. The reads obtained from the sequencing were analyzed and compared to sequences in the GenBank database. Virus-related sequences from the virus families Herpesviridae, Alloherpesviridae, Adenoviridae, Retroviridae and Myoviridae showed the highest overall frequencies in the samples. Viromeanalysis identified viruses that had not been found in wild duck feces and showed different virome profiles between different species and between samples of the same species. This study advances our understanding of viruses in wild ducks as possible viral reservoirs and provides a basis for further investigation and monitoring transmission of viruses from wild animals to humans and outbreaks of disease in domestic animals.
authors: RamÃ­rez-MartÃ­nez, L. A.;Loza-Rubio, E.;Mosqueda, J.;GonzÃ¡lez-Garay, M. L.;GarcÃ­a-Espinosa, G.

title: Nucleotide sequence of the gene encoding avian pneumovirus viral polymerase
abstract: We report here the nucleotide sequence of the L gene of avian pneumovirus (APV). This is the second pneumovirus L gene and the second avian paramyxovirus L gene, after Newcastle disease virus, to be sequenced. The APV-L gene is 6099 nucleotides long and encodes a single large ORF of 2004 amino acids. This makes the APV-L protein the smallest that can be described for any non-segmented negative-strand RNA virus. The protein contains six linear, non-contiguous domains, a putative ATP-binding site, and four polymerase motifs previously described for the L proteins of negative-strand RNA viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of domain III of 14 different L proteins suggests that pneumoviruses are evolutionarily distant from the other members of the Paramyxoviridae as are Filoviridae.
authors: Randhawa, J. S.;Wilson, S. D.;Tolley, K. P.;Cavanagh, D.;Pringle, C. R.;Easton, A. J.

title: Incidental Pathogen Risk Assessment Case Study: Assessing RotaTeq® for the Presence of Porcine Circovirus
abstract: In June 2010, results of a metagenomic and panmicrobial microarray analysis of a number of commercially available vaccine products were published, which identified the unexpected presence of porcine circovirus (PCV) in one of the tested vaccine products. This test did not detect any contaminating virus sequences in RotaTeq® (rotavirus vaccine, live, oral, pentavalent, RV5, Merck & Co., Inc., Whitehouse Station, NJ). To confirm this finding, Merck has developed and applied a series of polymerase chain reaction-based analysis methods and a testing algorithm to systematically demonstrate the absence of infectious PCV in RotaTeq®. This paper describes the methodology and rationale developed to thoroughly evaluate the key starting materials, product intermediates and the final product to demonstrate the absence of infectious PCV and the continued quality of this product. This approach could be applied to assess the validity of other adventitious drug risks encountered in biological processes and products. © PDA, Inc. 2011.
authors: Ranucci, C. S.;Tagmyer, T.;Duncan, P.

title: Deep sequencing as a method for typing bluetongue virus isolates
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is an economically important endemic livestock disease in the tropics and subtropics. In addition, recent spreads in temperate regions such as North America and northern Europe are of serious concern. Rapid serotyping and characterization of BT virus (BTV) is an essential step in identifying the origin of the virus and combating the disease. BTV serotyping is typically performed by serum neutralization and more recently by nucleotide sequencing. This report describes the near-complete genome sequencing and typing of two BTV isolates using Illumina's next-generation sequencing platform. Two of the BTV RNAs were multiplexed with ten other unknown probes. Viral RNA was isolated and fragmented, reverse transcribed, the cDNA ends repaired and ligated with a multiplex oligo. The genomic library was amplified using primers complementary to the ligated oligo and subjected to single and paired-end sequencing. The raw reads were assembled using a de novo method, and reference-based assembly was performed based on the contig data. Nearly complete sequences of all BTV segments were obtained with more than 20-fold coverage, and the single-read sequencing method was sufficient to identify the virus genotype and serotype. The two viruses used in this study were typed as BTV-1 and BTV-9E.
authors: Rao, P. P.;Reddy, Y. N.;Ganesh, K.;Nair, S. G.;Niranjan, V.;Hegde, N. R.

title: Full-length genomic sequences of swine epidemic diarrhea virus strain CV777; Using NGS to analyze genomic and subgenomic RNAs
abstract: Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus strain CV777 was originally characterized in 1978 as the causative agent of a disease first identified in the UK in 1971. This coronavirus has been widely spread in laboratories and passaged in both pigs and cell cultures. In order to determine the variability between different populations of the PEDV strain CV777, a full-length genome (approx. 28 kb) sequencing was performed in 6 different laboratories using different protocols. Not surprisingly, each of the various full genome sequences differ from each other and from the reference sequence (accession number AF353511), but they are >99% identical. Unique and common differences between sequences were identified. The coding region for the surface-exposed spike protein showed the highest level of variability, including both point mutations and small deletions. The predicted expression of the ORF3 gene product was more dramatically affected in three different variants of this virus by either losing the initiation codon or gaining a premature termination codon. The genome of one isolate had a substantially rearranged 5' terminal sequence. This rearrangement was validated by analyzing subgenomic mRNAs from infected cells. It is clearly important to know the characteristics of the specific sample of CV777 used for experimental studies.
authors: Rasmussen, T. B.;Boniotti, M. B.;Papetti, A.;Grasland, B.;Frossard, J. P.;Dastjerdi, A.;Hulst, M.;Hanke, D.;Pohlmann, A.;Blome, S.;van der Poel, W. H. M.;Steinbach, F.;Blanchard, Y.;Lavazza, A.;Botner, A.;Belsham, G. J.

title: Detection of three porcine vesicle viruses using multiplex real-time primer-probe energy transfer
abstract: Rapid identification of the etiological agent in infected animals is important for controlling an outbreak of vesicular disease in livestock. In the present study, we developed a multiplex real-time reverse transcription PCR based on primer-probe energy transfer (PriProET) for the simultaneous detection and differentiation of three vesicular viruses classified by the Office International des Epizooties (OIE): foot and Oral disease virus, vesicular stomatitis virus and vesicular vesicular disease causing clinically indistinguishable vesicular disease in swine. The multiplex assay consists of extraction of total RNA from clinical specimens; Reverse transcription to cDNA using random primers and real-time, one-tube amplification of cDNA using multiplex PriProET with specific fluorescently labeled primers and probes to detect the three viruses from the vesicular disease complex. The probes are labeled with unique reporter fluorophores that are excited during amplification by donor fluorophores that are incorporated into the 5” end of specific amplicons by primer extension. The sensitivity of the multiplex assay was approximately 100 TCID50, which is 10-fold lower compared to the individual PriProET assays for the three vesicular viruses. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Rasmussen, T. B.;Uttenthal, A.;AgÃ¼ero, M.

title: Using genomic tools to improve cattle health in the context of infectious disease screening
abstract: Although infectious diseases impose a heavy economic burden on the cattle industry, the etiology of many disorders affecting livestock is not fully understood and effective countermeasures are often lacking. The main tools available so far have been vaccines, antibiotics and antiparasitics. Although these have been very successful in some cases, the emergence of parasitic and microbial resistance to these treatments is a concern. Next-generation sequencing offers important opportunities to address problems related to pathogenic diseases. This review describes the rapid progress that has been made to follow disease progression, identify the pathogens involved, and map pathogen-host interactions. The use of novel genomic tools then aids in the development of treatments as well as the successful creation of breeding programs targeting less vulnerable livestock. These can be important tools to mitigate the long-term effects of infection control and reduce reliance on antibiotic treatments.
authors: Raszek, M. M.;Guan le, L.;Plastow, G. S.

title: Using genomic tools to improve cattle health related to infectious diseases
abstract: Although infectious diseases impose a heavy economic burden on the cattle industry, the etiology of many disorders affecting livestock is not fully understood and effective countermeasures are often lacking. The main tools available so far have been vaccines, antibiotics and antiparasitics. Although these have been very successful in some cases, the emergence of parasitic and microbial resistance to these treatments is a concern. Next-generation sequencing offers important opportunities to address problems related to pathogenic diseases. This review describes the rapid progress that has been made to follow disease progression, identify the pathogens involved, and map pathogen-host interactions. The use of novel genomic tools then aids in the development of treatments as well as the successful creation of breeding programs targeting less vulnerable livestock. These can be important tools to mitigate the long-term effects of infection control and reduce reliance on antibiotic treatments.
authors: Raszek, M. M.;Guan, L. L.;Plastow, G. S.

title: Metagenomic profiling of ticks: identification of novel Rickettsia genomes and detection of tick-borne canine parvovirus
abstract: BACKGROUND: Ticks act as vectors of human and animal pathogens worldwide. Ticks rely on bacterial endosymbionts, which often have close and complex evolutionary links with tick-borne pathogens. Since the prevalence, diversity, and virulence potential of tick-borne pathogens remain poorly understood, there is an urgent need for microbial surveillance of ticks as potential disease vectors. METHODOLOGY/MAIN RESULTS: We developed a two-step protocol involving 16S amplicon screening of pooled hard tick samples collected from dogs, sheep and camels in Palestine, followed by shotgun metagenomics on individual ticks to screen through Detect tick-borne pathogens and characterize endosymbionts. Two ticks isolated from sheep yielded an abundance of reads from the genus Rickettsia, which were assembled into draft genomes. One of the resulting genomes was very similar to Rickettsia massiliae strain MTU5. Analysis of signature genes showed that the other represents the first genome sequence of the potential pathogen Candidatus Rickettsia barbariae. Ticks from a dog and a sheep provided draft genome sequences of Coxiella strains. A sheep tick provided sequences from the sheep pathogen Anaplasma ovis, while camel hyalomma ticks provided sequences belonging to Francisella-like endosymbionts. We generated a genome sequence of a canine parvovirus from the metagenome of a dog tick from Jericho. SIGNIFICANCE: Here we demonstrated how an inexpensive two-step protocol can be used to detect and characterize tick-borne pathogens and endosymbionts. By recovering genome sequences of an unexpected pathogen (canine parvovirus) and a previously unsequenced pathogen (Candidatus Rickettsia barbariae), we demonstrate the open-ended nature of metagenomics. We also provide evidence that ticks can transmit canine parvovirus, raising the possibility that ticks could be helping to spread this troublesome virus.
authors: Ravi, A.;Ereqat, S.;Al-Jawabreh, A.;Abdeen, Z.;Abu Shamma, O.;Hall, H.;Pallen, M. J.;Nasereddin, A.

title: Network inference from multimodal data: A review of approaches to infectious disease transmission
abstract: Network inference problems are common in several biomedical subfields such as genomics, metagenomics, neuroscience, and epidemiology. Networks are useful to represent a wide range of complex interactions, ranging from those between molecular biomarkers, neurons, and microbial communities, to those found in human or animal populations. Recent advances in technology have resulted in an increasing amount of healthcare data across multiple modalities, increasing the preponderance of network inference problems. Multi-domain data can now be used to improve the robustness and reliability of recovered networks from unimodal data. For infectious diseases in particular, there is a body of knowledge that focuses on combining multiple pieces of linked information. Combining or analyzing different modalities together has provided better insight into disease transmission than would be possible with a single modality in isolation. This was particularly helpful in understanding the occurrence and transmission of infections with pandemic potential in early stages. Novel linked information in the form of spatial, temporal, and other covariates, including high-throughput sequence data, clinical visits, information from social networks, pharmaceutical prescriptions, and clinical symptoms (reported as free-text data), also encourage further investigation of these methods. The purpose of this review is to provide an in-depth analysis of multimodal inference methods for infectious disease transmission with a particular focus on Bayesian inference. We focus on analytical Bayesian inference methods as this allows for the simultaneous recovery of multiple parameters, for example not only the disease transmission network but also parameters of epidemic dynamics. Our review examines their assumptions, key inference parameters, and limitations, and ultimately provides insights into improving future network inference methods in multiple applications.
authors: Ray, B.;Ghedin, E.;Chunara, R.

title: Finding a needle in the virus-metagenome haystack - micro-metagenome analysis captures a snapshot of the diversity of a bacteriophage armoire
abstract: Viruses are ubiquitous in the oceans and are critical components of marine microbial communities that regulate nutrient transfer to higher trophic levels or the dissolved organic pool through lysis of host cells. Hydrothermal vent systems are oases of biological activity in the deep oceans for which the understanding of biodiversity and its impact on the global ocean biogeochemical cycle is still in its infancy. To gain biological insight into viral communities present in hydrothermal vent systems, we developed a method based on deep sequencing of pulsed-field gel electrophoresis bands representing key viral fractions found in seawater within and around a hydrothermal plume are present around, originating from Loki's Castle Vent field the mid-oceanic arctic ridge. The reduction in the complexity of the viral community enabled by this novel approach enabled the almost complete reconstruction of a lambda-like phage genome from the viral fraction of the cloud. The phylogenetic study of different gene regions in this lambdoid phage genome revealed the diversity at loci encoding superinfection exclusion and integrase-like proteins. This suggests the importance of fine-tuning lyosgenic conversion as a viral survival strategy and provides insights into the nature of host-virus and virus-virus interactions within hydrothermal plumes. By reducing the complexity of the viral community through targeted sequencing of prominent dsDNA viral fractions, this method has selectively mimicked viral dominance approaching that previously achieved only through culture, thereby allowing bioinformatic analysis to identify a lambdoid viral "needle" within the larger viral locate community. Haystack". Such targeted analyzes have great potential to accelerate the generation of biological knowledge from diverse and poorly understood environmental viral communities. © 2012 Ray et al.
authors: Ray, J.;Dondrup, M.;Modha, S.;Steen, I. H.;Sandaa, R. A.;Clokie, M.

title: Porcine sapelovirus in diarrhea piglets in India
