abstract: Porcine sapelovirus (PSV) A belongs to the genus Sapelovirus, family Picornaviridae. PSV infections in pigs have been reported from European countries, the United States, Japan, China, Korea and Brazil. The virus has been isolated/detected in the faeces of healthy pigs as well as pigs with diarrhoea, respiratory diseases, encephalitis, skin lesions and fertility disorders. This study was designed to investigate whether PSV is widespread in swine in India and to characterize PSV present in the study population. The study found that five out of 70 (7.14%) stool samples were found positive for PSV by RT-PCR. Three viruses were successfully isolated from fecal samples using the IB-RS-2 cell line. Full genome sequencing and analysis of an Indian PSV isolate revealed the highest homology (88%) with the V13 strain from England. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete polyprotein nucleotide sequences of 14 PSV strains classified the viruses into four different clades. This first report from India expands our knowledge of the genetic diversity of PSV previously identified in pigs in different countries. Large-scale surveillance of the virus is needed to understand its genomic diversity and economic impact.
authors: Ray, P. K.;Desingu, P. A.;Kumari, S.;John, J. K.;Sethi, M.;Sharma, G. K.;Pattnaik, B.;Singh, R. K.;Saikumar, G.

title: Genetic diversity of influenza A virus in wild bird populations in southern western Siberia
abstract: Variants of influenza A virus belonging to subtypes H3 and H4 have been isolated from wild ducks living in southern western Siberia. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of these viruses has revealed that H3 isolates are closely related to those isolated from the bird native to Western Europe (A/Teal/Germany/wv01r/01, A/Duck/Ukraine /1/63). and China (A/Aquatic bird/Hong Kong/399/99); and those isolated from the birds resident in Germany (A/Garganey/Germany/wv157k/01, A/Teal/Germany/wv153k/01). Therefore, closely related variants of influenza A virus circulate in wild bird populations living in widely separated regions of Eurasia. © KOJIJlEKTHB ABTOPOB, 2005.
authors: Razumova Yu, V.;Shchelkanov, M. Yu;Durymanova, A. A.;Zolotykh, S. I.;Ternovoi, V. A.;Slavsky, A. A.;Yurlov, A. K.;Beklemishev, A. B.;Shestopalov, A. M.;Lvov, D. K.

title: Comparison between transcriptome sequencing and 16S metagenomics for the detection of bacterial pathogens in wild animals
abstract: Background Rodents are major reservoirs of pathogens responsible for numerous zoonotic diseases in humans and livestock. Assessing their microbial diversity at both individual and population levels is critical for monitoring endemic infections and revealing microbial association patterns within reservoirs. Recently, NGS approaches have been used to characterize microbial communities of different ecosystems. However, their relative effectiveness has not been evaluated. Here we compared two NGS approaches, RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) and 16S metagenomics, and evaluated their ability to study neglected zoonotic bacteria in rodent populations. Methodology/Main Results We first extracted nucleic acids from the spleens of 190 voles collected in France. RNA extracts were pooled, randomly retro-transcribed, then RNA-Seq was performed using HiSeq. Composite bacterial sequences were assigned to the next taxon registered in GenBank. DNA extracts were analyzed via a 16S metagenomics approach using two sequencers: the 454 GS-FLX and the MiSeq. The V4 region of the gene encoding 16S rRNA was amplified for each sample using barcoded universal primers. Amplicons were multiplexed and processed on the different sequencers. The resulting datasets were demultiplexed and each read was pipelined to be classified taxonomically using the Ribosomal Database Project. A total of 45 pathogenic bacterial genera were detected. The bacteria identified by RNA-Seq were comparable to those discovered by the 16S metagenomics approach processed with MiSeq (16S-MiSeq). In contrast, 21 of these pathogens went unnoticed when the 16S metagenomics approach was processed via 454 pyrosequencing (16S-454). In addition, the 16S metagenomics approaches revealed high levels of co-infection in bank voles. Conclusions/Significance We concluded that RNA-Seq and 16S-MiSeq are equally sensitive in detecting bacteria. Although only the 16S-MiSeq method allowed for the identification of bacteria in each individual reservoir, with subsequent deduction of bacterial prevalence in host populations and generation of patterns of bacterial interactions within the reservoir. Finally, the number of bacterial reads obtained with the 16S-MiSeq could be a good indicator of bacterial prevalence.
authors: Razzauti, M.;Galan, M.;Bernard, M.;Maman, S.;Klopp, C.;Charbonnel, N.;Vayssier-Taussat, M.;Eloit, M.;Cosson, J. F.

title: Insights into resistome and stress response genes in the rumen of Bubalus bubalis by metagenomic analysis
abstract: Buffalo rumen microbiota experience a variety of diets and represent a vast reservoir of mobiloma, resistoma, and stress responses. However, knowledge of metagenomic responses to such conditions is still rudimentary. We analyzed the metagenomes of buffalo rumen in the liquid and solid phase of river buffalo rumen biomaterial adapted to different proportions of concentrate to green or dry roughage using high-throughput sequencing to determine the emergence of antibiotic resistance genes and genetic exchange between bacteria know population and environmental reservoirs. A total of 3914.94 MB of data was generated from all three treatment groups. Data were analyzed using Metagenome Rapid Annotation System Tools. At the phyla level, Bacteroidetes were dominant in all treatments followed by Firmicutes. Genes encoding functional responses to stress (oxidative stress and heat shock proteins) and resistome genes (resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds, phage, transposable elements, and pathogenicity islands) were prevalent in similar proportions in liquid and solid fractions of rumen metagenomes . The fluoroquinolone resistance, MDR efflux pump, and methicillin resistance genes were broadly distributed across 11, 9, and 14 bacterial classes, respectively. Bacteria responsible for phage replication, as well as prophages and phage packaging, and streptococcal rlt-like phage genes have been mainly assigned to the phyla Bacteroides, Firmicutes, and Proteaobacteria. In addition, more reads matching the sigma B genes were identified in the rumen of the buffalo. This study highlights the presence of different adaptation mechanisms to different diets, antibiotics, and other stresses in the buffalo rumen, reflecting the proportional representation of the major bacterial groups.
authors: Reddy, B.;Singh, K. M.;Patel, A. K.;Antony, A.;Panchasara, H. J.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Molecular characterization of Indian rabies virus isolates by partial sequencing of nucleoprotein (N) and phosphoprotein (P) genes
abstract: Rabies is endemic and an important zoonosis in India. There are very few reports on the molecular epidemiology of rabies virus of Indian origin. In this study on knowledge of rabies virus dynamics, a total of 41 rabies-positive brain samples from dogs, cats, domestic animals, wild animals and humans from 11 states underwent RT-PCR amplification of N gene between nucleotide N521-N1262 (742 bp) and P gene between nucleotide P239-P750 (512 bp). The N gene could be amplified from 30, the P gene from 41 samples using specific primer sets. N-gene-based phylogenetic analysis showed that all Indian virus isolates are genetically closely related to a single cluster among Arctic/Arctic-like viruses. However, two distinct clusters have been realized in the P gene-based phylogeny, namely rabies virus isolates from Punjab and rabies virus isolates from remaining parts of India (other than Punjab). All Indian rabies virus isolates were closely related geographically (>95% homology) but not with the host species. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Reddy, G. B. M.;Singh, R.;Singh, R. P.;Singh, K. P.;Gupta, P. K.;Desai, A.;Shankar, S. K.;Ramakrishnan, M. A.;Verma, R.

title: Genetic characterization of Belgian nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis virus (NIBV) reference strain B1648
abstract: The virulent nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis virus (NIBV) strain B1648 was first isolated in 1984 in Flanders, Belgium. Despite intensive vaccination, B1648 and its variants are still circulating in Europe and North Africa. Here, the full genome of this Belgian NIBV reference strain was determined by next-generation sequencing (NGS) to understand its evolutionary relatedness to other IBV strains and to identify possible genetic factors that may be associated with nephropathogenicity. Thirteen open reading frames (ORFs) were predicted in strain B1648 (51UTR-1a-1b-S-3a-3b-EM-4b-4c-5a-5b-N-6b-31UTR). ORFs 4b, 4c, and 6b, which have been rarely reported in the literature, were present in B1648 and most other complete IBV genomes. According to phylogenetic analysis of full-length genome, replicase-transcriptase complex, spike protein, partial S1 gene and M protein, B1648 strain clustered with non-Massachusetts-type strains NGA/A116E7/ 2006, UKr 27-11, QX-like ITA /90254/2005, QX-like CK/SWE/0658946/10, TN20/00, RF-27/99, RF/06/2007 and SLO/266/05. Based on the partial S1 fragment, B1648 clustered with strains TN20/00, RF-27/99, RF/06/2007 and SLO/266/05 and is further referred to as the B1648 genotype. The full-length genome of B1648 shared the highest sequence homology with UKr 27-11, Gray, JMK, and NGA/A116E7/2006 (91.2% to 91.6%) and was least related to the Beaudette and Massachusetts reference strains (89, 7%). . Nucleotide and amino acid sequence analyzes indicated that the B1648 strain may have played an important role in the development of IBV in Europe and North Africa. Furthermore, the determinants of nephropathogenicity could be located on the 1a, spike, M and accessory proteins (3a, 3b, 4b, 4c, 5a, 5b and 6b). Overall, strain B1648 differs from all strains previously reported in Europe and other parts of the world.
authors: Reddy, V. R.;Theuns, S.;Roukaerts, I. D.;Zeller, M.;Matthijnssens, J.;Nauwynck, H. J.

title: Avian influenza in swine: a threat to the human population?
authors: Reeth, K. Van

title: Tracing the antigenic evolution of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Quantifying and predicting the antigenic properties of a virus is something of a holy grail for infectious disease research because of its central importance in the emergence of new strains, the severity of outbreaks, and vaccine selection. However, these traits are defined by a complex interplay of viral and host factors such that phylogenetic measures of viral similarity often correlate poorly with antigenic relationships. Here, we generate antigenic phylogenies that track the phenotypic evolution of two foot-and-mouth disease virus serotypes by combining host serology and viral sequence data to identify sites critical to their antigenic evolution. For the SAT1 serotype, we validate our antigenic phylogeny against monoclonal antibody escape mutants consistent with all predicted antigenic sites. For serotype O, we validate against known sites where available, and otherwise directly evaluate the impact of substitutions on the antigenic phenotype at predicted sites using reverse genetics and serology. We also highlight a critical and poorly understood issue for vaccine selection by demonstrating qualitative differences between assays, which are often used interchangeably to determine antigenic correspondence between field viruses and vaccine strains. Our approach provides a tool to identify naturally occurring antigenic substitutions, allowing us to follow the genetic diversification and associated antigenic evolution of the virus. Despite the tremendously important role that vaccines have played in improving human and animal health, vaccinology remains a strikingly empirical science. This study advances the field by providing guidance for the matching of vaccine strains via site-directed mutagenesis through this high-resolution trace of the antigenic evolution of the virus between rare major changes in phenotype.
authors: Reeve, R.;Borley, D. W.;Maree, F. F.;Upadhyaya, S.;Lukhwareni, A.;Esterhuysen, J. J.;Harvey, W. T.;Blignaut, B.;Fry, E. E.;Parida, S.;Paton, D. J.;Mahapatra, M.

title: Identification and characterization of a potyvirus isolated from Siratro plants
abstract: The present work describes the identification and characterization of a potyvirus isolated from Siratro (Macroptilium atropurpureum Urb.) in the northwestern region of Sdo Paulo State, Brazil. The virus was transmitted by mechanical inoculation. Its host range was mainly restricted to members of the Fabaceae. A cDNA fragment of about 930 bp was amplified by RT/PCR, cloned and sequenced. The fragment containing the coat protein gene shared between 88 and 98% amino acid identity with isolates of Bean Common Mosaic Virus (BCMV). Phylogenetic analysis groups the. Siratro potyvirus and BCMV isolates in 99% of replicates, including Azuki mosaic virus, Dendrobium mosaic virus, Blackeye cowpea mosaic virus and peanut streak virus classified as BCMV strains. This is the first citation on the presence of BCMV in Siratro plants in Brazil.
authors: Regatier, L. J.;Gaspar, J. O.;Belintani, P.;Yuki, V. A.

title: Beak and feather disease viruses circulating in Cape parrots (Poicepahlus robustus) in South Africa
abstract: Captive and wild parrots are susceptible to the highly contagious parrot beak and feather disease. The causative agent, beak and feather disease virus (BFDV), has recently been identified in the largest remaining population of endangered Cape parrots (Poicepahlus robustus) endemic to South Africa. Whole genomes were isolated from 26 blood samples from wild and captive Cape Parrots and sequenced to determine possible sources of infection. All sequences had characteristic BFDV sequence motifs and were similar in length to those reported in the literature. However, BFDV coat protein (CP) sequences from this study did not contain a previously identified bipartite nuclear localization signal (NLS) within residues 39-56, indicating that an alternative NLS is involved in the shuttle of the CP into the nucleus. Sequences from the wild population showed a high degree of similarity regardless of year or location, suggesting that the disease outbreak occurred just prior to sample collection. Phylogenetic analysis of full-length genomes showed that captive Cape parrot sequences cluster with those isolated from captive-bred budgerigars in KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa. Exposure to captive bred Cape parrots from a KwaZulu-Natal breeding facility is suggested as a possible source of the virus infection. Phylogenetic analysis of BFDV isolates from wild and captive Cape Parrots revealed two separate events of infection in different populations, underscoring the potential risk of introducing new viral strains into the wild population. The present study represents the first systematic investigation of BFDV virus diversity in the southernmost population of Cape parrots.
authors: Regnard, G. L.;Boyes, R. S.;Martin, R. O.;Hitzeroth, I. I.;Rybicki, E. P.

title: Detection of non-reportable H4N6 avian influenza virus in UK poultry
abstract: 12-month pilot of notifiable bird disease (NAD) exclusion testing in UK chicken and turkey flocks, in partnership with industry, provided opportunities to perform differential diagnosis in flocks where NAD was not suspected and to identify undetected or undiagnosed ones infections. In May 2014, clinical samples received from a broiler breeder farm that had been experiencing health and production issues for about a week tested positive by avian influenza (AI) reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR). After immediate escalation to an official, statutory investigation to rule out the presence of a reportable AI virus (AIV; H5 or H7 subtypes), a non-reportable H4N6 low pathogenicity (LP) AIV was isolated by virus isolation in embryonated specifically pathogen-free (SPF ) proven ) poultry eggs, neuraminidase inhibition test, cleavage site sequencing and AIV subtype H4-specific serology. Restrictions on movement of premises have been lifted and no further disease control measures under UK legislation have been implemented. Phylogenetic analysis of the virus's haemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes revealed the closest relationship to viruses from mallard ducks in Sweden in 2007 and 2009. In June 2014, clinical suspicion of NAD in a flock of free-ranging laying hens was reported elsewhere in the UK, due to a increased daily mortality and decreased egg production over a five-day period. An H4N6 LPAIV with an intravenous pathogenicity index of 0.50 was isolated. This virus was genetically very similar, but not identical, to the virus discovered in May 2014. Full viral genome analyzes revealed characteristics of a strain that had not recently been transmitted from wild birds, suggesting spread to the poultry sector had taken place. A stalk deletion in the neuraminidase gene sequence indicated adaptation of the virus to poultry. In addition, the post-mortem revealed unexpected evidence of systemic spread of the virus. No other cases were reported. Infection with LPAIVs in poultry often results in variable clinical presentations, making the disease difficult to detect.
authors: Reid, S. M.;Brookes, S. M.;Nunez, A.;Banks, J.;Parker, C. D.;Ceeraz, V.;Russell, C.;Seekings, A.;Thomas, S. S.;Puranik, A.;Brown, I. H.

title: Whole genome of influenza A (H7N9) virus derived by direct sequencing without culture
abstract: An epidemic caused by influenza A virus (H7N9) was recently reported in China. Deep sequencing revealed the full genome of the virus, obtained directly from a patient's sputum without virus culture. The full genome showed significant sequence heterogeneity and large differences compared to that from embryonated chicken eggs.
authors: Ren, X.;Yang, F.;Hu, Y.;Zhang, T.;Liu, L.;Dong, J.;Sun, L.;Zhu, Y.;Xiao, Y.;Li, L.;Yang, J.;Wang, J.;Jin, Q.

title: Faustovirus, a new lineage of giant viruses related to Asfarvirus that infect amoebas
abstract: Giant viruses are protist-associated viruses belonging to the proposed order Megavirales; almost all were derived from Acanthamoeba spp. isolated. Their isolation in humans suggests they are part of the human virome. Using a high-throughput strategy to isolate novel giant viruses from their original protozoal hosts, we obtained eight isolates of a novel giant virus lineage from Vermamoeba vermiformis, the most common free-living protist found in the human environment. This new line has been proposed as the Faustovirus line. The prototype member, Faustovirus E12, forms ≤200 nm icosahedral virions that are devoid of fibrillae and that encapsulate a 466 kbp genome encoding 451 predicted proteins. Of these, 164 are in the virion. Phylogenetic analysis of the viral core genes showed that Faustovirus is distantly related to the mammalian pathogenic African swine fever virus, but encodes â‰ˆ 3-fold more mosaic gene complements. About two-thirds of these genes show no significant similarity to genes encoding any known proteins. These results indicate that expanding the protist panel to discover new giant viruses is a fruitful strategy. SIGNIFICANCE Using Vermamoeba, a protist living in humans and their environment, we isolated eight strains of a new giant virus that we named Faustovirus. The genomes of these strains were sequenced and their sequences revealed that faustoviruses are related but distinct from the African swine fever (ASFV) pathogen, which belongs to the Asfarviridae family. Furthermore, the Faustovirus gene pertoire is three times larger than that of ASFV and includes about two-thirds ORFans (open reading frames [ORFs] with no detectable homology to other ORFs in a database).
authors: Reteno, D. G.;Benamar, S.;Khalil, J. B.;Andreani, J.;Armstrong, N.;Klose, T.;Rossmann, M.;Colson, P.;Raoult, D.;La Scola, B.

title: Analysis of Hepatitis C Virus/Classical Swine Fever Virus Chimeric 5-NTRs: Sequences within the hepatitis C virus IRES are required for viral RNA replication
abstract: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is classified in the genus Hepacivirus of the family Flaviviridae, members of which have a single-stranded, positive-polarity RNA genome encoding a single polyprotein. Within this family, HCV is closely related to viruses of the genus Pestivirus, which includes classical swine fever virus (CSFV). Translation of the hepaci- and pestiviral polyprotein is initiated by internal entry of ribosomes promoted by the 5-NTR. The secondary and tertiary RNA structures of the HCV and pestivirus 5 NTRs are well conserved, although their sequences differ significantly. By analogy with other positive-strand RNA viruses, the HCV 5-NTR likely contains cis-acting determinants for replication as well as determinants for translation. Studies on both signals could be complicated because these signals could overlap. In this study, this problem was addressed by constructing chimeric HCV/CSFV-5 NTRs. A two-stage analysis of these 5-NTRs was performed: (a) in a translational assay, which offered the opportunity to examine translation independently of the possible effects on replication; and (b) in a replication assay examining only the chimeric 5-NTRs for which IRES-dependent translation was demonstrated. Overlap has been observed between the HCV RNA elements involved in these processes. The replacement of domain II had a minor impact on the translational efficiency of the chimeric 5-NTRs, while replication of subgenomic replicons containing these chimeric 5-NTRs was abolished. Swapping domain III subdomains greatly decreased translational activity while maintaining replication.
authors: Reusken, C. B. E.;Dalebout, T. J.;Eerligh, P.;Bredenbeek, P. J.;Spaan, W. J. M.

title: Divergent hepatitis E virus in raptors, kestrels (Falco tinnunculus) and red-footed hawks (F. vespertinus), Hungary
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV), family Hepeviridae, has raised significant public health concerns because of its zoonotic potential; however, animal-to-animal transmission and the natural chain of hepevirus infection in wild animals are less well known. Using random amplification and next-generation sequencing technology, a novel HEV was randomly identified in raptors in Hungary. HEV RNA was detected in a total of 2 (18%) of 11 and 1 (14%) of 7 fecal samples from kestrel and red-footed falcon, respectively. High fecal viral load (2.03 x 10(8) genomic copies/mL) measured by qPCR. The complete genome of the kestrel/MR22/2014/HUN (KU670940) HEV strain is 7033 nt in length, including a 35 nt 5' end and a 63 nt 3' end (excluding the poly(A) tail ). Sequence analysis showed that the proteins ORF1 (4920nt/639 aa), ORF2 (1989nt/662 aa), and ORF3 (360nt/119aa) from Kestrel/MR22/2014/HUN shared the highest identity (58.1%, 66.8 % and 28.5%). to the corresponding proteins of ferret, rat, and human orthohepevirus genotype 4, respectively. Interestingly, the ORF3 protein is possibly initiated with leucine (L) using an alternative non-AUG (UUG) start codon. This study reports the identification and full genome characterization of a novel orthohepevirus species related to mammalian HEVs in birds of prey. It is important to identify all potential hosts, reservoirs and propagators in nature and to reconstruct the phylogenetic history of hepeviruses.
authors: Reuter, G.;Boros, A.;Matics, R.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: A novel avian-like hepatitis E virus in wild aquatic birds, the little egret (Egretta garzetta), in Hungary
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV), family Hepeviridae, is of public health concern because of its zoonotic potential; Less well known, however, are the range of host species, animal-to-animal transmission, the natural chain of hepevirus infection, and the genetic diversity of HEV in wildlife, particularly birds. Using random amplification and next-generation sequencing technology, a genetically divergent avian HEV was randomly identified in wild birds in Hungary. HEV RNA was detected at high fecal viral loads (1.33 × 108 genomic copies/mL) as measured by real-time PCR in a fecal sample from a little egret (Egretta garzetta). The complete genome of HEV strain Little Egret/kocsag02/2014/HUN (KX589065) is 6660 nt in length including an 18 nt 5 inch end and a 103 nt 3 inch end (excluding the poly( A)-tail) . Sequence analysis showed that the proteins encoded by ORF1 (4554nt/1517aa), ORF2 (1728nt/593aa), and ORF3 (339nt/112aa) from little egret/kocsag02/2014/HUN shared the highest identity (62.8%, 71%, and 61 .5%). to the corresponding proteins of genotype 1 avian (chicken) HEV in the orthohepevirus B species. This study reports the first identification and full genome characterization of a novel orthohepevirus distantly related to avian (chicken) HEV, in wild birds. It is important to identify all potential hosts, reservoirs and propagators in nature and to reconstruct the phylogenetic history of hepeviruses. Birds in general could be an important reservoir of HEV and could be infected with genetically very different HEV strains.
authors: Reuter, G.;Boros, Ã;MÃ¡tics, R.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: Kobuviruses - a comprehensive overview
abstract: Kobuviruses are members of the large and growing family Picornaviridae. To date, two official species, Aichi virus and bovine kobuvirus, and one candidate kobuvirus species, porcine kobuvirus, have been identified in humans, cattle, and swine, respectively. In addition, recently Kobu-like viruses have been detected in bats. Aichi virus may be one of the causative agents of gastroenteritis in humans, and kobuviruses are also likely to cause diarrhea in cattle and swine. Although Aichi virus has been detected relatively rarely (0-3%) in human diarrhea, a high seroprevalence of up to 80-95% by age 30-40 years has been identified, reflecting the general mode of infection in various human indicates populations. Much new information about kobuviruses and their host species has accumulated in recent years. This review summarizes the current state of knowledge on kobuviruses, including taxonomy, biology, and viral properties, and covers all aspects of infection, including epidemiology, clinical picture, host species diversity, laboratory diagnostics, and provides an overview of possible future perspectives. © 2011 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
authors: Reuter, G.;Boros, A.;Pankovics, P.

title: Molecular Detection of Hepatitis E Virus in Non-Imported Hepatitis Case - Identification of a Potential Novel Human Hepatitis E Virus Lineage in Hungary Hungarian
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is one of the most common causes of hepatitis in endemic areas. However, it has recently been shown that human infections can occur in developed countries with no travel experience and that pigs can act as a reservoir. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to identify hepatitis E virus by molecular methods in patients with acute non-AC hepatitis infection with no recent travel history in Hungary and to determine viral genetic relatedness to known HEV strains. MATERIALS: Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis E virus infection was performed in patient sera by HEV IgM and IgG ELISA, IgM and IgG immunoblot and reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction using primers for a partial viral capsid region. RESULTS: A patient with acute hepatitis of unknown origin was treated in June 2004 at Szeged Hospital. The acute patient's sera were positive for HEV IgM and IgG, confirmed by immunoblot. Viral genome was successfully amplified in sera by RT-PCR. By sequence and phylogenetic analysis, the virus designated Hungary-1 showed 95% nucleotide identity with genotype 3 hepatitis E viruses, based on the highest identity with the porcine HEV strain (Sp354-1-02) and with 90 % Nucleic acid identity with the human strain (Greece2). DISCUSSION: Hepatitis E virus infection is present in Hungary with no travel to known endemic regions. The first identified HEV in Hungary, representing a new human genetic lineage, supports the possibility of endemic infections caused by genotype 3 strains in developed countries and that pigs could act as a reservoir for human HEV.
authors: Reuter, G.;Fodor, D.;Katai, A.;Szucs, G.

title: Astrovirus in wild boar (Sus scrofa) in Hungary
abstract: The Astroviridae family consists of two genera, Avastrovirus and Mamastrovirus, whose members are associated with gastroenteritis in avian and mammalian species, respectively. In this study, we report the first detection of Astrovirus in fecal samples from wild boar (Sus scrofa) using viral metagenomics and whole genome sequencing. The genome of the wild boar astrovirus (WBAstV-1/2011/HUN, JQ340310) is 6707 nucleotides long and had 76%, 95% and 56% amino acid (aa) identity in ORF1a (852aa), ORF1b (522aa) and ORF2 ( 845aa) regions with porcine Astrovirus 4 (PAstV-4, JF713713), the closest match. This study indicates that wild boar could be a reservoir for astroviruses. © 2012 Springer Verlag.
authors: Reuter, G.;Nemes, C.;Boros, Ã;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: Porcine kobuvirus in wild boar (Sus scrofa)
abstract: Fecal samples (N = 10) from 6 to 8 week old wild boar piglets (Sus scrofa) collected in April 2011 at a zoo in Hungary were analyzed using viral metagenomics and whole genome sequencing. Kobuvirus (genus Kobuvirus, family Picornaviridae) was detected in all (100%) specimens, with the closest nucleotide (89%) and amino acid (94%) sequence identity to the wild boar/WB1-HUN/2011/HUN (JX177612) strain to Porcine Kobuvirus S-1-HUN (EU787450) prototype. This study suggests that genetically very similar (virtually the same genotype/serotype) porcine kobuviruses circulate in wild boar, the wild counterparts of domestic pigs. Wild boar could be an important host and reservoir for the kobuvirus. © 2012 Springer Verlag.
authors: Reuter, G.;Nemes, C.;Boros, Ã;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: Nonsuppurative (aseptic) meningoencephalomyelitis associated with neurovirulent astrovirus infections in humans and animals
abstract: Astroviruses are considered enteric pathogens. Since 2010, a distinct group of astroviruses has been increasingly recognized as potential neurovirulent (Ni) causative agents of severe central nervous system (CNS) infections using modern random amplification and high-throughput next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods that encephalitis , meningoencephalitis and meningoencephalomyelitis. To date, cases or epidemics of neurovirulent astroviruses have been reported in humans and domestic mammals, including mink, cattle, sheep and pigs. This comprehensive review summarizes the virology, epidemiology, pathology, diagnosis, therapy and future prospects associated with neurovirulent astroviruses in humans and mammals, based on a total of 30 relevant articles available in PubMed (search for use of the terms "astrovirus/encephalitis" ) and "astrovirus/meningitis" on March 2, 2018). Based on the increasing knowledge of the causality-effect association between neurotrophic astroviruses and CNS infections, a paradigm shift should be considered and attention should be drawn to the role of astroviruses in unknown CNS disorders.
authors: Reuter, G.;Pankovics, P.;Boros, A.

title: Nonsuppurative (aseptic) meningoencephalomyelitis associated with neurovirulent astrovirus infections in humans and animals
abstract: SUMMARY Astroviruses are considered enteric pathogens. Since 2010, a distinct group of astroviruses has been increasingly recognized as potential neurovirulent (Ni) causative agents of severe central nervous system (CNS) infections using modern random amplification and high-throughput next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods that encephalitis , meningoencephalitis and meningoencephalomyelitis. To date, cases or epidemics of neurovirulent astroviruses have been reported in humans and domestic mammals, including mink, cattle, sheep and pigs. This comprehensive review summarizes the virology, epidemiology, pathology, diagnosis, therapy, and future prospects associated with neurovirulent astroviruses in humans and mammals, based on a total of 30 relevant articles available in PubMed (search for use of the terms "astrovirus/encephalitis" ) and "astrovirus/meningitis" on March 2, 2018). Based on the increasing knowledge of the causality-effect association between neurotrophic astroviruses and CNS infections, a paradigm shift should be considered and attention should be drawn to the role of astroviruses in unknown CNS disorders.
authors: Reuter, G.;Pankovics, P.;Boros, Ã

title: Identification of a novel astrovirus in domestic sheep in Hungary
abstract: The Astroviridae family consists of two genera, Avastrovirus and Mamastrovirus, whose members are associated with gastroenteritis in avian and mammalian species, respectively. We accidentally identified a novel ovine astrovirus in a faecal sample from a domestic sheep (Ovis aries) in Hungary by viral metagenomic analysis. Sequencing of the fragment showed that it was an ORF1b/ORF2/3 UTR sequence and it was submitted to the GenBank database as ovine astrovirus type 2 (OAstV-2/Hungary/2009) with accession number JN592482. The unique sequence features and phylogenetic position of OAstV-2 suggest that genetically divergent lineages of astroviruses exist in sheep. © 2011 Springer Verlag.
authors: Reuter, G.;Pankovics, P.;Delwart, E.;Boros, Ã

title: Genetic variability of immunomodulatory genes in ectromelia virus isolates detected by denaturing high performance liquid chromatography
abstract: The genetic variability of nine genes in 12 isolates and strains of the ectromelia virus, which causes a smallpox-like disease (mousepox) in mice, was determined and allows for the classification of ectromelia viruses. The low genetic variability suggests that evolutionary pressures maintain the activity of immunomodulatory genes in natural smallpoxvirus infections.
authors: Ribas, G.;Rivera, J.;Saraiva, M.;Campbell, R. D.;Alcami, A.

title: Kobuvirus (Aichivirus B) infection in Brazilian cattle herds
authors: Ribeiro, J.;Lorenzetti, E.;Alfieri, A. F.;Alfieri, A. A.

title: First detection of circulating pneumovirus in French pigs by detection of anti-swine orthopneumovirus nucleoprotein antibodies
authors: Richard, C. A.;Hervet, C.;MÃ©nard, D.

title: Further studies of the physical and metabolic properties of temperature-sensitive mutants of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Three temperature-sensitive (ts) mutants of foot-and-mouth disease virus were classified as ribonucleic acid negative and belonging to the same complementation group as measured by virus yield and [3H]uridine incorporation in paired, mixed infections at the non-permissive temperature (38.5°C). ). Mutants ts 22, the only mutant capable of producing plaques at 38.5°C, were more sensitive to acid than the parental wild-type or other mutant viruses. Diethylaminoethyldextran did not enhance the plaquing ability of the mutant viruses at 38.5°C. All viruses inhibited host cell protein synthesis at both permissive (33 °C) and non-permissive (38.5 °C) temperatures.
authors: Richmond, J. Y.;Polatnick, J.

title: Borna disease virus: a mystery as an emerging zoonotic pathogen
abstract: Borna disease (BD) has long been known to Central European veterinarians as a sporadically occurring, progressive viral polioencephalomyelitis, which mainly affects horses and sheep and - as discovered in the last decade - more and more domestic and zoo animals. The causative agent, Borna disease virus (BDV), a negative-sense single-stranded RNA virus that is classified in the new Bornaviridae virus family within the order Mononegavirales, can cause severe clinical symptoms, typically viral encephalitis with prominent behavioral abnormalities . After an incubation period of a few weeks to several months, BDV infection leads to motor and sensory impairment, followed by paralysis and death. Natural infections appear to be subclinical in most cases. BD attracted worldwide attention when it was reported that sera and/or cerebrospinal fluid from neuropsychiatric patients may contain antibodies specific to BDV. Since infected animals only produce BDV-specific antibodies after virus replication, it was assumed that the broad spectrum of BDV-sensitive species also includes humans. However, reports describing the presence of other BDV markers, ie BDV RNA or BDV antigen, in peripheral blood leukocytes or brain tissue of neuropsychiatric patients are highly controversial and thus the role of BDV in human neuropsychiatric disorders is questionable. (c) 2001 Harcourt Publishers Ltd.
authors: Richt, J. A.;Rott, R.

title: Segregation of bovine viral diarrhea virus into genotypes
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolates were divided into two groups based on comparison of sequences from the 5' untranslated region (UTR) of the viral genome. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that these groups, designated BVDV I and BVDV II, are as distinct from each other as reference BVDV (BVDV-NADL, BVDV-SD-1, BVDV-Osloss) are from porcine cholera virus. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays based on the 5' untranslated region and the genomic region encoding the p125 polypeptide were developed to distinguish between BVDV I and BVDV II. With these tests, 76 of 140 BVDV isolates were identified as BVDV II. Antigenic and pathological differences have been identified between BVDV I and BVDV II viruses. Under BVDV I were viruses commonly used in vaccine production, diagnostic testing and research. BVDV II was isolated primarily from fetal bovine sera, persistently infected cattle born to dams vaccinated against BVDV and cattle that had died of an acute form of BVDV, the so-called haemorrhagic syndrome.
authors: Ridpath, J. F.;Bolin, S. R.;Dubovi, E. J.

title: Change in the predominance of bovine viral diarrhea virus subgenotypes in samples sent to a diagnostic laboratory over a 20-year period
abstract: Although the causative agent of bovine viral diarrhea was originally categorized as 1 species, phylogenetic analysis revealed that these viruses belong to 2 different species, Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus 1 (BVDV-1) and BVDV-2, with 2-11 subgenotypes within each species . The distribution of species and subgenotypes has been shown to vary by geographic region. It is not known whether the distribution shifts over time. Surveys conducted between 1994 and 2008 revealed that 3 subgenotypes are circulating among cattle in the United States: BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b, and BVDV-2a. The mean percentage prevalence of BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b, and BVDV-2a strains reported in surveys prior to 2001 were 21%, 43%, and 36%, respectively. Surveys of viruses isolated after 2001 reported decreasing percentages of BVDV-1a and BVDV-2a strains, with BVDV-1b strains accounting for 75-100% of samples. Comparison of these surveys is distorted by differences in geographic location, survey methods, and the type of sample used in the survey. The purpose of the present study was to determine whether the prevalence of BVDV subgenotypes in samples collected from the same geographic region and laboratory changed over time. BVDV strains isolated in 1988, 1998 and 2008 at the Texas Veterinary Medical Diagnostic Laboratory, Amarillo, Texas were genotyped and the prevalence of BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b and BVDV-2a strains was determined definitely. Typing based on phylogenetic analysis was performed on 148 specimens. The strongest trend observed in these samples was a marked decrease in the number of BVDV-1a strains over time.
authors: Ridpath, J. F.;Lovell, G.;Neill, J. D.;Hairgrove, T. B.;Velayudhan, B.;Mock, R.

title: Isolation and characterization of a novel cervid adenovirus from white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) kids in a captive herd
abstract: novel adenovirus, CeAdV1, was isolated from buffy coat and nasal swab specimens collected from two captive white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus). The isolation was an incidental finding during the course of screening animals for use in a research study of an unrelated pathogen. In the screening procedure, virus isolation was performed on both nasal swab and buffy coat specimens and a cytopathic effect was observed. Electron microscopy showed viral particles with the shape and morphology of an adenovirus. Next-generation sequencing followed by phylogenetic analysis assigned this virus to the Mastadenovirus genus. Its sequence was genetically distinct from all other recognized species of this genus, with only 76% sequence identity to its closest genetic counterpart, bovine adenovirus 3 (BAdV3). The virus could be propagated in bovine-derived cells but grew to a higher titer in cervid-derived cells. Inoculation of white-tailed deer fawns with the isolated virus resulted in fever, thymic tissue breakdown and mild respiratory illness. A comparative serology performed with sera from convalescents showed clear antigenic differences between the novel cervid adenovirus and BAdV3. A retrospective serological study of the captive deer herd showed that this virus had been circulating in the herd for at least 14 years with no clinical disease reported. A study of the serum of free-ranging mule deer living in Nevada revealed high serum titers against this novel adenovirus.
authors: Ridpath, J. F.;Neill, J. D.;Palmer, M. V.;Bauermann, F. V.;Falkenberg, S. M.;Wolff, P. L.

title: Stability of the parainfluenza virus 5 genome demonstrated by deep sequencing of strains isolated from different hosts and subsequent passage in cell culture
abstract: UNLABELING: Strain diversity of a rubulavirus, parainfluenza virus 5 (PIV5), was examined by comparing 11 newly determined and 6 previously published genomic sequences. These sequences represent 15 PIV5 strains, of which 6 were isolated from humans, 1 from monkeys, 2 from pigs and 6 from dogs. Strain diversity is remarkably low, regardless of host, year of isolation, or geographic origin; a total of 7.8% of the nucleotides are variable and the mean pairwise difference between strains is 2.1%. The variation is unevenly distributed across the PIV5 genome, but no convincing evidence for selection for antibody-mediated evasion in hemagglutinin neuraminidase was found. The finding that some canine and porcine, but not primate, strains are mutated in the SH gene and do not produce SH raised the possibility that dogs (or pigs) may not be the natural host of PIV5. The genetic stability of PIV5 was also demonstrated during serial passage of a strain (W3) in Vero cells at a high multiplicity of infection under competitive conditions with large proportions of defective interfering genomes. A similar observation was made for a strain W3 mutant (PIV5VDELTAC) lacking V gene function, in which the dominant changes were related to pseudoreversion in this gene. The mutations detected in PIV5VDELTAC during pseudoreversion, and also those characterizing the SH gene in canine and porcine strains, predominantly affected U-to-C transitions. This suggests an important role for biased hypermutation via an adenosine deaminase, RNA-specific (ADAR)-like activity. IMPORTANT: Here we report the sequence variation of 16 different parainfluenza virus 5 (PIV5) isolates isolated from a range of species including humans, monkeys, dogs and pigs over 4 decades. Surprisingly, strain diversity was remarkably low, regardless of host, year of isolation, or geographic origin. The variation was unevenly distributed across the PIV5 genome, but no convincing evidence of immune or host selection was found. This general genome stability of PIV5 was also observed when the virus was grown in the laboratory, and the genome remained remarkably constant even during the selection of virus mutants. Some of the canine isolates had lost their ability to encode one of the viral proteins called SH, suggesting that while PIV5 commonly infects dogs, dogs may not be the natural host for PIV5.
authors: Rima, B. K.;Gatherer, D.;Young, D. F.;Norsted, H.;Randall, R. E.;Davison, A. J.

title: New Mintovirus: A new rhabdovirus from ticks in Alaska
abstract: Three virus strains were isolated from Haemaphysalis leporis-palustris (Packard) ticks removed from snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus Erxleben) in east-central Alaska. We propose naming the virus New Minto after the place where the ticks were collected. The prototype of the new Mintovirus is sensitive to the effects of sodium deoxycholate and kills lactating mice by the intracerebral but not the intraperitoneal route; weaned mice do not die after intracerebral, intraperitoneal, or subcutaneous inoculation. The virus produces plaque in serially expanded Vero cells but not in primary Pekin duck embryo cells. Through complement fixation and neutralization tests, New Minto is related to Sawgrass virus, a previously ungrouped virus from Florida. The formation of a Sawgrass group is suggested. In addition, it was determined by electron microscopy that sawgrass virus belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family.
authors: Ritter, D. G.;Calisher, C. H.;Muth, D. J.

title: Genetic mixing of multiple hosts and influenza A viruses
abstract: Influenza A viruses have a segmented, negative-stranded RNA genome. These viruses are classified according to the antigenic properties of the two glycoproteins expressed on the surface of the virus particles, hemagglutinin (HA or H) and neuraminidase (NA or N). To date, 17 H and 10 N have been described, and 116 HxNy combinations or subtypes have been described. With the exception of the H17N10 subtype recently identified in bats, all identified subtypes have been identified in wild waterfowl. These birds are considered natural reservoirs of influenza viruses, some subtypes of which can be transmitted to other bird and mammalian species, including humans. Transmission between species appears to be regular and can occasionally lead to the adaptation and stable establishment of a new viral lineage in a particular species. Recalling the genetic diversity of avian, porcine and human influenza viruses, this review focuses on lesser-known influenza A viruses that have been identified in horses, dogs and, more recently, bats. It discusses the genetic mixing that can result from transmission between species and the associated risks of animal diseases, zoonosis and pandemics.
authors: Rivailler, P.;Moisy, D.;Naffakh, N.

title: Detection of cattle infected with bovine viral diarrhea virus using nucleic acid hybridization
abstract: ribonucleic acid (RNA) hybridization assay for identifying bovine viral diarrheal virus (BVDV) infected cattle is described. The RNA probe was derived from the coding region at the 3' end of the genome of the NADL strain of BVDV. Total RNA from infected cell cultures or peripheral blood leukocytes from suspect animals was extracted and spotted onto nylon membranes using a slot blot device. Peripheral blood leukocytes were simultaneously tested for BVDV by virus isolation. The results of hybridization and virus isolation agreed 92% of the time. Compared to virus isolation, hybridization had a detection sensitivity of 59.5% and a specificity of 95%. Cross-reactivity with RNA extracts from Border Disease Virus-infected cells has been observed. No cross-reactivity has been demonstrated with other common bovine viruses (bovine herpesvirus-1, bovine respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza virus-3 and bluetongue virus), with viruses classified in related families (equine arteritis virus and Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus), or detected against viruses with similar genomic organization (dengue virus type 2 and Japanese encephalitis virus).
authors: Roberts, K. L.;Collins, J. K.;Carman, J.;Blair, C. D.

title: First report of apple mosaic virus in Alaska
abstract: The apple mosaic virus (ApMV; family Bromoviridae, genus Ilarvirus) is one of the oldest and economically most important viruses of the apple (Malus x domestica Borkh.) (1,3). Yield losses can vary from negligible to as much as 50% depending on the variety affected. Although ApMV is found worldwide and occurs naturally in more than 65 plant species (1), it has not previously been reported to occur in Alaska. In July 2011, conspicuous light yellow mosaic leaves were observed on the 'Valentine' apple and its root stem 'Ranetka' from an apple orchard in Wasilla, AK. Leaves were collected and extracted by reverse transcription (RT)-PCR using ApMV-specific primers (2) and total RNA with buffer modifications to the RNeasy Plant Mini Kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA). Briefly, 50 mg of leaf tissue was suspended in liquid nitrogen and 450 mL of SE buffer (0.14 M NaCl, 2 mM KCl, 2 mM KH 2 PO 4 , 8 mM Na<sub>2</sub>HPO<sub>4< /sub>.2H<sub>2</sub>O [pH 7.4], 0.05% v/v Tween-20, 2% w/v Polyvinylpyrrolidone 40 , 0.2% wt /vol ovalbumin, 0.5% w/v bovine serum albumin and 0.05% w/v sodium azide) were added and after vigorous vortexing 80 µl of the mixture was added to 400 µl RLT buffer supplied by the Kit and then processed according to the manufacturer's instructions (4). Direct sequencing of the predicted ~260 bp PCR product, when analyzed by BLAST, resulted in 97-98% nucleotide identities with ApMV accessions in GenBank. To determine the distribution and incidence of infection in the Wasilla orchard, all 118 apple trees (99 cultivars) were then sampled and serologically analyzed by double antibody sandwich ELISA with ApMV antiserum according to the manufacturer's protocol (Agdia, Inc., Elkhart, IN). The 'Geneva Early' apple and the same 'Valentine' tree and its rootstock tested positive for ApMV by ELISA and RT-PCR. Strong diagnostic ApMV symptoms were not evident in the infected 'Geneva Early', which is typical for most commercially grown apples. No leaves were available for virus indexing on the 'Ranetka' rootstock of the ApMV-infected 'Geneva Early'. An additional 21 asymptomatic apple trees from an orchard in Talkeetna, AK, tested negative for ApMV by ELISA. Limited natural spread of ApMV to other plants can occur through pollen and seed transmission. The most common route of transmission is from ApMV-infected rootstocks and slips. It is important to source new propagating plant material from certified virus-tested nurseries and to avoid grafting ApMV-containing plant material. To my knowledge, this is the first report of ApMV in Alaska. References: (1) RW Fulton. No. 83. CMI/AAB Descriptions of Plant Viruses. 1972. (2) W. Menzel et al. J.Virol.
authors: Robertson, N. L.

title: Genomics and Outbreak Investigation: From Sequence to Consequence
abstract: Outbreaks of infection can be devastating for individuals and societies. In this review, we examine the applications of new high-throughput sequencing approaches to identify and characterize outbreaks, focusing on the application of whole genome sequencing (WGS) to bacterial infection outbreaks. We describe traditional epidemiological analyzes and show how WGS can be informative in multiple steps of outbreak investigation, as evidenced by many recent studies. We conclude that high-throughput sequencing approaches can make a significant contribution to studying bacterial infection outbreaks and that the integration of WGS with epidemiological surveys, diagnostic assays, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing will bring about radical changes in clinical microbiology and epidemiology of infectious diseases in the near future . However, several challenges remain before WGS can be routinely used in outbreak investigation and clinical practice. © 2013 BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Robinson, E. R.;Walker, T. M.;Pallen, M. J.

title: Recent advances in henipavirus research: molecular biology, genetic diversity, animal models
abstract: Nipah and Hendra viruses are members of a newly identified genus of emerging paramyxoviruses called henipaviruses. Both viruses can cause serious lung infections and severe acute encephalitis. Since their discovery in the 1990s, outbreaks of these zoonotic paramyxoviruses have been associated with a high potential for public health and, in particular, for the economy. Currently, only geographic groupings in Asia and Australia have been described for the henipaviruses. Although few virus isolates are available and more detailed characterization is needed, there is recent evidence that distinct henipaviruses may be present on the African continent. This review attempts to capture recent advances in the field of henipavirus research, with a focus on genome structure and replication mechanisms, reservoir hosts, genetic diversity, pathogenesis, and animal models. © 2012 Elsevier BV.
authors: Rockx, B.;Winegar, R.;Freiberg, A. N.

title: The bovine leukemia virus can be divided into seven genotypes: Evidence for the existence of two new clades
abstract: Previous studies have classified the env sequences of the bovine leukemia virus (BLV) provirus from different locations worldwide into two to four genetic groupings. These various studies gave unique names to the identified groups, and no study to date has integrated all available sequences. Therefore, we hypothesized that many of the different groups previously identified actually correspond to a limited set of genotypes that are unevenly distributed worldwide. To test this hypothesis, we sequenced the env gene of 28 BLV field strains and compared these sequences to 46 env sequences representing all previously identified genetic groupings. Through the use of phylogenetic analysis, we have discovered six clades, or genotypes, which we have termed genotypes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. Genotypes 1-5 have counterparts among the previously identified sequence groupings. One env sequence did not aggregate with any of the others and was highly divergent compared to the six genotypes identified here. Therefore, an additional genotype, which we have named 7, may exist. Similarity comparisons were highly congruent with phylogenetic analyses. In addition, our analyzes confirmed the existence of geographic clusters. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Rodriguez, S. M.;Golemba, M. D.;Campos, R. H.;Trono, K.;Jones, L. R.

title: Ultrastructural findings in lymph nodes of pigs suffering from naturally occurring post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome
abstract: The aim of this study was to assess ultrastructural lesions in lymph nodes of pigs affected by post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS) and to correlate these changes with the detection of viral particles (VLPs). Lymph node samples were collected from 4 PMWS-affected pigs and 2 healthy animals and processed by transmission electron microscopy. Significant ultrastructural changes were found only in PMWS-affected pigs, mainly in histiocytes and rarely in other cell types. The histiocytes showed extensive swelling and proliferation of mitochondria, as well as proliferation and dilation of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi complex. Infected histiocytes contained large numbers of intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (ICI) with VLPs; some histiocytes also had intranuclear inclusions (INIs). Small inclusions were surrounded by a double membrane that was granular in appearance or contained paracrystalline arrays; icosahedral VLPs were 8–17 nm in diameter. Large ICIs were double membrane bounded or not and contained VLPs that usually form paracrystalline arrays. ICIs have often been found adjacent to, and also within, mitochondria with severe swelling. INIs were not surrounded by membranes and contained virions with a diameter of 10-13 nm. Lymphocyte depletion was a prominent finding of lymph nodes from PMWS-affected pigs. The inclusion bodies mentioned in the present study that contain VLPs should be classified as viral factories, suggesting that viral replication is likely a common event in macrophages in which mitochondria might play a role.
authors: Rodriguez-CariÃ±o, C.;SegalÃ©s, J.

title: Characterization of p20 gene sequences from a border disease-like pestivirus isolated from pigs
abstract: pestivirus isolated from pigs with hemorrhagic lesions was antigenically more similar to border disease virus (BD) than to porcine cholera (HC) or bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) viruses. After reverse transcription, the genome was amplified at the 5' end along with the same region from a sheep BD isolate by the polymerase chain reaction and cloned. The region of the p20 gene was sequenced and compared to published data for BVD and HC viruses. A number of motifs have been conserved in the amino acid sequences of all viruses. The porcine isolate had a greater degree of homology with the BD isolate (87%) than with BVD (73%) or HC viruses (74%) in this region. This further confirms the BD-like nature of the virus.
authors: Roehe, P. M.;Woodward, M. J.;Edwards, S.

title: Natural case of bovine herpesvirus 1 meningoencephalitis in an adult cow
authors: Roels, S.;Charlier, G.;Letellier, C.;Meyer, G.;Schynts, F.;Kerkhofs, P.;Thiry, E.;Vanopdenbosch, E.

title: Characterization of five unclassified orthobunyaviruses (Bunyaviridae) from Africa and America
abstract: The Bunyaviridae family consists of a variety of viruses, some of which cause disease and are of concern for human and animal health. Here we report the genomic and antigenic characterization of five previously uncharacterized bunyaviruses. Based on their ultrastructure, antigenic relationships, and phylogenomic relationships, the five viruses are classified as members of the Orthobunyavirus genus. Three are viruses of the California encephalitis virus serogroup and are related to the trivittatus virus; the other two are most similar to Mermet virus in the Simbu serogroup and Tataguine virus, which is not currently assigned to any serogroup. Each of these five viruses was pathogenic to newborn mice, indicating their potential to cause disease in humans and other animals.
authors: Rogers, M. B.;Gulino, K. M.;Tesh, R. B.;Cui, L.;Fitch, A.;Unnasch, T. R.;Popov, V. L.;Travassos da Rosa, A. P. A.;Guzman, H.;Carrera, J. P.;Vasilakis, N.;Ghedin, E.

title: Reemergence of a new variant of the H5N1 avian influenza virus, subclass 2.2.1.1, in Egypt in 2014
abstract: Large-scale surveillance is critical to understanding the evolution and emergence of avian influenza viruses (AIVs) in endemic areas. The spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza subtype H5N1 (HPAI) continues to cause significant economic losses to the Egyptian poultry industry and poses a public health threat. In this report, an HPAI H5N1 strain (A/chicken/Egypt/Fadllah-7/2014) was detected in a vaccinated flock showing clinical signs of infection. Genetic characterization of the isolate showed a high level of nucleotide identity (95-98%) with variants and classic groups of H5N1. In addition, multiple nucleotide and amino acid alignments revealed several prominent and characteristic substitutions in the surface glycoprotein that may have biological relevance to the pathobiology of the virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the reported isolate is closely related to H5N1 AIVs subclade 2.2.1.1, although there have been no reports of this subclade of AI-reported cases in Egyptian bird species since 2011. In conclusion, our results highlight the re-emergence of a new subclass 2.2.1.1 H5N1 AIV variant that may escape vaccine-induced immunity. This discovery illustrates the importance of continuous surveillance of poultry in this country for the control of AIV, including identification of vaccine seed virus sources.
authors: Rohaim, M. A.;El-Naggar, R. F.;Hamoud, M. M.;Nasr, S. A.;Ismael, E.;Laban, S. E.;Ahmed, H. A.;Munir, M.

title: Do hemagglutinin genes of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses form unique phylogenetic lineages?
abstract: Avian influenza A viruses of subtypes H5 and H7 periodically cause severe disease outbreaks in poultry. The question we wanted to address in this study is whether these highly pathogenic strains represent unique lineages or whether they and related nonpathogenic viruses descended from a common ancestor in the wild bird reservoir. We therefore compared the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the hemagglutinin (HA) genes of 15 H5 and 26 H7 influenza A viruses isolated over 91 years from a variety of host species in Eurasia, Africa, Australia and North America HA- Genes of H5 and H7 viruses, which cause severe diseases in domestic birds, do not form unique lineages but share common ancestors with nonpathogenic H5 and H7 viruses. These results predict that the highly pathogenic H5 and H7 avian influenza A viruses will continue to emerge from wild bird reservoirs. Another important question is whether H7 influenza viruses found in mammalian species originate from avian strains. We included eight equine influenza viruses and one seal isolate in the phylogenetic analysis of the H7-HA genes. We were able to show that the HA genes of both equine and seal viruses share common ancestors with the avian H7-HA genes. This indicates that currently circulating H7 viruses with an avian HA gene may have the potential to adapt to mammalian species and cause an influenza outbreak in the new host.
authors: Rohm, C.;Horimoto, T.;Kawaoka, Y.;Suss, J.;Webster, R. G.

title: 454-Pyrosequencing: A Molecular Battiscope for Freshwater Viral Ecology
abstract: Viruses, the most abundant biological entity on the planet, are capable of infecting organisms from all three branches of life, although most bacteria infect where the greatest cellular diversity resides. However, characterization and assessment of viral diversity in natural settings is only gradually becoming possible. By developing a novel technique for harvesting viral DNA and applying 454 pyrosequencing, a snapshot of the diversity of DNA viruses harvested from a stagnant pond on a cattle ranch was obtained. A large number of viral genotypes (785) were present within the virome. The absolute numbers of lambdoid and Shiga toxin (Stx)-encoding phage detected indicated that the depth of sequencing allowed recovery of only approximately 8% of the total virus population, numbers falling within less than an order of magnitude with dilution analysis predictions agreed. The most common viral genotypes in the pond were bacteriophages (93.7%). The predominant viral genotypes found associated with the farm and infecting higher life forms were pathogens causing disease in cattle and humans, e.g. B. Members of the Herpesviridae. The techniques and analyzes described here offer a new approach to monitoring viral populations in the aquatic environment, with the potential to become an integral part of the development of risk analysis tools to monitor the spread of viral pathogens of animal, plant and human diseases. © 2010 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Rooks, D. J.;Smith, D. L.;McDonald, J. E.;Woodward, M. J.;McCarthy, A. J.;Allison, H. E.

title: Studies on genetic relationships between bovine, caprine, cervine and rangiferin alphaherpesviruses and improved molecular methods for virus detection and identification
abstract: The genes for glycoprotein B (gB) and D (gD) of five ruminant alphaherpesviruses, bovine herpesvirus 1 (BHV-1), bovine herpesvirus 5 (BHV-5), caprine herpesvirus 1 (CapHV-1), cervin -Herpesvirus 1 and Rangiferin herpesvirus 1, have been partially sequenced. Nucleotide sequence alignments revealed a highly conserved gB gene with homologies ranging between 87.2 and 99.6% and a more variable gD gene with homologies ranging between 71.3 and 98.9%. Phylogenetic analysis of the gB and gD nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences revealed that BHV-5 is the virus most closely related to the BHV-1 subtype 1 and BHV-1 subtype 2 cluster and that CapHV-1 the most distantly related virus is . The phylogenetic data showed that all viruses examined were closely related to Suid Herpesvirus 1. Based on sequence data for the gB gene, a nested PCR combined with restriction enzyme analysis (REA) of the PCR products was developed for simultaneous detection and identification of the viruses examined. Nested primers were selected from highly conserved sequence stretches to amplify a 294 bp region in all five viruses and subsequent REA of the PCR products allowed specific identification. A mimic molecule was constructed to serve as an internal standard for amplification efficiency. The practical diagnostic utility of the assay was evaluated with clinical specimens consisting of semen and organ samples from experimentally infected animals.
authors: Ros, C.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Review of the taxonomy of the family Circoviridae: establishment of the genus Cyclovirus and removal of the genus Gyrovirus
abstract: The Circoviridae family contains viruses with covalently closed, circular, single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genomes, including the smallest known autonomously replicating, capsid-encoding animal pathogens. Members of this family are known to cause fatal diseases in birds and swine and have historically been classified into one of two genera: circovirus, which includes avian and swine pathogens, and gyrovirus, which comprises a single species (chicken anemia virus). However, over the past six years, viral metagenomic approaches as well as degenerate PCR detection in unconventional hosts and environmental samples have elucidated a broader range of hosts, including fish, a variety of mammals, and invertebrates for members of the family Circoviridae. Notably, these methods have uncovered a distinct group of viruses closely related to members of the Circovirus genus, comprising a new genus, Cyclovirus. The discovery of new viruses and a reassessment of genomic traits that characterize members of the Circoviridae prompted a revision of the classification criteria used for this family of animal viruses. Here we provide details of an updated Circoviridae taxonomy ratified in 2016 by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses that establishes the genus Cyclovirus and places the genus Gyrovirus in the family Anelloviridae, a separate lineage of animal viruses that also have circular ssDNA contains genomes. In addition, we provide a new species cut-off threshold of 80% genome-wide pairwise identity for members of the family Circoviridae based on pairwise identity distribution analysis, and list guidelines to distinguish between members of this family and other eukaryotic viruses with circular ssDNA genomes.
authors: Rosario, K.;Breitbart, M.;Harrach, B.;SegalÃ©s, J.;Delwart, E.;Biagini, P.;Varsani, A.

title: The whitefly viral RNA metagenome leads to the discovery and characterization of a whitefly-borne carlavirus in North America
abstract: Whiteflies from the species complex Bemisia tabaci can transmit a large number of plant viruses and are among the most harmful pests in agriculture. Although whiteflies are known to transmit both DNA and RNA viruses, most of the diversity has been recorded for the former, particularly for the Begomovirus genus. This study examined the overall diversity of DNA and RNA viruses found in whiteflies collected from a single Florida site to assess whether there are additional, previously undiscovered virus types within the B. tabaci vector . The metagenomic analysis of viral DNA extracted from the whiteflies only detected begomoviruses. In contrast, whiteflies contained sequences similar to RNA viruses from different groups, with a diversity beyond currently described viruses. Metagenomic analysis of whiteflies also led to the first report of a whitefly-borne RNA virus similar to Cowpea Mild Mottle Virus (CpMMV Florida) (genus Carlavirus) in North America. Further investigation led to the detection of CpMMV Florida in native and cultivated plants growing near the original field site of the whitefly collection and the determination of its experimental host range. Analysis of complete CpMMV Florida genomes obtained from whiteflies and plants suggests that the current classification criteria for carlaviruses need to be re-evaluated. Overall, metagenomic analysis supports that DNA plant viruses transmitted by B. tabaci are dominated by begomoviruses, while significantly less is known about RNA viruses present in this harmful insect vector. © 2014 Rosario et al.
authors: Rosario, K.;Capobianco, H.;Ng, T. F. F.;Breitbart, M.;Polston, J. E.

title: Diverse circovirus-like genome architectures revealed by environmental metagenomics
abstract: Circular genome single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) viruses are the smallest viruses known to infect eukaryotes. The present study identified 10 novel genomes resembling ssDNA circovinuses by data mining from public viral metagenomes. The metagenomic libraries included samples from treated water and three different marine environments (Chesapeake Bay, British Columbia coastal waters, and Sargasso Sea). All genomes share similarities with the replication protein (Rep) of circoviruses; however, only half have genomic features consistent with known circoviruses. Some of the genomes exhibit a mix of genomic features associated with different families of ssDNA viruses (i.e., circoviruses, geminiviruses, and parvoviruses). Unique genome architectures and phylogenetic analyzes of the Rep protein suggest that these viruses belong to novel genera and/or families. Studying the complex community of ssDNA viruses in the environment can lead to the discovery of distinct species and help elucidate evolutionary links between ssDNA viruses.
authors: Rosario, K.;Duffy, S.;Breitbart, M.

title: The discovery of viruses in all three major lineages of terrestrial arthropods underscores the diversity of single-stranded DNA viruses associated with invertebrates
abstract: Viruses encoding a replication-associated protein (Rep) within a covalently closed, single-stranded (ss)DNA genome are among the smallest viruses known to infect eukaryotic organisms, including economically valuable agricultural crops and livestock. Although circular Rep-encoding ssDNA (CRESS DNA) viruses are a widespread group for which our knowledge is rapidly increasing, biased sampling in relation to vertebrates and terrestrial plants has limited our understanding of their diversity and evolution. Here we screened terrestrial arthropods for CRESS DNA viruses and report the identification of 44 viral genomes and replicons associated with specimens representing all three major terrestrial arthropod lineages, namely Euchelicerata (spiders), Hexapoda (insects) and Myriapoda (centipedes). We identified virus genomes belonging to three established CRESS DNA virus families (Circoviridae, Genomoviridae, and Smacoviridae); however, more than half of the arthropod-associated viral genomes are only distantly related to currently classified CRESS viral DNA sequences. Although members of virus and satellite families known to infect plants (Geminiviridae, Nanoviridae, Alphasatellitidae) were not identified in this study, these plant-infecting CRESS DNA viruses and replicons are transmitted by Hemipterae. Therefore, members of six of the seven established CRESS DNA virus families circulate among arthropods. Furthermore, a phylogenetic analysis of Reps, including endogenous virus sequences, previously reported from a variety of organisms revealed that most of the known CRESS DNA virus diversity circulates among invertebrates. Our results underscore the enormous and unexplored diversity of CRESS DNA viruses among invertebrates and parallel results from efforts to discover RNA viruses in undersampled taxa.
authors: Rosario, K.;Mettel, K. A.;Benner, B. E.;Johnson, R.;Scott, C.;Yusseff-Vanegas, S. Z.;Baker, C. C. M.;Cassill, D. L.;Storer, C.;Varsani, A.;Breitbart, M.

title: Challenges of the Unknown: Clinical Applications of Microbial Metagenomics
abstract: The availability of rapid, high-throughput, and low-cost whole-genome sequencing holds promise in public health microbiology, with applications ranging from outbreak detection and transmission event tracking to understanding the role microbial communities play in health and disease. Within clinical metagenomics, the identification of microorganisms from a complex and host-rich background remains a key computational challenge. As a proof of principle, we sequenced two metagenomic samples, a known viral mix of 25 human pathogens and an unknown complex biological model using benchtop technology. The datasets were then analyzed using a bioinformatics pipeline designed around current rapid classification methods. A targeted approach was able to detect 20 of the viruses against a background of host contamination from multiple sources and bacterial contamination. An alternative, non-targeted identification method was highly correlated with these classifications and when applied to the complex biological model, over 1,600 species were identified, including several species recorded with over 50% genome coverage. In summary, this study demonstrates the great potential of applying metagenomics in the clinical laboratory setting and that it can be achieved with the infrastructure available to non-specialized sequencing centers.
authors: Rose, G.;Wooldridge, D. J.;Anscombe, C.;Mee, E. T.;Misra, R. V.;Gharbia, S.

title: Distribution of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus genotypes in Ontario in 2004-2007 and the association between genotype and clinical signs
abstract: Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) was first proposed in 1998 to classify porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV). The main objective of this study was to identify associations between different PRRSV-RFLP types in swine herds in southern Ontario and clinical signs of the disease in these herds. The herds included in the study submitted samples to the University of Guelph Animal Health Laboratory between September 2004 and August 2007. Each farm owner was interviewed to describe the clinical disease in the herd and the RFLP pattern of an isolate of PRRSV was obtained from a diagnostic sample. The most common isolates were RFLP types 1-4 (25.1%), 252 (14.7%), 134 (12%) and 1-2 (7.7%). It was noted that the distribution of RFLP types in this study differs from a previous study in Ontario. The RFLP types most strongly associated with clinical disease in the farrowing phase of production were 1-4, 1-2 and 134. The only virus type significantly associated with disease in the finishing phase was was RFLP type 262. During the study period, RFLP type 184 emerged in the population in November 2005.
authors: Rosendal, T.;Dewey, C.;Young, B.;Carman, S.;Ge, L.;Poljak, Z.

title: Deep sequencing reveals abundant noncanonical retroviral microRNAs in B-cell leukemia/lymphoma
abstract: Viral tumor models have contributed significantly to our understanding of oncogenic mechanisms. However, how transforming delta retroviruses induce malignancy remains poorly understood, particularly since viral mRNA/protein is tightly silenced in tumors. Here, we provide in vivo evidence for the production of noncanonical RNA polymerase III (Pol III)-transcribed viral microRNAs in leukemic B cells in the bovine leukemia virus sheep model of leukemia/lymphoma using deep window sequencing of wide windows of small RNA sizes complete lack of Pol II 5â€²LTR-driven transcriptional activity. Bovine leukemia virus microRNAs are processed from a cluster of five independent, self-sufficient transcription units in a proviral region dispensable for infectivity in vivo and account for ~40% of all microRNAs in both experimental and natural malignancies. They undergo strong purifying selection and associate with argonauts, consistent with a critical function in silencing important cellular and/or viral targets. Bovine leukemia virus microRNAs are highly expressed in preleukemic and malignant cells in which structural and regulatory gene expression is repressed, suggesting a key role in tumor onset and progression. Understanding how Pol III-dependent microRNAs infiltrate cellular and viral signaling pathways will help unravel the intricate disruptions underlying malignant transformation.
authors: Rosewick, N.;Momont, M.;Durkin, K.;Takeda, H.;Caiment, F.;Cleuter, Y.;Vernin, C.;Mortreux, F.;Wattel, E.;Burny, A.;Georges, M.;Van Den Broeke, A.

title: Metagenomics of rumen bacteriophages from thirteen lactating dairy cows
abstract: Background: The bovine rumen harbors a diverse and complex community of eukaryae, bacteria, archaea, and viruses (including bacteriophages). The viral population in the rumen (the rumen virome) has received little attention compared to the microbial population in the rumen (the rumen microbiome). We used massively parallel sequencing of virus-like particles to examine rumen virosome diversity in thirteen lactating Australian Holstein dairy cows, all housed at the same site, 12 of which were sampled on the same day. Results: Fourteen putative viral sequence fragments greater than 30 Kbp in length were assembled and annotated. Many of the putative genes in the assembled contigs showed no homology to previously annotated genes, underscoring the large amount of work still required to fully annotate the functions encoded in viral genomes. The frequency of the contig sequences varied greatly between animals, even though the cattle were of the same age and stage of lactation and received the same diets. Additionally, the twelve cohabiting animals shared a number of their dominant viral contigs. We compared the functional properties of our bovine viromes to those of other viromes and to rumen microbiomes. At a functional level, we found strong similarities between all virus samples, which differed greatly from the rumen microbiome samples. Conclusions: Our results indicate a large inter-animal variation in bovine rumen virome and that cohabiting animals may have similar viromes than non-cohabiting animals. We report on the most comprehensive sequencing of the rumen virus to date. This work highlights the tremendous amount of novelty and variation present in the rumen virome.
authors: Ross, E. M.;Petrovski, S.;Moate, P. J.;Hayes, B. J.

title: Identification and full genome sequencing of paramyxoviruses in mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) using random-access amplification and next-generation sequencing technologies
abstract: BACKGROUND: During a wildlife screening program for avian influenza A virus (AIV) and avian paramyxovirus (APMV) in Belgium, we isolated two haemagglutinating agents from cloacal swab pools of wild mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) collected at two different sampling sites times. AIV and APMV1 were excluded using hemagglutination inhibition (HI) testing and specific real-time RT-PCR testing. METHODS: To refine the virological identification of APMV2-10 by HI subtyping assays and in the absence of validated molecular assays for APMV2-10, random-access amplification was used in combination with next-generation sequencing for sequence-independent identification of the viruses and determination of their genomes. RESULTS: Three different APMVs were identified. The complete genome sequence (15054 nucleotides) of an APMV4 was assembled from the random sequences from a pooled sample. The almost complete genome sequence of an APMV6 (genome size of 16236 nucleotides) and a partial sequence of an APMV4 were determined from the second pooled sample. This APMV4 was closely related but not identical to the APMV4 isolated from the first sample. Although cross-reactivity with other APMV subtypes did not allow formal identification, HI subtyping revealed APMV4 and APMV6 in the respective pooled samples but failed to identify the co-infecting APMV4 in the APMV6-infected pool.
