CONCLUSIONS: These data further contribute to the knowledge of genetic diversity within serotypes APMV4 and 6 and confirm the limited sensitivity of the HI subtyping test. In addition, this study demonstrates the value of a random access nucleic acid amplification method in combination with massive parallel sequencing. Characterization and full genome sequencing of APMVs, including identification of viruses in mixed infections, can be achieved with only moderate and economical sequencing efforts.
authors: Rosseel, T.;Lambrecht, B.;Vandenbussche, F.;van den Berg, T.;Van Borm, S.

title: False positives in metagenomic virus detection: A strong case for subsequent diagnosis
abstract: viral metagenomic approach using virion enrichment, random amplification and next-generation sequencing was used to study an undiagnosed cohort of dairy cows with high persistent fever unresponsive to antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory treatment, diarrhea and nasal and teat redness addressed. Serum and whole blood samples were collected in the predicted hyperviremic state from an animal that showed these clinical signs a few days later. Bioinformatic analysis of the resulting data from the DNA virus identification workflow (a total of 32,757 sequences with an average read length of 335 bases) first showed the presence of parvovirus-like sequences in the tested blood sample. Thorough follow-up using specific real-time RT-PCR assays targeting the detected sequence fragments confirmed the presence of these sequences in the original sample as well as in a sample from an additional animal, but contamination with an identical genetic signature in negative extraction controls was demonstrated. Further investigations using an alternative extraction method identified contamination of the originally used Qiagen extraction columns with parvovirus-like nucleic acids or virus particles. Although we have not found any relevant virus to be associated with the disease, these observations clearly illustrate the importance of employing an appropriate control strategy and diagnostic follow-up testing in any viral metagenomic study. © 2014 Blackwell Verlag GmbH.
authors: Rosseel, T.;Pardon, B.;De Clercq, K.;Ozhelvaci, O.;Van Borm, S.

title: Next-generation DNase SISPA sequencing confirms Schmallenberg virus in Belgian field samples and identifies genetic variations in Europe
abstract: In 2011, a novel orthobunyavirus was identified in cattle and sheep in Germany and the Netherlands. This virus was named Schmallenberg virus (SBV). Later, the presence of the virus was confirmed by real-time RT-PCR in cases of bovine and ovine congenital malformations in several European countries, including Belgium. In the absence of specific sequencing protocols for this novel virus, we confirmed its presence in RT-qPCR positive field samples using DNase SISPA-Next Generation Sequencing (NGS), a virus discovery method based on random amplification and next-generation sequencing. An in vitro transcribed RNA was used to construct a standard curve allowing quantification of viral RNA in the field samples. Two field samples from aborted lambs with 7.66 and 7.64 log(10) RNA copies per microliter of total RNA allowed unequivocal identification of SBV. One sample yielded 192 SBV reads covering approximately 81% of the L segment, 56% of the M segment, and 13% of the S segment. The other sample resulted in 8 reads spread across the L and M segments. Three low positive field samples (one from an aborted calf, two from aborted lambs) with virus levels corresponding to 4.27-4.89 log(10) RNA copies per microliter failed to identify with DNase SISPA-NGS. This partial sequence information was compared to the full genome sequence of SBV isolated from cattle in Germany, identifying several sequence differences. The virus detection method used allowed the confirmation of SBV in RT-qPCR positive brain samples. However, the failure to confirm SBV in weakly PCR-positive samples demonstrates the importance of selecting properly targeted and fresh field samples in any virus detection method. The partial sequences obtained from the field samples showed some differences to the sequences from cattle in Germany, which indicates sequence divergences within the disease.
authors: Rosseel, T.;Scheuch, M.;Hoper, D.;De Regge, N.;Caij, A. B.;Vandenbussche, F.;Van Borm, S.

title: Markers for current or past hepatitis E virus infection are as common in wild ungulates as in humans in Sweden
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a zoonotic human pathogen that infects both domestic and wild animals. About 17% of the Swedish population is immune to HEV, but only a few cases are reported annually, indicating that most infections are subclinical. However, clinical hepatitis E can also be overlooked. In identified cases, the source of infection is usually unknown. To determine whether HEV can be transmitted from wild animals, the prevalence of markers for past and/or current infection in sera and stool samples from 260 hunted Swedish wild ungulates were examined. HEV markers were found in 43 (17%) of the animals. The most frequently infected animals were elk (Alces alces) with 19 out of 69 animals (28%) showing HEV markers, followed by wild boar (Sus scrofa) with 21 out of 139 animals (15%), roe deer (Capreolus capreolus) with 2 of 30 animals, red deer (Cervus elaphus) with 1 of 15 animals and fallow deer (Dama dama) with 0 of 7 animals. The partial open reading frame 1 (ORF1) of the viral genomes of the animals was sequenced and compared to those of 14 endemic human cases. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that three humans were infected with HEV strains similar to those found in wild boar. These results indicate that wildlife may be a source of transmission to humans and an unrecognized public health problem.
authors: Roth, A.;Lin, J.;Magnius, L.;Karlsson, M.;BelÃ¡k, S.;WidÃ©n, F.;Norder, H.

title: A new influenza A virus infection in turkeys. VII. Comparative Immunology
abstract: Four influenza A strains isolated from Ontario turkeys and the Chicken/Scotland/59 strain have been found to immunize turkeys against the deadly disease caused by the virus Turkey/Ontario 7732/66 (V7732). These viruses form avian influenza A serotype 5 (AA5). Immune protection against V7732 was not achieved with influenza viruses of other serotypes. Immunoprotective relationships between AA5 viruses were not always detectable in hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and serum neutralization (SN) tests, particularly with turkey and mammalian antisera; a better correlation between immunoprotection and these in vitro tests was observed with chicken antisera. The implications of these results in terms of virus classification, serodiagnosis, and vaccination are discussed.
authors: Rouse, B. T.;Lang, G.;Narayan, O.

title: Investigation of foot-and-mouth disease outbreak at a pig farm in Kollam district of Kerala, India
abstract: This paper describes the investigation into the foot and mouth disease (FMD) outbreak at a private pig farm in Kotty, Kollam district of Kerala in October 2013. During the clinical phase, severe vesicular lesions appeared on the snout and the skin around the coronary ligaments observed in pigs. A total of 48 serum samples and 12 clinical samples (ruptured snout epithelia) were collected. All serum samples were subjected to an indirect 3AB nonstructural protein (NSP) ELISA and a liquid phase blocking (LPB) ELISA. In the 3AB NSP ELISA, all serum samples were found positive for NSP antibodies, indicating infection. In the LPB-ELISA, 42 of 48 (87.5%) pigs were found to have a protective log10 antibody titer ≥1.8 against FMD virus serotypes O, A and Asia 1. All clinical materials were found positive for serotype O by antigen detection ELISA and multiplex reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (mRT-PCR). A phylogenetic analysis based on the VP1 region found that the serotype O isolates that caused the outbreak were clustered within the Ind2001 lineage. Pigs infected with FMD can pose a serious threat to other susceptible livestock because they exhale enormous amounts of virus. Consequently, they should be included in the prophylactic vaccination and surveillance programs ongoing in the country.
authors: Rout, M.;Subramaniam, S.;Mohapatra, J. K.;Dash, B. B.;Pattnaik, B.

title: Discovery of a new avian Bornavirus genotype in finches (Estrildidae) in Germany
abstract: Avian bornaviruses (ABV) are known to be the causative agents of proventricular dilatation disease (PDD) in parrots and their relatives (Psittaciformes). A wide range of ABV genotypes has been demonstrated not only in parrots but also in other bird species including canaries (Serinus canaria forma domestica) and Bengal finches (Lonchura striata f. dom.), both of which belong to the order Passeriformes. . In this study, 286 samples from captive and wild birds of different sparrow species in different parts of Germany were analyzed for the presence of ABV. Interestingly, only three ABV positive samples were identified by RT-PCR. They are descended from a Yellow-winged Pytilia (Pytilia hypogrammica) and two Black-rumped Waxbills (Estrilda troglodytes) from a flock of captive finches in Saxony. The ABV isolates detected here were only distantly related to ABV isolates found in sparrow species in Germany and Japan, and form a new genotype provisionally named ABV-EF (for "estrildid finches").
authors: Rubbenstroth, D.;Schmidt, V.;Rinder, M.;Legler, M.;Corman, V. M.;Staeheli, P.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated in mainland China between 2001 and 2009
abstract: Twenty Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from infected chicken flocks in China in 2001-2009 were characterized biologically and genetically. All 20 NDVs were classified into velogenic (n=17) and lentogenic (n=3) viruses according to the mean time of death (MDT) of chick embryos. Velogenic viruses carry the 112R-RQKR/F117 (n = 14) or 112G-RQGR/L117 (n = 3) motif at the F0 cleavage site, while all lentogenic viruses carry a sequence motif of 112G-RQGR/L117 (n = 3) at the the same place. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that at least three distinct genotypes (genotypes I, II and VII) existed in chicken flocks in China and VIId of genotype VII were mainly responsible for the current ND panzootics. Two natural recombinants (XD/Shandong/08 and QG/Hebei/07) were assumed and identified by the SimPlot program, and their two parental strains could be of the NDV vaccine line and the VIId velogen line, respectively. The results indicate that recombination plays a role in NDV evolution and the live vaccines have the ability to promote NDV evolution through homologous recombination with circulating virus. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Rui, Z.;Juan, P.;Jingliang, S.;Jixun, Z.;Xiaoting, W.;Shouping, Z.;Xiaojiao, L.;Guozhong, Z.

title: The potential of respiratory droplet-borne influenza virus A/H5N1 to evolve in a mammalian host
abstract: Avian influenza viruses A/H5N1 pose a pandemic threat. As little as five amino acid substitutions, or four with rearrangement, may be sufficient for mammalian-to-mammalian respiratory droplet transmission. From surveillance data we have found that two of these substitutions are common in A/H5N1 viruses, and therefore some viruses may require only three additional substitutions to become transmissible via respiratory droplets between mammals. We used a mathematical model of virus evolution within the host to study factors that might increase or decrease the likelihood that the remaining substitutions will evolve after the virus has infected a mammalian host. These factors, combined with the presence of some of these substitutions in circulating strains, make a virus evolving in nature a potentially serious threat. These results highlight critical areas where more data is needed to assess and potentially mitigate this threat.
authors: Russell, C. A.;Fonville, J. M.;Brown, A. E.;Burke, D. F.;Smith, D. L.;James, S. L.;Herfst, S.;van Boheemen, S.;Linster, M.;Schrauwen, E. J.;Katzelnick, L.;Mosterin, A.;Kuiken, T.;Maher, E.;Neumann, G.;Osterhaus, A. D.;Kawaoka, Y.;Fouchier, R. A.;Smith, D. J.

title: H1N1 influenza viruses with widely differing haemagglutinin stability are efficiently transmitted from pig to pig and to ferrets
abstract: pandemic-capable influenza virus requires a hemagglutinin (HA) surface glycoprotein that is immunologically unseen by most humans and capable of supporting human replication and transmission. HA stabilization has been linked to the 2009 human pH1N1 pandemic potential and the airborne transmissibility of H5N1 in the ferret model. Pigs have served as an intermediate host for zoonotic influenza viruses, but the evolutionary pressure this host exerts on HA stability was unknown. For over 70 contemporary porcine H1 and H3 isolates, we found the pH of HA activation to range from pH 5.1 to 5.9 for H1 viruses and pH 5.3 to 5.8 for H3 viruses measured. Thus, contemporary porcine isolates vary widely in HA stability, with values favored by both avian (pH > 5.5) and human and ferret (pH <= 5.5) species. Using an early 2009 pandemic H1N1 (pH1N1) viral backbone, we generated three viruses that differed by an HA residue that altered only HA stability: WT (pH 5.5), HA1-Y17H (pH 6, 0) and HA2-R106K (pH 5.3). All three replicated in pigs and were transmitted from pig to pig and from pig to ferret. WT and R106 viruses retained the HA genotype and phenotype after transmission. Y17H (pH 6.0) acquired HA mutations that stabilized the HA protein to pH 5.8 after transfer to pigs and to 5.5 after transfer to ferrets. Overall, we found that pigs support a wide range of HA activation pHs for contact transmission, and many recent pig H1N1 and H3N2 isolates have stabilized (human-like) HA proteins. This represents an increased risk of a pandemic and underscores the importance of ongoing swine virus surveillance and control.
authors: Russier, M.;Yang, G.;Marinova-Petkova, A.;Vogel, P.;Kaplan, B. S.;Webby, R. J.;Russell, C. J.

title: Discovery of an expanded set of avian leukosis subgroup E proviruses in chickens using Vermillion, a novel sequence acquisition and analysis pipeline
abstract: Transposable elements (TEs), such as B. endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), are widespread in the genomes of vertebrates. ERVs result from retroviral infections of germline cells, and once integrated into host DNA, they become part of the host's heritable genetic material. ERVs have been attributed positive effects on host physiology, such as generation of novel, adaptive genetic variations and resistance to infection, and negative effects as causative agents of tumorigenesis and disease. The avian leukosis virus subgroup E family (ALVE) of chicken endogenous viruses has been used as a model system to study the effects of ERVs on host physiology, and approximately 30 different ALVE proviruses have been described in the Gallus gallus genome. In this report we describe the development of a software tool we call Vermillion and the use of this tool in combination with targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) to count the number of known proviruses belonging to the ALVE family of ERVs. to increase the chicken genome four-fold, including expanding the number of known ALVE elements on chromosome 1 (Gga1) from the current 9 to a total of 40. Although we focused on the discovery of ALVE elements in chickens, with an appropriate choice of target sequences Vermillion can be used to develop profiles of other families of ERVs and TEs in chickens as well as in non-chicken species.
authors: Rutherford, K.;Meehan, C. J.;Langille, M. G.;Tyack, S. G.;McKay, J. C.;McLean, N. L.;Benkel, K.;Beiko, R. G.;Benkel, B.

title: Identification and classification of bovine leukemia virus isolates in Russia and Ukraine based on pol virus gene polymorphism
abstract: The bovine leukemia virus (BLV) is a widespread specific bovine pathogen. Analysis of pol virus gene polymorphism was used to characterize the polymorphism of BLV isolates on cattle herds in Russia and Ukraine. The fragments of the pol gene corresponding to reverse transcriptase and integrase, 494 and 233 bp, respectively, were used for the analysis. Phylogenetic analysis has revealed multiple variants of BLV clustered with high bootstrap support in Russia and Ukraine. A new classification of BLV variants is proposed. A comparison of phylograms based on the polymorphism of the nucleotide sequences of the integrase and reverse transcriptase domains revealed no topological conflicts. Therefore, no recombination between BLV variants was found. © 2012 Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.
authors: Ruzina, M. N.;Andrianov, B. V.;Shaikhaev, G. O.;Sulimova, G. E.

title: Serological differentiation of FMD virus strains in relation to the selection of suitable vaccine viruses
abstract: Serological differentiation for the purpose of selecting appropriate vaccine strains or for advice on vaccine use attempts to predict whether a particular vaccine/antigen is likely to induce antibodies protective against predominant field strains. The purpose of such distinctions is not identical to virus classification. It is therefore proposed that the most appropriate measure of this relationship (r) is given by: r = serum activity against heterologous (field) strain/serum activity against homologous (vaccine) strain. A comparison of the complement fixation test with viral neutralization test systems - i.e. metabolic inhibition (color), plaque reduction, a two-dimensional microneutralization cytopathy endpoint (microneut.) and neutralization kinetics - showed that the two test systems did not always produce identical results. Experience has also shown that in cattle there is a good correlation between neutralizing serum titre and challenge protection in both homologous and heterologous systems. It is possible to demonstrate a dose-response relationship between vaccine antigen dose and neutralizing serum titer. It is therefore suggested that the preferred strain comparison test for the purpose of vaccine use should be one based on the virus neutralization system. When comparing two virus strains, their identity must be assumed until their probable difference has been shown. It is therefore necessary for any test system to know the intrinsic test error in order to detect the smallest statistically significant difference between two test values. An analysis of the power of the different test systems used in our laboratory is presented. Experience has shown that methods of handling and storing vaccine viruses can lead to significant changes in the biophysical properties of the virus, e.g. virulence, plaque morphology, sucrose density gradient behavior, even antigenic shift and immunogenicity. It is therefore suggested that, as far as possible, reference antisera for comparing strains to assess the use of vaccines should be prepared from the strains currently used in vaccine production.
authors: Rweyemamu, M. M.;Pay, T. W. F.;Parker, M. J.

title: Universal oligonucleotide microarray for influenza A virus subtyping
abstract: universal microchip was developed for the genotyping of influenza A viruses. It contains two sets of oligonucleotide probes that allow to classify viruses according to the subtypes of hemagglutinin (H1-H13, H15, H16) and neuraminidase (N1-N9). Additional probe sets are used to detect H1N1 swine influenza virus. The probes were selected in two steps. First, amino acid sequences specific to each subtype were identified and then the most specific and representative oligonucleotide probes were selected. A total of between 19 and 24 probes were used to identify each subtype of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). Genotyping involved the production of fluorescently labeled PCR amplicons from influenza virus cDNA and their hybridization to microarrays of specific oligonucleotide probes. Of 40 samples tested, 36 clearly identified the HA and NA subtypes of influenza A virus.
authors: Ryabinin, V. A.;Kostina, E. V.;Maksakova, G. A.;Neverov, A. A.;Chumakov, K. M.;Sinyakov, A. N.

title: Diversity of invertebrate RNA virus from a taxonomic perspective
abstract: Invertebrates are hosts to various RNA viruses, which have all possible types of encapsulated genomes (positive, negative, and ambisense single-stranded RNA genomes or a double-stranded RNA genome). These viruses also differ markedly in virion morphology and genome structure. Invertebrate RNA viruses occur in three out of four currently recognized orders of RNA viruses: Mononegavirales, Nidovirales, and Picornavirales, and 10 out of 37 RNA virus families that have yet to be assigned to an order. This brief report describes general characteristics of the taxonomic groups to which invertebrate RNAviruses belong based on their current classification by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV). (C) 2016 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Ryabov, E. V.

title: Canid biotype rabies in wild dogs (Lycaon pictus) and spotted hyenas (Crocuta crocuta) in Madikwe Game Reserve, South Africa, 2014-2015: diagnosis, possible origins and implications for control
abstract: Rabies virus (RABV) infection is commonly diagnosed in South Africa in both native and wild carnivore species. Although the majority of confirmed rabies cases in wild carnivore species are reported from the yellow mongoose (Cynictis penicillata), the rest are from other wild carnivores, including the critically endangered wild dog (Lycaon pictus). Lyssavirus infection was confirmed in 2014 and 2015 in two wild dogs and one spotted hyena (Crocuta crocuta) at Madikwe Game Reserve, North West Province, South Africa using direct fluorescent antibody testing and immunohistochemistry. No new wild dogs have been introduced into Madikwe Game Reserve for many years and the wild dogs were last vaccinated against rabies about 11 years before the incident. The first wild dog euthanized was the last survivor of a rogue pack of 6, and the second was the last of a larger pack of 18, the remainder of which died with no carcasses found or carcasses too decomposed to sample. Subsequent antigenic typing of the lyssaviruses revealed that they were canid RABVs. The RABVs, derived from 22 wild carnivore species, 7 dogs and one goat, mainly from the Northwest Province, were genetically characterized by targeting a subregion of the nucleoprotein gene. Nucleotide sequence analyzes of these viruses and two previously characterized RABVs confirmed that the outbreak viruses were also canid rabies, phylogenetically associated with virus isolates from black-backed jackals recovered between 2012 and 2015 in the Northwest Province and domestic dogs from neighboring communities. The source(s) of the deaths and possible reservoir hosts for the virus could only be speculated based on data on specific predator numbers, movements and behaviour, killings, park management and the changing environmental ecology that have been closely monitored at Madikwe over several years. The most likely sources of rabies were border fence contacts between wild carnivores within the park, with domestic dogs or cats, and/or naturally occurring wild carnivores outside the park. The associated risk of zoonotic infection and threat to important and vulnerable predators can be mitigated through regional rabies control, primarily in domestic dogs and cats, and preventive vaccination of vulnerable park employees and their pets. The importance of continued prophylactic rabies protection through regular vaccination of critically endangered wild animal carnivores and submission of carcasses for rabies diagnosis of wild or domestic animals that behave uncharacteristically or are found dead is emphasized.
authors: Sabeta, C. T.;Janse Van Rensburg, D. D.;Phahladira, B.;Mohale, D.;Harrison-White, R. F.;Esterhuyzen, C.;Williams, J. H.

title: Characterization of a novel VIII subgenotype of Newcastle disease virus circulating in Iran
abstract: Newcastle disease is an economically important and highly contagious disease affecting wild and domestic bird species. Despite extensive vaccination efforts in the poultry industry, outbreaks of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) still occur, causing significant economic losses. Farm chickens may serve as a potential reservoir of NDVs for commercial poultry due to poor biosecurity and inadequate vaccination. The aim of this study was to investigate the phylogenetic relatedness and molecular characterization of eight NDVs isolated from backyard fowl in Iran between 2011 and 2013. The complete coding sequence of the fusion (F) and hemagglutinin neuraminidase (HN) genes of eight NDVs was determined and compared to other published NDVs. Based on distances between populations and phylogenetic topology between available NDV categories, Iranian isolates formed a new VIIl subgenotype distinct from previous groups, which have been termed genotype VII. In addition, both F and HN genes of the Iranian isolates shared high nucleotide sequence similarity to viruses isolated in China. All viruses analyzed contained a polybasic cleavage site motif (111G/RRRQKRâ†“F117), indicating that all isolates could be categorized as a virulent pathotype. No mutation was observed in the neutralizing epitopes of the F protein. Analysis of amino acids associated with neutralizing antigenic sites within the HN protein revealed that all isolates had a unique amino acid (Q) at position 347. These findings underscore the need to reinforce the biosecurity measures implemented on village flocks and to practice a mandatory vaccination program for domestic poultry. In addition, continuous monitoring of NDVs in different bird species can help gain more knowledge about the evolution of this virus and prevent future panzoa.
authors: Sabouri, F.;Vasfi Marandi, M.;Bashashati, M.

title: Simultaneous identification of DNA and RNA viruses in pig feces by process-driven deep sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: Animal feces contain a community of many different microorganisms, including bacteria and viruses. Little information is available on the diversity of viruses in pig faeces. Here we describe a protocol optimized for the purification of the total fraction of virus particles from pig feces. The genomes of the purified DNA and RNA viruses were simultaneously amplified by PCR and subjected to deep sequencing followed by bioinformatic analysis. The efficiency of the procedure was monitored using a process control consisting of three bacteriophages (T4, M13 and MS2) with different morphologies and genome types. Defined amounts of the bacteriophage were added to the sample and their abundance determined by quantitative PCR during the preparation process. RESULTS: The method was applied to a pooled fecal sample from five pigs. 69,613 sequence reads were generated from this sample. All added bacteriophage were identified by sequence analysis of the reads. Overall, 7.7% of the reads showed significant sequence identities with published viral sequences. They were mainly from bacteriophage (73.9%) and mammalian viruses (23.9%); 0.8% of the sequences showed identities to plant viruses. The most frequently detected swine viruses were Kobuvirus, Rotavirus C, Astrovirus, Enterovirus B, Sapovirus and Picobirnavirus. In addition, sequences with identities to chimpanzee stool-associated circular ssDNA virus were identified. Whole genome analysis indicates that this virus, tentatively named Pig Stool-associated circular ssDNA virus (PigSCV), is a novel porcine virus. CONCLUSION: The established protocol enables the simultaneous detection of DNA and RNA viruses in pig faeces including the identification of previously unknown viruses. It can be applied in studies examining the etiology, epidemiology and ecology of diseases. The implemented process control is used for quality control, ensures the comparability of the method and can be used for further method optimization.
authors: Sachsenroder, J.;Twardziok, S.;Hammerl, J. A.;Janczyk, P.;Wrede, P.;Hertwig, S.;Johne, R.

title: The general composition of porcine faecal virome is dependent on age, but not on feeding with a probiotic bacterium
abstract: Background: The porcine faecal virome, which encompasses the viral community present in porcine faeces, is complex and consists of porcine viruses, bacteriophages, transiently transmitted plant viruses and other smaller virus species. Little is known about factors affecting its general composition. Here, the effect of the probiotic bacterium Enterococcus faecium (E. faecium) NCIMB 10415 on the virometic composition of pig faeces was analyzed in a pig feeding trial with sows and their piglets either receiving or not receiving the probiotic bacterium. Results: DNA and RNA virus particles were prepared from 8 pooled fecal samples from the feeding trial and subjected to on-line next-generation sequencing, resulting in 390,650 sequence reads. On average, 14% of the reads showed significant sequence identities to known viruses. The percentage of detected mammalian virus sequences was highest in samples from the youngest piglets (55-77%) and lowest in samples from sows (8-10%). In contrast, the proportion of bacteriophage sequences increased from 22-44% in the youngest piglets to about 90% in the sows. The dominant mammalian viruses differed remarkably between 12-day-old piglets (Kobuvirus), 54-day-old piglets (Boca, Dependo, and Pig Feces-Associated Small Circular DNA Virus [PigSCV]), and the sows (PigSCV, circovirus, and "circovirus-like" viruses CB-A and RW-A).In addition, the Shannon index, which reflects the diversity of sequences present in a sample, was generally higher in the sows than in the piglets.Between the viromas of the probiotic bacteria-treated group and the no consistent differences in virome composition could be observed in the control group.Conclusion: The analysis shows that the porcine fecal virome shows a high variability and that its general composition depends mainly on the age of the pigs.Changes caused by feeding with the probiotic bacterium E. faecium could be detected with the The metagenomics method used cannot be detected © 2014 Sachsenröde r et al.
authors: SachsenrÃ¶der, J.;Twardziok, S. O.;Scheuch, M.;Johne, R.

title: Virome from US bovine calf serum
abstract: Using viral metagenomics, we analyzed four bovine serum pools from 715 calves in the United States. Two parvoviruses, bovine parvovirus 2 (BPV2) and a previously uncharacterized parvovirus designated bosavirus (BosaV), were detected in 3 and 4 pools, respectively, and their complete coding sequences generated. Based on NS1 protein identity, bosavirus qualifies as a member of a new species in the copiparvovirus genus. Also detected were a small number of reads consistent with ungulate tetraparvovirus 2, bovine hepacivirus, and several papillomaviruses. This study further characterizes the diversity of viruses in calf serum with the potential to infect fetuses and contaminate cell cultures through fetal bovine serum.
authors: Sadeghi, M.;Kapusinszky, B.;Yugo, D. M.;Phan, T. G.;Deng, X.;Kanevsky, I.;Opriessnig, T.;Woolums, A. R.;Hurley, D. J.;Meng, X. J.;Delwart, E.

title: Detection of porcine bocavirus in a child with acute respiratory infection
abstract: Porcine bocavirus is a recently discovered virus classified in the genus Bocavirus. We present a case of upper respiratory tract infection related to porcine bocavirus in a 3-year-old child who was in close contact with pigs in northeastern Iran. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of human porcine bocavirus infection.
authors: Safamanesh, S.;Azimian, A.;Shakeri, A.;Ghazvini, K.;Jamehdar, S. A.;Khosrojerdi, M.;Youssefi, M.

title: No viral association found in a series of differentiated cases of vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia by human papillomavirus and panviral microarray testing
abstract: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) is the precursor lesion of vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (VSCC), and the differentiated type (dVIN) is observed more frequently in association with VSCC. In contrast to common VIN (uVIN), which is associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, a germline mutation in the p53 gene is believed to be associated with ≥90% of dVIN cases. To date, no infectious agent associated with dVIN has been identified, and studies investigating this possibility have been hampered by the difficulty of accurately diagnosing dVIN from small biopsies. Here we used immunostaining for p16<sup>ink4a</sup>, a biomarker for HPV infection, to examine 14 high-grade VIN uVIN cases and 14 dVIN cases and select 10 dVIN cases to host them comprehensively for all known viruses using a panviral microarray platform (ViroChip). All uVIN tissue samples, including 8 wart and 6 basaloid cases, showed positivity with the p16<sup>ink4a</sup> immunodye. The staining pattern was consistent in all cases except in two cases where positive staining was localized to the lower third of the epidermis. In contrast, immunostaining for p16<sup>ink4a</sup> was negative in all dVIN cases. ViroChip analysis of 10 pure dVIN samples confirmed the absence of human papillomavirus subtypes or other viruses, with the exception of a single sample that showed a weak microarray signature for a swine herpesvirus. Subsequent PCR testing of the sample was negative for herpesvirus, and thorough next-generation metagenomic sequencing revealed only sequences consistent with non-pathogenic viral flora and bacterial contamination. In this study, we demonstrated the absence of viral association in 10 dVIN cases. Alternative pathways for carcinogenesis such as p53 mutation should be considered when investigating potential treatment options for dVIN.
authors: Saglam, O.;Samayoa, E.;Somasekar, S.;Naccache, S.;Iwasaki, A.;Chiu, C. Y.

title: Antigenic subtyping and competition analysis of porcine circovirus type 2 epitopes using monoclonal antibodies
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) strains have been classified into two major genotypes (PCV2a and PCV2b) and 8 genetic clusters: PCV2b-1A to PCV2b-1C and PCV2a-2A to PCV2a-2E. To date, no studies have been performed to antigenically subtype PCV2 strains encompassing eight PCV2 clusters. The present study aimed to antigenically subtype PCV2 and perform epitope competition analysis using monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). Fourteen PCV2 strains representative of eight clusters were tested with 20 mAbs (15 of them were generated against PCV2a strain Stoon-1010 and 5 of them against PCV2b strain 1147) in immunoperoxidase monolayer assays. Four mAbs reacted with all 14 PCV2 strains and one mAb reacted with all but one PCV2a 2C strain. One mAb reacted with all PCV2a strains except one PCV2a 2C strain and one mAb reacted with all PCV2b strains except one PCV2b 1C strain. Nine mAbs reacted with strains PCV2b-1A/1B, PCV2a-2A and PCV2a-2E. Three mAbs only reacted with strains PCV2a-2A and PCV2a-2E. A mAb specifically reacted with the strains of PCV2b-1A/1B. This suggests that discrete antigenic differences exist between different PCV2 genetic clusters and that these clusters can be distinguished using a panel of universal and cluster-specific mAbs. Six mAbs were selected for cross-competition analysis by a competitive ELISA using PCV2 strain Stoon-1010. Six overlapping epitopes have been identified on the PCV2 capsid protein. The universal mAbs recognized larger epitopes than the cluster-specific mAbs. These findings are helpful in the development of new generation diagnostic tests and vaccines against PCV2. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Saha, D.;Huang, L.;Bussalleu, E.;Lefebvre, D. J.;Fort, M.;Van Doorsselaere, J.;Nauwynck, H. J.

title: Comparison of the properties of avian reoviruses isolated from the alimentary and respiratory tract with viruses isolated from the synovia
abstract: Two week old gnotobiotic chicks were footpad inoculated with viruses isolated from synovia and synovial membrane: WVU 1464-29H, WVU 1675, WVU 2937, WVU 2986 and WVU 71-212; from the digestive tract: reoviruses 24, 25 and 59; or from the respiratory tract: reovirus Fahey Crawley (FC). All viruses induced swelling of the footpad and inflammatory changes in the synovial membrane. Serum from virus-infected chicks shared a common agar gel precipitin (AGP) lineage. On the basis of the plaque reduction test in primary chick kidney cells (PCK), the viruses were divided into 4 main serotypes. All viruses produced cytopathic effects (CPE) in primary chicken tissue cultures. Except for reovirus FC and WVU 1464-29H, all viruses produced CPE in the Vero cell line.
authors: Sahu, S. P.;Olson, N. O.

title: Sequence analysis of in vivo defective interfering RNA of pandemic influenza A H1N1 virus
abstract: Influenza virus defective interfering (DI) particles are naturally occurring, non-infectious virions that are typically generated during serial in vitro passages in cell cultures of the virus at a high multiplicity of infection. DI particles are known for their role in inhibiting viral replication and for the effects they have on the production of infectious virions. So far, influenza virus DI particles have mainly been described as a phenomenon of cell culture and in experimentally infected embryonated chicken eggs. They have also been isolated from a respiratory infection in chickens. Using a sequencing approach, we characterize multiple subgenomic viral RNAs from human nasopharyngeal samples infected with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. The distribution of these in vivo derived DI-like RNAs was similar to that of in vitro DIs, with the majority of the defective RNAs being generated from PB2 (segment 1) of the polymerase complex, followed by PB1 and PA. The lengths of the in vivo-derived DI-like segments are also similar to known in vitro DIs, and the in vivo-derived DI-like segments share internal deletions of the same segments. The presence of identical DI-like RNAs in patients linked by direct contact is compatible with transmission between them. The functional role of DI-like RNAs in natural infections remains to be elucidated.
authors: Saira, K.;Lin, X.;DePasse, J. V.;Halpin, R.;Twaddle, A.;Stockwell, T.;Angus, B.;Cozzi-Lepri, A.;Delfino, M.;Dugan, V.;Dwyer, D. E.;Freiberg, M.;Horban, A.;Losso, M.;Lynfield, R.;Wentworth, D. N.;Holmes, E. C.;Davey, R.;Wentworth, D. E.;Ghedin, E.;Group, I. F. S.;Group, I. F. S.

title: Characterization of a human influenza H9N2 virus isolated in Hong Kong
abstract: Two H9N2 viruses were first isolated from humans in Hong Kong in 1999. The isolation of influenza viruses with a new subtype of hemagglutinin (HA) has caught the attention of public health authorities worldwide in anticipation of a pandemic. The sequence analysis of the HA genes shows that HA from A/Hong Kong/1073/99 (H9N2) is most closely related to that from A/Quail/HK/G1/97 (H9N2), which contains the internal genes encoding those from Hong are similar to Kong/97 (H5N1) viruses. Phylogenetic and antigenic analyzes revealed diversity among H9 HA. A/Hong Kong/1073/99 has been shown to cause respiratory infection in Syrian hamsters, suggesting that the virus can replicate efficiently in mammalian hosts. We have developed a whole virion test vaccine using a formalin-inactivated egg-grown HK1073. Two-time intraperitoneal administration of the vaccine to hamsters conferred complete protection against challenge infection by the homologous virus grown on MDCK cells. The receptor specificity of HK1073 appeared to be different from that of other H9 subtype avian influenza viruses, which preferentially recognize α-2,3-linked sialic acid. The hemagglutination of HK1073 with guinea pig erythrocytes was inhibited by both α-2,3- and α-2,6-linked sialic acid-containing polymers. These data indicated that HK1073 had acquired a broader host range, including humans. Together with the data available so far, the present study suggested that the isolation of the H9 influenza viruses from humans requires precautions against the emergence of new human influenza. © 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Saito, T.;Lim, W.;Suzuki, T.;Suzuki, Y.;Kida, H.;Nishimura, S. I.;Tashiro, M.

title: DNA Virome: Sequencing and data analysis of the viral metagenome of poultry suffering from respiratory diseases
authors: Sajnani, M. R.;Sudarsanam, D.

title: Viral metagenomics of chickens with respiratory infection using MG-RAST
authors: Sajnani, M. R.;Sudarsanam, D.

title: Metagenomic data of DNA viruses from poultry with respiratory infections
abstract: The incidence and severity of respiratory disease in commercial broiler flocks has recently increased in India due to the intensification of the broiler industry. Virus populations are predominant in respiratory infections and pose a continuous economic burden on the poultry industry, causing severe economic losses through reduced productivity [1], [2]. To understand the viral metagenome of poultry related to respiratory infections, we performed DNA virome sequencing and data analysis of broilers from 8 districts of Gujarat state, India. We report high quality sequencing reads and a very abundant DNA virus population present in the infected broilers. The raw sequencing data used to perform the metagenomic analysis is available in the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under BioProject no. PRJNA322592 and Accession No.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/?term=PRJNA322592).
authors: Sajnani, M. R.;Sudarsanam, D.;Pandit, R. J.;Oza, T.;Hinsu, A. T.;Jakhesara, S. J.;Solosanc, S.;Joshi, C. G.;Bhatt, V. D.

title: Isolation and characterization of a novel rhabdovirus from a wild boar (Sus scrofa) in Japan
abstract: novel rhabdovirus was isolated from the serum of a healthy Japanese wild boar (Sus scrofa leucomystax) and identified using rapid viral nucleic acid sequence (RDV) determination, next-generation sequencing, and electron microscopy. The virus has been tentatively named wild boar rhabdovirus 1 (WBRV1). Phylogenetic analysis of the entire genome sequence showed that WBRV1 is closely related to Tupaia rhabdovirus (TRV) isolated from cultured cells of tree shrew hepatocellular carcinoma tissue. TRV has not yet been assigned to any genus of Rhabdoviridae. Analysis of the L gene showed that WBRV1 belongs to the genus Vesiculovirus. These observations suggest that both TRV and WBRV1 belong to a new genus of Rhabdoviridae. Next-generation genome sequencing of WBRV1 revealed 5 open reading frames of 1329, 765, 627, 1629, and 6336 bases in length. The WBRV1 gene sequences are similar to those of other rhabdoviruses. Epizootiological analysis of a population of wild boar in Wakayama Prefecture, Japan showed that 6.5% were positive for the WBRV1 gene and 52% were positive for WBRV1 neutralizing antibodies. In addition, such virus-neutralizing antibodies were found in domestic pigs in another prefecture. WBRV1 was inoculated intranasally and intraperitoneally into SCID and BALB/c mice, and viral RNA was detected in SCID mice, suggesting that WBRV1 can replicate in immunocompromised mice. These results indicate that this novel virus is endemic in wild and livestock in Japan.
authors: Sakai, K.;Hagiwara, K.;Omatsu, T.;Hamasaki, C.;Kuwata, R.;Shimoda, H.;Suzuki, K.;Endoh, D.;Nagata, N.;Nagai, M.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Kurane, I.;Saijo, M.;Morikawa, S.;Mizutani, T.;Maeda, K.

title: Bunyaviruses are prevalent in male and female Ixodes scapularis ticks in central Pennsylvania
abstract: The black-legged Ixodes scapularis tick is widespread in the United States and transmits multiple pathogens to humans, wildlife, and domestic animals. Recently, several novel viruses of the Bunyaviridae family (South Bay Virus (SBV) and Blacklegged tick phlebovirus (BTPV)) have been identified infecting female I. scapularis ticks collected in New York State. We used metagenomic sequencing to study the distribution of viruses infecting male and female I. scapularis ticks collected in Center County, Pennsylvania. We identified both SBV and BTPV in both male and female ticks from all collection sites. The role of male I. scapularis in pathogen epidemiology has been overlooked as they rarely sting and are not considered important pathogen vectors. However, males can act as a reservoir for pathogens, which can then be transmitted to females during mating. Our data underscore the importance of investigating all potential pathways of disease maintenance and transmission throughout the life cycle of vector pathogens in order to understand the epidemiology of tick-borne pathogens.
authors: Sakamoto, J. M.;Ng, T. F. F.;Suzuki, Y.;Tsujimoto, H.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Rasgon, J. L.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of porcine and ruminant pestiviruses isolated mainly in Japan
abstract: The genetic variability of porcine and ruminant pestiviruses was examined by comparative nucleotide sequence analysis of 73 isolates (42 pigs and 31 ruminants), including 65 Japanese isolates (35 pigs and 30 ruminants). The 5'-untranslated region (UTR) amplified by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was determined by direct sequencing and phylogenetic analysis was performed on the nucleotide sequence data. Most swine isolates have been divided into two major subgroups, classical swine fever virus (CSFV), subgroup 1 (CSFV-1 represented by the Brecia strain) and subgroup 2 (CSFV-2 represented by the Alfort strain). However, the Japanese strains Kanagawa/74, Okinawa/86, Okinawa/86-2 and Thai CBR/93 were the most pronounced variants and these were assigned to another new distinct subgroup, CSFV-3 (represented by the p97 strain). Most ruminant isolates were classified as Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) genotype-I (BVDV-I) and divided into two subgroups, BVDV-Ia (represented by the NADL strain) and Ib (represented by the Osloss strain). Two bovine isolates (MS-1 and SY-89) and one contaminating strain (V/FLL) from an ovine cell line were genetically classified as BVDV genotype II (BVDV-II). These data suggested that the detection and phylogenetic analysis of 5' UTRs are useful for the rapid characterization of field isolates.
authors: Sakoda, Y.;Ozawa, S. I.;Damrongwatanapokin, S.;Sato, M.;Ishikawa, K.;Fukusho, A.

title: Viral RNA load in tick-borne encephalitis patients, Slovenia
abstract: We determined RNA levels of tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) virus (TBEV) in serum samples collected from 80 patients during the initial phase of TBE in Slovenia. For most samples, concentrations ranged from 3-6 log(10) copies RNA/mL. Levels were higher in female patients than in male patients, but we found no association between viral load and several laboratory and clinical parameters, including TBE severity. However, a poor humoral immune response was associated with more severe disease progression, suggesting that inefficient clearance of the virus leads to more severe disease. To determine whether a particular genetic lineage of TBEV had a higher virulence potential, we obtained 56 partial coat protein gene sequences by direct sequencing of reverse transcription PCR products from clinical specimens from patients. This method provided a large set of patient-derived TBEV sequences. We observed no association between phylogenetic clades and viral load or disease severity.
authors: Saksida, A.;Jakopin, N.;Jelovsek, M.;Knap, N.;Fajs, L.;Lusa, L.;Lotric-Furlan, S.;Bogovic, P.;Arnez, M.;Strle, F.;Avsic-Zupanc, T.

title: Alternative growth promoters Modulate the broiler gut microbiome and improve body weight gain
abstract: Antibiotic growth promoters (AGPs) are commonly used to improve weight gain in poultry production. However, there is increasing concern about the impact of AGP on the emergence of antibiotic resistance among zoonotic bacterial pathogens in the avian gut microbial community. In this study, we applied mass spectrophotometric, phylogenetic, and shotgun metagenomic approaches to evaluate bioactive phenolic extracts (BPE) from blueberry (Vaccinium corymbosum) and blackberry (Rubus fruticosus) pomace as AGP alternatives in broilers. We conducted two trials with 100 Cobb 500 broilers (in each trial) in four equal groups given unsupplemented water, supplemented with AGP (tylosin, neomycin sulfate, bacitracin, erythromycin, and oxytetracycline) or supplemented with 0.1 g Gallic acid equivalent (GAE)/L or 1.0 g GAE/L (during the last 72 h before euthanasia) BPE for 6 weeks. Compared to the control group (water only), the chickens supplemented with AGP and 0.1 g GAE/L BPE gained 9.5 and 5.8% more body weight, respectively. The microbiomes of both the AGP- and BPE-treated chickens showed a higher ratio of Firmicutes to Bacteroidetes. AGP supplementation appeared to be associated with a higher relative frequency of bacteriophage and unique cecal resistoma compared to BPE supplementation or control. Functional characterization of cecal microbiomes revealed significant animal-to-animal variations in the relative abundance of genes involved in energy and carbohydrate metabolism. These results provided a basis on which to study mechanisms of plant performance enhancers in animal growth regulation. In addition, the data will aid in the development of alternative strategies to improve animal growth performance and consequently production.
authors: Salaheen, S.;Kim, S. W.;Haley, B. J.;Van Kessel, J. A. S.;Biswas, D.

title: Biological and molecular diagnosis of seedborne viruses in cowpea germplasm of geographically diverse sub-Saharan origins
abstract: total of 983 cowpea accessions obtained from the University of California, Riverside (UCR) Cowpea Repository were analyzed for seedborne viruses. A majority of the accessions originated from 11 countries representing different agroclimatic zones in sub-Saharan Africa and included landraces, local cultivars and breeding lines. After initial growth testing, 69 cowpea accessions, mostly with symptoms of viral infection, were selected for further evaluation using a combination of host range, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), and sequence analyses. Analysis revealed that samples from 46 (67%) accessions contained one or more known seed-borne cowpea viruses. These included accession seed samples from Botswana (13 accessions), Ghana (6), Nigeria (6), Mali (1), Kenya (5), Cameroon (7), Niger (4), Ivory Coast (1), Benin (1st ), India (1) and China (1). Viruses were identified by RT-PCR analysis of total RNAs extracted from putatively virus-infected specimens using virus species-specific primers, and by cloning and sequencing of RT-PCR products generated using virus genus- and family-specific degenerate oligonucleotide sequences. primers were amplified. Viruses identified included cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV), cucumber mosaic virus (CMV), and southern bean mosaic virus (SBMV). Phylogenetic analysis of the deduced coat protein (CP) amino acid sequences of selected CMV isolates obtained from five agroclimatically distinct localities confirmed their membership as new members of the CMV subgroup IB. This is the first time that cowpea accession seedborne viruses have been identified in a large collection (UCR) using RT-PCR and sequencing approaches.
authors: Salem, N. M.;Ehlers, J. D.;Roberts, P. A.;Ng, J. C. K.

title: Identification and characterization of the lumpy skin disease virus isolated from cattle in the Republic of North Ossetia-Alania in 2015
abstract: The first reports of the unknown cattle disease appeared in September-October 2015 in the North Caucasus region of Russia (Republic of North Ossetia-Alania). Clinical signs included watery eye discharge, apathy, anorexia, salivation, lameness, and nodular skin lesions. The capripoxvirus genome was detected in tissue samples from diseased animals using real-time PCR. The pathogen was isolated in the primary cell cultures of lamb testes and goat testes and in the continuous MDBK cell culture. Further sequencing of the GPCR gene and phylogenetic analysis revealed the close genetic relationship of the isolated capripoxvirus to a group of lumpy skin disease viruses. Koch's postulates were fulfilled by experimentally infecting four calves with a suspension of tissue samples from diseased animals.
authors: Salnikov, N.;Usadov, T.;Kolcov, A.;Zhivoderov, S.;Morgunov, Y.;Gerasimov, V.;Gogin, A.;Titov, I.;Yurkov, S.;Malogolovkin, A.;Kolbasov, D.;Lunitsyn, A.

title: The sequence of a complete chicken BG haplotype shows dynamic expansion and contraction of two gene lines with distinct expression patterns
abstract: Many genes important for immunity are found as multigene families. The butyrophilin genes are members of the B7 family and play diverse roles in coregulation and perhaps antigen presentation. In humans, a fixed number of butyrophilin genes are found in and around the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) and show a striking association with certain autoimmune diseases. In chickens, BG genes encode homologues with slightly different domain organization. Few BG genes have been characterized, one involved in the actin-myosin interaction in the intestinal brush border and another involved in viral disease resistance. We characterize all BG genes in B12 chickens and find a multigene family organized as tandem repeats in the BG region outside of the MHC, a single gene in the MHC (the BF-BL region), and another single gene another chromosome. There is precise cell and tissue expression for each gene, but overall there are two types, those expressed by hematopoietic cells and those expressed in tissues (presumably non-hematopoietic cells), which are associated with two different types of promoters and 5-inch untranslated regions correlated (5'UTR). However, the multigene family in the BG region contains many hybrid genes, suggesting recombination and/or deletion as major evolutionary forces. We identify BG genes in the shotgun sequence of the whole chicken genome as well as by comparison to other haplotypes by fiber fluorescence in situ hybridization, confirming the dynamic expansion and contraction within the BG region. Therefore, for reasons that have yet to be understood, the BG genes in chickens undergo much more rapid evolution compared to their mammalian homologues. © 2014 Salomonsen et al.
authors: Salomonsen, J.;Chattaway, J. A.;Chan, A. C. Y.;Parker, A.;Huguet, S.;Marston, D. A.;Rogers, S. L.;Wu, Z.;Smith, A. L.;Staines, K.;Butter, C.;Riegert, P.;Vainio, O.;Nielsen, L.;Kaspers, B.;Griffin, D. K.;Yang, F.;Zoorob, R.;Guillemot, F.;Auffray, C.;Beck, S.;SkjÃ¸dt, K.;Kaufman, J.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic study of velogenic Newcastle disease virus isolates in Iran
abstract: The pathogenicity and genetic characterization of six Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates derived from chicken farms in six different regions in Iran were performed using conventional and molecular techniques. Based on the pathogenicity indices (MDT, ICPI and IVPI), all of these isolates were determined to be velogenic (highly virulent) strains. Sequence analysis of the full-length mRNA encoding the fusion glycoprotein precursor (F0) of the NDV fusion proteins F1 and F2 in these six isolates revealed the presence of point mutations in the form of nucleic acid substitutions at positions 82(C†'T), 83(Tâ†' C), 736(Aâ†'G) and 1.633(Gâ†'A). However, it was found that the nucleic acid residues at positions 330-347 of the precursor F0 gene, corresponding to the cleavage site of the F0 protein, were conserved among the six NDV isolates. A phylogenetic comparison between the six Iranian isolates and the NDVs whose F0 gene sequences were previously deposited in the GenBank database showed that all of the newly characterized Iranian NDV isolates belonged to genotype VII. © 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Samadi, S.;Kianizadeh, M.;Najafi, M. F.;Nasab, S. D. M.;Davatgar, A. M. H.;Royaee, A.;Pilvar, P.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Lumpy Skin Disease Viruses in Northwestern Iran
abstract: Lumpy Skin Disease (LSD) is a devastating viral disease in cattle that has recently spread from Africa to Middle Eastern countries. The aim of the present study was to investigate the relationships between lumpy skin disease viruses (LSDV) isolated from different regions of Iran, as well as the origin and distribution of these viruses. In this study, a total of 234 blood samples from clinically affected animals from four provinces in northwestern Iran were analyzed for LSDV using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). From 80 positive samples for LSDV detected by PCR, the partial P32 gene (759 bp) of 12 isolates was sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically. LSD viruses have been classified into three subclusters with an overall nucleotide identity of 97.1-100%. LSDVs isolated from Gilan showed the lowest nucleotide identity with the other LSDVs. Four isolates of LSDV including KO-1, EA-1, EA-3 and WA-3 showed 100% similarity to each other and also to the Neethling strain. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the identified LSDVs were closely related and shared high sequence homology with other LSDV isolates from Africa. It was concluded that the LSD outbreak likely occurred in north-western Iran by LSDVs invading the country from Iraq, and the P32 nucleotide sequence information obtained in the present study is a valuable resource for understanding its genetic nature and molecular epidemiology of local LSDV isolates that can be used for future vaccine development based on the circulating strains in the region.
authors: Sameea Yousefi, P.;Dalir-Naghadeh, B.;Mardani, K.;Jalilzadeh-Amin, G.

title: A four biomarker blood signature distinguishes systemic inflammation due to viral infection from other etiologies
abstract: The innate immune system of humans and other mammals responds to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) that are conserved across broad classes of infectious agents such as bacteria and viruses. We hypothesized that a blood-based transcriptional signature could be detected, indicative of a systemic host response to viral infection. Previous work has identified host transcriptional signatures for individual viruses, including influenza, respiratory syncytial virus and dengue fever, but the generality of these signatures for all viral infection types has not been established. Based on 44 publicly available datasets and two clinical studies of our own design, we discovered and validated a four-gene expression signature in whole blood indicative of a general systemic host response to many types of viral infections. The signature genes are: Interferon Stimulated Gene 15 (ISG15), Interleukin 16 (IL16), 2',5'-Oligoadenylate Synthetase Like (OASL) and Adhesion G Protein Coupled Receptor E5 (ADGRE5). In each of the 13 validation datasets, which include humans, macaques, chimpanzees, pigs, mice, rats and all seven Baltimore virus classification groups, the signature provides a statistically significant (p<0.05) distinction between viral and non-viral states. The signature may be of clinical utility to distinguish systemic host inflammation (SI) due to viral versus bacterial or non-infectious causes.
authors: Sampson, D. L.;Fox, B. A.;Yager, T. D.;Bhide, S.;Cermelli, S.;McHugh, L. C.;Seldon, T. A.;Brandon, R. A.;Sullivan, E.;Zimmerman, J. J.;Noursadeghi, M.;Brandon, R. B.

title: The complete genome sequence of avian paramyxovirus (APMV) serotype 5 completes the analysis of nine APMV serotypes and reveals the longest APMV genome
abstract: Background: Avian paramyxoviruses (APMV) consist of nine known serotypes. The genomes of representatives of all APMV serotypes except APMV type 5 have recently been completely sequenced. Here we report the complete genome sequence of the APMV-5 prototype budgerigar/Kunitachi/74 strain. METHODS/MAIN RESULTS: The APMV-5 Kunitachi virus is unusual in that it lacks a virion hemagglutinin and does not grow in the allantoic cavity of embryonated chicken eggs. However, the virus grew in the amniotic sac of embryonated chicken eggs and in twelve different established cell lines and two primary cell cultures. The genome is 17,262 nucleotides (nt) long, which is the longest among members of the Avulavirus genus, and encodes six non-overlapping genes in the order 3 "NP/V/WMF-HN-L-5" with intergenic regions of 4- 57th The genome length follows the "rule of six" and contains a 55 nt leader sequence at the 3 inch end and a 552 nt trailer sequence at the 5 inch end. The phosphoprotein (P) gene contains a conserved RNA editing site and is expected to encode P, V, and W proteins. The F protein cleavage site (GKRKKR †“ F) corresponds to the cleavage site motif of the ubiquitous cellular protease furin. Consistent with this, no exogenous protease was required for virus replication in vitro. However, the intracerebral pathogenicity index of APMV-5 strain Kunitachi in day-old chicks was zero, suggesting that the virus is avirulent to chickens despite the presence of a polybasic F cleavage site. Conclusions/Relevance: The phylogenetic analysis of the sequences of the APVM-5 genome and proteins compared to those of the other APMV serotypes showed that APMV-5 is more closely related to APMV-6 than to the other APMVs. In addition, these comparisons provided evidence of extensive genome-wide divergence, supporting the classification of the APMVs into nine separate serotypes. The structure of the F cleavage site does not appear to be a reliable indicator of virulence among APMV serotypes 2-9. The availability of sequence information for all known APMV serotypes will facilitate studies in epidemiology and vaccinology.
authors: Samuel, A. S.;Paldurai, A.;Kumar, S.;Collins, P. L.;Samal, S. K.

title: Climate change affects the global potential spread of bluetongue virus
abstract: The geographic distribution of arboviruses has received considerable attention after several dramatic events around the world. Bluetongue virus (BTV) is a category "A" disease that must be reported to the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) and is transmitted among ruminants by mosquitoes of the Culicoides genus. Here, we developed a comprehensive occurrence dataset to map the current distribution, estimate the ecological niche, and investigate the future potential distribution of BTV worldwide using ecological niche modeling and based on diverse future climate scenarios from general circulation models (GCMs) for four representative concentration pathways (RCP's). The broad ecological niche and potential geographic distribution of BTV under contemporary conditions reflected the current global distribution of the disease in tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions. All model predictions were significantly better than random expectations. As a further assessment of the model's robustness, we compared our model predictions to 331 independent records of recent outbreaks from the Information System for the Food and Agriculture Organization's Transboundary Animal and Plant Pests and Diseases Emergency Prevention System (EMPRES-i); all were successfully anticipated by the BTV model. Finally, we tested the ecological niche similarity between putative vectors and BTV and could not reject the niche similarity hypotheses. Under future climatic conditions, it was predicted that the potential spread of BTV would expand, particularly in Central Africa, the United States, and western Russia.
authors: Samy, A. M.;Peterson, A. T.

title: Antigenic homology between coronaviruses associated with transmissible gastroenteritis virus
abstract: Antigenic homology of 26 coronavirus isolates, 22 of which were antigenically related to transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV), was determined using 42 monoclonal antibodies. Type, group and interspecies specific epitopes have been defined. Two group-specific MAbs distinguished the enteric (TGEV) isolates from the respiratory variants. An antigenic subsite involved in neutralization has been conserved in porcine, feline, and canine coronaviruses. Placing human coronavirus 229E in a taxonomic cluster distinct from the TGEV group is proposed.
authors: Sanchez, C. M.;Jimenez, G.;Laviada, M. D.;Correa, I.;Sune, C.;Bullido, M.;Gebauer, F.;Smerdou, C.;Callebaut, P.;Escribano, J. M.;Enjuanes, L.

title: Analysis of swine sera for functional antibody titers against influenza and neuraminidase proteins using an enzyme-linked lectin assay (ELLA)
abstract: Neuraminidase (NA) is an envelope glycoprotein of influenza viruses, including porcine influenza A viruses. NA possesses sialidase activity, which is functionally important at several sites in viral replication and balances the sialic acid receptor-binding activity of hemagglutinin (HA), the other important envelope glycoprotein. The NA proteins of influenza A viruses have been classified into nine serological subtypes and they undergo antigenic drift variation similar to that of HA. Antibodies against NA are analyzed much less frequently than antibodies against HA. Established decades ago, the traditional NA inhibition (NI) antibody titration assay is widely considered cumbersome and inefficient for routine use. In recent years, some new formats have been developed that still measure inhibition of NA enzymatic function, but more efficiently and with less chemical waste produced. The enzyme-linked lectin assay (ELLA) performed in 96-well plates and analyzed on a spectrophotometric plate reader is described here. An important factor in adopting ELLA technology for animal testing, such as B. pigs, is the choice of NA antigen, which can be purified protein or whole virus containing an antigenically irrelevant HA protein. This NI assay, in conjunction with the hemagglutination-inhibiting (HI) antibody assay, provides a convenient way to more comprehensively characterize viral isolates and quantify antibodies induced by infection or vaccination.
authors: Sandbulte, M. R.;Eichelberger, M. C.

title: Identification of further diversity among posaviruses
abstract: Recently there have been reports of new members of posavirus-like viruses in the order Picornavirales. In this study, 11 posavirus-like sequences (>7,000 nucleotides) were detected in 155 pig fecal samples using a metagenomic approach. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the newly identified viral sequences, along with other posavirus-like viruses, form distinct clusters within the order Picornavirus, consisting of eight genogroups and unassigned sequences based on amino acid sequences of the helicase and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase regions. there is < 40% or < 50% sequence identity. We propose further classifications of highly diverse posavirus populations based on newly identified sequences from Japanese pig feces.
authors: Sano, K.;Naoi, Y.;Kishimoto, M.;Masuda, T.;Tanabe, H.;Ito, M.;Niira, K.;Haga, K.;Asano, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Ouchi, Y.;Yamasato, H.;Ishida, M.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Detection and characterization of atypical capripoxviruses in small ruminants in India
abstract: Recent developments in molecular biology shed light on the interspecies transmission of SPPV and GTPV. The present study was designed to characterize the capripoxviruses circulating in sheep and goats under field conditions using RPO30 gene-based viral lineage (SPPV/GTPV), differentiation of PCR and sequencing of RPO30 and GPCR genes clinical samples. Of 58 scab cells examined (35 sheep and 23 goats), 27 sheep and 18 goat scab cells were found positive for capripox virus infections. With the exception of one sheep scab and one goat scab, all positive samples gave an amplicon size according to host origin, ie SPPV in sheep and GTPV in goats. In the two exceptional cases above, goat scab and sheep scab gave an amplicon size similar to that of SPPV and GTPV, respectively. In addition, sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of complete ORFs of RPO30 and GPCR genes from six sheep and three goat scabs revealed that all but the above two samples had host-specific signatures and were clustered according to their host origin. In the case of cross-species samples that infected samples, sheep scab possessed GTPV-like signatures and goat scab had SPPV-like signatures. Our study identifies the circulation of cross-infecting SPPV and GTPV in the field and warrants the development of a single-strain vaccine that can protect animals from both sheeppox and goatpox diseases.
authors: Santhamani, R.;Venkatesan, G.;Minhas, S. K.;Shivachandra, S. B.;Muthuchelvan, D.;Pandey, A. B.;Ramakrishnan, M. A.

title: The human urinary virus associated with urinary tract infections
authors: Santiago-Rodriguez, T. M.;Ly, M.;Bonilla, N.

title: Genetic characterization of small ruminant lentiviruses circulating in naturally infected sheep and goats in Ontario, Canada
abstract: Maedi visna virus (MVV) and caprine arthritis encephalitis virus (CAEV) are related members of a group of small ruminant lentiviruses (SRLVs) that infect sheep and goats. SRLVs are endemic in many countries including Canada. However, very little is known about the genetic characteristics of Canadian SRLVs, particularly in the province of Ontario. Given the importance of surveillance and eradication programs in controlling SRLVs, it is imperative that diagnostic tests used to identify infected animals be sensitive to local strains of SRLVs. The aim of this work was to characterize SRLV strains circulating in Ontario and to assess the variability of the immunodominant regions of the Gag protein. In this study, the nearly complete gag sequence of 164 SRLVs from 130 naturally infected sheep and 32 naturally infected Ontario goats were sequenced. The animals belonged to distant single and mixed animal holdings (sheep and goats). Ovine lentiviruses from the same farm tended to cluster more tightly than goat lentiviruses from the same farm. Sequence analysis revealed a higher degree of heterogeneity between the goat lentivirus sequences with an average pairwise DNA distance between farms of 10% and only 5% in the ovine lentivirus group. Interestingly, amplification of SRLVs from ELISA-positive sheep was successful in 81% of cases, while amplification of SRLV-proviral DNA was only possible in 55% of ELISA-positive goat samples; suggesting that a significant fraction of the caprine lentiviruses circulating in Ontario possess heterogeneity at the primer binding sites used in this study. Sequences from Ontario ovine and caprine SRLVs were assembled into pedigrees with other known SRLVs and found to belong to sequence groups A2 and B1, respectively, as reported by Shah et al. Are defined. (2004a). A new goat lentivirus with a pairwise genetic difference of 15.6-25.4% compared to other group B subtypes was identified. Therefore, we propose naming a new subtype, B4, within the caprine lentivirus-like cluster. Finally, we demonstrate evidence for recombination between ovine lentiviruses. These results underscore the wide genetic diversity of SRLV strains circulating in the province of Ontario and demonstrate that the gag region is amenable to phylogenetic studies and can be applied to monitor SRLV eradication programs. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Santry, L. A.;de Jong, J.;Gold, A. C.;Walsh, S. R.;Menzies, P. I.;Wootton, S. K.

title: Genomic characterization of two novel pathogenic avipoxviruses isolated from Pacific shearwaters (Ardenna spp.).
abstract: BACKGROUND: Over the past 20 years, many seabird populations have gradually declined, and the factors driving this continued deterioration are not always well understood. Avipoxvirus infections have been found in a variety of bird species worldwide, however very little is known about the disease ecology of avipoxvirus in seabirds. Here we present two novel avipoxviruses from Pacific shearwaters (Ardenna spp), one from a flesh-footed shearwater (A. carneipes) (SWPV-1) and the other from a wedge-tailed shearwater (A. pacificus) (SWPV-2). RESULTS: Epidermal smallpox lesions, liver and blood samples were examined from A. carneipes and A. pacificus from breeding colonies in Eastern Australia. After histopathological confirmation of the disease, PCR screening for avipoxvirus, circovirus, reticuloendothelosis virus, and fungal pathogens was performed. Two samples that were PCR positive for poxvirus were further evaluated by next-generation sequencing, which revealed complete genomes of shearwaterpox virus (SWPV) from A. pacificus and A. carneipes, both of which have the highest degree of similarity to the canarypox virus showed (98% and 67%, respectively). The new complete genome of SWPV-1 from A. carneipes is missing 43 genes compared to CNPV and contains 4 predicted genes not found in any other poxvirus, while the complete genome of SWPV-2 is missing 18 genes compared to CNPV and another 15 genes are significantly fragmented, likely rendering them nonfunctional. CONCLUSION: These are the first complete genome sequences of the avipoxvirus infecting marine seabirds. Comparing SWPV-1 and -2 to existing avipoxvirus sequences, our results indicate that the complete A. carneipes SWPV genome (SWPV-1) described here is not closely related to any other avipoxvirus genome derived from avian or other natural hosts species and that it should probably be considered a separate species.
authors: Sarker, S.;Das, S.;Lavers, J. L.;Hutton, I.;Helbig, K.;Imbery, J.;Upton, C.;Raidal, S. R.

title: Genetic variations of the hemagglutinin gene of pandemic influenza A (H1N1) viruses in Assam, India in 2016
abstract: Since its emergence in 2009, the influenza A/H1N1pdm09 virus has continuously evolved. Marked genetic variations have emerged in the HA1 domain of the hemagglutinin gene, causing the emergence of new variants. The present study genetically characterized the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of influenza A/H1N1pdm09 strains from Assam that circulated in 2016 and caused a mild outbreak with no reported mortality. Sequence analysis of the HA gene from 20 Assam/H1N1pdm09 positive strains revealed 3 mutations (K180Q, 5202T, S220T) at the antigenic sites along with several other reported mutations that are in close proximity to the antigenic sites and therefore affect viral antigenicity could. Phylogenetically, the Assam/H1N1pdm09 strains clustered in genogroup 6B. These genetic variations underscore the importance of continuous monitoring and characterization of influenza A/H1N1pdm09 virus activity to trace genetic makeup and diversification that may affect virus behavior.
authors: Sarmah, K.;Borkakoty, B.;Sarma, K.;Hazarika, R.;Das, P. K.;Jakharia, A.;Das, M.;Biswas, D.

title: Multi-reassortant G3P[3] clusters a rotavirus in a horseshoe bat in Zambia
abstract: Group A rotavirus is a major cause of diarrhea in humans, particularly in young children. Bats also harbor group A rotavirus, but the genetic backgrounds of bat rotavirus strains are usually different from human rotavirus strains. We identified a new strain of group A rotavirus in the intestinal contents of a horseshoe bat in Zambia. Whole genome sequencing revealed that the identified virus, named RVA/Bat-wt/ZMB/LUS12-14/2012/G3P[3], had the genotype constellation G3-P[3]-I3-R2-C2-M3-A9 - N2-T3-E2-H3. Several genome segments of LUS12-14 were very similar to those of group A rotaviruses identified in humans, cows and antelopes, suggesting interspecies transmission of rotaviruses between bats and other mammals with possible multiple genomic reassortment events.
authors: Sasaki, M.;Orba, Y.;Sasaki, S.;Gonzalez, G.;Ishii, A.;Hangâ€™Ombe, B. M.;Mweene, A. S.;Ito, K.;Sawa, H.

title: Metagenomic analysis of shrew enteric-coated virus reveals new viruses related to human stool-associated viruses
authors: Sasaki, M.;Orba, Y.;Ueno, K.;Ishii, A.

title: How to classify Inuenza A virus and understand its severity
abstract: As an application of the degree of chaos introduced in the context of information-adaptive dynamics, we examine the classification of influenza A viruses. What evolutionary processes determine the severity and ability to transmit influenza A viruses between humans? We performed phylogenetic classifications of influenza A viruses sampled between 1918 and 2009 using a measure called entropic chaos degree, which was developed through the study of chaos in information dynamics. Phylogenetic analysis of the internal protein (PB2, PB1, PA, NS, M1, M2, NS1, and NS2) showed that influenza A viruses that adapt to humans and transmit between humans clearly differ from the porcine and porcine strains distinguish bird line. In addition, the HA, NA, and internal proteins of the influenza strain that caused a pandemic or severe epidemic with high mortality were phylogenetically different from those of previous pandemic and severe epidemic strains. We concluded that the internal protein has a significant impact on the ability to transmit between humans. Based on this study, we are convinced that the degree of entropic chaos is very useful to understand the classification and severity of an isolated influenza A virus strain.
authors: Sato, K.;Tanabe, T.;Ohya, M.

title: Antiviral activities of xanthogenates
abstract: Strategies in the development of antiviral agents have been directed towards the development of substances that preferentially react with virus-encoded enzymes, e.g. B. polymerases and reverse transcriptase interact. Xanthates, antiviral/antitumor with distinct modes of action, selectively interact with cell proteins that regulate cell growth through protein kinase C-mediated phosphorylation pathways. Such regulatory processes appear to be essential for the growth of various taxonomically unrelated viruses. Xanthate structures in position R1 were replaced by aliphatic cyclic and non-cyclic residues and in position R2 by alkali metals. The antiviral effect of such substitutions has been evaluated in plaque reduction assays using the herpes virus as a rapid reliable test system. The criterion of cytotoxicity was based on the ability of logarithmically growing cell cultures to undergo active mitotic divisions. Position R1 should be occupied with a lipophilic substituent which should be structurally restricted as mono-, bi- and tricyclic groups. The specific antiviral activity of the xanthate compound D609, expressed by its IC50, compares well with that of other herpes inhibitors, e.g. phosphonoformic acid (10 µM) or phosphonoacetic acid (20 µM). Unlike the herpesvirus, which encodes its own DNA polymerase, the DNA tumor virus 'SV40' relies on cellular DNA polymerase for its DNA replication. There was a selective antiviral effect of xanthogenate in the absence of cytotoxicity of bovine papilloma virus (BPV-1) transformed cells. The inhibition of viral gene functions by xanthogenate without adverse effects on essential cell functions shows the high selectivity of the antiviral effect. Depending on the multiplicity of the Coxsackie B4 virus, despite the presence of D609, there was a direct correlation in the amount of viral proteins synthesized. In the case of vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), xanthogenate did not inhibit the synthesis of primary transcripts, which, being endowed with positive strand polarity, serve as messengers. The antiviral effect of xanthate only occurs at acidic pH, otherwise the antiviral/antitumor effects decrease. Because HIV-1 only replicates in appropriate lymphoma cells that exhibit characteristics of transformed cells, careful calibration of D609/monocarbonic acid concentration had to precede antiviral therapy. Such treatment inhibits the shedding of infectious HIV from chronically virus-producing lymphoma cultures. This is the only compound that prevents the shedding of HIV infection from carrier cultures. D609 antagonizes the action of the tumor-promoting compound TPA (12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate). The effects of D609 are not directed at pkc itself.
