Phospholipase C seems to be the main target. Diacylglycerol, the product of phospholipase C activity, is absent in cells treated with D609. D609 interacts with the growth signal transduction sequence in a very specific mechanism. The transaction mechanisms may lack biological activity as xanthogenate blocks pkC activity responsible for the appropriate phosphorylation of these parameters. Bolus injections of D609 in conjunction with monocarbonic acid exert therapeutic effects on tumor xenografts in athymic mice when D609/undecanoic or dodecanoic acid was administered. This compound can be administered intravenously in very high concentrations.
authors: Sauer, G.;Amtmann, E.;Mellert, W.

title: A member of a new Picornaviridae genus is excreted in pig feces
abstract: During a study of the faecal microbiomes of two healthy piglets using high-throughput sequencing (HTS), we identified a viral genome containing an open reading frame encoding a predicted polyprotein of 2,133 amino acids. This new viral genome showed the typical organization of picornaviruses and contained three structural proteins (VP0, VP3 and VP1) followed by seven nonstructural proteins (2A, 2B, 2C, 3A, 3B, 3Cpro and 3Dpol). Given its special relationship to parechovirus, we propose naming it "pasivirus" to the parecho sister clade virus, with "Swine pasivirus 1" (SPaV1) as the type species. Fecal samples collected at an industrial facility from healthy sows and piglets from the same herd (25 and 75, respectively) aged 4 to 28 weeks were analyzed for the presence of SPAV1 by one-step reverse transcription (RT)-PCR targeting a 3D region of 151 bp. SPAV1 was detected in faecal samples from 51/75 healthy piglets (68% of animals) and in none of the 25 faecal samples from healthy sows, suggesting that SPAV1 circulates through enteric infection of healthy piglets. We propose that SPAV1 represents the first member of a new Picornaviridae genus related to parechoviruses. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Sauvage, V.;Ar Gouilh, M.;Cheval, J.;Muth, E.;Pariente, K.;Burguiere, A.;Caro, V.;Manuguerra, J. C.;Eloit, M.

title: Identification of the first human gyrovirus, a virus related to chicken anemia virus
authors: Sauvage, V.;Cheval, J.;Foulongne, V.;Gouilh, M. A.

title: Novel putative bluetongue virus in healthy goats from Sardinia, Italy
abstract: In recent years, new bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes have been isolated and/or sequenced by researchers in the field. During bluetongue surveillance activities, we identified a putative new BTV serotype in healthy goats from Sardinia, Italy. RNAs purified from blood and serum samples were positive for BTV by generic real-time RT-PCR and c-ELISA, respectively, while genotyping and serotyping were unsuccessful. Using NGS, the entire genome sequence was obtained from two blood samples (BTV-X ITL2015 strains 34200 and 33531). Overall, Seg 2 of BTV-X ITL2015 shows the highest identity (75.3-75.5% nt/77.4-78.1% aa) with recently isolated BTV-27 from Corsica and with the most recently discovered BTV XJ1407 from China (75.9% nt/78.2% aa), while with BTV-25 from Switzerland (73.0% nt/75.0% aa) and BTV-26 from Kuwait (62.0% nt/60 .5% aa) less related. In this study, a specific RT-qPCR targeting Seg 2 of BTV-X ITL2015 was evaluated. Given the Seg 2/VP2 identity of BTV-X ITL2015 with BTV-25, 26, 27s and BTV XJ1407, and that serum from BTV-X ITL2015 infected goats failed to neutralize all serotypes present tested, we propose the existence of one new BTV serotype circulating in goats in Sardinia. Isolation has so far been unsuccessful, hampering proper antigenic characterization.
authors: Savini, G.;Puggioni, G.;Meloni, G.;Marcacci, M.;Di Domenico, M.;Rocchigiani, A. M.;Spedicato, M.;Oggiano, A.;Manunta, D.;Teodori, L.;Leone, A.;Portanti, O.;Cito, F.;Conte, A.;Orsini, M.;Camma, C.;Calistri, P.;Giovannini, A.;Lorusso, A.

title: Morphological, chemical, and antigenic organization of mammalian C-type viruses
abstract: New features in the architecture of mammalian type C viruses, in particular knob-like surface protrusions and hexagonally arranged subunits on the nuclear envelope, could be demonstrated by electron microscopy using newly developed preparation techniques. Murine leukemia viruses (MuLVs) and newly isolated porcine and bovine C viruses are presented as examples. The major proteins of a MuLV have been isolated and partially characterized chemically and in terms of their serological and other biological activities such as interfering and hemagglutinating (HA) capacity. Most of the characterized proteins could be localized to specific substructures of the virion either by selective removal or isolation of electron microscopically identifiable components. The information obtained allowed the design of a more detailed model of mammalian C viruses. Particular attention was paid to the further characterization of interspecies antigens of mammalian C viruses. Various antigenic determinants have been revealed. Their distribution allows for a further sub-classification of mammalian C-viruses.
authors: Schaefer, W.;Demsey, A.;Frank, H.

title: Origin of the 1957 pandemic H2 influenza A virus and the persistence of its possible progenitors in the avian reservoir
abstract: H2N2 influenza A viruses caused the Asian pandemic of 1957 and then disappeared from the human population 10 years later. To assess the potential for similar outbreaks in the future, we determined the antigenicity of H2-hemagglutinins (HAs) from representative human and avian H2viruses and then analyzed the nucleotide and amino acid sequences to determine their evolutionary characteristics in different hosts determine. The results of longitudinal virus surveillance studies were also examined to estimate the prevalence of avian H2 isolates in samples collected from wild ducks and domestic fowl. Patterns of reactivity obtained with a wide range of monoclonal antibodies indicated antigenic drift in the HA of human H2 influenza viruses from 1962 onwards. Amino acid changes were clustered in two regions of HA1 corresponding to antigenic sites A and D of H3-HA. In contrast, the antigenic profiles of most avian H2-HAs were remarkably conserved until 1991 and resembled the prototype strain Japan 57 (H2N2). Amino acid changes were distributed across HA1, indicating that antibodies do not play a major role in avian H2 virus selection. Phylogenetic analysis revealed two geographic, site-specific lineages of avian H2-HAs: North American and Eurasian. Evidence is presented to support interregional transmission of gull H2virus. The human H2-HAs that circulated between 1957 and 1968 form a separate phylogenetic lineage most closely related to the Eurasian avian H2-HAs. In 1988, there was an increased prevalence of H2 influenza virus among wild ducks in North America, which preceded the emergence of H2N2 virus in domestic fowl. As the prevalence of H2N2 avian influenza viruses has increased on turkey farms and live bird markets in New York City and elsewhere, greater numbers of these viruses have come into direct contact with susceptible people. We conclude that antigen-conserved counterparts of the 1957 human Asian pandemic strain continue to circulate in the avian reservoir and come close to susceptible human populations.
authors: Schafer, J. R.;Kawaoka, Y.;Bean, W. J.;Suss, J.;Senne, D.;Webster, R. G.

title: Caliciviridae
abstract: The caliciviruses, a proposed family of Caliciviridae, have a distinct virion morphology with cup-shaped depressions on a spherical capsid surface. The viruses have single-stranded RNA, which has a molecular weight of approximately 2.6 x 106 and is infectious. The RNA is covalently attached to a small protein. A single major polypeptide is found in the capsid. A subgenomic RNA with a molecular weight of approximately 1 x 106 that encodes the capsid polypeptide is found in infected cells. Caliciviruses infecting pigs, pinnipeds and cats have been characterized. Viruses morphologically identical to known caliciviruses have been identified in human feces; These viruses have been shown to be associated with gastroenteritis, but have not yet been propagated in the laboratory.
authors: Schaffer, F. L.;Bachrach, H. L.;Brown, F.

title: Single major polypeptide of a calicivirus: characterization by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and stabilization of virions by cross-linking with dimethyl suberimidate
abstract: calicivirus, San Miguel sea lion virus serotype 4, isolate 15FT, externally labeled with 125I, was shown by gel electrophoresis to have a single major polypeptide. The polypeptide migrated abnormally when electrophoresed in two sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) systems: slower than bovine serum albumin in a continuous phosphate-buffered system and faster than bovine serum albumin in a discontinuous system. The estimated molecular weights in the two systems were about 71,000 and 64,000, respectively. There was no clear evidence for a smaller virion polypeptide. Treatment of purified San Miguel sea lion virions with dimethyl suberimidate, a cross-linking reagent, preserved virion integrity during long-term storage at 4°C. Oligomeric species of the polypeptide have been observed in the electrophoresis of crosslinked virion products. Based on a preferred polypeptide molecular weight estimate of 71,000 and a distribution of oligomeric species, a calicivirion model with 120 monomeric protein units is proposed as an alternative to a 180 unit model.
authors: Schaffer, F. L.;Soergel, M. E.

title: Global Virome Overview: Identification and Characterization of HCV-Related Animal Hepaciviruses
authors: Scheel, T. K. H.;Simmonds, P.;Kapoor, A.

title: Bubaline alphaherpesvirus 1 (BuHV1) genome sequence isolated in Australia in 1972.
abstract: Bubaline alphaherpesvirus 1 (BuHV1) is a member of the family Herpesviridae, subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, genus Varicellovirus. To date, no complete genome sequence of BuHV has been published. Here we report the complete genome sequence of bubaline alphaherpesvirus 1 (BuHV1) strain b6 (BuHV1-b6) isolated from a water buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) in Australia in 1972. The virus was propagated in MDBK cells, the DNA extracted and subjected to high-throughput sequencing. The reads were aligned and combined into a single genomic sequence, using bovine alphaherpesvirus 5 (BoHV5) strain SV507/99 (accession number NC005261) as reference. The BuHV1-b6 genome is a linear double-stranded DNA molecule, 137,452 bp in length, with a GC content of 76.8%. The genome consists of two unique sequences: a long or UL sequence (103,818 bp) and a short or US sequence (9,586 bp), the latter being flanked by inverted IR and TR elements of 12,024 bp each. The arrangement is typical of D-type herpesvirus genomes. The overall sequence has 92.2% similarity to the BoHV5 reference strain at the nucleotide level. Our report represents a significant milestone in the history of herpesviruses, represented by the genome sequence of this 44-year-old virus isolate.
authors: Scheffer, C. M.;Varela, A. P.;Cibulski, S. P.;Schmidt, C.;Campos, F. S.;Paim, W. P.;Dos Santos, R. N.;Teixeira, T. F.;Loiko, M. R.;Tochetto, C.;Dos Santos, H. F.;de Lima, D. A.;Cerva, C.;Mayer, F. Q.;Petzhold, S. A.;Franco, A. C.;George, T. S.;Spilki, F. R.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Comparisons of Venezuelan encephalitis virus strains by chicken antibody hemagglutination inhibition assay
abstract: Twenty strains of Venezuelan encephalitis (VE) virus vaccinated intravenously in large doses in roosters produced hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibodies detectable in plasma within 7 to 10 days. There were no signs of disease and there was no evidence of viral growth in tissues as blood levels of infectious virus steadily decreased after inoculation. HI antibodies in early plasmas were specific for VE virus and showed no significant cross-reactivity with two other North American alphaviruses, Eastern and Western Encephalitis Viruses. VE virus strains could be distinguished by virus dilution, short incubation HI, but not by plasma dilution neutralization assays using early Hahn antibodies. The discriminations by the HI test were similar in some strains but different in other strains from those described by Young and Johnson with the spiny rat antisera used to establish their VE virus subtype classifications. Nevertheless, the results of HI tests with Hahn antibodies correlated with the virulence of horses, as did the results with spiny rat antibodies, and distinguished the new virus strains that emerged during the 1969 VE outbreak in Central America from pre-existing strains.
authors: Scherer, W. F.;Pancake, B. A.

title: Prevalence of porcine noroviruses, molecular characterization of emerging porcine sapoviruses from finishers in the United States, and a common classification scheme for sapoviruses
abstract: Noroviruses (NoVs) and sapoviruses (SaVs) are important human pathogens. Although the involvement of porcine NoVs in disease in swine is unclear, they are genetically and antigenically closely related to human NoVs. Human NoV-like strains have been detected in pigs, raising public health concerns about potential interspecies transmission. Pig SaVs are very diverse and occur in pig populations. Recently, at least three new genogroups of porcine SaVs have been proposed. In this study, we tested 413 pooled fecal samples collected in 2009 from apparently healthy finisher pigs on North Carolina pig farms. Reverse transcription (RT)-PCR coupled hybridization assays were performed to detect known porcine NoVs. The overall prevalence of pig NoVs determined using this method was 18.9%. The samples were then tested by RT-PCR targeting the 5= end of the capsid region on genogroup II (GII) NoVs, a group encompassing human NoVs, followed by sequence analysis. All identified NoVs belonged to typical porcine NoV genotypes and no human NoV-like strains were detected in samples from these pigs. Porcine NoV negative specimens (n=335) were then screened using universal calicivirus primers and 17 SaV strains were confirmed by sequencing. Based on the partial RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) region, they clustered with GIII, GVII, and GVIII and with currently unclassified SaVs. According to the analysis of the complete capsid sequences, 7 representative strains harboring GVII, GVIII and GIX.alpha. SaVs. We tentatively classified SaVs into 14 genogroups based on the full-length capsid protein VP1. In summary, porcine NoVs and highly divergent SaVs were present in North Carolina finishers. © 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Scheuer, K. A.;Oka, T.;Hoet, A. E.;Gebreyes, W. A.;Molla, B. Z.;Saif, L. J.;Wang, Q.

title: Molecular characterization and module composition of P22-related Salmonella phage genomes
abstract: Genomes from newly isolated Salmonella phages were analyzed by comparison of their EcoRI restriction patterns and by hybridization. Characteristic hybridization probes from reference phage P22, ES18 and E. coli phage κ were selected. Four probes selected from the lysis region examined the spread of lambdoid lysis genes. Other probes characterized were the replication genes and part of the structural genes. The complex immune region was examined using hybridization and biological assays. The results demonstrated the relatedness of the isolated phage to the P22 branch of lambdoid phage and revealed their modular genome organization consisting of different portions of P22-related sequences. The DNA restriction patterns of phage released from Salmonella strains sampled in limited geographic areas were significantly less heterogeneous than those of phage released from the SARA collection sampled worldwide. The use of prophage restriction patterns as a Salmonella typing tool to aid in the epidemiological classification of pathogenic strains is discussed. Copyright (C) 1999 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Schicklmaier, P.;Wieland, T.;Schmieger, H.

title: Genomic features of human bocaviruses
abstract: Human Bocavirus (HBoV) was first discovered in 2005 as the second pathogenic member of the parvovirus family alongside human parvovirus B19. Since then, HBoV has been shown to be very common worldwide, causing systemic infection in young children, often leading to respiratory disease. Three other, presumably enteric, human bocaviruses (HBoV2-4) were identified in stool samples. Parvoviruses are thought to replicate via their genomic terminal hairpin-like structures in a so-called "rolling hairpin model". These terminal sequences have recently been partially identified in head-to-tail HBoV PCR amplicons from clinical specimens and are most likely hybrid relics of HBoV's ancestors, namely the bovine parvovirus 1 on the left and the tiny canine virus on the right, shown for the first time in this article. The replication model postulated for HBoV remains questionable, since the occurrence of head-to-tail sequences is not a typical feature of the rolling hairpin replication model. However, such episomes can also be persistent storage forms of the genome.
authors: Schildgen, O.;Qiu, J.;Sderlund-Venermo, M.

title: First detection of porcine parvovirus 6 in North America by viral metagenomic sequencing of serum from pigs infected with porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus Other viruses (e.g. smallpox, papilloma, parvo, reoviridae)
abstract: Background: To date, eight species in four genera of parvoviruses infecting pigs have been described. These include ungulate protoparvovirus 1 (classic porcine parvovirus, PPV), ungulate tetraparvovirus 2 (PPV3), ungulate tetraparvovirus 3 (including PPV2, porcine hokovirus, porcine partetravirus, and porcine PARV4), ungulate copiparvovirus 2 (including PPV4 and PPV5) , ungulate bocaparvovirus 2 (including porcine bocavirus 1, 2 and 6), ungulate bocaparvovirus 3 (porcine bocavirus 5), ungulate bocaparvovirus 4 (porcine bocavirus 7) and ungulate bocaparvovirus 5 (porcine bocavirus 3, 4-1 and 4- 2). PPV6, the most recently described porcine parvovirus, was first identified in aborted pig fetuses in China in late 2014. It was found that the prevalence of PPV6 in China in fattening pigs from farms with and without evidence of reproductive disorders in pigs is similar. Methods: Porcine parvovirus 6 (PPV6) was detected by sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA) and confirmed by overlapping and real-time PCR in serum from porcine reproductive and respiratory virus (PRRSv)-positive specimens. Results: Seven nearly complete genomes of PPV6 were identified in PRRSv genotype 2 positive serum samples submitted to government veterinary diagnostic laboratories in 2014. Further testing using overlapping and real-time PCR revealed that PPV6 was present in 13.2% of the sera tested. In addition, PPV6 was present in samples from all geographic locations surveyed, including nine states in the United States and one state in Mexico. The presence of PPV6 in serum indicates that PPV6 infection is widespread and not localized to any particular tissue type. Alignments of the near-full-length genomes, NS1, and capsid genes identified one of the five PPV6 isolates from China (98.6-99.5% identity with the North American strains) as the closest relative of the North American strains. Conclusions: These results are the first to report the presence of PPV6 in North America and show that the virus is present in multiple geographic areas in the United States and Mexico. The overall prevalence of PPV6 in PRRSv viremic animals is relatively low. In addition, all PPV6 genomes found in North America are most closely related to a PPV6 strain first identified in healthy pigs from the Chinese province of Tianjin in 2014.
authors: Schirtzinger, E. E.;Suddith, A. W.;Hause, B. M.;Hesse, R. A.

title: Detection of a novel bovine astrovirus in a cow with encephalitis
abstract: Encephalitis can be caused by multiple infectious agents, including bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses. In many cases, the pathogen cannot be identified because the pathogens are unknown or detection methods are not routinely available. In our case, a 15-month-old cow developed central nervous system disorders and died within 6 days of the onset of clinical symptoms. Histopathology revealed acute encephalitis, predominantly in the brainstem, and ganglionitis of the trigeminal ganglion with massive neuronal necrosis in both the brain and ganglion. However, a relevant panel of bacterial and viral infections in cattle could be routinely excluded. Therefore, a brain sample from the cow was analyzed using a metagenomic approach with next-generation sequencing. Using the RIEMS analysis pipeline, a novel bovine astrovirus (BoAstV-BH89/14) was identified and the finding was confirmed with a specific BoAstV RT-qPCR. The genome of the bovine astrovirus (BoAstV), which belongs to the family Astroviridae in the genus Mamastrovirus, is 6478 bp in length. Sequence identities between 71% with a sheep astrovirus and 69% with two recently described bovine astroviruses from the USA and Switzerland were found. The latter have also been linked to cases of encephalitis in cattle. Like these, the new virus described here was also detected in various brain slices using the specific BoAstV RT-qPCR and fluorescence in situ hybridization. While astroviruses have so far been found mainly in connection with gastroenteritis in animals and humans, recently detected astrovirus infections have also been associated with encephalitis.
authors: Schlottau, K.;Schulze, C.;Bilk, S.;Hanke, D.;HÃ¶per, D.;Beer, M.;Hoffmann, B.

title: Occurrence of two different bovine hepacivirus clusters in Germany
abstract: In recent years, genetic information of hepaciviruses (Family Flaviviridae), the type species of which is human hepatitis C virus, has been detected in a variety of primates and non-primate vertebrates. Here, samples from 263 German cattle from 22 different farms were examined for the presence of hepacivirus N (syn. bovine hepacivirus; BovHepV). One hundred and eighty-six cattle suffering from non-specific clinical signs such as fever and reduced milk yield and 77 apparently healthy animals were included. A total of 39 cattle (14.8%) tested positive for BovHepV by real-time RT-PCR, but no correlation between clinical symptoms and viral infection could be established. Sequences of the NS3 coding region were generated from 31 of the virus-positive samples and viral sequences of the complete coding region were generated from two samples and compared with other European and African BovHepV sequences. Based on the NS3 genomic region, two distinct German BovHepV clusters were identified that differed by up to 20% at the nucleotide level, with diversity within each cluster reaching up to 10%. Based on the full-length sequences, the newly discovered virus variants group with other German and African viruses in a sister relationship to other primate and other mammalian hepaciviruses, but form distinct clusters within the BovHepV branch. In summary, it can be said that highly different hepaciviruses have been detected in German cattle, which further expand the known phylogenetic diversity of the genus Hepacivirus.
authors: Schlottau, K.;Wernike, K.;Forth, L.;Holsteg, M.;HÃ¶per, D.;Beer, M.;Hoffmann, B.

title: Iridescent insect virus type 6 encodes a polypeptide related to the largest subunit of eukaryotic RNA polymerase II
abstract: Cytoplasmic DNA viruses encode a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (DdRP) that is essential for the transcription of viral genes. The amino acid sequences of known large subunits of DdRPs contain highly conserved regions. Oligonucleotide primers derived from two conserved domains [RQP(T/S)LH and NADFDGDE] were used in PCR experiments to detect the corresponding gene of the genome of insect iridescent virus type 6, also known as Chilo Iridescent Virus (CIV) used. . A specific DNA product of approximately 150 bp could be amplified and used as a hybridization probe against the CIV gene library to identify the corresponding gene. The gene encoding DdRP was identified in EcoRI fragments M (7099 bp) and L (7400 bp) of CIV DNA between map units 0.310 and 0.347 (7990 bp). The DNA nucleotide sequence (3153 bp) of the gene encoding the largest subunit of DdRP (RPO1) was determined. Northern blot hybridization revealed the presence in CIV-infected cells of a 3.4 kb RNA transcript that hybridized to the CIV-DdRP gene. This predicted viral protein consists of 1051 amino acid residues (120K) and showed significantly greater similarity to the largest subunit of eukaryotic RNA polymerase II than to the homologous proteins of vaccinia virus and African swine fever virus. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that the putative RPO1 of CIV may have evolved from RNA polymerase II after the divergence of the three types of eukaryotic RNA polymerases. The putative CIV RPO1 lacked the C-terminal domain that is conserved in eukaryotic, eubacterial, and other viral RNA polymerases and was analogous to archaeal RNA polymerases in this respect. It is hypothesized that the equivalent of the C-terminal domain may reside in a different subunit of CIV DdRP encoded by an unidentified viral gene.
authors: Schnitzler, P.;Sonntag, K. C.;Muller, M.;Janssen, W.;Bugert, J. J.;Koonin, E. V.;Darai, G.

title: Molecular evolution of influenza viruses
abstract: There are two distinct mechanisms by which influenza viruses can evolve: (1) Because the RNA genome of influenza viruses is segmented, new strains can be suddenly produced through reassortment, such as occurs during an antigenic shift, resulting in new pandemic strains. (2) New viruses evolve relatively slowly through stepwise mutation and selection, for example during antigenic or genetic drift. Influenza A viruses have been found in several vertebrate species, where they form reservoirs that do not mix easily. While human influenza A viruses do not spread in birds and vice versa, the species barrier for pigs is relatively low, so pigs could act as "mixing vessels" for the creation of new pandemic reassortants in Southeast Asia, where the likelihood of dual infection of pigs is greatest with human and avian influenza viruses. Phylogenetic studies showed that about 100 years ago an avian influenza A virus had crossed the species barrier, presumably first to pigs and then to humans, forming the new stable human and classical pig lineages. In 1979 an avian virus reappeared in the northern European pig population and formed another stable pig lineage. The northern European pig isolates from 1979 to about 1985 were genetically extremely unstable. A hypothesis is put forward that a mutator mutation is necessary for the influenza virus to cross the species barrier by providing the new host with enough variants from which to choose the best-fit ones. As long as the mutator mutation is still present, such a virus should be able to cross the species barrier a second time, as it did about 100 years ago. Even if the most recent swine isolates from northern Germany are genetically stable again, we should still monitor whether a northern European swine virus appears in the human population in the near future.
authors: Scholtissek, C.

title: Analysis of influenza A virus nucleoproteins to evaluate molecular genetic mechanisms leading to new phylogenetic virus lineages
abstract: The nucleoprotein (NP) gene of influenza A viruses is critical for separating two large, individually evolving reservoirs in birds and humans. A phylogenetic analysis of the NP gene revealed that all mammalian influenza viruses descended - directly or indirectly - from an avian ancestor. The sustained introduction of an avian influenza A virus into a mammalian species appears to be a relatively rare event, the last occurring in 1979 when such an avian virus was introduced into pigs in northern Europe, resulting in a new lineage. At least two simultaneous events are required for such a new and stable introduction: (1) the new species must be infected, and (2) a mutation in the polymerase complex must establish a labile variant, which tends to give rise to a large number of different variants, some of which can quickly adapt to the new host (or unusual environments). Since such mutator mutations could only be advantageous in phases of stress, variants with a less error-prone polymerase could arise again after adaptation. Examples of such fluctuations in mutation and evolution rates are discussed in this brief overview.
authors: Scholtissek, C.;Ludwig, S.;Fitch, W. M.

title: Characterization of the full genome of Tupaia (tree shrew) adenovirus
abstract: Members of the family Adenoviridae are widespread among vertebrate host species and usually cause acute but harmless infections. Adenoviruses receive particular attention because of their ability to transform host cells, their potential application in vector technology, and their phylogeny. The primary structure of the genome of the Tupaia adenovirus (TAV) carrying Tupaia spp. (tree shrew) determined. Tree shrews are taxonomically thought to be at the base of the mammalian phylogenetic tree and are widely used as laboratory animals in neurological and behavioral research. The TAV genome is 33,501 bp in length with 49.96% G+C content and has 166 bp inverted terminal repeats. Analysis of the complete nucleotide sequence led to the identification of 109 open reading frames (ORFs) with a coding capacity of at least 40 amino acid residues. Thirty-eight of these are predicted to encode viral proteins based on the presence of transcriptional and translational signals and sequence and positional conservation. 30 viral OPFs were found to share significant similarities with known adenoviral genes, which are classified into discrete early and late genomic regions known from mastadenoviruses. Analysis of the nucleotide content of the TAV genome revealed a significant CG dinucleotide depletion at the ends of the genome, indicating methylation of these genomic regions during the viral life cycle. Phylogenetic analysis of the viral gene products, including penton and hexon proteins, viral protease, terminal protein, protein VIII, DNA polymerase, protein IVa2, and protein with a molecular weight of 100,000, revealed that the evolutionary lineage of TAV is a separate branch within the family tree of the Mastadenovirus genus.
authors: Schondorf, E.;Bahr, U.;Handermann, M.;Darai, G.

title: Metagenomic screening for viruses in western Arctic caribou, Alaska, by iterative assembly of taxonomic units
abstract: Animal pathogen surveillance does not provide a sufficient level of vigilance as it is generally limited to surveillance of pathogens of known economic importance in domestic animals and virtually absent in wildlife species. Since most (re)emerging viral infections are of animal origin, it is important from a public health perspective to gain insight into the viral pathogens present in the wildlife reservoir. When monitoring live, free-ranging wildlife for viruses, sample collection can be challenging and the availability of nucleic acids isolated from samples is often limited. The development of viral metagenomics platforms allows for a more comprehensive inventory of viruses found in wildlife. We report a metagenomic viral study of the West Arctic caribou herd (Rangifer tarandus granti) in Alaska, USA. The presence of mammalian viruses in eye and nasal swabs from 39 free-ranging caribou was assessed by random amplification combined with a metagenomic analysis approach that used an extensive iterative assembly of sequencing results to define taxonomic units of each metagenome. Through homology search methods, we identified the presence of several mammalian viruses, including various papillomaviruses, a novel parvovirus, polyomavirus, and a virus that may represent a member of a new genus in the family Coronaviridae.
authors: SchÃ¼rch, A. C.;Schipper, D.;Bijl, M. A.;Dau, J.;Beckmen, K. B.;Schapendonk, C. M. E.;Raj, V. S.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;Haagmans, B. L.;Tryland, M.;Smits, S. L.

title: Holstein Friesian Lethal Haplotype 5 (HH5) results from a complete deletion of TBF1M and cholesterol deficiency (CDH) from an ERV (LTR) insertion into the APOB coding region
abstract: BACKGROUND: With the availability of massive SNP data for several economically important cattle breeds, haplotype testing has been performed to identify unknown recessive diseases. A number of so-called lethal haplotypes have been discovered in Holstein-Friesian cattle, and causative mutations in candidate genes have been identified in at least seven of them. However, some deadly haplotypes are still elusive. Here we report the molecular genetic causes of lethal haplotype 5 (HH5) and cholesterol deficiency (CDH). Targeted enrichment for the known genomic regions followed by massive parallel sequencing was used to inquire about causative mutations in a case/control approach. METHODS: Targeted enrichment for the known genomic regions followed by massive parallel sequencing was used in a case/control approach. PCRs for the causative mutations were developed and compared to routine attribution in 2,100 (HH5) and 3,100 (CDH) cattle. RESULTS: HH5 is caused by a 138 kbp deletion spanning position 93.233 kb to 93.371 kb on chromosome 9 (BTA9) and harboring only dimethyl adenosine transferase 1 (TFB1M). The deletion breakpoints are flanked by long interspersed bovine nuclear elements Bov-B (upstream) and L1ME3 (downstream), suggesting a homologous recombination/deletion event. TFB1M dimethylates adenine residues in the hairpin loop at the 3' end of mitochondrial 12S rRNA, which is essential for the synthesis and function of the small ribosomal subunit of mitochondria. Homozygous TFB1M-/-mice have been reported to show embryonic lethality with developmental defects. An allele frequency of 2.8% was determined for the German HF population. CDH results from a 1.3 kbp insertion of an endogenous retrovirus (ERV2-1-LTR_BT) into exon 5 of the APOB gene at BTA11:77,959 kb. The insert is flanked by 6 bp duplications of the target site as described for retroviral integrase-mediated insertions. A premature stop codon is created in the APOB open reading frame, which leads to the protein being shortened to a length of just <140 amino acids. Such early shortenings have been shown to cause an inability of chylomicron secretion from intestinal cells, leading to malabsorption of cholesterol. The allelic frequency of this mutation in the German HF population was 6.7%, which is significantly higher than previously reported. Compared to PCR assays, which directly infer the genetic variants, the routine imputing used so far showed a diagnostic sensitivity of only 91% (HH5) and 88% (CDH), with a high specificity for both (> = 99.7 %). CONCLUSION: With the availability of direct genetic testing, it will now be possible to more effectively reduce the carrier frequency and ultimately eliminate the interference from HF populations. Furthermore, the fact that repetitive genomic elements (RE) are involved in both diseases underscores the evolutionary importance of RE, which can be detrimental as here but also beneficial across generations.
authors: Schutz, E.;Wehrhahn, C.;Wanjek, M.;Bortfeld, R.;Wemheuer, W. E.;Beck, J.;Brenig, B.

title: Animal noroviruses
abstract: Among enteric caliciviruses, noroviruses belong to the genus Norovirus, one of the four recognized genera in the family Caliciviridae. These positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses are highly variable, both genetically and antigenically. Several animal enteric caliciviruses that are morphologically indistinguishable and genetically closely related to human noroviruses have been identified. The first bovine enteric noroviruses were described in the UK and are known as Newbury Agent 2. At least three genetic clusters of porcine noroviruses combine within genogroup II noroviruses. Human noroviruses are the most important cause of acute gastroenteritis in humans of all ages. In the US, they are associated with approximately 30-50% of all foodborne outbreaks. So far, noroviruses have not been associated with gastroenteritis outbreaks in immunocompetent animals. Neither bovine nor porcine norovirus can replicate in cell culture, although human norovirus can grow in a complex 3D culture system. However, the recently discovered murine noroviruses can replicate in cell culture and are therefore used as model viruses to study human noroviruses. This review focuses on virus classification, virion structure, pathogenesis, epidemiology, immune response, and diagnosis of animal noroviruses compared to human noroviruses. The classification of animal enteric caliciviruses within the genus Norovirus raises the question of whether transmission from an animal reservoir to humans could occur. Answering this question is important to determine the risk of cross-species infections that affect the epidemiology and evolution of these viruses, thus complicating the control of human norovirus infections.
authors: Scipioni, A.;Mauroy, A.;VinjÃ©, J.;Thiry, E.

title: Nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequence analysis of hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein fusion protein and genes among Newcastle disease virus isolates. Phylogenetic relationships among the Paramyxovirinae based on binding glycoprotein sequences
abstract: Highly virulent isolates of Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV) are Schedule A pathogens for commercial poultry and reports of their isolation between Member States must be submitted to the Office of International Epizootes (OIE). The virus is classified as a member of the order Mononegavirales in the family Paramyxoviridae of the subfamily Paramyxovirinae. Two interactive surface glycoproteins, fusion protein (F) and hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein (HN), play essential roles in NDV attachment and fusion of cells during infection. Antibodies against the F or HN proteins can neutralize viruses; however, full length sequences are not available for these genes from recently obtained virulent isolates. Therefore, nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences of the F and HN protein genes of 16 NDV isolates representing highly virulent viruses from worldwide sources were obtained for comparison with older virulent isolates and vaccine strains. The amino acid sequence of F protein was relatively conserved among isolates that retained potential glycosylation sites and C residues for disulfide bonds. A dibasic amino acid motif was present at the cleavage site in the more virulent isolates, while the low virulence viruses lacked this sequence. However, a Eurasian collared pigeon virus had a K114Q substitution at the F cleavage site that is unique among NDV isolates. The HN protein among the NDV isolates retained predicted catalytic and active site residues necessary for neuraminidase activity and hemagglutination. The length of the HN for the Eurasian collared pigeon isolate and a previously reported heat-resistant virulent isolate were longer compared to other more recent virulent isolates. Phylogenetically, NDV isolates were divided into four groups, with newer virulent isolates forming a diverse branch, while all avian paramyxoviruses formed their own clade distinct from other members of the Paramyxoviridae. © Springer Verlag 2004.
authors: Seal, B. S.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus vaccines by biological properties and sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein gene
abstract: Six commercial live monovalent Newcastle disease virus (NDV) vaccines were evaluated for their biological and genomic stability compared to their stated parental virus. The thermostability of hemagglutinin at 56°C for 5 minutes was consistently observed for the majority of vaccine viruses. An exception was a recently developed NDV vaccine isolated from turkeys which showed a thermostability of 15 minutes. Neuraminidase activity, as measured by the elution rate of agglutinated red blood cells, varied between vaccine viruses and correlated with that of the parent isolate. Virulence, measured by the intracerebral pathogenicity index, ranged from 0 to 0.39 for NDV vaccine-type viruses, well within the range of avirulent lentogens. The sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site of all NDV vaccine isolates examined was consistent with that for Lentogen. The entire hemagglutinin neurominidase gene sequence was 98% similar in all NDV vaccine viruses examined, and the phylogenetic classification of the commercial vaccine types correlated with their parent virus. Consequently, the commercially produced NDV vaccines described here appear to be relatively stable when mass-produced in embryonated avian eggs.
authors: Seal, B. S.;King, D. J.;Bennett, J. D.

title: The avian response to Newcastle disease virus
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is classified as a member of the superfamily Mononegavirales in the family Paramyxoviridae. This virus family is divided into two subfamilies, the Paramyxovirinae and the Pneumovirinae. In 1993, the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses reorganized the order of the Paramyxovirus genus and placed NDV within the Rubulavirus genus under the Paramyxovirinae. The enveloped virus has a 15,186 kb negative-sense single-stranded RNA genome encoding an RNA-directed RNA polymerase, a hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein, a fusion protein, a matrix protein, a phosphoprotein, and a nucleoprotein in the 5'-to 3' direction encoded. The virus has a wide host range, with most bird species reportedly infected with NDV. Isolates are characterized by virulence in chickens and are divided into three main pathotypes depending on the severity of the disease. Lentogenic isolates are of low virulence, while viruses with intermediate virulence are referred to as mesogenic. Highly virulent viruses that cause high mortality in birds are called neurotropic or viscerotropic velogenic viruses. Velogenic NDVs are Schedule A pathogens that require reporting to the Office of International Epizootics, and outbreaks result in severe trade embargoes. The primary molecular determinant of NDV pathogenicity is the amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion protein. Vaccination against NDV is mainly done through mass application of live virus vaccines to commercial poultry. Although protection is measured by the presence of antibodies to NDV, vaccinated B cell-depleted chickens are resistant to disease. Consequently, immune protection involves responses that are currently incompletely defined. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd.
authors: Seal, B. S.;King, D. J.;Sellers, H. S.

title: Fusion protein predicted amino acid sequence of the first US avian pneumovirus isolate and lack of heterogeneity among other US isolates
abstract: Avian pneumovirus (APV) was first isolated from turkeys in the central western United States after the emergence of turkey rhinotracheitis (TRT) in 1996. Subsequently, several APV isolates were obtained from the north-central US. Matrix (M) and fusion protein (F) genes from these isolates were analyzed for sequence heterogeneity and compared to European APV subtypes A and B. Among the US isolates, the M gene shared greater than 98% nucleotide sequence identity, with only one non-synonymous change occurring in a single US isolate. Although the F gene shared 98% nucleotide sequence identity among US APV isolates, nine conserved substitutions were detected in the predicted amino acid sequence. The predicted amino acid sequence of the F protein of the US APV isolate had 72% sequence identity with the APV subtype A F protein and 71% sequence identity with the APV subtype B F protein. This is separated by an 83% sequence identity F protein amino acid sequences predicted for APV subtype versus A and B. The US isolates were phylogenetically distinguishable from their European counterparts on the basis of F gene nucleotides or predicted amino acid sequences. The lack of sequence heterogeneity among US APV subtypes indicates that these viruses have maintained a relatively stable population since the initial onset of TRT. Phylogenetic analysis of F protein among APV isolates supports classification of US isolates as a new APV subtype C. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Seal, B. S.;Sellers, H. S.;Meinersmann, R. J.

title: Genomic sequences of low virulence isolates of avian paramyxovirus-1 (Newcastle disease virus) obtained from live bird markets in North America and unrelated to commonly used commercial vaccine strains
abstract: Avian paramyxovirus 1 (APMV-1), also known as Newcastle disease virus (NDV), low-virulence variants have been isolated from chickens, ducks and other unidentified species grown in live bird markets in the Northeastern United States were found. These isolates were characterized as APMV-1 by the hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assay using NDV-specific polyclonal antisera. However, the isolates did not react with a monoclonal antibody specific for a variety of APMV-1 isolates. Although only highly virulent isolates require reporting to international regulatory agencies, the ability to correctly identify APMV-1 types is important for control and regulatory purposes. Protein gel patterns of the purified isolates resembled previously reported APMV-1, and anti-NDV polyclonal sera recognized the viral proteins. For three isolates, oligonucleotide primers specific for the NDV nucleoprotein, fusion protein and polymerase genes were used to synthesize cDNA using viral RNA as template. Approximately 12 kb of the genome was then sequenced for the three isolates containing the genes for nucleoprotein, phosphoprotein, matrix protein, fusion protein (F), hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein and a 5 inch stretch of the polymerase gene. The isolates had an F protein cleavage site sequence of ERQER/LVG, indicating low virulence viruses that phylogenetically diverged with other unique NDV isolates, designated the lineage 6 genotype. In addition, a four amino acid insert was detected in the predicted phosphoprotein, which conforms to the "rule of six" among paramyxoviruses. These APMV-1 genotypes have not previously been reported in North America and further support the heterogeneous genetic nature of these commercially important pathogens found worldwide. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Seal, B. S.;Wise, M. G.;Pedersen, J. C.;Senne, D. A.;Alvarez, R.;Scott, M. S.;King, D. J.;Yu, Q.;Kapczynski, D. R.

title: Evolutionary history and phylogeography of rabies viruses associated with outbreaks in Trinidad
abstract: Bat rabies is an emerging disease of public health concern in America. Livestock outbreaks are a regular occurrence on the Caribbean island of Trinidad. We performed molecular characterization of Trinidad rabies virus (RABV) and used a Bayesian phylogeographic approach to examine the extent to which outbreaks are the result of in situ evolution versus importing the virus from nearby mainland South America. Trinidadian RABV sequences have been confirmed as a bat variant and clustered with Desmodus rotundus (vampire bat) related sequences. They fell into two broadly temporally defined lineages designated Trinidad I and II. The Trinidad I lineage, which included sequences from 1997-2000 (all but two of which originated in the northeast of the island), was most closely associated with RABV from Ecuador (2005, 2007), French Guiana (1990), and Venezuela (1993, 1994) related). Trinidad II included sequences from the southwest of the island, grouped into two groups: Trinidad IIa, with one each from 2000 and 2007, and Trinidad IIb, with all sequences from 2010. The Trinidad II sequences were most closely related Related sequences from Brazil (1999, 2004) and Uruguay (2007, 2008). Phylogeographic analyzes support three separate mainland RABV introductions from which each of the three Trinidadian lineages arose. The estimated dates for the introductions and subsequent lineage extensions suggest periods of in situ evolution in Trinidad after each introduction. These data also indicate a joint circulation of Trinidad lineages I and IIa in 2000. Given these results and the likely origin of Trinidadian RABV vampire bats, further studies should be conducted to investigate the relationship between RABV spatiotemporal dynamics and vampire bat population ecology. particularly any movement between the mainland and Trinidad.
authors: Seetahal, J. F. R.;Velasco-Villa, A.;Allicock, O. M.;Adesiyun, A. A.;Bissessar, J.;Amour, K.;Phillip-Hosein, A.;Marston, D. A.;McElhinney, L. M.;Shi, M.;Wharwood, C. A.;Fooks, A. R.;Carrington, C. V. F.

title: Meaning of Campylobacter spp. for public health Colonization of wild pheasants (Phasianus colchicus) in Scotland
abstract: Campylobacter is the most common cause of bacterial foodborne diarrhea worldwide. Chicken meat is considered the main source of infection for humans; However, C. jejuni and C. coli have also been reported in a number of livestock and wildlife species, including pheasants. Wild pheasant meat finds its way onto consumers' tables through hunting, but information on the risk of Campylobacter infection in humans is lacking. The aim of this study was to determine the prevalence of Campylobacter in wild pheasants in Scotland, identify the major sequence types (STs) present and assess their public health implications. A total of 287 cecal samples were collected from five Scottish regions during the 2013/2014 hunting season. Campylobacter was detected and enumerated using standard culture methods. PCR and High Throughput Multi Locus Sequence Typing (HiMLST) were used for species identification and sequence typing. Overall, 36.6% of 287 cecal specimens (n==105; 95% CI: 14-59.2) were Campylobacter positive. Using PCR, 62.6% of the samples (n==99) were identified as C. coli and 37.4% as C. jejuni. HiMLST (nâ€¯=â€¯80) identified 19 different STs. ST-828 (nâ€¯=â€¯19) was the most common, followed by ST-827 (nâ€¯=â€¯12) and ST19 (nâ€¯=â€¯7). Sixteen of the 19 isolated STs are present in humans and eight are C. coli STs, accounting for 6.96% of human infections, although the overall public health risk from pheasant meat is still considered low.
authors: Seguino, A.;Chintoan-Uta, C.;Smith, S. H.;Shaw, D. J.

title: Molecular detection and analysis of Sheeppox and Orf viruses isolated from sheep from Qalubia, Egypt
abstract: In this study, an outbreak of sheeppox virus (SPPV) and orf virus (ORFV) in a flock of sheep in Qalubia province, Egypt was investigated. Both SPPV and ORFV caused clinically evident infections in sheep. The affected sheep showed skin lesions around the mouth or all over the body. Therefore, a reliable diagnosis should confirm the etiology of the infection, and then reduce the spread of the diseases in the affected areas. Clinical samples were examined by virus isolation, PCR and real-time PCR assays. In addition, PCR products from SPPV and ORFV isolates were sequenced and compared to reference isolates for phylogenetic analysis. Laboratory diagnosis showed that the real-time PCR assay was more accurate and sensitive than traditional PCR and virus isolation. In the phylogenetic analysis of the A29L gene, no genetic differences were observed between SPPV field strains and the strains showed 100% homology with two SPPV isolates from Kazakhstan and one isolate from Turkey. The ORFV field strains differ genetically in the P55 gene from others and from other published isolates from Egypt in 2006 and 2009.
authors: Selim, A.;Elhaig, M.;HÃ¶che, J.;Gaede, W.

title: Molecular characterization of infectious bronchitis viruses isolated from broiler and layer farms in Egypt in 2012
abstract: One of the main problems of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is the frequent emergence of new variants. In the present study, 205 tracheal swabs and organs were collected from broiler and layer farms in 19 governorates across Egypt from January to August 2012. The chickens showed respiratory symptoms and mortality. Of the samples examined, 130 (approx. 64%) of the farms with suspected IBV were positive with real-time RT-PCR. 13 IBV positive specimens were selected for further isolation and characterization. Isolation in specific pathogen-free (SPF) embryos was performed after three consecutive blind passages, and the spike protein 1 (SP1) hypervariable region was amplified by RT-PCR and sequenced to examine the genetic diversity between the isolated viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the obtained sequences of 13 isolates compared to other IBV strains from the Middle East and worldwide revealed that 11 of the 13 isolates were closely related to the Israeli variants (IS/885 and IS/1494/06) with nucleotide homology to 89.9% and 82.3%, respectively. Only two isolates were closely related to viruses CR/88121 and 4/91 with identities of 95% and 96%, respectively. This study indicates the existence of two variant groups of IBV circulating in Egypt in 2012. Group I was similar but distinguishable from Israeli variant IS/885 and Group II was related to vaccine strains 4/91 and CR/88121. There was no geographical connection between the two groups as they were spread across the country. These findings require a revision of vaccination programs and control measures for IBV. © 2013.
authors: Selim, K.;Arafa, A. S.;Hussein, H. A.;El-Sanousi, A. A.

title: â€¦ Materials: Incidence and pathologic phenotype of Bovine Astrovirus CH13/NeuroS1 infection in neurologically diseased cattle: To assess â€¦
authors: Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Boujon, C. L.;Hilbe, M.;Oevermann, A.

title: Frequency and pathologic phenotype of bovine Astrovirus CH13/NeuroS1 infection in neurologically diseased cattle: to assess causality
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) has opened up the possibility of detecting new viruses in unsolved diseases. Recently, astrovirus brain infections in neurologically diseased humans and animals have been identified by NGS, including bovine astrovirus (BoAstV) CH13/NeuroS1 found in brain tissues of cattle with nonsuppurative encephalitis. Studies on neurotrophic astroviruses are few, and a causal relationship between BoAstV-CH13/NeuroS1 infection and neurological disease has been postulated but remains unproven. Aiming to get one step closer to assessing causality, we collected brain samples from 97 cattle diagnosed with unresolved nonsuppurative encephalitis and analyzed them by in situ hybridization and immunohistochemistry to determine frequency and neuropathological distribution of BoAstV CH13/ NeuroS1 and its topographical correlation to pathology. We detected BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1 RNA or proteins in neurons in all parts of the central nervous system (CNS) in 34% of all cases, but none were detected in control cattle. In general, brain lesions correlated strongly with the presence of the virus. These findings demonstrate that a significant proportion of cattle with nonsuppurative encephalitis are infected with BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1 and further support the causal relationship between neurological diseases and Astrovirus infections.
authors: Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Boujon, C. L.;Hilbe, M.;Oevermann, A.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Isolation of bluetongue virus serotypes new to Indonesia from sentinel cattle in West Java
authors: Sendow, I.;Daniels, P. W.;Soleha, E.;Erasmus, B.

title: Evaluation of the broad-spectrum lytic ability of bacteriophage cocktails against various Salmonella serovars and their effects on weaned pigs infected with Salmonella Typhimurium
abstract: The broad lytic ability of Salmonella bacteriophages against various Salmonella species was evaluated to determine their potential as an alternative to antibiotics, and the safety and preventive effects of the bacteriophages were assessed in mice and pigs. Four bacteriophage cocktails were prepared using 13 bacteriophage and the lytic ability of the four bacteriophage cocktails was tested using Salmonella reference strains and field isolates. Bacteriophage cocktail C (SEP-1, SGP-1, STP-1, SS3eP-1, STP-2, SChP-1, SAP-1, SAP-2; ≥ 109 pfu/mL) showed the best lytic activity against the Salmonella reference strains (100% of 34) and field isolates (92.5% of 107). Fifty mice were then orally inoculated with bacteriophage cocktail C to determine the distribution of bacteriophage in various organs, blood and feces. The effects of bacteriophage on Salmonella infection in weaned pigs (n=15) were also evaluated by experimental challenge with Salmonella Typhimurium after treatment with bacteriophage cocktail C. All mice showed distribution of bacteriophages in all organs, blood and faeces up to 15 days post-treatment infection (dpi). After 35 dpi, no bacteriophage was detected in any of these samples. As shown in a challenge study in pigs, treatment with bacteriophage cocktail C reduced faecal shedding of Salmonella. The metagenomic analyzes of these pig faeces also showed that bacteriophage treatment reduced the number of species of the family Enterobacteriaceae without significantly disturbing the normal faecal flora. This study showed that bacteriophage effectively controlled Salmonella in a pig challenge model and could be a good alternative to antibiotics to control Salmonella infection.
authors: Seo, B. J.;Song, E. T.;Lee, K.;Kim, J. W.;Jeong, C. G.;Moon, S. H.;Son, J. S.;Kang, S. H.;Cho, H. S.;Jung, B. Y.;Kim, W. I.

title: Africa, a reservoir of new virulent strains of Newcastle disease?
authors: Servan de Almeida, R.;Maminiaina, O. F.;Gil, P.;Hammoumi, S.;Molia, S.;Chevalier, V.;Koko, M.;Andriamanivo, H. R.;TraorÃ©, A.;SamakÃ©, K.;Diarra, A.;Grillet, C.;Martinez, D.;Albina, E.

title: Genetic diversity of Newcastle disease virus in Pakistan: A nationwide perspective
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the deadliest poultry diseases worldwide. The disease is endemic in Pakistan and recurrent outbreaks in captive, rural and commercial poultry flocks are regularly reported. Although efforts have been made in some parts of the country to characterize the pathogen, the genetic nature of strains circulating across Pakistan is currently lacking. Material and methods. To determine the genetics of NDV, 452 blood samples were collected from 113 herds originating from all provinces of Pakistan and showing high mortality (30-80%). The samples represented domestic poultry (broilers, layers and farm fowl) as well as captive wild birds (pigeons, turkeys, pheasants and peacocks). Samples were screened for both matrix and fusion genes (1792 bp) using real-time PCR, positive samples underwent full-length fusion gene amplification followed by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis. Results: The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion protein revealed the presence of the motif (112RK/RQRRâ†“F117) typical of velogenetic NDV strains. The phylogenetic analysis of the hypervariable region of the fusion gene showed that all isolates belong to lineage 5 of NDV except the isolates collected from Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) province. Higher resolution phylogenetic analysis of lineage 5 revealed the distribution of Pakistani NDV strains to 5b. However, the isolates from KPK belonged to lineage 4c; the first report of such a lineage from that province. Conclusions: Taken together, the data demonstrated the prevalence of multiple lineages of NDV in different poultry populations, including captive birds. Such an understanding is crucial to underpin the nature of circulating NDV strains, their potential for transmission between species, and disease diagnosis and control strategies. © 2013 Shabbir et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Shabbir, M. Z.;Zohari, S.;Yaqub, T.;Nazir, J.;Shabbir, M. A. B.;Mukhtar, N.;Shafee, M.;Sajid, M.;Anees, M.;Abbas, M.;Khan, M. T.;Ali, A. A.;Ghafoor, A.;Ahad, A.;Channa, A. A.;Anjum, A. A.;Hussain, N.;Ahmad, A.;Goraya, M. U.;Iqbal, Z.;Khan, S. A.;Aslam, H. B.;Zehra, K.;Sohail, M. U.;Yaqub, W.;Ahmad, N.;Berg, M.;Munir, M.

title: A comparative analysis shows frequent recombination in parvoviruses
abstract: Parvoviruses are small, single-stranded DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. Infections with both autonomous and helper virus-dependent parvoviruses are common in both human and animal populations, and many animals harbor a number of different parvovirus species. Despite the epidemiological importance of parvoviruses, the presence and role of genome recombination within or between parvoviral species has not been well characterized. Here we show that natural recombination can be widespread in these viruses. Distinct genome regions of both porcine parvoviruses and Aleutian mink disease viruses have conflicting phylogenetic histories, providing evidence for recombination within each of these two species. Furthermore, the rodent parvoviruses show complex evolutionary histories for distinct genomic regions, suggesting recombination at the interspecies level. © 2007 SGM.
authors: Shackelton, L. A.;Hoelzer, K.;Parrish, C. R.;Holmes, E. C.

title: Phylogenetic analysis and reclassification of caprine and ovine lentiviruses based on 104 new isolates: Evidence for regular sheep-to-goat transmission and worldwide spread through livestock trade
abstract: We performed a phylogenetic analysis of caprine and ovine lentiviruses using long sequences in gag and pol from 104 new Swiss isolates and six available corresponding database sequences. Forty-five isolates forming five sequence clusters were unclassifiable by the present classification. Pairwise DNA distance analysis revealed different categories of relatedness, necessitating a new classification system. We propose four major sequence groups AD that differ by 25-37%. Groups A and B are further divided into subtypes that differ by 15-27%. Group D and four of the seven subtypes of group A, A3, A4, A5 and A7, are formed by new Swiss isolates. Molecular epidemiology revealed that Swiss B1 strains differed no more from French, Brazilian or US strains than from each other, suggesting a spread of the virus through the international livestock trade. In addition, infection of goats by subtypes A3 or A4 was significantly associated with documented contact with sheep also harboring these subtypes, suggesting regular sheep-to-goat transmission. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Shah, C.;BÃ¶ni, J.;Huder, J. B.;Vogt, H. R.;MÃ¼hlherr, J.;Zanoni, R.;Miserez, R.;Lutz, H.;SchÃ¼pbach, J.

title: Comparison of tissue sample processing methods to obtain the viral metagenome and a snapshot of the viral RNA community in a turkey gut
abstract: RNA viruses have been implicated in enteritis in poultry and have been isolated from diseased birds. The same viral pathogens have also been detected in healthy herds, calling into question their role in health and disease. To better understand eukaryotic viruses in the gut, this project focused on evaluating alternative methods for purifying and concentrating viral particles that do not use density gradients to generate viral metagenome data. In this study, the sequence results of three tissue processing methods were evaluated and a data analysis pipeline for RNA viruses from the gastrointestinal tract was established. In addition, using best method and increased sequencing depth, insight into the viral RNA community in the gastrointestinal tract of a clinically normal 5-week-old turkey is provided. Viruses of the families Reoviridae and Astroviridae together accounted for 76.3% of all identified viruses. The species-level dilution curve further showed that most of the species diversity was contained in the increased sequencing depth, suggesting that viruses from other virus families were present at very low abundance.
authors: Shah, J. D.;Baller, J.;Zhang, Y.;Silverstein, K.;Xing, Z.;Cardona, C. J.

title: Development of the intestinal RNA virus community in healthy broilers
abstract: Several RNA viruses such as astrovirus, rotavirus, reovirus and parvovirus have been detected in both healthy and diseased commercial poultry flocks. The aim of this study was to characterize (a) the development of the RNA viral community in the small intestine of healthy broilers from hatch to 6 weeks of age (marketing age) and (b) the contribution of breeder source versus bird age in the development of community structure . Intestinal tissue samples were harvested from breeders and their progeny, processed for viral RNA extraction, and sequenced using Illumina Hiseq sequencing technology, resulting in 100 bp PE reads. The results of this study showed that the brood source affected the RNA virus community only at hatch, but the later environment, i.e. bird age, had the more significant effect. The most abundant RNA virus family detected at 2, 4, and 6 weeks of age were Astroviridae, which decreased in frequency with age, while Picornaviridae increased in frequency with age.
authors: Shah, J. D.;Desai, P. T.;Zhang, Y.;Scharber, S. K.;Baller, J.;Xing, Z. S.;Cardona, C. J.

title: Analysis of host-parasite mismatch in papillomavirus evolution using importance sampling
abstract: The papillomaviruses (PVs) are a family of viruses that infect several mammalian and non-mammalian species that cause cervical cancer in humans. The evolutionary history of PVs, as they are associated with a variety of host species, is not well understood. Incongruences between the phylogenetic trees of different viral genes and between these genes and host phylogenies indicate historical viral recombination and violations of strict virus-host cospeciation. However, the extent of recombination events between PVs is uncertain, and there is little evidence to support a theory of PV spread via recent host transmissions. We have examined the incongruence between PV genes and thus the possibility of recombination using Bayesian phylogenetic methods. We find significant evidence of phylogenetic incongruence between the six PV genes E1, E2, E6, E7, L1 and L2, indicating significant recombination. Analysis of E1 and L1 phylogenies suggests ancestral recombination events. We also describe a new method to study alternative host-parasite association mechanisms by applying importance sampling to Bayesian divergence time estimation. This new approach is not constrained by a fixed viral tree topology or knowledge of viral divergence times, it can contain multiple parasite taxa per host, and it can distinguish between prior divergence of virus before host speciation and host transmission of virus after speciation will. Using this method, we find prior divergence of PV lineages associated with the ancestral mammalian host, resulting in at least 6 PV lineages prior to speciation of that host. These PV lineages have then followed paths of earlier divergence and cospecification to eventually be associated with the host species present. Only one significant case of host transmission is supported, transmission of the ancestral L1 gene between a primate and a hystricognathic host, based on the divergence times between the Ypsilon human type 41 and porcupine PVs.
authors: Shah, S. D.;Doorbar, J.;Goldstein, R. A.

title: The faecal virome of pigs on a high-density farm
abstract: Pigs are an important source of protein worldwide, but are subject to frequent viral outbreaks and numerous infections that can infect humans. Modern housing conditions can also increase virus transmission and potential zoonotic spread. We describe here the metagenomics-derived virome in the faeces of 24 healthy and 12 diarrheal piglets on a high-density farm. An average of 4.2 different mammalian viruses were shed by healthy piglets, reflecting a high level of asymptomatic infections. Diarrhea pigs shed an average of 5.4 different mammalian viruses. Ninety-nine percent of the viral sequences were related to the RNA virus families Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Coronaviridae, and Caliciviridae, while 1% were related to the small DNA virus families Circoviridae and Parvoviridae. Identified porcine RNA viruses, in order of decreasing number of sequence reads, consisted of kobuvirus, astrovirus, enterovirus, sapovirus, sapelovirus, coronavirus, bocavirus, and testovirus. The nearly complete genomes of several new species of porcine astroviruses and bocaviruses have been generated and phylogenetically analyzed. Several small circular DNA genomes encoding replicase proteins as well as two highly divergent members of the Picornavirales order have also been characterized. The possible origin of these viral genomes from porcine protozoa and nematodes, based on closest sequence similarities, is discussed. In summary, an unbiased study of viruses in the faeces of intensively reared animals revealed frequent coinfections with a very diverse group of viruses that provide favorable conditions for viral recombination. Viral studies of animals can easily document the circulation of known and emerging viruses, facilitating the detection of emerging viruses and the prospective assessment of their pathogenic and zoonotic potential. © 2011, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Shan, T.;Li, L.;Simmonds, P.;Wang, C.;Moeser, A.;Delwart, E.

title: Discovery of antiviral drugs to treat Enterovirus-71 infection
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) is a small, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus of the genus Enterovirus, family Picornavirus. It causes hand, foot, and mouth disease in infants and children, which in a small percentage of cases progresses to a central nervous system infection ranging from aseptic meningitis to fatal encephalitis. Sporadic cases of EV71 infection occur around the world, but recently major epidemics have emerged in Southeast Asia and China. There are currently no approved vaccines or antiviral therapies to prevent or treat EV71 infection. This paper provides an overview of efforts to develop antiviral therapies against EV71. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Shang, L.;Xu, M.;Yin, Z.

title: A naturally occurring recombinant enterovirus expresses a torovirus deubiquitinase
abstract: Enteroviruses (EVs) are implicated in a variety of human and animal diseases. In this study, a novel enterovirus (Enterovirus species G [EVG]) (EVG 08/NC_USA/2015) was isolated from a diagnostic specimen of neonatal swine diarrhea and identified using metagenomics and full genome sequencing. The viral genome shares 75.4% nucleotide identity with a prototypical EVG strain (PEV9 UKG/410/73). Notably, a 582 nucleotide long insertion flanked by 3Cpro cleavage sites at the 5= and 3= ends was found in the 2C/3A junction region of the viral genome. This insertion encodes a predicted protease with 54-68% amino acid identity to torovirus (ToV) papain-like protease (PLP) (ToV-PLP). Structural homology modeling predicts that this protease adopts a fold and catalytic site characteristic of minimal PLP catalytic domains. This structure is similar to that of the catalytic core domains of foot-and-mouth disease virus leader protease and coronavirus PLPs, which act as deubiquitinating and deISGylating (interferon [IFN]-stimulated gene 15 [ISG15]-removing) enzymes on host cell substrates . Importantly, the ToV-PLP recombinant protein derived from this novel enterovirus also showed potent deubiquitination and deISGylation activities and demonstrated the ability to repress IFN-β expression. Using reverse genetics, we have generated a recombinant ToV-PLP knockout virus. Compared to the wild-type virus, the ToV-PLP knockout mutant virus showed impaired growth and induced higher expression levels of innate immune system genes in infected cells. These results suggest that ToV-PLP functions as an antagonist of the innate immune system; Enterovirus G can therefore gain fitness by acquiring ToV-PLP from a recombination event.
authors: Shang, P.;Misra, S.;Hause, B.;Fang, Y.

title: Molecular epidemiological survey of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in northwest China from 2007 to 2010
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) is an economically important swine disease affecting swine worldwide. Northwest China has a sparse pig population and comprehensive information on PRRSV infection is not currently available. In this study, we analyzed the epidemiological characteristics and genetic diversity of PRRSV from this region. 322 field-isolated tissue or serum samples were collected from aborted pig fetuses or pigs with respiratory disease from 15 herds twice over a 2-year period. PRRSV infection was determined and virus strains were classified by GP5 sequencing. We found that 35.9% of the animals were PRRSV positive and the mean prevalence in 2007-2008 and 2009-2010 was 46.5 and 29.3%, respectively. To further investigate the genetic divergence of PRRSV samples collected from 2007 to 2010, 32 strains were isolated for GP5 sequencing and analysis, and phylogenetic trees were constructed based on GP5 amino acid sequences. All PRRSVs were of the North American genotype and belonged to the highly pathogenic HP PRRSV subgenotype. Isolates from Xinjiang Province formed a densely clustered branch and were closely related to an evolutionary intermediate subgroup isolate. Virus sequences from 2007 to 2008 were compared to those from 2009 to 2010 from the same flock. New mutations were found in isolates after 2009 and focused on nucleotides in the GP5 antibody decoy epitope. PRRSV strains in Northwest China from 2007 to 2010 were similar to those from other regions of China, with some regional characteristics. These results add to the knowledge of PRRSV epidemiology in China. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Shang, Y.;Wang, G.;Tian, H.;Yin, S.;Du, P.;Wu, J.;Chen, Y.;Yang, S.;Jin, Y.;Zhang, K.;Liu, X.

title: Origin of the H9N2 bird flu in Bangladesh
abstract: The H9N2 avian influenza subtype is endemic to many bird species in Asia and the Middle East and has contributed to the emergence of H5N1, H7N9 and H10N8, which pose potential pandemic threats. H9N2 viruses that have spread to Bangladesh acquired several gene segments from highly pathogenic (HP) H7N3 viruses thought to reside in Pakistan and currently cocirculating with HP H5N1. However, the source and geographic origin of these H9N2 viruses are not clear. We characterized the complete genetic sequences of 37 Bangladeshi H9N2 viruses isolated between 2011 and 2013 and examined their inter- and intra-subtypical genetic differences by tracing their genesis in relation to other H9N2 viruses isolated from neighboring countries. H9N2 viruses in Bangladesh are homogeneous with multiple mammalian host-specific markers and represent a novel H9N2 sublineage in which the hemagglutinin (HA) gene from an Iranian H9N2 lineage (Mideast-B Iran), the neuraminidase (NA) and Polymerase Basic 2 (PB2) genes are derived from Dubai H9N2 (Mideast-C Dubai), and the genes for nonstructural protein (NS), nucleoprotein (NP), matrix protein (MP), acidic polymerase (PA), and basic polymerase 1 (PB1) are from HP H7N3 originating in Pakistan. Different H9N2 genotypes were detected in Bangladesh, which were replaced by other reassortants in 2006 and 2009. Phylogenetic and molecular analyzes indicate that the current genotype derives from the prototypical H9N2 (G1) lineage that circulated in poultry in China in the late 1990s and entered Bangladesh via the Middle East poultry trade, and that this genotype subsequently coexisted with H7N3 was rearranged and H9N2 lines spread from Pakistan and across India. Therefore, continuous monitoring of Bangladeshi HP H5N1, H7N3 and H9N2 is warranted to identify further evolution and adaptation to humans.
authors: Shanmuganatham, K.;Feeroz, M. M.;Jones-Engel, L.;Walker, D.;Alam, S. M. R.;Hasan, M. K.;McKenzie, P.;Krauss, S.;Webby, R. J.;Webster, R. G.

title: Nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the fusion (F) epitope for Egyptian small ruminant plague virus (PPRV) to predict unique criteria reported as Egypt 2009
abstract: The Peste des Petit Ruminants virus was isolated and serologically identified as early as 2006 in suspected PPR outbreaks in sheep and goats in the province of Qalyubia, Egypt. In this study, six of these PPRV isolates were confirmed by reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) primer set for the fusion protein (F) epitope, then cDNA was sent to the Institute of Animal Health Pirbright, England for the To analyze nucleotide sequences of this F protein gene and the phylogenetic analysis properties by comparing it with other reference isolates recorded worldwide. A 322 nucleotide long cDNA fragment of the fusion protein gene was obtained as the gene sequence. The isolates presented unique phylogenetic analyzes previously unidentified internationally and defined as Egypt 2009. by using the obtained sequences generated from this gene-encoding protein; Egyptian PPRVs have been grouped phylogenetically and belong to lineage IV. To the author's knowledge, this is the first report describing the fusion protein (F) gene sequence, phylogenetic analysis, and lineage typing of Egyptian PPRV isolates. © 2011 Academic Journals Inc.
authors: Sharawi, S. S. A.;Abd-El-Rahim, I. H. A.

title: Molecular epidemiology and full genome characterization of the H1N1pdm virus from India
abstract: Background: The influenza A virus is one of the most important uncontrolled pathogens in the world, causing both seasonal epidemics and global pandemics. This was evidenced by the recent emergence and continued spread of the H1N1 influenza A virus of porcine origin in 2009, which triggered the first real pandemic in the last 40 years. During its evolution, the virus acquired many mutations, and several unidentified molecular determinants are likely responsible for the 2009 H1N1 virus' ability to cause increased disease severity in humans. The availability of limited full-genome data hampers continuous monitoring of these types of events. Outbreaks with significant morbidity and mortality have been reported from all parts of the country. Methods/Results: Considering a large number of clinical cases of infection, a complete genome-based sequence characterization of Indian H1N1pdm virus and its phylogenetic analysis in relation to globally circulating viruses was performed to reveal the phylodynamic pattern of H1N1pdm virus in India from 2009-2011. Clade VII has been observed as an important circulating clade in phylogenetic analysis. Selection pressure analysis revealed 18 positively selected sites in the major surface proteins of the H1N1pdm virus. Conclusions: This study has clearly demonstrated that clade VII has been identified as a recently circulating clade both in India and worldwide. Few well-identified markers specific for clade VII were positively selected during virus evolution. Continuous surveillance of the H1N1pdm virus is in place to follow virus evolution and further transmission. This study will serve as baseline data for future monitoring and also for the development of suitable therapeutics. © 2013 Sharma et al.
authors: Sharma, S.;Joshi, G.;Dash, P. K.;Thomas, M.;Athmaram, T. N.;Kumar, J. S.;Desai, A.;Vasanthapuram, R.;Patro, I. K.;Rao, P. V. L.;Parida, M.

title: Epidemiology of contagious pustular dermatitis in small ruminants from Punjab
abstract: Contagious pustular dermatitis (Orf) is caused by the Orf virus, which belongs to the genus Parapoxvirvs of the family Poxviridae. It is a non-systemic eruptive skin disease of sheep and goats that is transmissible to humans. The present work describes the epidemiology of contagious pustular dermatitis in small Punjab ruminants and the molecular diagnosis of the disease by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
authors: Sharma, S.;Mahajan, V.;Hosamani, M.;Singh, R. K.;Kallesh, D. J.;Kumar, H.;Verma, S.;Sandhu, K. S.

title: Response to the wing web challenge of Rous sarcoma virus subgroups in some chicken breeds
