abstract: Response to Wing Web Challenge (WWC) of Rous sarcoma virus (RSV) subsets was evaluated in 4-8 week old chicks of a light breed, a heavy breed, and a cross between a native black-feathered bantam and an australorp breed examined. Wing web tumor (WWT) began to develop within a week in response to infection with virus subgroups A (BS-RSV) and C [RSV (RAV-49)]. Chicks challenged with subgroup D virus [RSV (RAV-50)] took at least 4 weeks to develop WWT. The positive response to WWC by subgroups A, C and D viruses was 84%, 100% and 52%, respectively. The duration of occurrence of a positive reaction was maximal for subgroup A virus, followed by subgroup D and minimal for subgroup C virus.
authors: Sharma, S. N.

title: Comparative metagenomics of microbial traits within oceanic virus communities
abstract: Viral genomes often contain genes recently acquired from microbes. In some cases (e.g. psbA) the proteins encoded by these genes have been shown to be important for viral replication. In this study, using a unique search strategy for the Global Ocean Survey (GOS) metagenomes in combination with datasets based on pyrosequencing of marine viromes and microbiomes, we characterize previously undiscovered microbial metabolic abilities hidden in the genomes of uncultured marine virus communities. A total of 34 microbial gene families were identified on 452 viral GOS scaffolds. The majority of the metabolic helper genes found on these scaffolds have never been described in phage. Host genes detected in viruses have been mainly subdivided into genes encoding different energy pathways such as: B. electron transport and newly identified genes of the photosystem, or translation and post-translation mechanisms. Our results suggest previously undiscovered pathways by which marine phages adapt to their hosts and improve their fitness, including translational and posttranslational level control over the host rather than the already known transcriptional level control. The ISME Journal (2011) 5, 1178-1190; doi:10.1038/ismej.2011.2; published online on February 10, 2011 Subject category: integrated genomic and post-genomic approaches in microbial ecology
authors: Sharon, I.;Battchikova, N.;Aro, E. M.;Giglione, C.;Meinnel, T.;Glaser, F.;Pinter, R. Y.;Breitbart, M.;Rohwer, F.;Beja, O.

title: High prevalence and diversity of bovine astroviruses in the faeces of healthy and diarrhea calves in south-west Scotland
abstract: Astroviruses (AstV) are positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses and are a major cause of infant diarrhea worldwide. Diarrhea is a common and important cause of morbidity and mortality in calves; Therefore, we investigated whether the presence of AstV is associated with calf diarrhea. We identified distinct AstV lineages from faecal samples from both healthy and diarrhea calves and healthy adult cattle in south-west Scotland. AstV was common in calves (present in 74% (85/115) of samples) but uncommon in adult cattle (present in 15% (3/20) of samples). No association was found between the presence of AstV and calf diarrhea or the presence of a specific AstV lineage and calf diarrhea. AstV was strongly associated with the presence of group A rotavirus (RVA), and a protective effect of age was evident for both AstV and RVA. Coinfections with multiple AstV lines were detected in several calves, and serial infections with different viruses could also be detected by longitudinal sampling of individuals. In summary, our study found genotypically diverse AstV in the faeces of calves in south-west Scotland. However, no association was found between AstV and calf diarrhea, suggesting that the virus does not play a primary role in the etiology of calf diarrhea in the studied group. (C) 2015 The Authors. Published by Elsevier BV
authors: Sharp, C. P.;Gregory, W. F.;Mason, C.;Bronsvoort, B. M. D.;Beard, P. M.

title: The rapidly fermentable substance modulates the interactions between rumen commensals and toll-like receptors to promote immune tolerance of the goat rumen
abstract: Whether dietary non-fibrous carbohydrate (NFC), a rapidly fermentable substance, affects rumen immune homeostasis by modulating the interactions of rumen microbiota and epithelial toll-like receptors (TLRs) remains unclear. A combination of 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing and quantitative PCRs was applied to investigate the synergistic responses of rumen microbiota and epithelial TLRs to the 15-31% dietary NFC switch in the goat model. The results showed that the 31 percent NFC diet caused the radical increase in the richness and diversity of the rumen microbiota. The phylum Verrucomicrobia was most significantly expanded, while opportunistic pathogens, namely Rikenella, Anaeroplasma and Olsenella, were significantly reduced. In the ruminal epithelium, the markedly increased expressions of TLR1,6,10 were associated with the markedly decreased expressions of the pro-inflammatory cytokines interleukin-1beta (IL-1β), IL-6 and anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. The limited correlation analysis showed that the increased abundance of commensal bacteria in Verrucomicrobia subdivision 5 contributed to the upregulation of TLR10 expression. Finally, the significantly increased levels of rumen short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) associated with the significantly upregulated expression of epithelial genes related to SCFA absorption were observed in goats fed the 31% NFC diet. Thus, NFC-induced expansion of the rumen microbiota promoted epithelial tolerance by enhancing the intensity of TLR10 signaling. The newly established equilibrium promotes the transport of rumen energy substances into the blood.
authors: Shen, H.;Lu, Z.;Chen, Z.;Wu, Y.;Shen, Z.

title: Influenza A(H5N6) Virus Reassortant, Southern China, 2014
authors: Shen, H.;Wu, B.;Chen, Y.;Bi, Y.;Xie, Q.

title: Pathogenicity and genetic characterization of a duck tembusu virus associated with egg shedding in Muscovy ducks
abstract: Duck tembusu virus (DTMUV) has spread to the main duck breeding region in China, causing an acute decline in egg production in the Chinese duck population. In this study, we characterized a DTMUV strain (named GD2014) isolated from an egg-producing sniper duck farm in Guangdong Province, southern China. The virus was pathogenic to Muscovy duck embryos and caused a sharp decline in egg production in laying Muscovy ducks. The genome sequence of GD2014 shared 97-99% homologies with other Tembusuviruses derived from aquatic birds and 89% identities with the MM1775 strain isolated from mosquitoes. Phylogenetic analysis of the entire open reading frame (ORF), E gene and NS5 gene showed that GD2014 belonged to the Ntaya clade. These results have implications for understanding the origin, development and pathogenicity of DTMUV and for developing vaccines and diagnostics based on epidemiological data.
authors: Shen, H. Q.;Lin, W. C.;Wang, Z. X.;Zhang, K.;Yan, Z. Q.;Zhou, Q. F.;Qin, J. P.;Xie, Q. M.;Bi, Y. Z.;Chen, F.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin gene of chicken H9N2 influenza virus in southern China from 2012 to 2013
abstract: As part of our ongoing influenza surveillance program in southern China, 19 field strains of H9N2 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) were isolated from dead or diseased chicken flocks in Guangdong Province, southern China, between 2012 and 2013. Hemagglutinin (HA) genes from these strains were sequenced and analyzed, and phylogenetic analysis showed that 12 of the 19 isolates belonged to lineage h9.4.2.5, while the other seven belonged to h9.4.2.6. In particular, we found that all viruses isolated in 2013 belonged to the h9.4.2.5 lineage. Line h9.4.2.5 viruses contained a PSRSSR®-GLF motif at the HA cleavage site, while line h9.4.2.6 viruses contained a PARSSR®-GLF at the same position. Most isolates in lineage h9.4.2.5 lost a potential glycosylation site at residues 200-202 and had an additional one at residues 295-297 in HA1. Notably, 19 isolates had an amino acid change (Q226L) in the receptor binding site, indicating that the viruses had potential affinity for binding to human-like receptors. The present study demonstrates the importance of continuous monitoring of new H9N2 strains to better prepare for the next epidemic or pandemic outbreak of H9N2-AIV infection in chicken flocks.
authors: Shen, H. Q.;Yan, Z. Q.;Zeng, F. G.;Liao, C. T.;Zhou, Q. F.;Qin, J. P.;Xie, Q. M.;Bi, Y. Z.;Chen, F.

title: Genomic and evolutionary characterization of a novel porcine influenza C-like virus
abstract: We recently described the isolation of a novel influenza virus distantly related to human influenza C virus from swine with respiratory disease in the United States. Based on genetic, biochemical and morphological analyses, the virus has been tentatively classified as C/swine/Oklahoma/1334/2011 (C/OK). To better understand the genetics and evolution of this novel pathogen, we performed a comprehensive analysis of its sequence and phylogeny. Results showed that C/OK and human influenza C viruses share a conserved set of predicted functional domains in the replication of the viral RNA genome and viral entry machinery, but differ at important functional sites. Furthermore, our evolutionary analysis showed that homologous genes of C/OK and human influenza C viruses diverged from each other estimated several hundred to several thousand years ago. Taken together, the results described in this study support and extend our previous observations that C/OK is a genetically and evolutionarily distinct influenza virus in the Orthomyxoviridae family. © 2013 Springer Verlag Vienna.
authors: Sheng, Z.;Ran, Z.;Wang, D.;Hoppe, A. D.;Simonson, R.;Chakravarty, S.;Hause, B. M.;Li, F.

title: A metagenomic study of viral abundance and diversity in mosquitoes from Hubei Province
abstract: Mosquitoes, as one of the most common but important vectors, have the potential to transmit or acquire many viruses through bites, however, the viral flora in mosquitoes and their impact on the transmission of mosquito-borne diseases have not been well studied and evaluated. In this study, the metagenomic technique was successfully used to analyze the abundance and diversity of the viral community in three mosquito samples from Hubei, China. Among the 92,304 reads generated by a run on the 454 GS FLX System, 39% have high similarities to viral sequences associated with identified bacterial, fungal, animal, plant, and insect viruses, and 0, 02% were assigned to unidentified viral sequences, showing high abundance and diversity of viruses in mosquitoes. In addition, two new viruses in the Densovirinae subfamily and the Dicistroviridae family have been identified, and six torque tenosus viruses1 in the Anelloviridae family, three porcine parvoviruses in the Parvovirinae subfamily, and one Culex tritaeniorhynchus rhabdovirus in the Rhabdoviridae family have been preliminarily characterized. Viral metagenomic analysis provided us with a deep insight into the viral mosquito population, which played an important role in viral initiative or passive transmission and evolution during the process.
authors: Shi, C.;Liu, Y.;Hu, X.;Xiong, J.;Zhang, B.;Yuan, Z.

title: Genomic characterization and pathogenicity of a porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus strain isolated in China
abstract: Porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (PHEV) is a member of the genus Betacoronavirus within the family Coronaviridae that invades the central nervous system (CNS) via the peripheral nervous system and causes encephalomyelitis, or vomiting and wasting (VWD) in suckling piglets. Although only a few complete nucleotide sequences of PHEV have been reported so far, they are not annotated. This study aimed to elucidate the genomic characterization, phylogeny and pathogenicity of the PHEV/2008 strain. The total length of the genome of strain PHEV/2008 was 30,684 bp with a G+C content of 37.27%. The genome contained at least 11 predicted open reading frames (ORFs) flanked by 5″ and 3″ untranslated regions (UTRs) of 211 and 289 nucleotides. The replicase polyproteins pp1a and pp1ab, which were 4382 and 7094 amino acid residues, respectively, were predicted to be cleaved into 16 subunits by two viral proteinases. Phylogenetic analysis based on full genome sequence revealed that strain PHEV/2008 was genetically distinct from other known PHEV types representing a novel genotype (GI-1). In addition, we found that PHEV/2008 was neurotrophic and highly pathogenic in 4-week-old BALB/c mice. Taken together, this is the first detailed annotated full genome sequence of a new genotype PHEV strain in China.
authors: Shi, J.;Zhao, K.;Lu, H.;Li, Z.;Lv, X.;Lan, Y.;Guan, J.;He, W.;Gao, F.

title: Molecular Epidemiology of PRRSV: A Phylogenetic Perspective
abstract: Since it was first detected two decades ago, Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) has been the subject of intense research due to its tremendous impact on the global swine industry. Thanks to the phylogenetic analyses, much has been learned about the genetic diversity and evolutionary history of the virus. In this review, we focused on the evolutionary and epidemiological aspects of PRRSV from a phylogenetic perspective. We first described the diversity and transmission dynamics of type 1 and type 2 PRRSV, respectively. Then we focused on the older evolutionary history of PRRSV: the time of appearance of all existing PRRSV and an origin hypothesis were discussed. Finally, we summarized the results of previous recombination studies to assess the potential impact of recombination on viral epidemiology. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Shi, M.;Lam, T. T. Y.;Hon, C. C.;Hui, R. K. H.;Faaberg, K. S.;Wennblom, T.;Murtaugh, M. P.;Stadejek, T.;Leung, F. C. C.

title: Origin and molecular characterization of the human-infecting H6N1 influenza virus in Taiwan
abstract: In June 2013, the first human influenza H6N1 infection was confirmed in Taiwan. However, the origin and molecular characterization of this virus, A/Taiwan/2/2013 (H6N1), has not been well studied. In the present report we have performed phylogenetic and coalescence analyzes of this virus and compared its molecular profile/properties to other closely related strains. Molecular characterization of H6N1 revealed that it is a typical avian influenza virus with low pathogenicity that may not replicate and spread well in the mammalian upper respiratory tract. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the virus with A/chicken/Taiwan/A2837/2013 (H6N1) accumulates in seven genes other than PB1. For the PB1 gene, A/Taiwan/2/2013 was clustered with a different H6N1 lineage than A/chicken/Taiwan/A2837/2013. Although a previous study indicated that the PB2, PA, and M genes of A/Taiwan/2/2013 could have originated from the H5N2 viruses, coalescence analyzes indicated that these H5N2 viruses originated from newer strains than the ancestor of A /Taiwan/2/2013. Therefore, we propose that A/Taiwan/2/2013 is a reassortant from different H6N1 lines circulating in chickens in Taiwan. Furthermore, compared to avian isolates, a single P186L substitution (H3 numbering) in hemagglutinin H6 of the human isolate could increase the mammalian receptor binding and thus the pathogenicity of this strain in humans. Overall, human infection with this virus appears to be a random event and an influenza pandemic is unlikely to occur. However, its co-circulation and potential reassortment with other influenza subtypes still deserve attention. © 2013 Hochschulverlag and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Shi, W.;Shi, Y.;Wu, Y.;Liu, D.;Gao, G. F.

title: Repeated detection of H7N9 avian influenza virus in raw poultry meat illegally shipped to Japan by international airline passengers
abstract: H7N9 high and low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIV and LPAIV, respectively) have been isolated from duck meat products illegally brought into Japan by airline passengers in their hand luggage. These H7N9 virus isolates were phylogenetically closely related to those prevalent in China. Antigenic analysis revealed that the hemagglutinin of the H7N9-HPAIV isolate differed slightly from that of the H7N9-LPAIV and older H7 strains. These AIV-contaminated meat products, which are repeatedly imported into Japan, result in increased risks to poultry and public health. Continuous border disease control based on detection and culling of infected poultry and meat products is therefore essential to prevent the introduction and spread of AIV.
authors: Shibata, A.;Okamatsu, M.;Sumiyoshi, R.;Matsuno, K.;Wang, Z. J.;Kida, H.;Osaka, H.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Use of S1 nuclease in deep sequencing to detect double-stranded RNA viruses
abstract: The metagenomic approach with next-generation DNA sequencing has facilitated the detection of many pathogenic viruses from stool samples. In many cases, however, most of the detected sequences originate from the host genome and the bacterial flora in the gut. To improve the efficiency of detecting double-stranded (ds) RNA viruses from samples, we evaluated the applicability of S1 nuclease to deep sequencing here. Treatment of total RNA with S1 nuclease resulted in 1.5- to 28.4- and 10.1- to 208.9-fold increases in group A rotavirus sequence reads in fecal and viral culture samples, respectively. In addition, increasing coverage of assignment to reference sequences allowed sufficient genotyping using analysis software. These results suggest that library construction using S1 nuclease is useful for deep sequencing in the detection of dsRNA viruses.
authors: Shimada, S.;Nagai, M.;Moriyama, H.;Fukuhara, T.;Koyama, S.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Shirai, J.;Mizutani, T.

title: Genetic and phylogenetic characterization of rabies virus isolates from wild and farm animals in Paraiba, Brazil
abstract: Thirty-four rabies virus (RV) isolates from foxes (8), insectivorous bats (9), cattle (14), sheep (1), a goat (1), and a donkey (1) from Paraiba state in northeastern Brazil were genetically characterized . Sequences of 890 nts of nucleoprotein (N) genes from these isolates were analyzed and compared to those of other previously characterized Brazilian isolates. Phylogenetic analysis identified three RV genetic lineages coexisting in this region. Each lineage has been found to be associated with a specific host species and circulate independently. The first lineage was found in foxes (Dusicyon sp.) and could be distinguished from native carnivore isolates from Sao Paulo, Goias and Minas Gerais in southern and central Brazil. The second lineage was associated with insectivorous bats (Molossus spp.) and differed from RV isolates associated with vampire bats. The third lineage was found in livestock and clustered with vampire bat-associated RV isolates from Sao Paulo, Tocantins, Goias, and Matto Grosso. These results indicate that RV of these genetic lineages co-circulate in Paraiba state and that livestock in this region are infected with vampire bat-associated RV, suggesting that vampire bat is the main reservoir of livestock rabies in this region.
authors: Shoji, Y.;Kobayashi, Y.;Sato, G.;Gomes, A. A. B.;Itou, T.;Ito, F. H.;Sakai, T.

title: Evidence for interspecies transmission and resorting of influenza A virus in swine in southern China
abstract: The Asia/57, Hong Kong/68 and Russia/77 pandemics of this century occurred or reappeared in China. Interspecies transmission and genetic rearrangement of influenza viruses have been implicated in the origin of these human pandemic influenza viruses. It has been suggested that pigs are the 'mixing vessel' in which the rearrangement takes place. To investigate this possibility, 104 swine influenza viruses randomly collected from southern China between 1976 and 1982, including 32 H3N2 isolates and 72 H1N1 isolates, were examined using dot blot hybridization, partial sequencing, and phylogenetic analysis. There were 29 of 32 H3N2 isolates that were traits of originally human viruses; the other 3 isolates were reassortants containing genes from swine and human influenza viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of polymerase B1 (PB1) genes showed that pigs in southern China have undergone multiple human-pig interspecies transmission. All 72 H1N1 isolates were of porcine origin, characteristic of the classic swine H1N1 influenza virus. Analysis of 624 swine flu genes from southern China found no evidence of avian flu genes. This is in contrast to what is currently found in Europe, where the majority of swine flu virus isolates are of avian origin.
authors: Shu, L. L.;Lin, Y. P.;Wright, S. M.;Shortridge, K. F.;Webster, R. G.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of swine hepatitis e virus isolates from Yunnan Province, China in 2011-2012
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E is a disease of major public health concern, mainly in developing countries. Although molecular and seroepidemiological studies of HEV have been conducted in many provinces in China, the epidemiological data from Yunnan province are limited and the genotypes are not fully characterized. This study evaluated the prevalence and characteristics of hepatitis E virus (HEV) detected in pigs from Yunnan Province, China. Results: A total of 13 of 187 pig fecal samples collected in 2011 showed HEV positive results; Likewise, 7 out of 69 samples collected in 2012 showed positive results. These findings indicated an overall prevalence of 7.8% (20/256). The results of the phylogenetic and molecular evolution analysis showed that nine strains were found in the samples obtained in 2011, in which 87.1% to 99.4% of the nucleotide sequence identity was shared between these strains; and 77.0% to 81.9%, 52.2% to 53.6%, 77.0% to 88.2%, and 77.9% to 96.8% nucleotide sequence identities were shared with strains expressing genotypes 1 , 2, 3 and 4 represented. Five strains were detected in the samples obtained in 2012, in which 94.2% to 99.3% nucleotide sequence identity was shared between the strains and 81.0% to 82.5%, 81.8% to 83.2%, 81.0% to 92.7% and 81.0% to 97.8% nucleotide sequence identities were shared with strains representing genotypes 1, 2, 3 and 4. Conclusions: Analysis of fourteen recognized HEV strains revealed that three of them were subtype 4d, two subtype 4b; the nine remaining strains isolated were subtype 4h. These results indicated that the prevalence of HEV in the Yunnan pig herds was quite high, additional public health concerns should focus on the safety of pork.
authors: Shu, X.;Duan, X.;Song, C.;Li, J.;Jiang, L.;Yin, G.;Li, W.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of West Nile virus associated with multifocal retinitis in patients from southern India
abstract: Background: In late 2009/early 2010, a mysterious virus outbreak in a southern district of Tamil Nadu affected around 2000 people; This particularly affected those who lived in coastal areas. Blood samples from affected patients were sent for clinical analysis to determine the actual cause of the disease, but reports were inconclusive. Methods: The present study describes the clinical observations and laboratory investigations using molecular methods, which were carried out on 170 of the 2000 suspected clinical cases. These were patients admitted to Aravind Eye Hospital, Madurai, Tamil Nadu with ocular complications. Conventional reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), real-time RT-PCR, and reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal gene amplification assays (RT-LAMP) were used to detect West Nile virus (WNV) infection . A further study of the genetic diversity of WNV involved in ocular complications was performed by sequence phylogeny. Results: Of 170 specimens, 25 (15%) were positive for chikungunya IgM antibody, 10 (6%) for chikungunya antigen and 30 (18%) were positive for dengue IgM antibody. The remaining 105 seronegative samples were processed for WNV detection by IgM capture ELISA and molecular methods. Of the 105 samples, 35 (33%) were positive for WNV IgM antibodies, 15 (14%) were positive for WNV by RT-PCR, and 27 (26%) were positive for WNV by both real-time RT-PCR and RT -LAMP assays. Comparative analysis with acute-phase patient serum samples revealed 100% agreement between the real-time RT-PCR and RT-LAMP assays. Overall, these assays had higher sensitivity than conventional RT-PCR because they detected 12 additional samples with a low copy number of template. Further genotyping by sequence phylogeny revealed that all WNV isolates were clustered in lineage I. Conclusions: The association of West Nile virus with ocular infection in southern India during a mysterious fever epidemic in the first half of 2010 was unequivocally established by molecular envelope gene-specific real-time RT-PCR and RT-LAMP assays followed by nucleotide sequencing . © 2011 International Society for Infectious Diseases.
authors: Shukla, J.;Saxena, D.;Rathinam, S.;Lalitha, P.;Joseph, C. R.;Sharma, S.;Soni, M.;Rao, P. V. L.;Parida, M.

title: Complete genomic sequence analysis of swine genotype 3 hepatitis E virus isolated from Shanghai
abstract: The complete genomic nucleotide sequence of a previously identified genotype 3 hepatitis E virus (HEV), strain SAAS-JDY5, was obtained using RT-PCR and rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE). The genome consisted of 7225 nucleotides, without a poly-A tail at the 3-terminus, and contained three open reading frames (ORFs), ORF-1, ORF-2, and ORF-3, encoding 1702, 660, and 113 amino acids, respectively The phylogenetic analysis confirmed that SAAS-JDY5 belonged to HEV genotype 3 and was most closely related to the Japanese isolate wbJYG1 (AB222184). SAAS-JDY5 shared approximately 87% nucleotide similarity to human and porcine strains from the United States compared to 74-75% similarity to Asian (genotype 4) and Mexican (genotype 2) strains. The comparison of the genomic SAAS-JDY5 sequence with reference sequences of the same genotype revealed a nucleotide substitution and a deletion at positions 5145 and 7189 (3'' UTR). Furthermore, SAAS-JDY5 contained two extra nucleotides (AC) at the very end of the 3' terminus before the poly A tail of the genome. A comparison of the putative amino acid sequence encoded by the SAAS-JDY5 genome with sequences from other genotype 3 isolates revealed 15 unique amino acid substitutions and one deletion in ORF-1 and three substitutions in ORF-2. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Si, F. s;Zhu, Y. m;Dong, S. j;Yu, S. s;Yu, R. s;Shen, S. y;Yang, Q.;Li, Z.

title: Evolution of a bovine cytoplasmic tripartite motif protein (TRIM) that limits retroviral infection
abstract: Primate tripartite motif 5α (TRIM5α) proteins confer innate intracellular resistance to retroviruses. In humans, TRIM5 is in a paralogous cluster that includes TRIM6, TRIM34, and TRIM22. Although TRIM6 and TRIM34 orthologues are found in other mammals, TRIM5 has only been identified in primates to date. Cow cells show early blocks to infection by multiple retroviruses. We identify a cytoplasmic TRIM protein encoded by LOC505265 that is responsible for limiting infection by several lentiviruses and N-tropic murine leukemia virus in bovine cells. The susceptibility of N-tropic murine leukemia virus to 505265-mediated restriction is primarily determined by residue 110 of the viral capsid protein. Phylogenetically, cow LOC505265 segregates with the TRIM5/TRIM6/TRIM34 group but is not an ortholog of known TRIM genes. The B30.2/SPRY domain of 505265 has long variable regions, a feature of the proteins encoded by this paralogous group, and shows evidence of positive selection. Apparently, cows independently evolved a retroviral restriction factor from the same TRIM family that gave birth to TRIMS in primates. Certain features of this subset of cytoplasmic TRIM proteins may promote convergent evolution of virus limiting factors. © 2006 by the US National Academy of Sciences.
authors: Si, Z.;Vandegraaff, N.;O'Huigin, C.;Song, B.;Yuan, W.;Xu, C.;Perron, M.;Li, X.;Marasco, W. A.;Engelman, A.;Dean, M.;Sodroski, J.

title: Herpesvirus Strigis, a new avian herpesvirus. II. Biochemical and biophysical properties
abstract: virus, Herpesvirus Strigis (HSIS), derived from dead owls has been successfully cultured in chick embryo fibroblasts. Its replication was inhibited by IUDR. Tissue cultured virus was found to be sensitive to ether, chloroform, 0.5% trypsin and to pH 4.0 or below. Infectivity was rapidly destroyed at 56°C. Negatively stained naked virions with an average diameter of 100 nm and enveloped virions with a size of 160-250 nm were seen. The capsid consisted of hollow cylindrical capsomeres arranged in equilateral triangles with 5 capsomeres on each edge. Cubic symmetry and icosahedral structure resulted in a total of 162 capsomeres. All this biochemical and biophysical data led to the classification of the HSIS virus in the herpesvirus genus. Biological properties described in a previous publication supported such a grouping and indicated that the agent was a novel avian herpesvirus for which the name herpesvirus strigis was proposed.
authors: Sibalin, M.;Gerstl, F.;Pichler, L.;Buerki, F.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated during the 2006-2008 outbreaks in Pakistan reveal genetic diversity
abstract: Background: Since the first outbreak recorded in early 2006 in northern areas of Pakistan, highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses have been isolated from commercial poultry and wild/domestic birds from various areas of Pakistan up to July 2008. Various isolates of H5N1 have been sequenced to study the genetic diversity of these viruses. Results: Phylogenetic analysis revealed close clustering and highest sequence identity in all 8 genes to HPAI H5N1 isolates belonging to the uniform H5 clade 2.2, sublineage EMA-3, recovered from Afghanistan in the same period. Two subgroups within the Pakistani domestic and wild bird H5N1 viruses have been observed based on their sequence homology and mutations. HPAI motif, preferential receptor specificity for α-(2,3)-binding, potential N-linked glycosylation sites, and an additional glycosylation site at the globular head of the HA protein from four Pakistani H5N1 isolates. While the amino acids associated with susceptibility to various antiviral drugs (oseltamivir, zanamivir, amantadine) were found conserved in the Pakistani H5N1 isolates. Strikingly, some important mutations were observed at critical positions of antigenic sites (S141P, D155S, R162I & P181S) and at the receptor binding pocket (A185T, R189K & S217P) of HA-1. A high sequence similarity between the Pakistani viruses HP H5N1 and LP H9N2 was also observed. Avian-like host-specific markers with the exception of E627K in PB2, K356R in PA, V33I in NP, I28V in M2, and L107F in NS2 proteins were also observed. Conclusions: Different point mutations in different genes of H5 viruses from Pakistan were observed during field spread. The outbreaks started in 2006 in Khyber Pakhtoon Khawa province (Northwest) and spread to southern regions over time. Although migratory birds may play a role in the continued endemicity of 2.2 H5N1 virus in Pakistan in 2006-2008, the possibility of their transmission through legal or illegal poultry trade across borders cannot be ignored. © 2012 Siddique et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Siddique, N.;Naeem, K.;Abbas, M. A.;Ahmed, Z.;Malik, S. A.

title: Isolation and sequence analysis of reassortant low pathogenic avian influenza virus H4N6 from ducks and chickens in live bird markets from Pakistan
abstract: Live bird (LBM) markets may serve as a major source of AIV infection. During routine avian influenza surveillance in Pakistan, the low pathogenic avian influenza virus of subtype H4N6 was first isolated from Khaki Campbell's duck (Anal platyrhynchos) in 2010 and from broilers in 2011 at the live bird markets (LBMs) of the port city of Karachi in Sindh province . Whole genome sequencing revealed the introduction of a new reassortant Eurasian avian virus strain. Phylogenetically, HA, NA, M, NP, and PB2 genes clustered primarily with Russian strains of influenza viruses, and the PA gene with AI isolates from the Netherlands, while NS and PB1 genes with a Pakistani isolate of H3N1 were grouped. Sequence analysis revealed an LP amino acid motif (PEKASR), avian-like receptors, conservation of amino acids at the receptor binding sites and the amino acids known to be associated with antiviral drug susceptibility, loss of the glycosylation site in the NA gene and attainment of unique PDZ domain motif (ESEI) at the C-terminus of the NS gene. Seroconversion to the H4N6 subtype was mainly observed in the bird populations of Sindh and Khyber Pakhtoon Khawa provinces. The isolation revealed the role of LBM, where interbreeding of different bird species provides an excellent environment for the spread and potential rearrangement of AIV. Furthermore, various point mutations in these H4N6 isolates and the close relationship to Pakistani H3N1 and other Eurasian strains also reflect the prevailing diversity among the AIVs circulating in the local LBMs. (C)2016 PVJ. All rights reserved
authors: Siddique, N.;Naeem, K.;Ahmed, Z.;Abbas, M. A.;Ali, A.;Rafique, S.;Rashid, F.;Begum, I.;Farooq, R.

title: Characterization and classification of viral particles associated with hepatitis A. II. Nature and configuration of the nucleic acid
abstract: Virus particles that bound at 1.34 g/ml in CsCl and sedimented in sucrose gradients at 160 S were isolated from stool samples from patients suffering from hepatitis. In the presence of 4M urea and approximately 90% formamide, these particles released linear nucleic acid molecules with the kinked appearance characteristic of single-stranded RNA or single-stranded DNA. They could be distinguished from the lambda phage nucleic acid added to the preparation as a marker for the double-stranded configuration. Experiments in which the virus particles to be examined were incubated at pH 12.9 and 50 degrees C for 30 min showed that their nucleic acid molecules were hydrolyzed just as easily as the RNA genome of the poliovirus type 2 analyzed in parallel. Both the single-stranded DNA of the phage However, both phiX174 and parvovirus LuIII were found to be unaffected by this treatment, and the double-stranded DNA of phage lambda was denatured to single-stranded molecules. From this it was concluded that the human hepatitis A virus contains a linear genome of single-stranded RNA and must be assigned to the picornaviruses.
authors: Siegl, G.;Frosner, G. G.

title: Disorders of virome in urine in kidney transplants
authors: Sigdel, T. K.;Mercer, N.;Nandoe, S.;Nicora, C. D.

title: Distinguishing human Wa-like rotavirus versus porcine rotavirus genotype 1 genes and proteins
abstract: Group A rotaviruses (RVAs) are 11-segmented, double-stranded RNA viruses and important causes of gastroenteritis in young animals of many animal species. Previous studies have suggested that human Wa-like RVAs share a close evolutionary relationship with porcine RVAs. In particular, the genes VP1-VP3 and NSP2-5/6 of these viruses are usually classified as genotype 1 with >. 81% nucleotide sequence identity. However, it remains unknown whether the genotype 1 genes and proteins of human Wa-like strains are distinguishable from those of porcine strains. To investigate this, we performed extensive bioinformatic analyzes using all known genotype 1 gene sequences. The RVAs analyzed represent wild-type strains isolated from humans or pigs in various geographic locations in 2004-2013, including 11 newly sequenced porcine RVAs from Brazil. We also analyzed archival strains isolated in 1977-1992 and atypical strains involved in human-pig transmission. We found that, in general, the genotype 1 genes of typical modern human Wa-like RVAs were clustered together in phylogenetic trees and separate from those of typical modern porcine RVAs. The only exception was the NSP5/6 gene, which showed no host-specific phylogenetic clustering. Using amino acid sequence alignments, we identified 34 positions that differentiated the VP1-VP3, NSP2, and NSP3 genotype 1 proteins of typical modern human Wa-like RVAs from typical modern porcine RVAs and documented how these positions translate into vary with the archived/unusual isolates. No host specific amino acid positions have been identified for NSP4, NSP5 or NSP6. Overall, the results of this study support the notion that human Wa-like RVAs and porcine RVAs are evolutionarily related, but indicate that some of their genotype 1 genes and proteins have diverged over time, possibly as a reflection of one sequestered replication and protein co-adaptation in their respective hosts.
authors: Silva, F. D. F.;Gregori, F.;McDonald, S. M.

title: To follow the molecular epidemiology of Brazilian infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) isolates.
abstract: Infectious bursal disease is a highly contagious disease of young chickens caused by infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV). Genomic segment A encodes the capsid protein (VP2), while segment B encodes the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (VP1). In the present study, we trace the molecular epidemiology of IBDV in Brazil by analyzing 29 isolates collected from the main poultry production regions. To characterize the isolates genetically, phylogenetic and population dynamic analyzes were performed using 68 VP1 (2634nt) and 102 VP2 (1356nt) coding sequences of IBDV isolates from different regions of the world. In addition, the evolution of IBDV was analyzed by characterizing the selective forces at work during diversification of viral isolates. We show that IBDV isolates were introduced to Brazil mainly from the Netherlands and the USA. These introductions have been associated with all Brazilian poultry production regions analyzed in this work. Furthermore, we show that the evolution of IBDV was shaped by a combination of very low recombination rates and relatively high nucleotide substitution rates (2.988 × 10-4 for VP1 and 3.2937 × 10-4 for VP2), which are themselves a function of the purifying Selection that acts on VP1 and VP2. Furthermore, our expanded Bayesian skyline plot suggests that the increase in the effective population size of isolates of IBDV is consistent with their epidemiological history, with a large increase during the onset of acute outbreaks of IBD in the 1980s. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Silva, F. M. F.;Vidigal, P. M. P.;Myrrha, L. W.;Fietto, J. L. R.;Silva, A.;Almeida, M. R.

title: Bat coronavirus in Brazil associated with Appalachian crest and swine epidemic diarrheal viruses
authors: Simas, P. V. M.;A.C, D. E. Souza BarnabÃ©;DurÃ£es-Carvalho, R.;De Lima Neto, D. F.;Caserta, L. C.;Artacho, L.;Jacomassa, F. A. F.;Martini, M. C.;Dos Santos, M. M. A. B.;Felippe, P. A. N.;Ferreira, H. L.;Arns, C. W.

title: Current and Future Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance in Animals: Review of Principles and Practices
abstract: There is a broad consensus internationally that monitoring the level of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) emerging in different systems underpins strategies to address the problem. The main reasons for resistance surveillance are to determine (i) the magnitude of the problem, (ii) whether resistance is increasing, (iii) whether previously unknown types of resistance are emerging, (iv) whether a particular type of resistance is spreading, and (v) whether a particular type of resistance is associated with a particular outbreak. The implications of collecting and using this information must be considered when designing a monitoring system. Antimicrobial resistance surveillance provides a basis for assessing the burden of antimicrobial resistance and providing the evidence needed to develop efficient and effective control and prevention strategies. The joint development of AMR surveillance programs in humans and animals is essential, but several key elements remain that complicate data comparisons between AMR surveillance programs and between regions. Currently, AMR monitoring relies on straightforward in vitro antimicrobial susceptibility methods. However, the lack of harmonization between the programs and the limitation of the genetic information of AMR remain the main disadvantages of these phenotypic methods. The future of AMR monitoring is moving towards genotypic detection and molecular analysis methods are expected to provide a wealth of information. However, the expectation that these molecular techniques will outperform phenotypic susceptibility testing in the routine diagnosis and monitoring of AMR remains a distant reality, and phenotypic testing remains necessary to detect emerging resistant bacteria, emerging resistance mechanisms, and trends in AMR.
authors: Simjee, S.;McDermott, P.;Trott, D. J.;Chuanchuen, R.

title: Psittacine herpesvirus infection resembling Pacheco parrot disease
abstract: Herpesvirus was detected by electron microscopy in hepatocytes of parrots that died in a Florida aviary. The virus was identified in hepatocytes from chick embryos and budgerigars injected with liver suspensions from naturally infected parrots. Infected hepatocytes had prominent intranuclear inclusions containing naked nucleocapsids. Both naked and enveloped virions were seen in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes, and enveloped nucleocapsids were occasionally seen in the perinuclear cisternae and extracellularly. The experimental and spontaneous disease mimicked a condition in parrots previously described by Pacheco. The viral agent was classified as a herpesvirus based on the character of the intranuclear inclusions, the size and conformation of the agent as determined by electron microscopy and filtration, and the sensitivity of the agent to ether.
authors: Simpson, C. F.;Hanley, J. E.;Gaskin, J. M.

title: Genetic characterization of orf virus associated with a severe orf outbreak in goats at a farm in Lusaka, Zambia (2015)
abstract: Orf, or contagious ecthyma, is a neglected and economically important zoonosis caused by a dermatotropic parapoxvirus that commonly affects small domestic ruminants. Although orf has a global distribution, there is little information about the disease in many African countries. Here, a suspected severe orf outbreak in goats on a farm in Lusaka was investigated. Orf virus (ORFV) infection was confirmed by PCR amplification of viral DNA (RNA polymerase, B2L and virus interferon resistance genes) in clinical specimens. Some detected genes were sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically. This is the first report on the molecular characterization of ORFV in goats in Zambia.
authors: Simulundu, E.;Mtine, N.;Kapalamula, T. F.;Kajihara, M.;Qiu, Y.;Ngoma, J.;Zulu, V.;Kwenda, G.;Chisanga, C.;Phiri, I. K.;Takada, A.;Mweene, A. S.

title: Potential for cross-species transmission of torque tenovirus in pigs
authors: Singh, G.;Ramamoorthy, S.

title: Identification of the microRNA repertoire in TLR-ligand challenged bubaline PBMCs as a model for bacterial and viral infections
abstract: In the present study, we used high-throughput sequencing, miRNA-seq, to discover and examine the expression profiles of known and novel miRNAs in TLR ligand-stimulated versus unstimulated (i.e., control) peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) derived from the blood of healthy Murrah buffalo were isolated. Six small RNA (sRNA) libraries were multiplexed in the Ion Torrent PI chip and sequenced on the Ion Proton System. The reads obtained were matched to the Bos taurus genome (UMD3.1 assembly), which is phylogenetically closest to the buffalo (Bubalus bubalis). A total of 160 bovine miRNAs were biocomputationally identified in buffalo PBMCs and 130 putative novel miRNAs (not entered in the bovine mirBase) were identified. All of these 290 miRNAs identified in the six treatment and control samples represent the repertoire of novel miRNAs for the buffalo species. The expression profiles of these miRNAs across samples were represented by sample dendrograms and heat map plots. The clearly expressed miRNAs in each treatment and control group were identified. Some miRNAs were expressed at very high levels, while most of them were moderately expressed. The miRNAs bta-miR-103 and -191 were found to be very abundant and expressed in all samples. Other abundantly expressed miRNAs include bta-miR-19b, -29b, -15a, -19a, -30d, -30b-5p and let family members (let 7a-5p, let 7g and let 7f) in LPS and CpG - treated PBMCS and bta-miR-191, -103 & -19b in poly I:C-stimulated PBMCs. Only one novel miRNA (bta-miR-11039) out of 130 identified putative novel miRNAs was expressed in all six samples, and differentially expressed (>2-fold) miRNAs were identified. Six of the differentially expressed miRNAs across groups (bta-miR-421, bta-let-7i, bta-miR-138, bta-miR-21-5p, bta-miR-222, and bta-miR-27b) were subsequently examined and confirmed by TaqMan quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR). In addition, the target genes of differentially expressed miRNAs were enriched for roles in innate immunity and TLR signaling pathways. This first study on the profiling and cataloging of bubalin miRNAs expressed in TLR ligand-stimulated PBMCs will provide an important reference point for future studies on the regulatory role of miRNAs in the buffalo immune system.
authors: Singh, J.;Mukhopadhyay, C. S.;Kaur, S.;Malhotra, P.;Sethi, R. S.;Choudhary, R. K.

title: Taxonomic and gene-centric metagenomics of the faecal microbiome of low and high feed conversion ratio (FCR) broilers.
abstract: Individual weight gain among broiler farmers appears to vary, which may be due in part to variations in their gut microbiota. In this article, we analyze the faecal microbiota of low and high feed conversion ratio (FCR) broilers. After shotgun sequencing of the faecal microbiome, we used the SEED database to identify microbial diversity and metabolic potential in low and high FCR birds. Domain-level breakdown of our samples included bacteria (>95%), eukaryotes (>2%), archaea (>0.2%), and viruses (>0.2%). At the strain level, Proteobacteria (78.83% at low and 52.04% at high FCR), Firmicutes (11.97% at low and 27.53% at high FCR) and Bacteroidetes (7.10% at low FCR and 17 .53% at high FCR). fecal microbial community. Poultry dropping metagenomes revealed the sequences related to 33 genera in both low and high FCR with significantly different proportions. Functional analysis revealed that genes for carbohydrate, amino acid and derivative metabolism, and protein metabolism were the most abundant in both samples in the SEED subsystem. Genes associated with stress, virulence, cell wall and cell capsule were also abundant. Indeed, genes associated with sulfur assimilation, flagellum and flagellar motility were over-represented in low FCR birds. This information could aid in the development of strategies to improve feed efficiency and feed formulation for broilers. © 2013 Institute of Plant Genetics, Polish Academy of Sciences, Poznań.
authors: Singh, K. M.;Shah, T. M.;Reddy, B.;Deshpande, S.;Rank, D. N.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Complete sequence analyzes of enterovirus 71 strains from fatal and non-fatal cases of hand, foot and mouth disease outbreak in Singapore (2000)
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) is an important etiologic agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). In recent years, several outbreaks in East Asia have been associated with neurological complications and numerous fatalities. An outbreak in Singapore in October 2000 affected thousands of children, resulting in four fatal cases, three of which isolated EV71. The genomes of two representative EV71 strains, isolated from one fatality and one surviving patient, were completely sequenced and their nucleotide and amino acid sequences compared to known EV71 strains. The two outbreak strains were assigned to genogroup B along with strains previously isolated in Singapore, Malaysia and Japan. Comparative sequence analysis of the two Singapore strains revealed 99% nucleotide similarity, while their deduced amino acid sequences were almost identical except for residue 1506 in the nonstructural region of 3A. Given that the outbreak affected closely related genetic variants of EV71, the wide range of disease severity can be attributed to critical factors such as different viral vaccine doses or different post-infection host immune responses, but is less likely due to the occurrence of EV71 attributed strains with increased virulence.
authors: Singh, S.;Poh, C. L.;Chow, V. T. K.

title: Complex virome in feces of Native American children in remote Amazonian villages
abstract: The number of viruses circulating in small isolated human populations can be reduced by viral extinctions and infrequent introductions. Here we used viral metagenomics to characterize eukaryotic virome in feces of healthy children from a large urban center and from three Native American villages with minimal outside contact. Numerous human enteric viruses, mainly from the families Picornaviridae and Caliciviridae, were sequenced from each of the sites. Several children from the same villages shed closely related viruses, indicating common clusters of transmission. The faeces of isolated villagers also contained multiple viral genomes of unknown cellular origin from the order Picornavirals and the CRESS DNA group, as well as higher levels of nematode and protozoan DNA. Therefore, despite cultural and geographic isolation, human enteric virus diversity was not reduced in these Amazonian villages. Frequent viral introductions and/or an increased susceptibility to enteric infections may account for complex fecal virus among Native American children in remote villages.
authors: Siqueira, J. D.;Dominguez-Bello, M. G.;Contreras, M.;Lander, O.;Caballero-Arias, H.;Deng, X. T.;Noya-Alarcon, O.;Delwart, E.

title: ENDEMIC INFECTION OF BEACHED SOUTH SEA OTTER (ENHYDRA LUTRIS NEREIS) WITH NEW PARVOVIRUS, POLYOMAVIRUS AND ADENOVIRUS
abstract: Over the past century, the southern sea otter (SSO; Enhydra lutris nereis) population has slowly recovered from extinction due to overfishing. The SSO is a threatened subspecies under federal law and a fully protected species under California law, USA. Through an interagency collaborative program, stranded animals are rehabilitated and released, while deceased animals are autopsied and tissues are cryopreserved to facilitate scientific study. Here we processed archival tissues to enrich for particle-associated viral nucleic acids, which we randomly amplified and deeply sequenced to identify viral genomes through sequence similarities. Anelloviruses and endogenous retroviral sequences accounted for over 50% of the observed viral sequences. Polyomavirus, parvovirus, and adenovirus sequences accounted for most of the remaining reads. We have characterized and phylogenetically analyzed the complete genome of sea otter polyomavirus 1 and the complete coding sequence of sea otter parvovirus 1 and found that the closest known viruses infect primates and domestic pigs (Sus scrofa domesticus), respectively. We tested archival tissue from 69 stranded SSO autopsied by PCR over 14 years (2000-13). Polyomavirus, parvovirus, and adenovirus infections were detected in 51, 61, and 29% of the animals examined, respectively, with no significant increase in frequency over time, indicating endemic infection. We found that 80% of the SSO tested were infected with at least one of the three DNA viruses whose tissue distribution we determined in 261 tissue samples. Parvovirus DNA was most commonly detected in the mesenteric lymph node, polyomavirus DNA in the spleen, and adenovirus DNA in multiple tissues (spleen, retropharyngeal and mesenteric lymph nodes, lung, and liver). This study describes the virome in tissues of an endangered species and shows that stranded SSO are often infected with multiple viruses, warranting future research to investigate associations between these infections and observed lesions.
authors: Siqueira, J. D.;Ng, T. F.;Miller, M.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Dodd, E.;Batac, F.;Delwart, E.

title: To evaluate the pathogenic potential of aquatic bird-derived influenza A virus in chickens
abstract: Intravenous pathogenicity index tests (IVPI) on 29 wild duck type A influenza viruses, two turkey type A influenza viruses and one chicken type A influenza virus gave indices ranging from 0.0 to 0.49. Most of the wild duck viruses and the two turkey viruses had indices of 0.0, indicating that they are non-pathogenic. Six of the duck-derived viruses had indices ranging from 0.25 to 0.49 and the IVPI for A/Chicken/Alabama/75 (H4N8) was 0.49, indicating that they had low pathogenic potential. An IVPI of 1.25 to a maximum of 3.0 is necessary for a type A influenza virus to be classified as highly pathogenic. Gross lesions observed in chickens that died after intravenous virus exposure included renal swelling with more pronounced lobular patterns, but visceral urate deposits were absent. The usefulness of the IVPI test in assessing the pathogenicity potential of non-pathogenic and low-pathogenic strains of avian influenza virus may be limited.
authors: Slemons, R. D.;Condobery, P. K.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Dangers of disease transmission from marine mammals to terrestrial mammals: review and current results
abstract: In a 5-year study (1972-1977) of microbial pathogens isolated from both clinically normal and diseased marine mammals, it was shown that certain pathogens are widespread in a variety of marine populations and that some also affect a number of Mammalian species are transmissible to terrestrial dwellers. Leptospira interrogans serovar pomona was repeatedly isolated from 2 species of pinnipeds (Zalophus californianus califonianus and Callorhinus ursinus). Some of the more important bacterial pathogens for terrestrial mammals isolated from wild marine mammals are Pseudomonas mallei, Clostridium chauvoei, C novyi, Neisseria mucosa var. heidelbergensis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Salmonella spp and Pasteurella multocida. Numerous virus serotypes classified as caliciviruses have been isolated from a variety of marine mammals. Some of these are known to infect multiple land mammal species including pigs, horses and primates. For this reason, precautions should be taken to ensure that pathogens shed by captive marine mammals are not transmitted to susceptible land mammals, including keepers and other humans.
authors: Smith, A. W.;Vedros, N. A.;Akers, T. G.;Gilmartin, W. G.

title: Genetic variability and the classification of hepatitis E virus
abstract: The classification of hepatitis E virus (HEV) variants is currently in transition, with no agreed definitions for genotypes and subtypes, or for deeper taxonomic groupings into species and genera, which might include recently characterized viruses assigned to the family Hepeviridae and birds, bats, rodents, and fish. These conflicts arise because of differences in the viruses and genomic regions being compared and in the methodology used. We reexamined published sequences and found that synonymous substitutions saturated in comparisons between and within virus genotypes. Analysis of full genome sequences or concatenated ORF1/ORF2 amino acid sequences showed that HEV variants most closely related to those infecting humans can be consistently divided into six genotypes (types 1 to 4 and two additional genotypes from wild boar). Variants isolated from rabbits closely related to genotype 3 occupy an intermediate position. No uniform criteria for the assignment of virus subtypes could be defined. Analysis of the amino acid sequences of these viruses with the more divergent variants from chickens, bats and rodents in three conserved subgenomic regions (residues 1 to 452 or 974 to 1534 of ORF1 or residues 105 to 458 of ORF2) provided consistent support for a division into 4 groups corresponding to HEV variants infecting humans and pigs, those infecting rats and ferrets, those from bats, and those from chickens. This approach could form the basis for a future genetic classification of HEV into four species, with the more divergent HEV-like virus from fish (Cutthroat Trout Virus) being a second genus. © 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Smith, D. B.;Purdy, M. A.;Simmonds, P.

title: Classification and genomic diversity of enterally transmitted hepatitis viruses
abstract: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) and hepatitis E virus (HEV) are major human pathogens and are responsible for a significant proportion of cases of severe acute hepatitis worldwide. Both viruses are genetically heterogeneous and are divided into several genotypes that differ in their geographical distribution and risk group affiliation. However, there is little evidence that variants of HAV or HEV differ antigenically or in their propensity to cause severe disease. Genetically more divergent but mainly hepatotropic variants of both HAV and HEV have been found in several mammalian species, with those of HAV being classified into eight species within the genus Hepatovirus in the virus family Picornaviridae. HEV is classified as a member of the species Orthohepevirus A in the virus family Hepeviridae, a species that also contains viruses that infect pigs, rabbits, and a variety of other mammalian species. Other species (Orthohepevirus B-D) infect a wide range of other mammalian species, including rodents and bats.
authors: Smith, D. B.;Simmonds, P.

title: Proposed consensus for classification of the family Hepeviridae
abstract: The Hepeviridae family consists of positive-strand RNA viruses that infect a wide variety of mammalian species as well as chicken and trout. A subset of these viruses infects humans and can cause self-limiting acute hepatitis, which can become chronic in immunocompromised individuals. Current published descriptions of the taxonomic subdivisions within the family Hepeviridae are inconsistent in terms of species and genotype assignments. By analyzing existing sequence information, we propose a taxonomic scheme in which the family is divided into the genera Orthohepevirus (all isolates of mammalian and avian hepatitis E virus (HEV)) and Piscihepevirus (necktrout virus). Species within the Orthohepevirus genus are classified as Orthohepevirus A (human, pig, wild boar, deer, mongoose, rabbit, and camel isolates), Orthohepevirus B (chicken isolates), Orthohepevirus C (rat, marsupial, Asiatic musk shrew, ferret, and mink) and orthohepevirus D (isolates from bats). Suggestions are also made for naming genotypes within the human and rat HEVs. This hierarchical system is consistent with hepevirus phylogeny, and the three levels of classification (genus, species, and genotype) are consistent with and reflect discontinuities in the regions of pairwise spacing between amino acid sequences. Adoption of this system would involve the avoidance of hostnames in taxonomic identifiers and provide a logical framework for assigning new variants.
authors: Smith, D. B.;Simmonds, P.;Jameel, S.;Emerson, S. U.;Harrison, T. J.;Meng, X. J.;Okamoto, H.;Van der Poel, W. H. M.;Purdy, M. A.

title: Updates to nomenclature due to the development of avian influenza virus A(H5) clades 2.1.3.2a, 2.2.1 and 2.3.4 in 2013-2014
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The A/goose/Guangdong/1/96-like hemagglutinin (HA) genes of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A(H5) viruses have rapidly evolved since the WHO recently updated the H5 clade nomenclature further developed /OIE/FAO H5N1 Evolution Working Group. New clades that transcend established boundaries need to be identified and accounted for accordingly. METHOD: Hemagglutinin sequences deposited in publicly accessible databases as of December 31, 2014 were analyzed by phylogenetic and average pairwise distance methods to identify new clades deserving of nomenclature changes. RESULTS: Three new clade designations were recommended based on the split of clade 2.1.3.2a (Indonesia), 2.2.1 (Egypt) and 2.3.4 (widespread recognition in Asia, Europe and North America) representing the emerging HPAI virus includes subtypes H5N2, H5N3, H5N5, H5N6 and H5N8. CONCLUSION: Continued global surveillance for HPAI A(H5) viruses in all host species and timely reporting of sequence data will be critical to rapidly identify new clades and assess their potential impact on human and animal health.
authors: Smith, G. J.;Donis, R. O.;World Health Organization/World Organisation for Animal, H. F.;Agriculture Organization, H. E. W. G.

title: Dating the emergence of pandemic influenza viruses
abstract: Pandemic influenza viruses cause significant mortality in humans. In the 20th century, three influenza viruses caused major pandemics: the 1918 H1N1 virus, the 1957 H2N2 virus, and the 1968 H3N2 virus animal source, resulting in antigenic shift. Despite global concerns about a new pandemic influenza, the pathway of pandemic strains remains unknown. Here we estimated the evolutionary history and inferred date of introduction into humans of each of the genes for all 20th-century pandemic influenza strains. Our results indicate that genetic components of the 1918 H1N1 pandemic virus were circulating in mammalian hosts, ie, pigs and humans, as early as 1911 and were unlikely to be a recently introduced avian virus. Phylogenetic relationships indicate that the A/Brevig Mission/1/1918 virus (BM/1918) was generated by reassortment between mammalian viruses and a previously circulating human strain, either porcine or possibly human. Furthermore, seasonal and classic H1N1 swine viruses were not directly derived from BM/1918, but their progenitors circulated together during the pandemic. Mean estimates of the time of the most recent common ancestor also suggest that the H2N2 and H3N2 pandemic strains may have been generated by rearrangement events in unknown mammalian hosts and involved multiple avian viruses prior to the detection of the pandemic. The potential generation of pandemic strains by a series of mammalian reassortment events over a period of years prior to pandemic detection suggests that appropriate surveillance strategies to detect precursor viruses can abort future pandemics.
authors: Smith, G. J. D.;Bahl, J.;Vijaykrishna, D.;Zhang, J.;Poon, L. L. M.;Chen, H.;Webster, R. G.;Peiris, J. S. M.;Guan, Y.

title: Bats and their virus: An important source of emerging viruses that can infect humans
abstract: Bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of zoonotic viruses from various families including SARS coronavirus, Nipah virus, Hendra virus and Ebola virus. Several recent studies have hypothesized that bats, an ancient group of flying mammals, are the main reservoir of several important RNA virus families from which other mammalian viruses of livestock and humans have been derived. Although this hypothesis needs further investigation, the premise that bats transmit a large number of viruses is generally accepted. The question of whether bats have unique biological characteristics that make them ideal reservoir hosts has been the subject of several recent reviews. In this review, we focus on the public health impact of bat outbreaks, examine the drivers and risk factors of past disease outbreaks, and outline research directions for better control of future disease events.
authors: Smith, I.;Wang, L. F.

title: Identification and isolation of a novel herpesvirus in a captive mob of eastern gray kangaroos (Macropus giganteus)
abstract: novel herpesvirus was detected in a captive mob of eastern gray kangaroos (Macropus giganteus) during diagnostic work-up of individuals with ulcerative cloacitis. Virus was initially detected in tissues using consensus herpesvirus PCR. No viral inclusions or particles were evident in routine histological or transmission electron microscopy sections of cloacal lesions. Virus was isolated from specimens and transmission electron microscopy of the resulting isolates confirmed that the virus was morphologically consistent with a herpesvirus. Nucleotide sequencing of the PCR product from tissue samples and from the isolates revealed that the virus belonged to the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily and was distinct from other known herpesviruses. The correlation between the lesions and the novel virus remains unknown. Two herpesviruses, both in the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, have been previously described in macropods and are known to cause systemic clinical disease. This is the first reported gammaherpesvirus within the order Marsupialia and can provide valuable information on the evolution and phylogeny of this virus family. Based on the current nomenclature convention for herpesviruses, the authors propose to name the novel herpesvirus macropodid herpesvirus 3 (MaHV-3).
authors: Smith, J. A.;Wellehan, J. F., Jr.;Pogranichniy, R. M.;Childress, A. L.;Landolfi, J. A.;Terio, K. A.

title: Reassembly and analysis of an ancient variola virus genome
abstract: We report a significant improvement in the assembly of published short-read sequencing data from an ancient variola virus (VARV) genome by removing contig-capping sequencing tags and manually searching for cross-gap reads. The new arrangement, together with camelpox and taterapox genomes, allowed new data to be calculated for the last common ancestor of all VARV genomes. Analysis of recently sequenced VARV-like vaccinia virus genomes showed that single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and amino acid changes in the vaccinia virus (VACV) cop-O1L ortholog predicted to be associated with VARV host specificity and virulence introduced the lineage before the divergence of these viruses. A comparison of ancient and modern VARV genome sequences also revealed a measurable drift towards adenine + thymine (A + T) richness.
authors: Smithson, C.;Imbery, J.;Upton, C.

title: Novel gyroviruses, including chicken anemia virus, in clinical and chicken specimens from South Africa
authors: Smuts, H. E. M.

title: An overview of the strain diversity and pathogenesis of the chicken astrovirus
abstract: Although a relatively new virus, only identified as a distinct species of avian astrovirus in 2004, chicken astrovirus (CAstV) has been associated with poor growth of broiler flocks, enteritis and diarrhea and is a candidate for the causative agent of runting-stunting syndrome. More recently, CAstV has been implicated as the sole etiologic agent in cases of two other broiler diseases, namely severe renal disease in young broilers with visceral gout and white chick brood disease. Examination of the CAstV strains associated with the latter two diseases shows that they are genetically closely related. This review discusses the pathogenesis of CAstV in terms of strain diversity and the effects of vertical versus horizontal transmission, viral load, co-infections and the age of the bird at infection, all factors that affect disease severity can affect.
authors: Smyth, V. J.

title: Sequence analysis of foot-and-mouth disease virus type O/IRN/2007 VP1 gene from Iranian isolate
abstract: Foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus causes a vesicular and contagious disease in even-toed ungulates. In this study, the virus was isolated from vesicles of infected cattle using cell culture and serotyped using an ELISA test. The extracted RNA from the infected cells was reverse transcribed and amplified by one-step RT-PCR using VP1 gene-specific primer pairs. The purified VP1 gene was subcloned into the unique KpnI and BamHI cloning sites of the pcDNA3.1+ vector. The DH5α strain of E. coli was transformed by the vector. The sequences of the subcloned FMDV type O/IRN/2007 VP1 were aligned to FMDV type O/UKG/2001 VP1 using MegAlign software. Nucleotide sequence comparisons were performed using BLAST software, available from the NCBI website. The amino acid sequences of three subcloned FMDV types O/IRN/2007 VP1 were also aligned to three other similar sequences using the MegAlign software. Nineteen of the most similar VP1 nucleotide sequences (through the BLASTN program), the FMDV-O/IRN/2007 VP1 sequence, twenty isolates of FMDV-O-VP1 in Iran and eight topotypes of FMDV type O were aligned by Mega5, to generate an FMDV-O-VP1 -based sequence similarity tree. The nucleotide sequence comparison showed that FMDV O/IRN/2007 VP1 had the greatest nucleotide sequence similarity to the VP1 gene of FMDV O1/Manisa/Turkey/69 (99%), FMDV O1/Manisa/Netherlands (98%) and FMDV O1/Manisa /iso87/Turkey (98%). It was also observed that the highest identity between the FMDV-O/IRN/2007 VP1 sequence and other nucleotide sequences of FMDV type O VP1 genes isolated between 1997 and 2004 in Iran was about 91% . © 2006 -2013 Folia Biologica.
authors: Soleimanjahi, H.;Sedeh, F. M.;Jalilian, A. R.;Mahravani, H.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of neuraminidase genes from H9N2 avian influenza viruses isolated from commercial broilers in Iran (2008 and 2009)
abstract: total of 512 tissue samples collected from 30 farms in different states of Iran in 2008-2009 as part of a surveillance program for avian influenza virus infection (AIVs) in the Iranian poultry population. To determine the genetic relatedness of Iranian viruses, neuraminidase (NA) genes from ten isolates of H9N2 viruses isolated from commercial chickens in Iran between 2008 and 2009 were amplified and sequenced. The neuraminidase gene of the viruses was >90% similar to that of subline A/Quail/Hong Kong/G1/97 (H9N2). The neuraminidase stalk regions in these viruses had no deletion compared to those of the chicken/Beijing/1/94 subline (Beijing-like viruses) and the two human isolates A/HK/1073/99, A/HK/1074/99. Phylogenetic analysis of the neuraminidase (NA) gene showed that it shared a common ancestral A/Quail/Hong Kong/G1/97 isolate that contributed the internal genes of the H5N1 virus. The results of this study showed that no (Beijing-like) virus and no (Korea-like) virus were found in chickens in Iran, and that the NA genes of H9N2 influenza viruses circulating in Iran in recent years are well preserved and the earlier Iranian isolates can be considered as representative of such a progenitor. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media BV
authors: Soltanialvar, M.;Shoushtari, H.;Bozorgmehrifard, M.;Charkhkar, S.;Akbarnejad, F.

title: Molecular characterization of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of H9N2 avian influenza viruses isolated from commercial broilers in Iran
abstract: total of 512 tissue samples were collected from 30 farms in different states of Iran between 2008 and 2009 as part of a program to monitor AIV infection in the Iranian poultry population. Avian influenza virus was isolated from poultry farms with a history of respiratory disease and increased mortality. Nucleotide sequence analysis of five representative isolates confirmed that all isolates possessed one type of amino acid motif (RSSR/GL) at the HA cleavage site. Deduced amino acid sequences indicated the presence of L226 (234 in H9 numbering) in all five Iranian isolates, indicating a preference for binding of α(2-6) sialic acid receptors. The surface glycoprotein genes of the viruses were >90% similar to those of the A/Quail/Hong Kong/Gl/97 (H9N2) lineage. The neuraminidase stalk regions in these viruses had no deletion compared to the A/Dk/HK/Y280/97 lineage (Ck/Bei-like viruses) and the 2 human isolates A/HK/1073/99, A/HK/ 1074/99. The neuraminidase hemadsorption site had up to 3 amino acid substitutions and differs from those of previous Iranian viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA and NA genes showed that they share a common ancestral Qa/HK/Gl/97 isolate that contributed internal genes of the H5N1 virus. © 2010 Asian Network for Scientific Information.
authors: Soltanialvar, M.;Shoushtari, H.;Bozorgmehrifard, M.;Charkhkar, S.;Eshratabadi, F.

title: Molecular epidemiology of the pseudorabies virus in Yunnan and the sequence analysis of its gD gene
abstract: Pseudorabies (PRs) outbreaks have occurred in Yunnan, China, causing significant economic losses. To determine the prevalence and origin of PR in Yunnan, particularly in vaccinated pigs, a total of 791 samples of blood, tissue, semen and sera were analyzed by serological methods, PCR and gD gene sequence analysis. Detection with viral gI antibody or PCR showed that the annual positive rates of PR virus (PRV) in Yunnan from 2010 to 2014 were 48.15, 21.26, 2.17, 5.22 and 0.35%, respectively with an average of 15.43%. In general, the incidence decreased over the period 2010-2014, probably due to the use of PRV eradication strategies. Based on the complete sequence of the gD gene, a phylogenetic tree was constructed, clustering all phyla into two independent clades, i.e. Asian and European-American clades. The virus isolates from Henan, Tianjin, Heilongjiang, Sichuan, Shandong, Fujian, Xinjiang, Hubei, Guangdong and Yunnan fell into the Asian group that harbored South Korea isolate. Four isolates of Yunnan virus along with South Korea's Namyangju fell into the European-American group. PR was shown to be a pandemic as there has been no clear indication of the geographic origin of PRV isolates in China since 2010.
authors: Song, C.;Gao, L.;Bai, W.;Zha, X.;Yin, G.;Shu, X.

title: Detection and classification of infectious bronchitis viruses isolated in Korea by dot immunoblotting assay using monoclonal antibodies
abstract: Dot immunoblotting assay (DIA) using five monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) against infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) was used to detect and classify the viruses propagated in embryonated chicken eggs. Using a group-specific MAb 3F5, 10 reference strains and 12 Korean isolates of IBV were successfully detected by DIA, and the lowest viral titer of IBV detected by DIA was approximately less than 103.8 mean embryo infective dose/ml. To evaluate the diagnostic efficiency, DIA was compared to the conventional diagnostic method of infectious bronchitis (IB). IBV antigens in allantoic fluid from embryonated eggs inoculated with field samples suspected of having IBV were specifically detected by DIA within only one or two egg passages, whereas the traditional embryonated egg inoculation method required four to seven egg passages to confirm IBV infection . These results indicated that DIA could significantly reduce the time and cost of diagnosing IB. To examine the possibility of classifying IBV by DIA, four strain-specific MAbs, 3A4, 2A3, 6F7 and 2C6 were used. According to the MAb response patterns to the IBV antigens, the 10 IBV reference strains were divided into six groups; seven tribes belonged to three different groups, and the other three tribes each belonged to an individual group. In the case of 12 Korean isolates of IBV, they were divided into six groups. Among the six groups, the MAb response patterns of three groups matched those of the IBV reference strains, but the others did not. These data suggest that there are at least three variants of IBV serotypes in Korea.
authors: Song, C. S.;Kim, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.;Kim, S. J.;Izumiya, Y.;Tohya, Y.;Jang, H. K.;Mikami, T.

title: Epidemiological classification of infectious bronchitis virus isolated in Korea between 1986 and 1997
abstract: Forty Korean isolates and four reference strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were classified by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis. Each Korean isolate was isolated from different types of commercial chicken flocks between 1986 and 1997. RFLP patterns of an amplified DNA fragment (1722 bp) containing the IBV S1 gene digested by the restriction enzyme HaeIII showed that the 40 Korean isolates were classified into five genotypes, I to V. Six of them belonged to the genotype I, which had the same HaeIII and XcmI cleavage pattern as the Massachusetts type (H120 and M41), but the other four genotypes had a different HaeIII cleavage pattern than the four reference IBV strains used in this study. Genotype III appeared to be the predominant type since 29 of the 40 isolates belonged to this type, which has been consistently found in chicken flocks since 1990. On the other hand, genotypes II, IV, and V were only found in the field in 1986, 1995, and 1995, respectively. Five isolates selected from each of the five genotypes were inoculated into 1-day-old specific pathogen-free chicks to assess their pathogenicity. Genotype III induced 50% mortality and severe renal urine deposition on the kidneys, but the other four genotypes showed respiratory distress only 1-2 days after inoculation. The live H120 vaccine protected chicks from challenge with isolates selected from genotype I but not genotypes IV through V. A live KM91p120 strain selected from major genotype III protected chicks from challenge with isolates from genotype III, in addition to other genotypes, including two recent isolates of genotypes IV and V.
authors: Song, C. S.;Lee, Y. J.;Kim, J. H.;Sung, H. W.;Lee, C. W.;Izumiya, Y.;Miyazawa, T.;Jang, H. K.;Mikami, T.

title: Profiling novel microRNAs evoked by EV71 and CA16 infection in human bronchial epithelial cells using high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) are two major causes associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide. Although they both belong to the Enterovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family, there are many differences in the infection process of these viruses. However, the underlying mechanisms have not been elucidated. Several studies have shown that microRNAs (miRNAs) can play a crucial role in host-pathogen interaction. Our previous study reported that EV71 and CA16 infection results in differential expression of miRNAs in human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE). Here we aimed to further investigate the expression profile and possible roles of other differentially expressed miRNAs in 16HBE cells after EV71 and CA16 infections using high-throughput sequencing. We describe 44 new differentially expressed miRNAs in all samples. Among these miRNAs, 7 new differentially expressed miRNAs show an opposite expression trend during the progression of EV71 and CA16 infections. Bioinformatic analysis, including the Gene Oncology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) databases, were then used to identify the biological processes, molecular functions, cellular components, and signaling pathways involved. The top 10 GO and Pathway annotations showed that 849 target genes are involved in cell development such as: B. in the development of the nervous system, the development of multicellular organisms and developmental biology. Finally, the genes identified in both GO and pathway analysis were used to construct a co-expression network to further identify the potential function of these co-expressed genes. Therefore, our data may be helpful to guide further studies on the molecular mechanism of developmental regulation in EV71- and CA16-mediated HFMD pathogenesis. In addition, it provided new candidate biomarkers or therapeutic targets for HFMD.
authors: Song, J.;Hu, Y.;Jiang, X.;Zhu, W.;Wu, Z.;Dong, S.

title: miR-1303 regulates BBB permeability and promotes CNS lesions after CA16 infection by directly targeting MMP9
abstract: Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) belongs to the Picornaviridae family and causes mild and self-limiting hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in infants and young children. CA16 infection can also lead to central nervous system (CNS) complications; However, the underlying mechanism by which CA16 crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and then causes CNS damage remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the mechanism of CA16 neurotropic tropism by establishing an in vitro BBB model of CA16 infection and an in vivo infant CA16 rhesus monkey infection model.
