Results showed that CA16 infection induced increased BBB permeability accompanied by upregulation of matrix metalloproteinase 9 (MMP9) expression. Subsequently, high-throughput miRNA sequencing technology and bioinformatic analysis revealed that miR-1303 can regulate BBB permeability by targeting MMP9. Next, we used dual luciferase, qRT-PCR, and Western blot assays to provide evidence of MMP9 targeting by miR-1303. Further experiments showed that CA16 infection promoted the breakdown of junction complexes (Claudin4, Claudin5, VE-cadherin and ZO-1), likely by down-regulating miR-1303 and up-regulating MMP9. Finally, EGFP-CA16 infection could enter the CNS by facilitating the breakdown of junction complexes, eventually leading to neuroinflammation and damage to the CNS, which was confirmed using the in vivo rhesus monkey model. Our results suggest that CA16 could penetrate the BBB and then invade the CNS by downregulating miR-1303, which disrupts junction complexes by directly regulating MMP9 and ultimately causing CNS pathological changes. These results provide new therapeutic targets in HFMD patients after CA16 infection.
authors: Song, J.;Hu, Y.;Li, H.;Huang, X.;Zheng, H.;Hu, Y.;Wang, J.;Jiang, X.;Li, J.;Yang, Z.;Fan, H.;Guo, L.;Shi, H.;He, Z.;Yang, F.;Wang, X.;Dong, S.;Li, Q.;Liu, L.

title: Different microRNA profiles demonstrate the different outcomes induced by EV71 and CA16 infection in human umbilical vein endothelial cells using high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) remain the predominant causative agents of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), but the factors underlying the pathogenesis of EV71 and CA16 infections have not been elucidated. Recently, the functions of microRNAs (miRNAs) in pathogen-host interactions have been highlighted. In the present study, we performed comprehensive miRNA profiling in EV71- and CA16-infected human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) at multiple time points using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that 135 known miRNAs showed remarkable differences in expression. Of these, 30 differentially expressed miRNAs showed opposite trends in EV71 and CA16 infected samples. We then mainly focused on the top 30 differentially expressed miRNAs by further screening to predict targets. Gene ontology (GO) and pathway analysis of the predicted targets revealed the enrichment of 14 biological processes, 9 molecular functions, 8 cellular components, and 85 pathways. The regulatory networks of these miRNAs with predicted targets, GOs, signaling pathways, and coexpression genes have been determined, suggesting that miRNAs exhibit intricate regulatory mechanisms during the infection phase. Consequently, we specifically analyzed the hierarchical GO categories of predicted targets involved in biological adhesion. The results suggested that the marked changes induced by EV71 and CA16 infection may be partially related to blood-brain barrier function. Taken together, this is the first report describing miRNA expression profiles in HUVECs with EV71 and CA16 infections using high-throughput sequencing. Our data provide useful insights that can help elucidate the different host-pathogen interactions after EV71 and CA16 infection and offer new therapeutic targets for these infections.
authors: Song, J.;Hu, Y.;Li, J.;Zheng, H.;Wang, J.;Guo, L.;Ning, R.;Li, H.;Yang, Z.;Fan, H.;Liu, L.

title: High-throughput sequencing of putative novel microRNAs in peripheral blood mononuclear cells of rhesus monkeys after EV71 and CA16 infection
abstract: Objectives: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) remain the main pathogens in cases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), but the mechanisms of the various pathogenesis following EV71 and CA16 infection are still poor unknown. Methods: Here we used deep microRNA (miRNA) sequencing to investigate the role of novel differentially expressed miRNAs in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) infected with EV71 and CA16. Results: The results identified 13 new differentially expressed miRNAs in each group. In addition, the target genes were predicted by the miRanda and RNAhybrid programs and a total of 2,501 targets were found across the two databases. Then, enrichment analyzes of Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) showed that these targets were mainly involved in cellular development and associated with nervous system development, system development, development of multicellular organisms, Wnt signaling pathway, the PDGF signaling pathway and the EGF receptor signaling pathway. Finally, a co-expression regulatory network was constructed with the key targets to further extrapolate the functional interactions of the targets and their co-expressed genes. Conclusion: Our results have not only revealed potential biomarkers or targets for the diagnosis and treatment of HFMD, but also provided new insights to explore the mechanisms of EV71 and CA16 pathogenesis.
authors: Song, J.;Jiang, X.;Hu, Y.;Li, H.;Zhang, X.;Xu, J.;Li, W.;Zheng, X.;Dong, S.

title: Evidence of human-to-pig transmission of the 2009 pandemic (H1N1) influenza virus in South Korea
abstract: As the 2009 pandemic influenza (H1N1) virus continues to infect human populations worldwide, reports of epidemiological animal infections are also increasing. Since December 2009, pandemic (H1N1) 2009-like viruses have been isolated in pigs from various pig farms in South Korea. Genetic and phylogenetic analyzes of viral segments revealed multiple events of human-to-pig transmission with no apparent signs of rearrangement. These events were also supported by serological monitoring of pig sera collected from April to December, suggesting that retransmission probably started between June and July, with a sharp increase in prevalence in the following months. Although molecular characterization shows that the porcine isolates are generally stable, some viruses continue to evolve genetically, most notably in their surface proteins. Animal experiments (ferrets and mice) show that swine pandemic isolates embody biological properties attributed to the currently circulating human pandemic viruses, including replication kinetics and efficient transmission, indicating their potential to reenter the human cycle. Taken together, these results indicate widespread human-to-animal transmission of 2009 pandemic influenza (H1N1) viruses in South Korea. Given the important role of swine in the ecology of influenza viruses, these transmission events should be closely monitored and minimized to prevent the risk of generating viruses of major human health concern. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Song, M. S.;Lee, J. H.;Pascua, P. N. Q.;Baek, Y. H.;Kwon, H. I.;Park, K. J.;Choi, H. W.;Shin, Y. K.;Song, J. Y.;Kim, C. J.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Chilo Iridescent Virus encodes a putative helicase belonging to a distinct family within the "DEAD/H" superfamily: implications for the evolution of large DNA viruses
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequence of the EcoRI DNA fragment M (7099 bp; 0.310-0.345 map units) of the genome of insect iridescent virus type 6 - Chilo-iridescent virus (CIV) - was determined. A 606 codon open reading frame located in this region encoded a protein (p69) related to a diverse family of putative DNA and/or RNA helicases belonging to the 'DEAD/H' superfamily. Unique sequence signatures were derived that allowed selective retrieval of the putative new family helicases from amino acid sequence databases. The family includes yeast, Drosophila, mammalian, and bacterial proteins involved in transcriptional regulation and repairing damaged DNA. It is hypothesized that p69 of CIV could be a DNA or RNA helicase possibly involved in viral transcription. A distant relationship has been observed between this family of helicases and another group of proteins composed of putative helicases from poxviruses, African swine fever virus and mitochondrial yeast plasmids. CIV p69 is shown to be much more closely related to cellular helicases than any other known viral helicase. Phylogenetic analysis suggested an independent origin for the p69 gene and the genes encoding other viral helicases.
authors: Sonntag, K. C.;Schnitzler, P.;Koonin, E. V.;Darai, G.

title: Small RNA deep sequencing identifies viral microRNAs during malignant catarrh fever induced by Alcelaphine herpesvirus 1
abstract: Alcelaphine herpesvirus 1 (AlHV-1) is a γ-herpesvirus (γ-HV) asymptomatically carried by wildebeest. When transmitted across species, AlHV-1 induces a deadly lymphoproliferative disease called malignant catarrhal fever (MCF) in many ruminants, including cattle, and in rabbit models. Latency has been shown to be essential for MCF induction. However, the mechanisms causing activation and proliferation of infected CD8+ T cells are unknown. Many γ-HVs express microRNAs (miRNAs). These small non-coding RNAs can regulate the expression of host or viral target genes involved in various signaling pathways and are thought to facilitate viral infection and/or mediate activation and proliferation of infected lymphocytes. The AlHV-1 genome was predicted to encode a large number of miRNAs. However, their precise contribution to viral infection and pathogenesis in vivo remains unknown. Here, using small RNA cloning and sequencing, we identified 36 putative miRNAs expressed in a lymphoblastoid cell line propagated from a calf infected with AlHV-1 and developing MCF. Among the candidate miRNAs sequenced, 32 were expressed in two major clusters on the reverse strand of the genome. The expression of these 32 viral miRNAs was further validated using Northern blot and quantitative reverse transcription PCR in lymphoid organs of calves or rabbits developing in MCF. To determine the concerted contribution in MCF of 28 viral miRNAs clustered in the non-protein coding region of the AlHV-1 genome, a recombinant virus was generated. The absence of these 28 miRNAs had no effect on virus growth in vitro or MCF induction in rabbits, indicating that the AlHV-1 miRNAs clustered in this non-protein-coding genomic region are dispensable for MCF induction.
authors: Sorel, O.;Tuddenham, L.;Myster, F.;Palmeira, L.;Kerkhofs, P.;Pfeffer, S.;Vanderplasschen, A.;Dewals, B. G.

title: Fulminant Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis in Adults: Pathologic and Molecular Studies-A Case Report
abstract: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare progressive neurological disorder caused by a persistent measles virus that typically affects children. We describe a case of fulminant subacute sclerosing panencephalitis in a 25-year-old man. Brain tissue biopsy showed histological evidence of encephalitis with eosinophilic intranuclear inclusion bodies (Cowdry types A and B), intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, perivascular lymphoplasmic infiltration and gliosis. Immunohistochemical studies with an anti-measles antibody were positive. Reverse transcriptase PCR detected measles virus RNA and phylogenetic analysis revealed a C2 genotype. The rare form with adult onset is often atypical and difficult to diagnose and should be included in the differential diagnosis of subacute "unexplained" neurological disorders and rare infectious diseases. © 2009 Dustri-Verlag Dr. K Feistle.
authors: Souraud, J. B.;Faivre, A.;Waku-Kouomou, D.;Gaillard, T.;Aouad, N.;Meaudre, E.;Wild, F. T.;Fouet, B.;Soulard, R.

title: Pathologic and molecular findings of avian avulavirus type 1 outbreak in pigeons (Columba livia) in southern Brazil
abstract: Newcastle disease, caused by strains of avian avulavirus type 1 (APMV-1), is an important avian disease associated with high mortality rates and economic losses. Over the past 30 years, several outbreaks of Columbiformes caused by an adapted strain variant of AAvV-1 called pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1) have been reported in different parts of the world. High mortality associated with an outbreak was analyzed in free-ranging pigeons (Columba livia) in a public square in Porto Alegre, southern Brazil. A total of 24 moribund or newly dead pigeons underwent autopsy, histopathological, immunohistochemical (anti-Newcastle) and RT-PCR within five weeks, followed by sequencing of amplification product analysis. They presented neurological symptoms, nonsuppurative encephalitis and encephalomyelitis, and a mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate in various organs. Immunohistochemical analysis in tissues from nine pigeons showed that anti-Newcastle was expressed in brain, kidney, liver and pancreas. The RT-PCR test for Newcastle disease virus M protein was positive in six pigeons. The differential diagnosis of influenza, West Nile, Mycoplasma gallisepticum and Mycoplasma synoviae in all pigeons was negative. The sequence of amino acids in the cleavage site region of F protein was 112RRQKRF117, classifying the strain as virulent. Phylogenetic analysis classified this virus strain into class II and class VI genotypes.
authors: Souza, S. O.;Fredo, G.;Dupont, P. M.;Leite-Filho, R. V.;Teifke, J. P.;Pavarini, S. P.;Canal, C. W.;Driemeier, D.

title: Viral variety of Rhipicephalus microplus parasitizing cattle in southern Brazil
abstract: Ticks are ectoparasites found worldwide and are known to be carriers of many viruses that are of great importance to human and animal health. However, viral diversity in ticks is still poorly understood, particularly in South America. Here we characterized viral diversity in Rhipicephalus microplus-parasitizing cattle in the southern region of Brazil using metagenomics. Our study revealed the presence of viruses not previously described in the region, including Lihan tick virus (family Phenuiviridae) and Wuhan tick virus 2 (family Chuviridae), and extended the biogeography of Jingmen tick virus (family Flaviviridae ). Brazil. We have also described three new tymoviruses (order Tymovirales) named Guarapuava Tymovirus-like 1 to 3. We have described the genomic and phylogenetic characterization of these viruses. Our study sheds light on the viral diversity of Rhipicephalus microplus in South America and also extends the biogeography of tick viruses previously only described in Asia.
authors: Souza, W. M.;Fumagalli, M. J.;Torres Carrasco, A. O.;Romeiro, M. F.;Modha, S.;Seki, M. C.;Gheller, J. M.;Daffre, S.;Nunes, M. R. T.;Murcia, P. R.;Acrani, G. O.;Figueiredo, L. T. M.

title: Characterization of low pathogenicity H5N1 avian influenza viruses from North America
abstract: Surveillance of wild birds in North America for avian influenza (AI) viruses with the goal of early identification of the Asian highly pathogenic AI virus H5N1 between 2004 and 2006 identified at least six H5N1 AI viruses with low pathogenicity. The hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of all 6 H5N1 viruses and an additional 38 H5 subtype viruses from North American wild birds and 28 N1 subtype viruses were sequenced and compared by phylogenetic analysis to sequences contained in GenBank Are available. Both HA and NA were phylogenetically distinct from those for viruses from outside North America and for viruses recovered from mammals. Four of the H5N1-AI viruses were characterized as low pathogenic by standard in vivo pathotyping tests. One of the H5N1 viruses, A/MuteSwan/MI/451072-2/06, has been shown to replicate at low titers in chickens, turkeys and ducks. However, transmission of A/MuteSwan/MI/451072-2/06 was more efficient in ducks than chickens or turkeys due to virus shedding. The 50% chicken infectious dose for A/MuteSwan/MI/451072-2/06 and three other H5 viruses derived from wild waterfowl was also determined and ranged from 10 5.3 to 107.5 50% egg infectious doses. Finally, seven H5 viruses representing different phylogenetic clades were screened for their antigenic relatedness by a hemagglutination inhibition assay, showing that antigenic relatedness was largely associated with geographic origin. Overall, the data support the conclusion that North American wild bird H5-AI viruses are wild bird-adapted viruses with low pathogenicity and are antigenically and genetically distinct from the highly pathogenic Asian H5N1 virus lineage. Copyright © 2007, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Spackman, E.;Swayne, D. E.;Suarez, D. L.;Senne, D. A.;Pedersen, J. C.;Killian, M. L.;Pasick, J.;Handel, K.;Pillai, S. P. S.;Lee, C. W.;Stallknecht, D.;Slemons, R.;Ip, H. S.;Deliberto, T.

title: Prevalence and phylogenetic analysis of hepatitis E virus in pigs, wild boar, roe deer, red deer and elk in Lithuania
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a major cause of acute viral hepatitis worldwide. In Europe, foodborne zoonotic transmission of HEV genotype 3 has been associated with domestic and feral pigs. Data on the circulation of the virus in animals used for human consumption are controversial and a gold standard for the diagnosis of HEV-associated hepatitis has not yet been defined. To investigate the current HEV infection status in Lithuanian pigs and wild ungulates, the presence of viral RNA was analyzed by nested reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-nPCR) in randomly selected samples and the viral RNA was subsequently genotyped. RESULTS: Overall, 32.98% and 22.55% of domestic pig samples were HEV positive using RT-nPCR targeting the ORF1 and ORF2 fragments, respectively. Among ungulates, 25.94% of wild boar samples, 22.58% of roe deer samples, 6.67% of red deer samples, and 7.69% of elk samples were positive for HEV RNA using primers targeting the ORF1 fragment. Using primers targeting the ORF2 fragment of the HEV genome, viral RNA was only detected in 17.03% of wild boar samples and 12.90% of roe deer samples. Phylogenetic analysis based on a 348 nucleotide region of HEV ORF2 showed that all conserved sequences detected in Lithuanian domestic pigs and wild animals belonged to genotype 3 3i subtype reference sequences from GenBank database. The sequences obtained from pig farms in two different districts of Lithuania were of the HEV 3f subtype. The wild boar sequences clustered within subtypes 3i and 3h, clearly indicating that wild boar can harbor additional subtypes of HEV. The ORF2 nucleotide sequences obtained from roe deer proved for the first time that the HEV subtype 3i can be found in a novel host. CONCLUSION: The results of the viral prevalence and phylogenetic analyzes clearly demonstrated viral infection in Lithuanian pigs and wild ungulates, underscoring the significant concern about transmission of zoonotic viruses both through the food chain and through direct contact with animals. The unexpected diversity of the HEV genotype 3 subtype in Lithuania and neighboring countries has shown that further studies are needed to understand the mode of HEV transmission between animals and humans in the Baltic States region.
authors: Spancerniene, U.;Grigas, J.;Buitkuviene, J.;Zymantiene, J.;Juozaitiene, V.;Stankeviciute, M.;Razukevicius, D.;Zienius, D.;Stankevicius, A.

title: Physical and chemical characterization of an avian reovirus
abstract: The avian viral agent S1133 was previously serologically classified as a member of the avian reovirus group. This viral agent grows in chick embryo fibroblast cells, bands at a density of 1.37 g/ml in CsCl equilibrium density gradients, has a particle diameter of 75 nm and a morphology similar to human reovirus type 3. Its nucleic acid consists of double-stranded RNA and adenosine-rich oligonucleotides. The dsRNA is divided into 10 segments with molecular weights of 2.7 x 106, 2.6 x 106, 2.4 x 106, 1.7 x 106, 1.5 x 106, 1.3 x 106, 1.2 x 106 , 0.80 x 106, 0.74 x 106 and 0.68 x 106 distributed for the largest (L1) to the smallest (S4) segment as determined by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. These 10 segments migrate differently on polyacrylamide gels compared to those of human reovirus type 3. The avian reovirus capsid proteins consist of eight types of polypeptides as determined by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. These are Δ1, Δ2, Δ3, Δ1, Δ2, Sigma1, Sigma2, and Sigma3 with molecular weights of 140, 125, 115, 85, 72, 40, 36, and 32 x 103, respectively. Only the sigma2 polypeptide, located in the inner capsid or nucleus co-migrated with the type 3 reovirus sigma2 polypeptide. Antiserum against reovirus type 3 did not neutralize avian reovirus. Avian reovirus core particles have been found to possess transcriptase and methylase activity.
authors: Spandidos, D. A.;Graham, A. F.

title: Dynamic balance of Marek's disease genomes during in vitro serial passage
abstract: Attenuation of gallid herpesvirus-2 (GaHV-2), the causative agent of Marek's disease, can be achieved by serial passage of a virulent field isolate in avian embryo fibroblasts. In order to better understand the genes involved in the attenuation and to assign observed changes in phenotype to specific genetic variations, the genomic DNA sequence of a single virulent GaHV-2 strain (648A) was determined at defined passage intervals. Biological characterization of these "interval isolates" in chickens previously indicated that the ability to induce transient paralysis was lost after passage 40 and the ability to induce sustained neurological disease was lost after passage 80, which coincides with was accompanied by the loss of formation of neoplastic lesions. Deep sequencing of the interval isolates allowed detailed cataloging of the mutations present within a single passage population and the frequency with which a given mutation occurs across passages. Gross genetic changes have been identified in both novel and well-characterized genes and cis-acting regions involved in replication and cleavage/packaging. Between passages 61 and 101 there were deletions in genes encoding the virulence factors vLipase, vIL8 and RLORF4, as well as a deletion in the promoter of ICP4. In addition, three mutations in the virus-encoded telomerase that were prevalent in late passages were identified. Overall, the frequency of mutations varied greatly during serial passage and few genetic changes were absolute. This indicates that serial passage of GaHV-2 leads to the generation of a library of genomes with limited sequence heterogeneity.
authors: Spatz, S. J.;Volkening, J. D.;Gimeno, I. M.;Heidari, M.;Witter, R. L.

title: Dual natural infection with bovine viral diarrhea virus-1 and -2 in a stillborn calf: tissue distribution and molecular characterization
abstract: Dual infections with Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV)-1 and -2 appear to be uncommon. The aim of this study was to describe infection with both BVDV genotypes in a stillborn calf. Virus isolation and phylogenetic analyzes of the 5´UTR and NS5B regions confirmed the presence of BVDV-1b and -2b in spleen and lung, while BVDV-2b was also detected in brain, heart, liver, kidney and cavernous fluid. These results confirm that dual infections with both BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 species can occur naturally and their tissue distribution can be different.
authors: Spetter, M. J.;Uriarte, E. L. L.;Altamiranda, E. A. G.;Leunda, M. R.;Pereyra, S. B.;Verna, A. E.;OdeÃ³n, A. C.

title: Serological and virological studies on selected cattle with antibodies against bovine herpesviruses
abstract: To examine the specificity of low titre antibodies against BHV 1, twelve cattle were subjected to stress and dexamethasone treatment. They were monitored virologically by inoculating cell cultures with nasopharyngeal, ocular and vaginal or preputial swabs and serologically by determining the prevalence and incidence of antibodies to bovine, caprine, porcine and equine herpesviruses and to bovine leukemia virus. Antibodies were considered specific for BHV 1 if the animals shed IBR virus, or if the antibodies neutralized BHV 1 and reacted with BHV 1 antigens, or if they additionally reacted with CapHV antigens. Animals whose sera recognized BHV 1 and BHV 2 but no other herpesviruses were judged to have suffered both infections. Nine of the twelve animals showed specific BHV 1 antibodies. For three animals, the question of the specificity of their antibodies remains open. Two animals suffered multiple herpesvirus infections. Therefore, the induction of cross-reacting antibodies directed against epitopes common to herpesviruses could not be ruled out. The sera of one animal reacted with BHV 1 and BHV 4 antigens in ELISA tests. However, they did not neutralize BHV 1.
authors: Spirig, C.;Ackermann, M.;MÃ¼ller, H. K.;Bruckner, L.;Kihm, U.

title: Orf virus infection in sheep or goats
abstract: Orf virus, a member of the Parapoxvirus genus, is the causative agent of contagious ecthyma ("orf"). It is a globally distributed pathogen that causes significant financial losses in livestock farming. The disease mainly affects sheep and goats, but various other ruminants and mammals have also been reported to be infected. It is also a zoonosis, mainly affecting people who come into direct or indirect contact with infected animals (e.g. farmers, veterinarians). The disease is usually benign and self-limiting, although in many cases, particularly in young animals, it can be persistent and even fatal. It is assumed that production losses due to the orf virus are underestimated since it is not a notifiable disease. This literature review contains all the latest information on the virus; Treatment and prevention considerations are also discussed.
authors: Spyrou, V.;Valiakos, G.

title: Characterization of infectious bursal disease virus from four-layer flocks in the United States
abstract: Twenty bursa samples were obtained from four flocks of laying hens vaccinated with infectious bursial disease virus (IBDV) and having problems with immunosuppression considered to be infectious bursial disease. All samples were found positive for IBDV by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis of the samples identified them as classic viruses of molecular groups 3 and 4. Two samples from each of the four flocks were sequenced and within one flock these sequences were identical; however, some differences were observed between herds. One virus from each of the four herds was selected for further analysis. The VP2 hypervariable sequence region of samples GA-1, H-30 and CS-2-35 had nucleotide and amino acid similarities to the classical D78 and Vi Bursa G vaccines used in these flocks. The sequence of HPR-2 was similar to the Bursa Vac 4 vaccine used in this herd and the virulent STC IBDV classic strain. Deduced amino acid sequence of these isolates showed that all isolates had proline at position 222, which is characteristic of classical US viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of these isolates based on the hypervariable VP2 amino acid sequence grouped GA-1, H-30 and CS-2-35 with the D78 vaccine and HPR-2 with STC. The pathogenicity of these isolates was tested on specifically pathogen-free chickens. Bursal body weight (B-BW) ratios and histopathologic lesion scores in the bursa were determined. Gross lesions were observed in the bursa, and the B:BW ratios of the birds infected with all four wild-type viruses were significantly different compared to the D78 vaccine and the unvaccinated control groups. The histopathology of the bursa of groups infected with GA-1, H-30, CS-2-35 and HPR-2 showed variable degrees of follicle depletion and necrosis. A very slight lymphoid depletion was observed in the D78-infected group 5 days post-inoculation and no microscopic lesions were observed in this group 8 days post-inoculation or at any time in the uninoculated control group. The bursae collected from the field viruses and D78-infected birds at autopsy revealed the presence of IBDV via RT-PCR and the VP-2 hypervariable nucleotide sequences of GA-1, H-30, CS-2-35, HPR-2- and D78 samples were identical to the original virus isolates and vaccine, respectively.
authors: Sreedevi, B.;LeFever, L. J.;Sommer-Wagner, S. E.;Jackwood, D. J.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of poly- and non-structural proteins in Japanese encephalitis virus with other related virus families
abstract: BACKGROUND: Japanese encephalitis (JE) causes inflammation of the brain. The mortality rate from JE is 30%, while 10-15% of patients fully recover. The disease spreads through infected mosquito bites that breed in paddy fields and feed on pigs, birds and ducks. PURPOSE: Since proteins have an important structure-function relationship, the study was designed to perform the identification of poly- and non-structural proteins in the infectious virus group using different strains of Japanese encephalitis virus, i.e. JAOARS982, Nakayama strain SA (V ), strain SA-14. Methods: Using non-structural proteins, protein sequences of the following Japanese encephalitis virus groups were obtained: Japanese encephalitis virus, Weatnile virus, Kunjin virus. Further comparative and phylogenetic analyzes were conducted to examine the evolutionary relationship between these groups. RESULTS: Alignment score phylogeny results were 375184 using multiple alignment, Jal view, ClustalW(1.83) and ClustalW2. However, analysis among the nonstructural proteins of Japanese encephalitis virus, West Nile virus and Kunjin virus revealed that the phylogeny alignment score was 875 by multiple sequence alignment and tree view, respectively. CONCLUSION: Phylogenetic analysis revealed that these four strains are related and show high similarity to the other viruses of this group due to conserved regions in their sequences.
authors: Srivastava, P.;Trivedi, A. C.;Tiwari, A.;Verma, A.;Pant, A. B.

title: Animal models of Ebola virus infection
abstract: Ebola virus is a highly pathogenic member of the Filoviridae family that causes severe hemorrhagic disease in humans and NHP. The 2013–2016 outbreak in West Africa has increased interest in developing and refining animal models of Ebola virus disease. These models are used to test countermeasures and vaccines, generate scientific knowledge about the mechanisms of disease progression and transmission, and study key correlates of immunology. The Ebola virus is classified as a BSL4 pathogen and a Category A pathogen for which the United States government must be prepared in the event of bioterrorism. Rodents such as Syrian golden hamsters (Mesocricetus auratus), mice (Mus musculus) and guinea pigs (Cavia porcellus) are the most common types of research. However, NHP, particularly macaques, are preferred for research into Ebola virus disease due to similarities to humans in terms of pathogenesis, clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and causes of death. To meet regulatory requirements for approving countermeasures against high-impact pathogens, the FDA introduced the animal rule, allowing efficacy studies in animal models in place of human clinical data when such studies are impractical or ethically unacceptable. This review article provides a comprehensive summary of different animal models and their use in Ebola virus disease research.
authors: St Claire, M. C.;Ragland, D. R.;Bollinger, L.;Jahrling, P. B.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of classical swine fever virus in Central Europe
abstract: The aim of this work was to genetically characterize Central European isolates of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) and to evaluate the applicability of molecular analysis in the epizootiology of CSFV infections. 34 viruses originating from Central European pigs or wild boars were examined. All of these viruses were detected by each of three sets of oligonucleotide primers designed for specific RT-PCR amplification of different genomic regions. Comparative sequence analyzes of the PCR products showed that it was a genetic type common in Western Europe. A further differentiation of virus isolates into subgroups broadly consistent with their regions of origin in Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and Estonia was possible. The discrimination ability of the technique was enhanced by analyzing a composite data set consisting of all sequence data from all viruses. Using this approach, we were able to distinguish between all viruses and grouped them to exactly match their geographic origins, with the exception of a single Estonian isolate, which grouped with viruses from eastern Poland.
authors: Stadejek, T.;VilÄek, Å ;Lowings, J. P.;Ballagi-PordÃ¡ny, A.;Paton, D. J.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Comparative sequence analysis of the 5'-noncoding region of classical swine fever virus strains from Europe, Asia and America
abstract: The polymerase chain reaction was used to determine the sequence of a 280 base pair fragment from 5'-noncoding region cDNAs of 29 isolates of classical swine fever virus. The phylogenetic analysis of the sequences revealed low genomic variation, which correlated with the geographic origin of the isolates.
authors: Stadejek, T.;Warg, J.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: First detection of porcine circovirus type 3 in commercial pig farms in Poland
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3) is a novel circovirus species recently discovered in the United States and China in cases of porcine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome, reproductive failure, respiratory disease, and multisystemic inflammation. This study reports the first identification of PCV3 in Europe in the serum of pigs from Polish herds. Between 2014 and 2017, a total of 1,050 serum samples were collected from sows and 3-20 week old pigs from 14 commercial farms from different regions of Poland, of different size and health status. Samples were pooled from 4-6 and assayed for PCV3 by real-time PCR. PCV3 DNA was detected in 12 out of 14 farms (85.7%). In the PCV3-positive farms, the virus was detected in 5.9% to 65% of the serum pools. PCV3 was most common in weaned and finisher pigs (26.1% and 28.0% of serum pools, respectively). Sequence analysis of the 359 nucleotide fragment of ORF2 showed the highest 99.7% identity with PCV3-US/SD2016 from USA. Our results show that PCV3 is a common virus in Polish pigs, but no links to unexplained disease states have been established.
authors: Stadejek, T.;WoÅºniak, A.;MiÅ‚ek, D.;Biernacka, K.

title: Markers of Venezuelan encephalitis virus that distinguish enzootic strains of subtype ID from those of IE
abstract: Strains of Venezuelan encephalitis virus isolated from enzootic habitats during interepizootic periods in Central America and northern South America can be antigenically distinguished from one another by inhibition of hemagglutination. This test provided the basis for classifying these virus strains into subtypes IE and ID. Virus strains of these two subtypes were found to be fundamentally different in terms of virulence to English shorthaired guinea pigs. Studies are described which confirm that virus strains of the ID subtype are virulent for guinea pigs and that the virulence is not the result of cocycling subpopulations of epizootic subtype I AB or IC virions. Two additional markers were found that distinguish viral strains of ID and IE subtypes of Venezuelan encephalitis. First, hydroxyapatite chromatography of intact virions at pH 6.5 showed differential elution of ID and IE prototype strains. Virions from subtype ID strains eluted at 0.08-0.11 M phosphate, while those from subtype IE strains eluted at 0.15-0.20 M phosphate. Second, the isoelectric points of the E1 envelope glycoproteins of the ID and IE prototype strains were significantly different; pH 6.85 to 7.00 and pH 7.25 to 7.30, respectively. There was no significant difference in the isoelectric points of the E2 envelope glycoproteins. These distinguishing features most likely reflect a fundamental difference in virion surface structure.
authors: Stanick, D. R.;Wiebe, M. E.;Scherer, W. F.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus in Lithuanian wild boar populations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is recognized worldwide as an important and economically devastating pathogen in swine production. Although PRRSV is widespread in domestic pigs, there is a lack of information on PRRSV infection in European wild boar (Sus scrofa). The information currently available does not provide conclusive evidence that wild boar is a reservoir of PRRSV. Nevertheless, wild boar can become infected through occasional direct or indirect contact with domestic pigs. In addition, wild boar can act as a reservoir for infectious diseases of domestic pigs. Therefore, the aims of the present study were to determine virus prevalence and to further investigate the epidemiology and diversity of PRRSV strains present in Lithuanian wild boar over a 5-year period. A total of 1597 tissue and serum samples from wild boar living in 44 districts and ten counties in Lithuania were analyzed using conventional nested reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and real-time Taqman RT-PCR for the detection of PRRSV-specific Openness analyzed reading frame (ORF) 1 and 6 sequences. RESULTS: PRRSV was widespread in Lithuanian wild boar populations, with an average rate of 18.66% by conventional RT-PCR and 19.54% by real-time RT-PCR. PRRSV was detected in 36.71% and 41.77% of the 237 hunting grounds tested by conventional RT-nPCR and real-time RT-PCR, respectively. No statistically significant differences in PRRSV prevalence by geographic area were observed in the ten Lithuanian counties. Animals infected with PRRSV were identified in all age groups; However, significantly higher prevalence rates were found in subadult and adult wild boar than in young animals up to 12 months of age. No positive results were obtained using conventional PCR with type 2 specific primers. Phylogenetic analysis of the partial ORF5 region revealed that ten wild boar harbor virus sequences of genetic subtypes 3 and 4 and therefore may pose a serious threat to Lithuanian pig farms where only subtype 2 strains are circulating. CONCLUSIONS: The results of virus prevalence and phylogenetic analyzes strongly support the role of wild boar as a possible natural reservoir for PRRSV in Lithuania.
authors: Stankevicius, A.;Buitkuviene, J.;Sutkiene, V.;Spancerniene, U.;Pampariene, I.;Pautienius, A.;Oberauskas, V.;Zilinskas, H.;Zymantiene, J.

title: The analysis of influenza A viruses of subtype H1 from wild birds, turkeys and pigs in Germany shows transmission events between the species
abstract: Background Influenza A virus transmission between wild birds, poultry and swine has been repeatedly demonstrated between species despite significant host species barriers. In particular, viruses of subtypes H1 and H3 have been transmitted between pigs and poultry, predominantly turkeys, in regions with high population densities of both species. The detection of a swine influenza H1N1 virus in a flock of turkeys in Germany in 2009 prompted us to molecularly investigate the H1 subtype viruses recently detected in wild birds, pigs and poultry. Aims The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between H1N1 viruses originating from wild and domestic animals from Germany and to identify possible transspecies transmission or reassortment events. Methods Haemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes and full-length genome sequences were generated from selected, current H1N1 viruses from wild birds, pigs and turkeys. Phylogenetic analyzes were combined with genotyping and analyzes of the deduced amino acid sequences for biologically active sites. Antigenic relationships were assessed by hemagglutination inhibition responses. Results Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin sequences revealed that viruses from different H1 subgroups co-circulate between domestic and wild birds. In addition, these viruses comprised different genotypes and were antigenically distinct. An H1N1 virus isolated from a turkey farm in northern Germany in 2009 showed the greatest similarity to the bird-like H1N1 swine influenza virus that has been circulating in Europe since the late 1970s. Conclusions The data demonstrate the genetic and antigenic heterogeneity of the H1 viruses currently circulating in domestic and wild animals in Germany and point to turkeys as a possible bridge between avian and mammalian hosts. © 2011 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Starick, E.;Fereidouni, S. R.;Lange, E.;Grund, C.;Vahlenkamp, T.;Beer, M.;Harder, T. C.

title: Circular replication-associated protein encoding DNA viruses identified in the faeces of various animals in New Zealand
abstract: In recent years, innovations in molecular techniques and sequencing technologies have led to a rapid increase in the number of known viral sequences, particularly those with circular replication-associated protein (Rep)-encoding single-stranded (CRESS) DNA genome. CRESS DNA viruses are found in the virome of many ecosystems and are known to infect a wide variety of organisms. A large number of the recently identified CRESS-DNA viruses cannot be assigned to any known virus family, suggesting that the current view of the CRESS-DNA viral sequence space is grossly underestimated. Animal feces have proven to be a particularly useful source for sampling CRESS DNA viruses in an ecosystem because they are inexpensive and non-invasive. In this study, a viral metagenomic approach was used to examine the diversity of CRESS DNA viruses present in the faeces of domestic and wild animals in New Zealand. Thirty-eight complete CRESS DNA viral genomes and two circular molecules (which may be defective molecules or individual components of multicomponent genomes) were identified from forty-nine individual animal fecal samples. Based on shared genome organization and sequence similarity, eighteen of the isolates were classified as gemycircularviruses and twelve isolates as smacoviruses. The remaining eight isolates lack significant sequence similarity to members of known CRESS DNA virus groups. This research adds significantly to our knowledge of CRESS DNA viral diversity in New Zealand, emphasizes the prevalence of CRESS DNA viruses in nature, and reinforces the suggestion that a large subset of CRESS DNA viruses has yet to be identified .
authors: Steel, O.;Kraberger, S.;Sikorski, A.;Young, L. M.;Catchpole, R. J.;Stevens, A. J.;Ladley, J. J.;Coray, D. S.;Stainton, D.;Dayaram, A.;Julian, L.;van Bysterveldt, K.;Varsani, A.

title: Widespread recombination, reassortment, and transmission of unbalanced composite viral genotypes in natural arenavirus infections
abstract: Arenaviruses are one of the largest families of human hemorrhagic fever viruses and are known to infect both mammals and snakes. Arena viruses package a large (L) and a small (S) genome segment into their virions. For segmented RNA viruses like these, new genotypes can be generated through mutation, recombination, and reassortment. Although it is believed that an ancient recombination event led to the emergence of a new lineage of mammalian arenaviruses, neither recombination nor reassortment have been definitively documented in natural arenavirus infections. Here we used metagenomic sequencing to examine the viral diversity present in captive arenavirus-infected snakes. From 48 infected animals we determined the complete or nearly complete sequence of 210 genome segments grouped into 23 L and 11 S genotypes. The majority of snakes were multiply infected, with up to 4 different S and 11 different L segment genotypes in individual animals. This S/L imbalance was typical: in all cases, the L segment genotypes predominated within the host over the S genotypes, and a particular S segment genotype was dominant at individual animals and at the population level. We confirmed the sequencing results by qRT-PCR and virus isolation and isolates replicated as ensembles in culture. Numerous cases of recombination and reassortment were discovered, including recombinant segments with unusual organizations with 2 intergenic regions and superfluous content, which despite their atypical structures were capable of stable replication and transmission. Overall, this represents diversity within the host on a scale and in a form far exceeding what has been observed for arenaviruses or for viruses in general. This diversity can plausibly be attributed to the mixing of subclinically infected wild caught in captivity. Thus, these results not only provide a unique opportunity to study the evolution and adaptation of arenaviruses, but also allow the study of unintended anthropogenic impacts on viral ecology, diversity, and disease potential.
authors: Stenglein, M. D.;Jacobson, E. R.;Chang, L. W.;Sanders, C.;Hawkins, M. G.;Guzman, D. S.;Drazenovich, T.;Dunker, F.;Kamaka, E. K.;Fisher, D.;Reavill, D. R.;Meola, L. F.;Levens, G.;DeRisi, J. L.

title: Isolation and cloning of two variants of papillomaviruses from domestic pigs: Sus scrofa papillomavirus type 1 variants a and b
abstract: The healthy skin of two female domestic pigs (Sus scrofa domestica) was sampled with cotton swabs. Total genomic DNA was extracted from the samples and subjected to PCR with degenerate papillomavirus (PV)-specific primers. Similarity searches performed with BLASTN showed that partial E1 and L1 sequences were amplified from two new PVs. Subsequently, the complete genomes of these Sus scrofa papillomaviruses (SsPVs) were amplified using long template PCR, cloned and sequenced using a transposon insertion method. They contained the typical PV open reading frames (ORFs) E1, E2, E4, E6, L1 and L2, but the E7 ORF was absent in both viruses. The pairwise nucleotide sequence alignment of the L1 ORFs of the SsPVs showed a similarity of 98.5%, classifying these viruses as SsPV type 1 "variants" (SsPV-1a and -1b). A contiguous phylogenetic tree was constructed based on a chained alignment of the E1, E2, L1, and L2 ORFs of SsPV-1 variants a and b and 81 other human and animal PV-type species. This phylogenetic analysis showed that the SsPV-1a and -1b variants did not cluster with the other PVs of artiodactyl (hoofed hoof) host species, but clustered at the edge of the genus Alphapapillomavirus, very close to the root of that genus. © 2008 SGM.
authors: Stevens, H.;Rector, A.;van der Kroght, K.;van Ranst, M.

title: The cloning and sequencing strategy for small RNA affects the expression signatures of host and virus microRNA
abstract: The establishment of microRNA (miRNA) expression signatures is the fundamental element to study the role played by these regulatory molecules in the biology of an organism. Marek's disease virus 1 (MDV-1) is an avian herpesvirus that naturally infects chickens and induces T-cell lymphoma. During latency, MDV-1, like other herpesviruses, expresses a limited subset of transcripts. This includes three miRNA clusters. Several studies identified the expression of virus- and host-encoded miRNAs from MDV-1 infected cell cultures and chickens. However, when comparing miRNA cloning frequencies from different cloning and sequencing protocols, a large discrepancy was observed. Therefore, we analyzed the effect of preparing and sequencing small RNA libraries on miRNA frequencies obtained from the same RNA samples collected during MDV-1 infection of chickens at different steps of oncoviral pathogenesis. Depending on the strategy used, qualitative and quantitative discrepancies were found in the data. One of the mature miRNAs derived from the Latency Associated Transcript (LAT), mdv1-miR-M7-5p, showed the highest variation. Its cloning frequency was 50% of viral miRNA counts when a small-scale sequencing approach was used. Its frequency was 100 times lower when determined by the deep sequencing approach. Northern blot analysis showed better correlation with the miRNA frequencies found by the small-scale sequencing approach. By analyzing the cellular miRNA repertoire, we also found a gap between the two sequencing approaches. Overall, our study shows that next-generation sequencing data, considered alone, is limited for assessing the absolute copy number of transcripts. Therefore, small RNA quantification should be addressed by compiling data obtained using various techniques such as microarrays, qRT-PCR, and NB analysis in support of high-throughput sequencing data. These observations should be considered when investigating miRNA variations before attempting functional studies. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Stik, G.;Muylkens, B.;Coupeau, D.;Laurent, S.;Dambrine, G.;Messmer, M.;Chane-Woon-Ming, B.;Pfeffer, S.;Rasschaert, D.

title: Molecular and biological properties of avian polyomaviruses: Isolates from different avian species indicate that avian polyomaviruses constitute a distinct subgenus within the polyomavirus genus
abstract: The isolation and characterization of two avian polyomaviruses from chicken (BFDV-2) and one parrot (BFDV-3) is reported. Both isolates are closely related to the non-mammalian polyomavirus (BFDV) (now called BFDV-1) isolated from budgies, and all three viral genomes have been shown to share the same basal size of 4981 bp. However, a 151 bp insertion was observed in the non-coding region of BFDV-2, representing an exact duplication of the left half of the non-coding region, including the putative early promoter and the amino terminus of the large T antigen. With an additional 15 base pairs swapped elsewhere in the three genomes, these viruses have varying degrees of tropism for different bird species. The production of antibodies directed against a β-galactosidase-large T-antigen fusion protein of BFDV-1 is described. These antibodies detected the large T antigen with an M(r) of approximately 80K and the small t antigen with an M(r) of approximately 24K in cells infected with BFDV isolates. While these antibodies bind with low affinity to the simian virus 40 (SV40) large T antigen, SV40 or mouse polyomavirus specific antibodies do not bind to the BFDV large T antigen. Antibodies directed against BFDV structural polypeptides show broad reciprocal cross-reactivities with all three structural proteins of mammalian polyomaviruses. The importance of polyomavirus infections in different bird species is discussed. Based on unique structural and biological features, we propose to place these viruses in a distinct subgenus (avipolyomavirus) within the polyomaviruses.
authors: Stoll, R.;Luo, D.;Kouwenhoven, B.;Hobom, G.;Muller, H.

title: Whole genome sequencing shows that geographic variation in Escherichia coli O157 genotypes dominates host association
abstract: Genetic variation in an infectious disease agent can be caused by ecological niche differences resulting from different host species and different geographic locations. Whole genome sequencing was used to compare E. coli O157 isolates from host reservoirs (cattle and sheep) from Scotland and to compare genetic variation of isolates (human, animal, environment/food) collected from Scotland, New Zealand , the Netherlands, Canada and the USA UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. Nei's genetic distance, calculated from nuclear genome single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), showed that the animal isolates came from the same population. Examination of the Shiga toxin bacteriophage and its insertion sites (SBI typing) revealed that bovine and ovine isolates had statistically indistinguishable dilution profiles, diversity and genotypes. In contrast, isolates from different countries showed significant differences in Nei genetic distance and SBI typing. Therefore, after successful international transmission, which has occurred multiple times, local genetic variation occurs, resulting in a global patchwork of continental and transcontinental phylogeographic clades. These results are important for three reasons: first, to understand the transmission and evolution of infectious diseases associated with multiple host reservoirs and multiple geographic locations; second, emphasizing the importance of the sheep reservoir when considering farm-based interventions; and third, improving our understanding of why the incidence of human disease varies across the world.
authors: Strachan, N. J.;Rotariu, O.;Lopes, B.;MacRae, M.;Fairley, S.;Laing, C.;Gannon, V.;Allison, L. J.;Hanson, M. F.;Dallman, T.;Ashton, P.;Franz, E.;van Hoek, A. H.;French, N. P.;George, T.;Biggs, P. J.;Forbes, K. J.

title: Detection and subtyping of foot-and-mouth disease virus in infected cattle by polymerase chain reaction and amplified VP1 sequencing
abstract: Rapid and accurate detection of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreaks is necessary to contain the spread of the disease through appropriate vaccination. The use of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has revolutionized the way viral diseases are diagnosed. Sequence analysis of the amplified VP1 sequence can allow classification of the FMD virus detected in the diseased animal. PCR assays were performed to identify the virus and its serotype in suspect animals from 2 outbreaks of FMD type O virus. Sequence analysis of the amplified VP1 cDNA showed 78% homology with O1K and over 95% homology between samples. These results suggest that the two outbreaks were due to infection with the same virus serosubtype.
authors: Stram, Y.;Molad, T.;Chai, D.;Gelman, B.;Yadin, H.

title: Expanding the conversation on high-throughput virome sequencing standards to include microbial sources of contamination
authors: Strong, M. J.;Lin, Z.;Flemington, E. K.

title: Increased phylogenetic diversity of bovine diarrhea type 1 viral virus isolates in England and Wales since 2001
abstract: There are currently two recognized bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) genotypes, type 1 and type 2. These genotypes are divided into subtypes based on phylogenetic analysis, namely ap for BVDV-1 and ac for BVDV-2. In this study, the genetic heterogeneity of BVDV-1 in England and Wales was examined and compared to the situation in 1996/1997. Viral RNA was extracted from 316 blood samples previously identified as positive for BVDV-1 collected between 2004 and 2009. A region of the 5' untranslated region (UTR) was amplified by RT-PCR and the PCR products were sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the 5'UTR revealed the existence of five subtypes of BVDV-1 circulating in England and Wales, namely BVDV-1a (244 samples), BVDV-1b (50), BVDV-1e (3), BVDV- 1f (1) and BVDV-1i (18). Phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequence for the Npro region of the viral genome supported the classification obtained with the 5' UTR. Given that only three subtypes were detected in 1999, this report supports the notion that the repopulation of cattle from continental Europe following the mass culling during the 2001 foot-and-mouth outbreak and the slaughter of cattle for infection with bovine tuberculosis occurred has increased the genetic diversity of BVDV-1 subtypes in England and Wales over the past 10 years. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Strong, R.;Errington, J.;Cook, R.;Ross-Smith, N.;Wakeley, P.;Steinbach, F.

title: Infectious pustular vulvovaginitis virus infection of bulls
authors: Studdert, M. J.;Barker, C. A.;Savan, M.

title: A novel parrot herpesvirus found in African gray parrots (Psittacus erithacus erithacus).
abstract: DNA of a novel alphaherpesvirus was amplified from a cloacal papilloma, a skin papilloma and normal cloacal mucosa of gray parrots (Psittacus erithacus erithacus). Phylogenetically, the virus was most closely related to parrot herpesvirus, but displayed sufficient nucleotide and amino acid diversity to be considered a novel alphaherpesvirus. It is proposed that the previously described puffin herpesvirus be named puffin herpesvirus 1 (PsHV-1) and this new species classified as puffin herpesvirus 2 (PsHV-2). It is speculated that PsHV-2 co-evolved with the African gray parrot and should therefore be present in these birds in the wild. © 2005 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Styles, D. K.;Tomaszewski, E. K.;Phalen, D. N.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Gansu sheeppox virus isolates based on P32, GPCR and RPO30 genes
abstract: Two outbreaks of sheeppox in sheep have occurred in Gansu Province, China. The genes P32, GPCR and RPO30 were used as markers for the differential diagnosis. We have confirmed that the outbreaks were caused by the sheeppox virus. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the P32, GPCR and RPO30 genes revealed a close relationship between the two isolates and Chinese sheeppox viruses. Because sick sheep were imported from Jingyuan, another county in Gansu Province, our results strongly suggest the importance of veterinary supervision prior to shipment.
authors: Su, H. L.;Jia, H. J.;Yin, C.;Jing, Z. Z.;Luo, X. N.;Chen, Y. X.

title: Liver rupture hemorrhage syndrome in chickens caused by a novel genotype of avian hepatitis E virus
abstract: Since 2016, severe outbreaks of Hepatic Rupture Hemorrhage Syndrome (HRHS) in chickens have occurred in several Chinese provinces and have caused huge economic losses in the poultry industry, but the etiological features and pathogenic potential thereof have remained unclear. This study sequenced the partial helicase and capsid gene of the potentially novel avian hepatitis E virus (HEV) isolated from chickens with HRHS and tested the pathogenicity thereof on SPF chicks, while showing clinical symptoms, histopathological changes , virus distribution, viremia and virus shedding was monitored 14 days post-infection (dpi). The analysis revealed that the HRHS-related avian HEV belongs to a new genotype and infected chicks developed the typical symptoms of HRHS. Thus, this study successfully developed an experimental infection model to investigate the pathogenicity and role of the novel avian HEV in HRHS. Meanwhile, the novel avian HEV was mainly present in liver and spleen, which induces rapid viremia and chronic virus shedding in infected chicks and could cause 40% mortality before 14 dpi. In summary, this study found the new avian HEV genotype and confirmed its role in HRHS.
authors: Su, Q.;Li, Y.;Meng, F.;Cui, Z.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.

title: Characterization of H7N2 avian influenza virus in wild birds and pikas in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau area
abstract: Qinghai Lake is an important breeding ground for migratory birds, which has recently seen several outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) animal diseases. From 2006 to 2009, we examined Qinghai's wild birds and pikas for evidence of AIV infection. We sampled 941 healthy wild animals and isolated seventeen H7N2 viruses (eight from pikas and nine from wild birds). The H7N2 viruses were phylogenetically closely related to each other and to viruses isolated in Hong Kong in the 1970s. We determined the pathogenicity of H7N2 viruses by infecting chickens and mice. Our results suggest that pikas may play an important role in the ecology of AIVs as they act as intermediate hosts where viruses are better adapted to mammals. Our results of AI infection in pikas are consistent with previous observations and raise the possibility that picas may play a previously unrecognized role in the ecology of the peridomestic aquatic environment of AIV.
authors: Su, S.;Xing, G.;Wang, J.;Li, Z.;Gu, J.;Yan, L.;Lei, J.;Ji, S.;Hu, B.;Gray, G. C.;Yan, Y.;Zhou, J.

title: Overexpression of the Rybp gene inhibits differentiation of bovine myoblasts into myotubes
abstract: The RING1 and YY1 Binding Protein (Rybp) genes inhibit myogenesis in mice, but the effects of these genes in cattle have not been reported. The aim of this study is to investigate the role of the Rybp gene in bovine skeletal muscle development and myoblast differentiation. In the present study, the Rybp gene was overexpressed in bovine myoblasts via adenovirus. RNA-seq was performed to screen differentially expressed genes (DEGs). The results showed that overexpression of the Rybp gene inhibited myotube formation. The morphological differences in the myoblasts started on the second day and were very significant 6 days after adenovirus induction. A total of 1311 (707 upregulated and 604 downregulated) DEGs were screened using RNA-seq between myoblasts with added negative control adenoviruses (AD-NC) and Rybp adenoviruses (AD-Rybp) after 6 days of induction. Gene ontology (GO) and KEGG analysis showed that the downregulated DEGs were mainly involved in biological functions related to muscle, and that of the 32 signaling pathways, those related to muscle development were significantly enriched for the identified DEGs. This study can not only provide a theoretical basis for the regulation of skeletal muscle development in cattle by examining the role of Rybp gene in myoblast differentiation, but also lay a theoretical basis for molecular breeding of beef cattle.
authors: Su, X.;Zhao, Y.;Wang, Y.;Zhang, L.;Zan, L.;Wang, H.

title: Isolation and genetic characterization of a novel adeno-associated virus from Muscovy ducks in China
abstract: Adeno-associated virus (AAV; genus Dependoparvovirus, family Parvoviridae) was first discovered in 1965 as a contaminant in adenovirus preparations. The AAVs are generally considered non-pathogenic and have the ability to attenuate the replication of other, more pathogenic viruses, making them attractive as potential therapeutics or preventive measures. This study characterized a novel AAV isolated from Muscovy ducks in China. The novel virus (MHH-05-2015) was isolated after a field isolate of DAdV-3 virus (a type 3 duck adenovirus) was propagated in duck embryonic fibroblasts. The complete genome sequence of MHH-05-2015 was determined and the nucleotide and amino acid sequences were compared to other avian AAVs. The genomic distribution of the structural and nonstructural protein-encoding genes in MHH-05-2015 was conserved and consistent with the other AAVs. Compared to previously isolated avian AAVs, MHH-05-2015 had approximately 63-64% sequence identity. Phylogenetic analysis showed that MHH-05-2015 clustered separately from other avian AAVs, suggesting that MHH-05-2015 is not directly descended from other members of the dependoparvovirus family. These results suggest that MHH-05-2015 is a new subtype of AAV distinct from other avian AAVs.
authors: Su, X. N.;Liu, J. J.;Zhou, Q. F.;Zhang, X. H.;Zhao, L. C.;Xie, Q. M.;Chen, W. G.;Chen, F.

title: Companion Animal Symposium: Microbial and Gastrointestinal Health of Dogs and Cats Review
abstract: Recent molecular studies have revealed complex communities of bacteria, fungi, archaea and viruses in the gastrointestinal tract of dogs and cats. More than 10 strains of bacteria have been identified, with Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, Proteobacteria, Fusobacteria and Actinobacteria accounting for more than 99% of all gut microbiota. Microbes act as a defensive barrier against invading pathogens, aid in digestion, support enterocytes with nutrients, and play a critical role in immune system development. Of importance to gastrointestinal health is their ability to ferment food substrates into short-chain fatty acids, primarily acetate, propionate, and butyrate. However, microbes can also have adverse effects on the health of the host. Specific pathogens (e.g. Salmonella, Campylobacter jejuni and enterotoxigenic Clostridium perfringens) have been implicated in acute and chronic gastrointestinal disorders. Changes in the composition of the small intestine microbiota, possibly leading to changes in gut permeability and digestive function, have been suggested in dogs with small intestine dysbiosis or antibiotic-responsive diarrhea. There is growing evidence that microbes play an important role in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in dogs and cats. Current theories on the development of IBD suggest a combination of environmental factors, the gut microbiota, and host genetic susceptibility. Recent studies have demonstrated a genetic susceptibility to defective bacterial clearance in boxer dogs with granulomatous colitis. Differential expression of pathogen recognition receptors (ie toll-like receptors) has been identified in dogs with chronic enteropathies. Similar to humans, microbial dysbiosis has been identified in IBD in cats and dogs. Frequently observed microbial changes are increased proteobacteria (ie Escherichia coli) with a simultaneous decrease in Firmicutes, in particular a reduced diversity of the Clostridium clusters XIVa and IV (ie Lachnospiraceae, Ruminococcaceae, Faecalibacterium spp.). This suggests that these groups of bacteria, key producers of short-chain fatty acids, may play an important role in promoting gut health.
authors: Suchodolski, J. S.

title: Viruses detected in the cecal contents of healthy pigs representing a new genetic cluster in genogroup II of the genus Norwalk-like viruses
abstract: Viruses of the genus Norwalk-like viruses (NLVs) that have been identified in humans have been classified genetically into two major genetic groups, genogroups I and II (GI and GII), which together consist of at least 14 genetic subgroups. However, a comparable classification of NLVs in other animal species is still pending. We sequenced a 2 kb region from within the RNA polymerase gene to the 3 inch end of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) from two NLV strains previously detected in the cecal contents of healthy pigs. The entire ORF2 sequences of these two NLV strains were analyzed for their genetic relationships to 15 human strains previously reported and used as references for the genetic classification of human NLV strains and two other strains; first, a recently reported human strain that appears to represent a novel genetic subgroup of GII; and the other an animal NLV strain. Analysis of a matrix showing pairwise identities and the topology of a neighbor-joining tree showed that the two pig strains could be classified into a new genetic subgroup of GII based on the amino acid sequences of the entire capsid protein. The grouping of the two pig strains was well confirmed by results of similar analyzes of the nucleotide sequences of the entire ORF2 and a 510 base region at the 3 inch end of ORF1. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Sugieda, M.;Nakajima, S.

title: Differentiation of respiratory syncytial virus subgroups with cDNA probes in a nucleic acid hybridization assay
abstract: new approach to determining the respiratory syncytial (RS) virus subgroups was developed using a simple nucleic acid filter hybridization technique. By this method, virus-infected cells are bound and fixed in a single step, and the viral RNA in the fixed cell preparation is directly characterized by its ability to hybridize to cDNA probes specific for either the A or B subgroups of the RS are virus. The subgroup-specific probes were constructed from cDNA clones encoding part of the extracellular domain of the RS virus G protein of either RS virus subgroup B (8/60) or RS virus subgroup A (A2). corresponded. The cDNA probes were 32 P labeled and used to analyze RS virus isolates collected over a three decade period. Replicate matrices from infected cell preparations were hybridized with either subgroup A or B probe. The subgroup assignments of 40 viruses tested by nucleic acid hybridization were consistent with the results of subgroup determinations based on their reactivities with monoclonal antibodies, which was previously the only method available to determine the subgroup classification of RS virus isolates. The nucleic acid hybridization assay has the advantage of providing a broad differentiation of the two subgroups based on nucleic acid homology, regardless of minor antigenic differences detected in assays using monoclonal antibodies. The nucleic acid hybridization technique provides a reliable method for characterizing the RS virus subset.
authors: Sullender, W. M.;Anderson, L. J.;Anderson, K.;Wertz, G. W.

title: Evaluation of an epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for the detection of antibodies to influenza A virus in domestic and wild birds and mammalian species
abstract: An epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (bELISA) was developed to detect antibodies against the influenza A virus in taxonomically different domestic and wild vertebrate species. Unlike previously published bELISAs, which require preparation of reagents or manipulation by the end-user, or have not been evaluated for use in mammals and birds, this assay is performed using commercially available recombinant nucleoprotein antigen and corresponding nucleoprotein-specific monoclonal antibody and has been shown to work with multiple avian and mammalian species. The effectiveness of the bELISA as a serum screening assay was compared to the agar gel immunodiffusion assay (AGID) using 251 serum samples obtained from experimentally infected mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) and raccoons (Procyon lotor). The agreement between the AGID test and the bELISA was 94.1% (95% CI = 89.9, 98.3) for raccoons and 71.2% (95% CI = 63.5, 78.9) for mallards and 82.8% (95% CI = 78.2, 87.3) overall. The bELISA was more sensitive than the AGID assay as demonstrated by the detection of antibodies to influenza A virus earlier in experimental infection studies and at higher serial dilutions. The effectiveness of the bELISA for monitoring natural influenza A virus exposure was also compared to the AGID assay using an additional 745 serum samples from six avian and six mammalian species. This bELISA provides a rapid, reliable, and inexpensive technique for large-scale monitoring of influenza A virus exposure in taxonomically diverse vertebrate species.
authors: Sullivan, H. J.;Blitvich, B. J.;VanDalen, K.;Bentler, K. T.;Franklin, A. B.;Root, J. J.

title: Viral metagenomics analysis of picobirnavirus-positive feces from children with sporadic diarrhea in China
abstract: Picobirnaviruses (PBVs) infect humans and a variety of animals and can cause diarrhea. The aim of this study was to investigate PBV infection and its association with diarrhea. Here, seven PBV-RT-PCR-positive stool samples from children with diarrhea and four stool samples from healthy children as controls were analyzed by viral metagenomics. The results showed that all seven diarrhea fecal samples contained high titers of PBV sequences, while three of the controls were negative and had a low PBV titer. Three of the diarrhea fecal samples were also positive for other viruses including anellovirus, human gyrovirus, human parechovirus and porcine stool-associated circular virus. PBV sequences from the seven patients were assembled, generating seven large contigs with the complete RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) ORF. Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid sequences of RdRp showed that the seven PBVs in the present study belonged to three different genogroups. Our data suggest that PBV may have been the cause of diarrhea in these seven children.
authors: Sun, G.;Zang, Q.;Gu, Y.;Niu, G.;Ding, C.;Zhang, P.

title: Epidemiological and genetic characteristics of porcine pseudorabies virus in mainland China between 2012 and 2017
abstract: The outbreak of pseudorabies (PR) in many Bartha-K61 vaccinated farms in China in late 2011 seriously damaged the pig industry of one of the world's largest producers of pork products. To understand the epidemiological characteristics of the pseudorabies virus (PRV) strains currently prevalent in China, a total of 16,256 samples from pig farms in 27 provinces of China suspected of being infected with PRV were analyzed for the detection of PRV between 2012 and 2017. Since the extensive use of gE-deleted PRV vaccine in China, the PRV-gE has been used to determine wild-type virus infection by PCR. Of the 16,256 samples detected, approximately 1,345 samples were positive for detection of PRV-gE, representing an average positive rate of 8.27%. Positive PRV detection rates from 2012 to 2017 were 11.92% (153/1284), 12.19% (225/1846), 6.70% (169/2523), 11.10% (269/2424), 5.57% (147/2640) and 6.90% (382/5539), respectively. To understand the genetic properties of the currently circulating PRV strains, 25 PRV strains isolated from these PRV-gE positive samples were selected for further investigation. Phylogenetic analyzes based on gB, gC and gE showed that the PRV strains dominant in China had a remarkably strong evolutionary relationship with PRVs from other countries, which could explain the observation that the Bartha-K61 vaccine did not fully protect against emerging strains could offer. Sequence alignments identified many amino acid changes within the gB, gC, and gE proteins of PRVs circulating after the outbreak in China compared to those from other countries or those prevalent in China; These changes could also affect the protective efficacy of previously used vaccines in China and may be partly related to the increased virulence of the current PRV epidemic strains in China.
authors: Sun, Y.;Liang, W.;Liu, Q.;Zhao, T.;Zhu, H.;Hua, L.;Peng, Z.;Tang, X.;Stratton, C. W.;Zhou, D.;Tian, Y.;Chen, H.;Wu, B.

title: Novel triple reassortant H1N1 swine influenza virus in pigs in Tianjin, north China
abstract: Pigs are susceptible to both human and avian influenza viruses and have therefore been proposed as mixing vessels for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses by resorting. In this study, we report for the first time the isolation and genetic analysis of three novel triple reassortant H1N1 swine influenza viruses from pigs in Tianjin, north China. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these novel viruses contained genes from the 2009 pandemic H1N1 (PB2, PB1, PA, and NP), Eurasian pigs (HA, NA, and M), and triple reassorted pigs (NS). This indicated that the rearrangement between the 2009 H1N1, Eurasian swine influenza and triple reassortant swine influenza viruses had occurred in pigs in Tianjin and led to the generation of new viruses. In addition, three humanoid H1N1 viruses, two classical swine H1N1 viruses, and two Eurasian swine H1N1 viruses were isolated during swine influenza virus surveillance from 2009 to 2013, suggesting that multiple genetic lineages of swine H1N1 viruses exist in of the pig population circulate together in Tianjin, China. The emergence of new triple reassortant H1N1 swine influenza viruses may pose a potential threat to human health and underscores the importance of further continuous surveillance.
authors: Sun, Y. F.;Wang, X. H.;Li, X. L.;Zhang, L.;Li, H. H.;Lu, C.;Yang, C. L.;Feng, J.;Han, W.;Ren, W. K.;Tian, X. X.;Tong, G. Z.;Wen, F.;Li, Z. J.;Gong, X. Q.;Liu, X. M.;Ruan, B. Y.;Yan, M. H.;Yu, H.

title: Separate evolution of virulent Newcastle disease viruses from Mexico and Central America
abstract: In 2008, an outbreak of Newcastle disease (ND) in poultry was reported in Belize (NDV-Belize-12/08) was assessed by genomic analysis and by clinicopathological characterization in specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens. The results indicated that all three strains belong to the NDV genotype V and are virulent as judged by the intracerebral pathogenicity index and the polybasic amino acid sequence at the cleavage site of the fusion protein. In 4-week-old SPF chickens, NDV-Belize-3/08 behaved like a typical velogenic viscerotropic NDV strain and caused severe necrohaemorrhagic lesions in the lymphoid organs with systemic virus distribution. The phylogenetic analysis of several representatives of the NDV genotype V revealed that the genotype V can be divided into three subgenotypes namely Va, Vb and Vc and that all tested isolates from Belize belong to the subgenotype Vb. Furthermore, these isolates are nearly identical to a 2007 isolate from Honduras and appear to have evolved separately from other contemporary viruses circulating in Mexico, merging into a new clade within the NDV subgenotype Vb. Copyright © 2014, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Susta, L.;Hamal, K. R.;Miller, P. J.;Cardenas-Garcia, S.;Brown, C. C.;Pedersen, J. C.;Gongora, V.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Pigs as a possible source of transmission of hepatitis E virus to humans in Thailand
abstract: This report describes a study demonstrating swine-to-human transmission of HEV in Thailand using molecular genetic analysis. Viruses recovered from Thai patients were found to be closely related to genotype 3 and swine hepatitis E virus in Thailand. Based on the analysis of a 302 bp ORF2 fragment, the strains examined belong to subgroup 3e and are closely related to European strains. Based on the results obtained, pigs are suspected to be a source of HEV transmission to humans in Thailand. © 2010 Springer Verlag.
authors: Suwannakarn, K.;Tongmee, C.;Theamboonlers, A.;Komolmit, P.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Efficacy of an inactivated influenza vaccine prepared from A/duck/Mongolia/245/2015 (H10N3) against H10 influenza virus infection in a mouse model
abstract: The H10N8 influenza virus became a public health threat when cases of fatal infections were recorded in China in 2013 and 2014. Therefore, the genetic and antigenic characterization of H10 influenza viruses and the development of an appropriate vaccine are essential to prepare for a future pandemic caused by H10 influenza viruses. However, current information on these properties of H10 influenza viruses circulating in birds is limited. In this study, genetic analysis of H10 influenza viruses revealed that the viruses recently circulating in wild birds in East Asia are genetically close to human H10N8 influenza viruses. In addition, the antigenicity of the H10 influenza viruses was stable among the viruses circulating in birds. An inactivated vaccine genetically and antigenically similar to human H10 influenza viruses was prepared from A/duck/Mongolia/245/2015 (H10N3). The vaccine induced sufficient neutralizing antibodies against homologous and heterologous viruses in mice. The inactivated vaccine induced sufficient protective immunity to reduce the effects of challenge with A/Duck/Hokkaido/W87/2007 (H10N2), a pathogenic strain in mice. This study shows that the inactivated whole virus particle vaccine prepared from viruses isolated from wild birds would be useful against a future pandemic influenza caused by H10 influenza viruses.
authors: Suzuki, M.;Okamatsu, M.;Fujimoto, Y.;Hiono, T.;Matsuno, K.;Kida, H.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Doppelsträngige RNA des Ibaraki-Virus
abstract: Ibaraki virus was described by Omori et al. (1969a,b) of diseased cattle with clinical signs of paralysis in the upper area of the digestive organs. This virus is an RNA virus and resembles bluetongue virus in biological (Omori et al., 1969a,b; Matsumoto et al., 1970) and physicochemical (Inaba et al., 1970) properties. The diameter of the virion is 55 nm and the capsid consists of 32 capsomeres (Saito et al., 1972; Ito et al., 1973). There is no evidence of serological cross-reaction between Ibaraki virus and bluetongue virus (Inaba et al., 1970). It is not known whether Ibaraki virus RNA is single-stranded or double-stranded; therefore the classification of Ibaraki virus is uncertain. The present paper presents evidence that this virus contains double-stranded RNA. It should therefore be classified in the same group as bluetongue virus, i.e. as orbivirus.
authors: Suzuki, Y.;Saito, Y.;Nakagawa, S.

title: Past, present and future of hepatitis E virus infection: zoonotic perspectives
abstract: The origin of the hepatitis E virus (HEV) is not fully understood, but it is considered an emerging zoonotic pathogen. To date, HEV has been isolated from many animal species. The family Hepeviridae consists of two genera. The Orthohepevirus genus includes four distinct species (A, B, C, and D), each with different genotypes. Within the species Orthohepevirus A, the host ranges HEV-1 and HEV-2 are restricted to humans, while genotypes 3 and 4 primarily infect a wide range of different animal species and are also zoonotic to humans.
