Previously, pig and wild boar species were thought to be the primary natural reservoir of HEV, but recently rabbits have also been identified as major carriers. In addition, the increasing number of HEV infections within the food supply chain underscores the important role of agricultural and food processing practices in limiting virus transmission. In particular, a Chinese commercial vaccine has the potential to protect humans and possibly animal reservoirs from HEV infection. This review summarizes the status of HEV infection worldwide in different animal species and outlines different routes of zoonotic transmission with reference to interspecies transmission and recent vaccine developments.
authors: Syed, S. F.;Zhao, Q.;Umer, M.;Alagawany, M.;Ujjan, I. A.;Soomro, F.;Bangulzai, N.;Baloch, A. H.;Abd El-Hack, M.;Zhou, E. M.;Arain, M. A.

title: Studies on swine enteroviruses. II. Morphology of cytopathic changes generated in porcine kidney monolayers
authors: Szent Ivanyi, T.

title: wide range of strain diversity in virulent and vaccine strains of alphaherpesviruses
abstract: Alphaherpesviruses are widespread in the human population and include herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) and 2 and varicella zoster virus (VZV). These viral pathogens cause epithelial lesions and then infect the nervous system to cause lifelong latency, reactivation, and spread. A related veterinary herpesvirus, pseudorabies (PRV), causes similar diseases in livestock, resulting in significant economic losses. Vaccines developed for VZV and PRV serve as useful models for the development of an HSV-1 vaccine. We present full genome sequence comparisons of the PRV vaccine strain Bartha and two virulent PRV isolates, Kaplan and Becker. These genomic sequences were determined by high-throughput sequencing and assembly and provide new insight into the attenuation of a mammalian alphaherpesvirus vaccine strain. We find many previously unknown coding differences between PRV Bartha and the virulent strains, including changes to the fusion proteins gH and gB and over forty other viral proteins. The variation in PRV protein sequences between strains is much closer to the values previously observed for HSV-1 than for the highly stable VZV proteome. Almost 20% of the PRV genome contains tandem short sequence repeats (SSRs), a class of nucleic acid motifs whose length variation has been implicated in changes in DNA binding site efficiency, transcriptional regulation, and protein interactions. We find SSRs throughout the herpesvirus family and provide the first global characterization of SSRs in viruses, both within and between strains. We find variations in SSR length between different isolates of PRV and HSV-1, which may provide a novel mechanism for interstrain phenotypic variation. Finally, we discovered a small number of polymorphic bases in each plaque-purified PRV strain and we characterize the effect of passage and plaque purification on these polymorphisms. These data add to the growing evidence that even plaque-purified stocks of stable DNA viruses exhibit limited sequence heterogeneity that is likely to trigger future strain evolution. © 2011 Szpara et al.
authors: Szpara, M. L.;Tafuri, Y. R.;Parsons, L.;Shamim, S. R.;Verstrepen, K. J.;Legendre, M.;Enquist, L. W.

title: A new microplate neutralization test for the typing of herpes simplex virus
abstract: As a first step to simplify the typing of the herpes simplex virus (HSV), a microplate serum neutralization test for the assessment of complement-dependent neutralizing (CRN) antibodies was established. When immunizing guinea pigs with HSV type 2, the late sera were usually better at differentiating between HSV types than hyperimmune rabbit sera, with the CRN titer against the heterologous HSV type 1 being much lower than the homologous titer. Sera from guinea pigs immunized with HSV type 1 showed approximately the same level of cross-reactivity against HSV type 2 as rabbit antisera. Guinea pig sera with minimal cross-reactivity levels were selected and their high dilution (1:160) and complement were added to serial 10-fold virus dilutions in the microplate titration of virus infectivity. A selective reduction in virus titer by each antiserum could determine the HSV type. No equivocal incident was found in a number of strains, including many fresh isolates. The typing result agreed with that obtained by a modification of the method of Yang et al. was determined based on virus titers obtained with Vero and primary chick embryo cells. Typing based on plaques in chick embryo cells sometimes failed to identify type 1 HSV.
authors: Tada, A.;Yoshino, K.

title: The bovine virus diarrhea virus 1 is divided into different subgenotypes depending on the analyzed region within the viral genome
abstract: Phylogenetic analyzes of Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) were performed based on the nucleotide sequences of the 5 inch untranslated region (5-UTR) and the E2-encoding gene. Thirty-six BVDV detected in naturally infected cattle in the northern region of Japan were classified into three genotypes, BVDV1a, BVDV1b and BVDV2, in a 5-UTR pedigree. BVDV1c was identified in a phylogenetic tree constructed from the E2-encoding gene, and viruses classified in BVDV1c were placed in BVDV1a in the 5-UTR pedigree. Furthermore, BVDV1a and BVDV1b clustered closer together in the E2 phylogenetic tree than in the 5-UTR tree. These results suggest that phylogenetic analysis of the E2 gene is more useful for identifying subgenotypes within BVDV1. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Tajima, M.

title: Molecular characterization of a novel hepatitis E virus (HEV) strain recovered from a wild boar in Japan, which differs greatly from previously recognized HEV strains
abstract: Although no consensus classification system for hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes is currently available, HEV variants (JBOAR135-Shiz09 and wbJOY_06) from wild boar (Sus scrofa leucomystax) have been tentatively classified into two new genotypes (5 and 6). Conducting a survey of HEV infections among 566 wild boar captured in Japan between January 2010 and August 2013, we found 24 boars (4.2%) with persistent HEV infections: 13 had HEV genotype 3, 10 had HEV genotype 4 and the rest The boar possessed a novel HEV variant (designated wbJNN_13). The entire wbJNN_13 genome was 7247 nucleotides excluding the poly(A) tail and differed significantly from known HEV isolates of genotypes 1 to 4 derived from human, pig, wild boar, deer, mongoose and rabbit by 22 .4-28.2%, JBOAR135-Shiz09 and wbJOY_06 by 19.6-21.9% and rat, ferret, bat and avian HEV isolates by 40.9-46.1% across the genome . Pedigrees confirmed that wbJNN_13 is distantly related to all known HEV isolates. A Simplot analysis revealed no significant recombination between the existing HEV strains. These results indicate the presence of at least three genetic lineages of putative boar-native HEV strains. Further studies to fully understand the extent of genomic heterogeneity of HEV variants infecting wild boar are warranted. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Takahashi, M.;Nishizawa, T.;Nagashima, S.;Jirintai, S.;Kawakami, M.;Sonoda, Y.;Suzuki, T.;Yamamoto, S.;Shigemoto, K.;Ashida, K.;Sato, Y.;Okamoto, H.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated in Indonesia between 2003 and 2007
abstract: The widespread distribution of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus poses a global threat to human health. Indonesia has had the highest number of human infections and deaths caused by these viruses. To understand the enzootic conditions of the viruses in Indonesia, 24 H5N1 viruses isolated from poultry from 2003 to 2007 were phylogenetically characterized. Although previous studies classified the Indonesian viruses exclusively into clades 2.1.1-2.1.3, our phylogenetic analyzes revealed a new sublineage that did not belong to any of the current clades. In addition, novel reassortant viruses that emerged between this new sublineage and other clades in Java Island in 2005-2006 were identified. H5N1 viruses were introduced multiple times from Java Island to Sulawesi, Kalimantan and Sumatra Island between 2003 and 2007, resulting in geographical spread of these viruses in Indonesia. These results identify Java Island as the epicenter of the Indonesian spread of the H5N1 virus. © 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Takano, R.;Nidom, C. A.;Kiso, M.;Muramoto, Y.;Yamada, S.;Sakai-Tagawa, Y.;Macken, C.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Agar gel precipitation line pattern and pathogenicity of infectious bursa disease viruses
abstract: Twenty-nine strains of infectious bursal disease virus could be classified into three groups by agar gel precipitation line patterns using two representative base antigens of strains F539 and G691. The precipitation line of the first group (16 strains including F539) did not fuse with that of the G691 base antigen and a spur was seen. The lineage of the second group (2 strains) did not fuse with those of either base antigen. The lineage of the third group (11 strains including G691) did not fuse with that of the F539 base antigen. Each strain of the first group was highly pathogenic to chickens and showed a mortality of 40% or more.
authors: Takase, K.;Uchimura, T.;Katsuki, N.;Yamamoto, M.

title: Novel reassortant avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in humans, South Vietnam, 2014
authors: Takayama, I.;Hieu, N. T.;Shirakura, M.;Nakauchi, M.;Fujisaki, S.;Takahashi, H.;Nagata, S.;Long, N. T.;Odagiri, T.;Tashiro, M.;Kageyama, T.

title: A thymic cell marker in mouse leukemia virus-induced rat lymphoma
abstract: specific marker for an immature population of thymus cells in the rat was demonstrated by rosette formation between thymus cells and guinea pig erythrocytes. This method was used to classify murine leukemia virus-induced rat lymphomas. Eight of nine Grobvirus-induced rat lymphoma lines originating in the thymus formed rosettes; whereas Friend, Rauscher, or Moloney virus-induced rat lymphoma lines derived from either the thymus, spleen, or mesenteric lymph nodes did not rosette. The percentage of total cells that rosettes in the gross lymphoma lines decreased with in vivo passages. If the tumor cells were subjected to trypsin treatment, then the tumor cells would form rosettes. Lymphoma lines lacking rosette-forming cells failed to form rosettes after trypsin treatment. An immunofluorescence test showed that none of the lymphoma lines induced by Gross, Friend, Rauscher or Moloney viruses carried the surface immunoglobulin characteristic of B cells. These results suggest that macrolymphomas may arise from the thymic cortex and that Friend, Rauscher, or Moloney lymphomas arise from either mature thymic cells (non-rosette forming cells) or from a subpopulation of the B cell lineage that does cannot have the surface immunoglobulin G receptor.
authors: Takeichi, N.;Suzuki, K.;Kobayashi, H.

title: Porcine influenza A viruses (IAV-S) in Vietnam from 2010 to 2015: Multiple introductions of A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses into the pig population and diversification of genetic constellations of enzootic IAV-S
abstract: Active surveillance of porcine influenza A virus (IAV-S) in 262 farms and 10 slaughterhouses in seven provinces in North and South Vietnam from 2010 to 2015 revealed 388 isolates from 32 farms; These viruses have been classified into the subtypes H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2. Whole genome sequencing followed by phylogenetic analysis showed that the isolates represented 15 genotypes, corresponding to the genetic constellation of the eight segments. All H1N1 viruses were fully A(H1N1)-pdm09 viruses, while all H1N2 and H3N2 viruses were reassortants among 5 different ancestral viruses: H1 and H3 triple reassortant (TR) IAV-S, originating before 2009 from North America originated human seasonal H1, human seasonal H3N2 and A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses. Notably, 93% of the reassorted IAV-S retained M genes derived from A(H1N1)pdm09, indicating some advantage in terms of their host adaptation. Monte Carlo analysis of Bayesian Markov chain revealed that the multiple introduction of A(H1N1)pdm09 and TR IAV-S into the Vietnamese pig population has driven the genetic diversity of the currently circulating Vietnamese IAV-S. Furthermore, our results indicate that a reassortant IAV-S with human-like H3 and N2 genes and an A(H1N1)pdm09 origin M gene probably caused a human case in Ho Chi Minh City in 2010 . Transmission to pigs as well as the co-circulation of different IAV-S have contributed to diversifying the gene constellations of IAV-S in Vietnam.
authors: Takemae, N.;Harada, M.;Nguyen, P. T.;Nguyen, T.;Nguyen, T. N.;To, T. L.;Nguyen, T. D.;Pham, V. P.;Le, V. T.;Do, H. T.;Vo, H. V.;Tin Le, Q. V.;Tran, T. M.;Nguyen, T. D.;Thai, P. D.;Nguyen, D. H.;Thi Le, A. Q.;Nguyen, D. T.;Uchida, Y.;Saito, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of a European-type genotype 3 hepatitis E virus variant obtained from a Japanese patient with autochthonous acute hepatitis E
abstract: unique European-type HEV strain (HE-JA12-0725) classifiable in subgenotype 3f was obtained from a 66-year-old Japanese female with autochthonous acute hepatitis E and its entire genomic sequence was determined and characterized. The HE-JA12-0725 strain shared the highest 92.7% identity with a Spanish pig isolate (EU723514) over the entire genome and possessed a long hypervariable region sequence of 111 amino acids, identical to the 3f strains of European origin. The patient had been eating pork liver, which he had received by home delivery in Japan, about two months before the onset of the disease. These results indicate the circulation of rare 3f-HEV strains in Japan.
authors: Takeuchi, S.;Yamazaki, Y.;Sato, K.;Takizawa, D.;Yamada, M.;Okamoto, H.

title: Evaluation methods for whole genome sequencing of avian avulavirus-1
abstract: Background: The avian avulavirus-1 (AAvV-1, formerly Newcastle Disease Virus) is responsible for the outbreak of poultry and wild bird disease. Numerous whole genome sequencing methods have been described for this virus. These methods included cloning, amplification of specific primers, shotgun PCR approaches, sequence-independent single primer amplification, and next-generation sequencing platform kits. Methods: Three methods were used to sequence 173 Israeli avian avulavirus-1 field isolates and one vaccine (VH) strain. Sequencing was performed on Proton and Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine and, to a lesser extent, Illumina MiSeq and NextSeq sequencers. Target Specific Primer (SP) and Sequence Independent Single Primer Amplification (SISPA) products sequenced via the Ion Torrent Sequencer exhibited high error rates and truncated genomes. All next generation sequencing platform sequencing kits generated high sequence fidelity and near complete genomic size. Results: A high level of mutations was observed in the intergenic regions between the avian Avulavirus-1 genes. Within genes, several regions are more mutated than the fusion region currently used for typing. Conclusions: Our results indicate that whole genome sequencing by the Ion Torrent Sequencing Kit is sufficient. However, when higher fidelity is desired, the Illumina NextSeq and Proton Torrent sequencing kits have proven preferable.
authors: Tal, S.;Ben Izhak, M.;Wachtel, C.;Wiseman, A.;Braun, T.;Yechezkel, E.;Golan, E.;Hadas, R.;Turjeman, A.;Banet-Noach, C.;Bronstein, M.;Lublin, A.;Berman, E.;Raviv, Z.;Pirak, M.;Klement, E.;Louzoun, Y.

title: Evaluation of broadband PCR electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (PCR/ESI-MS) system and virus microarrays for virus detection
abstract: Advanced nucleic acid-based technologies are powerful research tools for novel virus discovery, but need to be standardized for broader applications such as virus detection in biological products and clinical samples. We used well-characterized retrovirus stocks to assess the limit of detection (LOD) for broadband PCR using electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (PCR/ESI-MS or PLEX-ID), RT-PCR assays, and virus microarrays. The results showed that in the absence of background cellular nucleic acids, PLEX-ID and RT-PCR had a similar LOD for xenotropic murine retrovirus-related virus (XMRV; 3.12 particles per μl), while the sensitivity of virus detection was 10-fold higher was virus microarrays. When virus was spiked into a background of cellular nucleic acids, the LOD remained the same using PLEX-ID, while virus detection by RT-PCR was 10-fold less sensitive and no virus could be detected by microarrays. Expected endogenous retrovirus (ERV) sequences were detected in cell lines tested, and known species-specific viral sequences were detected in bovine serum and porcine trypsin. A follow-up strategy was developed using PCR amplification, nucleotide sequencing, and bioinformatics to show that an RD114-like retroviral sequence detected by PLEX-ID in canine cell lines (Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) and Cf2Th canine thymus) was due to defective endogenous gammaretrovirus-related sequences. © 2014 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Taliaferro, L. P.;Galvin, T. A.;Ma, H.;Shaheduzzaman, S.;Williams, D. K.;Glasner, D. R.;Khan, A. S.

title: Distribution of highly virulent infectious bursal disease virus in birds in Finland
abstract: In spring 2014, infectious bursal disease (IBD) was confirmed in a Finnish laying hen flock with clinical symptoms and increased mortality. Organ and blood samples were sent to the Finnish Food Safety Authority Evira for diagnosis. IBD virus (IBDV) has been detected in RT-PCR studies. In total, hens from six laying hen farms with increased mortality (7–10%, worst case 30%) were diagnosed with IBD in 2014. Antibodies were also detected by IBD ELISA testing in hens on two farms. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the causative agent of the 2014 IBD outbreak was a non-reassortant IBDV of the very virulent type. The representative virus strains from previous IBD outbreaks in 1978, 1987 and 1993 were also included in the analysis. The strains isolated in 2014 and 1993 were very similar, suggesting that a very virulent IBDV has been circulating in the country for over 20 years. Despite the extensive phylogenetic analysis, the definitive origin of the viruses from 2014 and earlier outbreaks remains unclear.
authors: Tammiranta, N.;Ek-Kommonen, C.;Rossow, L.;Huovilainen, A.

title: A generic assay for whole genome amplification and deep sequencing of Enterovirus A71
abstract: Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) has emerged as the leading cause of large outbreaks of severe and sometimes fatal hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in the Asia-Pacific region. EV-A71 outbreaks have been associated with (sub)genogroup switches, sometimes accompanied by recombination events. Understanding EV-A71 population dynamics is therefore crucial to understanding this emerging infection and can provide crucial information for vaccine development. Despite the public health burden of EV-A71, relatively few full genome sequences of EV-A71 are available for analysis and from limited geographic locations. The availability of an efficient method for whole genome sequencing would stimulate efforts to generate more viral sequence data. Here we report for the first time the development of a next-generation sequencing-based protocol for sequencing the entire genome of EV-A71 directly from clinical samples. We were able to sequence viruses of subgenogroup C4 and B5, while RNA was successfully amplified from culture materials of different EV-A71 subgenogroups belonging to both genogroup B and C. The nature of the genetic diversity within the host was examined in 22 clinical specimens, revealing 107 positions carrying minor variants (ranging from 0 to 15 variants per specimen). Our analysis of EV-A71 strains collected in 2013 showed that they all belonged to subgenogroup B5, representing the first report of this subgenogroup in Vietnam. In summary, we have successfully developed a next-generation sequencing-based high-throughput assay for whole genome sequencing of EV-A71 from clinical specimens.
authors: Tan, L. V.;Tuyen, N. T. K.;Thanh, T. T.;Ngan, T. T.;Van, H. M. T.;Sabanathan, S.;Van, T. T. M.;Thanh, L. T. M.;Nguyet, L. A.;Geoghegan, J. L.;Ong, K. C.;Perera, D.;Hang, V. T. T.;Ny, N. T. H.;Anh, N. T.;Ha, D. Q.;Qui, P. T.;Viet, D. C.;Tuan, H. M.;Wong, K. T.;Holmes, E. C.;Chau, N. V.;Thwaites, G.;van Doorn, H. R.

title: Virometic profiling of rodents in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China: isolation and characterization of a new strain of Wenzhou virus
authors: Tan, Z.;Yu, H.;Xu, L.;Zhao, Z.;Zhang, P.;Qu, Y.;He, B.;Tu, C.

title: Suppression of coronavirus replication by cyclophilin inhibitors
abstract: Coronaviruses infect a wide range of mammalian and avian species, causing severe disease in humans, cats, mice, and birds in the forms of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), mouse hepatitis, and avian infectious bronchitis, respectively. No effective vaccine or treatment has been developed for either the SARS coronavirus or the FIP virus, both of which cause deadly diseases. A cyclophilin inhibitor, cyclosporin A (CsA), has been reported to inhibit the replication of coronaviruses. CsA is a known immunosuppressive drug that binds to cellular cyclophilins to inhibit calcineurin, a calcium-calmodulin-activated serine/threonine-specific phosphatase. Inhibition of calcineurin blocks nuclear factor translocation of activated T cells from the cytosol to the nucleus, preventing transcription of genes encoding cytokines such as interleukin-2. Cyclophilins are peptidyl-prolyl isomerases with physiological functions that have been reported for many years to include chaperone and foldase activities. In addition, many viruses require cyclophilins for replication; these include human immunodeficiency virus, vesicular stomatitis virus and hepatitis C virus. However, the molecular mechanisms leading to suppression of viral replication differ for different viruses. This review describes the suppressive effects of CsA on coronavirus replication. © 2013 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Tanaka, Y.;Sato, Y.;Sasaki, T.

title: Characterization of Akabane virus from native bamboo rat, southern China
abstract: Identification of pathogens in 3 large-scale outbreaks of encephalitis and death in farmed bamboo rats (Rhizomys pruinosus). Routine bacterial culture and identification were performed. No significant pathogenic bacteria were isolated from the brain, heart, liver, spleen, lung or kidney of diseased bamboo rats. Using PCR-based methods, we excluded the following as pathogens: smallpox virus, herpes virus, adenovirus, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, rabies virus and Sendai virus. In addition, the homogenate of the diseased bamboo rats underwent viral metagenomic analysis, which revealed 48506 filtered viral reads annotated with Akabane virus (AKAV) with >75% nucleotide identity, indicating the presence of AKAVs in bamboo rats. Five new AKAV isolates were successfully isolated and characterized. In addition, the newly isolated AKAV isolate was used to show that it can reproduce severe encephalitic and pneumonic disease in bamboo rats and mice. The results contribute to a better understanding of AKAV epidemiology and prevention and control of Akabane diseases in China.
authors: Tang, H. B.;Chen, F. L.;Rao, G. B.;Bai, A. B.;Jiang, J. J.;Du, Y. C.;Ren, P. F.;Liu, J. F.;Qin, S. M.;Yang, L.;Wu, J. M.

title: Metagenomics to discover novel human viruses
abstract: Modern laboratory techniques to detect novel human viruses are urgently needed as physicians and epidemiologists become increasingly concerned with infectious diseases caused by new or previously unknown pathogens. There are many clinical syndromes in which viruses are suspected to play a role, but in which traditional microbiological techniques routinely fail to reveal the etiological agent. In addition, emerging viruses continue to pose challenges to human populations due to the encroachment of human settlements into animal and livestock habitats, globalization, climate change, increasing numbers of immunocompromised people, and bioterrorism. Metagenomics-based tools such as microarrays and high-throughput sequencing are ideal to address these challenges. Panviral microarrays containing representative sequences of all known viruses were used to detect novel and distantly related variants of known viruses. Sequence-based methods have also been used successfully to detect new viruses and have the potential to detect the full spectrum of viruses, including those that are present in low numbers. © 2010 Future Medicine Ltd.
authors: Tang, P.;Chiu, C.

title: Molecular evolution of porcine Japanese encephalitis virus isolates in Oita, Japan during 1980-2009
abstract: To identify patterns of genetic modification in Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) strains circulating in Oita, the complete envelope (E) gene was sequenced for 35 isolates from pigs over a 30-year period. Using nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences, the genetic variation was examined, the phylogeny estimated and the selection pressure analysed. This study showed that the major genotype (G) of JEV isolates had shifted from GIII to GI in Oita in the mid-1990s. The selection intensities acting on the Oita GIII and GI strains were found to be nearly equal. This suggests that the intensity of selection may not be the reason for such a genotype shift observed in Oita. Pairwise comparisons showed the high conservation of the E gene at the protein level. Compared to the Oita GIII strains, all Oita GI strains shared four amino acid changes at E129 (TM), E222 (AS), E327 (ST), and E366 (AS). Among all 70 JEV isolates involved in this publication, the GI strains shared only one amino acid change at E222 (AA) compared to the GIII strains. No strong evidence for positive selection was found, JEV evolution was generally subject to strong purifying selection, but an ongoing evolutionary pathway was found to lie beneath relaxed purifying selection in Oita. This study is a localized example of the molecular evolution of JEV in nature. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Tang, W. F.;Ogawa, M.;Eshita, Y.;Aono, H.;Makino, Y.

title: Isolation and characterization of H3N2 influenza A virus from turkeys
abstract: Five 34-week-old turkey breeder flocks in separate pens, each containing 2550 birds, on a single farm in Ohio experienced a decline in egg production from late January to early February 2004. Tracheal swabs (n = 60), cloacal swabs (n = 50) and convalescent sera (n = 110) from the flocks were sent to the laboratory for diagnostics. Virus isolation was attempted in specific pathogen-free embryonating chicken eggs and Vero and MDCK cells. Virus characterization was performed using agar gel immunodiffusion, hemagglutination assay, hemagglutination inhibition assay, virus neutralization assay, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, sequencing, and phylogenetic analysis. A presumptive influenza virus was successfully propagated and isolated at the first passage in MDCK cells, but initially not in Vero cells or specific pathogen-free chick embryos. After two passages in MDCK cells, the isolate could be propagated in specifically pathogen-free chicken embryos. Preliminary sequence analysis of the isolated virus confirmed it to be an influenza A virus with almost 100% (235/236) identity to the swine influenza A virus matrix gene, A/Swine/Illinois/100084/01 (H1N2) , acted. However, it was not possible to subtype the virus using conventional serotyping methods. The results of the genetic characterization of the isolated virus showed that it was of the H3N2 subtype and was designated A/Turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2). Phylogenetic analysis of the eight gene segments of the virus showed that isolate A/Turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2) was most closely related to the triple reassortant H3N2 swine viruses [A/Swine/WI/14094/99 (H3N2) ] , which has been circulating among swine in the United States since 1998 and contains gene segments from avian, swine, and human viruses. A/Turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2) isolated from turkeys in this study was classified as a low pathogenic avian influenza A virus because it caused only a decrease in egg production with minor other clinical signs and no mortality.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lee, C. W.;Zhang, Y.;Senne, D. A.;Dearth, R.;Byrum, B.;Perez, D. R.;Suarez, D. L.;Saif, Y. M.

title: Detection and characterization of two coinfection variant strains of avian orthoreovirus (ARV) in young laying hens using next-generation sequencing (NGS)
abstract: Using next-generation sequencing (NGS) for full genomic characterization studies of the emerging field avian orthoreovirus (ARV) strains isolated in Pennsylvania poultry, we identified two co-infectious ARV variant strains from one ARV isolate, obtained from young laying hens infected with ARV. De novo assembly of the ARV reads generated 19 contigs from two different ARV variant strains corresponding to 10 genome segments of each ARV strain. The two variants shared the same M2 segment. The complete genomes of each of the two variant strains were 23,493 bp in length, and 10 dsRNA segments ranged from 1192 bp (S4) to 3958 bp (L1) and encoded 12 viral proteins. Sequence comparison of nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) sequences of all 10 genome segments revealed 58.1-100% and 51.4-100% aa identity between the two variant strains and 54.3-89.4% and 49.5-98.1% aa identity between the two variants and classic vaccine strains. Phylogenetic analysis revealed moderate to significant divergence in nt sequence between the two variants and the ARV reference strains. These results have demonstrated the first naturally occurring co-infection of two ARV variants in commercial young laying hens and provided scientific evidence that multiple ARV strains can be present simultaneously in a chicken host species.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lin, L.;Sebastian, A.;Lu, H.

title: Genomic characterization of a novel avian arthritis orthoreovirus variant by next-generation sequencing
abstract: Using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technology, we identified a divergent field variant of avian orthoreovirus (ARV) (Reo/PA/Broiler/15511/13 or PA15511) isolated from broiler chickens with viral arthritis in Pennsylvania in 2013. The complete genome of field strain PA15511 was 23,495 bp in length with 10 dsRNA segments encoding 12 viral proteins. The lengths of the genomic segments ranged from 1192 bp (S4) to 3958 bp (L1). Genome analyzes have shown that this virus differs from reference ARV strains and meets the criteria for a new or novel strain.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lu, H.

title: Genomic characterization of a turkey reovirus field strain by next-generation sequencing
abstract: The genome of a turkey arthritis reovirus (TARV) field strain (Reo/PA/Turkey/22342/13) isolated from a flock of turkeys in Pennsylvania (PA) in 2013 was sequenced using next-generation sequencing (NGS) on the sequences Illumina MiSeq platform. The genome of the field strain PA TARV was 23,496 bp long with 10 dsRNA segments encoding 12 viral proteins. The lengths of the genomic segments ranged from 1192 bp (S4) to 3959 bp (L1). The 5' and 3' conserved terminal sequences of the PA-TARV field strain were similar to the two Minnesota (MN) TARVs (MN9 and MN10) recently published and the avian orthoreovirus (ARV) reference strains. Phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequences of all 10 genome segments revealed that there was a low to significant nucleotide sequence mismatch between the PA-TARV field strain and the reference TARV and ARV strains. Analysis of the PA TARV sequence shows that this PA TARV field strain is a unique strain and differs from TARV MN9 or MN10 in the M2 segment genes and the ARV S1133 vaccine strain.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lu, H.;Sebastian, A.;Yeh, Y. T.;Praul, C. A.;Albert, I. U.;Zheng, S. Y.

title: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) open reading frames 1a and 1b jointly initiate viral negative-strand RNA synthesis
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) poses an ongoing threat to the swine industry, particularly when highly pathogenic PRRSV (HP-PRRSV) emerges. Previous studies have shown that PRRSV RNA synthesis correlates with HP PRRSV virulence. PRRSV RNA synthesis involves genomic RNA and subgenomic mRNA, and these processes require negative-strand RNA as a template. However, the mechanisms involved in PRRSV minus-strand RNA synthesis are not yet fully understood. A mini-genome system can be used to assess viral replication mechanisms and assess the effects of potential antiviral drugs on viral replicase activities. In this study, we developed a minigenome system using firefly luciferase as a reporter. Based on this system, we found that the PRRSV RNA-dependent RNA polymerase nsp9 alone was unable to activate virus negative-strand RNA synthesis. We have also shown that combinations of open reading frames 1a (ORF1a) and ORF1b are required for viral minus-strand RNA synthesis.
authors: Tang, Y. D.;Fang, Q. Q.;Liu, J. T.;Wang, T. Y.;Wang, Y.;Tao, Y.;Liu, Y. G.;Cai, X. H.

title: Combining a comprehensive analysis of off-site lambda phage integration with a CRISPR-based means to characterize downstream physiology
abstract: During its lysogenic life cycle, the phage genome is integrated into the host chromosome by site-specific recombination. In this report, we analyze lambda phage integration into non-canonical sites using next-generation sequencing and show that it generates significant genetic diversity by targeting over 300 unique sites in the Escherichia coli host genome. Furthermore, these integration events can have important phenotypic consequences for the host, including changes in cell motility and increased antibiotic resistance. Importantly, the new technologies we developed to enable this study—sequencing secondary sites using next-generation sequencing, and then selecting relevant lysogens using CRISPR (clustered regular interspaced short palindromic repeat)/Cas9-based Selection - broadly applicable to other phage bacteria IMPORTANT Bacteriophages play an important role in bacterial evolution through lysogenesis, in which the phage genome becomes integrated into the host chromosome. While phage integration generally occurs at a specific site in the host chromosome, it is known to occur at other, so-called secondary, sites as well. In this study, we developed a new experimental technology to comprehensively study secondary integration sites and discovered that phage can integrate into over 300 unique sites in the host genome, resulting in significant genetic diversity in bacteria. We further developed an assay to study the phenotypic consequences of such different integration events and found that phage integration can cause changes in evolutionarily relevant traits such as bacterial motility and an increase in antibiotic resistance. Importantly, our method is easily applicable to other phage-bacteria systems.
authors: Tanouchi, Y.;Covert, M. W.

title: A metagenomic approach to characterize temperate bacteriophage populations from patients with cystic fibrosis and bronchiectasis without cystic fibrosis
abstract: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa), usually a ground commensal, is an important opportunistic pathogen in cystic fibrosis (CF) and non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis (nCFBR). Persistent infection correlates with accelerated decline in lung function and early mortality. Horizontal DNA transfer by temperate bacteriophages can confer gene function and selective advantages on their bacterial host within the restricted environment of the lower lung. In this study, we chemically induce temperate bacteriophages from Pa clonal cultures and identify their mixed viral communities using metagenomic approaches. We compared 92 moderate phage metagenomes stratified by these clinical backgrounds (47 CF and 45 nCFBR-Pa isolates) using MG-RAST and GeneWise2. The KEGG analysis shows that the complexity of the transport of accessory genes of temperate phages increases with the duration and severity of the disease. In addition, we identify the presence of Ig-like motifs in phage structural genes associated with bacterial adhesion and carbohydrate binding, including Big_2, He_Pig, and Fn3. This study provides the first clinical support for the proposed model of bacteriophage adherence to mucus (BAM) and the evolution of phage interacting at these mucosal surfaces over time.
authors: Tariq, M. A.;Everest, F. L. C.;Cowley, L. A.;De Soyza, A. D.;Holt, G. S.;Bridge, S. H.;Perry, A.;Perry, J. D.;Bourke, S. J.;Cummings, S. P.;Lanyon, C. V.;Barr, J. J.;Smith, D. L.

title: Genetically distinct highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses in West Africa, 2015
abstract: To follow the evolution of the highly pathogenic influenza A(H5N1) virus in West Africa, we sequenced the genomes of 43 viruses collected in 2015 from poultry and wild birds in 5 countries. We found 2 co-circulating genetic groups within clade 2.3.2.1c. Mutations that could increase mammalian adaptation raise concerns about a possible risk to humans.
authors: Tassoni, L.;Fusaro, A.;Milani, A.;Lemey, P.;Awuni, J. A.;Sedor, V. B.;Dogbey, O.;Commey, A. N.;Meseko, C.;Joannis, T.;Minoungou, G. L.;Ouattara, L.;Haido, A. M.;Cisse-Aman, D.;Couacy-Hymann, E.;Dauphin, G.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Fifth Annual Meeting on Retroviruses
abstract: The Fifth Annual Meeting of the RNA Tumor Virus Group on Retrovirus was held in October 1977. Over 100 scientists from France, Belgium and Switzerland and some others from Great Britain, Italy and the United States attended this meeting. They discussed their projects and the interpretation of their results on: virus-cell interaction (cellular changes, oncornavirus and cell differentiation, endogenous viruses); morphogenesis and genetic analysis; cellular restriction to viral infection; and proviral DNA (characterization and gene expression). Some topics also related to human and bovine leukemia research.
authors: Tavitian, A.

title: The epidemiology of small ruminant plague in the Sultanate of Oman
abstract: Virological and serological evidence was obtained showing that small ruminant plague virus was widespread in Omani sheep and goats. There was no evidence of co-presence of rinderpest virus in these species. Two virus isolates were classified as Pest des petits ruminants virus because of their pathogenicity in experimental animals and their specific hybridization with nucleic acid probes. However, neutralization tests and polyacrylamide gel analysis of their nucleocapsid proteins showed that they were not identical to the highly conserved African strains of this virus.
authors: Taylor, W. P.;al Busaidy, S.;Barrett, T.

title: Virology, serology and demography of hepatitis E virus blood donors in south-east England
abstract: BACKGROUND The hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotype 3 (G3) in England comprises two main phylogenetic groups (group 1 and group 2) and can be transmitted by transfusion. Unselected screening identified 79 viremic donors; 76 participated in a follow-up study. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS Viral RNA dynamics, phylogenetics and seroconversion were characterized in the donors. Detailed demographic, travel, clinical, and lifestyle questionnaires were completed. RESULTS The majority of viremic subjects (57/79) were seronegative at the time of donation, but all seroconverted. The viremia was short-lived, with a median of 6.5 weeks to confirmed viral clearance. All infections were acquired in the UK and were G3, with group 2 virus predominating (43/54; 80%). Infection was associated with some clinical symptoms both at and after donation (8/77; 10%). Viral load and symptoms were more pronounced in group 1 infections. There was no serological evidence of reinfection. Male donors were more common (p=0.002); both male and female donors were older than comparison donors. Animal contact was unlikely to be the source of infection. Eating chicken and pork was common to all infected donors; processed pork was most commonly purchased from a particular retail chain. CONCLUSION Viremic donors represent a primary infection in older members of the community and reflect a widespread zoonosis in the UK. The two phylogenetic groups of HEV G3 show different pathogenicity and the more common group 2 appears to be less adapted to humans. There are no objective demographic criteria that can identify donors at increased risk of HEV.
authors: Tedder, R. S.;Tettmar, K. I.;Brailsford, S. R.;Said, B.;Ushiro-Lumb, I.;Kitchen, A.;Morgan, D.;Lattimore, S.;Tossell, J.;Ijaz, S.;Hewitt, P. E.

title: Increased prevalence of anellovirus in pediatric patients with fever
abstract: The Anelloviridae family consists of non-enveloped, circular, single-stranded DNA viruses. Three genera of anelloviruses are known to infect humans, namely TTV, TTMDV and TTMV. Although anelloviruses were originally thought to cause non-AG viral hepatitis, continued research to date has not shown any definitive links between anellovirus and human disease. Using high-throughput sequencing, we investigated the association between anelloviruses and fever in pediatric patients aged 2 to 36 months. We found that although anelloviruses were present in a large number of samples from both febrile and afebrile patients, they were more abundant in the plasma and nasopharynx (NP) samples from febrile patients compared to afebrile controls. Using PCR to detect each of the three anellovirus species that infect humans, we found that the anellovirus species TTV and TTMDV were more common in plasma and NP samples from febrile patients than in afebrile controls. This was not the case for the species TTMV, which was found in similar percentages of febrile and nonfebrile patient samples. Analysis of patient age showed that the percentage of plasma and NP samples containing anellovirus increased with age until patients reached 19 to 24 months of age, after which the percentage of anellovirus-positive patient samples fell. This trend was striking for TTV and TTMDV and very moderate for TTMV in both plasma and NP samples. Finally, as the temperature of febrile patients increased, so did the frequency of TTV and TTMDV detection. Again, TTMV was equally present in febrile and nonfebrile patient samples. Taken together, these data show that the human anellovirus species TTV and TTMDV are associated with fever in children, while the closely related human anellovirus TTMV has no association with fever.
authors: TeKippe, E. M.;Wylie, K. M.;Deych, E.;Sodergren, E.;Weinstock, G.;Storch, G. A.

title: Animal viral metagenomics as a tool to detect zoonoses prior to human infection?
abstract: Many human viral infections are of zoonotic, ie wild or domesticated, origin. Several zoonotic viruses are transmitted to humans directly through contact with an animal or indirectly through the urine or feces of infected animals or the bite of a blood-sucking arthropod. If a virus is able to adapt and replicate to its new human host, human-to-human transmission can occur, potentially leading to an epidemic like the A/H1N1 flu pandemic of 2009. Therefore, predicting emerging zoonotic infections is an important public health challenge in the coming decades. The recent development of viral metagenomics, i.e. the characterization of the complete viral diversity isolated from an organism or environment using high-throughput sequencing technologies, shows promise for the surveillance of such diseases and can be performed by analyzing the viromes of selected animals and become arthropods that are in close contact with humans. In this Review, we summarize our current knowledge on viral diversity within such animals (particularly blood-sucking arthropods, wild and domestic animals) using metagenomics and present their potential future application for zoonotic and arboviral disease surveillance. © 2014 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Temmam, S.;Davoust, B.;Berenger, J. M.;Raoult, D.;Desnues, C.

title: Faustovirus-like asfarvirus in hematophagous mosquitoes and their vertebrate hosts
abstract: Faustovirus, a new giant virus related to Asfarviridae, was recently isolated in Vermamoeba vermiformis, a protist found in sewage in various geographic locations and occasionally reported in cases of human eye infections. As part of a global metagenomic analysis of viral communities existing in midges, we report here for the first time the identification and isolation of a faustovirus-like virus in hematophagous arthropods and its detection in their animal hosts. DNA virome analysis of three pools of Culicoides sp., stuffed female Culicoides imicola and unstuffed male/female C. imicola mosquitoes collected in Senegal revealed the presence of giant amoeba-infecting viruses and a plurality of sequences among them associated with the Faustovirus. Phylogenetic analyzes performed on several structural genes of Faustovirus confirmed the clustering of arthropod-borne Faustovirus with sewage-borne Faustoviruses with a clear geographical clustering of Senegalese Faustovirus strains. Transmission electron microscopy identified viral particles with morphologies and diameters compatible with Faustovirus. The presence of the infectious arthropod-borne Faustovirus was finally confirmed by the successful isolation of V. vermiformis amoebas. A global proteomic analysis of mosquitoes revealed that the blood meal came from bovine, rodent and human arthropods. Further screening of bovine sera and rodent tissue revealed that the prevalence of Faustovirus was estimated at 38% in rodents and 14% in cattle, suggesting a possible origin of Faustovirus occurrence in arthropods through ingestion of contaminated blood meal. Viral loads were highest in rodent urine and kidney samples, suggesting possible shedding of viral particles into the environment. Faustovirus DNA polymerase-related sequences were also detected in more than 9% and 11% of febrile patients and in sera from healthy Senegalese people, respectively. Our study therefore underscores the need to investigate the role of arthropods, wild and domestic animals in the life cycle of amoeba-infecting giant viruses and in particular in the environmental cycle of Faustovirus.
authors: Temmam, S.;Monteil-Bouchard, S.;Sambou, M.;Aubadie-Ladrix, M.;Azza, S.;Decloquement, P.;Bou Khalil, J. Y.;Baudoin, J. P.;Jardot, P.;Robert, C.;Scola, B. L.;Mediannikov, O. Y.;Raoult, D.;Desnues, C.

title: Genetic characterization of coronaviruses from native ferrets, Japan
abstract: We detected ferret coronaviruses in 44 (55.7%) of 79 pet ferrets tested in Japan and classified the viruses into 2 genotypes based on genotype-specific PCR. Our results show that two ferret coronaviruses that cause infectious feline peritonitis-like disease and epizootic catarrhal enteritis are enzootic among ferrets in Japan.
authors: Terada, Y.;Minami, S.;Noguchi, K.;Mahmoud, H. Y.;Shimoda, H.;Mochizuki, M.;Une, Y.;Maeda, K.

title: Avian pox virus infection in flamingos (Phoenicopterus roseus) at a zoo in Japan
abstract: Two diseased flamingos (Phoenicopterus roseus) with nodular lesions (smallpox) characteristic of smallpox virus infection were found in a zoo in Japan. Avian pox virus was isolated from the lesions (upper beak) of affected birds and genetically characterized by polymerase chain reaction, nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis. Based on phylogenetic analysis, the virus isolated from these flamingos was genetically similar to the virus isolated from pigeons, suggesting the possibility of interspecies transmission. © 2010 American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Terasaki, T.;Kaneko, M.;Mase, M.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolates obtained from Eurasian collared pigeons (Streptopelia decaocto) in Italy
abstract: Eurasian collared pigeons (Streptopelia decaocto) are believed to have originated in India and over the centuries have inhabited the Middle East and more recently Mediterranean countries such as Italy and Spain. In the present work, we report the isolation and characterization of Newcastle disease (NDV) viruses recovered from Eurasian collared pigeons in 2000-2001 and compare them to isolates recovered from feral pigeons (Columba livia ) were won. All isolates could be classified as avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV1) and belonged to the group of pigeon variants (PPMV1) since their hemagglutinating activity was inhibited by the PPMV1-specific mAb 161/617. The intracerebral pathogenicity indices ranged from 0.68 to 1.38 and all isolates contained several basic amino acids at the deduced cleavage site of the fusion protein, which is a typical feature of virulent viruses. The phylogenetic analysis of the isolates shows that 18/20 of them form a separate cluster from the isolates obtained from pigeons in the same period. These results suggest that different lineages are circulating in feral pigeon populations and that a separate lineage affects the Eurasian collared pigeon.
authors: Terregino, C.;Cattoli, G.;Grossele, B.;Bertoli, E.;Tisato, E.;Capua, I.

title: Heterologous viral expression systems in fosmid vectors increase the functional analysis potential of metagenomic libraries
abstract: The exceptional potential of metagenomic functional analysis to identify activities of interest in uncultured microorganisms has been limited by reduced gene expression in surrogate hosts. We have developed vectors and specialized E. coli strains as improved heterologous expression systems for metagenomic DNA, taking advantage of viral components that prevent transcription termination at metagenomic terminators. One of the systems uses phage T7 RNA polymerase to drive metagenomic gene expression, while the other approach uses the lambda phage transcriptional antitermination protein N to limit transcription termination. A metagenomic library was constructed and functionally screened to identify genes conferring carbenicillin resistance to E. coli. Using these enhanced expression systems resulted in a 6-fold increase in the frequency of carbenicillin-resistant clones. Subcloning and sequence analysis showed that efflux pumps in addition to β-lactamases can not only contribute to carbenicillin resistance, but are actually sufficient to mediate carbenicillin resistance.
authors: TerrÃ³n-GonzÃ¡lez, L.;Medina, C.;LimÃ³n-MortÃ©s, M. C.;Santero, E.

title: Identification of a novel aviadenovirus, termed pigeon adenovirus 2, in domestic pigeons (Columba livia)
abstract: Young pigeon disease syndrome (YPDS) mainly affects young pigeons under one year old and causes crop congestion, vomiting, diarrhoea, anorexia and occasionally death. This disease is a major health concern internationally due to its seasonal occurrence in competitions such as carrier pigeon races or ornamental bird shows. While the etiology of YPDS is still unclear, adenoviruses are often discussed as possible causative agents. Electron microscopy of faeces from a YPDS outbreak showed massive shedding of adenovirus-like particles. Whole genome sequencing of this sample identified a novel adenovirus tentatively named Pigeon Adenovirus 2 (PiAdV-2). Phylogenetic and comparative genomic analyzes indicate that PiAdV-2 belongs to a new species within the genus Aviadenovirus, for which we propose the name Pigeon Aviadenovirus B. . In a screening of other herds affected by YPDS, two variants of PiAdV-2 (variants A and B) were detected that shared 97.6% nucleotide identity of partial polymerase sequences but only 79.7% nucleotide identity of partial hexon sequences. The distribution of both PiAdV-2 variants was further investigated in faecal samples collected between 2008 and 2015 from healthy or YPDS-affected carrier pigeons from different lofts. Regardless of their state of health, about 20% of the young and 13% of the adult flocks of pigeons carried PiAdV-2 variants. The birds were free of PiAdV-1 or other avidenoviruses as determined by PCRs targeting the aviadenovirus polymerase and the PiAdV-1 fiber gene, respectively. In conclusion, there is no evidence of a correlation between YPDS outbreaks and the presence of PiAdV-2 or other avidenoviruses, arguing against a causal role in this disease complex.
authors: Teske, L.;Rubbenstroth, D.;Meixner, M.;Liere, K.;Bartels, H.;Rautenschlein, S.

title: Characterization of a genetically heterogeneous porcine rotavirus C and other viruses present in the faecal virome of a Belgian piglet without diarrhea
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are becoming more accessible, leading to an expanded interest in the composition of the porcine enteric virome. In the present study, the faecal virome of a Belgian piglet without diarrhea was determined. Although only the virome of a single piglet was analyzed, some interesting data were obtained, including the second complete genome of a group C porcine rotavirus (RVC). This Belgian strain was only distantly related to the only other fully characterized porcine RVC strain, Cowden. Its relationship to RVC strains from other host species was also analyzed and the pig strain found in our study was only distantly related to RVCs detected in humans and cows. The gene encoding the outer capsid protein VP7 belonged to the rare porcine G3 genotype, which may be serologically distinct from most other porcine RVC strains. A putative new RVC-VP6 genotype was also identified. A group A rotavirus strain also present in this stool sample contained the rare porcine genotype combination G11P[27], but was only partially characterized. Typical porcine RVA genotypes I5, A8 and T7 were found for the viral proteins VP6, NSP1 and NSP3, respectively. Interestingly, the piglet fecal virome also contained an astrovirus and an enterovirus, of which the complete genomes were characterized. The results of the current study indicate that many viruses can be present simultaneously in faecal samples from piglets without diarrhea. In this study, these viruses could not be directly associated with disease, but they could still have had a potential subclinical impact on pig growth performance. The rapid development of NGS will be a powerful tool for future diagnostics in veterinary practice. Its application will certainly lead to better insights into the relevance of many (sub)clinical enteric viral infections that may have gone unnoticed with traditional diagnostic techniques. This will stimulate the development of new and permanent prophylactic measures to improve pig health and performance.
authors: Theuns, S.;ConceiÃ§Ã£o-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.;Roukaerts, I. D. M.;Desmarets, L. M. B.;Van Ranst, M.;Nauwynck, H. J.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Nanopore sequencing as a revolutionary diagnostic tool for porcine viral enteric disease complexes identifies porcine kobuvirus as an important enteric virus
abstract: Gastrointestinal diseases in pigs are often caused by different pathogens and therefore metagenomics is a useful diagnostic tool. Here, the possibilities of nanopore sequencing for virus diagnostics were examined. First, cell culture grown porcine epidemic diarrhea virus and rotavirus A were pooled and sequenced on a MinION. Reads were detected as early as 7 seconds into sequencing, resulting in high sequencing depths (19.2 to 103.5X) at 3 hours. Next, the diarrheal feces of a week-old piglet were analyzed. Almost all reads (99%) belonged to bacteriophages that may have remodeled the piglet microbiome. Contigs were consistent with Bacteroides, Escherichia and Enterococcus phage. In addition, the porcine Kobuvirus was detected in faeces for the first time in Belgium. Suckling piglets shed kobuvirus from one week of age, but during a follow-up study. The retrospective analysis showed the wide distribution (n = 25, 56.8% positive) of genetically moderately related kobuviruses among Belgian diarrhea piglets. MinION enables rapid detection of enteric viruses. Such new methods will change diagnostics, but more extensive validations should be carried out. The true enteric pathogenicity of porcine kobuvirus should be questioned, while its subclinical importance cannot be ruled out.
authors: Theuns, S.;Vanmechelen, B.;Bernaert, Q.;Deboutte, W.;Vandenhole, M.;Beller, L.;Matthijnssens, J.;Maes, P.;Nauwynck, H. J.

title: Molecular Characterization of Positive-Strand RNA Viruses: Pestiviruses and Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV)
abstract: Molecular characterization has become an important tool for the analysis of viruses including their classification. The manuscript focuses on the molecular analysis of two members of the Pestivirus genus (Hog Cholera Virus, HCV and Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus, BVDV) and the recently discovered Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV). The first protein encoded within the single large pestivirus ORF is a nonstructural protein with autoproteolytic activity. The cleavage site between the protease and the capsid protein p14 was previously predicted, but recent experimental data indicate that processing occurs at a different site. The capsid protein is followed by a putative internal signal sequence and three glycoproteins that are part of the virion envelope. According to a new proposal for the nomenclature of the structural proteins of pestiviruses, they are designated C, E0, E1 and E2. The genomes of BVDV pairs isolated from animals suffering from mucosal diseases were analyzed. The genomes of cytopathogenic (cp) BVD viruses may contain inserts that are highly homologous to cellular sequences. In addition, cp BVDV can differ from its non-cytopathogenic (noncp) counterpart by mere rearrangement of viral sequences. The PRRS disease, which emerged a few years ago, is caused by a single-stranded RNA virus; the viral genome is positive polarity and 15 kb in size. Data on morphology, morphogenesis and virion composition already suggested that PRRSV belongs to a group of so-called arteriviruses that includes Equine Arteritis Virus (EAV), Lactate Dehydrogenase Elevating Virus (LDV) and Simian Hemorrhagic Fever Virus (SHFV). includes. This conclusion has now been confirmed by analyzing the genome organization, the gene expression strategy and by comparing derived protein sequences.
authors: Thiel, H. J.;Meyers, G.;Stark, R.;Tautz, N.;RÃ¼menapf, T.;Unger, G.;Conzelmann, K. K.

title: Case reports of hemorrhagic diathesis in calves infected with bovine diarrhea virus
abstract: Clinical and pathological findings in six fattening calves suffering from hemorrhagic diathesis are reported. Additional pathological and virological results strongly suggested mucosal disease (BVD). No virus isolation or classification was possible. The autopsy results indicated that the virus could have been cytopathogenic. The cases are discussed and compared to similar field and experimental publications dealing with thrombocytopenia in beef calves in the US. These are the first case reports published in Germany.
authors: Thiel, W.

title: Estimation of seroprevalence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) in pigs using ELISA and Western blot and comparison between human and porcine HEV sequences in Belgium
abstract: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus (HEV) is of particular concern, particularly in high-income countries where waterborne infections are less common than in developing countries. High HEV seroprevalences can be found in European pig populations. The aim of this study was to obtain prevalence data on HEV infection in pigs in Belgium and to phylogenetically compare Belgian human HEV sequences with those derived from pigs. In Belgian pigs, an ELISA screening prevalence of 73% (95% CI 68.8-77.5) was determined and part of the results were reassessed by Western Blot (WB). A receiver operating characteristic curve analysis was performed and scenarios for varying ELISA specificity relative to WB were analyzed. The seroprevalences estimated by the different scenarios ranged between 69 and 81% and are consistent with the high HEV exposure of the European pig population. Porcine HEV sequences were compared genetically to those detected in humans in Belgium and genotype 3 subtype f dominance was demonstrated in both pigs and humans. The high HEV seroprevalence in pigs and the close phylogenetic relationship between pig and human HEV sequences further support the risk of zoonotic transmission of HEV between humans and pigs. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Thiry, D.;Mauroy, A.;Saegerman, C.;Thomas, I.;Wautier, M.;Miry, C.;Czaplicki, G.;Berkvens, D.;Praet, N.;van der Poel, W.;Cariolet, R.;Brochier, B.;Thiry, E.

title: Molecular biology of bovine herpesvirus type 4
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus type 4 (BHV-4) is a ubiquitous bovine virus. Its genome is a 144 ± 6 kb double-stranded DNA consisting of a unique central piece (L-DNA) flanked at both ends by tandem repeats called polyrepetitive DNA (prDNA or H-DNA). The overall arrangement of genes was obtained by analyzing homologies between short BHV-4 DNA sequences and corresponding genes from Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and herpesvirus saimiri (HVS). Gene expression is regulated in time. The glycoprotein precursor p(gp10/gp17) is expressed as a gamma-1 polypeptide. Glycoproteins gp1, gp8, gp11 and their precursors are gamma-2 proteins. Strain variation analysis allows the definition of two types of strains based on DNA patterns: the Movar 33/63-like and the DN 599-like strains. Only the M40 strain isolated in India does not fit this classification. The genomic variations were assembled to create a dendrogram showing three degrees of divergence between BHV-4 strains or isolates. The available molecular data show that the BHV-4 genome bears a high degree of similarity to the DNA of EBV and HVS, two representative members of the Gammaherpesvirinae. BHV-4 can therefore be classified in the subfamily Gammaherpesvirinae.
authors: Thiry, E.;Bublot, M.;Dubuisson, J.;Van Bressem, M. F.;Lequarre, A. S.;Lomonte, P.;Vanderplasschen, A.;Pastoret, P. P.

title: The Origin of Lentivirus Research: Maedi Visna Virus
abstract: Maedi and Visna are contagious sheep diseases introduced to Iceland in 1933 by imported Karakul sheep. Maedi, a slowly progressive pneumonia, and the central nervous system disease Visna have been shown to be transmissible to sheep and are most likely caused by a virus. In 1957, the visna virus was isolated in tissue culture from the brain of sheep and the following year the maedi virus was isolated from the lungs of sheep. Both viruses showed similar cytopathic effects in tissue culture. Electron microscopic studies of ultrathin sections of Visna virus-infected cells revealed spherical particles 70–100 nm in diameter formed by budding from the cell membrane. Later studies showed identical particles in cultures infected with Maedi virus. This and several other comparative studies strongly suggest that maedi and visna were caused by strains of the same virus, later named maedi visna virus (MVV). Comparative studies in tissue culture suggested that MVV is related to animal RNA tumor viruses, the oncornaviruses. This was later supported by the finding that MVV is an RNA virus. A few months after reverse transcriptase was detected in oncornaviruses, the enzyme was also found in MVV virions. Thus, MVV has been classified as a retrovirus along with the oncornaviruses. However, MVV is not oncogenic in vivo or in vitro and was classified in 1975 in a subgroup of retroviruses called lentiviruses, which cause cytopathic action and slowly progressive inflammatory disease in animals in vitro, but are non-oncogenic. In the early 1980's the causative agent of AIDS was determined to be a non-oncogenic retrovirus and classified as a lentivirus. This made HIV the first human lentivirus. © 2013 Bentham Science Publishers.
authors: Thormar, H.

title: Prevalence and diversity of H9N2 avian influenza in chickens in North Vietnam, 2014
abstract: Despite their classification as avian influenza viruses of low pathogenicity (LPAIV), A/H9N2 viruses cause significant losses in poultry in many countries in Asia, the Middle East and North Africa. To date, poultry surveillance in Vietnam has focused on the detection of influenza H5 viruses and there is limited knowledge of the epidemiology and transmission dynamics of influenza H9. We determined the prevalence and diversity of influenza A virus in live bird markets (LBM) chickens from 7 North Vietnamese provinces using pooled oropharyngeal swabs collected from October to December 2014. Screening by real-time RT-PCR gave 1207/4900 (24.6%). from pooled swabs to be influenza A virus positive; the estimated overall prevalence after accounting for pooling (5 swabs/pools) was 5.8% (CI 5.4-6.0). Subtyping was performed on 468 pooled swabs with M gene Ct < 26. No influenza H7 was detected; 422 (90.1%) were H9 positive; and 22 (4.7%) were H5 positive. There was no evidence of an interaction between the detection rates of H9 and H5 viruses. We sequenced 17 whole genomes from A/H9N2, 2 from A/H5N6 and 11 partial genomes. All H9N2 viruses had internal genes clustered with genotype 57 and closely related to Chinese human isolates of A/H7N9 and A/H10N8. Using a 98% nucleotide divergence cutoff, we identified 9 distinct H9 genotypes. Phylogenetic analysis suggested multiple introduction of H9 viruses into North Vietnam rather than in situ transmission. Further investigation of H9 prevalence and diversity in other regions of Vietnam is warranted to assess H9 endemic elsewhere in the country.
authors: Thuy, D. M.;Peacock, T. P.;Bich, V. T. N.;Fabrizio, T.;Hoang, D. N.;Tho, N. D.;Diep, N. T.;Nguyen, M.;Hoa, L. N. M.;Trang, H. T. T.;Choisy, M.;Inui, K.;Newman, S.;Trung, N. V.;van Doorn, R.;To, T. L.;Iqbal, M.;Bryant, J. E.

title: Chimeric Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome viruses display full function of genotype 1 envelope proteins in the genotype 2 backbone
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is divided into two genotypes, type 1 and type 2, which share only about 60% genetic identity. Here we report viable chimeric viruses in which the coat protein genes from ORF2a to ORF5 of vSHE (type 1) have been swapped into the genetic backbone of vAPRRS (type 2). We found that the genotype 1 envelope proteins were fully functional in genotype 2 PRRSV and the rescued chimeric progeny viruses displayed robust genetic stability and similar replication properties to the parental strains in vitro. To our knowledge, this is the first study to report the substitution of entire ORFs between different porcine arterivirus genotypes. These findings pave the way to further elucidate the structure-function relationship of PRRSV envelope proteins and could allow the development of novel marker vaccines that can be used to distinguish vaccinated from infected animals. © 2010 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Tian, D.;Zheng, H.;Zhang, R.;Zhuang, J.;Yuan, S.

title: Genome sequence of a novel reassortant H3N2 avian influenza virus in southern China
abstract: The distribution and prevalence of H3 subtype influenza viruses in avian and mammalian species poses a potential threat to human and avian health. We report a complete genome sequence of a novel reassortant H3N2 avian influenza virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that HA and NA shared the highest sequence homologies with those of A/white-backed munia/Hong Kong/4519/2009 (H3N2). However, the internal genes had the highest sequence homologies with those of subtypes H6 and H7. The data provide further evidence for the existence of a natural reassortant H3N2 strain in southern China.
authors: Tian, J.;Zhang, C.;Qi, W.;Xu, C.;Huang, L.;Li, H.;Liao, M.

title: Immunodominant E2 (gp53) sequences of highly virulent bovine viral group II diarrhea viruses indicate close similarity to a subgroup of border disease viruses
abstract: The genes encoding the E2 envelope protein, which elicits virus-neutralizing antibodies, from members of the newly described group II bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDVs) have been cloned and sequenced. These BVDVs included a thrombocytopenic strain from the United States, a fetal bovine serum contamination, a strain from western Canada, and two highly virulent strains from Quebec that cause high mortality rates. The nucleotide and amino acid sequences of these E2s shared only 60-65% homology with group I BVDV E2s, but >90% homology with the E2 of a subgroup of sheep border disease viruses. The E2 gene of the NADL strain was expressed and monospecific antibodies were raised in calves and rabbits. The virus neutralizing titers of these antisera were 15- to 80-fold lower for the heterologous group of BVDVs compared to those for the homologous BVDVs.
authors: Tijssen, P.;Pellerln, C.;Lecomte, J.;Van Den Hurk, J.

title: Invasion of exotic ephemeral bovine fever virus in Taiwan in 2013-2014
abstract: Bovine ephemeral fever virus is a member of the Rhabdoviridae family, and bovine ephemeral fever has been common in cattle populations in Taiwan since 1967. During the 2013 and 2014 outbreaks, exotic bovine ephemeral fever viruses were detected by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction and nucleotide sequencing. Sequence comparison showed that the exotic viruses shared 99.0–99.4% nucleotide identities (99.4–100.0% amino acid identities) with Chinese viruses and, in contrast, 96.2–97.2% nucleotide identities (97.8–98 .6% amino acid identities) with native Taiwanese shared viruses. In addition, our phylogenetic analysis also supported that the newly invaded bovine ephemeral fever viruses were closely related to the Chinese strains. Dating back to 2013-2014, these exotic viruses have been widespread since their emergence, displacing native virus strains.
authors: Ting, L. J.;Lee, M. S.;Lin, Y. L.;Cheng, M. C.;Lee, F.

title: Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever in Tajikistan Review
abstract: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a pathogenic tick-borne disease caused by a single-stranded negative-sense RNA virus belonging to the genus Nairovirus of the family Bunyaviridae. Cases of CCHF have been recorded in Tajikistan since the disease was first treated medically in 1944. However, historical Tajik manuscripts describe the characteristics of tick-related hemorrhagic fever, suggesting that the disease in this region may have been known for many years before it was officially characterized. Here we review the historical context of CCHF in Tajikistan, much of which has been described in Russian literature over several decades, and include accounts of recent outbreaks in Tajikistan.
authors: Tishkova, F. H.;Belobrova, E. A.;Valikhodzhaeva, M.;Atkinson, B.;Hewson, R.;Mullojonova, M.

title: Targeted high-throughput 16S rRNA sequencing to characterize microbial communities during composting of livestock deaths
abstract: Aim A thorough understanding of the microbial community is necessary to ensure a significant reduction of pathogens during the composting process. Methods and Results Two biosecure, static composting systems containing cattle deaths were constructed in sub-zero temperatures. The temperature at each sampling site was measured continuously and samples were grouped as either <= 50 or >= 55 degrees C based on the temperature exposure required for effective pathogen inactivation during composting. High-throughput 454 sequencing was used to characterize the bacterial communities in each sample. Depending on the temperature, an accumulation of bacterial communities was observed. However, neither richness nor diversity differed between the temperature groups. Firmicutes was the most abundant strain in both temperature groups, but was more pronounced (63 mean point 6%) in samples >= 55 degrees C (P<0 mean point 05). Similar are members of Clostridia, Clostridium sensu stricto (3 mean dot 64%), Clostridium XI (0 mean dot 59%), UF (Clostridiaceae 1) (5 mean dot 29%) and UF (Clostridiales Incertae Sedis XI) (6 mean dot dot 20%) were prominent at >= 55 °C (P < 0, dot 05 in the middle), likely reflecting spore survival and/or anaerobic microenvironments in passively aerated compost heaps. Members of Thermobifida (3 mean dot 54%), UO (Actinomycetales) (12 mean dot 29%), and UO (Bacillales) (19 mean dot 49%) were also prominent at >= 55 degrees C (P<0 mean dot 05 ). Conclusion Considerable spatial diversity exists within bacterial communities in field-scale compost heaps. The localized temperature at the sampling site may be one of the factors contributing to this phenomenon. Significance and Impact of the Study This is the first study to describe the profile of the microbial community using high-throughput targeted 16S rRNA sequencing in passively aerated composted livestock dies.
authors: Tkachuk, V. L.;Krause, D. O.;Knox, N. C.;Hamm, A. C.;Zvomuya, F.;Ominski, K. H.;McAllister, T. A.

title: An extensive repertoire of type III secretory effectors in Escherichia coli O157 and the role of lambdoid phage in their dissemination
abstract: Several pathogenic strains of Escherichia coli use the Type III secretion to inject "effector proteins" into human cells, which then subvert eukaryotic cell biology to the bacterium's advantage. We used bioinformatics and experimental approaches to determine that the effector repertoire in the Sakai strain of enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) O157:H7 is much larger than previously thought. Homology searches led to the identification of >60 putative effector genes. Thirteen of these were judged to be probable pseudogenes, while 49 were judged to be potentially functional. A total of 39 proteins were experimentally confirmed as effectors: 31 by proteomics and 28 by translocation assays. At the protein level, the EHEC effector sequences fall into >20 families. The largest family, the NIeG family, contains 14 members in the Sakai tribe alone. EHEC also harbors functional homologues of effectors from plant pathogens (HopPtoH, HopW, AvrA) and from Shigella (OspD, OspE, OspG), as well as two other members of the Map/IpgB family. Genes encoding established or predicted effectors are found in >20 interchangeable effector loci scattered throughout the chromosome. Crucially, the majority of functional effector genes are encoded by nine interchangeable effector loci residing within lambdoid prophages. Thus, type III secretion in E. coli is linked to a vast phage "metagenome" that serves as a crucible for the evolution of pathogenicity. © 2006 by the US National Academy of Sciences.
authors: Tobe, T.;Beatson, S. A.;Taniguchi, H.;Abe, H.;Bailey, C. M.;Fivian, A.;Younis, R.;Matthews, S.;Marches, O.;Frankel, G.;Hayashi, T.;Pallen, M. J.

title: Complete genome sequence of porcine circovirus type 3 obtained from the serum of stillborn sows in Brazil
abstract: Two complete genome sequences of porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3) are reported. The genomes were obtained from pooled serum samples from sows that had just given birth to litters with different numbers of stillbirths. The two circular genomes (PCV3-BR/RS/6 and PCV3-BR/RS/8) are 2,000 nucleotides long and contain two open reading frames (ORFs) oriented in opposite directions and the putative capsid (Cap) and the replicase (Rep ) proteins. The intergenic region contains a stem loop motif as reported for other circoviruses. Rolling circle replication motifs and putative helicase domains have been identified in the Rep coding region. The degree of overall nucleotide similarity between the genomes reported here and those available at GenBank was greater than 97%. No PCV3 sequence was detected in pooled serum samples from sows that did not have stillbirths on the same herds. However, more studies are needed to confirm the link between PCV3 and the occurrence of stillbirth.
authors: Tochetto, C.;Lima, D. A.;Varela, A. P. M.;Loiko, M. R.;Paim, W. P.;Scheffer, C. M.;Herpich, J. I.;Cerva, C.;Schmitd, C.;Cibulski, S. P.;Santos, A. C.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Circoviruses: immunosuppressive threats to avian species: a review
abstract: Circoviruses are small, non-enveloped, icosahedral viruses unique among animal viruses in having circular, single-stranded DNA genomes. Their genomes are also the smallest possessed by animal viruses. The circovirus family currently includes three members, chicken anemia virus, porcine circovirus and parrot beak and feather disease virus, with pigeon circovirus classified as a tentative member. Infections with each of the four circoviruses are associated with potentially fatal diseases in which virus-induced lymphoid tissue damage and immunosuppression are common features. Experiences with other animal virus families suggest that other animal species are infected by as yet undiscovered circoviruses and that they may have similar tissue tropism and disease-causing potential. Recent reports describing the association of circovirus-like viruses with immunodeficiency diseases in geese and southern black-backed gulls suggest that circovirus infections are more common in avian species than previously thought, and raise the question of whether novel circoviruses cause infection in poultry clinical and/or subclinical diseases that may be economically significant. This review has three purposes. First, the information currently available on the classified circoviruses and viruses considered circovirus-like will be summarized. Second, it aims to alert readers to the possibility that other bird species, including farmed poultry, may be infected with novel circoviruses. Finally, possible methods for discovering new circoviruses and combating infections by such viruses are suggested.
authors: Todd, D.

title: Morphogenesis of a cytomegalovirus from an American bison affected by malignant catarrhal fever
abstract: herpesvirus isolated from multiple organs of an American bison afflicted with malignant catarrhal fever was cultured in fetal bovine spleen cells and examined by electron microscopy. The subtle structural features of the mature virion and the mode of virus morphogenesis were found to be similar to the herpesviruses, which are classified in the cytomegalovirus subgroup. The capsids were granular, hexagonal in shape, and contained pleomorphic cores in thin sections. The encasing of the capsids occurred mainly by budding on cytoplasmic membranes that appeared to be formed as distended vesicles of the Golgi apparatus; Budding on nuclear membranes has only rarely been observed. Cytoplasmic inclusions, consisting of granular threads and amorphous, electron-dense material, have been found associated with virions during the late stages of infection. The formation of cytoplasmic inclusions, morphogenesis and ultrastructure of the virus are all consistent with the classification of this virus as a cytomegalovirus.
authors: Todd, W. J.;Storz, J.

title: Distinguishing between vaccine and wild-type varicella-zoster virus genotypes by high-resolution melting analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms
abstract: Background: Analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of varicella zoster virus (VZV) has enabled differentiation between wild-type genotypes of the Oka vaccine strain (V-Oka). Objectives: Genotyping of VZV strains in Australia using high-resolution melting analysis (HRM) of SNPs in five gene targets. Study design: Extracted DNA from 78 samples from chickenpox and zoster patients was genotyped by HRM analysis of SNPs in five open reading frames (ORFs): 1 (685 G > A), 21 (33 725 C > T), 37 ( 66 288 G > A), 60 (101 464 C > A) and 62 (106 262 T > C) using a double-stranded (ds) DNA saturating dye, LC Green Plus.
