Results: For each genotype, the temperature shifts in the melting curve (Tm) differentiated the nucleotide present at that locus (P < 0.0001) with melting curve shifts between alleles ranging from 0.56 °C (ORF 37) to 3.34 °C (ORF 62). . The most frequently detected genotypes were the European type C (59%) and type B (18%) strains. This was followed by the African/Asian type A (14%) and Japanese J1 (9%), strains both widespread in the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Conclusions: HRM analysis of SNPs showed that European B and C genotypes were most prevalent in Australia, with genotypes A and J strains also present. HRM analysis using a dsDNA dye provides a useful tool for classifying varicella-zoster viruses. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Toi, C. S.;Dwyer, D. E.

title: Discovery of a novel nidovirus in cattle with respiratory diseases
abstract: The Coronaviridae family represents a diverse group of vertebrate RNA viruses, all with genomes greater than 26,000 nt. Here we report the discovery and genetic characterization of a novel virus present in cattle with respiratory disease. The phylogenetic characterization of this virus revealed that it is grouped within the subfamily Torovirinae in the family Coronaviridae. The full genome consists of only 20,261 nt and represents the smallest known coronavirus genome. We identified seven ORFs, including the canonical nidovirus ORF1a and ORF1b. Analysis of polyprotein 1ab revealed that this virus, tentatively named bovine nidovirus (BoNV), has the highest homology to the recently described python-transmitted nidoviruses and contains several conserved nidovirus motifs but not the present NendoU or O-MT domains encoded in other viruses within the Coronaviridae family. Along with its reduced genome, the atypical domain architecture indicates that this virus represents a unique lineage within the order Nidovirales.
authors: Tokarz, R.;Sameroff, S.;Hesse, R. A.;Hause, B. M.;Desai, A.;Jain, K.;Ian Lipkin, W.

title: Virome analysis of Amblyomma americanum, Dermacentor variabilis and Ixodes scapularis ticks reveals new, very different vertebrate and invertebrate viruses
authors: Tokarz, R.;Williams, S. H.;Sameroff, S.;Leon, M. S.

title: Phylogenetic study of viral isolates of porcine and human hepatitis E virus
authors: Tolari, F.;Del Chiaro, L.;Card, R.;Mazzei, M.;Bandecchi, P.;Banks, M.

title: Birds and viruses at a crossroads - surveillance of influenza A virus in Portuguese waterfowl
abstract: In recent years, extensive data on influenza A virus (IAV) in wild birds has become available in northern Europe, while information from southern Europe is more limited. Here we present an IAV surveillance study conducted in western Portugal in 2008-2009 that analyzed 1653 samples from six different waterfowl species, with most samples coming from mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos). A total of 4.4% of the examined birds were infected. Sampling results showed significant temporal variation in IAV prevalence, including a pronounced peak in predominantly juvenile birds in June, suggesting that IAVs are circulating within breeding populations in the wetlands of western Portugal. Among the viruses isolated, subtypes H10N7 and H9N2 were predominant. Phylogenetic analyzes of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase sequences of H10N7, H9N2, and H11N3 viruses showed that sequences from Portugal were closely related to viral sequences from central Europe, as well as to IAVs isolated in southern parts of Africa, reflecting the position of Portugal on the Euro-African reflects migratory bird migration. This study highlights the importance of Portugal as a migratory hub for IAV by linking breeding stationary waterfowl to birds migrating between continents, enabling IAV transmission and dispersal.
authors: Tolf, C.;Bengtsson, D.;Rodrigues, D.;Latorre-Margalef, N.;Wille, M.;Figueiredo, M. E.;Jankowska-Hjortaas, M.;Germundsson, A.;Duby, P. Y.;Lebarbenchon, C.;Gauthier-Clerc, M.;Olsen, B.;Waldenstrom, J.

title: Birds and viruses at a crossroads - surveillance of influenza A virus in Portuguese waterfowl
abstract: In recent years, extensive data on influenza A virus (IAV) in wild birds has become available in northern Europe, while information from southern Europe is more limited. Here we present an IAV surveillance study conducted in western Portugal in 2008-2009 that analyzed 1653 samples from six different waterfowl species, with most samples coming from mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos). A total of 4.4% of the examined birds were infected. Sampling results showed significant temporal variation in IAV prevalence, including a pronounced peak in predominantly juvenile birds in June, suggesting that IAVs are circulating within breeding populations in the wetlands of western Portugal. Among the viruses isolated, subtypes H10N7 and H9N2 were predominant. Phylogenetic analyzes of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase sequences of H10N7, H9N2, and H11N3 viruses showed that sequences from Portugal were closely related to viral sequences from central Europe, as well as to IAVs isolated in southern parts of Africa, reflecting the position of Portugal on the Euro-African reflects migratory bird migration. This study highlights the importance of Portugal as a migratory hub for IAV by linking breeding stationary waterfowl to birds migrating between continents, enabling IAV transmission and dispersal. © 2012 Tolf et al.
authors: Tolf, C.;Bengtsson, D.;Rodrigues, D.;Latorre-Margalef, N.;Wille, M.;Figueiredo, M. E.;Jankowska-Hjortaas, M.;Germundsson, A.;Duby, P. Y.;Lebarbenchon, C.;Gauthier-Clerc, M.;Olsen, B.;WaldenstrÃ¶m, J.

title: Development of an RT-qPCR assay for the specific detection of a specific genetic lineage of infectious bursal disease virus
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) is a major health threat to the global poultry industry, despite intensive controls including appropriate biosecurity practices and vaccination. IBDV (Avibirnavirus, Birnaviridae) is a non-enveloped virus with a bisegmented double-stranded RNA genome. The virus has traditionally been divided into classic, variant and highly virulent strains, each with different epidemiological relevance and clinical implications. Recently, a new genetic lineage with a global distribution was described and named distinct (d) IBDV. Here we report the development and validation of a reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) assay for the specific detection of dIBDVs in the global poultry industry. The assay uses a TaqMan MGB probe that hybridizes to a unique molecular signature of dIBDV. The assay successfully detected all evaluated strains belonging to the dIBDV genetic lineage and demonstrated high specificity and lack of cross-reactivity with non-dIBDVs, IBDV-negative specimens and other common avian viruses. Using serial dilutions of in vitro transcribed RNA, we obtained acceptable PCR efficiencies and detection coefficients, and relatively low intra- and inter-assay variability. The assay showed a wide dynamic range between 103 and 108 RNA copies/reaction. This rapid, specific and quantitative assay is expected to improve IBDV surveillance and control worldwide and advance our understanding of the molecular epidemiology of this economically detrimental poultry pathogen.
authors: TomÃ¡s, G.;HernÃ¡ndez, M.;Marandino, A.;Techera, C.;Grecco, S.;HernÃ¡ndez, D.;Banda, A.;Panzera, Y.;PÃ©rez, R.

title: Contagious ecthyma, rangiferine brucellosis, and lungworm infection in a musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) from the Canadian Arctic, 2014
abstract: An adult male musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) harvested on August 26, 2014 on Victoria Island, Nunavut, in the Canadian Arctic presented with proliferative dermatitis on the snout and pasterns consistent with contagious ecthyma or orf (parapoxvirus ) indicated. Histopathologic features of the lesions were consistent with this diagnosis. Orf virus DNA, phylogenetically similar to an isolate from a captive musk ox at the Minnesota Zoo, USA, was detected in the lesions by PCR using parapoxvirus primers. In addition, there was a metaphyseal abscess with a cortical fistula in the right metacarpal, from which Brucella suis biovar 4 was isolated and the identification was supported by PCR. Brucella spp. Antibodies were detected in the serum. Finally, 212 nodules were dissected from the lungs. Fecal analysis and lung examination showed co-infection with the lungworms Umingmakstrongylus pallikuukensis and Varestrongylus eleguneniensis. The zoonotic potential of orf and rangiferine brucellosis adds an important public health dimension to this case, especially given that musk oxen are a valuable food source for Arctic residents. Careful investigation of these pathogens at the population level is required as they contribute to the decline of the musk ox population and may be a cause of food insecurity in local communities. This case underscores the importance of wildlife health surveillance as a management tool to conserve wildlife populations and maintain food security in subsistence communities.
authors: Tomaselli, M.;Dalton, C.;Duignan, P. J.;Kutz, S.;van der Meer, F.;Kafle, P.;Surujballi, O.;Turcotte, C.;Checkley, S.

title: Detection and heterogeneity of herpesviruses causing Pacheco's disease in parrots
abstract: Pacheco disease (PD) is a common, often fatal, disease in parrots. We cloned a virus isolate from a parrot showing lesions characteristic of PD. Three viral clones were partially sequenced, showing that this virus was an alpha herpesvirus most closely related to gallid herpesvirus 1. Five primer sets were developed from these sequences. The primer sets were used with PCR to screen tissue or tissue culture media suspected of containing virus from 54 PD outbreaks. The primer sets amplified DNA from all but one sample. Ten amplification patterns were discovered suggesting that PD is caused by a genetically heterogeneous viral population. A single genetic variant (psittacid herpesvirus variant 1) amplified with all primer sets and was the most common virus variant (62.7%). A single set of primers (23F) amplified DNA from all positive samples, suggesting that PCR could be used as a rapid post-mortem assay for these viruses. PCR was found to be significantly more sensitive than tissue culture for the detection of psittacid herpesviruses.
authors: Tomaszewski, E.;Wilson, V. G.;Wigle, W. L.;Phalen, D. N.

title: Molecular phylogeny of the parrot acid herpesviruses causing Pacheco's disease: correlation of genotype with phenotypic expression
abstract: Fragments of 419 bp of the UL16 open reading frame from 73 parrot herpesviruses (PsHVs) from the United States and Europe were sequenced. All viruses caused Pacheco's disease and serotypes of the European isolates were known. A pedigree derived from these sequences showed that the PsHVs that cause Pacheco's disease comprised four major genotypes, with each genotype containing between two and four variants. With the exception of two viruses, the serotypes of the virus isolates could be predicted from the genotypes. Genotypes 1 and 4 corresponded to serotype 1 isolates, genotype 2 corresponded to serotype 2 isolates, and genotype 3 corresponded to serotype 3 isolates. The single serotype 4 virus assigned to genotype 4. DNA from a virus with a unique serotype could not be amplified with primers that amplified DNA from all other PsHVs, and their classification remains unknown. Viruses representing all four genotypes were found in both the United States and Europe and therefore serotypes 1, 2 and 3 were predicted to be present in the United States. Serotype 4 was represented by a single European isolate that was genetically indistinguishable from serotype 1 viruses; therefore, the presence of serotype 4 in the United States could not be predicted. It has been found that genotype 4 viruses are most commonly associated with Pacheco disease in macaws and conures and are least likely to be isolated in chick embryo fibroblasts in the United States. All four genotypes caused deaths in Amazon parrots, but genotype 4 has only been associated with Pacheco disease in Amazons in Europe. Genotypes 2, 3 and 4, but not 1, have been found in African gray parrots. Although parrots from the Pacific range make up a relatively small percentage of the total number of birds with Pacheco disease, all four genotypes have been found to cause disease in these species.
authors: Tomaszewski, E. K.;Kaleta, E. F.;Phalen, D. N.

title: Characterization of the dynamic transcriptome of a herpesvirus using long-read single molecule real-time sequencing
abstract: Herpesvirus gene expression is coordinately regulated and sequenced during productive infection. The viral genes can be divided into three distinct kinetic groups: immediate early, early and late classes. In this study, a massively parallel sequencing technique based on the PacBio Single Molecule real-time sequencing platform was used to quantify the poly(A) fraction of the pseudorabies virus (PRV) lytic transcriptome during a 12-hour production interval. cells. Other approaches, including microarray, real-time RT-PCR, and Illumina sequencing, are able to detect only aggregated transcriptional activity of specific genomic regions, but not individual herpesvirus transcripts. However, SMRT sequencing allows discrimination between transcript isoforms, including length and splice variants, and between overlapping polycistronic RNA molecules. The method of unamplified isoform sequencing (Iso-Seq) was used to analyze the kinetic properties of the lytic PRV transcripts and then to classify them accordingly. Furthermore, the present study demonstrates the general utility of long-read sequencing for time-course analysis of global gene expression in virtually any organism.
authors: TombÃ¡cz, D.;BalÃ¡zs, Z.;Csabai, Z.;MoldovÃ¡n, N.;SzÅ±cs, A.;Sharon, D.;Snyder, M.;BoldogkÅ‘i, Z.

title: Metagenomic evaluation of adventitious viruses in commercial bovine sera
abstract: Animal serum is an indispensable supplement to cell culture media. Contamination of animal serum with incoming viruses has led to extensive regulatory action and product recalls. We used metagenomic methods to detect and characterize viral contaminants in 26 bovine serum samples from 12 manufacturers. Across samples, we have detected sequences with homology to 20 viruses at depths of up to 50,000 viral reads per million. The viruses detected represented nine virus families plus four taxonomically unassigned viruses and had both RNA genomes and DNA genomes. The sequences ranged from 28% to 96% and were similar at the amino acid level to viruses in the GenBank database. The number of viruses varied from zero to 11 among samples and from 1 to 11 among suppliers, with only one product from one supplier being completely 'clean' calculated from metagenomic data (viral reads per million) exactly matched the Ct values real-time quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (rtq-PCR), with metagenomics being about as sensitive as rtq-PCR. Metagenomics is useful to detect taxonomically and genetically distinct adventitious viruses in commercial serum products and provides sensitive and quantitative information.
authors: Toohey-Kurth, K.;Sibley, S. D.;Goldberg, T. L.

title: Sequencing approach to analyze the role of quasi-species in classical swine fever
abstract: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is a positive-sense RNA virus with a high degree of genetic variability among isolates. There is also great diversity in terms of virulence, with strains covering the entire spectrum from avirulent to highly virulent. The underlying genetic determinants are far from understood. Because RNA polymerases of RNA viruses lack proofreading activity, various genome variations called haplotypes occur during replication. A set of haplotypes is referred to as a viral quasi-species. Genetic variability can be a fitness advantage by facilitating a more effective escape from the host immune response. To investigate the correlation of quasispecies composition and virulence in vivo, we analyzed next-generation sequencing data from CSFV isolates of different virulence. Virus samples from pigs infected with the highly virulent isolates "Koslov" and "Brescia" showed higher quasispecies diversity and more nucleotide variability compared to samples from pigs infected with weakly and moderately virulent isolates.
authors: Topfer, A.;Hoper, D.;Blome, S.;Beer, M.;Beerenwinkel, N.;Ruggli, N.;Leifer, I.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus: Most Slovenian isolates belong to genotypes 1d and 1f
abstract: panel of 43 bovine viral diarrheal viruses isolated from mainly persistently infected cattle on 23 Slovenian farms between 1997 and 2001 was genetically characterized. Viral RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures, reverse transcribed and amplified by PCR with primers targeting the 5-UTR and the Npro gene, followed by direct sequencing of the purified PCR products obtained for both genomic regions. The Npro sequences provided the best genetic resolution and also provided higher statistical support for the phylogenetic classification of the viruses. Thirty-eight of the Slovenian isolates belonged to genetic subtypes 1d and 1f, four were 1b and one subtype 1g. No BVDV type 2 viruses were found. This genetic prevalence was consistent with those previously reported for neighboring countries, in contrast to results reported for more distant European countries, e.g. B. France, Spain and the United Kingdom have been reported. Several virus isolates were analyzed from eight cattle herds; all but one of the isolates from each herd belonged to the same genetic group. Extended sequencing of the Npro and part of the C gene of virus isolates with identical 5-UTR sequences allowed discrimination between isolates obtained at different time points from a flock. © 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Toplak, I.;Sandvik, T.;BarliÄ-Maganja, D.;Grom, J.;Paton, D. J.

title: Biological and molecular characterization of avian influenza virus (H9N2) isolates from Iran
abstract: Three influenza A virus (H9N2) isolates obtained from three separate broiler flocks with different mortality rates were cloned twice in embryonated SPF chick eggs by limiting dilution. The biological properties of these isolates were studied in 4-week-old SPF chickens and chicken embryo fibroblast (CEF) cultures. The isolates did not cause mortality in the inoculated chickens, nor did they produce CPE in cell cultures, indicating low pathogenicity. 486 bp PCR products containing the sequences for the hemagglutinin (HA) cleavage site generated from the isolates were subjected to nucleotide sequencing. Sequence analysis of the isolates' HA region containing the cleavage site revealed a similar sequence motif (PARSSRG) but different flanking regions. Phylogenetic analysis of the deduced amino acid sequences revealed that the isolates were closely related to those previously isolated, indicating a common source. In addition, the amino acid sequences of the newer isolates were very similar to those from Saudi Arabia, Germany and Pakistan. It is postulated that the pathogenicity of Iranian isolates appears to be similar to that of other Eurasian isolates, with the exception of some Chinese isolates. It is possible that an increase in mortality under field conditions is caused by co-infection of newer isolates with bacteria such as Mycoplasma, Escherichia coli and Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale rather than the emergence of a pathogenic H9N2 subtype of the virus.
authors: Toroghi, R.;Momayez, R.

title: Emergence of the amantadine-resistant H5N1 avian influenza virus in India
abstract: This study reports the genetic characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) (subtype H5N1) isolated from poultry in West Bengal, India. We analyzed all eight genome segments of two viruses isolated from chickens in January 2010 to understand their genetic relatedness to other Indian H5N1 isolates and possible links between different outbreaks. The viruses' hemagglutinin (HA) gene contained several basic amino acids at the cleavage site, a marker for high virulence in chickens. Of most concern, the viruses had a serine to asparagine amino acid substitution at position 31 of the M2 ion channel protein, suggesting the emergence of amantadine-resistant mutants that have not previously been reported in HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in India. The amino acid lysine at position 627 of the PB2 protein illustrates the risk that the virus poses to mammals. In the phylogenetic trees, the viruses in all genes clustered within the lineage of avian isolates from India (2008-2009) and avian and human isolates from Bangladesh (2007-2009). These two viruses were most closely related to the 2008 West Bengal viruses within H5N1 virus subclass 2.2.3. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Tosh, C.;Murugkar, H. V.;Nagarajan, S.;Tripathi, S.;Katare, M.;Jain, R.;Khandia, R.;Syed, Z.;Behera, P.;Patil, S.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Dubey, S. C.

title: First Genetic Characterization of Peste des Petits Ruminants from Niger: On the Advancing Frontline of the Asian Virus Lineage
abstract: Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR) is a serious transboundary infectious disease of small ruminants. The causative agent, the PPR virus (PPRV), can be divided into four genetically distinct lineages using phylogenetic analysis. In recent decades, Line IV of PPRV has dramatically expanded its geographic range from Asia to the Middle East and Africa, where it has gradually replaced other PPRV lines. Lineages I and II are historically common in West Africa. Currently, Line II appears to dominate the region, while the last recorded occurrence of Line I was in 1994. Recent studies reported the presence of lineage IV in Nigeria, suggesting that this lineage is spreading into West Africa. In Niger, a close neighboring country to Nigeria, PPRV has never been genetically characterized despite reports of the occurrence of PPR. In this study, pathological samples from diseased goats collected in 2013 during a suspected PPR outbreak in southern Niger near the Nigerian border were compared to samples collected in a previous investigation in October 2001 in southwestern Niger. These strains were characterized by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis to identify their genetic lineage. Our results show that lineages I and II circulated together in southwestern Niger in 2001, while the strain that caused the 2013 outbreak belonged to lineage IV and is closely related to the strains identified in Nigeria. These results confirm lineage IV progression in West Africa. The process of replacement of the PPRV lineage and its implications for the epidemiology and control of the disease in this region are unclear and should be the subject of further studies in this area.
authors: Tounkara, K.;Bataille, A.;Adombi, C. M.;Maikano, I.;Djibo, G.;Settypalli, T. B. K.;Loitsch, A.;Diallo, A.;Libeau, G.

title: Genetic and biological characterization of an H1N2 avian-like swine influenza virus generated by resorting circulating H1N1 and H3N2 avian-like subtypes in Denmark
abstract: Background: Influenza A virus subtypes H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 are the most common subtypes in swine. In 2003, a rearranged H1N2 swine influenza virus (SIV) subtype emerged and spread in Denmark. In the present study, the reassortant H1N2 subtype was genetically characterized and the infection dynamics compared to a “bird-like” H1N1 virus by an experimental infection study. methods. Sequence analyzes of the H1N2 virus were performed. Two groups of pigs were vaccinated with the reassortant H1N2 virus and an "bird-like" H1N1 virus, respectively, followed by an inoculation with the opposite subtype four weeks later. Measurements of HI antibodies and acute phase proteins were performed. Nasal virus shedding and pulmonary viral load were determined by real-time RT-PCR. Results: Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the reassorted H1N2 virus contained a European "bird-like" H1 gene and a European "pig-like" N2 gene, making it genetically different from most H1N2 viruses circulating in Europe, but virus-like is reported in Sweden and Italy in 2009/2010. Sequence analysis of the internal genes revealed that the rearrangement likely occurred between circulating Danish 'bird-like' H1N1 and H3N2 SIVs. Infected pigs developed cross-reactive antibodies and increased levels of acute phase proteins after vaccination. Pigs vaccinated with H1N2 showed nasal virus shedding for seven days, peaking on day 1 post-inoculation, two days earlier than H1N1-infected pigs and at a level six-fold higher. However, the difference was not statistically significant. Pigs euthanized on day 4 post-inoculation had high viral loads in all lung lobes. After the second vaccination, nasal virus shedding was minimal. There were no clinical signs other than elevated body temperature under the experimental conditions. Conclusions: The H1N2 'bird-like' subtype, which has been established in the Danish pig population since at least 2003, is a reassortant between the circulating swine 'bird-like' H1N1 and H3N2. Danish H1N2 has a 'bird-like' H1 and is distinct from most other known H1N2 viruses in Europe and North America/Asia, which have H1 genes of human and 'classic swine' origin, respectively. However, the variant also seems to be circulating in countries such as Sweden and Italy. The infection dynamics of the newly sorted "bird-like" H1N2 are similar to the older "bird-like" H1N1 subtype. © 2013 Trebbien et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Trebbien, R.;Bragstad, K.;Larsen, L. E.;Nielsen, J.;BÃ¸tner, A.;Heegaard, P. M.;Fomsgaard, A.;Viuff, B.;Hjulsager, C. K.

title: Neuropathological survey shows underestimation of the prevalence of neuroinfectious diseases in cattle in Switzerland
abstract: Neuroinfectious diseases in livestock pose a serious threat to animal health, but their prevalence is not well documented and the etiology of the disease often remains undetected. The aim of this study was to generate basic data on the prevalence of neuroinfectious diseases in cattle in Switzerland through neuropathological surveys and to identify disease-associated pathogens. The survey was conducted over a period of one year with a representative number of brainstem samples (n = 1816) from fallen cattle. Overall, 4% (n = 73) of the animals had significant lesions, the most common types of which indicated viral (n = 27) and bacterial (n = 31) etiologies. Follow-up diagnostics using immunohistochemistry, PCR protocols, and next-generation sequencing identified infection with Listeria monocytogenes (n = 6), ovine herpesvirus 2 (n = 7), bovine astrovirus CH13 (n = 2), bovine herpesvirus 6 (n = 6). ), bovine retrovirus CH15 (n=2), posavirus 1 (n=2), and porcine astroviruses (n=2). A retrospective, questionnaire-based study found that animal owners observed clinical signs of neurological disease in about a third of the cases with lesions, which is estimated to be about 85 cases per year in the adult fallen cattle population in Switzerland. This estimate stands in stark contrast to the number of cases reported to authorities and reveals a gap in disease surveillance. Systematic neuropathological assessments and subsequent molecular testing in neurologically diseased cattle could greatly improve the efficiency of disease detection to estimate the prevalence of endemic diseases, identify new or re-emerging pathogens, and provide "early warning" of disease outbreaks.
authors: Truchet, L.;Walland, J.;Wuthrich, D.;Boujon, C. L.;Posthaus, H.;Bruggmann, R.;Schupbach-Regula, G.;Oevermann, A.;Seuberlich, T.

title: High-throughput sequencing reveals differential immune responses in the intestinal mucosa of two inbred lines affected by necrotic enteritis
abstract: We examined the necrotic enteritis (NE)-induced transcripts of immune-related genes in the intestinal mucosa of two highly inbred white Leghorn chicken lines, line 6.3 and line 7.2, which share the same MHC haplotype and show different levels of NE susceptibility using high - Throughput RNA Sequencing Technology (RNA-Seq). NE was induced by the previously described coinfection model using Eimeria maxima and Clostridium perfringens. RNA-Seq generated over 38 million sequence reads for the Marek's disease (MD)-resistant 6.3 line and over 40 million reads for the MD-prone 7.2 line. Matching these sequences to the Gallus gallus genomic database revealed the expression of over 29,900 NE-induced gene transcripts in these two lines, of which 7,841 genes were significantly upregulated and 2,919 genes were downregulated in lineage 6.3 chickens, and 6,043 genes were significantly upregulated and 2,764 Genes were downregulated in the NE-induced line 7.2 compared to their uninfected controls. Analysis of 560 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) using the Gene Ontology database revealed annotations for 246 biological processes, 215 molecular functions, and 81 cellular components. Among the 53 cytokines and 96 cytokine receptors, 15 cytokines and 29 cytokine receptors were highly expressed in lineage 6.3, while the expression of 15 cytokines and 15 cytokine receptors was higher in lineage 7.2 than in lineage 6.3 (fold change >=2, p<0.01) . In a hierarchical cluster analysis of novel mRNAs, the novel mRNA transcriptome showed higher expression at line 6.3 than line 7.2, consistent with the expression profile of immune-related target genes. In qRT-PCR and RNA-Seq analysis, all examined genes showed similar responses to NE (correlation coefficient R=0.85–0.89, p<0.01) in both lineages 6.3 and 7.2. This study is the first report describing NE-induced DEGs and novel transcriptomes using RNA-seq data from two inbred chick lines showing different degrees of NE sensitivity. These results provide important insights into our current knowledge of host-pathogen interaction and the nature of host genes that can serve as NE resistance markers for molecular breeding.
authors: Truong, A. D.;Hong, Y. H.;Lillehoj, H. S.

title: Analysis of heterogeneous populations of antihemagglutination antibodies in hyperimmune sera against influenza virus by indirect solid-phase radioimmunoassay Russian
abstract: Populations of antihemagglutinating antibodies in hyperimmune rabbit sera against influenza A/PR8/34, A/Moscow/PAN/52 and A/Swine-Iowa/15/31 viruses were assayed by solid-phase indirect competitive radioimmunoassay (SPRIA). Under the conditions of a competitive assay with immobilized virus homologous to the serum tested, not all subpopulations of cross-reacting antibodies are identified in the sera. The competition in the immobilized heterologous virus system identifies a more complete spectrum of cross-reacting antibodies. A composite analysis of the sera among both competing variants showed that each of the sera contained a heterogeneous population of antibodies that interacted to varying degrees with determinants of a panel of heterologous viruses classified according to the 1971 nomenclature as having H0, H1 and Hsw1- Hemagglutinin subtypes. The identification of cross-reacting antibodies allowed a conclusion on the existence of both antigenic determinants on the surface of hemagglutinin molecules of the studied viruses and an analysis of their variability. The pattern of changes in similar determinants when moving from viruses of one subtype to viruses of another subtype is characteristic of the drift type.
authors: Trushinskaia, G. N.;Rovnova, Z. I.;Berezina, O. N.;Grigor'eva, T. A.;Isaeva, E. I.

title: Analysis of a heterogeneous population of anti-hemagglutinating antibodies in hyperimmune rabbit sera against influenza virus by indirect solid-phase radioimmunoassay
abstract: Populations of antihemagglutinating antibodies in hyperimmune rabbit sera against influenza A/PR8/34, A/Moscow/PAN/52 and A/Swine-Iowa/15/31 viruses were assayed by solid-phase indirect competitive radioimmunoassay (SPRIA). Under the conditions of a competitive assay with immobilized virus homologous to the serum tested, not all subpopulations of cross-reacting antibodies are identified in the sera. The competition in the immobilized heterologous virus system identifies a more complete spectrum of cross-reacting antibodies. A composite analysis of the sera among both competing variants showed that each of the sera contained a heterogeneous population of antibodies that interacted to varying degrees with determinants of a panel of heterologous viruses classified according to the 1971 nomenclature as having H0, H1 and Hsw1- Hemagglutinin subtypes. The identification of cross-reacting antibodies allowed a conclusion on the existence of both antigenic determinants on the surface of hemagglutinin molecules of the studied viruses and an analysis of their variability. The pattern of changes in similar determinants when moving from viruses of one subtype to viruses of another subtype is characteristic of the drift type.
authors: Trushinskaya, G. N.;Rovnova, Z. I.;Berezina, O. N.

title: Relevant oncogenic viruses in veterinary medicine: Original pathogens and animal models for human diseases
abstract: Oncogenic viruses are important pathogens in livestock and domestic animals. These original pathogens are divided into different virus families such as Retroviridae, Papillomaviridae and Herpesviridae. In addition to a role as pathogens for their original host, animal viruses serve as valuable models for viruses that affect humans, such as the hepatitis B virus, and questions of immunity, therapy, but also basic pathophysiological mechanisms can often only be addressed in these animal systems be addressed.
authors: Truyen, U.;LÃ¶chelt, M.

title: There is nothing permanent except change. The emergence of new viral diseases
abstract: The sudden emergence of apparently new viruses with pathogenic potential is of fundamental importance in medical microbiology and a constant threat to humans and animals. The emergence of a "new" pathogen is not an isolated case, as is shown, for example, by the frequent occurrence of new influenza virus strains. Often the new strains of the virus circulate alongside the older strains in a susceptible population, but crowding out of the older strains has also been observed. In rare cases, the new viruses can cause dramatic epidemics or pandemics, such as those observed with the human immunodeficiency virus, canine parvovirus or, most recently, with the causative agent of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in the United Kingdom. Mechanisms of formation are not always clearly understood, but altered host range appears to be a common occurrence. Whether a true host range change is occurring or whether the virus has adapted to the host and replicated more efficiently is often unknown. This review article attempts to summarize the facts that are known about a variety of "new" mammalian viruses, such as the transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. Particular attention is paid to the genetic mechanisms that may have taken place and that could be responsible for their sudden appearance.
authors: Truyen, U.;Parrish, C. R.;Harder, T. C.;Kaaden, O. R.

title: Molecular epidemiological studies on the Taiwanese foot-and-mouth disease type O viruses from the 1997 epidemic
abstract: The sequence diversity of the full-length VP1 gene was directly amplified from 49 clinical specimens during an explosive foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreak in Taiwan. Taiwan type O foot-and-mouth disease virus is genetically very homogeneous, as evidenced by the minute variation of 0.2-0.9% uncovered in 20 variants. Virus variants O/HCP-0314/TW/97 and O/TCP-022/TW/97 dominated FMD outbreaks and were widespread in most affected pig farming areas. A comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences around the major neutralizable antigenic sites on the VP1 polypeptide revealed no significant antigenic variation. However, the O/CHP-158/TW/97 variant had an alternative critical residue at position 43 in antigenic site 3, possibly due to selective printing in the field. Two vaccine production strains (O1/Manisa/Turkey/69 and O1/Campos/Brazil/71) are likely to provide partial heterologous protection of swine against O-Taiwan viruses. The Type O Taiwan variants clustered in sublineage A1 of four major lineages in the phylogenetic tree. Viruses O/Hong Kong/9/94 and O/1685/Moscow/Russia/95 in sublineage A2 are closely related to variants O Taiwan. The causative agent of the 1997 epidemic is believed to have originated from a single common source of type O FMD virus common to neighboring areas. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Tsai, C. P.;Pan, C. H.;Liu, M. Y.;Lin, Y. L.;Chen, C. M.;Huang, T. S.;Cheng, I. C.;Jong, M. H.;Yang, P. C.

title: New influenza viruses H1N2 and H3N1 in Taiwanese pig herds
authors: Tsai, C. P.;Pan, M. J.

title: Emergence of a sylvatic enzootic formosan ferret-badger-associated rabies in Taiwan and the geographic separation of two phylogenetic groups of rabies viruses
abstract: Taiwan had been declared rabies-free in humans and pets for five decades, until July 2013 when three Formosan ferret badgers (FB) were surprisingly diagnosed with rabies. Since then, a variety of wild carnivores and other wildlife species have been found dead, neurologically ill, or exhibiting aggressive behavior across the island. To determine the animal species, geographic areas and environments affected, animal carcasses were examined for rabies using a direct fluorescent antibody test (FAT). The viral genomes from the brains of selected rabid animals were sequenced for the phylogeny of rabies viruses (RABV). Of a total of 1016 wild carnivores, 276/831 (33.2%) were Formosan FBs FAT positive, with occasional biting incidents in 1 dog and suspected defection in 1 house shrew. All other animals tested, including dogs, cats, bats, mice, house shrews and squirrels, were negative for rabies. The rabies was badger-associated and confined to nine counties/cities in Sylvatic environments. The phylogeny of the nucleoprotein and glycoprotein genes of 59 Formosan FB-associated RABV showed that they are clustered into two distinct groups, TWI and TWII, consistent with the geographic separation in western and eastern Taiwan provided by the Central Mountain Range and in rabies-free in the north coincides with central-southern rabies-affected regions by a river bisecting western Taiwan. The unique features of RABV's geographic and genetic segregation, sylvatic enzooticity, and FB association suggest a logical strategy for rabies control in this nation.
authors: Tsai, K. J.;Hsu, W. C.;Chuang, W. C.;Chang, J. C.;Tu, Y. C.;Tsai, H. J.;Liu, H. F.;Wang, F. I.;Lee, S. H.

title: An endogenous retrovirus of an evolutionarily young polar bear (Ursus maritimus) identified from next-generation sequence data
abstract: Transcriptome analysis of polar bear (Ursus maritimus) tissues identified sequences with similarity to porcine endogenous retroviruses (PERV). Based on these sequences, four proviral copies and 15 solo long terminal repeats (LTRs) of a newly described endogenous retrovirus were characterized from the polar bear draft genome sequence. Closely related sequences were identified by PCR analysis of brown bears (Ursus arctos) and black bears (Ursus americanus), but were absent in non-Ursinae bear species. The virus was therefore named UrsusERV. Two distinct groups of LTRs were observed, including one recombinant ERV containing one LTR belonging to each group, suggesting that recent genomic invasions by at least two UrsusERV variants have occurred. Age estimates based on proviral LTR divergence and preservation of integration sites in ursids suggest that the viral clade is only a few million years old. The most recent provirus was polar bear specific, had intact open reading frames (ORFs), and could potentially encode functional proteins. Phylogenetic analyzes of UrsusERV consensus protein sequences suggest that it is part of a retrovirus clade from pigs, gibbons and koalas. The estimates for the young age and lineage specificity of the virus suggest that UrsusERV is a recent cross-species transmission from an unknown reservoir, and places the virus group among the most recent ERVs identified in mammals.
authors: Tsangaras, K.;Mayer, J.;Alquezar-Planas, D. E.;Greenwood, A. D.

title: Identification of a novel bat papillomavirus by metagenomics
abstract: The discovery of novel viruses in animals increases our understanding of viral diversity and potential emerging zoonoses. High-Throughput Sequencing (HTS) technology enables millions or even billions of sequence reads per run, enabling comprehensive investigation of the genetic content in a sample without prior nucleic acid amplification. In this study, we collected 156 rectal swab specimens from apparently healthy bats (n=96), pigs (n=9), cattle (n=9), stray dogs (n=11), stray cats (n=11), and monkeys (n = 20) using an HTS metagenomics approach. The complete genome of a novel papillomavirus (PV), Miniopterus schreibersii papillomavirus type 1 (MscPV1), with L1 of 60% nucleotide identity to canine papillomavirus (CPV6), was isolated from a bentwing bat (M. schreibersii ) sample. It is approximately 7.5 kb in length, has a G+C content of 45.8%, and a genomic organization similar to that of other PVs. Despite the higher nucleotide identity between the MscPV1 and CPV6 genomes, a maximum likelihood phylogenetic analysis of the L1 gene sequence showed that MscPV1 and the Erethizon dorsatum papillomavirus (EdPV1) are most closely related. The estimated time of divergence of MscPV1 from the common EdPV1/MscPV1 ancestor was approximately 60.2-91.9 million years ago, inferred under strict clocks using the L1 and E1 genes. Estimates were limited by the lack of reliable calibration points from codivergence due to possible host shifts. Because the nucleotide sequence of this virus showed only limited similarity to that of related animal PVs, it would be unlikely that the conventional PCR approach using consensus primers would have detected the new virus in the sample. In contrast to the first bat papillomavirus RaPV1, MscPV1 was found in an asymptomatic bat with no obvious mucosal or skin lesions, while RaPV1 was detected in the basosquamous carcinoma of a fruit bat Rousettus aegyptiacus. We propose MscPV1 as the first member of the novel genus Dyolambda papillomavirus. © 2012 Tse et al.
authors: Tse, H.;Tsang, A. K. L.;Tsoi, H. W.;Leung, A. S. P.;Ho, C. C.;Lau, S. K. P.;Woo, P. C. Y.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Discovery and genomic characterization of a novel ovine Partetravirus and a novel bovine Partetravirus genotype
abstract: Partetravirus is a recently described group of animal parvoviruses that includes human partetravirus, bovine partetravirus, and porcine partetravirus (formerly known as human parvovirus 4, bovine hokovirus, and porcine hokovirus, respectively). In this report, we describe the discovery and genomic characterization of parttetraviruses in bovine and ovine specimens from China. These parttetraviruses were detected by means of PCR in 1.8% of the bovine liver samples, 66.7% of the sheep liver samples and 71.4% of the sheep spleen samples. One of the bovine partetraviruses detected in the present samples differs phylogenetically from previously reported bovine partetraviruses and probably represents a new genotype. The ovine partetravirus is a new partetravirus and phylogenetically most closely related to the bovine partetraviruses. The genome organization is conserved in these viruses, including the presence of a putative transmembrane protein encoded by an overlapping reading frame in ORF2. The results of the present study further support the classification of partetraviruses as a separate genus within Parvovirinae. © 2011 Tse et al.
authors: Tse, H.;Tsoi, H. W.;Teng, J. L. L.;Chen, X. C.;Liu, H.;Zhou, B.;Zheng, B. J.;Woo, P. C. Y.;Lau, S. K. P.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: A novel activation mechanism of the avian influenza virus H9N2 by furin
abstract: The H9N2 avian influenza virus is widespread in waterfowl and has become endemic in poultry in Asia and the Middle East. H9N2 influenza viruses have served as a reservoir of internal genes for other avian influenza viruses that infect humans, and several cases of human infection by H9N2 influenza viruses have suggested their pandemic potential. Fortunately, a comprehensive surveillance program allows for close monitoring of H9N2 influenza viruses worldwide and has yielded a large collection of viral sequences and phylogenetic information. Despite the large amount of sequences in different databases, very little is known about specific virus isolates and their pathogenesis. Here we characterize a low pathogenicity avian influenza virus, A/Chicken/Israel/810/2001 (H9N2) (Israel810), which is representative of influenza virus strains that have caused severe morbidity and mortality in poultry farms. We show that under certain circumstances, the Israel810 hemagglutinin (HA) can be activated by furin, a hallmark of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus. We show that Israel810 HA can be cleaved in cells with high levels of furin expression and that a mutation that eliminates a glycosylation site in HA1 allows Israel810 HA to be universally cleaved in cell culture. Pseudoparticles generated from Israel810 HA or the glycosylation mutant efficiently transduce cells. In contrast, introduction of a polybasic cleavage site into Israel810 HA results in pseudoviruses impaired for transduction. Our data point to a mechanism for an H9N2 evolutionary pathway that might allow it to acquire virulence in a different way than H5 and H7 influenza viruses. © 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Tse, L. V.;Hamilton, A. M.;Friling, T.;Whittaker, G. R.

title: Similarities and differences between the E5 oncoproteins of bovine papillomavirus type 1 and type 4: cytoskeleton, motility and invasiveness in E5-transformed bovine and mouse cells
abstract: Bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) are oncogenic viruses. In cattle, BPV-1/2 is associated with bladder cancer and BPV-4 with upper gastrointestinal cancer. BPV E5 is a small hydrophobic protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and Golgi apparatus (GA). E5 is the major transforming protein of BPVs, capable of inducing cell transformation in cultured mouse fibroblasts and, in cooperation with E7, in primary bovine cells. E5-induced cellular transformation is accompanied by activation of multiple cellular protein kinases, including growth factor receptors, and alkalinization of endosomes and GA. We have reported that BPV E5 causes swelling and fragmentation of the GA and extensive vacuolation of the cytoplasm. We now show that E5 from both BPV-1 and BPV-4 disrupts the actin cytoskeleton and focal adhesions in transformed bovine cells, where these morphological and behavioral characteristics are accompanied by hyperphosphorylation of the cellular phosphotyrosine kinase c-src. Both BPV-1 and BPV-4 E5 increase the motility of transformed mouse cells, but only BPV-1 E5 causes transformed mouse cells to penetrate a Matrigel matrix. BPV-1 transformed mouse cells but not BPV-4 transformed mouse cells have hyperphorylated c-src. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Tsirimonaki, E.;Ullah, R.;Marchetti, B.;Ashrafi, G. H.;McGarry, L.;Ozanne, B.;Campo, M. S.

title: Dynamics of envelope development in clade C SHIV-infected hog-tailed macaques during disease progression analyzed by ultra-deep pyrosequencing
abstract: Understanding the evolution of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) envelope during disease progression can provide tremendous insights for vaccine development, and simian-human immunodeficiency virus (SHIV) infection in non-human primates provides an ideal platform for such studies. A newly evolved clade C SHIV, SHIV-1157ipd3N4, capable of infecting rhesus monkeys and closely resembling primary HIV-1 in transmission and pathogenesis, was used to infect several hog-tailed macaques. One of the infected animals subsequently progressed to AIDS while one did not progress. The development of the viral envelope in the infected animals during the course of the disease was analyzed by a bioinformatic approach using ultra-deep pyrosequencing. Our results showed significant envelope changes that occurred in the progressive animal after the onset of AIDS. These envelope variations affected the length of the variable loops and loading of different envelope regions. In addition, several mutations were localized at the CD4 and CCR5 binding sites that potentially affect receptor binding affinity and viral fitness and could be selected for in late disease stages. More importantly, these envelope mutations are not random, as they have been repeatedly observed in a rhesus monkey and a human infant infected with either SHIV or HIV-1 and carrying the parental envelope of the infectious molecular clone SHIV-1157ipd3N4. In addition, similar mutations were also observed from other studies on different clades of envelopes independent of the host species. These recurring mutations in different envelopes suggest that there may be a common evolutionary pattern and selection pathway for the HIV-1 envelope during disease progression.
authors: Tso, F. Y.;Tully, D. C.;Gonzalez, S.;Quince, C.;Ho, O.;Polacino, P.;Ruprecht, R. M.;Hu, S. L.;Wood, C.

title: Genetic diversity and recombination of enterovirus G strains in Japanese pigs: high prevalence of strains carrying a papain-like cysteine protease sequence in the enterovirus G population
abstract: To investigate the genetic diversity of Enterovirus G (EV-G) in Japanese pigs, metagenomic sequencing was performed on fecal samples from pigs with and without diarrhea collected between 2014 and 2016. Fifty-nine EV-G sequences >5,000 nucleotides long were obtained. Complete VP1 sequence analysis classified Japanese EV-G isolates into G1 (17 kindreds), G2 (four kindreds), G3 (22 kindreds), G4 (two kindreds), G6 (two kindreds), G9 (six kindreds), G10 (five strains) and a new genotype (one strain). Notably, 16 G1 and one G2 strains identified in stool samples with diarrhea (23.5%; four strains) or normal (76.5%; 13 strains) possessed a papain-like cysteine protease (PL-CP)- Sequence recently found in the US and Belgium in the EV-G genome at the 2C-3A junction. This paper presents the first report of the high prevalence of viruses carrying PL-CP in the EV-G population. In addition, possible inter- and intragenotype recombination events have been found in EV-G strains, including G1-PL-CP strains. Our results may advance the understanding of the molecular epidemiology and genetic evolution of EV-Gs.
authors: Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Imai, R.;Masuda, T.;Ito, M.;Akagami, M.;Ouchi, Y.;Ishii, K.;Sakaguchi, S.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Satani, Y.;Takashima, Y.;Taniguchi, Y.;Takasu, M.;Madarame, H.;Sunaga, F.;Aoki, H.;Makino, S.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Identification of a novel bovine enterovirus possessing highly divergent amino acid sequences in the capsid protein
abstract: Background: Bovine enterovirus (BEV) belongs to the species Enterovirus E or F, genus Enterovirus and family Picornaviridae. Although numerous studies have identified BEV in the faeces of cattle with diarrhea, the pathogenicity of BEV remains unclear. Previously, we reported the detection of a novel Kobu-like virus in calf feces by metagenomic analysis. In the present study, we identified a novel BEV in diarrheal faeces collected for this survey. Complete genome sequences were determined by deep sequencing in feces. Secondary RNA structure analysis of the 5-inch untranslated region (UTR), phylogenetic tree construction, and pairwise identity analysis were performed. Results: The complete genome sequences of BEV were genetically distant from other EVs and the VP1 coding region contained new and unique amino acid sequences. We have designated this strain as BEV AN12/Bos taurus/JPN/2014 (referred to as BEV-AN12). According to genomic analysis, the genome length of this virus is 7414 nucleotides excluding the poly(A) tail, and its genome consists of a 5 inch UTR, an open reading frame encoding a single polyprotein, and a 3 inch UTR. The results of the secondary RNA structure analysis showed that BEV-AN12 had an additional trefoil structure and a small stem-loop structure in the 5-UTR, similar to other BEVs. In the pairwise identity analysis, BEV-AN12 showed high amino acid (aa) identities with Enterovirus F in the polyprotein, P2 and P3 regions (aa identity ≥ 82.4%). Therefore, BEV-AN12 is closely related to Enterovirus F. However, amino acid sequences in the capsid protein regions, especially in the VP1 coding region, showed a significantly low amino acid identity to other viruses of the genus Enterovirus (VP1-AA identity ≥ 58.6%). Furthermore, BEV-AN12 branched separately from Enterovirus E and F in pedigrees based on the aa sequences of P1 and VP1, although it was clustered with Enterovirus F in trees based on sequences in the P2 and P3 genomic region. Conclusions: We identified new BEV with highly divergent aa sequences in the VP1 coding region in Japan. According to the species definition, we proposed naming this strain "Enterovirus K", which is a new species within the Enterovirus genus. Further genomic studies are needed to understand the pathogenicity of BEVs.
authors: Tsuchiaka, S.;Rahpaya, S. S.;Otomaru, K.;Aoki, H.;Kishimoto, M.;Naoi, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Sano, K.;Okazaki-Terashima, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nagai, M.;Mizutani, T.

title: Evidence of serological diversity within group C rotaviruses
abstract: Cowden strain of group C porcine rotavirus and Shintoku strain of group C bovine rotavirus were classified as distinct serotypes by two-way cross-neutralization tests. Two patterns of neutralization against the Cowden and Shintoku strains were observed when hyperimmune or convalescent phase antisera against three uncultivable group C swine rotavirus and one group C human rotavirus were used in one-way cross-neutralization assays. Antisera against two group C swine rotaviruses and human group C rotavirus neutralized the Cowden strain at high titers but did not neutralize the Shintoku strain, suggesting that these three strains are serotypically related to the Cowden strain. The remaining antisera against a group C porcine rotavirus (HF strain) reacted with the Cowden and Shintoku group C rotaviruses in cell culture immunofluorescence assays, but did not neutralize either virus in a one-way cross-neutralization, suggesting that the HF strain belongs to a third serotype. However, confirmation of these findings requires additional analysis by mutual cross-neutralization. Our results support the existence of at least two distinct serotypes of group C rotavirus and possibly a third in animals and humans. The observed serotypic similarity between the Cowden strain and a human group C rotavirus suggests that the culturable Cowden strain and antiserum against this virus may provide important reagents for the diagnosis of group C rotavirus in humans.
authors: Tsunemitsu, H.;Jiang, B.;Yamashita, Y.;Oseto, M.;Ushijima, H.;Saif, L. J.

title: Porcine rotavirus C in pigs with gastroenteritis on Thai pig farms, 2011–2016
authors: Tuanthap, S.;Phupolphan, C.;Luengyosluechakul, S.

title: Porcine rotavirus C in pigs with gastroenteritis on Thai pig farms, 2011-2016
abstract: Pigs are economically important food animals, but highly contagious porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) and rotavirus can afflict pig herds and contribute significantly to piglet morbidity and mortality. While studies of group A rotavirus (RVA) have been conducted in Thailand, reports of group C rotavirus (RVC) are limited. Here we aimed to identify the prevalence of RVC circulating in Thai commercial pig farms. We analyzed 769 fecal and intestinal mucosal contents from pigs affected by diarrhea between 2011 and 2016 using RT-PCR specific for the PEDV spike (S), rotavirus glycoprotein (G) VP7 and protease-sensitive genes Protein (P) VP4 were. We found that 6.6% (51/769) of specimens tested positive for RVC, of which 11 specimens were co-infected with RVA and four specimens with PEDV. Three samples tested positive for all three viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP7 gene showed that the most common RVC genotype was G1, which was grouped with the prototypical RVC Cowden strain. While G6 and G9 were also common, G3 was relatively rare. Analysis of the VP4 gene revealed that the most common P type was P[5], followed by P[4], P[7] and P[1]. There were a total of six G/P combinations (G6P[5], G1P[1], G1P[4], G1P[5], G9P[4] and G9P[7]), including G6P[5]. the most predominant.
authors: Tuanthap, S.;Phupolphan, C.;Luengyosluechakul, S.;Duang-In, A.;Theamboonlers, A.;Wattanaphansak, S.;Vongpunsawad, S.;Amonsin, A.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Seroepidemiology of Bivens arm virus infections in cattle in Florida, St. Croix and Puerto Rico
abstract: Bivens arm virus (BAV) is a newly discovered rhabdovirus that infects cattle and water buffalo in Florida. The virus is classified as a member of the Tibrogargan group, members of which have only been found in Australasia so far. They are considered transmitted by Culicoides species. Bivens arm virus was first isolated from Culicoides insignis, suggesting that BAV is also transmitted by this genus. A serological study of two small groups of cattle raised in St. Croix and Puerto Rico in the Caribbean found antibodies to BAV or a closely related virus were present on both islands. A retrospective analysis of seroconversions to BAV in Florida sentinel calves compared to potential Culicoides vector populations failed to demonstrate a statistically significant correlation.
authors: Tuekam, T.;Greiner, E. C.;Gibbs, E. P. J.

title: Antigenic relationship between influenza A viruses of human and animal origin
abstract: Reciprocal antigenic relationships between 17 influenza A viruses of human, porcine, equine, and avian origin were examined by hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and strain-specific complement fixation (CF). Cross-reactions were observed between the following strains: (a) Equi/1/Prague/1/56, Avian influenza (Dutch strain) and Turkey/England/1/63 (Langham strain); (b) Equi/2/Miami/1/63, Quail/Italy/1117/65, Pheasant/Italy/647/66, Duck/England/1/62 and Turkey/Canada/1/63; (c) A2/Singapore/1/57 and Turkey/Massachussets/65; (d) Pig/S15/30 and Chicken/Scotland/1/59. Overall, the results of the HI tests performed with post-infection sera showed a lower specificity than that of HI with hyperimmune sera or that of strain-specific CF. There is clearly no sharp delineation of the antigenic subtypes of influenza A viruses, and studies on an even broader range of strains are likely to reveal a continuous spectrum of antigenic variation across the group. The authors suggest that in practice host specificity rather than antigen specificity must be used as the main criterion in classifying influenza A viruses.
authors: Tumova, B.;Pereira, H. G.

title: Gene-centric metagenomics analysis of the feline gut microbiome using 454 junior pyrosequencing
abstract: The feline gastrointestinal microbiota has a direct impact on feline and human health as a reservoir for potential zoonotic pathogens and antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains. To describe the microbial diversity of the gastrointestinal tract in cats, fecal faecal samples were characterized using both culture-dependent and culture-independent methods. However, data correlating overall microbial composition and their functions are lacking. The present descriptive study evaluated both the phylogenetic and metabolic diversity of feline gut microbiota using GS Junior Titan shotgun pyrosequencing. A total of 152,494 pyrosequencing reads (5405 assembled contigs) were generated and classified into both phylogenetic and metabolic profiles of feline gut microbiota. The Bacteroides/Chlorobi group was the predominant bacterial group with ~. 68% of the total classified variety, followed by Firmicutes (about 13%) and Proteobacteria (about 6%) respectively. Archaea, fungi, and viruses formed the smaller communities in the overall microbial diversity. Interestingly, this study also identified a number of potential enteric zoonotic pathogens (0.02–1.25%) and genes involved in antibiotic resistance (0.02–0.7%) in cat fecal materials. Based on clustering between nine gastrointestinal metagenomes from five different monogastric hosts (dog, human, mouse, cat and chicken), the feline metagenome clustered closely together with chicken at both phylogenetic and metabolic levels (>80%). Future studies are needed to provide a deeper understanding of both intrinsic and extrinsic effects such as the impact of age, genetics and dietary interventions on the composition of the feline gastrointestinal microbiome. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Tun, H. M.;Brar, M. S.;Khin, N.;Jun, L.;Hui, R. K. H.;Dowd, S. E.;Leung, F. C. C.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N8), Democratic Republic of the Congo, 2017
abstract: In 2017, the highly pathogenic bird flu A(H5N8) virus was detected in poultry in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Whole genome phylogeny showed that the virus was clustered with H5N8 clade 2.3.4.4B strains of birds in central and southern Asia. The emergence of this virus in Central Africa poses a threat to animal health and food security.
authors: Twabela, A. T.;Tshilenge, G. M.;Sakoda, Y.;Okamatsu, M.;Bushu, E.;Kone, P.;Wiersma, L.;Zamperin, G.;Drago, A.;Zecchin, B.;Monne, I.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Japanese encephalitis virus: Envelope gene-based analysis reveals a fifth genotype, geographic clustering and multiple introductions of the virus in the Indian subcontinent
abstract: We report the analysis of the full nucleotide sequence for the Indian isolate (P20778; Genbank accession number AF080251) of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). The phylogenetic tree topology obtained using thirteen complete genome sequences of JEV was reproduced with the envelope, NS1, NS3 and NS5 genes and showed considerable divergence between the two included Indian tribes. A more comprehensive analysis of JEV evolution using 107 envelope sequences available for isolates from different geographic locations worldwide revealed five distinct genotypes of JEV that exhibit a minimal 7% nucleotide divergence with high bootstrap support values. The tree also revealed a general aggregation of tribes based on geographical location, as well as multiple introductions of JEV in the Indian subcontinent. Non-synonymous nucleotide divergence rates of the envelope gene estimated that the ancestor common to all JEV genotypes arose within the last three hundred years.
authors: Uchil, P. D.;Satchidanandam, V.

title: Cotia virus studies; an unclassified smallpox virus
abstract: This paper is a report on studies of the Cotia virus; this was first isolated in Brazil in 1965 and later turned out to be a smallpox virus. Cotia virus grew in a variety of cell cultures and on the chick chorioallantois (CAM). Its growth characteristics are similar to those of other smallpoxviruses. Microscopy showed virus factories, or type B inclusions, that emerged before infectious progeny viruses could be detected. Type A inclusions appeared later, after the development of the progeny virus; these have been shown by electron microscopy to be distinct from the type A inclusions of cowpox and other smallpoxviruses and have been named Cotia bodies. Immunofluorescence staining also revealed ring structures that appeared prior to the development of Cotia bodies. Cotia virus growth in human embryonic lung (HEL) cells was sensitive to inhibitors of DNA and protein synthesis, but resistant to a concentration of rifampicin that inhibited vaccinia virus. Antigen sharing between Cotia virus and vaccinia virus has been demonstrated by gel precipitation assays and immunofluorescence staining. There was no cross-neutralization between cotiavirus and vaccinia virus, nor did anti-cotia sera neutralize representatives of other poxvirus groups.
authors: Ueda, Y.;Dumbell, K. R.;Tsuruhara, T.;Tagaya, I.

title: Use of DOP-PCR for non-specific virus detection
abstract: The detection and identification of pathogens in a specific sample without knowledge of the pathogen requires the combination of sample purification and generic signal amplification. Our universal virus detection assay combines viral capsid purification with a generic polymerase chain reaction (PCR) optimized for virus-sized genomes. As a general strategy, nucleic acid extraction is preceded by biochemical and physical purification by targeted digestion of contaminating host nucleic acids. RNA is transcribed into cDNA; cDNA and the DNA are then used as templates for degenerate oligonucleotide primer-PCR (DOP-PCR). This PCR uses a pool of related but distinct primers that combine degenerate and specific annealing conditions. PCR products can be identified by cloning and sequencing, by microarray, or by high-throughput sequencing. We have detected enveloped and non-enveloped DNA and RNA viruses using DOP-PCR in both cell cultures and clinical specimens. The assay can detect single and double stranded genomes, circular genomes, segmented genomes and linear genomes. Both large virus genomes such as herpesvirus and very small virus genomes (eg circovirus) can be sensitively detected in the same assay. The DOP-PCR assay can be used to identify viruses either directly from biological samples or from cell cultures. A strong feature of DOP-PCR is its ability to amplify viral sequences without prior knowledge of those sequences, increasing the likelihood of finding mutated or new viruses. In combination with high-throughput sequencing, DOP-PCR is a very sensitive tool that can potentially be used to characterize a specific sample. © PDA, Inc. 2011.
authors: Uhlenhaut, C.;McClenahan, S.;Krause, P. R.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of IT-227/82, an avian paramyxovirus type 1 strain of pigeon (Columba livia)
abstract: This paper describes the complete genome sequence of IT-227/82, a strain of pigeon avian paramyxovirus type-1 (PPMV-1). IT-227/82 is an antigenic variant of chicken Newcastle disease virus (NDV). The genome is 15,192 nucleotides (nt) long, similar to the previously published NDV strain ZJ1. However, it is six nt longer than the genomes of NDV strains LaSota/46 and Beaudette C. The 6 nt insertion was in the 5'' non-coding region of the nucleoprotein (NP) gene. The presence of this Six-nt insertion showed no correlation with the virulence or reservoir of the NDV strains sequenced to date. However, the genome length of 15,186 and 15,192 nt can be associated with “old” (I, II, III and IV) and “new” (V, VI, VII and VIII) NDV genotypes, respectively. Comparison of open reading frames showed that PPMV-1 strain IT-227/82 encodes the longest W protein (227 amino acids). The length of the W protein also showed remarkable differences within the genotypes and therefore cannot be regarded as a phylogenetic trait. The hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein of strain IT-227/82 consists of 571 amino acids, similar to NDV strains of genotypes IV, V and VII, while strains of genotypes I and II have longer HN proteins, 616 and 577 amino acids, respectively . The length of the hemagglutinin neuraminidase protein has phylogenetic importance. © Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2006.
authors: UjvÃ¡ri, D.

title: Identification and subgrouping of pigeon-type Newcastle disease virus strains by restriction enzyme cleavage site analysis
abstract: host variant of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV, genus Avulavirus, family Paramyxoviridae) is responsible for an autonomic disease in pigeons. It originated in the Mediterranean region in the late 1970s. Despite great genetic diversity, the vast majority of strains belong to a monophyletic group (sublineage VIb) within genotype VI of the NDV strains native to the region at the time. To date, only one monoclonal antibody test is available for specific identification of pigeon-type strains. A specific genetic assay suitable for the identification of pigeon isolates is described. Cleavage site analysis of a 1349 bp amplicon of the fusion protein gene was performed using the restriction enzymes (RE) HinfI, BstOI and RsaI. RE analysis of over 100 strains isolated between 1978 and 2002, originating from 16 countries, revealed nine RE patterns that were progressive site variants of the parental (Group VI) genotype. Despite significant site variation, existing pigeon viruses lacked a BstOI cleavage site at nucleotide 1601 shared by other NDV strains of chicken origin. RE analysis is a simple and reliable method for both identification and subgrouping of pigeon viruses. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: UjvÃ¡ri, D.;Wehmann, E.;Herczeg, J.;Lomniczi, B.

title: Genetic characterization of Bovine Virus Diarrhea (BVD) viruses: confirming the presence of BVD genotype 2 in Africa
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) has emerged as one of the economically important pathogens in cattle populations, spreading worldwide and causing a complex of disease syndromes. There are two genotypes, BVDV 1 and 2, which are differentiated based on the sequence of the 5'-noncoding region (5'-NCR) using real-time PCR. Real-time PCR is more sensitive, more specific, and less time-consuming than traditional PCR, and carries less risk of cross-contamination of samples. There is limited information on BVDV genetic subtypes in South Africa. The aim of this study was to determine the genotypes of BVDV currently circulating in South African feedlots. A total of 279 samples (219 tissue samples, 59 transtracheal aspirates and 1 blood sample) were collected from dead and live cattle with lesions or clinical signs consistent with BVDV infection. Pooled homogenates from the same animals were prepared and total RNA was extracted. A screening test was performed on the pooled specimens and positive pools were evaluated individually. A Cador BVDV type 1/2 RT-PCR kit (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany) was used for the real-time PCR assay on a LightCycler® V2. 0 real-time PCR machine (Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim, Germany). Results were read at 530 and 640 nm for BVDV 1 and 2, respectively. Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus was detected in a total of 103 specimens, including 91 tissue specimens, 1 blood specimen and 11 transtracheal aspirates. Eighty-five (82.5%) of the strains were genotype 1 and 18 (17.5%) were genotype 2. Comparing the sequencing data, genotypes 1 and 2 of the field strains did not cluster with the vaccine strains currently used in feedlots in South Africa . The present study demonstrated the presence of BVDV genotype 2 in cattle in South Africa based on the high sequence similarity between field strains of genotype 2 and strain 890 from North America. The presence of genotype 2 viruses belonging phylogenetically to different clusters and coexisting in feedlots is consistent with the possibility of multiple virus introduction. These results represent the first documented evidence for the presence of BVDV genotype 2 in African cattle. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Ularamu, H. G.;Sibeko, K. P.;Bosman, A. B.;Venter, E. H.;van Vuuren, M.

title: Comparative Clinical Sample Preparation of Viral DNA and RNA Nucleic Acids for a Commercial Deep Sequencing System (Illumina MiSeq())
abstract: Sequence-independent virus discovery methods have been widely used for whole-genome sequencing of viruses. Various protocols for viral enrichment, library preparation, and sequencing are increasingly available and at lower cost. However, no study to date has focused on optimizing the preparation of viral samples for commercial deep sequencing. Accordingly, the aim of the present study was to evaluate an in-house enzymatic protocol for double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) synthesis and also to compare the use of a commercially available kit protocol (Nextera XT, Illumina Inc, San Diego, CA, USA) and its combination with a library quantification kit (Kapa, Kapa Biosystems, Wilmington, MA, USA) for deep sequencing (Illumina Miseq). Two RNA viruses (canine distemper virus and dengue virus) and one ssDNA virus (porcine circovirus type 2) were tested with the optimized protocols. The method tested for dsDNA synthesis has shown satisfactory results and can be used in the laboratory, especially when enzymes are already available. Library preparation combining commercial kits (Nextera XT and Kapa) has resulted in more reads and genome coverage, likely due to a lack of small fragments recovering at the Nextera XT normalization step. In addition, libraries can be diluted or concentrated to increase genome coverage with Kapa quantification.
authors: Ullmann, L. S.;de Camargo Tozato, C.;Malossi, C. D.;da Cruz, T. F.;Cavalcante, R. V.;Kurissio, J. K.;Cagnini, D. Q.;Rodrigues, M. V.;Biondo, A. W.;Araujo, J. P., Jr.

title: Characterization of the complete genome sequence of velogenic Newcastle disease virus genotypes VI and VII from Japan
abstract: The complete genome sequences of three strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from vaccinated commercial laying hen flocks in Japan over a period of three decades have been characterized. All strains had a genome length of 15,192 nucleotides consisting of six genes in the order 3″-NP-P/V/WMF-HN-L-5″. The general genomic properties of the Japanese field strains were consistent with the previously characterized class II NDV, except for those belonging to early genotypes (genotypes I-IV), which have the six-nucleotide insertion at nucleotide positions 1,648-1,653 of the nucleoprotein (NP) absent. Gen. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the Japanese strains could be classified into genotypes VIc and VIIe according to the unified NDV classification system using the complete genomic sequence and the complete coding sequence of the fusion gene (F). The characterization of functional domains and neutralizing epitopes of the F and hemagglutinin neuraminidase (HN) proteins of Japanese field strains revealed a total of 31 amino acid substitutions compared to the vaccine strains Ishii and B1, which are widespread in Japan. Although the virus neutralization test (VN) showed that poor immunity of the flock due to vaccination failure or partial and uneven immunization may be the main factors involved in the mechanism of breakthrough infection of the Japanese field strains, the VN titer decreases by about two to triple the field NDV strains possessing a point mutation (E347K or E347G) at the linear epitope of the HN protein were observed compared to the vaccine strain B1 and the field strain 2440/69 lacking the point mutation. This study can be a useful reference for characterizing future outbreaks of ND in vaccinated chickens and as a genetic map for future investigations related to vaccine designs, reverse genetic systems and the development of molecular diagnostic tools to prevent future outbreaks of ND in vaccinated poultry flocks. © 2014 Springer Science+Business Media.
authors: Umali, D. V.;Ito, H.;Shirota, K.;Katoh, H.;Ito, T.

title: Molecular epidemiology of Newcastle disease virus isolates from vaccinated commercial poultry farms in non-epidemic areas of Japan
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is a highly contagious and economically devastating poultry disease. There is currently limited molecular epidemiological data on the causes of ND outbreaks in vaccinated commercial poultry farms. Knowing the genomic properties of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV), which infects commercial poultry farms despite vaccination, could provide important insights into the infection dynamics of these viruses. In addition, molecular analyzes at the subgenotype level and studies on the relationship of Japanese NDVs to other isolates from around the world are lacking. Therefore, in the present study, a molecular-epidemiological investigation was performed to characterize nine NDVs isolated from vaccinated commercial poultry flocks in five different prefectures in non-epidemic areas of Japan between 1969 and 2002. methods. Nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic studies were performed to identify the complete fusion (F) protein gene, the 3-prime end of the nucleoprotein (NP) gene, and the 5-prime end of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L) gene characterize. The sequence data was compared to 180 GenBank NDV strains representing different NDV genotypes and subgenotypes from different regions of the world at different time periods. Deduced amino acids were analyzed for homologies, recombination and mutation. Recombination events were estimated using the recombination detection program (RDP) version 3.44. Phylogenetic trees were constructed to determine evolutionary relationships between tribes. Results: Mean time of death (MDT: 48-56 h), intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI: 1.7-1.9) and deduced amino acid sequences of the proteolytic F0 cleavage site (§ssup§112§esup§RRQKR§ssup§116§ esupÂ§ ) revealed that all nine field isolates were velogen. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these isolates could be classified into two genetic lineages and three sublineages, namely genotypes VIa (lineage 4a), VId (lineage 4d), and VIId (lineage 5d). No recombination events were observed, but a point mutation in one of the neutralizing epitopes of the F protein was identified in the field isolates from Japan. Conclusions: All field isolates from vaccinated poultry in non-epidemic areas of Japan were part of much larger outbreaks in provinces and regions and in some cases on continents. In general, four ND pansoots emerged in Japan and these outbreaks were mainly characterized by the co-circulation of genetically distinct virus lines due to the involvement of infected wild birds. The point mutation identified in the field isolates from Japan may be due to escaping vaccination pressure. Identification of such a mutation may be useful for future site-directed mutagenesis to understand the dynamics of NDV infection in vaccinated chickens. © 2013 Umali et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Umali, D. V.;Ito, H.;Suzuki, T.;Shirota, K.;Katoh, H.;Ito, T.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolated from clinical cases of Newcastle disease in commercial layer farms in the Philippines
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is an economically devastating poultry disease. Limited data are currently available on the molecular characteristics of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) from the Philippines. Clinical and molecular characterizations were performed on five clinical cases of ND in vaccinated commercial layer farms from four provinces in the Philippines, namely Bulacan, Pampanga, Zamboanga del Sur and Davao Del Sur. Clinical signs observed in affected flocks were conjunctivitis, wheezing, rales, facial swelling, lethargy, greenish diarrhea, torticollis and paralysis. Disease onset ranged from 21 to 124 days with mortality rates from 15 to 61%. The gross morphologic lesions identified were the presence of serous exudates in the infraorbital cavities, hemorrhagic trachea, inflamed spleen, liver and kidneys, and petechial hemorrhages in the proventriculus and cecal tonsils. Nucleotide sequencing showed that all field strains with FO proteolytic cleavage sites of 112RRRKRz.ast;F117 and 112RRQKRz.ast;F117 patterns were velogen. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all field NDV strains belong to class II genotype VII, subgenotypes Vila, VIIIh and Vili.
