The evolutionary divergence showed that the field NDV strains were closely related (up to 99% similarity) to the newly identified subgenotypes of virulent NDVs currently emerging in Southeast Asia and the Middle East.
authors: Umali, D. V.;Lopez, A. L. M.;Torres, M. I. P.;Umandal, M. C.;Katoh, H.

title: Screening of human cell lines for viral infection using RNA-Seq data analysis
abstract: The surveillance of viral infections of cell cultures is largely neglected, although the viruses have an impact on the physiology of cells and can pose a biological hazard in terms of laboratory safety and the safety of bioactive drugs produced by cell cultures. PCR, immunological assays and enzyme activity tests are common methods for detecting viral infections. We screened more than 300 cancer cell line encyclopedia RNA sequencing datasets and 60 complete human cell line exome sequencing datasets for specific viral sequences and overall viral nucleotide and protein sequence assessments using the taxonomeric bioinformatics tool developed by IDbyDNA. The results were compared to our previous findings from virus-specific PCR analyses. Both the results obtained from the direct alignment method and from the taxonomere alignment method showed complete agreement with the PCR results: twenty cell lines were found to be infected with five virus species. Taxonomer also revealed bovine polyomavirus infection in the breast cancer cell line SK-BR-3, most likely introduced by contaminated fetal bovine serum. RNA-Seq datasets were more sensitive for virus detection, although a significant proportion of cell lines had a low number of virus-specific alignments due to low nucleotide contamination during the RNA preparation or sequencing process. Low-quality reads that lead to false positive taxonomer results can be eliminated by trimming the sequence data prior to analysis. Another important finding is that no viruses were detected that have never been detected in cell cultures. The results show that the currently used testing of cell cultures is sufficient to detect contamination and to assess the risk of cell cultures. The results underscore that next-generation sequencing is an efficient tool to determine the viral infection status of human cells.
authors: Uphoff, C. C.;Pommerenke, C.;Denkmann, S. A.;Drexler, H. G.

title: Ephemeral cattle fever
abstract: Ephemeral fever remains a viral disease of considerable concern to many countries including Australia. The virus has only been partially characterized and is awaiting final classification. Although the BEF virus was initially thought to contain 6 structural proteins, there is increasing evidence that it contains the 5 proteins characteristic of the Rhabdoviridae. Although BEF is thought to be transmitted by arthropods, the vector has yet to be identified, but the distribution of BEF suggests that more than one vector is capable of transmitting the disease. Despite rigorous study of the clinical symptoms and pathology of ephemeral fever, little progress has been made in the pathogenesis of the disease. This is partly due to the difficulty of propagating the BEF virus in vitro and the inability to define the site of replication. However, there is increasing evidence that BEF is immunopathological in nature and that the clinical expression of the disease is influenced by the release of one or more inflammatory mediators. The disease is characterized by a number of haematological and biochemical changes and early and prolonged treatment with phenylbutazone can reverse a number of these changes. Intravenous calcium, together with prolonged phenylbutazone therapy, can now be considered a reasonable adjunct to the treatment regimen. The vaccines currently available are made from either live attenuated or killed virus and may be less reliable. There appears to be a need for a reliable, low cost, cold chain independent alternative vaccine.
authors: Uren, M. F.

title: Unassigned reads from bovine RNAseq data: A source for missing and mismatched sequences in the reference arrays and for detecting in-host pathogens
abstract: Normally, reads from transcriptome sequencing data that are not mapped to the reference genome of the target species are not considered. A recent RNAseq project on the new killer disease bovine-neonatal pancytopenia had pointed to an unexplained signature of the immune response to a double-stranded RNA virus. To elucidate the background, contigs were assembled de novo from unmapped RNAseq reads and matched to the bovine genome assemblies and multispecies NCBI databases. The lack of true virus sequence contigs rejected the hypothesis that a live virus is responsible for the unexplained immune response. Alignment data also revealed incomplete bovine reference genome alignments. In addition, we found that several parasite and virus genome reference arrays in the NCBI were contaminated with bovine DNA and confirmed recombination of bovine DNA in BVD virus strains. Examination of unmapped reads can extract useful biological information about the presence of microorganisms and highlight problems with reference genome assemblies from host and pathogen species.
authors: Usman, T.;Hadlich, F.;Demasius, W.;Weikard, R.;Kuhn, C.

title: Nucleoprotein (N) partial gene sequencing and sequence analysis and phylogenetic analysis of rabies virus field isolates from Gujarat State, India
abstract: The present study was carried out with the aim of characterizing the rabies virus (genus Lyssavirus of the family Rhabdoviridae under the order Mononegavirales) by sequencing of the partial nucleoprotein (N) gene of the rabies virus and phylogenetic analysis to determine the genotype and lineage of the rabies virus present know in the Indian state of Gujarat. A total of 32 specimens (18 brain specimens and 14 saliva specimens) were collected aseptically from live and dead animals (namely, dog, buffalo, cow, goat, donkey and hyena) for the detection of rabies virus. Of 32 samples, 24 samples were found positive by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reactions, and from these 24 positive samples, 20 samples with a good level of gene product were selected for sequencing. ClustalW alignment of nucleotide sequences and amino acid sequences of field rabies isolates revealed 95.20-100 and 97.95-100% similarity to each other, respectively. Multiple sequence alignments of field rabies isolates and reference vaccine strains [Pasteur strain and Challenge Virus (CVS) strain] revealed single nucleotide mutations at a total of 91 positions and amino acid mutations at a total of 17 different positions. Phylogenetic analysis of N gene sequences using our 20 field rabies isolates and 21 other reported isolates in the gene bank resulted in 3 phylogenetic clusters. All field rabies isolates shared the same genetic ancestry with each other and with other previously reported Indian rabies isolates, which placed them in the arctic lineage of genotype 1 rabies virus. However, they were genetically distant from Pasteur and CVS reference strains, which clustered in different phylogenetic clusters.
authors: Vagheshwari, D. H.;Bhanderi, B. B.;Mathakiya, R. A.;Jhala, M. K.

title: Global distribution of human protoparvoviruses
abstract: The development of next-generation sequencing and metagenomics has revolutionized the detection of novel viruses. Among these viruses are 3 human protoparvoviruses: bufavirus, tusavirus and cutavirus. These viruses have been detected in the stool of children with diarrhea. In addition, cutavirus was detected in skin biopsies from patients with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma in France and in a melanoma patient in Denmark. We examined the seroprevalences of IgG against bufavirus, tusavirus and cutavirus in different populations (n = 840) and found a notable geographical difference in the prevalence of bufavirus IgG. Although prevalence in adult populations was low in Finland (1.9%) and the United States (3.6%), bufavirus IgG was high in populations in Iraq (84.8%), Iran (56, 1%) and widespread in Kenya (72.3%). Conversely, cutavirus IgG showed consistently low prevalences (0%–5.6%) in all cohorts, and tusavirus IgG was not detected. These results provide new insights into the global distribution and endemic areas of protoparvoviruses.
authors: Vaisanen, E.;Mohanraj, U.;Kinnunen, P. M.;Jokelainen, P.;Al-Hello, H.;Barakat, A. M.;Sadeghi, M.;Jalilian, F. A.;Majlesi, A.;Masika, M.;Mwaengo, D.;Anzala, O.;Delwart, E.;Vapalahti, O.;Hedman, K.;Soderlund-Venermo, M.

title: Epidemiology of two human protoparvoviruses, bufavirus and tusavirus
abstract: Two human parvoviruses were recently discovered by metagenomics in Africa, bufavirus (BuV) in 2012 and tusavirus (TuV) in 2014. These viruses have been studied exclusively by PCR in stool and have only been detected in patients with diarrhea, albeit with less prevalence. Three genotypes of BuV have been identified. We detected BuV1-3 IgG antibodies in 7/228 children (3.1%) and 10/180 adults (5.6%) by internal EIA, while TuV-IgG was found in one child (0.4%). . All children and 91% of adults were Finnish, but interestingly 3/6 adults of Indian origin were BuV-IgG positive. No cross-reactivity between the BuVs was detected by competition EIA, suggesting that the BuV genotypes represent distinct serotypes. In addition, we analyzed by BuV qPCR stool and nasal swab samples from 955 children with gastroenteritis, respiratory disease, or both, and found BuV DNA in three stools (0.3%) and, for the first time, in one nasal swab (0.1%). This is the first study to document the presence of BuV and TuV antibodies in humans. Although seroprevalences of both viruses were low in Finland, our results suggest that BuV infection may be widespread in Asia. The BuV-specific humoral immune responses appeared strong and long-lasting, indicating systemic infection in humans.
authors: Vaisanen, E.;Paloniemi, M.;Kuisma, I.;Lithovius, V.;Kumar, A.;Franssila, R.;Ahmed, K.;Delwart, E.;Vesikari, T.;Hedman, K.;Soderlund-Venermo, M.

title: S1 gene-based phylogeny of infectious bronchitis virus: An attempt to harmonize virus classification
abstract: Infectious bronchitis (IBV) virus is the causative agent of a highly contagious disease that is causing severe economic losses to the global poultry industry. The virus exists in a wide variety of genetically distinct virus types, and both phylogenetic analysis and measurements of pairwise similarity between nucleotide or amino acid sequences have been used to classify IBV strains. However, there is currently no consensus on the method by which IBV sequences should be compared, and heterogeneous genetic group designations have been adopted that are inconsistent with phylogenetic history, resulting in a confusing coexistence of multiple genotyping schemes. Here we propose a simple and repeatable phylogeny-based classification system combined with a unique and rational lineage nomenclature for the assignment of IBV strains. By using complete nucleotide sequences of the S1 gene, we determined the phylogenetic structure of IBV, which in turn enabled us to define 6 genotypes that collectively encompass 32 different viral lineages and a number of interlineage recombinants. Because of the extensive rate variation between IBVs, we propose that inferring phylogenetic relationships alone is a more appropriate criterion for sequence classification than pairwise sequence comparisons. Adoption of an internationally recognized viral nomenclature is critical for future studies of IBV epidemiology and evolution, and the classification scheme presented here is subject to update, and revised new S1 sequences should become available.
authors: Valastro, V.;Holmes, E. C.;Britton, P.;Fusaro, A.;Jackwood, M. W.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Genetic typing and prevalence of border disease virus (BDV) in small ruminant herds in Spain
abstract: Between 2001 and 2002, samples from 1413 animals in 21 Spanish small ruminant flocks, most of them with animals showing clinical signs compatible with Border Disease (BD), were tested for the presence of pestivirus antigen and antibodies by a indirect peroxidase monolayer assay (IPMA) or the virus neutralization test (VNT). Although all herds harbored seropositive animals, virus could only be isolated from animals in five of the herds. Between 4 and 11 months later, all animals older than 6 months were sampled again in three flocks. At this point, 51-83% of them had neutralizing antibodies. The prevalence of persistently infected (PI) animals in two flocks was 0.3 and 0.6%, respectively. The third herd had probably eliminated all PI animals. Fourteen virus isolates were obtained. The 5 inch untranslated region (5-UTR) was amplified by RT-PCR and directly sequenced. Phylogenetic analyzes classified them as a group of border disease viruses (BDV) that are separate from BDV-1 but have a relatively low bootstrap score. Three of the 14 isolates were in the same subgroup as a set of previously characterized Spanish isolates from the Basque Country, assigned to subgroup BDV-C. They were also grouped with an isolate from chamois, currently assigned to group BDV-4. Due to their close relationship to the chamois isolate, these isolates were provisionally assigned to a subgroup BDV-4a. The remaining isolates generated a new subgroup related to but not in the same cluster as the chamois isolate and were therefore tentatively assigned to a new subgroup, BDV-4b. Our results show that BDV classification and nomenclature need to be harmonized. © 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Valdazo-GonzÃ¡lez, B.;Ãlvarez-MartÃ­nez, M.;Greiser-Wilke, I.

title: Interspecies transmission of rotavirus in ruminants, dogs and humans: current facts and comments
abstract: Rotavirus is recognized as a major cause of diarrhea in humans and a wide variety of animals, and can cause serious economic losses in livestock, particularly swine and ruminants. This fact, along with the genetic diversity that characterizes members of the rotavirus group, has raised concerns about the possibility of virus transmission between different animal and human species. Regarding the occurrence and epidemiology of rotavirus in ruminants associated with closely related humans and dogs, research is limited and little data has been presented in recent years. In this review, we present the latest information on the distribution of genotypes of rotavirus strains in ruminants, canines, and humans.
authors: Valiakos, G.;Chatzopoulos, D. C.;Tsokana, C. N.

title: Anaplasma marginal superinfection due to pathogen strains with different genomic backgrounds
abstract: Strain superinfection occurs when a second strain of pathogen infects a host that is already infected with a primary strain. The selection pressures driving the strain divergence underlying superinfection and enabling the entry of a new strain into a host population are critical knowledge gaps relevant to changes in infectious disease epidemiology. In endemic regions with high infection prevalence, broad population immunity to Anaplasma marginale, a high antigenic variant rickettsial pathogen, develops and creates strong selective pressure for emergence and superinfection with strains differing in their Msp2 variant repertoire. The kindreds can arise either through msp2 locus duplication and allelic divergence on an existing genomic background, or by introducing a kindred with a different msp2 allelic repertoire on a different genomic background. To answer this question, we developed a multilocus typing assay based on high-throughput sequencing of non-msp2 target loci to distinguish between strains with different genomic backgrounds. The technical error level was statistically defined using the percentage of perfect sequence matches of clones of each target locus and validated using experimental single strains and pairs of strains. Testing of A. marginale-positive specimens from tropical regions where A. marginale infection is endemic identified single infections that contained unique alleles for all five target loci. The data showed a highly significant difference in the number of strains per animal in tropical regions compared to infections in temperate regions and strongly supported the hypothesis that transmission of genomically diverse A. marginale strains is prevalent in endemic areas.
authors: Vallejo Esquerra, E.;Herndon, D. R.;Alpirez Mendoza, F.;Mosqueda, J.;Palmer, G. H.

title: What is in a burden? Viral metagenomics identifies genetic variations and contaminating circoviruses in laboratory isolates of Pigeon Paramyxovirus type 1
abstract: We used next-generation sequencing on randomly amplified viral nucleic acids to determine the genome sequence of 11 isolates of pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1) from Belgium (period 1998-2011). The PPMV-1 deep sequence data allowed the identification of sequence variability in several PPMV-1 isolates, including a STOP codon in the matrix gene that was present in 15% of an isolate's viral population. In particular, mutations previously associated with pathogenicity in chickens were identified as minor sequence variants in a parental laboratory strain. A phylogenetic analysis of the consensus PPMV-1 genomic sequences was performed. In addition to providing nearly complete Paramyxovirus genome sequences, our sequence-independent approach identified the presence of pigeon circovirus (PiCV) sequences in four of these virus strains. Quantitative real-time RT-PCR analysis specific for PMV-1 and PiCV showed that these contaminants were present in seven virus stocks composed of allantoic fluids and occasionally also detected in stocks passaged in embryonated chicken eggs. Phylogenetic analysis of the PiCV consensus genome sequences revealed a circulation of PiCV covering the entire genetic diversity of known PiCV. Co-infecting viruses or sequence variants from the original sample may remain in the populations without being identified by routine virus-specific diagnostic tools. The exact role of PiCV in pigeon disease - specifically Newcastle disease - and its potential interference with PPMV-1 diagnostics remains to be investigated. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Van Borm, S.;Rosseel, T.;Steensels, M.;Van den Berg, T.;Lambrecht, B.

title: Complete coding sequence of a novel Picorna-like virus in a blackbird infected with Usutu virus
abstract: Using high-throughput random RNA sequencing, the complete coding sequence of a novel Picorna-like virus (a 9,228 nt contig with 212,202 reads) from a blackbird (Turdus merula) infected with Usutu virus was determined. This sequence shares only 36% amino acid sequence identity with its closest homologue, Arivirus 1 (an unclassified member of the order Picornaviruses), and shares its dicistronic genome arrangement. The new virus was therefore provisionally named “Blackbird Arilivirus” (ari-like virus). The nearly complete genome sequence consists of at least 9,228 nt and contains two open reading frames (ORFs) encoding the nonstructural polyprotein (2235 amino acids) and the structural polyprotein (769 amino acids). Two TaqMan RT-qPCR assays specific for ORF1 confirmed the presence of high levels of this novel virus in the original sample. Nucleotide composition analysis suggests that blackbird arilivirus is dietary (plant) derived.
authors: Van Borm, S.;Steensels, M.;Mathijs, E.;Yinda, C. K.;Matthijnssens, J.;Lambrecht, B.

title: Genital warts in Burmeister's porpoises: characterization of Phocoena spinipinnis papillomavirus type 1 (PsPV-1) and evidence for a second, distantly related PsPV
abstract: We identified sequences of two distantly related papillomaviruses in genital warts from two Burmeister's porpoises, including a PV antigen-positive specimen, and characterized Phocoena spinipinnis papillomavirus type 1 (PsPV-1). The PsPV-1 genome is 7879 nt and has unusual features. It lacks an E7, an E8, and a true E5 open reading frame (ORF) and has a large E6 ORF. The PsPV-1 L1 ORF showed the highest percentage of nucleotide identity (54-55%) with human papillomavirus type 5, bovine papillomavirus type 3 (BPV-3), and Tursiops truncatus papillomavirus type 2 (TtPV-2) . This justifies the classification of PsPV-1 as a prototype of the genus omicron papillomavirus. PsPV-1 groups with TtPV-2 in the E6 and E1-E2 phylogenetic trees and with TtPV-2 and BPV-3 in the L2L1 tree. This supports the hypothesis that PV evolution may not be monophyletic across all genes. © 2007 SGM.
authors: Van Bressem, M. F.;Cassonnet, P.;Rector, A.;Desaintes, C.;Van Waerebeek, K.;Alfaro-Shigueto, J.;Van Ranst, M.;Orth, G.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the first complete hepatitis E virus (HEV) genome from Africa
abstract: The hepatitis E virus (HEV) is distributed worldwide, is transmitted enterally and between humans and animals. Phylogenetic analysis has identified five distinct HEV genotypes. The first full sequence of an African strain (Chad) is presented and compared to 31 available full HEV genomes, including the fulminant hepatitis strain from India, pig strains and a strain from Morocco. The two African strains are more closely related to genotype 1 than to any other genotype and together they may form a sub-genotype or sixth genotype. The first evidence for recombination between different HEV strains is presented. © 2003 Federation of European Microbiological Societies. Published by Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Van Cuyck, H.;Juge, F.;Roques, P.

title: Development and validation of a genotype 3-based recombinant protein-based immunoassay for hepatitis E virus serology in swine
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is classified in the Hepeviridae family, genus Hepevirus. HEV genotype 3 (Gt3) infections are endemic in swine in western Europe and the Americas and cause zoonotic infections in humans. Several serological assays for the detection of HEV antibodies in pigs have been developed, initially mainly based on HEV genotype 1 (Gt1) antigens. To develop a sensitive HEV Gt3 ELISA, a recombinant baculovirus expression product of the HEV Gt3 open reading frame 2 was prepared and plated on polystyrene ELISA plates. After incubation of pig sera, bound HEV antibodies were detected with anti-pig anti-IgG and anti-IgM conjugates. Sera sets from pigs experimentally infected with HEV Gt3 were used for the primary assessment of the sensitivity and specificity of the assay. A batch of 1100 pig sera was used to further validate the assay and establish the cutoff value. All swine sera were tested with the developed HEV Gt3 assay and two other serological assays based on HEV Gt1 antigens. Since no gold standard for HEV antibody testing is available, further validation and final determination of the cutoff of the developed HEV Gt3 assay was performed using a statistical approach based on Bayes' theorem. The developed and validated HEV antibody assay demonstrated effective detection of HEV-specific antibodies. This assay may contribute to improved HEV antibody detection and provide more reliable estimates of the prevalence of HEV Gt3 in pigs in different regions.
authors: van der Poel, W. H. M.;Pavio, N.;van der Goot, J.;van Es, M.;Martin, M.;Engel, B.

title: Micro-neuraminidase inhibition assay for classifying influenza A virus neuraminidases
abstract: neuraminidase inhibition (NI) assay performed in microtiter plates is described. This micro NI test is a modification of the NI test recommended by the World Health Organization. It reduces the amount of reagents required and allows the antigenic classification of many isolates simultaneously. To determine the accuracy and sensitivity of this micro NI assay, 110 influenza A viruses representing all subtypes based on the nine known neuraminidases (NAs) were analyzed by both the micro NI and macro NI -Assay classified in two separate laboratories. The NAs were accurately identified by the micro NI assay. Virus mixtures were detected by both assays, with the macro NI being significantly more sensitive. The micro NI assay was also suitable for testing sera for the presence of antibodies to the NAs. Although the micro NI assay did not provide the quantification of the macro NI assay, it proved to be a rapid method for virus classification and antibody studies of influenza A viruses.
authors: Van Deusen, R. A.;Hinshaw, V. S.;Senne, D. A.;Pellacani, D.

title: One world, one health. Humans, animals and the environment are inextricably linked - a fact that must be taken into account and exploited in our modern understanding of health
authors: van Helden, P. D.;van Helden, L. S.;Hoal, E. G.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of the novel simian T-lymphotropic virus STLV-PH969 from a hamadryas baboon and unusual features of its long terminal repeat
abstract: third type of T-lymphotropic primate virus, PTLV-L, prototyped with STLV-PH969, was recently isolated from an African baboon (Papio hamadryas). The classification of this virus is based on a partial sequence analysis of cDNA from a virus-producing cell line, PH969. We obtained the complete nucleotide sequence of this virus with a proviral genome of 8,916 bp. All major genes homologous in all human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV)-related viruses and their corresponding mRNAs, including appropriate splices, have been identified. An additional non-homologous open reading frame in the proximal pX region is accessible for translation by alternative splicing. Sequence comparison shows that STLV-PH969 is equidistantly related to HTLV type 1 (HTLV-1) and HTLV-2. In all coding regions, similarity tends to be lowest between STLV-PH969 and HTLV-1. However, the least similarity between STLV-PH969 and HTLV-2 was found in the long terminal repeat (LTR) region. The U3-R and R-U5 borders of the STLV-PH969-LTR were determined experimentally at nucleotides 268 and 52.4, respectively. This 695 bp LTR is 60 and 73 bp shorter than the HTLV-1 and HTLV-2 LTRs, respectively, but its general organization is similar to that found in the HTLV bovine leukemia virus genus. In the long region between the polyadenylation signal and the poly(A) site, sequence similarity to the HTLV-1 Rex-responsive element (RexRE) core and secondary structure prediction suggest the presence of a RexRE. The presence of three 21 bp repeats is conserved within the U3 region of HTLV-1, HTLV-2 and BLV. Only two direct repeats with similarity to these Tax-responsive elements were found in the STLV-PH969 LTR, suggesting differences in the Tax-mediated transactivation of this virus. We conclude that STLV-PH969 has all the genes and genomic regions that suggest a replication cycle comparable to that of HTLV-1 and HTLV-2.
authors: Van Marianne, B.;Goubau, P.;Rousseau, R.;Desmyter, J.;Vandamme, A. M.

title: Genetic heterogeneity in foot-and-mouth disease virus leaders and 3C proteinases
abstract: The leader and 3C proteinases of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) are responsible for almost all proteolytic processing events of the viral polyprotein precursor. Examination of the genetic heterogeneity of the regions encoding these proteins from isolates from six FMDV serotypes revealed that the 3C proteinase is more conserved than the leader proteinase. Maximum likelihood analysis revealed similar phylogenetic groupings for the nonstructural protein coding regions of both the leader and the 3C. These groupings differed from the structural coding region of the VP1 protein, which was grouped by serotype as previously shown. Two distinct clades were evident for both the leader and 3C coding regions: one comprising serotypes A, O and C together with SAT isolates (South African Territories) from East Africa. The other group consisted of SAT isolates originating from southern Africa. Only one virus isolate obtained from a buffalo in Uganda did not fit this phylogenetic pattern. This SAT 1 virus was grouped with types A, O and C in leader analysis but with the South African SAT types in 3C analysis, implying intertypic recombination. The leader proteinases of South African SAT-type isolates differed from those present in European-type isolates, particularly in the self-processing region. A three-dimensional structure was modeled for the leader proteinase of one of the SAT-type viruses, ZIM/7/83/2, and compared to the previously elucidated crystal structure of the O1Kaufbeuren leader proteinase. The active sites of the two leaders were found to closely overlap despite the observed sequence variation between the two molecules. A comparison of 3C proteinase P1 cleavage sites suggested that FMDV 3C proteinase may have broader substrate specificity than that observed with hepatitis A virus 3C proteinase. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Van Rensburg, H.;Haydon, D.;Joubert, F.;Bastos, A.;Heath, L.;Nel, L.

title: Origin of the 1918 Spanish influenza virus: A comparative genomic analysis
abstract: To test the avian origin hypothesis of the 1918 Spanish influenza virus, we surveyed influenza sequences from a broad taxonomic distribution and collected 65 full-length genomes, which included numerous other porcine (H1N2, H3N1, and H3N2), human (H2N2, H3N2, and H5N1) and avian (H1N1, H4N6, H5N1, H6N1, H6N6, H6N8, H7N3, H8N4, H9N2, and H13N2) subtypes. Amino acids from all eight segments were concatenated, aligned, and used for phylogenetic analysis. In addition, the genes of the polymerase complex (PB1, PB2 and PA) were analyzed individually. All of our results placed the Brevig-Mission/1918 strain in a position basal to the rest of the clade containing human H1N1s and were consistent with a resort hypothesis for the origin of the 1918 virus. Our genomic phylogeny further indicates a sister relationship with the "classic" porcine H1N1 lineage. The individual PB1, PB2, and PA phylogenies were consistent with reassortment/recombination hypotheses for these genes. These results demonstrate the importance of using a whole genome approach to address the hypothesis of avian origin and predict the emergence of new pandemic influenza strains. © 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Vana, G.;Westover, K. M.

title: An ecological and conservational perspective on advances in applied virology of zoonoses
abstract: The aim of this manuscript is to describe how modern advances in our knowledge of viruses and viral evolution can be applied to the fields of disease ecology and protection. We review recent advances in virology and provide examples of how they affect both empirical research in field ecology and applied conservation. We include a discussion of necessary breakthroughs and ways to bridge communication gaps between the field and the laboratory. To encourage this interdisciplinary effort, we have also included a table listing key term definitions. It emphasizes the importance of understanding the dynamics of zoonotic agents in their reservoir hosts, both to assess risk factors for spillover and to test hypotheses related to treatment and/or intervention strategies. Finally, we emphasize the need for intelligent monitoring, virus detection efforts, and predictive modeling. In today's globalized society, a shift towards a predictive approach is needed because, as demonstrated by the 2009 H1N1 pandemic, identification after occurrence is often too late to prevent global spread. The integration of molecular virology and ecological techniques will enable earlier detection of potentially dangerous pathogens, ideally before they spill over from wildlife reservoirs to human or livestock populations and cause serious public health or conservation problems. © 2011 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Vandegrift, K. J.;Wale, N.;Epstein, J. H.

title: Comparative genome sequencing identifies a prophage-associated genomic island associated with host adaptation of Lawsonia intracellularis infections
abstract: Lawsonia intracellularis is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the causative agent of proliferative enteropathy (PE). The disease is endemic in pigs, occurs in horses and has also been reported in a variety of other animal species, including non-human primates. Comparing the entire genome sequences of a homologous porcine L. intracellularis isolate cultured for passage 10 and 60 in vitro, we identified a 18 kb prophage-associated genomic island at passage 10 (pathogenic variant) that was isolated at passage 60 ( non-pathogenic variant). This chromosomal island encompasses 15 genes downstream of the prophage DLP12 integrase gene. The prevalence of this genetic element was assessed in 12 other L. intracellularis isolates and in 53 infected animals and found to be conserved in all pig isolates cultured for up to 20 passages and in isolates cultured for more than 40 passages were cultivated was lost. In addition, the prophage region was also present in 26 fecal samples obtained from pigs clinically affected by both acute and chronic forms of the disease. However, the equine L. intracellularis isolates examined did not contain this genomic island, regardless of in vitro passage. Furthermore, fecal samples from 21 clinically affected horses and four wild rabbits trapped in horse farms with PE outbreaks did not show this prophage-associated islet. Although the presence of this prophage-associated islet was not essential for a virulent L. intracellularis phenotype, this genetic element was porcine isolate specific and possibly contributed to the ecological specialization of this organism for the porcine host.
authors: Vannucci, F. A.;Kelley, M. R.;Gebhart, C. J.

title: Sequence-based taxonomic framework for the classification of uncultured single-stranded DNA viruses of the Genomoviridae family
abstract: With the advent of metagenomic approaches, a wide variety of known and unknown viruses have been identified in different types of environmental, plant, and animal samples. One such widespread group of viruses is the recently established family Genomoviridae, which includes viruses with small (approximately 2-2.4 kb), circular ssDNA genomes that encode rolling circle replication initiation proteins (Rep) and unique capsid proteins. Here we propose a sequence-based taxonomic framework for the classification of 121 novel viral genomes within this family. Genomoviruses exhibit approximately 47% sequence diversity, which is very similar to that within the well-established and extensively studied family Geminiviridae (46% diversity). Based on our analysis, we set a genome-wide pairwise identity of 78% as the species differentiation threshold. Furthermore, using a Rep sequence phylogeny-based analysis in conjunction with current knowledge on geminivirus classification, we establish nine genera within the Genomoviridae family. These are Gemycircularvirus (n=73), Gemyduguivirus (n=1), Gemygorvirus (n=9), Gemykibivirus (n=29), Gemycolovirus (n=3), Gemykrogvirus (n=3), Gemykroznavirus (n=1) , Gemytondvirus (n=1), Gemyvongvirus (n=1). The presented taxonomic framework provides a rational classification of genomic viruses based solely on the sequence information and is an example for the future classification of other groups of uncultured viruses discovered using metagenomic approaches.
authors: Varsani, A.;Krupovic, M.

title: Smacoviridae: a new family of animal-associated single-stranded DNA viruses
abstract: Smacoviruses have small (similar to 2.3–2.9 kb), circular, single-stranded DNA genomes that encode rolling circle replication-associated proteins (Rep) and unique capsid proteins. Although smacoviruses are widespread in the faeces of various vertebrates, including humans, none of these viruses have been cultured. Smacoviruses exhibit a genome-wide sequence diversity of approximately 45%, which is very similar to that of other families of circular Rep-encoding single-stranded DNA (CRESS) viruses, including members of the families Geminiviridae (46% diversity) and Genomoviridae (47% diversity). Here we announce the creation of a new family Smacoviridae and describe a sequence-based taxonomic framework used to classify 83 Smacovirus genomes into 43 species within six new genera, Bovismacovirus (n = 3), Cosmacovirus (n = 1) , Dragsmacovirus (n=1), Drosmacovirus (n=3), Huchismacovirus (n=7) and Porprismacovirus (n=28). As in the case of gemoviruses, species delineation is based on genome-wide pairwise identity, while genera are established based on Rep amino acid sequence identity coupled with strong phylogenetic support. A similar sequence-based taxonomic framework should guide the classification of a stunning variety of other uncultured and currently unclassified CRESS-DNA viruses discovered by metagenomic approaches.
authors: Varsani, A.;Krupovic, M.

title: A new variant of the influenza virus h1n1 swine flu virus
abstract: In 2009, a swine-derived H1N1 virus strain, commonly referred to as swine flu, caused the 2009 flu pandemic. Most countries with cold climates are affected by the disease. In the US, between 1979 and 2001, an average of 41,000 people died from influenza each year. Influenza, commonly referred to as the flu, is an infectious disease caused by RNA viruses of the Orthomyxoviridae family that affects birds and mammals. This virus is mainly classified into three types: 1) Influenza virus A 2) Influenza virus B 3) Influenza virus C. Swine flu belongs to influenza virus A(H1N1). The virus particle is 80-120 nanometers in size. In the early stages of swine flu, it can be difficult to distinguish between a cold and influenza, but flu can be identified by a sudden onset of high fever and extreme fatigue. Transmitted through three main routes: direct transmission, the air bone route, and direct personal contact (like shaking hands). Since influenza viruses can persist outside the body, they can also be transmitted through contaminated surfaces such as banknotes, doorknobs, etc. H1N1 spreads easily, rarely fatally. One of the mechanisms of H1N1 is believed to be inhibition of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which leads to lower cortisol levels. Influenza viruses can be inactivated by sunlight, disinfectants and detergents. Commonly used antivirals are oseltamivir and zanamivir, which are neuraminidase inhibitors, and amantadine and rimantadine block a viral ion channel and prevent viruses from infecting cells. Vaccines such as Live Intranasal Monovalent Vaccines, Intramuscular Injection Monovalent Vaccines, Fluzone, etc.
authors: Veeranjaneyulu, T. N.;Seerishna, B.;Kiran, T. N. R.;Madhulatha, A. V. S.;Bindu, A. H.

title: Autochthonous hepatitis E virus infection as the cause of acute hepatitis in Germany - a case report
abstract: There is increasing evidence that the hepatitis E virus (HEV) causes acute hepatitis not only in tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, Africa and America with poor hygiene standards, but also in highly industrialized countries. We report here on two patients from Thuringia (Germany) with an HEV infection without a recent stay abroad. All other common causes of hepatitis were excluded. Transaminases were significantly increased in both cases, while jaundice was detectable in only one patient. Both patients made a full recovery over the long term. Epidemiological and phylogenetic data from virus analyzes suggest that HEV infection must be considered a zoonosis. It is likely that animal-to-human virus transmission occurs through undercooked meat or entrails, e.g. B. of pigs or wild animals takes place. In summary, HEV infection is a relevant differential diagnosis in acute non-A/B/C viral hepatitis. Further studies are required to identify other transmission routes, pathogen reservoirs and novel concepts for prophylaxis, especially in patients at risk of liver diseases. © 2010 Georg Thieme Verlag KG Stuttgart · New York.
authors: Veitt, R.;Reichardt, M.;Wenzel, J.;Jilg, W.

title: Phylodynamics of the genus Parapoxvirus in Mexico (2007–2011)
abstract: In this study, we report for the first time the phylodynamics of the genus Parapoxvirus (PPV) in Mexico. Based on PCR analysis of 124 epithelial samples collected from naturally infected goats, sheep and cows in Mexico between 2007 and 2011, we found that various PPVs were present in 21 of the 24 states sampled during this study. Our phylogenetic analysis confirmed the occurrence of different PPV species in Mexico and their phylogenetic relationship with other PPV circulating in the US and Canada. Furthermore, we describe the existence of two distinct phylogenetic ORFV groups that are uniquely associated with the host (ovine or caprine). Evidence for directed selection at five specific amino acid residues in the enveloped glycoprotein B2L may help support this host preference. Overall, the results obtained in this study underscore the importance of the genus PPV in Mexico and open the possibility for future studies that will describe in more detail the importance of this genus in North America.
authors: Velazquez-Salinas, L.;Ramirez-Medina, E.;Bracht, A. J.;Hole, K.;Brito, B. P.;Gladue, D. P.;Carrillo, C.

title: Avian influenza viruses in wild birds: viral evolution in a multi-host ecosystem
abstract: Wild ducks and gulls are the main reservoirs of avian influenza A viruses (AIVs). The mechanisms driving AIV evolution are complex in sites where diverse duck and gull species from multiple flight routes breed, winter, or reside in instars. The Republic of Georgia lies at the crossroads of three migratory routes: the Central Asian Air Route, the East Africa/West Asia Air Route, and the Black Sea-Mediterranean Air Route. For six full study years (2010 to 2016), we collected AIV samples from various duck and gull species breeding, migrating, and wintering in Georgia. We found a considerable variety of virus subtypes, the prevalence of which varied from year to year. The low pathogenic AIV (LPAIV) subtypes included H1N1, H2N3, H2N5, H2N7, H3N8, H4N2, H6N2, H7N3, H7N7, H9N1, H9N3, H10N4, H10N7, H11N1, H13N2, H13N6, H13N8 and H16N3, as well as two highly pathogenic ones AIVs (HPAIVs) belonging to clade 2.3.4.4, H5N5 and H5N8 have been found. Whole-genome pedigrees revealed significant host-species ancestry restriction for almost all gene segments and significant differences in observed resort rates, defined by quantification of phylogenetic incongruity, and in nucleotide sequence diversity for LPAIVs between different host species. Hemagglutinin clade 2.3.4.4 H5N8 viruses circulating in Eurasia in 2014 and 2015 did not reorder, but analysis after their subsequent spread in 2016 and 2017 revealed reordering in all gene segments except NP and NS. Some virus lineages appeared unrelated to AIVs in wild bird populations in other regions, with local AIVs being preserved in Georgia, while other lineages showed significant genetic interactions with viruses circulating in other parts of Eurasia and Africa, despite relatively small samples in the region.
authors: Venkatesh, D.;Poen, M. J.;Bestebroer, T. M.;Scheuer, R. D.;Vuong, O.;Chkhaidze, M.;Machablishvili, A.;Mamuchadze, J.;Ninua, L.;Fedorova, N. B.;Halpin, R. A.;Lin, X.;Ransier, A.;Stockwell, T. B.;Wentworth, D. E.;Kriti, D.;Dutta, J.;van Bakel, H.;Puranik, A.;Slomka, M. J.;Essen, S.;Brown, I. H.;Fouchier, R. A. M.;Lewis, N. S.

title: Molecular characterization of Belgian pseudorabiesvirus isolates from domestic pigs and wild boar
abstract: Aujeszky's disease is an economically important disease in domestic pigs caused by suid herpesvirus 1, also known as pseudorabies virus (PRV). In several European countries, including Belgium, the virus has been successfully eradicated from the domestic pig population. However, the presence of PRV in the wild boar population poses a risk of possible reintroduction of the virus into the domestic pig population. It is therefore important to assess the genetic relatedness between circulating strains and possible epidemiological links. In this study, nine historical Belgian domestic pig isolates circulating before 1990 and five more recent wild boar isolates sourced from Belgium and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg since 2006 were genetically characterized by restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis and phylogenetic analysis. While all wild boar isolates have been characterized as type I RFLP genotypes, the RFLP patterns of domestic pig isolates suggest that a genotype I to genotype II shift may have occurred in the domestic pig population in the 1980s. Phylogenetic analysis observed Belgian wild boar isolates belonging to both clade A and B, while all domestic pig isolates were grouped within clade A. Joint phylogenetic analysis of wild boar and domestic pig strains showed that some isolates with identical sequences were present in both populations, raising the question of whether these strains pose an increased risk of reintroducing the virus into the native population. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Verpoest, S.;Cay, A. B.;De Regge, N.

title: The ability of UL49.5 proteins to inhibit TAP is widespread among members of the Varicellovirus genus
abstract: Lifelong infection by varicelloviruses is characterized by a delicate balance between the host's immune response and the immune evasion strategies employed by these viruses. Viral-derived peptides are presented to cytotoxic T lymphocytes by class I molecules of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC). The antigen processing-associated transporter (TAP) transports the peptides from the cytosol to the endoplasmic reticulum, where loading with MHC-I molecules takes place. The varicelloviruses bovine herpesvirus 1 (BoHV-1), pseudorabies virus and equine herpesvirus 1 and 4 have been found to encode a UL49.5 protein that inhibits TAP-mediated peptide transport. To investigate the extent to which UL49.5-mediated TAP inhibition is conserved within the Alphaherpesvirinae family, the homologues of five additional varicelloviruses, one mardivirus and one iltovirus were examined. The UL49.5 proteins from BoHV-5, bubaline herpesvirus 1, cervid herpesvirus 1, and felid herpesvirus 1 have been identified as potent TAP inhibitors. The UL49.5 proteins of varicella zoster virus and simian varicellovirus cannot block TAP; this is not due to the lack of viral cofactors that might aid in this process, since cells infected with these viruses also showed no reduced TAP function. The UL49.5 homologues of Mardivirus Marek's Disease Virus 1 and Iltovirus infectious laryngotracheitis virus did not block TAP, suggesting that the ability to inhibit TAP via UL49.5 was acquired only by varicelloviruses. A phylogenetic analysis of viruses that inhibit TAP through their UL49.5 proteins reveals an interesting heritable pattern that points to the existence of this ability in defined clades within the genus Varicellovirus. Copyright © 2011, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Verweij, M. C.;LipiÅ„ska, A. D.;Koppers-Lalic, D.;Van Leeuwen, W. F.;Cohen, J. I.;Kinchington, P. R.;Messaoudi, I.;BieÅ„kowska-Szewczyk, K.;Ressing, M. E.;Rijsewijk, F. A. M.;Wiertz, E. J. H. J.

title: Detection and genotyping of classical swine fever virus isolates in Serbia
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF) is a highly contagious swine fever that causes significant economic losses worldwide. Classical swine fever virus can be divided into three genogroups, each consisting of three or four subgroups. However, there is a lack of knowledge about the genotypes of CSFV isolates in the Republic of Serbia. This study, based on sequence analysis of the partial E2 gene and 5' non-coding region (NCR) of 15 CSFV isolated from domestic pigs between 2006 and 2008, revealed that all were clustered in genetic group 2.3. Furthermore, we showed that the two most commonly used real-time RT-PCR assays could detect all local CSF viruses circulating in Serbia during an intensive vaccination campaign against CSF in recent years
authors: Vesna, M.;Sonja, R.;Valcic, A. M.;Ivovic, V.;Jelena, M. Z.;Radosavljevic, V.

title: Metagenomic detection and characterization of viruses in faecal samples from Australian wild birds
abstract: We present an optimized metagenomics method for the detection and characterization of all virus types, including single- and double-stranded DNA/RNA, enveloped and non-enveloped viruses. Initial analysis included both spiked and unspiked bird faecal samples, as well as unspiked human faecal samples. We detected 21 viruses in the non-spiked bird samples (Australian Muscovy duck and Pacific black duck) and we also present a summary of some viruses detected in human faecal samples. We then present a detailed analysis of selected virus sequences in the bird samples that were somewhat similar to known viruses and had good quality (Q20 or higher) and quantity from next-generation sequencing reads and were of interest from a virological point of view B. Avian Coronavirus and Avian Paramyxovirus 6. Some of these viruses were closely related to known viruses, while others were more distantly related with 70% or less identity to currently known/sequenced viruses. In addition to virus detection, the technique also enabled the characterization of the host's mitochondrial DNA present and hence the identification of the host species, while ribosomal RNA sequences provided insight into the "ribosomal activity microbiome"; from intestinal parasites; and from foods eaten, such as plants or insects, which we correlated with viruses not associated with the bird host.
authors: Vibin, J.;Chamings, A.;Collier, F.;Klaassen, M.;Nelson, T. M.;Alexandersen, S.

title: Metagenomic analyzes of viruses in stool samples from children with acute flaccid paralysis
abstract: We analyzed viral nucleic acids in stool samples from 35 South Asian children with acute flaccid non-polio paralysis (AFP). Sequence-independent reverse transcription and PCR amplification of capsid-protected, nuclease-resistant viral nucleic acids were followed by DNA sequencing and sequence similarity searches. Limited Sanger sequencing (35 to 240 subclones per sample) identified an average of 1.4 different eukaryotic viruses per sample, while Pyrosequencing revealed 2.6 viruses per sample. In addition to bacteriophages and plant viruses, we detected known enteric viruses including rotavirus, adenovirus, picobirnavirus, and human enterovirus species A (HEV-A) through HEV-C, as well as numerous other members of the Picornaviridae family including parechovirus, aichi virus, rhinovirus, and human cardiovirus. The viruses with the most divergent sequences compared to previously reported viruses included members of a new genus Picornaviridae and four new virus species (members of the families Dicistroviridae, Nodaviridae and Circoviridae and the genus Bocavirus). Samples from six healthy contacts of AFP patients were similarly analyzed and also contained multiple viruses, particularly HEV-C, including a potentially novel enterovirus genotype. Determining the prevalences and pathogenicities of the new genotypes, species, genera, and potential new virus families identified in this study in different demographic groups requires further studies with different demographic and patient groups, now facilitated by knowledge of these viral genomes.
authors: Victoria, J. G.;Kapoor, A.;Li, L. L.;Blinkova, O.;Slikas, B.;Wang, C. L.;Naeem, A.;Zaidi, S.;Delwart, E.

title: Viral nucleic acids in live attenuated vaccines: detection of minority variants and an adventitious virus
abstract: Metagenomics and a panmicrobial microarray were used to study eight live attenuated vaccines. Viral nucleic acids in trivalent oral poliovirus (OPV), rubella, measles, yellow fever, varicella-zoster, multivalent measles/mumps/rubella, and two live rotavirus vaccines were partially purified, randomly amplified, and pyrosequenced. Over half a million sequence reads were generated, covering 20 to 99% of the attenuated viral genomes at depths of up to 8,000 reads per nucleotide. Mutations and minority variants compared to vaccine strains not known to affect attenuation have been detected in OPV, mumps virus and varicella-zoster virus. The expected detection of endogenous retroviral sequences from the producing avian and primate cells was confirmed. Avian leukosis virus (ALV), previously shown to be non-infectious to humans, was present as RNA in virus particles, while Simian retrovirus (SRV) was present as genetically defective DNA. Rotarix, an oral rotavirus vaccine, contained porcine circovirus-1 (PCV1), a common nonpathogenic swine virus that has not been shown to be infectious in humans. Hybridization of vaccine nucleic acids to a panmicrobial microarray confirmed the presence of endogenous retroviral and PCV1 nucleic acids. Deep sequencing and microarrays can therefore detect attenuated virus sequence changes, minority variants and adventitious viruses and help maintain the current safety record of live attenuated vaccines. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Victoria, J. G.;Wang, C.;Jones, M. S.;Jaing, C.;McLoughlin, K.;Gardner, S.;Delwart, E. L.

title: Whole genome characterization by deep sequencing of rotavirus A isolates from pig neonatal diarrhea outbreaks in Spain
abstract: Since early 2017, there has been an apparent increase in reports of rotavirus involvement in neonatal diarrheal outbreaks in Spain, also affecting adult sows. In this study, 16 independent outbreaks of diarrhea in suckling piglets and sows in which rotavirus A was the only identified pathogen were examined. Deep sequencing was performed on total RNA from 24 positive fecal samples. Genotyping, phylogenetic and Bayesian analyzes indicated that all isolates shared a common porcine or human porcine ancestor. The new strain was introduced to the population just before the outbreaks began. In addition, high diversification of the VP7 and VP4 genes occurred in a short period of time. Isolates showed a high number of amino acid changes in the neutralizing epitopes compared to vaccine sequences. This report illustrates how a new rotavirus A strain can spread rapidly and what extremely high diversification these pathogens can undergo in a short period of time.
authors: Vidal, A.;Clilverd, H.;Cortey, M.;Martin-Valls, G. E.;Franzo, G.;Darwich, L.;Martin, M.;Mateu, E.

title: Application of standard and molecular methods to diagnose Newcastle disease
abstract: Four pooled samples of whole poultry carcasses with their internal organs were used to determine the presence of Newcastle disease (ND) virus. In January 2007, samples were taken from an animal disease area in the Republic of Serbia. Newcastle disease virus strains were isolated from four samples. Isolated strains were identified using haemagglutination and haemagglutination inhibition tests. ND virus nucleic acid was identified in all four samples. It was confirmed that all the isolated strains were velogen strains. Analysis of the nucleotide sequences of the gene encoding the F cleavage site of the fusion F protein revealed the presence of (112)RRQKRFIG(119) motifs characteristic of the velogenic strains of ND virus. The phylogenetic analysis of the F gene sequences revealed that all isolated virus strains belong to class II and genotype VIId.
authors: Vidanovic, D.;Sekler, M.;Polacek, V.;Vaskovic, N.;Asanin, R.;Milic, N.;Nisavic, J.

title: Stumbling upon emerging pathogens around the world: A phylogeographic approach to determining the epidemiology of porcine circovirus-2 (PCV-2) considering global trade
abstract: Porcine Circovirus-2 (PCV-2) is an emerging virus that has been implicated in a number of different syndromes in pigs known as Porcine Circovirus Associated Diseases (PCVAD). Since its identification and characterization in the early 1990s, PCV-2 has achieved a global distribution, has become endemic in most swine producing countries, and is currently recognized as a major cause of losses on swine farms. In this study, we analyzed the main pathways of PCV-2 spread between pig producing countries using phylogenetic and phylogeographic approaches. A search of PCV-2 genomic sequences in GenBank was performed and the 420 PCV-2 sequences obtained were grouped into haplotypes (set of sequences showing 100% identity) based on the infinite site model of genome evolution. A phylogenetic hypothesis was derived from Bayesian inference for virus strain classification, and a haplotype network was constructed from median joining to predict the geographic distribution of and genealogical relationships between haplotypes. In order to provide epidemiological and economic context to these analyses, we considered all available information on PCV-2 sequences in GenBank, including published articles on virus isolation and statistics on live pig trade, contained in the UN Comtrade database (http: //comtrade.un.org/). In these analyses, we identified a strong correlation between the spread of PCV-2 predicted by the haplotype network and international live pig trade statistics. This correlation offers a new perspective on the epidemiology of PCV-2, underscores the importance of animal movement around the world for the emergence of new pathogens, and demonstrates the need for effective sanitary barriers in the live animal trade. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Vidigal, P. M. P.;Mafra, C. L.;Silva, F. M. F.;Fietto, J. L. R.;Silva JÃºnior, A.;Almeida, M. R.

title: Detection of hepadnavirus in bile and liver samples from domestic pigs from commercial slaughterhouses
abstract: Background: Preliminary studies demonstrated the prevalence of human hepatitis B virus-like virus (HBV-like) in farm pigs in China and molecular evidence of hepadnavirus infection in domestic swine herds in Brazil. In this study, we genetically characterize the porcine hepadnavirus strains in pigs from slaughterhouses located in certified slaughterhouses in Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil, and assess their hepatotropic potential. Results: Porcine bile and liver samples were positive for partial genome amplification (ORF S and ORF C), direct sequencing and viral load quantification. Sequencing of the gene encoding the surface antigen allowed classification of hepadnavirus into genotypes, similar to HBV genotype classification. Indirect immunofluorescence confirmed the presence of HBsAg antigen in liver tissue sections. Conclusions: So far, our data suggest that commercial pigs harbor an HBV-like virus, and this relevant finding should be considered in studies of virus origin and evolution.
authors: Vieira, Y. R.;Dos Santos, D. R. L.;Portilho, M. M.;Velloso, C. E. P.;Arissawa, M.;Villar, L. M.;Pinto, M. A.;De Paula, V. S.

title: Hendra and Nipah Infection: Pathology, Models, and Possible Therapies
abstract: The Paramyxoviridae family includes several genera that contain emerging or re-emerging threats to human and animal health, with no truly specific effective treatment available. Hendra and Nipah viruses belong to a newly identified genus of emerging paramyxoviruses, henipavirus. Since their discovery in the 1990s, henipavirus outbreaks have been associated with high potential economic and public health threats. Compared to other paramyxoviruses, henipaviruses appear to have unique properties. Henipaviruses are zoonotic paramyxoviruses with a broader tropism than most other paramyxoviruses and can cause severe acute encephalitis with features unique among viral encephalitis. There are currently no approved effective prophylactic or therapeutic treatments for henipavirus infection. Although ribavirin has been used empirically and appeared useful during the largest outbreak caused by one of these viruses, Nipah virus, its effectiveness is controversial given its lack of efficacy in several animal models of henipavirus infection. Nevertheless, due to its highly pathogenic nature, much effort has been invested in the development of anti-henipavirus therapeutics. In this review, we describe the unique characteristics of henipavirus infections and the various strategies and animal models that have been developed to date to identify and test potential drugs to prevent or treat henipavirus infections. Some of these components have the potential to be broad spectrum antiviral agents because they target effectors of viral pathogenesis common to other viruses. We will focus on small molecules or biologics rather than vaccine strategies developed as anti-henipaviral therapeutics. © 2011 Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.
authors: Vigant, F.;Lee, B.

title: Analysis of the crow's lung transcriptome in response to infection with the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI) H5N1 currently circulating in Asia causes severe disease in domestic poultry as well as wild birds such as crows. However, the molecular pathogenesis of HPAIV infection in crows and other wild birds is not well understood. Therefore, as a step of investigation, a comprehensive global gene expression analysis was performed on crows infected with HPAI H5N1 crow isolate (A/Crow/India/11TI11/2011) using high-throughput next-generation sequencing (NGS) (GS FLX Titan XLR70 ). The reference crow genome is not available, so RNA-Seq analysis was performed based on a de novo assembled transcriptome. The RNA-seq result shows that 4052 genes were expressed only in uninfected samples, 6277 genes were expressed only in HPAIV-infected samples, and of the 6814 genes that were expressed in both samples, 2279 genes were expressed significantly differently. Our transcriptome profile data allow to understand the molecular mechanism behind the recent fatal HPAIV outbreak in crows, which until recently was thought to cause fatal infections only in gallinaceous birds such as chickens but not in wild birds. The pattern of differentially expressed genes suggests that this isolate of H5N1 virus evades the host's innate immune response by attenuating interferon (IFN)-induced signaling, possibly by downregulating IFN type I (IFNAR1 and IFNAR2 ) and type II IFN receptors, upregulates the signaling inhibitors suppressor of cytokine signaling 1 (SOCS1) and SOCS3 and alters the expression of Toll-like receptors (TLRs). This can be the cause of disease and mortality in crows.
authors: Vijayakumar, P.;Mishra, A.;Ranaware, P. B.;Kolte, A. P.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Burt, D. W.;Raut, A. A.

title: Evaluation of the envelope glycoprotein Erns of an atypical bovine pestivirus as an antigen in a microsphere immunoassay for the detection of antibodies to bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 and atypical bovine pestivirus
abstract: Atypical bovine pestiviruses are antigenically and phylogenetically related to bovine viral diarrheaviruses (BVDV-1 and BVDV-2) and can produce the same clinical manifestations in animals. Glycoprotein Erns of an atypical bovine pestivirus Th/04_KhonKaen was produced in a baculovirus expression system and purified by affinity chromatography. The recombinant Erns protein was used as an antigen in a microsphere immunoassay to detect antibodies to BVDV-1 and atypical bovine pestivirus. The diagnostic performance of the new method was evaluated by testing a total of 596 serum samples and the assay was compared to the Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA). Based on the median negative/positive cutoff fluorescence intensity (MFI) of 2800, the microsphere immunoassay had a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 100% compared to the ELISA. The immunoassay was able to detect antibodies against both BVDV-1 and the atypical pestivirus. This novel microsphere immunoassay has the potential to be multiplexed for the simultaneous detection of antibodies against various bovine pathogens in a high-throughput and economical manner. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Vijayaraghavan, B.;Xia, H.;Harimoorthy, R.;Liu, L.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Pathotyping of a Newcastle disease virus isolated from peafowl (Pavo cristatus).
abstract: This report describes Newcastle disease in peacocks and the isolation and characterization of the virus. The virus had an intracerebral pathogenicity index of 1.71 and a median death time of 47 hours. The isolate had several basic amino acids at the cleavage site sequence of the fusion protein ((110)GGRRQRRFIG(119)) with a phenylalanine at residue 117. Biological and molecular characterization revealed that the virus is velogen. The phylogenetic analysis assigned the isolate to genotype II.
authors: Vijayarani, K.;Muthusamy, S.;Tirumurugaan, K. G.;Sakthivelan, S. M.;Kumanan, K.

title: Human coronavirus OC43 full genome sequence: Molecular clock analysis suggests a relatively recent zoonotic coronavirus transmission event
abstract: Corona viruses are enveloped, positive-stranded RNA viruses with a genome of around 30 kb. Based on genetic similarities, coronaviruses are divided into three groups. Two group 2 coronaviruses, human coronavirus OC43 (HCoV-OC43) and bovine coronavirus (BCoV), share remarkable antigenic and genetic similarities. In this study, we report the first complete genome sequence (30,738 nucleotides) of the prototype HCoV OC43 strain (ATCC VR7S9). Whole genome and open reading frame (ORF) analyzes were performed in comparison to the BCoV genome. There is a 290 nucleotide deletion in the region between the spike and membrane protein genes, corresponding to the absence of the BCoV ORFs ns4.9 and ns4.8. Nucleotide and amino acid similarity percentages were determined for the major HCoV OC43 ORFs and for those of other group 2 coronaviruses. The highest degree of similarity is shown between HCoV-OC43 and BCoV in all ORFs except the E gene. Molecular clock analysis of the spike gene sequences of BCoV and HCoV-OC43 suggest a relatively recent zoonotic transmission event, dating their most recent common ancestor to around 1890. An evolutionary rate on the order of 4 × 10 -4 nucleotide changes per site per year has been estimated. This is the first zoonotic animal-human coronavirus pair that can be analyzed to provide insight into the processes of adaptation of a non-human coronavirus to a human host, which is important for understanding the interspecies transmission events leading to the emergence of the virus Coronavirus have led severe outbreak of acute respiratory syndrome. Copyright © 2005, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Vijgen, L.;Keyaerts, E.;MoÃ«s, E.;Thoelen, I.;Wollants, E.;Lemey, P.;Vandamme, A. M.;Van Ranst, M.

title: Distribution and genetic characterization of enterovirus G and sapelovirus A in six Spanish pig herds
authors: Vilar, M. J.;Peralta, B.;GarcÃ­a-Bocanegra, I.;Simon-GrifÃ©, M.

title: Organization and diversity of the 3'-noncoding region of the classical swine fever virus genome
abstract: Specific PCR primers were chosen to amplify a 359 bp DNA fragment encoding the 3' portion of the polymerase gene and the 3' non-coding (3'-NC) region of the classical swine fever virus genome (CSFV) flanked. In RT-PCR, the selected fragment was amplified from the genomes of 27 virus strains collected over half a century from Europe, America and Asia, and from three vaccine strains of CSFV. Eight PCR products were sequenced using an automated sequencer. The nucleotide sequence analysis was performed with the computer programs DNASTAR and PHYLIP. The comparative studies revealed that the 3'-NC region contains a variable nucleotide region located immediately after the stop codon TGA or TAA. In addition, a highly conserved constant region near the extreme 3' terminus was identified. Two imperfect repeated sequences were found in both the variable and constant regions. In addition, the variable region was characterized by the appearance of a 50 bp poly-AT lane. Phylogenetic analyzes using different mathematical approaches (MegAlign, Neighbor-Joining-Method, Maximum Likelihood, Parsimony) revealed that the investigated CSFV strains were divided into two main phylogenetic groups. Group I consisted of the Brescia reference strain along with ancient American and European field isolates and a Brazilian vaccine strain. Group II included the reference strain Alfort (Tübingen) and newer European field strains. The congenital tremor strain formed a distinct lineage which, although very different, was more closely related to group I than to group II. In summary, the present phylogenetic grouping yielded very similar results to previous studies based on a comparison of the E2 (gp55) region. The agreement of the phylogenetic analysis in the two different regions confirms the reliability of the genetic grouping of CSFV strains into two major genogroups.
authors: VilÄek, Å ;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Genetic diversity of BVDV: implications for classification and molecular epidemiology
abstract: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is important for the accurate classification of viruses and for the development of molecular epidemiology. BVDV isolates were typically typed based on comparison of genomic sequences from the 5" untranslated region (5" UTR), Npro and E2 regions. Recently, we have identified 11 genetic groups (subgenotypes) of BVDV-1. Our further experiments confirmed a new subgenotype, BVDV-1k, isolated from cattle in Switzerland. BVDV isolates from India have been typed as BVDV-1b, while BVDV-1c is a predominant subgenotype in Australia. The results of BVDV genetic typing indicate that the distribution of subgenotypes is unrelated to the geographic origin of the virus isolates. © 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Vilcek, S.;Durkovic, B.;Kolesarova, M.;Paton, D. J.

title: Genetic diversity of recent bovine viral diarrheal viruses from south-eastern Austria (Styria)
abstract: To characterize the isolates of the Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) circulating in the south-east of Austria, namely in Styria, 71 blood samples taken between 1998 and 2000 from persistently infected cattle in 62 herds were subjected to genetic typing. For this purpose, 288 bp fragments from the 5″ untranslated region (5″-UTR) were amplified by polymerase chain reaction after reverse transcription (RT-PCR). The products were sequenced and used for phylogenetic analysis. Seventy virus isolates were typed as BVDV species 1 (BVDV-1). Only one isolate was typed as BVDV species 2 (BVDV-2), which is the first isolate of this pestivirus genotype found in Austria. In addition, phylogenetic analysis revealed that viruses belonging to five genetic groups within BVDV-1 are circulating in Styria. Most viruses (53) were found in group BVDV-1f, nine viruses in BVDV-1h, four viruses in BVDV-1b, three viruses in BVDV-1d and one virus in BVDV-1g. No virus was found in the BVDV-1a genetic group, which is prevalent in the UK and widespread in the US. Likewise, the BVDV isolates predominant in a neighboring country, namely Germany, belonged to different genogroups than those circulating in Styria. We conclude that certain BVDV-1 genetic groups are predominant in a given region and environment. New groups, including BVDV-2, can be introduced, eg through animal trade. The low incidence of BVDV-2 in Styria is consistent with the sporadic occurrence of this virus in other regions of Europe. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Vilcek, S.;Greiser-Wilke, I.;Durkovic, B.;Obritzhauser, W.;Deutz, A.;KÃ¶fer, J.

title: Molecular characterization of sheep pestiviruses
abstract: Forty-two ovine pestivirus isolates collected over an 18-year period were compared by phylogenetic analysis. The viruses were mainly field isolates from Great Britain; two more were from Sweden and two from New Zealand. RT-PCR products were obtained from two genomic regions, one within the 5' non-coding (5'-NC) region and the other encompassing parts of the p20 (N(pro)) and C coding regions. Direct sequencing of the 5'-NC-PCR products, followed by computer-aided phylogenetic analysis, classified the ovine pestiviruses into three major genotypes. The results showed that sheep can be naturally infected not only with border disease virus (BDV), but also with bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) types I and II. The BDV isolates separated into two major subtypes represented by the Moredun strain from Scotland and the 137/4 strain from England. The BVDV-I group consisted of three clusters, two of which were represented by the BVDV reference strains NADL and Osloss, respectively, and the third by the sheep isolates D1120/1 and D1432/P. The grouping of ovine pestiviruses based on a comparative nucleotide sequence analysis of the 5'-NC region was confirmed by a comparative analysis of the p20 (NP(pro)) and C coding regions performed at both the nucleotide and amino acid levels . The occurrence of three genotypes in sheep, including BVDV-I and BVDV-II, indicates the inadequacy of the current host-species-based nomenclature and classification of pestiviruses.
authors: VilÄek, Å ;Nettleton, P. F.;Paton, D. J.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Genetic variability of classical swine fever virus
abstract: The genetic variability of classical swine fever virus was examined by comparative nucleotide sequence analysis of 76 virus isolates collected on three continents during half a century. Portions of the E2 (gp55) and polymerase gene coding regions of the viral genome were amplified by RT-PCR and DNA fragments of 254 and 207 bp, respectively, were sequenced. Comparative sequence analysis of the E2 region revealed two main phylogenetic groups of CSFV, suggesting that the virus apparently evolved from two ancestral nodes. Group I (represented by the Brescia strain) consisted of old and newer American and Asian viruses, as well as old English isolates from the 1950's. This group was divided into three subgroups, designated IA IC. Group II (represented by the Alfort strain) consisted of relatively recent isolates from Europe, along with the Osaka strain isolated in Japan from a pig of European origin. Based on genetic distances, the group was divided into subgroups II.A and II.B. Malaysian isolates have branched into both groups, indicating multiple origins for simultaneous outbreaks in that country. All ten vaccine strains tested were branched into Group I, suggesting a common ancestor. The Japanese Kanagawa strain isolated in 1974 and the British congenital tremor strain of 1964 were the most prominent variants of CSFV in our collection. Comparison of the nucleotide sequences of the polymerase coding region of 32 European strains distinguished subgroups II.A and II.B, which were similar to the corresponding subgroups of the E2 pedigree. Thus, the results indicated that the E2 region and the polymerase-encoding regions appear appropriate for the grouping of CSFV isolates from around the world, distinguishing two main groups of virus. The reliability of these regions for phylogenetic analysis is indicated by the similarity of the results obtained from the two separate parts of the CSFV genome.
authors: VilÄek, Å ;Stadejek, T.;Ballagi-PordÃ¡ny, A.;Lowings, J. P.;Paton, D. J.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Diversity of hepatitis E virus genotype 3: phylogenetic analysis and presence of subtype 3b in wild boar in Europe
abstract: Indigenous hepatitis E cases caused by genotype 3 (HEV-3) viruses are increasingly being diagnosed worldwide, particularly in developed countries. Hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease and accumulating evidence suggests that domestic and wild pigs are the main reservoirs of HEV-3. A detailed analysis of HEV-3 subtypes could help determine the interplay of human activity, the role of animals as reservoirs, and transmission between species. Although full genomic sequences are the most useful for HEV subtype determination, only partial genomic sequences are available in most cases. We therefore performed a subtype classification analysis using regions from all three open reading frames of the genome. More than 1000 published HEV-3 isolates have been subtyped using this approach. Newly obtained HEV partial sequences from killed German wild boar were also included in this study. These sequences have been assigned to genotype 3 and clustered within subtypes 3a, 3i and unexpectedly one of them within subtype 3b, a first non-human report of this subtype in Europe.
authors: Vina-Rodriguez, A.;Schlosser, J.;Becher, D.;Kaden, V.;Groschup, M. H.;Eiden, M.

title: Investigation of human cancers for retroviruses by low-stringency target enrichment and high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Although almost one fifth of all human cancers have an infectious etiology, the causes of most cancers remain unexplained. Despite the enormous data output from high-throughput shotgun sequencing, viral DNA in a clinical sample typically represents a fraction of the host DNA that is too small to be detected. Sequence variations between viral genomes complicate the use of sequence-specific and highly sensitive PCR methods. It was therefore our goal to develop and characterize a method that allows sensitive detection of sequences despite considerable variation. We show that our low stringency in-solution hybridization method enables the detection of <100 virus copies. Furthermore, distantly related proviral sequences can be enriched by orders of magnitude, enabling the discovery of previously unknown viral sequences by high-throughput sequencing. The sensitivity was sufficient to detect retroviral sequences in clinical specimens. We used this method to screen for novel retroviruses in samples from three cancer types. Consistent with recent studies, our investigation revealed no retroviral infections in human B-cell lymphoma, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, or colon cancer biopsies. Nevertheless, our generally applicable method enables sensitive detection and allows sequencing of distantly related sequences from complex material.
authors: Vinner, L.;Mourier, T.;Friis-Nielsen, J.;Gniadecki, R.;Dybkaer, K.;Rosenberg, J.;Langhoff, J. L.;Cruz, D. F.;Fonager, J.;Izarzugaza, J. M.;Gupta, R.;Sicheritz-Ponten, T.;Brunak, S.;Willerslev, E.;Nielsen, L. P.;Hansen, A. J.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis of the variable region of the VP2 gene of two infectious bursal virus isolates from commercial poultry farms
abstract: Two isolates of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) were obtained from commercial poultry farms with a history of severe outbreaks. A 474 bp product encompassing the hypervariable region of the IBDV VP2 gene was amplified by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). The nucleotide sequences of two isolates, VMB1 and VMB2, were determined and compared to twenty IBDV strains, including seven very virulent, four classically virulent, four classically attenuated, three antigenic variants and two avirulent serotype 2 strains. The two isolates showed 96.5–98.4% similarity to very virulent strains, 84.6–94.6% to classically virulent strains, 90.0–91.4% to classical attenuated strains, 83.0– 91.9% with antigenic variants and 65.8-68.7% with avirulent strains. The deduced amino acid sequences of the two isolates revealed amino acid substitutions of V256I, N279D, L294I and N299S, specific for very virulent strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the two isolates, along with a reported highly virulent Indian strain, were closely related to European, Japanese and Chinese highly virulent strains, indicating their evolutionary origin.
authors: Viswas, K. N.;Muniyappa, L.;Suryanarayana, V. V. S.;Byregowda, S. M.

title: Experimental infection of conventional nurse pigs and their dams with porcine deltacoronavirus
abstract: Porcine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV) is a newly identified virus that has been shown to be associated with enteric disease in swine herds in North America. The aim of this study was to demonstrate the pathogenicity, course of infection, viral kinetics and aerosol transmission of PDCoV using 87 conventional piglets and their 9 dams, including aerosol and contact controls to emulate field conditions.
