Piglets aged 2-4 days and their dams were administered an oronasal PDCoV inoculum with a quantitative real-time reverse transcription (qRT)-PCR quantification cycle (Cq) value of 22 generated from a field sample with 100% nucleotide identity USA/Illinois121/2014 was determined by metagenomic sequencing and negative testing for other enteric pathogens using standard assays. Serial samples of blood, serum, oral fluids, nasal and stool swabs, and tissues from sequential autopsies performed daily on days 1-8 and periodically thereafter were collected for qRT-PCR, histopathology, and immunohistochemistry throughout the 42-day study . Diarrhea developed in all vaccinated and contact control pigs, including dams, 2 days post-inoculation (dpi) and in aerosol control pigs and dams 3-4 dpi, with resolution occurring at 12 dpi. Mild to severe atrophic enteritis with PDCoV antigen staining was observed in the small intestine of affected piglets from 2 to 8 dpi. The mesenteric lymph node and small intestine were the primary sites of antigen detection by immunohistochemistry, and viral RNA was detected in these tissues up to the end of the study. Viral RNA was detectable in fecal swabs from piglets up to 21 dpi and from dams up to 14-35 dpi.
authors: Vitosh-Sillman, S.;Loy, J. D.;Brodersen, B.;Kelling, C.;Doster, A.;Topliff, C.;Nelson, E.;Bai, J.;Schirtzinger, E.;Poulsen, E.;Meadors, B.;Anderson, J.;Hause, B.;Anderson, G.;Hesse, R.

title: Novel hemotropic mycoplasma are widespread and genetically diverse in vampire bats
abstract: Bats (order: Chiroptera) have been extensively studied as reservoir hosts for viruses important to human and animal health. However, whether bats are equally competent hosts for non-viral pathogens as bacteria remains an important open question. Here we analyzed blood and saliva samples from vampire bats from Peru and Belize for hemotropic Mycoplasma spp. (hemoplasma), bacteria that can cause inapparent infection or anemia in hosts. 16S rRNA gene amplification of blood showed that 67% (150/223) of common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) were infected with hemoplasma. Sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene amplicons revealed three new genotypes that were phylogenetically related but not identical to hemoplasma described from other (non-vampire) bat species, rodents, humans, and non-human primates. Hemoplasm prevalence in vampire bats was highest in non-reproductive and young individuals, did not differ between countries, and was relatively stable (ie, endemic) over time. Metagenomics from pooled D. rotundus saliva from Peru discovered non-hemotropic mycoplasma species and hemoplasma genotypes phylogenetically similar to those identified in blood, providing indirect evidence for possible direct transmission of hemoplasma through biting or social contact. This study shows that vampire bats harbor several novel hemoplasmas and sheds light on risk factors for infection and basic modes of transmission. Given the high frequency of direct contact that occurs when vampire bats eat humans, domestic animals, and wildlife, the potential for these bacteria to be transmitted between species should be explored in future work.
authors: Volokhov, D. V.;Becker, D. J.;Bergner, L. M.;Camus, M. S.;Orton, R. J.;Chizhikov, V. E.;Altizer, S. M.;Streicker, D. G.

title: Lung changes in Norwegian fatal cases of pandemic influenza H1N1 infection (2009): a morphological and molecular genetic study
abstract: BACKGROUND: During the 2009 swine influenza (A(H1N1)pdm09) pandemic outbreak in Norway, 32 fatal cases occurred, of which 19 were included in this study. OBJECTIVES: We characterized pulmonary changes in these fatal Norwegian cases. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Detailed clinical information and upper and lower airway specimens were collected after hospitalization. At autopsy, lung tissue was collected, fixed in formalin, and embedded in paraffin. Immunohistochemical and light microscopy studies were performed to visualize local expression of the A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and pyrosequencing of the unfixed samples enabled the identification of mutations in the influenza virus surface glycoprotein (hemagglutinin gene) particularly at position 222. RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS: The overall course of the disease lasted from 2 to 40 days (median 9 days). Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) was evident in 11 cases, 4 of which had no apparent underlying disease. Obesity was evident in 12 cases, with three people classified as otherwise healthy. The HA D222G mutation was detected in six cases, 3 of which had no underlying disease. Immunohistochemistry showed that A(H1N1)pdm09 virus is prominent at the site of inflammation both in close proximity to and within alveolar structures in lung tissue. In addition to a possible role for the HA-D222G mutation, our results indicate that host factors and underlying diseases in the infected individuals are of fundamental importance for the course of the disease in many cases. This study advances our understanding of the determinants of clinical outcome of pandemic influenza that may guide future treatment.
authors: Voltersvik, P.;Aqrawi, L. A.;Dudman, S.;Hungnes, O.;Norwegian Lung Pathology, G.;Bostad, L.;Brokstad, K. A.;Cox, R. J.

title: 99th Dahlem Conference on Infection, Inflammation and Chronic Inflammatory Diseases: Agricultural Lifestyles and the Hygiene Hypothesis
abstract: About 15 years have passed since Strachan first put forward the idea that infection and unsanitary contact can offer protection against the development of allergic diseases. The so-called "hygiene hypothesis" has since undergone numerous modifications in the fields of epidemiology, clinical science and immunology. Three main areas of research were advanced: exploring the role of overt viral and bacterial infections in the etiology of allergic diseases; to investigate the importance of environmental exposure to microbial compounds for the development of allergies; and to examine the effect of both exposures on the underlying innate and adaptive immune responses. A concept that unifies these different aspects has not been found, but different parts of a complex interplay between host immune responses, properties of the invading microorganism, the extent and variety of environmental exposure, and the interactions between the genetic background of an exposed subject and the environmental pressures become visible. A natural experiment on the hygiene hypothesis is the recurring observation of a protective effect of growing up on a farm for asthma and allergies. This has been shown in a large number of epidemiological studies worldwide in children and adults. The timing and duration of exposure probably play a crucial role. The greatest risk reduction was demonstrated for those who were exposed prenatally and then continuously into adulthood. The protective factors in these agricultural environments are not yet fully elucidated. Findings from various studies indicate that contact with livestock confers protection, at least in childhood. The consumption of unprocessed cow's milk directly from the farm has also been proven to protect against asthma and allergies in children. Increased levels of microbial substances can at least partially contribute to the "farm effect". However, few studies have measured microbial exposure in these environments and the results obtained so far suggest that the underlying protective microbial exposure(s) have not been identified, but a number of studies have using metagenomic approaches are currently underway. The mechanisms by which such environmental exposures confer protection against respiratory allergies are also not well understood. There is good evidence for the involvement of innate immune responses, but translation into protective mechanisms for asthma and allergies is lacking. In addition, a number of gene-environment interactions have been observed. © 2010 British Society for Immunology.
authors: Von Mutius, E.

title: The possible role played by buffalo in recent outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in South Africa
abstract: The African buffalo (Syncerus caffer) serves as a maintenance host for foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in southern Africa. A single buffalo can become infected with all three endemic serotypes of FMD virus (SAT-1, SAT-2, and SAT-3) and pose a risk of infection to other susceptible cloven-hoofed animals. The 2000 floods in southern Africa severely damaged the Kruger National Park (KNP) deer fence and there were several reports of buffalo escaping the park. The VP1 gene, which encodes the major antigenic determinant of FMD virus, was used to determine phylogenetic relationships between virus isolates recovered from the outbreaks and those previously recovered from buffalo in the KNP. These results show that buffalo were most likely the source of the outbreaks, suggesting that disease control through fencing, as well as vaccination, is extremely important to ensure FMD does not become established in livestock populations.
authors: Vosloo, W.;Boshoff, K.;Dwarka, R.;Bastos, A.

title: Genome variation in the SAT types of foot-and-mouth disease viruses prevalent in buffalo (Syncerus caffer) in Kruger National Park and other regions of southern Africa, 1986-93
abstract: Dideoxynucleotide sequencing of a portion of the 1D gene of SAT-type foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) was used to infer phylogenetic relationships between viruses recovered from the oesophago-pharyngeal secretions of buffalo in Kruger National Park as well as several viruses became other wildlife sanctuaries in southern Africa. The three serotypes differed from each other by more than 40%, while the intratypical variation did not exceed 29%. Within each type, isolates from certain countries were more closely related to each other than to isolates from other countries, lending credence to previous observations that FMD evolved independently in different regions of the subcontinent.
authors: Vosloo, W.;Kirkbride, E.;Bengis, R. G.;Keet, D. F.;Thomson, G. R.

title: What should the chickenpox virus be called?
authors: Votava, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the polyprotein coding region of an infectious strain of South African bursal disease virus (IBDV).
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) causes gumboro disease, which is highly contagious and immunosuppressive in young chickens. A virulent form of IBDV entered South Africa in 1989 and little molecular information is available on this strain to date. In this study, the polyprotein coding region of the South African strain SA-KZN95 was sequenced and analyzed along with 52 representative sequences from other serotype I and II strains. We examined the relative impact of recombination on phylogenetic reconstruction using a multidimensional scaling approach. Phylogenetic analyzes consistently placed the South African isolate within the very virulent IBDV clade. Selection analyzes were also performed to identify evolutionarily relevant amino acid residues. Previously, 19 residues in the polyprotein were shown to be potentially diagnostic for the different IBDV pathotypes. This study identified two additional unique residues in the polyprotein that can be used as genetic signatures in future viral identifications. Better strain identification would support vaccine development and application. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Vukea, P. R.;Willows-Munro, S.;Horner, R. F.;Coetzer, T. H. T.

title: Human spermidine synthase: cloning and primary structure
abstract: Using a synthetic deoxyoligonucleotide mixture constructed for a bovine enzyme tryptic peptide as a probe, cDNA encoding the complete subunit of spermidine synthase was isolated from a human decidual cDNA library constructed on phage γgt11. After subcloning into the EcoRI site of pBR322 and amplification, both strands of the insert were sequenced using a shotgun strategy. Starting from the first initiation codon, immediately preceded by a GC-rich region encompassing four overlapping CCGCC consensus sequences, an open reading frame for a 302 amino acid long polypeptide was resolved. This peptide had an M(r) of 33,827, started with methionine and ended with serine. The identity of the isolated cDNA was confirmed by comparison of the deduced amino acid sequence with resolved sequences of bovine spermidine synthase tryptic peptides. The coding strand of the cDNA showed no specific regulatory or ribosome binding signals within 82 nucleotides before the start codon and no polyadenylation signal within 247 nucleotides after the stop codon. The coding region, which contained a 13 nucleotide repeat near the 5' end, was longer than and quite different from its bacterial counterpart. This region appears to be of retroviral origin and shows significant homology with sequences found in a variety of human, mammalian, avian, and viral genes and mRNAs. By computer analysis, the first 200 nucleotides of the 5' end of the coding strand appear to be capable of forming a very stable secondary structure with a free energy change of -157.6 kcal/mol. In Northern blot hybridization experiments, the labeled cDNA specifically recognized a 1.5 kb poly(A)+ RNA from cultured human and murine cell lines.
authors: Wahlfors, J.;Alhonen, L.;Kauppinen, L.;Hyvonen, T.;Janne, J.;Eloranta, T. O.

title: Evolutionary insights into the common bean mosaic necrosis virus and the cowpea aphid transmitted mosaic virus
abstract: Plant viral diseases are one of the major constraints in legume production in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), accounting for up to 100% of production losses on smallholder farms. In this study, field surveys were conducted in the western highlands of Kenya, collecting viral symptomatic leaf samples. Next-generation sequencing was then performed to provide insight into the molecular evolution and evolutionary relationships of Bean Common Mosaic Necrosis Virus (BCMNV) and Cowpea Aphid Borne Mosaic Virus (CABMV) found in symptomatic communities Beans and cowpeas are present. Eleven nearly complete genomes of BCMNV and two of CABMV were obtained from western Kenya. Bayesian phylogenomic analyzes and tests for differential selection pressures within sites and across tree branches of the viral genomes were performed. Three well-supported clades in BCMNV and one supported clade for CABMNV were resolved and matched individual gene trees. Analysis of selection pressures within sites and across phylogenetic branches suggested that both viruses evolved independently, but under strong purifying selection at a slow evolutionary rate. These results provide valuable insights into the evolution of BCMNV and CABMV genomes and their relationship to other viral genomes worldwide. The results will contribute significantly to addressing the knowledge gap affecting the phylogenomic relationship of these viruses, particularly for CABMV for which few genome sequences are available, and will inform current breeding efforts towards BCMNV and CABMV resistance.
authors: Wainaina, J. M.;Kubatko, L.;Harvey, J.;Ateka, E.;Makori, T.;Karanja, D.;Boykin, L. M.;Kehoe, M. A.

title: In vivo characterization of two Australian isolates of Marek's disease virus, including pathology, viral load and neuropathotyping based on clinical signs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the pathogenicity of Australian Marek's disease virus (MDV), isolate MPF23 (1985) against the reference strain MPF57 based on pathology, viral load and neuropathotyping based on clinical signs. METHODS: Two MDV challenge isolates (MPF57 or MPF23) were administered to unvaccinated, specific pathogen-free (SPF) layer chicks on day 5 post hatch at three challenge doses (500, 2000 or 8000 plaque forming units (pfu)/chick). . Mortality, body weight, immune organ weights, MDV load in peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL), and clinical signs were measured up to 56 days post-challenge (dpc). RESULTS: MPF23 was the more pathogenic of the two viruses and resulted in a higher mortality (81% vs. 62%) and a higher incidence of MD lesions (100% vs. 76%). MPF23 induced earlier, more persistent and more severe neurological signs in the period 26-56 dpc. However, there were few differences during the 0-23 dpc used in the neuropathotyping classification to be tested. The pattern observed during this earlier period classified both viruses as neuropathotype B, consistent with a very virulent pathotype. MDV burden in PBL at 7 and 44 dpc did not differ between virus isolates, but burden at 7 dpc was significantly and negatively associated with time to euthanasia or death. CONCLUSION: MPF23 appears to be at least as virulent as the MDV strains isolated over the following two decades. The neuropathotyping system developed in the USA did not clearly distinguish between the two isolates tested; However, extending the time to assess clinical symptoms beyond 26 dpc showed clear differences.
authors: Wajid, S. J.;Walkden-Brown, S. W.;Vanselow, B. A.;Islam, A. F.;Renz, K. G.

title: ICTV virus taxonomy profile: Rhabdoviridae
abstract: The family Rhabdoviridae includes viruses with negative-sense (-) single-stranded RNA genomes of 10.8-16.1 kb. Virions are typically enveloped with a spherical or bacilliform morphology, but may also be non-enveloped filaments. Rhabdoviruses infect plants and animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, and fish, as well as arthropods, which serve as single hosts or act as biological vectors for transmission to animals or plants. Rhabdoviruses are important pathogens of humans, livestock, fish and agricultural crops. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the taxonomy of Rhabdoviridae, available at www.ictv.global/report/rhabdoviridae.
authors: Walker, P. J.;Blasdell, K. R.;Calisher, C. H.;Dietzgen, R. G.;Kondo, H.;Kurath, G.;Longdon, B.;Stone, D. M.;Tesh, R. B.;Tordo, N.;Vasilakis, N.;Whitfield, A. E.;Lefkowitz, E. J.;Davison, A. J.;Siddell, S. G.;Simmonds, P.;Sabanadzovic, S.;Smith, D. B.;Orton, R. J.

title: A global genomic characterization of nairoviruses identifies nine discrete genogroups with distinctive structural features and host-vector associations
abstract: Nairoviruses are primarily tick-borne bunyaviruses, some of which are known to cause mild to severe febrile illness in humans or livestock. We describe the genome sequences of 11 poorly characterized nairoviruses that have ecological associations with either birds (viruses Farallon, Punta Salinas, Sapphire II, Zirqa, Avalon, Clo Mor, Taggert, and Abu Hammad), rodents (viruses Qalyub and Bandia), or camels (Dera -Ghazi Khan virus). Global phylogenetic analyzes of proteins encoded in the L, M, and S RNA segments of these and 20 other available nairovirus genomes identified nine well-supported genogroups (Nairobi sheep disease, Thiafora, Sakhalin, Keterah, Qalyub, Kasokero , Dera Ghazi Khan, Hughes , and Tamdy). Genogroup-specific structural variations were evident, particularly in the M segment, which encodes a polyprotein from which virion envelope glycoproteins (Gn and Gc) are generated by proteolytic processing. Structural variations include the extension, truncation, or absence of sequences encoding an O-glycosylated mucin-like protein in the N-terminal domain, distinctive patterns of conserved cysteine residues in the GP38-like domain, insertion of sequences expressing a double-membrane span encode protein (NSm) between the Gn and Gc domains and the presence of an alternative long open reading frame encoding a viroporin-like transmembrane protein (Gx). We also observed strong genogroup-specific associations with host and tick vector categories.
authors: Walker, P. J.;Widen, S. G.;Wood, T. G.;Guzman, H.;Tesh, R. B.;Vasilakis, N.

title: The history of bluetongue disease and a current global overview
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) disease was first reported more than 125 years ago when European breeds of sheep were introduced to southern Africa. BT virus (BTV) has been identified in many tropical and temperate regions of the world. BT, the disease, is a ruminant phenomenon in temperate zones. Clinical diseases are few in the tropical and subtropical regions of the world. At least 24 serotypes of BTV have been described. While the viruses are classified antigenically and taxonomically as BTV, each serotype is unique and may not cause BT disease. The BTVs are transmitted among ruminants by competent vector species of the genus Culicoides, ie mosquitoes or midges. BTV serotypes exist with vector species of Culicoides in predictable, but finite, geographic and ecological cycles or ecosystems around the world. Despite the almost certain movement of livestock and Culicoides species between these ecosystems, there is little evidence that introduced BTV serotypes have become established in these ecosystems. Rather, periodic cyclical expansions and regressions of these virus-vector ecosystems allow the virus and disease to move into and out of adjacent, non-endemic areas in a pattern common to many other known arthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses). is characteristic. Previous publications suggested that a carrier condition occurred in cattle infected with BTV as fetuses. No subsequent natural experience or research supports the hypothesis, which has not been validated. The conclusions of the research are not accepted by the scientific community. It is therefore logical to propose that regulatory restrictions on the movement of cattle from BTV-affected countries be relaxed or removed.
authors: Walton, T. E.

title: Detection of African swine fever virus-like sequences in ponds in the Mississippi Delta by metagenomic sequencing
abstract: The metagenomic characterization of aquatic vioma was performed in four catfish ponds in Mississippi. Although they differed significantly from African swine fever virus (ASFV), 48 of 446,100 sequences from 12 samples were similar enough to indicate that they represent new members in the Asfarviridae family. Currently, ASFV is the only member of the Asfarviridae and this study provides the first evidence of a similar virus in North America. At this time there is no evidence that the identified viruses pose a threat to human or animal health and further research is needed to characterize their potential risks to both public health and agricultural development. © 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Wan, X. F.;Barnett, J. L.;Cunningham, F.;Chen, S.;Yang, G.;Nash, S.;Long, L. P.;Ford, L.;Blackmon, S.;Zhang, Y.;Hanson, L.;He, Q.

title: Perspective on the emergence and recurrence of amantadine-resistant influenza A virus in domestic animals in China
abstract: In China, about 20% of animal-derived influenza A viruses have molecular markers for amantadine resistance. Through phylogenetic data analysis and geospatial statistical analysis, this study suggests that the emergence of amantadine resistance in animal influenza may be due to selective pressures in China, such as the use of amantadine in some areas. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Wan, X. F.;Carrel, M.;Long, L. P.;Alker, A. P.;Emch, M.

title: Identification of novel and differentially expressed microRNAs in enzootic goat nasal adenocarcinoma
abstract: Background: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) post-transcriptionally regulate a variety of genes involved in growth, development, metabolism, and other biological processes in eukaryotic cells, and numerous miRNAs are involved in cancer development and progression. Enzootic nasal adenocarcinoma (ENA), an epithelial tumor induced in goats and sheep by enzootic nasal tumor virus (ENTV), is a chronic, progressive, contact-borne disease. Methods: In this work, small RNA Illumina high-throughput sequencing was used to construct a goat nasal miRNA library. This study aimed to identify novel and differentially expressed miRNAs in tumor and paracarcinoma nasal tissues of Nanjiang yellow goats with ENA. Results: Four hundred six known miRNAs and 29 new miRNAs were identified. A total of 116 miRNAs were significantly differentially expressed in paracarcinoma nasal tissues and ENA (54 down-regulated; 60 up-regulated; two expressed only in the control group); Target gene prediction and functional analysis revealed that 6176 non-redundant target genes, 1792 significant GO and 97 significant KEGG signaling pathways were predicted for 121 miRNAs (116 significant expression miRNAs and five-star sequence). Analysis of the GO and KEGG signaling pathways revealed that the majority of target genes in ENA are involved in cell proliferation, signaling and other processes associated with cancer. Conclusions: This is the first large-scale identification of miRNAs in Capra hircus ENA and provides a theoretical basis for studying the intricate miRNA-mediated regulatory networks involved in ENA pathogenesis and progression.
authors: Wang, B.;Ye, N.;Cao, S. J.;Wen, X. T.;Huang, Y.;Yan, Q. G.

title: Microbial phylogeny determines the transcriptional response of the resistome to dynamic composting processes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Animal manure is a reservoir of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) that pose a potential health risk worldwide, particularly for resistance to antibiotics commonly used in animal production (such as tetracycline, sulfonamide, and fluoroquinolone). At present, the effects of biological treatment (composting) on the transcriptional response of manure ARGs and their microbial hosts are not well characterized. Composting is a dynamic process consisting of four different phases differentiated by the temperature resulting from microbial activity, namely the mesophilic, thermophilic, cooling and maturation phase. In this study, changes in resistome expression were determined and related to active microbiome profiles during the dynamic composting process. This was achieved by integrating metagenomic and metatranscriptomic time series data for the developing microbial community during composting. RESULTS: Composting markedly reduced the aggregate expression level of the manure resistome, which consisted mainly of genes encoding tetracycline, vancomycin, fluoroquinolone, beta-lactam and aminoglycoside resistance and efflux pumps. Furthermore, a differential transcriptional response of Resistom to composting at the ARG level was highlighted. Expression of tetracycline resistance genes (tetM-tetW-tetO-tetS) decreased during composting, with marked shifts in the four stages of composting being associated with variations in antibiotic concentration. Composting had no effect on the expression of sulfonamide and fluoroquinolone resistance genes, which increased slightly during the thermophilic period and then declined to initial levels. As indigenous populations changed widely during dynamic composting, the core resistome persisted and the composition of their reservoir hosts significantly correlated with dynamic active microbial phylogenetic structure. Hosts for sulfonamide and fluoroquinolone resistance genes changed markedly in their phylogenetic structure, experiencing an initial increase and then a decrease in frequency. In contrast, hosts for tetracycline resistance genes (tetM-tetW-tetO-tetS) showed a constant decline over time. CONCLUSIONS: The transcriptional patterns of a nuclear resistome during composting were identified, and microbial phylogeny was the key factor in defining the differential transcriptional response of the resistome to this dynamic biological process. This research demonstrated the benefits of composting for manure treatment. It reduced the risk of emerging environmental contaminants such as tetracyclines, tetracycline resistance genes and clinically relevant pathogens bearing ARGs, as well as RNA viruses and bacteriophages.
authors: Wang, C.;Dong, D.;Strong, P. J.;Zhu, W.;Ma, Z.;Qin, Y.;Wu, W.

title: Comprehensive virome analyzes demonstrate the complexity and diversity of the viral spectrum in pediatric patients diagnosed with severe and mild hand, foot, and mouth disease
abstract: Treatment of the hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) epidemic is challenging because non-EV71 and non-CVA16 enteroviruses are common and some cases have tested negative for HFMD-associated pathogens. To clarify the virus spectrum of mild and severe HFMD, a comprehensive viroma analysis of 238 samples was carried out using next-generation sequencing (NGS). The data showed a total of thirteen mammalian and plant virus families and diverse virus populations, including enteroviruses, common respiratory viruses, diarrheal viruses, plant viruses and anelloviruses. A total of 18 viruses from 7 virus families were identified in severe cases versus 37 viruses from 12 virus families in mild cases. In addition, complicated mixed infections of enteroviruses with common respiratory viruses were mainly found in severe cases (P=0.013), while diarrheal viruses were mainly found in mild cases (P<0.001). This study provides the preliminary understanding of viromas in both mild and severe cases, which may benefit pathogen detection and prevention of HFMD.
authors: Wang, C.;Zhou, S.;Xue, W.;Shen, L.;Huang, W.;Zhang, Y.;Li, X.;Wang, J.;Zhang, H.;Ma, X.

title: Isolation, full genome sequencing, and phylogenetic analysis of the first chuzan virus in China
abstract: chuzan virus (CHUV), defined here as GX871, was first isolated in China from the blood of sentinel cattle and its full-length genome was sequenced in this study. The GX871 genome was 10 segments and 18914 bp, one base less than the CHUV prototype strain K-47 due to a one base deletion in the 5 inch noncoding region of segment 8. In a short encoding, a frameshift mutation detected region (1010-1026 nt) corresponding to VP1 protein; this frameshift resulted in a five amino acid mutation from 336CVLSY340 to 336YGAKL340. In addition, there was a one base deletion at 1713 nt and a one base insertion at 1682 nt in the 3'' non-coding region of segment 5. Based on a phylogenetic analysis of the deduced VP2 amino acid sequences, viruses of the palyam serogroup have been identified in divided into three groups. The Chinese CHUV isolate GX871 has been placed in the same group as the CHUV prototype strain K-47. The pedigree was divided into three clusters according to the geographic distribution of the partial nucleotide sequences of VP7, and this arrangement might define the geographic gene pool of CHUV.
authors: Wang, F.;Lin, J.;Chang, J.;Cao, Y.;Qin, S.;Wu, J.;Yu, L.

title: Plasma viromes from bovines from forest regions displayed various small circular ssDNA virus genomes
abstract: Background: Free-ranging cattle are widespread in northeast China, which have close contact with farmers and can transmit viruses that threaten cattle and farmers. Methods: Using viral metagenomics, we analyzed virome in plasma samples from 80 cattle from the forested region of Northeast China. Results: The bovine plasma virome consists of the viruses belonging to families including Parvoviridae, Papillomaviridae, Picobirnaviridae, and divergent viral genomes that share sequence similarity to circular Rep-encoding single-stranded DNA (CRESS) viruses. Five such CRESS DNA genomes have been fully characterized, with Rep sequences related to circovirus and gemycircular virus. Three bovine parvoviruses belonging to two different genera have also been characterized. Conclusion: Virome was revealed in bovine plasma samples from the forested region of Northeast China, further characterizing the viral diversity in bovine plasma.
authors: Wang, H.;Li, S.;Mahmood, A.;Yang, S.;Wang, X.;Shen, Q.;Shan, T.;Deng, X.;Li, J.;Hua, X.;Cui, L.;Delwart, E.;Zhang, W.

title: Novel phlebovirus with zoonotic potential isolated from ticks, Australia
abstract: Recently discovered tick-borne phleboviruses have been linked to serious illness and death in individuals in Asia and the United States. We report the discovery of a novel tick-borne phlebovirus in the state of Tasmania, Australia, which is closely related to zoonotic viruses found in Asia and North America.
authors: Wang, J.;Selleck, P.;Yu, M.;Ha, W.;Rootes, C.;Gales, R.;Wise, T.;Crameri, S.;Chen, H.;Broz, I.;Hyatt, A.;Woods, R.;Meehan, B.;McCullough, S.;Wang, L. F.

title: Identification of the precursors of Indonesian and Vietnamese avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses from southern China
abstract: Transmission of the highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu virus to Southeast Asian countries triggered the first major outbreak and transmission wave in late 2003, accelerating the global threat of a pandemic. Due to the lack of influenza surveillance prior to these outbreaks, the genetic diversity and transmission routes of the H5N1 viruses from this period remain undefined. To determine the possible source of the H5N1 wave 1 viruses, we recently performed further sequencing and analysis of samples collected from 2001-2004 from live poultry markets in Guangdong, Hunan and Yunnan in southern China. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes from 73 H5N1 isolates from this period revealed greater genetic diversity in southern China than previously reported. In addition, the results show that eight viruses isolated from Yunnan in 2002 and 2003 were most closely related to the clade 1 virus sublineage from Vietnam, Thailand and Malaysia, while two viruses isolated from Hunan in 2002 and were most closely related to viruses from Indonesia in 2003 (Group 2.1). Further phylogenetic analysis of the six internal genes showed that all 10 of these viruses maintained similar phylogenetic relationships as the surface genes. The 10 progenitor viruses were of genotype Z and had a high degree of similarity (≥ 99%) to their respective progeny viruses in most gene segments. These results suggest a direct transmission link for H5N1 virus between Yunnan and Vietnam and between Hunan and Indonesia in 2002 and 2003. The poultry trade could be responsible for the introduction of the virus into Vietnam, while the route of transmission from Hunan to Indonesia remains unclear. Copyright © 2008, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Wang, J.;Vijaykrishna, D.;Duan, L.;Bahl, J.;Zhang, J. X.;Webster, R. G.;Peiris, J. S. M.;Chen, H.;Smith, G. J. D.;Guan, Y.

title: Transcriptomic analysis identifies candidate genes and sets of genes that control the response of porcine peripheral blood mononuclear cells to poly-I:C stimulation
abstract: Polyinosine-polycytidylic acid (poly I:C), a synthetic dsRNA analogue, has been shown to have similar stimulatory effects to viral dsRNA. In the present study, in order to gain deep knowledge of the transcriptional response of the host of pigs to poly-I:C stimulation, we cultured peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from piglets of a Chinese native breed (Dapulian) and a modern commercial breed and stimulated (Landrace) with poly I:C, and compared their transcription profiles using RNA sequencing (RNA-seq). Our results showed that poly-I:C stimulation can induce significantly differentially expressed (DE) genes in Dapulian (g=290) as well as Landrace (g=85). We also performed a gene set analysis using the Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) package and identified some significantly enriched gene sets in Dapulian (g=18) and Landrace (g=21). Most of the shared DE genes and gene sets were immune related and may play critical rules in the immune response to poly I:C stimulation. Furthermore, when comparing the gene expression profile between the two breeds, including control and poly I:C stimulation groups, we discovered large sets of significantly DE genes and enriched gene sets. Besides immune-related functions, some of the DE genes and sets of genes between the two breeds were involved in the development and growth of different tissues, which may be correlated with the different traits of the two breeds. The DE genes and gene sets discovered here provide crucial information for understanding the immune regulation of antiviral responses and the molecular mechanisms of differential genetic resistance to viral infections in modern and domestic pigs.
authors: Wang, J.;Wang, Y.;Wang, H.;Wang, H.;Liu, J. F.;Wu, Y.;Guo, J.

title: Characterization of emerging Newcastle disease virus isolates in China
abstract: Summary Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is a devastating worldwide poultry disease characterized by increased respiration, circulatory disturbances, hemorrhagic enteritis and nervous signs. Sequence analysis reveals multiple amino acid residue substitutions at neutralizing epitopes on the F and HN proteins of recent Shaanxi strains. Both cross-protection and cross-serum neutralization tests showed that the conventional vaccine strains could not provide complete protection for the flocks. Methods: To better understand the epidemiology of Newcastle disease outbreak, a partial F gene and the complete HN gene were amplified from Shaanxi isolates by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), followed by sequence and phylogenetic analyzes performed. In the pathogenicity analysis, tests were performed on both the high intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) and the mean time to death (MDT) of chick embryos. In addition, a cross-protection experiment was also conducted in which specific pathogen-free chickens vaccinated with a LaSota vaccine strain were challenged with the new Shaanxi strain. Results: Nine isolates of Newcastle disease (ND) virus (NDV) recovered from ND outbreaks in chicken flocks in China were genotypically and pathotypically characterized. Amino acid sequence analysis revealed that all NDVs recently isolated in Shaanxi have <sup>112</sup>RRQKRF<sup>117</sup> for the C-terminus of F2 protein and have high ICPI and MDT of chick embryos. suggesting that they were all classified as velogenic NDVs. Phylogenetic analysis of these isolates showed that they belong to subgenotype VIId, which has been implicated in recent outbreaks in northwestern China. The percentage of amino acid sequence identity of F protein between recent Shaanxi strains and five vaccine strains ranged from 81.9%-88.1%, while the percentage of amino acid sequence identity of HN protein between recent Shaanxi strains and vaccine strains ranged from 81 .9% to 88.1% ranged from 87.4%-91.2%. In addition, a number of amino acid residue substitutions at neutralizing epitopes on the F and HN proteins of these isolates were observed, which may result in an alteration in antibody recognition and neutralization capacity. A cross-protection experiment showed that specific pathogen-free chickens vaccinated with a LaSota vaccine strain could not provide complete protection for the flocks challenged by the recent Shaanxi strain. Conclusions: Taken together, our results indicate that the recent Shannxi NDV strains exhibit antigenic variations that may be responsible for the recent outbreaks of NDVs in northwestern China.
authors: Wang, J. Y.;Liu, W. H.;Ren, J. J.;Tang, P.;Wu, N.;Wu, H. Y.;Ching, C. D.;Liu, H. J.

title: Genome sequence characterization of pigeon circoviruses in China
abstract: Pigeon circovirus (PiCV) was detected by PCR in pigeons from China. A total of 48 pigeons out of 244 tested positive for PiCV (positive rate 19.67%), indicating that the virus was widespread in China. From the 48 PiCV-positive samples, approximately 2040 bp complete genome fragments were obtained by full-length genome amplification and sequenced using a next-generation sequencing platform. The properties of the ORFs of different PiCV strains tested in this study were analyzed. Several insertions, deletions or substitutions were discovered during analysis of the nucleotide sequence compared to previously reported sequences. In the phylogenetic tree analysis, 48 sequences isolated in this study could be further subdivided into five clades (A, B, C, D and F), clade E contains only reference sequences. Two main groups were found in the six clades, differing by ATA and ATG initiation codons. Most of the viruses isolated in the study belonged to the ATG group, less to the ATA branch.
authors: Wang, K. C.;Zhuang, Q. Y.;Qiu, Y.;Wang, T.;Chen, J. M.

title: New variant of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus, USA, 2014
authors: Wang, L.;Byrum, B.;Zhang, Y.

title: Classification of duck hepatitis virus into three genotypes based on molecular evolutionary analysis
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of the complete VP1, VP0, VP3 and partial 3D regions of seven duck hepatitis virus (DHV) serotype 1 (DHV-1) strains isolated in China between 2001 and 2007 and one DHV-1 strain originally obtained from ATCC Strains were determined and compared to previously available DHV sequences in GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis based on VP1 sequences revealed three distinct genetic groups. There was excellent agreement between the genetic groups assigned based on the full VP0, VP3, and the partial 3D regions. Given the growing importance of molecular techniques in diagnosis, we propose to designate the three genetic groups as DHV types A, B, and C. The new serotype strains isolated in South Korea grouped into genotypes B and C, respectively, suggesting a potential genetic correlate of the serotype. In pairwise comparisons of complete VP1, VP0 and VP3 nucleotide and amino acid sequences and the partial 3D nucleotide sequence, DHVs of the same genotype were clearly distinguished from those of heterologous genotypes. Analysis of the amino acid sequences of the three capsid proteins revealed the presence of conserved elements that make up the eight-stranded β-barrel structures, as well as intervening domains whose sequence varies between strains of different genotypes, as in other picornaviruses. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Wang, L.;Pan, M.;Fu, Y.;Zhang, D.

title: Characterization of miRNAs involved in the response to poly(I:C) in porcine airway epithelial cells
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNA) have been implicated in a variety of pathological conditions, including infectious diseases. Knowledge of the miRNAs affected by poly(I:C), a synthetic analogue of viral double-stranded RNA, in porcine airway epithelial cells (PAECs) contributes to the understanding of the mechanisms of viral airway diseases in pigs, which cause huge economic losses worldwide every year. In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing to profile miRNA expression in poly(I:C)-treated PAECs compared to the untreated control. This approach yielded 23 differentially expressed miRNAs (DEMs), five of which had not previously been associated with viral infections. Nineteen of the 23 miRNAs were downregulated, including members of the miR-17-92 cluster, a known polycistronic oncomir heavily implicated in human viral infections. Target genes of DEMs, predicted using bioinformatic methods and validated by luciferase reporter analysis on two representative DEMs, were significantly enriched in multiple signaling pathways including transformation of growth factor-β signaling. A large set of sequence variations (IsomiRs) were found, including a substitution at position 5, which was verified by a luciferase reporter assay along with bioinformatic analysis, to redirect miRNAs to a new spectrum of targets. Twelve novel porcine miRNAs conserved in other species were identified by homology analysis along with cloning verification. In addition, expression analysis revealed the potential importance of three new miRNAs for the immune response of pigs to viruses. Taken together, our data contribute to the elucidation of the mechanisms underlying the host immune response against porcine respiratory viruses and enrich the repertoire of porcine miRNAs.
authors: Wang, L.;Wang, J. K.;Han, L. X.;Zhuo, J. S.;Du, X.;Liu, D.;Yang, X. Q.

title: Isolation of a swine-man-bird reassortant H1N2 swine flu strain and its genetic variability analysis
authors: Wang, L. B.;Chen, Q. Y.;Wu, X. M.;Che, Y. L.

title: A new enterovirus species identified in goats with severe diarrhea
abstract: Background The enterovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family consists of 9 species of enteroviruses and 3 species of rhinoviruses based on the latest virus taxonomy. These viruses are major contributors to respiratory and digestive disorders in humans and animals. Out of 9 Enterovirus species, Enterovirus EG are closely related to diseases affecting livestock. While enterovirus infections have been increasingly reported in cattle and swine, enterovirus infections in small ruminants are largely unknown. Methods Virological, molecular, and bioinformatic methods were employed to characterize a novel caprine enterovirus CEV-JL14 that exhibited severe diarrhea in China with morbidity and mortality rates of up to 84% and 54%, respectively. Results CEV-JL14 has been defined and proposed as a new enterovirus species L within the genus Enterovirus of the family Picornaviridae. CEV-JL14 had a complete genomic sequence of 7461 nucleotides with an ORF encoding 2172 amino acids and shared 77.1% genomic sequence identity with TB4-OEV, an ovine enterovirus. Comparison of 5'-UTR and structural genes of CEV-JL14 with known enterovirus species revealed high levels of genetic variation between CEV-JL14 with known enterovirus species. The VP1 nucleotide sequence identities of CEV-14 were 51.8%-53.5% with those of Enterovirus E and F, 30.9%-65.3% with Enterovirus G and 43.8-51. 5% with enterovirus AD. CEV-JL14 has been proposed as a new species within the Enterovirus genus according to the current ICTV enterovirus delineation criteria. Conclusions CEV-JL14 did not group phylogenetically into enterovirus E and F, nor into enterovirus G. It was defined and proposed as a new species L within the Enterovirus genus. This is the first report of goat enterovirus in China, the first complete genomic sequence of a goat enterovirus to be revealed, and revealing significant genetic differences between ovine enterovirus and goat enterovirus, thereby improving the current understanding of enteroviruses is expanded.
authors: Wang, M.;He, J.;Lu, H.;Liu, Y.;Deng, Y.;Zhu, L.;Guo, C.;Tu, C.;Wang, X.

title: Metagenomic insights into the contribution of phages to antibiotic resistance in water samples associated with pig farm wastewater treatment
abstract: In this study, we investigated the types of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) possessed by bacteria and bacteriophages in pig farm effluent before and after treatment with a metagenomic approach. We found that the relative abundance of ARGs in bacterial DNA was significantly higher than that in phage DNA in all water samples (>10.6-fold), and wastewater treatment did not increase the relative abundance of bacteria- or phage-associated ARGs significantly changed. We have further demonstrated the distribution and diversity of the different types of ARGs according to the class of antibiotics to which they confer resistance, the tetracycline resistance genes were the most abundant resistance genes, and phage are more likely to harbor ATP-binding cassette transporter families and ribosomal protective genes. In addition, the colistin resistance gene mcr-1 was also detected in the phage population. When assessing the contribution of phage to the spread of different groups of ARGs, β-lactamase resistance genes had relatively high spreadability, although abundance was low. These findings potentially indicate that phage might not only serve as an important reservoir of ARGs, but also carry specific ARGs in pig farm effluent, and this phenomenon is independent of the environment.
authors: Wang, M.;Xiong, W.;Liu, P.;Xie, X.;Zeng, J.;Sun, Y.;Zeng, Z.

title: Complete sequence and evolutionary genome analysis of the transposable bacteriophage Pseudomonas aeruginosa D3112
abstract: The bacteriophage D3112 represents one of two distinct groups of transposable phages found in the clinically relevant opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa. To advance our understanding of transposable phages in P. aeruginosa, we sequenced the entire genome of D3112. The genome is 37,611 bp with a total G+C content of 65%. We identified 53 potential open reading frames, including three genes (the c-repressor gene and early genes A and B) that were previously characterized and sequenced. The organization of the putative coding regions conforms to published genetic and transcription maps and is very similar to that of enterobacteriophage Mu. In contrast, the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses has classified D3112 as a lambda-like phage based on its morphology. Similarity-based analyzes identified 27 open reading frames with significant matches to proteins in the NCBI databases. Forty-eight percent of these were similar to Mu-like phage and prophage sequences, including proteins responsible for transposition, transcriptional regulation, virion morphogenesis, and capsid formation. The tail proteins closely resembled the prophage sequences in Escherichia coli and phage Phi12 from Staphylococcus aureus, while the right-end proteins closely resembled the proteins in Xylella fastidiosa. We performed phylogenetic analyzes to understand the evolutionary relationships of D3112 in terms of Mu-like versus lambda-like bacteriophages. In some cases, different results were obtained from similarity-based versus phylogenetic analyses. Overall, our results reveal a highly mosaic structure and suggest that extensive horizontal exchange of genetic material played an important role in the evolution of D3112.
authors: Wang, P. W.;Chu, L.;Guttman, D. S.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis of the E2 major protective antigen coding region of 12 Hogcholera virus (HCV) strains
abstract: HCV envelope glycoprotein E2 major gene cDNA fragments from 11 field strains isolated at different times in China and 1 French reference strain (Thiveral) were each amplified by the RT-PCR method and sequenced. The amplified fragments were located from 5' 2485 to 2708 of the major E2 domains B and C and encoded 75 amino acid residues of the E2 glycoprotein. All products amplified by RT-PCR from 12 strains in the study were the same size of 224 bp. Comparing 12 sequences with other 9 reference strains reported prior to using the DNAstar software, it was found that the Hog Cholera virus could be divided into two groups by pedigree analysis. Strains Brescia, Gpe, Ald, Thiverval, C, CW, HCLV, HCVSM, BJCY1/96, BJTX3/96, BJSY2/96, HeNXH2/98, HeNZZ1/82 and GDGZ1/95 were assigned to group A and were 85 .7% 100% for the nucleotide sequence and 83.8%-100% for the amino acid sequence in homology; but strains HCVF98, HCVF94, HeBHH2/95, LN1/84, SZGM1/85, SCCD1/79 and Alfort were assigned to group B and were 84.3%-100% in nucleotide sequence and 85.1%-100 % in terms of amino acid sequence homology; and 21 HCV strains were 78.1%-100% homologous in nucleotide sequence and 78.4%-100% in amino acid sequence. The homology was 99.1% for the nucleotide sequence and 100% for the amino acid sequence between the HCLV strains in our study and the C strains reported by Rijn's in the Netherlands. Our sequencing method has been shown to be reliable. There were apparent differences between the two groups in the sequences of the major envelope glycoprotein E2 gene, particularly in the amino acid substitutions at sites 713 and 729, respectively, and it was shown that the two groups of HCV field strains may vary genetically to some extent. The results of other reports on the challenge of the partial field strains showed that the Chinese strain vaccine virus (HCLV) has good immunity.
authors: Wang, Q.;Wang, Z.;Zhao, Y.;Li, B.;Qiu, H.

title: Prevalence of norovirus and sapovirus in pigs of different ages determined by reverse transcription-PCR and microplate hybridization assays
abstract: Noroviruses (NoVs) and sapoviruses (SaVs) are emerging enteric pathogens that cause diarrhea in humans and animals. Porcine Genogroup II (GII) NoVs replicate in pigs, but their pathogenesis is undefined. The swine strain SaV/GIII/Cowden/80/US causes diarrhea and intestinal lesions in pigs. Recently, genetically distinct porcine NoVs (genotypes 11, 18, and 19 within GII) and SaVs containing at least two genogroups (GIII and GVI?/JJ681-like) and two unclassified strains (G?/QW19 and G?/LL26 ) comprised identified; however, their prevalence has not been reported. To investigate the prevalence of porcine NoVs and SaVs, 621 fecal samples from pigs of different ages were collected from seven pig farms and one slaughterhouse in three states of the United States. Stool samples were tested by reverse transcription PCR and microwell hybridization assays with porcine NoV and SaV specific primers and probes, respectively. Porcine GII NoVs were only detected in fattening pigs with an overall prevalence of 20%. Porcine GIII-SaVs were detected in 62% of pigs, with the highest prevalence in post-weaning pigs and the lowest in lactating pigs. Porcine GVIα/JJ681-like SaVs and the Gβ/QW19-like SaVs have rarely been detected in pigs. The Gα/LL26-like SaVs were mainly detected in younger pigs. Because some porcine NoVs and SaVs are genetically or antigenically related to human strains, and recombinants exist within NoVs or SaVs for both human and porcine strains, the high prevalence and subclinical infection rate of these viruses in pigs raises questions as to whether pigs are reservoirs for human strains or for the emergence of new human and porcine recombinants. Copyright © 2006, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Wang, Q. H.;Souza, M.;Funk, J. A.;Zhang, W.;Saif, L. J.

title: Classification of emerging US strains of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus by phylogenetic analysis of nucleocapsid and ORF3 genes
authors: Wang, S.;Cheng, X.;Chen, S.;Lin, F.;Jiang, B.;Zhu, X.;Li, Z.;Wang, J.;Chen, S.

title: Computation of the evolutionary correlation between individual genes and full-length genome: a method useful for selecting phylogenetic markers for molecular epidemiology
abstract: Single genes or regions are still widely used to estimate phylogenetic relationships between viral isolates. The genomic regions that can reliably provide scores consistent with those predicted from full-length genomic sequences would preferably serve as good candidates as the phylogenetic markers for molecular epidemiological studies of many viruses. Here, we used a statistical method to assess the evolutionary relationships between individual viral genes and full-length genomes without tree construction to determine which gene can match well with the genome in phylogenetic analyses. This method was performed by calculating linear correlations between the genetic distance matrices of aligned individual gene sequences and aligned genomic sequences. We applied this method to the phylogenetic analyzes of porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2), measles virus (MV), hepatitis E virus (HEV), and Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). Phylogenetic trees were constructed for comparisons and the possible factors affecting the accuracy of the method were also discussed in the calculations. The results indicated that this method could provide results consistent with previous studies on the correct consensus sequences that could be successfully used as phylogenetic markers. And our results also suggested that these evolutionary correlations could provide useful information for identifying genes that could be used effectively to infer the genetic relationships. Copyright: © 2013 Wang et al.
authors: Wang, S.;Luo, X.;Wei, W.;Zheng, Y.;Dou, Y.;Cai, X.

title: Analysis of codon usage preference in hemagglutinin genes of porcine influenza A (H1N1) virus
abstract: Background The porcine influenza A (H1N1) virus (S-OIV) has come to the fore since 2009 and has been identified as a new reassortant strain. The glycoprotein hemagglutinin (HA) mediates viral binding, contains antigenic regions recognized by neutralizing antibodies, and is associated with viral cross-species infection and adaptation. The comparative study on codon usage preferences in influenza virus genomes was less extensive. In this study, we used codon usage pattern analysis to validate the adaptation and origins of S-OIV. Methods The codon usage pattern was used to assess the host adaptation of S-OIVs. A phylogenetic analysis of the HA gene was performed to understand the phylogeny of H1N1 viruses isolated from different hosts. The amino acid signature pattern at antigenic sites of HA was analyzed to understand antigenic properties. Results Results from phylogenetic analyzes of the HA gene indicate that S-OIVs group in identical clusters. The analyzes of the synonymous codon usage patterns show that the effective number of codons versus GC content at the third codon position in the HA1 gene is slightly different from that in porcine H1N1 and gradually adapts to humans. Our data show that S-OIV development occurred according to positive selection within these antigenic regions. Comparison of amino acid antigenic sites shows similar signature patterns between S-OIV and 1918 human influenza strains. Conclusion This study proposes a new and effective way to gain a better understanding of the features of the S-OIV genome and the evolutionary processes based on the codon usage pattern. It is useful in tracing the origin of influenza viruses and the transmission of viruses between different species.
authors: Wang, S. F.;Su, M. W.;Tseng, S. P.;Li, M. C.;Tsao, C. H.;Huang, S. W.;Chu, W. C.;Liu, W. T.;Chen, Y. M. A.;Huang, J. C.

title: Divergent pathogenic properties of circulating coxsackievirus A6 associated with emerging hand, foot, and mouth disease
abstract: Coxsackievirus A6 (CV-A6) is an emerging pathogen associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). Its genetic characterization and pathogenic properties are largely unknown. Here we report 39 circulating CV-A6 strains isolated from HFMD patients in northeast China in 2013. Three major CV-A6 clusters were identified and related to CV-A6, mainly from Shanghai, indicating that native CV-A6 strains were responsible for the emergence of HFMD in NE China. Four full-length CV-A6 genomes representing each cluster were sequenced and further analyzed. Boat scanning tests showed that all four CV-A6 Changchun strains were most likely recombinants between CV-A6 prototype Gdula and prototype CV-A4 or CV-A4-related viruses, while the recombination pattern was related to the strains , but differed from them in isolation from other regions of China. Furthermore, different CV-A6 strains displayed different viral replication, shedding and pathogenesis abilities in a mouse model. Further analysis showed that the viral protein 2C contributed to CV-A6's diverse pathogenic capabilities by inducing autophagy and triggering cell death. To our knowledge, this study is the first to report fatal and non-fatal CV-A6 strains associated with HFMD. The 2C protein region may play a key role in the pathogenicity of CV-A6 strains. IMPORTANCE Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a major and ongoing threat to infants and children. In addition to the most common pathogens such as enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16), other enteroviruses are also increasingly contributing to HFMD. The present study focused on the recently emerged CV-A6 strain. We found that CV-A6 strains isolated in the city of Changchun in northeast China were associated with native origins. These Changchun viruses were novel recombinants of CV-A6 prototype Gdula and CV-A4. Our results imply that measures to control CV-A6 transmission are urgently needed. Further analysis revealed different pathogenicities in strains isolated in a neonatal mouse model. One of the possible causes was narrowed down to the viral protein 2C by phylogenetic studies, viral sequences and direct tests on cultured human cells. Therefore, the viral 2C protein is a promising target for antiviral drugs to prevent CV-A6-induced tissue damage.
authors: Wang, S. H.;Wang, A.;Liu, P. P.;Zhang, W. Y.;Du, J.;Xu, S.;Liu, G. C.;Zheng, B. S.;Huan, C.;Zhao, K.;Yu, X. F.

title: The discovery of a highly divergent coronavirus in the Asian house shrew from China sheds light on the origin of alphacoronaviruses
abstract: Although shrews are one of the largest mammalian groups, little is known about their role in the evolution and transmission of viral pathogens, including coronaviruses. We captured 266 Asian house shrews (Suncus murinus) in Jiangxi and Zhejiang provinces, China, between 2013 and 2015. Coronavirus (CoV) RNA was detected in 24 Asian house shrews, with an overall prevalence of 9.02%. Complete viral genome sequences were successfully obtained from the RNA positive samples. The newly discovered shrew-CoV fell into four lineages that reflect their geographic origins, indicating largely allopatric evolution. Remarkably, these viruses were most closely related to alphacoronaviruses, but so different that they should be considered a new member of the alphacoronavirus genus, which we refer to as Wencheng Shrew virus (WESV). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that WESV was a highly divergent member of the alphacoronaviruses and, more dramatically, that WESV's S gene fell into a cluster genetically distinct from that of known coronaviruses. WESV's divergent position suggests that coronaviruses have a long association with Asian house shrews. In addition, the genome of WESV contains a distinct NS7 gene that bears no sequence similarity to known viruses. Taken together, these data suggest that shrews are natural reservoirs of coronaviruses and may have played an important and long-term role in the evolution of CoV syndrome coronavirus, Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus, and porcine epidemic diarrhea virus. Due to their genetic diversity and phylogenetic relationship, it has been suggested that the alphacoronaviruses likely have their final ancestor in those viruses that live in bats. Here we have described a novel alphacoronavirus (Wencheng-Shrew virus, WESV) collected from Asian house shrews in China. In particular, WESV is a very divergent member of the alphacoronaviruses and possesses an S gene that is genetically distinct from that of all known coronaviruses. In addition, the genome of WESV contains a distinct NS7 gene that bears no sequence similarity to known viruses. Taken together, these data suggest that shrews are important and long-standing hosts for coronaviruses that merit additional research and surveillance.
authors: Wang, W.;Lin, X. D.;Liao, Y.;Guan, X. Q.;Guo, W. P.;Xing, J. G.;Holmes, E. C.;Zhang, Y. Z.

title: Detection of avian influenza virus clade 7.1 (H5N1) in Lake Qinghai
abstract: The highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza A virus subtype has spread across Asia since 2003, reaching Europe, the Middle East and Africa in 2005, and has raised global concerns over the past decade about a potential pandemic threat. A clade 2.3.2 H5N1 virus became dominant in the Qinghai Lake region in 2009 with sporadic cases of infection in mammals and was transmitted to Russia and Europe by wild migratory birds. Currently, HPAI H5N1 clades 2.3.4, 2.3.2 and 7 are the dominant cocirculating H5N1 viruses in poultry in Asia. 2.3.2 Clade is dominant in wild birds worldwide, while there are no apparent data on clade 7 circulation in wild birds. We detected HPAI H5N1 clade 7.1 virus in Qinghai Lake, which is closely related to Shanxi-like and Vietnam viruses co-circulating in poultry. This is the first report of Clade 7.1 H5N1 in wild birds. Based on phylogenetic analyses, the virus may have originated from the clade 7.1 virus gene pool that spread in Vietnam and Chinese poultry and could spread to Lake Qinghai with migratory birds. Lake Qinghai remains a significant hotspot for H5N1 surveillance, with outbreaks in wild birds and mammals occurring regularly there. Based on these facts and findings, the researchers involved should pay more attention to the Qinghai Lake Basin as a major hotspot for H5N1 avian influenza surveillance, since it has seen regular outbreaks of H5N1 in wild birds with sporadic cases of infection in mammals.
authors: Wang, W.;Sharshov, K.;Li, Z.;Zheng, S. S.;Sun, H.;Yang, F.;Wang, X. L.;Li, L. X.

title: Genetic characterization of a novel duck picornavirus with six 2A proteins
abstract: novel virus has been detected and fully characterized in diseased ducks. The virus has been shown to have a picornavirus-like genome layout. Interestingly, the genome contained up to six 2As in total, including four 2As (2A1–2A4), each having an NPGP motif, an AIG1-like 2A5, and a parechovirus-like 2A6. The 5-UTR was predicted to possess a hepacivirus/pestivirus-like internal ribosome entry site (IRES). However, subdomain IIIe consisted of a 3-nt stem and five unpaired bases that differed from those found in all other HP-like IRESs. The virus was most closely related to duck hepatitis A virus, with amino acid identities of 37.7%, 39%, and 43.7% in the P1, P2, and P3 regions, respectively. Based on these studies, together with phylogenetic analyses, the virus could be considered a founding member of a new picornavirus genus, which we tentatively named "Aalivirus", with "Aalivirus A" as the type species.
authors: Wang, X.;Liu, N.;Wang, F.;Ning, K.;Li, Y.;Zhang, D.

title: Genomic characterization and pathogenicity of a porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome type 1 virus
abstract: The emergence of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) type 1 was recently detected in China. In the present study, the complete genomic characterization of a type 1 PRRSV strain (designated GZ11-G1) and its pathogenicity in piglets was analyzed. The results showed that the full genome of GZ11-G1, 15,094 nt in size, excluding the poly(A) tails, shared 80.2-96.3% identity with the representative strains of type 1 PRRSV and in particular the highest had homology (96.3%) with Amervac PRRS, a live vaccine type 1 PRRSV virus, and SHE, a rescued virus from an infectious clone of Amervac PRRS virus. Compared to the vaccine virus, the nonstructural and structural proteins of GZ11-G1 showed extensive amino acid variation with the exception of its ORF5a. GZ11-G1 was clustered by further phylogenetic analysis with strains of PRRSV type 1 including Cresa3267, Cresa3249, Cresa3256, Olot/91, 9625/2012, ESP-1991-Olot91 and Amervac PRRS vaccine virus. In addition, GZ11-G1 has been shown to cause fever, higher viremia, and lung and lymph node lesions in piglets. Our results indicate that GZ11-G1 is genetically linked to type 1 PRRSV strains within the cluster formed by Cresa3267, Cresa3249, Cresa3256, Olot/91, 9625/2012, ESP-1991-Olot91 and the Amervac PRRS vaccine virus is related and pathogenic to piglets. This study contributes to the understanding of the genetic variation and evolution of type 1 PRRSV.
authors: Wang, X.;Yang, X.;Zhou, R.;Zhou, L.;Ge, X.;Guo, X.;Yang, H.

title: RNA-Seq analysis of gene expression of duck embryo fibroblast cells during the early stage of egg drop syndrome virus infection
abstract: Egg drop syndrome virus (EDSV), a member of the Adenoviridae family and an economically important pathogen with a wide host range, results in significantly reduced egg production. However, the molecular mechanism underlying the host-EDSV interaction remains unclear. Here, we performed high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) to examine the dynamic changes in host gene expression at 6, 12, and 24 hours post-infection in EDSV-infected duck embryo fibroblasts (DEFs). A total of 441 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified after EDSV infection. Analysis of the Gene Ontology pathogenicity category and the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes Pathway Enrichment revealed that these DEGs are associated with multiple biological functions, including signal transduction, host immunity, viral infection, cell apoptosis, cell proliferation, and signaling pathways related to pathogenicity and metabolic processes . We screened and identified 12 DEGs for further study using qRT-PCR. The qRT-PCR and RNA-Seq results were very consistent. This study analyzed EDSV infection-induced viral infection and host immunity from a novel perspective, and the results provide valuable information on the mechanisms underlying host-EDSV interactions, which proves useful for future antiviral drug or vaccine development Poultry and the entire poultry industry will benefit from it.
authors: Wang, X. P.;Qi, X. F.;Yang, B.;Chen, S. Y.;Wang, J. Y.

title: Integrated analysis of microRNA expression and mRNA transcriptome in the lungs of avian influenza virus-infected broilers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Avian influenza virus (AIV) outbreaks are global threats to poultry and humans. Our previous study suggested that microRNAs (miRNAs) play an important role in regulating the host response to AIV infection in laying hens. The aim of this study was to test the hypothesis whether the genetic background plays an essential role in the miRNA regulation of AIV infection in chickens and whether miRNAs differentially expressed in AIV-infected laying hens are found in broiler chickens be modulated in the same way. In addition, potential molecular mechanisms of the host response to AIV infection can be further exploited by integrating with parallel mRNA expression profiling. RESULTS: Total RNA isolated from the lungs of uninfected and low pathogenic H5N3-infected broilers four days post-infection was used for both miRNA depth sequencing and mRNA microarray analysis. A total of 2.6M and 3.3M filtered high quality reads were obtained from infected and uninfected chickens, respectively, using the Solexa GA-I Sequencer. A total of 271 miRNAs were identified in miRBase 16.0 and one potential new miRNA was discovered. 121 miRNAs were differentially expressed with a false detection rate of 5% by Fisher's exact test. More miRNAs were highly expressed in infected lungs (108) than in uninfected lungs (13), which was in contrast to the results in laying hens. This result suggests that a different regulatory mechanism of the host response to miRNAs-mediated AIV infection may exist in broilers. Analysis using the chicken 44K Agilent microarray showed that 508 mRNAs (347 down-regulated) were differentially expressed after AIV infection. CONCLUSIONS: A comprehensive analysis combining both miRNA and targeted mRNA gene expression suggests that gga-miR-34a, 122-1, 122-2, 146a, 155, 206, 1719, 1594, 1599 and 451 as well as MX1, IL-8, IRF-7, TNFRS19 are strong candidates for miRNAs or genes involved in regulation of host response to AIV infection in broiler lungs. Further miRNA or gene-specific knock-down assays are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanism of chicken AIV infection regulation.
authors: Wang, Y.;Brahmakshatriya, V.;Lupiani, B.;Reddy, S. M.;Soibam, B.;Benham, A. L.;Gunaratne, P.;Liu, H. C.;Trakooljul, N.;Ing, N.;Okimoto, R.;Zhou, H.

title: Adelaide River Virus Nucleoprotein Gene: Analysis of the Phylogenetic Relatedness of Ephemeroviruses and Other Rhabdoviruses
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the Adelaide River Virus (ARV) genome was determined from the 3' terminus to the end of the nucleoprotein (N) gene. The 3' leader sequence is 50 nucleotides long and shares a common terminal trinucleotide (3'-UGC-), a conserved U-rich domain and a variable AU-rich domain with other animal rhabdoviruses. The N gene spans 1355 nucleotides from the transcription start sequence (AACAGG) to the poly(A) sequence [CATG(A)7] and encodes a polypeptide of 429 amino acids. The N protein has a calculated molecular mass of 49429 Da and a pI of 5.4 and, like the N protein of the bovine ephemeral fever virus (BEFV), has a strongly acidic C-terminal domain. Analysis of the amino acid sequence relationships between all available rhabdovirus N proteins revealed that ARV and BEFV are closely related viruses (48.3% similarity), sharing greater sequence similarity with vesiculoviruses than with lyssaviruses. Phylogenetic trees based on a multiple sequence alignment of all available rhabdovirus N protein sequences revealed an accumulation of viruses according to genome organization, host range, and established taxonomic relationships.
authors: Wang, Y.;Cowley, J. A.;Walker, P. J.

title: The faecal virome of red-crowned cranes
authors: Wang, Y.;Yang, S.;Liu, D.;Zhou, C.;Li, W.;Lin, Y.;Wang, X.

title: Comprehensive analysis of the amino acid sequence diversity at the F protein cleavage site of Newcastle disease virus during fusogenic activity
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is a contagious agent of Newcastle disease in avian species and seriously affects the poultry industry. The viral F protein (Fcs) cleavage site is a key determinant of membrane fusion and viral virulence. In this study, we examined the precise effect of variable amino acid sequences of Fcs on fusogenic activity. Based on viral pathogenicity, the Fcs sequences of natural isolates (n = 1572) are classified into eight types of virulent Fcs (VFcs) with the motif "G/R/KRQ/R/KR/K-Râ†"F" ten types of avirulent Fcs (AFcs) with the motif "G/R/ER/K/QQG/E-Râ†"L". The VFcs is only found in the class II cluster of the viral classification and not in class I. AFcs occurs in both class I and class II isolates. The VFc and AFc types show an evolutionary relationship with temporal distribution and host species. Using an in vitro fusion assay, VFcs-1 “RRQKRâ†“F” and VFcs-2 “RRQRRâ†“F” show the highest efficiency in triggering membrane fusion. The neutral Q residue at the P3 position of the VFcs plays an enhancing role compared to the effect of the basic R and K residues. A single K residue at P3 or P5 is less efficient for fusogenic activity in the VFcs with all basic residues. Furthermore, the cleavage efficiencies of F0 proteins with different types of Fcs motifs do not appear to affect membrane fusion. Our results provide insight into the effect of amino acid variation of the Fcs on NDV-induced fusion.
authors: Wang, Y.;Yu, W.;Huo, N.;Wang, W.;Guo, Y.;Wei, Q.;Wang, X.;Zhang, S.;Yang, Z.;Xiao, S.

title: Complete and defective enterovirus G genomes with different torovirus protease insertions are widespread in a Chinese pig farm
abstract: Recombination often occurs between enteroviruses (EVs) classified within the same species of the Picornaviridae family. Here, the genomes of two recombinant EV-Gs (strains EVG 01/NC_CHI/2014 and EVG 02/NC_CHI/2014) found in the feces of pigs from a pig farm in China are described using viral metagenomics. The two strains are characterized by a different insertion of a papain-like protease gene from toroviruses, which belong to the Coronaviridae family. According to recent reports, the torovirus protease insertion site in EVG 02/NC_CHI/2014 was in the 2C/3A junction region. In the other variant, EVG 01/NC_CHI/2014, the inserted protease sequence replaced the entire viral capsid protein region up to the VP1/2A junction. These two EV-G strains were widespread on the same pig farm, with all animals secreting the full-length genome (EVG 02/NC_CHI/2014), while 65% also secreted the capsid deletion mutant (EVG 01/NC_CHI/2014). A helper-defective virus relationship between the two cocirculating EV-G recombinants is hypothesized.
authors: Wang, Y.;Zhang, W.;Liu, Z.;Fu, X.;Yuan, J.;Zhao, J.;Lin, Y.;Shen, Q.;Wang, X.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Shan, T.;Yang, S.

title: hepatitis E virus
abstract: Since the sequence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) was determined in 1989 in a patient with enterally transmitted non-A non-B hepatitis, similar sequences have been isolated from many different animals including pigs, wild boar, deer, rabbits, bats , rats, chickens and trout. All of these sequences have the same genomic organization containing open reading frames (ORFs) 1, 2, and 3, although their genomic sequences are variable. Some have suggested classifying them as a new family, Hepeviridae, which would be further subdivided into distinct genera and species according to their sequence variability. The size of these virus particles generally ranged from 27 to 34 nm. However, HEV virions produced in cell culture differ in structure from viruses found in feces. Those from cell culture have a lipid envelope and a little ORF3 on their surface, while the viruses isolated from feces have no lipid envelope and ORF3. Surprisingly, most of the secreted ORF2 protein from these two sources is not associated with HEV RNA.
authors: Wang, Y.;Zhao, C.;Qi, Y.;Geng, Y.

title: Genotyping of Newcastle disease viruses isolated in China between 2002 and 2004
abstract: The major functional region of the fusion (F) protein gene from 124 strains of Newcastle disease virus isolated in China between 2002 and 2004 was amplified and sequenced for further phylogenetic and residue substitution analyses. Most isolates have been assigned to genotypes VIIc, VIId, VIf, and VIb, others to genotypes IX, III, or II. Genotype IX, a unique genotype that includes strain F48, the first Chinese virulent NDV strain isolated in 1948 has still been found causing sporadic infections in certain areas. Viruses of subgenotypes VIIc, VIId, and VIIe, distributed in clusters in the phylogenetic tree distinct from members of subgenotypes Vila and VIIb, have been responsible for most outbreaks in China and have been circulating mainly in China in recent years. Strain NDV03-026, a genotype II isolate that is normally lentogenic, was found to be a virulent strain carrying the 112RRQKRF117 motif at the F protein cleavage site. © 2006 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Wang, Z.;Liu, H.;Xu, J.;Bao, J.;Zheng, D.;Sun, C.;Wei, R.;Song, C.;Chen, J.

title: H13 influenza viruses in wild birds have undergone genetic and antigenic diversification in nature
abstract: Among the 16 hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes of avian influenza viruses (AIVs), H13-AIVs have rarely been isolated from wild waterfowl. H13-AIVs cause asymptomatic infections and are mainly kept in populations of gulls and terns; However, the antigenic information recorded on the viruses was limited. In this study, 2 H13 AIVs, A/duck/Hokkaido/W345/2012 (H13N2) and A/duck/Hokkaido/WZ68/2012 (H13N2), isolated in the same year in our surveillance from the same area, were genetically and Antigenic analysis using 10 representative H13 strains, including a prototype strain, A/gull/Maryland/704/1977 (H13N6). The HA genes of H13-AIVs have been classified phylogenetically into 3 groups (I, II and III). A/Duck/Hokkaido/W345/2012 (H13N2) was genetically classified in group III. This virus differed from a prototype strain, A/gull/Maryland/704/1977 (H13N6), and the virus, A/duck/Hokkaido/WZ68/2012 (H13N2), both of which belonged to group I. Group I viruses were antigenic closely related to those in Group II but distinct from those in Group III, including A/duck/Hokkaido/W345/2012 (H13N2). In conclusion, our study shows that H13-AIVs have undergone antigenic diversification in nature.
authors: Wang, Z. J.;Kikutani, Y.;Nguyen, L. T.;Hiono, T.;Matsuno, K.;Okamatsu, M.;Krauss, S.;Webby, R.;Lee, Y. J.;Kida, H.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of the first G24P 14 rotavirus strain detected in humans
abstract: Here we report the genome of a novel rotavirus A (RVA) strain detected in a stool sample collected during routine surveillance by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's New Vaccine Surveillance Network. The RVA/human-wt/USA/2012741499/2012/G24P[14] strain has a genomic constellation of G24-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A3-N2-T9-E2-H3. The VP2, VP3, VP7, and NSP3 genes cluster phylogenetically with bovine strains. The other genes occupy mixed clades containing animal and human strains. The strain RVA/human-wt/USA/2012741499/2012/G24P[14] is most likely the product of interspecies transmission and reassortment events. This is the second report of the G24 genotype and the first report of the combination of the G24P[14] genotype in humans.
