authors: Ward, M. L.;Mijatovic-Rustempasic, S.;Roy, S.;Rungsrisuriyachai, K.;Boom, J. A.;Sahni, L. C.;Baker, C. J.;Rench, M. A.;Wikswo, M. E.;Payne, D. C.;Parashar, U. D.;Bowen, M. D.

title: Antigenic analysis of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus sublineages co-circulating in Egypt
abstract: The highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread across Eurasia and Africa, and outbreaks are now endemic in several countries, including Indonesia, Vietnam and Egypt. The continuous circulation of the H5N1 virus in Egypt from a single infected source has resulted in significant genetic diversification with phylogenetically separable sublineages, providing an opportunity to study the impact of genetic evolution on viral phenotypic variation. In this study, we analyzed the phylogeny of H5-hemagglutinin (HA) genes in influenza viruses isolated in Egypt from 2006 to 2011 and examined the effect of conserved amino acid mutations in the HA genes in each of the sublineages on their antigenicity. The analysis showed that in 2011 viruses were still present in at least four sublineages in poultry in Egypt. Using reverse genetics to generate HA reassortment viruses with specific HA mutations, we found antigenic drift in the HA in two influenza virus sublineages compared to the other currently co-circulating influenza virus sublineages in Egypt. In addition, the two sublineages with significant antigenic drift were antigenically distinct. Our results indicated that phylogenetically divergent H5N1 viruses that were not antigenically cross-reactive co-circulated in Egypt, indicating that there is a problem in using a single influenza virus strain as a seed virus to produce influenza virus vaccines in Egypt and the Data provided to develop more effective control strategies in H5N1 endemic areas. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Watanabe, Y.;Ibrahim, M. S.;Ellakany, H. F.;Kawashita, N.;Daidoji, T.;Takagi, T.;Yasunaga, T.;Nakaya, T.;Ikuta, K.

title: Several genotypes of nonpathogenic H6N2 influenza viruses isolated from chickens in California
abstract: From February 2000 to September 2001, a limited number of H6N2 influenza viruses were isolated from chickens in California. This report describes the genetic characterization of nine of these H6N2 viruses. All viruses analyzed had phylogenetically similar hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase molecules, suggesting that the viruses shared a recent common ancestor. Analysis of the HA sequence of these viruses with all available H6 viruses from different hosts and locations showed that these genes do not segregate into well-defined North American and Eurasian lineages. The neuraminidase genes of California viruses contain an 18 amino acid deletion, a possible adaptation for growth in chickens. Analysis of the remaining gene segments of the California viruses revealed that three distinct genotypes of H6N2 viruses were present.
authors: Webby, R. J.;Woolcock, P. R.;Krauss, S. L.;Walker, D. B.;Chin, P. S.;Shortridge, K. F.;Webster, R. G.

title: Antigenic drift, antigenic shift and interferon antagonists: how bunyaviruses counteract the immune system
abstract: Members of the Bunyaviridae family are among the most widespread viruses worldwide. They are found on every inhabited continent at virtually all latitudes and can infect a wide variety of arthropods, plants, and mammals, including humans. More than 300 named viruses are included in the Bunyaviridae family (Virus Taxonomy: Seventh Report of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (2000) 599), and several members cause significant disease in humans or domestic animals. Despite being recognized as an emerging threat, relatively little is known about their virulence mechanisms. Here we try to summarize the current state of knowledge on how the Bunyaviridae viruses manage to become infected against a strong immune system. © 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Weber, F.;Elliott, R. M.

title: Characterization of canine serum vioma from northeastern Brazil
abstract: Domestic dogs share habitats with humans, making them a potential source of zoonotic viruses. In addition, knowledge of potential bloodborne pathogens is important due to the increasing use of blood transfusions in dogs. In the present study, we evaluated the serum virome of 520 dogs using throughput sequencing (HTS). Serum samples were pooled and sequenced using an Illumina MiSeq platform. Our unbiased method identified predominant canine pathogens such as canine protoparvovirus 1 (canine parvovirus 2), understudied pathogens such as canine bocaparvovirus 1 (canine circovirus) and canine circovirus, circular viruses closely related to viruses recently found in human Specimens were found, as well as new parvoviruses and anelloviruses. The canine virome described in the present work promotes knowledge about the virus population in domestic animals. The present data includes information on viral agents that may be transmitted between dogs by blood transfusions.
authors: Weber, M. N.;Cibulski, S. P.;OlegÃ¡rio, J. C.;da Silva, M. S.;Puhl, D. E.;MÃ³sena, A. C. S.;Alves, C. D. B. T.;Paim, W. P.;Baumbach, L. F.;Mayer, F. Q.;Fernandes, A. R. F.;Azevedo, S. S.;Canal, C. W.

title: Evaluation of serum virome in calves persistently infected with pestivirus A and present or not with mucosal disease
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus 1, reclassified as pestivirus A, causes a globally prevalent, economically important cattle disease. Pestivirus A can cause persistent infection as calves shed the virus throughout their lives and spread the infection throughout the herd. Many persistently infected (PI) calves die within the first 2 years of life from mucosal disease (MD) or secondary infections, probably as a result of virus-induced immune depression. Here, high-throughput sequencing (HTS) was used to assess total viromea in sera from (i) PI calves with clinically apparent MD (n=8); (ii) PI calves with no evidence of MD (n=8); and (iii) control, pestivirus A-free calves (n=8). All groups were collected at the same time and from the same herd. Serum samples from calves in each of the groups were pooled, subjected to viral RNA/DNA enrichment and sequenced by HTS. Viral genomes of pestivirus A, ungulate erythroparvovirus 1, bosavirus (BosV), and hypothetical circular Rep-encoding single-stranded DNA (CRESS-DNA) viruses have been identified. Specific real-time PCR assays were developed to determine the frequency of occurrence of such viruses in each of the groups. The absolute number of different viral genomes detected in both PI calf groups was higher than in the control group, as evidenced by a higher number of reads, contigs and genomes representing a wider range of taxons. Genomes representing members of the Parvoviridae family, such as U. erythroparvovirus 1 and BosV, were detected most frequently in all three groups of calves. Only in MD-affected PI calves did we find two previously unreported hypothetical single-stranded DNA genomes clustered together with CRESS DNA viruses. These results indicate that parvoviruses were the most commonly detected viral genomes in bovine serum; its detection rate shows no statistical correlation with the status of the calves for pestivirus A infection, since clinically normal or MD-affected/unaffected PI calves were infected with similar U. erythroparvovirus 1 genome loads. In addition, MD-affected PI calves have been shown to support viremia of CRESS DNA virus genomes; however, the importance of such a correlation has yet to be established.
authors: Weber, M. N.;Cibulski, S. P.;Silveira, S.;Siqueira, F. M.;MÃ³sena, A. C. S.;da Silva, M. S.;OlegÃ¡rio, J. C.;Varela, A. P. M.;Teixeira, T. F.;Bianchi, M. V.;Driemeier, D.;Pavarini, S. P.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.;Canal, C. W.

title: First evidence of bovine viral diarrhea virus infection in wild boar
abstract: Background: Wild boar farming has increased due to interest in human consumption of this exotic meat. Such a development may mean an increased risk of disease transmission between wild boar and domestic animals. The wild boar population has increased in South America in recent years due to the lack of predators, causing economic losses through direct damage to crops and the risk of disease transmission. The genus Pestivirus within the family Flaviviridae is composed of four species recognized by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV): classical swine fever virus (CSFV), border disease virus (BDV), bovine viral diarrhea type 1 virus ( BVDV-1) and 2 (BVDV-2). Other putative species designated as atypical pestiviruses have been identified as "HoBi"-like virus, giraffe pestivirus, Bungowannah pestivirus, pronghorn antelope virus, porcine atypical pestivirus (APPV), Norwegian rat pestivirus (NrPV), and Rhinolophus affinis -bat pestivirus (RaPestV-1) ). CSFV is frequently detected in wild boar, but despite positive serology, bovine viral diarrheal virus (BVDV) has never been detected in this species. This communication describes the first detection of BVDV in the lungs of captive boars using RT-PCR and DNA sequencing. Materials, Methods & Results: Forty lung samples from farmed wild boar were collected after slaughter at a commercial slaughterhouse. The organs were minced separately, centrifuged and the supernatant saved for further analysis. Total RNA was isolated using a phenol-based protocol and an RT-PCR protocol was performed that amplified 118 bp of the 5' untranslated region (5'-UTR). One out of 40 samples was positive. In the case of the positive sample, partial fragments of the 5'-UTR and N-terminal autoprotease (N-pro) were sequenced and analyzed. Strain LV Java/2012 shared 99% identity in the 5'-UTR and 98% in the N-pro region with a BVDV-2 previously reported in cattle in southern Brazil. In both 5'UTR and Npro phylogenetic analysis, strain LV Java/2015 aggregated with BVDV-2 strains and was most closely related to subtype 2b identified in cattle in southern Brazil and found in the same end node grouped. Discussion: Wild boar are often associated with the transmission of pathogens to domestic animals. This animal species is considered a reservoir of the pestivirus CSFV and an important key in CSFV control and eradication programs in Europe. Although the indirect presence of BVDV in wild boar has been reported by serological testing, direct detection of the viral agent has never been reported. The present study demonstrated the presence of BVDV-2 genomic segments obtained by RT-PCR followed by DNA sequencing in captive feral pigs. The reported data suggest a potential importance of this species in the epidemiology of ruminant pestiviruses, which could interfere with control and eradication programs of these important bovine pathogens worldwide. The LV Java/2012 strain was closely related to BVDV-2b and showed the highest identity with a strain detected in cattle from southern Brazil. These data suggest that wild boar and cattle may share this pathogen due to strain similarity and that both have been reported in the same region. This may result in the need to include feral pigs in BVDV control programs as feral pigs circulate between different regions and can transmit this pathogen to different herds of cattle. The present study reported the first molecular detection of BVDV in wild boar in the literature. The data generated here suggest a possible role of boars in the epidemiology of ruminant pestiviruses.
authors: Weber, M. N.;Pino, E. H. M.;Souza, C. K.;Mosena, A. C. S.;Sato, J. P. H.;de Barcellos, Desn;Canal, C. W.

title: Evolution of influenza viruses in wild birds
abstract: The emergence of highly pathogenic (HP) H5 influenza A viruses in Asia and the rise of HP-H7 viruses in Europe and America drew more attention to the ecology of wild bird influenza. Influenza virus surveillance studies in wild bird populations in America, Europe and Asia confirmed that wild waterfowl are the reservoir for all known influenza A viruses. Phylogenetic analysis groups the influenza viruses in wild waterfowl into two distinct superfamilies - one in America and one in Eurasia. The separation of viruses into American and Eurasian clades implies that wild bird transmission of HP H5 to the Americas is likely to be a rare event. The rapid evolution of Eurasian H5NI viruses makes them an ongoing threat to poultry and humans worldwide.
authors: Webster, R. G.;Krauss, S.;Hulse-Post, D.;Sturm-Ramirez, K.

title: The pangenome of Lactobacillus reuteri strains derived from the porcine gastrointestinal tract
abstract: BACKGROUND: Lactobacillus reuteri is an intestinal symbiont of a variety of vertebrate species that has diversified into distinct phylogenetic clades that are highly host-specific. Previous work demonstrated host specificity in mice and began to determine the mechanisms by which gut colonization and host restriction are achieved. However, how L. reuteri strains colonize the porcine gastrointestinal (GI) tract is unknown. RESULTS: To gain insight into the ecology of L. reuteri in the porcine intestine, the genome sequence of the small intestinal porcine isolate L. reuteri ATCC 53608 was completed and consisted of a chromosome of 1.94 Mbp and two plasmids of 138.5 kbp and 9, 09 kbp , respectively. In addition, we generated draft genomes from four additional L. reuteri strains isolated from pig feces or the lower gastrointestinal tract, lp167-67, pg-3b, 20-2, and 3c6, and subjected all five genomes together with genome of strain I5007 completed by previous comparative genome analysis. A phylogenetic analysis based on whole genomes showed that porcine L. reuteri strains fall into two distinct clades as previously suggested by multi-locus sequence analysis. These six pigs-L. reuteri genomes contained a core set of 1364 orthologous gene clusters, as determined by OrthoMCL analysis, which contributed to a pangenome with a total of 3373 gene clusters. Genome comparisons of the six porcine L. reuteri strains with 14 L. reuteri strains from other host strains yielded a total pangenome of 5225 gene clusters containing a nuclear genome of 851 gene clusters, but showed that there were no pig-specific genes per se. However, genes specific to Strains of the two phylogenetic porcine lineages are, and are conserved among, some of which encode cell surface proteins that may contribute to the diversification of the two lineages and their observed host specificity. CONCLUSIONS: This study extends the phylogenetic analysis of L. reuteri strains to the genome-wide level, pointing to distinct evolutionary trajectories of porcine L. reuteri lineages and provides new insights into the genomic events in L. reuteri that have occurred during specialization to their hosts. The appearance of two distinct porcine-derived clades may reflect differences in host genotype, environmental factors such as dietary components, or the evolution of ancestral strains of human and rodent origin after exposure to porcine populations.
authors: Wegmann, U.;MacKenzie, D. A.;Zheng, J.;Goesmann, A.;Roos, S.;Swarbreck, D.;Walter, J.;Crossman, L. C.;Juge, N.

title: Genetic dynamic analysis of influenza A H5N1 NS1 gene in China
abstract: The direct progenitors of the A/Goose/Guangdong/1/1996 (GS/GD) virus lineage and its reassortants have been geographically and ecologically established. To examine the variation and evolutionary dynamics of H5N1 viruses, whole genome viral sequences (n=164) were retrieved from the NCBI Influenza Virus Resource. Here we present phylogenetic evidence for reassortments within subtypes among H5N1 viruses isolated from China between 1996 and 2012. Based on the phylogenetic analysis, we identified four main groups and further classified the reassortant viruses into three subgroups. Putative mosaic structures were mainly found in the viral ribonucleoprotein (vRNP) complexes and 91.0% (10/11) mosaics were preserved from terrestrial birds. Sequence variability and selection pressure analyzes showed that both surface glycoproteins (HA and NA) and nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) have a higher dN/dS ratio and variability than other internal proteins. In addition, we discovered 47 positively selected sites in genomic segments excluding the PB2 and M1 genes. Hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) are considered highly variable due to host immune pressure, but what drives NS1 variability is unknown. Therefore, we performed a thorough analysis of the genetic variation and selection pressure of the NS1 protein (462 available NS1 sequences). We found that most of the positively selected sites and variable amino acids were located in the C-terminal effector domain (ED) of NS1. In addition, we focused on the NS1 RNA and NS1 protein interactions involved in viral replication mechanisms and the host immune response. Transcriptomic analysis of H5N1-infected monkey lungs showed that certain PI3K-related genes were upregulated.
authors: Wei, K.;Chen, Y.;Lin, Y.;Pan, Y.

title: Global genetic variation and transmission dynamics of the H9N2 avian influenza virus
abstract: The H9N2 influenza viruses circulate extensively in the poultry population, and mutation, recombination, and reassortment can generate variable genotypes that may be better adapted to infect a new host, resist drug treatment, or evade immune system pressure . The LPAI H9N2 viruses have the potential to evolve to high levels of virulence in humans. Some regional spread studies have been presented, but little is known about the global spread and drivers of the virus, particularly at the genomic level. Here we analyzed all eight gene segments from 168 randomly sampled H9N2 genomes to provide a panoramic framework for a better understanding of the genesis and genetic variation of the viruses, and used phylogeographic and spatial epidemiological approaches to uncover the implications of genetic variation, predictors, and Spread of H9N2 virus. We found that more frequent rearrangement events affect the PA, NP and NS segments and 21 isolates show possible mosaicism resulting from recombination events. Estimates of gene-specific global dN/dS ratios indicated that all genes underwent purifying selection. However, a total of 13 sites under positive selection were detected by at least two of three methods, located within the HA, NA, M2, NS1 and PA segments. Furthermore, we concluded that the NA segment has the highest nucleotide substitution rate and its tMRCA estimate is the most recent than the conclusion of the remaining segments. In terms of spatial history, human air transport was identified using GLM analysis as the dominant driver of global virus migration, and economic factors and geographic distance were the modest predictors. Higher migration rates were estimated between five pairs of regions (>0.01), indicating the frequent migration of the viruses between individual geographic locations. Furthermore, our Markov jump analysis showed that virus migration is more frequent between southern China and northern China, and that a high rate of gene flow was observed between the Americas and East Asia. Additionally, along with Southeast Asia, the Americas acted as the primary hub of global transmission, forming the trunk of the evolutionary tree. These results suggest a complex interaction between virus evolution, epidemiology and human behavior.
authors: Wei, K.;Li, Y.

title: Reemergence of a virulent Newcastle disease genotype VIII virus isolated from Chinese wildfowl after 13 years
abstract: The circulation of the dominant Newcastle disease virus (NDV) genotypes VI and VII is causing significant economic losses to the poultry industry in China. However, reports of Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks caused by genotype VIII strains of NDV are rare. In this study, a virulent genotype VIII strain of NDV, designated GXGB2011, was isolated from a vaccinated wildfowl flock showing clinical signs of infection in Pinxiang County, Guangxi, China. The entire genome of the isolate was fully sequenced and comprised 15,192 nucleotides (nt) encoding the six structural proteins in the order 3-NP-PMF-HN-L-5. The pattern of cleavage site 112RRQKRâ†“F117 in the fusion protein (F) and the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) value of 1.5 indicated that strain GXGB2011 was a velogen NDV. The results of the challenge experiment with the 5 week old SPF chickens showed that the strain was highly pathogenic with 100% morbidity and mortality of the challenged birds. Based on detection of virus in various organs of the infected birds, the highest viral load was observed in cecal tonsils and virus concentrations in immune organs were higher than in respiratory organs. Bayesian full genome reconstruction based on the sequences of 66 NDV reference strains showed that the strain belonged to genotype VIII of NDV. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that the strain was more closely related to foreign strains gamefowl/US(CA)/24225/98, 1ITTY94060 and IT-147/94 than to the first native strains of emergence genotype VIII in Qinghai, China in 1979â €“1985. In summary, the results of the study demonstrated the re-emergence of a highly pathogenic virulent NDV genotype VIII isolate. These results indicate the risk that this NDV genotype VIII may spread from wildfowl to commercial chickens.
authors: Wei, T.;Deng, Q.;Zhai, G.;He, C.;Li, H.;Zhang, Y.;Zeng, R.;Mo, M.;Huang, T.;Wei, P.

title: Genetic and pathobiological characterization of pandemic H1N1 2009 influenza viruses from a naturally infected pig herd
abstract: Since it was first identified in Mexico and the United States, concerns have been raised that the novel H1N1 influenza virus could cause a pandemic of comparable severity to the 1918 pandemic. In late April 2009, viruses phylogenetically related to the pandemic H1N1 influenza virus were isolated in an outbreak on a Canadian pig farm. This outbreak also had epidemiological links to a suspected human case. Experimental infections performed in pigs with one of the pig isolates from this outbreak and the human isolate A/Mexico/InDRE4487/2009 showed differences in virus recovery from the lower respiratory tract. Virus was consistently isolated from the lungs of pigs infected with A/Mexico/InDRE4487/2009, while only one pig infected with A/swine/Alberta/OTH-33-8/2008 yielded live virus from the lungs, despite comparable amounts of RNA and virus antigen in both groups of pigs. The clinical illness was similar to other influenza virus infections in pigs, albeit with somewhat prolonged viral antigen detection and delayed viral RNA clearance from the lungs. There was also a notable amount of genotypic variability among the viruses isolated from the pigs on the farm. This, together with the somewhat erratic pathobiological features observed in experimentally infected animals, suggests that although the virus may be of porcine origin, significant viral evolution is still ongoing. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Weingartl, H. M.;Berhane, Y.;Hisanaga, T.;Neufeld, J.;Kehler, H.;Emburry-Hyatt, C.;Hooper-McGreevy, K.;Kasloff, S.;Dalman, B.;Bystrom, J.;Alexandersen, S.;Li, Y.;Pasick, J.

title: The proposed family Toroviridae: causative agents of enteric infections
authors: Weiss, M.;Horzinek, M. C.

title: Coronavirus pathogenesis and the emerging causative agent of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus
abstract: Coronaviruses are a family of enveloped, single-stranded, positive-stranded RNA viruses that are classified in the order Nidovirales. This family of coronaviruses consists of pathogens from many animal species and humans, including the recently isolated severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). This review is divided into two main parts; the first concerns animal coronaviruses and their pathogenesis with a focus on the functions of individual viral genes, and the second addresses the newly described human emerging pathogen SARS-CoV. The coronavirus part includes (i) a description of a group of coronaviruses and the diseases they cause, including the prototype coronavirus, the murine hepatitis virus, which is one of the accepted animal models for multiple sclerosis, and viruses of veterinary importance that infect the Pig, Chicken and Cat and a Summary of Human Viruses; (ii) a brief summary of the replication cycle of coronaviruses in cell culture; (iii) the development and application of reverse genetics systems; and (iv) the role of individual coronavirus proteins in replication and pathogenesis. The SARS-CoV portion covers the pathogenesis of SARS, the evolving animal models for infection, and advances in vaccine development and antiviral therapies. The data collected on animal coronaviruses continues to be helpful in understanding SARS-CoV. Copyright © 2005, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Weiss, S. R.;Navas-Martin, S.

title: Investigation of possible causes for the development of pig ear necrosis: Different study designs - comparable results? German
abstract: In recent years, two studies to research the etiology of pig ear necrosis have been carried out at the pig clinic of the University of Veterinary Medicine, Vienna. In Study 1, parameters discussed in this context were collected from veterinarians by completing specially designed questionnaires in farms with symptoms of Pig Ear Necrosis Syndrome. In Study 2, piglet and feed samples were collected for laboratory analysis of key infectious agents and mycotoxins. The results of both projects were compared in this manuscript. Although the selection criteria of the two studies differed, the affected age group was comparable (5.5 to 10 weeks of age in study 1 and 6 to 10 weeks of life in study 2). The herd-specific prevalence of pig ear necrosis syndrome varied considerably with percentages between 2 or 10 and 100%. The evaluation of the questionnaires in study 1 showed that 51% of the farms had problems with cannibalism. Particles of plant material commonly seen on the histological sections of Study 2 could have entered the tissue through chewing of the housemates' ears or through cannibalism. While study 1 considered the negative influence of parameters such as high pig density, suboptimal climate, lack of enrichment material and poor feed and water quality, in study 2 all these factors were checked during sampling and excluded as precursors for cannibalism. In both studies, bacterial pathogens proved to be a crucial co-factor for the spread of necrosis into deeper tissue layers, while viral pathogens were classified as less important. In both projects, the direct influence of infectious agents and mycotoxins as a direct trigger of the necrosis and their involvement as co-factors or precursors in terms of immunosuppression or previous damage to blood vessels or tissue could not be assessed.
authors: Weissenbacher-Lang, C.;Voglmayr, T.;Weissenbock, H.;Pyrek, R.;Waxenecker, F.;Hofstetter, U.;Hoelzle, K.;Hoelzle, L. E.;Welle, M.;Bruns, G.;Ritzmann, M.

title: Genomic analysis of some Japanese isolates of Getah virus
abstract: Using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and direct sequencing, capsid protein and nonstructural protein 1 (nsP1) regions of Sagiyama virus and eight Getah virus strains were analyzed. The viruses were isolated from Malaysia and various areas of Japan over a 30-year period. Based on the available published sequence data, oligonucleotide primers for RT-PCR were designed and the sequences determined. Our results showed that although there were differences in the nucleotide sequences in the nsP1 region, there was 100% amino acid homology. On the other hand, the nucleotide differences in the capsid region caused a large difference in the amino acid sequence. Therefore, the difference in the capsid region is one of the useful markers in the genetic classification between Sagiyama virus and Getah virus strains and might be responsible for the serological difference in the complement fixation test. The genomic differences between the Getah virus strains are due to the time factor rather than geographic distribution.
authors: Wekesa, S. N.;Inoshima, Y.;Murakami, K.;Sentsui, H.

title: Purification, morphology, and partial characterization of a reovirus-like agent associated with neonatal calf diarrhea
abstract: Studies have been conducted on a virus that has recently been implicated as an etiologic agent in widespread cases of calf diarrhea. The virus was isolated from faeces and intestinal mucosa of experimentally infected calves and from cell cultures inoculated with material from infected calves. Virus was purified by differential centrifugation, nuclease treatment, extraction with Genetron 113 and cesium chloride (CsCl) gradient. Cleaned and uncleaned samples were examined by electron microscopy. Both types of preparations contained non-coated particles of approximately 64 nm diameter with a hexagonal core region of 36 nm diameter. Capsid subunits appeared to be arranged in accordance with cubic symmetry. Essential lipids have not been associated with the virus. The buoyant density of the purified virus was 1.359. Viral nucleic acid was determined to be ribonucleic acid (RNA) by chemical methods. The morphology and some chemical properties appear to be similar to those of the reovirus group. However, the exact classification of this virus and its relationship to other groups has yet to be determined.
authors: Welch, A. B.

title: Avianpox Viruses: Infection Biology and Their Use as Vaccine Vectors
abstract: Avipoxviruses (APVs) belong to the Chordopoxvirinae subfamily of the Poxviridae family. APVs are distributed worldwide and cause disease in domestic, pet, and wild birds of many species. APVs are transmitted by aerosols and biting insects, particularly mosquitoes and arthropods, and are usually named after the bird species from which they were originally isolated. Fowlpoxvirus (FWPV) virus type causes disease in poultry and associated mortality is usually low, but in flocks under stress (other diseases, high production) mortality can reach up to 50%. APVs also play an important role in the development of viral vaccine vectors for human and veterinary diseases. Abortive infection in mammalian cells (no progeny virus production) and their ability to accommodate multiple gene inserts are some of the properties that make APVs promising vaccine vectors. Although abortive infection in mammalian cells may represent a major advantage for vaccine biosafety, the molecular mechanisms that restrict APVs to specific hosts are not yet fully understood. This review summarizes the current knowledge regarding APVs, including classification, morphogenesis, host-virus interactions, diagnostics and disease, and also highlights the use of APVs as recombinant vaccine vectors. © 2011 Weli and Tryland; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Weli, S. C.;Tryland, M.

title: Types and Strains: Their Essential Role in Understanding Protein Aggregation in Neurodegenerative Diseases
abstract: Protein misfolding and aggregation is a key event in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD) or Parkinson's disease (PD) and is associated with neurodegeneration. Factors that induce protein misfolding and the role of protein aggregation in disease pathophysiology are major challenges for the neuroscientific community. Although accumulation of the same misfolded protein, e.g. Interestingly, since all idiopathic Parkinson's patients have idiopathic Parkinson's disease, such as a-synuclein, the spectrum of disease includes a variety of different clinical presentations and disease courses. In a more recent experiment, this clinical variance is explained by different conformations of protein aggregates in analogy to prion diseases. In prion diseases, a relationship between conformational properties of protein aggregates and the clinical course of the disease has been demonstrated by associating different prion types with dementia and atactic disease in Creutzfeldt-Jakob patients. This principle is currently being applied to AD, PD and other neurodegenerative diseases with protein aggregation. However, differences in the conformation of protein aggregates are often addressed as disease strains. The term "strain" also comes from prion research and arose by adopting virus terminology at a time when it was assumed that transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSE; later called prion diseases) were caused by a virus. The problem is that in viral taxonomy, the term "type" refers to characteristics of the pathogen itself, and the term "strain" refers to host-associated factors that can interact with the pathogen and moderately modify the clinical picture. Stress factors can only be discovered after transfer and passage of the agent in a host of another species. Incorrect use of terminology confuses pathogens and host factors and hampers understanding of the pathophysiology of protein aggregate-associated neurodegenerative diseases. This review article summarizes the discoveries that explain how the terms "type" and "strain" came about for unconventional pathogens. This may help avoid confusion in protein aggregation disease terminology and correctly reflect the influence of protein aggregate conformation as well as the contribution of host factor to different clinical variations of AD, PD and other neurodegenerative diseases.
authors: Wemheuer, W. M.;Wrede, A.;Schulz-Schaeffer, W. J.

title: Comments on the definition of the duck circovirus (DuCV) genotype
abstract: standardized methodology was used to define genotypes based on pairwise sequence comparisons (PASC). PASC is a widely accepted method in virus taxonomy based on the histogram of pairwise differences between sequences. Recently, Zhang et al. (2013) concluded that the mean p-distance of duck circovirus (DuCV) between genotypes 1 and 2 was 0.170 and the subtype distance thresholds were 0.032 in DuCV-1 and 0.018 in DuCV-2, respectively. However, there might be some concerns about the application of the methodology to define the genotype of DuCV. With the above concerns in mind, our authors performed the PASC analyzes of the 54 capsid gene (ORF2) and genomic sequences, including all sequences from Zhang et al. (2013). Our results confirmed the existence of two DuCV genotypes (1 and 2) and we propose that the DuCV ORF2 and genotype thresholds for genomic distance were 0.061 and 0.038, respectively. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Wen, H.;Wu, Y.;Yang, C.;Zhang, X.;Lian, C.;Chen, H.;Han, L.

title: Characterization of porcine and some ruminant pestiviruses by cross-neutralization
abstract: Serological relationships between 11 pestivirus strains of porcine origin and five of bovine or ovine origin were examined by cross-neutralization. Experiments were performed with pig and sheep sera raised against the strains. The results were analyzed by a computerized taxonomic method. The 16 viruses were divided into four different serological groups. All strains of swine cholera virus (HCV) were divided into one group; the other three groups consisted of strains that can infect pigs but have been identified as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) or border disease virus (BDV) or showed a closer relationship to BVDV and BDV than to HCV.
authors: Wensvoort, G.;Terpstra, C.;de Kluyver, E. P.

title: Detection of the hepatitis E virus (HEV) from pig livers in south-eastern Germany and high sequence homology to human HEV isolates
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) has been identified as a new cause of infectious hepatitis in industrialized countries in recent years. In contrast to travel-associated hepatitis E, zoonotic sources of infection are suspected in autochthonous cases in Europe. Objective: Because pigs are known to be reservoirs of HEV, we tested pig livers sold as food in south-eastern Germany for the presence of hepatitis E virus RNA. Study design: We purchased 200 pig liver samples from 81 butcher and grocery stores in Regensburg, Germany. Nucleic acid preparations were tested for the presence of HEV RNA using quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR). HEV isolates from positive samples were characterized by partial sequencing of the ORF1 and ORF2 regions in the HEV genome and by phylogenetic analysis. Results: Samples from eight (4%) of 200 purchased pig livers had detectable levels of HEV RNA. Sequence determination and phylogenetic analysis enabled the classification of two new isolates as HEV genotype 3, subgenotype 3a (swR437) and 3c (swR269), respectively. Both novel porcine HEV isolates showed high sequence homology to isolates obtained from patients with acute HEV infection from the same geographic region. Conclusions: These results support the proposed role of undercooked pork products in food as a source of zoonotic HEV infection in humans. It remains to be clarified whether this transmission mechanism is responsible for the surprisingly high prevalence of anti-HEV IgG recently observed in some European countries and the USA. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Wenzel, J. J.;PreiÃŸ, J.;Schemmerer, M.;Huber, B.;Plentz, A.;Jilg, W.

title: Schmallenberg virus: A novel virus of veterinary importance
abstract: At the end of 2011, non-specific clinical symptoms such as fever, diarrhea and reduced milk yield were observed in dairy cattle in the Dutch-German border area. After exclusion of classic endemic and emerging viruses by targeted diagnostic systems, blood samples from acutely ill cows were subjected to metagenomic analysis. An insect-transmitted orthobunyavirus of the Simbu serogroup was identified as the causative agent and named Schmallenberg virus (SBV). It was one of the first evidence of introduction of a novel virus of veterinary importance in Europe using new next-generation sequencing technology. The virus was subsequently isolated from identical samples used for metagenomic analysis in insect and mammalian cell lines, and disease symptoms were reproduced in calves experimentally infected with both this cultured virus and blood samples from diseased cattle. Since its emergence, SBV has spread very rapidly in the European ruminant population, causing mild non-specific disease in adult animals, but also premature birth or stillbirth and severe fetal malformations when naïve dams became infected during a critical gestation period. In the years that followed, SBV was regularly recirculated on a larger scale; in the 2014 and 2016 carrier seasons, the virus was again repeatedly detected in the blood of adult ruminants, and several malformed calves and lambs occurred in the subsequent winter and spring months. The genome of viruses present in viraemic adults showed very high sequence stability; in sequences generated between 2012 and 2016 only a few amino acid substitutions could be detected compared to the original SBV isolate. In contrast, high sequence variability has been identified in the amino-terminal part of the glycoprotein Gc coding region of viruses present in the brain of malformed newborns. This mutational hotspot is independent of the region or host species from which the samples are derived and may be involved in immune evasion mechanisms.
authors: Wernike, K.;Beer, M.

title: Schmallenberg virus recurrence, Germany, 2014
abstract: Schmallenberg virus (SBV) emerged in Germany in 2011, spread rapidly across Europe and was almost gone by 2013. However, since late summer 2014, new cases have emerged in adult cattle. Full genome analysis revealed some amino acid substitution differences from the first SBV sample. Viremia developed in experimentally infected sheep and cattle for 4-6 days.
authors: Wernike, K.;Hoffmann, B.;Conraths, F. J.;Beer, M.

title: Detection and typing of the highly pathogenic porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus by multiplex real-time RT-PCR
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) causes economic losses in the swine industry worldwide and PRRS viruses (PRRSV) are classified into two distinct genotypes, North American (NA, Type 2) and European (EU, Type 1). . . In 2006, a highly pathogenic NA strain of PRRSV (HP-PRRSV), characterized by high fever and high morbidity and mortality, emerged in pig farms in China. Therefore, a real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) assay specific for HP-PRRSV was developed and combined with type 1 and type 2 specific RT-qPCR systems. In addition, an internal control based on a heterologous RNA was successfully introduced. This final multiplex PRRSV RT-qPCR for the detection and typing of PRRSV had an analytical sensitivity of less than 200 copies per microliter for the type 1 assay and 20 copies per microliter for the type 2 and HP assays and a high diagnostic sensitivity. A panel of reference strains and field isolates were reliably detected and samples from an animal study with a Chinese HP-PRRS strain were used for test validation. The new multiplex PRRSV RT-qPCR system enables the highly sensitive detection and rapid differentiation of PRRSV of both genotypes and the direct detection of HP-PRRSV for the first time. © 2012 Wernike et al.
authors: Wernike, K.;Hoffmann, B.;Dauber, M.;Lange, E.;Schirrmeier, H.;Beer, M.

title: West Nile Virus: An update on recent developments
abstract: West Nile virus came to North America a little over 12 years ago and since that time much has been learned about its pathology and transmission of infection and the factors affecting prevalence. Important developments uncovered critical risk factors for severe neurological diseases and revealed successful host defense strategies. Only equine vaccines are currently available; Human vaccines are still in various stages of clinical trials. This review discusses the advances and limitations of current research regarding the emergence and continued spread of West Nile Virus across America. © 2012 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Wertheimer, A. M.

title: Molecular evolution of viral fusion and matrix protein genes and phylogenetic relationships among the Paramyxoviridae
abstract: Phylogenetic relationships among the Paramyxoviridae, a broad family of viruses whose members cause devastating diseases in wildlife, livestock, and humans, have been studied using both fusion (F) and matrix (M) protein-encoding sequences. Neighboring trees of F and M protein sequences showed that the Paramyxoviridae were divided into the two traditionally recognized subfamilies, the Paramyxovirinae and the Pneumovirinae. Within the Paramyxovirinae, the results also revealed groups corresponding to three currently recognized genera: Respirovirus, Morbillivirus, and Rubulavirus. The relationships between the three genera of Paramyxovirinae were resolved using M protein sequences and there was significant bootstrap support (100%) showing that members of the genus Respirovirus and genus Morbillivirus were more closely related than members of the genus Rubulavirus . Both F and M phylogeny showed that Newcastle disease virus (NDV) was more closely related to the Rubulavirus genus than to the other two genera, but agreed with the proposal (BS Seal et al., 2000 , Virus Res. 66, 1-11) that NDV is to be classified as an independent genus within the Paramyxovirinae. Both F and M phylogeny were also consistent with the proposal (L. Wang et al., 2000, J. Virol 74, 9972-9979) that Hendra virus be classified as a new genus closely related is related and basal to the genus Morbillivirus. Rinderpest was most closely related to measles and a more strongly derived virus than to canine distemper virus, phocine distemper virus, or dolphin morbillivirus. © 2001 Academic Press.
authors: Westover, K. M.;Hughes, A. L.

title: Kakapo (Strigops habroptilus) exudative cloacitis possibly associated with Escherichia coli infection
abstract: METHODS: Metagenomics using unbiased RNA or DNA sequencing was applied to fecal material from an 11-year-old female kakapo with exudative cloacitis and a pool of eight birds (male and female aged 1-20 years) with no current signs or history of the disease . Fecal material from the diseased bird was collected before and after treatment. For RNA sequencing, extracted RNA/DNA was subjected to DNase and the remaining RNA was reverse transcribed into cDNA and subjected to multiple displacement amplification prior to sequencing. RESULTS: No significant alignment with any known avian virus sequence was obtained from fecal samples. However, significant BLAST alignments to five bacteriophages known to infect enterobacteria were obtained. Strong evidence for the presence of the bacteriophage Escherichia phage TL-2011b, a bacteriophage known to be present in Escherichia coli and known to cause outbreaks of foodborne illness in humans, was found in the sample from the diseased bird but not in the non-diseased pool. Differences in E. coli community structure between the diseased bird and the non-diseased pool were also evident. CONCLUSIONS: Escherichia coli infection of human origin is suggested as a possible cause of exudative cloacitis, although confirmatory work is needed to test this hypothesis. AIM: To investigate the underlying causes of cloacitis (inflammation of the cloaca) in kakapos (Strigops habroptilus).
authors: White, D. J.;Hall, R. J.;Jakob-Hoff, R.;Wang, J.;Jackson, B.;Tompkins, D. M.

title: Discovery and full genome sequence of a novel circovirus-like virus in the endangered rowi kiwi, Apteryx rowi
abstract: Circoviruses are circular, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses approximately 2000 nucleotides (nt) in length and include the pathogenic species Porcine Circovirus 1 and Beak and Feather Disease Virus, which can cause significant morbidity and mortality. This group of viruses can be robust to degradation by external environments, and avian circoviruses are known to move between closely related hosts. Using a de novo metagenomic approach followed by confirmatory PCR, we identify for the first time a circular Rep-encoding single-stranded DNA (CRESS) virus in New Zealand kiwis, Apteryx spp., isolated from faeces of the Rowi kiwi (A . rowi) with signs of verminous dermatitis. The entire 2085 nt genome has been cloned and sequenced and contains both capsid and replicase genes and a conserved 9 nt motif. Phylogenetic analyzes place it within the Circoviridae, along with other CRESS-DNA viruses in the environment and most closely related to the badger circovirus-like virus (Meles meles circovirus-like virus). As the rowi is the most endangered kiwi, it is important to understand the role of the rowi-kiwi circovirus-like virus as a possible pathogen and also any potential cross-species transmission.
authors: White, D. J.;Hall, R. J.;Wang, J.;Moore, N. E.;Park, D.;McInnes, K.;Gartrell, B. D.;Tompkins, D. M.

title: Serological evidence of exposure to influenza D virus in persons with occupational contact with cattle
abstract: Background: Influenza D virus (IDV), a novel influenza virus with proposed classification: Family Orthomyxoviridae, Genus Influenza virus D, Species Influenza D virus, has been associated with influenza-like illness in cattle and swine. More recently, anti-IDV antibodies have also been detected in small ruminants. A seroprevalence of approximately 1.3% has been estimated for the general human population. Objectives: To gain knowledge of the zoonotic potential of IDV for adult humans with occupational exposure to cattle in north-central Florida. Study: A cross-sectional serological study was performed on human serum samples from 35 bovine exposed and 11 non-bovine exposed adults to screen for IDV antibodies using haemagglutination inhibition (HI) and microneutralization (MN) tests. Results: Among those working with cattle in Florida, the seroprevalence was 91% by HI assay and 97% by MN assay. In subjects not exposed to cattle, the seropositivity determined (only) by the MN test was lower (18%). Conclusions: IDV poses a zoonotic risk for workers exposed to cattle based on evidence of high seroprevalence (94-97%). While it is not yet known whether IDV causes disease in humans, our studies indicate that the virus could be an emerging pathogen among cattle workers.
authors: White, S. K.;Ma, W.;McDaniel, C. J.;Gray, G. C.;Lednicky, J. A.

title: Characterization of unknown Orthobunya-like viruses from India
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of human idiopathic disease pathogens has been critical to the identification of new viruses. This study describes the isolation and characterization of two novel orthobunyaviruses recovered from a jungle myna and a rice bird from Karnataka state, India. Using an NGS approach, these isolates were classified as cat que and balagodu viruses belonging to the Manzanilla clade of the Simbu serogroup. Closely related viruses of the manzanilla group have been isolated from mosquitoes, humans, birds and pigs over a large geographic region. Because orthobunyaviruses have a high regrouping frequency and can cause acute, self-limiting febrile illnesses, these data suggest that Oya/Cat Que/Manzanilla virus infections in humans and livestock may be more prevalent and/or underreported than expected. Therefore, it is imperative to identify new and unknown viruses in order to understand their role in human and animal pathogenesis. The current study is a step forward in this regard and would serve as a prototype method for the isolation, identification and detection of several other emerging viruses.
authors: Whitmer, S. L. M.;Yadav, P. D.;Sarkale, P.;Chaubal, G. Y.;Francis, A.;Klena, J.;Nichol, S. T.;Stroher, U.;Mourya, D. T.

title: Prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis E virus in apparently healthy humans and pigs in Bali, Indonesia: identification of a pig infected with genotype 4 hepatitis E virus
abstract: In Indonesia, where hepatitis E virus (HEV) is considered highly endemic, only three outbreaks of HEV transmission have been documented in restricted areas (West Kalimantan and East Java). A total of 1,115 serum samples collected in 1996 from apparently healthy individuals in Bali, Lombok and Surabaya in Indonesia, where no epidemic transmission of HEV has ever been reported, were tested for IgG-class antibodies to HEV (anti-HEV). In Bali, anti-HEV was detected in 20% (54/276) of the population tested, in striking contrast to 4% (17/446) in Lombok and 0.5% (2/393) in Surabaya. On the other hand, antibodies against hepatitis A virus were widespread in all three regions (95% in Bali, 90% in Lombok and 89% in Surabaya). Although the majority of the population in Indonesia is Muslim, the Balinese are predominantly Hindu and have a habit of consuming pork. Therefore, serum samples were taken from the 99 farm pigs in Bali and tested for anti-HEV and HEV RNA. Sera from 71 pigs (72%) were positive for anti-HEV and one 2 month old pig had detectable HEV RNA. The porcine HEV isolate obtained from the viremic pig was named SB66-Bali. The SB66 Bali isolate was most closely related to genotype 4 isolates from China, India, Japan and Taiwan, but shared only 82.6-90.0% identity in the common 241-412 nucleotides within open reading frame 2 (ORF2). These results indicate that one or more putative native HEV strains are circulating in Bali, Indonesia, and that HEV infection can occur even in developing countries via zoonosis. © 2004 Wiley-Liss, Inc.
authors: Wibawa, I. D. N.;Muljono, D. H.;Mulyanto;Suryadarma, I. G. A.;Tsuda, F.;Takahashi, M.;Nishizawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Matrix gene of influenza A viruses isolated from wild waterfowl: ecology and origin of influenza A viruses
abstract: Wild waterfowl are the main reservoir of influenza A virus, but little is known about the viral gene pool in wild birds. Therefore, we studied the ecology and emergence of influenza viruses by performing phylogenetic analyzes of 70 matrix (M) genes of influenza viruses isolated from shorebirds and gulls in the Delaware Bay region and from ducks in Alberta, Canada during a > 18- years of surveillance have been isolated. In our analysis we included 61 published M genes from isolates from different hosts. We have shown that the M genes of the Canadian duck viruses and those of the Delaware Bay shorebird and gull viruses share ancestry with the M genes of the North American avian viruses. We found that North American and Eurasian avian lineages are divided into sublineages, suggesting that multiple branches of virus evolution may be sustained in wild aquatic birds. The presence of non-H13 gull viruses in the gull-like lineage and H13 gull viruses in other avian lineages suggested that the gull M genes do not preferentially associate with the H13 subtype or segregate into a distinct lineage. Some North American avian influenza viruses contained M genes closely related to those of Eurasian avian viruses. Therefore, interregional mixing of the two clades can occur. Reassortment of shorebird M and HA genes was evident, but there was no correlation between HA or NA subtype, M gene sequence, and isolation time. Taken together, these results support the hypothesis that influenza viruses in wild aquatic birds contain distinct lineages of M genes.
authors: Widjaja, L.;Krauss, S. L.;Webby, R. J.;Xie, T.;Webster, R. G.

title: An emerging genotype subset within PCV-2b dominates PMWS in Switzerland
abstract: Postweaning Multisystemic Wasting Syndrome (PMWS) is one of the most important emerging swine diseases worldwide. The insidious nature of the disease initially made it difficult to localize the pathogen. The presence of porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) in all PMWS-stricken animals led to its acceptance as the causative agent of PMWS, possibly together with an unknown factor. Even the presence of PCV2 in healthy individuals did not facilitate understanding of the disease. The phylogenetic classification divides PCV2 viruses into at least two main groups. The viruses are identified as belonging to PCV-2a or PCV-2b with the aid of a signature motif, a short amino acid motif encoded in the capsid protein. Recently, this classification has received more attention as it appeared to define PCV-2b as more virulent. However, this simplification could not be confirmed experimentally. Therefore, we investigated whether the genetic shift of the virus was an initiator for PMWS in Switzerland. Piglet lymphoid tissues from 1973 to 2005 were examined histologically, immunohistochemically (IHC) and PCR. A sequence amplicon of 137 bp encompassing the signature motif was used for genotype classification. The onset of the Swiss PMWS plague showed a clear shift in PMWS-sick and subclinically infected piglets to PCV-2b and specifically to a subset of the genotype. Complementary to these observations, healthy piglets, also defined as negative by the IHC, are positive in the PCR reaction and free of any PCV-2b virus during the animal epidemic. Consequently, our data support plasticity of the PCV2 genome as a major factor in PMWS disease manifestation. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Wiederkehr, D. D.;Sydler, T.;Buergi, E.;Haessig, M.;Zimmermann, D.;Pospischil, A.;Brugnera, E.;Sidler, X.

title: Cowpox virus infection in an 11-year-old girl
abstract: We describe an 11-year-old girl with vaccinia virus infection who presented with a 14-day-old crusty, ulcerated lump on the chin/neck and a 6-day-old eroded blister on the left leg. The girl lived in a rural area, was in close contact with several neighborhood cats and had an atopic predisposition. The presence of orthopoxvirus in the left leg lesion was demonstrated by electron microscopy (negative staining, transmission electron microscopy) and virus isolation. Classification as vaccinia virus was determined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) followed by restriction enzyme digestion of the PCR product.
authors: Wienecke, R.;Wolff, H.;Schaller, M.;Meyer, H.;Plewig, G.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of picobirnaviruses in piglets with diarrhea in Thailand
abstract: Picobirnavirus (PBV) is a small, bipartite, double-stranded RNA virus. Taxonomically, the genus Picobirnavirus belongs to the family Picobirnaviridae. PBV infects a variety of hosts and causes opportunistic infections, but its role in diarrheal diseases remains unclear. To determine the prevalence and genetic diversity of swine PBV in northern Thailand, 380 fecal samples from piglets with and without diarrhea reared at 22 pig farms were tested for the presence of PBV. Reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) was performed using primer sets specific for the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) gene. PBV was detected in 86/265 (32.5%) piglets with diarrhea and 26/115 (22.6%) piglets without diarrhoea. All PBV strains detected in this study belonged to genogroup I, and a high proportion of PBV-positive piglets were co-infected with group A rotavirus (RVA) and bocavirus (BoV). The phylogenetic analysis of representative strains of genogroup I revealed a remarkably high similarity between the strains; these formed a monophyletic cluster with 97-100% sequence identity in the RdRP gene. The strains were also closely related to the genogroup I Chinese PBV pig strain. The results show that PBV infection is common in piglets with and without diarrhea in northern Thailand.
authors: Wilburn, L.;Yodmeeklin, A.;Kochjan, P.;Saikruang, W.;Kumthip, K.;Khamrin, P.;Maneekarn, N.

title: Influenza A viruses in ducks in northwestern Minnesota: fine-scale spatial and temporal variation in prevalence and subtype diversity
abstract: Northwest Minnesota waterfowl were tested for avian influenza virus (AIV) by cloacal swabs in July-October 2007 and 2008. AIV was detected in 222 (9.1%) of 2,441 ducks in 2007 and in 438 (17.9%) of 2,452 ducks in 2008. The prevalence of AIV peaked in late summer. We detected 27 AIV subtypes in 2007 and 31 in 2008. Ten hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes were detected each year (ie, H1, 3-8, and 10-12 in 2007; H1-8, 10, and 11 in 2008). All neuraminidase (NA) subtypes were detected in each study year. The diversity of subtypes varied between years and increased with prevalence into September. The predominant subtypes in 2007 (covering ≥ 5% of the subtype diversity) included H1N1, H3N6, H3N8, H4N6, H7N3, H10N7 and H11N9. The predominant subtypes in 2008 included H3N6, H3N8, H4N6, H4N8, H6N1 and H10N7. In addition, within each HA subtype, the same predominant HA/NA subtype combinations were found each year, including H1N1, H3N8, H4N6, H5N2, H6N1, H7N3, H8N4, H10N7, and H11N9. The H2N3 and H12N5 viruses also dominated within the H2 and H12 subtypes, respectively, but were only detected in a single year (H2 and H12 viruses were not detected in 2007 and 2008, respectively). Mallards were the predominant species sampled (63.7% of the total) and 531 AIV were isolated from this species (80.5% of all isolates). Mallard data collected in both years adequately described the observed temporal and spatial prevalence of the overall sample and also adequately represented subtype diversity. Juvenile mallards were also useful to characterize the temporal and spatial prevalence of AIV as well as subtype diversity.
authors: Wilcox, B. R.;Knutsen, G. A.;Berdeen, J.;Goekjian, V.;Poulson, R.;Goyal, S.;Sreevatsan, S.;Cardona, C.;Berghaus, R. D.;Swayne, D. E.;Yabsley, M. J.;Stallknecht, D. E.

title: Virus-virus interactions and host ecology are linked to RNA-viroma structure in wild birds
authors: Wille, M.;Eden, J. S.;Shi, M.;Klaassen, M.;Hurt, A. C.

title: Virus-virus interactions and host ecology are linked to RNA-viroma structure in wild birds
abstract: Little is known about the factors shaping the ecology of RNA viruses in nature. Wild birds are an important example because, other than influenza A virus, samples from birds are rarely tested for virus, particularly in the absence of overt disease. Using bulk RNA sequencing ("meta-transcriptomics"), we have revealed the viral diversity present in Australian wild birds through the lens of ecological factors that can determine vioma structure and abundance. Meta-transcriptomic analysis of four Anseriformes (waterfowl) and Charadriiformes (shorebirds) species sampled in temperate and arid Australia revealed the presence of 27 RNA virus genomes, 18 of which represent newly described species. Viruses identified included a previously described gamma-coronavirus and influenza A viruses. In addition, we identified new virus species from the families Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Reoviridae, Rhabdoviridae, Picobirnaviridae and Picornaviridae. We found differences in virome structure that reflect underlying differences in location and influenza A infection status. Red-necked avocets (Recurvirostra novaehollandiae) from the arid interior of Australia possessed the greatest virus diversity and abundance, significantly more than individuals sampled in temperate Australia. In ruddy turnstones (Arenaria interpres) and dabbed ducks (Anas spp.), virus abundance and diversity were higher and more similar in hosts positive for influenza A infection than in those negative for this virus, despite specimens on which were taken on the same day and from the same place. This study highlights the extent and diversity of RNA viruses in wild birds and lays the groundwork for understanding the factors that determine vioma structure in wild populations.
authors: Wille, M.;Eden, J. S.;Shi, M.;Klaassen, M.;Hurt, A. C.;Holmes, E. C.

title: An aberrant hepatitis D-like pathogen in birds
abstract: Hepatitis delta virus (HDV), currently only found in humans, is a satellite virus that depends on hepatitis B virus (HBV) envelope proteins for assembly, release, and entry. Using metatranscriptomics, we identified the genome of a novel HDV-like pathogen in ducks. Sequence analysis revealed secondary structures shared with HDV, including self-complementarity and ribozyme features. The predicted viral protein shares 32% amino acid similarity with the HDV small delta antigen and encompasses a divergent phylogenetic lineage. The discovery of an avian HDV-like pathogen has important implications for understanding the origins of HDV and subviral pathogens.
authors: Wille, M.;Netter, H. J.;Littlejohn, M.;Yuen, L.;Shi, M.;Eden, J. S.;Klaassen, M.;Holmes, E. C.;Hurt, A. C.

title: Viral diversity of house mice in New York City
abstract: The microbiome of wild Mus musculus (house mouse), a global invasive pest that lives in close contact with humans in urban centers, remains largely unexplored. Here we report the analysis of fecal virome of house mice in residential buildings in New York City, NY. Mice were collected from seven sites in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx over a one-year period. High-throughput unbiased sequencing of faeces revealed 36 viruses from 18 families and 21 genera, including at least 6 new viruses and 3 new genera. A representative screening of 15 viruses by PCR confirmed the presence of 13 of these viruses in the liver. We found an uneven distribution of diversity, with multiple viruses assigned to specific loci. Higher mouse weight was associated with an increase in the number of viruses detected per mouse after adjusting for location, sex, and length. We found no genetic traces of known human viral pathogens, nor antibodies to lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus. IMPORTANCE Mice carry a wide range of infectious agents with zoonotic potential. Their proximity to humans in the built environment is therefore a public health concern. Laboratory mice are also the most common experimental model for studying the pathobiology of infectious diseases. In this study of mice trapped at multiple locations in New York City over a year, we found a diverse collection of viruses, including some not previously associated with house mice and others that were new to seem to be Although we have not found any known human pathogens, our results provide insights into viral ecology and may yield models useful for clinical microbiology.
authors: Williams, S. H.;Che, X. Y.;Garcia, J. A.;Klena, J. D.;Lee, B.;Muller, D.;Ulrich, W.;Corrigan, R. M.;Nichol, S.;Jain, K.;Lipkin, W. I.

title: Conference Report: 2013 PDA Virus & TSE Safety Forum
abstract: The report provides a summary of the presentations and discussions at the Virus & TSE Safety Forum 2013 organized by the Parenteral Drug Association (PDA) and held June 4-6, 2013 in Berlin, Germany. The conference was accompanied by a workshop, "Viral tip preparations and virus removal by filtration: Emerging trends and developments". The workshop presentations and discussions are summarized in a separate report, which will also appear in this issue of the journal. As with previous conferences in this series, the PDA Virus & TSE Safety Forum 2013 again provided an excellent opportunity for industry, research institutes and regulatory authorities to exchange information and views. Updates on regulatory considerations related to the safety of biopharmaceuticals from viruses and transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE) have been provided by European Union (EU), United States (US) and Singapore authorities. The epidemiology and detection methods of newly emerging pathogens such as the hepatitis E virus and the parvovirus (PARV 4) were presented as examples, and in particular the risk of contamination of animal raw materials such as trypsin was considered. The utility of using new sequence-based virus detection methods was discussed. Past bioreactor contamination events drew attention to root cause analysis and preventative measures, illustrated by several examples. Virus clearance data for certain unit operations was provided; The discussion focused on the mechanism of virus clearance and on the strategic concept of virus clearance integration. As in previous years, the viral safety section was followed by a section on TSEs, which addressed current scientific evidence that may influence the risk assessment of blood and cell substrates. This included the finding that interspecies transmission of TSEs by blood components in sheep is greater than predicted by assays in transgenic mice. In addition, the pathogenesis and possibility of productive TSE infection from cell substrates were considered, and cell-based assays that might be suitable for use in TSE clearance studies were discussed. The current report gives an overview of the results of the PDA Virus & TSE Safety Forum 2013, a unique event in this field. © PDA, Inc. 2014.
authors: Willkommen, H.;BlÃ¼mel, J.;Brorson, K.;Chen, D.;Chen, Q.;GrÃ¶ner, A.;Hubbard, B. R.;Kreil, T. R.;Ruffing, M.;Ruiz, S.;Scott, D.;Silvester, G.

title: Sexually Transmitted Infection (e-STI) Testing and Outcomes Service via the Internet: A Randomized, Single-Blinded, Controlled Trial
abstract: Background: Internet-based sexually transmitted infection tests (e-STI tests) are increasingly being offered as an alternative to tests in clinics. Typically, this testing modality allows users to order a test kit from a virtual service (via a website or app), collect their own samples, send test samples back to a laboratory, and be notified of their results via short message service (SMS) or phone. e-STI testing is thought to improve access to testing compared to face-to-face services, but the evidence is unclear. We conducted a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of an e-STI testing and outcomes service (chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and syphilis) on STI testing uptake and diagnosed STI cases. Methods and results: The study took place in the London boroughs of Lambeth and Southwark. Between November 24, 2014 and August 31, 2015, we recruited 2,072 participants, ages 16 to 30, residing in these counties, who had at least 1 sex partner in the past 12 months, who agreed to have an STI test make, and had access to the Internet. Those who could not give consent and could not read English were excluded. Participants were randomly assigned 1 SMS with the web link of an e-STI testing and results service (intervention group) or 1 SMS with the web link of a customized website listing the locations, contact details and websites of 7 local sexual health clinics health (control group). Participants were free to use other services or interventions during the study period. The primary endpoints were self-reported STI testing at 6 weeks verified by medical record review and self-reported STI diagnoses at 6 weeks verified by medical record review. Secondary endpoints were the proportion of participants prescribed treatment for an STI, time from randomization to completion of STI testing, and time from randomization to treatment for an STI. Participants were sent £10 cash upon presentation of self-reported data. We completed all follow-up visits, including medical record reviews, by June 17, 2016. Utilization of STI testing was increased in the intervention group at 6 weeks (50.0% vs. 26.6%, relative risk [RR] 1.87, 95% CI 1.63 to 2.15, P<0.001). The proportion of participants diagnosed was 2.8% in the intervention group versus 1.4% in the control group (RR 2.10, 95% CI 0.94 to 4.70, p=0.079). No evidence of heterogeneity was observed in any of the pre-specified subgroup analyses. The proportion of participants treated was 1.1% in the intervention group versus 0.7% in the control group (RR 1.72, 95% CI 0.71 to 4.16, p=0.231). Time to test was shorter in the intervention group than in the control group (28.8 days versus 36.5 days, P<0.001, test for difference in reduced median survival [RMST]), but no differences in time were found observed until treatment (83.2 days vs. 83.5 days, P=0.51, test for difference in RMST). We could not recruit the planned 3,000 participants and therefore had no power for the analysis of STI diagnoses and treated STI cases. Conclusions: The e-STI testing service increased STI testing utilization for all groups, including high-risk groups. The intervention required patients to attend a clinic for treatment and did not reduce time to treatment. Service innovations to improve treatment rates for people diagnosed online are needed and could include e-treatment and post-treatment services. e-STI testing services require long-term monitoring and evaluation. Test Registration: ISRCTN Registry ISRCTN13354298.
authors: Wilson, E.;Free, C.;Morris, T. P.;Syred, J.;Ahamed, I.;Menon-Johansson, A. S.;Palmer, M. J.;Barnard, S.;Rezel, E.;Baraitser, P.

title: Diagnostic tools for bluetongue virus and epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus applicable to the evaluation of North American veterinary diagnosticians
abstract: This review provides an overview of current and potential new diagnostic tests for Bluetongue (BT) and Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease (EHD) viruses, compiled by international participants in the Orbivirus Gap Analysis Workshop, Diagnostic Group. The focus of this review is on diagnostic tools available to North American veterinary diagnosticians. Standard diagnostic tests are readily available for BT/EHD viruses and there are described tests published in the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Manual. However, there are significant differences in the diagnostic approach to these viruses. Serological assays are well established and many laboratories have experience in performing these assays. Numerous nucleic acid amplification assays are also available for BT virus (BTV) and EHD virus (EHDV). Although there is extensive experience with BTV reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), there are no standards or comparisons of the protocols used by various state and federal veterinary diagnostic laboratories.
authors: Wilson, W. C.;Daniels, P.;Ostlund, E. N.;Johnson, D. E.;Oberst, R. D.;Hairgrove, T. B.;Mediger, J.;McIntosh, M. T.

title: Virus Risk Reduction for Commodities: A European Perspective
authors: Wisher, M.

title: Classification of Marek's disease viruses by pathotype: philosophy and methodology
abstract: The concept of the pathotype in Marek's disease (MD) probably dates back to the recognition of a more virulent form of the disease in the late 1950's (Benton & Cover, 1957). The distinctions between MD virus strains were further expanded with the description of the vv patotype in the early 1980s and the vv+ patotype in the 1990s. Pathotype designations reflect important biological properties that correlate with breakthrough vaccine immunity in the field. However, the pathotyping methods used by different laboratories were not consistent, which prevented a critical comparison of the results. Better consistency in pathotyping procedures is desirable. The Avian Disease and Oncology Laboratory (ADOL) method is based on the induction of lymphoproliferative lesions in vaccinated chickens. This method has been used to pathotype more than 45 isolates and is the basis for the current pathotype classification of MD virus strains. Its limitations include requirements for a specific type of chicken (15 x 7 ab+), large number of animals, and a statistical method to compare lesion responses to those of JM/102W and Md5 control strains. Because of these limitations, it has not been and probably will not be used in other laboratories. Comparability in pathotyping can be improved by comparing field isolates to standard prototype strains such as JM/102W, Md5 and 648A (American Type Culture Collection) or their equivalents. Data can be generated by various in vivo methods that measure tumor induction, neurological disease (both neoplastic and non-neoplastic lesions), or purely non-neoplastic criteria (such as lymphoid organ weights or viral replication). Methods based on neoplastic criteria, particularly when generated in MD-immunized chickens, will likely correlate most closely with the ADOL method and be most relevant to the development of MD virus in the field. Based on data from several experiments, a modification of the ADOL method is proposed that uses fewer chickens and can be performed with commercial specific pathogen-free strains. The modified procedure is based on "best-fit" comparisons with prototype strains and is expected to provide results that are generally comparable to the original procedure. A variety of other alternative criteria (see above) are also evaluated both for primary pathotyping and as an adjunct to other pathotyping methods. Advantages and disadvantages of alternative methods are presented. © 2005 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Witter, R. L.;Calnek, B. W.;Buscaglia, C.;Gimeno, I. M.;Schat, K. A.

title: Equine Parvovirus: Initial Isolation and Partial Characterization
abstract: viral agent was isolated from the fetal liver of an aborted horse fetus. The isolate hemagglutinated red blood cells from guinea pig, rhesus monkey and rooster. The isolate was shown to be antigenically different from parvoviruses of bovine and canine origin by haemagglutination inhibition tests. 26 of 136 horse sera tested showed specific haemagglutination-inhibiting antibodies against the viral isolate. The isolated virus displayed properties compatible with those of an autonomous parvovirus, including size, morphology, stability to ether treatment and heating to 56°C, the presence of a 5300 base DNA genome, characteristic protein composition and density (1.405 g/ ml). The virus was classified as equine parovovirus.
authors: Wong, F. C.;Spearman, J. G.;Smolenski, M. A.;Loewen, P. C.

title: Use of enteric viruses to track sources of faecal pollution in environmental waters
abstract: Microbial Source Tracking (MST) tools are used to identify sources of fecal pollution to accurately assess public health risk and implement Best Management Practices (BMPs). This review focuses on the potential of enteric viruses for MST applications. After host infection, enteric viruses multiply and are shed in large numbers in the host's feces and urine. Because of the specificity in host infections, enteric viruses are considered one of the most accurate library-independent, culture-independent MST tools. When evaluating viral molecular assays based on the sensitivity, specificity, and density of the target virus in fecal-exposed samples, human adenovirus and human polyomavirus emerged as the most promising human-specific viral markers. However, due to cross-reactions observed between livestock species or the limited number of samples tested for specificity, further research is needed to identify promising viral markers for livestock. Other viral indicators of faecal origin, F+ RNA Coliphage and Pepper Mild Mottle Virus have also been suggested as potential targets for MST marker development. Improving the utility of enteric viruses for MST applications through next-generation sequencing (NGS) and virus concentration technology is discussed in the final part of this review. The massive sequence databases generated by shotgun and gene-directed metagenomics allow for more efficient and reliable design of MST assays. Finally, recent studies have shown that alternative virus concentration methods may be less expensive than standard technologies such as 1MDS; however, improvements in recovery efficiency and consistency are still needed. Overall, developments in metagenomic information combined with efficient concentration methods and high host specificity make enteric viruses a promising tool in MST applications. © 2012 .
authors: Wong, K.;Fong, T. T.;Bibby, K.;Molina, M.

title: Cloning and sequencing of the full-length cDNA of the LPC strain of classical swine fever virus
abstract: The cDNAs of classical swine fever virus (LPC vaccine strain) were cloned by transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and their nucleotide sequences determined. In this work, we obtained the sequence information of 786 bases of 5-terminal region, 6049 bases of middle region and 1648 bases of 3-terminal region. Taking our previous results and the present data together, the entire genomic sequence of the LPC strain has been completed (12344 nucleotides long). The genome of LPC has a large open reading frame that can encode a polypeptide of 3897 amino acids and is flanked by untranslated regions (UTR), 373 bases at the 5' end and 278 bases at the 3' end. Phylogenetic analyzes based on genomic sequences of several viruses suggested that the LPC strain is closer in order to the Chinese, Riems, HCLV, Alfort/187, Brescia and Alfort strains. Upon further analysis, we found that a 13 nucleotide insertion, TTT(C/T)CTTTTTTTT, in the 3-UTR of LPC, Chinese, and HCLV strains. Immediately downstream of the 13 nucleotides, a unique LPC sequence consisting of 28 thymidines was observed.
authors: Wong, M. L.;Peng, B. Y.;Liu, J. J.;Chang, T. J.

title: Neutralizing DNA aptamers against swine influenza H3N2 viruses
abstract: Triple reassortant porcine influenza A viruses (IAVs), particularly the North American H3N2 subtype, circulate in swine herds and can reassort and lead to the emergence of new zoonotic strains. Current diagnostic tools rely on virus isolation followed by serotyping by hemagglutination or genome sequencing, both of which can be expensive and time-consuming. Therefore, new subtype-specific ligands and methods for rapid testing and subtyping of IAVs in the field are needed. To meet this need, we selected DNA aptamers against the recombinant HA protein from porcine IAV H3 cluster IV using systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment (SELEX). Four candidate aptamers (HA68, HA7, HA2a and HA2b) were identified and characterized. The dissociation constants (Kd) of the aptamers HA68, HA7, HA2a and HA2b against the recombinant H3 protein were 7.1, 22.3, 16.0 and 3.7 nM, respectively. The binding site of HA68 to H3 was identified between nucleotide residues 8 and 40. All aptamers inhibited H3 hemagglutination. HA68 was highly specific for all four lineages within the North American H3N2 subtype.
