In addition, the other three aptamers specifically identified live viruses belonging to phylogenetic clusters I, II/III and IV, specifically the virus closely related to the youngest H3N2 variant (H3N2v). Aptamer HA68 was also able to bind and detect H3N2v isolated from recent human cases. In summary, we provide subtype-specific aptamers against porcine H3N2 IAVs that can now be used in rapid detection and typing protocols for field applications. Copyright © 2013, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Wongphatcharachai, M.;Wang, P.;Enomoto, S.;Webby, R. J.;Gramer, M. R.;Amonsin, A.;Sreevatsan, S.

title: The metagenomic analysis of viromas from dromedary camel feces samples shows a large number and high diversity of circoviruses and picobirnaviruses
abstract: The recent discovery of Middle East respiratory coronavirus and another novel dromedary-camel coronavirus UAE-HKU23 in dromedaries has increased interest in searching for novel viruses in dromedaries. In this study, fecal samples from 203 dromedaries in Dubai were pooled and deeply sequenced. Of the 7330 assembled viral contigs, 1970 were assigned to mammalian viruses. The largest groups of these contigs corresponded to the Picobirnaviridae, Circoviridae, Picornaviridae, Parvoviridae, Astroviridae and Hepeviridae. Many of these virus families were previously unknown to dromedaries. In addition to the high abundance of contigs from Circoviridae (n=598 with 14 complete genomes) and Picobirnaviridae (n=1236), a high diversity of contigs from these two families was found, with the 14 complete genomes of Circoviridae forming at least five clusters and contigs both genogroup I and genogroup II, potentially novel picobirnaviruses. Further studies comparing the occurrence of these virus families in healthy and diseased dromedaries will reveal their pathogenic potential. (C) 2014 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Woo, P. C. Y.;Lau, S. K. P.;Teng, J. L. L.;Tsang, A. K. L.;Joseph, M.;Wong, E. Y. M.;Tang, Y.;Sivakumar, S.;Bai, R.;Wernery, R.;Wernery, U.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: High diversity of genogroup I picobirnaviruses in mammals
abstract: In a molecular epidemiological study of 791 fecal samples collected from various terrestrial and marine mammals in Hong Kong, genogroup I picobirnaviruses (PBVs) were positive by RT-PCR targeting the partial RdRp gene in samples from five cattle, six monkeys, 17 horses and nine targeted pigs, one rabbit, one dog and 12 California sea lions, with 11, 9, 23, 17, 1, 1 and 15 sequence types in the positive samples from the corresponding animals, respectively. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the PBV sequences of each animal species were widespread throughout the tree with high diversity and shared 47.4-89.0% nucleotide identities with other genogroup I PBV strains based on the partial RdRP gene. Nine complete segment 1 (viral loads 1.7 x 10(4) to 5.9 x 10(6)/mL) and 15 segment 2 (viral loads 4.1 x 10(3) to 1.3 x 10(6)/mL) ml) of Otarine PBVs from fecal samples serially collected from California sea lions were sequenced. In the two phylogenetic trees constructed using ORF2 and ORF3 of segment 1, the nine segment 1 sequences were clustered into four distinct clades (C1-C4). In the tree constructed using the segment 2 RdRp gene, the 15 segment 2 sequences were clustered into nine distinct clades (R1-R9). PBVs were detected in four sea lions in two different years, with the same segment 1 glade (C3) present in two consecutive years from one sea lion and different clades in different years from three sea lions. A large diversity of PBVs has been observed in a variety of land and marine mammals. Multiple sequence types with significant differences representing multiple PBV strains were present in the majority of PBV positive samples from different animal species.
authors: Woo, P. C. Y.;Teng, J. L. L.;Bai, R.;Wong, A. Y. P.;Martelli, P.;Hui, S. W.;Tsang, A. K. L.;Lau, C. C. Y.;Ahmed, S. S.;Yip, C. C. Y.;Choi, G. K. Y.;Li, K. S. M.;Lam, C. S. F.;Lau, S. K. P.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Resolution of virus subtypes of bovine viral diarrhea virus from persistently infected US beef calves with complete genome sequence
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) is divided into two genotypes, BVDV-1 and BVDV-2, each containing distinct subtypes with genetic and antigenic variations. To effectively control BVDV through vaccination, it is important to know which subtypes of the virus are circulating and how their prevalence is changing over time. Accordingly, the purpose of our study was to estimate the current prevalence and diversity of BVDV subtypes from persistently infected (PI) beef calves in the central United States. Phylogenetic analysis of the 5'-UTR (5'-untranslated region) for 119 virus strains revealed that the majority (82%) belonged to genotype 1b and the remaining strains were distributed between genotypes 1a (9%) and 2 (8%). was. ; However, BVDV-2 subtypes could not be reliably resolved. Therefore, to better define the variability of US BVDV isolates and to further investigate the subdivision of BVDV-2 isolates into subtypes, complete genome sequences were obtained for these isolates as well as for representatives of BVDV-1a and -1b. Phylogenetic analyzes of the full coding sequence provided a more conclusive genetic classification, showing that US BVDV-2 isolates belong to at least 3 different genetic groups, which are statistically supported by both full and individual coding gene analyses. These results indicate that a more complex set of BVDV-2 subtypes circulate in this region than previously thought.
authors: Workman, A. M.;Heaton, M. P.;Harhay, G. P.;Smith, T. P.;Grotelueschen, D. M.;Sjeklocha, D.;Brodersen, B.;Petersen, J. L.;Chitko-McKown, C. G.

title: Revised and updated nomenclature for highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses.
abstract: The divergence of the hemagglutinin gene of H5N1 viruses of A/Gans/Guangdong/1/1996 lineage in 2011 and 2012 (807 new sequences collected up to December 31, 2012) was determined using phylogenetic and p-distance methods analyzed to define new clades using a prepackaged nomenclature system. Eight new clade designations were created based on the division of clade 1.1 (Mekong Delta), 2.1.3.2 (Indonesia), 2.2.2 (India/Bangladesh), 2.2.1.1 (Egypt/Israel) and 2.3.2.1 (Asia) recommended. . To facilitate this and future updates, a simplification of the previously defined criteria was proposed, adding a letter instead of a number to the rightmost digit of fifth-order clades.
authors: World Health Organization/World Organisation for Animal, H. F.;Agriculture Organization, H. N. E. W. G.

title: Genetic characterization of an adapted 2009 H1N1 pandemic influenza virus showing enhanced replication rates in human lung epithelial cells
abstract: The 2009 influenza pandemic originated from a porcine H1N1 virus that, while less pathogenic than expected, may acquire additional virulence-associated mutations in the future. To assess the potential risk, we passaged the isolate A/Hamburg/04/2009 sequentially in A549 human lung epithelial cells. After passage 6 we observed a 100-fold increased replication rate. High-throughput sequencing of viral gene segments identified five dominant mutations whose contribution to increased growth was analyzed by reverse genetics. The increased replication rate was attributed to two mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene segment (HA1 D130E, HA2 I91L) near the receptor binding site and the stem domain. The adapted virus also replicated more efficiently in mice in vivo. Increased replication rate correlated with increased HA protein fusion pH and decreased receptor affinity. Our data could be relevant for monitoring prepandemic strains and developing high titer cell culture strains for vaccine production.
authors: WÃ¶rmann, X.;Lesch, M.;Welke, R. W.;Okonechnikov, K.;Abdurishid, M.;Sieben, C.;Geissner, A.;Brinkmann, V.;Kastner, M.;Karner, A.;Zhu, R.;Hinterdorfer, P.;Anish, C.;Seeberger, P. H.;Herrmann, A.;Meyer, T. F.;Karlas, A.

title: Does the complexity of the rumen microbial ecology preclude methane abatement?
abstract: Ruminants are responsible for the production of some of the greenhouse gases, particularly methane (61 Tg/year), which are believed to contribute to global warming and climate change. Methane is an end product of the fermentation of plant matter by the microbial ecosystem in the rumen. Methanogenesis is performed by methanogenic archaea and is a mechanism by which H(2) is removed from fermentation to regenerate biochemical co-factors such as NAD+. The microbial ecosystem is very complex and includes thousands of species of bacteria (10(10)-10(11) cells/ml), archaea (10(7)-10(9) cells/ml), protozoa (10(4)-10 (6) cells/ml), fungi (10(3)-10(6) cells/ml) and viruses (10(9)-10(10) cells/ml) that interact with food, their hosts and each other . This ecosystem is relatively poorly understood, particularly the interactions between species and interactions with the host. Less than 15% of the microbial species in the gastrointestinal tract have been cultured and characterized. However, knowledge of this ecosystem is increasing, particularly with the advent of molecular biology and culture-independent technologies. New high-throughput sequencing methods such as pyrosequencing will greatly improve the rate of knowledge acquisition, and techniques such as stable isotope studies will improve our ability to understand relationships between species. While we can expect an increase in our knowledge of this complex ecosystem and an improved ability to predictably reduce CH(4) emissions, there are already examples of successful reductions, including the use of feed (e.g. cereal grains) and chemical additives (e.g. 2-bromoethanesulfonate, bromochloromethane). Achieving significant reductions in CH(4) emissions may be possible with advances in our knowledge of the intricacies of this complex ecosystem. This paper is part of the special issue entitled: Greenhouse Gases in Animal Agriculture Finding a Balance between Food and Emissions, Guest Edited by TA McAllister, Section Guest Editors: KA Beauchemin, X. Hao, S. McGinn and Editor for Animal Feed Science and Technology, P. H. Robinson. (C) 2011 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Wright, A. D. G.;Klieve, A. V.

title: Molecular Characterization of H1N1 Influenza A Viruses from Human Cases in North America
abstract: Subtypes of H1N1 influenza virus can be found in humans in North America while also being associated with infection in swine. Characterizing the genotypes of viral strains in human populations is important to understanding the source and distribution of viral strains. Genome and protein sequences of 10 isolates of the 2009 North American influenza A (H1N1) virus outbreak were obtained from the GenBank database. To characterize the genotypes of these viruses, phylogenetic trees of the PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP, NA, NS, and M genes were constructed by the Phylip3.67 program and N-linked glycosylation sites of HA, NA, PB2, NS1, and M2 constructed proteins were analyzed online by the program NetNGlyc1.0. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these isolates are virtually identical but may be recombinant viruses since their genomic fragments are from different viruses. The isolates also contain a characteristic weakly pathogenic amino acid motif at their HA cleavage sites (IPSIQSRa dagger"GL) and an E residue at position 627 of the PB2 protein, showing its high affinity for humans. The homologous model of M proteins demonstrated this the viruses had acquired anti-amantadine ability due to the mutation at the drug-sensitive site, while sequence analysis of NA proteins showed that the viruses are still sensitive to the neuraminidase inhibitor drug (i.e., oseltamivir and zanamivir) as none Mutations have occurred Our results strongly suggest that the viruses responsible for the 2009 outbreaks of influenza A (H1N1) virus have the ability to cross species barriers to infect humans and mammals based on molecular Analyzes: These results could further facilitate the therapy and prevention of possible transmission from North America in other countries.
authors: Wu, B.;Wang, C. M.;Dong, G. Y.;Luo, J.;Zhao, B. H.;He, H. X.

title: Genetic and molecular characterization of H9N2 and H5 avian influenza viruses from live poultry markets in Zhejiang province, east China
abstract: Live poultry markets (LPMs) are a major source of rearranged avian influenza viruses (AIVs) due to the density of terrestrial and aquatic poultry and the frequency of AIV infection. H9N2 virus is widespread in terrestrial poultry throughout Asia and has been isolated from poultry outbreaks worldwide. They infect both avian and mammalian species and can be important donors of genetic material for emerging human pathogens. LPMs in Zhejiang Province were screened for AIVs in 2013-2014. Three hundred seventy-four (374) AIV strains were isolated from 3,328 samples. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes were performed. We identified a new H9N2 virus genotype that was reassorted with gene segments from Qa/HK/G1/97-like, Ck/BJ/1/94-like and Dk/HK/Y439/97-like viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes indicated that the H9N2 viruses had undergone regrouping with other AIV subtypes. The results also indicated that two different clades (2.3.2 and 2.3.4.6) of H5 viruses co-circulated in Zhejiang province. Since reassorted H5-AIVs have been detected in geese and ducks, it is possible that apparently healthy birds contribute to newly emerging H5-AIVs. Continuous monitoring is required for poultry in eastern China.
authors: Wu, H.;Peng, X.;Peng, X.;Cheng, L.;Lu, X.;Jin, C.;Xie, T.;Yao, H.;Wu, N.

title: Specific microRNA library of IFN-t on bovine endometrial epithelial cells
abstract: IFN-t is specifically secreted by conception in ruminants during early gestation and plays a crucial role in the immunological function of gestation. However, the mechanism involving microRNA (miRNA) is not yet well understood. Deep sequencing was used to probe the IFN-t specific miRNA library on bovine endometrial epithelial cells (bEECs). The results showed that 574 known bovine miRNAs and 109 new miRNAs were identified. We found 74 differentially expressed miRNAs, including 30 commonly expressed miRNAs in the experiment. Then qPCR verification of six selected miRNAs showed that they matched the sequence data. Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway analyzes revealed significant enrichment of predicted target genes of differentially expressed miRNAs, including influenza A, herpes simplex infection, antigen processing and presentation, viral myocarditis, TNF pathway, Graft versus - host disease and allograft rejection. These results may make important contributions to the immune response during early pregnancy in ruminants, but further studies are needed to verify the proposed cellular/immunological effects and the role of specific miRNAs as biomarkers in vivo.
authors: Wu, H.;Zhang, T.;Ma, X.;Jiang, K.;Zhao, G.;Qiu, C.;Deng, G.

title: There are shared RNA replication signals in group 2 coronaviruses: evidence for in vivo recombination between animal and human coronavirus molecules
abstract: 5” and 3” UTR sequences on the coronavirus genome are known to carry cis-acting elements for DI RNA replication and presumably also viral genome replication. It is also believed that 5â€²UTR-contiguous coding sequences harbor cis-acting elements. Here we determined the 5-inch UTR and adjacent 289-nt sequences, as well as the 3-inch UTR sequences for six group 2 coronaviruses and compared them to each other and to three previously reported group 2 members. Extensive regions of very similar UTR sequences were found, but also small regions of divergence, suggesting that group 2 coronaviruses could be subdivided into those similar to bovine coronavirus (BCoV) (BCoV, human respiratory coronavirus -OC43, human enteric coronavirus, porcine haemagglutinating). encephalomyelitis virus and equine coronavirus) and those similar to murine hepatitis virus (MHV) (A59, 2 and JHM strains of MHV, puffinosis virus and rat sialodacryoadenitis virus). The BCoV and MHV 3-inch UTRs have previously been shown to be interchangeable. Here it was shown that a reporter-containing BCoV-DI RNA is replicated by all five BCoV-like helper viruses and by MHV-H2 (a human cell-adapted MHV strain), a representative of the MHV-like subgroup, showing that group 2 has in common 5″ and 3″ replication signaling elements. Furthermore, BCoV DI RNA acquired the leader of HCoV-OC43 through leader switching, demonstrating for the first time in vivo recombination between animal and human coronavirus molecules. These results indicate that common replication signaling elements exist among group 2 coronaviruses despite a two-cluster pattern within the group, and imply that there might be a high potential for recombination between group members. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Wu, H. Y.;Guy, J. S.;Yoo, D.;Vlasak, R.;Urbach, E.;Brian, D. A.

title: Impact of live poultry market interventions on influenza A(H7N9) virus, Guangdong, China
abstract: Since March 2013, three waves of human infection with the avian influenza virus A(H7N9) have been detected in China. To examine virus transmission within and between epidemic waves, we used surveillance data and whole genome analyzes of viruses collected in Guangdong between 2013 and 2015. We observed a geographical shift in human A(H7N9) infections from the second to the third wave. Interventions in the live poultry market have been carried out in epicentric cities; However, spatial phylogenetic analysis showed that the third wave outbreaks in central Guangdong were most likely due to local virus persistence rather than introduction from elsewhere. Although the number of human clinical cases decreased by 35% from the second to the third wave, the genetic diversity of the third wave virus increased in Guangdong. Our results underscore the epidemic risk for a region that reports comparatively few A(H7N9) cases. Furthermore, our results indicate that interventions in the live poultry market cannot completely stop the persistence and spread of the A(H7N9) virus.
authors: Wu, J.;Lu, J.;Faria, N. R.;Zeng, X.;Song, Y.;Zou, L.;Yi, L.;Liang, L.;Ni, H.;Kang, M.;Zhang, X.;Huang, G.;Zhong, H.;Bowden, T. A.;Raghwani, J.;He, J.;He, X.;Lin, J.;Koopmans, M.;Pybus, O. G.;Ke, C.

title: Molecular detection of hepatitis E virus in sheep from southern Xinjiang, China
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a causative agent of infectious hepatitis in animals and humans in both developing and industrialized countries. Here we collected 500 sheep sera and 75 raw sheep liver samples from a slaughterhouse in southern part of Xinjiang region, China along with 26 sera from butchers from the same slaughterhouse. All serum samples were tested for anti-HEV antibodies by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Both serum and liver samples were assayed for the presence of HEV RNA by nested polymerase chain reaction targeting partial nucleotide sequences of open reading frame 2 (ORF2). The results show that the seroprevalence in sheep was 35.20% (176/500) and that four of the 75 (5.3%) sheep livers had detectable levels of HEV RNA. The seroprevalence of the butchers was 57.7% (15/26). The four amplicons shared 97.8-100% nucleotide sequence identity and had pairwise sequence identities of 81.6-85.3%, 84.2-85.3%, 82.1-85.3%, and 84.7-97.9 % the corresponding regions of HEV genotypes 1, 2, 3 and 4, respectively. A phylogenetic tree was constructed based on alignments of an amplified 186 bp ORF2 sequence and corresponding reference strains. Analysis showed that the four ovine strains detected in our study formed a lineage within a genotype 4 cluster containing hb-3, bjsw1, T1, swCH189 and swCH25, all belonging to genotype 4 subtype 4d. The results showed high levels of seroconversion in sheep and suggested that sheep liver could be a source of foodborne HEV infection in humans.
authors: Wu, J.;Si, F.;Jiang, C.;Li, T.;Jin, M.

title: High-throughput sequencing of the pituitary and hypothalamic microRNA transcriptome associated with high egg production rate
abstract: Background: MicroRNAs are widespread in viruses, plants and animals. As endogenous small noncoding RNAs, miRNAs regulate a variety of biological processes. Tissue miRNA expression studies have uncovered numerous functions for miRNAs in different chicken tissues, but the regulation of miRNAs in chicken pituitary and hypothalamic development related to high and low egg-laying performance remained unclear. Results: In this study, using high-throughput sequencing technology, we sequenced two tissues (pituitary and hypothalamus) in 3 high and 3 low egg producing Luhua chickens at 300 days of age. By comparing low and high egg producing chickens, 46 known miRNAs and 27 novel miRNAs were identified as differentially expressed (P<0.05). Six differentially expressed known miRNAs, expressed in both tissues, were used in RT-qPCR validation and SNP detection. Among them, seven SNPs were found in two miRNA precursors (gga-miR1684a and gga-miR-1434) that could enhance or reduce the production of the mature miRNAs. Furthermore, 124 and 30 reciprocally expressed miRNA-target pairs were identified by RNA-seq in pituitary and hypothalamic tissues, respectively, and randomly selected candidate miRNA and miRNA-target pairs were validated by RT-qPCR in Jiuyuan black chickens. Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway annotation showed that a large number of oviposition-related signaling pathways were enriched in high egg producing chickens, including ovarian steroidogenesis and steroid hormone biosynthesis. Conclusions: These differentially expressed miRNAs and their predicted target genes, specifically identified reciprocally expressed miRNA-target pairs, promote the study of miRNA function and miRNA identification associated with egg production. Analysis of the miRNA-related SNPs and their effects provided insights into the effects of SNPs on miRNA biogenesis and function. The data generated in this study will advance our understanding of miRNA regulatory mechanisms in the hen egg laying process.
authors: Wu, N.;Zhu, Q.;Chen, B. L.;Gao, J.;Xu, Z. X.;Li, D. Y.

title: Genetic diversity of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from native poultry species in eastern China between 2005 and 2008
abstract: Seventy-nine Newcastle disease (NDV) viruses isolated between 2005 and 2008 from clinical specimens of various poultry species including chickens, pigeons (Columba livia), geese and ostriches in eastern China were characterized biologically and phylogenetically. The results demonstrated the genetic diversity of these viruses: three class I viruses and one genotype I and 12 class II genotype II viruses circulating in chickens were avirulent; four genotype VIb viruses isolated from pigeons were moderately virulent; and two genotype III viruses and 57 genotype VIId viruses were highly virulent. The three class I viruses were further classified as genotypes 2 and 3. The very high F protein sequence identity of one genotype I virus with the Queensland V4 strain and 12 genotype II viruses with the La Sota strain indicated that these viruses are descended from the two vaccine strains. Two genotype III viruses shared greater than 99% sequence identity with the moderately virulent vaccine strain Mukteswar, but showed significantly higher virulence, suggesting that they evolved from the vaccine virus and that the Mukteswar vaccine will be banned in China should. Fifty-seven of the 63 virulent NDVs in this study belonged to genotype VIId, indicating its prevalence in eastern China. Genotype VIId viruses could be further divided into two subgroups. Four of the five NDVs isolated from pigeons belonged to genotype VIb, indicating its host-specific preference. Both the VIb and VIId genotype NDVs showed low amino acid similarity to the vaccine strains currently used in China, implying the urgent need to develop better vaccines against the most prevalent NDVs in China.
authors: Wu, S.;Wang, W.;Yao, C.;Wang, X.;Hu, S.;Cao, J.;Wu, Y.;Liu, W.;Liu, X.

title: Molecular and antigenic properties of domestic duck Newcastle disease virus isolates in China
abstract: Newcastle Disease (ND) is one of the most devastating diseases for the poultry industry. The causative agents of ND are virulent strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV), which are members of the Avulavirus genus within the Paramyxoviridae family. Waterfowl such as ducks and geese are generally considered potential reservoirs of NDV and may show little or no clinical signs when infected with viruses that are evidently virulent in chickens. However, over the past decade, frequent outbreaks of ND in native waterfowl have been reported in many countries. In this study, 18 NDV strains isolated from domestic ducks in southern and eastern China between 2005 and 2013 were genetically and phylogenetically characterized. The complete genomes of these strains have been sequenced and they revealed genome sizes of 15,186 nucleotides (nt), 15,192. nt and 15,198. nt that follow the "rule of six" required for replication of NDV strains. Based on the F protein cleavage site and pathogenicity tests in chickens, 17 of our NDV isolates were categorized as lentogenic viruses and one was characterized as a velogenic virus. Phylogenetic analyzes based on the partial and full genome sequences of the F gene revealed that at least four genotypes of NDV are circulating in domestic ducks; GD1, AH224, and AH209 belong to genotypes VIId, Ib, and II of class II NDVs, respectively, and the remaining 15 isolates belong to genotype 1b of class I NDVs. Cross-reactive hemagglutination inhibition assays demonstrated that the antigenic relatedness between NDV strains associated with their genotypes rather than their hosts. These results indicate that while these NDV isolates are from ducks, they do not form a phylogenetic group because they are from the same species; However, they can play an important role in promoting the development of NDVs.
authors: Wu, W.;Liu, H.;Zhang, T.;Han, Z.;Jiang, Y.;Xu, Q.;Shao, Y.;Li, H.;Kong, X.;Chen, H.;Liu, S.

title: DEF cells infected with virulent duck enteritis virus produce a unique pattern of viral microRNAs and a novel set of host microRNAs
abstract: Background: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) belongs to the family Herpesviridae and is a major epinogenic agent causing economic losses in the waterfowl industry. The Chinese virulent (CHv) and attenuated vaccine (VAC) are two different pathogenic DEV strains. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of noncoding RNAs that regulate gene expression in viral infections. However, little information is available on virulent duck enteritis virus (DEV)-encoded miRNAs. Results: Using high-throughput sequencing, we identified 39 mature viral miRNAs from CHv-infected duck embryo fibroblast cells. Compared to the reported 33 VAC-encoded miRNAs, only 13 miRNA sequences and 22 miRNA "seed sequences" were identical, and 8 new viral miRNAs were detected and confirmed by stem-loop RT-qPCR in this study. Using RNAhybrid and PITA software, it was predicted that 38 CHv-encoded miRNAs target 41 viral genes and form a complex regulatory network. Dual luciferase reporter assay (DLRA) confirmed that viral dev-miR-D8-3p can directly target the 3'-UTR of the CHv US1 gene (p<0.05). Gene ontological analyzes of host target genes of viral miRNAs have been mainly involved in biological regulation, cellular and metabolic processes. In addition, 598 new duck-encoded miRNAs were discovered in this study. Thirty-eight host miRNAs showed significant differential expression after CHv infection: 13 miRNAs were upregulated and 25 miRNAs were downregulated, which may affect viral replication in the host cell. Conclusions: These data suggest that CHv encodes a different set of microRNAs compared to VAC and forms a unique regulatory network. This is the first report of the expression profile of DEF miRNAs and an analysis of the regulatory mechanisms of these miRNAs during DEV infection. These data provide a basis for further exploration of the regulatory role of miRNA in the pathogenesis of DEV infection and contribute to the understanding of CHv-host interaction at the miRNA level.
authors: Wu, X.;Jia, R.;Zhou, J.;Wang, M.;Chen, S.;Liu, M.;Zhu, D.;Zhao, X.;Sun, K.;Yang, Q.;Wu, Y.;Yin, Z.;Chen, X.;Wang, J.;Cheng, A.

title: Peste des Petits Ruminant Viruses Reemerging in China, 2013-2014
abstract: The resurgence of the plague of small ruminants (PPR) was officially reported in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region in northwest China in November 2013, and then this disease quickly spread to other provinces, autonomous regions and others along with the movements of goats and sheep Provinces from Municipalities (P/A/M) of China. As of September 2014, a total of 256 PPR-affected districts have been identified in 22 P/A/M. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the currently circulating strains and the Tibetan strains previously isolated in 2007 both belonged to Lineage IV, but in different subbranches. However, compared to the Tibetan strains, the currently circulating strains shared a high level of genetic homology with those from Pakistan and Tajikistan.
authors: Wu, X.;Li, L.;Li, J.;Liu, C.;Wang, Q.;Bao, J. Y.;Zou, Y.;Ren, W.;Wang, H.;Zhang, Y.;Lv, Y.;Liu, F.;Wang, S.;Ma, H.;Wang, Z.

title: A novel high-throughput capillary electrophoresis-based multiplex polymerase chain reaction system for the simultaneous detection of nine porcine pathogens
abstract: Here we aimed to develop a capillary electrophoresis-based high-throughput multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) system for the simultaneous detection of nine pathogens in pigs. Nine pairs of specific primers and one set of universal primers were designed; multiplex PCR was established. The specificity and cross-reactivity of this assay were examined and the limit of detection was determined using serial 10-fold dilutions of plasmids containing the target sequences. The assay was further tested using 144 clinical specimens. We found that the nine specific peaks of amplification were observed and the assay had a high degree of specificity with no non-specific amplification. The simultaneous detection limit for the nine viruses reached 10,000 copies ΔL-1 when all premixed viral targets were present. Seventy-seven of the clinical specimens tested positive for at least one of the viruses; The main viral infections in the clinical specimens were porcine circovirus type 2 and porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus. This approach has great potential for advancing high-throughput detection tools for animal disease diagnosis.
authors: Wu, X. L.;Xiao, L.;Lin, H.;Yang, M.;Chen, S. J.;An, W.;Wang, Y.;Yao, X. P.;Yang, Z. X.;Tang, Z. Z.

title: The molecular characteristics of avian influenza virus (H9N2) derived from air samples at live poultry markets
abstract: Aim: To study the molecular properties of H9N2 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) isolated from air samples collected at live poultry markets (LPMs) and explore their sequence identities with AIVs that caused infection in humans. Methods: From 2015 to 2016, weekly monitoring of airborne H9N2 subtype AIVs from LPMs was conducted. H9 positive samples were isolated from chick embryos. Whole genome sequences of the isolated AIVs were obtained by high-throughput sequencing. The phylogenetic analysis and the major loci variations of the sequences were further analyzed. Results: A total of 327 aerosol samples of LPMs were collected. Nine samples were positive for H9 subtype AIVs based on real-time quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRRT-PCR). According to whole genome sequence analysis and phylogenetic analysis, in 2015, except strain A/Environment/Zhongshan/ZS201505/2015 (ZS201505), 8 gene segments of 8 aerosol H9N2 isolates and 2 H9N2 human isolates were in the same clade. Among the major loci variations, except for the ZS201505 strain, H9N2 subtype AIVs had no mutations in eight receptor-binding sites of hemagglutinin (HA), and stalks of neuraminidase (NA) proteins had a three-base deletion site. The PA gene of ZS201503 and ZS201602 had an L336M mutation. The N30D and T215A mutations in the M1 gene and the amino acid residues L89V in PB2, P42S in NS1 and S31N in M2 were retained in these 9 strains of H9N2 isolates, which could enhance the virulence of the virus. Conclusion: Live H9N2-AIVs survived in the aerosol from LPMs in Zhongshan city. The aerosol viruses had a close evolutionary relationship with human epidemic strains, suggesting that there may be a risk of AIV transmission to humans from polluted aerosols in LPMs. Mutations in H9N2 subtype AIVs isolated from air samples from LPMs indicated that their pathogenicity to infect humans was enhanced.
authors: Wu, Y.;Lin, J.;Yang, S.;Xie, Y.;Wang, M.;Chen, X.;Zhu, Y.;Luo, L.;Shi, W.

title: A porcine epithelial cell line infected with pseudorabies virus produces a diverse set of host microRNAs and a specific cluster of viral microRNAs
abstract: Pseudorabies virus (PRV) belongs to the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily, which causes enormous economic losses in the swine industry worldwide. Recently, many herpesviruses have been shown to encode microRNAs (miRNAs), which play critical roles in the viral life cycle. However, knowledge of PRV-encoded miRNAs is still limited. Here we report a comprehensive analysis of both viral and host miRNA expression profiles in PRV-infected porcine epithelial cell lines (PK-15). Deep sequencing data showed that the ~4.6 kb intron of the large latency transcript (LLT) acts as the primary microRNA precursor (pri-miRNA) that forms a cluster of 11 different miRNAs in the PRV genome as well as 209 known and 39 novel porcine miRNAs were identified. Viral miRNAs were further confirmed by stem loop RT-PCR and Northern blot analysis. Interestingly, all of these viral miRNAs displayed terminal heterogeneity at both the 5' and 3' ends. Seven miRNA genes produced mature miRNAs from both arms and two of the viral miRNA genes showed partial overlap in their precursor regions. Unexpectedly, a high abundance end-loop derived small RNA and a specific miRNA offset RNA (moRNA) were processed from the same viral miRNA precursor. The polymorphisms of viral miRNAs shed light on the complexity of the host miRNA processing machinery and the viral miRNA regulation mechanism. The porcine and PRV genes were pooled for target prediction of the viral miRNAs, revealing a complex network composed of both host and viral genes. GO enrichment analysis of host target genes suggests that PRV miRNAs are involved in complex cellular signaling pathways, including cell death, immune system processes, and metabolic pathways, indicating that these miRNAs play an important role in the virus-cell interaction of PRV and its play innkeepers. Taken together, these data suggest that a PRV-infected epithelial cell line produces a diverse set of host miRNAs and a specific cluster of viral miRNAs that might facilitate PRV replication in cells.
authors: Wu, Y. Q.;Chen, D. J.;He, H. B.;Chen, D. S.;Chen, L. L.;Chen, H. C.;Liu, Z. F.

title: Discovery of different rodent and bat pestiviruses with different genomic and phylogenetic features in several Chinese provinces
abstract: Bats and rodents are widespread worldwide and may be native or intermediate reservoirs of many important zoonotic viruses. Pestiviruses are a group of virus species in the genus Pestivirus under the family Flaviviridae that can infect a variety of Artiodactylus hosts, including swine and ruminants. Two classic types of pestiviruses, bovine viral diarrhea virus and classical swine fever virus, are important causative agents of mild to severe disease in cattle and swine, respectively, causing enormous economic losses in these industries. Recent reports indicated that bats and rodents may also act as natural hosts of pestiviruses, and an atypical porcine pestivirus that causes disease in piglets showed a close genetic relationship to a specific bat pestivirus, RaPestV-1. This study aimed to describe the detection and characterization of novel pestiviruses from bats and rodents in different localities by analyzing the available bat and rodent viroma data from across China. Two bat pestivirus species and four rodent pestivirus species distinct from other known viruses have been identified and sequenced. These viruses have been identified in two bat species and four rodent species in different Chinese provinces. Two distinct lineages distinct from the Artiodactylus pestivirus were present in these viruses. These results advance our understanding of the genetic diversity of pestiviruses in bats and rodents and suggest that a diverse group of pestiviruses are present in non-artiodactyl hosts. This study may provide new insights for the prevention of future outbreaks of viral diseases caused by bats and rodents.
authors: Wu, Z.;Liu, B.;Du, J.;Zhang, J.;Lu, L.;Zhu, G.;Han, Y.;Su, H.;Yang, L.;Zhang, S.;Liu, Q.;Jin, Q.

title: Decoding the bat virom catalog to better understand the ecological diversity of bat viruses and the bat origin of emerging infectious diseases
abstract: Studies have shown that approximately 60% to 80% of human emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) originate from wild animals. Bats are natural reservoirs of a wide variety of viruses, including many important zoonotic viruses that cause serious disease in humans and domestic animals. However, understanding of the virus population and the ecological diversity present in bat populations is unclear, making it difficult to determine the origin of specific EIDs. Using bats as a typical wildlife reservoir model, virome analysis was performed based on pharyngeal and anal swab samples from 4440 bat individuals from 40 large bat species across China. The purpose of this study was to investigate the ecological and biological diversity of viruses found in these bat species, to investigate the presence of potential bat-borne zoonotic viruses, and to assess the public health impact of these viruses. The data obtained in this study provided an overview of the viral community present in these bat samples. Many novel bat viruses have been reported for the first time, and several bat viruses closely related to known human or animal pathogens have been identified. This genetic evidence provides new clues in the search for the origin or evolutionary pattern of certain viruses, such as B. Corona viruses and noroviruses. This data provides meaningful ecological information for predicting and tracing EIDs derived from wild animals.
authors: Wu, Z.;Yang, L.;Ren, X.;He, G.;Zhang, J.;Yang, J.;Qian, Z.;Dong, J.;Sun, L.;Zhu, Y.;Du, J.;Yang, F.;Zhang, S.;Jin, Q.

title: Virome analysis to identify novel mammalian viruses in bat species from Chinese provinces
abstract: Bats are natural hosts for a variety of zoonotic viruses. This study aimed to describe the range of bat vioma including mammalian, insect, fungal, plant and phage viruses in 11 insectivorous bat species (216 bats in total) distributed in six provinces of China. To analyze viromes, we used sequence-independent PCR amplification and next-generation sequencing technology (Solexa Genome Analyzer II; Illumina). The viromes were identified by sequence similarity comparisons with known viruses. The mammalian viruses included those of Adenoviridae, Herpesviridae, Papillomaviridae, Retroviridae, Circoviridae, Rhabdoviridae, Astroviridae, Flaviridae, Coronaviridae, Picornaviridae and Parvovirinae; Insect viruses included those of the Baculoviridae, Iflaviridae, Dicistroviridae, Tetraviridae and Densovirinae; Fungal viruses included those of Chrysoviridae, Hypoviridae, Partitiviridae and Totiviridae; and phage included those of Caudovirales, Inoviridae and Microviridae and unclassified phage. In addition to the viruses and phages associated with the insect, plant, and bacterial flora associated with feeding and colonization in bats, we identified the full or partial genome sequences of 13 novel mammalian viruses. These included herpesviruses, papillomaviruses, a circovirus, a bocavirus, picornaviruses, a pestivirus, and a foamyvirus. Pairwise alignments and phylogenetic analysis indicated that these novel viruses shared little genetic similarity to previously reported viruses. This study also showed high prevalence and diversity of bat astroviruses and coronaviruses in some provinces. These results have advanced our understanding of viromes of bats in China and indicated the presence of a large diversity of unknown mammalian viruses in many common mainland China bat species.
authors: Wu, Z. Q.;Ren, X. W.;Yang, L.;Hu, Y. F.;Yang, J.;He, G. M.;Zhang, J. P.;Dong, J.;Sun, L. L.;Du, J.;Liu, L. G.;Xue, Y.;Wang, J. M.;Yang, F.;Zhang, S. Y.;Jin, Q.

title: Exploring the virome of bovine non-suppurative encephalitis of unknown etiology by metagenomics
abstract: Nonsuppurative encephalitis is one of the most common pathologic diagnoses in cattle with neurological disease, but there is a gap in knowledge about disease-associated pathogens. To identify viruses associated with bovine nonsuppurative encephalitis, we applied a viral metagenomics approach to a sample of 16 neurologically diseased cows. We have identified six virus candidates: parainfluenza virus 5 (PIV-5), bovine astrovirus CH13/NeuroS1 (BoAstV-CH13/NeuroS1), bovine polyomavirus 2 (BPyV-2 SF), ovine herpesvirus 2 (OvHV-2), bovine herpesvirus 6 ( BHV-6) and a new bovine beta retrovirus designated BoRV-CH15. In a case-control study using PCR, BoAstV-CH13 (p=0.046), BoPV-2 SF (p=0.005), and BoHV-6 (p=4.3E-05) were statistically associated with the disease. These data advance our knowledge of bovine encephalitis-associated pathogens and indicate the value of NGS in solving complex infection scenarios in a clinical disease setting.
authors: WÃ¼thrich, D.;Boujon, C. L.;Truchet, L.;Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Oevermann, A.;Bouzalas, I. G.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Equine rhinovirus serotypes 1 and 2: relationship to each other and to aphthoviruses and cardioviruses
abstract: Equine rhinoviruses (ERVs) are picornaviruses that cause mild respiratory infection in horses. The disease resembles the common cold caused by rhinoviruses in humans; however, the presence of viremia during ERV-1 infection, the occurrence of persistent infections, and physical characteristics are all more reminiscent of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus. cDNA cloning and sequencing of the ERV-1 and ERV-2 genomes between the poly(C) and poly(A) stretches showed that the serotypes are heterogeneous. Nevertheless, the genomic architecture of both serotypes is most similar to that of FMDV. Indeed, a comparison of the deduced protein sequences of ERV-1 shows that its identity is strongest to FMDV. In contrast, most ERV-2 proteins are more closely related to encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) proteins than to FMDV or ERV-1. These results place ERV-1 along with FMDV in the aphthovirus genus of the picornavirus family and indicate that this virus can serve as a model system for studying the biology of FMDV.
authors: Wutz, G.;Auer, H.;Nowotny, N.;Grosse, B.;Skern, T.;Kuechler, E.

title: Sequence analysis of the human vioma in febrile and afebrile children
authors: Wylie, K. M.;Mihindukulasuriya, K. A.;Sodergren, E.

title: Virome genomics: a tool to define the human virome
authors: Wylie, K. M.;Weinstock, G. M.;Storch, G. A.

title: Improved virome sequencing through targeted sequence acquisition
authors: Wylie, T. N.;Wylie, K. M.;Herter, B. N.;Storch, G. A.

title: Comparative transcriptomics highlights the role of the transcription factor activator protein 1 in the host response to Ebola virus
abstract: Ebola virus and Marburg virus comprise two genera of negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses that cause severe hemorrhagic fevers in humans. Despite significant research efforts, the molecular events following Ebola virus (EBOV) infection are poorly understood. With a view to identifying host factors underlying EBOV pathogenesis, we compared the transcriptomes of EBOV-infected human, porcine, and bat kidney cells using a transcriptome sequencing approach (RNA-seq). Despite a significant difference in viral transcription/replication between cell lines, all cells responded to EBOV infection by robust induction of extracellular growth factors. In addition, significant upregulation of activator protein 1 (AP1) transcription factor complex members FOS and JUN was observed in permissive cell lines. Functional studies focused on human cells showed that EBOV infection induces protein expression, phosphorylation and nuclear accumulation of JUN and to a lesser extent FOS. Using a luciferase-based reporter, we show that EBOV infection induces AP1 transactivation activity in human cells at 48 and 72 h post-infection. Finally, we show that JUN knockdown decreases expression of EBOV-induced host gene expression. Taken together, our study underscores the role of AP1 in promoting the host gene expression profile that defines EBOV pathogenesis.IMPORTANT Many questions remain about the molecular events underlying filovirus pathophysiology. The rational design of new intervention strategies, such as B. post-exposure therapeutics, is greatly enhanced by a thorough understanding of these molecular events. We believe that new insights into the molecular pathogenesis of EBOV may be possible by examining the transcriptomic response of taxonomically distinct cell lines (derived from human, pig and bat). We first identified the reaction pathways using an RNA-seq based transcriptomics approach. Further functional and computational analysis focused on human cells highlighted an important role of the AP1 transcription factor in mediating the transcriptional response to EBOV infection. Our study sheds new light on how host transcription factors respond to and promote the transcriptional landscape after viral infection.
authors: Wynne, J. W.;Todd, S.;Boyd, V.;Tachedjian, M.;Klein, R.;Shiell, B.;Dearnley, M.;McAuley, A. J.;Woon, A. P.;Purcell, A. W.;Marsh, G. A.;Baker, M. L.

title: Microbiological safety of the first clinical porcine islet xenotransplantation study in New Zealand
authors: Wynyard, S.;Nathu, D.;Garkavenko, O.

title: Molecular phylogenetic analysis of bovine viral diarrhea virus: A Bayesian approach
abstract: Genetic typing of Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) is important for accurate classification of viruses. Traditionally, the derivation of BVDV phylogeny has been performed by a distance-based method, i.e., neighbor joining for single genes. In this study, a Bayesian approach was used to analyze five genetic regions of the BVDV genome (5'' UTR, Npro, E2a, E2b, and NS3) for 68 taxa retrieved from GenBank. The results showed that all taxa in the E2a consensus tree were correctly assigned to the appropriate groups, i.e. Type-2 BVDV and BVDV-1a, -1b, -1c, -1e and -1g, supported by a high posterior probability. In contrast, subgroup 1a formed polytomies in the consensus trees of 5″ UTR and NS3. Polytomies also appeared in subgroup 1b in the Npro and E2b consensus trees. Analysis of a combined dataset revealed a clear, well-supported phylogenetic hypothesis. The topologies found for each genetic region separately and combined were different, but the differences were mainly weakly supported by the data. Combining the data allowed the identification of well-supported strains of strains that correspond to some of the previously defined subgroups. Only a combined approach will allow the reliable placement of new strains in the current classification of viruses into genotype and subgenotype. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Xia, H.;Liu, L.;Wahlberg, N.;Baule, C.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Sequence analysis of Peste des petits ruminants virus from ibex in Xinjiang, China
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an infectious disease caused by the peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV). While PPR primarily affects domestic goats and sheep, it also affects wild ungulates such as ibex, blue sheep, and gazelle, although there have been few reports of PPRV infection in wild animals. Between January 2015 and February 2015, wild ibex were first noted to be dying from PPRV infection in Bazhou, Xinjiang, China, where a total of 38 ibex (including young and adult ibex) were found to be abnormal with PPR-related issues. First, we tested for the presence of the F gene of PPRV by RT-PCR. We then compared the sequence of the isolated F gene from the ibex strain designated PPRV Xinjiang/Ibex/2015 to those previously identified from small domestic ruminants from local areas near where the reported isolate was found, as well as to those from other regions . The current sequence was classified phylogenetically as a lineage IV virus and shared a high degree of sequence identity (99.7%) with a previously described PPRV isolate from Xinjiang.
authors: Xia, J.;Zheng, X. G.;Adili, G. Z.;Wei, Y. R.;Ma, W. G.;Xue, X. M.;Mi, X. Y.;Yi, Z.;Chen, S. J.;Du, W.;Muhan, M.;Duhaxi, C.;Han, T.;Gudai, B.;Huang, J.

title: Transmission of Newcastle disease virus from poultry to wild birds in southern China's Guangdong province
abstract: Despite intensive vaccination programs in many countries, including China, Newcastle disease has been reported sporadically and still poses a significant threat to the poultry industry in China. Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is contagious to at least 250 species of birds, but the role of wild birds in virus epidemiology is still largely unknown. Fourteen NDV isolates were recovered from 2040 samples collected from wild birds or the environment in Guangdong Province, southern China, from 2013 to 2015. The isolation rate was highest during the period of overwintering and lowest during the periods of spring migration, nesting, and post-nesting. A phylogenetic analysis of maximum clade credibility found that at least four genotypes circulate in southern China: three class II genotypes (II, VI, and IX) and one class I (1b). We also showed that most isolates from wild birds were very similar to isolates from poultry and two isolates were associated with viruses from wild birds in northern China. These data suggested that wild birds could spread NDV and that poultry-borne viruses could spread to wild birds. Accordingly, vaccine development and poultry management strategies should be considered to prevent future NDV outbreaks, especially given the strength of the poultry industry in developing countries like China.
authors: Xiang, B.;Han, L.;Gao, P.;You, R.;Wang, F.;Xiao, J.;Liao, M.;Kang, Y.;Ren, T.

title: Cloning and structural analysis of the mouse Chinese genomic nucleophosmin gene
abstract: Nucleophosmin (NPM) is an abundant nucleolar phosphoprotein. NPM gene-involved chromosomal translocations have been found in patients with anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), acute myeloid leukemia (AML), and acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). To generate NPM gene knockout mice and study their biological function in vivo, we screened the lambda phage genomic library derived from 129S1 mice with mouse NPM cDNA probe. A positive phage clone containing full-length NPM genomic DNA was obtained, and the insert of 15.3 kb genomic DNA in this clone was sequenced by the shotgun method. BLAST analysis showed that the sequence of the insert is 99.8% identical to that of the NPM gene of the C57BL/6 mouse strain. Based on the sequence, a bioinformatic analysis of the genomic structure of NPM and the transcription factor binding sites in the 5'-flanking region of NPM was performed.
authors: Xiang, Y. G.;Lu, S. Y.;Gu, M. M.;Wang, S. Y.;Ren, S. X.;Fu, G.;Wang, Z. G.

title: Characterization of porcine parvovirus type 2 (PPV2), which is widespread in the USA.
abstract: novel porcine parvovirus, termed porcine parvovirus 2 (PPV2), was first identified in Myanmar in 2001, China in 2006-2007, and Hungary in 2012. To investigate the presence and prevalence of PPV2 in the US, a novel TaqMan® real-time PCR method was developed and used for PPV2 screening using 483 lung samples, 185 fecal samples, and 122 sera collected from pigs collected from 295 farms in 18 US states. The overall prevalence of PPV2 was 20.7% (100/483) in lung samples and 7.6% (14/185) in faecal samples from pigs of different ages and 1.6% (2/122) in sera or thoracic fluids from newborn pigs . Further comparison of the genomic sequences showed that the 2011 US PPV2 sequences share 95.4-97.7% nucleotide identities with the 2006-2007 strains discovered in China, while the nucleotide identity with the 2001 strain discovered in Myanmar 94.7%, indicating continued evolution of the virus. Phylogenetic and sequence homology analyzes revealed a close relationship of PPV2 to members of the proposed genus of PARV4-like viruses and the classification of PPV2 into this proposed genus is proposed. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Xiao, C. T.;Gerber, P. F.;GimÃ©nez-Lirola, L. G.;Halbur, P. G.;Opriessnig, T.

title: Molecular evolutionary genetic analysis of emerging parvoviruses identified in pigs
abstract: Parvoviruses infect a wide variety of vertebrates and arthropods and are associated with diverse clinical manifestations. Recently, due to the advent of new sequence-independent PCR methods and high-throughput sequencing, several new members of parvoviruses within the subfamily Parvovirinae have been described. Some of these viruses do not fit the current classification and others now have confusing or conflicting nomenclature, as two or more names have been used for similar or identical groups of parvoviruses, or identical names for different virus groups. In this study, recently described vertebrate parvoviruses were identified with a focus on those identified in pigs by phylogenetic analyzes based on the sequences of their complete or nearly complete genome, open reading frame (ORF) 1 (nonstructural protein, NS1), ORF2 (capsid protein, VP1), and ORF3 (nuclear phosphoprotein, NP1) genes using Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), Maximum Likelihood (ML), and Neighbor Joining (NJ) methods. Among all available vertebrate parvovirus sequences, eight different clades have been identified, corresponding to five well-established genera Parvovirus, Erythrovirus, Denpendovirus, Amdovirus and Bocavirus. In addition, three new clades were identified and tentatively named PARV4-like virus, new clade 1 and new clade 2. Parvoviruses in pigs have been found to be distributed across four distinct clades including parvovirus, bocavirus, PARV4-like virus and the new clade 2. All porcine parvoviruses identified to date have been organized based on the current analysis. The present analysis will help to clarify the nomenclature of porcine parvoviruses and facilitate future uniform naming of new parvoviruses within the subfamily Parvovirinae. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Xiao, C. T.;Halbur, P. G.;Opriessnig, T.

title: Identification and classification of endogenous bovine retroviruses
abstract: The aim of this study was to identify the endogenous retrovirus (ERV) sequences in a bovine genome. We subjected bovine genomic DNA to PCR with degenerate or ovine ERV (OERV) family-specific primers designed to amplify the retroviral Pro/Pol region. Sequence analysis of 113 clones obtained by PCR revealed that 69 were of retroviral origin. Based on the OERV classification system, these degenerate PCR clones could be classified into the β3, β4, and β9 families. PCR with family-specific OERV primers revealed an additional ERV that has been classified into the bovine endogenous retrovirus (BERV)-β7 family. Finally, we report here the results of a genome-wide study of BERV. Our study shows that the expansion of the ERV family in cattle may be somewhat limited, while more diverse family members of ERVs have been reported from other artiodactyls such as pigs and sheep. Copyright © 2008, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Xiao, R.;Park, K.;Lee, H.;Kim, J.;Park, C.

title: Understanding PRRSV infection in pig lungs based on the genome-wide transcriptome response identified by deep sequencing
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most economically significant diseases affecting the swine industry worldwide, causing large economic losses every year. PRRS virus (PRRSV) replicates primarily in porcine alveolar macrophages (PAMs) and dendritic cells (DCs) and develops persistent infections, antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE), interstitial pneumonia, and immunosuppression. But the molecular mechanisms of PRRSV infection are still poorly understood. Here we report the first genome-wide host transcriptional responses to infection with classic North American PRRSV (N-PRRSV) strain CH 1a using the Solexa/Illumina digital gene expression (DGE) system, a tag-based high-level transcriptome sequencing method throughput, and to systematically analyze the relationship between pulmonary gene expression profiles after N-PRRSV infection and infection pathology. Our results suggest that N-PRRSV appears to employ multiple strategies for its replication and spread in infected pigs, including undermining the host's innate immune response, inducing an anti-apoptotic and anti-inflammatory state, and developing ADE. Upregulated expression of virus-induced pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, adhesion molecules and inflammatory enzymes and inflammatory cells, antibodies, complement activation likely led to the development of inflammatory responses during N-PRRSV infection processes. N-PRRSV-induced immunosuppression could be mediated by apoptosis of infected cells, which caused immune cells to become depleted and induced an anti-inflammatory cytokine response in which they failed to eradicate the primary infection. Our systems analysis will help to better understand the molecular pathogenesis of N-PRRSV infection, develop novel antiviral therapies and identify genetic components for porcine resistance/susceptibility to PRRS. © 2010 Xiao et al.
authors: Xiao, S.;Jia, J.;Mo, D.;Wang, Q.;Qin, L.;He, Z.;Zhao, X.;Huang, Y.;Li, A.;Yu, J.;Niu, Y.;Liu, X.;Chen, Y.

title: Abnormal host immune response induced by highly virulent PRRSV identified by digital gene expression tag profiling
abstract: Background: In 2006 and 2007, a large-scale outbreak of the highly pathogenic porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) occurred in China and Vietnam, resulting in unusually high morbidity and mortality in pigs of all ages. The mechanisms underlying the molecular pathogenesis of the highly virulent PRRS virus (H-PRRSV) are still unknown. Therefore, the relationship between pulmonary gene expression profiles after H-PRRSV infection and infection pathology was analyzed in this study using high-throughput deep sequencing and histopathology. Results: H-PRRSV infection resulted in severe pulmonary pathology. The results indicate that aberrant host innate immune responses to H-PRRSV and induction of an antiapoptotic state may be responsible for the aggressive replication and spread of H-PRRSV. Productive rapid replication of H-PRRSV may have elicited abnormal sustained expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, resulting in a highly robust inflammatory response amplified by significant cell death and increased oxidative damage. The end result was severe tissue damage and high pathogenicity. Conclusions: The systems analysis used in this study provides a comprehensive basis for a better understanding of the pathogenesis of H-PRRSV. In addition, it allows for the identification of the genetic components involved in H-PRRSV resistance/susceptibility in swine populations. © 2010 Xiao et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Xiao, S.;Mo, D.;Wang, Q.;Jia, J.;Qin, L.;Yu, X.;Niu, Y.;Zhao, X.;Liu, X.;Chen, Y.

title: Generation of an effective, stable, live attenuated Newcastle disease virus vaccine by reverse genetics based on a currently circulating, highly virulent Indonesian strain
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) can cause serious illness in chickens. Although NDV vaccines exist, reports of outbreaks in vaccinated chickens are common. In 2009-2010, despite intensive vaccination, NDV caused major outbreaks in commercial poultry farms in Indonesia. These outbreaks have raised concerns about the protective immunity of current vaccines against circulating virulent strains in Indonesia. In this study, we investigated whether a recombinant attenuated Indonesian NDV strain could provide better protection against prevalent Indonesian viruses. A reverse genetics system for the highly virulent NDV strain Banjarmasin/010/10 (Ban/010) isolated in Indonesia in 2010 was constructed. The Ban/010 virus is classified in genotype VII class II NDV, which is genetically distinct from the commercial vaccine strains B1 and LaSota, which belong to genotype II, and share only 89 and 87% amino acid identity for the protective antigens F and HN and A mutant virus called Ban/AF was engineered in which the virulent F protein cleavage site motif "RRQKRâ†"F" was modified by three amino acid substitutions (underlined) into an avirulent motif "GRQGRâ†"L". The Ban/AF vaccine virus did not produce syncytia or plaques in cell culture, even in the presence of added protease. Pathogenicity tests showed that Ban/AF was completely avirulent. Ban/AF replicated efficiently during 10 consecutive passages in chickens and remained genetically stable. Serological analysis showed that Ban/AF induced higher neutralization and hemagglutination inhibition antibody titers against the predominant viruses than commercial vaccines B1 or LaSota. Both Ban/AF and commercial vaccines provided protection against clinical morbidity and mortality following challenge with the virulent NDV strain Ban/010 (genotype VII) or GB Texas (genotype II). However, Ban/AF significantly reduced the shedding of challenge virus from the vaccinated birds compared to the B1 vaccine. These results suggest that Ban/AF may provide better protection than commercial vaccines and is a promising vaccine candidate against NDV strains circulating in Indonesia.
authors: Xiao, S.;Nayak, B.;Samuel, A.;Paldurai, A.;Kanabagattebasavarajappa, M.;Prajitno, T. Y.;Bharoto, E. E.;Collins, P. L.;Samal, S. K.

title: Design and validation of a universal influenza virus enrichment probe set and its utility in deep sequence analysis of primary wild bird cloacal swab monitor samples
abstract: Influenza virus infections in humans and animals are a major public health problem. In the current study, a set of universal influenza enrichment probes was developed to increase the sensitivity of sequence-based virus detection and characterization for all influenza viruses. This universal influenza enrichment probe set contains 46,953 120nt RNA biotin-labeled probes designed based on all available influenza virus sequences and can be used to enrich for influenza sequences without prior knowledge of the type or subtype. Marked accumulation has been demonstrated in influenza A/H1N1, influenza B and H1 to H16 hemagglutinin plasmids transfected into human DNA and in cultured influenza A/H2N1 viruses. In addition, accumulation effects and mixed infections with the influenza A virus were found in cloacal swab samples from wild birds. Therefore, this universal influenza virus enrichment probe system can selectively and effectively detect and enrich for influenza virus sequences in various samples, especially those with degraded RNA or with low amounts of influenza RNA.
authors: Xiao, Y.;Nolting, J. M.;Sheng, Z. M.;Bristol, T.;Qi, L.;Bowman, A. S.;Taubenberger, J. K.

title: Characterization of faecal virome and faecal virus shedding patterns of commercial mink (Neovison vison)
authors: Xie, X. T.

title: Analysis of the miRNA expression profile in an Aedes albopictus cell line in response to bluetongue virus infection
abstract: Cellular microRNAs (miRNAs) have been reported to be key regulators of virus-host interactions. Bluetongue virus (BTV) is an insect-borne virus that causes huge economic losses in livestock industries worldwide. Aedes albopictus cell lines have become powerful and convenient tools for studying BTV-vector interactions. However, the role of miRNAs in A. albopictus cells during BTV infection is not well understood. In this study, we performed deep sequence analysis of small RNA libraries from BTV-infected and mock-infected A. albopictus cells and a total of 11,206,854 and 12,125,274 clean reads were identified, respectively. Differential expression analysis showed that 140 miRNAs, including 15 known and 125 novel miRNAs, were significantly dysregulated after infection and a total of 414 and 2307 target genes were annotated, respectively. Real-time quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction validated the expression patterns of 11 selected miRNAs and their mRNA targets. The functional annotation of the target genes suggested that these target genes were mainly involved in metabolic pathways, oxidative phosphorylation, endocytosis, RNA transport, as well as FoxO, Hippo, Jak-STAT, and MAPK signaling pathways. This is the first systematic study of the effect of BTV infection on miRNA expression in A. albopictus cells. This study provides information on the cellular miRNA expression profile in response to BTV infection and offers clues to identify potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies.
authors: Xing, S.;Du, J.;Gao, S.;Tian, Z.;Zheng, Y.;Liu, G.;Luo, J.;Yin, H.

title: First detection of porcine parvovirus 7 in China
abstract: Porcine parvovirus (PPV) are small, non-enveloped, and single-stranded DNA viruses that are taxonomically classifiable within the Parvoviridae family. So far, seven PPV genotypes (PPV1 to PPV7) have been identified. PPV7, the most recently discovered PPV genotype, was first reported in US swine in 2016. To investigate PPV7 status in Chinese pig populations, a total of 64 serum samples collected from two commercial farms in Guangdong province in 2014 were analyzed. PPV7 DNA was detected in 32.8% (21/64) of the samples tested. On the porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) positive farm, the prevalence rate of PPV7 was 65.5% (19/29), which was significantly higher than that on the PCV2 negative farm (2/35, 5.7%) , suggesting a possible link between these PCV2 and PPV7 infections. The sequences of three PPV7 strains were determined. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the identified PPV7 strains circulating in China share 98.7% to 99.7% nucleotide homology with the US strain. Further sequence comparison analysis showed that GD-2014-2 and GD-2014-3 possess a consecutive 9 nt deletion in the VP gene. This is the first report of the existence of PPV7 in China and this finding will enhance the understanding of the epidemiology of porcine parvovirus in Chinese pigs.
authors: Xing, X.;Zhou, H.;Tong, L.;Chen, Y.;Sun, Y.;Wang, H.;Zhang, G.

title: Porcine endogenous retrovirus study in the maintenance population of Ningxiang pigs
abstract: Porcine endogenous retrovirus (PERV) varies between pig breeds. The screening and analysis of PERV in putative pig breeds can provide basic parameters to assess the biosafety of pig-to-human xenotransplantation. In this study, PERV was examined in the maintenance population of the Ningxiang pig. The result showed that the genotype of PERV distribution was subtype A, 100%; subtype B, 100%; and subtype C, 100%. The env sequences of PERV-A and -B revealed 11 clones detected by KpnI and MboI digestion, indicating that multiple variants of PERV-A and -B existed in the Ningxiang pig. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction results showed that PERV had transcriptional activity in these individuals. In addition, PERV A/C was recombinantly detected in most individuals of Ningxiang pigs. Because PERV A/C recombinants increase the potential risk of infection, the breed may not be a suitable donor for xenotransplantation. Crown Copyright © 2009.
authors: Xing, X. W.;Hawthorne, W. J.;Yi, S.;Simond, D. M.;Dong, Q.;Ye, B.;Tong, Q. J.;Ye, Z.;Wang, W.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of porcine bocaviruses transmitted by murine rodents and house shrews in China
abstract: Bocaparvovirus infections of humans and both wild and domestic animals have been widely reported worldwide. In this study, we detected and genetically characterized porcine bocavirus (PBoV) transmitted by murine rodents (Rattus norvegicus, Rattus tanezumi, and Rattus loosea) and domestic shrews (Suncus murinus) in China. Between May 2015 and May 2017, 496 murine rodents and 23 house shrews were caught in four Chinese provinces. The nested polymerase chain reaction was used to study the prevalence of PBoV in throat swab, stool and serum samples. A total of 7.5% (39/519) throat swab specimens, 60.5% (309/511) stool specimens, and 22.9% (52/227) serum specimens were PBoV positive. The prevalence in R. norvegicus and R. tanezumi was higher than in R. losea and house shrews. PBoV-positive samples were found in all four provinces. Phylogenetic analysis based on the partial viral capsid protein 1/2 (VP1/VP2) showed that the sequences obtained in this study formed a new group (PBoV G4). In addition, five nearly full-length (4,715-4,798 nt) PBoV genomes were acquired. These genomes encoded two nonstructural proteins, NS1 (1,908 nt in four genomes and 1,923 nt in the remaining genome) and NP1 (600 nt), and the structural proteins VP1/VP2 (1,851 nt). Phylogenetic analysis showed that PBoV G4 is distinct from rodent, human, and other bocaviruses. In conclusion, the prevalence of PBoV G4 in two common murine rodents in China was high and the pathogenicity of PBoV G4 needs to be further clarified.
authors: Xiong, Y. Q.;You, F. F.;Chen, X. J.;Chen, Y. X.;Wen, Y. Q.;Chen, Q.

title: Metagenomic analysis of the faecal microbiome of Rhinopithecus bieti reveals a wide variety of bacterial and glycoside hydrolase profiles associated with lignocellulose degradation
abstract: BACKGROUND: The gastrointestinal tract of animals contains a complex community of microbes whose composition ultimately reflects the coevolution of microorganisms with their animal host and the diet adopted by the host. Although the importance of the human gut microbiota has been well established, there is a lack of research on non-human primates (NHPs), particularly herbivorous NHPs. RESULTS: In this study, an analysis of 97,942 pyrosequencing reads generated from Rhinopithecus bieti fecal DNA extracts was performed to provide a better understanding of the microbial diversity and functional capacity of the Rhinopithecus bieti gut microbiome. Taxonomic analysis of the metagenomic reads revealed that the faecal microbiomes of R. bieti were dominated by strains Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, Proteobacteria, and Actinobacteria. The comparative analysis of the taxonomic classification revealed that the metagenome of R. bieti was characterized by an overrepresentation of bacteria of the phyla Fibrobacteres and Spirochaetes compared to other animals. Primary functional categories have been mainly associated with protein, carbohydrate, amino acids, DNA and RNA metabolism, cofactors, cell wall and capsule and membrane transport. Comparing the glycoside hydrolase profiles of R. bieti with those of other animals revealed that the R. bieti microbiome was most closely related to the cow rumen. CONCLUSIONS: Metagenomic and functional analyzes revealed that R. bieti possesses a broad bacterial diversity and numerous glycoside hydrolases responsible for lignocellulosic biomass degradation, which may reflect the adaptations associated with a high-fiber diet. These results would add to the limited number of NHPs metagenome studies and provide a unique genetic resource of plant cell wall degrading microbial enzymes. However, future studies of R. bieti metagenome sequencing regarding the effects of age, genetics, diet, and environment on metagenome composition and activity are needed.
authors: Xu, B.;Xu, W.;Li, J.;Dai, L.;Xiong, C.;Tang, X.;Yang, Y.;Mu, Y.;Zhou, J.;Ding, J.;Wu, Q.;Huang, Z.

title: Hybrid DNA virus in Chinese patients with seronegative hepatitis detected by deep sequencing
abstract: Seronegative hepatitis—non-A, non-B, non-C, non-D, non-E hepatitis—is poorly characterized but strongly associated with serious complications. Between 1999 and 2007, we collected 92 serum samples from patients with non-AE hepatitis in Chongqing, China. Ten serum pools were screened using Solexa deep sequencing. We detected a 3,780 bp contig present in all 10 pools, yielding BLASTx E scores of 7e-05-0.008 against parvoviruses. The complete sequence of the 3,780 bp contig assembled in silico was confirmed by gene amplification of overlapping regions across most of the genome, and the virus was tentatively named NIH-CQV. Further analysis revealed that the contig was composed of two main ORFs. For protein BLAST, ORF1 and ORF2 were most homologous to the bat circovirus replication-associated protein and the porcine parvovirus capsid protein, respectively. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that NIH-CQV is localized at the interface of Parvoviridae and Circoviridae. The prevalence of NIH-CQV in patients was determined by quantitative PCR. Sixty-three of 90 patient samples (70%) were positive, but all of 45 healthy controls were negative. The mean viral titer in patient samples was 1.05 e4 copies/microliter. Using an immunoblot, specific antibodies against NIH-CQV were searched for. 84% of patients were positive for IgG and 31% were positive for IgM; in contrast, 78% of the healthy controls were positive for IgG, but all were negative for IgM. Although more work is needed to determine the etiological role of NIH-CQV in human disease, our data indicate that a parvovirus-like virus is prevalent in a cohort of patients with non-AE hepatitis.
authors: Xu, B.;Zhi, N.;Hu, G.;Wan, Z.;Zheng, X.;Liu, X.;Wong, S.;Kajigaya, S.;Zhao, K.;Mao, Q.;Young, N. S.

title: Comprehensive serological profiling of human populations using a synthetic human virome
authors: Xu, G. J.;Kula, T.;Xu, Q.;Li, M. Z.;Vernon, S. D.

title: Transcriptome analysis of HepG2 cells expressing orf3 from porcine hepatitis e virus to determine the effects of ORF3 on host cells
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV)-mediated hepatitis has become a global public health problem. A key HEV regulatory protein, ORF3, affects multiple signaling pathways in host cells. In this study, to investigate the function of ORF3 from porcine HEV (SHEV), a high-throughput RNA-Seq-based screen was performed to identify the differentially expressed genes in ORF3-expressing HepG2 cells. The results were validated with quantitative real-time PCR and differentially expressed genes were assigned to functional categories using gene ontology. The results showed that in the established ORF3-expressing HepG2 cells, mRNA levels of CLDN6, YLPM1, APOC3, NLRP1, SCARA3, FGA, FGG, FGB and FREM1 were upregulated, while mRNA levels of SLC2A3, DKK1, BPIFB2 , and PTGR1 were downregulated. Deregulated expression of CLDN6 and FREM1 could contribute to changes in integral membrane protein and basement membrane protein expression, expression changes for NLRP1 could affect apoptosis of HepG2 cells, and altered expression of APOC3, SCARA3, and DKK1 could affect lipid metabolism in HepG2 cells. In summary, ORF3 plays a functional role in virus-cell interactions by affecting the expression of integral membrane proteins and basement membrane proteins and altering the process of apoptosis and lipid metabolism in host cells. These findings provide important insights into the pathogenic mechanism of HEV.
authors: Xu, K.;Guo, S.;Zhao, T.;Zhu, H.;Jiao, H.;Shi, Q.;Pang, F.;Li, Y.;Li, G.;Peng, D.;Nie, X.;Cheng, Y.;Wu, K.;Du, L.;Cui, K.;Zhang, W.;Wang, F.

title: Isolation and genetic analysis of a novel triple reassortant H1N1 influenza virus from a pig in China
abstract: Influenza A virus H1N1 subtype has been widely reported in pigs in China associated with clinical diseases. These mainly include classical swine H1N1, avian H1N1 and human-like H1N1 viruses. In this study, we reported a novel triple reassortant H1N1 virus (A/swine/Guangdong/1/2010) encoding classical swine (NP, NS), human (PB1), and avian (HA, NA, M , PB2) contains , PA) lines, which were first reported in China. In addition, phylogenetic analysis further confirmed that five gene segments (NS, NP, PB2, PB1, PA) of the isolate were closely related to the new reassortant H1N2 viruses isolated in China in 2006, while the other three (HA, NA, M) were closely related to avian H1N1 viruses in China. The isolation of the triple reassortant H1N1 influenza virus provides further evidence that pigs serve as emergent hosts or "mixing vessels" and that swine influenza virus (SIV) surveillance should be a high priority in China. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Xu, M.;Huang, Y.;Chen, J.;Huang, Z.;Zhang, J.;Zhu, Y.;Xie, S.;Chen, Q.;Wei, W.;Yang, D.;Huang, X.;Xuan, H.;Xiang, H.

title: Properties of Highly Virulent Infectious Bursal Viruses Isolated from Chinese Broilers (2012-2013)
abstract: The aim of this study was to characterize the infectious bursal disease viruses (IBDVs) circulating in broiler farms in China between 2012 and 2013. The VP2 gene sequences of nine newly isolated IBDVs obtained using the reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction were determined and compared to worldwide reference isolates that were previously well characterized. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the nine broiler IBDV isolates are closely related to very virulent IBDV (vvIBDV) strains. Analysis of the predicted amino acid sequences of VP2 from the nine vvIBDVs isolated from the broilers revealed that they share 99.2 to 100% sequence similarity. In addition, amino acids A222, I242, I256, I294 and S299 of VP2, which are conserved among previously characterized vvIBDV strains, are also encoded by the nine isolates. This study confirms that the circulation of vvIBDVs in Chinese broiler farms underwent slow evolution and was relatively stable in China.
authors: Xu, M. Y.;Lin, S. Y.;Zhao, Y.;Jin, J. H.;Tang, N.;Zhang, G. Z.

title: Epidemiological and evolutionary implication of the transmission network of the 2014 highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N2 outbreak in British Columbia, Canada
abstract: The first North American outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) with a virus of the Eurasian A/Goose/Guangdong/1/1996 (H5N1) lineage began in late November 2014 in the Fraser Valley of British Columbia, Canada. A total of 11 commercial and 1 non-commercial (backyard) farms were infected before the outbreak ended. Control measures included movement restrictions imposed on a total of 404 individual premises, 150 of which were within a 3km radius of infected premises (IP). A full epidemiological investigation revealed that the source of this HPAI H5N2 virus for 4 of the commercial IPs and the single non-commercial IP likely involved indirect contact with wild birds. Three IPs were associated with movement of birds or service providers and the remaining 4 IPs were suspected to have local/environmental spread as a source of infection. Viral phylogenies determined by Bayesian inference and maximum likelihood methods were used to validate the epidemiologically derived transmission network. The phylogenetic clustering of concatenated viral genomes and the median-connecting viral phylogenetic network largely supported the transmission network inferred from the epidemiological analysis.
