authors: Xu, W.;Berhane, Y.;DubÃ©, C.;Liang, B.;Pasick, J.;VanDomselaar, G.;Alexandersen, S.

title: A novel enterovirus 96 circulating in China causes hand, foot, and mouth disease
abstract: Enterovirus 96 (EV-96) is a recently described member of the Enterovirus C species and is associated with paralysis and myelitis. In this study, we identified a novel enterovirus 96 strain (EV-96-SZ/GD/CHN/2014) as the sole pathogen causing hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) using metagenomic sequencing. Genomic comparison showed that EV-96-SZ/GD/CHN/2014 is most similar (85% identity) to strain EV-96-05517, which was also detected in Guangdong Province. This is the first time that metagenomic sequencing has been used to identify an EV-96 strain that has been shown to be associated with HFMD.
authors: Xu, Y.;Sun, Y.;Ma, J.;Zhou, S.;Fang, W.;Ye, J.;Tan, L.;Ji, J.;Luo, D.;Li, L.;Li, J.;Fang, C.;Pei, N.;Shi, S.;Liu, X.;Jiang, H.;Gong, S.;Xu, X.

title: The H9N2 influenza virus isolated from mink has increased virulence in mice
abstract: H9N2 is one of the major subtypes of influenza virus circulating in poultry in China, which has a wide host range from avian to mammalian. Two H9N2 viruses were isolated from a mink farm in 2014. The phylogenetic analysis showed that the internal genes of the H9N2 viruses are closely related to those of the H7N9 viruses. Interestingly, two H9N2 were separated in pedigrees, indicating that they were introduced to this mink farm in two independent events. And further studies in mice showed that one H9N2 caused apparent weight loss and 20% mortality in infected mice, while another virus caused no clinical signs in mice infected with the same dose. Genetic analyzes showed that the virulent H9N2 contains a natural mutation at 701N in the PB2 protein that has been reported to contribute to mammalian adaptation. However, such a substitution is absent in H9N2, which is avirulent to mice. Circulating H9N2 in mink can trigger the virus to adapt to mammals; continuous surveillance of influenza virus in mink was warranted.
authors: Xue, R.;Tian, Y.;Hou, T.;Bao, D.;Chen, H.;Teng, Q.;Yang, J.;Li, X.;Wang, G.;Li, Z.;Liu, Q.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of surface protein genes of emerging H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from poultry in two geographic regions of China
abstract: Avian influenza viruses (AIVs) of the H9N2 subtype circulating in China have raised increasing concerns about their impact on poultry and their risk to public health. The present study was an attempt to elucidate the phylogenetic relationship of H9N2-AIVs in two geographically distinct regions of China where vaccination is routinely practiced. A total of 18 new H9N2 isolates were identified and genetically characterized. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes confirmed that the isolates belonged to the Y280 lineage. Based on the HA genes, the isolates were divided into two subgroups. The viruses from Zhejiang Province were grouped into Group I, while the isolates from Guangdong Province were grouped into Group II. The antigenic characterization showed that the tested viruses differed antigenically compared to the currently used vaccine strain. It was notable that 14 out of a total of 18 isolates had an amino acid substitution (Q?L) at position 216 (226 by H3 numbering) in the receptor binding site, suggesting that the virus had potential affinity for binding to human-like receptors. These results suggest that the emerging viruses pose a potential risk to public health than previously thought. Therefore, continuous surveillance studies of the H9N2 influenza virus are very important for forecasting and controlling future influenza pandemics. © Springer Science+Business Media 2014.
authors: Xue, Y.;Wang, J. L.;Yan, Z. Q.;Li, G. W.;Chen, S. Y.;Zhang, X. B.;Qin, J. P.;Li, H. Y.;Chang, S.;Chen, F.;Bee, Y. Z.;Xie, Q. M.

title: Isolation and characterization of Oya virus, a member of the Simbu serogroup, family Bunyaviridae, isolated from Karnataka, India
abstract: During a study of Japanese Encephalitis (JE) from Kolar District, Karnataka State, India in 1986; two virus isolates were obtained in infant Swiss albino mice from a pig and a human serum sample. To characterize these virus isolates, they were propagated in Vero CCL-81 cells. These virus isolates were tested for flaviviruses (Japanese encephalitis, West Nile, Dengue, Kyasanur forest disease) and alphavirus (Chikungunya) by RT-PCR and found negative. They were also screened for Bunyavirus using genus-specific primers. A virus isolate from a human sample was sequenced using next-generation sequencing; who identified it as Oya virus, Simbu group of the genus Orthobunyavirus of the family Bunyaviridae. The phylogenetic analysis of L, M, S (N and NSs) revealed their close association with the Chinese strain of Oya virus in the Simbu serogroup with a distance of 6.5 > 4.2 > 3.2% for nucleotides and 2.4 > 0.8 > 0.0% for the amino acid of L > M > S segments. Based on the PCR results; an isolate from a pig sample was also confirmed as Oya virus. This study was strengthened by findings of IgG antibody positivity against Oya virus in retrospective serum samples from presumptive febrile cases from this area by a specially developed ELISA. Oya virus positivity was also recorded in human specimens collected in Karnataka using nested RT-PCR. This is the first report of the presence of Oya virus in human specimens. Further studies are needed to determine the disease-causing potential in humans.
authors: Yadav, P.;Shete, A.;Bondre, V.;Patil, D.;Kokate, P.;Chaudhari, S.;Srivastava, S.;Jadhav, S.;Mourya, D.

title: Molecular analysis of the genome of Chuzan virus, a member of the Palyam serogroup viruses, and its phylogenetic relationship to other orbiviruses
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the entire genome of Chuzan virus, which belongs to the Palyam serogroup orbiviruses and causes congenital abnormalities in bovines, was completed by analysis of genes coding for minor nuclear proteins (VP1, VP4 and VP6) and nonstructural proteins (NS1, NS2 and NS3). The genome of Chuzan virus is 18,915 bp and the coding capacity of its open reading frames is 6071 aa. Comparative sequence analysis with other serogroups of the genus Orbivirus showed that the outer capsid protein VP2, the neutralizing antigen, appears to be the most variable and the major core protein VP3 the most conserved. Overall, the structural proteins, with the exception of VP2, are more conserved in orbiviruses than the nonstructural proteins. Chuzan virus is phylogenetically most closely related to African equine disease virus.
authors: Yamakawa, M.;Kubo, M.;Furuuchi, S.

title: Genomic analyzes of bovine viral diarrhea viruses isolated from cattle imported to Japan between 1991 and 1995
abstract: Thirty-one isolates of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolated from imported cattle by the Japan Animal Quarantine Service (AQS) over the past 15 years were used in this study, in which a 5-inch untranslated region of each isolate was genetically analyzed . 26 of the 31 isolates were classified as BVDV1 and the remainder as BVDV2. Phylogenetic analysis of the RT-PCR fragments amplified from the isolates revealed the presence of viruses belonging to BVDV1a, BVDV1b, BVDV1c, unclassified BVDV1 genotypes and BVDV2. From cattle of Australian origin, 16 out of 17 isolates were classified as BVDV1c. This result was consistent with a report showing that BVDV1c was a predominant subgenotype in Australia. Both BVDV1 and BVDV2 species have been found in cattle of North American origin. BVDV2 from North American cattle was identified as the same cluster as strain BVDV 890, which is the prototype of BVDV2. These results suggest that the BVDVs isolated from exported cattle at AQS reflect the predominant genotypes of BVDVs found in the exporting countries. The unclassified BVDV1 genotype of Chinese origin was in the same cluster as the ZM-95 strain isolated from pigs in China. In this study, the genomic properties of 31 BVDV isolates collected in the AQS were examined. We concluded that isolates are genetically heterogeneous but geographically restricted. The information gained from this report will be useful in conducting epidemiological investigations of BVDV isolated in Japan. © 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yamamoto, T.;Kozasa, T.;Aoki, H.;Sekiguchi, H.;Morino, S.;Nakamura, S.

title: Three male patients with sporadic acute hepatitis E in Sendai, Japan, who were locally infected with hepatitis E virus genotype III or IV
abstract: Recent studies indicate that hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections occur not only in developing countries but also in industrialized nations. However, the characteristics of domestic hepatitis E infections in Japan are not yet fully understood. We analyzed serum samples from 34 patients examined between January 1997 and December 2002 at a municipal hospital in Sendai, Japan, who were diagnosed with sporadic acute hepatitis of non-A, non-B, non-C etiology . Of these 34 patients, 3 (9%; all males; aged 54, 59 and 61 years) were positive for both IgG and IgM anti-HEV antibodies and for HEV RNA. The HEV isolates obtained from case 1 and case 3 (HE-JAS1 and HE-JAS3) segregated in genotype III; they had the highest nucleotide sequence identity of 99.5% and 99.0% with HE-JA7 and HE-JA8, respectively, both of which were isolated in Iwate, a neighboring prefecture of Sendai. In contrast, the remaining HEV isolate (HE-JAS2) obtained from case 2 segregated in genotype IV; it had the highest nucleotide sequence identity of 99.8% and 99.3% with JKK-Sap and HE-JA3, respectively, both of which had been isolated in Hokkaido, Japan, although Case 2 had never been to Hokkaido. Our three patients with hepatitis E had not traveled abroad in the previous year, had no contact with pigs and had no history of blood transfusions. These results indicate that HEV should be considered as an etiological agent of acute hepatitis with non-A, non-B, non-C etiology in Japan. The risk factor(s) for acquiring domestic HEV infection in Japan needs to be clarified in future studies. © Springer Verlag 2004.
authors: Yamamoto, T.;Suzuki, H.;Toyota, T.;Takahashi, M.;Okamoto, H.

title: Characterization of infectious bursal disease virus variant from a broiler farm in Japan using immunized sentinel chickens
abstract: We attempted the isolation of infectious bursal disease (IBD) virus variants using sentinel chickens immunized with inactivated classic-type IBD vaccine. Immunized sentinel chicks with high levels of neutralizing antibodies and non-immunized sentinel chicks were reared alongside broilers in a commercial farm. From the second week after cohabitation, severe atrophy of Fabricius' bursa was observed in non-immunized sentinel chickens. However, atrophy was observed in immunized sentinel chickens and broilers from the third week after cohabitation. The IBD virus (IBDV) isolated from the Fabricius bursa of immunized sentinel chickens, designated strain IBDV TY2, showed severe bursal atrophy in infected SPF chickens. Antiserum against IBDV TY2 strain showed higher neutralizing activity against heterologous IBDV strains than antiserum against K strain vaccine virus. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the nucleotide sequences encoding the hypervariable region of viral protein 2 of the IBDV TY2 strain did not aggregate with the classic, variant, or very virulent IBDV groups. Based on these results, we propose that the IBDV TY2 strain may represent a new variant type of IBDV.
authors: Yamazaki, K.;Ohta, H.;Kawai, T.;Yamaguchi, T.;Obi, T.;Takase, K.

title: Hepatitis E virus in yellow cattle, Shandong, east China
authors: Yan, B.;Zhang, L.;Gong, L.;Lv, J.;Feng, Y.;Liu, J.;Song, L.;Xu, Q.;Jiang, M.;Xu, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 gene of infectious bronchitis virus isolates from China
abstract: Between 2006 and 2009, seven strains of infectious bronchitis (IB) virus (IBV) were isolated from vaccinated chicken flocks at different chicken farms in China. The pathogenic properties of seven IBV strains were evaluated. Each of the seven strains was infectious to the test chickens and could elicit an immune response. The results of the cross-neutralization tests with chick embryos showed that these strains differed antigenically from the classic IBV strains of H120, M41, Conn and Gray. Compared to the H120 vaccine strain, point mutations, short insertions and deletion occurred at many positions in the S1 protein of the seven strains. Five of the seven strains had the motif (HRRRR) identical to that of the epidemic IBV strains in China. Two new motifs (HRLRR and RRIRR) emerged in the isolated strains. The homology of the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the S1 gene between the seven isolates was 81.7%-99.7% and 79.0%-99.4%, respectively. These seven strains were also genetically distinct from the vaccine and non-Chinese IBV strains, but were closely related to a large number of Chinese strains. The seven isolates and 36 IBV reference strains were divided into six different groups (IVI). The seven strains were grouped into Groups I, II and III, forming a large phylogenetic branch closely related to Chinese IBV, while the vaccine strains belonging to Group VI are genetically distant from Groups I, II and III. The results of this study show that different strains of IBV co-circulate in the chicken population in China. © American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Yan, F.;Zhao, Y.;Yue, W.;Yao, J.;Lv, L.;Ji, W.;Li, X.;Liu, F.;Wu, Q.

title: Failed detection of Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus 2 subgenotype a (BVDV-2a) by direct fluorescent antibody test on tissue specimens due to reduced reactivity of field isolates to crude anti-BVDV antibody
abstract: Bovine virus diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1) is associated with mild or subclinical infections, while BVDV-2 is commonly associated with outbreaks of severe thrombocytopenia and acute fatal illness. In the present study, the carcass of a beef breed cow and tissue samples from a beef calf were obtained for laboratory diagnostics. Both animals presented severe clinical signs consistent with thrombocytopenia or hemorrhagic syndrome. In both cases, the direct fluorescent antibody test (DFAT) could not detect any BVDV antigen in the tissue samples. However, immunohistochemistry (IHC) showed the presence of BVDV antigen in the oral and esophageal mucosa and Peyer's patches of the pedigree cattle. Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (real-time RT-PCR) detected BVDV-2 in selected tissues of both animals. Subsequently, BVDV was isolated from both cases and subjected to genetic and serological characterizations. Mutations in the primer and probe binding sites of the 5'-untranslated genomic region (5'-UTR) and in the E2 gene were associated with reduced efficiency of an established real-time RT-PCR assay and amino acid changes in the E2 glycoprotein, respectively. Both virus isolates were classified as BVDV-2 subgenotype a using real-time RT-PCR and phylogenetic analysis. In contrast to the BVDV reference strains Singer and 125c, the isolates cross-reacted with anti-BVDV-1 and anti-BVDV-2 reference sera, indicating antigenic variation in field isolates. The isolates also showed reduced reactivity to swine anti-BVDV antiserum (the crude serum used to make BVDV-DFA conjugate). In summary, the data from the present study suggest that genetic and antigenic variations impair the performance of detection assays, particularly DFAT, underscoring the need for regular evaluation and modification of BVDV tests.
authors: Yan, L.;Pace, L. W.;Baughman, B.;Wilson, F. D.;Zhang, S.;Zhang, M. Z.

title: Genome-wide identification of copy number variations between two chicken lines differing in genetic resistance to Marek's disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Copy number variation (CNV) is a major source of genomic polymorphism that directly contributes to phenotypic variations such as infectious disease resistance. Lines 63 and 72 are two highly inbred experimental chicken lines that differ greatly in susceptibility to Marek's disease (MD) and have been used extensively to identify the genetic and molecular basis for genetic resistance to MD. Using next-generation sequencing, we present a genome-wide assessment of CNVs potentially associated with genetic resistance to MD. METHODS: Three chickens selected at random from each line were sequenced to an average depth of 20x. Two popular software, CNVnator and Pindel, were used to name genomic CNVs separately. The results were combined to obtain a pooled set of genomic CNVs in the two chicken lines. RESULTS: After merging the two datasets, a total of 5,680 CNV regions (CNVRs) were identified, of which 1,546 and 1,866 were specific to the MD-resistant and -susceptible lineage, respectively. More than half of the line-specific CNVRs were shared by 2 or more chickens, reflecting reduced diversity in both inbred lines. The CNVRs fixed in the susceptible lines were significantly enriched in genes involved in MAPK signaling. We also found 67 CNVRs that overlap with 62 genes previously shown to be strong candidates for the underlying genes responsible for susceptibility to MD. CONCLUSIONS: Our results provide new insights into the genetic architecture of the two chicken lines and additional evidence that MAPK signaling may play an important role in the host response to MD virus infection. The rich source of lineage-specific CNVs is valuable for future disease-related association studies in the two chicken lines.
authors: Yan, Y.;Yang, N.;Cheng, H. H.;Song, J.;Qu, L.

title: Isolation and Characterization of a Novel Tembusu Virus Circulating in Musk Ducks in Southern China
abstract: Duck tembusu virus (DTMUV) is an infectious agent that can cause epidemics in egg-laying ducks. Here we have isolated and characterized a DTMUV, designated GDLH01, which is believed to be responsible for noticeable egg loss in Muscovy duck flocks in southern China since 2011. and 99.5% homology with the mosquito-borne strain SDMS recently reported in China. Phylogenetic analysis based on the nucleotide sequence of the entire open reading frame confirmed that the isolate was of avian origin and closely related to a mosquito-transmitted strain. Our results characterize a novel Tembusu virus circulating in Muscovy ducks in southern China and emphasize the importance of strengthening biosecurity measures and developing vaccines to prevent the spread of this viral pathogen.
authors: Yan, Z.;Shen, H.;Wang, Z.;Lin, W.;Xie, Q.;Bi, Y.;Chen, F.

title: Sequence analysis of the middle RNA segment of three viruses of the Simbu serogroup, Akabane, Aino and Peaton viruses
abstract: Sequence analysis was performed for the middle (M) RNA segment of Akabane virus (AKAV), Aino virus (AINV) and Peaton virus (PEAV) of the Simbu serogroup of the genus Orthobunyavirus of the family Bunyaviridae. The complementary sequences of the M-RNA segments of AKAV, AINV and PEAV, like other orthobunyaviruses, contain a single large open reading frame (ORF). The ORFs potentially encode 1401 amino acids (aa), 1404 aa and 1400 aa polypeptides, respectively. The identity of the M segment in these viruses is remarkably low, although previous investigators reported that the small RNA segments are highly conserved. Since the M segment encodes the viral surface glycoproteins G1 and G2, the variability of the M segment can affect the antigenicity of these viruses. Phylogenetic studies based on the sequences of the M and S segments suggested that genetic rearrangement among the ancestral viruses of the three Simbu serogroup viruses occurred throughout their evolution. (C) 2003 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yanase, T.;Yoshida, K.;Ohashi, S.;Kato, T.;Tsuda, T.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of porcine pegivirus in swine in the United States
abstract: Porcine pegivirus (PPgV) was first identified and genetically characterized in the United States using next-generation sequencing of vesicle swabs and serum from US pigs with lameness and vesicles. Further screening using RT-PCR revealed that 24 of 159 (15.1%) serum samples were positive for PPgV. Future studies are needed to understand the clinical implications of the virus.
authors: Yang, C.;Wang, L.;Shen, H.;Zheng, Y.;Bade, S. A.;Gauger, P. C.;Chen, Q.;Zhang, J.;Guo, B.;Yoon, K. J.;Harmon, K. M.;Main, R. G.;Li, G.

title: Newcastle disease virus isolated from recent outbreaks in Taiwan, phylogenetically related to viruses (genotype VII) from recent outbreaks in Western Europe
abstract: In the past three decades (1969, 1984, and 1995), there have been three major outbreaks of Newcastle disease (ND) in Taiwan. The Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) isolated in the three outbreaks were sequenced along with the viruses isolated in 1998 between nucleotides 47 and 435 of the fusion gene. A phylogenetic tree based on conserved sequences showed that the NDV isolated in 1969 was similar to genotype III viruses. In contrast, all isolates in 1984 and seven of the eight isolates in 1995 fell into genotype VII, along with all isolates in 1998. These results suggest that the 1969 ND outbreak in Taiwan was caused by genotype III virus was caused, while the 1984 and 1995 outbreaks were caused by genotype VII viruses. To date, genotype VII viruses have caused many outbreaks in East Asia and Western Europe. We hypothesize that these outbreaks represented the fourth panzoosis of ND, distinct from the third panzoosis caused by the 'pigeon PMV-1 viruses'. NDV, isolated in Taiwan in 1984, was the earliest genotype VII virus isolation.
authors: Yang, C. Y.;Shieh, H. K.;Lin, Y. L.;Chang, P. C.

title: Genetic analysis of H3N2 avian influenza viruses isolated from live poultry markets and poultry slaughterhouses in Shanghai, China in 2013
abstract: Five H3N2 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) were isolated from live poultry markets (LPMs) and poultry slaughterhouses in Shanghai, China in 2013. All viruses were characterized by whole genome sequencing followed by genetic comparison and phylogenetic analysis. The hemagglutinin cleavage site of all viruses indicated that the five strains were low pathogenic AIVs. Phylogenetic analysis of all eight viral genes showed that the five H3N2 viruses are in the Eurasian lineage of influenza viruses. The eight genes showed evidence of reassortment events between these H3 subtype viruses and other subtype viruses, particularly H5 and H7 subtypes, likely in pigeons, domestic ducks and wild birds. These results underscored the importance of AIV monitoring in LPMs and poultry slaughterhouses in understanding the emergence and emergence of novel reassortants with pandemic potential.
authors: Yang, D.;Liu, J.;Ju, H.;Ge, F.;Wang, J.;Li, X.;Zhou, J.;Liu, P.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of genomic segment 2 of bluetongue virus strains belonging to serotypes 5, 7 and 24 were first isolated in China between 2012 and 2014
abstract: Bluetongue disease is endemic in China, and bluetongue virus (BTV) belongs to eight different serotypes (BTV-1, BTV-2, BTV-3, BTV-4, BTV-9, BTV-12, BTV-15, and BTV-16 ). ) had been isolated between 1996 and 1997. Since then, however, there has been a long pause in studying the epidemiology of BTV infection. Between 2012 and 2014, eight BTV strains of serotypes 5, 7 and 24 were isolated from the blood of guard animals in Yunnan and Guangdong provinces for the first time. Phylogenetic analyzes of genome segment 2 of these Chinese BTV strains grouped them into nucleotypes E, F, and A, respectively, along with reference strains of the same serotype. For each serotype, Chinese strains group closely together to form a Chinese subline. Additionally, these tribes were most closely related to tribes from Africa, suggesting that they may have shared recent ancestry with African tribes. To our knowledge, this is the first time that BTV-5, BTV-7, and BTV-24 strains have been isolated in Southeast Asia. These data will be useful for understanding BTV epidemiology and improving diagnostic assays and control measures against bluetongue in China and its neighboring Asia-Pacific countries.
authors: Yang, H.;Xiao, L.;Wang, J.;Meng, J.;Lv, M.;Liao, D.;Song, J.;Gao, L.;Xiong, H.;He, Y.;Niu, B.;Chuang, X.;Li, H.

title: Isolation and genomic characterization of a novel chicken-derived orthoreovirus causing hepatitis in goslings
abstract: serious infectious disease characterized by nephritis, hepatitis and splenitis has been affecting goslings in Shandong province of China since 2016. A novel chicken avian orthoreovirus (ARV) was isolated using LMH cells from affected goslings named Reo/Goose/SDPY/1116/17 (SDPY-ARV) strain and the infection was successfully reproduced experimentally. Full ARV-SDPY genome sequencing was performed using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technology on the Illumina HiSeq platform. The complete genome of SDPY-ARV was 23,427 bp long and consisted of 10 dsRNA segments ranging from 1192 bp (S4) to 3958 bp (L1) encoding 12 viral proteins. Genomic sequence analysis showed that the SDPY-ARV strain is in the same branch as pheasant broiler ARV isolates and shares 51.8-96.2% of the nucleotide identity of the sigmaC gene with them; while only 49.3-50.3% isolated with waterfowl. In addition, the occurrence of a genetic rearrangement of 10 segments of the SDPY strain among the PA15511, the 1733 and the PA13649 strains from America is confirmed. In summary, the causative agent of gosling hemorrhagic necrotic hepatitis and nephritis occurring in China is a novel chicken goose orthoreovirus.
authors: Yang, J.;Tian, J.;Chen, L.;Tang, Y.;Diao, Y.

title: Isolation and genomic characterization of goose gout caused by a novel goose astrovirus
abstract: A severe infectious disease characterized by gout, hemorrhage and kidney swelling affects goslings in main goose producing regions in China (Coreper-SDPY) strain has been isolated from diseased goslings since November 2016, and experimental propagation of gout was using Coreper -SDPY root successful. In addition, AStV-SDPY was performed for its full genomic sequencing characterization using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technique on the Illumina HiSeq platform. A complete AStV-SDPY genome was 7,252 nt long and encoded three viral proteins. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that the AStV-SDPY strain belongs to an independent branch of avian astroviruses and the nucleotide homology between AStV-SDPY and other classical avian astrovirus strains was only 48.8%-68.2%.
authors: Yang, J.;Tian, J.;Tang, Y.;Diao, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of the avian influenza virus (H7N8) isolated from poultry in central China in the mid-1980s
abstract: The molecular and pathogenic properties of the avian influenza virus (A/duck/Hubei/216/1985/H7N8) isolated in 1985 from Hubei province of China have been characterized. The hemagglutinin (HA) gene of Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 had multiple amino acid sequences (-PEIPKGRG-) at the junction peptide between HA1 and HA2, which is considered to be a molecular characteristic of low pathogenicity. The key host marker sites among the genes (M, NP, NS, PA and PB2) of Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 were similar to those of H5N1 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the genes (M, NS and PB2) of Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 were closely clustered with those of Gs/Guangdong/1996/H5N1 (Gs/GD/96), implying that three ancient genes of Gs/GD/96-like viruses were circulating in central China in the 1980s. When challenged experimentally, Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 was weakly pathogenic to chickens and mice, consistent with the molecular characteristics of the HA gene.
authors: Yang, J. L.;Xia, H.;Zhao, J. R.;He, X. B.;Pan, L. M.;Tang, S. A.;Zhang, Z.;Kou, Z.;Li, T. X.

title: Genomes and seroprevalence of severe fever associated with thrombocytopenic syndrome virus and Nairobi sheep disease virus in Haemaphysalis longicornis ticks and goats in Hubei, China
abstract: Ticks are medically important arthropods that receive and transmit numerous emerging viruses. China suffers severely from tick-borne viral diseases such as tick-borne encephalitis and severe fever with thrombocytopenic syndrome (SFTS), but the background of tick-borne viruses is very limited. Here we report viromeprofiling of tick and goat sera from SFTS epidemic areas and serological investigation of SFTS virus (SFTSV) and Nairobi sheep disease virus (NSDV). Results showed different viruses in tick and goat sera including SFTSV and NSDV. Sequence and phylogenetic analyzes indicated that the SFTSV identified here was most closely related to the human SFTSV in sampling and surrounding areas, and the NSDV to the previously identified NSDV from Northeast China. Serological testing of SFTSV infection in goats revealed intense activity in these areas. Surprisingly, two different methods of serological NSDV investigation showed no positive sera for this virus.
authors: Yang, L. E.;Zhao, Z.;Hou, G.;Zhang, C.;Liu, J.;Xu, L.;Li, W.;Tan, Z.;Tu, C.;He, B.

title: Westward spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H7N9) virus among humans, China
abstract: We report on human infection with the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H7N9) in May 2017 in Shaanxi, China. We obtained complete genomes for samples from 5 patients and from live poultry markets or farms in 4 cities.
authors: Yang, Q.;Shi, W.;Zhang, L.;Xu, Y.;Xu, J.;Li, S.;Zhang, J.;Hu, K.;Ma, C.;Zhao, X.;Li, X.;Liu, F.;Tong, X.;Zhang, G.;Yu, P.;Pybus, O. G.;Tian, H.

title: A novel rodent chaparvovirus in feces of wild rats
abstract: Chapparvovirus, a recently discovered new genus in the Parvoviridae family, can infect many species of animals, including bats, chickens and pigs. Here, we identified a novel chapparvovirus from feces of wild rats using the viral metagenomics method and named it rat parvovirus 2 (RPV2). The nearly complete genome of RPV2 is 4222 nt in length and comprises two ORFs encoding a 654 amino acid nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) and a 472 amino acid capsid protein (VP), respectively. Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid sequence of NS1 showed that RPV2 was clustered with Eidolon helvum parvovirus 2 (EHPV2), porcine parvovirus 7 (PPV7), and turkey parvovirus 1 (TP1), forming a separate clade. Sequence analysis showed that the RPV2 NS1 protein shared the highest amino acid sequence identity (51%) with that of EHPV2. According to criteria based on genetic distance, the RPV2 identified here belongs to a new species of Chapparvovirus.
authors: Yang, S.;Liu, Z.;Wang, Y.;Li, W.;Fu, X.;Lin, Y.;Shen, Q.;Wang, X.;Wang, H.;Zhang, W.

title: A novel bocavirus from native mink, China
abstract: Bocaviruses have been found in the feces of humans and a variety of animals including pigs, cattle, dogs, gorillas, cats and sea lions. Here we have characterized the almost complete genome (5224 nt) of a novel bocavirus from domestic mink feces, tentatively named mink bocavirus. The mink bocavirus NS1 protein shared 36.9-52% amino acid sequence identities with those of other known bocaviruses and was phylogenetically clustered with bocaviruses of other carnivores. According to criteria based on genetic distance, mink bocavirus qualifies as a new species of bocavirus. PCR of faeces from a group of domestic mink, which included both healthy and diarrhea afflicted animals, revealed that 30% (9/30) shed virus. However, no connection could be established between virus shedding and the presence of diarrhea.
authors: Yang, S.;Wang, Y.;Li, W.;Fan, Z.;Jiang, L.;Lin, Y.;Fu, X.;Shen, Q.;Sun, Z.;Wang, X.;Deng, X.;Zhang, W.;Delwart, E.

title: High-throughput nucleotide sequence analysis of different bacterial communities in leachate from decomposing pig carcasses
abstract: The leachate produced by the decomposition of animal carcasses has been considered an environmental pollutant in the vicinity of the burial site. High-throughput nucleotide sequencing was performed to study bacterial communities in leachate from pig carcass decomposition. We acquired 51,230 reads from six different specimens (1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 14 week old carcasses) and found that sequences representing phylum Firmicutes predominated. Diversity of bacterial 16S rRNA gene sequences in leachate was highest at 6 weeks, in contrast to those at 2 and 14 weeks. The relative abundance of Firmicutes was reduced while the proportion of Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria increased from 3-6 weeks. Strains were restored after 14 weeks. However, the community structures between the 1-2 and 14 week samples differed at the bacterial classification level. The pH trend was similar to changes observed in bacterial communities, suggesting that leachate pH may be related to the shift in the microbial community. The results indicate that the composition of bacterial communities in the leachate from decomposing pig carcasses changes continuously during the study period and is possibly influenced by the burial site.
authors: Yang, S. H.;Lim, J. S.;Khan, M. A.;Kim, B. S.;Choi, D. Y.;Lee, E. Y.;Ahn, H. K.

title: Next-generation sequencing enables the discovery of more diverse positive clones from a phage-displayed antibody library
abstract: Phage display technology provides a powerful tool to search a library for a binding molecule via an enrichment process. It has been adopted as a crucial technology in the development of therapeutic antibodies. However, a major disadvantage of phage display technology is that it often results in a limited number of clones as the level of enrichment cannot be controlled during the bio-panning process. In this study, we applied next-generation sequencing (NGS) to screen clones from a library and determine whether NGS can identify a larger number of clones than traditional methods. Three chicken variable single chain fragment (scFv) libraries were bio-panned for prostate-specific antigen (PSA). Phagemid DNA prepared from the original libraries as well as from the Escherichia coli pool after each round of bio-panning was analyzed using NGS and the heavy chain complementarity determining region 3 (HCDR3) sequences of the scFv clones were set. The entire scFv gene was then obtained by two-stage linker PCR and cloning and analyzed for its reactivity towards PSA in a phage enzyme immunoassay. After four rounds of bio-panning, the conventional colony screening procedure was performed for comparison. The scFv clones recovered from the NGS analysis included all clones identified by the conventional colony screening method plus many additional clones. Enrichment of the HCDR3 sequence throughout the biopanning process was a positive predictor for the selection of PSA-reactive scFv clones.
authors: Yang, W.;Yoon, A.;Lee, S.;Kim, S.;Han, J.;Chung, J.

title: Genetic characterization of a densovirus isolated from the great tit (Parus major) in China
abstract: During a study on ornithophilic viruses in China, a new densovirus (DNV) was isolated from Parus major lung tissue (PmDNV-JL). The complete genome of PmDNV-JL has been cloned and sequenced. Five open reading frames (ORFs) were identified in the 5166nt sequence based on deduced amino acids. This virus has also been shown to cause cytopathic effects (CPE) in feline kidney cells. The NS1 gene sequence of PmDNV-JL shares 70-99% nucleotide sequence identity with isolates of Blattella germanica densovirus (BgDNV) and BgDNV-like virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the predicted amino acid sequences of the capsid (VP) and nonstructural domain (NS1) of PmDNV-JL were clustered with the BgDNV and similar to BgDNV-HB within the Densovirus genus.
authors: Yang, W. T.;Shi, S. H.;Jiang, Y. L.;Zhao, L.;Chen, H. L.;Huang, K. Y.;Yang, G. L.;Wang, C. F.

title: Genome characterization of a novel porcine bocavirus
abstract: Using a high-throughput DNA sequencing method, a DNA sequence (contig01006) putatively belonging to a novel porcine bocavirus (PBoV) was found with a high detection rate (19.6%) in fecal samples from healthy piglets. In addition, a new PBoV (tentatively named PBoV3C) with an almost complete genome sequence (5235 bp) was identified. PBoV3C shows typical genome properties of bocaviruses and shows the highest genomic sequence identity (78% to 81%) to PBoV3A/B (PBoV3/4-UK) or PBoV3D/E (PBoV3/4-HK). Phylogenetic and recombination analyzes revealed high diversity, prevalence, and complexity among PBoVs. The phospholipase A2 (PLA2) site of VP1 and the secondary structure of VP2 of PBoV3C were also analyzed. Additionally, we propose a unified method of PBoV nomenclature based on the VP1 gene. © 2012 Springer Verlag.
authors: Yang, W. Z.;Yu, J. M.;Li, J. S.;Cheng, W. X.;Huang, C. P.;Duan, Z. J.

title: MicroRNA transcriptome analysis in chick kidneys in response to various virulent infectious bronchitis virus infections
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) can cause a highly contagious and acute respiratory disease in poultry. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) have emerged as a class of critical regulators of gene expression and are involved in the regulation of viral defense and immunological processes. To understand miRNA regulation in chickens in response to IBV infection, high-throughput sequencing was performed to compare the small RNA libraries from the kidneys of SCK2, SCDY2, and LDT3-A infected chickens. By comparing this data to healthy chickens, a total of 58 differentially expressed (DE) miRNAs were identified. The DE miRNAs were further classified into five miRNA expression patterns (up or down regulation compared to control). Using Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment prediction, it was shown that the DE miRNAs are mainly associated with metabolic processes, catalytic activities, gene expression, binding activities, and immune responses. Seven highly expressed miRNAs (gga-miR-30d, gga-miR-1454, gga-miR-7b, gga-miR-215-5p, gga-miR-1a-3p, gga-miR-3538 and gga-miR-2954 ) were selected for joint miRNA-mRNA analysis. Furthermore, the miRNAs inversely correlated with the corresponding target gene mRNAs. These seven miRNAs have been hypothesized to play important roles in IBV-host interactions and differential virulence of IBV strains. This is the first demonstration that infection with different virulent IBVs induces differential expression of miRNAs in chick kidneys; this expression also appears to be related to the virulence of IBV. These results are important for studying miRNA-mediated immune responses to infection with various virulent IBVs, as well as the interaction between the chicken host and IBV.
authors: Yang, X.;Gao, W.;Liu, H.;Li, J.;Chen, D.;Yuan, F.;Zhang, Z.;Wang, H.

title: Novel features of the avian gyrovirus-2 genome
abstract: Avian gyrovirus 2 (AGV2) was the second discovered member of the viral genus Cyclovirus. This virus poses a significant potential threat to humans and poultry due to its global distribution and infectivity. We used three overlapping polymerase chain reactions (PCRs) to map the entire AGV2 genome. We then modeled the evolutionary history of this novel sequence data in the context of related sequences from GenBank. We analyzed the viral protein properties of the different phylogenetic groups and examined differences in evolutionary trends between Chinese strains and strains from other countries. We obtained 17 avian-derived AGV2 whole genomes from different regions of China from 2015 to 2016. Phylogenetic analyzes of these Chinese AGV2 sequences and related sequences revealed four distinct groups (AD) with significant bootstrap values. We have also constructed phylogenies using predicted viral protein sequences. We found a potential hypervariable region in VP1 at positions 288-314 and we identified the amino acid changes responsible for the different VP2 and VP3 groups. Three new motifs in the AGV2 5'-UTR Direct Repeat (DR) region were discovered and grouped. The novel properties and diverse research into the AGV2 genome provide a valuable framework for further research.
authors: Yao, S.;Gao, X.;Tuo, T.;Han, C.;Gao, Y.;Qi, X.;Zhang, Y.;Liu, C.;Gao, H.;Wang, Y.;Wang, X.

title: Isolation of a new serotype strain of the infectious bronchitis virus ZZ2004 from ducks in China
abstract: In chickens, infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) often causes respiratory distress, a decrease in egg production, poor egg quality, and occasionally nephritis. However, ZZ2004, a Chinese IBV isolate, was obtained from ducks with clinical growth suppression and mild respiratory symptoms raised with hens in central China. Virus isolation, virus neutralization assays, and RT-PCR were used to identify the causative pathogen, while sequence alignment was used to analyze gene variation of the S1 subunit and the M genes. The results showed that the ducks were infected with IBV due to the appearance of a dwarf phenotype and death of the embryos between 48 and 144 h after vaccination. RT-PCR also confirmed the presence of the expected fragment sizes of the S1 subunit and M genes by RT-PCR. Meanwhile, the results of the virus neutralization test showed that the strains of JX/99/01, GD, SAIBK, LDT3 showed cross-reactivity with the ZZ2004 isolate, and hardly any cross-neutralization of IBV ZZ2004 was observed with the strains of M41, H120, Grau, Holte or Aust-T. The phylogenetic analysis suggested that there were major differences between ZZ2004 and other IBV reference strains in the S1 subunit. Meanwhile, the homologies in the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of M gene of IBV ZZ2004 were 86.9-92.0% and 91.1-93.9%, respectively, compared to 35 other IBV reference strains originating from different regions. This result showed that there were striking variations between the selected strains. In addition, the results showed that the predominant IBV strains in ducks had no antigen homology with the vaccine strains widely used in China other than the LDT3 strain, urging the research and development of new IBV vaccines.
authors: Yao, S.;Ou, C.;Liu, X.;Wang, X.;Yao, Z.;Liu, J.

title: Isolation and characterization of a native avirulent strain of Streptococcus suis serotype 2: a perspective for vaccine development
abstract: Streptococcus suis, an emerging infectious agent, is the cause of two large-scale outbreaks of human streptococcal toxic shock syndrome in China and has attracted much attention from the scientific community. The genetic basis of its pathogenesis remains enigmatic and no effective preventive measures have been established. To better understand the virulence differentiation of S. suis and to develop a promising vaccine, we isolated and sequenced a native avirulent S. suis strain (05HAS68). Animal experiments revealed that 05HAS68 is an avirulent strain and could protect piglets from attack by virulent strains. Comparative genomic analyzes revealed the genetic basis for the lack of virulence in 05HAS68, which is characterized by the absence of some important virulence-associated factors and the intact 89K pathogenicity island. Lack of virulence was also illustrated by reduced survival of 05HAS68 compared to a virulent strain in porcine whole blood. Further investigation revealed a large-scale genomic rearrangement in 05HAS68 that was hypothesized to be mediated by transposase genes and/or prophages. This genomic rearrangement may have caused the genomic diversity of S. suis and led to biological discrepancies between 05HAS68 and highly virulent S. suis strains.
authors: Yao, X.;Li, M.;Wang, J.;Wang, C.;Hu, D.;Zheng, F.;Pan, X.;Tan, Y.;Zhao, Y.;Hu, L.;Tang, J.;Hu, F.

title: Novel microRNAs encoded by duck enteritis virus
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is an important herpesvirus pathogen associated with an acute, highly contagious fatal disease in aquatic birds. Using a deep sequencing approach to RNA from infected chick embryo fibroblast cultures, we identified several novel DEV-encoded micro(mi)RNAs. Unlike most Mardivirus-encoded miRNAs, DEV-encoded miRNAs map primarily to the unique long region of the genome. The progenitors of DEV miR-D18 and miR-D19 overlapped, suggesting similarities to miRNA offset RNAs, although only DEV-miR-D18-3p was functional in reporter assays. The identification of these novel miRNAs will add to the growing list of virus-encoded miRNAs that will allow exploration of their role in pathogenesis.
authors: Yao, Y.;Smith, L. P.;Petherbridge, L.;Watson, M.;Nair, V.

title: Relationship of SARS-CoV to other pathogenic RNA viruses examined by tetranucleotide usage profiling
abstract: BACKGROUND: The exact origin of the cause of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is still an open question. The genomic sequence relationship of SARS-CoV with 30 different single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) viruses from different families was examined using two non-standard approaches. Both approaches started with vectorial profiling of the tetranucleotide usage pattern V for each virus. In the first approach, a distance measure of a vector V based on a correlation coefficient was developed to construct a relationship tree by the neighbor joining algorithm. In approach two, multivariate factor analysis was performed to infer embedded tetranucleotide usage patterns. These patterns were then used to classify the selected viruses. RESULTS: Both approaches yielded relationship results consistent with known virus classification. They also showed that the genomes of RNA viruses of the same family conform to a specific pattern of word usage. Based on the correlation of overall tetranucleotide usage patterns, transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGV) and feline corona virus (FCoV) are closest to SARS-CoV. Surprisingly, the RNA viruses that do not progress through a DNA stage showed remarkable discrimination against the CpG and UpA dinucleotide (z = -77.31 and -52.48, respectively) and selection for UpG and CpA (z = 65, 79 and 49.99 respectively). . Possible factors influencing these biases are discussed. CONCLUSION: Studying genomic word usage is a powerful tool for classifying RNA viruses. The agreement of the relationship results with the known classification indicates that there are phylogenetic signals in the tetranucleotide usage patterns that are most evident in the open reading frames of the replicates.
authors: Yap, Y. L.;Zhang, X. W.;Danchin, A.

title: Frequency of D222G and Q223R hemagglutinin mutants of the 2009 pandemic (H1N1) influenza virus in Japan between 2009 and 2010
abstract: Background: In April 2009, a novel swine-derived influenza A virus (H1N1pdm) emerged and spread rapidly around the world, including Japan. It has been suggested that the virus can bind to both 2,3- and 2,6-linked sialic acid receptors in infected mammals, in contrast to contemporary seasonal H1N1 viruses which have a preference for 2,6-linked sialic acid. Methods/Results: To elucidate the existence and transmissibility of α2,3-sialic acid-specific viruses in H1N1pdm, amino acid substitutions within viral hemagglutinin molecules, specifically D187E, D222G, and Q223R, that are associated with a shift from human to avian receptor specificity were investigated. Samples from people infected during the first and second waves of the outbreak in Japan were examined using a high-throughput sequencing approach. In May 2009, three samples from mild cases showed D222G and/or Q223R substitutions in a small subpopulation of viruses infecting these individuals. However, in samples from five mild cases in December 2010, the substitutions almost completely disappeared. The D187E substitution was not prevalent in the samples, even as of May 2009. Conclusions: These results suggest that α2,3-sialic acid-specific viruses, including G222 and R223, are more prevalent in humans than a smaller population in the early phase of the pandemic existed, and that D222 and Q223 became more dominant through human-to-human transmission during the first and second waves of the epidemic. These results are consistent with the low substitution rates found in seasonal H1N1 viruses in 2008. © 2012 Yasugi et al.
authors: Yasugi, M.;Nakamura, S.;Daidoji, T.;Kawashita, N.;Ramadhany, R.;Yang, C. S.;Yasunaga, T.;Iida, T.;Horii, T.;Ikuta, K.;Takahashi, K.;Nakaya, T.

title: Isolation and molecular characterization of influenza A/H5N1 viruses isolated during the 2005 avian influenza outbreak among birds in European part of Russia: A virus strain with ozeltamivir resistance mutation was found
abstract: Isolation and characterization of influenza A/H5NI viruses isolated from chickens that died during the bird flu outbreak in the autumn of 2005 in the village of Yandovka (Tula region) and from a wild swan living near the mouth of the Volga River died in the zone of the Karalat Furrow were carried out. Molecular biological and phylogenetic analyzes were carried out with a view to determining a possible geographic origin of the strains, the phylogenetic similarity of viruses and the assessment of their pathogenicity, risk of disease in humans and possible resistance to antiviral drugs. It was found that the virus was one of the highly pathogenic variants that arose in China as a result of the rearrangement of genotype Z and V viruses circulating in poultry and wild birds. A number of molecular markers characterizing the high pathogenicity of the virus for gallinaceous birds and mammals were uncovered, but the specific mutations in the hemagglutinin gene, which promote the high virus replication rate in the human organism, and the adaptation mutations to it were not found. It was found that the variants of the influenza A/H5N1 virus circulating in this animal disease reacted sensitively to remantadine. The strain isolated from the wild swan had the mutation that caused resistance to Tamiflu/Ozeltamivir.
authors: Yatsyshina, S. B.;Shestopalov, A. M.;Evseyenko, V. A.;Astakhova, T. S.;Braslavskaya, S. I.;Ternovoi, V. A.;Kondratieva, T. Y.;Alekseev, A. Y.;Zolotykh, S. I.;Rassadkin, Y. N.;Zaikovskaya, A. V.;Durymanov, A. G.;Netesov, S. V.;Shipulin, G. A.

title: ISOLATION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF A SMALL ROUND VIRUS WITH A DIAMETER OF APPROX. 15 NM FROM THE POCKET OF THE PIGLET WITH DIARRHEA
authors: Yawei, N.;Huishen, Q.;Guoan, L.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis and Pathogenicity Assessment of Two Strains of Avian Influenza Virus Subtype H9N2 Isolated from Migratory Birds: High Homology of Internal Genes with the Human H10N8 Virus
abstract: Two human-infecting avian influenza viruses (AIVs), H7N9 and H10N8, have emerged in China, further suggesting that the H9N2 subtype of AIVs, as an internal gene donor, may play an important role in generating new cross-infected viruses. Species transferability and pathogenicity. H9N2 viruses containing such internal genes are widespread in poultry but are rarely reported in migratory birds. In this study, two strains of the H9N2 virus were isolated from faecal samples from migratory birds in 2014: one from Lake Caizi in Anhui Province and one from Lake Chen in Hubei Province in China. Nucleotide sequence analysis revealed high homology of all six internal genes of these two strains with the internal genes of human H10N8 virus in Jiangxi Province as well as human H7N9 virus. Phylogenetic analyzes indicated a possible origin of these two strains of fowl in southern China. Both of the two viruses tested could be replicated in the respiratory organs of infective mice without adaptation by either strain of wild bird H9N2 AIVs, indicating their potential ability to directly infect mammals. Our results indicate the existence of H9N2 viruses that contain internal genes that are highly homologous to human H10N8 or H7N9 viruses. Wild birds can contribute to the spread of the H9N2 virus, which contains the "harmful" internal gene complex, resulting in gene rearrangement with other influenza viruses and the creation of new pathogenic viruses. Therefore, increased AIV surveillance in wild birds can advance the understanding of virus presence and prevalence and provide scientific evidence for the prevention and control of AIVs and human-infecting AIVs.
authors: Ye, G.;Liang, C. H.;Hua, D. G.;Song, L. Y.;Xiang, Y. G.;Guang, C.;Lan, C. H.;Ping, H. Y.

title: Complete sequence analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes and proteins of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 detected in Iran, 2015
abstract: Over the past two decades, the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus has attracted much attention due to its zoonotic and mutative nature. Iran is among the countries hit hard by the virus as it hosts migratory birds during seasonal migration. In this study, the molecular characterizations of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes and proteins of H5N1 strain A/chicken/Iran/8/2015 detected in backyard fowl, Mazandaran province were examined. Phylogenetic analysis classified this virus as a member of subclass 2.3.2.1c with the cleavage site motif "PQRERRRK-R/GLF". HA carried some mutations that altered affinity for mammalian cells; However, the virus has been categorized as a bird. The NA protein had the 20 amino acid deletion at aa positions 49-69 similar to those isolated since 2000. Mutations of H253Y and H274Y that contributed to antiviral resistance were present in NA. From this analysis, it can be concluded that the wild migratory birds flying from West Asia to East Africa are likely to be the main carriers of seasonal H5N1 in the country.
authors: Yegani, S.;Shoushtari, A. H.;Eshratabadi, F.;Molouki, A.

title: Molecular characterization of low pathogenic avian influenza viruses isolated from food products imported to Singapore
abstract: We have completed the genetic characterization of all eight gene segments for four low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) viruses. The aim of this study was to detect the presence of new signatures that can serve as early warning indicators for the conversion of LPAI viruses into highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAI). This study included three H5N2 and one H5N3 virus isolated from live poultry imported to Singapore under the national Avian Influenza Virus (AIV) surveillance program. Based on the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) molecular criterion, sequence analysis using the translated amino acid (aa) sequence of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene revealed the absence of multibasic aa at the HA cleavage site, thereby identifying all four virus isolates as LPAI. Detailed phylogenetic tree analysis using the HA and neuraminidase (NA) genes grouped these isolates in the Eurasian H5 lineage but away from the HPAI H5 subtypes. This analysis further revealed that the internal genes were concentrated in different avian and swine subtypes, suggesting that the four isolates may share ancestry with these different influenza subtypes. Our results indicate that the four LPAI isolates in this study contained mostly avian signatures, and the phylogenetic tree for the internal genes further suggests the potential for regrouping with other distinct circulating avian subtypes. This is the first comprehensive report on the genetic characterization of LPAI H5N2/3 viruses isolated in Southeast Asia. © 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yeo, D. S. Y.;Ng, S. H.;Liaw, C. W.;Ng, L. M.;Wee, E. J. H.;Lim, E. A. S.;Seah, S. L. K.;Wong, W. K.;Lim, C. W.;Sugrue, R. J.;Tan, B. H.

title: Presence of bovine hepacivirus in Turkish cattle
abstract: The hepatitis C virus (HCV), a human pathogen spread worldwide, causes one of the most important viral infections in humans. HCV is the type species of the genus Hepacivirus (Flaviviridae), to which newly discovered animal viruses, for example from horses, bats, rodents and cattle, are assigned. According to preliminary reports in 2015 from German and African cattle, a wide spread of bovine hepacivirus (BovHepV, Hepacivirus N) has been suggested. We investigated the possible presence of BovHepV in bovine serum samples from different locations in Turkey. Analysis of a total of 120 samples from 98 female (dairy) and 22 male (beef) cattle by real-time RT-PCR yielded 15 (12.5%) positive results. BovHepV infection was detected at 6 out of 10 sites included in the study. There were positive samples from both the east and west of the country, indicating a possible widespread distribution in the Turkish cattle population. Phylogenetic analysis of 9 selected positive samples clearly assigned 8 sequences to a separate cluster based on the NS3 gene region, while one of the sequences obtained from an imported animal from northern Italy was grouped with sequences obtained from cattle in Germany became. The latter finding could indicate a possible occurrence of this genetic group of BovHepV not only in Germany but also in other European countries. The results of the present study indicate the presence of BovHepV infections in Turkey and the Middle East.
authors: Yesilbag, K.;Baechlein, C.;Kadiroglu, B.;Toker, E. B.;Alpay, G.;Becher, P.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of feline bocavirus in Northeast China
abstract: Background: Bocaviruses have been reported to cause respiratory infections and gastroenteritis in most animal species. Different genotype bocaviruses have been identified in cats in the US, Japan, Hong Kong and Portugal. However, the clear association between clinical symptoms and FBoV infection is unknown, and the prevalence of FBoV and the distribution of FBoV genotypes in China are still unclear. Results: In this study, 197 fecal samples from cats with diarrhea (n = 105) and healthy cats (n = 92) were collected in different regions between January 2016 and November 2017 and analyzed for different FBoV genotypes using PCR. The screening results showed that 51 out of 197 specimens (25.9%) were positive for FBoV, and a higher positive rate was observed in cats with diarrhea (33.3%, 35/105) than in healthy cats (17, 4%, 16/92). Of these FBoV-positive specimens, 35 were identified as FBoV-1, 12 as FBoV-2, and 4 as co-infection of FBoV-1 and FBoV-2. A phylogenetic analysis based on a partial NS1 gene showed that 24 sequences from randomly selected FBoV-positive samples were classified into 2 different FBoV groups: FBoV-1 and FBoV-2. In addition, 6 strains were randomly selected and the complete genome was sequenced and analyzed. These strains showed the typical Bocavirus genome organization and were closely related to FBoV. Two FBoV-2 identified strains shared high homologies with FBoV-2 reference strains based on full genome and entire encoding gene, but lower identities were found in the NP1 and VP1 regions for the other 4 FBoV-1 identified strains Reference strains shown in comparison to FBoV-1. Conclusion: These results indicate that genetically distinct FBoV-1 and FBoV-2 are widespread in cats in Northeast China and that FBoV-1 is more common. The high prevalence of FBoV in cats with symptoms of diarrhea suggests that FBoV infection may be associated with diarrhea in cats.
authors: Yi, S. S.;Niu, J. T.;Wang, H. L.;Dong, G. Y.;Zhao, Y. L.;Dong, H.;Guo, Y. B.;Wang, K.;Hu, G. X.

title: Novel highly divergent sapoviruses discovered by metagenomic analysis in straw-colored fruit bats in Cameroon
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaVs) belong to the genus Sapovirus in the family Caliciviridae. They have been linked to gastroenteritis in humans and pigs, but not in other animals. In addition, some strains of pigs, chimpanzees, and rodents show close sequence identity with human SaVs, suggesting the possibility of interspecies transmission. Bats are known to be a major reservoir of zoonotic viruses, however very little is known about the genetic diversity of SaVs in bats. To examine the genetic diversity of bat SaVs, fecal samples from Eidolon helvum and Epomophorus gambianus were treated according to the NetoVIR protocol and sequenced using Illumina technology. Near-complete genomic sequences of six highly divergent SaVs and one partial SaV (only VP1 region) have been identified in Eidolon helvum and based on sequence identities and phylogenetic analysis they may represent two new genogroups only distantly related to known SaVs. In addition, comparison of these sequences with currently used screening primers and probes indicated that the new SaVs would not be detected in routine human epidemiological screening studies should transmission between species occur. Therefore, we designed and validated new primers that can recognize both human and bat SaVs. In this study, we identified several novel bat SaVs, however, further human epidemiological studies are needed to uncover their potential role in gastroenteritis.
authors: Yinda, C. K.;ConceiÃ§Ã£o-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.;Maes, P.;Ghogomu, S. M.;Van Ranst, M.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Cameroonian fruit bats harbor diverse viruses including rotavirus H, bastroviruses, and picobirnaviruses that use an alternative genetic code
abstract: Most infectious diseases affecting humans originate from wild animals, and bats are an important reservoir of viruses, some of which are highly pathogenic to humans. In some regions of Cameroon, bats are hunted and eaten as a delicacy. This close proximity between humans and bats provides ample opportunity for zoonotic events. To elucidate the viral diversity of Cameroonian fruit bats, we collected and metagenomic screened eighty-seven fecal samples from Eidolon helvum and Epomophorus gambianus fruit bats. The results revealed a wealth of known and novel viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of the eleven gene segments of the first complete bat rotavirus H genome revealed clearly distinct clusters of human, porcine, and bat rotavirus H strains, indicating no recent interspecies transmission. In addition, we identified and analyzed a bat bastrovirus genome (a new group of recently described viruses related to astroviruses and hepatitis E viruses), confirmed their recombinant nature, and provided further evidence of additional recombination events between bat bastroviruses. Interestingly, picobirnavirus-like RNA-dependent RNA polymerase gene segments were identified using an alternative mitochondrial genetic code, and further principal component analysis suggested that they may have a lifestyle similar to that of mitoviruses, a group of virus-like elements known to live they infect the mitochondria of fungi. Although the identified bat coronavirus, parvovirus, and cyclovirus strains belong to established genera, most of the identified partitiviruses and densoviruses form putative new genera in their respective families. Finally, the results of the phage community analyzes of these bats indicate a highly diverse, geographically distinct bat phage population, likely reflecting different diets and gut bacterial ecosystems.
authors: Yinda, C. K.;Ghogomu, S. M.;Conceicao-Neto, N.;Beller, L.;Deboutte, W.;Vanhulle, E.;Maes, P.;Van Ranst, M.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Phylogenetic evidence for intertypic recombination in the emergence of human enterovirus 71 subgenotypes
abstract: Background: Human enterovirus 71 (EV-71) is a common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). In recent years, the virus has caused multiple outbreaks with many fatalities and severe neurological complications. Several new EV-71 subgenotypes were identified in these outbreaks. The mechanisms that contributed to the emergence of these subgenotypes are unknown. Results: Six EV-71 isolates from a 1997 outbreak in Malaysia were fully sequenced. These isolates have been identified as EV-71 subgenotypes B3, B4 and C2. Using these complete genome sequences and all other available EV-71 and human enterovirus A (HEV-A) complete genome sequences, a pedigree was constructed that correlated well with the present enterovirus classification scheme. However, using the 5-inch UTR, P2, and P3 genomic regions, isolates of EV-71 subgenotypes B3 and C4 separated from other EV-71 subgenotypes in a cluster along with coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16/ G10) and EV-71 subgenotype C2 clustered with CV-A8. The results of the similarity plot analyzes supported the clustering of these isolates with other HEV-A. In contrast, a CV-A16 isolate, Tainan5079, was clustered with EV-71 in the same genomic regions. This suggests that only the structural genes were conserved among EV-71 and CV-A16. The 3-inch end of the viral genome varied and consisted of sequences very similar to those of various HEV-A viruses. Numerous recombination crossover breakpoints have been identified within the nonstructural genes of some of these newer EV-71 subgenotypes. Conclusion: Phylogenetic evidence from full genome sequence analyzes supports the possible occurrence of intertypic recombination involving EV-71 and various HEV-A, including CV-A16, the most common causative agent of HFMD. It is hypothesized that these recombination events played an important role in the emergence of the different EV-71 subgenotypes. © 2006 Yoke-Fun and AbuBakar; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Yoke-Fun, C.;AbuBakar, S.

title: Tracing the genetic history of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses derived from the complete ORF 5-7 sequences: A Bayesian coalescing approach
abstract: To trace the genetic history of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV), we determined the complete sequences of ORFs 5 to 7 from four PRRSV isolates. These sequences were analyzed along with published sequences from 146 isolates from different parts of the world using a Bayesian coalescence approach, Bayesian inference and maximum likelihood methods. All European-type (EU-type) viruses were classified into one of two groups or unclassified (4 isolates), while all North American-type (NA-type) viruses belonged to one of three main groups or were unclassified (5 isolates) . No apparent periodic and/or geographic influence on the development of PRRSVs was observed within each genotype. The evolution rate of PRRSV isolates was estimated at 1.55 x 10-3 substitutions/site/year and the time of the most recent common ancestor (TMRCA) was 491.2 years ago. Here the TMRCA for the EU and NA type viruses was 58.7 and 62.6 years ago, respectively. A Bayesian skyline plot showed that the viruses evolved at a nearly constant population size until the late 1970s, when they experienced a population expansion that lasted until the late 1980s. The population size then remained constant again until the early 2000s, when there was a rapid, sharp decline in the effective number of infections. © 2012 Springer Verlag.
authors: Yoon, S. H.;Kim, H.;Park, B.;Kim, H.

title: Phylogenomics and molecular evolution of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: This report describes the use of Bayesian methods to analyze polyprotein coding region sequences (n=217) obtained from GenBank to define the genome-wide phylogeny of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD). The results strongly supported the monophyly of five FMDV serotypes, O, A, Asia 1, C and SAT 3, while the sequences for the two remaining FMDV serotypes, SAT 1 and SAT 2, did not segregate into completely distinct clades. The phylogenomic tree revealed three sister group relationships, serotype O + Asia 1, A + C and SAT 1 + 3 + 2, with a new branching pattern: {[(O, Asia 1), (A, C)], (SA 1, 2 , 3)}. Within each serotype, there was no apparent periodic, geographic, or host species impact on global foot-and-mouth disease virus evolution. Analysis of the polyprotein coding region of these sequences provided evidence for the influence of purification selection on the evolution of FMD. Using a Bayesian coalescence approach, the evolution rate of FMD isolates circulating in the years 1932-2007 has been estimated at 1.46 × 10-3 substitutions/site/year, and the virus's most recent common ancestor existed about 481 years ago years . The Bayesian skyline diagram showed an increase in population in the early 20th century followed by a rapid decline in population size from the late 20th century to the present. These results provide new insights into the mechanisms affecting the evolution of this important livestock pathogen. © 2011 KSMCB.
authors: Yoon, S. H.;Park, W.;King, D. P.;Kim, H.

title: Polymerase chain reaction-based genetic typing of Japanese viruses of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses (PRRSVs) are divided into 2 different genotypes: the North American type and the European type. The Japanese PRRSVs were genotyped by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction using the reported primer pairs reactive for either both types, specific for the North American type, or specific for the European type. All PRRSV genomes from 66 tissue homogenates or sera and 55 infectious viruses were North American-type, whereas no European-type viral genome was detected. Two North American type specific PCR primers showed different detection efficiencies. Half of the tissue samples and 15% of the infectious virus were not detected with one primer pair, although all were detected with the other primer pair. Nucleotide sequence analysis of the forward and reverse primer binding sites of the non-reactive viruses showed that all of these viruses had nucleotide mismatches within the 4 bases corresponding to the 3 inch end of the reverse primer. These mismatches appeared to account for the non-reactivity of the earlier primers towards these viruses.
authors: Yoshii, M.;Kaku, Y.;Murakami, Y.;Shimizu, M.;Kato, K.;Ikeda, H.

title: Molecular and serological epidemiology of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) on a remote island in western Japan: An impact of JEV migration across the East China Sea
abstract: Background: Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). About 1-10 cases with severe central nervous system symptoms have been reported in Japan every year. To clarify the mechanism of maintenance of JEV, the present study examined pigs for serological evidence of JEV infection and isolated JEV strains from pigs and mosquitoes in Isahaya City (Isahaya) and Goto City (Goto) in the Goto Islands in the Nagasaki Prefecture from 2008 to 2014. Results: Serological examination of pigs showed the increase of IgM seropositivity against JEV in July or August and was maintained every year until October or November in both Isahaya and Goto. From 2001 to 2014, 47 JEV strains were isolated in Nagasaki, including the isolates in this study, and they belonged to genotype 1. 34 of the isolated strains were from pigs in Isahaya and were classified into six subclusters (1-A-1, 1- A-2, 1-A-3, 1-A-4, 1-A-5 and 1-A-9). Thirteen strains were isolated from pigs and mosquitoes in Goto and classified into three subclusters (1-A-5 (2008); 1-A-1 (2009); and 1-A-2). In subcluster 1-A-2, three distinct monophyletic subgroups, 1-A-2-2 (2010), 1-A-2-3 (2011), and 1-A-2-1 (2013, 2014), appeared in Goto . Conclusions: These data strongly suggest that the occurrence of JEV in Goto appears to depend on the frequent introduction of JEV from outside the island, and this pattern differs from what has been observed on subtropical islands in the East China Sea such as Okinawa and Taiwan the same populations of JEV (1-A-7 (1998-2008) in Okinawa; genotype 3 (until 2012) in Taiwan) have been maintained over a long period of time.
authors: Yoshikawa, A.;Nabeshima, T.;Inoue, S.;Agoh, M.;Morita, K.

title: Molecular epidemiology of coxsackievirus A6 derived from hand, foot and mouth disease in Fukuoka between 2013 and 2017
abstract: Coxsackievirus (CV)-A6 has been the leading cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in Japan since 2011. In Fukuoka, CV-A6-associated HFMD caused epidemics in 2013, 2015, and 2017. This article reports the genetic characteristics of total viral CV-A6 protein 1 (VP1) derived from patients with HFMD in Fukuoka between 2013 and 2017. CV-A6 was detected in 105 out of 280 clinical specimens, and the entire VP1 sequences could be analyzed for 90 out of the 105 specimens. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the CV-A6 strains were classified in clade A and divided into subclade A3 or subclade A4. Each subclass strain carried amino acid substitutions in the putative DE and GH loops of VP1, and no amino acid substitutions were identified as deleterious to protein function. No significant difference was found in clinical symptoms between the genetic subclasses in statistical analyses. In summary, this study clarified the genetic diversity of CV-A6 in Fukuoka from 2013 to 2017. The emergence of the CV-A6 strains was deduced into new subclades based on the phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 gene, which can cause CV-A6-associated divided HFMD epidemics about every 2 years.
authors: Yoshitomi, H.;Ashizuka, Y.;Ichihara, S.;Nakamura, T.;Nakamura, A.;Kobayashi, T.;Kajiwara, J.

title: VIRAL INFECTION IN PETS review
authors: Young, G. A.

title: Isolation and genetic characterization of avian H1N1 and novel resortant H1N2 porcine influenza viruses in China
abstract: Because pigs are susceptible to both human and avian influenza viruses, they have been suggested as intermediate hosts or mixing vessels for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses by reassortment or adaptation to the mammalian host. In this study, we reported avian H1N1 and novel resistant H1N2 porcine influenza viruses in China. Homology and phylogenetic analyzes showed that H1N1 virus (A/swine/Zhejiang/1/07) closely resembled avian H1N1 viruses and appeared to be descended from European swine H1N1 viruses, first reported in China; and the two H1N2 viruses (A/swine/Shanghai/1/07 and A/swine/Guangxi/13/06) were novel resortant H1N2 influenza viruses containing genes from classical swine (HA, NP, M and NS), des Human (NA and PB1) and avian (PB2 and PA) lineages suggesting that reassortment between human, avian and swine influenza viruses had occurred in pigs in China and led to the generation of new viruses. The isolation of the avian-like H1N1 influenza virus, derived from the European swine H1N1 viruses, particularly the emergence of two new resortant H1N2 influenza viruses, provides further evidence that pigs serve as intermediate hosts or "mixing vessels" and monitor the swine flu virus in China should be given high priority. © 2009.
authors: Yu, H.;Zhang, P. C.;Zhou, Y. J.;Li, G. X.;Pan, J.;Yan, L. P.;Shi, X. X.;Liu, H. L.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Genetic Diversity of H9N2 Swine Influenza Viruses in China: A Potential Threat to Human Health?
abstract: Pandemic strains of influenza A virus can arise through genetic rearrangement between viruses from different hosts. Pigs are susceptible to both human and avian influenza viruses and have been proposed as intermediate hosts or mixing vessels for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses by reassortment or adaptation to the mammalian host. In this study, we summarize and report for the first time the coexistence of 10 (AJ) genotypes in pigs in China by analyzing the eight genes of 28 porcine H9N2 viruses isolated in China between 1998 and 2007. Porcine H9N2 viruses in genotypes A and B were fully derived from Y280-like and Shanghai/F/98-like viruses, respectively, suggesting that there was interspecies transmission of H9N2 viruses from bird to swine in China. The other eight genotype (CJ) viruses could be doubly reassorted viruses, in which six genotype (EJ) viruses 1-4 possessed H5-like gene segments, indicating that they were reassortants of H9 and H5 viruses. In conclusion, the genetic diversity of H9N2 swine influenza viruses in China provides further evidence that transmission of H9N2 viruses between birds and swine has occurred and to the generation of new reassortant viruses through genetic reassortment with swine H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 influenza viruses. Therefore, these H9N2 swine influenza viruses could pose a potential threat to human health, and further surveillance of swine flu virus in China is of great importance. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Yu, H.;Zhou, Y. J.;Li, G. X.;Ma, J. H.;Yan, L. P.;Wang, B.;Yang, F. R.;Huang, M.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Further evidence of infection of pigs with H1N1 human-like influenza virus in China
abstract: Classical swine and avian-like H1N1 influenza viruses have been commonly reported in swine populations worldwide, but human-like H1N1 swine viruses have occasionally been reported. In 2006, a human-like H1N1 swine virus (A/swine/Guangdong/96/06) was isolated from pigs in Guangdong province, which was first reported in China. To obtain further evidence for infection of swine with H1N1 humanlike influenza viruses, we analyzed eight gene segments from three porcine H1N1 humanlike viruses (A/swine/Guangdong/96/06, A/swine/Tianjin/01/04 and A /swine/Henan/01/06) isolated in China. All eight genes of the three viruses are highly homologous to recent (circa 2000) or early (1980s) human H1N1 influenza viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that A/Swine/Guangdong/96/06 was directly derived from about 2000 human H1N1 influenza viruses, while A/Swine/Tianjin/01/04 and A/Swine/Henan/01/06 to be human descendants appeared H1N1 viruses circulating in the 1980s. The seroprevalence of our isolate (A/swine/Guangdong/96/06) confirmed the presence of H1N1 human-like virus in pigs in China. The presence of these influenza viruses, particularly older viruses (A/swine/Tianjin/01/04 and A/swine/Henan/01/06), indicates that human-like H1N1 influenza viruses can remain invariant in swine for long periods of time, and offers this is evidence that pigs serve as a reservoir of older influenza viruses for human pandemics. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yu, H.;Zhou, Y. J.;Li, G. X.;Zhang, G. H.;Liu, H. L.;Yan, L. P.;Liao, M.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Detection of novel viruses in pig stool samples from China
abstract: Background: Pigs are a known source of human infectious diseases. To better understand the spectrum of viruses present in pigs, we used the 454 Life Sciences GS-FLX high-throughput sequencing platform to sequence stool samples from healthy pigs. Results. Total nucleic acid was extracted from stool samples from healthy piglets and randomly amplified. The amplified materials were pooled and processed using a high-throughput pyrosequencing technique. The raw sequences were unwrapped from the barcode and then processed through a standardized bioinformatics pipeline. The unique reads (348, 70, and 13) had limited resemblance to known astroviruses, bocaviruses, and parechoviruses. Specific primers were synthesized to determine the prevalence of the viruses in healthy piglets. Our results indicate extremely high positivity rates. Conclusions: Several new astroviruses, bocaviruses and ljungan-like viruses were identified in stool samples from healthy pigs. Isolation rates for the new viruses were high. The high detection rate, diverse sequences and categories indicate that pigs are well-established reservoirs and likely sources of various enteric viruses. © 2013 Yu et al.; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Yu, J. M.;Li, J. S.;Ao, Y. Y.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Identification of a novel picornavirus in healthy piglets and seroepidemiological evidence of its presence in humans
abstract: In this study, we describe a novel porcine parechovirus-like virus (tentatively named PLV-CHN) from healthy piglets in China using 454 high-throughput sequencing. The complete genome of the virus is 6832 bp and encodes a predicted polyprotein of 2132 amino acids most similar to Ljungan virus (32% identity). A similar virus belonging to a new genus of Picornaviridae called swine Pasivirus 1 (SPaV-1) was reported at the time of writing this article. Sequence analysis revealed that PLV-CHN and SPAV1 shared 82% nucleotide identity and 89% amino acid identity. Further genomic and phylogenetic analysis indicated that both SPAV1 and PLV-CHN share similar genomic features and belong to the same new genus Picornaviridae.
