A total of 36 (20.0%) stool specimens from 180 healthy piglets were positive for PLV-CHN by RT-PCR, while no stool specimens from 100 healthy children and 100 children with diarrhea, and no CSF specimens from 196 children suspected of having viral encephalitis, were positive for the virus. However, Western blot and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays using recombinant PLV-CHN-VP1 polypeptide as antigen showed a high seroprevalence of 63.5% in the healthy population. Antibody positivity rates grouped by age showed that the majority of children under the age of 12 were infected with the virus. It has been suggested that PLV-CHN, SPAV1, or an as yet uncharacterized virus can infect humans early in life. Therefore, investigating the role of this novel virus is crucial. © 2013 Yu et al.
authors: Yu, J. M.;Li, X. Y.;Ao, Y. Y.;Li, L. L.;Liu, N.;Li, J. S.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Molecular characteristics of the full-length genomic segment A of three infectious bursal disease viruses in China: two attenuated strains and one virulent field strain
abstract: The full-length cDNA of the genomic segment A of three infectious bursal virus viruses, two attenuated strains (HZ2 and JD1) and one virulent field strain (ZJ2000), was amplified in a single step by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and cloned into pGEM-T Easy Vector and sequenced. The full-length cloned segment A contains 3259 nucleotides comprising two partially overlapping open-reading fragments (ORFs) ORF1 and ORF2 flanked by 5' and 3' non-coding regions. These strains shared high sequence identity with each other, either at the nucleotide or deduced amino acid level. Strains HZ2 and JD1 were closely related to two attenuated strains, CEF94 and P2, while ZJ2000 was closely related to two other virulent strains, Cu-1 and Harbin. Four amino acid substitutions at positions 253, 279, 284 and 330 were also observed in these three strains, a feature common to attenuated and most virulent strains. Two major hydrophilic peaks were conserved in the three strains; however, there are two amino acid substitutions at positions 280 (N to S) and 290 (M to L) in the second small hydrophilic peak for all three strains that could have a critical impact on antigenicity. In the virulent strain JZ2000, two amino acid substitutions near the VP2-VP4 site were identified that may be involved in increasing the virulence of the virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these three Chinese strains are most closely related to some European virulent strains but distinct from highly virulent infectious bursal virus and variant strains.
authors: Yu, L.;Li, J. R.;Huang, Y. W.;Dikki, J.;Deng, R.

title: Growth characteristics and complete genomic sequence analysis of a novel pseudorabiesvirus in China
abstract: Porcine pseudorabies (PR) has reappeared in Bartha-vaccinated pig herds, causing the deaths of millions of piglets in China since late 2011. We isolated a novel pseudorabies virus (PRV) named HNX strain from the brain of aborted fetuses to diagnose the disease. To reveal the genomic organization and to characterize the HNX strain, the complete genomes of the HNX and the Fa strain, an isolate in the 1960s, were sequenced and analyzed. The genomic size of the HNX and Fa strains was 142,294 and 141,930 nt, respectively, with corresponding G+C contents of 73.56 and 73.70%. The two strains had 70 open reading frames throughout. In addition, a comparative genomic analysis between HNX and Bartha strains was performed to understand the possible cause of the immune failure. The major virulence-associated genes of the HNX strain had minor alterations, while the glycoprotein B and glycoprotein C genes of the HNX strain had 73 mutations; the homology at the entire genomic level between HNX and Bartha strains was 90.6%. A genome-wide comparison between HNX and Fa strains showed that the strains shared approximately 96.4% homology and were grouped in a separate Chinese isolate group; The two strains are also removed from the isolates from other countries. Similarity diagrams and boats-scanning analysis of whole genome sequences of nine PRV strains, including HNX and Fa, four new Chinese strains and three traditional reference strains, showed that non-recombinant events occurred in the HNX strain. The PRV HNX strain with genomic variations may be contributing to the PR outbreak in China since late 2011.
authors: Yu, T.;Chen, F.;Ku, X.;Fan, J.;Zhu, Y.;Ma, H.;Li, S.;Wu, B.;He, Q.

title: Influenza H7N9 and H9N2 viruses: coexistence in poultry associated with human H7N9 infection and genomic features
abstract: Recently, avian influenza virus A of the new H7N9 reassortant subtype was found to cause severe respiratory infections in humans in China. Live poultry markets have been suggested as the sites of human H7N9 infection sources based on the exposure history of the cases and sequence similarities between virus isolates. To investigate the role of live poultry markets in the emergence of the novel H7N9 virus, we systematically examined poultry and environmental samples from local markets and farms in Hangzhou, next using real-time reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) as well as high-throughput -Generational Sequencing (NGS). RT-PCR identified samples positive for the H7 and N9 genomic segments in all 12 poultry markets epidemiologically linked to 10 human H7N9 cases. Chickens, ducks, and environmental samples from markets contained highly mixed subtypes, including H7, N9, H9, and N2, and sometimes H5 and N1. The idea of the coexistence of H7N9 and H9N2 subtypes in chickens was further supported by metagenomic sequencing. In contrast, human H7N9 infection cases (n=31) were all negative for H9N2 virus by real-time RT-PCR. The six internal segments were indistinguishable for the H7N9 and H9N2 viruses. The H9, N2 and internal segment sequences were very similar to the sequence of the H9N2 virus recently circulated in chickens in China. Our results provide direct evidence that H9N2 strains coexisted with the novel human pathogenic H7N9 influenza virus in epidemiologically linked live poultry markets. The avian influenza A virus of the H9N2 subtype has probably recently contributed to the development of the H7N9 virus and continues to do so. © 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Yu, X.;Jin, T.;Cui, Y.;Pu, X.;Li, J.;Xu, J.;Liu, G.;Jia, H.;Liu, D.;Song, S.;Yu, Y.;Xie, L.;Huang, R.;Ding, H.;Kou, Y.;Zhou, Y.;Wang, Y.;Xu, X.;Yin, Y.;Wang, J.;Guo, C.;Yang, X.;Hu, L.;Wu, X.;Wang, H.;Liu, J.;Zhao, G.;Zhou, J.;Pan, J.;Gao, G. F.;Yang, R.;Wang, J.

title: Emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus of subtype H5N9
abstract: The novel avian influenza virus H7N9 (AIV) has been shown to cause serious respiratory infections in humans in China. Here we examined poultry samples from live bird markets associated with human H7N9 infection in Hangzhou, China. Metagenomic sequencing revealed mixed subtypes (H5, H7, H9, N1, N2 and N9). Subsequently, the AIV subtypes H5N9, H7N9 and H9N2 were isolated. Evolutionary analyzes showed that the hemagglutinin gene of the novel H5N9 virus originated from A/Muscovy Duck/Vietnam/LBM227/2012 (H5N1) belonging to clade 2.3.2.1. The neuraminidase gene of the novel H5N9 virus is derived from the human infectious A/Hangzhou/1/2013 (H7N9). The six internal genes were similar to those of other H5N1, H7N9 and H9N2 virus strains. The virus contained the PQRERRRKR/GL motif at the HA cleavage site, which is characteristic of highly pathogenic AIVs. Receptor binding experiments showed that the virus binds α-2,3-sialic acid but not α-2,6-sialic acid. Identically, pathogenicity experiments also showed that the virus caused low mortality rates in mice. This newly isolated H5N9 virus is a highly pathogenic reassortant virus derived from the H5N1, H7N9 and H9N2 subtypes. Live bird markets pose a potential transmission risk to public health and the poultry industry.
authors: Yu, Y.;Wang, X.;Jin, T.;Wang, H.;Si, W.;Yang, H.;Wu, J.;Yan, Y.;Liu, G.;Sang, X.;Wu, X.;Gao, Y.;Xia, X.;Yu, X.;Pan, J.;Gao, G. F.;Zhou, J.

title: Analysis of microRNA expression profile in specific pathogen-free chickens in response to reticuloendothelosis virus infection
abstract: Reticuloendothelosis virus (REV) is an avian retrovirus that causes immunosuppression, growth retardation, and oncogenesis in a variety of birds. REV infection is epidemic in many countries. In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing to identify microRNAs (miRNAs) associated with REV infection. A total of 88 differentially expressed miRNAs were identified in samples collected on days 21 and 28 after REV infection. Possible target genes of the differentially expressed miRNAs were analyzed. We observed that the expression of pro-apoptotic, proto-oncogenic, and carcinogenic cytokine mRNAs was highly up-regulated, while the expression of anti-apoptotic cytokine mRNAs was significantly down-regulated. Our results establish a potential link between miRNA expression and the pathogenesis of REV infection.
authors: Yu, Z.;Gao, X.;Liu, C.;Lv, X.;Zheng, S.

title: Isolation and molecular analysis of swine encephalomyocarditis virus strain BD2 from North China
abstract: Encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) can cause acute myocarditis in young pigs or reproductive disorders in sows. In this study, an EMCV strain (BD2) was isolated from putative piglets with EMCV in China. It was identified by an indirect immunofluorescence assay and a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. The virus was able to grow on BHK-21 cells and peak at 16 hpi with maximum titers of 108.22 TCID50/0.1 ml. Phylogenetic analyzes of the open reading frame and VP3/VP1 genes using neighbor joining method revealed that EMCV isolates fell into two clusters: group I and II. The BD2 isolate belonged together with strains NJ08, HB1, BJC3 , CBNU, K3, K11, BEL-2887A, GX0601, GXLC, pEC9, and PV21 belonged to group I, while four strains (D variant, EMCV-B, EMCV-D, and PV2) belonged to group II. © 2013.
authors: Yuan, W.;Song, Q.;Zhang, X.;Zhang, L.;Sun, J.

title: Hepatitis E virus: food, aquatic and zoonotic transmission
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is responsible for epidemics and endemics of acute hepatitis in humans, primarily via aquatic, foodborne, and zoonotic transmission routes. HEV is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus classified in the family Hepeviridae and comprises four known genotypes (1-4), at least two new putative genotypes of mammalian HEV, and a pending genus of avian HEV. HEVs of genotypes 1 and 2 affect only humans, while genotypes 3 and 4 are zoonotic and are responsible for sporadic and autochthonous infections in humans as well as in several other animal species worldwide. HEV has an ever-expanding host range and has been identified in numerous animal species. Pigs serve as a reservoir species for HEV transmission to humans; However, it is likely that other animal species also act as reservoirs. HEV poses an important public health concern, as cases of disease are definitely associated with handling infected pigs, consumption of raw and undercooked animal meat, and contamination of drinking or irrigation water with animal manure. Infectious HEV has been identified in numerous sources of concern, including animal feces, wastewater, inadequately treated water, contaminated shellfish and produce, and animal meat. Many aspects of HEV pathogenesis, replication and immunological responses remain unknown as HEV is an extremely understudied but important human pathogen. This article provides an overview of the current understanding of HEV transmission pathways with a focus on dietary and environmental sources and the prevalence of HEV in animal species with zoonotic potential in humans. © 2013 by the authors; Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Yugo, D. M.;Meng, X. J.

title: A new family of hybrid virophages from an animal gut metagenome
abstract: Searching metagenomic sequence databases for homologues of virophage capsid proteins led to the discovery of a new family of virophages in the ovine rumen metagenome. Rumen virophage (RVP) genomes encode a typical virophage major capsid protein, ATPase and protease combined with a protein-primed Polinton-type family B DNA polymerase. The RVP genomes appear to be linear molecules with terminal inverted repeats. Thus, the RVP appear to represent virophage-Polinton hybrids likely capable of producing infectious virions. Mimivirus virion proteins were detected in the same metagenomes as the RVP, suggesting that the new family virophages parasitize giant viruses that infect protistic rumen residents.
authors: Yutin, N.;Kapitonov, V. V.;Koonin, E. V.

title: Genetic and antigenic characterization of Indian foot-and-mouth disease serotype O isolates collected in the period 2001-2012
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 sequences of 39 O-type foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) isolates collected in 2001-12 from different regions of India revealed that all isolates belong to the Middle East-South Asia (ME- SA) belonged to . Based on the degree of divergence between isolates, the viruses were further classified into three distinct lineages, namely Ind 2001, PanAsia, and PanAsia-2, and a smaller, unnamed group. Ind 2001 lineage viruses have been responsible for most recent type O outbreaks. At the nucleotide level, these isolates showed a divergence of 2% to 14% with an average sequence divergence of ∼9.9%. The serological spectrum of the current vaccine strain was examined using bovine vaccine serum (BVS) raised against O/IND/R2/75. All current field isolates (n = 24) were homologous ('.r' value 0.4 to 1.0) to the vaccine strain. Examination of the amino acid sequences for selection pressure revealed positive selection at amino acid sites 13 and 45. © 2012 Elsevier BV.
authors: Yuvaraj, S.;Madhanmohan, M.;Nagendrakumar, S. B.;Kumar, R.;Mohana Subramanian, B.;Mohapatra, J. K.;Sanyal, A.;Pattnaik, B.;Srinivasan, V. A.

title: Mapping of virome in wild-caught Aedes aegypti from Cairns and Bangkok
authors: Zakrzewski, M.;RaÅ¡iÄ‡, G.;Darbro, J.;Krause, L.;Poo, Y. S.

title: The vampire bat virome: Evolutionary implications in an immunological context
authors: Zamudio, M. Escalera

title: The C-type transactivating retroviruses share one or more distinct epitopes that induce antibodies in certain infected hosts
abstract: Using sera from hosts infected with bovine leukemia virus (BLV), human T-cell lymphoma virus types I and II (HTLV-I and -II), or simian T-cell lymphoma virus type I (STLV-I) were infected, we found that the major gag proteins of these viruses cross-react immunologically. The specificity of this cross-reactivity was demonstrated by absorbance using purified viral proteins, viral lysates and infected cell extracts. The data strongly suggest that the cross-reacting epitope(s) designated CE differ from those responsible for cross-reactions between the major gag proteins of HTLV-I, HTLV-II and STLV- I and between those of BLV and HTLV are responsible - I have previously reported. The prevalence of antibodies to CE was low, even in infected hosts with high titers to other epitopes present in the major gag proteins of the homologous viruses. CE was not detected in any of the other C- or D-type retroviruses or lentiviruses examined. Therefore, it is likely that CE can be used to serologically define a subset of C-type retroviruses whose genomes exhibit unique features and functional activities.
authors: Zandomeni, R.;Carrera-Zandomeni, M.;Esteban, E.;Ferrer, J. F.

title: Matrix protein gene sequence analysis of avian Paramyxovirus-1 isolates obtained from pigeons
abstract: The matrix protein gene has been cloned and sequenced for several recent isolates of avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV-1). In particular, isolates from pigeons and pigeons, members of the Columbidae family, were studied. APMV-1 is the causative agent of Newcastle disease and the virus is associated with disease in a wide range of bird species. Isolates of pigeon Newcastle disease virus (NDV) have also been classified as pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1). Matrix protein gene sequences for PPMV-1 isolates phylogenetically clustered together as a group relative to isolates from other species. However, there were also isolates from pigeons or pigeons that grouped with APMV-1 isolates from other species. This indicates that PPMV-1 may circulate among Columbidae members as a distinct lineage, but that these bird species may harbor other NDV strains as well. Of particular interest was a pigeon isolate from Europe that had an aberrant fusion protein cleavage site and was phylogenetically a distant member between the two major groups of APMV-1 isolates.
authors: Zanetti, F.;RodrÃ­guez, M.;King, D. J.;Capua, I.;Carrillo, E.;Seal, B. S.;Berinstein, A.

title: Genomic heterogeneity of small ruminant lentiviruses detected by PCR
abstract: To detect a broad spectrum of small ruminant lentiviruses, primers were selected for PCR in conserved portions of the Icelandic visna virus 1514 LTR and GAG genes and the caprine arthritis encephalitis virus POL gene. This primer set was tested in six different isolates of caprine arthritis encephalitis virus (CAEV) and maedi visna virus of Dutch, American and Swiss origin. The LTR primers allowed detection of the corresponding fragments of all isolates. The GAG primers allowed amplification of the corresponding fragments from all but the Swiss Maedi-Visna virus strain OLV. Using the POL primers, one Maedi Visna and two caprine arthritis encephalitis virus strains were detected after one round of amplification. Sequencing of the GAG and POL amplification products and comparison to Icelandic Visna virus and CAEV strain CO revealed an overall heterogeneity of 38% for the GAG and 28% for the POL fragment. The virus strains studied fall into two groups that are more closely related than to Icelandic visna virus.
authors: Zanoni, R. G.;Nauta, I. M.;Kuhnert, P.;Pauli, U.;Pohl, B.;Peterhans, E.

title: Influenza A(H9N2) virus, Burkina Faso
abstract: We identified the G1 lineage of influenza A(H9N2) virus in poultry in Burkina Faso. Urgent action is needed to raise awareness of the risk associated with the spread of this zoonotic virus subtype in the Region and to develop a strategy to effectively prevent and control influenza caused by this virus.
authors: Zecchin, B.;Minoungou, G.;Fusaro, A.;Moctar, S.;Ouedraogo-Kabore, A.;Schivo, A.;Salviato, A.;Marciano, S.;Monne, I.

title: Phylogeography and phylodynamics of European genotype 3 hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus is divided into four genotypes that have distinct geographic and host distributions. The main cause of sporadic autochthonous acute type E hepatitis in developed countries is genotype 3, which is distributed worldwide and widely affects pigs. The aim of this study was to hypothesize the origin and global routes of spread of this genotype by reconstructing the spatial and temporal dynamics of 208 HEV genotype 3 ORF-2 sequences (from public databases) localized in different geographic areas have been isolated. The evolutionary rates, time of most recent common ancestors (tMRCAs), epidemic growth, and phylogeography of HEV-3 were jointly estimated using a MCMC-Bayes method for only European subtypes (HEV-3e and 3f) and clade B derived from the European subtype 3c and all Asian subtypes (3a, 3b and 3d) that share a common ancestor that most likely existed in Asia in the 1920s. All North American isolates belonged to the Asian subtype 3a. Based on our time-scaled phylogeographic reconstruction, we hypothesize that HEV, after originating in the early 1800s in Europe, reached Asia in the first decades of the 1900 and then migrated to the Americas, probably in the 1970s to 1980s. Analysis of the Skyline plot showed a sharp increase in infection numbers between the 1980s and 2005, suggesting the intervention of new and highly efficient modes of transmission, possibly related to changes in the swine industry. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Zehender, G.;Ebranati, E.;Lai, A.;Luzzago, C.;Paladini, S.;Tagliacarne, C.;Galli, C.;Galli, M.;Ciccozzi, M.;Zanetti, A. R.;RomanÃ², L.

title: New Ecological Aspects of Hantavirus Infection: A Paradigm Shift and a Prevention Challenge - A Review
abstract: In the last few decades, despite intensive research and extraordinary efforts of modern medicine to contain and eradicate infectious diseases, a considerable number of previously unknown or underestimated pathogens have become fundamental health threats to the human population. Almost all incidents caused by such emerging pathogens could be attributed to pathogens that are zoonotic or have expanded their host range and crossed species boundaries. Many different factors influence a pathogen's status, going unnoticed or evolving into a global threat. The adaptability of an infectious agent to changing environmental conditions and variations in human behavior, population development, nutrition, education, social and health status are relevant factors affecting the correlation between pathogen and host. Hantaviruses are among the emerging pathogens that have attracted increasing attention in recent decades. These viruses are members of the Bunyaviridae family and are classified in a separate genus known as Hantavirus. Hantaan (HTN), Seoul (SEO), Puumala (PUU), and Dobrava (DOB) virus serotypes predominantly cause hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS), a disease characterized by renal failure, bleeding, and shock. In the recent past, many hantavirus isolates have been identified and classified in previously unaffected geographic regions in the New World (North, Central, and South America) with characteristics affecting the lungs of infected individuals and causing acute pulmonary syndrome. Hantavirus outbreaks in the United States of America at the beginning of the 10th decade of the last century have fundamentally changed our knowledge of the occurrence of the hantavirus-specific clinical picture, mortality, origin and transmission route in humans. Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) was first identified in the Four Corners region of the United States in 1993 and had a mortality rate of more than 50%. Although the causative virus was first named in connection with the geographic name of its region of outbreak, analysis of the individual viruses suggests that the causative virus of HPS was a genetically distinct hantavirus and was consequently named Sin Nombre virus. Hantaviruses are distributed worldwide and are thought to share a long period of co-evolution with certain rodent species as their natural reservoir. The degree of relatedness between virus serotypes is usually consistent with the relatedness between their respective hosts. There are no known diseases associated with hantavirus infection in rodents, underscoring the friendly virus-host relationship that has evolved through mutual interaction over hundreds of thousands of years. Although rodents are the main reservoir, antibodies to hantavirus are also present in domestic and wild animals such as cats, dogs, pigs, cattle and deer. Domestic animals and rodents live together in a similar habitat. Therefore, transmission of hantaviruses from rodents to domestic animals appears to be possible if the target organs, tissues, and cell parenchyma of cohabiting domestic animals have sufficient viral receptors and are suitable for hantavirus entry and replication. The most likely accidental infection of species other than rodents, such as humans, turns hantaviruses from harmless to life-threatening pathogens, drawing attention to this virus group, its ecology, and evolution to save the human population from a serious health risk. Much more studies on the impact of non-natural hosts on hantavirus ecology are needed to understand the direction hantavirus evolution might take. At a minimum, pets that share their environmental habitat with rodents and humans, especially in areas known to be highly endemic hantavirus regions, need to be screened extensively. Any transmission of hantaviruses from their original natural hosts to other, often accidental, hosts is accompanied by a change in ecology, a change in environment, a modulation of numerous factors likely to affect the pathogenicity and virulence of the virus. The new environment puts altered evolutionary pressures on the virus, forcing it to adapt and likely adopt a form that is much more dangerous to other host species than the original one. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Zeier, M.;Handermann, M.;Bahr, U.;Rensch, B.;MÃ¼ller, S.;Kehm, R.;Muranyi, W.;Darai, G.

title: ICTV virus taxonomy profile: Picornaviridae
abstract: The Picornaviridae family includes small non-enveloped viruses with RNA genomes ranging from 6.7 to 10.1 kb and contains > 30 genera and > 75 species. Most of the known picornaviruses infect mammals and birds, but some have also been identified in reptiles, amphibians, and fish. Many picornaviruses are important human and veterinary pathogens and can cause diseases of the central nervous system, heart, liver, skin, gastrointestinal tract or upper respiratory tract. Most picornaviruses are transmitted faecal-oral or respiratory. This is a summary of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) report on the taxonomy of the Picornaviridae, available at www. icv. global/report/picornaviridae.
authors: Zell, R.;Delwart, E.;Gorbalenya, A. E.;Hovi, T.;King, A. M. Q.;Knowles, N. J.;Lindberg, A. M.;Pallansch, M. A.;Palmenberg, A. C.;Reuter, G.;Simmonds, P.;Skern, T.;Stanway, G.;Yamashita, T.

title: Molecular Basics Neoclassifier der Rinder-Enteroviren
abstract: Bovine enteroviruses are currently divided into two serotypes within the bovine enterovirus (BEV) species. The comparison of the sequences of six American and eleven German BEV isolates with published BEV sequences revealed the need to revise the taxonomy of these viruses. Molecular data show that the bovine enteroviruses consist of two clusters (designated BEV-A and -B) with two and three geno/serotypes, respectively. While the low amino acid identity of the capsid proteins 1C (VP3) and 1D (VP1) is the main criterion for distinguishing genotypes/serotypes, the BEV clusters putatively representing species differ in the sequence identity of all viral proteins. In addition, characteristic lengths of (i) the capsid proteins 1B, 1C and 1D, (ii) the 2C protein and (iii) the 3'' untranslated region are observed. The BEVs can be distinguished from the other enteroviruses by sequence identity and unique features of the 5'' untranslated region, ie a conserved second leaf clover and characteristic RNA structures of the internal ribosome entry site. Phylogenetically, the porcine enteroviruses are the closest relatives of the bovine enteroviruses. Incongruent phylogenies; In the 5″ untranslated region, capsid proteins and 3D polymerase indicate frequent intraserotypic and interserotypic recombination within the non-capsid and capsid regions of the BEV genome. © 2006 SGM.
authors: Zell, R.;Krumbholz, A.;Dauber, M.;Hoey, E.;Wutzler, P.

title: Application of genome sequence information to classify bovine enteroviruses: the importance of 5' and 3' untranslated regions
abstract: The comparative genomics of viruses in evolutionary and phylogenetic studies is well established. Previous nucleic acid sequence analyzes have shown that enteroviruses and rhinoviruses of the family Picornaviridae share a similar 5'-nontranslated region (NTR) structure that differs significantly from the 5'-NTR of cardiovirus, aphthovirus, hepatovirus, and echovirus 22 (tentatively parechovirus) 1 ). Available nucleotide sequence information of the 5' and 3' untranslated regions of more than 70 serotypes of enteroviruses, bovine enteroviruses and rhinoviruses was compared and correlated with previous knowledge obtained after analysis of the coding and noncoding regions of the genome. As a result, the 5' and 3' NTRs of all three virus groups are characterized by group-specific nucleotide sequences. With a focus on bovine enterovirus (BEV) serotypes, unique features were observed in all secondary structures of the NTRs. These features clearly distinguish BEVs from human enteroviruses and rhinoviruses. Concerning the 5'-NTR, the most notable feature is an insertion of approximately 110 nucleotides between the putative trefoil structure at the very 5' end of the viral genome and the IRES element. This insertion was made for BEV I and :! demonstrated. and has a predicted folding pattern very similar to the 5' trefoil structure. A stem loop of this second trefoil is nearly identical to the 3CD(pro) binding domain of rhinoviral 5' clovers. It has also been shown that the IRES elements and the 3'-NTRs of both enteroviruses and rhinoviruses have group-specific features that differ significantly from the corresponding genomic regions of BEV. These results indicate that bovine enteroviruses occupy an exceptional taxonomic position alongside the established genera Enterovirus and Rhinovirus. Within the enterovirus and rhinovirus genera, the existence of virus clusters representing subgenera has previously been suggested. While the 5' NTRs of the four human enterovirus clusters fall into two groups, all four clusters have distinctive secondary structures at the 3' NTR, supporting the concept of enterovirus clusters. The existence of two virus clusters has been confirmed for rhinoviruses.
authors: Zell, R.;Stelzner, A.

title: â€¦ Novel human-like H3N2 influenza A viruses, A/swine/Oklahoma/65980/2017 (H3N2) and A/Swine/Oklahoma/65260/2017 (H3N2), identified in pigs in the United Statesâ€¦
authors: Zeller, M. A.;Li, G.;Harmon, K. M.;Zhang, J.

title: Complete genome sequence analysis of goatpox virus isolated from China shows high variation
abstract: Goatpox virus (GTPV), a member of the genus Capripoxvirus of the family Poxviridae, is the causative agent of variolo caprina (goatpox). GTPV can cause significant economic losses to native ruminants in endemic areas and threaten breeding stocks. In this study, we report the assembly of the complete genomic sequence of an isolated GTPV field strain FZ (GTPV_FZ). The 150.194. The GTPV genome consists of a central coding region bounded by two identical 2301 bp inverted terminal repeats and contains 151 putative genes. Comparative genomic analyzes show that the apparent genetic relationships between capripoxviruses are close, but enough genomic variants have been identified in field isolate strain FZ to distinguish it from other GTPV strains and other capripoxvirus species. Phylogenetic analysis based on the p32 and the full GTPV genome can be used to distinguish SPPVs, GTPVs and LSDVs. These data may contribute to the epidemiological study of Chinese capripox virus and help to develop more specific detection methods to distinguish GTPVs, SPPVs and LSDVs. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Zeng, X.;Chi, X.;Li, W.;Hao, W.;Li, M.;Huang, X.;Huang, Y.;Rock, D. L.;Luo, S.;Wang, S.

title: Integrative analyzes of transcriptome sequencing identify functional mirnas in chick embryo fibroblast cells infected with reticuloendothelosis virus
abstract: In this study, we found that a much higher proportion of reticuloendothelosis virus (REV)-infected chick embryo fibroblasts (CEF) were in the active phase of cell division than that of control cells, indicating that REV can influence the fate of CEF. Therefore, we performed high-throughput sequencing and transcriptome analysis to identify functional miRNAs to elucidate the possible mechanism of REV-CEF interaction. A total of 50 differentially expressed miRNAs (DEmiRNAs) were identified. Then target genes were predicted from DEmiRNAs and identified from transcriptome profile results. The Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) enrichment was performed to analyze the identified target genes of miRNAs, which showed that metabolism, cell cycle and apoptosis were the most closely related pathways involved in the infection of REV. We analyzed cell cycle-related genes, which suggested that the cyclinD1-CDK6 complex played an important role in regulating the transition of the cell cycle from G1 phase to S phase during REV infection. Fluorescence microscopic identification showed that REV inhibited CEF apoptosis, consistent with transcriptome results. A new miRNA named Novel-72 was found, KEGG analysis was performed to predict the biological function of its target genes, which showed that these target genes were significantly enriched in the mTOR signaling pathway and promoted cell cycle and cell growth during REV infection . In conclusion, REV could induce upregulation of cellular metabolism, cell cycle and mTOR signaling pathway while inhibiting cell apoptosis.
authors: Zhai, J.;Ga, C.;Fu, L.;Jing, L.;Dang, S.;Zheng, S.

title: Viral metagenomics analysis reveals the diversity of viral flora in piglet diarrhea faeces in China
abstract: To examine the diversity of viral flora, we used metagenomics to study viral communities in a pooled fecal sample from 27 diarrheal piglets from intensive commercial farms in China. The 15 different mammalian viruses identified in the pooled diarrhea sample were, in order of nucleic acid sequence, Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV), Sapovirus, Porcine Bocavirus-4 (PBoV-4), Sapelovirus, Torovirus, Coronavirus, PBoV-2 , stool-associated single-stranded DNA virus (poSCV), astrovirus (AstV), kobuvirus, posavirus-1, porcine enterovirus-9 (PEV-9), porcine circovirus-like (po-circo-like) virus, picobirnavirus (PBV) and Torque Tenosus Virus 2 (TTSuV-2). The prevalence rate of each virus was verified in diarrheal and healthy piglets using a PCR assay. An average of 5.5 different viruses were shed in piglets suffering from diarrhea, and one piglet was actually co-infected with 11 different viruses. On the other hand, healthy piglets excrete an average of 3.2 different viruses. Compared to samples from healthy piglets, co-infection of PEDV and PBoV had a high prevalence rate in diarrhea samples, suggesting a correlation with incidence of diarrhea in piglets. Furthermore, we report here for the first time the presence of several recently described viruses in China and the identification of new genotypes. Therefore, our study results provide an unbiased overview of viral communities and prevalence in piglet fecal samples.
authors: Zhang, B.;Tang, C.;Yue, H.;Ren, Y.;Song, Z.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel rodent bocavirus from different rodent species in China
abstract: Members of the genus Bocaparvovirus are closely related to human health and have a broad host range. The different hosts increase the possibility of crossing species barriers, which is a feature of emerging viruses. Among mammalian hosts, rodents are generally recognized as important reservoirs of emerging viruses. Here, rodent samples from six provinces and autonomous regions of China (Liaoning, Inner Mongolia, Tibet, Xinjiang, Guangxi and Yunnan) were used to study the prevalence and spread of bocaparvovirus. Using next-generation sequencing, a partial nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) gene belonging to a putative novel bocaparvovirus was first discovered. A PCR-based screening of the NS1 gene was then performed in 485 rodent samples, finding 106 positive results in seven rodent species (Rattus norvegicus, Mus musculus, Apodemus agrarius, Cricetulus barabensis, Rattus flavipectus, Rattus rattus and Rhombomys opimus). Eventually, six nearly full-length genomes and three complete CDS were obtained, and the newly identified bocaparvovirus was tentatively named rodent bocavirus (RoBoV). RoBoV has three ORFs: NS1, NP1 and VP that are characteristic of bocaparvoviruses. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that the virus most closely related to RoBoV was the porcine bocavirus isolate PBoV-KU14, a member of ungulate bocaparvovirus 4, with 92.1-92.9% amino acid identity in the NS1 protein. Alignments of RoBoV-related sequences showed that RoBoV isolates could be classified into two clades, demonstrating genetic diversity between hosts. The results indicate a possible interspecies transmission of RoBoV between rodents and pigs and expand our knowledge of bocaparvoviruses in rodent populations.
authors: Zhang, C.;Song, F.;Xiu, L.;Liu, Y.;Yang, J.;Yao, L.;Peng, J.

title: [Phylogenetic analysis of 2009 H1N1(A) influenza virus based on genomic sequence features]
abstract: Since April 2009, a new strain of the H1N1 human flu virus has swept the world. The genome of the influenza virus consists of 8 segments, each encoding 10 proteins. The rearrangements between the 8 segments cause the variation of the influenza virus. Therefore, the phylogenetic analysis of the 8 genes is very important. In this article, we choose the frequencies of adjacent words as genomic traits, using VC++ programming to analyze the evolution of the 8 segments of the H1N1 virus. As a result, we found that PB2 genes and PA genes of these three isolated viruses were derived from North American avian influenza virus, PB1 genes were from human seasonal influenza virus, and HA genes, NS genes and NP genes were from North American classical swine influenza A virus. The NA segments and M segments were from European swine influenza virus.
authors: Zhang, F.;Guo, X.;Cheng, W.;Wang, Y.;Zhang, S.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of a Coxsackie B5 virus and its relationship to swine vesicular disease virus
abstract: We report the first complete nucleotide sequence of picornavirus coxsackievirus B5 (CB5) strain 1954/UK/85, an isolate from a case of hand, foot, and mouth disease. We compared the sequence to those of other coxsackie B viruses, coxsackievirus A9, poliovirus and swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV). The genes encoding the three major capsid proteins are most closely related to those of SVDV, but the 5' and 3' non-coding regions and the P3 gene are more similar than the corresponding regions in the other coxsackie B viruses by SVDV. These observations are considered in light of the antigenic and biochemical relationships between SVDV and CB5.
authors: Zhang, G.;Wilsden, L. G.;Knowles, L. N. J.;McCauley, J. W.

title: Characterization of an Enterovirus species E isolated from naturally infected cattle in China
abstract: Bovine enteroviruses, which belong to the Picornaviridae family, can cause clinical symptoms in cattle and are excreted in the faeces. In this study, a cytolytic virus was isolated from Madin-Darby bovine kidney (MDBK) cells from fecal samples from cattle with severe diarrhea and hemorrhagic intestinal mucosa and initially diagnosed with bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) caused by bovine viral diarrhea virus Ag Point -of-care test (IDEXX, American). Random priming PCR was used to amplify underlying viral sequences and identify the isolated virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the isolated virus closely matched the EV-E2 species, distinct from other previously isolated Chinese strains. The newly identified virus was named HLJ-3531/2013. We infected the pouting mice with the isolated virus. Reverse transcription PCR, hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining, serum neutralization (SN) assay and virus isolation from various tissues showed that HLJ-3531/2013 can infect the intestine, liver and lungs of lactating mice. The present work is the first to report the reproduction of clinical symptoms by an isolated virus in an experimental animal infection model and provides a solid basis for the development of the pathogenesis of bovine enteroviruses.
authors: Zhang, H.;Liu, H.;Bao, J.;Guo, Y.;Peng, T.;Zhou, P.;Zhang, W.;Ma, B.;Wang, J.;Gao, M.

title: Genome-wide analysis of differentially expressed genes and modulation of PEDV infection in Vero E6 cells
abstract: PEDV remains one of the most important swine diseases affecting pigs of all ages. It causes devastating viral enteric diseases in piglets with a high mortality rate, resulting in significant threats and huge economic losses to the pork industry. In this study, a transcriptomic shotgun sequencing method (RNA-Seq) was used to examine gene responses against PEDV infection. A genome-wide analysis of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) was performed in Vero E6 cells after PEDV infection. The mTOR pathway activator MHY1485 and the inhibitor PP242 were used to study antiviral function. The results showed that IRF3 was significantly upregulated after PEDV infection. Although most of the IFN-regulatory and related genes evaluated in this study were either down-regulated or remained unchanged, IL11 behaved significantly up-regulated, peaking at 16 hpi. Almost 90% of PEDV infections were suppressed in the PP242-pretreated cells, while the opposite effect was observed in the MYH1485-pretreated cells. The results showed that the mTOR signaling pathway played an important role in the antiviral regulation of PEDV in the Vero E6 cells. Future studies will help to better understand the cellular antiviral mechanism against PEDV.
authors: Zhang, H.;Liu, Q.;Su, W.;Wang, J.;Sun, Y.;Zhang, J.;Shang, K.;Chen, Z.;Cheng, S.;Wu, H.

title: Porcine bocaviruses: genetic analysis and prevalence in the Chinese swine population
abstract: Among members of the Bocavirus genus, which contain three open reading frames (ORFs) of the Parvovirinae subfamily, porcine bocaviruses (PoBoVs) exhibit the greatest genetic diversity. Based on the classification of the ORF2-encoded viral protein (VP1), the six reported porcine bocaviruses have been classified into four types: PoBoV1 (porcine Boca-like virus or PBoLV), PoBoV2 (porcine parvovirus 4 or PPV4), PoBoV3 (PBoV1/PBoV2) and PoBoV4 (6V/7V), where PoBoV3 and PoBoV4 each have two genotype viruses. All four PoBoV species were detected in the 166 samples collected from pig herds in ten provinces of China in 2010. The recognition rates for PoBoV1-4 were 28 x 9%, 6 x 6%, 19 x 3% and 39 x 7%, respectively. The co-infection combinations with these six porcine bocaviruses in the collected samples were very complex. In addition, mixed infections with viruses from other families (porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus, classical swine fever virus and porcine circovirus type 2) have also been detected. ©Cambridge University Press 2011.
authors: Zhang, H. B.;Huang, L.;Liu, Y. J.;Lin, T.;Sun, C. Q.;Deng, Y.;Wei, Z. Z.;Cheung, A. K.;Long, J. X.;Yuan, S. S.

title: Response to “Classification of Emerging US Strains of Porcine Epidemic Diarrheal Virus by Phylogenetic Analysis of Nucleocapsid and ORF3 Genes”
authors: Zhang, J.;Chen, Q.;Gauger, P. C.;Harmon, K. M.;Yoon, K. J.

title: Molecular characterization and seroprevalence in swine of SC0806, a cat que virus isolated from mosquitoes in Sichuan Province, China
abstract: The Simbu serogroup currently consists of a very diverse group of related arboviruses that infect both humans and economically important livestock species. Cat que virus (CQV), a virus of the Simbu serogroup of the genus Orthobunyavirus (family Bunyaviridae), was first isolated from mosquitoes in 2004 during surveillance of arbovirus activity in acute pediatric encephalitis in northern Vietnam. We report here the complete genome sequence of SC0806 isolated from mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus) in Sichuan Province, China. Consistent with the genomic organization of Simbu serogroup viruses, the SC0806 genome comprises three RNA segments - a large (L) segment (6928 nucleotides) encoding the 2261 amino acid long RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, a medium (M ) segment (4481 nucleotides) encoding the 1433 amino acid polyprotein and a small (S) segment (984 nucleotides) encoding a 234 amino acid nucleocapsid protein and a 95 amino acid nonstructural protein. The respective lengths of the 5″ untranslated region (UTR) and 3″ UTR of L, M and S are 56 and 86, 43 and 136 and 44 and 238 nucleotides. Sequence comparisons (nucleotides and deduced amino acids) and phylogenetic analysis revealed that SC0806 was closely related to the reported Vietnam isolate CQV. This is the first time CQV has been isolated in Sichuan Province, China. Anti-SC0806 immunoglobulin M (IgM) and IgG antibodies were found in pigs reared locally, suggesting that CQV has cycled naturally in the region. Surveillance of the spread and pathogenicity of SC0806 should be strengthened.
authors: Zhang, J.;Wang, J.;Wang, L.;Fu, S.;Li, M.;Zhao, G.;Zhu, W.;Wang, D.;Liang, G.

title: High-throughput whole genome sequencing of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus from cell culture materials and clinical specimens using next-generation sequencing technology
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are increasingly playing a crucial role in biological and medical research, but are not yet routinely used in veterinary diagnostic laboratories. We have developed and applied a method for high-throughput RNA sequencing of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) from cell culture-derived isolates and clinical specimens. Ten PRRSV isolates with known sequence information, 2 mixes each containing 2 different PRRSV isolates and 51 clinical samples (19 sera, 16 lungs and 16 buccal fluids) with different PCR threshold cycle (Ct) values were subjected to nucleic acid extraction, cDNA library preparation ( 24-plexed) and sequencing. Complete genomic sequences were obtained from 10 reference isolates with expected sequences and from sera with PRRSV real-time reverse transcription PCR Ct ≤ 23.6, lung tissue with Ct ≤ 21 and oral fluids with Ct ≤ 20.6. When mixed with PRRSV-1 and -2 isolates (57.8% nucleotide identity), NGS was able to distinguish them and preserve their respective genomic sequences. In mixtures containing 2 PRRSV-2 isolates (92.4% nucleotide identity), sequence reads with nucleotide ambiguity were observed at numerous sites, indicating mixed infection; however, individual virus sequences could only be separated if 1 isolate identity and sequence were known in the mixture. The NGS approach described here offers the prospect of high-throughput sequencing and could be adapted to routine workflows in veterinary diagnostic laboratories, although further improvement in sequencing results from clinical samples with higher Ct values remains to be explored.
authors: Zhang, J.;Zheng, Y.;Xia, X. Q.;Chen, Q.;Bade, S. A.;Yoon, K. J.;Harmon, K. M.;Gauger, P. C.;Main, R. G.;Li, G.

title: Insights into the response of male hepatocellular Leghorn cells to avian adenovirus serotype 4 infection by transcriptome analysis
abstract: Avian adenovirus serotype 4 (FAdV-4), a member of the Aviadenovirus genus of the Adenoviridae family, causes hepatitis hydropericardium syndrome (HHS) in chickens. It causes up to 80% mortality in 3-6 week old broilers and poses a significant threat to the poultry industry. However, the specific host responses to the virus are not well understood. To better understand the interactions between the host and FAdV-4 and to study the pathogenesis of this virus, high-throughput RNA-seq technology was performed on Leghorn male hepatocellular (LMH) cells at 12, 24, and 48 h after FAdV-4 infection . We identified a total of 7000 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) that were enriched in a variety of biological processes and signaling pathways using Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway enrichment analysis. Following FAdV-4 infection, several immune-related signaling pathways were activated, including toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling and the cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction pathway. The transcription data were validated by real-time quantitative PCR. The expression profiles of 10 genes involved in FAdV-4 infected chicken liver, including TLR2A, TLR3, TLR5, MyD88, IL12B, IL15, IL18, CCL20, TNFRSF21 and CD30, were consistent with RNA-seq profiles. By transfecting small interfering RNA into LMH cells, our results confirmed that MyD88 mediated FAdV-4-induced inflammation. To our knowledge, this was the first study to use transcriptome analysis to examine host responses to FAdV-4 infection. These results provide insight into the mechanisms of FAdV-4 pathogenesis and host-FAdV-4 interaction.
authors: Zhang, J.;Zou, Z.;Huang, K.;Lin, X.;Chen, H.;Jin, M.

title: Human infection with goat Orf virus in China, 2012
abstract: Orf virus, belonging to the genus Parapoxvirus, induces a zoonotic infectious disease characterized by acute, highly vascularized pustular skin lesions in sheep and goats. A number of orf outbreaks in sheep and goats have been reported in recent years, but no reports have described a human orf virus strain in China. In this study, we diagnosed orf virus infection in two people, a mother and a son, in Gansu Province, China. The human orf virus was isolated and its phylogenetic characterization analyzed using a complete B2L gene. Findings are useful for developing prospective programs to control orfvirus infections in goats and humans © Copyright 2014, Mary Ann Liebert, Inc. 2014.
authors: Zhang, K.;Liu, Y.;Kong, H.;Shang, Y.;Liu, X.

title: Identification and analysis of differential miRNAs in PK-15 cells after infection with foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: The changes in microRNAs (miRNAs) in host cells after infection with foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) are still unclear. To improve our understanding of FMD pathogenesis at the level of post-transcriptional regulation, Solexa high-through microRNAs (miRNAs) play important roles in both post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression and host-virus interactions. Despite studies of miRNA expression, ghput sequencing and bioinformatic tools were used to identify differentially expressed miRNAs and analyze their functions during FMD infection of PK-15 cells. Results showed that 9,165,674 and 9,230,378 clean reads were obtained, with 172 known and 72 novel miRNAs differentially expressed in infected and uninfected groups, respectively. Some of the differentially expressed miRNAs were validated by real-time quantitative RT-PCR with stemloop. GO annotation and KEGG pathway analysis for target genes revealed that differentially expressed miRNAs were involved in immune response and cell death pathways. © 2014 Zhang et al.
authors: Zhang, K. S.;Liu, Y. J.;Kong, H. J.;Cheng, W. W.;Shang, Y. J.;Tian, H.;Zheng, H. X.;Guo, J. H.;Liu, X. T.

title: Molecular detection of indigenous hepatitis E virus (HEV) from Tibetan pigs in Tibet, China
abstract: Hepatitis E is an important public health problem worldwide. Many molecular and serological studies have reported the prevalence and genotypic characteristics of HEV in humans and animals worldwide. However, the genotypic characterization of this virus in Tibetan pigs is very limited. Therefore, we wanted to study the genotype of HEV prevalent in Tibetan pigs in China. For this purpose, 253 bile samples from Tibetan pigs (free range animals) were collected from different slaughterhouses in the period 2017-2018 and then tested for HEV RNA by RT-nPCR. A total of 11 of 253 (4.35%) specimens tested were positive for HEV RNA. Based on sequence alignment and phylogenetic analysis, all isolated HEV strains belonged to genotype 4 and clustered in subtype 4b, sharing more than 84.8-95.2% identities with other reported strains. Our results concluded that HEV genotype 4 is predominant in Tibetan pigs in Tibet, China.
authors: Zhang, L.;Huang, S.;Li, K.;Rehman, M. U.;Jiang, X.;Tong, X.;Zhang, H.;Iqbal, M. K.;Mehmood, K.;Liu, S.;Shen, Y.;Li, J.

title: Identification and characterization of microRNA in lung tissue from pigs with variable susceptibility to PCV2 infection
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) is the leading cause of postweaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS) and other PCV-associated diseases. According to our previous RNA sequencing analysis, differences in susceptibility to PCV2 infection depended on genetic differences between Laiwu (LW) and Yorkshire × Landrace (YL) pigs, but on cellular microRNA (miRNA), which is differentially expressed between the LW and YL pigs before and after PCV2 infection have yet to be determined. In this study, high-throughput sequencing was performed to determine the abundance and differential expression of miRNA in lung tissues of PCV2-infected and PCV2-uninfected LW and YL pigs. A total of 295 known and 95 novel miRNAs were identified, and 23 known and 25 novel miRNAs became significantly different in the PCV2-infected vs. PCV2-uninfected LW pigs and/or the PCV2-infected vs. PCV2-uninfected YL pigs expressed. The expression levels of ssc-miR-122, ssc-miR-192, ssc-miR-451, ssc-miR-486 and ssc-miR-504 were confirmed by real-time quantitative PCR (qRT-PCR). Analysis of the potential targets of the four upregulated miRNAs (ie, ssc-miR-122, ssc-miR-192, ssc-miR-451, and ssc-miR-486) identified pathways and genes that may be important in disease resistance. Among the upregulated miRNAs, ssc-miR-122 can repress protein expression and viral DNA replication of PCV2, and downregulate expression of activated T cell nuclear factor 5 (NFAT5) and aminopeptidase puromycin sensitive (NPEPPS) binding to their 3″ untranslated region (3rd ″UTR) in PK15 cells. Therefore, ssc-miR-122 can indirectly suppress PCV2 infection by targeting genes related to the host's immune system, such as NFAT5 and NPEPPS.
authors: Zhang, P.;Wang, L.;Li, Y.;Jiang, P.;Wang, Y.;Wang, P.;Kang, L.;Wang, Y.;Sun, Y.;Jiang, Y.

title: Characterization and full genome sequence analysis of a novel virulent Siphoviridae phage against Staphylococcus aureus isolated from bovine mastitis in Xinjiang, China
abstract: Bovine mastitis is one of the most costly diseases in dairy cows worldwide. It can be caused by over 150 different microorganisms, with Staphylococcus aureus being the most commonly isolated and a major pathogen responsible for severe economic losses in the dairy industry. Although antibiotic therapy is the most common, alternative treatments are required due to increasing antibiotic resistance. Using phages to control pathogens is a promising tool in the fight against antibiotic resistance. Primarily using high-throughput sequencing, bioinformatics, and our proposed phage termini identification method, we isolated and characterized a novel virulent phage, designated vB_SauS_IMEP5, from manure used by dairy farms in Shihezi, Xinjiang, China for use as a biological pest control agent Staphylococcus aureus infections. Its latency was about 30 minutes and its burst size was about 272 PFU/cell. The phage vB_SauS_IMEP5 survives in a wide pH range between 3 and 12. A 20-minute treatment at 70 °C can inactivate the phage. Morphological analysis of vB_SauS_IMEP5 revealed that phage vB_SauS_IMEP5 is morphologically similar to phages in the Siphoviridae family. Among our tested multiplicities of infection (MOIs), the optimal multiplicity of infection (MOI) of this phage was determined to be 0.001, suggesting that phage vB_SauS_IMEP5 has high bacteriolytic potential and good efficiency in reducing bacterial growth. The complete genome of IME-P5 is a 44,677 bp linear double-stranded DNA with a G+C content of 34.26% containing 69 putative ORFs. The termini of the genome were determined with next-generation sequencing data using our previously proposed termini identification method, suggesting that this phage has non-redundant termini with 9nt 3″ protruding cohesive ends. The genomic and proteomic properties of IMEP5 indicate that this phage does not belong to any of the previously recognized Siphoviridae Staphylococcus phage groups, suggesting the creation of a new lineage and thus expanding the knowledge of Staphylococcus phage diversity. An N-acetylmuramoyl-l-alanine amidase gene and several conserved genes have been predicted, while no virulence or antibiotic resistance genes have been identified. This study isolated and characterized a new S. aureus phage vB_SauS_IMEP5 and our results suggest that this phage may potentially be used as a therapeutic or prophylactic candidate against S. aureus infection.
authors: Zhang, Q.;Xing, S.;Sun, Q.;Pei, G.;Cheng, S.;Liu, Y.;An, X.;Zhang, X.;Qu, Y.;Tong, Y.

title: Phylogenetic and pathotypic analysis of two virulent Newcastle disease viruses isolated from domestic ducks in China
abstract: In this study, two velogenic Newcastle disease (NDV) viruses recovered from outbreaks in domestic ducks in China were characterized. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that both strains were clustered with the class II viruses, one phylogenetically resembling genotype VII NDVs and the other more closely resembling genotype IX. The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion protein (F) confirmed that both isolates contained the virulent 112RRQK/RRF117 motif at the cleavage site. The two NDVs had severe pathogenicity in fully susceptible chickens, resulting in 100% mortality. One of the isolates also showed some pathogenicity in domestic ducks. The present study suggests that more than one genotype of NDV is circulating in domestic ducks in China and virus transmission can occur in chickens and domestic ducks. © 2011 Zhang et al.
authors: Zhang, S.;Wang, X.;Zhao, C.;Liu, D.;Hu, Y.;Zhao, J.;Zhang, G.

title: Serological and virological testing to detect infection with velogenic Newcastle disease virus in Chinese duck farms
abstract: serological and virological study was performed to determine the prevalence and spread of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) infection in Chinese duck flocks. NDV infection was detected in nine of the 12 farms surveyed in the two geographic regions covered by the survey. The percentage antibody positivity among the 406 serum samples was 35.7%. Three velogen NDVs were obtained from different duck flocks, which were identified by hemagglutination and hemagglutination inhibition tests, a pathogenicity test and a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction on the fusion genes (F). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all three isolates were clustered with the class II viruses; two were phylogenetically close to genotype VII NDVs and the other was more closely related to genotype IX NDVs. These results suggest that NDV infections were widespread and at least two distinct virulent genotypes may be responsible for recent epidemics in Chinese duck flocks. © American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Zhang, S.;Zhao, L.;Wang, X.;Zhang, D.;Zhao, J.;Zhang, G.

title: Transcript profiling identifies early response genes against FMD infection in PK-15 cells
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is a highly contagious disease that causes enormous economic losses worldwide. Although the protection that vaccination offers is limited during early infection, it is recognized as the best way to prevent FMD outbreaks. In addition, the mechanism of early host responses to foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) infection remains unclear. In our study, a pig kidney cell line (PK-15) was used as a cell model to elucidate the mechanism of pigs' early responses to FMD infection. Four untreated control cells and four FMDV-treated PK-15 cells were sequenced using RNA-seq technology and the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) analyzed. The results showed that 1212 DEGs were in the FMDV-infected PK-15 cells, including 914 up-regulated and 298 down-regulated genes. Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) signaling pathways were significantly enriched with tumor necrosis factor (TNF), cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction, NOD-like receptor, toll-like receptor, NF-kappaB and the chemokine signaling pathways. To verify the results of the DEGs, 30 immune-related DEGs (19 upregulated and 11 downregulated) were selected for quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) verification. The results showed that RT-qPCR measured genes showed a similar pattern as the RNA-seq analyses. Based on a bioinformatic analysis, we found during early infection with FMD that a number of cytokines such as interleukins (IL6), chemokines (CXCL2, CCL20 and CCL4) and transcription factors (ZFP36, FOS, NFKBIA, ZBTB3, ZNF503, ZNF283, dymeclin (DYM) and orthodenticle homeobox 1 (OTX1)) were involved in the fight between FMD and the host. Combined with their features and functions, we propose inflammation as the key early mechanism by which the host responds to FMD infection. These data provide an additional panel of candidate genes for deciphering the mechanisms of a host's early response to FMD infection.
authors: Zhang, T.;Chen, H.;Qi, L.;Zhang, J.;Wu, R.;Zhang, Y.;Sun, Y.

title: Effects of PrPC on the biological processes of DF-1 cells and RNA-seq based analysis of differential genes
abstract: Revealing the effects of PrPC on cell biological processes and on gene expression. We established stable DF-1 (PrPC-knockdown (KD)) cells and combined with DF-1 (wt) and DF-1 (PrPC-overexpression (OE)) cells that we had previously established, we examined the Effect of chicken PrPC (PrPC) on the processes of DF-1 cells. Then, using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) technology and bioinformatics, we analyzed the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between these cells. The results show that DF-1 (PrPC-KD) are significantly reduced compared to DF-1 (wt) and DF-1 (PrPC-Scramble) in terms of adhesion, proliferation, colony formation rate and cell number of colonies, scratch wounds Healing rate, cell number of invasion and migration, S-phase cell populations, but apoptosis rate and G1-phase cell populations are significantly increased. Conversely, all of these features are opposite in DF-1 (PrPC-OE). In addition, compared to DF-1 (wt), we found that a total of 1055 DE genes are present between DF-1 (PrPC-KD) and DF-1 (PrPC-OE) cells. After Go and Pathway accumulation analysis, we know that these DEGs are significantly enriched in cells, cell parts, cellular processes and metabolic pathways. In short, we found that PrPC can promote processes of DF-1 cells except apoptosis. In addition, PrPC is involved in focal adhesion, cancer, ribosomes, metabolic pathways, etc., and PrPC overexpression can promote amebiasis pathway, but its down-regulation can promote serotonergic synapse pathway. However, the details remain unknown and that would be our next research.
authors: Zhang, T. L.;Wan, X. R.;Wu, R.;Wang, C.

title: Evolution and variation of the influenza A virus H3 gene and interaction between hosts
abstract: Objective: Continuous mutations in the influenza A virus hemagglutinin (HA) gene create new antigenic strains that cause annual epidemics. The aim of this study was to evaluate the evolutionary trend of the H3 gene over a long period of time. Methods: 1842 H3 HA1 nucleotide strains from different hosts were pooled for analysis. A two-step clustering procedure was used to classify tribes into groups, and then a phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the clustering results. The rate of evolution in lineages has been estimated in the future. Results: The tree structure revealed three lineages: horse/canine, human/porcine, and avian. As a single tribe, the human-pig lineage consisted mostly of human tribes, and other large branches appeared in recent years. The tree topology showed no evidence that pigs influenced the main evolutionary bias of human H3 strains. The rate of evolution of H3 strains varied between lineages. We observed that the rate in the human line decreased from 3.2 substitutions/year before 1980 to 1.8 after 1997. Conclusion: We concluded that human H3 gene variation was associated with pig strains but independent of others, including avian strains. The rate of evolution of human H3 strains seems to have been declining in recent years, while the reasons for the rate change need to be further explored. Copyright © 2007 S. Karger AG.
authors: Zhang, W.;Jiang, Q.;Chen, Y.

title: Feces of cats in an animal shelter
authors: Zhang, W.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Kapusinszky, B.

title: What's for lunch? US store viral metagenomics bought beef, pork and chicken
abstract: We describe here the metagenomics-derived viral sequences detected in beef, pork, and chicken purchased from San Francisco stores. In beef we detected four previously reported viruses (two parvoviruses belonging to different genera, an anellovirus and a circovirus-like virus) and a new bovine polyomavirus species (BPyV2-SF) whose closest relatives infect primates. Detection of porcine Hocovirus in beef indicated that this parvovirus can infect both ungulate species. In pork we detected four known parvoviruses from three genera, an anellovirus and porcine circovirus 2. Chicken meat contained numerous gyrovirus sequences including those of chicken anemia virus and a new gyrovirus species (GyV7-SF). Our results provide a first characterization of some of the viruses commonly found in US store-bought meat, including a diverse group of parvoviruses and virus families with small circular DNA genomes. Whether any of these viruses can infect humans requires testing human sera for specific antibodies.
authors: Zhang, W.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.

title: Hepatitis E virus infection in domestic animals in eastern China
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a zoonotic agent that has been reported as a reservoir in several animal species. Antibodies against HEV and HEV RNA have been detected in some Chinese populations and groups of pigs, but only a few other domestic animals. In this study, to investigate HEV prevalence, we tested sera from 788 pigs, 100 cows, 50 goats, 49 horses, 101 domestic dogs, 105 chickens, 47 ducks, and 45 pigeons in eastern China for anti-HEV immunoglobulin G (IgG). . We also tested 50% of pig sera, all sera from other domestic animals and 13 human sera from Shanghai positive for anti-HEV immunoglobulin M (IgM) on HEV RNA using reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction. Our results showed that 82.5% (222/269) of sows, 53.9% (104/193) of 4-6 month old pigs, 63.4% (168/265) of 1-3 month old pigs Pigs, 55.7% (34/61) of slaughter pigs, 24% (12/50) of goats, 16.3% (8/49) of horses, 17.8% (21/101) of pet dogs, 6% (6/100) of cows, 12.8% (6/47) of ducks, 4.4% (2/45) of pigeons and 1.9% (2/105) of chickens were positive for anti-HEV IgG The inhibition test confirmed infection with HEV or HEV-like viruses in these domestic animals except pigeons and chickens. From the sera we isolated 18 porcine HEV strains, one horse HEV strain and two human HEV strains. Sequence analysis showed that the horse HEV isolate and one porcine isolate belonged to genotype 3. The other isolates belonged to genotype 4. The two human isolates were phylogenetically closely related to eight of the pig isolates. In short, the presence of anti-HEV antibodies has been confirmed in several species of domestic animals in east China, and HEV RNA has been identified in pigs, humans and horses. This suggested that authorities should pay more attention to the prevalence of HEV in eastern China. © 2008 The Authors.
authors: Zhang, W.;Shen, Q.;Mou, J.;Gong, G.;Yang, Z.;Cui, L.;Zhu, J.;Ju, G.;Hua, X.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of a novel feline anellovirus species
abstract: Here, a novel feline anellovirus strain (named FelineAV621 and GenBank number KX262893) was detected in two cats with diarrhea. The complete genome of FelineAV621 is 2409 nt in length with a G+C content of 56.67% including three open reading frames (ORFs). A phylogenetic analysis based on the amino acid sequence of the putative capsid protein (ORF1) showed that feline AV621 belonged to a new anellovirus species within a clade containing seal anellovirus, canine TTVs and porcine TTVs, but from all previous feline anelloviruses was removed.
authors: Zhang, W.;Wang, H.;Wang, Y.;Liu, Z.;Li, J.;Guo, L.;Yang, S.;Shen, Q.;Zhao, X.;Cui, L.;Hua, X.

title: Virome comparisons in wildly diseased and healthy captive giant pandas
abstract: Background: The giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) is an endangered herbivore living wild in central China. Viral infections have become a potential health threat to these vulnerable animals, however there is limited information on these infections. Methods: Using a viral metagenomic approach, we examined viruses in feces, nasopharyngeal secretions, blood, and various tissues of a wild giant panda that died of an unknown disease, a healthy wild giant panda, and 46 healthy captive animals. Results: The previously uncharacterized complete or nearly complete genomes of four viruses from three genera in the family Papillomaviridae, six viruses from a proposed new genus in the Picornaviridae (Aimelvirus), two unclassified viruses related to posaviruses in the order Picornaviridae, 19 anelloviruses in four different clades of the Anelloviridae family, four putative circoviruses and 15 viruses belonging to the recently described Genomoviridae family were sequenced. Numerous insect viral sequences related to the families Iflaviridae, Dicistroviridae, Iridoviridae, Baculoviridae, Polydnaviridae, and the subfamily Densovirinae, and sequences of plant viruses related to the families Tombusviridae, Partitiviridae, Secoviridae, Geminiviridae, Luteoviridae, Virgaviridae, and Rhabdoviridae reflect the diet of giant pandas reflected ; Genus Umbravirus, Alphaflexiviridae and Phycodnaviridae were also detected in stool samples. A small number of insect virus sequences have also been detected in the nasopharyngeal secretions of healthy giant pandas and lung tissue of dead wild giant pandas. Although the virus families present in the sick giant panda were also detected in the healthy panda, a higher proportion of papillomaviruses, picornaviruses and anelloviruses were detected in the diseased panda. Conclusion: This viral survey advances our understanding of eukaryotic viruses in giant pandas and provides a basis for comparison to viruses detected in future infectious disease outbreaks. The similar virus families detected in diseased and healthy giant pandas indicate that these viruses cause commensal infections in most immunocompetent animals.
authors: Zhang, W.;Yang, S. X.;Shan, T. L.;Hou, R.;Liu, Z. J.;Li, W.;Guo, L. H.;Wang, Y.;Chen, P.;Wang, X. C.;Feng, F. F.;Wang, H.;Chen, C.;Shen, Q.;Zhou, C. L.;Hua, X. G.;Cui, L.;Deng, X. T.;Zhang, Z. H.;Qi, D. W.;Delwart, E.

title: The hemagglutinin/esterase gene of human coronavirus strain OC43: phylogenetic relationships with bovine and mouse coronaviruses and influenza C virus
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequences of the hemagglutinin/esterase (HE) genes of human coronavirus (HCV) strain OC43 and bovine respiratory coronavirus (BRCV) strain G95 were determined from single-stranded cDNA fragments generated and amplified by reverse transcription of virus-specific mRNAs Polymerase chain reaction. An open reading frame of 1272 nucleotides was identified as a putative HE gene by homology to the bovine coronavirus HE gene. This open reading frame encodes a protein of 424 amino acids with an estimated molecular weight of 47.7 kDa. Ten potential N-linked glycosylation sites were predicted in the HE protein of HCV OC43, while nine of these were present in BRCV G95. 14 cysteine residues were conserved in the HE proteins of both viruses. Two hydrophobic sequences at the N-terminus and at the C-terminus can serve as signal peptide and transmembrane anchor domain, respectively. The predicted HE protein of HCV-OC43 was 95% identical to the HEs of BRCV-G95 and other bovine coronaviruses and 60% identical to the HEs of mouse hepatitis viruses. Phylogenetic analysis suggests that the HE genes of coronaviruses and influenza C virus share a common origin and that bovine coronaviruses and HCV-OC43 are closely related.
authors: Zhang, X.;Kousoulas, K. G.;Storz, J.

title: Decoding the sharp decline in H7N9 infections in humans
abstract: The H7N9 virus has caused five waves of human infection since 2013. In the past year, however, human infections have almost disappeared. In a recent study, Shi et al. showed that the use of a bivalent H5/H7 vaccine successfully prevented chicken infections and thus prevented and nearly eliminated human infections.
authors: Zhang, X.;Luo, T.;Shen, Y.

title: Complete genome sequence of H9N2 influenza virus, fatal to chickens
abstract: An H9N2 virus, which is fatal to chickens, was isolated in 2012 from an acutely ill chicken flock. Phylogenetic analysis showed that this virus was phylogenetically related to the Y280 lineage. Sequence analysis revealed 1 amino acid deletion in HA1 and 3 amino acid deletions in the NA stalk region.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Guo, X.;Qi, J.;Liu, L.;Wang, J.;Xu, S.;Wang, J.;Yin, Y.

title: Integration analysis of miRNA and mRNA expression profiles in porcine testicular cells infected with Japanese encephalitis virus
abstract: To elucidate the role of microRNAs (miRNA) in regulating gene expression in Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV)-infected swine testis (ST) cells, we analyzed the miRNA and mRNA expression profiles of JEV-infected ST cells by high-throughput sequencing technology compared to uninfected controls. The results showed that 104 known miRNAs and 9 novel miRNA candidates were differentially expressed in ST cells after JEV infection. We identified 396 differentially expressed mRNAs. Bioinformatic analysis identified 435 known miRNA-mRNA interaction pairs and 94 new miRNA-mRNA interaction pairs involving miRNAs that inversely correlated with the expression of their predicted target mRNAs. The known miRNAs, which are inversely correlated with their target genes, have been implicated in the biological processes of immunity, cytokine production, inflammation and apoptosis. Selected miRNA-mRNA interactions were validated by a luciferase reporter assay. Overall, our results suggest that miRNAs may play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of JEV infection.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Jing, J.;Li, X.;Wang, J.;Feng, X.;Cao, R.;Chen, P.

title: Characterization of the ÏƒC-encoding gene from Musocvy Duck Reovirus
abstract: The ÏƒC-encoding gene from two strains of musk duck reovirus (DRV) S14 and C4 have been cloned and completely sequenced. The open reading frame (ORF) was 810 bp and encoded 269 amino acids with a predicted molecular mass of 29.5 kDa. Expressed ÏƒC fusion protein in Escherichia coli BL21 strain could be detected by Western blotting under duck anti-reovirus polyclonal serum. There are two major gap insertions at the N-terminal portion of the DRV ΔC when required to optimize the alignment of the amino acid sequences of the DRV ΔC had a heptapeptide repeat and leucine zipper pattern structurally related to ARV ΔC. All DRVs grouped into a distinct genogroup within subgroup II of the Orthoreovirus genus. The degree of differences between S14/C4 and ARV was only 23-24% and 21-22%, respectively, at both the nucleotide and deduced amino acid levels, suggesting that DRVs are quite different from ARVs and should give an accurate classification for DRVs in the genus Orthoreovirus. © Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2006.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Liu, M.;Hu, Q.;Ouyang, S.;Tong, G.

title: Isolation and characterization of avian influenza A virus H7N9 from people with respiratory diseases in Zhejiang, China
abstract: In 2013, novel reassortant influenza A virus (H7N9) of avian origin was reported in China. Through increased surveillance, human infection with the H7N9 virus has been detected for the first time in Zhejiang province. Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used to confirm infection. Embryonated chicken eggs were used for virus isolation from throat swabs of infected human patients. The H7N9 isolates were first identified by hemagglutination assay and electron microscopy and then used for whole genome sequencing. Bioinformatics software was used to construct the phylogenetic tree and to calculate the mean evolutionary rate of the HA gene in H7Nx and NA in HxN9. Two new H7N9 avian influenza A viruses (A/Zhejiang/1/2013 and A/Zhejiang/2/2013) were isolated from the positive infection cases. Substitutions were found in both Zhejiang isolates and identified as human viruses. All phylogenetic results indicated that the new reassortant in H7N9 originated from viruses that infected birds. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis revealed a mean evolution rate of the HA gene in H7NX of 5.74E-3 (95% highest posterior density: 3.8218E-3 to 7.7873E-3), while the NA gene was 2.243 showed E-3 (4,378E-4 to 3.79E-3) substitutions per nucleotide site per year. Molecular methods confirmed that the novel reassortant H7N9 virus originated in avian origin, with the mutations occurring during the spread of H7N9 virus infection. Live poultry markets played an important role in the overall spread of H7N9. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Zhang, Y.;Mao, H.;Yan, J.;Zhang, L.;Sun, Y.;Wang, X.;Chen, Y.;Lu, Y.;Chen, E.;Lv, H.;Gong, L.;Li, Z.;Gao, J.;Xu, C.;Feng, Y.;Ge, Q.;Xu, B.;Xu, F.;Yang, Z.;Zhao, G.;Han, J.;Guus, K.;Li, H.;Shu, Y.;Chen, Z.;Xia, S.

title: The epidemiological and virological analysis of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in Inner Mongolia in 2007
abstract: In 2007, an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) occurred in Jungar Banner, Erdos City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China fever, vesicular rash on hands, feet, mouth and buttocks occurred in most cases on patients. Most patients were infants under 5 years of age and there was an apparent peak at onset of the disease. From 28 hospitalized patients, 23 stool specimens and 6 throat swab specimens were collected for enterovirus isolation, and 15 enteroviruses were isolated, 9 were identified as human enterovirus 71 (HEV71, the isolation rate is 31.03%), and 1 was identified as coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16). After the comprehensive analysis of the clinical manifestation, epidemiological data and laboratory results, this outbreak was probably mainly caused by HEV71. The variability at the nucleotide acid and amino acid levels among 9 HEV71 was relatively low and the homology was more than 99.4% and 99.0%, respectively, showing that this outbreak was caused by only one viral transmission chain. Phylogenetic analysis of 9 HEV71 strains isolated during this outbreak revealed that they all belonged to the C4 subgenotype, which has been continuously circulating in mainland China since its first reported occurrence in the city of Shenzhen in 1998. It has also been suggested that the C4 HEV71 subgenotype had widespread distribution and transmission in mainland China.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Nan, L. J.;Wu, G. S.;Tan, X. J.;Xu, D. D.;Gu, S. Y.;Zhu, S. L.;Yan, D. M.;An, H. Q.;Xu, W. B.

title: The potential of the human immune system to evolve broadly neutralizing HIV-1 antibodies: implications for vaccine development
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND DESIGN: The development of an effective HIV-1 vaccine that elicits broadly neutralizing human HIV-1 antibodies (bnAbs) remains a challenging goal. Extensive studies of HIV-1 have revealed various strategies that the virus employs to evade host immune surveillance. Here we examined the human antibody gene repertoire of uninfected and HIV-1 infected individuals at the genomic DNA (gDNA) and cDNA level by deep sequencing followed by high-throughput sequence analysis to determine the frequency of putative germline antibody genes of known HIV-1 monoclonal bnAbs (bnmAbs). METHODS: Combinatorial gDNA and cDNA antibody libraries were constructed using the gDNAs and mRNAs isolated from uninfected and HIV-1 infected human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). All libraries were deeply sequenced and the sequences analyzed using the IMGT/HighV-QUEST software (http://imgt.org/HighV-QUEST/index.action). The frequency of putative germline antibodies of known bnmAbs in the gDNA and cDNA libraries was determined.
