RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: The human gDNA antibody libraries were more diverse in terms of heavy and light chain V gene lineage than the cDNA libraries, suggesting that the human gDNA antibody gene pertoires have greater potential than the cDNA repertoires for development of HIV-1 bnAbs. The frequencies of kappa and lambda heavy and light chain variable regions with identical V(D)J recombinations to known HIV-1 bnmAbs were extremely low in the human antibody gene repertoire. However, we found relatively high frequencies of heavy and kappa and lambda light chain variable regions that used the same V genes and had the same CDR3 lengths as known HIV-1 bnmAbs, regardless of the use of the (D)J -gens. B cells bearing B cell receptors of such kappa and lambda heavy and light chain variable regions can be stimulated to induce HIV-1 bnAbs. Â© 2013 Wolters Kluwer Health | Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Yuan, T.;Li, J.;Zhang, Y.;Xu, J.;Shao, Y.;Chen, Z.;Zhang, M. Y.

title: Complete genome sequence of a Newcastle disease virus subgenotype VIId circulating mainly in chickens in China
abstract: At least 11 genotypes of class II viruses have been identified since the discovery of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in 1926. Here we reported the complete genome sequence of a widespread NDV variant from China belonging to subgenotype VIId in class II Viruses have been the predominant strains circulating in China for the past decade, accounting for over 80% of the predominant strains in China and differed phylogenetically from currently available vaccines. © 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Zhang, S.;Wang, X.;Zhang, G.

title: [Research on construction of ovine lung adenoma virus pEGFP-C1/exJSRV-env and induction of malignant transformation in NIH3T3]
abstract: This study aims to construct a eukaryotic expression system for the envelope gene of Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus, monitor its localization in 293T cells, and investigate the potential to induce malignant transformation of NIH3T3 cells. The complete cDNA of the envelope gene of Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus (exJSRV-env) was amplified by RT-PCR from the extract of a naturally infected sheep lung. The clone of the target gene was subcloned into the eukaryotic expression system pEGFP-C1 and validated by PCR, restriction endonuclease and sequencing. A bioinformatic analysis regarding biological function and cellular localization of exJSRV-env was also performed. The recombinant clone of exJSRV-env was transfected into 293T cells and NIH3T3 cells by Lipofectamine LTX. Expression and cell localization in 293T cells were validated by confocal microscopy. The soft agar colony formation assay was used to test anchorage-independent growth of NIH3T3. DNA sequencing and restriction enzyme digestion with Kpn I and Hind III showed the correct construction of the recombinant plasmid, which was named pEGFP-C1/exJSRV-env. Amino acid sequence alignment of exJSRV-env with reference sequences revealed 85%-100% homogeneity. A YRNM motif unique to exogenous viruses was discovered on the cytoplasmic tail of the envelope gene. Phylogenetic tree analysis showed that our clone of exJSRV-env was closely clustered with pathogenic exogenous Jaagsiekte sheep retroviruses. Fluorescence microscopy showed a typical membrane localization of the exJSRV env protein. NIH3T3 cells transfected with exJSRV-env lost contact inhibition and acquired the ability to form colonies in soft agar. This study demonstrated that the Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus coat protein can induce malignant transformation of the mouse fibroblast cell NIH3T3. The findings of this study provide a basis for further structural and functional investigations of the coat protein of the Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus.
authors: Zhang, Y. F.;Liu, Y.;Wang, Z. J.;Sun, X. L.;Liu, S. Y.

title: Molecular characterization of chicken-derived Newcastle disease genotype VIId virus isolates in China in 2005-2012 reveals a new length of hemagglutinin neuraminidase
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the most important poultry diseases and causes severe economic losses in the global poultry industry. Although all Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates belong to a single serotype, significant genetic diversity between different NDV isolates has been described. Here we report the molecular characterization of 23 virulent NDV class II genotype VIId isolates circulating in China. Phylogenetic construction and analysis revealed the existence of marked genomic and amino acid differences that clearly distinguished these isolates from other typical NDV genotypes and vaccine strains. We also report a new 582 amino acid hemagglutinin neuraminidase in NDV genotype VII strains NDV of genotype VIId class II provides. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Zhang, Y. Y.;Shao, M. Y.;Yu, X. H.;Zhao, J.;Zhang, G. Z.

title: A simple method for high-throughput quantification of genome-wide DNA methylation using fluorescence polarization
abstract: In order to rapidly determine the DNA methylation level from a large number of biological or clinical samples, we have developed an accurate and sensitive method for high-throughput quantification of the global methylation of 5'-Cm(5) CGG-3' sites in the genome, the is visualized by fluorescence polarization (FP) based measurement of DNA methylation (FPDM). In FPDM, the methyl-sensitive HpaII and methyl-insensitive MspI restriction enzymes were employed to achieve DNA cleavage, followed by incorporation of fluorescent dCMP into the enzyme cleavage products by polymerase chain elongation, yielding an FP ratio between HpaII and MspI - restricted preparations as a measure of methylation. FPDM provided stable estimates of the methylation level of submicrograms of lambda or human DNA and a 255 bp DNA segment containing a unique HpaII/MspI restriction site, consistent with and more accurate than determination by gel electrophoresis. FPDM was also applied to measure dose-dependent DNA hypomethylation in human embryonic kidney 293T cells treated with the DNA methyltransferase inhibitor 5-aza-dC.
authors: Zhao, C.;Xue, H.

title: The unfolded protein response induced by Tembusu virus infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Tembusu virus (TMUV), belonging to the genus Flavivirus, causes reduced egg production and neurological problems in poultry. Flavivirus replication depends on the host endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and induces ER stress, which leads to activation of the cellular unfolded protein response (UPR), an important signaling pathway that regulates many biological functions involved in viral pathogenesis and innate immunity involved. However, the mechanism of TMUV-induced UPR activation remains unclear. RESULTS: In this study, we systematically examined the three UPR signaling pathways in TMUV-infected BHK-21 cells. Our results showed that the expression of glucose-related protein 78 (GRP78) and GRP94 was upregulated during TMUV infection. We then showed that TMUV activates the PERK pathway early in infection, leading to upregulation of ATF4, GADD34 and CHOP, with CHOP induction resulting in caspase-3 activation. We also found that the IRE1 pathway is activated, leading to splicing of X-box-binding protein 1 (XBP1) mRNA and increased expression of p58IPK. Finally, we observed increased expression of ATF6 and activity of ER stress-response elements, suggesting stimulation of ATF6 signaling. Furthermore, activation of the ATF6 signaling pathway correlated with induction of the downstream chaperones calnexin, calreticulin, ERp57 and PDI. UPR activity was also observed by the marked increase in GRP78 and sXBP1 levels in TMUV-infected DF-1 cells. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first report that TMUV infection-induced ER stress activates three branches of the UPR, and these results lay the foundation for elucidating the pathogenesis of TMUV and understanding the inherent mechanism of TMUV infection as well as the host response.
authors: Zhao, D.;Yang, J.;Han, K.;Liu, Q.;Wang, H.;Liu, Y.;Huang, X.;Zhang, L.;Li, Y.

title: Transcriptomic analysis of porcine PBMCs in response to FMD infection
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is a major zoonotic infectious disease. It has an important economic impact around the world. It is also a significant threat to food security. The molecular mechanism of FMD infection is still largely unclear. The innate immune response is the first line of defense against infectious diseases. The systematic analysis of the host immune response to an infection plays an important role in understanding the pathogenesis of an infection. However, there are few reports on the effect of immune regulation on viral replication in the virus-host cell interaction. High-throughput RNA-seq technology as a powerful and efficient means of transcript analysis offers new insights into the FMDV study. In this study, RNA was extracted from O-subtype FMDV infected porcine PBMCs at 4 dpi. A total of 29942658 and 31452917 Illumina read pairs were obtained from the uninfected (NI) group and the infected (I) group, respectively. The clean bases for all samples are 3.61 G (NI group) and 3.79 G (I group), respectively. The NI and I group clean reads mapped to pig genome data were 47195073 (81.82%) and 46556714 (76.85%), respectively. Most clean reads were distributed in the exon region, followed by the intron region and the intergenic region. Differentially expressed (DE) genes were analyzed using edgeR software. 451 genes were differentially expressed between infected and uninfected groups. According to the comparative analysis, more genes were downregulated in the uninfected samples than in those infected with FMD. 66 out of 451 genes were downregulated, 385 out of 451 genes were upregulated after FMD infection. For functional classification and signaling pathway analysis, among 17741 composite unigens, there are 349 genes that are different genes of GO notes. In addition, 49 genes were downregulated, 300 genes were upregulated associated with the GO term. 1621 have been successfully annotated by GO assignments belonging to one or more of three categories: biological process, cellular component, and molecular function. According to KEGG analysis, the main pathway has been presented, including protein processing in the endoplasmic reticulum, phagosome, cell cycle and cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction. Some important DE genes related to immune processes and signaling pathways were analyzed and quantified by RT-PCR. This is the first systematic transcriptome analysis of FMD-infected porcine PBMCs. These insights will help us to better understand the host cell-FMD interaction and its relation to pathogenesis and contribute to the prevention and control of FMD.
authors: Zhao, F. R.;Xie, Y. L.;Liu, Z. Z.;Shao, J. J.;Li, S. F.;Zhang, Y. G.;Chang, H. Y.

title: Characterization of an H6N6 influenza virus isolated from pigs in China
abstract: There is several evidence that pigs may act as a vessel for the generation of novel influenza A viruses. In this study, we analyzed the development and pathogenicity of a strain of H6N6 influenza virus isolated from pigs with clinical signs of infection in China. Although phylogenetic analyzes indicated that this virus could have originated in domestic ducks, pathogenicity experiments suggested that the virus replicated in mice without prior adaptation. These results suggest that the virus was transmitted from ducks to pigs in China and replicated in mammalian hosts without prior adaptation, which could pose a threat to both veterinary medicine and public health. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Zhao, G.;Chen, C.;Huang, J.;Wang, Y.;Peng, D.;Liu, X.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of swine pandemic influenza virus H1N1/09 in Jiangsu province of China
abstract: To study whether the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus is still transmitted to pigs, a total of 1029 nasal swab samples were collected from healthy pigs in Jiangsu Province, China, from January to May 2010. Eight H1N1 influenza viruses have been isolated and identified, and their full-length genomes have been sequenced. We found that all eight H1N1 viruses shared greater than 98.0% sequence identity with the 2009 pandemic virus A/Jiangsu/1/2009 (JS1). Furthermore, some of these viruses had D225G (3/8) mutations in the receptor binding sites of the hemagglutinin (HA) protein, indicating an improvement in their binding affinity to the sialic α2,3Gal receptor. In summary, the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus retro-infected human pigs in mainland China, and significant viral evolution is still ongoing in this species. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Zhao, G.;Fan, Q.;Zhong, L.;Li, Y.;Liu, W.;Liu, X.;Gao, S.;Peng, D.;Liu, X.

title: Molecular evolution of H6 subtype avian influenza viruses in eastern China from 2002 to 2010
abstract: Background: Although extensive data show that the majority of H6 duck isolates from 2000 to 2005 in southern China belonged to a single H6N2 virus lineage with a single gene constellation, the prevalence of H6N2 virus in poultry in eastern China is largely unknown. Results: Epidemiology revealed that H6N2 viruses were the most frequently detected influenza subtypes in live bird markets in eastern China from 2002 to 2008, but from 2009 they were replaced by new H6N6 viruses. We phylogenetically and antigenically analyzed 42 H6 viruses isolated mainly from domestic ducks in eastern China between 2002 and 2010. Surprisingly, none of these isolates were grouped with the previously described H6N2 viruses belonging to a single H6N2 virus lineage with a single gene constellation in domestic ducks in southern China from 2000-2005. Two distinct hemagglutinin lineages were identified and all were frequently reassorted with multiple virus subtypes from the natural gene pool, but few reassortants were persistent or widespread. Conclusions: Five subtypes of H6 influenza viruses (H6N1, H6N2, H6N5, H6N6, and H6N8) co-circulated in eastern China, constituting a significant portion of the natural influenza virus reservoir in domestic ducks, and significant viral rearrangement is still occurring in this species. Â© 2011Zhao et al; Licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Zhao, G.;Lu, X.;Gu, X.;Zhao, K.;Song, Q.;Pan, J.;Xu, Q.;Duan, Z.;Peng, D.;Hu, S.;Wang, X.;Liu, X.

title: Characterization of the VP1 sequence of coxsackievirus A16 isolates by the Bayesian evolution method
abstract: Background: Coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16), one of the most important etiopathological causes of pediatric hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide, is believed to have caused several deaths. Uncovering the evolutionary and epidemiological dynamics of CV-A16 across time and space is central to understanding its outbreak potential. Methods: In this study, we isolated six CV-A16 strains in Jilin Province, China, and constructed a Maximum Clade Credibility (MCC) tree for the CV-A16 VP1 gene according to the Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo method using 708 strains from the GenBank with epidemiological information. The evolutionary characteristics of the CV-A16 VP1 gene were also dynamically analyzed by Bayesian skyline diagram. Results: All identified CV-A16 strains could be divided into five main genogroups, denoted GI-GV. GIV and GV have been circulating together in China since 2007, and the epidemic strain CV-A16 isolated in Jilin Province, China can be classified as GIV-3. The CV-A16 genogroups recently circulating in China have shared the same ancestor since 2007. The genetic diversity of the CV-A16 VP1 gene shows a continuous increase since the mid-1990s, with genetic diversity increasing sharply in 1997 and 2007, peaking in 2007. Post 2010, there was very little genetic diversity. The evolution rate of the CV-A16 VP1 gene was 6,656E-3 substitutions per site per year. Conclusions: We have predicted the dynamic phylogenetic trends indicative of CV-A16 outbreak trends and provide theoretical underpinnings for the clinical prevention and treatment of HFMD caused by CV-A16.
authors: Zhao, G.;Zhang, X.;Wang, C.;Wang, G.;Li, F.

title: Metagenomic analysis of Jinding duck faecal virome
abstract: Ducks play an important role in the transmission and maintenance of mammalian viruses in nature and are a reservoir host for many animal viruses. We analyzed the faecal virome of four isolated strains of ducks (A, B, C, and D) using metagenomic analysis. The faeces of the ducks tested contained 18 animal virus families. The percentages of RNA virus reads compared to total animal virus reads in each of the four strains were 96.96% (A), 97.30% (B), 98.01% (C), and 67.49% (D) and were mainly from Orthomyxoviridae, Mimiviridae, Bunyaviridae, Picobirnaviridae and Reoviridae. Meanwhile, the minority of DNA virus readings were related to Herpesviridae, Adenoviridae, Iridoviridae and other low frequency virus families. The percentages of Orthomyxoviridae, Mimiviridae, Bunyaviridae, Picobirnaviridae, and Herpesviridae readings did not differ significantly between strains A, B, and C; However, there were marked differences in the frequency of these reads in Strain D. In conclusion, this study provides an unbiased examination of fecal viral diversity from four duck strains during specific pathogen-free periods and highlights the variation in the percentage of viral families present. These results can be used as a reference for detecting duck viral pathogens and predicting zoonotic potential.
authors: Zhao, L.;Niu, Y.;Lu, T.;Yin, H.;Zhang, Y.;Xu, L.;Wang, Y.;Chen, H.

title: Sequence analyzes of the representative strain of avian nephritis virus predominant in China in healthy chicken flocks
abstract: Avian nephritis virus (ANV), a member of the Astroviridae family, has been associated with acute nephritis in chickens. Cases of ARF infection have been recorded in Japan and in several European countries. However, such studies have never been conducted in China. Therefore, this study isolated ARF in Chinese chicken flocks. ANV RNA was detected in 2009 by reverse transcription PCR in stool samples from healthy laying hens in Sichuan Province, China. Of the 192 stool samples collected, 32.3% (62/192) were positive for ARF infection. The entire genome of ANV Sichuan54, the first representative Chinese strain, was 6941 nucleotides in length, including the 5-inch untranslated region, three open reading frames (ORFs), a 3-inch UTR, and a poly(A) tail . Comparative and phylogenetic analyzes based on partial RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (ORF1b) showed that the majority of ARF studies were more closely related to the US ARF strain (DQ324827-324836) than to G-4260 (AB033998). © 2011 American Association of Avian Pathologists.
authors: Zhao, W.;Hua, X. G.;Yuan, C. L.;Cui, L.;Shan, T. L.;Dai, X. Q.;Zhu, A. L.;Yu, Y.;Zhu, C. X.;Yang, Z. B.

title: Diagnosis confirmed by RT-PCR and phylogenetic analysis of small ruminant plague viruses in Tibet, China
abstract: This paper reports the confirmed diagnosis of PPR cases in Tibet, China by nested RT-PCR in 2007 and the results of phylogenetic analysis. The results showed that the 11 samples tested were PPRV positive by nested RT-PCR, of which 2 samples were genetically close to lineage I strain X7443 (Nigeria 75/1) and 3 samples to lineage strain AY560591 (Sungri96). IV with 96.6%, 97.3%, 97.6%, and 98% nucleotide sequence homogeneity, respectively, based on partial sequencing of the F gene from 5 samples and complete sequencing of the N/M/F/H genes from a sample. This study suggests that there are at least two origins of PPRV in China. © 2009 Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Zhao, W. H.;Yang, S. B.;Han, J. Q.;Jiang, M.;Li, H. C.;Zhang, N. Z.;Li, Q. H.

title: [Detection of a molecular marker of the NA gene in avian influenza virus subtype H7N9 by pyrosequencing]
abstract: This study aimed to establish a method for the detection and identification of H7N9 avian influenza viruses based on the NA gene by pyrosequencing. According to the published NA gene sequences of avian influenza virus A (H7N9), a 15 nt deletion was found in the NA gene of avian influenza viruses H7N9. The 15 nt deletion of the NA gene was targeted as a molecular marker for the rapid detection and identification of H7N9 avian influenza viruses by pyrosequencing. Three H7N9 avian influenza virus isolates were pyrosequenced using the same assay and shown to share the same 15 nt deletion. Pyrosequencing technology based on the molecular marker of the NA gene can be used to identify H7N9 avian influenza viruses.
authors: Zhao, Y. G.;Liu, H. L.;Wang, J. J.;Zheng, D. X.;Zhao, Y. L.;Ge, S. Q.;Wang, Z. L.

title: Genomes and seroprevalence of severe fever associated with thrombocytopenic syndrome virus and Nairobi sheep disease virus in Haemaphysalis longicornis ticks and…
authors: Zhao, Z.;Hou, G.;Zhang, C.;Liu, J.;Xu, L.;Li, W.;Tan, Z.;Tu, C.

title: Molecular characterization of Japanese encephalitis virus strains prevalent in Chinese swine herds
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is the leading cause of viral encephalitis in Asia, and domestic pigs serve as amplifying hosts. In the present study, the complete genomic sequences of two JEV strains (HEN0701 and SH0601) isolated from pigs in China were determined and compared to other 12 JEV strains deposited in GenBank. These two strains shared 88.8% nucleotide sequence similarity and 97.9% deduced amino acid sequence homology. HEN0701 shared high nucleotide sequence and high amino acid sequence identity with genotype I (GI) strains, while SH0601 shared high nucleotide sequence and high amino acid sequence identity with GIII strains at both the gene and full genome levels. Further phylogenetic analysis showed that HEN0701 belonged to the JEV-GI group and SH0601 was classified as a GIII strain. Analysis of codon usage showed that there were some differences between the GI and GIII strains in nucleotide composition and codon usage for the open reading frames. Â© 2013 The Korean Veterinary Science Society.
authors: Zheng, H.;Shan, T.;Den, Y.;Sun, C.;Yuan, S.;Yin, Y.;Tong, G.

title: The emergence of porcine circovirus 3 without clinical signs of infection in Shandong province
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3) has been detected in Shandong, China. One hundred and thirty-two of 222 (59.46%) specimens were PCV3 positive, while 52 of 132 (39.39%) specimens were co-infected with PCV2. There were no clinical signs of infection in either multiparous sows or liveborn pups. Two PCV3 strains were identified from natural stillborn fetuses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the two PCV3 strains are 96% identical to the known PCV3/porcine/USA (KX778720.1, KX966193.1 and KX898030.1) and are closely related to Barbel circovirus. Further studies on the epidemiology of PCV3 and co-infection with PCV2 are needed.
authors: Zheng, S.;Wu, X.;Zhang, L.;Xin, C.;Liu, Y.;Shi, J.;Peng, Z.;Xu, S.;Fu, F.;Yu, J.;Sun, W.;Xu, S.;Li, J.;Wang, J.

title: Genetic typing and epidemiological observation of bovine viral diarrheal virus in western China
abstract: Whole blood samples (472) were collected in 2006-2008 from 15 cattle farms in seven districts of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, which is an important grazing area and covers 1/6 of China's territory. Bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) was detected by nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction assay (RT-nPCR) and sequenced within the 5″ untranslated region of the genome. Approximately 43% (202 samples) were BVDV positive. Of the positive samples, 24 were selected for further sequencing, sequence comparison, and phylogenetic reconstruction. The phylogenetic reconstructions showed that these isolates clustered into either BVDV1b (18 samples) or BVDV1c (six samples) subgenotypes. None of the sequenced isolates showed a cytopathic effect in culture. In contrast to previously published studies in Chinese cattle, no BVDV2 genotypes were detected. These results show that the predominant subgenotypes in Xinjiang are BVDV1b and BVDV1c. This finding may be useful for further epidemiological BVDV studies in China. © 2010 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Zhong, F.;Li, N.;Huang, X.;Guo, Y.;Chen, H.;Wang, X.;Shi, C.;Zhang, X.

title: Single-reaction genomic amplification accelerates sequencing and vaccine production for classical and porcine human influenza A viruses
abstract: Pandemic influenza A viruses emerging from animal reservoirs are inevitable. Therefore, rapid genome analysis and vaccine development are crucial. We have developed a multi-segment reverse transcription PCR (M-RTPCR) approach that simultaneously amplifies eight genomic RNA segments, independent of virus subtype. M-RTPCR amplicons can be used for high-throughput sequencing and/or cloned into modified reverse genetic plasmids via regions of sequence identity. We used these methods to rescue a contemporary H3N2 virus and a porcine H1N1 virus directly from human swab specimens. Together, M-RTPCR and the modified reverse genetics plasmids we designed streamline the generation of vaccine seed stocks (9 to 12 days). Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Zhou, B.;Donnelly, M. E.;Scholes, D. T.;St. George, K.;Hatta, M.;Kawaoka, Y.;Wentworth, D. E.

title: Reticuloendothelosis virus and avian leukosis virus subgroup J synergistically increase the accumulation of exosomal miRNAs
abstract: BACKGROUND: Co-infection with avian leukosis virus subgroup J and reticuloendoteliosis virus induces synergistic pathogenic effects and increases mortality. However, the role of exosomal miRNAs in the molecular mechanism of the synergistic infection of the two viruses remains unknown. RESULTS: In this study, exosomal RNAs from CEF cells infected with ALV-J, REV, or both at the optimal synergistic time of infection were analyzed using Illumina RNA deep sequencing. A total of 54 (23 upregulated and 31 downregulated) and 16 (7 upregulated and 9 downregulated) miRNAs were identified by comparing co-infection with two viruses, single-infected ALV-J and REV, respectively. In addition, five key miRNAs including miR-184-3p, miR-146a-3p, miR-146a-5p, miR-3538, and miR-155 were validated by qRT-PCR in both exosomes and CEF cells. GO annotation and KEGG pathway analysis of miRNA target genes revealed that the five differentially expressed miRNAs were involved in virus-vector interaction, oxidative phosphorylation, energy metabolism, and cell growth. CONCLUSIONS: We have shown that REV and ALV-J synergistically increase the accumulation of exosomal miRNAs, shedding light on the synergistic molecular mechanism of ALV-J and REV.
authors: Zhou, D.;Xue, J.;He, S.;Du, X.;Zhou, J.;Li, C.;Huang, L.;Nair, V.;Yao, Y.;Cheng, Z.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of the first chicken sicinivirus isolate in mainland China using viral metagenomics
abstract: In contrast to traditional approaches to virus isolation and sequencing, the sequence-independent, amplification-based viral metagenomics technique allows for the efficient discovery of unexpected or new viruses while bypassing the culturing step. Here we report the discovery of the first sicinivirus isolate (designated strain JSY) of picornaviruses from commercial laying hens in mainland China using a viral metagenomics technique. This sicinivirus isolate, which contains a total genome of 9,797 nucleotides (nt) not including the poly(A) tail, possesses one of the largest picornavirus genomes reported to date, but has only 88.83% and 82.78% amino acid sequence identity with that of ChPV1 100C (KF979332) or sicinivirus 1 strain UCC001 (NC-023861). The full 939 nt 50UTR of the isolate strain contains at least twelve stem loop domains (AL), representing the highest group of loops reported within the sicinivirus genus. The conserved "dumbbell-like" structure was also present in the 272 nt 30 UTR of the isolate as that in the 30 UTR of sicinivirus 1 strain UCC001. The 8,586 nt open reading frame encodes a 2,862 amino acid precursor polyprotein. In addition, sicinivirus infection could be widespread in commercial chicken farms in Yancheng region of Jiangsu province, as evidenced by all stool samples tested from three different farms, which were positive (17/17) for sicinivirus detection. This is the first report of the identification of sicinivirus in commercial laying hens with severe clinical disease in mainland China, however, further studies are needed to evaluate the pathogenic potential of this picornavirus in chickens.
authors: Zhou, H.;Zhu, S.;Quan, R.;Wang, J.;Wei, L.;Yang, B.;Xu, F.;Wang, J.;Chen, F.;Liu, J.

title: Features of codon usage bias in two regions downstream of foot-and-mouth disease virus initiation codons
abstract: The mechanism of the use of alternative two AUGs in foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) is still unknown to date. In this study, the codon usage bias (CUB) characteristics of the region between the two AUGs (the region-La) and the equally sized region behind the second AUG (the region-Lb) were found in 94 different FMDV RNA sequences below Analyzed using Relative Synonymous Codon Usage (RSCU) values. The results showed that many negative CUB codons were preferentially used in the -La region. There were two conserved residues (Thr and Cys) at the 4th and 6th residue positions of the La region. The conserved residues had a general tendency to choose synonymous codons with negative CUB. Although most positions in the -La region did not contain conserved residues, many positions tended to use negative CUB codons in this region. Among these codons, the majority belonged to the amino acids containing synonymous codons with clearly positive and negative CUB, including Asp, Val, Ile, Leu, Thr, Ala, Ser, Asn, and Arg. The presence of many negative CUB codons in the region -La might affect the efficiency of the first AUG selection. The phylogenetic incongruence of the region-La and the region-Lb implied that intertypic recombination played an important role in the evolution of FMD. Furthermore, due to the existence of more positions with positive CUB and a more widespread phylogenetic incongruity in region-Lb than in region-La, a probable relationship between CUB grade and evolution of the two target regions was revealed. © 2010 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
authors: Zhou, J. H.;Zhang, J.;Ding, Y. Z.;Chen, H. T.;Ma, L. N.;Liu, Y. S.

title: Global pairwise RNA interaction landscapes reveal core features of protein recognition
abstract: RNA-protein interactions pervade biology. Transcription, translation, and splicing all depend on the recognition of structured RNA elements by RNA-binding proteins. Models of RNA-protein interactions are generally limited to short linear motifs and structures, as extensive sequence sampling is required to access longer elements. Here we develop an integrated approach that calculates global pairwise interaction scores from in vitro selection and high-throughput sequencing. We study four RNA-binding proteins from phages, viruses and humans. Our approach uncovers regulatory motifs, distinguishes between regulated and unregulated RNAs within their native genomic context, and correctly predicts the impact of mutational events on binding activity. We design binding elements that enhance binding activity in cells and derive mutational pathways revealing permissive versus disruptive evolutionary pathways between regulated motifs. These coupling landscapes are broadly applicable for the discovery and characterization of protein-RNA recognition at single nucleotide resolution.
authors: Zhou, Q.;Kunder, N.;De la Paz, J. A.;Lasley, A. E.;Bhat, V. D.;Morcos, F.;Campbell, Z. T.

title: Rovac is the possible ancestor of the Russian lapinized vaccines LK-VNIVViM and CS strains, but not the Chinese strain (C strain) classical swine fever vaccine
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF) or swine fever is a highly contagious disease that emerged in the first half of the 19th century. To combat the disease and protect pigs, various vaccines have been developed, including the early generation of the lapinized Rovac strain and the later development of the "Chinese" (C-strain) strain. However, details on the development of these vaccines are lost in history. To examine the phylogenetic relationship between Rovac and other lapinized vaccines, this study determined the genome sequence of Rovac, which comprised 12,304 nucleotides, specifically with the 3' untranslated region (3'UTR) containing a 13 nucleotide insertion. The near-complete genome of the Russian vaccine strain LK-VNIVViM was determined by next-generation sequencing on the Illumina MiSeq platform. Whole genome phylogenetic analysis revealed a closer relationship of the Rovac strain to the Russian LK-VNIVViM, CS strain and its derivative RUCSFPLUM (genotype 1.2) and not to the C strain (genotype 1.1). Furthermore, it showed a lineage role of the LK-VNIVViM in relation to the CS strain and RUCSFPLUM. The study suggested that the Rovac vaccine is the possible ancestor of the Russian vaccine strains, but not the C strain vaccine.
authors: Zhou, W.;Gao, S.;Podgorska, K.;Stadejek, T.;Qiu, H. J.;Yin, H.;Drew, T.;Liu, L.

title: Molecular studies on the prevalence and viral load of enteric viruses in pigs from five European countries
abstract: Enteric virus infections in pigs can cause diarrhea leading to poor economy and significant economic losses. This study reports enteric infections with porcine astrovirus type 4 (PAstV4), porcine group A rotavirus (GARV), porcine group C rotavirus (GCRV), porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2), and porcine kobuvirus (PKoV) in 419 pigs, both of which were include healthy animals and animals with diarrhea from 49 farms in five European countries (Austria, Germany, Hungary, Spain and Sweden). Real-time RT-PCR assays were developed to test stool samples and compare prevalence and viral load in relation to health status, farms of origin and age groups. The results showed that PAstV4 (70.4%) was the dominant virus type, followed by PKoV (56.7%), PCV2 (42.2%), GCRV (3%) and GARV (0.9%). Pigs with diarrhea had a higher viral load of PAstV4 in the rearing and finisher groups. Rotavirus was mainly detected in diarrheal pigs, while PCV2 was more frequently detected in clinically healthy than in diarrheal pigs, suggesting that most PCV2 infections were subclinical. PAstV4, PCV2 and PKoV were considered ubiquitous in the European pig herd and co-infections among them were common regardless of disease status, in contrast to a low prevalence of classic rotavirus infections.
authors: Zhou, W.;Ullman, K.;Chowdry, V.;Reining, M.;Benyeda, Z.;Baule, C.;Juremalm, M.;Wallgren, P.;Schwarz, L.;Zhou, E.;Pedrero, S. P.;Hennig-Pauka, I.;Segales, J.;Liu, L.

title: MicroRNA expression profiling in alveolar macrophages of native Chinese Tongcheng pigs infected with PRRSV in vivo
abstract: Porcine respiratory and reproductive syndrome (PRRS), caused by the PRRS virus (PRRSV), is one of the most serious infectious diseases in the swine industry worldwide. Indigenous Chinese Tongcheng (TC) pigs have reportedly exhibited strong resistance to PRRSV infection. The miRNA expression profiles of porcine alveolar macrophages (PAMs) from control TC pigs and those infected with PRRSV in vivo were analyzed by high-throughput sequencing to examine infection-induced changes. A total of 182 known miRNAs, including 101 miRNA-5p and 81 miRNA-3p, were identified with 23 up-regulated differentially expressed miRNAs (DEmiRNAs) and 25 down-regulated DEmiRNAs. Analysis of gene ontology showed that predicted target genes for the DEmiRNAs were enriched for immune response, transcriptional regulation, and cell death. Integrative analysis of mRNA and miRNA expression revealed that down-regulated methylation-related genes (DNMT1 and DNMT3b) were targeted by five up-regulated DEmiRNAs. In addition, 35 miRNA pairs (70 miRNAs) were co-expressed after PRRSV infection, and six pairs were differentially co-expressed. Our results describe miRNA expression profiles of TC swine in response to PRRSV infection and provide a solid basis for the development of novel therapies to combat PRRS in swine.
authors: Zhou, X.;Michal, J. J.;Jiang, Z.;Liu, B.

title: Complete genome sequence of Japanese encephalitis genotype III virus isolated from pigs in Sichuan, China
abstract: complete genome sequence of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) was verified by viral metagenomic analysis of aborted piglets. A phylogenetic analysis of this genome shows that it is very similar to previously reported Indian JEV genomes. The complete JEV sequence is 10,718 nucleotides long.
authors: Zhou, Y.;Zhuo, X.;Ye, J.;Cai, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of a novel bat-associated circovirus with a poly-T tract in the 3″ intergenic region
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes a large group of small circular single-stranded DNA viruses with multiple members that cause severe swine and poultry diseases. In recent years, the number of new viruses within the family has exploded, demonstrating high genetic diversity and a broad host range. In this report, we describe two additional circoviruses identified in bats in Yunnan and Heilongjiang provinces in China. Full genome sequencing has revealed that these bat-associated circoviruses (bat ACV) should be classified as a new species within the genus Circovirus based on the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) demarcation criteria. The most notable result is the novel finding of a 21–28 nt polythymidine (poly-T) tract in the 3″ terminal intergenic region of bat ACV isolates from Heilongjiang Province. To understand its role in viral replication, a wild-type bat ACV and a mutant version deleted for the entire poly-T were rescued by constructing infectious clones. The in vitro replication comparison showed that the poly-T is not essential for viral replication. The identification of additional ACV isolates from bats and the study of their biological properties will be the main task in the future to understand the potential role of bats in the transmission of circoviruses to terrestrial mammals and humans.
authors: Zhu, A.;Jiang, T.;Hu, T.;Mi, S.;Zhao, Z.;Zhang, F.;Feng, J.;Fan, Q.;He, B.;Tu, C.

title: Comparative genomic analysis identifies structural features of CRISPR-Cas systems in Riemerella anatipestifer
abstract: Background: Infection with Riemerella anatipestifer is a contagious disease that has caused significant economic losses in the duck industry worldwide. This study attempted to characterize CRISPR-Cas systems in the pathogen Riemerella anatipestifer (R. anatipestifer). The CRISPR-Cas system provides adaptive immunity against foreign genetic elements in prokaryotes, and CRISPR-cas loci are abundant in the genomes of archaea and bacteria. However, the structural features of R. anatipestifer CRISPR-Cas systems remain to be elucidated due to the limited availability of genomic data. Results: To identify the structure and components associated with CRISPR-Cas systems in R. anatipestifer, we performed comparative genomic analyzes of CRISPR-Cas systems in 25 R. anatipestifer strains using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that most of the analyzed R. anatipestifer strains (20/25) have two CRISPR loci (CRISPR1 and CRISPR2). CRISPR1 has been shown to be flanked on one side by cas genes, while CRISPR2 has been orphaned. The other strains analyzed contained only one locus, either CRISPR1 or CRISPR2. The length and content of the consensus direct repeat sequences as well as the length of the spacer sequences associated with the two loci differed from each other. Only three cas genes (cas1, cas2 and cas9) were located upstream of CRISPR1. It was also shown that CRISPR1 is flanked by a 107 bp putative leader sequence and a 16 nt anti-repeat sequence. In combination with the analysis of the similarity in spacer organization and phylogenetic tree of R. anatipestifer strains, CRISPR arrays can be divided into different subgroups. Diversity in spacer organization was observed in the same subgroup. In general, spacer organization was more different in CRISPR1 than in CRISPR2. In addition, only 8% of the spacers (13/153) were homologous to phage or plasmid sequences. The Cas operon flanking CRISPR1 was observed to be relatively conserved based on multiple sequence alignments of Cas amino acid sequences. Phylogenetic analysis associated with Cas9 showed that the Cas9 sequence of R. anatipestifer was closely related to that of Bacteroides fragilis and formed part of the subtype II-C subcluster. Conclusions: Our data revealed for the first time the structural features of R. anatipestifer CRISPR-Cas systems. Elucidating structural features of the CRISPR-Cas system may aid in studying the specific mechanism related to CRISPR-mediated adaptive immunity and other biological functions in R. anatipestifer.
authors: Zhu, D. K.;Yang, X. Q.;He, Y.;Zhou, W. S.;Song, X. H.;Wang, J. B.;Zhang, Y.;Liu, M. F.;Wang, M. S.;Jia, R. Y.;Chen, S.;Sun, K. F.;Yang, Q.;Wu, Y.;Chen, X. Y.;Cheng, A. C.

title: Prevalence of hepatitis E virus in animals in Changchun region, China
abstract: Aim: To analyze the prevalence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) in animals in the Changchun region, China, and the phylogenetics of the virus. Methods: The sera of pig, bovine, sheep, deer, chicken and horse were tested for antibodies against HEV with the anti-HEV antibody kit, part of them with RT-PCR on HEV RNA, and the positive ones were subjected to gene cloning subjected and sequencing. Results: From 493 pigs, 266 cattle, 93 sheep, 798 deer, 369 chickens and 197 horse sera, 427 (86.61%), 122 (45.86%), 7 (7.53%), 348 (43.61 %), 18 (4.88%). ) and 31 (15.74%) were positive for anti-HEV antibodies, and 5 of the 493 pig sera were positive for HEV RNA. The homology of the 5 HEV RNA positive clones was 91.2%-99.1%, and that of 348 PS in the ORF2 domain to HEV genotype 1, 2, 3 and 4 was 77.8%-82, 3%, 77.2%-78.1%, 77.2%-99.1%, and 85.2%-95.2%, respectively. Conclusion: The prevalence of HEV was observed in different animals in the Changchun area. The prevalence in pigs was much higher than in other animals. The porcine predominant HEV gene sequence showed high homology to that of HEV-4 isolated from sporadic human HE cases. Analysis of phylogenetics proved that the HEV belonged to the same branch in pigs and humans in the Changchun region.
authors: Zhu, G. Z.;Liu, T. M.;Sun, Z. F.

title: Origins and evolutionary dynamics of the H3N2 canine influenza virus
abstract: UNTAGGED: Influenza A viruses (IAVs) are mainly maintained in wild birds, and despite frequent spillover infections from avian IAVs to mammals, only a small number of viruses have become established in mammalian hosts. A new H3N2 canine influenza virus (CIV) of avian origin emerged in Asia in the mid-2000s and is now circulating in canine populations in China and South Korea, and possibly Thailand. The emergence of CIV offers new opportunities for zoonotic infections and interspecies transmission. We examined 14,764 full-length IAV genomes along with all publicly available CIV genomes since their first isolation up to 2013. We show that CIV may have arisen as early as 1999 as a result of segment reorganization between Eurasian and North American avian IAV lineages. We also identified amino acid changes that may have played a role in the emergence of CIV, some of which have not previously been identified in other species changes. CIV evolves more slowly than H3N2 human influenza viruses, and viral phylogenies exhibit a geographic structure compatible with high levels of local transmission. We discovered several intrasubtypic and heterosubtypic reassortment events, including acquisition of the NS segment of an H5N1 avian influenza virus that had previously been overlooked. Taken together, our results provide insight into the adaptive changes required for avian viruses to become established in mammals, and also underscore the potential role of dogs as intermediate hosts from which viruses with zoonotic and/or pandemic potential might originate, particularly with an estimated one Dog population of ~700 million. IMPORTANT: Influenza A viruses circulate in humans and animals. This multihost ecology has important implications, as past pandemics have been caused by IAVs carrying gene segments of both human and animal origin. Adaptive evolution is central to leaps between species, and therefore understanding the evolutionary processes that shape the genomes of the influenza A virus is key to elucidating the mechanisms underlying virus emergence. A canine influenza virus (CIV) of avian origin has recently emerged in dogs and is spreading in Asia. We have reconstructed the evolutionary history of CIV and show that it originated in both Eurasian and North American bird lineages. We also identified the mutations that may have been responsible for the interspecies jump. Finally, we provide evidence for multiple reassortment events between CIV and other influenza viruses (including an H5N1 avian virus). This is of concern as there is a large global canine population to which humans are highly exposed.
authors: Zhu, H.;Hughes, J.;Murcia, P. R.

title: Phylogenetic and pathotypic characterization of Newcastle disease virus in Tibetan chickens, China
abstract: Chickens are considered potential reservoirs of Newcastle disease virus (NDV). In this study, six Newcastle disease virus strains were isolated and characterized in Tibetan chickens. The HN gene was sequenced and the phylogenetic relationship to reference strains was examined. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these six isolated strains were closely related to NDV isolates of reference strains GQ245823, KT002186, KU527561, KJ563939, AY225110, EU305607, KM056357, Y18898, GQ245832, AF077761 and the Lasota strain. Among them, EU305607, KJ563939, and KM056357 were isolated from India, while the Lasota strain came from an attenuated vaccine widely used in China. Then the mean time to death (MDT) and the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) were used to estimate the pathogenicity of the isolates. The pathogenicity experiment showed that HNH1 and HN17 are virulent. Our results showed that genetically distinct viruses circulate in Tibetan chickens, and based on the phlogeographic analysis, we estimated the origin of the ancestral viruses of the isolates and their sister strains from India and China (Lasota strain). It points to the importance of continuous monitoring to improve the current understanding of the genetic evolution of NDV strains.
authors: Zhu, H.;Zhang, H.;Wang, Y.;Ciren, D.;Dong, H.;Wu, Q.;Rehman, M. U.;Nabi, F.;Mehmood, K.;Li, J.

title: Molecular characterization of the H3N2 and H4N6 subtypes of avian influenza viruses isolated in 2010 from mallard ducks in Lake Poyang, China
abstract: Poyang Lake is the largest inland freshwater lake in China and is home to many species of wild and aquatic birds. We conducted an avian influenza virus survey in nine semi-artificial waterfowl farms in Lake Poyang from January to March 2010. Three H3N2 and one H4N6 influenza virus were isolated from 1036 cloacal swabs collected from healthy mallard ducks. All isolates were characterized genetically and phylogenetically. Analysis of putative HA cleavage sites showed that all four isolates possessed the molecular characteristics (QTRGL for H3N2 virus, PEKASR for H4N6 virus) of low pathogenic avian influenza virus (LPAI). Phylogenetic analysis of the viral genomes showed that all four virus isolates belonged to the Eurasian group of influenza viruses. The M gene of the viruses had the highest homology to highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza viruses. In addition, co-infection of H3N2 and H4N6 on the same farm was observed. And interestingly, we isolated two subtypes of viruses (H3N2 and H4N6) and their progeny viruses (H3N2) with evidence of genome reassortment from the same farm in which the PB1 and PB2 gene segments of H4N6 replaced those of the H3N2 strain. The results of animal infection experiments showed that all four isolated viruses were weakly pathogenic to chickens and non-pathogenic to mice, consistent with the results of genetic analysis.
authors: Zhu, N.;Zhao, J. R.;Li, Y. D.;Ding, C. Q.;Xia, H.;Tang, S.;Zhang, Z.;Yu, J. F.;Chen, J.;Fan, Z. J.;Kou, Z.;Li, T. X.

title: Phylogenetic and pathogenetic analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolated from house sparrow (Passer domesticus) living near a poultry farm in southern China
abstract: The house sparrow (Passer domesticus) is one of the most widespread wild birds in China. Five strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) have been isolated from house sparrows living near poultry farms in southern China. These isolates were characterized by pathogen assays and phylogenetic analysis. The results showed that all NDV isolates except one were velogen and virulent for chickens. These four strains, which are virulent for chickens, have the amino acid sequence 112R/KRQK/RR-F117 in the F0 cleavage site typical of velogenes NDV. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that these isolates belong to genotype VII and are closely related to the strains isolated from NDV outbreaks in chickens since 2000 /LaSota/46). The result of this study proved that house sparrows can transmit the virulent NDV strains and the same genotype of viruses circulating in poultry is present in house sparrows living near poultry farms in southern China. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2009.
authors: Zhu, W.;Dong, J.;Xie, Z.;Liu, Q.;Khan, M. I.

title: Human monoclonal antibodies as therapeutic candidates against emerging viruses and HIV-1
abstract: More than 40 monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) have been approved for a range of disease indications, with only one of them (Synagis) - for a viral disease and not for therapy, but for prevention. However, over the past decade, new potent mAbs have been discovered and characterized with the potential to be used as therapeutics against viruses of major public health and biosecurity concern, including Hendra virus (HeV), Nipah virus (NiV) , the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). ), Ebola Virus (EBOV), West Nile Virus (WNV), Influenza Virus (IFV) and Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 (HIV-1). Here we review such mAbs with a focus on antibodies of human origin and highlight recent results as well as technologies and mechanisms related to their potential as therapeutics. Â© Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2013.
authors: Zhu, Z.;Prabakaran, P.;Chen, W.;Broder, C. C.;Gong, R.;Dimitrov, D. S.

title: First detection of foot-and-mouth disease virus O/ME-SA/Ind2001 in China
abstract: Foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) is endemic to China and is mainly due to the lineage of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMD) serotype O Mya-98. In recent years, the FMDV O/ME-SA/Ind2001 lineage has spread from the Indian subcontinent to Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Africa, which may pose a potential threat to future transregional cattle movements. In this study, we identified the occurrence of FMDV O/ME-SA/Ind2001 in China; the first time this virus line was found there. Sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of VP1 sequences revealed that this newly identified strain belongs to the O/ME-SA/Ind2001 sublineage d and is closely related to strains causing recent FMD outbreaks in Nepal, Myanmar, Russia and South Korea to have. The results indicate extensive movements of the current O/ME-SA/Ind2001 sublineage d-viruses and provide essential information for an effective national FMD control program in China.
authors: Zhu, Z.;Yang, F.;He, J.;Li, J.;Cao, W.;Li, J.;Xia, Y.;Guo, J.;Jin, Y.;Zhang, K.;Zheng, H.;Liu, X.

title: Selected microRNA-192 mutant indicates association with multiple functional genes in bovine cells
abstract: MicroRNAs are involved in many cellular processes such as cell differentiation and development, tumorigenesis and immune regulation. In this study, miR192 was detected by real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) when MDBK cells were challenged with Escherichia coli. bta-miR-192 dysfunctional cells were established using transcription activator-like effector nuclease (TALEN) technology. Finally, bta-miR-192 mutant cells were screened for differentially expressed genes by RNA sequencing (RNA-seq). The results showed that miR192 decreased significantly in cells exposed to E. coli F18ac and E. coli K88ac. The RNA-seq results showed that 1673 differentially expressed transcripts were identified; 890 genes were upregulated and 775 genes were downregulated. Using the Gene Ontology enrichment analysis, 431 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were classified into 937 Gene Ontology terms. Pathway enrichment analysis showed that 535 genes were involved in 254 pathway terms. Interestingly, most of these DEGs were associated with cancer or infectious disease signaling pathways. When the selected DEGs (n=162) in these signaling pathways containing 120 differential transcripts were cut, 11 DEGs were identified. Subsequently, several genes associated with regulation, cancer or viral infections, such as LEF1, AXIN2, MX1 and FCGR2B, were identified among the DEGs by functional analysis. Furthermore, associations between bta-miR-192 and DEGs were demonstrated by cutting the target genes of bta-miR-192 with the DEGs, indicating that three genes including CBL, DICER1 and TRERF1 were involved in this relationship. These results provided useful guidance for studying the role played by bta-miR-192 in cellular functionality in bovine cells.
authors: Zi, C.;Zeng, D.;Zhou, J.;Dai, J.;Jiang, L.;Xue, F.;Jiang, Y.;Li, B.

title: Evidence of an independent third Usutu virus introduction to Germany
abstract: Usutu virus (USUV) is an arbovirus of the genus Flavivirus that was first introduced into southern Europe about twenty years ago and has caused disease in wild and captive birds. In Germany, USUV was first detected in wild birds, mainly blackbirds (Turdus merula), in the Upper Rhine Valley in the southwest of the country in 2011 and has not spread very far north since then. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the still ongoing USUV epidemic is caused by two different USUV strains, USUV-Germany belonging to USUV Europe 3 lineage and USUV-Bonn belonging to USUV Africa 3 lineage. The two strains were introduced independently. In August 2015, a new USUV strain named USUV-Berlin was isolated in Vero cells from two carcasses of young great gray owls (Strix nebulosa) kept at the Berlin Zoological Garden that had suffered from a hyperacute fatal systemic infection. Both owls carried high USUV genome loads. Full-length USUV genome sequences were determined and phylogenetic analyzes showed a close relationship to a 2006 sequence derived from the Spanish mosquito. Immunohistochemical antigen detection in organ samples from the owls revealed the typical USUV infection pattern. According to the phylogenetic analysis, USUV-Berlin belongs to the Africa 2 lineage and can thus be distinguished from the other strains circulating in Germany. Repeated finds of various USUV strains indicate more frequent introductions to Central Europe and a higher mobility of this virus than previously assumed.
authors: Ziegler, U.;Fast, C.;Eiden, M.;Bock, S.;Schulze, C.;Hoeper, D.;Ochs, A.;Schlieben, P.;Keller, M.;Zielke, D. E.;Luehken, R.;Cadar, D.;Walther, D.;Schmidt-Chanasit, J.;Groschup, M. H.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the rabies virus N-coding region in Lithuanian rabies isolates
abstract: Rabies infections in wild and domestic animals are a well-known problem in Lithuania, but only one canine rabies virus isolate sequence (1992) from Lithuania was used in the phylogenetic analysis of European rabies virus. The aim of this work was to determine nucleoprotein (N) gene sequences and to genetically characterize the rabies virus isolates to learn which virus group (biotype) is circulating in reservoir species in Lithuania. Nucleoprotein (N) gene sequences from classical rabies virus isolates from different parts of Lithuania were found to be closely related, showing 97.7 to 100% nucleotide identity and could be lineaged with 100% bootstrap support. All 12 sequences of raccoon dog, red fox, canine and sable rabies viruses showed 97.7-99.0% identity to previously published sequences from eastern parts of Poland, Estonia, Finland and northeastern part of Russia. The phylogenetic analysis revealed that all Lithuanian strains belong to the Northeast European (NEE) group of rabies virus.
authors: Zienius, D.;Sajute, K.;Zilinskas, H.;Stankevicius, A.

title: Genetic analysis revealed that LX4 genotype strains of infectious avian bronchitis virus have become predominant in Sichuan region, China in recent years
abstract: Between 2008 and 2010, 19 strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were isolated from vaccinated chicken flocks in Sichuan Province, China. The S1 genes of the isolates were amplified and sequenced. The phylogenetic analysis showed that the 19 isolates and 37 IBV reference strains can be divided into eight genotypes. Although Taiwan I type, Massachusetts type and proventriculitis type IBV were isolated, most of the isolates were of the LX4 genotype. The homology analysis of the sequences of the S1 genes of the 19 isolates and 37 reference IBV strains revealed that the identity of the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the S1 genes between the 15 LX4-type isolates and other IBV strains 71.9-99, 3% and 72.1 was -99.1%, while those of the analyzed LX4-type IBV were 96.0-99.9% and 94.3-99.8%, respectively. The results of this study and other published results in the GenBank database showed that the isolates circulating in Sichuan Province in recent years were mainly of the LX4 genotype, which is the predominant genotype circulating in China in recent years was circulated. © 2010 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Zou, N. L.;Zhao, F. F.;Wang, Y. P.;Liu, P.;Cao, S. J.;Wen, X. T.;Huang, Y.

title: Molecular characterization and receptor binding specificity of H9N2 avian influenza viruses based on avian environmental surveillance in China between 2013 and 2016
abstract: H9N2 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) have become panzootic and have caused sporadic human cases since 1998. Based on the poultry-related environmental monitoring data in mainland China from 2013 to 2016, a total of 68 representative environmental isolates were selected and systematically further examined. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that Y280-like H9N2 viruses were prevalent between 2013 and 2016 and have acquired several specific amino acid substitutions that may favor avian-mammalian virus transmission. In addition, the viruses have undergone dramatic evolution and rearrangements, resulting in increased genetic diversity or acting as gene contributors to new avian viruses. Receptor binding assays showed that most H9N2 isolates bound to human-type receptors, allowing them to easily cross the species barrier and infect humans efficiently. Our results suggest that H9N2-AIVs prevalent in poultry may pose a serious public health threat.
authors: Zou, S.;Zhang, Y.;Li, X.;Bo, H.;Wei, H.;Dong, L.;Yang, L.;Dong, J.;Liu, J.;Shu, Y.;Wang, D.

title: Insights into the increasing virulence of swine pandemic influenza virus H1N1/2009
abstract: Pandemic H1N1/2009 viruses have been stabilized in swine herds and some strains show higher pathogenicity than isolates of human origin. In this study, high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) is applied to examine the systemic transcriptome responses of mouse lungs infected with porcine (Jia6/10) and human (LN/09) H1N1/2009 viruses. The transcriptome data indicate that Jia6/10 activates stronger virus sensing signals that play an important role in inducing innate immunity. Most cytokines and interferon-stimulated genes show a higher level of expression in Jia/06-infected groups. Meanwhile, the Jia6/10 virus activates more reactive oxygen species production, which could further promote a higher mutation rate of the virus genome. Overall, our data indicate that the porcine pandemic H1N1/2009 virus elicits a stronger innate immune response and prooxidative stimulation, which may be closely related to the increased pathogenicity.
authors: Zou, W.;Chen, D.;Xiong, M.;Zhu, J.;Lin, X.;Wang, L.;Zhang, J.;Chen, L.;Zhang, H.;Chen, H.;Chen, M.;Jin, M.

title: Genetic analysis of ancient Hungarian avian influenza viruses
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis has been performed on specific genes from 13 avian influenza viruses (AIV) isolated in the 1970s. The viruses originated from the eastern part of Hungary from ducks and guinea fowl with relatively severe respiratory symptoms. In addition to the hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes (H4, H5, H6, H7 and H10) serologically identified at the time, genetically analyzed neuraminidase (NA) subtypes were identified (Table). Based on the amino acid pattern at the proteolytic cleavage site of HA, it was determined that all H5 and H7 strains belonged to the low pathogenicity (LP) category. The phylogenetic analysis of the HA, NA and NS genes allowed the following epidemiological conclusions. (1) All Hungarian tribes belonged to the Eurasian AIV lineage. (2) H5 strains were members of an ancient European group (Figure 1). The H4 strains (Figure 2) came from three different sources (two from the Far East and one from Europe). (3) The fact that most viruses of the H4 and H5 subtypes were reassortants (some even multiple; Figure 3) suggested that their reservoirs were probably not wild waterfowl but rather domestic ducks. Further studies of ancient viruses would be required to gain more detailed knowledge of the role of these "artificial" reservoirs in the maintenance and epidemiology of AIV.
authors: Zsofia, S.;Sandor, K.;Istvan, K.;Bela, L.

title: Molecular epidemiology of rabies: focus on domestic dogs (Canis familiaris) and black-backed jackals (Canis mesomelas) from northern South Africa
abstract: Phylogenetic relationships of rabies viruses recovered from black-backed jackals (Canis mesomelas) and domestic dogs (Canis familiaris) in northern South Africa were examined to determine whether the black-backed jackal is an emerging conservation host species for rabies in this region. A panel of 123 rabies viruses obtained from the two host species between 1980 and 2006 was characterized by nucleotide sequencing of the cytoplasmic domain of the glycoprotein gene and the non-coding GL intergenic region. Phylogenetic analysis has delineated a virus cluster specific to black-backed jackals in the western Limpopo spanning a 5-year period. Virus strains associated with domestic dogs are prevalent in densely populated communal areas of northeast Limpopo and south and east Mpumalanga. The data presented in this study demonstrated the likelihood of black-backed jackals being able to suffer cycles of rabies independent of domestic dogs. It is proposed to consider wild rabies control strategies in synergy with domestic animal vaccination for effective rabies control in South Africa. © 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Zulu, G. C.;Sabeta, C. T.;Nel, L. H.

title: Novel picornavirus associated with avian keratin dysfunction in Alaskan birds
abstract: UNLABELING: Avian keratin disease (AKD), characterized by debilitating overgrowth of the bird's beak, was first documented in black-capped tit (Poecile atricapillus) in Alaska. Subsequently, similar deformities have appeared in numerous species on all continents. Despite the widespread prevalence of this emerging pathology, the cause of AKD remains elusive. As a result, it is not known whether suspected cases of AKD in affected species are causally linked, and the impact of this pathology at the population and community levels is difficult to assess. We applied unbiased next-generation metagenomic sequencing to screen for candidate pathogens in birds affected by AKD. We identified and sequenced the entire coding region of a novel picornavirus, which we call poecivirus. Subsequent screening of 19 AKD-affected titmouse and 9 controls for the presence of poecivirus revealed that 19/19 (100%) of the AKD-affected individuals were positive, while only 2/9 (22%) of the controls infected with the virus were poecivirus. Two Northwestern crows (Corvus caurinus) and two Red-breasted nuthatches (Sitta canadensis) with AKD-consistent pathology also tested positive for Poecivirus. We propose that poecivirus is a possible etiological agent of AKD. IMPORTANT: Avian keratin disease (AKD) is an increasingly common disease in wild birds. Characterized by excessive beak growth, this disease was first described in the late 1990s and has spread rapidly both geographically and in terms of affected host species. AKD decreases the host's fitness and can be fatal. However, the cause of the disease has remained elusive and its effects on host populations are poorly understood. We found a novel and variant picornavirus in 19/19 AKD-affected chickadees we studied, but only in 2/9 control cases. We also found this virus in 4 individuals from 2 other sparrow species showing symptoms consistent with AKD. Our data suggest that this novel picornavirus warrants further investigation as a causative agent of AKD.
authors: Zylberberg, M.;Van Hemert, C.;Dumbacher, J. P.;Handel, C. M.;Tihan, T.;DeRisi, J. L.
